og: Enobarbus?
t: Enobarbus?

og: Peace! Hark further.
t: Be quiet! Keep listening.

og: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,  The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me,  That life, a very rebel to my will,  May hang no longer on me.
t: Oh moon, you royal mistress of genuine melancholy, pour down the poisonous mists of night upon me, so that I may no longer live, now that I no longer wish to.

og: Throw my heart  Against the flint and hardness of my fault,  Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder  And finish all foul thoughts.
t: Take my heart and throw it against my hard sin. which is weak from grief. It will burst into pieces and all my bitter thoughts will end with my death.

og: O Antony,  Nobler than my revolt is infamous,  Forgive me in thine own particular,  But let the world rank me in register  A master-leaver and a fugitive.  O Antony! O Antony!
t: Oh Antony, your nobility is even greater than my fault is terrible. I wish that you would forgive me for those sins that I've committed against you, but I want the rest of the world to remember me as a deserter and someone who abandoned his master. Oh Antony! Oh Antony!

og: Let’s speak to him.
t: Let's speak to him.

og: Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.
t: Let's listen to him, because the things he's talking about might have to do with Caesar.

og: Let’s do so. But he sleeps.
t: Let's do that. But he's asleep.

og: Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as hisWas never yet for sleep.
t: I think he's fainted, actually. No one ever said such a despairing prayer to lull themselves to sleep.

og: Go we to him.
t: Let's go to him.

og: Awake, sir, awake. Speak to us.
t: Wake up, sir, wake up. Speak to us.

og: Hear you, sir?
t: Can you hear us, sir?

og: The hand of death hath raught him.
t: Death has struck him down.

og: Hark, the drums  Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him  To th’ court of guard.
t: Listen, the drums are waking up the sleeping men with their subdued noise. Let's carry him to the guardroom.

og: He is of note. Our hour  Is fully out.
t: He's a person of high rank. The time of our watch is up.

og: Come on, then. He may recover yet.
t: Come on, then. He might still wake up.

og: Their preparation is today by sea.We please them not by land.
t: They're preparing to fight by sea today. They're not happy fighting us on land.

og: For both, my lord.
t: They're preparing to fight by both land and sea, my lord.

og: I would they’d fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air,  We’d fight there too. But this it is: our foot  Upon the hills adjoining to the city  Shall stay with us.
t: I wish they'd also fight in fire or in the air—we'd fight them there too. But this is how we'll do things—our foot soldiers up on the hills beside the city will stay with us.

og: Order for sea is given;  They have put forth the haven,  Where their appointment we may best discover  And look on their endeavor.
t: I've given the orders for our preparations at sea. The ships have left the port. Let's go up higher where we can better observe their battle plans and watch what they're doing.

og: But being charged, we will be still by land—  Which, as I take ’t, we shall, for his best force  Is forth to man his galleys.
t: Unless we are attacked, we won't take any action on land—and I guess that we won't be attacked, since most of his troops have been sent out to guard his ships.

og: To the vales,  And hold our best advantage.
t: Let's go to the valleys and take the best position.

og: Yet they are not joined. Where yond pine does standI shall discover all. I’ll bring thee wordStraight how ’tis like to go.
t: But they still aren't fighting. I'll go over to where that pine stands and survey the whole scene. I'll tell you shortly how things are likely to go.

og: Swallows have built  In Cleopatra’s sails their nests. The auguries  Say they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly,  And dare not speak their knowledge.
t: Swallows have built nests in the sails of Cleopatra's ships. The soothsayers say they don't know what this means, they cannot say. They look grim and dare not tell us what they know.

og: Antony  Is valiant and dejected, and by starts  His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear  Of what he has and has not.
t: Antony is both brave and dejected, and in fits and starts his diminished luck gives him reasons for both hope and fear—hope thanks to what he does have, fear because of what he does not have.

og: All is lost!  This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.  My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder  They cast their caps up and carouse together  Like friends long lost.
t: All is lost! That foul Egyptian has betrayed me. My fleet has surrendered to the enemy, and down there, they throw their caps in the air and drink together like long-lost friends.

og: Triple-turned whore! ’Tis thou  Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart  Makes only wars on thee.
t: That whore, who's betrayed three men! It's you, Cleopatra, who has sold me out to this boy Caesar, and my anger is directed only at you.

og: Bid them all fly,  For when I am revenged upon my charm,  I have done all. Bid them all fly. Begone!
t: Tell all my forces to flee, for all I intend to do now is take revenge on this woman who bewitched me. Tell them all to flee. Get going!

og: O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.  Fortune and Antony part here. Even here  Do we shake hands.
t: Oh sun, I will never see you rise agin. This is when I lose all my luck; at this very moment I bid it goodbye.

og: All come to this? The hearts  That spanieled me at heels, to whom I gave  Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets  On blossoming Caesar, and this pine is barked  That overtopped them all.
t: Has it all come to this? Those men who fawned on me with all their hearts, whose wishes I granted, fall away from me and fawn now on Caesar with his growing good fortune, and I am destroyed even though I was once greater than all of them.

og: Betrayed I am.  Oh, this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm,  Whose eye becked forth my wars and called them home,
t: I am betrayed. Oh, this treacherous queen of Egypt! This deadly enchantress, who decided when I went to war and when I brought my armies home,

og: Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,  Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose  Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.
t: whose love was my main goal and greatest glory, she has cheated me like a true gypsy and tricked me until I lost everything.

og: What, Eros, Eros!
t: Hey there, Eros, Eros!

og: Why is my lord enraged against his love?
t: Why is my lord so angry at his love?

og: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,  And blemish Caesar’s triumph. Let him take thee  And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
t: Get away, or I'll give you what you deserve and diminish the glory of Caesar's triumphal procession. Let him take you and display you in public in front of the screaming crowd!

og: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot  Of all thy sex. Most monsterlike be shown  For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let  Patient Octavia plow thy visage up  With her preparèd nails!
t: Follow his chariot, like the most disgraced woman that has ever lived. Be displayed like a spectacle for fools, for the common people to stare at, and let long-suffering Octavia scratch your face with the nails she has sharpened for you!

og: ’Tis well th’art gone,  If it be well to live, but better ’twere  Thou fell’st into my fury, for one death  Might have prevented many.
t: It's good that you're gone, if you wish to remain alive, but it would have been better if you had fallen prey to my anger. Then your death might have prevented the death of many others.

og: —Eros, ho!—
t: Eros, hey there!

og: The shirt of Nessus is upon me. Teach me,  Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage.
t: I feel as if I were wearing the shirt of Nessus. Hercules, my ancestor, I pray that you will show me how to show my anger as you did.

og: Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o’ th’ moon,  And with those hands that grasped the heaviest club  Subdue my worthiest self.
t: Let me destroy my enemy, and with my own hands—hands that once wielded the heaviest weapons—destroy myself with honor.

og: The witch shall die.  To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall  Under this plot. She dies for ’t.
t: That witch Cleopatra will die. She's sold me to that young Roman boy Caesar, and I am destroyed by her plot. She will die for it.

og: —Eros, ho!
t: Eros, hey there!

og: Help me, my women! Oh, he’s more madThan Telamon for his shield. The boar of ThessalyWas never so embossed.
t: Help me, my women! Oh, he's more angrier than Ajax when he was denied Achilles' shield. The boar of Thessaly never foamed at the mouth with more rage.

og: To th’ monument!  There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
t: Go to your tomb! Lock yourself inside and send him a message that you are dead.

og: The soul and body rive not more in parting  Than greatness going off.
t: When a great man loses his greatness, he falls lower than anyone—his greatness goes farther from him than the soul goes from the body in death.

og: To th’ monument!—
t: To the tomb!

og: Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself.  Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,”  And word it, prithee, piteously.
t: Mardian, go tell him I have killed myself. Tell him the last word I spoke was "Antony," and please, fill your voice with pity when you say it.

og: Hence, Mardian,  And bring me how he takes my death.
t: Get going, Mardian, and tell me how he reacts to the news of my death.

og: To th’ monument!
t: To the tomb!

og: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?
t: Eros, you still see me?

og: Ay, noble lord.
t: Yes, my noble lord.

og: Sometimes we see a cloud that’s dragonish,  A vapor sometime like a bear or lion,  A towered citadel, a pendant rock,  A forkèd mountain,
t: Sometimes we see a cloud that looks like a dragon, and sometimes a mist that looks like a bear or a lion, like a fortress with towers, an overhanging rock, a mountain with many peaks.

og: or blue promontory  With trees upon ’t that nod unto the world  And mock our eyes with air.
t: Sometimes we see a blue rock with trees on it that shake before our eyes and make mockeries of our sight since they are made only of air.

og: Thou hast seen these signs.  They are black vesper’s pageants.
t: You have seen the signs. They are the apparitions that tell us night and death are coming.

og: Ay, my lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: That which is now a horse, even with a thoughtThe rack dislimns and makes it indistinctAs water is in water.
t: We see a shape that now looks like a horse, and even as we think it, the cloud dims and makes the shape indistinct, like one drop in a body of water.

og: It does, my lord.
t: It does, my lord.

og: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is  Even such a body. Here I am Antony,  Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
t: My good young man Eros, your captain's body behaves in just the same way now. I am myself for now, but I cannot maintain this bodily form, my boy.

og: I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,  Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine—  Which whilst it was mine had annexed unto ’t  A million more, now lost
t: I went to war for the sake of Egypt and the Queen. I thought I had the Queen's love, for she had mine—and until I loved her, I had the love of a million more people, which I have now lost.

og: —she, Eros, has  Packed cards with Caesar and false-played my glory  Unto an enemy’s triumph.
t: But now she has concocted a plot with Caesar, Eros, and betrayed me so that an enemy may defeat me and destroy my glory.

og: Nay, weep not, gentle Eros. There is left us  Ourselves to end ourselves.
t: No, do not weep, gentle Eros. We still have enough of our own power to put an end to our lives.

og: Oh, thy vile lady!She has robbed me of my sword.
t: Oh, your despicable mistress! She has destroyed all my fortitude.

og: No, Antony,My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingledWith thine entirely.
t: No, Antony, my mistress loved you, and her fate was inseparable from yours.

og: Hence, saucy eunuch! Peace!She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
t: Get out, you shameless eunuch! Be quiet! She has betrayed me and she will die as she deserves.

og: Death of one person can be paid but once,  And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do  Is done unto thy hand.
t: A person can only die once, and she has done that. What you intended to do, she has done for you.

og: The last she spake  Was “Antony, most noble Antony!”  Then in the midst a tearing groan did break  The name of Antony.
t: The last words she spoke were, "Antony, most noble Antony!" Then she broke off in the middle of saying your name to let out a heart-rending groan.

og: It was divided  Between her heart and lips. She rendered life,  Thy name so buried in her.
t: She spoke half of the word, the other half remained in her heart. And so she died with your name buried inside her.

og: Dead, then?
t: She is dead, then?

og: Dead.
t: Dead.

og: Unarm, Eros. The long day’s task is done,And we must sleep.    That thou depart’st hence safeDoes pay thy labor richly. Go.
t: Take off my armor, Eros. Our long day's work is finished, and we must sleep.

og: Off, pluck off!  The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep  The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
t: Off, take my armor off! [EROS removes his armor] Not even the shield of Ajax, with all its seven layers, can protect my heart from this assault. Oh, if only my sides would burst open!

og: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.  Crack thy frail case!—Apace, Eros, apace.  No more a soldier.
t: I wish my heart were stronger than the weak body that contains it and crack open. Quickly, Eros, quickly. I am no longer a soldier.

og: Bruisèd pieces, go.  You have been nobly borne.  (to EROS)  From me awhile.
t: Let these damaged pieces of armor be cast aside. I wore them nobly. Eros, leave me alone for a while.

og: What would my lord?
t: What do you want, my lord?

og: Since Cleopatra died  I have lived in such dishonor that the gods  Detest my baseness.
t: Since Cleopatra died, my life has had such dishonor that even the gods hate how disgraceful I am.

og: I, that with my sword  Quartered the world, and o’er green Neptune’s back  With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack  The courage of a woman
t: I, who divided the world into quarters and sailed across the green sea with so many ships that they appeared to make a city on the waves—I disgrace myself by having less courage than a woman.

og: —less noble mind  Than she which by her death our Caesar tells  “I am conqueror of myself.”
t: I have a less noble mind than she, who tells Caesar with her death, "I am conqueror of myself."

og: Thou art sworn, Eros,  That when the exigent should come which now  Is come indeed, when I should see behind me  Th’ inevitable prosecution of  Disgrace and horror, that on my command,  Thou then wouldst kill me  .
t: You have sworn, Eros, that when it became necessary, as it is now, when I could see inevitable disgrace and horror looming, that you would kill me on my command.

og: Do ’t. The time is come.  Thou strik’st not me, ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.  Put color in thy cheek.
t: Do it. The time has come. It isn't me you strike, it's Caesar you're defeating. Pull yourself together.

og: The gods withhold me!Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
t: May the gods prevent me! All of the Parthians' arrows missed their target and could not kill you, how could I kill you instead?

og: Eros,  Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see  Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down  His corrigible neck, his face subdued  To penetrative shame,
t: Eros, would you rather look down from a window in the great city of Rome and see your master displayed like this, with his arms tied, bending his neck in submission, his face subdued by penetrating shame,

og: whilst the wheeled seat  Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded  His baseness that ensued?
t: while lucky Caesar's chariot was drawn before him, indicating to everyone that the man who walked behind was disgraced?

og: I would not see ’t.
t: I couldn't look at it.

og: Come, then, for with a wound I must be cured.Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast wornMost useful for thy country.
t: Come, then, for you can only help me by wounding me. Draw your faithful sword, which you have used to do good service for your country.

og: O sir, pardon me!
t: Oh sir, pardon me!

og: When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then  To do this when I bade thee?
t: When I freed you from servitude, didn't you swear to me then that you would do this when I told you to?

og: Do it at once,  Or thy precedent services are all  But accidents unpurposed. Draw and come.
t: Do it immediately, or all your previous service to me was nothing but an accident, not something you intended to do. Draw your sword and come.

og: Turn from me then that noble countenanceWherein the worship of the whole world lies.
t: Turn away from me, then, that noble face that the whole world used to worship.

og: Lo thee!
t: Here you are!

og: My sword is drawn.
t: My sword is drawn.

og: Then let it do at onceThe thing why thou hast drawn it.
t: Then do it at once, the thing you drew it in order to do.

og: My dear master,My captain, and my emperor, let me say,Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
t: My dear master, my captain, and my emperor, before I strike this deadly stroke, let me say goodbye to you.

og: ’Tis said, man, and farewell.
t: You've said it, man, goodbye.

og: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?
t: Goodbye, great captain. Shall I strike now?

og: Now, Eros.
t: Now, Eros.

og: Why, there then!
t: Why, then there it is!

og: Thrice nobler than myself,  Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what  I should and thou couldst not.
t: You are three times nobler than I am. Oh brave Eros, you teach me how to do the thing that I should do and that you couldn't do.

og: My Queen and Eros  Have by their brave instruction got upon me  A nobleness in record.
t: In this brave deed that they've taught me, my Queen and Eros have gained a noble reputation ahead of me, recorded in the history books.

og: But I will be  A bridegroom in my death, and run into ’t  As to a lover’s bed.
t: But I will embrace death as willingly as a bridegroom embraces his bride, and seek it as eagerly as a lover's bed.

og: Come then, and Eros,  Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus  I learned of thee.
t: Come then. Eros, I was once your master but now I am your student. I learned how to do this from you.

og: What’s the noise?
t: What's all this noise?

og: I have done my work ill, friends. Oh, make an endOf what I have begun!
t: I've done my work badly, my friends. Oh, finish what I started!

og: The star is fall’n.
t: The greatest man has fallen.

og: And time is at his period.
t: And time comes to a halt.

og: Alas, and woe!
t: Alas, the sorrow!

og: Let him that loves me strike me dead.
t: If anyone loves me, let him kill me.

og: Not I.
t: Not I.

og: Nor I.
t: Nor I.

og: Nor anyone.
t: Nor anyone.

og: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
t: Your death and your fallen fortunes show your followers that they ought to leave you.

og: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,Shall enter me with him.
t: If I just show this sword to Caesar and tell him this news, I'll gain favor with him.

og: Where’s Antony?
t: Where's Antony?

og: There, Diomed, there.
t: There, Diomed, there.

og: Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?
t: Is he alive? Won't you answer, man?

og: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword and give meSufficing strokes for death.
t: Are you there, Diomed? Draw your sword and strike me hard enough to kill me.

og: Most absolute lord,My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
t: Greatest lord, my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you.

og: When did she send thee?
t: When did she send you?

og: Now, my lord.
t: Just now, my lord.

og: Where is she?
t: Where is she?

og: Locked in her monument. She had a prophesying fear  Of what hath come to pass.
t: Locked in her tomb. She was afraid of what she foresaw might happen.

og: For when she saw—  Which never shall be found—you did suspect  She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage  Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.
t: For when she saw that you suspected her of plotting with Caesar—something you will never find to be true—and that your rage could not be overcome, she sent you a message that she was dead.

og: But fearing since how it might work, hath sent  Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come,  I dread, too late.
t: But then she became afraid of what effect the news might have on you, and she sent me to tell you the truth. Now I'm afraid that I've arrived too late.

og: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.
t: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, please.

og: What ho, the Emperor’s guard! The guard, what ho!Come, your lord calls!
t: Hey there, the Emperor's guard! The guard, hey there! Come, your lord is calling you!

og: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.’Tis the last service that I shall command you.
t: Good friends, carry me to where Cleopatra is. This is the last service that I will command you to carry out.

og: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wearAll your true followers out.
t: We are sorrowful, sorrowful, sir, that you will not live longer than your followers.

og: Most heavy day!
t: Most sorrowful day!

og: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate  To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome  Which comes to punish us, and we punish it,  Seeming to bear it lightly.
t: No, my good friends, do not give cruel fate the satisfaction of seeing your sorrows. If we welcome something that was intended to punish us, we punish it in return by seeming not to mind it.

og: Take me up.  I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends,  And have my thanks for all.
t: Pick me up. I have often led you; carry me now, good friends. I thank you for everything.

og: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
t: Oh Charmian, I will never leave this place.

og: Be comforted, dear madam.
t: Be comforted, good madam.

og: No, I will not.  All strange and terrible events are welcome,  But comforts we despise.
t: No, I will not. I welcome all strange and terrible events, but I despise comfort.

og: Our size of sorrow,  Proportioned to our cause, must be as great  As that which makes it.
t: The size of our sorrow is proportionate to the cause of our sorrow, and so it must be as great as the cause.

og: How now? Is he dead?
t: What's going on? Is he dead?

og: His death’s upon him, but not dead.Look out o’ th’ other side your monument.His guard have brought him thither.
t: His death is approaching fast, but he is not dead. Look out from the other side of your tomb. His guards have brought him there.

og: O sun,  Burn the great sphere thou mov’st in. Darkling stand  The varying shore o’ th’ world!
t: Oh sun, burn up the path of your orbit and leave it. May all the shores of the world lie in darkness!

og: O Antony,  Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!  Help, friends below! Let’s draw him hither.
t: Oh Antony, Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, Iras, help! Help, friends below! Let's draw him up here.

og: Peace!Not Caesar’s valor hath o’erthrown Antony,But Antony’s hath triumphed on itself.
t: Be at peace! Caesar's bravery did not overthrow me. I conquered myself with my own bravery.

og: So it should be, that none but AntonyShould conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!
t: That is how it should be, that no one should conquer Antony except Antony himself—but what a pity that it has come to pass!

og: I am dying, Egypt, dying. Only  I here importune death awhile,
t: I am dying, Queen of Egypt, dying. I just ask now that death hold off for a short while,

og: until  Of many thousand kisses the poor last  I lay upon thy lips.
t: until I lay the poor last kiss of many thousands of kisses on your lips.

og: I dare not, dear,  Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not,  Lest I be taken. Not th’ imperious show  Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall  Be brooched with me.
t: I dare not come down to you, dear. My dear lord, forgive me, I dare not, for fear I will be captured. I will never serve as an ornament to adorn the triumphal procession of Caesar, for all his good fortune.

og: If knife, drugs, serpents, have  Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
t: As long as knives have edges, serpents have teeth, or drugs have power, I will be safe from him.

og: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes  And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor  Demuring upon me.
t: Your wife Octavia, with her modestly lowered eyes and her silent judgments, will get no honor from gazing upon me.

og: But come, come, Antony—  Help me, my women—We must draw thee up.  Assist, good friends.
t: But come, come, Antony—help me, my women—we must draw you up. Help, good friends.

og: Oh, quick, or I am gone.
t: Oh, quick, or I will be dead.

og: Here’s sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!  Our strength is all gone into heaviness,  That makes the weight.
t: Here's a fine game! How heavy my lord is! All our strength is dissolved by sadness—that's what makes the weight so great.

og: Had I great Juno’s power,  The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up  And set thee by Jove’s side.
t: If I had great Juno's power, Mercury with his strong wings would bring you up and set you at Jove's side.

og: Yet come a little.  Wishers were ever fools. Oh, come, come, come!
t: Still, come a little closer. Wishing has always been a foolish thing to do. Oh, come, come, come!

og: And welcome, welcome! Die when thou hast lived.Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,Thus would I wear them out.
t: And welcome, welcome! Die only after you have lived. Let kissing bring you back to life. If my lips had the power to do that, I would wear them out like this.

og: A heavy sight!
t: A sad sight!

og: I am dying, Egypt, dying.Give me some wine and let me speak a little.
t: I am dying, Queen of Egypt, dying. Give me some wine and let me speak a little.

og: No, let me speak, and let me rail so highThat the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,Provoked by my offense.
t: No, let me speak, I will complain and rant so bitterly that deceitful, treacherous Fortune will be so provoked by my insults that she will give up her power.

og: One word, sweet Queen:Of Caesar seek your honor, with your safety—Oh!
t: One word, sweet Queen. Appeal to Caesar to protect your honor and your safety—oh!

og: They do not go together.
t: He cannot do both.

og: Gentle, hear me.None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.
t: Gentle lady, listen to me. Don't trust any of Caesar's followers except Proculeius.

og: My resolution and my hands I’ll trust,None about Caesar.
t: I'll trust my determination and my own hands. I won't trust anyone around Caesar.

og: The miserable change now at my end  Lament nor sorrow at, but please your thoughts  In feeding them with those my former fortunes,  Wherein I lived the greatest prince o’ th’ world,  The noblest,
t: Do not lament or be sorry for the miserable turn that my life has taken. Rather, please yourself by thinking about the great fortunes I enjoyed in the past, when I was the greatest and noblest prince in the world.

og: and do now not basely die,  Not cowardly put off my helmet to  My countryman
t: I do not die dishonorably now, nor do I surrender like a coward to my fellow countryman.

og: —a Roman by a Roman  Valiantly vanquished. Now my spirit is going.  I can no more.
t: I am a Roman who has been bravely conquered by another Roman. Now my last breath is leaving me. I cannot speak any more.

og: Noblest of men, woo’t die?  Hast thou no care of me?
t: Noblest of men, are you dying? Don't you care about me?

og: Shall I abide  In this dull world, which in thy absence is  No better than a sty?
t: Can I remain in this dull world, which will be no better than a pigsty when you are gone from it?

og: O see, my women,  The crown o’ th’ earth doth melt. My lord!
t: Oh look, my women, the greatest monarch of the earth is fading away. My lord!

og: Oh, withered is the garland of the war.  The soldier’s pole is fall’n! Young boys and girls  Are level now with men.
t: Oh, the glories that crown battle are all gone now. The guide of every soldier has fallen! The men that are left now are no better than young boys and girls.

og: The odds is gone,  And there is nothing left remarkable  Beneath the visiting moon.
t: There is no person of distinction left among humankind, and there is no longer anything remarkable on earth.

og: Oh, quietness, lady!
t: Oh, be calm, my lady!

og: She’s dead too, our sovereign.
t: She's dead too, our queen.

og: Lady!
t: Lady!

og: Madam!
t: Madam!

og: O madam, madam, madam!
t: Oh madam, madam, madam!

og: Royal Egypt, Empress!
t: Royal Queen of Egypt, Empress!

og: Peace, peace, Iras.
t: Peace, peace, Iras.

og: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded  By such poor passion as the maid that milks  And does the meanest chares.
t: I am no longer a queen but just an ordinary woman. I am overpowered by the same unworthy emotions as any milkmaid who performs the humblest chores.

og: It were for me  To throw my scepter at the injurious gods,  To tell them that this world did equal theirs  Till they had stolen our jewel.
t: It would be more fitting for me to hurl my scepter at the gods who have injured me and tell them that this earthly world was as good as their divine world until they stole away the greatest man.

og: All’s but naught.  Patience is sottish, and impatience does  Become a dog that’s mad. Then is it sin  To rush into the secret house of death  Ere death dare come to us?
t: Everything is worthless. It is idiotic to be patient and endure things calmly, and to become impatient is quickly to become like a mad dog. In that case, is it really sinful to rush towards death before death comes to us naturally?

og: How do you, women?  What, what, good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian?  My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look,  Our lamp is spent, it’s out. Good sirs, take heart.
t: How are you, my women? What, what, be cheerful! Why, how are you doing there, Charmian? My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look, our lamp has run out of oil, it's gone out. Good women, take heart.

og: We’ll bury him, and then, what’s brave, what’s noble,  Let’s do ’t after the high Roman fashion  And make death proud to take us.
t: We'll bury him, and then, whatever is brave or noble, we'll do it in the noble Roman style, and die so nobly that death will be proud to take us.

og: Come, away.  This case of that huge spirit now is cold.  Ah, women, women! Come. We have no friend  But resolution, and the briefest end.
t: Come, away. The body that contained that great spirit is now cold. Ah, women, women! Come. The only thing that can help us is determination, and the quickest possible death.

og: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocksThe pauses that he makes.
t: Go to Antony, Dolabella, and tell him to surrender. His delay in doing so makes him look ridiculous.

og: Caesar, I shall.
t: Caesar, I will.

og: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar’stAppear thus to us?
t: What is that? And who are you to dare and appear before me armed?

og: I am called Dercetus.  Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy  Best to be served. Whilst he stood up and spoke,  He was my master, and I wore my life  To spend upon his haters.
t: My name is Dercetus. I served Mark Antony, who was the man most worthy of being served. While he was alive, he was my master, and I used my life to oppose those who hated him.

og: If thou please  To take me to thee, as I was to him  I’ll be to Caesar. If thou pleasest not,  I yield thee up my life.
t: If it pleases you to employ me as Antony did I'll be loyal to you, Caesar. If not, I surrender my life to you.

og: What is ’t thou say’st?
t: What do you mean?

og: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
t: I mean, Caesar, that Antony is dead.

og: The breaking of so great a thing should make  A greater crack. The round world  Should have shook lions into civil streets  And citizens to their dens.
t: It should cause a greater disturbance when someone so great dies. The globe should have shaken so much that lions left their dens and entered the city streets and the citizens fled to the lions' dens.

og: The death of Antony  Is not a single doom. In the name lay  A moiety of the world.
t: His death was not the death of an ordinary man. He controlled half of the world.

og: He is dead, Caesar,  Not by a public minister of justice,  Nor by a hirèd knife,
t: He is dead. He wasn't killed by a public minister of justice or a hired assassin.

og: but that self hand  Which writ his honor in the acts it did  Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,  Splitted the heart.
t: With a courageous heart, he killed himself with the same hand that he performed many honorable acts.

og: This is his sword.  I robbed his wound of it. Behold it stained  With his most noble blood.
t: This is his sword. I took it away after it wounded him. See how it's stained with his most noble blood.

og: Look you, sad friends,The gods rebuke me, but it is tidingsTo wash the eyes of kings.
t: See, my sad friends, the gods might criticize me for weeping, but this news is enough to make even a king cry.

og: And strange it isThat nature must compel us to lamentOur most persisted deeds.
t: And it is strange that our nature makes us weep for something that we tried hard to achieve.

og: His taints and honorsWaged equal with him.
t: His flaws and his virtues fought inside him, both with equal power.

og: A rarer spirit neverDid steer humanity, but you gods will give usSome faults to make us men. Caesar is touched.
t: No man was ever governed with such an uncommonly noble spirit. But the gods give us some faults to make us human. Caesar is emotional over the news.

og: When such a spacious mirror’s set before him,He needs must see himself.
t: When he thinks about such a great man, he sees what he himself could become.

og: O Antony,  I have followed thee to this, but we do launch  Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce  Have shown to thee such a declining day,  Or look on thine.  We could not stall together  In the whole world.
t: Oh Antony, I was trying to end your life, but we have to get rid of a disease if it threatens our body. Either I would have had to die, or you would have. The world wasn't big enough for both of us.

og: But yet let me lament  With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts  That thou, my brother, my competitor  In top of all design, my mate in empire,  Friend and companion in the front of war,  The arm of mine own body, and the heart  Where mine his thoughts did kindle
t: But I will still weep, with tears as powerful as the blood in my heart, for you, my brother, my greatest competitor, my co-ruler of the empire, my friend and companion on the battlefield, the arm of my own body, and to whom I confided all my thoughts

og: —that our stars,  Unreconcilable, should divide  Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends—
t: —I weep that our partnership was divided by our irreconcilable fates. Listen to me, good friends—

og: But I will tell you at some meeter season.
t: But I'll tell you what I have to say at a more appropriate time.

og: The business of this man looks out of him.
t: This man looks like he's here on urgent business.

og: We’ll hear him what he says.
t: We'll hear what he has to say.

og: (to EGYPTIAN)  Whence are you?
t: [To the EGYPTIAN] Who sent you?

og: A poor Egyptian yet, the Queen my mistress,  Confined in all she has, her monument,  Of thy intents desires instruction,
t: That poor Egyptian, the Queen my mistress. She has locked herself in her tomb—which is now all she has left—and she wants to know what you intend to do,

og: That she preparedly may frame herself  To th’ way she’s forced to.
t: so that she can prepare herself for her fate.

og: Bid her have good heart.  She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,  How honorable and how kindly we  Determine for her,
t: Tell her to take comfort. I will soon send some messengers to tell her how honorable and kind my plans are for her.

og: for Caesar cannot live  To be ungentle.
t: For it is impossible for me not to be gracious and noble.

og: So the gods preserve thee!
t: May the gods bless you.

og: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say  We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts  The quality of her passion shall require,
t: Come here, Proculeius. Go and tell Cleopatra that we have no intention of disrespecting her. Give her whatever comforts she requires, given her current emotional state.

og: Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke  She do defeat us, for her life in Rome  Would be eternal in our triumph.
t: Otherwise, her nobility may lead her to kill herself and so prevent me from gaining undying glory by bringing her to Rome as my captive.

og: Go,  And with your speediest bring us what she says  And how you find of her.
t: Go, and then report back with her response quickly and tell me how she appears.

og: Caesar, I shall.
t: Caesar, I will.

og: Gallus, go you along.
t: Gallus, get going.

og: Dolabella!
t: Dolabella!

og: Let him alone, for I remember now  How he’s employed. He shall in time be ready.
t: Forget it, I just remembered that I sent him on an errand. He'll be ready shortly.

og: Go with me to my tent, where you shall see  How hardly I was drawn into this war,  How calm and gentle I proceeded still  In all my writings. Go with me and see  What I can show in this.
t: Come with me to my tent, and see how I was drawn into this war against my will and how calm and gentle I always was. Come with me and I will prove it.

og: My desolation does begin to make  A better life. ’Tis paltry to be Caesar.  Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave,  A minister of her will.
t: My isolation has helped me better understand my life. It's no great thing to be Caesar. He doesn't control his own fate, he's controlled by fate, and does whatever fortune dictates.

og: And it is great  To do that thing that ends all other deeds,  Which shackles accidents and bolts up change,
t: And it is great, to do that deed that puts an end to everything else, that puts a stop to all the accidents of fortune and to all change,

og: Which sleeps and never palates more the dung,  The beggar’s nurse, and Caesar’s.
t: that makes us sleep forever so that we never eat food from the earth again—food that nourishes beggars as well as great men like Caesar.

og: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt,And bids thee study on what fair demandsThou mean’st to have him grant thee.
t: Caesar sends greetings to the Queen of Egypt and asks what requests you have for him.

og: What’s thy name?
t: What is your name?

og: My name is Proculeius.
t: My name is Proculeius.

og: Antony  Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but  I do not greatly care to be deceived,  That have no use for trusting.
t: Antony told me about you and told me to trust you, but I am still hesitant to trust people, since I do not like being deceived.

og: If your master  Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him,  That majesty, to keep decorum, must  No less beg than a kingdom.
t: If your master wants me, a queen, to beg for favors from him, then you must tell him that a queen, if she is to act appropriately, cannot ask for anything less than a kingdom.

og: If he please  To give me conquered Egypt for my son,  He gives me so much of mine own as I  Will kneel to him with thanks.
t: If Caesar is willing to give Egypt back to me so I can make my son its ruler, then I will kneel down and thank him for giving me back what is rightfully mine.

og: Be of good cheer.  You’re fall’n into a princely hand. Fear nothing.  Make your full reference freely to my lord,  Who is so full of grace that it flows over  On all that need.
t: Take comfort. You've been conquered by a noble and generous man. Don't be afraid of anything. Make all your requests to my lord without hesitation. His generosity is so great that he will willingly meet your needs.

og: Let me report to him  Your sweet dependency, and you shall find  A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness  Where he for grace is kneeled to.
t: Let me report back to him how humbly you acknowledge his power, and you'll find that this conquerer will beg you to tell him new ways to show kindness to you, once you've knelt down to ask him for mercy.

og: Pray you, tell him  I am his fortune’s vassal, and I send him  The greatness he has got.
t: Please, tell him that I am at the mercy of fortune and that I acknowledge the great power he has won through his good fortune.

og: I hourly learn  A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly  Look him i’ th’ face.
t: Every hour I learn to become more obedient, and I would gladly speak to him face to face.

og: This I’ll report, dear lady.Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitiedOf him that caused it.
t: I'll tell him this, dear lady. Take comfort, for I know that Caesar, who put you in this position, pities you for what he's done.

og: You see how easily she may be surprised.    Guard her till Caesar come.
t: You see how easily someone can sneak up on her. Guard her until Caesar arrives.

og: Royal Queen!
t: Royal Queen!

og: O Cleopatra! Thou art taken, Queen.
t: Oh Cleopatra! You are captured, Queen.

og: Quick, quick, good hands.
t: Act quickly, my good hands.

og: Hold, worthy lady, hold!Do not yourself such wrong, who are in thisRelieved but not betrayed.
t: Stop, worthy lady, stop! Do not do yourself such wrong. We are trying to help you, not betray you.

og: What, of death too,That rids our dogs of languish?
t: What, you are depriving me of my death, too? Even dogs are allowed to die to avoid prolonged suffering.

og: Cleopatra,Do not abuse my master’s bounty byTh’ undoing of yourself. Let the world seeHis nobleness well acted, which your deathWill never let come forth.
t: Cleopatra, do not show such ingratitude to my master's generosity by killing yourself. Let the world have a chance to see how nobly he acts; if you die, his nobility cannot be displayed.

og: Where art thou, Death?Come hither, come! Come, come and take a queenWorth many babes and beggars!
t: Where are you, Death? Come here, come! Come, come, and kill me, a queen, who is worth more than the babies and beggars that you so frequently kill!

og: Oh, temperance, lady!
t: Oh, be patient, my lady!

og: Sir, I will eat no meat, I’ll not drink, sir.  If idle talk will once be necessary,  I’ll not sleep neither. This mortal house I’ll ruin,  Do Caesar what he can.
t: Sir, I will eat no food and I will not drink, sir. Even if it takes idle chatter to keep me awake, I won't sleep either. I'll destroy my own body, no matter what Caesar tries to do.

og: Know, sir, that I  Will not wait pinioned at your master’s court,  Nor once be chastised with the sober eye  Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up  And show me to the shouting varletry  Of censuring Rome?
t: You should know, sir, that I won't wait around to be a captive at your master's court, or to be judged with solemn looks from dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up and display me to the shouting mobs of Rome with all their harsh judgments?

og: Rather a ditch in Egypt  Be gentle grave unto me. Rather on Nilus’ mud  Lay me stark naked and let the waterflies  Blow me into abhorring. Rather make  My country’s high pyramides my gibbet  And hang me up in chains!
t: I'd rather have a friendly grave in a ditch in Egypt. I'd rather be laid stark naked in the mud on the shores of the Nile and let waterflies lay eggs on me until I become disgusting. I'd rather you turned Egypt's tall pyramids into a gallows and hung me from them in chains!

og: You do extendThese thoughts of horror further than you shallFind cause in Caesar.
t: You'll learn from Caesar that you're alarming yourself needlessly.

og: Proculeius,  What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,  And he hath sent for thee.
t: Proculeius, your master Caesar knows what you have done, and he's sent for you.

og: For the Queen,  I’ll take her to my guard.
t: As for the Queen, I'll guard her.

og: So, Dolabella,  It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.
t: That sounds fine to me, Dolabella. Be gentle with her.

og: To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,  If you’ll employ me to him.
t: I'll tell Caesar whatever you wish, if you'll send a message to him through me.

og: Say I would die.
t: Tell him I wish to die.

og: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
t: Most noble Empress, have you heard of me?

og: I cannot tell.
t: I cannot tell.

og: Assuredly you know me.
t: I'm sure that you know me.

og: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.Is ’t not your trick?
t: It doesn't matter, sir, what I have heard or known. You laugh when boys or women tell you about their dreams. Isn't that your habit?

og: I understand not, madam.
t: I don't understand, madam.

og: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.Oh, such another sleep, that I might seeBut such another man!
t: I dreamt Antony was emperor. Oh, I wish I could sleep again like that, so I could dream about another man like that!

og: If it might please ye—
t: If you care to—

og: His face was as the heavens, and therein stuckA sun and moon, which kept their course and lightedThe little “O,” the earth.
t: His face was as bright and majestic as the heavens. In his face were two bright orbs, like the sun and moon, that followed their course and shed light on this whole round planet, the earth.

og: Most sovereign creature—
t: Most royal lady—

og: His legs bestrid the ocean. His reared arm  Crested the world. His voice was propertied  As all the tunèd spheres, and that to friends.
t: He was so tall that his legs straddled the ocean. His upraised arm reached across the whole world. When he spoke to friends, his voice had the same qualities as musical spheres.

og: But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,  He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,  There was no winter in ’t, an autumn ’twas  That grew the more by reaping.
t: But when he wanted to frighten and shake the world, his voice rumbled like thunder. His generosity was endless. It was like an autumn harvest, that grew more bountiful the more you drew from it.

og: His delights  Were dolphinlike; they showed his back above  The element they lived in.
t: The things he took delight in revealed his extraordinary character; just as a dolphin's fin rises above the water, his character made him rise above the level of common people.

og: In his livery  Walked crowns and crownets. Realms and islands were  As plates dropped from his pocket.
t: Kings and princes were his servants. He could give away realms and islands as easily as he could drop silver coins from his pocket.

og: Cleopatra—
t: Cleopatra—

og: Think you there was or might be such a manAs this I dreamt of?
t: Do you think there was, or could be, a man like the one I dreamed of?

og: Gentle madam, no.
t: Gentle madam, no.

og: You lie up to the hearing of the gods.  But if there be nor ever were one such,  It’s past the size of dreaming.
t: You lie so blatantly that even the gods can hear you! But if there is or ever was such a man, he's greater than anything that could be dreamed up.

og: Nature wants stuff  To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t’ imagine  An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy,  Condemning shadows quite.
t: Nature cannot create creatures as strange as the ones we can imagine, but if nature could create a man like Antony, it would outdo even the imagination, and reveal how pathetic and worthless our imaginary visions are.

og: Hear me, good madam.  Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it  As answering to the weight.
t: Listen to me, good madam. Your loss is great because you yourself are great, and you bear it like the heavy burden it is.

og: Would I might never  O’ertake pursued success, but I do feel,  By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites  My very heart at root.
t: May I never achieve the success I seek if this is not true: that from sympathizing with your grief, I feel a grief that strikes deep in my own heart.

og: I thank you, sir.Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
t: I thank you, sir. Do you know what Caesar intends to do with me?

og: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.
t: It pains me to tell you what I want you to know.

og: Nay, pray you, sir.
t: No, please, go on, sir.

og: Though he be honorable—
t: Even though Caesar is honorable—

og: He’ll lead me, then, in triumph.
t: He'll lead me in his triumphal procession, then.

og: Madam, he will. I know ’t.
t: Madam, he will. I know it.

og: Make way there! Caesar!
t: Make way there! Caesar is coming!

og: Which is the Queen of Egypt?
t: Which person is the Queen of Egypt?

og: It is the Emperor, madam.
t: It is the Emperor, madam.

og: Arise, you shall not kneel.I pray you, rise. Rise, Egypt.
t: Get up, you shouldn't kneel. Please, rise. Rise, Queen of Egypt.

og: Sir, the godsWill have it thus. My master and my lordI must obey.
t: Sir, this is what the gods have willed. I must obey my lord and master.

og: Take to you no hard thoughts.
t: Please don't hold any grudges.

og: The record of what injuries you did us,  Though written in our flesh, we shall remember  As things but done by chance.
t: Even though our bodies still bear the wounds from battle, we'll agree to forget about the injuries you inflicted on us, treating them as accidents.

og: Sole sir o’ th’ world,  I cannot project mine own cause so well  To make it clear,
t: Only ruler of the world, I cannot explain my side of the story well enough to make it clear.

og: but do confess I have  Been laden with like frailties which before  Have often shamed our sex.
t: I can only confess that I have some of the same weaknesses that have often brought shame to women.

og: Cleopatra, know  We will extenuate rather than enforce.  If you apply yourself to our intents,  Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find  A benefit in this change,
t: Cleopatra, you should know that I intend to excuse your offenses rather than dwell on them. If you agree to go along with my plans, which are very generous, you'll find that this change will benefit you.

og: but if you seek  To lay on me a cruelty by taking  Antony’s course, you shall bereave yourself  Of my good purposes and put your children  To that destruction which I’ll guard them from  If thereon you rely. I’ll take my leave.
t: But if you try to injure me by killing yourself as Antony did, you'll lose all the generosity I intend to show you and ensure that I destroy your children—which I will not do if you submit to me. I'll leave you now.

og: And may, through all the world! ’Tis yours, and we,Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shallHang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.
t: And you may go freely wherever you like in the world! The world is yours, and just as you can freely display the shields of your conquered enemies, you can do whatever what you like with me.

og: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
t: You will let me know everything you need.

og: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewelsI am possessed of. ’Tis exactly valued,Not petty things admitted. Where’s Seleucus?
t: Here's an inventory of all the money, precious metals, and jewels that I own. I've calculated the exact value of everything except for the smaller items. Where's Seleucus?

og: Here, madam.
t: I'm here, madam.

og: This is my treasurer. Let him speak, my lord,  Upon his peril, that I have reserved  To myself nothing.
t: [To CAESAR] This is my treasurer. He will tell you on his honor, my lord, that I haven't held back anything for myself.

og: —  Speak the truth, Seleucus.
t: [To SELEUCUS] Speak truthfully, Seleucus.

og: Madam, I had rather seal my lipsThan to my peril speak that which is not.
t: Madam, I would rather not speak than risk endangering myself by saying something false.

og: What have I kept back?
t: What have I held back?

og: Enough to purchase what you have made known.
t: You've held back enough treasure to buy back everything you listed on that inventory.

og: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra. I approveYour wisdom in the deed.
t: No, don't blush, Cleopatra. I approve of the wisdom you demonstrated in this trick.

og: See, Caesar! Oh, behold  How pomp is followed!
t: See, Caesar! Oh, see what happens when all the spectacle is over!

og: Mine will now be yours,  And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine.  The ingratitude of this Seleucus does  Even make me wild.
t: My followers will now be your followers, and if we exchanged our positions, your followers would be my followers. Still, Seleucus's ingratitude makes me wild with anger.

og: O slave, of no more trust  Than love that’s hired!  What, goest thou back? Thou shalt  Go back, I warrant thee!
t: Oh you villainous man, you are less trustworthy than a mercenary! What, do you retreat from me? I bet you do!

og: But I’ll catch thine eyes,  Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog!  Oh, rarely base!
t: But even if your eyes had wings to fly away, I would catch them. Scoundrel, soulless villain, dog! Oh, you uncommonly corrupt man!

og: Good Queen, let us entreat you—
t: Good Queen, let me ask you to—

og: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,  That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me,  Doing the honor of thy lordliness  To one so meek, that mine own servant should  Parcel the sum of my disgraces by  Addition of his envy!
t: Oh Caesar, I am so ashamed—you agreed to visit me here and honor me in my humiliation with your great presence, and my own servant adds to all my disgraces out of spite!

og: Say, good Caesar,  That I some lady trifles have reserved,  Immoment toys, things of such dignity  As we greet modern friends withal,
t: Let's suppose, good Caesar, that I did hold back some little feminine, insignificant trinkets, the kind of common items that we give them away to our ordinary friends;

og: and say  Some nobler token I have kept apart  For Livia and Octavia, to induce  Their mediation, must I be unfolded  With one that I have bred?
t: and let's suppose that I did hold back some more valuable objects to give to your wife Livia and to Octavia, to persuade them to intervene for me—even supposing all that, do I deserve to be betrayed by a servant I have nurtured?

og: The gods! It smites me  Beneath the fall I have.
t: The gods! This causes me more agony than the embarrassment I've already endured.

og: Prithee, go hence,  Or I shall show the cinders of my spirit  Through th’ ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,  Thou wouldst have mercy on me.
t: Get out of here, or I'll show what's left of my strong will with what resources luck has left me. If you were a real man, you would have had sympathy for me.

og: Forbear, Seleucus.
t: Hold back, Seleucus.

og: Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought  For things that others do,
t: Let it be known that we, the greatest, are misjudged for the things other people do,

og: and when we fall  We answer others’ merits in our name,  Are therefore to be pitied.
t: and when we fall, we have to answer for the things that others have done in our name. We should therefore be pitied.

og: Cleopatra,  Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged  Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest. Still be ’t yours.
t: Cleopatra, I don't claim as a right of conquest either the treasure you have held back or the treasure you have declared in your inventory. Let it all still belong to you.

og: Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe  Caesar’s no merchant, to make prize with you  Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheered.  Make not your thoughts your prison.
t: Do what you like with it, and do not think that I am like a common merchant, so concerned with material things that I would haggle with you over your property. Therefore, be cheerful. Don't imprison yourself in gloomy thoughts.

og: No, dear Queen,  For we intend so to dispose you as  Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed and sleep.  Our care and pity is so much upon you  That we remain your friend. And so, adieu.
t: No, dear, Queen, because I intend to treat you in whatever way you yourself advise me to. Eat and sleep. I have so much care and pity for you that I will continue to be your friend. And so, goodbye.

og: My master, and my lord!
t: My master, and my lord!

og: Not so. Adieu.
t: I am not your master or your lord. Goodbye.

og: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should notBe noble to myself. But, hark thee, Charmian.
t: He tries to pacify me with empty words, girls, empty words, so that I will not do the noble thing and commit suicide. But, listen to me, Charmian.

og: Finish, good lady. The bright day is done,And we are for the dark.
t: Wrap things up, my lady. The bright day is over and night is upon us.

og: Hie thee again.I have spoke already, and it is provided.Go put it to the haste.
t: Hurry back. I have already given instructions, and everything is arranged. Go set things in motion quickly.

og: Madam, I will.
t: Madam, I will.

og: Where’s the Queen?
t: Where is the Queen?

og: Behold, sir.
t: She's there, sir.

og: Dolabella!
t: Dolabella!

og: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,  Which my love makes religion to obey,  I tell you this:
t: Madam, I vowed to obey your commands, and my devotion compels me to uphold that vow. Therefore, I must tell you this:

og: Caesar through Syria  Intends his journey, and within three days  You with your children will he send before.  Make your best use of this. I have performed  Your pleasure and my promise.
t: Caesar intends to travel back through Syria, and within three days, he'll send you and your children on the road ahead of him. Make the best use of this information that you can. I've carried out my promise and served you well.

og: Dolabella,I shall remain your debtor.
t: Dolabella, I will always be in your debt.

og: I your servant.Adieu, good Queen. I must attend on Caesar.
t: And I will always be your servant. Goodbye, good Queen. I must go to Caesar.

og: Farewell, and thanks.
t: Goodbye, and thank you.

og: The gods forbid!
t: May the gods forbid it!

og: Nay, ’tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors  Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers  Ballad us out o’ tune.
t: No, it will certainly happen, Iras. Insolent officers will grab at us as if we were prostitutes, and good-for-nothing poets will make up vulgar ballads about us.

og: The quick comedians  Extemporally will stage us and present  Our Alexandrian revels.
t: Witty actors will improvise plays about us and dramatize the parties we had in Alexandria.

og: Antony  Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see  Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness  I’ th’ posture of a whore.
t: They'll bring out some drunken man to play Antony, and I'll see some squeaky-voiced boy play me, in all my greatness, as if I were nothing more than a whore.

og: Oh, the good gods!
t: Oh, may the good gods forbid it!

og: Nay, that’s certain.
t: No, it's certain.

og: I’ll never see ’t! For I am sure mine nailsAre stronger than mine eyes.
t: I'll never see it! For I'm sure I have enough will-power to tear out my eyes with nails first.

og: Why, that’s the wayTo fool their preparation and to conquerTheir most absurd intents.
t: Why, that's the best way to ruin their plans and undermine the terrible things they intend to do.

og: Now, Charmian!  Show me, my women, like a queen. Go fetch  My best attires. I am again for Cydnus,  To meet Mark Antony.
t: Now, Charmian! Dress me, my women, like a queen. Go get my best robes. I am going to Cydnus, to meet Mark Antony.

og: —Sirrah Iras, go.—
t: Iras, get going.

og: Now, noble Charmian, we’ll dispatch indeed,  And when thou hast done this chare I’ll give thee leave  To play till doomsday.
t: Now, noble Charmian, we'll put our plans into action, and when you've done this task, I give you permission to do as you please until the end of the world.

og: Bring our crown and all.
t: Bring my crown and everything.

og: Here is a rural fellowThat will not be denied your Highness’ presence.He brings you figs.
t: Here's a country peasant who insists on seeing the Queen. He brings you figs.

og: Let him come in.
t: Let him come in.

og: This is the man.
t: This is the man.

og: Avoid, and leave him.
t: Get out, and leave him here.

og: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal. Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.
t: Yes, I have him, but I wouldn't advise you to touch him, for his bite is fatal. Those that die from the bite seldom or never recover.

og: Remember’st thou any that have died on ’t?
t: Do you know of any people who have died from it?

og: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them nolonger than yesterday—a very honest woman, but something given to lie, as a woman should not do but in the way of honesty
t: Very many, both men and women. I heard of one just yesterday. She was a very honest woman, but had a slight tendency to lie, which women should not do except when it's honest.

og: —how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt. Truly, she makes a very good report o’ th’ worm.
t: I heard she died from its bite and the pain. Really, she had very favorable things to say about the serpent.

og: But he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do. But this is most falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.
t: But if you believe what they say about the serpent and act on it, you'll never reach heaven. But this is definitely certain, that the serpent is an odd creature.

og: Get thee hence, farewell.
t: Get going, goodbye.

og: I wish you all joy of the worm.
t: I wish you luck with the serpent.

og: Farewell.
t: Goodbye.

og: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.
t: Be careful, you should be aware that the serpent will do what serpents typically do.

og: Ay, ay. Farewell.
t: Yes, yes. Goodbye.

og: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people, for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.
t: See here, it isn't safe for anyone except a wise person to hold on to that serpent, for it really is a dangerous animal.

og: Take thou no care. It shall be heeded.
t: Don't worry. I will listen to your warnings.

og: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.
t: Very good. Don't give it any food, I advise you, for it isn't worth keeping alive.

og: Will it eat me?
t: Will it eat me?

og: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her not.
t: You can't think I'm so foolish—I know that even the devil would not eat a woman. I know that a woman is worthy food for the gods, so long as the devil doesn't corrupt her.

og: But, truly, these same whoreson devils do the gods great harmin their women, for in every ten that they make, the devils mar five.
t: But in fact, those terrible devils do the gods great harm by ruining so many women. For every ten women the gods make, the devil ruins five.

og: Well, get thee gone. Farewell.
t: Well, get going. Goodbye.

og: Yes, forsooth. I wish you joy o’ th’ worm.
t: Yes, indeed. I wish you luck with the worm.

og: Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I haveImmortal longings in me. Now no moreThe juice of Egypt’s grape shall moist this lip.
t: Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I long to enter into the afterlife. I will never again drink wine made from Egypt's grapes.

og: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may sayThe gods themselves do weep!
t: May the thick clouds dissolve and rain so that I can say the gods themselves weep!

og: This proves me base.  If she first meet the curlèd Antony,  He’ll make demand of her and spend that kiss  Which is my heaven to have.
t: Iras's act makes mine seem less noble. If she meets the curly-haired Antony in the afterlife before I do, he'll speak to her and give her that heavenly kiss that belongs to me.

og: —Come, thou mortal wretch,
t: Come, you wretched, poisonous thing.

og: O eastern star!
t: Oh goddess!

og: Peace, peace!Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,That sucks the nurse asleep?
t: Quiet, quiet! Don't you see this baby that's lulling me to sleep by sucking on my breast?

og: Oh, break! Oh, break!
t: Oh, I wish my heart would break!

og: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle—O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too.
t: This feeling is as sweet as perfumed oil, as soft as air, as gentle—O Antony!—Oh yes, I will take you too.

og: In this wild world? So, fare thee well.Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession liesA lass unparalleled. Downy windows, close,
t: In this wild world? So, farewell. Now, Death, you can boast that you have taken a woman who has no equal. Let's close these soft eyelids.

og: Where’s the Queen?
t: Where's the Queen?

og: Speak softly. Wake her not.
t: Speak softly. Don't wake her up.

og: Caesar hath sent—
t: Caesar has sent—

og: Too slow a messenger.
t: A messenger that was too slow.

og: Approach, ho! All’s not well. Caesar’s beguiled.
t: Hey there, come here! Something's gone wrong. Caesar has been tricked.

og: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar. Call him.
t: There's Dolabella, who was sent from Caesar. Call him.

og: What work is here, Charmian? Is this well done?
t: What happened here, Charmian? Was this a good thing to do?

og: It is well done and fitting for a princessDescended of so many royal kings.Ah, soldier!
t: It was a good thing to do, and it was fitting for a princess who was descended from so many royal kings. Ah, soldier!

og: How goes it here?
t: What's going on here?

og: All dead.
t: They are all dead.

og: Caesar, thy thoughts  Touch their effects in this.
t: Caesar, this is the effect of all your planinng.

og: Thyself art coming  To see performed the dreaded act which thou  So sought’st to hinder.
t: You'll arrive and see she's done the dreaded act you tried so hard to prevent.

og: A way there, a way for Caesar!
t: Make way there, make way for Caesar!

og: O sir, you are too sure an augurer.That you did fear is done.
t: Oh sir, your prediction came true. What you feared has happened.

og: Bravest at the last,  She leveled at our purposes and, being royal,  Took her own way.
t: She was bravest at the very end; she guessed what I planned to do and, being noble, took matters into her own hands.

og: The manner of their deaths?  I do not see them bleed.
t: How did they die? I don't see any blood.

og: Who was last with them?
t: Who was the last person with them?

og: A simple countryman that brought her figs.This was his basket.
t: A simple peasant who brought her figs. This was his basket.

og: Poisoned, then.
t: They must have been poisoned, then.

og: Oh, Caesar,  This Charmian lived but now. She stood and spake.
t: Oh, Caesar, this woman Charmian was alive until a moment ago. She stood and spoke.

og: I found her trimming up the diadem  On her dead mistress. Tremblingly she stood  And on the sudden dropped.
t: I found her adjusting the crown of her dead mistress. She stood trembling and then suddenly collapsed.

og: Oh, noble weakness!  If they had swallowed poison, ’twould appear  By external swelling,
t: Oh, these women were weak but noble, too! If they had taken poison, we would be able to tell by the swelling of their bodies,

og: but she looks like sleep,  As she would catch another Antony  In her strong toil of grace.
t: but Cleopatra just looks as if she were sleeping—as if she were dreaming of catching another man like Antony with her strong, bewitching charms.

og: Here on her breastThere is a vent of blood, and something blown.The like is on her arm.
t: There's a trail of blood here on her breast, and some discharge. The same thing appears on her arm.

og: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leavesHave slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leavesUpon the caves of Nile.
t: This is the trail of a serpent. These fig leaves have a slimy discharge on them too, just as a serpent leaves in the caves of the Nile.

og: Most probable  That so she died, for her physician tells me  She hath pursued conclusions infinite  Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed  And bear her women from the monument.
t: It's most likely that she died from the serpents' bite, for her doctor tells me that she performed countless experiments to find easy ways to die. Pick up her bed and carry her women out of the tomb.

og: She shall be buried by her Antony.  No grave upon the earth shall clip in it  A pair so famous. High events as these  Strike those that make them, and their story is  No less in pity than his glory which  Brought them to be lamented.
t: She will be buried beside her Antony. No grave on earth will contain such a famous couple. Great events like these strike the hearts of those who brought them about. The pity of their story is as great as the glory of that person who brought them to this lamentable end.

og: Our army shall  In solemn show attend this funeral,  And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see  High order in this great solemnity.
t: Our army will solemnly watch this funeral, and then they will go to Rome. Come, Dolabella, and observe the great decorum that this solemn occasion requires.

og: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.
t: In saying goodbye to my son, it's like I'm losing another husband.

og: And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's deathanew: but I must attend his majesty's command, towhom I am now in ward, evermore in subjection.
t: And for me, in leaving, mother, I mourn my father's death all over again, but I must serve at the king's command, since I am now his subject and eternally in servitude to him.

og: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you,  sir, a father:
t: The king will be like a husband to you, madam, and like a father to you, sir.

og: he that so generally is at all times  good must of necessity hold his virtue to you;
t: If he's so good to all his subjects, you can be sure he'll be good to you.

og: whose  worthiness would stir it up where it wanted rather  than lack it
t: Your family has been so important to him that you'd bring out the generosity in him even if he was miserable

og: where there is such abundance.
t: —since he is generous, there's no way he won't share that kindness with you.

og: What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?
t: How likely is it that his majesty will recover?

og: He hath abandoned his physicians, madam;
t: He's given up on his doctors, madam.

og: under whose  practises he hath persecuted time with hope,
t: He's wasted a lot of time and hope following their orders,

og: and  finds no other advantage in the process but only the  losing of hope by time.
t: and all he's getting out of it is gradually losing hope over time.

og: This young gentlewoman had a father,
t: This young woman had a father

og: —O, that  'had'! how sad a passage 'tis!
t: —oh, that word "had!" What a sad word it is!

og: —whose skill was  almost as great as his honesty;
t: —and his skill was only outshined by his goodness.

og: had it stretched so  far, would have made nature immortal, and death  should have play for lack of work.
t: If he'd had the chance, he could have made men immortal. Death would have been out of business.

og: Would, for the  king's sake, he were living!
t: If only he were living now, for the king's sake!

og: I think it would be  the death of the king's disease.
t: I think he would cure the king's illness.

og: How called you the man you speak of, madam?
t: What was the name of this man you speak of, madam?

og: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it washis great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.
t: He was famous in his line of work, sir, and he absolutely deserved that fame: Gerard de Narbon.

og: He was excellent indeed, madam:
t: He was excellent indeed, madam.

og: the king very  lately spoke of him admiringly and mourningly:
t: The king only recently was talking admiringly and sadly about him.

og: he  was skilful enough to have lived still, if knowledge  could be set up against mortality.
t: Narbon had enough skill to keep himself alive, if only you could fight mortality with brilliance.

og: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?
t: What exactly is the king's sickness, my good lord?

og: A fistula, my lord.
t: A fistula, my lord.

og: I heard not of it before.
t: I haven't heard of that before.

og: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewomanthe daughter of Gerard de Narbon?
t: Don't let the word get out. So this woman was the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

og: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my  overlooking.
t: His only child, my lord, and left to my care.

og: I have those hopes of her good that  her education promises;
t: I have high hopes that she'll live up to the education she's received.

og: her dispositions she  inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer;
t: She got her lovely personality from her father—that makes good-looking women even better-looking.

og: for where  an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there  commendations go with pity;
t: If a sinful mind accompanies a woman with many skills, those skills are praiseworthy but also regrettable

og: they are virtues and  traitors too;
t: —they're virtues but also traitors.

og: in her they are the better for their  simpleness;
t: In Helena, though, these virtues are stronger because she is so pure.

og: she derives her honesty and achieves her goodness.
t: She gets her honesty from her father and earns her goodness herself.

og: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.
t: I can see the proof of your praises in her tears, madam.

og: 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise  in.
t: It's the best salt water a maiden can wash her praises in.

og: The remembrance of her father never approaches  her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all  livelihood from her cheek.
t: As soon as she remembers her father, the cruelty of her sorrow takes all the joy out of her cheeks.

og: No more of this, Helena;
t: No more of this, Helena.

og: go to, no more;
t: Come on, no more.

og: lest it be rather thought you affect  a sorrow than have it.
t: You don't want people to think that you're performing sorrow rather than genuinely feeling it.

og: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.
t: I do perform my sorrow, but I genuinely feel it too.

og: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,excessive grief the enemy to the living.
t: Moderate mourning is what we owe to the dead, but excessive grief is an enemy to the living.

og: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excessmakes it soon mortal.
t: If the living is an enemy to grief, too much grief will kill the mourners.

og: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.
t: Madam, I desire your blessing.

og: How understand we that?
t: What should we make of that?

og: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father  In manners, as in shape!
t: Be blessed, Bertram, and follow your father in behavior as well as in looks!

og: thy blood and virtue  Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness  Share with thy birthright!
t: Your blood and your manners are fighting for power inside of you, so let your goodness take the side of your noble blood!

og: Love all, trust a few,  Do wrong to none:
t: Be good to all, trust a few, don't wrong anyone.

og: be able for thine enemy  Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend  Under thy own life's key:
t: Win over your enemies by holding power, not by abusing it, and value your friends as much as you value your own life.

og: be cheque'd for silence,  But never tax'd for speech.
t: Be scolded for being silent but don't talk so much that you make yourself a nuisance.

og: What heaven more will,  That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,  Fall on thy head!
t: Otherwise, I hope you'll be blessed with whatever heaven wants to supply you with, to make you better and to answer my prayers!

og: Farewell, my lord;
t: Farewell, my lord.

og: He cannot want the bestThat shall attend his love.
t: He'll have only the best advice from me.

og: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.
t: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

og: The best wishes that can be forged inyour thoughts be servants to you! Be comfortableto my mother, your mistress, and make much of her.
t: I wish the best for you that you can imagine! Take care of my mother, your mistress, and keep her well.

og: Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold the credit ofyour father.
t: Farewell, pretty lady: you must maintain the reputation of your father.

og: O, were that all!
t: Oh, if only that were all!

og: I think not on my father;
t: I don't think of my father.

og: And these great tears grace his remembrance more  Than those I shed for him.
t: And these over-the-top tears honor his memory more than the tears I genuinely shed for him.

og: What was he like?  I have forgot him:
t: What was he like? I have forgot him.

og: my imagination  Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
t: My imagination thinks not of any face but Bertram's. I am ruined.

og: I am undone: there is no living, none,  If Bertram be away.
t: There's no point in being alive, none, if Bertram is away.

og: 'Twere all one  That I should love a bright particular star  And think to wed it, he is so above me:
t: What terrible luck that I should love a bright star and want to marry it. He is so high above me.

og: In his bright radiance and collateral light  Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
t: I must be comforted by the bright radiance he gives off and the light emanating from him, for I can't be close to him.

og: The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
t: Loving someone so far above my station will be fatal to my love.

og: The hind that would be mated by the lion  Must die for love.
t: The deer that wants to mate with the lion must die in the process.

og: 'Twas pretty, though plague,  To see him every hour; to sit and draw  His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,  In our heart's table;
t: It was lovely, though torturous, to see him every hour, to sit and draw his arched eyebrows, his hawklike eye, his curls, on the drawing-table of my heart.

og: heart too capable  Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:
t: My heart knows too well every line and feature of his sweet face.

og: But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy  Must sanctify his reliques.
t: But now he's gone, and my idol-worshipping love must cling to the things he's left behind.

og: Who comes here?
t: Who comes here?

og: One that goes with him:
t: Here's one that accompanies him.

og: I love him for his sake;
t: I love this man for Bertram's sake,

og: And yet I know him a notorious liar,  Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;
t: but, at the same time, I know that he's a notorious liar, pretty much a fool, completely a coward.

og: Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him,  That they take place, when virtue's steely bones  Look bleak i' the cold wind:
t: These evils are so engrained in him that they stay firm even when virtue's own firmness wavers in the cold wind.

og: withal, full oft we see  Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.
t: Moreover, extreme foolishness often becomes more powerful than sturdy wisdom.

og: Save you, fair queen!
t: God be with you, beautiful queen!

og: And you, monarch!
t: And you, monarch!

og: No.
t: No.

og: And no.
t: And no.

og: Are you meditating on virginity?
