t: Are you thinking about virginity?

og: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let meask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; howmay we barricado it against him?
t: Yes. You have some hint of soldier about you: let me ask you a question. Man is the enemy of virginity: how can we barricade it up against him?

og: Keep him out.
t: Keep him out.

og: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant,in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us somewarlike resistance.
t: But he attacks, and our virginity, though brave, is weak in defense. Share with us some warrior tips for resistance.

og: There is none: man, sitting down before you, willundermine you and blow you up.
t: There's no resistance. Man, sitting down in front of you, will conquer you and blow you up.

og: Bless our poor virginity from underminers andblowers up! Is there no military policy, howvirgins might blow up men?
t: Bless our poor virginity and keep it safe from conquerers and blower-uppers! Is there no military policy on how virgins could blow up men?

og: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be  blown up:
t: When virginity gets blown down, men will quickly be blown up.

og: marry, in blowing him down again, with  the breach yourselves made, you lose your city.
t: Indeed, in blowing him down again, your fortified city's already been lost by the fracture that you yourselves have made.

og: It  is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to  preserve virginity.
t: It's not right under nature's laws to preserve your virginity.

og: Loss of virginity is rational  increase and there was never virgin got till  virginity was first lost.
t: Loss of virginity leads to a population increase and no virgins have ever been born until their mothers lost their virginity first.

og: That you were made of is  metal to make virgins.
t: The stuff you were made of is material used to make more virgins.

og: Virginity by being once lost  may be ten times found;
t: Once you've lost your virginity, you can make ten more virgins.

og: by being ever kept, it is  ever lost:
t: By keeping your virginity forever, no more virgins will be made.

og: 'tis too cold a companion; away with 't!
t: It's too cold a companion—get rid of it!

og: I will stand for 't a little, though therefore I die a virgin.
t: I will stick with it a little bit longer even if it means I die a virgin.

og: There's little can be said in 't;
t: There's no argument in favor of it.

og: 'tis against the  rule of nature.
t: It's against the laws of nature.

og: To speak on the part of virginity,  is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible  disobedience.
t: To speak out in favor of virginity is to accuse your mothers of behaving badly which is unacceptable disobedience.

og: He that hangs himself is a virgin:  virginity murders itself
t: A virgin is like a man who hangs himself, because virginity should kill itself

og: and should be buried in  highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate  offendress against nature.
t: and should therefore, like a suicide victim, be buried far outside  holy ground as something that has committed a crime against nature.

og: Virginity breeds mites,  much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very  paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach.
t: Virginity breeds mites like a cheese does, and, just like a cheese, grows moldy, rots, and dies, like it's eating itself.

og: Besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of  self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the  canon.
t: Besides, virginity is silly, proud, lazy, made of self-love, which is the most forbidden sin in the Bible.

og: Keep it not; you cannot choose but lose  by't: out with 't!
t: Don't keep your virginity; no matter what you'll lose out this way. Get rid of it!

og: within ten year it will make  itself ten, which is a goodly increase;
t: Within ten years, it will bring you ten babies, which is a good increase,

og: and the  principal itself not much the worse: away with 't!
t: and the original body itself won't be much the worse for wear. Away with it!

og: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?
t: How might somebody lose it as she pleases, sir?

og: Let me see:
t: Let me see.

og: marry, ill, to like him that ne'er it  likes.
t: Well, unfortunately, you'll have to like a man you've never liked before.

og: 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with  lying; the longer kept, the less worth:
t: It's merchandise that will lose its shine if it doesn't get used. The longer you keep it, the less it's worth.

og: off with 't  while 'tis vendible;
t: Get rid of it while you can still sell it.

og: answer the time of request.
t: You'd better act while the clock's still ticking.

og: Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out  of fashion:
t: Virginity, like an old nobleman, wears a cap that's out of fashion:

og: richly suited, but unsuitable: just  like the brooch and the tooth-pick, which wear not  now.
t: it looks nice, but it doesn't fit, just like the brooch or the tooth-pick, which are completely out of fashion these days.

og: Your date is better in your pie and your  porridge than in your cheek;
t: You'd do better to cook your date in your pie or porridge than in your cheek,

og: and your virginity,  your old virginity, is like one of our French  withered pears,
t: and your virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our withered French pears.

og: it looks ill, it eats drily; marry,  'tis a withered pear;
t: It looks ill, it tastes dry. Indeed, it is a withered pear.

og: it was formerly better;  marry, yet 'tis a withered pear: will you anything withit?
t: It used to be better, but it's still a withered pear: will you do anything with it?

og: Not my virginity yet—
t: I'm not giving it up just yet.

og: There shall your master have a thousand loves,
t: At court, your master will have a thousand relationships.

og: A mother and a mistress and a friend,  A phoenix, captain and an enemy,  A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,  A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;
t: A mother and a mistress and a friend, a phoenix, a captain, and an enemy, a guide, a goddess, and a sovereign, a counsellor, a traitress, and a dear loved one.

og: His humble ambition, proud humility,  His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,  His faith, his sweet disaster
t: His humble ambition, his proud humility, his jarring harmony, and his dissonant sweetness, his faith, his sweet misfortune,

og: ; with a world  Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms,  That blinking Cupid gossips.
t: and lots of pretty, silly nicknames that blind Cupid might have given at a christening.

og: Now shall he—  I know not what he shall. God send him well!
t: Now shall he—I know not what he shall. God protect him!

og: The court's a learning place, and he is one—
t: The court's a good place to get an education, and he's someone—

og: What one, i' faith?
t: Someone what, pray tell?

og: That I wish well. 'Tis pity—
t: Someone who I wish all the best. It's a pity—

og: What's pity?
t: What's a pity?

og: That wishing well had not a body in't,  Which might be felt;
t: That wishing someone well is just a thought and not something physical that could be felt.

og: that we, the poorer born,  Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,  Might with effects of them follow our friends,
t: If only we, the poorer folk, whose more unlucky fates leave us just with our wishes, could go along with our friends,

og: And show what we alone must think, which never  Return us thanks.
t: and show the love that we must keep to ourselves and that never earns us any gratitude.

og: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.
t: Monsieur Parolles, my lord is calling for you.

og: Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember thee, Iwill think of thee at court.
t: Little Helena, farewell. If I can remember you, I'll think of you at court.

og: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.
t: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a generous star.

og: Under Mars, I.
t: I was born under Mars, the god of war.

og: I especially think, under Mars.
t: I especially think you were born under Mars.

og: Why under Mars?
t: Why under Mars?

og: The wars have so kept you under that you must needsbe born under Mars.
t: You've been so subservient to the wars that you must have been born under Mars.

og: When he was predominant.
t: When the star was ascending.

og: When he was retrograde, I think, rather.
t: When he was descending, I think, actually.

og: Why think you so?
t: Why do you think so?

og: You go so much backward when you fight.
t: You tend to flee backwards when you fight.

og: That's for advantage.
t: That's to gain advantage.

og: So is running away, when fear proposes the safety;but the composition that your valour and fear makesin you is a virtue of a good wing, and I like the wear well.
t: So is running away, when fear leads you to flee to safety. But the mixture of bravery and fear has helped you develop an impressively swift flight and it suits you well.

og: I am so full of businesses, I cannot answer thee  acutely.
t: I am so busy, I cannot answer you fully.

og: I will return perfect courtier;
t: I will come back the perfect nobleman,

og: in the  which, my instruction shall serve to naturalize  thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's  counsel and understand what advice shall thrust upon  thee;
t: and, when I've done so, I will teach you what I've learned so that you can keep up with a nobleman's advice and understand the guidance given to you.

og: else thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and  thine ignorance makes thee away:  farewell.
t: Otherwise, you'll die in your ungratefulness and your ignorance will kill you: farewell.

og: When  thou hast leisure, say thy prayers;
t: When you have free time, say your prayers.

og: when thou hast  none, remember thy friends;
t: When you don't have time, just remember your friends.

og: get thee a good husband,  and use him as he uses thee; so, farewell.
t: Get a good husband for yourself and use him as he uses you. So, farewell.

og: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie,  Which we ascribe to heaven:
t: Often, we find the solution in ourselves, even though we say they came from heaven.

og: the fated sky  Gives us free scope,
t: For all we say that heavens control our fates, we have free will

og: only doth backward pull  Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
t: —that talk of fate only slows us down when we ourselves are lazy in getting what we want.

og: What power is it which mounts my love so high,  That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
t: What power is it that makes me love someone so high up, that makes me see his wondrousness but doesn't give me the ability to gain his love?

og: The mightiest space in fortune nature brings  To join like likes and kiss like native things.
t: Even people who are on opposite ends of the social spectrum can be brought together by nature and their mutual attraction, and they can kiss like they were born equals.

og: Impossible be strange attempts to those  That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose  What hath been cannot be:
t: Of course, unusually difficult attempts will seem impossible to people who think rationally and rigidly about their limitations and suppose that they can't do things that others have managed to do before them.

og: who ever strove  To show her merit, that did miss her love?
t: Who's ever failed to win her love when she successfully showed her merit?

og: The king's disease—my project may deceive me,  But my intents are fix'd and will not leave me.
t: The king's disease—I might be misguided in this plan, but my intentions are firm and I'll stick to them.

og: The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears;Have fought with equal fortune and continueA braving war.
t: The Florentines and the Sienese are fighting each other. They've each had equal success and the war goes on.

og: So 'tis reported, sir.
t: That's what's been reported, sir.

og: Nay, 'tis most credible;
t: No, it's definitely true.

og: we here received it  A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria,  With caution that the Florentine will move us  For speedy aid;
t: We received confirmation from it from our friend the King of Austria, with a warning that the Duke of Florence will be asking us for immediate assistance.

og: wherein our dearest friend  Prejudicates the business and would seem  To have us make denial.
t: Our dearest friend, the King of Austria, doesn't support that request and urges us to deny it.

og: His love and wisdom,Approved so to your majesty, may pleadFor amplest credence.
t: If your majesty thinks so highly of his love and wisdom, that should serve as sufficient guidance.

og: He hath arm'd our answer,  And Florence is denied before he comes:
t: He's convinced me of my answer. Before he even arrives, I've decided the Duke of Florence will be denied.

og: Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see  The Tuscan service, freely have they leave  To stand on either part.
t: Yet, if any of our gentlemen are planning to go fight in this war in Tuscany, they're welcome to fight for either side.

og: It well may serveA nursery to our gentry, who are sickFor breathing and exploit.
t: That should be good news for our soldiers, who are dying to actually get to fight.

og: What's he comes here?
t: Who's he who's just come here?

og: It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord,Young Bertram.
t: It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord, young Bertram.

og: Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face;
t: Young man, you have your father's face.

og: Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,  Hath well composed thee.
t: Nature being generous, and meticulous rather than hasty, has made you handsome.

og: Thy father's moral parts  Mayst thou inherit too!
t: I hope you have your father's morality too!

og: Welcome to Paris.
t: Welcome to Paris.

og: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.
t: I give my thanks and pledge my service to your majesty.

og: I would I had that corporal soundness now,  As when thy father and myself in friendship  First tried our soldiership!
t: I wish I was as physically healthy now as when my friend—your father—and I first became soldiers!

og: He did look far  Into the service of the time and was  Discipled of the bravest:
t: He wanted to rise up in the military service then and had a reputation for being one of the bravest.

og: he lasted long;
t: He stuck around a long time.

og: But on us both did haggish age steal on  And wore us out of act.
t: But horrid age stole up on both of us and wore us out.

og: It much repairs me  To talk of your good father.
t: It makes me feel much better to talk of your good father.

og: In his youth  He had the wit which I can well observe  To-day in our young lords;
t: In his youth, he had the same wit which I now see today in our young lords.

og: but they may jest  Till their own scorn return to them unnoted  Ere they can hide their levity in honour;
t: But these young folks today can joke until people start ignoring them before they'd ever swap their quick-wittedness for honorable deeds.

og: So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness  Were in his pride or sharpness;
t: Like a real nobleman, your father had neither contempt nor bitterness in his pride, nor sharpness.

og: if they were,  His equal had awaked them, and his honour,  Clock to itself, knew the true minute when  Exception bid him speak,
t: If he did ever speak sharply, it was to an equal, and his honor, which he always maintained, knew exactly when it was appropriate for him to speak out,

og: and at this time  His tongue obey'd his hand:
t: only if he could back up his words with action.

og: who were below him  He used as creatures of another place  And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks,
t: He'd treat men who were below him like they were better than they were and bowed down, despite his greatness, to those low soldiers.

og: Making them proud of his humility,  In their poor praise he humbled.
t: That would put them in awe of his humility and he'd humble himself to praise them, even low as they were.

og: Such a man  Might be a copy to these younger times;
t: Such a man should be a role model to these young folks.

og: Which, follow'd well, would demonstrate them now  But goers backward.
t: If they followed his example, but young people now are going backwards in their manners.

og: His good remembrance, sir,  Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb;
t: Your thoughts honor his memory, sir, more richly than the words on his tomb do.

og: So in approof lives not his epitaph  As in your royal speech.
t: His legacy lives on not in his epitaph but in your royal speech.

og: Would I were with him!
t: If only I were with him!

og: He would always say—  Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words  He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them,  To grow there and to bear,
t: He would always say—I think I hear him now; his pleasing words he wouldn't tell many people but planted them carefully to grow and bear fruit

og: —'Let me not live,'—  This his good melancholy oft began,
t: —"Let me not live,"—that's how his good melancholy speeches would often begin,

og: On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,  When it was out,
t: when a fun event of leisure had come to an end,

og: —'Let me not live,' quoth he,  'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff  Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses  All but new things disdain;
t: —"Let me not live," he'd say, "after my spirit has lost its fire, to stick around stifling younger folks, whose quick sense hate anything that is not new.

og: whose judgments are  Mere fathers of their garments;
t: All their thinking only leads to getting new clothes.

og: whose constancies  Expire before their fashions.'
t: Their loyalties fade out before their new fashions do."

og: This he wish'd;  I after him do after him wish too,
t: This is what he wished, and, now, I wish the same thing too.

og: Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,  I quickly were dissolved from my hive,  To give some labourers room.
t: Since I can no longer bring the wax or honey home, I'd quickly be tossed out of my hive, so the laboring bees have room to take over.

og: You are loved, sir:They that least lend it you shall lack you first.
t: You are loved, sir. Those that least show their love will miss you most.

og: I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, count,Since the physician at your father's died?He was much famed.
t: I hold an important place, I know it. How long is it, count, since the physician at your father's died? He was very famous.

og: Some six months since, my lord.
t: Six months ago, my lord.

og: If he were living, I would try him yet.
t: If he were living, I'd still try him.

og: Lend me an arm;
t: Give me a hand.

og: the rest have worn me out  With several applications;
t: The rest of the doctors have worn me out with their many cures.

og: nature and sickness  Debate it at their leisure.
t: Nature and sickness are fighting over me.

og: Welcome, count;  My son's no dearer.
t: Welcome, count. You are as dear to me as my own son.

og: Thank your majesty.
t: I thank your majesty.

og: I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?
t: I will hear you now. What do you say of this gentlewoman?

og: Madam, the care I have had to even your content, I  wish might be found in the calendar of my past  endeavours;
t: Madam, I hope you'll recognize in my past behavior how much care I've taken to make you happy.

og: for then we wound our modesty and make  foul the clearness of our deservings, when of  ourselves we publish them.
t: It would be harmful to my modesty and would muddy my clear honor if I were to announce my past deeds myself.

og: What does this knave here?
t: What is this rogue doing here?

og: Get you gone, sirrah:
t: Get out of here, slave.

og: the complaints I have heard of you I do not all  believe:
t: I don't believe all the complaints I've heard of you.

og: 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I know  you lack not folly to commit them,
t: It's my own fault that I don't believe them because I know you're foolish enough to do these things,

og: and have ability  enough to make such knaveries yours.
t: and you have the ability to misbehave in these ways.

og: 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.
t: It's not unknown to you, madam, that I am a poor fellow.

og: Well, sir.
t: Well, sir.

og: No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though  many of the rich are damned:
t: No, madam, it's not so well that I am poor, although many rich people are damned.

og: but, if I may have  your ladyship's good will to go to the world, Isbel  the woman and I will do as we may.
t: But, if I have your ladyship's good permission to go out into the world, Isbel the servant girl and I will do what we can.

og: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?
t: Will you need to be a beggar?

og: I do beg your good will in this case.
t: I do beg for your good will in this case?

og: In what case?
t: In what case?

og: In Isbel's case and mine own.
t: In the case of Isbel and myself.

og: Service is no  heritage:
t: Being servants doesn't build up much of an inheritance,

og: and I think I shall never have the  blessing of God till I have issue o' my body; for  they say barnes are blessings.
t: and I don't think I'll ever have God's blessing until I've had children, for they say kids are blessings.

og: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.
t: Tell me why you want to marry.

og: My poor body, madam, requires it: I am driven onby the flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.
t: My poor body, madam, requires it. I am driven on by the desires of the flesh and I must respond to the devil's commands.

og: Is this all your worship's reason?
t: Is this your only reason?

og: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons such as theyare.
t: Actually, madam, I have other nicer reasons as it so happens.

og: May the world know them?
t: May the world know what they are?

og: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you andall flesh and blood are; and, indeed, I do marrythat I may repent.
t: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, just as you and anyone of flesh and blood have been. Indeed, I want to get married so that I can repent.

og: Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.
t: You'll repent your marriage before you repent your wickedness.

og: I am out o' friends, madam; and I hope to havefriends for my wife's sake.
t: I have no friends, madam, and I hope to have friends for my wife's sake.

og: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.
t: Such friends are your enemies, fool.

og: You're shallow, madam, in great friends;
t: You're not too knowledgable, madam, about great friends.

og: for the  knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary of.
t: The rogues come to do things for me that I'm tired of doing for myself.

og: He that ears my land spares my team and gives me  leave to in the crop;
t: He that takes care of my land and spares my animals from having to do the work leaves me time to focus on the harvest.

og: if I be his cuckold, he's my  drudge:
t: If he ends up sleeping with my wife, he's my slave:

og: he that comforts my wife is the cherisher  of my flesh and blood;
t: he that comforts my wife cherishes my flesh and blood;

og: he that cherishes my flesh  and blood loves my flesh and blood;
t: he that cherishes my flesh and blood loves my flesh and blood;

og: he that loves my  flesh and blood is my friend:
t: he that loves my flesh and blood is my friend.

og: ergo, he that kisses  my wife is my friend.
t: Therefore, he that kisses my wife is my friend.

og: If men could be contented to  be what they are, there were no fear in marriage;
t: If men could be happy to be what they are, they wouldn't be afraid to get married.

og: for young Charbon the Puritan and old Poysam the  Papist, howsome'er their hearts are severed in  religion, their heads are both one;
t: Young Charbon the Puritan and old Poysam the Papist, even though they have different religions, have the same head.

og: they may jowl  horns together, like any deer i' the herd.
t: They can knock their horns together like any deers in the herd.

og: Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and calumnious knave?
t: Will you always be a foul-mouthed and lying knave?

og: A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next  way:
t: I'll be a prophet, madam, and I speak the truth this way:

og: Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.
t: Leave, sir. I'll talk with you more later.

og: May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come toyou: of her I am to speak.
t: If it's alright with you, madam, he should tell Helena to come to you. Its about her I need to discuss.

og: Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her;Helen, I mean.
t: Sir, tell my gentlewoman I want to speak with her. Helena, I mean.

og: Was this fair face the cause, quoth she,  Why the Grecians sacked Troy?
t: Was this fair face the cause, she asked, Of why the Greeks destroyed Troy?

og: Fond done, done fond,  Was this King Priam's joy?
t: Foolishly done, lovingly done, Was this the joy of King Priam?

og: With that she sighed as she stood,  With that she sighed as she stood,
t: With that she sighed while she stood, With that she sighed while she stood,

og: And gave this sentence then;
t: And then gave this sentence:

og: Among nine bad if one be good,  Among nine bad if one be good,
t: If there is one good among nine bad, If there is one good among nine bad,

og: There's yet one good in ten.
t: There's still one good in ten.

og: What, one good in ten? you corrupt the song, sirrah.
t: What, one good in ten? You ruined the song, sir.

og: One good woman in ten, madam; which is a purifying  o' the song:
t: One good woman in ten, madam, which purifies the song.

og: would God would serve the world so all  the year!
t: If only God would serve the world as I've served the song all year!

og: we'ld find no fault with the tithe-woman,  if I were the parson.
t: We'd find nothing bad about the one woman in ten if I were the parson.

og: One in ten, quoth a'!
t: One in ten, I sing!

og: An we  might have a good woman born but one every blazing  star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lottery  well  :
t: If we might have a good woman born once every comet or during an earthquake, it would help our chances:

og: a man may draw his heart out, ere a' pluck  one.
t: a man can tear his heart out before he finds a good woman.

og: You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you.
t: Get out of here, rogue, and do as I command you.

og: That man should be at woman's command, and yet no  hurt done!
t: Can you imagine, woman should command man and no harm is done by it!

og: Though honesty be no puritan, yet it  will do no hurt;
t: Although my honest character doesn't follow strict morals, it won't do any harm.

og: it will wear the surplice of  humility over the black gown of a big heart.
t: I will, like a secret Puritan, wear my Anglican robes over my black gown that shows my true colors.

og: I am  going, forsooth: the business is for Helen to come hither.
t: I am going now: my task is to summon Helena here.

og: Well, now.
t: Well, now.

og: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.
t: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman completely.

og: Faith, I do:
t: Well, yes, I do.

og: her father bequeathed her to me; and  she herself, without other advantage,  may lawfully  make title to as much love as she finds:
t: Her father left her in my care, and she herself, regardless of any other qualities, deserves as much love as she can find, wherever she can find it.

og: there is  more owing her than is paid; and more shall be paid  her than she'll demand.
t: She is owed more than she's been paid, and she'll be paid more than she'd ever demand.

og: Madam, I was very late more near her than I think  she wished me:
t: Madam, I recently was nearer to her than I think she wanted me to be.

og: alone she was, and did communicate  to herself her own words to her own ears;
t: She was alone, and spoke her words for her own ears only.

og: she  thought, I dare vow for her, they touched not any  stranger sense.
t: She thought, I'd assume on her behalf, that no one else could hear.

og: Her matter was, she loved your son:
t: Her subject was that she loved your son.

og: Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put  such difference betwixt their two estates;
t: Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put such a difference between their stations.

og: Love no  god, that would not extend his might, only where  qualities were level;
t: Love was no god that would not bless the union of two people of different social levels.

og: Dian no queen of virgins, that  would suffer her poor knight surprised, without  rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward.
t: Diana is no queen of virgins that would allow her poor servant to be so captured by love without any way to be rescued from the passion or to earn her love later.

og: This she delivered in the most bitter touch of  sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim in:
t: She delivered this in the most bitter tone of sorrow that I've ever heard a virgin give.

og: which I  held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal;
t: I thought it was my duty to share this information with you quickly.

og: sithence, in the loss that may happen, it concerns  you something to know it.
t: Since, in the grief that might follow, it's important for you to know about it.

og: You have discharged this honestly;
t: You've done your duty honestly.

og: keep it to  yourself:
t: Keep it to yourself.

og: many likelihoods informed me of this  before, which hung so tottering in the balance that  I could neither believe nor misdoubt.
t: Many moments made me suspect this before, but it was so uncertain that I could neither believe it nor doubt it.

og: Pray you,  leave me:
t: Please, leave me.

og: stall this in your bosom; and I thank you  for your honest care:
t: Keep this in your heart and I thank you for your honest service.

og: I will speak with you further anon.
t: I will speak with you further later.

og: Even so it was with me when I was young:
t: It was just like this for me when I was young.

og: If ever we are nature's, these are ours;
t: If we belong to nature, these things happen:

og: this thorn  Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
t: this thorn of love accompanies our rose of youth.

og: Our blood to us, this to our blood is born;
t: Our blood gives into these passions.

og: It is the show and seal of nature's truth,  Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth:
t: When love's strong passion emerges in youth, that's how we know that nature's doing its job.

og: By our remembrances of days foregone,  Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.
t: In our memories of days long gone, these were our faults, but then we didn't think of them as faults.

og: Her eye is sick on't: I observe her now.
t: Her face looks ill with love: I watch her now.

og: What is your pleasure, madam?
t: Why did you summon me, madam?

og: You know, Helen,I am a mother to you.
t: You know, Helena, I am a mother to you.

og: Mine honourable mistress.
t: My honorable mistress.

og: Nay, a mother:
t: No, a mother.

og: Why not a mother?
t: Why not a mother?

og: When I said 'a mother,'  Methought you saw a serpent:
t: When I said "a mother," I thought you saw a snake.

og: what's in 'mother,'  That you start at it?
t: What's in "mother" that so startles you?

og: I say, I am your mother;  And put you in the catalogue of those  That were enwombed mine:
t: I say, I am your mother, and I put you in the list of my children that came out of my womb.

og: 'tis often seen  Adoption strives with nature
t: It's often the case that adopted children feel as close to us as natural children

og: and choice breeds  A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
t: and the family that we choose feel as familiar to us even though they came from another family tree.

og: You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan,  Yet I express to you a mother's care:
t: You never put me through labor pains, but I still tell you I have a mother's love for you.

og: God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood  To say I am thy mother?
t: By god, lady! Does it boil your blood to hear me say I am your mother?

og: What's the matter,  That this distemper'd messenger of wet,  The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye?
t: What's the matter, that Iris, the rainbow-goddess messenger of the rain clouds, brings tears to your eye?

og: Why? that you are my daughter?
t: Why? Because you are my daughter?

og: That I am not.
t: Because I am not your daughter.

og: I say, I am your mother.
t: I say, I am your mother.

og: Pardon, madam;
t: I'm sorry, madam.

og: The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother:
t: The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother.

og: I am from humble, he from honour'd name;
t: I come from humble origins, he from an honorable family.

og: No note upon my parents, his all noble:
t: My parents are nobodies, his are nobles.

og: My master, my dear lord he is;
t: He's my master, my dear lord.

og: and I  His servant live, and will his vassal die:
t: And I live as his servant and will die as his subject.

og: He must not be my brother.
t: He must not be my brother.

og: Nor I your mother?
t: And I must not be your mother?

og: You are my mother, madam; would you were,—
t: You are my mother, madam. I wish you were

og: So that my lord your son were not my brother,—  Indeed my mother!
t: —if only my lord your son were not then my brother—indeed, my mother!

og: or were you both our mothers,  I care no more for than I do for heaven,  So I were not his sister.
t: Even if you were both our mothers, I'd rather die, as long as I'm not his sister.

og: Can't no other,  But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?
t: Is there no way for me to be your daughter without him being my brother?

og: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law:
t: Yes, Helena, you might be my daughter-in-law.

og: God shield you mean it not!
t: God save you from meaning it!

og: daughter and mother  So strive upon your pulse.
t: "Daughter" and "mother" make your pulse quicken.

og: What, pale again?
t: What, why have you turned pale again?

og: My fear hath catch'd your fondness: now I see  The mystery of your loneliness, and find  Your salt tears' head:
t: My fear has found out your fondness: now I have solved the mystery of your loneliness, and I see where your tears come from.

og: now to all sense 'tis gross  You love my son;
t: Now it's completely clear to me that you love my son.

og: invention is ashamed,  Against the proclamation of thy passion,
t: It would be shameful to deny it, given how clearly your looks proclaim your passions.

og: To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true;
t: Therefore, tell me the truth, and tell me it's true.

og: But tell me then, 'tis so; for, look thy cheeks  Confess it, th' one to th' other;
t: Your cheeks are confessing it in their blushes, one to the other,

og: and thine eyes  See it so grossly shown in thy behaviors  That in their kind they speak it:
t: and your eyes are so obviously demonstrating it in their behavior that they're practically speaking it.

og: only sin  And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue,  That truth should be suspected.
t: Only sinful and damned stubbornness keeps you from speaking along with your frustration that the truth should be suspected.

og: Speak, is't so?
t: Speak, is it true?

og: If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
t: If it is, you've made a good tangle of things.

og: If it be not, forswear't:
t: If not, swear it.

og: howe'er, I charge thee,  As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,  Tell me truly.
t: But, I command you, as heaven will help me fight for you, tell me the truth.

og: Good madam, pardon me!
t: Good madam, forgive me!

og: Do you love my son?
t: Do you love my son?

og: Your pardon, noble mistress!
t: I beg your pardon, noble mistress!

og: Love you my son?
t: Do you love my son?

og: Do not you love him, madam?
t: Don't you love him, madam?

og: Go not about;
t: Don't mess around with me.

og: my love hath in't a bond,  Whereof the world takes note:
t: My love for you is strong enough that everyone recognizes it.

og: come, come, disclose  The state of your affection; for your passions  Have to the full appeach'd.
t: Come, come, tell me what your affections are, for your passions have already given you away.

og: Then, I confess,  Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,  That before you, and next unto high heaven,  I love your son.
t: Then, I confess, here on my knee, before heaven and you, first to you, and then to heaven, I love your son.

og: My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love:
t: My friends were poor but honest and my love is too.

og: Be not offended; for it hurts not him  That he is loved of me:
t: Don't be offended, for it doesn't hurt him to be loved by me.

og: I follow him not  By any token of presumptuous suit;
t: I don't follow him claiming anything of him

og: Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
t: and I wouldn't want to be with him until I'm worthy of him.

og: Yet never know how that desert should be.  I know I love in vain, strive against hope;
t: I don't know how I'd ever be worthy of him. I know I love him in vain, I have no hope.

og: Yet in this captious and intenible sieve  I still pour in the waters of my love  And lack not to lose still:
t: It's like I pour the waters of my love into a strainer trying to catch them, but they always evade me.

og: thus, Indian-like,  Religious in mine error, I adore  The sun, that looks upon his worshipper,  But knows of him no more.
t: So, like an Indian, worshipping the wrong religion, I adore the sun, that looks down on his worshipper but doesn't even know the one who worships him exists.

og: My dearest madam,  Let not your hate encounter with my love  For loving where you do:
t: My dearest madam, don't hate me for loving the son that you love.

og: but if yourself,  Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
t: If you yourself—whose honor in old age suggests you were a virtuous young woman,

og: Did ever in so true a flame of liking  Wish chastely and love dearly,
t: ever loved chastely and passionately like me,

og: that your Dian  Was both herself and love:
t: so that Diana, goddess of chastity, and Venus, goddess of love, merged into one

og: O, then, give pity  To her, whose state is such that cannot choose  But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
t: —oh, then, give pity to a girl whose condition means that she cannot choose but to give her love to someone who can never return it.

og: That seeks not to find that her search implies,  But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies!
t: She is a girl who won't seek to pursue her love but will keep her secret sweetly until death!

og: Had you not lately an intent,—speak truly,—To go to Paris?
t: Did you not recently have a plan—speak honestly—to go to Paris?

og: Madam, I had.
t: Madam, I did.

og: Wherefore? tell true.
t: Why? Tell the truth.

og: I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
t: I will tell the truth; I swear to God.

og: You know my father left me some prescriptions  Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading  And manifest experience had collected  For general sovereignty;
t: You know that my father left me some medicines with rare and tested powers that he collected for general usefulness based on his reading and impressive experience.

og: and that he will'd me  In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them,
t: He meant to leave them to me for safe-keeping and to use

og: As notes whose faculties inclusive were  More than they were in note:
t: since I understood that their powers were beyond the reputation that they carry.

og: amongst the rest,  There is a remedy, approved, set down,
t: Among those medicines, there is a remedy, that's been tested and studied,

og: To cure the desperate languishings whereof  The king is render'd lost.
t: that will cure the terrible sickness that is thought to be a death sentence for the king.

og: This was your motiveFor Paris, was it? speak.
t: That was your reason to go to Paris, was it? Speak.

og: My lord your son made me to think of this;
t: My lord your son gave me this idea.

og: Else Paris and the medicine and the king  Had from the conversation of my thoughts  Haply been absent then.
t: Otherwise Paris and the medicine and the king would never have crossed my mind.

og: But think you, Helen,  If you should tender your supposed aid,  He would receive it?
t: But do you think, Helena, if you should offer this supposed help to the king that he would accept it?

og: he and his physicians  Are of a mind;
t: He and his physicians all think the same thing:

og: he, that they cannot help him,  They, that they cannot help:
t: he thinks they can't help him and they think that he can't be helped.

og: how shall they credit  A poor unlearned virgin,
t: Why would they trust a poor, uneducated virgin,

og: when the schools,  Embowell'd of their doctrine, have left off  The danger to itself?
t: when the leading doctors, having put all of their learning to practice, have left the sickness to take its natural course?

og: There's something in't,  More than my father's skill, which was the greatest  Of his profession,
t: My hope is that, beyond just my father's skill, which was the greatest of his profession,

og: that his good receipt  Shall for my legacy be sanctified  By the luckiest stars in heaven:
t: that his good reputation will be blessed by all the stars in heaven and will bring me good fortune.

og: and, would your honour  But give me leave to try success,
t: And, if your ladyship would only give me the chance to attempt success,

og: I'ld venture  The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure  By such a day and hour.
t: I'd wager my life on his grace being cured down to the very day and hour.

og: Ay, madam, knowingly.
t: Yes, madam, completely.

og: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
t: Why, Helena, you will have my permission and love,

og: Means and attendants and my loving greetings  To those of mine in court:
t: everything you need to travel and servants to wait on you and my loving greetings to my friends at court.

og: I'll stay at home  And pray God's blessing into thy attempt:
t: I'll stay at home and pray for God's blessing in your attempt.

og: Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this,  What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss.
t: Leave tomorrow, and be sure of this: anything that I can help you with, you shall have.

og: Farewell, young lords;
t: Farewell, young lords.

og: these warlike principles  Do not throw from you:
t: Don't forget your warlike principles.

og: 'Tis our hope, sir,After well enter'd soldiers, to returnAnd find your grace in health.
t: It's our hope sir, after we've fought well, to return and find your grace in good health.

og: No, no, it cannot be;
t: No, no, it cannot be.

og: and yet my heart  Will not confess he owes the malady  That doth my life besiege.
t: And yet my heart will not admit that I am sick and dying.

og: Farewell, young lords;  Whether I live or die, be you the sons  Of worthy Frenchmen:
t: Farewell, young lords. Whether I live or die, act like the sons of worthy Frenchmen.

og: let higher Italy,—  Those bated that inherit but the fall  Of the last monarchy,—see that you come  Not to woo honour, but to wed it;
t: Let strong Italy—those lesser people that inherit only the fallen Roman Empire—see that you haven't come just to court honor like a lover but to marry it.

og: when  The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,  That fame may cry you loud:
t: When the bravest man of them flees, push onwards, and fame will remember you well for it.

og: I say, farewell.
t: I say, farewell.

og: Health, at your bidding, serve your majesty!
t: Health, upon your command, serve your majesty!

og: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them:
t: Take heed of those girls from Italy.

og: They say, our French lack language to deny,  If they demand:
t: They say that Frenchmen don't have the language to deny what they demand.

og: beware of being captives,  Before you serve.
t: Beware of falling captive to them before you serve your captains.

og: Our hearts receive your warnings.
t: We hear your warnings.

og: Farewell. Come hither to me.
t: Farewell. Come along with me.

og: O, my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!
t: Oh, my dear lord, what a shame that you must stay behind!

og: 'Tis not his fault, the spark.
t: It's not his fault, the little bugger.

og: O, 'tis brave wars!
t: Oh, these are exciting wars!

og: Most admirable: I have seen those wars.
t: Most admirable: I have seen the wars.

og: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with'Too young' and 'the next year' and ''tis too early.'
t: I am commanded to remain here, and am told I am "Too young" and "the next year" and "it's too early."

og: An thy mind stand to't, boy, steal away bravely.
t: If you're fixed on fighting, boy, steal away to the wars bravely.

og: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,  Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry,  Till honour be bought up
t: Otherwise, I'd stay here to dance with women, creaking my shoes on the flat stone, until there was honor left to buy.

og: and no sword worn  But one to dance with! By heaven, I'll steal away.
t: I'd wear no sword except one to dance with. By heaven, I'll steal away.

og: There's honour in the theft.
t: There's honor in stealing if you're stealing away to fight.

og: Commit it, count.
t: Commit to doing this, count.

og: I am your accessary; and so, farewell.
t: I am your accomplice in this, and so, farewell.

og: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.
t: I've enjoyed our growing friendship, and our parting is torturous.

og: Farewell, captain.
t: Farewell, captain.

og: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!
t: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

og: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin.
t: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are family.

og: Good  sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals:
t: Good young buggers and shiny, in a word, good young metals:

og: you shall  find in the regiment of the Spinii one Captain  Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of war, here  on his sinister cheek;
t: you shall find in the regiment of the Spinii a man named Captain Spurio, with his scar, received in war, here on his evil cheek.

og: it was this very sword  entrenched it:
t: It was this very sword that gave him the wound.

og: say to him, I live; and observe his  reports for me.
t: Tell him that I live and observe how he reacts for me.

og: We shall, noble captain.
t: We shall, noble captain.

og: Mars dote on you for his novices! what will ye do?
t: May Mars look down on you, his young warriors! What will you do, Bertram?

og: Stay: the king.
t: Hold on: the king comes.

og: Use a more spacious ceremony to the  noble lords;
t: Speak with more warmth to the noble lords.

og: you have restrained yourself within the  list of too cold an adieu:
t: You've held back and just said a cold farewell.

og: be more expressive to  them:
t: Be more expressive to them:

og: for they wear themselves in the cap of the  time, there do muster true gait, eat, speak, and  move under the influence of the most received star;
t: they behave in the new fashion, and they walk, eat, speak, and move following the most successful, popular trends.

og: and though the devil lead the measure, such are to  be followed:
t: Even though the devil may be behind these fashions, you want an in with them.

og: after them, and take a more dilated farewell.
t: Follow after them, and have a more extended farewell.

og: And I will do so.
t: And I will do so.

og: Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.
t: They're worthy fellows, and they'll probably prove to be talented sword-men.

og: Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.
t: Give pardon, my lord, to me and my news.

og: I'll fee thee to stand up.
t: I'll ask you to stand up.

og: Then here's a man stands, that has brought his pardon.I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy,And that at my bidding you could so stand up.
t: Then a man stands here before you having received his pardon. I wish you had kneeled, my lord, to ask me for mercy, and that you'd have waited for my permission to stand up too.

og: I would I had; so I had broke thy pate,And ask'd thee mercy for't.
t: I wish I had. Then I'd have broken your head and asked you mercy for that.

og: Good faith, across: but, my good lord 'tis thus;Will you be cured of your infirmity?
t: That's well said. But, my good lord, I have to ask you, will you be cured of your disease?

og: No.
t: No.

og: O, will you eat no grapes, my royal fox?
t: Oh, do you not like to eat grapes, my royal fox?

og: Yes, but you will my noble grapes, an if  My royal fox could reach them:
t: Yes, but you will eat the noble grapes that I bring, if my royal fox can reach them.

og: I have seen a medicine  That's able to breathe life into a stone,  Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary  With spritely fire and motion;
t: I've been shown a medicine that can breathe life into a stone, bring a rock to life, and make you dance the canary with spritely energy and vigor.

og: whose simple touch,  Is powerful to araise King Pepin,
t: The simple touch of this medicine is powerful enough to resurrect King Pepin,

og: nay,  To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand,  And write to her a love-line.
t: no, to resurrect great Charlemagne, put a pen in his hand, and have him write to her a love letter.

og: What 'her' is this?
t: What "her" do you speak of?

og: Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's one arrived,  If you will see her:
t: Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's a lady who's arrived if you will now see her.

og: now, by my faith and honour,  If seriously I may convey my thoughts  In this my light deliverance,
t: Now, by my faith and honor, if I can seriously share my thoughts beyond this silly speech,

og: I have spoke  With one that, in her sex, her years, profession,  Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more  Than I dare blame my weakness:
t: I have spoken with a woman that, in her gender, her age, profession, wisdom, and loyalty, has amazed me more than I can blame on my weakness for her beauty.

og: will you see her  For that is her demand, and know her business?
t: Will you see her and know what she has to say? That is her demand.

og: That done, laugh well at me.
t: Once you've done that, you can laugh at me all you want.

og: Now, good Lafeu,  Bring in the admiration;
t: Now, good Lafeu, bring in this admirable woman.

og: that we with thee  May spend our wonder too, or take off thine  By wondering how thou took'st it.
t: Along with you, I'll wonder at her too, or, at the very least, I'll wonder why you found her so wonderful.

og: Nay, I'll fit you,And not be all day neither.
t: No, I'll get her for you, and I won't take all day either.

og: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.
t: He always introduces his topic with this special nonsense.

og: Nay, come your ways.
t: No, come along.

og: This haste hath wings indeed.
t: You've done this quickly indeed.

og: Nay, come your ways:
t: No, come along.

og: This is his majesty; say your mind to him:
t: This is his majesty, say what you will to him.

og: A traitor you do look like; but such traitors  His majesty seldom fears:
t: You look like a traitor, but his majesty is seldom afraid of traitors who look like this.

og: I am Cressid's uncle,  That dare leave two together; fare you well.
t: I'm like Cressida's uncle, daring to leave a man and a woman together. Farewell.

og: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?
t: Now, beautiful one, does your business here have to do with me?

og: Ay, my good lord.Gerard de Narbon was my father;In what he did profess, well found.
t: Yes, my good lord. Gerard de Carbon was my father. He was well-renowned in his profession.

og: I knew him.
t: I knew him.

og: The rather will I spare my praises towards him:  Knowing him is enough.
t: Then I won't waste breath praising him. If you know him, that's enough.

og: On's bed of death  Many receipts he gave me: chiefly one.
t: On his deathbed, he gave me many medicines, but one in particular.

og: Which, as the dearest issue of his practise,  And of his old experience the oily darling,  He bade me store up,
t: That one, as the most special product of all his work, and his favorite of all his practice, he commanded me to store up,

og: as a triple eye,  Safer than mine own two, more dear;
t: and to watch it as if I had three eyes, more safely than I could with these two, more dearly.

og: I have so;
t: I have done so.

og: And hearing your high majesty is touch'd  With that malignant cause wherein the honour  Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
t: Now, since I've heard your majesty is infected with this terrible disease that my dear father's medicine was made to cure,

og: I come to tender it and my appliance  With all bound humbleness.
t: I come to offer it to you, along with my medical care, with all appropriate humility.

og: We thank you, maiden;
t: Thank you for that, girl.

og: But may not be so credulous of cure,  When our most learned doctors leave us
t: But I don't believe so quickly in this cure when the most educated doctors in the land have given up

og: and  The congregated college have concluded  That labouring art can never ransom nature  From her inaidible estate;
t: and their gathered colleagues have concluded that no medicine will ever defeat nature in this helpless condition.

og: I say we must not  So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope,  To prostitute our past-cure malady  To empirics,
t: I wouldn't want to cast aside my judgement, or overreach my hope, to offer up my incurable sickness to quacks,

og: or to dissever so  Our great self and our credit, to esteem  A senseless help when help past sense we deem.
t: or to so divide my great self and my reputation, to pursue an impossible cure when I've been called beyond help.

og: My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
t: Having done my duty in making you this offer will be enough payment for coming here.

og: I will no more enforce mine office on you.
t: I won't try harder to convince you to try this.

og: Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts  A modest one, to bear me back again.
t: I just humbly ask your highness kindly to send me back home again.

og: I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful:
t: I cannot offer less than to say that I'm grateful.

og: Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give  As one near death to those that wish him live:
t: You thought of helping me, and I give you the thanks of a man near death who's grateful to those who wish him to live.

og: But what at full I know, thou know'st no part,  I knowing all my peril, thou no art.
t: But the extent of what I know, you know only a little bit. I know all of my suffering, you don't know anything about medicinal art.

og: What I can do can do no hurt to try,  Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.
t: What I can offer can hardly hurt to try since you're convinced you're beyond curing.

og: He that of greatest works is finisher  Oft does them by the weakest minister:
t: God often does great deeds through the weakest of humans.

og: So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown,  When judges have been babes;
t: We have seen this when the youth have shown holy judgement, when judges have been youths.

og: great floods have flown  From simple sources, and great seas have dried  When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
t: Great floods have come from small sources, and great seas have dried up when the most powerful have said miracles were impossible.

og: Oft expectation fails and most oft there  Where most it promises, and oft it hits  Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.
t: Often, our expectation fails exactly where we think success most likely to happen, and often we get what we prayed for where hope seems weakest and it seems to make the most sense to despair.

og: I must not hear thee; fare thee well, kind maid;Thy pains not used must by thyself be paid:Proffers not took reap thanks for their reward.
t: I must not listen to you further. Farewell, kind maid. You'll have to make up the difference for your efforts coming here: offers not accepted can earn only thanks as a reward.

og: Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd:  It is not so with Him that all things knows
t: I'm not saying that my mortal words can guarantee power over divine will.

og: As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
t: God knows all and has powers beyond us humans who can only guess based on what we see.

og: But most it is presumption in us when  The help of heaven we count the act of men.
t: But it's presumptuous of us to call events the act of men when they actually are controlled from heaven.

og: Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent;
t: Dear sir, consent to my attempts.

og: Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
t: Test heaven, not me.

og: I am not an impostor that proclaim  Myself against the level of mine aim;
t: I'm not an imposter who claims to be able to do things greater than I can.

og: But know I think and think I know most sure  My art is not past power nor you past cure.
t: But just know that I believe and I think I can be sure that the art that I know is powerful and you can still be cured.

og: Are thou so confident? within what spaceHopest thou my cure?
t: Are you so confident? How long do you think it will take for this cure to work?

og: The great'st grace lending grace  Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring  Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
t: If God lends his power, before the sun's horses can twice bring that sun to nighttime,

og: Ere twice in murk and occidental damp  Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp,
t: before the evening star Hesperus can twice turn off his sleepy lamp.

og: Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass  Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass,
t: When the hourglass has counted the fleeting minutes twenty-four times,

og: What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,  Health shall live free and sickness freely die.
t: the sickness in your healthy bones will flee, and health shall live free and sickness will die.

og: Upon thy certainty and confidenceWhat darest thou venture?
t: How much are you willing to wager on your certainty and confidence?

og: Tax of impudence,  A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame  Traduced by odious ballads:
t: An accusation of arrogance, the boldness of a whore, an infamous shame carried out in horrid ballads:

og: my maiden's name  Sear'd otherwise;
t: my maiden's name defamed this way and that.

og: nay, worse—if worse—extended  With vilest torture let my life be ended.
t: No, worse—if this is worse—let my life be ended with vilest torture.

og: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak  His powerful sound within an organ weak:
t: I think some blessed sprit speaks in you, his powerful sound playing from a weak organ.

og: And what impossibility would slay  In common sense, sense saves another way.
t: And even though common sense says this should be impossible, my senses tell me differently.

og: Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate  Worth name of life in thee hath estimate,
t: Your life is valuable. All worth that can be bestowed on a person finds itself in you:

og: Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all  That happiness and prime can happy call:
t: youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, everything that one hopes for in the prime of their life to be happy.

og: Thou this to hazard needs must intimate  Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
t: If you're willing to risk all of this, then that must mean you have either infinite skill or horrible desperation.

og: Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,  That ministers thine own death if I die.
t: Sweet doctor, I'll try your medicine. It will be the prescription of your own death if I die.

og: If I break time, or flinch in property  Of what I spoke,
t: If your cure doesn't meet this deadline, or if I don't do exactly what I've said,

og: unpitied let me die,  And well deserved:
t: then let me die without pity, and it will be well deserved.

og: not helping, death's my fee;
t: If I don't help, death's the cost.

og: But, if I help, what do you promise me?
t: But, if I help, what do you promise me?

og: Make thy demand.
t: Make your demand.

og: But will you make it even?
t: But will you do whatever I ask?

og: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.
t: Yes, by my scepter and my hopes to go to heaven.

og: Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand  What husband in thy power I will command:
t: Then you will give me with your kingly hand whatever husband I choose.

og: Exempted be from me the arrogance  To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
t: You'll give me the right to choose from among all the royal blood of France

og: My low and humble name to propagate  With any branch or image of thy state;
t: so that I can spread my low and humble name to any branch or family of your kingdom.

og: But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know  Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.
t: I know someone who falls into that category, your subject, and it would be acceptable for me to ask for his hand and for you to bestow it.

og: Here is my hand  ;
t: Here is my hand.

og: the premises observed,  Thy will by my performance shall be served:
t: If what you promise comes to pass, I will do exactly what you ask.

og: So make the choice of thy own time, for I,  Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.
t: So tell me when you're ready to choose, for I, your new patient, rely entirely on you.

og: More should I question thee, and more I must,
t: I should question you more, and I will question you more,

og: Though more to know could not be more to trust,  From whence thou camest, how tended on:
t: although I wouldn't trust you any more no matter how much I knew about where you came from or how you got here.

og: but rest  Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
t: But leave those questions aside and be welcome and undoubtedly blessed.

og: Give me some help here, ho!
t: Give me some help here, hey!

og: If thou proceed  As high as word, my deed shall match thy meed.
t: If you follow through with what you claim, my deeds for you will match your gift to me.

og: Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height ofyour breeding.
t: Come on, sir. I will now make you demonstrate the extent of your breeding.

og: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught: Iknow my business is but to the court.
t: I will show myself to be well fed but poorly educated. I know I will be only sent to the court.

og: To the court! why, what place make you special,when you put off that with such contempt? But to the court!
t: To the court! Why, what place do you think of as special if you can talk of the court in such a contemptuous tone? Only sent to the court!

og: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he  may easily put it off at court:
t: Truly, madam, if God has bestowed a man with any manners, he can discard them all at court.

og: he that cannot make  a leg, put off's cap, kiss his hand and say nothing,
t: If a man can't bow, doff his cap, kiss his hand and say nothing,

og: has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed  such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the  court;
t: or has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap, then such a fellow, to say precisely, is not made for court.

og: but for me, I have an answer will serve all  men.
t: For me, though, I have an answer that will respond to all men.

og: Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits allquestions.
t: Well, that's quite an answer that can respond to all questions.

og: It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocks,the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawnbuttock, or any buttock.
t: It's like a barber's chair that fits all types of buttocks: the narrow buttock, the fat buttock, the brawny buttock, or any buttock.

og: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?
t: Will you answer be fit to respond to all questions?

og: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney,
t: It will be as fit as four pence is fit for the hand of an attorney,

og: as your French crown for your taffeta punk,
t: as fit as a French crown is fit for the hand of a scantily clad prostitute,

og: as Tib's  rush for Tom's forefinger,
t: or as fit as a lady's ring is fit for a man's finger,

og: as a pancake for Shrove  Tuesday,
t: or as fit as a pancake on Shrove Tuesday

og: a morris for May-day,
t: or a morris dance on May-day

og: as the nail to his  hole, the cuckold to his horn,
t: or as a nail to a hole or as a cuckold to his horn

og: as a scolding quean  to a wrangling knave,
t: or as a scolding woman to a wayward rogue.

og: as the nun's lip to the  friar's mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.
t: Or as fit as the nun's lip to the friar's mouth, no, sorry, that should be as fit as the sausage to the sausage skin.

og: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for allquestions?
t: Have you, I say, an answer that can respond to all questions?

og: From below your duke to beneath your constable, itwill fit any question.
t: From a duke to a constable, it will be good for any question.

og: It must be an answer of most monstrous size thatmust fit all demands.
t: It must be an answer of a gigantic size that would fit any question.

og: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned  should speak truth of it:
t: But a little one, actually, to speak the truth:

og: here it is, and all that  belongs to't.
t: here it is and everything attached to it.

og: Ask me if I am a courtier: it shall  do you no harm to learn.
t: Ask me if I am a nobleman: it won't hurt you to learn.

og: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool inquestion, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. Ipray you, sir, are you a courtier?
t: Oh, to be young again, if we could. I will play the fool in asking you a question, hoping to become wiser from your answer. Please, sir, are you a nobleman?

og: O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting off. More,more, a hundred of them.
t: "Oh Lord, sir!" That's a phrase used to evade answering the question. More, more questions, ask a hundred of them.

og: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.
t: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that cares for you.

og: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.
t: "Oh Lord, sir!" More, more, don't spare me with your questions.

og: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.
t: I think, sir, you can't eat more of this plain meat.

og: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.
t: "Oh Lord, sir!" No, ask me more of these, I beg you.

og: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.
t: You were recently whipped, sir, I think.

og: O Lord, sir! spare not me.
t: "Oh Lord, sir!" Don't spare me.

og: Do you cry, 'O Lord, sir!' at your whipping, and  'spare not me?'
t: Do you cry, "Oh Lord, sir?" about your whipping, and "Don't spare me?"

og: Indeed your 'O Lord, sir!' is very  sequent to your whipping:
t: Indeed, your "Oh Lord, sir!" is an appropriate thing to cry out during a whipping.

og: you would answer very well  to a whipping, if you were but bound to't.
t: You would answer very well during a whipping if you were only sentenced to such a punishment.

og: I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord,sir!' I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.
t: I never had worse luck in my life in my "Oh Lord, sir!" than the threat of whipping. I see some phrases may serve me for a while but not serve me forever.

og: I play the noble housewife with the timeTo entertain't so merrily with a fool.
t: I act like a noble household manager entertaining the time with a fool like this.

og: O Lord, sir! why, there't serves well again.
t: "Oh Lord, sir!" Why, there, now, the phrase is serving me well again.

og: An end, sir; to your business.
t: Let's wrap this up, sir.

og: Give Helen this,  And urge her to a present answer back:
t: To your task. Give Helena this, and tell her to send me back an answer quickly.

og: Commend me to my kinsmen and my son:  This is not much.
t: Send my best wishes to my family and my son. That's not very much.

og: Not much commendation to them.
t: Not much best wishes to them.

og: Not much employment for you: you understand me?
t: Not much of a task for you: you understand me?

og: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.
t: Most heartily. I am there ahead of my legs.

og: Haste you again.
t: Go quickly again.

og: They say miracles are past; and we have our  philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar,  things supernatural and causeless.
t: They say miracles no longer exist, and we have our scientists and philosophers to explain in modern and familiar terms the things that seem supernatural and without cause.

og: Hence is it that  we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves  into seeming knowledge,
t: So these days we think of terrors as just little trifles, wrapping ourselves in knowledge,

og: when we should submit  ourselves to an unknown fear.
t: when we should be filled with fear of the unknown.

og: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hathshot out in our latter times.
t: Why, it's the strangest story of wonder that has come to pass in modern times.

og: And so 'tis.
t: And so it is.

og: To be relinquish'd of the artists,—
t: To be given up on by the physicians—

og: So I say.
t: That's what I've been saying.

og: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.
t: Both the schools of ancient and more recent medicine.

og: So I say.
t: That's what I've been saying.

og: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,—
t: Of all the learned and famous doctors—

og: Right; so I say.
t: Right. That's what I've been saying.

og: That gave him out incurable,—
t: That said he was incurable—

og: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.
t: Why, there it is. I've been saying that too.

og: Not to be helped,—
t: Not to be helped—

og: Right; as 'twere, a man assured of a—
t: Right. As it were, he was a man assured of a—

og: Uncertain life, and sure death.
t: An uncertain life and definite death.

og: Just, you say well; so would I have said.
t: Exactly so. You speak well. I would have said the same.

og: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.
t: I may truly say, this is a new thing in the world.

og: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, youshall read it in—what do you call there?
t: It is, indeed. We'll hear it narrated, we'll read it in—what do you call it there?

og: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.
t: "A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly man."

og: That's it; I would have said the very same.
t: That's it. I would have said it exactly the same.

og: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: 'fore me,I speak in respect—
t: Why, no dolphin is more sprightly than the king now. Of course, I speak in respect—

og: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange, that is thebrief and the tedious of it; and he's of a mostfacinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the—
t: No, it's strange, it's very strange, that is the long and the short of it. And only someone wicked could fail to acknowledge it to be the—

og: Very hand of heaven.
t: Very hand of heaven.

og: Ay, so I say.
t: Yes, so I say.

og: In a most weak—and debile minister, great power, great transcendence: which should, indeed, give us a further use to be made than alone the recovery of the king, as to be—generally thankful.
t: In a most weak—and feeble person, great power, great heavenly transcendence. That power should give us comfort, even bound the king's recovery so that we can be—generally thankful.

og: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the king.
t: I would have said it just like that. You say it well. Here comes the king.

og: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll like a maid thebetter, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why, he'sable to lead her a coranto.
t: "Lustig," or frolicsome, as the Dutch say: I'll still like maids as long as I have teeth in my head. Why, the king's strong enough to lead her in a dance.

og: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?
t: A ridiculous oath! Isn't that Helena?

og: 'Fore God, I think so.
t: By God, I think it is.

og: Go, call before me all the lords in court.
t: Go, call all the lords in the court before me.

og: Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
t: Sit, my savior, by your patient's side, and with this healthy hand,

og: And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense  Thou hast repeal'd, a second time receive  The confirmation of my promised gift,
t: whose death sentence you've revoked, hear me confirm a second time the gift I've promised you.

og: Which but attends thy naming.
t: I only wait for you to name it.

og: Fair maid, send forth thine eye
t: Fair maid, look around the room.

og: : this youthful parcel  Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,
t: This youthful group of noble bachelors stand ready to be given away by me.

og: O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice  I have to use:
t: I have both the king's power and the voice of a father over them.

og: thy frank election make;
t: Choose who you want.

og: Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.
t: You have the power to choose and they have no power to refuse.

og: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistressFall, when Love please! marry, to each, but one!
t: I hope all of you will find a fair and virtuous mistress when Love pleases to bestow her upon you! Yes, just one to each of you!

og: I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture,My mouth no more were broken than these boys',And writ as little beard.
t: I'd give my horse Curtal and all his accoutrements if my mouth were as young as these boys' are, and covered with as little beard as they have.

og: Peruse them well:Not one of those but had a noble father.
t: Look over them well. All of them had a noble father.

og: Gentlemen,Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.
t: Gentlemen, through me, heaven has restored the king to health.

og: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.
t: We understand that, and we thank heaven for you.

og: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest,  That I protest I simply am a maid.
t: I am a simple maid and I am most valuable in my simple maidenhood.

og: Please it your majesty, I have done already:
t: So please your majesty, I have finished already.

og: The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,
t: The blushes in my cheeks whisper this to me:

og: 'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,  Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever;  We'll ne'er come there again.'
t: "We blush that you should have the power to choose, but if you are refused, let the white paleness of death sit on your cheek forever. We'll never come to your cheek again."

og: Make choice; and, see,Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.
t: Make your choice. You'll see that he who rejects your love rejects all my love for him too.

og: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,And to imperial Love, that god most high,Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?
t: Now, chaste Diana, I fly from your altar, and turn with my sighs to powerful Love, that most mighty of gods.  Sir, will you hear my wishes?

og: And grant it.
t: And grant them.

og: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.
t: Thanks, sir. I have nothing else to say.

og: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-acefor my life.
t: I would want to be one of her choices here even if it meant I would lose at dice for the rest of my life.

og: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,  Before I speak, too threateningly replies:
t: Before I speak, the honor, sir, that I see in your fair eyes, seems to reply threateningly:

og: Love make your fortunes twenty times above  Her that so wishes and her humble love!
t: I hope that love will make your fortunes twenty times greater than my own humble love can offer!

og: No better, if you please.
t: No better, if you please.

og: My wish receive,Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.
t: Well, receive my wish, anyway, which I hope Love will grant you! And so, I take my leave of you.

og: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine,I'd have them whipped; or I would send them to theTurk, to make eunuchs of.
t: Do they all deny her? If they were sons of mine, I'd have them whipped, or else I'd send them Turkey to be made into eunuchs.

og: Be not afraid that I your hand should take;
t: Don't be afraid that I should take your hand.

og: I'll never do you wrong for your own sake:
t: I'll never wrong you in that way.

og: Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed  Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!
t: May your marriage vows be blessed and may you find fairer fortune than me in your bed if you ever get married!

og: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have her:sure, they are bastards to the English; the Frenchne'er got 'em.
t: These boys are made of ice. None of them will have her. They must be English bastards. They can't have French parentage.

og: You are too young, too happy, and too good,To make yourself a son out of my blood.
t: You are too young, too happy, and too good, to father a son from my blood.

og: Fair one, I think not so.
t: Fair one, I don't think that.

og: There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunkwine: but if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youthof fourteen; I have known thee already.
t: There's one man left  yet. I am sure your father drank wine, but if you're not an ass, then I'm a youth of fourteen. I know you to be an ass already.

og: I dare not say I take you; but I giveMe and my service, ever whilst I live,Into your guiding power. This is the man.
t: I dare not say that I take you. But I give myself and my service, as long as I live, into your guiding power.

og: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.
t: Why, then, young Bertram, take her, she's your wife.

og: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness,In such a business give me leave to useThe help of mine own eyes.
t: My wife, my lord! I will plead with your highness that in such a business I can use my own eyes to make my choice.

og: Know'st thou not, Bertram,What she has done for me?
t: Don't you know what she's done for me, Bertram?

og: Yes, my good lord;But never hope to know why I should marry her.
t: Yes, my good lord, but I don't have a clue why I should marry her.

og: Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.
t: You know that she has raised me from my sickbed.

og: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down  Must answer for your raising?
t: But does it make sense, my lord, that I must be brought down because you've been raised up?

og: I know her well:
t: I know her well.

og: She had her breeding at my father's charge.
t: She was brought up in my father's court.

og: A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain  Rather corrupt me ever!
t: A poor physician's daughter as my wife! I'd rather be hated forever!

og: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which  I can build up.
t: It's only her title that you hate in her, and that I can improve.

og: Strange is it that our bloods,  Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together,  Would quite confound distinction
t: How strange it is that our blood, its color and weight and heat, when you pour all our blood together, all looks the same

og: , yet stand off  In differences so mighty.
t: but we still put so much stock in social differences.

og: If she be  All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest,  A poor physician's daughter,
t: If she is totally virtuous, and you only dislike her because she's a poor physician's daughter,

og: thou dislikest  Of virtue for the name:  but do not so:
t: you dislike someone virtuous only because she lacks a title. Don't do that.
