og: From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,  The place is dignified by the doer's deed:
t: When low-born people do virtuous things, their status is raised up by their virtuous deed.

og: Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,  It is a dropsied honour.
t: When a high-born person has no virtue, it's a swollen, fake honor.

og: Good alone  Is good without a name. Vileness is so:
t: Goodness is goodness with or without a title. Vileness is the same.

og: The property by what it is should go,  Not by the title.
t: It's the deeds that matter, not the title.

og: She is young, wise, fair;
t: She is young, wise, and beautiful.

og: In these to nature she's immediate heir,  And these breed honour:
t: She's the legitimate heir of nature in all of that and those qualities make her honorable.

og: that is honour's scorn,  Which challenges itself as honour's born  And is not like the sire:
t: Honor mocks people who claim to be honorable by birth but don't behave like it.

og: honours thrive,  When rather from our acts we them derive  Than our foregoers:
t: Honors matter most when they come from our acts, not from our ancestors.

og: the mere word's a slave  Debauched on every tomb, on every grave
t: The mere word "honor" is a slave we carve into every tomb, a memorial on every grave.

og: A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb  Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb  Of honour'd bones indeed.
t: In every case, it's a silent legacy because dust and eternal nothingness are all that's inside a tomb of so-called "honored" bones.

og: What should be said?
t: What else can be said?

og: If thou canst like this creature as a maid,  I can create the rest:
t: If you can like this creature just as she is, I can provide the rest.

og: virtue and she  Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.
t: She herself and her virtue is what she brings. I can supply honor and wealth.

og: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.
t: I cannot love her and I won't try to.

og: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.
t: You wrong yourself if you should try to get out of this.

og: That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad:Let the rest go.
t: I'm just glad you're recovered, my lord. Let the rest go.

og: My honour's at the stake;
t: My honor's at risk.

og: which to defeat,  I must produce my power.
t: To eliminate that risk, I must wield my power.

og: Here, take her hand,  Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift;
t: Here, take her hand, you proud, scornful boy, you're unworthy of this good gift.

og: That dost in vile misprision shackle up  My love and her desert;
t: In your vile hate you throw away my love and her worthiness.

og: that canst not dream,  We, poising us in her defective scale,  Shall weigh thee to the beam;
t: You can't imagine how, when I add my weight to hers on the scale how little you will be valued.

og: that wilt not know,  It is in us to plant thine honour where  We please to have it grow.
t: You pretend not to know that it's in my power to decide how much honor you have.

og: Cheque thy contempt:
t: Stop your contempt.

og: Obey our will, which travails in thy good:
t: Obey my will which is all for your own good.

og: Believe not thy disdain, but presently  Do thine own fortunes that obedient right  Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
t: Don't listen to your hate, but just do yourself the obedient favor of doing what duty and my power commands of you.

og: Or I will throw thee from my care for ever  Into the staggers and the careless lapse  Of youth and ignorance;
t: If not, I'll throw you out of my protection forever into the confusion and careless idiocy of your youth and ignorance.

og: both my revenge and hate  Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,  Without all terms of pity.
t: I'll apply both my hate and revenge upon you, in the name of justice, with no pity.

og: Speak; thine answer.
t: Speak. Give me your answer.

og: Pardon, my gracious lord;
t: Pardon me, my gracious lord.

og: for I submit  My fancy to your eyes:
t: I will give in and allow you to choose for me.

og: when I consider  What great creation and what dole of honour  Flies where you bid it,
t: When I think about what greatness you create and how much honor you bestow wherever you want,

og: I find that she, which late  Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now  The praised of the king;
t: I realize that she, who I used to think of as low-class, is now praised by the king.

og: who, so ennobled,  Is as 'twere born so.
t: Being made so noble by you, it's as if she were born noble.

og: Take her by the hand,  And tell her she is thine:
t: Take her by the hand, and tell her that she is yours.

og: to whom I promise  A counterpoise, if not to thy estate  A balance more replete.
t: I promise her a compensation that may not equal your estate but will make you equals nonetheless.

og: I take her hand.
t: I take her hand.

og: Good fortune and the favour of the king  Smile upon this contract;
t: Good fortune and a king's favor will smile upon this union.

og: whose ceremony  Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,  And be perform'd to-night:
t: The ceremony will happen quickly and will be performed tonight.

og: the solemn feast  Shall more attend upon the coming space,  Expecting absent friends.
t: The celebratory feast will come later since there are friends who will be absent.

og: As thou lovest her,  Thy love's to me religious;
t: As long as you love her, your love is holy to me.

og: else, does err.
t: If you don't love her, I view your love for me with anger.

og: Do you hear, monsieur? a word with you.
t: Did you hear that, monsieur? I'd like to have a word with you.

og: Your pleasure, sir?
t: What do you want, sir?

og: Your lord and master did well to make hisrecantation.
t: Your lord and master made the right choice to take back what he'd said.

og: Recantation! My lord! my master!
t: Take it back! My lord! My master!

og: Ay; is it not a language I speak?
t: Yes. Do you not understand the words I'm saying?

og: A most harsh one, and not to be understood withoutbloody succeeding. My master!
t: They're harsh ones, and they're not to be understood without a bloody fight. My master!

og: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?
t: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?

og: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.
t: To any counts, to all counts, to all mankind.

og: To what is count's man: count's master is ofanother style.
t: You're a count's servant. A count's master is another thing altogether.

og: You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too old.
t: You are too old, sir. Be happy with that, you are too old.

og: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to whichtitle age cannot bring thee.
t: I must tell you, sir, I call myself a man. Your young age can't bring you that title.

og: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.
t: I'd love to fight you, but I dare not.

og: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty  wise fellow;
t: For about two meals, I thought you were a pretty wise fellow.

og: thou didst make tolerable vent of thy  travel;
t: You spoke well about your travels.

og: it might pass: yet the scarfs and the  bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from  believing thee a vessel of too great a burthen.
t: It might be the case, but the scarfs and the doodads you wore completely convinced me that you couldn't be a man of much substance.

og: I  have now found thee; when I lose thee again, I care  not:
t: I have now found you out. If I lose you, I won't care.

og: yet art thou good for nothing but taking up; and  that thou't scarce worth.
t: You're good for nothing but being attacked and you're hardly worth that much.

og: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee,—
t: If you didn't have the privilege of being ancient—

og: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou  hasten thy trial;
t: Don't go too far in anger or you might speed up the time of your trial;

og: which if—Lord have mercy on thee  for a hen!
t: which if—Lord have mercy on you, chicken!

og: So, my good window of lattice, fare thee  well:
t: So, my good see-through window, farewell:

og: thy casement I need not open, for I look  through thee.
t: I don't need to open you up because I can see through you.

og: Give me thy hand.
t: Give me your hand.

og: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.
t: My lord, you do me most remarkably wrong.

og: Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.
t: Yes, with all my heart, and you are worthy of it.

og: I have not, my lord, deserved it.
t: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

og: Yes, good faith, every dram of it; and I will notbate thee a scruple.
t: Yes, good faith, every piece of it, and I won't give you back a hair.

og: Well, I shall be wiser.
t: Well, I will be wiser.

og: Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at  a smack o' the contrary.
t: Do that as soon as you can, for you'll have to be the total opposite of what you are now.

og: If ever thou be'st bound  in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is  to be proud of thy bondage.
t: If you ever find yourself tied up in your scarf and beaten, you'll find out what it means to be proud of your bondage.

og: I have a desire to hold  my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge,  that I may say in the default, he is a man I know.
t: I would love to keep up my acquaintance with you, or rather my knowledge of you, so that I can say when you get tied up and beaten, he is a man I know.

og: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.
t: My lord, you irritate me enormously.

og: I would it were hell-pains for thy sake, and my poordoing eternal: for doing I am past: as I will bythee, in what motion age will give me leave.
t: I wish you felt pains from hell for your sake, and my poor attempts to irritate you forever. For doing this, I'm done, and I'll now pass by you with whatever speed my great age will allow me.

og: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off  me;
t: Well, you have a son who will pay for this disgraceful talk.

og: scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord!
t: Worthless, old, filthy, worthless lord!

og: Well, I must  be patient; there is no fettering of authority.
t: Well, I must be patient. There is no violence I can take against authority.

og: I'll beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with  any convenience, an he were double and double a  lord.
t: I'll beat him, on my life, if I can run into him in a convenient way, if he were twice and twice again as great a lord.

og: I'll have no more pity of his age than I  would of
t: I won't have any more sympathy for his age than I would have

og: —I'll beat him, an if I could but meet him again.
t: —I'll beat him if only I could just meet him again.

og: Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's newsfor you: you have a new mistress.
t: Sir, your lord and master is married. There's news for you. You have a new mistress.

og: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to makesome reservation of your wrongs: he is my goodlord: whom I serve above is my master.
t: I most seriously beg your lordship to plead pardon for your wrongs. He is my good lord. Only he that I serve above is my master.

og: Who? God?
t: Who? God?

og: Ay, sir.
t: Yes, sir.

og: The devil it is that's thy master.
t: The devil is your master.

og: Why dost thou  garter up thy arms o' this fashion?
t: Why do you dress up your arms in this fashion?

og: dost make hose of  sleeves? do other servants so?
t: Do you make pantaloons of sleeves? Do other servants do so?

og: Thou wert best set  thy lower part where thy nose stands.
t: You'd do best to put your leg where your nose is.

og: By mine  honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'ld beat  thee:
t: I swear, if I were only two hours younger, I'd beat you.

og: methinks, thou art a general offence, and  every man should beat thee:
t: I think you are an offense to everyone and every man should beat you.

og: I think thou wast  created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.
t: I think you were created for men to practice their beating on you.

og: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.
t: This is harsh and undeserved talk, my lord.

og: Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking a  kernel out of a pomegranate;
t: Oh, come on, sir, you were beaten in Italy just for picking a seed out of a pomegranate.

og: you are a vagabond and  no true traveller:
t: You are a vagabond and not a true traveller.

og: you are more saucy with lords  and honourable personages than the commission of your  birth and virtue gives you heraldry.
t: You are more rude to lords and honorable people than the quality of your birth and your manners should allow you to be.

og: You are not  worth another word, else I'ld call you knave.
t: You are not worth another word. Otherwise, I'd call you a rogue.

og: I leave you.
t: I leave you now.

og: Good, very good; it is so then: good, very good;let it be concealed awhile.
t: Good, very good. It is so then. Good, very good. Let my knowledge of this be kept secret for a while.

og: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!
t: Undone, and sacrificed to woes forever!

og: What's the matter, sweet-heart?
t: What's the matter, sweet heart?

og: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,I will not bed her.
t: Although I've sworn to love in front of the solemn priest, I will not sleep with her.

og: What, what, sweet-heart?
t: What, what, sweet heart?

og: O my Parolles, they have married me!I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.
t: Oh, my Parolles, they have forced me to marry! I'll flee to the Tuscan wars and never sleep with her.

og: France is a dog-hole, and it no more meritsThe tread of a man's foot: to the wars!
t: France is a hellhole and it no longer deserves a man's foot walking on it. To the wars!

og: There's letters from my mother: what the import is,I know not yet.
t: There are letters from my mother. What they say, I don't yet know.

og: Ay, that would be known.
t: Yes, that should be known.

og: To the wars, my boy, to the wars!
t: To the wars, my boys, to the wars!

og: He wears his honour in a box unseen,  That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,  Spending his manly marrow in her arms,
t: A man keep his honor hidden away, when he stays at home with his darling spending his manly energy in her arms,

og: Which should sustain the bound and high curvet  Of Mars's fiery steed.
t: when he should be riding and leaping on Mars's fiery horse in war.

og: To other regions  France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades;
t: In the eyes of other nations, France is like a stable and the people who dwell in it are horses.

og: Therefore, to the war!
t: Therefore, to the war!

og: It shall be so:
t: We will go.

og: I'll send her to my house,  Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,  And wherefore I am fled;
t: I'll send her to my house, let my mother know how much I hate my wife and why I'm fleeing.

og: write to the king  That which I durst not speak;
t: I'll write to the king these words I don't dare speak.

og: his present gift  Shall furnish me to those Italian fields,  Where noble fellows strike:
t: His recent gift to me will fund my escape to those Italian fields where noble fellows fight.

og: war is no strife  To the dark house and the detested wife.
t: War is nothing compared to the awful home and the detested wife.

og: Will this capriccio hold in thee? art sure?
t: Will you stick to this commitment? Are you sure?

og: Go with me to my chamber, and advise me.I'll send her straight away: to-morrowI'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.
t: Go with me to my chamber and advise me. I'll send her away immediately. Tomorrow, I'll go to war and she'll go live a single life in sorrow.

og: Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it.
t: Why, these tennis balls are bouncing now, you can hear it.

og: 'Tis hard:  A young man married is a man that's marr'd:
t: It's hard indeed: a young man who's married is a man that is damaged goods.

og: Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go:
t: Therefore, get away and leave her hastily. Go.

og: The king has done you wrong: but, hush, 'tis so.
t: The king has wronged you, but don't say that aloud.

og: My mother greets me kindly; is she well?
t: My mother greets me kindly. Is she well?

og: She is not well; but yet she has her health:
t: She is not well, but she still has her health.

og: she's  very merry; but yet she is not well:
t: She's very cheerful. But yet she is not well.

og: but thanks be  given, she's very well and wants nothing i', the  world;
t: But, thankfully, she's very well and doesn't need anything in the world.

og: but yet she is not well.
t: But still she's not well.

og: If she be very well, what does she ail, that she'snot very well?
t: If she is so well, what pains her, that she's still not very well?

og: Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.
t: Truly, she's very well indeed, except for two things.

og: What two things?
t: What two things?

og: One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send herquickly! the other that she's in earth, from whenceGod send her quickly!
t: One, that she's not in heaven, where God will send her quickly! The other, that she's on the earth, from where God will send her quickly!

og: Bless you, my fortunate lady!
t: God bless you, my fortunate lady!

og: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine owngood fortunes.
t: I hope, sir, I have your blessing to celebrate my own good fortune.

og: You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep themon, have them still. O, my knave, how does my old lady?
t: I prayed for you to pursue your good fortune. And so you can keep them, have them still. Oh, my rogue, how is my old lady doing?

og: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money,I would she did as you say.
t: If you could have her wrinkles and I could have her money, I wish she would do as you say.

og: Why, I say nothing.
t: But I have said nothing.

og: Marry, you are the wiser man;
t: Ah, you are the wiser man.

og: for many a man's  tongue shakes out his master's undoing:
t: Many a man's tongue causes his master's downfall.

og: to say  nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have  nothing, is to be a great part of your title;
t: To say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing, is going to be a big part of your position,

og: which  is within a very little of nothing.
t: which is pretty close to nothing itself.

og: Away! thou'rt a knave.
t: Get away! You're a rogue.

og: You should have said, sir, before a knave thou'rt aknave; that's, before me thou'rt a knave: this hadbeen truth, sir.
t: You should have said, sir, in front of a rascal that you are a rascal. That is, in front of me, you are a rascal. This would have been a true statement, sir.

og: Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.
t: Get out, you're a witty fool. I've found you out.

og: Did you find me in yourself, sir? or were you  taught to find me?
t: Did you find me in yourself, sir? Or were you taught to find me?

og: The search, sir, was profitable;
t: The search was successful, sir.

og: and much fool may you find in you, even to the  world's pleasure and the increase of laughter.
t: And you may find a big fool inside yourself, even one who can please the world and make many people laugh.

og: A good knave, i' faith, and well fed.
t: You're a good rascal, I swear, and well fed.

og: Madam, my lord will go away to-night;
t: Madam, my lord will go away tonight.

og: A very serious business calls on him.
t: A very serious business summons him.

og: The great prerogative and rite of love,  Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge;  But puts it off to a compell'd restraint;
t: He acknowledges the great needs and ceremonies of love, which you're entitled to, but he has no choice but to put them off.

og: Whose want, and whose delay, is strew'd with sweets,  Which they distil now in the curbed time,
t: The absence of those love ceremonies, and their delay, will make them all the sweeter, now that they're distilled in the meantime,

og: To make the coming hour o'erflow with joy  And pleasure drown the brim.
t: so that when you finally consummate your love, that hour will overflow with joy and pleasure will run over the brim.

og: What's his will else?
t: What else does he want me to do?

og: That you will take your instant leave o' the king  And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
t: That you will immediately leave the king and tell him that your urgency is your own idea.

og: Strengthen'd with what apology you think  May make it probable need.
t: Use whatever excuse you think makes your story sound stronger and more probable.

og: What more commands he?
t: What else does he command?

og: That, having this obtain'd, you presentlyAttend his further pleasure.
t: That, once you've done this, you wait to hear more from him.

og: In every thing I wait upon his will.
t: In everything, I serve him.

og: I shall report it so.
t: I shall report that to him.

og: I pray you.
t: I pray you do so.

og: Come, sirrah.
t: Come, sir.

og: But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.
t: But I hope your lordship doesn't think that he's a soldier.

og: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.
t: Yes, my lord, and with very brave proof of it.

og: You have it from his own deliverance.
t: You've heard that from him.

og: And by other warranted testimony.
t: And by other believable testimony.

og: Then my dial goes not true: I took this lark for a bunting.
t: Then my estimation of him was wrong. I took him to be a fraud.

og: I do assure you, my lord, he is very great inknowledge and accordingly valiant.
t: I do assure you, my lord, he has a lot of knowledge and is very brave.

og: I have then sinned against his experience and  transgressed against his valour;
t: Well, then I've been unfair to his experience and misjudged his bravery.

og: and my state that  way is dangerous, since I cannot yet find in my  heart to repent.
t: Yet I might be in danger of damnation since I can't yet find it in my heart to repent.

og: Here he comes:
t: Here he comes.

og: I pray you, make  us friends; I will pursue the amity.
t: I hope that you'll make us friends. I'll pursue our reconciliation.

og: These things shall be done, sir.
t: These things will be done, sir.

og: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?
t: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

og: Sir?
t: Sir?

og: O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, 's a goodworkman, a very good tailor.
t: Oh, I know him well, yes, sir. He, sir, he's a good workman, a very good tailor.

og: Is she gone to the king?
t: Has she gone to the king?

og: She is.
t: She has.

og: Will she away to-night?
t: Will she leave court tonight?

og: As you'll have her.
t: As you bid her.

og: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure,  Given order for our horses;
t: I have written my letters, packed up my treasure, called for our horses,

og: and to-night,  When I should take possession of the bride,  End ere I do begin.
t: and tonight, when I should be consummating my marriage, I'll end that act before it begins.

og: A good traveller is something at the latter end of a  dinner;
t: A man who's well travelled is a nice thing to have at the end of a dinner to tell stories,

og: but one that lies three thirds and uses a  known truth to pass a thousand nothings with,
t: but a man who lies three out of three times and tells one truth to convince you of a thousand lies

og: should  be once heard and thrice beaten.
t: should be heard once and then beaten three times.

og: Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?
t: Is there a feud between you and this lord, monsieur?

og: I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord'sdispleasure.
t: I don't know what I've done to earn his displeasure.

og: You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs  and all, like him that leaped into the custard;
t: You have managed to run directly into my displeasure, boots and spurs and all, like a jester who jumped into the custard,

og: and  out of it you'll run again, rather than suffer  question for your residence.
t: and you'll flee again rather than stick around to defend yourself.

og: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.
t: It might be that you're mistaken about him, my lord.

og: And shall do so ever, though I took him at 's  prayers.
t: And I'll continue to be mistaken about him forever, then, even if I stumbled upon him praying.

og: Fare you well, my lord;  and believe this  of me,
t: Farewell, my lord. Believe this from me.

og: there can be no kernel in this light nut; the  soul of this man is his clothes.
t: There can be no kernel at the core of this lightweight nut. This man's soul is in his clothes.

og: Trust him not in  matter of heavy consequence; I have kept of them  tame, and know their natures.
t: Don't trust him with important matters. I have kept tame animals and I know to beware of them.

og: Farewell, monsieur:  I have spoken better of you than you have or will to  deserve at my hand; but we must do good against evil.
t: Farewell, monsieur. I have spoken better of you than you have or ever will deserve from me, but we must try to do good even in the presence of evil.

og: An idle lord. I swear.
t: He's a foolish lord, I swear.

og: I think so.
t: I think so.

og: Why, do you not know him?
t: Why, do you not know him?

og: Yes, I do know him well, and common speechGives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.
t: Yes, I do know him well, and most people say he's very worthy. Here comes my clog.

og: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you,  Spoke with the king and have procured his leave  For present parting;
t: Sir, as you commanded me to do, I have spoken with the king and have gotten permission to leave immediately.

og: only he desires  Some private speech with you.
t: He just wants to speak to you in private.

og: I shall obey his will.
t: I will obey his request.

og: You must not marvel, Helen, at my course,  Which holds not colour with the time,
t: You mustn't be confused, Helena, at my behavior, which isn't normal for such a marriage day.

og: nor does  The ministration and required office  On my particular.
t: I know I'm not doing the things expected of me as a husband.

og: Prepared I was not  For such a business; therefore am I found  So much unsettled:
t: I wasn't prepared for such an event and it's unsettled me.

og: this drives me to entreat you  That presently you take our way for home;
t: This makes me ask you to go home ahead of me.

og: And rather muse than ask why I entreat you,
t: You can think for yourself, rather than ask, why I request this of you.

og: For my respects are better than they seem
t: My reasons are better than they seem.

og: And my appointments have in them a need  Greater than shows itself at the first view  To you that know them not.
t: These actions are more necessary than they seem at first sight because you don't know my reasons.

og: This to my mother:
t: Bring this to my mother.

og: 'Twill be two days ere I shall see you, soI leave you to your wisdom.
t: It will be two days before I will see you, so I'll leave you to your thoughts.

og: Sir, I can nothing say,But that I am your most obedient servant.
t: Sir, I can't say anything except that I am your most obedient servant.

og: Come, come, no more of that.
t: Come, come, no more of that.

og: And ever shall  With true observance seek to eke out that
t: And I shall forever with truth and honesty aim to be worthy

og: Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd  To equal my great fortune.
t: of this great fortune which my plain upbringing did not deserve.

og: Let that go:My haste is very great: farewell; hie home.
t: Forget that. I'm in a big hurry. Farewell. Go home.

og: Pray, sir, your pardon.
t: Please, sir, your pardon.

og: Well, what would you say?
t: Well, what would you say?

og: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,  Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is;
t: I am unworthy of the wealth I've received and I don't dare say it belongs to me, and yet it is.

og: But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal  What law does vouch mine own.
t: But, like a shy thief, I would still like to steal what the law says is mine.

og: What would you have?
t: What is it that you want?

og: Something; and scarce so much: nothing, indeed.
t: Something. And hardly that much. Nothing, indeed.

og: I would not tell you what I would, my lord:
t: I can't tell you what I want, my lord.

og: Faith yes;  Strangers and foes do sunder, and not kiss.
t: Well, yes. Only strangers and foes part ways without a kiss.

og: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.
t: I plead with you, don't stay here, but hurry to your horse.

og: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.
t: I won't fail to do what you command, my good lord.

og: Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell.
t: Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell.

og: Go thou toward home; where I will never comeWhilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum.Away, and for our flight.
t: Yes, go towards home where I will never come while I can still use my sword or hear the drums of war. Let's get away, and prepare to flee.

og: Bravely, coragio!
t: Bravely, courage!

og: So that from point to point now have you heard  The fundamental reasons of this war,
t: So now you've heard point by point the basic reasons for this war.

og: Whose great decision hath much blood let forth  And more thirsts after.
t: The weighty decision to go to war has already caused so many deaths and more are still to come.

og: Holy seems the quarrelUpon your grace's part; black and fearfulOn the opposer.
t: It seems like God is on your side in this fight, your grace. Things are looking pretty dire and frightening for your enemy.

og: Therefore we marvel much our cousin FranceWould in so just a business shut his bosomAgainst our borrowing prayers.
t: That's why we're astonished that the King of France would refuse to help us when we have such a just cause and pray for support.

og: Good my lord,  The reasons of our state I cannot yield,
t: My good lord, I can't explain why our king does what he does.

og: But like a common and an outward man,  That the great figure of a council frames  By self-unable motion  :
t: I can only say, as a common observer, that great men tend to act in ways I'm incapable of explaining.

og: therefore dare not  Say what I think of it,
t: Don't ask me what I think about it then,

og: since I have found  Myself in my incertain grounds to fail  As often as I guess'd.
t: since I tend to be so uncertain about such things that I'm usually wrong whenever I guess.

og: Be it his pleasure.
t: Well, he'll do as he pleases.

og: But I am sure the younger of our nature,That surfeit on their ease, will day by dayCome here for physic.
t: But I'm sure that our younger countrymen, that are sick of easy leisure, will come here to recover themselves more and more every day.

og: Welcome shall they be;
t: They'll be welcome here.

og: And all the honours that can fly from us  Shall on them settle.
t: All the honors that I can bestow, I'll bestow upon them.

og: You know your places well;
t: You know where you're supposed to be.

og: When better fall, for your avails they fell:
t: When better positions open up, you'll be the first to know.

og: To-morrow to the field.
t: Tomorrow, the battlefield!

og: It hath happened all as I would have had it, savethat he comes not along with her.
t: It's all happened just as I wanted it to, except that he doesn't come along with her.

og: By my troth, I take my young lord to be a verymelancholy man.
t: Truthfully, I think my young lord is a very melancholy man.

og: By what observance, I pray you?
t: Based on what, may I ask?

og: Why, he will look upon his boot and sing; mend the  ruff and sing; ask questions and sing; pick his  teeth and sing.
t: Why, he tends to look at his boot and sing, mend his ruff and sing, ask questions and sing, pick his teeth and sing.

og: I know a man that had this trick of  melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.
t: I know a man that had this melancholic trait and sold a vast manor in exchange for a song.

og: Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.
t: Let me see what he writes and when he means to come home.

og: I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court:
t: I haven't been very interested in Isbel since I was at court.

og: our  old lings and our Isbels o' the country are nothing  like your old ling and your Isbels o' the court:
t: Our old fish and our Isbels in the country are nothing compared to your old fish and your Isbels at the court.

og: the brains of my Cupid's knocked out, and I begin to  love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.
t: The brains of my heart's been knocked out, and I've started to love her, as an old man loves his money, with no appetite.

og: What have we here?
t: What have we here?

og: E'en that you have there.
t: Whatever it is that you have there.

og: I have sent you a daughter-in-law:
t: "I have sent you a daughter-in-law.

og: she hath  recovered the king, and undone me.
t: She has healed the king and ruined me.

og: I have wedded  her, not bedded her; and sworn to make the 'not'  eternal.
t: I have married her but not slept with her, and I've sworn to make that 'not' last forever.

og: You shall hear I am run away: know it  before the report come.
t: You shall hear that I've run away. I want you to know it before you hear the report.

og: If there be breadth enough  in the world, I will hold a long distance.
t: As long as there are more miles in the world, I will stay far away.

og: My duty  to you. Your unfortunate son,  BERTRAM.
t: I pledge my duty to you. Your unfortunate son, Bertram."

og: O madam, yonder is heavy news within between twosoldiers and my young lady!
t: Oh madam, over there comes heavy news shared between two soldiers and the young lady!

og: What is the matter?
t: What's the matter?

og: Nay, there is some comfort in the news, somecomfort; your son will not be killed so soon as Ithought he would.
t: No, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort. Your son won't be killed as soon as I expected he would.

og: Why should he be killed?
t: Why should he be killed?

og: So say I, madam,  if he run away, as I hear he does:
t: Well, that's what I say, madam, if he runs away as I hear he does.

og: the danger is in standing to't;
t: The danger is in standing erect and fighting.

og: that's the loss of  men, though it be the getting of children.
t: That's how men die, although standing erect can also lead to fathering children.

og: Here  they come will tell you more:
t: They're coming now and they'll tell you more.

og: for my part, I only  hear your son was run away.
t: For my part, I only heard your son had run away.

og: Save you, good madam.
t: I hope you're well, good madam.

og: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.
t: Madam, my lord is gone, forever gone.

og: Do not say so.
t: Don't say so.

og: Think upon patience.
t: Be patient.

og: Pray you, gentlemen,  I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief,
t: Please, gentlemen, I have been pushed back and forth between joy and grief in such fits and stars,

og: That the first face of neither, on the start,  Can woman me unto't:
t: that I can barely take in the sudden announcement of either one of them and react like a woman.

og: where is my son, I pray you?
t: Where is my son, pray tell?

og: Madam, he's gone to serve the duke of Florence:
t: Madam, he's gone to serve the Duke of Florence.

og: We met him thitherward;
t: We met him on his way there.

og: for thence we came,  And, after some dispatch in hand at court,  Thither we bend again.
t: From there we came, and, now that we've taken care of some necessary things at court, we go back there again.

og: Look on his letter, madam; here's my passport.
t: Look at his letter, madam. Here's my dismissal.

og: When thou canst get the ring upon my finger which  never shall come off,
t: "When you can get the ring off my finger which will never come off,

og: and show me a child begotten  of thy body that I am father to, then call me  husband:
t: and when you can show me a child born from your body that I am the father to, then you can call me husband.

og: but in such a 'then' I write a 'never.'
t: But I write a 'never' on top of this 'then.'"

og: This is a dreadful sentence.
t: This is a terrible sentence.

og: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?
t: You brought this letter, gentlemen?

og: Ay, madam;And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pain.
t: Yes, madam. And we're very sorry to have done so given the contents.

og: I prithee, lady, have a better cheer;
t: I plead with you, lady, cheer up.

og: If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine,  Thou robb'st me of a moiety:
t: If you claim that the only griefs are yours, you steal a right from me too.

og: he was my son;  But I do wash his name out of my blood,  And thou art all my child.
t: He was my son, but I wash his name out of my blood, and you are my only child.

og: Towards Florence is he?
t: He's gone to Florence?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: And to be a soldier?
t: And to become a soldier?

og: Such is his noble purpose; and believe 't,The duke will lay upon him all the honourThat good convenience claims.
t: That's his noble purpose, and you can believe that the duke will bestow him with all the honors that the moment makes suitable.

og: Return you thither?
t: You're returning there?

og: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.
t: Yes, madam, as fast as we can.

og: Till I have no wife I have nothing in France.'Tis bitter.
t: "Until I have no wife, I have nothing in France." It's bitter.

og: Find you that there?
t: Was that written in the letter?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: 'Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply, which hisheart was not consenting to.
t: It's but the rashness of his hand, maybe, and his heart doesn't go along with it.

og: Nothing in France, until he have no wife!
t: Nothing in France until he has no wife!

og: There's nothing here that is too good for him  But only she;
t: There's nothing in France that is too good for him except her.

og: and she deserves a lord  That twenty such rude boys might tend upon  And call her hourly mistress.
t: She deserves a lord that would have more than twenty servant boys waiting upon her and calling her "mistress" every hour.

og: Who was with him?
t: Who was with him?

og: A servant only, and a gentlemanWhich I have sometime known.
t: Just a servant, and a gentleman who I've met a few times.

og: Parolles, was it not?
t: Parolles, wasn't it?

og: Ay, my good lady, he.
t: Yes, my good lady, it was him.

og: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.My son corrupts a well-derived natureWith his inducement.
t: A very foul fellow, and full of wickedness. My son corrupts his formerly moral nature by spending time with Parolles.

og: Indeed, good lady,The fellow has a deal of that too much,Which holds him much to have.
t: Indeed, good lady. The fellow has a very persuasive power that leads men to corrupt themselves.

og: You're welcome, gentlemen.
t: You're welcome, gentlemen.

og: I will entreat you, when you see my son,  To tell him that his sword can never win  The honour that he loses:
t: I will ask you that, when you see my son, to tell him that his sword can never earn him the honor that he's given up.

og: more I'll entreat you  Written to bear along.
t: I'll also ask you to bring along a letter.

og: We serve you, madam,In that and all your worthiest affairs.
t: We serve you, madam, in that and all your affairs where we can be of service.

og: Not so, but as we change our courtesies.Will you draw near!
t: Not really, only in exchanging courtesies. Will you come along with me?

og: 'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.'
t: "Until I have no wife, I have nothing in France."

og: Nothing in France, until he has no wife!
t: Nothing in France until he has no wife!

og: Thou shalt have none, Rousillon, none in France;  Then hast thou all again.
t: You will have no wife, Rousillon, none in France. Then you'll have everything back again.

og: Poor lord! is't I  That chase thee from thy country and expose  Those tender limbs of thine to the event  Of the none-sparing war?
t: Poor lord! Is it I that makes you flee from your country and expose your tender limbs to the violence of this destructive war?

og: and is it I  That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou  Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark  Of smoky muskets?
t: And is it I that drives you out of the leisurely court, where you were only shot at by the eyes of fair ladies, now to be the target of smoky muskets?

og: O you leaden messengers,  That ride upon the violent speed of fire,  Fly with false aim;
t: Oh, you bullets, that violently speed from weapons, miss your targets.

og: move the still-peering air,  That sings with piercing;
t: Move the torn air that sings from being pierced by bullets again and again.

og: do not touch my lord.
t: Do not touch my lord.

og: Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
t: Whoever shoots at him, it's my fault that he's there.

og: Whoever charges on his forward breast,  I am the caitiff that do hold him to't;
t: Whoever charges towards him, I am the wretch that keeps him on the battlefield.

og: And, though I kill him not, I am the cause  His death was so effected:
t: And even though I won't be the one to kill him, I'll be the reason for his death.

og: better 'twere  I met the ravin lion when he roar'd  With sharp constraint of hunger;
t: I'd rather meet a ravenous lion when he was roaring with violent hunger.

og: better 'twere  That all the miseries which nature owes  Were mine at once.
t: I'd rather all the miseries that nature can deliver were rained down on me all at once.

og: No, come thou home, Rousillon,  Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,  As oft it loses all:
t: No, come home, Rousillon, where danger only leaves the honorable men with scars, and never takes their lives.

og: I will be gone;
t: I will be gone.

og: My being here it is that holds thee hence:
t: My staying here is what keeps you in the war.

og: Shall I stay here to do't?
t: Shall I stay here to let you die?

og: no, no, although  The air of paradise did fan the house  And angels officed all:
t: No, no, not even if the air from paradise filled the house and angels flocked into it.

og: I will be gone,  That pitiful rumour may report my flight,  To consolate thine ear.
t: I will be gone so that a rumor can spread that I have fled and that will reach your ear.

og: Come, night; end, day!  For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away.
t: Come, night. End, day! With the dark, that poor thief of daylight, I'll steal away.

og: The general of our horse thou art; and we,Great in our hope, lay our best love and credenceUpon thy promising fortune.
t: You're now commander of the cavalry. We're putting all our hope, love, and belief in your great potential.

og: Sir, it is  A charge too heavy for my strength,
t: Sir, that's too weighty an honor for my little worth,

og: but yet  We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake  To the extreme edge of hazard.
t: but still I'll try to bear it for your sake, even to the death.

og: Then go thou forth;And fortune play upon thy prosperous helm,As thy auspicious mistress!
t: Then go forth, Bertram. May good fortune be on your side, following your helmet, like a devoted mistress!

og: This very day,  Great Mars, I put myself into thy file:
t: This very day, great Mars, god of war, I declare myself one of your soldiers.

og: Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove  A lover of thy drum, hater of love.
t: Make me as warlike as my thoughts, and I'll prove to be a lover of the drums of battle and a hater of gentle love.

og: Alas! and would you take the letter of her?Might you not know she would do as she has done,By sending me a letter? Read it again.
t: Oh no! And you took the letter from her? Didn't you figure out what she was going to do when she gave you a letter to send to me? Read it again.

og: I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone:
t: "I am a pilgrim of Saint Jaques, gone on a pilgrimage.

og: Ambitious love hath so in me offended,  That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,  With sainted vow my faults to have amended.
t: My love for a man above my station has caused so much pain that I will walk the cold ground barefoot and try to make amends for my faults with prayers to the saints.

og: Write, write, that from the bloody course of war  My dearest master, your dear son, may hie:  Bless him at home in peace,
t: Write, write to my dearest husband, your dear son, so that he can leave the war as soon as possible. He can come home to live in peace with your blessing

og: whilst I from far  His name with zealous fervor sanctify:
t: while I wander far away to pray and honor his name.

og: His taken labours bid him me forgive;
t: Ask him to forgive me for forcing him to go to war.

og: I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth  From courtly friends, with camping foes to live,  Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth:
t: It's because of me, his wicked Juno, that he left his friends at court, taking up camp closer to his enemies, where great men are pursued by death and danger.

og: He is too good and fair for death and me:  Whom I myself embrace, to set him free.
t: He is too good and just for me and for death. Now I embrace death myself in order to set him free."

og: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
t: Oh, how sharply even her mildest words sting me!

og: Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much,  As letting her pass so:
t: Rinaldo, you've never made such an awful mistake as letting her leave like this.

og: had I spoke with her,  I could have well diverted her intents,  Which thus she hath prevented.
t: If I had spoken with her, I could have changed her mind, but she's prevented me from interfering this way.

og: Pardon me, madam:
t: I'm sorry, madam.

og: If I had given you this at over-night,  She might have been o'erta'en;
t: If I had given this to you in the middle of the night, she might have been overtaken.

og: and yet she writes,  Pursuit would be but vain.
t: At the same time, she writes that pursuing her would be in vain.

og: What angel shall  Bless this unworthy husband?
t: What angel will bless this unworthy husband of hers?

og: he cannot thrive,  Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear  And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath  Of greatest justice.
t: He cannot expect salvation, unless her prayers, which God will delight to hear and surely will grant, save him from damnation.

og: Write, write, Rinaldo,  To this unworthy husband of his wife;
t: Write, write, Rinaldo, to Helena's unworthy husband.

og: Let every word weigh heavy of her worth  That he does weigh too light:
t: In every word, make it clear how much she's worth and how little he values her.

og: my greatest grief.
t: That's my greatest sorrow.

og: Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
t: He won't care much, but write it down harshly.

og: Dispatch the most convenient messenger:
t: Then get the fastest messenger.

og: When haply he shall hear that she is gone,  He will return;
t: When he hears that she's gone, he'll happily come back.

og: and hope I may that she,  Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,  Led hither by pure love.
t: I really do hope that when she hears he's come home, she'll run back to him, spurred on by her pure love.

og: Which of them both  Is dearest to me, I have no skill in sense  To make distinction.
t: I really couldn't say which of Helena and Bertram is dearest to me.

og: Provide this messenger.
t: Go get this messenger.

og: My heart is heavy and mine age is weak.
t: My heart is heavy and I'm feeling my age.

og: Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.
t: Such grief demands my tears, and this sorrow compels me to speak my mind.

og: Nay, come; for if they do approach the city, weshall lose all the sight.
t: No, come, because if they do come towards the city, we won't be able to see them.

og: They say the French count has done most honourable service.
t: They say the French count has served very honorably.

og: It is reported that he has taken their greatestcommander; and that with his own hand he slew theduke's brother.
t: It's been reported that he has captured their greatest commander and that he slew the duke's brother himself.

og: We have lost our labour; they are gone a contraryway: hark! you may know by their trumpets.
t: We've missed our chance. They've gone a different way. Listen! You can hear where they are from their trumpets.

og: Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves with  the report of it.
t: Come, let's return again, and be satisfied just hearing a report of it.

og: Well, Diana, take heed of this  French earl:
t: Well, Diana, beware this French earl.

og: the honour of a maid is her name; and  no legacy is so rich as honesty.
t: A virgin's honor is like her name and no legacy is as rich as honesty.

og: I have told my neighbour how you have been solicitedby a gentleman his companion.
t: I told my neighbor how you've been propositioned by the gentleman who's the earl's companion.

og: I know that knave; hang him!
t: I know that scoundrel. Hang him!

og: one Parolles: a  filthy officer he is in those suggestions for the  young earl.
t: His name's Parolles. What a filthy officer to urge the young earl to behave so immorally.

og: Beware of them, Diana; their promises,  enticements, oaths, tokens, and all these engines of  lust, are not the things they go under:
t: Beware of them, Diana. Their promises, gifts, oaths, tokens, and all these things driven by lust, are not what they seem.

og: many a maid  hath been seduced by them;
t: Many an innocent young lady has been seduced by them.

og: and the misery is,  example, that so terrible shows in the wreck of  maidenhood,
t: What's terrible about it is that, as horrible as these stories of lost chastity might be,

og: cannot for all that dissuade succession,  but that they are limed with the twigs that threaten  them.
t: they can't dissuade other women from falling prey in the same way because so many women give into seductive men as easily as birds fall into traps.

og: I hope I need not to advise you further;
t: I hope I won't need to give you further advice

og: but  I hope your own grace will keep you where you are,  though there were no further danger known but the  modesty which is so lost.
t: but that your own grace will keep you pure even if the worst that could happen is that you'd lose your modest reputation.

og: You shall not need to fear me.
t: You don't need to worry about me being fooled.

og: I hope so.
t: I hope not.

og: Look, here comes a pilgrim: I know she will lie atmy house; thither they send one another: I'llquestion her. God save you, pilgrim! whither are you bound?
t: Look, here comes a pilgrim. I'm sure she'll want to sleep at my house. They are always sending each other here. I'll question her. God save you, pilgrim! Where are you heading?

og: To Saint Jaques le Grand.Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?
t: To Saint Jaques le Grand. Where do the pilgrims stay, could you tell me, please?

og: At the Saint Francis here beside the port.
t: At the inn with the sign of Saint Francis here near the port.

og: Is this the way?
t: Is this the way?

og: Ay, marry, is't.
t: Yes, it certainly is.

og: Hark you! they come this way.
t: Listen up! They're coming this way.

og: If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,  But till the troops come by,  I will conduct you where you shall be lodged;
t: If you will wait around, holy pilgrim, just until the troops have walked by, I'll bring you to where you'll stay.

og: The rather, for I think I know your hostess  As ample as myself.
t: I'm suited for this job since I think I know your hostess there as well as I know myself.

og: Is it yourself?
t: Is it yourself?

og: If you shall please so, pilgrim.
t: If that's all right with you, pilgrim.

og: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.
t: I thank you, and I'll wait until it's a good time for you.

og: You came, I think, from France?
t: You came, I think, from France?

og: I did so.
t: I did.

og: Here you shall see a countryman of yoursThat has done worthy service.
t: Here you're about to see a countryman of yours that has served worthily.

og: His name, I pray you.
t: His name, tell me.

og: The Count Rousillon: know you such a one?
t: The Count Rousillon. Do you know him?

og: But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him:His face I know not.
t: Just by word-of-mouth. One hears noble things about him. I don't know what he looks like.

og: Whatsome'er he is,  He's bravely taken here.
t: Whatever else he is, he's been a brave soldier.

og: He stole from France,  As 'tis reported, for the king had married him  Against his liking:
t: He fled from France, as it's reported, because the king had made him marry a bride he didn't like.

og: think you it is so?
t: Do you think that's true?

og: Ay, surely, mere the truth: I know his lady.
t: Yes, surely, it's absolutely the truth. I know his wife.

og: There is a gentleman that serves the countReports but coarsely of her.
t: There is a gentleman who serves the count who only reports rude things about her.

og: What's his name?
t: What's his name?

og: Monsieur Parolles.
t: Mister Parolles.

og: O, I believe with him,
t: Oh, I agree with him,

og: In argument of praise, or to the worth  Of the great count himself, she is too mean  To have her name repeated:
t: in terms of praise, or in terms of the worth of the great count himself, she is too lowly to have her name repeated.

og: all her deserving  Is a reserved honesty, and that  I have not heard examined.
t: All that she has of value is her honesty, and I don't know if even that has been examined.

og: Alas, poor lady!'Tis a hard bondage to become the wifeOf a detesting lord.
t: Alas, poor lady! It's a hard bondage to become the wife of a lord who detests you.

og: I warrant, good creature, wheresoe'er she is,Her heart weighs sadly: this young maid might do herA shrewd turn, if she pleased.
t: I assume, good creature, wherever she may be, her heart is heavy. This young maid here might do her a great wrong if she wanted to.

og: How do you mean?May be the amorous count solicits herIn the unlawful purpose.
t: What do you mean? Maybe the loving count is trying to seduce her?

og: He does indeed;
t: He is indeed.

og: And brokes with all that can in such a suit  Corrupt the tender honour of a maid:
t: And he comes with full force on this mission to corrupt the tender honor of a virgin.

og: But she is arm'd for him and keeps her guard  In honestest defence.
t: But she is prepared for him and keeps her guard up in honest defense.

og: The gods forbid else!
t: The gods forbid she do otherwise!

og: So, now they come:
t: So, now they come.

og: That is Antonio, the duke's eldest son;That, Escalus.
t: That is Antonio, the duke's eldest son. That one's Escalus.

og: Which is the Frenchman?
t: Which one is the Frenchman?

og: He;  That with the plume:
t: Him. That one with the plume.

og: 'tis a most gallant fellow.  I would he loved his wife:
t: He's a very well-dressed fellow. I wish he loved his wife.

og: if he were honester  He were much goodlier:
t: If he were more honest, he would be much more appealing;

og: is't not a handsome gentleman?
t: but still, is he not a handsome man?

og: I like him well.
t: I like his looks.

og: 'Tis pity he is not honest: yond's that same knaveThat leads him to these places: were I his lady,I would Poison that vile rascal.
t: It's a pity he's not honest. There's the same rogue that takes him to these places. If I were his wife, I would poison that vile rascal.

og: Which is he?
t: Which one's he?

og: That jack-an-apes with scarfs: why is he melancholy?
t: That silly looking man in the scarves. Why is he melancholy?

og: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.
t: Maybe he got hurt in the battle.

og: Lose our drum! well.
t: Lose our drum! Well.

og: He's shrewdly vexed at something: look, he has spied us.
t: He's clearly upset about something. Look, he's seen us.

og: Marry, hang you!
t: Well, hang him!

og: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!
t: And his manners, the dirty deceiver!

og: The troop is past.
t: The troop's gone past.

og: Come, pilgrim, I will bring you  Where you shall host:
t: Come, pilgrim, I'll bring you to where you will stay.

og: of enjoin'd penitents  There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,  Already at my house.
t: There's already four or five pilgrims bound for Saint Jaques staying at my house.

og: I humbly thank you:
t: I thank you humbly.

og: Please it this matron and this gentle maid  To eat with us to-night,
t: I hope this woman and this gentle maid will eat with us tonight.

og: the charge and thanking  Shall be for me;
t: I'll gladly pay for the meal,

og: and, to requite you further,  I will bestow some precepts of this virgin  Worthy the note.
t: and, to pay you further, I'll share some advice with this virgin that will be worth hearing.

og: We'll take your offer kindly.
t: We'll take your offer gratefully.

og: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have hisway.
t: No, my good lord, put him to the test. Let him be examined.

og: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me nomore in your respect.
t: If your lordship doesn't find him to be a worthless nothing, don't respect me any longer.

og: On my life, my lord, a bubble.
t: On my life, my lord, he'll prove to be nothing but a bubble.

og: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?
t: You really think I'm so completely deceived by him?

og: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,  without any malice, but to speak of him as my  kinsman,
t: Believe it, my lord, based on my own personal knowledge, without any ill will, but to speak of him as I would speak of a family member:

og: he's a most notable coward, an infinite and  endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker,
t: he's a real coward, an infinite and endless liar, he breaks promises every hour,

og: the owner  of no one good quality worthy your lordship's  entertainment.
t: and he doesn't have one good quality worthy of following your lordship.

og: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far inhis virtue, which he hath not, he might at somegreat and trusty business in a main danger fail you.
t: It would be best that you know him as he is. Otherwise, if you're too trusting of his virtue, which he doesn't have, he might fail you at some great and important moment.

og: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.
t: I wish I could think of a particular way to test him.

og: None better than to let him fetch off his drum,which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.
t: There's no better way than to let him fetch back his lost drum which we've all heard him so confidently say he'll do.

og: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly  surprise him;
t: Along with a troop of Florentines, I'll suddenly ambush him.

og: such I will have, whom I am sure he  knows not from the enemy:
t: I'll bring the men I have that he won't be able to tell apart from the enemy.

og: we will bind and hoodwink  him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he  is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when  we bring him to our own tents.
t: We'll bind him and blindfold him so that he'll think he's been brought into enemy territory, when we're really bringing him into our own tents.

og: Be but your lordship  present at his examination:
t: Your lordship will be present at his examination.

og: if he do not, for the  promise of his life and in the highest compulsion of  base fear, offer to betray you and deliver all the  intelligence in his power against you,
t: If he doesn't, in order to save his life and out of extraordinary fear, offer to betray you and inform against you with all the intelligence he can share,

og: and that with  the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never  trust my judgment in any thing.
t: after swearing that everything he says is true, don't trust my judgement in anything ever again.

og: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum;
t: Oh, since we love to laugh, let him try to fetch his drum back.

og: he says he has a stratagem for't:
t: He says he has a plan to do it.

og: when your  lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to  what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be  melted,
t: When your lordship sees his failure in trying to get it back, and how this fake lump of ore melts down when the truth comes out,

og: if you give him not John Drum's  entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed.
t: if you don't kick him out, it will only be because of a tremendous bias in his favor.

og: Here he comes.
t: Here he comes.

og: O, for the love of laughter,hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetchoff his drum in any hand.
t: Oh, since we love to laugh, don't try to stop his ludicrous plans. Let him try to fetch the drum how ever he sees fit.

og: How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in yourdisposition.
t: How now, monsieur! This situation with the drum is making you moody.

og: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.
t: Just move on, get over it, it's only a drum.

og: 'But a drum'! is't 'but a drum'? A drum so lost!There was excellent command,—to charge in with ourhorse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!
t: "Only a drum!" Is it "only a drum?" A drum lost in this way! What an excellent command—to charge right into battle with the cavalry coming in on either side, and to divide our own soldiers!

og: That was not to be blamed in the command of the  service:
t: That's not the fault of the commander of the service.

og: it was a disaster of war that Caesar  himself could not have prevented, if he had been  there to command.
t: It was a war disaster that not even Caesar could have prevented if he had ben there to command.

og: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: somedishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it isnot to be recovered.
t: Well, we cannot be too upset about our success. We had a little bit of dishonor in losing that drum, but there's no way it can be stolen back.

og: It might have been recovered.
t: It might have been stolen back.

og: It might; but it is not now.
t: It might have, but there's no way now.

og: It is to be recovered:
t: It is to be taken back.

og: but that the merit of  service is seldom attributed to the true and exact  performer,
t: If it weren't that tasks are almost never assigned to the person most capable of carrying them out,

og: I would have that drum or another, or  'hic jacet.'
t: I would have that drum back or another one, or I'd die trying.

og: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur:
t: Well, if you have the bravery for it, monsieur.

og: if you  think your mystery in stratagem can bring this  instrument of honour again into his native quarter,  be magnanimous in the enterprise and go on;
t: If you think your mysterious strategy can bring this honorable instrument back again to its troops, be generous in the attempt and go on.

og: I will  grace the attempt for a worthy exploit:
t: I will report the attempt as a worthy one.

og: if you  speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it.  and extend to you what further becomes his  greatness,
t: If you succeed in it, the duke shall not only speak of it but also grant you with whatever else his greatness thinks you deserve,

og: even to the utmost syllable of your  worthiness.
t: every last drop that you are worthy of.

og: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.
t: By the hand of a soldier, I will do this.

og: But you must not now slumber in it.
t: But now you must sleep on it.

og: I'll about it this evening:
t: I'll do it this evening.

og: and I will presently  pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my  certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation;
t: And I will now write down my concerns, encourage myself in my sure success, arm myself and prepare for death.

og: and by midnight look to hear further from me.
t: By midnight, look to hear more from me.

og: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?
t: Can I be so bold to tell his grace that you are going to attempt this?

og: I know not what the success will be, my lord; butthe attempt I vow.
t: I don't know if I'll be successful, my lord, but I vow that I will attempt it.

og: I know thou'rt valiant; and, to the possibility ofthy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.
t: I know you are valiant, and I'll support you when I speak of your soldierly ability. Farewell.

og: I love not many words.
t: I do not love speaking at length.

og: No more than a fish loves water.
t: Sure, no more than a fish loves water.

og: Is not this a  strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems  to undertake this business, which he knows is not to  be done;
t: Isn't this a strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently claims to take on this task, which he knows he won't actually do?

og: damns himself to do and dares better be  damned than to do't?
t: He condemns himself to do it when he'd rather be damned than actually attempt to carry it out?

og: You do not know him, my lord, as we do:
t: You don't know him, my lord, as we do.

og: certain it  is that he will steal himself into a man's favour and  for a week escape a great deal of discoveries;
t: It's certain that he'll convince some man to cover for him and no one will discover the truth for a week.

og: but  when you find him out, you have him ever after.
t: But once you've found him out, you'll have him disgraced forever after.

og: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all ofthis that so seriously he does address himself unto?
t: Why, do you think he will really make no attempt at all to do this thing he so seriously vows to do?

og: None in the world;
t: No attempt in the world.

og: but return with an invention and  clap upon you two or three probable lies:
t: He'll return instead with some story and tell you two or three probable lies.

og: but we  have almost embossed him;
t: But we've almost caught him.

og: you shall see his fall  to-night; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.
t: You'll see his downfall tonight, for indeed he is not worthy of your lord's respect.

og: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case  him.
t: We'll have you watch some sport with the fox before we reveal him.

og: He was first smoked by the old lord Lafeu:
t: He was first caught in the act of lying by the old lord Lafeu.

og: when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a  sprat you shall find him;
t: When he's finally parted from his disguise, tell me what a fool you take him for.

og: which you shall see this  very night.
t: You'll see it this very night.

og: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.
t: I must go prepare the trap. He'll be caught.

og: Your brother he shall go along with me.
t: Your brother shall go along with me.

og: As't please your lordship: I'll leave you.
t: As your lordship requests. I'll leave you.

og: Now will I lead you to the house, and show youThe lass I spoke of.
t: Now I'l lead you to the house and show you the lady I was telling you about.

og: But you say she's honest.
t: But you say she's honest.

og: That's all the fault:
t: That's the whole problem.

og: I spoke with her but once  And found her wondrous cold;
t: I spoke with her once and found her incredibly cold.

og: but I sent to her,  By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind,  Tokens and letters which she did re-send;
t: But I sent to her, via this same fool that we're about to play a trick on, some tokens and letters which she sent back.

og: And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature:
t: This is all I've done. She's a pretty creature.

og: Will you go see her?
t: Will you go see her?

og: With all my heart, my lord.
t: With all my heart, my lord.

og: If you misdoubt me that I am not she,I know not how I shall assure you further,But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.
t: If you doubt that I'm she, I don't know how else I'll prove it to you further without ruining my whole plan.

og: Though my estate be fallen, I was well born,  Nothing acquainted with these businesses;
t: Although I've fallen in society, I was well born, nothing to do with these seedy businesses.

og: And would not put my reputation now  In any staining act.
t: I wouldn't put my reputation at risk now by committing any scandalous act.

og: Nor would I wish you.
t: Nor would I wish you to do so.

og: First, give me trust, the count he is my husband,  And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken  Is so from word to word;
t: First, trust me, the count is my husband, and what I've spoken to your sworn secrecy is true to the very word.

og: and then you cannot,  By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,  Err in bestowing it.
t: You cannot do wrong by offering to help me.

og: I should believe you:For you have show'd me that which well approvesYou're great in fortune.
t: I'm led to believe you for you've shown me things that convincingly demonstrate that you have a great fortune.

og: Take this purse of gold,  And let me buy your friendly help thus far,
t: Take this purse of gold, and let me pay for your help so far,

og: Which I will over-pay and pay again  When I have found it.
t: which I'll over-pay and pay over again once your help is complete.

og: The count he wooes your daughter,  Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
t: The count woos your daughter, attempts to capture her beauty.

og: Resolved to carry her:
t: He is resolved to conquer her.

og: let her in fine consent,  As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it.
t: Let her consent, as we'll tell her exactly how it's best to word it.

og: Now his important blood will nought deny  That she'll demand:
t: Now his lustful blood will never deny what she demands:

og: a ring the county wears,  That downward hath succeeded in his house  From son to son,
t: a ring the count wears, that has been passed down in his house from son to son,

og: some four or five descents  Since the first father wore it:
t: some four or five generations since the first ancestor wore it.

og: this ring he holds  In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire,  To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,  Howe'er repented after.
t: This ring he holds very dearly, but in his idle passion, to buy what he wants from her, it would not seem too priceless, however much he regrets it after.

og: Now I seeThe bottom of your purpose.
t: Now I see the endgame of your plan.

og: You see it lawful, then:
t: You see that it's lawful then.

og: it is no more,  But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,  Desires this ring;
t: It's nothing more but that your daughter, before she agrees to be won by him, requests this ring.

og: appoints him an encounter;
t: Then she schedules an encounter with him.

og: In fine, delivers me to fill the time,  Herself most chastely absent:
t: In short, she brings me instead to fill the bed, and she's entirely absent and chaste.

og: after this,  To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns  To what is passed already.
t: After this, as a dowry, I'll add three thousand crowns to what I've already given you.

og: I have yielded:
t: I'm sold.

og: Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,  That time and place with this deceit so lawful  May prove coherent.
t: Instruct my daughter on how she will do this so that the time and place for this lawful trick will all be successful.

og: Every night he comes  With musics of all sorts and songs composed  To her unworthiness:
t: Every night he comes with all sorts of music and songs composed to her unworthy self.

og: it nothing steads us  To chide him from our eaves; for he persists  As if his life lay on't.
t: It doesn't do anything for us to tell him to get away from our house as he persists as if his life hangs in the balance.

og: Why then to-night  Let us assay our plot;
t: Why then, tonight, we'll lay our plot.

og: which, if it speed,  Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed  And lawful meaning in a lawful act,
t: If it goes well, it's wicked intention but lawful action for Bertram and lawful intention and lawful action for me.

og: Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact:
t: Therefore, neither of us will sin, and yet he'll think it to be a sinful act.

og: But let's about it.
t: But let's get to it.

og: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
t: There's no other way that he can come except by these bushes.

og: When you sally upon him, speak what terrible  language you will:
t: When you ambush him, speak whatever terrible language you can.

og: though you understand it not  yourselves, no matter;
t: If you don't even understand the language you're speaking, it doesn't matter.

og: for we must not seem to  understand him, unless some one among us whom we  must produce for an interpreter.
t: We must not seem to be able to understand him except for one among us whom we put forward as our interpreter.

og: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.
t: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

og: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?
t: Don't you know him? Doesn't he know your voice?

og: No, sir, I warrant you.
t: No, sir, I promise you.

og: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?
t: But what nonsense language do you have to speak back to us?

og: E'en such as you speak to me.
t: Whatever nonsense language you speak to me.

og: He must think us some band of strangers i' the  adversary's entertainment.
t: He must be convinced that we're some group of strangers connected to our enemy.

og: Now he hath a smack of  all neighbouring languages;
t: He knows a little bit of the neighboring language.

og: therefore we must every  one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we  speak one to another;
t: Therefore we all must each speak whatever random language we know and not know what we're saying to each other.

og: so we seem to know, is to  know straight our purpose:
t: As long as we pretend to understand each other, our purpose will be served.

og: choughs' language,  gabble enough, and good enough.
t: Chatter like a crow, gabble like a goose, and that's good enough.

og: As for you,  interpreter, you must seem very politic.
t: As for you, interpreter, you must seem very wise.

og: But couch,  ho!
t: But hold, hey!

og: here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep,  and then to return and swear the lies he forges.
t: Here he comes, to sleep for two hours and then to return and swear to the lies he makes up.

og: Ten o'clock:
t: Ten o'clock.

og: within these three hours 'twill be  time enough to go home.
t: Within three hours I'll have stayed away long enough to go home.

og: What shall I say I have  done? It must be a very plausive invention that  carries it:
t: What shall I say I have done? It must be a very plausible story that I tell.

og: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces  have of late knocked too often at my door.
t: They're beginning to suspect me, and I've lately had too many disgraces.

og: I find  my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the  fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not  daring the reports of my tongue.
t: I find that my tongue says whatever it wants, but my heart is afraid of Mars, the god of war, and all his soldiers, regardless of the stories my tongue tells.

og: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tonguewas guilty of.
t: This is the first truth that your tongue has ever been guilty of.

og: What the devil should move me to undertake the  recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the  impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose?
t: What the devil would make me attempt to get back this drum since I know it's impossible and I have no reason to go after it?

og: I  must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in  exploit:
t: I must inflict some wounds on myself and say I got them in the attempt.

og: yet slight ones will not carry it;
t: Minor wounds won't be convincing;

og: they  will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great  ones I dare not give.
t: they would say, "You escaped with just a little scratch?" and I don't dare to give myself serious wounds.

og: Wherefore, what's the  instance?
t: Why, what's the evidence?

og: Tongue, I must put you into a  butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of  Bajazeth's mule,
t: Tongue, I must put you into the mouth of a dairy-woman and buy myself another one of Bajazeth's mules,

og: if you prattle me into these perils.
t: if you keep talking me into these dangerous situations.

og: Is it possible he should know what he is, and bethat he is?
t: Is it possible he should know what he's like and still behave the way that he does?

og: I would the cutting of my garments would serve theturn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.
t: I'm thinking maybe cutting my garments would do the trick, or breaking my Spanish sword.

og: We cannot afford you so.
t: The army can't afford that.

og: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was instratagem.
t: Or cutting off my beard and saying I lost it in a fight.

og: 'Twould not do.
t: That wouldn't do.

og: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.
t: Or to drown my clothes and say they were stripped off me.

og: Hardly serve.
t: That would hardly serve.

og: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.
t: And I'd swear that I leapt from the window of the fortress.

og: How deep?
t: How deep?

og: Thirty fathom.
t: Thirty fathoms.

og: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.
t: Even if you swore three great oaths, that would hardly be believable.

og: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swearI recovered it.
t: I wish I had any drum belonging to the enemy. I would swear I had stolen it back.

og: You shall hear one anon.
t: You'll hear one soon.

og: A drum now of the enemy's,—
t: A drum now of the enemy's—

og: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.
t: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

og: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.
t: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

og: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.
t: Oh, I'll pay ransom, I'll pay ransom! Don't cover my eyes!

og: Boskos thromuldo boskos.
t: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

og: I know you are the Muskos' regiment:
t: I know you are the Muscovite regiment.

og: And I shall lose my life for want of language;
t: And I shall lose my life since I don't speak the language.

og: If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,  Italian, or French, let him speak to me;
t: If anyone here is German or Danish, Dutch, Italian, or French, let him speak to me.

og: I'll  Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.
t: I'll reveal a secret that will destroy the Florentine.

og: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speakthy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thyfaith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.
t: Boskos vauvado. I understand you and I can speak your language. Kerely bonto, sir, you'd better pay for seventeen swords are pointed at your chest.

og: O!
t: Oh!

og: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.
t: Oh, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

og: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.
t: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

og: The general is content to spare thee yet;
t: The general is still content to spare you.

og: And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on  To gather from thee:
t: And, blindfolded as you are, will lead you on to get information from you.

og: haply thou mayst inform  Something to save thy life.
t: Maybe you can share information that will save your life.

og: O, let me live!
t: Oh, let me live!
