og: And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,  Their force, their purposes;
t: And I'll reveal all the secrets of our army. How many men there are, what our plans are.

og: nay, I'll speak that  Which you will wonder at.
t: No, I'll speak things that you will wonder at.

og: But wilt thou faithfully?
t: But will you do so honestly?

og: If I do not, damn me.
t: If I don't, damn me.

og: Acordo linta.Come on; thou art granted space.
t: Acordo linta. Come on. You are granted an audience.

og: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother,We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffledTill we do hear from them.
t: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother, we have caught the fool, and will keep him tied up until we hear from them.

og: Captain, I will.
t: Captain, I will.

og: A' will betray us all unto ourselves:Inform on that.
t: He will betray us all to ourselves. Let them know that.

og: So I will, sir.
t: So I will, sir.

og: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.
t: Till then I'll keep him blindfolded and securely imprisoned.

og: They told me that your name was Fontibell.
t: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

og: No, my good lord, Diana.
t: No, my good lord, it's Diana.

og: Titled goddess;
t: You have a goddess' name.

og: And worth it, with addition!
t: And you're worth it, and then some!

og: But, fair soul,  In your fine frame hath love no quality?
t: But, fair soul, in your beautiful body, haven't you got any interest in love?

og: If quick fire of youth light not your mind,  You are no maiden, but a monument:
t: If your youthful passions don't ignite your mind, you're not a maiden but a statue:

og: When you are dead, you should be such a one  As you are now, for you are cold and stem;
t: when you're dead, you'd be just as you are now, for you are cold and stern.

og: And now you should be as your mother was  When your sweet self was got.
t: You should be like your mother was when your sweet self was conceived.

og: She then was honest.
t: She was honest then.

og: So should you be.
t: You would honest too.

og: No:My mother did but duty; such, my lord,As you owe to your wife.
t: No. My mother only did her duty. The same duty, my lord, that you owe your wife.

og: No more o' that;
t: No more of that.

og: I prithee, do not strive against my vows:
t: Please, don't fight me on the things I've sworn to you.

og: I was compell'd to her; but I love thee  By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever  Do thee all rights of service.
t: I was forced to marry her, but I love you by love's own sweet force, and I'll forever serve you.

og: Ay, so you serve us  Till we serve you;
t: Yes, you'll serve us until we've served you.

og: but when you have our roses,  You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves
t: But when you've taken the rose of our virginity, you barely leave us even with the thorns to prick ourselves,

og: And mock us with our bareness.
t: and you mock us for having nothing of value left.

og: How have I sworn!
t: Think of how much I've sworn to you!

og: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
t: Swearing many oaths doesn't make you faithful.

og: But the plain single vow that is vow'd true.
t: I'd rather you swear one plain single vow that you really mean.

og: What is not holy, that we swear not by,  But take the High'st to witness:
t: We don't swear by what's not holy, but we swear by what's most holy.

og: then, pray you, tell me,  If I should swear by God's great attributes,  I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,  When I did love you ill?
t: Then, please, tell me, if I should swear to God that I loved you dearly, would you believe my vows when I didn't really love you faithfully at all?

og: This has no holding,  To swear by him whom I protest to love,  That I will work against him:
t: What would be the value of swearing by God, who I claim to love, that I will do this evil thing against him?

og: therefore your oaths  Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd,  At least in my opinion.
t: Therefore, your oaths are just words and flimsy promises, non-binding, at least in my opinion.

og: Change it, change it;
t: Change your opinion, change it.

og: Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;  And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts  That you do charge men with.
t: Don't be so cruel in your holiness. Love is holy, and I have way too much integrity to ever be as crafty as you claim men are.

og: Stand no more off,  But give thyself unto my sick desires,  Who then recover:
t: Stop being standoffish and give yourself to my yearning desire that you can heal.

og: say thou art mine, and ever  My love as it begins shall so persever.
t: Say you're mine and my love will last forever as strong as it begins.

og: I see that men make ropes in such a snareThat we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.
t: It seems like men make ropes into such a snare that we'll give ourselves up. Give me that ring.

og: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no powerTo give it from me.
t: I'll lend it to you, my dear, but I don't have the option of giving it away.

og: Will you not, my lord?
t: Will you not, my lord?

og: It is an honour 'longing to our house,  Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
t: It's a token belonging to my house, passed down from many ancestors.

og: Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world  In me to lose.
t: It would be the greatest disgrace in the world for me to lose it.

og: Mine honour's such a ring:
t: My virginity's just such a ring.

og: My chastity's the jewel of our house,  Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
t: My chastity's the jewel of our house, passed down from many ancestors.

og: Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world  In me to lose:
t: It would be the greatest disgrace in the world for me to lose it.

og: thus your own proper wisdom  Brings in the champion Honour on my part,  Against your vain assault.
t: So, your own logic makes honor the champion on my part against your hopeless attempts to win me.

og: Here, take my ring:My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,And I'll be bid by thee.
t: Here, take my ring. My house, my honor, yes, my life, is yours, and I'll be instructed by you.

og: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:
t: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window.

og: I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
t: I'll make sure my mother won't hear.

og: Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
t: Now I'll give you instructions and you need to be true to them.

og: When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed,  Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
t: When you've conquered my still virgin bed, stay there only an hour and don't speak to me.

og: My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them  When back again this ring shall be deliver'd:
t: I have very strong reasons, and you'll know them when I deliver this ring back again.

og: And on your finger in the night I'll put  Another ring, that what in time proceeds  May token to the future our past deeds.
t: And in the middle of the night, I'll put another ring on your finger which will be a sign in the future of our past deeds.

og: Adieu, till then; then, fail not.
t: Farewell, till then. Then, don't fail in this.

og: You have won  A wife of me, though there my hope be done
t: You have won a wife of me though this will ruin me.

og: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.
t: I've won a heaven on earth by wooing you.

og: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
t: And I hope you'll live to thank heaven and me for that!

og: You may so in the end.
t: You may do so in the end

og: My mother told me just how he would woo,  As if she sat in 's heart;
t: . My mother told me exactly how he would woo, as if she'd seen into his heart.

og: she says all men  Have the like oaths
t: She says all men make the same oaths.

og: : he had sworn to marry me  When his wife's dead;
t: He had sworn to marry me when his wife was dead.

og: therefore I'll lie with him  When I am buried.
t: Therefore, I'll lie with him when I'm buried.

og: Since Frenchmen are so braid,  Marry that will, I live and die a maid:
t: Since Frenchmen are so deceitful, marry if you like, but I'll live and die a virgin.

og: Only in this disguise I think't no sin  To cozen him that would unjustly win.
t: In this context, I don't think it's a sin to trick a man who would win a woman so unjustly.

og: You have not given him his mother's letter?
t: You haven't given him his mother's letter?

og: I have delivered it an hour since: there issomething in't that stings his nature; for on thereading it he changed almost into another man.
t: I delivered it an hour ago. There is something in it that upsets him. Upon reading it, he almost changed into a different man.

og: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shakingoff so good a wife and so sweet a lady.
t: He deserves all the blame placed on him for getting rid of such a good wife and sweet lady.

og: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting  displeasure of the king,
t: Especially since he's earned the everlasting displeasure of the king,

og: who had even tuned his  bounty to sing happiness to him.
t: who had gone all out in his generosity to, and happiness for, him.

og: I will tell you a  thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.
t: I will tell you something, but you can't tell anyone.

og: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am thegrave of it.
t: When you've spoken it, it's dead, and it's buried in me.

og: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in  Florence, of a most chaste renown;
t: He has seduced a young gentlewoman here in Florence, who has a very chaste reputation.

og: and this night he  fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour:
t: This night he'll take her chastity.

og: he hath  given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself  made in the unchaste composition.
t: He's given her his ancestral ring, and he think he's definitely going to be successful in going through with it tonight.

og: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves,what things are we!
t: Now, God protect us from our fleshly desires! Without God's help, what things we turn out to be!

og: Merely our own traitors.
t: Just traitors to ourselves.

og: And as in the common course  of all treasons, we still see them reveal  themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends,
t: And, as with most acts of treason, we always see the perpetrators reveal their true natures, until they achieve their horrific goals.

og: so he that in this action contrives against his own  nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows himself.
t: In acting against his own proper noble behavior, he'll ruin himself and give himself away by talking about it.

og: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters ofour unlawful intents? We shall not then have hiscompany to-night?
t: Isn't it supposed to be sinful to go around proclaiming our immoral desires? We won't have his company tonight then?

og: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.
t: Not till after midnight. He only gets one hour.

og: That approaches apace;
t: That's coming soon.

og: I would gladly have him see  his company anatomized,
t: I would gladly have him see his companion under interrogation

og: that he might take a measure  of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had  set this counterfeit.
t: so he could make his own judgements since he's had so much faith in this liar.

og: We will not meddle with him till he come; for hispresence must be the whip of the other.
t: We won't bother with Parolles till Bertram comes. We'll start working on him when Bertram shows up.

og: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?
t: In the meantime, what have you heard of these wars?

og: I hear there is an overture of peace.
t: I've heard there's been a start to peace talks.

og: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.
t: No, I assure you, peace has been made.

og: What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travelhigher, or return again into France?
t: What will Count Rousillon do then? Will he travel onwards, or go back to France?

og: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogetherof his council.
t: I gather, by this question, that you're not a close confidant of his.

og: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great dealof his act.
t: God forbid, sir. If I were, I'd be accountable for his actions.

og: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his  house:
t: Sir, his wife fled two months ago from his house.

og: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques  le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere  sanctimony she accomplished;
t: She said she was going on a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand and she completed that holy task with impressive piety.

og: and, there residing the  tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her  grief;
t: And, while she was there, her grief overcame the tenderness in her nature.

og: in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and  now she sings in heaven.
t: In short, her last breath became a groan, and now she sings in heaven.

og: How is this justified?
t: What proof is there?

og: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which  makes her story true, even to the point of her  death:
t: Most of the proof is in her own letters, which shows her story to be true right up to her death.

og: her death itself, which could not be her  office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by  the rector of the place.
t: Her death itself, which she couldn't herself have announced, was faithfully confirmed by the rector where she was staying.

og: Hath the count all this intelligence?
t: Does the count have this information?

og: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point frompoint, so to the full arming of the verity.
t: Yes, and the specific confirmations, point by point, so all the evidence showing it to be true.

og: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.
t: I am very sorry that this news will have made him glad.

og: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!
t: Sometimes we mightily make comforts out of our losses!

og: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain  in tears!
t: And some other times we mightily drown the positives in tears!

og: The great dignity that his valour hath  here acquired for him shall at home be encountered  with a shame as ample.
t: All the great respect that his bravery has earned him here will be matched by an equal shame at home.

og: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and  ill together:
t: The web of our life is like tangled yarn, good and bad together.

og: our virtues would be proud, if our  faults whipped them not; and our crimes would  despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.
t: Our virtues would become too proud if our faults didn't attack them, and our crimes would fall into despair if they weren't embraced by your virtues.

og: How now! where's your master?
t: What's going on? Where's your master?

og: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath  taken a solemn leave:
t: He met the duke in the street, sir, and he's said farewell to him.

og: his lordship will next  morning for France.
t: His lordship will leave tomorrow morning for France.

og: The duke hath offered him  letters of commendations to the king.
t: The duke has offered him letters of praise addressed to the king.

og: They shall be no more than needful there, if theywere more than they can commend.
t: Those will definitely be necessary even if they're full of more praise than he deserves.

og: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness.Here's his lordship now.
t: They can't be sweet enough for the king's displeasure. Here's his lordship now.

og: How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?
t: How's it going, my lord? Isn't it after midnight?

og: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a  month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success:
t: Tonight I've taken care of sixteen different things, a month's worth of tasks, with total success:

og: I have congeed with the duke, done my adieu with his  nearest;
t: I've taken leave of the duke, said goodbye to his nearest and dearest.

og: buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my  lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy;
t: I've buried a wife and mourned for her. I've written to my mother that I'm returning home. I've entertained my followers.

og: and between these main parcels of dispatch effected  many nicer needs;
t: And between these main things I had to get done, I've met many more pleasurable needs.

og: the last was the greatest, but  that I have not ended yet.
t: The last was the most significant, but I haven't ended that yet.

og: If the business be of any difficulty, and thismorning your departure hence, it requires haste ofyour lordship.
t: If this business is at all difficult, and you're leaving this morning, your lordship had better hurry up.

og: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to  hear of it hereafter.
t: I mean, the business is not ended, as in I'm afraid word will get out later.

og: But shall we have this  dialogue between the fool and the soldier?
t: But shall we hear this dialogue between the fool and the soldier?

og: Come,  bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived  me, like a double-meaning prophesier.
t: Come, bring for this lying rogue, he has deceived me, like a fortune-teller who speaks in double meanings.

og: Bring him forth: has sat i' the stocks all night,poor gallant knave.
t: Bring him forth. He has sat in the stocks all night, poor foppish rogue.

og: No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurpinghis spurs so long. How does he carry himself?
t: No matter: his heels have deserved the discomfort for pretending to be brave for so long. How does he behave himself?

og: I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry  him.
t: I've told your lordship already, he behaves like a coward.

og: But to answer you as you would be understood;  he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk:
t: But to answer you more specifically, he weeps like a young woman that had spilled her milk.

og: he  hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes  to be a friar,
t: He has given confession to Morgan, who he believes to be a friar,

og: from the time of his remembrance to  this very instant disaster of his setting i' the  stocks:
t: from as far back as he can remember to the very instant he was placed in the stocks.

og: and what think you he hath confessed?
t: And what do you think he has confessed?

og: Nothing of me, has a'?
t: Nothing of me, has he?

og: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to hisface: if your lordship be in't, as I believe youare, you must have the patience to hear it.
t: His confession is taken, and it will be read to his face. If your lordship is in it, as I believe you are, you must have the patience to listen to it.

og: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing ofme: hush, hush!
t: A plague on him! I wish his mouth were covered! He can say nothing about me: hush, hush!

og: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa
t: The blindfolded man comes! Portotartarosa.

og: He calls for the tortures: what will you saywithout 'em?
t: He calls for the tortures to begin. What will you say without their help?

og: I will confess what I know without constraint: ifye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.
t: I will confess what I know without constraint. If you pinch me until I'm a pie, I'd have nothing more to add.

og: Bosko chimurcho.
t: Bosko chimurcho.

og: Boblibindo chicurmurco.
t: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

og: You are a merciful general. Our general bids youanswer to what I shall ask you out of a note.
t: You are a merciful general. Our general commands you answer to what I shall ask you from this piece of paper.

og: And truly, as I hope to live.
t: And I'll answer truly, as truly as I hope to live.

og: 'First demand of him how many horse theduke is strong.' What say you to that?
t: "First, ask him how many horses are in the duke's army." What do you say to that?

og: Five or six thousand; but very weak and  unserviceable:
t: Five or six thousand, but they're very weak and unready for battle.

og: the troops are all scattered, and  the commanders very poor rogues,
t: The troops are all scattered, and the commanders are weak scoundrels.

og: upon my reputation  and credit and as I hope to live.
t: I swear upon my reputation and credit and my life.

og: Shall I set down your answer so?
t: Should I write that down as your answer?

og: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way youwill.
t: Do so. I'll take the sacrament on that, however and whichever way you want me to.

og: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!
t: It's all the same to him. This slave is beyond saving!

og: You're deceived, my lord:
t: You're deceived, my lord.

og: this is Monsieur  Parolles, the gallant militarist,—that was his own  phrase,—
t: This is Monsieur Parolles, the "gallant militarist"—that was his own phrase—

og: that had the whole theoric of war in the  knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of  his dagger.
t: that knew the whole theory of war like the knot in his scarf, and had the strategies of war in the sheath of his dagger.

og: I will never trust a man again for keeping his swordclean. Nor believe he can have every thing in himby wearing his apparel neatly.
t: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword clean. Nor will I believe he can be a great man just because he wears his uniform neatly.

og: Well, that's set down.
t: Well, that's written down.

og: Five or six thousand horse, I said,— I will saytrue,—or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.
t: Five or six thousand horses, I said—I will tell the truth—or thereabouts. Write it down, for I'll say the truth.

og: He's very near the truth in this.
t: He is very near the truth in this.

og: But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature hedelivers it.
t: But I'll give him no thanks for it, given the situation in which he delivers it.

og: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.
t: Poor scoundrels, please, say something.

og: Well, that's set down.
t: Well, that's written down.

og: I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, therogues are marvellous poor.
t: I humbly thank you, sir. A truth is a truth. The rogues are incredibly weak.

og: 'Demand of him, of what strength they area-foot.' What say you to that?
t: "Demand of him how strong they are on foot." What do you say to that?

og: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present  hour, I will tell true.
t: I swear, sir, if I were to die this hour, I would tell the truth.

og: Let me see: Spurio, a  hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so  many; Jaques, so many;
t: Let me see: Spurio has a hundred and fifty. Sebastian, the same number. Corambus, the same number. Jaques, the same number.

og: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick,  and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own  company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and  fifty each:
t: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each. My own company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and fifteen each.

og: so that the muster-file, rotten and  sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand  poll;
t: So the whole army, useless or in good shape, upon my life, comes up not even to fifteen thousand people,

og: half of the which dare not shake snow from off  their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.
t: half of which wouldn't even dare to shake snow off their boots, they're so afraid they'd shake themselves to pieces.

og: What shall be done to him?
t: What shall be done to him?

og: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him mycondition, and what credit I have with the duke.
t: Nothing, just thank him.

og: Well, that's set down.
t: Well, that's written down.

og: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular ofthe inter'gatories: demand them singly.
t: I plead with you, let me answer to each particular question. Ask them one at a time.

og: Do you know this Captain Dumain?
t: Do you know this Captian Dumain?

og: I know him:
t: I know him.

og: a' was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris,  from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's  fool with child,
t: He was a tailor's apprentice in Paris and he was whipped out of the city for getting a girl pregnant

og: —a dumb innocent, that could not  say him nay.
t: —an innocent mute girl that could not say no to him.

og: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I knowhis brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.
t: No, hold on, resist fighting him, even though I know you'll smash his brains out at the nearest opportunity.

og: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?
t: Well, is this captain in the Duke of Florence's camp?

og: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.
t: As far as I know he is, and he's lousy.

og: Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of yourlordship anon.
t: Don't look at me like that. We'll hear about your lordship soon enough.

og: What is his reputation with the duke?
t: What's his reputation with the Duke?

og: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officerof mine; and writ to me this other day to turn himout o' the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.
t: The Duke knows him to be a poor officer in my charge. He wrote me the other day to throw him out of the army. I think I have his letter in my pocket.

og: Marry, we'll search.
t: Okay, we'll search.

og: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there,or it is upon a file with the duke's other lettersin my tent.
t: Sad to say, I'm not sure. Either it is there or maybe it is in a file with the duke's other letters in my tent.

og: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?
t: Here it is. Here's a paper. Should I read it to you?

og: I do not know if it be it or no.
t: I don't know if that's it or not.

og: Our interpreter does it well.
t: Our interpreter's good at this.

og: Excellently.
t: He's excellent.

og: 'Dian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,'—
t: "Diana, the count's a fool, and only very rich,"—

og: That is not the duke's letter, sir;
t: That's not the duke's letter, sir.

og: that is an  advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one  Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count  Rousillon,
t: That's a message to a very admirable lady in Florence, one Diana, to watch out for the seduction of the Count Rousillon,

og: a foolish idle boy, but for all that very  ruttish:
t: a foolish, lazy boy but, despite that, also very lecherous.

og: I pray you, sir, put it up again.
t: I beg you, sir, put the letter back again.

og: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.
t: No, I'll read it first, if you don't mind.

og: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the  behalf of the maid;
t: My meaning in it, if I can explain, was very honest on behalf of the maid.

og: for I knew the young count to be  a dangerous and lascivious boy,
t: Because I knew the young count was a dangerous and lustful boy,

og: who is a whale to  virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.
t: who is like a whale that feeds on virginity and devours up all the virgins it can find.

og: Damnable both-sides rogue!
t: Damned two-timing rogue!

og: 'When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;
t: "When he makes vows to you, tell him to give you gold and then take it.

og: After he scores, he never pays the score:
t: After he gets what he wants, he never pays what he owes.

og: Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;
t: You've already done half the work if you can make a good deal with him. Make a match of it, and take what you can get first.

og: He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before;
t: He never pays afterwards, take it before.

og: And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this,
t: And say that a soldier told you this, Diana.

og: Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss:
t: You can mess around with men, but don't kiss boys.

og: For count of this, the count's a fool, I know it,
t: To wrap things up, the count's a fool, I know that to be true.

og: Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.
t: He pays to get what he wants but not if he owes it after he's gotten what he's after.

og: Thine, as he vowed to thee in thine ear,  PAROLLES.'
t: Yours, just like vowed to be yours in your ear, Parolles."

og: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhymein's forehead.
t: He'll be whipped throughout the army with this rhyme stuck in his forehead.

og: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifoldlinguist and the armipotent soldier.
t: This is supposedly your devoted friend, sir, who speaks so many languages and is such a brave soldier.

og: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and nowhe's a cat to me.
t: I used to be able to tolerate anything except a cat and now this man is like a cat to me.

og: I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall befain to hang you.
t: I see, sir, based on the general's expression, we'll have to hang you.

og: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to  die;
t: Give me my life, sir, at least. It's not that I'm afraid to die.

og: but that, my offences being many, I would  repent out the remainder of nature:
t: It's just that since I've committed so many sins, I'd rather live out the rest of my life being repentant.

og: let me live,  sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I may live.
t: Let me live, sir, in a dungeon or in the stocks or anywhere just so I may live.

og: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;
t: We'll see what may done as long as you confess truthfully.

og: therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain:
t: Therefore, let's go back to this Captain Dumain.

og: you  have answered to his reputation with the duke and to  his valour:
t: You've talked about his reputation with the duke and about his bravery.

og: what is his honesty?
t: What about his honesty?

og: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister:
t: He will steal an egg out of a church, sir.

og: for  rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus:
t: In terms of raping and ravishing, he's as bad as Nessus.

og: he  professes not keeping of oaths;
t: He doesn't ever keep his oaths.

og: in breaking 'em he  is stronger than Hercules:
t: He's stronger than Hercules when it comes to breaking his oaths.

og: he will lie, sir, with  such volubility, that you would think truth were a  fool:
t: Sir, his lies are so versatile that you'd think truth was just a fool.

og: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will  be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little  harm, save to his bed-clothes about him;
t: Drunkenness is his best virtue for he tends to get blackout drunk, and in his sleep he doesn't do any harm (except to his bedsheets).

og: but they  know his conditions and lay him in straw.
t: His servants know his behaviors, though, and they lay him down to sleep in straw.

og: I have but  little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has  every thing that an honest man should not have; what  an honest man should have, he has nothing.
t: I don't have much more to say about his honesty, sir. He has every quality than an honest man should not have and no qualities that an honest man should.

og: I begin to love him for this.
t: I'm starting to find this endearing.

og: For this description of thine honesty? A pox uponhim for me, he's more and more a cat.
t: Because of this description of your honesty? A curse on him, I say. He's more and more like a cat.

og: What say you to his expertness in war?
t: What do you have to say about his expertise in war?

og: Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English  tragedians;
t: Well, sir, he's just an actor when it comes to being in the war.

og: to belie him, I will not, and more of  his soldiership I know not;
t: I won't tell lies about him and I don't know very much about him as a a soldier.

og: except, in that country  he had the honour to be the officer at a place there  called Mile-end,
t: Except that I do know that in that country he had the honor to be the officer in charge at a place called Mile-end

og: to instruct for the doubling of  files:
t: and his job was to instruct during the doubling of files drill.

og: I would do the man what honour I can, but of  this I am not certain.
t: I would say whatever honorable things about him I could, but I don't know very much.

og: He hath out-villained villany so far, that therarity redeems him.
t: He's out-villained villainy so far, but this nice gesture is redeeming.

og: A pox on him, he's a cat still.
t: Curse him, he's still a cat.

og: His qualities being at this poor price, I need notto ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.
t: Given that you've rated his qualities so poorly, I don't need to waste time asking you if he could be bribed with gold to revolt.

og: Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple  of his salvation, the inheritance of it;
t: Sir, for just a silver coin, he'd sell all his chances at being saved and his heirs' chances too.

og: and cut the  entail from all remainders, and a perpetual  succession for it perpetually.
t: He'd cast off his salvation and his descendants' salvation forever.

og: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?
t: What's his brother like, the other Captain Dumain?

og: Why does he ask him of me?
t: Why does he ask him about me?

og: What's he?
t: What's he like?

og: E'en a crow o' the same nest;
t: He's a crow from the same nest.

og: not altogether so  great as the first in goodness, but greater a great  deal in evil:
t: He's not really as great as the first brother in terms of goodness, but he's a great deal greater in terms of evil.

og: he excels his brother for a coward,  yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is:
t: He's much more of a coward than his brother even though his brother is known as one of the biggest cowards there is.

og: in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming  on he has the cramp.
t: In running away, he outruns any man. Yes, and when the troop is advancing, he gets a cramp.

og: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betraythe Florentine?
t: In order to save your life, will you be willing to betray the Florentine?

og: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.
t: Yes, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

og: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.
t: I'll whisper with the general and find out what he wants.

og: I'll no more drumming; a plague of all  drums!
t: I won't drum anymore. Curse all drums!

og: Only to seem to deserve well, and to  beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy  the count, have I run into this danger.
t: I've only run into this danger because I wanted to seem courageous, and because I wanted to win over that lustful young boy, the count.

og: Yet who  would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?
t: But who would have suspected there would be an ambush in the play where I was?

og: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die:
t: There's no way out, sir, but you'll have to die.

og: the  general says, you that have so traitorously  discovered the secrets of your army
t: The general says that someone who has been such a traitor in sharing the secrets of his army

og: and made such  pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can  serve the world for no honest use;
t: and made such lying reports of men who are known to be noble can never serve the world for any honest purpose.

og: therefore you  must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.
t: Therefore you must die. Come, executioner, off with his head.

og: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!
t: Oh Lord, sir, let me live, or let me at least see my death!

og: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.
t: Yes, you will do that, and say farewell to all your friends.

og: So, look about you: know you any here?
t: So, look around you. Do you know anyone here?

og: Good morrow, noble captain.
t: Good morning, noble captain.

og: God bless you, Captain Parolles.
t: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

og: God save you, noble captain.
t: God protect you, noble captain.

og: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu?I am for France.
t: Captain, what greeting will you send to Lord Lafeu? I'm going to France.

og: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet  you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon?
t: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet that you wrote to Diana on behalf of the Count Rousillon?

og: an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel it of you:
t: If I weren't a total coward, I'd demand it of you.

og: but fare you well.
t: But farewell.

og: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; thathas a knot on't yet
t: You are ruined, captain, all but your scarf. That still has a knot in it.

og: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?
t: Who cannot be crushed by a plot against them?

og: If you could find out a country where but women were  that had received so much shame,
t: If you could discover a country where only women were and all of them had been as shamed as you've been,

og: you might begin an  impudent nation.
t: maybe you could father a shameless nation.

og: Fare ye well, sir; I am for France  too:
t: Farewell, sir. I'm heading for France too.

og: we shall speak of you there.
t: We shall speak of you there.

og: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,  'Twould burst at this.
t: Yet I'm thankful. If my heart were big, it would burst at this.

og: Captain I'll be no more;  But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft  As captain shall:
t: I won't be a captain anymore. But I'll eat and drink and I'll sleep as softly as a captain does.

og: simply the thing I am  Shall make me live.
t: Simply being what I am will keep me alive.

og: Who knows himself a braggart,  Let him fear this, for it will come to pass  that every braggart shall be found an ass.
t: If any man knows himself to be a braggart, let him be afraid of what's happened to me. It is sure to happen that every braggart shall be revealed to be an ass.

og: Rust, sword; cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live  Safest in shame!
t: My sword will rust and my blushes will fade and Parolles will live most safely in his shame!

og: being fool'd, by foolery thrive!  There's place and means for every man alive.
t: By being fooled, my foolery will help me survive! Every man can find a place and a way to live.

og: I'll after them.
t: I'll go after them.

og: That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you,  One of the greatest in the Christian world  Shall be my surety;
t: So you can be totally sure I haven't wronged you, one of the greatest men in the Christian world will speak for me.

og: 'fore whose throne 'tis needful,  Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:
t: Before his throne, I will need to kneel before I can make everything clear.

og: Time was, I did him a desired office,  Dear almost as his life;
t: There was once a time I did a great service to him almost as dear as his life.

og: which gratitude  Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,  And answer, thanks:
t: Even if he was a violent Tartar, the gratitude for that deed would still overwhelm him and answer with thanks.

og: I duly am inform'd  His grace is at Marseilles; to which place  We have convenient convoy.
t: I've been told that his grace is in Marseilles, and we have convenient means to get there.

og: You must know  I am supposed dead:
t: You must know that I am assumed dead.

og: the army breaking,  My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,  And by the leave of my good lord the king,  We'll be before our welcome.
t: The army breaking up, my husband's hurrying home, where, with heaven's help, and with the king's support, we'll be there ahead of him.

og: Gentle madam,You never had a servant to whose trustYour business was more welcome.
t: Gentle madam, you never had a servant who trusted you more in whatever you say.

og: Nor you, mistress,  Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour  To recompense your love:
t: And you, mistress, have never had a friend who more desires to pay you back for your love.

og: doubt not but heaven  Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,  As it hath fated her to be my motive  And helper to a husband.
t: I'm confident that heaven has put me here to pay your daughter's dowry just as heaven has put her here to be my instrument and helper to win my husband.

og: But, O strange men!  That can such sweet use make of what they hate,  When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts  Defiles the pitchy night:
t: But, oh strange men! They can make such sweet use of the women they hate, even when they are giving into such lustful thoughts that defile the dark night.

og: so lust doth play  With what it loathes for that which is away.  But more of this hereafter.
t: In that way, his lust has played with the thing it loathes instead of that thing which is absent. But more of this later.

og: You, Diana,  Under my poor instructions yet must suffer  Something in my behalf.
t: You, Diana, under my poor instructions still must suffer something on my behalf.

og: Let death and honestyGo with your impositions, I am yoursUpon your will to suffer.
t: Even if I had to give up death and chastity on your orders, I'll follow you in whatever you need me to undergo.

og: Yet, I pray you:
t: Not quite yet.

og: But with the word the time will bring on summer,  When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,  And be as sweet as sharp.
t: But when it comes time for me to give the word, summer will arrive, and the roses will have leaves as well as thorns and be as sweet as they are sharp.

og: We must away;  Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us:
t: We must get away. Our wagon is ready, and time is ticking.

og: All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown;
t: All's well that end's well. The conclusion is the crowning moment.

og: Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.
t: Whatever the means, the end is what will be remembered.

og: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta  fellow there,
t: No, no, no, your son was misled by a fellow with his silk slashed there,

og: whose villanous saffron would have  made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation in  his colour:
t: who would have, in his villainy, made all the young and impressionable youth of a nation believe him and wear his same orange color.

og: your daughter-in-law had been alive at  this hour, and your son here at home, more advanced  by the king than by that red-tailed humble-bee I speak of.
t: Your daughter-in-law could have been alive right now, and your son here at home, with greater honors from the king than from that red-tailed bumble-bee I speak of.

og: I would I had not known him;
t: I wish I had never known him.

og: it was the death of the  most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had  praise for creating.
t: This caused the death of the most virtuous lady that nature ever created.

og: If she had partaken of my  flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I  could not have owed her a more rooted love.
t: If she had been my own daughter, and made me groan in labor, I could not have loved her more deeply.

og: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick athousand salads ere we light on such another herb.
t: She was a good lady, she was a good lady. We can sift through a thousand salads before we find another herb like her.

og: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of thesalad, or rather, the herb of grace.
t: Indeed, sir, she was like the sweet marjoram in the salad, or, if you prefer, the herb of grace, rue.

og: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.
t: Those aren't herbs, you dummy. Those are just plants that smell nice.

og: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not muchskill in grass.
t: I'm no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir. I don't know very much about grass.

og: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?
t: Which do you claim yourself to be, a rogue or a fool?

og: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.
t: A fool, sir, when I serve a woman, and a rogue when I serve a man.

og: Your distinction?
t: What's the difference?

og: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.
t: I would steal the man's wife and do his service with her.

og: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.
t: Then you'd definitely be a rogue if that was the service you did him.

og: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.
t: And I would give his wife my rod, sir, to do her service.

og: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.
t: I'll say it's true, you are both a rogue and a fool.

og: At your service.
t: At your service.

og: No, no, no.
t: No, no no.

og: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve asgreat a prince as you are.
t: But, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve a man who's as great a prince as you are.

og: Who's that? a Frenchman?
t: Who's that? A Frenchman?

og: Faith, sir, a' has an English name; but his fisnomyis more hotter in France than there.
t: Indeed, sir, he has an English name, but his face is hotter in France than in England.

og: What prince is that?
t: What prince is that?

og: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince ofdarkness; alias, the devil.
t: The black prince, sir. Also known as the prince of darkness. Also known as the devil.

og: Hold thee, there's my purse: I give thee not thisto suggest thee from thy master thou talkest of;serve him still.
t: Stop there, there's my purse. I don't give this to you to tempt you away from the master that you talk of. Serve him still.

og: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a  great fire;
t: I'm a woodland fellow, sir, and I've always loved a great fire.

og: and the master I speak of ever keeps a  good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the  world;
t: The master I speak of always keeps a good fire burning. But, of course, he is the devil.

og: let his nobility remain in's court.
t: Let his nobility stay firmly inside his kingdom.

og: I am for  the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be  too little for pomp to enter:
t: I am headed for the house with the narrow gate which I understand to be too little for many people to enter.

og: some that humble  themselves may; but the many will be too chill and  tender,
t: Some who are very humble may enter but most people will be too fainthearted and self-interested.

og: and they'll be for the flowery way that  leads to the broad gate and the great fire.
t: They'll end up following the flowery path that leads to the broad gate and the great fire of hell.

og: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee;
t: Go away now. I'm going to get tired of thee,

og: and I  tell thee so before, because I would not fall out  with thee.
t: and I want to tell you that now because I don't want to quarrel with you.

og: Go thy ways: let my horses be well  looked to, without any tricks.
t: Go away now. Let my horses be well looked to, and don't play any tricks on them.

og: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall bejades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.
t: If I play any tricks on them, sir, they would be jades' tricks, which they deserve given their names.

og: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.
t: A clever rogue and an unhappy one.

og: So he is.  My lord that's gone made himself much  sport out of him
t: So he is. My late husband had a lot of fun with him.

og: : by his authority he remains here,  which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness;
t: By my husband's order he stays here, which he thinks means he has free reign to be saucy.

og: and,  indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.
t: Indeed, he has no self-control but runs about wherever he wants.

og: I like him well; 'tis not amiss.
t: I like him a lot. There's nothing wrong with that.

og: And I was about to  tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death and  that my lord your son was upon his return home,
t: And I was about to tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death that my lord your son was on his way home,

og: I  moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of  my daughter;
t: I convinced the king, my master, to speak on behalf of my daughter.

og: which, in the minority of them both,  his majesty, out of a self-gracious remembrance, did  first propose:
t: When Bertram and my daughter were minors, his majesty, out of a very gracious kindness to remember us, proposed that first.

og: his highness hath promised me to do  it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath  conceived against your son, there is no fitter  matter.
t: His highness has promised me to do it. There's no better way to end this displeasure that the king has developed against your son.

og: How does your ladyship like it?
t: How does your ladyship like this?

og: With very much content, my lord; and I wish ithappily effected.
t: It makes me very content, my lord, and I hope it will come to pass happily.

og: His highness comes post from Marseilles,
t: His highness comes directly from Marseilles.

og: of as able  body as when he numbered thirty:
t: He's in as good physical shape as when he was thirty.

og: he will be here  to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such  intelligence hath seldom failed.
t: He'll be here tomorrow unless I'm deceived by a reporter who has rarely failed me in his information.

og: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I  die.
t: It makes me happy to hope that I will see the king before I die.

og: I have letters that my son will be here  to-night:
t: I have letters that say my son will be here tonight.

og: I shall beseech your lordship to remain  with me till they meet together.
t: I'll request that your lordship will stay with me until the king and Bertram are together.

og: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I mightsafely be admitted.
t: Madam, I was wondering what I'd need to say to be admitted to that meeting.

og: You need but plead your honourable privilege.
t: You only have to remind the kingdom of the privilege that your honor deserves.

og: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but Ithank my God it holds yet.
t: My lady, I've been as bold as I would dare in saying that, but I thank God it hasn't failed me yet.

og: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of  velvet on's face:
t: Oh, madam, my lord your son is nearby wearing a velvet patch on his face.

og: whether there be a scar under't  or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of  velvet:
t: Whether there's a scar under it or not, the velvet knows the truth, but it's a good-looking patch of velvet.

og: his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a  half, but his right cheek is worn bare.
t: His left cheek is wearing velvet of two pile and a half quality, but his right cheek has nothing on it.

og: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good liveryof honour; so belike is that.
t: A scar he received nobly, or a noble scar, is a good sign of honor. This probably is too.

og: But it is your carbonadoed face.
t: But it is your slashed face.

og: Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talkwith the young noble soldier.
t: Let's go see your son, I beg you. I'm longing to talk with the young noble soldier.

og: Faith there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate finehats and most courteous feathers, which bow the headand nod at every man.
t: Wow, there's a dozen of them, with delicate, fine hats and fancy feathers, which weigh down their heads and look like they're nodding at every man.

og: But this exceeding posting day and night  Must wear your spirits low;
t: But walking constantly day and night must be tiring you out.

og: we cannot help it:
t: We can't help it.

og: But since you have made the days and nights as one,  To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
t: Since we've been treating the days and nights like they're all the same, and you've been wearing out your gentle bodies just for my sake,

og: Be bold you do so grow in my requital  As nothing can unroot you.
t: rest assured that I am more and more in your debt and nothing will ever undo that.

og: In happy time;
t: Oh, good timing!

og: This man may help me to his majesty's ear,If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.
t: This man might help me to reach the king if he's willing to lend a hand. God bless you, sir.

og: And you.
t: And you.

og: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.
t: Sir, I have seen you at the French court.

og: I have been sometimes there.
t: I have been there sometimes.

og: I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen  From the report that goes upon your goodness;
t: I assume, sir, that you're still maintaining your good reputation.

og: An therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions,  Which lay nice manners by,
t: If that's true, since I'm in a difficult situation that forces me to forget my manners,

og: I put you to  The use of your own virtues, for the which  I shall continue thankful.
t: I'll ask you to act in your typical virtuous way, for which I'd be forever grateful.

og: What's your will?
t: How can I help?

og: That it will please you  To give this poor petition to the king,
t: If you could please give this little letter to the king,

og: And aid me with that store of power you have  To come into his presence.
t: and help me with whatever power you have to visit him in person.

og: The king's not here.
t: The king's not here.

og: Not here, sir!
t: Not here, sir?

og: Not, indeed:He hence removed last night and with more hasteThan is his use.
t: Indeed not. He just left last night and more quickly than he usually does.

og: Lord, how we lose our pains!
t: Lord, we've been exhausting ourselves for nothing!

og: All's well that ends well yet,Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.I do beseech you, whither is he gone?
t: All's well that ends well still, even though our timing and methods seem to fail us.

og: Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon;Whither I am going.
t: Well, as far as I know, to Roussillon. I'm going there too.

og: I do beseech you, sir,  Since you are like to see the king before me,
t: I beg you, sir, since you'll probably see the king before I do,

og: Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
t: bring this paper to his kind hand.

og: Which I presume shall render you no blame  But rather make you thank your pains for it.
t: I'm pretty sure that doing so won't get you in trouble but will make you glad you did it.

og: I will come after you with what good speed  Our means will make us means.
t: I'll come after you as fast as we're able.

og: This I'll do for you.
t: I'll do this for you.

og: And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd,Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again.Go, go, provide.
t: And you'll find yourself to be well thanked, whatever else happens. We must ride our horses again.

og: Good Monsieur Lavatch, give my Lord Lafeu this  letter:
t: Good Monsieur Lavatach, give my lord Lafeu this letter.

og: I have ere now, sir, been better known to  you, when I have held familiarity with fresher  clothes;
t: You knew me before, sir, when I wore fresher clothes.

og: but I am now, sir, muddied in fortune's  mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong  displeasure.
t: Now, sir, I have been muddied by fortune turning against me, and so I smell somewhat like fortune's fool.

og: Truly, fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it  smell so strongly as thou speakest of:
t: Well, fortune in a bad mood must be quite dirty if it smells as strongly as you do.

og: I will  henceforth eat no fish of fortune's buttering.  Prithee, allow the wind.
t: I will never again eat any fish that fortune has buttered. Let's air you out.

og: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spakebut by a metaphor.
t: No, you don't need to hold your nose sir. I was just using a metaphor.

og: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop mynose; or against any man's metaphor. Prithee, getthee further.
t: Well, sir, since your metaphor stinks, I will hold my nose. I'd hold my nose at any man's metaphor. Please, stand further away from me.

og: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.
t: I hope, sir, that you'll deliver this note.

og: Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortune'sclose-stool to give to a nobleman! Look, here hecomes himself.
t: Pffh! Stand further away. A note from fortune's chamber pot to give to a nobleman! Look, here he comes himself.

og: Here is a purr of fortune's, sir, or of fortune's  cat,—but not a musk-cat,
t: Sir, here is fortune's rogue, a plaything of fortune's cat—but not a sweet-smelling cat,

og: —that has fallen into the  unclean fishpond of her displeasure,
t: —who has fallen into the dirty fishpond of fortune's displeasure.

og: and, as he  says, is muddied withal:
t: And, as he says, is muddied from the fall.

og: pray you, sir, use the  carp as you may;
t: I ask you, sir, use this fish as you want.

og: for he looks like a poor, decayed,  ingenious, foolish, rascally knave.
t: He looks like a poor, decayed, clever, foolish, rascally rogue.

og: I do pity his  distress in my similes of comfort and leave him to  your lordship.
t: In my own state of something like comfort, I do take pity on how distressed he is, and I leave him with your lordship.

og: My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruellyscratched.
t: My lord, I am a man who has been cruelly scratched by fortune.

og: And what would you have me to do?
t: And what would have me do about that?

og: 'Tis too late to  pare her nails now.
t: It's too late to trim Fortune's nails now.

og: Wherein have you played the  knave with fortune, that she should scratch you,
t: What have you done to Fortune to make her scratch you?

og: who  of herself is a good lady and would not have knaves  thrive long under her?
t: Fortune's a good lady and she wouldn't allow rogues to have good fortune for very long.

og: There's a quart d'ecu for  you:
t: Here's a silver coin for you.

og: let the justices make you and fortune friends:  I am for other business.
t: I hope you and fortune can become friends. I have other things to deal with.

og: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.
t: I beg your honor to listen to one single word from me.

og: You beg a single penny more: come, you shall ha't;save your word.
t: You beg just a single penny more from me. Come, then, you shall have it. Don't bother with your single word.

og: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.
t: My name is Parolles, my good lord.

og: You beg more than 'word,' then. Cox my passion!give me your hand. How does your drum?
t: You beg more than just one "word" then. By God! Give me your hand. How is your drum?

og: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!
t: Oh, my good lord, you were the first man that found me out!

og: Was I, in sooth? and I was the first that lost thee.
t: Was I, really? And I was the first man that lost you too.

og: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace,for you did bring me out.
t: You're the only man, my lord, who can see that I find favor with the court since you brought me out of favor when you saw through me.

og: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at onceboth the office of God and the devil? One bringsthee in grace and the other brings thee out.
t: How dare you, you rascal! Do you claim that I do the work of both God and the devil at the same time? One is bringing you into favor and the other one's bringing you out of it.

og: The king's coming; I know by his trumpets.
t: The king's coming. This is his fanfare.

og: Sirrah,  inquire further after me; I had talk of you last  night:
t: Sir, ask for me later. I heard people talking about you last night.

og: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall  eat;
t: Even though you're a fool and a rogue, I'll make sure you eat.

og: go to, follow.
t: Go along, follow.

og: I praise God for you.
t: I praise God for you.

og: We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem  Was made much poorer by it:
t: In losing her, we lost a jewel, and I'm worth much less from losing her.

og: but your son,  As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know  Her estimation home.
t: But your son, as if he was mad, didn't have the sense to know how worthy she was.

og: 'Tis past, my liege;
t: It's over, my lord.

og: And I beseech your majesty to make it  Natural rebellion, done i' the blaze of youth;
t: I beg your majesty to think of it as natural, youthful rebellion,

og: When oil and fire, too strong for reason's force,  O'erbears it and burns on.
t: like when oil and fire refuse to listen to reason, and burn in spite of what they're told.

og: My honour'd lady,  I have forgiven and forgotten all;
t: My honored lady, I have forgiven and forgotten everything,

og: Though my revenges were high bent upon him,  And watch'd the time to shoot.
t: though I was ready to revenge her death on him and was just waiting for the right time.

og: This I must say,  But first I beg my pardon,
t: I have to say this, but first I beg pardon.

og: the young lord  Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady  Offence of mighty note;
t: The young lord mightily affronted his king, his mother, and his wife,

og: but to himself  The greatest wrong of all.
t: but he did the greatest wrong of all to himself.

og: He lost a wife  Whose beauty did astonish the survey  Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive,  Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve  Humbly call'd mistress.
t: He lost a wife whose beauty astonished all the richest eyes in the land, whose words took all ears as their captives, and whose perfection made previously scornful men humbly serve her.

og: Praising what is lost  Makes the remembrance dear.
t: When we praise what we've lost, it makes remembering even more dear to us.

og: Well, call him hither;
t: Well, call him in.

og: We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill  All repetition:
t: We're friends again, and once we're reunited, we won't need to repeat this first reunion.

og: let him not ask our pardon;
t: Don't let him ask for my forgiveness.

og: The nature of his great offence is dead,  And deeper than oblivion we do bury  The incensing relics of it:
t: The woman he wronged is dead, and now I bury the memory of his offenses deeper than you can imagine.

og: let him approach,  A stranger, no offender;
t: Let him approach as a stranger, not as an enemy.

og: and inform him  So 'tis our will he should.
t: Inform him it's my will that he should do so.

og: I shall, my liege.
t: I will, my lord.

og: What says he to your daughter? have you spoke?
t: What does he say to your daughter? Have you spoken with him?

og: All that he is hath reference to your highness.
t: All that he has said has focused on your highness.

og: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent meThat set him high in fame.
t: Then we shall have a match made. I've had letters sent to me that put him among the most famous.

og: He looks well on't.
t: He looks well considering.

og: I am not a day of season,
t: My moods aren't like just one season.

og: For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail  In me at once:
t: You might see sunshine and hail in me at the same time.

og: but to the brightest beams  Distracted clouds give way;
t: Clouds eventually part and give way to bright sunbeams, though.

og: so stand thou forth;  The time is fair again.
t: So come forward, the sun is shining on you again.

og: My high-repented blames,Dear sovereign, pardon to me.
t: Dear king, pardon me for my wrongs that I greatly repent.

og: All is whole;
t: You're fully pardoned.

og: Not one word more of the consumed time.
t: Don't speak one word more about the time that's passed.

og: Let's take the instant by the forward top;
t: Let's seize the day.

og: For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees  The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time  Steals ere we can effect them  .
t: I'm old, and the silent foot of Father Time appears before I can get anything done.

og: You remember  The daughter of this lord?
t: You remember this lord's daughter?

og: Admiringly, my liege, at first  I stuck my choice upon her,
t: I admired her, my lord, and I originally wanted to marry her.

og: ere my heart  Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue  Where the impression of mine eye infixing,  Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me,
t: Before I could express my love for her, I started to scorn the faces of all other women.

og: Which warp'd the line of every other favour;  Scorn'd a fair colour, or express'd it stolen;
t: I'd say that fair faces were ugly or just looked nice because of makeup.

og: Extended or contracted all proportions  To a most hideous object:
t: I thought of all other women's forms except this lord's daughter as hideous.

og: thence it came  That she whom all men praised and whom myself,  Since I have lost, have loved,
t: That's why, when my wife, praised by all men and loved by me myself since I lost her,

og: was in mine eye  The dust that did offend it.
t: looked to me like dust in my eye.

og: Well excused:
t: That's a good excuse.

og: That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away  From the great compt:
t: Knowing that you did love her frees you from some of your debt.

og: but love that comes too late,  Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried,  To the great sender turns a sour offence,
t: But love that comes too late, like a pardon delivered too late to the gallows, is an offense to God.

og: Crying, 'That's good that's gone.'
t: What good does it do to cry, "What's gone was good!"

og: Our rash faults  Make trivial price of serious things we have,
t: Our unthinking faults make us undervalue the worthy things we have.

og: Not knowing them until we know their grave:
t: Doesn't it always seem to go that you don't know what you've got till it's gone?

og: Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
t: Often our scornfulness is unjust to ourselves.

og: Destroy our friends and after weep their dust  Our own love waking cries to see what's done,
t: It destroys our friends and then, after we've mourned them, our love for them finally surfaces and makes us cry when we realize what we've done.

og: While shame full late sleeps out the afternoon.
t: We don't feel shame until it's too late.

og: Be this sweet Helen's knell, and now forget her.
t: Memorialize sweet Helena and now forget her.

og: Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin:
t: Send your tokens of love to fair Maudlin, Lafeu's daughter.

og: The main consents are had; and here we'll stay  To see our widower's second marriage-day.
t: Consent has been given for the union and so here today we'll see this widower's second marriage.

og: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless!Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!
t: Which I hope will go better than the first, oh dear heaven, bless! If not, I hope I die before they meet!

og: Come on, my son, in whom my house's name  Must be digested,
t: Come on, my son-in-law-to-be, you'll soon take hold of my estate.

og: give a favour from you  To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,  That she may quickly come.
t: Give a present to ignite my daughter's love so she will quickly come to you.

og: By my old beard,  And every hair that's on't, Helen, that's dead,  Was a sweet creature:
t: By my old beard and every hair in it, the late Helena was a sweet creature.

og: such a ring as this,  The last that e'er I took her at court,  I saw upon her finger.
t: The last time I saw her at court, I saw a ring just like this on her finger.

og: Hers it was not.
t: It wasn't hers.

og: Now, pray you, let me see it;
t: Hold on, let me see it.

og: for mine eye,  While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to't.
t: While I was speaking just now, I couldn't stop staring at it.

og: This ring was mine;
t: This ring was mine.

og: I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood  Necessitied to help, that by this token  I would relieve her.
t: When I gave it to Helena, I instructed her that if she ever needed my help, to send me the ring and I would help her.

og: Had you that craft, to reave  her  Of what should stead her most?
t: Have you been so crafty as to steal the thing from her that would have been her greatest help?

og: My gracious sovereign,Howe'er it pleases you to take it so,The ring was never hers.
t: My gracious king, whatever you think you know, the ring was never hers.

og: Son, on my life,I have seen her wear it; and she reckon'd itAt her life's rate.
t: Son, on my life, I've seen her wear it. She priced it as highly as her life.

og: I am sure I saw her wear it.
t: I am sure I saw her wear it.

og: You are deceived, my lord; she never saw it:
t: You are wrong, my lord. She never saw it.

og: In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
t: It was thrown to me out of a window in Florence.

og: Wrapp'd in a paper, which contain'd the name  Of her that threw it:
t: It was wrapped in a paper with the name of the lady who threw it written on it.

og: noble she was, and thought  I stood engaged:
t: She was noble and thought we were engaged,

og: but when I had subscribed  To mine own fortune and inform'd her fully  I could not answer in that course of honour
t: but when I had explained the situation and told her that I couldn't marry her,

og: As she had made the overture, she ceased  In heavy satisfaction and would never  Receive the ring again.
t: since she had brought that up, she refused to to interact with me and wouldn't take back the ring.

og: Plutus himself,  That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine,
t: Plutus himself, the god of riches who knows how to turn metals into gold,

og: Hath not in nature's mystery more science  Than I have in this ring:
t: doesn't know more about the science of nature than I know about this ring.

og: 'twas mine, 'twas Helen's,  Whoever gave it you.
t: It was mine and it was Helena's, regardless of who gave it to you.

og: Then, if you know  That you are well acquainted with yourself,  Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement  You got it from her:
t: Then, if you know what's required of you, confess that it was hers, and how you took it from her by force.

og: she call'd the saints to surety  That she would never put it from her finger,  Unless she gave it to yourself in bed,
t: She swore to the saints that she would never take it off her finger unless she gave it to you in bed,

og: Where you have never come, or sent it us  Upon her great disaster.
t: where you've never been with her, or unless she sent it to me if there was some great catastrophe.

og: She never saw it.
t: She never saw it.

og: Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour;
t: That's a lie, by my honor.

og: And makest conjectural fears to come into me  Which I would fain shut out.
t: You're making me fear terrible things which I wish I'd never thought of.

og: If it should prove  That thou art so inhuman,—'twill not prove so;—  And yet I know not:
t: If it is proven that you could be so inhuman—it won't prove to be so—and yet I can't be sure.

og: thou didst hate her deadly,  And she is dead;
t: You hated her and now she's dead.

og: which nothing, but to close  Her eyes myself, could win me to believe,  More than to see this ring.
t: Nothing could make me believe that she's dead more than seeing this ring unless I had been present at her deathbed myself.

og: Take him away.
t: Take him away.

og: My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall,  Shall tax my fears of little vanity,  Having vainly fear'd too little.
t: Given the evidence I already have, whatever the truth turns out to be, I won't be thought to have overreacted, given that I already trusted you too much.

og: Away with him!
t: Away with him!

og: We'll sift this matter further.
t: We'll investigate this matter further.

og: If you shall prove  This ring was ever hers,
t: If you can prove that the ring was ever hers,

og: you shall as easy  Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,  Where yet she never was.
t: you can prove as easily that I slept with her in bed in Florence, where she's never been.

og: I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings.
t: I am overwhelmed by terrible thoughts.

og: Gracious sovereign,  Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not:
t: Gracious king, I don't know if this is a bad time.

og: Here's a petition from a Florentine,  Who hath for four or five removes come short  To tender it herself.
t: Here's a petition from a Florentine who's followed you but has arrived too late four or five times to give it to you herself.

og: I undertook it,  Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech  Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know  Is here attending:
t: I took on the task, persuaded by the fair words and behaviors of the poor woman, who is waiting outside.

og: her business looks in her  With an importing visage;
t: She looks like she means business.

og: and she told me,  In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern  Your highness with herself.
t: She told me in person that it has something to do with your highness and herself.

og: Upon his many protestations to marry me  when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won  me.
t: "After he told me many times that he would marry me when his wife was dead, I blush to say that I gave myself to him.

og: Now is the Count Rousillon a widower:
t: Now the Count Rousillon is a widower.

og: his vows  are forfeited to me, and my honour's paid to him.
t: He broke his vows to me and I've already given my honor away to him.

og: He  stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow  him to his country for justice:
t: He fled from Florence without saying goodbye, and I've followed him to his country for justice.

og: grant it me, O  king!
t: Grant me justice, oh king!

og: in you it best lies;
t: You're the only one who can.

og: otherwise a seducer  flourishes, and a poor maid is undone.  DIANA CAPILET.
t: Otherwise, a seducer will live happily and a poor maid will be ruined. Diana Capilet."

og: I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll forthis: I'll none of him.
t: I will buy myself a son-in-law at a fair and sell this one. I don't want anything to do with him.

og: The heavens have thought well on thee Lafeu,  To bring forth this discovery.
t: The heavens have been kind to you, Lafeu, to reveal this information.

og: Seek these suitors:
t: Find these people who want to speak to me.

og: Go speedily and bring again the count.
t: Go quickly and bring the count back in.

og: I am afeard the life of Helen, lady,  Was foully snatch'd.
t: Lady, I am afraid that Helena was the victim of foul play.

og: Now, justice on the doers!
t: Now, may the perpetrators be brought to justice!

og: I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you,And that you fly them as you swear them lordship,Yet you desire to marry.
t: I'm surprised, sir, since wives are like monsters to you and you flee from them as soon as you make your vows to them, that you would want to marry again.

og: What woman's that?
t: What woman is that?

og: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine,  Derived from the ancient Capilet:
t: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine of the ancient Capilet family.

og: My suit, as I do understand, you know,  And therefore know how far I may be pitied.
t: You know why I'm here, I've been told, and therefore you know how much I deserve to be pitied.

og: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honourBoth suffer under this complaint we bring,And both shall cease, without your remedy.
t: I am her mother, sir. I'm too old for this shock and my honor has taken a hit because of this. I'll lose both my life and honor if you don't help us.

og: Come hither, count; do you know these women?
t: Come here, count. Do you know these women?

og: My lord, I neither can nor will denyBut that I know them: do they charge me further?
t: My lord, I can't and won't deny that I know them. Do you they accuse me of anything else?

og: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?
t: Why do you look upon your wife like you're a stranger?

og: She's none of mine, my lord.
t: She's not my wife, my lord.

og: If you shall marry,  You give away this hand, and that is mine;
t: If you marry someone, you'll give away your hand that belongs to me.

og: You give away heaven's vows, and those are mine;
t: You'll give away heaven's vows and those belong to me.

og: You give away myself, which is known mine;
t: You'll give yourself away and you are known to belong to me.

og: For I by vow am so embodied yours,
t: For, by your vow, I am part of your body.

og: That she which marries you must marry me,  Either both or none.
t: A woman who marries you must also then marry me. It's both of us or neither of us.

og: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter; youare no husband for her.
t: Your reputation is much too bad to marry my daughter. You won't be marrying her.

og: My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature,  Whom sometime I have laugh'd with:
t: My lord, this is a foolish and desperate creature who I laughed with occasionally.

og: let your highness  Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour  Than for to think that I would sink it here.
t: I hope your highness would more nobly trust that I've been honorable than to think that I'd give my honor away to this woman.

og: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friendTill your deeds gain them: fairer prove your honourThan in my thought it lies.
t: Sir, don't look for my thoughts to be friendly to you until your actions have earned it. Prove yourself to be more honorable than I think you are.

og: Good my lord,Ask him upon his oath, if he does thinkHe had not my virginity.
t: My good lord, ask him to swear that he didn't take my virginity.

og: What say'st thou to her?
t: What do you say to her?

og: She's impudent, my lord,And was a common gamester to the camp.
t: She's shameless, my lord, and was a common whore for the soldiers.

og: He does me wrong, my lord;
t: He wrongs me, my lord.

og: if I were so,  He might have bought me at a common price:  Do not believe him.
t: If I were what he says, he might have bought my love cheaply. Don't believe him.

og: O, behold this ring,  Whose high respect and rich validity  Did lack a parallel;
t: Oh, look at this ring, that has no equal in respect and richness.

og: yet for all that  He gave it to a commoner o' the camp,  If I be one.
t: For all that value, you think he gave it to a common army whore, if that's what you think I am?

og: He blushes, and 'tis it:
t: He blushes and that seals the deal.

og: Of six preceding ancestors, that gem,  Conferr'd by testament to the sequent issue,  Hath it been owed and worn.
t: For six generations, that gem, required by the wills and testaments to be passed down to the next heir, has been worn by our family.

og: This is his wife;  That ring's a thousand proofs.
t: This is his wife. That ring gives the proof a thousand times.

og: Methought you saidYou saw one here in court could witness it.
t: I thought you said you saw someone in the court who could be a witness.

og: I did, my lord, but loath am to produceSo bad an instrument: his name's Parolles.
t: I did, my lord, but I hate to produce such a bad man. His name's Parolles.

og: I saw the man to-day, if man he be.
t: I saw the man today, if he is a man.

og: Find him, and bring him hither.
t: Find him, and bring him here.

og: What of him?
t: You'll believe Parolles?

og: He's quoted for a most perfidious slave,  With all the spots o' the world tax'd and debosh'd;
t: He's known to be a lying rascal as disgraced and horrible as the worst blemishes in human history.

og: Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth.
t: It would make him ill to tell the truth just once.

og: Am I or that or this for what he'll utter,  That will speak any thing?
t: Are you going to make up your mind about me based on what he says when he'll say anything?

og: She hath that ring of yours.
t: She has your ring.

og: I think she has:
t: I thinks he does.

og: certain it is I liked her,  And boarded her i' the wanton way of youth:
