t: It's true that I liked her, and I made advances towards her like youths always do.

og: She knew her distance and did angle for me,  Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
t: She knew how far apart we were socially and tried to win me, making me more eager by playing hard-to-get,

og: As all impediments in fancy's course  Are motives of more fancy;
t: as all obstacles to desire tend to make the desire greater.

og: and, in fine,  Her infinite cunning, with her modern grace,  Subdued me to her rate: she got the ring;
t: In short, her endless cunning, with her common charm, made me give her what she wanted: she got the ring.

og: And I had that which any inferior might  At market-price have bought.
t: And I had something from her that any lower-class man could buy from her more cheaply.

og: I must be patient:
t: I must be patient.

og: You, that have turn'd off a first so noble wife,  May justly diet me.
t: If you've gotten rid of your first noble wife so easily, you'll obviously try to get rid of me too.

og: I pray you yet;
t: I plead with you still.

og: Since you lack virtue, I will lose a husband;
t: Since you have no virtue at all, I will lose a husband.

og: Send for your ring, I will return it home,  And give me mine again.
t: Call for your ring, I'll put it back on and get out of here.

og: I have it not.
t: I don't have it.

og: What ring was yours, I pray you?
t: What ring belonged to you, can I ask?

og: Sir, much likeThe same upon your finger.
t: Sir, a ring very similar to the one on your finger.

og: Know you this ring? this ring was his of late.
t: You know this ring? This ring belonged to him recently.

og: And this was it I gave him, being abed.
t: And this was the ring I gave him when we were in bed.

og: The story then goes false, you threw it himOut of a casement.
t: This story must be false. You threw it to him out of a window.

og: I have spoke the truth.
t: I have spoken the truth.

og: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.
t: My lord, I confess that the ring was hers.

og: You boggle shrewdly, every feather stars you.Is this the man you speak of?
t: You tell lies manically, every change in the story startles you. Is this the man you mean?

og: Ay, my lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true, I charge you,
t: Tell me, sir, but tell me the truth, I command you.

og: Not fearing the displeasure of your master,
t: Don't be afraid of making your master mad.

og: Which on your just proceeding I'll keep off,
t: I'll deal with that if you answer honestly.

og: By him and by this woman here what know you?
t: What do you know about him and this woman here?

og: So please your majesty, my master hath been anhonourable gentleman: tricks he hath had in him,which gentlemen have.
t: If it please your majesty, my master has been an honorable gentleman. He's only done things that gentlemen do.

og: Come, come, to the purpose: did he love this woman?
t: Come, come, answer my question: did he love this woman?

og: Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?
t: Well, sir, he did love her. But how did he love her?

og: How, I pray you?
t: How, will you tell us?

og: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.
t: Sir, he loved her as a gentleman loves a woman.

og: How is that?
t: How is that?

og: He loved her, sir, and loved her not.
t: Sir, he loved her and loved her not.

og: As thou art a knave, and no knave. What anequivocal companion is this!
t: Just like you're a rogue and not a rogue. What a rambling companion this man is!

og: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.
t: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.

og: He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.
t: He beats the drum, well, my lord, but he speaks naughtily.

og: Do you know he promised me marriage?
t: Do you know he promised me marriage?

og: Faith, I know more than I'll speak.
t: Well, I know more than I'll say.

og: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest?
t: You won't say all you know?

og: Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between them,  as I said;
t: Yes, if it please your majesty. I did go between them as I said.

og: but more than that, he loved her:
t: Beyond that, he loved her.

og: for  indeed he was mad for her, and talked of Satan and  of Limbo and of Furies and I know not what:
t: He was crazy for her and he talked in his passion about Satan and Limbo and the Furies and I don't know what else.

og: yet I  was in that credit with them at that time that I  knew of their going to bed, and of other motions,
t: I was still friends with them when I knew that they had gone to bed together, and that other things had happened,

og: as promising her marriage, and things which would  derive me ill will to speak of;
t: like him promising her marriage, and things which would make you angry to hear from me.

og: therefore I will not  speak what I know.
t: Therefore I won't say what I know.

og: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say  they are married:
t: You've said everything I need to know already unless you can say that they are married.

og: but thou art too fine in thy  evidence; therefore stand aside.
t: But you are clear enough in your evidence. Therefore, stand aside.

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: Where did you buy it? or who gave it you?
t: Where did you buy it? Or who gave it to you?

og: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.
t: It was not given to me and I did not buy it.

og: Who lent it you?
t: Who lent it to you?

og: It was not lent me neither.
t: It wasn't lent to me either.

og: Where did you find it, then?
t: Where did you find it, then?

og: I found it not.
t: I didn't find it.

og: If it were yours by none of all these ways,How could you give it him?
t: If you didn't get it any of these ways, how did you have it to give it to him?

og: I never gave it him.
t: I never gave it to him.

og: This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes offand on at pleasure.
t: This woman's like a loose glove, my lord. She slips off and on, going back and forth, without warning.

og: This ring was mine; I gave it his first wife.
t: This ring belonged to me. I gave it to his first wife.

og: It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.
t: It could be yours or it could be hers for all that I know.

og: Take her away; I do not like her now;
t: Take her away. I don't like her anymore.

og: To prison with her: and away with him.
t: Take her to prison and away with him.

og: Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring,  Thou diest within this hour.
t: Unless you tell me where you got this ring, you'll die within the hour.

og: I'll never tell you.
t: I'll never tell you.

og: Take her away.
t: Take her away.

og: I'll put in bail, my liege.
t: I'll post my bail, my lord.

og: I think thee now some common customer.
t: Now I think you probably are a whore.

og: By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.
t: By God, if I've ever slept with a man, it was you.

og: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while?
t: Why have you accused him of sleeping with you all this time then?

og: Because he's guilty, and he is not guilty:
t: Because he's guilty and he's not guilty.

og: He knows I am no maid, and he'll swear to't;
t: He knows I'm not a virgin and he'll swear to it.

og: I'll swear I am a maid, and he knows not.
t: I swear I am a virgin and he doesn't know it.

og: Great king, I am no strumpet, by my life;
t: Great king, I'm no loose woman, by my life.

og: I am either maid, or else this old man's wife.
t: I am either a virgin, or else this old man's wife.

og: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.
t: She just talks nonsense to us. To prison with her.

og: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir:
t: Good mother, get my bail. Hold one moment, royal sir.

og: The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,  And he shall surety me.
t: The jeweler that the ring came from is coming, and he will pay my bail.

og: But for this lord,  Who hath abused me, as he knows himself,  Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him:
t: As for this lord, who has abused me, as he's said himself, although he's never yet harmed me, this is the last I'll say of him:

og: He knows himself my bed he hath defiled;  And at that time he got his wife with child:
t: He knows he's defiled my bed, and when he did so, he got his wife pregnant.

og: Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick:
t: Even though she's dead, she feels her child kick inside her.

og: So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick:  And now behold the meaning.
t: So there's my riddle: someone who's dead is pregnant. And now you'll see what I mean.

og: Is there no exorcistBeguiles the truer office of mine eyes?Is't real that I see?
t: Is there no sorcerer who has bewitched me to see what my eyes present to me? Is what I see real?

og: No, my good lord;'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,The name and not the thing.
t: No, my good lord. It's only the shadow of a wife you see before you. The name of wife but not the thing itself.

og: Both, both. O, pardon!
t: Both, both. Oh, forgive me!

og: O my good lord, when I was like this maid,  I found you wondrous kind.
t: Oh, my good lord, when I pretended to be this maid, I found you incredibly kind.

og: There is your ring;  And, look you, here's your letter;  this it says:
t: There's your ring. And, look at this, here's your letter. Here's what it says:

og: 'When from my finger you can get this ring  And are by me with child,' etc.
t: "When you can get this ring from my finger and are pregnant by me, etc."

og: This is done:  Will you be mine, now you are doubly won?
t: This is done. Will you be mine, now that I've fulfilled both conditions?

og: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.
t: My lord, if she can explain this to me clearly, I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

og: If it appear not plain and prove untrue,Deadly divorce step between me and you!O my dear mother, do I see you living?
t: If it's not clear and it proves untrue, then we'll instantly be separated by divorce!

og: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon:
t: My eyes smell onions. I'm going to weep.

og: Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so,I thank thee: wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee:Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.
t: Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkerchief. There, I thank you. Come visit me at home and we'll have a fun time. Forget your manners—your manners are worthless anyway.

og: Let us from point to point this story know,  To make the even truth in pleasure flow.
t: Tell us the story from beginning to end so that we can enjoy the whole tale.

og: The king's a beggar, now the play is done:
t: The king now turns into a beggar since the play is over.

og: All is well ended, if this suit be won,  That you express content;
t: All will indeed end well if you tell us you're happy with our performance.

og: which we will pay,  With strife to please you, day exceeding day:
t: We'll do whatever we can to please you day after day.

og: Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
t: Now we'll patiently listen while you perform for us:

og: Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
t: give us your hands in applause and we'll love you for it.

og: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour  Draws on apace. Four happy days bring in  Another moon.
t: Now, beautiful Hippolyta, the hour of our wedding is speeding closer. In four joyful days there will be a new crescent moon, and we will marry.

og: But oh, methinks how slow  This old moon wanes! She lingers my desires,  Like to a stepdame or a dowager  Long withering out a young man’s revenue.
t: But oh! The old moon seems to me to shrink away so slowly! It delays me from getting what I desire, just like an old rich widow will force her stepson to wait forever to receive his inheritance.

og: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night.  Four nights will quickly dream away the time.
t: Four days will quickly pass and turn to night. And each night, we will dream away the time.

og: And then the moon, like to a silver bow  New bent in heaven, shall behold the night  Of our solemnities.
t: And soon the moon—like a silver bow newly bent into a curve in the sky—will look down on the night of our wedding celebration.

og: Go, Philostrate,  Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments.
t: Go, Philostrate, get the young people of Athens in the mood to celebrate.

og: Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth.
t: Wake up the lively and swift spirit of fun.

og: Turn melancholy forth to funerals.  The pale companion is not for our pomp.
t: Send sadness out to funerals—that pale emotion has no place at our festivities.

og: Hippolyta, I wooed thee with my sword  And won thy love doing thee injuries.
t: Hippolyta, I wooed with you by fighting against you, and won your love by injuring you.

og: But I will wed thee in another key,  With pomp, with triumph, and with reveling.
t: But I’ll marry you in a different way—with splendid ceremonies, public festivities, and celebration.

og: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd duke.
t: Joy to you, Theseus—our famous and distinguished duke!

og: Thanks, good Egeus. What’s the news with thee?
t: Thank you, dear Egeus. What’s going on with you?

og: Full of vexation come I with complaint  Against my child, my daughter Hermia.
t: I’ve come to you full of anger, to protest against the actions of my daughter, Hermia.

og: Stand forth, Demetrius.  My noble lord,  This man hath my consent to marry her.
t: Step forward, Demetrius. My noble lord Theseus, this man, Demetrius, has my blessing to marry her.

og: Stand forth, Lysander. And my gracious duke,  This man hath bewitched the bosom of my child.  Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,  And interchanged love tokens with my child.
t: Step forward, Lysander. Yet, my gracious duke, this man, Lysander, has put a spell on my daughter’s heart. You, you, Lysander, you have given her poems, and exchanged tokens of love with my daughter.

og: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung  With feigning voice verses of feigning love,  And stol'n the impression of her fantasy  With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits,  Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats—messengers  Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth.
t: You’ve come beneath her window in the moonlight and pretended to love her with your fake love songs. And you’ve stolen her fancy by giving her locks of your hair, rings, toys, trinkets, knickknacks, little presents, flowers, and candies—all of which will powerfully influence an innocent child.

og: With cunning hast thou filched my daughter’s heart,  Turned her obedience (which is due to me)  To stubborn harshness.
t: You’ve sneaked and schemed to steal my daughter’s heart, transforming the obedience which she owes me into harsh stubbornness.

og: And, my gracious duke,  Be it so she will not here before your grace  Consent to marry with Demetrius,  I beg the ancient privilege of Athens.
t: My gracious duke, if Hermia, standing here in front of you, won’t agree to marry Demetrius, then I demand my traditional rights as a father in Athens.

og: As she is mine, I may dispose of her—  Which shall be either to this gentleman  Or to her death—according to our law  Immediately provided in that case.
t: Since she belongs to me, I can do what I want with her, as the law expressly states for just such a case as this: either she marries Demetrius, or she dies.

og: What say you, Hermia? Be advised, fair maid:
t: And what do you say, Hermia? Take this advice, pretty girl:

og: To you your father should be as a god,  One that composed your beauties,
t: you should see your father as a god, since he’s the one who created your beauty.

og: To whom you are but as a form in wax,  By him imprinted and within his power  To leave the figure or disfigure it.  Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
t: To him, you’re like a figure that he sculpted out of wax, giving him the power to leave it as it is or to destroy it. Demetrius is a good man.

og: So is Lysander.
t: So is Lysander.

og: In himself he is.But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice,The other must be held the worthier.
t: Yes he is. But in this situation, because he lacks your father's support, you must consider Demetrius to be better.

og: I would my father looked but with my eyes.
t: I wish my father could look at them through my eyes.

og: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
t: Instead, your view of them must be influenced by your father's wishes.

og: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.  I know not by what power I am made bold  Nor how it may concern my modesty  In such a presence here to plead my thoughts,
t: I beg your Grace to forgive me. I don’t know what is making me bold enough to do this, or even how speaking my thoughts to such an important person as you might harm my reputation for modesty.

og: But I beseech your grace that I may know  The worst that may befall me in this case,  If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
t: But I beg you to explain to me the worst thing that could happen to me in this situation if I refuse to marry Demetrius.

og: Either to die the death or to abjure  Forever the society of men.  Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires.
t: You’ll either be sentenced to death or to never again interact with another man. Therefore, beautiful Hermia, really think about what you want.

og: Know of your youth. Examine well your blood—
t: Think about how young you are, and explore your feelings

og: Whether, if you yield not to your father’s choice,  You can endure the livery of a nun,  For aye to be in shady cloister mewed,  To live a barren sister all your life,  Chanting faint hymns to the cold, fruitless moon.
t: —if you do not give in to your father's wishes, will you be able to tolerate life wearing the robes of a nun, shut up in a dark convent, living your whole life without husband or children, chanting quietly to Diana.

og: Thrice-blessèd they that master so their blood  To undergo such maiden pilgrimage.
t: Those who can control their passions and remain virgins their whole lives are three times as blessed.

og: But earthlier happy is the rose distilled  Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,  Grows, lives, and dies in single blessedness.
t: But a married woman lives happier in this world than a virgin, who achieves the blessing of chastity but grows, lives, and withers to death as a flower on the stem.

og: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,  Ere I will yield my virgin patent up  Unto his lordship,
t: That is how I will grow, live, and die, my lord. I will not give up the ownership of my virginity to my lord father.

og: whose unwishèd yoke  My soul consents not to give sovereignty.
t: My soul refuses to let him command me into the yoke of a marriage I do not want.

og: Take time to pause, and by the next new moon—  The sealing day betwixt my love and me  For everlasting bond of fellowship—
t: Take some time to consider. By the next new moon—the day when my beloved and I will be joined in marriage

og: Upon that day either prepare to die  For disobedience to your father’s will,  Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would,
t: —be ready either to die for disobeying your father's desires, to marry Demetrius, as your father wishes.

og: Or on Diana’s altar to protest  For aye austerity and single life.
t: Or else, you can go to the temple of Diana and vow to spend the rest of your life as a virgin priestess.

og: Relent, sweet Hermia And, Lysander, yieldThy crazèd title to my certain right.
t: Give in, sweet Hermia. And, Lysander, give up your crazy claim to possession of what is mine.

og: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.Let me have Hermia’s. Do you marry him.
t: Her father loves you, Demetrius. Let me have Hermia, and you can marry him.

og: Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love,
t: Rude Lysander, it's true, I do love him.

og: And what is mine my love shall render him.
t: And because I love him, I will give to him what is mine.

og: And she is mine, and all my right of her  I do estate unto Demetrius.
t: Hermia is  mine, and I’m giving my rights to her to Demetrius.

og: I am, my lord, as well derived as he,  As well possessed. My love is more than his.
t: My lord, I’m as noble as Demetrius, and as rich. I love Hermia more than he does.

og: My fortunes every way as fairly ranked,  (If not with vantage) as Demetrius'.  And—which is more than all these boasts can be—  I am beloved of beauteous Hermia.
t: My prospects are in every way as good as Demetrius', if not better. And, more importantly than all of those things I just boasted about, beautiful Hermia loves me.

og: Why should not I then prosecute my right?  Demetrius, I’ll avouch it to his head,  Made love to Nedar’s daughter, Helena,  And won her soul.
t: Why shouldn’t I be able to pursue my rights marry her? Demetrius—and I’ll declare this to his face—wooed Nedar’s daughter, Helena, and won her love.

og: And she, sweet lady, dotes,  Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry  Upon this spotted and inconstant man.
t: Now Helena, that sweet lady, obsesses, deeply obsesses, obsesses over this stained and unfaithful man, idolizing him as if he were a god.

og: I must confess that I have heard so much  And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof,
t: I must admit I’ve heard that too, and meant to speak about it with Demetrius.

og: But being overfull of self-affairs,  My mind did lose it. But, Demetrius, come.  And come, Egeus. You shall go with me.  I have some private schooling for you both.
t: But because I was too busy with my own concerns, I forget about it. But now, Demetrius and Egeus, come with me. I have some advice for you both that I want to give in private.

og: For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself  To fit your fancies to your father’s will,  Or else the law of Athens yields you up  (Which by no means we may extenuate)  To death, or to a vow of single life.
t: As for you, beautiful Hermia, prepare yourself to shape your desires to match what your father wants, or else the law of Athens—which I can’t modify or lessen in any way—demands that you either die or take a vow of chastity and never marry.

og: Come, my Hippolyta. What cheer, my love?  Demetrius and Egeus, go along.  I must employ you in some business  Against our nuptial and confer with you  Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
t: Come along, Hippolyta. How are you, my love? Demetrius and Egeus, come with us. I have some work I need you to do regarding our wedding, and there's something that concerns the two of you that I want to discuss.

og: With duty and desire we follow you.
t: We follow you because it is our duty, and because we want to.

og: How now, my love? Why is your cheek so pale?How chance the roses there do fade so fast?
t: How are you, my love? Why are your cheeks so pale? How is it that the roses in them have faded so quickly?

og: Belike for want of rain, which I could wellBeteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
t: Probably because they lacked rain, which I could easily give them from the tears in my eyes.

og: Ay me! For aught that I could ever read,  Could ever hear by tale or history,  The course of true love never did run smooth.
t: Oh dear! In every book that I have ever read, whether  a story or a history, the path of true love is never smooth or easy.

og: But either it was different in blood—
t: Perhaps the lovers are of different social classes—

og: O cross! Too high to be enthralled to low.
t: Oh, what an obstacle! Being a person of high rank in love with someone of low stature.

og: Or else misgraffèd in respect of years—
t: Or else they were very different ages—

og: O spite! Too old to be engaged to young.
t: Oh, vicious fate! Being too old to marry someone young.

og: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends—
t: Or else their ability to choose depended on the wishes of their relatives—

og: O hell, to choose love by another’s eyes!
t: Oh, what a hell, to have someone else's wishes determine who you can love!

og: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,  War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it,  Making it momentary as a sound,  Swift as a shadow, short as any dream,
t: Or—even if two people loved each other and could choose to marry—war, death, or sickness might intervene, so that their love lasts no longer than a sound, is as fleeting as a shadow, short as a dream.

og: Brief as the lightning in the collied night;  That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and Earth,  And ere a man hath power to say “Behold!”
t: Or it's as brief as a bolt of lightning that—like a flash of passion—lights up heaven and Earth but then disappears into darkness before you can even say "Look!"

og: The jaws of darkness do devour it up.  So quick bright things come to confusion.
t: That’s how bright things that are full of life are destroyed.

og: If then true lovers have been ever crossed,  It stands as an edict in destiny.
t: If true lovers are always thwarted, then it proves that destiny is saying that our thwarted love must be true.

og: Then let us teach our trial patience,
t: So let’s make sure to approach our problem with patience.

og: Because it is a customary cross,  As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs,  Wishes and tears, poor fancy’s followers.
t: Since all true love must be thwarted, then being thwarted is as much a part of love as dreams, sighs, wishes, and tears are.

og: A good persuasion.
t: That's the right way to think about it.

og: Therefore, hear me, Hermia.  I have a widow aunt, a dowager  Of great revenue, and she hath no child.
t: So, listen, Hermia. I have an aunt who is a widow, who has property and great wealth, and doesn’t have any children.

og: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues,  And she respects me as her only son.  There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee.  And to that place the sharp Athenian law  Cannot pursue us.
t: Her house is about twenty miles from Athens, and she thinks of me as a son.  Dear Hermia, I could marry you there, where the harsh laws of Athens can’t follow us.

og: If thou lovest me then,  Steal forth thy father’s house tomorrow night.
t: So if you love me, sneak out of your father’s house tomorrow night.

og: And in the wood, a league without the town—  Where I did meet thee once with Helena  To do observance to a morn of May—  There will I stay for thee.
t: I will wait for you in the woods, three miles out of town, at the spot where I once met you with Helena to celebrate May Day.

og: My good Lysander!  I swear to thee by Cupid’s strongest bow,  By his best arrow with the golden head,  By the simplicity of Venus' doves,
t: My noble Lysander! I swear to you—by Cupid's strongest bow, by his best gold-tipped arrow; by the innocent doves that drive Venus' chariot;

og: By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,  And by that fire which burned the Carthage queen  When the false Troyan under sail was seen,
t: by everything that binds souls together and makes love grow; by the bonfire upon which Queen Dido of Carthage burned herself to death when she saw that her lover Aeneas had secretly sailed away from her;

og: By all the vows that ever men have broke  (In number more than ever women spoke),
t: and by all the promises that men have ever broken (which outnumber all the promises women have ever made).

og: In that same place thou hast appointed me,  Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.
t: I will meet you tomorrow at the spot you have asked me to go to.

og: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.
t: Keep your promise, my love. Look, here comes Helena.

og: Godspeed, fair Helena! Whither away?
t: Welcome, beautiful Helena! Where are you going?

og: Call you me “fair?” That “fair” again unsay.  Demetrius loves your fair. O happy fair!
t: Did you call me “beautiful?” Take it back. Your beauty is what Demetrius loves. Oh, lucky beauty!

og: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air  More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear  When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.
t: Your eyes are like stars, and your sweet voice is more melodic than a lark’s song is to a shepherd in the springtime, when the wheat is green and hawthorn buds appear.

og: Sickness is catching. Oh, were favor so,  Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go.
t: Sickness is contagious. Oh, I wish beauty was also. I would catch yours, beautiful Hermia, before I left.

og: My ear should catch your voice. My eye, your eye.  My tongue should catch your tongue’s sweet melody.  Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,  The rest I’d give to be to you translated.
t: My ear would be infected by your voice, my eye by your eye, and my tongue would catch your tongue's musical voice. If I owned the world, I’d give it all up—with the exception of Demetrius—to be transformed into you.

og: O, teach me how you look and with what art  You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
t: Oh, teach me how you look at Demetrius, and the tricks you use to make him fall in love with you.

og: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.
t: I frown at him, but he still loves me.

og: Oh, that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!
t: Oh, if only your frowns could teach my smiles to have that same ability!

og: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.
t: I curse him, but he responds with love.

og: Oh, that my prayers could such affection move!
t: Oh, if only my prayers could arouse that kind of affection!

og: The more I hate, the more he follows me.
t: The more I hate him, the more he follows me.

og: The more I love, the more he hateth me.
t: The more I love him, the more he hates me.

og: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
t: Helena, his foolishness is not my fault.

og: None, but your beauty. Would that fault were mine!
t: It’s only your beauty’s fault. I wish I had that fault!

og: Take comfort. He no more shall see my face.  Lysander and myself will fly this place.
t: Don’t worry. He'll never see my face again. Lysander and I are running away from here.

og: Before the time I did Lysander see  Seemed Athens as a paradise to me.
t: Before the first time I saw Lysander, Athens seemed like paradise to me.

og: Oh, then, what graces in my love do dwell,  That he hath turned a heaven unto a hell!
t: But Lysander is so beautiful and graceful that, by comparison, he’s turned what I thought was heaven into hell!

og: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold.
t: Helena, we’ll let you in on our plan.

og: Tomorrow night when Phoebe doth behold  Her silver visage in the watery glass,  Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass
t: Tomorrow night—when Phoebe is reflected on the water and decorates the grass with beads of pearly light

og: (A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal),  Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.
t: (the time of night that always hides lovers on the run—we plan to sneak out through the gates of Athens.

og: And in the wood where often you and I  Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,  Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,  There my Lysander and myself shall meet.
t: In the woods where you and I used to laze around on the pale primroses, sharing all of the sweet secrets of our hearts—that’s where Lysander and I will meet.

og: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes  To seek new friends and stranger companies.  Farewell, sweet playfellow. Pray thou for us.  And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!
t: Then we’ll turn away from Athens and  look for new friends and the company of strangers. Goodbye, sweet friend of my youth. Pray for us, and may fate give you Demetrius!

og: Keep word, Lysander. We must starve our sight  From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
t: Keep your promise, Lysander. We must refrain from the pleasure of seeing each other until tomorrow at midnight.

og: I will, my Hermia.
t: I will, my Hermia.

og: How happy some o'er other some can be!  Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.  But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so.
t: How happy some people can be compared to others!  Throughout Athens, people think I'm as beautiful as Hermia. But what does that matter? Demetrius doesn't think so.

og: He will not know what all but he do know.  And as he errs, doting on Hermia's eyes,  So I, admiring of his qualities.
t: The only opinion he has is his own. And as he wanders, idolizing Hermia's eyes, likewise I admire his beauty.

og: Things base and vile, holding no quantity,  Love can transpose to form and dignity.  Love looks not with the eyes but with the mind.  And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind.
t: Love can transform crude and horrible things of no worth into beautiful and dignified things. Love doesn't look with eyes, but with the mind. That's why they paint winged Cupid blind.

og: Nor hath Love's mind of any judgment taste—  Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste.  And therefore is Love said to be a child,  Because in choice he is so oft beguiled.
t: And Love doesn't have good judgment or taste—wings and blindness make for undue speed in falling in love.  Thus, Love is thought of as a child, because he often makes the wrong choice.

og: As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,  So the boy Love is perjured everywhere.
t: Just like mischievous boys who go back on their word as they play games, so too does the boy Love perjure himself everywhere.

og: For ere Demetrius looked on Hermia's eyne,  He hailed down oaths that he was only mine.  And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,  So he dissolved, and showers of oaths did melt.
t: Because before Demetrius saw Helena's eyes, he swore that he belonged to only me. And when he felt attracted to Hermia, he dissolved. His promises melted down like hail in the heat.

og: I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight.  Then to the wood will he tomorrow night  Pursue her. And for this intelligence  If I have thanks, it is a dear expense.
t: I will go and tell him that beautiful Hermia is running away. Then he'll got to the forest tomorrow night to pursue her. And if he thanks me for this piece of information, it will all be worth it.

og: But herein mean I to enrich my pain,  To have his sight thither and back again.
t: But in this way I plan to make my pain worse, by seeing him go there and back again.

og: Is all our company here?
t: Are all of us here?

og: You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the scrip.
t: You'd be best off calling their names generally, one person at a time, following the order of the names on the list.

og: Here is the scroll of every man’s name which is thoughtfit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his wedding day at night.
t: Here is the list of the names of every man in Athens who we consider good enough to act in the short play we’re going to perform for the duke and duchess on the night of their wedding day.

og: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.
t: First, Peter Quince, tell us what the play is about. Then read the names of the actors, and in that way build up to a conclusion.

og: Marry, our play i s The most lamentable comedy and mostcruel death of Pyramus and Thisbe.
t: Indeed, I will. Our play is called The Very Tragic Comedy of the Awful Deaths of Pyramus and Thisbe.

og: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.
t: Believe me, it’s a great piece of work, and very funny, too. Now, Peter Quince, call out the actors on your list. Men, gather around.

og: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver?
t: Answer when I call your name. Nick Bottom, the weaver?

og: Ready. Name what part I am for and proceed.
t: Here. Say which part I’m going to play, and then continue.

og: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.
t: Nick Bottom, you will play the role of Pyramus.

og: What is Pyramus? A lover or a tyrant?
t: What’s Pyramus? A lover or a tyrant?

og: A lover that kills himself, most gallant, for love.
t: A lover who, very nobly, kills himself for love.

og: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it. If I do it, let the audience look to their eyes. I will move storms.
t: That role will require some tears from me if I am to perform it well. If I perform it, the audience better check their own eyes. I’ll make tears fall like rainstorms.

og: I will condole in some measure.
t: I’ll make them weep.  I'll express grief—just the right amount of grief, of course.

og: To the rest. Yet my chief humor is for a tyrant. I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in to make all split.
t: Okay, now list the other actors.   But, actually, my first choice would be to play a tyrant. I'd make a wonderful Hercules, or any other part that requires ranting and raving that will bring the house down.

og: The raging rocks  And shivering shocks  Shall break the locks  Of prison gates.
t: The raging rocksAnd shivering shocksWill break the locksOf prison gates.

og: And Phoebus' car  Shall shine from far  And make and mar  The foolish Fates.
t: And Phoebus' cartWill shine from afarAnd make and marThe foolish Fates.

og: This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players. This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant’s vein. A lover is more condoling.
t: That was high art! Now say who the other actors are. That speech was in the style of Hercules, the tyrant's style. A lover would be more weepy.

og: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender?
t: Francis Flute, the bellows-repairman?

og: Here, Peter Quince.
t: Here, Peter Quince.

og: Flute, you must take Thisbe on you.
t: Flute, you’ll play the part of Thisbe.

og: What is Thisbe? A wandering knight?
t: Who’s Thisbe? A knight on a quest?

og: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.
t: Thisbe is the lady whom Pyramus loves.

og: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman. I have a beard coming.
t: No, really, please don’t make me play a woman. I’m growing a beard.

og: That’s all one. You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.
t: That makes no difference. You’ll be wearing a mask, and you can make your voice as high as you want.

og: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too! I’ll speak in a monstrous little voice: “Thisne, Thisne!” “Ah, Pyramus, my lover dear, thy Thisbe dear and lady dear!”
t: If I can wear a mask, let me play Thisbe too! I’ll speak in an amazing high-pitched voice. Pyramus will say: “Thisne, Thisne!” Then I'll say: “Ah, Pyramus, my dear love! I’m your dear Thisbe—your dear lady!”

og: No, no. You must play Pyramus. And Flute, you Thisbe.
t: No, no. You’re playing Pyramus. And Flute, you’re playing Thisbe.

og: Well, proceed.
t: Well, all right. Continue.

og: Robin Starveling, the tailor?
t: Robin Starveling, the tailor?

og: Here, Peter Quince.
t: Here, Peter Quince.

og: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother. Tom Snout, the tinker?
t: Robin Starveling, you’re going to play Thisbe’s mother. Tom Snout, the repairman?

og: Here, Peter Quince.
t: Here, Peter Quince.

og: You, Pyramus' father. Myself, Thisbe’s father. Snug thejoiner, you, the lion’s part. And I hope here is a playfitted.
t: You’ll play Pyramus’ father. As for myself, I’ll play Thisbe’s father. Snug, the cabinetmaker, you’ll play the part of the lion. Now, I hope the play has been well cast.

og: Have you the lion’s part written? Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.
t: Do you have the lion’s part written down? If you do, please give it to me, because I'm a slow learner.

og: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.
t: You can improvise the whole thing, because it's just roaring.

og: Let me play the lion too. I will roar, that I will do any man’s heart good to hear me.
t: Let me play the lion, too! I’ll roar so well that it’ll delight anyone who hears me.

og: I will roar, that I will make the duke say, “Let him roar again. Let him roar again.”
t: I’ll roar so well that the duke will say, “Let him roar again. Let him roar again.”

og: An you should do it too terribly, you would fright the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek.
t: If you roar too terrifyingly, you’ll scare the duchess and the other ladies, and make them scream.

og: And thatwere enough to hang us all.
t: And that would be enough to get us all hanged.

og: That would hang us, every mother’s son.
t: They'd hang every single one of us.

og: grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us.
t: I agree, my friends, that if you scare the ladies out of their wits, they’d have no choice but to hang us.

og: But I will aggravate my voice so that I will roar you as gently as any sucking dove. I will roaryou an ’twere any nightingale.
t: But I’ll aggravate my voice so that I’ll roar as gently as a baby dove. I’ll roar like a melodic nightingale.

og: You can play no part but Pyramus. For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely, gentlemanlike man.
t: You can’t play any part but Pyramus. Because Pyramus is a good-looking man, the most handsome man you could find on a summer’s day, the most lovely gentlemanly man.

og: Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.
t: Therefore you must play Pyramus.

og: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?
t: Very well, I’ll do it. What would be the best beard for me to wear for the part?

og: Why, what you will.
t: Why, whichever one you want to wear.

og: I will discharge it in either your straw-color beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French crown-color beard, your perfect yellow.
t: I’ll play the role wearing either a straw-colored beard, or a brownish-yellow beard, or a deep red beard, or a bright yellow beard the color of a French crown.

og: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play barefaced.
t: Some French heads have no hair at all, so maybe you could play the role clean-shaven.

og: But masters, here are yourparts. And I am to entreat you, request you, and desireyou to con them by tomorrow night and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight.
t: But, gentlemen, here are your scripts. I beg you, ask you, and desire you to please learn your lines by tomorrow night. Then meet me by moonlight in the duke’s forest a mile outside of town.

og: There will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known.
t: There we will rehearse, because if we do it in the city, we’ll be bothered by crowds of people and everyone will know what we're going to perform.

og: In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants. I pray you, fail me not.
t: In the meantime, I’ll make a list of props that we’ll need for the play. Now, I beg you, don't miss the rehearsal.

og: We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously. Take pains. Be perfect. Adieu.
t: We’ll be there, and there we’ll rehearse obscenely and courageously. Work hard, memorize your lines perfectly. Farewell.

og: At the duke’s oak we meet.
t: We’ll meet at the giant oak tree in the duke’s forest.

og: How now, spirit? Whither wander you?
t: How are you, spirit? Where are you going?

og: Over hill, over dale,  Thorough bush, thorough brier,  Over park, over pale,  Thorough flood, thorough fire.
t: Over hill, over valley, through bush, through thorn, over park, over fenced-in pastures, through water, through fire.

og: I do wander everywhere  Swifter than the moon’s sphere.
t: I wander everywhere faster than the moon revolves around the Earth.

og: And I serve the fairy queen  To dew her orbs upon the green.  The cowslips tall her pensioners be:  In their gold coats spots you see.  Those be rubies, fairy favors.  In those freckles live their savors.
t: I serve the fairy queen, decorating the grass with dew. The tall cowslip flowers are her bodyguards: the spots you see on their gold coats are rubies, fairy gifts. Their sweet smells come from those spots.

og: I must go seek some dewdrops here  And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.
t: Now I must go find some dewdrops, and hang a pearl of dew in every cowslip flower.

og: Farewell, thou lob of spirits. I’ll be gone.  Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
t: Farewell, you silly unsophisticated spirit. I must go. The queen and her elves will be here soon.

og: The king doth keep his revels here tonight.  Take heed the queen come not within his sight.  For Oberon is passing fell and wrath
t: The king is having a party here tonight. Be careful that the queen doesn’t come within his sight, because King Oberon is beyond angry.

og: Because that she, as her attendant hath  A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king.  She never had so sweet a changeling.
t: She stole an charming boy from an Indian king to be her servant. She’s never kidnapped such an adorable human child,

og: And jealous Oberon would have the child  Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild.
t: and Oberon is jealous. He wants the child to be a knight within his own retinue, to wander with him through the wild forests.

og: But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy,  Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.
t: But the queen refuses to give up the beloved boy. Instead she crowns the boy’s head with flowers and treasures him.

og: And now they never meet in grove or green,  By fountain clear or spangled starlight sheen.
t: Now Oberon and Titania refuse to meet each other, whether in the forest or the fields, by the clear water of a stream, or beneath the stars.

og: But they do square, that all their elves for fear  Creep into acorn cups and hide them there.
t: They just argue, so that all their elves get frightened and sneak off to hide in acorns.

og: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,  Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite  Called Robin Goodfellow.
t: Either I’m completely mistaken, or else you’re that mischievous and naughty spirit named Robin Goodfellow.

og: Are not you he  That frights the maidens of the villagery,  Skim milk, and sometimes labor in the quern  And bootless make the breathless housewife churn,
t: Aren’t you the one who plays pranks on the maidens in the village, skimming the cream off the milk; clogging up the flour mill so they can't grind grain into flour; and making housewives breathless by keeping their milk from turning into butter no matter how much they churn?

og: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm,  Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?
t: Don't you stop beer from foaming, and lead people out at night the wrong way while you laugh at them?

og: Those that “Hobgoblin” call you, and “sweet Puck,”  You do their work, and they shall have good luck.  Are not you he?
t: But those who call you “Hobgoblin,” or “sweet Puck"— you do their work for them and make sure they have good luck. Aren't you him?

og: Thou speak’st aright.  I am that merry wanderer of the night.  I jest to Oberon and make him smile
t: You are correct. I am the mischievous wanderer of the night. I joke to Oberon and make him smile.

og: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,  Neighing in likeness of a filly foal.  And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl  In very likeness of a roasted crab,
t: Sometimes I’ll trick a fat, well-fed horse by neighing as if I'm a young filly. Sometimes I hide at the bottom of an old gossipy woman’s cup in the form of a crab apple.

og: And when she drinks, against her lips I bob  And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.  The wisest aunt telling the saddest tale  Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me.
t: When she drinks, I bob against her lips so that she spills the beer on her old wrinkly neck. Sometimes an old woman telling a sad story will mistake me for a three-legged stool and try to sit on me.

og: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,  And “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough,  And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh,
t: Then I slip out from underneath her butt and she falls down, crying, “I'm sitting cross-legged like a tailor!” Then she starts to cough, and everyone around holds their bellies and laughs.

og: And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear  A merrier hour was never wasted there.
t: Their laughter grows, and they sneeze, and I swear none of them has ever wasted an hour in greater fun.

og: But, room, fairy! Here comes Oberon.
t: But make room, fairy! Here comes Oberon.

og: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!
t: And here’s my queen. I wish he’d go away!

og: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.
t: I'm not glad to see you this night, proud Titania.

og: What, jealous Oberon? Fairies, skip hence.I have forsworn his bed and company.
t: What, are you jealous, Oberon? Fairies, let’s leave this place. I’ve sworn I’ll never sleep with him or be near him again.

og: Tarry, rash wanton. Am not I thy lord?
t: Wait, you impulsive and willful creature. Am I not your lord and husband?

og: Then I must be thy lady. But I know  When thou hast stolen away from Fairyland,  And in the shape of Corin sat all day,  Playing on pipes of corn and versing love  To amorous Phillida.
t: If you were, then I would have to be your lady and wife, to whom you are faithful. But I know that you snuck away from Fairyland disguised as a shepherd, and spent all day playing music and reciting love poems to an infatuated shepherdess.

og: Why art thou here,  Come from the farthest steep of India?
t: Why have you come here, all the way from the furthest mountains of India?

og: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,  Your buskined mistress and your warrior love,  To Theseus must be wedded, and you come  To give their bed joy and prosperity.
t: Because, of course, that bouncing Amazon Hippolyta—your half-boot-wearing mistress and warrior lover—is getting married to Theseus, and you’ve come to bless their wedding bed with joy and prosperity.

og: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania,  Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?
t: How can you shamelessly make insinuations about my relationship with Hippolyta, when you know that I know about your love for Theseus?

og: Glance at my creditwith Hippolyta,  Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night  From Perigouna, whom he ravishèd?
t: Didn't you entice him through the glimmering night away from Perigouna, whom he had just abducted and raped?

og: And make him with fair Ægles break his faith,  With Ariadne and Antiopa?
t: And didn't you make him be unfaithful to Aegles, Ariadne, and Antiopa?

og: These are the forgeries of jealousy.
t: These are lies that emerge from your jealousy.

og: And never, since the middle summer’s spring,  Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead,  By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook,  Or in the beachèd margent of the sea,  To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,  But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport.
t: Not once, since the beginning of midsummer—whether on a hill, in a valley, a forest, or a meadow, by a pebbly spring or rushing brook, or on a beach next to the ocean—have my fairies and I been able to meet and perform our ring dances to honor the whistling wind without you showing up with your shouting to interrupt our fun.

og: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,  As in revenge, have sucked up from the sea  Contagious fogs,
t: Because of that, the winds have gotten angry at our lack of response to their calls. In revenge the winds have made nasty fogs rise up from the sea,

og: which falling in the land  Have every pelting river made so proud  That they have overborne their continents.
t: and make rain fall upon the land so that rivers have grown so large they flood the land around them.

og: The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain,  The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn  Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.
t: All the work done by farmers' and their oxen has been ruined, and the corn has rotted before it could grow ripe.

og: The fold stands empty in the drownèd field,  And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.
t: Animal pens stand empty in flooded fields, and the crows are fat from eating the bodies of sheep and cattle killed by disease.

og: The nine-men’s-morris is filled up with mud,  And the quaint mazes in the wanton green  For lack of tread are undistinguishable.
t: The village greens where men play games together are filled with mud, and the maze-like paths people have made through the high-grown grass have faded away because no one walks on them.

og: The human mortals want their winter here.  No night is now with hymn or carol blessed.
t: The humans have not gotten the winter they should have, and the nights to not receive the blessings of the hymns or carols of that season.

og: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,  Pale in her anger, washes all the air,  That rheumatic diseases do abound.
t: As a result the moon, who controls the tides, is pale with anger, and moistens the air so that colds and flu spread everywhere.

og: And thorough this distemperature we see  The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts  Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose,  And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown  An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds  Is, as in mockery, set.
t: Because of this disturbance in the normal natural order, the seasons have changed: bitter frosts descend upon red roses. And Old Man Winter wears an icy crown decorated with sweet summer flower buds, like some kind of cruel prank.

og: The spring, the summer,  The childing autumn, angry winter change  Their wonted liveries, and the mazèd world,  By their increase, now knows not which is which.
t: The spring, summer, fruitful autumn, and angry winter have all changed out of their normal clothes, and now the confused world can't tell one from the other.

og: And this same progeny of evils comes  From our debate, from our dissension.  We are their parents and original.
t: And all of these bad outcomes are the result of our argument. We are the cause of this.

og: Do you amend it then. It lies in you.
t: So fix it, then. You have the power to do that.

og: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?
t: Why would Titania want to argue with her Oberon?

og: I do but beg a little changeling boy,  To be my henchman.
t: All I’m asking for is to have that little human boy to be my attendant.

og: Set your heart at rest.  The Fairyland buys not the child of me.
t: Calm your little heart. I wouldn't trade the child for all of Fairyland.

og: His mother was a votaress of my order,  And in the spicèd Indian air by night  Full often hath she gossiped by my side,  And sat with me on Neptune’s yellow sands,  Marking th' embarkèd traders on the flood,
t: His mother was one of my priestesses, and we often used to gossip together in the spiced night air in India, or sit on the beach by the ocean watching merchant ships sail by on the water.

og: When we have laughed to see the sails conceive  And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;
t: We'd laugh when we saw the wind fill up the sails, as if that amorous wind had made them pregnant and big-bellied.

og: Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait  Following—her womb then rich with my young squire—  Would imitate,
t: She would imitate the ships—she was pregnant at the time with the little boy—

og: and sail upon the land  To fetch me trifles and return again  As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.
t: and she would pretend to sail over the land to get me little presents, and then come back carrying gifts like she was a trading ship returning from a voyage, rich with cargo.

og: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die.  And for her sake do I rear up her boy,  And for her sake I will not part with him.
t: But she was a mortal, and she died giving birth to the boy. For her sake I will not give him up.

og: How long within this wood intend you stay?
t: How long do you plan to stay in this forest?

og: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding day.
t: Perhaps until after Theseus’ wedding day.

og: If you will patiently dance in our round  And see our moonlight revels, go with us.
t: If you will join us in our circle dance and moonlight celebrations without causing trouble, then come with us.

og: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.
t: If not, stay away from me, and I’ll avoid your lands.

og: Give me that boy and I will go with thee.
t: Give me that boy and I’ll come with you.

og: Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away!We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.
t: Not for your entire fairy kingdom. Fairies, let’s go! We’re going to have a real fight if I stay any longer.

og: Well, go thy way. Thou shalt not from this grove  Till I torment thee for this injury.
t: Well, then go on your way. You won’t leave this grove until I’ve made you suffer for this insult.

og: My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememberest  Since once I sat upon a promontory  And heard a mermaid on a dolphin’s back
t: My noble Puck, come here. Do you remember that time when I was sitting on a cliff and heard a mermaid riding on a dolphin’s back

og: Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath  That the rude sea grew civil at her song  And certain stars shot madly from their spheres  To hear the seamaid’s music?
t: sing with such a sweet and harmonious voice that the rough waters of the ocean grew calm, and some stars shot out of the sky in order to hear her sing?

og: I remember.
t: I remember.

og: That very time I saw (but thou couldst not)  Flying between the cold moon and the Earth,  Cupid all armed.
t: On that night, I saw Cupid (even though you couldn't); Cupid with all his arrows, flying from the cold moon to the earth.

og: A certain aim he took  At a fair vestal thronèd by the west,  And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow  As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.
t: He aimed at a beautiful virgin who sat upon a throne in the western end of the world, and he shot his love arrow hard enough to pierce a hundred thousand hearts.

og: But I might see young Cupid’s fiery shaft  Quenched in the chaste beams of the watery moon,  And the imperial votaress passèd on,  In maiden meditation, fancy-free.
t: But I saw young Cupid’s fiery arrow weakened by the virginal beams of the watery moon, and so the royal virgin was unaffected by the arrow, and so continued on with her virginal thoughts, without a care.

og: Yet marked I where the bolt of Cupid fell.  It fell upon a little western flower,  Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.  And maidens call it “love-in-idleness.”
t: But I noticed where Cupid’s arrow fell. It fell on a little western flower, which used to be as white as milk but turned purple when it was wounded by the arrow of love. Young women call that flower “love-in-idleness."

og: Fetch me that flower. The herb I showed thee once.  The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid  Will make or man or woman madly dote  Upon the next live creature that it sees.
t: Bring me that flower. I showed the plant to you once. If the juice of that flower is dropped on the eyelids of a sleeping person, that man or woman will then fall madly in love with the next living creature he or she sees.

og: Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again  Ere the leviathan can swim a league.
t: Bring me this plant, and return here before Leviathan can swim three miles.

og: I’ll put a girdle round about the EarthIn forty minutes.
t: I'll circle the world in forty minutes.

og: Having once this juice,  I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep  And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.
t: Once I get this juice, I’ll spy on Titania until she falls asleep and then drop some of it on her eyes.

og: The next thing then she waking looks upon—  Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull,  On meddling monkey or on busy ape—  She shall pursue it with the soul of love.
t: The first thing she sees when she wakes up—whether it's a lion, bear, wolf, bull, monkey, or an ape—she'll fall deeply and madly in love with.

og: And ere I take this charm from of her sight—  As I can take it with another herb—  I’ll make her render up her page to me.
t: And before I remove the spell from her eyes—which I can do by using another plant—I’ll make her give that little boy to me.

og: But who comes here? I am invisible.  And I will overhear their conference.
t: But who’s that coming this way? I've made myself invisible and listen in on their conversation.

og: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
t: I don’t love you, so stop following me.

og: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?  The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.
t: Where are Lysander and beautiful Hermia? I want to kill Lysander, but Hermia kills me with her beauty.

og: Thou told’st me they were stol'n unto this wood.  And here am I, and wood within this wood,  Because I cannot meet my Hermia.
t: You told me they snuck into this forest. And here I am, going crazy in the middle of the woods because I cannot find my Hermia.

og: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
t: Go away, get out of here, and stop following me.

og: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.
t: You attract me to you, you heartless magnet!

og: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart  Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,  And I shall have no power to follow you.
t: But you must not attract iron, because my heart is as true as steel. If you give up your power to attract me, then I won’t have any power to follow you.

og: Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?Or rather, do I not in plainest truthTell you I do not, nor I cannot, love you?
t: Do I invite you to follow me? Do I speak to you kindly? Instead, don’t I tell you as clearly and plainly as possible that that I do not and cannot love you?

og: And even for that do I love you the more.  I am your spaniel. And, Demetrius,  The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
t: And for that I love you even more. I’m your little dog. And, Demetrius, the more you beat me, the more I’ll love you.

og: Use me but as your spaniel—spurn me, strike me,  Neglect me, lose me. Only give me leave,  Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
t: Treat me like a dog—kick me, hit me, ignore me, try to lose me. Just allow me to follow you, even though I'm not good enough for you.

og: What worser place can I beg in your love—  And yet a place of high respect with me—  Than to be usèd as you use your dog?
t: Is there a worse position I could ask to be held in your heart than to be treated as you would treat a dog? And yet I would consider it a place of honor.

og: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit.For I am sick when I do look on thee.
t: Don’t tempt me to hate you any more than I already do. It makes me sick just to look at you.

og: And I am sick when I look not on you.
t: And I am sick when I'm not looking at you.

og: You do impeach your modesty too much,  To leave the city and commit yourself  Into the hands of one that loves you not,
t: You shouldn't risk your reputation or your virginity by leaving the city and putting yourself into the hands of someone who doesn’t love you

og: To trust the opportunity of night  And the ill counsel of a desert place  With the rich worth of your virginity.
t: in the middle of the night in a deserted place, what with all the bad ideas that occur to people in deserted places.

og: Your virtue is my privilege. For that  It is not night when I do see your face.
t: Your goodness will protect me. And, anyway, the beauty of your face shines, so it doesn't seem like nighttime to me.

og: Therefore I think I am not in the night.  Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,  For you in my respect are all the world.
t: Besides, the forest doesn’t seem deserted, because for me you are the entire world.

og: Then how can it be said I am alone  When all the world is here to look on me?
t: So how can anyone say I’m alone, when the whole world is here to look at me?

og: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
t: I’ll run away from you and hide in the bushes, and leave you to the mercy of wild animals.

og: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.  Run when you will, the story shall be changed.
t: Not even the wildest animal is as vicious as you. Run whenever you want to. The old story of the lustful god Apollo chasing the virginal nymph Daphne will be flipped:

og: Apollo flies and Daphne holds the chase.  The dove pursues the griffin. The mild hind  Makes speed to catch the tiger
t: Apollo will run, and Daphne will pursue him. The dove will chase the griffin. The gentle deer will race to catch the tiger

og: —bootless speed,  When cowardice pursues and valor flies.
t: . Speed is useless when the cowardly person is chasing the brave one.

og: I will not stay thy questions. Let me go.Or if thou follow me, do not believeBut I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
t: I’m not going to wait around listening to your arguments. Let me go by myself. Or if you follow me, understand that I’ll do bad things to you in the forest.

og: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field  You do me mischief.
t: Well, you've already done bad things to me in the church, in the town, and in the fields.

og: Fie, Demetrius!  Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.
t: Curse you, Demetrius! Your bad behavior is an insult to all women.

og: We cannot fight for love as men may do.  We should be wooed and were not made to woo.
t: We can't fight for love as men can. We should be pursued. We weren’t made to be the pursuer.

og: I’ll follow thee and make a heaven of hell, To die uponthe hand I love so well.
t: I’ll follow you and turn this hell of mine into a heaven, by ensuring that I am killed by the one I love so much.

og: Fare thee well, nymph. Ere he do leave this grove,Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.
t: Goodbye, nymph. Before he leaves this forest, you’ll be running from him and he'll be chasing after your love.

og: Ay, there it is.
t: Yes, here it is.

og: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.
t: Do you have the flower? Welcome, traveler.

og: I pray thee, give it me.
t: Please, give it to me.

og: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,  Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,  Quite overcanopied with luscious woodbine,  With sweet musk roses and with eglantine.
t: I know a hill where wild thyme blooms, and oxlips and violets grow. It’s covered with a canopy of luscious honeysuckle, sweet musk-roses, and sweetbrier.

og: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,  Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.
t: Titania sometimes sleeps there at night among the flowers, soothed to sleep by dances and delights.

og: And there the snake throws her enameled skin,  Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.  And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes  And make her full of hateful fantasies.
t: In that place snakes shed their skin, producing clothes just large enough to wrap a fairy in. There I’ll wet her eyes with the juice of this flower, and fill her with pathetic fantasies.

og: Take thou some of it and seek through this grove:  A sweet Athenian lady is in love  With a disdainful youth.
t: You take some of it and search the forest: there's a sweet Athenian lady who is in love with a young man who does not want her.

og: Anoint his eyes.  But do it when the next thing he espies  May be the lady.
t: Put some juice on his eyes, and do it in a way that ensures that the lady will be the next thing he sees.

og: Thou shalt know the man  By the Athenian garments he hath on.  Effect it with some care, that he may prove  More fond on her than she upon her love.
t: You’ll recognize the man by the Athenian clothes he's wearing. Be careful when you do it, so that when it's done he loves her more than she loves him.

og: And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.
t: Then meet me before the rooster’s first crow at dawn.

og: Fear not, my lord. Your servant shall do so.
t: Don't worry, my lord. As your servant, I'll follow your orders.

og: Come now, a roundel and a fairy song.  Then for the third part of a minute, hence—
t: Come, dance in a circle and sing a fairy song. Then go off for a while to do your work.

og: Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds,  Some war with reremice for their leathern wings  To make my small elves coats,
t: Some of you can kill the worms plaguing the rosebuds. Others can fight with bats for their leathery wings, so we can use them to make coats for my small elves.

og: and some keep back  The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders  At our quaint spirits.
t: And still others of you can keep away the loud owl that hoots in surprise when it sees us pretty fairies.

og: Sing me now asleep.  Then to your offices and let me rest.
t: Now sing me to sleep, then go off to your work and let me rest.

og: Philomel, with melody  Sing in our sweet lullaby.
t: Nightingale, melodiously Sing our sweet lullaby.

og: Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby.  Never harm  Nor spell nor charm  Come our lovely lady nigh.
t: Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby.Let no harmOr spell or charmCome near our lovely lady.

og: So good night, with lullaby.
t: Say good night with a lullaby.

og: Weaving spiders, come not here.  Hence, you long-legged spinners, hence!
t: Spiders with your webs, stay away.You long-legged things, begone!

og: Beetles black, approach not near.  Worm nor snail, do no offense.
t: Black beetles, don’t come near.Worms and snails, don’t be bad.

og: Philomel, with melody  Sing in our sweet lullaby.  Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby.
t: Nightingale, melodiouslySing our sweet lullaby.Lulla, lulla, lullaby, lulla, lulla, lullaby.

og: Never harm  Nor spell nor charm  Come our lovely lady nigh.  So good night, with lullaby.
t: Let no harmOr spell or charmCome near our lovely lady.Say good night with a lullaby.

og: Hence, away! Now all is well. One aloof stand sentinel.
t: Come on, let’s go! All is well. One of us can remain alone and stand guard.

og: What thou seest when thou dost wake,  Do it for thy true love take.  Love and languish for his sake.
t: Whatever you first see when you wake up, take it as your true love. Love and yearn for him.

og: Be it ounce or cat or bear,  Pard or boar with bristled hair,  In thy eye that shall appear,  When thou wakest, it is thy dear.
t: Whether he’s a lynx, a wildcat, a bear, a leopard, or a wild boar with bristly hair—when you wake, it will look like your love in your eyes.

og: Wake when some vile thing is near.
t: May you wake up when something disgusting is close by.

og: Fair love, you faint with wandering in the wood.  And to speak troth, I have forgot our way.
t: My beautiful love, wandering like this in the wood is making you weaker and weaker. And, to speak truthfully, I’m lost.

og: We’ll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good.  And tarry for the comfort of the day.
t: If you think it’s a good idea, let's take a rest, and wait until it's daytime and less difficult to travel.

og: Be it so, Lysander. Find you out a bed,For I upon this bank will rest my head.
t: Let’s do that, Lysander. Find yourself somewhere to sleep, and I will rest my head on this little ridge.

og: One turf shall serve as pillow for us both.One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.
t: We can sleep next to each other on the same ground. We’ll have one heart, one bed, two bodies, and one vow.

og: Nay, good Lysander. For my sake, my dear,Lie further off yet. Do not lie so near.
t: No, good Lysander. For my sake, my dear, sleep a little farther away. Don’t lie so close to me.

og: O, take the sense, sweet, of my innocence.  Love takes the meaning in love’s conference.
t: Oh, my sweetheart, what I was saying was totally innocent. When lovers talk to each other, they should interpret what the other has said in a loving way.

og: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit  So that but one heart we can make of it.
t: What I meant is that my heart is bound to yours, so we can think of them as one heart.

og: Two bosoms interchainèd with an oath—  So then two bosoms and a single troth.
t: Our two bodies are joined together by our vows of love, so that's why we have two bodies and one faithful vow.

og: Then by your side no bed-room me deny.  For, lying so, Hermia, I do not lie.
t: So if I am lying by your side, I will not be lying to you.

og: Lysander riddles very prettily.  Now much beshrew my manners and my pride  If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied.
t: Lysander has some skill with words. A curse upon my manners and my pride if I was saying that you were a liar.

og: But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy  Lie further off in human modesty.  Such separation as may well be said  Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid.
t: But, my noble love, for the sake of love and propriety, sleep a little further away. It's proper for a well-behaved bachelor and girl to sleep separately.

og: So far be distant. And, good night, sweet friend.  Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
t: For now, stay a distance away. And, good night, my sweet friend. May your love for me never change for your whole life!

og: Amen, amen to that fair prayer, say I.And then end life when I end loyalty!Here is my bed. Sleep give thee all his rest!
t: I say "amen" to that beautiful prayer. And may my life end if my loyalty to you ever does. I’ll sleep over here. May the god of sleep give you all his rest!

og: With half that wish the wisher’s eyes be pressed!
t: May half that rest be yours.

og: Through the forest have I gone.  But Athenian found I none,  On whose eyes I might approve  This flower’s force in stirring love.
t: I’ve gone all through the forest, but I've found no Athenian on whose eyes to use the love juice of this flower.

og: Night and silence! Who is here?  Weeds of Athens he doth wear.  This is he, my master said,  Despisèd the Athenian maid.
t: Whoa! Who is this? He’s wearing Athenian clothes. This must be the man who shunned the Athenian girl.

og: And here the maiden, sleeping sound  On the dank and dirty ground.  Pretty soul! She durst not lie  Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.
t: And here’s the girl, sleeping soundly on the damp, dirty ground. Pretty girl! She shouldn’t lie near this hard-hearted, crude man.

og: Churl, upon thy eyes I throw  All the power this charm doth owe.  When thou wakest, let love forbid  Sleep his seat on thy eyelid.
t: Villain, I throw all the power that this magic charm has on your eyes. When you wake up, may love stop you from falling back to sleep.

og: So awake when I am gone,  For I must now to Oberon.
t: Wake up when I’m gone, because now I must go to Oberon.

og: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.
t: Stop, Demetrius! Even if it's just to kill me.

og: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.
t: I demand that you get out of here, and stop following me like this.

og: O, wilt thou darkling leave me? Do not so.
t: Oh, will you leave me in the dark? Don't!

og: Stay, on thy peril. I alone will go.
t: Stay at your own risk. I’m going on my own.

og: Oh, I am out of breath in this fond chase.  The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.
t: Oh, I’m out of breath from this foolish chase of love. The more I pray, the less good fortune I am given.

og: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies,  For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.  How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears.  If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers.
t: Hermia is happy, wherever she is, because she has blessed and magnetic eyes. How did her eyes become so bright? Not from crying salty tears. If that was the cause, well, my eyes get washed by tears more often hers.

og: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear,  For beasts that meet me run away for fear.
t: No, no, I’m as ugly as a bear, because animals that see me run away in fear.

og: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius  Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus.  What wicked and dissembling glass of mine  Made me compare with Hermia’s sphery eyne?
t: So it’s not a shock that Demetrius runs from me the way he does—as if I were a monster. What cruel and lying mirror made me compare my eyes with Hermia’s bright ones?

og: But who is here? Lysander, on the ground?  Dead or asleep? I see no blood, no wound.  Lysander, if you live, good sir, awake.
t: But who is this here? Lysander, on the ground? Is he dead or asleep? I see no blood or injuries. Lysander, good sir, wake up if you’re alive.

og: And run through fire I will for thy sweet sake.
t: I’d not just wake up, but run through fire for you.

og: Transparent Helena! Nature shows art  That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart.
t: Radiant Helena! Mother Nature shows her magic by letting me see through your body into your heart.

og: Where is Demetrius? Oh, how fit a word  Is that vile name to perish on my sword!
t: Where is Demetrius? Oh, that name deserves to be killed by my sword!

og: Do not say so, Lysander. Say not so.What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though?Yet Hermia still loves you. Then be content.
t: Don’t say that, Lysander. Don’t say that. Why does it matter if he loves Hermia? Lord, what does it matter? Hermia still loves you. So be happy.

og: Content with Hermia? No. I do repent  The tedious minutes I with her have spent.  Not Hermia but Helena I love.
t: Happy with Hermia? No. I regret all that boring time I spent with her. It's not Hermia I love. It's Helena.

og: Who will not change a raven for a dove?  The will of man is by his reason swayed,  And reason says you are the worthier maid.
t: Who wouldn’t choose a dove over a crow? What a man wants is influenced by his reason, and reason makes it obvious that you are better than Hermia.

og: Things growing are not ripe until their season.  So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason.  And touching now the point of human skill,  Reason becomes the marshal to my will
t: Just as fruits and vegetables don't ripen until the right season, I—being young—did not until now have a fully mature sense of reason. Now, with fully developed taste and judgment, my reason has more control over my desires.

og: And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlook  Love’s stories written in love’s richest book.
t: And it’s leading me to look into your eyes, where I find the richest collection of love stories ever written.

og: Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born?  When at your hands did I deserve this scorn?
t: Why is it my destiny to always be made fun of? What have I done to you to deserve this kind of mockery?

og: Is ’t not enough, is ’t not enough, young man,  That I did never, no, nor never can,  Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye,  But you must flout my insufficiency?
t: Isn't it enough, isn't it enough, young man, that I never have and never will get a kind look from Demetrius? Must you also make fun of my defectiveness?

og: Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do,  In such disdainful manner me to woo.
t: Honestly, you are being cruel to woo me so disdainfully, without meaning it.

og: But fare you well. Perforce I must confess  I thought you lord of more true gentleness.
t: So goodbye, though I have to say that I thought you were a much kinder and nobler person.

og: Oh, that a lady of one man refused  Should of another therefore be abused!
t: Oh, how terrible that a lady who’s been rejected by one man would then be mocked for that rejection by another man!

og: She sees not Hermia. Hermia, sleep thou there.  And never mayst thou come Lysander near!
t: She doesn’t see Hermia. Hermia, keep sleeping over there, and never come near me again!

og: For as a surfeit of the sweetest things  The deepest loathing to the stomach brings,  Or as the heresies that men do leave  Are hated most of those they did deceive,
