t: Eating too many sweet things makes people sick to their stomachs, and the mistakes that people make are always hated most by the one who made them.

og: So thou, my surfeit and my heresy,  Of all be hated, but the most of me.
t: Hermia, you're my sweet and my mistake, so I hate you more than anyone.

og: And, all my powers, address your love and might  To honor Helen and to be her knight.
t: Now, I’ll use all my love and energy to honor Helen, and be her loyal man.

og: Are we all met?
t: Are we all here?

og: Pat, pat. And here’s a marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal. This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house, and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.
t: Right on time. And this is a great place for us to rehearse. This clearing will be the stage, and this hawthorn bush will be our dressing room. We'll rehearse the play exactly the same way that we’ll perform it for the duke.

og: Peter Quince.
t: Peter Quince.

og: What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
t: What is it, my fine friend Bottom?

og: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please.
t: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please the audience.

og: First, Pyramus must draw a swordto kill himself, which the ladies cannot abide. How answer you that?
t: First of all, Pyramus has to take out a sword and use it to kill himself, which the women in the audience won’t be able to stand. What do you think about that?

og: By 'r lakin, a parlous fear.
t: By the Virgin Mary, that’s a serious problem.

og: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.
t: I think, in the end, we’ll have to leave out all the killing.

og: Not a whit. I have a device to make all well.
t: Not at all! I’ve got an idea that will solve the problem.

og: Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed indeed.
t: Write, as I describe, a prologue that explains to the audience that we won’t actually hurt anyone with our swords, and that Pyramus isn’t really killed.

og: And for the more better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver. This will put them out of fear.
t: And to make everyone even more comfortable, explain that that while I look like Pyramus I'm not actually him, I'm really Bottom the weaver. That will stop the audience from being afraid.

og: Well. We will have such a prologue, and it shall be written in eight and six.
t: Good. We’ll perform that prologue, and we'll write it in traditional ballad form, with alternating lines of eight- and six-syllables.

og: No, make it two more. Let it be written in eight and eight.
t: No, add two more. Write it with alternating lines of eight and eight syllables.

og: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?
t: Won’t the women be frightened by the lion?

og: I fear it, I promise you.
t: I’m very worried about that.

og: Masters, you ought to consider with yourselves. To bring in—God shield us!—a lion among ladies is a most dreadful thing.
t: Sirs, you should all think about this: bringing in—God protect us!—a lion in front of women is really an awful thing to do.

og: For there is not a more fearful wildfowlthan your lion living. And we ought to look to ’t.
t: Because there's not a more frightening wild bird living than the lion. We should remember that.

og: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.
t: So we'll have another prologue that explains he’s not actually a lion.

og: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.
t: No, you should announce to the audience his actual name, and make it so that half of his face is visible through the lion costume.

og: And he himself must speak through, saying thus—or to the same defect—“Ladies,” or “Fair ladies,” “I would wish you” or “I would request you” or “I would entreat you” “not to fear, not to tremble, my life for yours.
t: And he himself should say something like the following, or something else to the same defect: “Ladies,” or “Beautiful ladies,” “I would ask you” or “I would request you” or “I would beg you” “not to fear, not to tremble, because I would defend your lives by giving up my own.

og: If you think I come hither as a lion, it were pity of my life. No, I am no such thing. I am a man as other men are.”
t: If you thought I came here as a real lion, it would endanger my life. No, I am no lion. I am a man, just like other men.”

og: And there indeed let him name his name, and tell them plainly he is Snug the joiner.
t: And at that point he should say his name, and tell them plainly that he’s Snug the carpenter.

og: Well, it shall be so. But there is two hard things: that is, to bring the moonlight into a chamber. For, youknow, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.
t: Good, that’s what we’ll do. But there are two more problems we have to solve. How are we going to bring moonlight into the room where we perform? Because, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet in the moonlight.

og: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?
t: Will the moon be shining on the night we’re performing our play?

og: A calendar, a calendar! Look in the almanac. Find out moonshine, find out moonshine!
t: A calendar; we need a calendar! Look in an almanac. Look up when the moon shines, look up when the moon shines!

og: Why then, may you leave a casement of the great chamberwindow where we play open, and the moon may shine in atthe casement.
t: Well then, you could leave a window open in the great room where we’ll be performing, and the moon will shine in through the window.

og: Ay. Or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a lantern, and say he comes to disfigure, or to present,the person of Moonshine.
t: Yes, or else someone will have to come in carrying a bundle of sticks and a lantern and say he’s come to disfigure, or represent, the character of Moonshine.

og: Then, there is another thing: we must have a wall in the great chamber. For Pyramus and Thisbe, says the story, did talk through the chink of a wall.
t: Then there's another problem: we need to have a wall in the great room. Because Pyramus and Thisbe talked to each other through a little hole in a wall, as the story goes.

og: You can never bring in a wall. What say you, Bottom?
t: You’ll never be able to bring in a wall. What do you think, Bottom?

og: Some man or other must present Wall.
t: Someone has to play the part of Wall.

og: And let him have some plaster, or some loam, or some roughcast about him to signify wall. And let him hold his fingers thus,
t: For a costume, he can be covered in some plaster or clay with pebbles stuck to him to show that he’s a wall. Then he can hold his fingers like this

og: and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisbe whisper.
t: , and Pyramus and Thisbe can whisper to each other through that crack.

og: If that may be then all is well. Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and rehearse your parts.
t: If we do that, everything will be fine. Now sit down everyone and rehearse your parts.

og: Pyramus, you begin. When you have spoken your speech, enter into thatbrake.
t: Pyramus, you start. When you've said your lines, go behind that bush as if it were a curtain offstage.

og: And so everyone according to his cue.
t: Everyone else, do the same according to whether you should be on or offstage.

og: What hempen homespuns have we swaggering here,  So near the cradle of the fairy queen?
t: Who are these country bumpkins making so much noise so close to the fairy queen's bed?

og: What, a play toward? I’ll be an auditor.  An actor too, perhaps, if I see cause.
t: What? Are they about to perform a play? I’ll be the audience. And I’ll act in it, too, if I see a reason to.

og: Speak, Pyramus. Thisbe, stand forth.
t: Speak, Pyramus. Thisbe, come forward.

og: Thisbe, the flowers of odious savors sweet—
t: Thisbe, flowers with odious smelling sweet—

og: “Odors,” “odors.”
t: “Odors,” “odors.”

og: —odors savors sweet,  So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisbe dear.
t: —odors smelling sweet, are like your breath, my dearest Thisbe dear.

og: But hark, a voice! Stay thou but here awhile,  And by and by I will to thee appear.
t: But listen, a voice! Wait here for a moment, and I’ll be back soon!

og: A stranger Pyramus than e'er played here.
t: A stranger Pyramus has never been performed anywhere.

og: Must I speak now?
t: Should I talk now?

og: Ay, marry, must you. For you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.
t: Yes, you should. You’re supposed to show that you think that Pyramus just went to check on a noise he heard and will soon come back.

og: Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue,  Of color like the red rose on triumphant brier,  Most brisky juvenal and eke most lovely Jew,
t: My shining Pyramus, you are as white as a lily, the color of a red rose on a splendid rosebush, a lively young man and also a lovely Jew,

og: As true as truest horse that yet would never tire.  I’ll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny’s tomb.
t: as trustworthy as a horse that never gets tired. I’ll meet you, Pyramus, at Ninny’s grave.

og: “Ninus' tomb,” man. Why, you must not speak that yet. That you answer to Pyramus. You speak all your part at once, cues and all. Pyramus, enter. Your cue is past. Itis “never tire.”
t: That’s “Ninus’ grave,” man. And also, don’t say that part yet, because you're supposed to say it to Pyramus. You just said all your lines at once, cues and all. Enter, Pyramus. You missed your cue. It’s “never gets tired.”

og: Oh.    As true as truest horse that yet would never tire.
t: Oh!  As trustworthy as a horse that never gets tired.

og: If I were fair, Thisbe, I were only thine.
t: If I were handsome, my lovely Thisbe, I would still be entirely yours.

og: Oh, monstrous! Oh, strange! We are haunted. Pray, masters! Fly, masters! Help!
t: Oh! A monster! How strange! We’re being haunted. Pray, gentlemen! Run, gentlemen! Help!

og: I’ll follow you. I’ll lead you about a round  Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier.
t: I’ll follow you. I’ll lead you all in circles, through bogs, through bushes, through hedges, and through thorns.

og: Sometime a horse I’ll be, sometime a hound,  A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire.
t: Sometimes I’ll take the shape of a horse, sometimes a dog or a pig or a headless bear. Sometimes I’ll be A fire!

og: And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn,  Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.
t: And I’ll neigh like a horse, bark like a dog, grunt like a pig, growl like a bear, and burn like a fire wherever you run.

og: Why do they run away? This is a knavery of them to makeme afeard.
t: Why are they running away? This is some practical joke of theirs to try to scare me.

og: O Bottom, thou art changed! What do I see on thee?
t: Oh, Bottom, you’ve been changed! What do you have on your head?

og: What do you see? You see an ass head of your own, do you?
t: What do you think I have on my head? You see something you've imagined with your own asinine head, right?

og: Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee. Thou art translated.
t: God bless you, Bottom, God bless you. You’ve been transformed.

og: I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me, to fright me if they could.
t: I see what joke they're trying to pull. They want to make an ass of me, to scare me if they can.

og: But I will not stir from this place, do what they can. I will walk up and down here and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid.
t: But I won’t move from this spot, whatever they do. I’ll walk back and forth and sing a song so that they’ll hear me and know I’m not afraid.

og: The ouzel cock, so black of hue  With orange-tawny bill,  The throstlewith his note so true,  The wren with little quill—
t: The blackbird, so black in colorWith an orange-and-tan beak,The thrush with its beautiful voice,The wren with its high piping voice—

og: What angel wakes me from my flowery bed?
t: What angel wakes me from my bed of flowers?

og: The finch, the sparrow, and the lark,  The plainsong cuckoo gray,  Whose note full many a man doth mark  And dares not answer “Nay”—
t: The finch, the sparrow, and the lark,The gray cuckoo with his unchanging songWhose voice so many men hearBut don’t dare say no to it—

og: For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?
t: Indeed, who would try to win an argument with a stupid bird?

og: Who would give a bird the lie, though he cry “cuckoo” never so?
t: Who would say that a bird was lying, now matter how many times the bird called out that his wife was cheating on him?

og: I pray thee, gentle mortal, sing again.  Mine ear is much enamored of thy note.  So is mine eye enthrallèd to thy shape.
t: Noble human, I beg you, sing again. My ears cannot get enough of your voice, and my eyes are entranced by your looks.

og: And thy fair virtue’s force perforce doth move me  On the first view to say, to swear, I love thee.
t: Though this is the first time I have ever seen you, the power of your beauty compels me to swear that I love you.

og: Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that. And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays.
t: I don’t think you should have a good reason to love me. And yet, to be honest, reason and love are seldom found together these days.

og: The more the pity thatsome honest neighbors will not make them friends.
t: It’s a shame that some mutual friend of theirs doesn’t introduce them.

og: Nay, I can gleek upon occasion.
t: Ha, I've been known to tell a joke from time to time.

og: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.
t: You’re as wise as you are beautiful.

og: Not so, neither. But if I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.
t: That’s not true, either. But if I were wise enough to get out of this forest, I’d have all the wisdom I needed.

og: Out of this wood do not desire to go.  Thou shalt remain here whether thou wilt or no.
t: Please don't wish that you could leave this forest. You will stay here whether you want to or not.

og: I am a spirit of no common rate.  The summer still doth tend upon my state.
t: I’m not some ordinary fairy. The summer itself serves me as one of my followers.

og: And I do love thee. Therefore go with me.  I’ll give thee fairies to attend on thee.  And they shall fetch thee jewels from the deep,  And sing while thou on pressèd flowers dost sleep.
t: And I love you. So come with me. I’ll give you fairies to serve you, and they’ll bring you jewels from the ocean depths, and sing to you as you sleep on a bed of pressed flowers.

og: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so  That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.  Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!
t: And I’ll remove you from your physical body, so you will be a spirit of the air. Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed, come here!

og: Ready.
t: Ready.

og: And I.
t: Me too.

og: And I.
t: Me too.

og: And I.
t: Me too.

og: Where shall we go?
t: Where should we go?

og: Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.  Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes.
t: Be kind and considerate to this gentleman. Follow where he walks. Run and jump joyfully where he can watch you.

og: Feed him with apricoks and dewberries,  With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.  The honey bags steal from the humble-bees,
t: Feed him apricots and blackberries, along with purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries. Steal honey from the bumblebees, and make candles from beeswax taken from the bees' legs.

og: And for night tapers crop their waxen thighs  And light them at the fiery glowworms' eyes  To have my love to bed and to arise.
t: Then light the candles with the fire from glowworms' eyes so that my love will have light when he goes to bed and wakes up.

og: And pluck the wings from painted butterflies  To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes.  Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
t: Pluck the wings from colorful butterflies, then use them to fan moonbeams away from his sleeping eyes. Fairies, bow and curtsy to him.

og: Hail, mortal.
t: Hello, mortal!

og: Hail.
t: Hello!

og: Hail.
t: Hello!

og: Hail.
t: Hello!

og: I cry your worships' mercy, heartily. I beseech your worship’s name.
t: I beg your pardon, sirs, very much. Will you tell me your names, sirs?

og: Cobweb.
t: Cobweb.

og: I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good MasterCobweb. If I cut my finger, I shall make bold with you.Your name, honest gentleman?
t: I would like to get to know you better, good Mister Cobweb. If I cut my finger, I’ll use you as a bandage. And your name, good sir?

og: Peaseblossom.
t: Peaseblossom.

og: I pray you, commend me to Mistress Squash, your mother,and to Master Peascod, your father.
t: Please, give my regards to Mrs. Peapod, your mother, and to Mr. Peapod, your father.

og: Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too. Your name, I beseech you, sir?
t: Good Mr. Peaseblossom, I’d like to get to know you better too. And now, may I ask what your name is, sir?

og: Mustardseed.
t: Mustardseed.

og: Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well. That same cowardly, giantlike ox-beef hath devoured manya gentleman of your house.
t: Good Mr. Mustardseed, I know how you have patiently suffered, and how those cowardly, gigantic sides of beef have caused so many of your family members to get eaten.

og: I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now. I desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.
t: I promise you that many of your mustard relatives have made my eyes water before now. I'd like to get to know you better, good Mr. Mustardseed.

og: Come, wait upon him. Lead him to my bower.
t: Serve him well, and lead him to the place I sleep.

og: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye.  And when she weeps, weeps every little flower,  Lamenting some enforcèd chastity.
t: I think the moon looks sad, and when she cries, every little flower cries, lamenting the fact that they are forced to remain chaste.

og: Tie up my love's tongue. Bring him silently.
t: Make my lover stay quiet. Bring him to me in silence.

og: I wonder if Titania be awaked.Then, what it was that next came in her eye,Which she must dote on in extremity.
t: I wonder if Titania is awake. And, if she is, I wonder what thing she saw first that she must love completely now.

og: Here comes my messenger. How now, mad spirit?What night-rule now about this haunted grove?
t: Here comes my messenger. What’s going on, crazy spirit? What fun have you had tonight around this haunted forest?

og: My mistress with a monster is in love.
t: My mistress is in love with a monster.

og: Near to her close and consecrated bower,  While she was in her dull and sleeping hour,  A crew of patches, rude mechanicals  That work for bread upon Athenian stalls,
t: While she was sleeping nearby in her secret bed beneath a canopy of flowers, there came a bunch of fools—ignorant manual workers who earn their money working in shops in Athens.

og: Were met together to rehearse a play  Intended for great Theseus' nuptial day.
t: They met to rehearse a play they hope to perform on Theseus’ wedding day.

og: The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort,  Who Pyramus presented in their sport,  Forsook his scene and entered in a brake,
t: The silliest blockhead of that whole dumb group, who played Pyramus in their play, finished his scene and went offstage to sit in the bushes.

og: When I did him at this advantage take,  An ass’s nole I fixèd on his head.  Anon his Thisbe must be answerèd,  And forth my mimic comes.
t: While he sat there I played a prank on him, and stuck an ass' head on him. Soon it was time for him to respond to his Thisbe, and he came out of the bushes.

og: When they him spy,  As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,  Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,  Rising and cawing at the gun’s report,  Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky,
t: When they saw him, his friends ran away, like wild geese that spot an approaching hunter, or like a flock of red-headed jackdaws rising, cawing, and madly flying across the sky at the sound of a gunshot.

og: So at his sight away his fellows fly;  And, at our stamp, here o'er and o'er one falls.  He “Murder!” cries and help from Athens calls.
t: When one of the friends heard my footsteps, he fell head over heels, shouted “Murder!” and called for help from Athens.

og: Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears thus strong,  Made senseless things begin to do them wrong.  For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch,  Some sleeves, some hats—from yielders all things catch.
t: Their fear was so strong that they lost their common sense, and began to think that inanimate objects were trying to get them, such as thorns that caught at their clothing, sleeves, and hats.

og: I led them on in this distracted fear  And left sweet Pyramus translated there.
t: I led them away in their frightened confusion, and left sweet, transformed Pyramus there.

og: When in that moment so it came to pass,  Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.
t: At that moment, it just so happened that Titania woke up and fell in love with an ass.

og: This falls out better than I could devise.But hast thou yet latched the Athenian’s eyesWith the love juice, as I did bid thee do?
t: This has turned out even better than I could have planned. But have you put the love juice on the eyes of that Athenian, as I told you to?

og: I took him sleeping—that is finished too—And the Athenian woman by his side,That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
t: I did it while he was sleeping, so that task is completed too. And the Athenian woman was sleeping near him. So, when he woke up, he certainly must have seen her.

og: Stand close. This is the same Athenian.
t: Be quiet. This is the Athenian we were talking about.

og: This is the woman, but not this the man.
t: That’s the woman I saw, but that is not the man.

og: Oh, why rebuke you him that loves you so?Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.
t: Oh, why be so mean to someone who loves you so much? You should aim such cruel language only at your worst enemy.

og: Now I but chide, but I should use thee worse.  For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse.
t: I’m scolding you at the moment, but I should be treating you even worse than that. I’m frightened that you’ve given me good reason to curse you.

og: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,  Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,  And kill me too.
t: If you killed Lysander while he was sleeping, then you’re already knee-deep in blood, and you should just plunge in deeper and kill me too.

og: The sun was not so true unto the day  As he to me. Would he have stolen away  From sleeping Hermia?
t: He is more faithful to me than the sun is to the day. Would he have snuck away from me while I was asleep?

og: I’ll believe as soon  This whole Earth may be bored, and that the moon  May through the center creep and so displease  Her brother’s noontide with th' Antipodes.
t: I’ll only believe that’s true when a hole appears through the center of the Earth, and the moon sneaks through it to surprise her brother, the sun, on the other side of the world.

og: It cannot be but thou hast murdered him.  So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.
t: The only possibility is that you murdered him. A murderer should look like you do—so pale and grim.

og: So should the murdered look, and so should I,  Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.
t: That’s how someone who’s been murdered should look. And that’s how I should look, too, because you’ve pierced me through the heart with your cruelty.

og: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,  As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.
t: And yet you, the murderer, look as bright and shining as the planet Venus, glimmering in its orbit in the sky.

og: What’s this to my Lysander? Where is he?Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?
t: What does any of that have to do with my Lysander? Where is he? Oh, good Demetrius, will you bring him to me?

og: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.
t: I would rather feed his corpse to my dogs.

og: Out, dog! Out, cur! Thou drivest me past the bounds  Of maiden’s patience.
t: Get away, you dog! Go away, you mutt! You’ve driven me past what any woman could endure.

og: Hast thou slain him then?  Henceforth be never numbered among men!
t: Have you killed him, then? From now on you should not even be thought of as a human being.

og: Oh, once tell true, tell true even for my sake—  Durst thou have looked upon him being awake,  And hast thou killed him sleeping?
t: Oh, tell the truth for once. Tell the truth, for my sake. You wouldn’t have even dared to look at him when he was awake, but then you murdered him while he was sleeping?

og: O brave touch!  Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?  An adder did it, for with doubler tongue  Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.
t: Oh, how brave of you! A snake, a poisonous snake, would do it just the same. And in fact a snake did do it, because no snake has ever had a more forked, lying tongue than you have, you serpent.

og: You spend your passion on a misprised mood.I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood.Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.
t: You’re working yourself into a rage out of a misunderstanding. I’m not guilty of killing Lysander. As far as I know, he’s not dead.

og: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.
t: I beg you, then: tell me he’s all right.

og: An if I could, what should I get therefore?
t: If I could tell you that, what would I get out of it?

og: A privilege never to see me more.And from thy hated presence part I so.See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
t: The privilege of never seeing me again. Now I’m going to depart from your presence, which I hate. I hope you never see me again, whether he’s  dead or not.

og: There is no following her in this fierce vein.
t: There’s no point in following her when she’s so angry.

og: Here therefore for a while I will remain.  So sorrow’s heaviness doth heavier grow  For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe,
t: So, for a while I’ll just stay here. Sadness becomes harder to bear when it’s combined with a lack of sleep.

og: Which now in some slight measure it will pay,  If for his tender here I make some stay.
t: Now I’ll try to lighten my sadness by getting a little sleep.

og: What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite,  And laid the love juice on some true love’s sight.
t: What have you done? You’ve made a complete mistake and put the love-juice on someone who was truly in love.

og: Of thy misprision must perforce ensue  Some true love turned, and not a false turned true.
t: Because of your mistake someone’s true love has been turned false, instead of someone's false love being turned into a true love.

og: Then fate o'errules that, one man holding troth,A million fail, confounding oath on oath.
t: That’s the fate of love. For every man who’s faithful to his love, a million others cancel out each oath of love they make with a new one, over and over again.

og: About the wood go swifter than the wind,  And Helena of Athens look thou find—
t: Race all through the forest, moving faster than the wind, and find Helena of Athens.

og: All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer,  With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.
t: She’s lovesick, and her face is pale because of all of her sighing, which is bad for the blood.

og: By some illusion see thou bring her here.  I’ll charm his eyes against she do appear.
t: Use some magic illusion to bring her here, and I’ll put the love juice on his eyes for when she arrives.

og: I go, I go. Look how I go,Swifter than arrow from the Tartar’s bow.
t: I'm going, I'm going. See how I go? Faster than an arrow from a Tartar’s bow.

og: Flower of this purple dye,  Hit with Cupid’s archery,  Sink in apple of his eye.
t: Purple flower, hit by Cupid’s arrow, sink into the pupils of his eyes.

og: When his love he doth espy,  Let her shine as gloriously  As the Venus of the sky.
t: When he sees the girl he should love, make her seem to him as bright as Venus shining in the sky.

og: When thou wakest, if she be by,  Beg of her for remedy.
t: When you wake up, if she’s nearby, beg her to answer your love with love.

og: Captain of our fairy band,  Helena is here at hand,  And the youth, mistook by me,  Pleading for a lover’s fee.
t: Leader of fairies, Helena is coming. So, too, is the young man whom I mistook for this one sleeping here, and he’s begging her to love him.

og: Shall we their fond pageant see?  Lord, what fools these mortals be!
t: Should we watch this absurd show? Lord, mortals are such fools!

og: Stand aside. The noise they makeWill cause Demetrius to awake.
t: Stand out of the way. The noise they’re making is going to wake up Demetrius.

og: Then will two at once woo one.  That must needs be sport alone.
t: Then both of them will pursue one girl at the same time.

og: And those things do best please me  That befall preposterously.
t: Watching that will be unparalleled entertainment. Ridiculous things are the things I like best.

og: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?  Scorn and derision never come in tears.
t: Why would you think that I’m making fun of you when I tell you of my love for you? Mockery is never accompanied by tears.

og: Look, when I vow, I weep. And vows so born,  In their nativity all truth appears.
t: Look, I cry when I swear my love for you. And when vows are made by someone who is crying, that shows how true and since the vow is.

og: How can these things in me seem scorn to you,  Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true?
t: How can you think I am mocking you, when my tears are like a badge of honesty?

og: You do advance your cunning more and more.  When truth kills truth, O devilish holy fray!
t: You display your sneaky ways more and more clearly. What a nasty fight it will be, when one “true” vow invalidates another “true” vow you made earlier.

og: These vows are Hermia’s. Will you give her o'er?
t: These promises you’re making to me belong to Hermia. Are you going to just jilt her?

og: Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh.  Your vows to her and me, put in two scales,  Will even weigh, and both as light as tales.
t: If you weigh the vows you’ve made to Hermia against the vows you made to me, they’ll cancel each other out, and weigh nothing. They’ll be as weightless as lies.

og: I had no judgment when to her I swore.
t: I had no true power of reason when I swore those vows to her.

og: Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er.
t: In my opinion, you don’t have any reason now, as you are breaking those vows.

og: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.
t: Demetrius loves her, and he doesn’t love you.

og: O Helena, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!  To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne?
t: Oh, Helena, goddess! Divine, perfect nymph! My love, to what can I compare your eyes?

og: Crystal is muddy. Oh, how ripe in show  Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!
t: Crystal is like mud compared to them. Oh, your lips look like ripe, tempting cherries just touching together!

og: That pure congealèd white, high Taurus' snow,  Fanned with the eastern wind, turns to a crow  When thou hold’st up thy hand.
t: The pure white snow on the tops of the Taurus mountains, fluffed by winds from the east, look as black as a crow in comparison to the whiteness of your hands.

og: Oh, let me kiss  This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!
t: Oh, let me kiss your pure white hand in a pledge of happiness!

og: O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent  To set against me for your merriment.  If you were civil and knew courtesy,  You would not do me thus much injury.
t: Oh cruelty! Oh hell! I see you’ve all joined together to humiliate me for your own enjoyment. If you were civilized or had good manners, you wouldn’t hurt me this way.

og: Can you not hate me, as I know you do,  But you must join in souls to mock me too?
t: Can’t you just hate me, as I know you do? Do you have to team up to mock me too?

og: If you were men, as men you are in show,  You would not use a gentle lady so  To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts,  When I am sure you hate me with your hearts.
t: If you were true men, as you pretend to be, you wouldn’t treat a noble woman this way—making vows and promises and praising my beauty in such over-the-top ways when I know you both hate me in your hearts.

og: You both are rivals, and love Hermia,  And now both rivals to mock Helena—  A trim exploit, a manly enterprise,  To conjure tears up in a poor maid’s eyes  With your derision!
t: You’re both competing for Hermia’s love, and now you’re competing to see who can mock me more. What an impressive feat, what a manly thing to do, to put tears in a poor girl's eyes through your mockery!

og: None of noble sort  Would so offend a virgin, and extort  A poor soul’s patience, all to make you sport.
t: No truly noble person would offend an innocent girl like this, or torture a poor soul's patience just so you can have some fun.

og: You are unkind, Demetrius. Be not so.  For you love Hermia. This you know I know.
t: You’re being mean, Demetrius. Don’t be. You love Hermia. You know I know it.

og: And here, with all good will, with all my heart,  In Hermia’s love I yield you up my part.
t: And here, with everyone’s best interests in mind, and with all my heart, I give up all my claim to Hermia’s love and give it to you.

og: And yours of Helena to me bequeath,  Whom I do love and will do till my death.
t: Now you give up your claim to Helena’s love and give it to me, because I love her, and will continue to love her, until I die.

og: Never did mockers waste more idle breath.
t: No one has ever put in so much pointless effort just to make fun of someone.

og: Lysander, keep thy Hermia. I will none.
t: Lysander, keep your Hermia. I’m not interested.

og: If e'er I loved her, all that love is gone.
t: If I ever loved her, all that love is now gone.

og: My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourned,  And now to Helen is it home returned,  There to remain.
t: My heart visited her as if it was on a little journey, but how my heart has returned home to Helena and it will remain with her.

og: Helen, it is not so.
t: Helena, it’s not true.

og: Disparage not the faith thou dost not know,Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.Look, where thy love comes. Yonder is thy dear.
t: Don’t insult a true love you don’t know anything about, or else you risk paying a terrible price. Look, your love is coming. Over there is the one you love.

og: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes,  The ear more quick of apprehension makes.  Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense,  It pays the hearing double recompense.
t: While the darkness of night makes eyes work less well, it helps ears to work better. While it blocks the ability to see, it more than makes up for that by increasing the ability to hear.

og: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found.  Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound  But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
t: My eyes couldn’t find you, Lysander. But thankfully my ears heard your voice. Why did you so cruelly leave me alone?

og: Why should he stay, whom love doth press to go?
t: Why should I stay, when love pushed me to go?

og: What love could press Lysander from my side?
t: What love could make you move from my side?

og: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide,  Fair Helena, who more engilds the night  Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.
t: I could not wait because of my love for beautiful Helena, who shines in the night more brightly than all those fiery orbs and stars.

og: Why seek’st thou me? Could not this make thee know  The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so?
t: Why are you looking for me? Wasn’t it obvious that I left you because of the hatred I feel toward you?

og: You speak not as you think. It cannot be.
t: You don’t believe what you’re saying. It can’t be.

og: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!  Now I perceive they have conjoined all three  To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.
t: So, she’s a part of your little gang! Now I see that all three of them have joined together to create this game of lies in order to hurt me.

og: Injurious Hermia! Most ungrateful maid!  Have you conspired, have you with these contrived  To bait me with this foul derision?
t: Hurtful Hermia! Ungrateful girl! Have you conspired and schemed to torment me with this awful mockery?

og: Is all the counsel that we two have shared,  The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent  When we have chid the hasty-footed time  For parting us—oh, is it all forgot?  All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence?
t: Have you forgotten about all the confidential conversations we’ve shared, the vows of sisterhood we made, the hours we spent together while scolding time for moving so fast and forcing us apart? Our schoolgirl friendship, our childhood innocence?

og: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods,  Have with our needles created both one flower,  Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion,  Both warbling of one song, both in one key,  As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds,  Had been incorporate.
t: Hermia, we used to sit together like two gods of craftsmanship, and sew one flower with our two needles, working on the same single piece of cloth. We would sit on the same cushion, singing the same song in perfect tune, as if our hands, our sides, our voices and our minds were joined as one.

og: So we grew together,  Like to a double cherry—seeming parted  But yet an union in partition—  Two lovely berries molded on one stem;
t: We grew up together, like two cherries—which seem to be separate but are also joined together. Two loving cherries sharing one stem.

og: So, with two seeming bodies but one heart,  Two of the first, like coats in heraldry,  Due but to one and crownèd with one crest.
t: That's just how it was with us, who seemed to have two bodies but one heart, like doubled coats of arms that belong separately to a husband and wife who also share a single crest.

og: And will you rent our ancient love asunder  To join with men in scorning your poor friend?  It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.
t: Are you really going to rip apart our old friendship by joining these men to humiliate your poor friend? It’s not friendly, and it’s not ladylike.

og: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it,  Though I alone do feel the injury.
t: All women, not just me, will scold you for acting this way, even though I’m the only one who’s getting hurt.

og: I am amazèd at your passionate words.I scorn you not. It seems that you scorn me.
t: I’m shocked by your angry words. I don't hate you. It seems like you hate me.

og: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,  To follow me and praise my eyes and face?
t: Didn't you get Lysander to mock me by following me around, praising my eyes and face?

og: And made your other love, Demetrius—  Who even but now did spurn me with his foot—  To call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare,  Precious, celestial?
t: And didn't you make your other love, Demetrius—who just before kicked me with his foot—to call me a goddess, a nymph, and some divine, rare, precious angel?

og: Wherefore speaks he this  To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander  Deny your love, so rich within his soul,  And tender me, forsooth, affection,  But by your setting on, by your consent?
t: Why would he say that to a girl he hates? And why does Lysander deny that he loves you, when he loves you all the way down to his very soul, and offer me his affection, unless you told him to and he agreed to it?

og: What though I be not so in grace as you—  So hung upon with love, so fortunate—  But miserable most, to love unloved?  This you should pity rather than despise.
t: Why do you care that I’m not as blessed as you are—so surrounded by love, so fortunate—and am instead completely miserable, my love unreturned? You should pity me for it, not despise me.

og: I understand not what you mean by this.
t: I don’t understand what you’re saying.

og: Ay, do. Persever, counterfeit sad looks,  Make mouths upon me when I turn my back,  Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up—
t: Yes, do that. Keep it up, pretend to be serious, but then make faces at me behind my back, wink at each other, and keep the joke going.

og: This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.
t: You're doing such a good job with this prank it will go down in history.

og: If you have any pity, grace, or manners,  You would not make me such an argument.
t: If you had any compassion, refinement, or manners, you wouldn’t pretend to fight over me.

og: But fare ye well. 'Tis partly my own fault,  Which death or absence soon shall remedy.
t: But goodbye. It’s partly my own fault (given how I've acted), but I can fix it by leaving, or dying.

og: Stay, gentle Helena. Hear my excuse.My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!
t: Stay, sweet Helena. Listen to my excuse. My love, my life, my soul, beautiful Helena!

og: Oh, excellent!
t: Oh, nice one!

og: Sweet, do not scorn her so.
t: My love, don’t mock her like that.

og: If she cannot entreat, I can compel.
t: If Hermia’s pleas don't get you to stop, I can force you to.

og: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat.
t: You can’t force me to stop any more than Hermia can plead for me to.

og: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.  Helen, I love thee. By my life, I do.
t: Your threats aren't any stronger than her weak begging. Helena, I love you. On my life, I swear I do.

og: I swear by that which I will lose for thee  To prove him false that says I love thee not.
t: I swear on my life, which I will risk by fighting this man to prove he's lying when he says that I don't love you.

og: I say I love thee more than he can do.
t: I say that I love you more than he does.

og: If thou say so, withdraw and prove it too.
t: If that’s what you say, draw your sword and prove it.

og: Quick, come.
t: You’re on. Let’s do it.

og: Lysander, whereto tends all this?
t: Lysander, what does all this mean?

og: Away, you Ethiope!
t: Go away, you African!

og: No, no. He’llSeem to break loose. Take on as you would follow,But yet come not. You are a tame man, go!
t: No, no. He’s just pretending like he’s trying to break loose.

og: Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! Vile thing, let looseOr I will shake thee from me like a serpent.
t: Let go of me, you cat, you clinging burr. Let go of me, vile thing, or I’ll shake you off of me like a snake.

og: Why are you grown so rude? What change is this,Sweet love?
t: Why have you become so rude? What’s changed you, my sweet love?

og: Thy love? Out, tawny Tartar, out!Out, loathèd medicine! O hated potion, hence!
t: Your love? Get away from me, you dark-skinned Tartar! Get away, you disgusting poison. You hated potion, get away!

og: Do you not jest?
t: Are you joking?

og: Yes, sooth, and so do you.
t: Yes, of course he is, and so are you.

og: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.
t: Demetrius, I’ll honor what I said and fight you.

og: I would I had your bond, for I perceiveA weak bond holds you. I’ll not trust your word.
t: I wish I had that in writing, because it seems to me that Hermia's rather weak arms somehow seem to be holding you back. I don’t trust your word that you actually want to fight.

og: What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.
t: What? Should I hurt Hermia, hit her, kill her? Although I hate her, I'm not going to harm her.

og: What, can you do me greater harm than hate?  Hate me? Wherefore? O me! What news, my love?
t: What, do you think you could hurt me any more than by saying you hate me? Hate me? Why? What’s happened, my love?

og: Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander?  I am as fair now as I was erewhile.
t: Am I not Hermia? Are you not Lysander? I’m as beautiful now as I was just before.

og: Since night you loved me. Yet since night you left me.  Why then, you left me—Oh, the gods forbid!—  In earnest, shall I say?
t: You loved me last night. But last night you left me. So—God forbid—did you actually leave me?

og: Ay, by my life,  And never did desire to see thee more.
t: Yes, I swear on my life that I did, and I never wanted to see you again.

og: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt.  Be certain, nothing truer. 'Tis no jest  That I do hate thee and love Helena.
t: So give up your hopes, your questions, and your doubts. You can be sure that there's nothing more true than this: it’s not a joke that I hate you and love Helena.

og: O me!    You juggler! You canker-blossom!You thief of love! What, have you come by nightAnd stol'n my love’s heart from him?
t: Oh no!

og: Fine, i' faith!  Have you no modesty, no maiden shame,  No touch of bashfulness?
t: Really, honestly! Have you no modesty, no decency, not even a little bit of shame?

og: What, will you tear  Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?
t: What, do you want to make me mad enough that I'll respond to you, despite my usual gentleness?

og: Fie, fie! You counterfeit, you puppet, you!
t: You disgust me! You liar, you doll!

og: “Puppet”? Why so? Ay, that way goes the game.  Now I perceive that she hath made compare  Between our statures.
t: “Doll?” Why do you say that? Ah, I see where you're taking this. She’s comparing our difference in height.

og: She hath urged her height,  And with her personage, her tall personage,  Her height, forsooth, she hath prevailed with him.
t: She’s shown off how tall she is, and used her body—her tall body, her height—to win him over.

og: And are you grown so high in his esteem  Because I am so dwarfish and so low?  How low am I, thou painted maypole?
t: Does he admire you so highly because I’m so small and short? So how short am I, you painted pole?

og: Speak.  How low am I? I am not yet so low  But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes.
t: Tell me. How short am I? I’m not so short that I can't reach up to gouge your eyes out with my fingernails.

og: I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen,  Let her not hurt me. I was never cursed.  I have no gift at all in shrewishness.
t: I beg you—even though you're making fun of me, gentlemen—don’t let her hurt me. I've never been good at trading insults.

og: I am a right maid for my cowardice.  Let her not strike me.
t: I’m not mean like her. I’m shy, like a girl should be. Don’t let her hit me.

og: You perhaps may think,  Because she is something lower than myself,  That I can match her.
t: You might be thinking that I could overpower her because she is somewhat shorter than me.

og: “Lower”? Hark, again!
t: “Shorter?” See, there it is again!

og: Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.  I evermore did love you, Hermia,  Did ever keep your counsels,
t: Good Hermia, please don’t be so angry with me. Hermia, I always loved you, and kept your secrets confidential.

og: never wronged you—  Save that, in love unto Demetrius,  I told him of your stealth unto this wood.
t: I never did anything to hurt you—other than, out of love for Demetrius, telling him about your plan to sneak into this forest.

og: He followed you. For love I followed him.  But he hath chid me hence and threatened me  To strike me, spurn me—nay, to kill me too.
t: He followed you. And I followed him, out of love. But he shouted at me to go away and threatened to hit me, kick me—and to kill me too.

og: And now, so you will let me quiet go,  To Athens will I bear my folly back  And follow you no further.
t: And now, so that you'll let me go without attacking me further, I'll carry my foolishness back with me to Athens and won’t follow you anymore.

og: Let me go.  You see how simple and how fond I am.
t: Let me go. You see how naïve and foolish I can be.

og: Why, get you gone! Who is ’t that hinders you?
t: So, get going! Who's stopping you?

og: A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.
t: My silly heart, which I’m leaving behind here.

og: What, with Lysander?
t: What, with Lysander?

og: With Demetrius.
t: With Demetrius.

og: Be not afraid. She shall not harm thee, Helena.
t: Don’t be afraid. She won't hurt you, Helena.

og: No, sir, she shall not, though you take her part.
t: No, sir, she won't, even if you take Hermia's side.

og: Oh, when she’s angry, she is keen and shrewd!She was a vixen when she went to school.And though she be but little, she is fierce.
t: Oh, when she's angry, she gets vicious and mean. She was a hellcat when we were in school. And though she’s little, she's fierce.

og: “Little” again? Nothing but “low” and “little”! Why will you suffer her to flout me thus?Let me come to her.
t: “Little” again? Nothing but “short” and “little!” Why do you allow her to mock me like this? Let me at her!

og: Get you gone, you dwarf,You minimus of hindering knotgrass made,You bead, you acorn!
t: Get out of here, you dwarf, you tiny little creature made of knotgrass weed, you tiny bead, you acorn!

og: You are too officious  In her behalf that scorns your services.
t: You’re trying too hard to help a woman who doesn't want anything from you.

og: Let her alone. Speak not of Helena.  Take not her part.
t: Leave Helena alone. Don’t talk about her. Don’t try to help her.

og: For if thou dost intend  Never so little show of love to her,  Thou shalt aby it.
t: And if you plan on showing so little love to Hermia, you’ll pay for it.

og: Now she holds me not.Now follow, if thou darest, to try whose right,Of thine or mine, is most in Helena.
t: Hermia’s not holding me anymore. So follow me, if you dare, to find out through a duel which of us has more right to Helena.

og: “Follow”? Nay, I’ll go with thee, cheek by jowl.
t: “Follow?” No, I’ll walk next to you, side by side.

og: You, mistress, all this coil is long of you.Nay, go not back.
t: You, mistress, are the cause of all this fighting. No, don't walk away from me!

og: I will not trust you, I,  Nor longer stay in your curst company.
t: I don't trust you. And I'm not going to stay anywhere near you.

og: Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray.  My legs are longer though, to run away.
t: You may have faster hands in a fight than I do, but I can run away faster because my legs are longer.

og: I am amazed and know not what to say.
t: I'm shocked and don't know what to say.

og: This is thy negligence. Still thou mistakest,Or else committ’st thy knaveries willfully.
t: This is your fault. You continually make mistakes, or else you're making trouble on purpose.

og: Believe me, King of Shadows, I mistook.  Did not you tell me I should know the man  By the Athenian garment he had on?
t: Believe me, King of Shadows—it was a mistake. Didn’t you tell me that I’d recognize the man by the Athenian clothes he was wearing?

og: And so far blameless proves my enterprise,  That I have 'nointed an Athenian’s eyes.
t: I can't be blamed for what I've done—I put the love juice on an Athenian’s eyes.

og: And so far am I glad it so did sort,  As this their jangling I esteem a sport.
t: And so far I’m glad it worked out this way, as I find all this uproar entertaining.

og: Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight.  Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night.  The starry welkin cover thou anon  With drooping fog as black as Acheron,
t: You can see that these lovers are looking for a place to fight. Therefore, rush, Robin, and make the night dark and cloudy. As quickly as possible, cover the starry sky with a low fog as dark as hell,

og: And lead these testy rivals so astray  As one come not within another’s way.  Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue,  Then stir Demetrius up with bitter wrong.
t: and lead around these manic rivals so that they get so lost that they won't run into each other. Imitate Lysander’s voice to get Demetrius all riled up with insults.

og: And sometime rail thou like Demetrius.  And from each other look thou lead them thus,  Till o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sleep  With leaden legs and batty wings doth creep.
t: Then rage a bit in Demetrius’ voice. And in that way you’ll lead them away from each other until tiredness creeps over them with its heavy legs and bat-like wings that they fall dead asleep.

og: Then crush this herb into Lysander’s eye,  Whose liquor hath this virtuous property  To take from thence all error with his might  And make his eyeballs roll with wonted sight.
t: Then crush this flower over Lysander’s eyes, because its juice has the ability to remove from his eyes the mistaken love he was given by the first love juice—and to make his eyes see the way he would normally.

og: When they next wake, all this derision  Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision.
t: When they wake, all this mockery and fighting will seem like a dream or an insignificant hallucination.

og: And back to Athens shall the lovers wend,  With league whose date till death shall never end.
t: Then the lovers will return to Athens, bound together by love until they die.

og: Whiles I in this affair do thee employ,  I’ll to my queen and beg her Indian boy.
t: While you’re working on this job I've given you, I’ll go visit Titania and ask her for the Indian boy.

og: And then I will her charmèd eye release  From monster’s view, and all things shall be peace.
t: And then I’ll reverse the spell on her eyes and she will stop loving that monster. Then everything will be at peace.

og: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.  For night’s swift dragons cut the clouds full fast,
t: My fairy lord, all this must be done quickly. The dragons that pull the night's chariot are speeding through the sky.

og: And yonder shines Aurora’s harbinger,  At whose approach, ghosts, wandering here and there,  Troop home to churchyards.
t: In the distance the morning star, which appears just before the dawn, is shining, and all the ghosts that wander in the night are marching back to their graveyards.

og: Damnèd spirits all,  That in crossways and floods have burial,  Already to their wormy beds are gone.
t: The damned souls of all those who committed suicide, buried at crossroads or at the bottom of a river, have already returned to their wormy graves.

og: For fear lest day should look their shames upon,  They willfully themselves exile from light  And must for aye consort with black-browed night.
t: They fear that day will expose their shame, and so they avoid all sunlight and remain forever in darkest night.

og: But we are spirits of another sort.  I with the morning’s love have oft made sport,  And like a forester the groves may tread  Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red,
t: But we’re a different sort of spirit. I've often enjoyed the pleasures of the morning, and like a forest ranger, wander the woods until in the East the sun rises, all fiery red

og: Opening on Neptune with fair blessèd beams,  Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams.
t: —spreading its rays over the ocean and turning the salty green water to gold.

og: But notwithstanding, haste. Make no delay.  We may effect this business yet ere day.
t: But anyway, hurry. Don’t delay. We can get all this done before it's day.

og: Up and down, up and down,  I will lead them up and down.
t: Here and there, here and there,I will lead them here and there.

og: I am feared in field and town.
t: I am feared in the country and in town.

og: Goblin, lead them up and down.  Here comes one.
t: Goblin, lead them here and there.Here comes one of them.

og: Where art thou, proud Demetrius? Speak thou now.
t: Where are you, arrogant Demetrius? Say something.

og: Here, villain. Drawn and ready. Where art thou?
t: I’m over here, you villain. I have my sword out and am ready to fight. Where are you?

og: I will be with thee straight.
t: I’ll find you in a moment.

og: Follow me thenTo plainer ground.
t: Then follow me to flatter ground, which will be better for fighting.

og: Lysander, speak again!Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?
t: Lysander, say something! You quitter, you coward, have you run away? Say something! Are you in some bush? Where are you hiding?

og: Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars,  Telling the bushes that thou look’st for wars,  And wilt not come?
t: You coward! Are you bragging to the stars and telling the bushes that you're looking for a fight, but then you won't actually come find me?

og: Come, recreant. Come, thou child!  I’ll whip thee with a rod. He is defiled  That draws a sword on thee.
t: Come here, coward! Come here, you child! I’ll whip you with a stick. You're such a coward, anyone who tries to fight you with a sword would be disgraced.

og: Yea, art thou there?
t: Hey, are you there?

og: Follow my voice. We’ll try no manhood here.
t: Follow my voice. This isn’t a good place to test our manhood in a fight.

og: He goes before me and still dares me on.  When I come where he calls, then he is gone.
t: He walks ahead of me and keeps daring me to follow him. But when I get to the spot where he’s calling from, he's not there.

og: The villain is much lighter-heeled than I.  I followed fast, but faster he did fly,  That fallen am I in dark uneven way,  And here will rest me.
t: This scoundrel is much quicker than I am. I chased him as fast as I could, but he ran away from me even faster, and now I’m lost in this dark part of the forest with uneven ground. I’ll rest here.

og: Come, thou gentle day!  For if but once thou show me thy grey light,  I’ll find Demetrius and revenge this spite.
t: May the comfort of daytime arrive soon! Because as soon as I see the gray light of morning, I’ll find Demetrius and get my revenge for this insult.

og: Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why comest thou not?
t: Ha, ha, ha! Coward, why aren’t you coming?

og: Abide me, if thou darest!
t: Wait for me, if you dare!

og: For well I wot  Thou runn’st before me, shifting every place,  And darest not stand nor look me in the face.
t: You keep running away from me, dashing all over the place, but you don’t dare to stand and face me eye to eye.

og: Where art thou now?
t: Where are you now?

og: Come hither. I am here.
t: Come this way. I’m over here.

og: Nay, then, thou mock’st me. Thou shalt buy this dear  If ever I thy face by daylight see.
t: No, you’re just mocking me. You’ll pay dearly for this if I ever see your face in the daylight.

og: Now go thy way. Faintness constraineth me  To measure out my length on this cold bed.  By day’s approach look to be visited.
t: Now run wherever you want. I’m so tired I need to lie down and sleep on this cold ground. But expect me to come find you by the dawn.

og: O weary night, O long and tedious night,  Abate thy hours.
t: Oh, exhausting, long, and boring night, please end already!

og: Shine comforts from the east,  That I may back to Athens by daylight  From these that my poor company detest.
t: You reassuring dawn, start shining in the east, so I can go back to Athens in the daylight and leave behind these people who hate spending time with me.

og: And sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow’s eye,  Steal me awhile from mine own company.
t: Now sleep, which can make us forget our sorrows, help me escape for a while from my own company.

og: Yet but three? Come one more.  Two of both kinds make up four.
t: Still only three? One more is needed. Two men and two women make four.

og: Here she comes, cursed and sad.  Cupid is a knavish lad  Thus to make poor females mad.
t: Now here she comes, angry and sad. Cupid is a tricky, deceitful boy to drive poor girls crazy like this.

og: Never so weary, never so in woe,  Bedabbled with the dew and torn with briers,  I can no further crawl, no further go.
t: I’ve never been so exhausted or so sad. I’m covered in dew and scratched by thorns, and I can’t crawl any farther.

og: My legs can keep no pace with my desires.  Here will I rest me till the break of day.
t: I can’t go any further. My legs can’t keep moving, even though I want them too. This is where I’ll rest until the morning comes.

og: Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!
t: May the gods protect Lysander if he and Demetrius do end up fighting!

og: On the ground  Sleep sound.  I'll apply  To your eye.  Gentle lover, remedy.
t: Sleep soundly on the ground. And I'll apply a remedy to your eye, dear lover.

og: When thou wakest,  Thou takest  True delight  In the sight  Of thy former lady's eye.
t: When you wake up, you will be truly delighted to see the lady you once loved.

og: And the country proverb known—  That every man should take his own—  In your waking shall be shown.  Jack shall have Jill.
t: And you'll be a walking reminder of that country saying—each man should take what's his.  Yes, Jack will have his Jill.

og: Nought shall go ill.  The man shall have his mare again, and all shall be well.
t: Nothing can go wrong. The man will have his lady again, and everything will be all right.

og: Come, sit thee down upon this flowery bed  While I thy amiable cheeks do coy,
t: Come and sit here on this flowery bed while I caress your lovable cheeks,

og: And stick musk roses in thy sleek, smooth head,  And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.
t: and stick roses into the fur of your silky, smooth head, and kiss your big, beautiful ears, my gentle darling.

og: Where’s Peaseblossom?
t: Where’s Peaseblossom?

og: Ready.
t: At your service.

og: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom. Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?
t: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom. Where’s Sir Cobweb?

og: Ready.
t: At your service.

og: Monsieur Cobweb, good monsieur, get you your weapons inyour hand and kill me a red-hipped humble-bee on the top of a thistle. And, good monsieur, bring me the honeybag.
t: Monsieur Cobweb, my good sir, get out your weapons and kill for me a red-tailed bumblebee that has landed on a thistle. And, good sir, bring me its honey.

og: Do not fret yourself too much in the action, monsieur. And good monsieur, have a care the honey bag break not. I would be loath to have you overflown with ahoney bag, signor.
t: Now don’t overwork yourself too much in doing it, sir. Oh, and good sir, be careful not to break the honey-sac. I’d be sad if you drowned in honey, sir.

og: Ready.
t: At your service.

og: Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed. Pray you, leave your courtesy, good monsieur.
t: Give me your first, Sir Mustardseed. Please, no need to take off your hat and bow, good sir.

og: What’s your will?
t: What would you like?

og: Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch. I must to the barber’s, monsieur, for methinks I am marvelous hairy about the face.
t: Nothing, good sir, except for you to help Sir Cobweb scratch my head. I should go to the barber’s, sir, because I think I’m getting amazingly hairy on my face.

og: And I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.
t: And I am such a sensitive ass that if my hair even tickles me even slightly, I have to scratch.

og: What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?
t: Would you like to hear some music, my sweet love?

og: I have a reasonable good ear in music. Let’s have the tongs and the bones.
t: I have a fairly good ear for music. Let’s have someone play the triangle and smack some sticks together.

og: Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.
t: Or tell me, sweet love, what you want to eat.

og: Truly, a peck of provender. I could munch your good dryoats. Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay. Good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.
t: Actually, I’d like two gallons of animal feed. Or I wouldn’t mind munching on some good dry oats. Though I think I would also really like a bundle of hay. Good, sweet hay has no equal.

og: I have a venturous fairy that shall seekThe squirrel’s hoard and fetch thee new nuts.
t: I have an adventurous fairy who’ll go find a squirrel’s secret stockpile and get you fresh nuts.

og: I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me. I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
t: I’d rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, please, don’t let any of your attendants wake me up. An exposition for sleep has come over me.

og: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.Fairies, be gone, and be all ways away.
t: Sleep my love, and I will put my arms around you. Fairies, get out of here. Go off in all directions.

og: So doth the woodbine the sweet honeysuckle  Gently entwist. The female ivy so  Enrings the barky fingers of the elm.
t: I’ll wrap my arms around you just as the tendrils of the woodbine plant gently twist around the sweet honeysuckle, and just as the female ivy curls around the branches of the elm tree.

og: Oh, how I love thee! How I dote on thee!
t: Oh, how I love you! How I love to take care of you!

og: Welcome, good Robin. Seest thou this sweet sight?  Her dotage now I do begin to pity.
t: Welcome, good Robin. Do you see this sweet sight? I've now begun to pity Titania for her obsessive crush.

og: For, meeting her of late behind the wood,  Seeking sweet favors from this hateful fool,  I did upbraid her and fall out with her.
t: I met her a while ago near the edge of the forest as she was searching for pretty flowers for this intolerable idiot, and I scolded her and fought with her.

og: For she his hairy temples then had rounded  With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers,  And that same dew, which sometime on the buds  Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls,  Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes  Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.
t: She had put a little crown of fresh, sweet-smelling flowers around his hairy forehead. And the dew, which used to decorate the flowers like the most beautiful pearls, now lay in the center of the flowers like tears of shame for being forced to sit on that ass' head.

og: When I had at my pleasure taunted her  And she in mild terms begged my patience,  I then did ask of her her changeling child,  Which straight she gave me and her fairy sent  To bear him to my bower in Fairyland.
t: After taunting her as much I wanted to, she quietly asked me to stop, and then I asked her for the Indian boy. Right away she agreed to give him to me, and sent a fairy to bring him to my chamber in Fairyland.

og: And now I have the boy, I will undo  This hateful imperfection of her eyes.
t: Now that I have the boy, I’ll undo the awful flaw affecting Titania's eyes.

og: And, gentle Puck, take this transformèd scalp  From off the head of this Athenian swain,  That, he awaking when the other do,  May all to Athens back again repair  And think no more of this night’s accidents  But as the fierce vexation of a dream.
t: And, gentle Puck, remove the ass’ head from the head of this Athenian yokel, so that when he wakes up along with the others, they can all return to Athens and remember the craziness of this night as nothing more than the wild troubles of a bad dream.

og: But first I will release the fairy queen.
t: But first I’ll cure the fairy queen.

og: Be as thou wast wont to be.  See as thou wast wont to see.
t: Be the way you used to be, and see the way you used to see.

og: Dian’s bud o'er Cupid’s flower  Hath such force and blessèd power.  Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.
t: This juice comes from a flower bud belonging to Diana, and it has the power to overturn the effects of the juice from Cupid’s flower. Now, Titania, wake up, my sweet queen.

og: My Oberon, what visions have I seen!Methought I was enamored of an ass.
t: My dear Oberon, what a wild dream I had! I dreamed I was in love with an ass.

og: There lies your love.
t: Your love is lying right there.

og: How came these things to pass?Oh, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!
t: How did all this happen? Oh, my eyes can’t stand to see his face now!

og: Silence awhile. Robin, take off this head.Titania, music call, and strike more deadThan common sleep of all these five the sense.
t: Be quiet for a while. Robin, remove his ass’ head. Titania, call to your fairies for some music, so that these five humans will sleep more deeply than is normal.

og: Music, ho! Music such as charmeth sleep!
t: Music, now! Play music that magically makes people sleep.

og: Now when thou wakest, with thine own fool’s eyes peep.
t: Now when you wake up, you'll see things with your own foolish eyes once more.

og: Sound, music! Come, my queen, take hands with me,  And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.
t: Play the music! Come here, my queen, take my hands. And we’ll dance on the ground where these sleepers are lying, and so rock them to sleep.

og: Now thou and I are new in amity,  And will tomorrow midnight solemnly  Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly,  And bless it to all fair prosperity.
t: Now that you and I are again at peace, tomorrow at midnight we will perform a ceremonial dance at Duke Theseus’ palace to celebrate and bless his marriage with good fortune.

og: There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be  Wedded, with Theseus, all in jollity.
t: These two pairs of faithful lovers will get married along with Theseus, all in great joy.

og: Fairy King, attend, and mark.I do hear the morning lark.
t: Fairy King, pay attention, and listen. I can hear the singing of the lark, which sings when it is morning.

og: Then, my queen, in silence sad,  Trip we after the night’s shade.
t: Then, my queen, let’s quietly and seriously follow after the night,

og: We the globe can compass soon  Swifter than the wandering moon.
t: crossing the earth faster even than the moon.

og: Come, my lord, and in our flight  Tell me how it came this night
t: Come, my lord, and as we fly you can tell me what happened in the night

og: That I sleeping here was found  With these mortals on the ground.
t: that resulted in me sleeping with these humans on the ground.

og: Go, one of you, find out the forester.
t: Go, one of you, and find the forest ranger.

og: For now our observation is performed.  And since we have the vaward of the day,  My love shall hear the music of my hounds.
t: Now that we've completed the May Day ceremonies, and since we are still in the early part of the day, my love will get to hear the musical barking of my dogs as we go hunting.

og: Uncouple in the western valley. Let them go.  Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
t: Unleash the dogs in the western valley. Let them go. Now go, I say, and find the forest ranger.

og: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once,  When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear  With hounds of Sparta.
t: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, when their Spartan hunting dogs surrounded a bear.

og: Never did I hear  Such gallant chiding. For, besides the groves,  The skies, the fountains, every region near  Seemed all one mutual cry.
t: I’d never before heard barking that courageous. Not just the forests, but also the skies, the waterfalls, everything nearby seemed to be part of the same communal cry.

og: I never heard  So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
t: I’d never heard such wild music, such lovely thunder.

og: My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind,  So flewed, so sanded, and their heads are hung  With ears that sweep away the morning dew,
t: My dogs are bred from Spartan line. They have the same fleshy folds around their jaws, the same sandy color, and on their heads they have the same ears that hang low enough to brush the morning dew from the grass.

og: Crook-kneed, and dew-lapped like Thessalian bulls,  Slow in pursuit, but matched in mouth like bells,  Each under each.
t: They have crooked knees, and folds of skin hang down under their necks, like bulls from the region of Thessaly.

og: A cry more tunable  Was never hollaed to, nor cheered with horn,  In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly.
t: Though they're not very fast when chasing prey, their barks sound like a set of bells—different notes, but all perfectly in tune. No one has ever blown a hunting horn in answer to a more melodic pack of dogs—not in Crete, or Sparta, or Thessaly.

og: Judge when you hear.  But, soft! What nymphs are these?
t: Judge for yourself when you hear them. But wait! Who are these girls?

og: My lord, this is my daughter here asleep.
t: My lord, this is my daughter, asleep.

og: And this, Lysander. This Demetrius is.  This Helena, old Nedar’s Helena.
t: And that's Lysander. This one here is Demetrius. This is Helena—old Nedar’s daughter Helena.

og: I wonder of their being here together.
t: I wonder why they’re all here together.

og: No doubt they rose up early to observe  The rite of May, and hearing our intent  Came here in grace our solemnity.
t: Most likely they woke up early to celebrate May Day and, knowing we would be here, they came to attend and honor our ceremony.

og: But speak, Egeus. Is not this the day  That Hermia should give answer of her choice?
t: But tell me, Egeus, isn’t today the day when Hermia has to tell us whether she's chosen Demetrius, death, or to become a virgin priestess?

og: It is, my lord.
t: It is, my lord.

og: Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past. Begin these woodbirds but to couple now?
t: Good morning, my friends. Valentine’s Day is over. Have you lovebirds only begun to couple up now?

og: Pardon, my lord.
t: Forgive us, my lord.

og: I pray you all, stand up.
t: Please, all of you, stand up.

og: I know you two are rival enemies.
t: I know you two are bitter rivals.

og: How comes this gentle concord in the world,  That hatred is so far from jealousy  To sleep by hate and fear no enmity?
t: What has happened to make the world such a gentle place that two people who hate each other somehow don't distrust each other, and in fact are willing to sleep next to an enemy without fear of being harmed?

og: My lord, I shall reply amazèdly,  Half sleep, half waking. But as yet, I swear,  I cannot truly say how I came here.
t: My lord, I can only respond that I am also baffled, and feel as if I am half asleep, half awake. I can't honestly say how I wound up here.

og: But as I think—for truly would I speak,  And now do I bethink me, so it is—  I came with Hermia hither.
t: But I think—and I want to speak honestly, and now that I think about it, I'm sure it's true. I came here with Hermia.

og: Our intent  Was to be gone from Athens, where we might,  Without the peril of the Athenian law—
t: Our plan was to escape from Athens so that we could, without the threat of Athenian law—

og: Enough, enough, my lord. You have enough!  I beg the law, the law, upon his head.
t: Enough, enough, my lord. You’ve heard enough: I ask that the law, the law, be brought down upon his head.

og: They would have stol'n away, they would, Demetrius,  Thereby to have defeated you and me,  You of your wife and me of my consent,  Of my consent that she should be your wife.
t: Demetrius, these two were going to run away in order to trick us, stealing your wife from you and stealing from me of my ability to order that she should be your wife.

og: My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth,  Of this their purpose hither to this wood.  And I in fury hither followed them,  Fair Helena in fancy following me.
t: My lord, the beautiful Helena told me they were going to sneak away to escape into this forest. In a fury, I followed them here, and the lovely Helena followed me because of her love for me.

og: But, my good lord, I wot not by what power—  But by some power it is—my love to Hermia,  Melted as the snow,
t: Now, my good lord, I don't know what made this happen—but by some power it did happen—my love for Hermia melted away like snow.

og: seems to me now  As the remembrance of an idle gaud  Which in my childhood I did dote upon.
t: That love seems to me now like a memory of some worthless trinket I used to love when I was a child.

og: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart,  The object and the pleasure of mine eye,  Is only Helena. To her, my lord,  Was I betrothed ere I saw Hermia.
t: Now the only person to whom I want to be faithful, who owns my entire heart, who is the greatest pleasure to my eye, is Helena. I was engaged to her before I ever met Hermia.

og: But like in sickness did I loathe this food.  But as in health, come to my natural taste,
t: But then, like a sick man who can't stand the food that sustains him, I hated her for a time. But now, healthy once again, my normal taste has returned.

og: Now I do wish it, love it, long for it,  And will for evermore be true to it.
t: Now I want Helena. I love her, and long for her, and will always be true to her.

og: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met.  Of this discourse we more will hear anon.  Egeus, I will overbear your will.
t: Beautiful lovers, it's lucky that you've met me here. You'll tell me more about all of this later. Egeus, I’m overruling your commands.

og: For in the temple by and by with us  These couples shall eternally be knit.
t: Later on in the temple these couples will be married alongside Hippolyta and me.

og: And, for the morning now is something worn,  Our purposed hunting shall be set aside.
t: And now, because the morning is nearly over, we'll set aside our planned hunting.

og: Away with us to Athens. Three and three,  We’ll hold a feast in great solemnity.  Come, Hippolyta.
t: Come with us to Athens. Three men and three women, we'll throw a feast and celebration. Come along, Hippolyta.

og: These things seem small and undistinguishable,Like far-off mountains turnèd into clouds.
t: Everything that happened seems distant and difficult to figure out, like mountains that look like clouds from far away.

og: Methinks I see these things with parted eye,When everything seems double.
t: It seems to me that my eyes are out of focus, and everything looks double.

og: So methinks.And I have found Demetrius like a jewel,Mine own, and not mine own.
t: Me too. It's like I came upon Demetrius like a jewel I found by accident, so that while he is in my possession, he might really belong to someone else.

og: Are you sure  That we are awake?  It seems to me  That yet we sleep, we dream.
t: Are you sure that we’re awake? It seems to me like we are sleeping, and dreaming.

og: Do not you think  The duke was here, and bid us follow him?
t: Do you think the duke was really just here, and told us to follow him?

og: Yea, and my father.
t: Yes I do, and my father was here too.

og: And Hippolyta.
t: And Hippolyta.

og: And he did bid us follow to the temple.
t: And he told us to follow him to the temple.

og: Why then, we are awake. Let’s follow himAnd by the way let us recount our dreams.
t: Well, then, we’re awake. Let’s follow him. And as we go, why don't we tell each other our dreams?

og: When my cue comes, call me, and I will answer.My next is "Most fair Pyramus."
t: When it's my cue, call me—and I'll say my line. My next cue is "Most handsome Pyramus."

og: Heigh-ho! Peter Quince?Flute the bellows-mender? Snout the tinker? Starveling?God's my life, stol'n hence, and left me asleep?
t: Hey there! Peter Quince? Flute the bellows-repairman? Snout the repairman? Starveling? My God, they went away from here, and left me asleep?

og: I havehad a most rare vision. I have had a dream—past the witof man to say what dream it was. Man is but an ass if he go about to expound this dream.
t: I have had the strangest dream. I have had a dream so strange that it's beyond explanation. A man would be a fool if he tried to explain this dream.

og: Methought I was—thereis no man can tell what. Methought I was, and methoughtI had—but man is but a patched fool if he will offer tosay what methought I had.
