t: I thought I was—well, nobody could describe what I was. I thought I was, and I thought I had—but a man would have to be a true fool to try and say what I thought I had.

og: The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report what my dream was.
t: My dream was so odd that no man's eyes have heard, or his ears have seen, or his hands have tasted, or his tongue felt, or his heart described what it was like.

og: I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream. It shall be called "Bottom's Dream" because it hath no bottom.
t: I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad about this dream. It will be called "Bottom's Dream" because it's so complex that it has no bottom.

og: And I will sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke. Peradventure, to make it more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.
t: And I'll sing it for the duke at the end of the play. Or, better yet, to make it more pleasing, I'll sing it when Thisbe dies.

og: Have you sent to Bottom’s house? Is he come home yet?
t: Have you checked Bottom’s house? Has he come home yet?

og: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is transported.
t: No one’s heard from him. There's no question he's been kidnapped by fairies.

og: If he come not, then the play is marred. It goes not forward. Doth it?
t: If he doesn’t come, then the play will be ruined. We won't be able to perform it. Will we?

og: It is not possible. You have not a man in all Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.
t: It wouldn't be possible. There's not another man in all of Athens who can play Pyramus besides Bottom.

og: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in Athens.
t: It's true. To be blunt, he’s the smartest craftsman in Athens.

og: Yea, and the best person too. And he is a very paramourfor a sweet voice.
t: Yes, and the best looking too. And his voice is the paramour of sweetness.

og: You must say “paragon.” A “paramour” is, God bless us, a thing of naught.
t: You mean “paragon.” A "paramour" is, God bless us, something naughty.

og: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married. If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.
t: Gentlemen, the duke is leaving the temple, along with two or three additional lords and ladies who were also married. If we could only have performed our play, we would all have gotten rewards and been set for life.

og: O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life.
t: Oh that sweet, good guy, Bottom! By not being here he's missed out on a pension of six pence a day for the rest of his life.

og: He could not have ’scaped sixpence a day. An the duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I’ll be hanged.
t: He wouldn't have been able to avoid getting six pence a day, even if he'd wanted to. If the duke wouldn’t have given him six pence a day for playing Pyramus, I'd go jump off a bridge.

og: He would have deserved it. Sixpence a day in Pyramus, or nothing.
t: And he would have deserved it. Pyramus is worth six pence a day, or nothing at all.

og: Where are these lads? Where are these hearts?
t: Where are my boys? Where are my good fellows?

og: Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!
t: Bottom! Oh, what a great day! Oh, what a happy moment!

og: Masters, I am to discourse wonders—but ask me not what,for if I tell you I am no true Athenian. I will tell you everything, right as it fell out.
t: Gentlemen, I have incredible stories to tell you—but don’t ask me what, because if I told you, then I would not be a true Athenian citizen. I’ll tell you everything, exactly how it happened.

og: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.
t: Tell us, good Bottom.

og: Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is that the duke hath dined.
t: You won't get a word out of me!  All that I'll tell you is that the duke has had his dinner.

og: Get your apparel together, good stringsto your beards, new ribbons to your pumps. Meet presently at the palace. Every man look o'er his part.
t: Gather your costumes, some new strings for your false beards,  and some new ribbons to decorate your shoes. Then meet me at the palace as soon as you can. We should each look over our lines again.

og: For the short and the long is, our play is preferred. Inany case, let Thisbe have clean linen. And let not him that plays the lion pair his nails, for they shall hang out for the lion's claws.
t: In sum, our play is going to be performed! So make sure that Thisbe has clean underpants. And make sure whoever is playing the lion doesn't cut down his nails, because they are going to need to stand in for the lion's claws.

og: And most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath. AndI do not doubt but to hear them say, "It is a sweet comedy." No more words. Away, go away!
t: And, my most dear fellow actors, please don't eat onions or garlic. We must have sweet-smelling breath so the audience will say, "it's a sweet play." Enough talk.  Come on, let's go!

og: 'Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.
t: My dear Theseus, what these lovers are describing is strange.

og: More strange than true. I never may believe  These antique fables nor these fairy toys.
t: I think the story is more strange than it is true. I don't believe any of these ancient stories or fairy tales.

og: Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,  Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend  More than cool reason ever comprehends.
t: Lovers and madmen have so much going on in their heads, such active imaginations, that they see and hear things that cool, calm, rational people can't understand.

og: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet  Are of imagination all compact.  One sees more devils than vast hell can hold—  That is the madman.
t: Madmen, lovers, and poets all are all controlled by their imaginations: The ones who see devils and monsters all over the place—those are the madmen.

og: The lover, all as frantic,  Sees Helen’s beauty in a brow of Egypt.  The poet’s eye, in fine frenzy rolling,  Doth glance from heaven to Earth, from Earth to heaven.
t: Lovers, who are just as wild, see a gypsy's face and think it is as beautiful as Helen of Troy's. Poets, who are always glancing around as if they are overcome by passion, make constant connections between things that are earthly and things that are heavenly.

og: And as imagination bodies forth  The forms of things unknown, the poet’s pen  Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing  A local habitation and a name.
t: And they take the unreal things that tumble out of their imagination and write about them as if they were actual places or things.

og: Such tricks hath strong imagination,  That if it would but apprehend some joy,  It comprehends some bringer of that joy.  Or in the night, imagining some fear,  How easy is a bush supposed a bear!
t: When people who have such strong imaginations feel some kind of joy, they imagine that it must be some entity or power that brings or creates that joy. Or if, in the night, they feel some fear, they see a bush and imagine it’s a bear!

og: But all the story of the night told over,  And all their minds transfigured so together,  More witnesseth than fancy’s images  And grows to something of great constancy,
t: But the full story that the lovers are telling about last night—along with the fact that they all described it the same way—suggests that it's something that they really experienced rather than some imagined fantasy.

og: But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
t: It has a consistency to it that suggests truth, even if it is strange and unbelievable.

og: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.Joy, gentle friends! Joy and fresh days of loveAccompany your hearts!
t: Here come the lovers, full of joy and laughter. Joy to you, kind friends! May joy and sweet days of love be with you always.

og: More than to usWait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!
t: May even more joy than you wish for us await you—on your royal journeys, at your table, and in your bed!

og: Come now, what masques, what dances shall we have  To wear away this long age of three hours  Between our after-supper and bedtime?
t: Now, what performances and dances will we see to pass these three hours between dinner and bedtime?

og: Where is our usual manager of mirth?  What revels are in hand?
t: Where is our Master of the Revels? What entertainments do we have ready?

og: Is there no play,  To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?  Call Philostrate.
t: Isn’t there a play for us to watch to ease the torture of free time? Call Philostrate.

og: Here, mighty Theseus.
t: I’m here, Theseus.

og: Say, what abridgement have you for this evening?What masque, what music? How shall we beguileThe lazy time if not with some delight?
t: Tell us, what entertainment do you have that will shorten the evening? What plays, what music? How will we enjoy this boring time without some entertainment?

og: There is a brief, how many sports are ripe.Make choice of which your highness will see first.
t: That is a list of all of the performances that are ready to go. Choose which one your highness would like to see first.

og: “The battle with the Centaurs, to be sung  By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.”
t: “The battle between Hercules and the Centaurs at the wedding feast of Pirothous, sung by an Athenian eunuch  accompanied by a harp.”

og: We’ll none of that. That have I told my love,  In glory of my kinsman Hercules.
t: No, we don’t want that. I’ve already told that story to Hippolyta, telling her of the glory of my cousin Hercules. What else?

og: “The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,  Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.”
t: “The riot of the drunk Bacchanals who in the grip of their drunken frenzy rip the singer Orpheus to shreds.”

og: That is an old device, and it was played  When I from Thebes came last a conqueror.
t: That’s a story often told in plays, and I saw it when I returned from conquering Thebes.

og: “The thrice three Muses mourning for the death  Of learning, late deceased in beggary.”
t: “The nine Muses mourning the death of learning and the arts, which lately have become so reduced.”

og: That is some satire, keen and critical,  Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.
t: That’s a satire—a sharp and critical satire—and wouldn’t be right to perform at a wedding.

og: “A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus  And his love Thisbe. Very tragical mirth.”
t: “A boring short drama about young Pyramus and his love Thisbe. Very sad and funny.”

og: “Merry” and “tragical?” “Tedious” and “brief?”  That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow.  How shall we find the concord of this discord?
t: Funny and sad? Short but still boring? That’s like hot ice and very strange snow. What will we think of this play which claims to be such contradictory things?

og: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long,  Which is as brief as I have known a play.  But by ten words, my lord, it is too long,  Which makes it tedious.
t: My lord, it is a play that's about ten words long, which is the shortest play I’ve ever encountered. But, my lord, it’s ten words too long, which is what makes it tedious.

og: For in all the play  There is not one word apt, one player fitted.
t: In the entire play, there is not one well-placed word, and not one actor is a good fit for his part.

og: And tragical, my noble lord, it is.  For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
t: It is tragic, my noble lord, because Pyramus does kill himself.

og: Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess,  Made mine eyes water—but more merry tears  The passion of loud laughter never shed.
t: When I saw the suicide during rehearsal, I must admit that it brought tears to my eyes—but I've never cried tears of such loud and merry laughter.

og: What are they that do play it?
t: Who are the people performing it?

og: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,  Which never labored in their minds till now,
t: Manual workers from here in Athens who have never until now spent much doing anything that required thinking.

og: And now have toiled their unbreathed memories  With this same play against your nuptial.
t: Now they’ve overburdened their under-exercised brains to create this play for your wedding.

og: And we will hear it.
t: And we will watch it.

og: No, my noble lord.  It is not for you.
t: No, my noble lord. It’s not something you’ll like.

og: I have heard it over,  And it is nothing, nothing in the world—
t: I’ve seen it, and it’s worthless, as worthless as anything ever created

og: Unless you can find sport in their intents,  Extremely stretched and conned with cru 'l pain  To do you service.
t: —unless you find their sad attempt funny, with their bad acting and incorrectly remembered lines.

og: I will hear that play.
t: I’ll watch this play.

og: For never anything can be amiss  When simpleness and duty tender it.
t: Because nothing can be bad when it’s motivated by a simple desire to bring pleasure to a person's betters.

og: Go, bring them in. And take your places, ladies.
t: Go and bring them in. And find your seats, ladies.

og: I love not to see wretchedness o'er chargedAnd duty in his service perishing.
t: I don’t enjoy seeing incompetent people overwhelmed and made to look bad when they are only trying to serve.

og: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.
t: Why, my noble love, you won’t see any such thing.

og: He says they can do nothing in this kind.
t: Philostrate says they’re not good at acting.

og: The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing.  Our sport shall be to take what they mistake,  And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect  Takes it in might, not merit.
t: Then we’re even more kind, for giving them thanks for something they’re not good at. Our entertainment will be to watch their mistakes, and what their own poor talent can't accomplish. Our noble generosity will see the effort they are giving rather than the quality of their performance.

og: Where I have come, great clerks have purposèd  To greet me with premeditated welcomes,
t: When I have visited foreign cities, great scholars have tried to greet me with speeches they've rehearsed.

og: Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,  Make periods in the midst of sentences,  Throttle their practiced accent in their fears,  And in conclusion dumbly have broke off,  Not paying me a welcome.
t: And I have seen them shiver and turn pale from nervousness, and pause incorrectly in the middle of their sentences, and mess up the tones of voice they've practiced, and then finish by suddenly breaking off without even welcoming me.

og: Trust me, sweet,  Out of this silence yet I picked a welcome,
t: Trust me, my love, even in their silence I could sense the welcome they meant to give.

og: And in the modesty of fearful duty  I read as much as from the rattling tongue  Of saucy and audacious eloquence.
t: I can understand the same meaning from those who are modest and frightened but also want to do their duty as I can from those who can rattle off a speech with wit, talent, and eloquence.

og: Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity  In least speak most, to my capacity.
t: As I see it, my love, tongue-tied simplicity says the most precisely by saying the least.

og: So please your grace, the Prologue is addressed.
t: If it please your Grace, the actor who will deliver the prologue is ready.

og: Let him approach.
t: Let him come forward.

og: If we offend, it is with our good will.  That you should think we come not to offend,  But with good will.
t: If our play offends you, it is our intention. That you know we have not come here to offend, but it is our intention.

og: To show our simple skill,  That is the true beginning of our end.  Consider then we come but in despite.
t: Showing off the little skill we have in acting will end up getting us executed. Understand, then, that we come in a spirit of ill will.

og: We do not come as minding to contest you,  Our true intent is. All for your delight  We are not here.
t: We don’t come here with the purpose of making you happy. We did not come here for your complete delight.

og: That you should here repent you,  The actors are at hand, and by their show  You shall know all that you are like to know.
t: You should regret that the actors are ready. By watching their show, you’ll find out everything you’re likely to know.

og: This fellow doth not stand upon points.
t: This guy doesn’t pay attention to punctuation.

og: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt. He knows not the stop. A good moral, my lord: it is not enough tospeak, but to speak true.
t: He rode his prologue like a wild colt. He didn’t know how to make it stop. The moral here, my lord, is that it’s not enough to speak. You have to speak correctly.

og: Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child on arecorder—a sound, but not in government.
t: Yes, he’s performed the prologue like a child plays a recorder—he can make sounds, but not with any purposeful control.

og: His speech was like a tangled chain. Nothing impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?
t: His speech was like a tangled chain. Unbroken, but all jumbled up. Who’s next?

og: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show.  But wonder on, till truth make all things plain.
t: Ladies and gentlemen, perhaps you're wondering about the subject of this play. Keep on wondering, until the truth makes everything clear.

og: This man is Pyramus, if you would know.  This beauteous lady Thisbe is certain.  This man, with lime and roughcast, doth present  Wall, that vile wall which did these lovers sunder.
t: This man is Pyramus, if you'd like to know. It's certain that this beautiful lady is Thisbe. This man, dusted in lime and plaster, is playing the Wall, that awful wall that separated these lovers.

og: And through Wall’s chink, poor souls, they are content  To whisper. At the which let no man wonder.
t: Through a little hole in the Wall, the poor souls are content to whisper. And no one should be amazed by that.

og: This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn,  Presenteth Moonshine. For, if you will know,  By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn  To meet at Ninus' tomb—there, there to woo.
t: This man, who has the lantern, dog, and thorn bush, is playing the role of Moonshine. Because, if you'd like to know, the lovers didn't think it was shameful to meet each other in the moonlight by Ninus’s tomb—there, they would woo each other.

og: This grisly beast, which “Lion” hight by name,  The trusty Thisbe, coming first by night,  Did scare away, or rather did affright.  And, as she fled, her mantle she did fall,  Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain.
t: This dreadful beast, which is called “Lion,” scared away, or rather frightened, the faithful Thisbe when she arrived first at the meeting place one night. And, as she ran away, she dropped her cloak, which the awful Lion stained with his bloody mouth.

og: Anon comes Pyramus, sweet youth and tall,  And finds his trusty Thisbe’s mantle slain.  Whereat, with blade, with bloody blameful blade,  He bravely broached his boiling bloody breast.
t: Soon Pyramus arrives, a sweet and tall young man, and finds his faithful Thisbe’s cloak covered in blood. Because of that, he raised his sword—his bloodthirsty responsible blade—and bravely stabbed his raging, ferocious chest.

og: And Thisbe, tarrying in mulberry shade,  His dagger drew, and died.
t: Then Thisbe, waiting in the shade of the mulberry bushes, took out his dagger and killed herself.

og: For all the rest,  Let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and lovers twain  At large discourse, while here they do remain.
t: To hear the rest of the story, let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and the two separated lovers explain it more fully while they stand here on the stage.

og: I wonder if the lion be to speak.
t: I wonder if the lion will speak.

og: No wonder, my lord. One lion may when many asses do.
t: It wouldn’t be shocking, my lord. When a bunch of asses are up on stage talking, a lion might talk too.

og: In this same interlude it doth befall  That I, one Snout by name, present a wall.
t: At this moment of the play I, Snout, play a wall.

og: And such a wall, as I would have you think,  That had in it a crannied hole, or chink,  Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisbe,  Did whisper often very secretly.
t: I want you to know that this wall has a little hole in it, through which the lovers Pyramus and Thisbe often secretly whispered.

og: This loam, this roughcast, and this stone doth show  That I am that same wall. The truth is so.
t: This clay, this plaster, and this stone that I have on me show that I’m that wall. That's the truth.

og: And this the cranny is, right and sinister,  Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.
t: And this is the crack, running horizontally right to left, through which the fated lovers will whisper.

og: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?
t: Would you ever hope to hear plaster speak more eloquently?

og: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.
t: It’s the smartest barrier that I’ve ever heard speak, my lord.

og: Pyramus draws near the wall. Silence!
t: Pyramus is approaching the wall. Be quiet!

og: O grim-looked night! O night with hue so black!  O night, which ever art when day is not!  O night, O night! Alack, alack, alack,
t: Oh, grim-looking night! Oh, night colored so black! Oh night, which always exists when day does not! Oh night, oh night! Sad, sad, sad.

og: I fear my Thisbe’s promise is forgot!  And thou, O Wall, O sweet, O lovely Wall,  That stand’st between her father’s ground and mine.
t: I’m afraid my Thisbe has forgotten her promise! And you, oh Wall, oh sweet, oh lovely Wall, which stands between Thisbe’s father’s land and mine.

og: Thou Wall, O Wall, O sweet and lovely Wall,  Show me thy chink to blink through with mine eyne!
t: You Wall, oh Wall, oh sweet and lovely Wall. Show me your hole that I can peer through with my eye!

og: Thanks, courteous Wall. Jove shield thee well for this!  But what see I? No Thisbe do I see.
t: Thanks, considerate Wall. May Jove protect you for doing this. But what do I see? I don’t see Thisbe.

og: O wicked Wall through whom I see no bliss!  Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!
t: Oh wicked Wall, through which I see no happiness! Curse your stones for tricking me like this!

og: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.
t: Since the wall has thoughts and feelings, I think it should curse back at him.

og: No, in truth, sir, he should not. “Deceiving me” is Thisbe’s cue. She is to enter now and I am to spy her through the wall. You shall see, it will fall pat as I told you. Yonder she comes.
t: No, in fact, sir, he shouldn't. "Tricking me” is the cue for Thisbe to speak. She’s going to enter now, and I’ll spot her through the wall. You’ll see, it’ll happen just as I am telling you. There she comes.

og: O Wall, full often hast thou heard my moans,  For parting my fair Pyramus and me!
t: Oh Wall, you’ve so often heard my moans because you separate me from my handsome Pyramus!

og: My cherry lips have often kissed thy stones,  Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in thee.
t: My cherry lips have often kissed your stones which are held together by plaster.

og: I see a voice. Now will I to the chink,To spy an I can hear my Thisbe’s face. Thisbe?
t: I see a voice! Now I’ll go to the hole to find out if I can hear my Thisbe’s face. Thisbe?

og: My love thou art, my love, I think.
t: You are my love, my love, I think.

og: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover’s grace.And like Limander am I trusty still.
t: Whatever you think, I am your gracious lover. And, like Limander, I’m still faithful to you.

og: And I like Helen, till the Fates me kill.
t: And I’ll be as faithful as Helen of Troy, until the day I’m destined to die.

og: Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true.
t: Not even Shafalus was as faithful to his lover Procrus as I am to you.

og: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.
t: I’m as faithful to you as Shafalus was to Procrus.

og: Oh, kiss me through the hole of this vile wall!
t: Oh, kiss me through the hole in this awful wall.

og: I kiss the wall’s hole, not your lips at all.
t: I’m kissing the wall’s hole, not your lips at all.

og: Wilt thou at Ninny’s tomb meet me straightway?
t: Will you meet me at Ninny’s grave right now?

og: Tide life, tide death, I come without delay.
t: No matter what comes in life or death, I will be there without delay.

og: Thus have I, Wall, my part dischargèd so.And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.
t: In this way, I, Wall, have played my part. Now, since I’m done, Wall can go away.

og: Now is the moon down between the two neighbors.
t: With the wall gone, now the two lovers will see each other by the light of the moon.

og: No remedy, my lord, when walls are so willful to hear without warning.
t: There's nothing you can do about it, my lord, when walls have ears.

og: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.
t: This is the silliest thing I’ve ever seen.

og: The best in this kind are but shadows, and the worst are no worse if imagination amend them.
t: The best plays are a kind of illusion, and the worst are no worse if you use your imagination to fix them up.

og: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.
t: Then it's your imagination that's good, not theirs.

og: If we imagine no worse of them than they of themselves,they may pass for excellent men. Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.
t: If we imagine these actors as being no worse than they imagine themselves to be, then they'd seem like accomplished actors. Here come two noble beasts, a man and a lion.

og: You, ladies, you whose gentle hearts do fear  The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor,  May now perchance both quake and tremble here,  When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar.
t: You gentle-hearted ladies—who fear even the smallest monstrous mouse that sneaks along the floor—may shake and tremble when the wild lion roars in its most violent rage.

og: Then know that I, as Snug the joiner, am  A lion fell, nor else no lion’s dam.  For if I should as lion come in strife  Into this place, ’twere pity on my life.
t: Therefore, know that I, Snug the carpenter, am neither a cruel lion nor a lioness, because if I were a lion that had come to this place in order to fight, then it would cost me my life.

og: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.
t: It’s a noble beast, with a good conscience.

og: A very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw.
t: He’s the best actor at being a beast that I’ve ever seen, my lord.

og: This lion is a very fox for his valor.
t: This lion seems like a fox, by being more sly than courageous.

og: True. And a goose for his discretion.
t: True. And he's just about as wise as a goose—that is, not wise at all!

og: Not so, my lord. For his valor cannot carry his discretion, and the fox carries the goose.
t: Not true, my lord. He’s not courageous enough pull off being discreet, just as the fox pulls along the goose by carrying it in its mouth.

og: His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his valor, for the goose carries not the fox. It is well. Leave it to his discretion, and let us listen to the moon.
t: He’s not discreet enough to be brave, actually, just as the goose can't carry the fox. It doesn't matter. Let's leave all this to his discretion, and listen to the what the moon has to say.

og: This lanthorn doth the hornèd moon present—
t: This lantern symbolizes the horned moon.

og: He should have worn the horns on his head.
t: He should have worn the horns on his head.

og: He is no crescent, and his horns are invisible within the circumference.
t: He’s not shaped like a crescent moon, so his horns are probably invisible inside the circle.

og: This lanthorn doth the hornèd moon present.Myself the man i' th' moon do seem to be.
t: This lantern represents the crescent moon. I am pretending to be the man in the moon.

og: This is the greatest error of all the rest. The man should be put into the lanthorn. How is it else the “mani' th' moon?”
t: That’s a bigger mistake that all the others. The man should be put inside the lantern. How else can he be the “man in the moon?”

og: He dares not come there for the candle. For you see, itis already in snuff.
t: He doesn't dare to go in there on account of the candle. Because, you see, the candle must first be put out.

og: I am aweary of this moon. Would he would change!
t: I’m tired of this moon. If only he would wane away.

og: It appears by his small light of discretion, that he isin the wane. But yet, in courtesy, in all reason, we must stay the time.
t: It seems by the meager amount of light he's giving off that he is waning. But, to be polite, we’ll have to wait to find out.

og: Proceed, Moon.
t: Continue, Moon.

og: All that I have to say is to tell you that the lanthornis the moon; I, the man in the moon; this thornbush, mythornbush; and this dog, my dog.
t: All I have to say is that the lantern is the moon. I’m the man in the moon. This thorn bush is my thorn bush. And this dog is my dog.

og: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn, for all theseare in the moon. But silence! Here comes Thisbe.
t: Well, all of these should be in the lantern, because all of them are in the moon. But be quiet! Here comes Thisbe.

og: This is old Ninny’s tomb. Where is my love?
t: This is old Ninny’s tomb. Where is my love?

og: O!
t: Grr!

og: Well roared, Lion!
t: Nice roar, Lion!

og: Well run, Thisbe!
t: Nice running, Thisbe!

og: Well shone, Moon! Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.
t: Nice shining, Moon! Really, the Moon shines quite well.

og: Well moused, Lion!
t: Way to shake that mantle around the way a cat shakes a mouse, Lion!

og: And then came Pyramus.
t: And then Pyramus arrived.

og: And so the lion vanished.
t: So then the lion disappeared.

og: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams.  I thank thee, Moon, for shining now so bright.  For by thy gracious, golden, glittering gleams,  I trust to take of truest Thisbe sight.
t: Sweet Moon, I thank you for your sunny beams. I thank you, Moon, for shining now so bright, because by the light of your helpful, golden, glittering beams, I will be able to see my faithful Thisbe.

og: But stay, O spite!  But mark, poor knight,  What dreadful dole is here!  Eyes, do you see?  How can it be?
t: But wait. Oh, misfortune! Look, you poor knight, what an awful sight! Eyes, do you see? How can this be?

og: O dainty duck! O dear!  Thy mantle good,  What, stained with blood?
t: Oh, my dainty duck! Oh, my dear! What? Your beautiful cloak, is it stained with blood?

og: Approach, ye Furies fell!  O Fates, come, come,  Cut thread and thrum.  Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!
t: Come, you cruel Furies! Come, come you Fates, and cut the thread of my life. Conquer, crush, bring to an end, and kill!

og: This passion and the death of a dear friend would go near to make a man look sad.
t: Watching this performance would be almost enough to make a man sad—so long as a good friend of yours died while you were watching it.

og: Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.
t: Curse my heart, but I feel sorry for this man.

og: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?  Since lion vile hath here deflowered my dear,  Which is—no, no—which was the fairest dame  That lived, that loved, that liked, that looked with cheer.
t: Oh why, Mother Nature, did you create lions? A dreadful lion has deflowered my darling, who is—no, no—who was the most beautiful woman that ever lived, loved, liked, or smiled.

og: Come, tears, confound!  Out, sword, and wound!  The pap of Pyramus—  Ay, that left pap  Where heart doth hop.
t: Come, tears, overwhelm me! Come out, sword, and wound me in the chest—yes, on the left side where the heart beats.

og: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.  Now am I dead.  Now am I fled.  My soul is in the sky.  Tongue, lose thy light.  Moon, take thy flight.
t: And so, I die, so, so, so. Now I am dead. Now my soul has flown from my body. Tongue, see no more. Moon, disappear.

og: No die, but an ace for him, for he is but one.
t: This guy is just a single face of a die—the one, because he's a true original.

og: Less than an ace, man. For he is dead. He is nothing.
t: He’s a die with even fewer than one dot. He's dead, so he's nothing.

og: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and prove an ass.
t: With the help of a doctor he might recover and become an ass.

og: How chance Moonshine is gone before Thisbe comes back and finds her lover?
t: What's going to happen since Moonshine has left before Thisbe comes back. How will she be able to find her lover?

og: She will find him by starlight. Here she comes, and herpassion ends the play.
t: She’ll see him by starlight. Here she comes. Her crying will end the play.

og: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a Pyramus.I hope she will be brief.
t: I don’t think this Pyramus deserves a whole lot of crying. I hope she does her part quickly.

og: A mote will turn the balance, which Pyramus, which Thisbe, is the better. He for a man, God warrant us, shefor a woman, God bless us.
t: The difference in who's better between Pyramus and Thisbe is razor thin. God save us from him, as a man. But God save us from her, as a woman.

og: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.
t: She's seen him already with those sweet eyes of hers.

og: And thus she means , videlice t —
t: And so she’ll start moaning, as we expected—

og: Asleep, my love?  What, dead, my dove?  O Pyramus, arise!  Speak, speak. Quite dumb?  Dead, dead? A tomb  Must cover thy sweet eyes.
t: Are you asleep, my love? What, are you dead, my dove? Oh, Pyramus, wake up! Speak, speak. Can you talk? Dead, dead? A tomb must cover your sweet eyes.

og: These lily lips,  This cherry nose,  These yellow cowslip cheeks  Are gone, are gone.  Lovers, make moan.
t: Your lily-white lips, your cherry-red nose, your marigold-yellow cheeks are gone, gone. Lovers, moan.

og: His eyes were green as leeks.  O Sisters three,  Come, come to me  With hands as pale as milk.
t: His eyes were as green as leeks. Oh, you three Fates, come, come to me, with hands as pale as milk.

og: Lay them in gore,  Since you have shore  With shears his thread of silk.
t: Place your hands in blood, since you have cut with scissors the thread of his life.

og: Tongue, not a word.  Come, trusty sword.  Come, blade, my breast imbrue.
t: Tongue, don't say a word. Come, trusty sword. Come, trusted sword, stain my breast with blood.

og: Thus Thisbe ends.  Adieu, adieu, adieu.
t: Goodbye, friends! This is how Thisbe dies. Goodbye, goodbye, goodbye.

og: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
t: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

og: Ay, and Wall too.
t: Yes, and Wall too.

og: No, assure you. The wall is down that parted their fathers. Will it please you to see theepilogue, or to hear a Bergomask dance between two of our company?
t: No, I assure you. The wall that separated their fathers' land has been taken down. Would you like to see the epilogue or see two of our actors perform a country dance?

og: No epilogue, I pray you, for your play needs no excuse.Never excuse—for when the players are all dead, there needs none to be blamed.
t: No epilogue, please. Your play does not need to offer any apology for itself through an epilogue. Never apologize—when the actors are all dead, no one must be blamed.

og: Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe’s garter, itwould have been a fine tragedy.
t: In fact, if the man who wrote the play had performed as Pyramus and hanged himself with Thisbe’s stockings, it would have been a very good tragedy.

og: And so it is, truly, and very notably discharged. But come, your Bergomask. Let your epilogue alone.
t: And that's exactly what it is, honestly, and remarkably performed. Now please, perform your country dance. But don't worry about performing your epilogue.

og: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve. Lovers, to bed. 'Tis almost fairy time.
t: The hands of the clock have struck midnight. Lovers, let's go to bed. It’s almost fairy time.

og: I fear we shall outsleep the coming morn  As much as we this night have overwatched.  This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled  The heavy gait of night.
t: I’m afraid we’re going to sleep past morning because we've stayed up so late tonight. This obviously idiotic play has done a good job to help us pass the tired hours of night.

og: Sweet friends, to bed. A fortnight hold we this solemnity,  In nightly revels and new jollity.
t: Sweet friends, let’s go to bed. For two weeks we will continue to celebrate, with parties and new fun every night.

og: Now the hungry lion roars  And the wolf behowls the moon,  Whilst the heavy ploughman snores,  All with weary task fordone.
t: Now the hungry lion roars and the wolf howls at the moon, while the tired farmer snores, exhausted from all the work he's done.

og: Now the wasted brands do glow,  Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud,  Puts the wretch that lies in woe  In remembrance of a shroud.
t: The embers of the fire glow, while the owl’s screeching hoot makes the man lying in his sickbed think about the shroud that will cover him in death.

og: Now it is the time of night  That the graves all gaping wide,  Every one lets forth his sprite,  In the churchway paths to glide.
t: Now is the time of night when the graves all open wide, and release their spirits to glide over the paths of graveyards.

og: And we fairies, that do run  By the triple Hecate’s team  From the presence of the sun,  Following darkness like a dream,  Now are frolic.
t: And we fairies—who run from the sun just like Hecate, following darkness like a dream—are jolly.

og: Not a mouse  Shall disturb this hallowed house.  I am sent with broom before  To sweep the dust behind the door.
t: I will ensure that not even a mouse will disturb this blessed house. I’ve been sent ahead with a broom to sweep the dust behind the door.

og: Through the house give glimmering light,  By the dead and drowsy fire.
t: The dying fire gives off a glimmering light throughout the house.

og: Every elf and fairy sprite  Hop as light as bird from brier.  And this ditty, after me,  Sing and dance it trippingly.
t: Now every elf and fairy, hop as lightly as a bird on a twig, and sing this little song along with me, and dance.

og: First, rehearse your song by rote,  To each word a warbling note.
t: First rehearse your song from memory, and sing each word with a bird-like note.

og: Hand in hand with fairy grace  Will we sing and bless this place.
t: With everyone holding hands, we'll sing and bless this place with fairy grace.

og: Now until the break of day,  Through this house each fairy stray.
t: Now, until the dawn, Each fairy wander through this house.

og: To the best bride bed will we,  Which by us shall blessèd be.  And the issue there create  Ever shall be fortunate.
t: Titania and I will go To the bless the royal marriage bed, So that the children conceived in itWill have good luck.

og: So shall all the couples three  Ever true in loving be.  And the blots of Nature’s hand
t: All three of the couples will always be Faithful in love, And none of the defects of nature Will appear in their children.

og: Shall not in their issue stand.  Never mole, harelip, nor scar,  Nor mark prodigious, such as are  Despisèd in nativity,  Shall upon their children be.
t: They won’t have moles, or cleft lips, or scars, Or abnormal birthmarks, All of which will cause upset If a baby is born with it.

og: With this field dew consecrate,  Every fairy take his gait.  And each several chamber bless  Through this palace with sweet peace.
t: Fairies, take this holy dew from the fields, And as you walk Through the rooms of the palace, Bless them with sweet peace.

og: And the owner of it blessed  Ever shall in safety rest.  Trip away. Make no stay.  Meet me all by break of day.
t: And the owner of the palace Will always be blessed and safe. Now go, but don’t stay long. Meet me at dawn.

og: If we shadows have offended,  Think but this, and all is mended—  That you have but slumbered here  While these visions did appear.
t: If we actors have offended you, simply think about it this way, and everything will be better: you just slept here, and saw these visions in a dream.

og: And this weak and idle theme,  No more yielding but a dream,  Gentles, do not reprehend.  If you pardon, we will mend.
t: This foolish and silly plot was only a dream. Ladies and gentlemen, don't rebuke me. If you forgive us, we'll make everything better.

og: And, as I am an honest Puck,  If we have unearnèd luck  Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue,  We will make amends ere long.
t: And since I, Puck, am honest, I promise to make everything better—if we're lucky enough to escape your boos and hisses.

og: Else the Puck a liar call.  So good night unto you all.  Give me your hands if we be friends,  And Robin shall restore amends.
t: Otherwise, call me a liar. So, good night to all of you. If we are friends, please give us a round of applause—and Robin will make it all up to you.

og: I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albanythan Cornwall.
t: I thought the king liked the Duke of Albany more than the Duke of Cornwall.

og: It did always seem so to us. But now in the division ofthe kingdom, it appears not which of the dukes he values most,
t: It always seemed like that to me, too. But now that he has divided the kingdom, no one can tell which duke he prefers the most.

og: for equalities are so weighed that curiosity in neither can make choice of either’s moiety.
t: He's divided the kingdom so evenly that not even the closest scrutiny reveals any favoritism to either one.

og: Is not this your son, my lord?
t: Isn't this your son, my lord?

og: His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge. I have so often blushed to acknowledge him that now I am brazed toit.
t: Well, his education has certainly been at my expense. I used to be embarrassed to acknowledge him as my son, but I've done it so many times now that I can do it without blushing.

og: I cannot conceive you.
t: I can't conceive of what you mean by that.

og: Sir, this young fellow’s mother could, whereupon she grew round-wombed, and had indeed, sir, a son for her cradle ere she had a husband for her bed. Do you smell afault?
t: Well, sir, this young fellow's mother certainly could conceive—she conceived him. She got pregnant and had a son for her crib before she had a husband in her bed. Do you perceive a sin in this?

og: I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.
t: Well, I can't wish to undo the sin, since its result—your son—turned out so well.

og: But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year olderthan this, who yet is no dearer in my account.
t: I also have a legitimate son, sir, a few years older than this one, though he's not more valuable to me than Edmund.

og: Though this knave came something saucily to the world before hewas sent for, yet was his mother fair, there was good sport at his making, and the whoreson must be acknowledged.—
t: This rascal Edmund may have come into this world somewhat rudely, and before he was meant to, but his mother was beautiful, we had a good time making him, and I must now acknowledge the bastard as my son.

og: Do you know this noble gentleman, Edmund?
t: [To EDMUND]Do you know this noble gentleman, Edmund?

og: No, my lord.
t: No, my lord.

og: My lord of Kent. Remember him hereafter as my honorable friend.
t: This is Lord Kent. Remember him from now on, as he is my honorable friend.

og: My services to your lordship.
t: I'm at your service, my lord.

og: I must love you and sue to know you better.
t: I sincerely look forward to knowing you better.

og: Sir, I shall study deserving.
t: Sir, I'll try to earn your approval.

og: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
t: He's been abroad for nine years, and he's soon leaving again.

og: The king is coming.
t: The king is coming.

og: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.
t: Go attend to the rulers of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

og: I shall, my lord.
t: I will, my lord.

og: Meantime we shall express our darker purpose.—  Give me the map there.—
t: In the meantime I will discuss my more secret plan. Give me that map there.

og: Know that we have divided  In three our kingdom, and ’tis our fast intent  To shake all cares and business from our age,  Conferring them on younger strengths while we  Unburdened crawl toward death.—
t: I now declare that I have divided my kingdom into three parts, which will be handed over to my sons-in-law. It's my firm intention to free myself from all worry and business in my old age, so that I can crawl unburdened towards death.

og: Our son of Cornwall,  And you, our no less loving son of Albany,  We have this hour a constant will to publish  Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife  May be prevented now.
t: To you, my son-in-law Cornwall, and to you, my equally loving son-in-law Albany, at this time I want to publicly announce what each of my daughters will inherit from me, so as to prevent quarreling after I die.

og: The two great princes, France and Burgundy,  Great rivals in our youngest daughter’s love,  Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn,  And here are to be answered.—
t: The two great rulers of France and Burgundy—who are rivals in pursuing my youngest daughter Cordelia's love—have stayed at my court for a long time. And they will soon have their answer.

og: Tell me, my daughters,  (Since now we will divest us both of rule,  Interest of territory, cares of state)  Which of you shall we say doth love us most
t: Now tell me, my daughters, (since I'm about to give up my throne, my lands, and the worries and stress of being a ruler), tell me which one of you loves me the most.

og: That we our largest bounty may extend  Where nature doth with merit challenge?—  G  oneril,  Our eldest born, speak first.
t: Then I can give my greatest gifts to the one who best deserves them. Goneril, my oldest, you speak first.

og: Sir, I do love you more than words can wield the matter,  Dearer than eyesight, space, and liberty,  Beyond what can be valued, rich or rare,
t: Sir, I love you more than words can express, more dearly than eyesight, space, and liberty, beyond all wealth, no matter how valuable or precious.

og: No less than life, with grace, health, beauty, honor,  As much as child e'er loved or father found—  A love that makes breath poor and speech unable.
t: I love you as much as life itself, and I love you with all my grace, health, beauty, and honor, as much as any daughter ever loved, or any father ever received. My love is so great that it makes my voice weak and my words fail.

og: Beyond all manner of so much I love you.
t: I love you beyond any comparison I could ever make.

og: What shall Cordelia speak? Love, and be silent.
t: What will I do when it's my turn to speak? I can only love, and be silent.

og: Of all these bounds, even from this line to this,  With shadowy forests and with champains riched,  With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads,  We make thee lady.
t: [To GONERIL] I now give you all this land, from this line to that one, containing dark forests, fertile plains, bountiful rivers, and wide meadows.

og: To thine and Albany’s issue  Be this perpetual.—What says our second daughter,  Our dearest Regan, wife of Cornwall? Speak.
t: This land will forever belong to you and Albany's descendants. Now what does my second daughter, my dear Regan, Cornwall's wife, have to say? Speak.

og: Sir, I am made of that self mettle as my sister,  And prize me at her worth. In my true heart,  I find she names my very deed of love—
t: Sir, I am made of the same materials as my sister, and I consider myself her equal in my love for you. Truly, she has described my feelings for you exactly—

og: Only she comes too short, that I profess  Myself an enemy to all other joys,  Which the most precious square of sense possesses.
t: but she fell a little short. I reject any joy whatsoever except my love for you, which is everything I need in life,

og: And find I am alone felicitate  In your dear highness' love.
t: and I find that the only thing that makes me truly happy is your dear Highness's love.

og: Then poor Cordelia!And yet not so, since I am sure my love’sMore ponderous than my tongue.
t: And now it's poor Cordelia's turn! And yet I'm not poor at all, since I know my love is weightier and more sincere than my words.

og: To thee and thine hereditary ever  Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom,  No less in space, validity, and pleasure  Than that conferred on Goneril.—
t: [To REGAN] To you and your heirs I now give this large third of my fair kingdom, which is no less in area, value, or beauty than the land I gave to Goneril.

og: But now, our joy,  Although our last and least, to whose young love  The vines of France and milk of Burgundy  Strive to be interessed.
t: But now for Cordelia, the joy of my life—though the youngest of my daughters—who has been courted so seriously by the rulers of fertile France and Burgundy.

og: What can you say to draw  A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.
t: What can you tell me that will earn a larger portion of my kingdom than your sisters?

og: Nothing, my lord.
t: Nothing, my lord.

og: Nothing?
t: Nothing?

og: Nothing.
t: Nothing.

og: How? Nothing will come of nothing. Speak again.
t: What is this? "Nothing" will earn you nothing. Speak again.

og: Unhappy that I am, I cannot heaveMy heart into my mouth. I love your majestyAccording to my bond, no more nor less.
t: I am unlucky, for I can't put my heart's emotions into words. I love your Majesty as a daughter should love her father, no more and no less.

og: How, how, Cordelia? Mend your speech a little,Lest you may mar your fortunes.
t: What is this, Cordelia? Fix your speech a little, or you may damage your future.

og: Good my lord,  You have begot me, bred me, loved me. I  Return those duties back as are right fit—  Obey you, love you, and most honor you.
t: My good lord, you fathered me, raised me, and loved me. In return, I am dutiful to you, as I should be. I obey you, love you, and honor you.

og: Why have my sisters husbands if they say  They love you all? Haply when I shall wed  That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry  Half my love with him, half my care and duty.
t: Why do my sisters have husbands if they claim that they love only you? I hope that when I get married, my husband will take half of my love, and half of my care and sense of duty.

og: Sure, I shall never marry like my sisters,  To love my father all.
t: Surely I'll never get married like my sisters are married—loving only their father.

og: But goes thy heart with this?
t: But do you really mean this?

og: Ay, good my lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: So young and so untender?
t: So young and so heartless?

og: So young, my lord, and true.
t: So young, my lord, and honest.

og: Let it be so. Thy truth then be thy dower.  For by the sacred radiance of the sun,  The mysteries of Hecate and the night,  By all the operation of the orbs  From whom we do exist and cease to be—
t: Then this is how it will be: your truth will be your only inheritance. For now I swear by the holy light of the sun, the mysteries of witchcraft and the night, and by all the stars whose movements control our lives—

og: Here I disclaim all my paternal care,  Propinquity, and property of blood,  And as a stranger to my heart and me  Hold thee from this for ever.
t: I hereby disown you as my daughter. I give up all my duties as a father and dissolve all family ties between us. From now on you will be a stranger to me.

og: The barbarous Scythian,  Or he that makes his generation messes  To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom  Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved  As thou my sometime daughter.
t: Even a foreign barbarian who eats his own children will be as close to my heart, pitied, and helped during difficult times as you were, my former daughter.

og: Good my liege—
t: But your Majesty—

og: Peace, Kent.  Come not between the dragon and his wrath.  I loved her most and thought to set my rest  On her kind nursery.
t: Quiet, Kent. Don't come between the dragon and its anger. I loved Cordelia most of all, and had hoped to spend my old age in her loving care.

og: [To CORDELIA]  Hence, and avoid my sight!—  So be my grave my peace as here I give  Her father’s heart from her.—
t: [To CORDELIA] Now go away, and get out of my sight! I'll only have peace when I'm dead, now that I've decided to stop loving her.

og: Call France. Who stirs?  Call Burgundy.—
t: [To his servants] Call the King of France. Will someone go? Call the Duke of Burgundy.

og: Cornwall and Albany,  With my two daughters' dowers digest this third.  Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.
t: Cornwall and Albany, you divide Cornelia's third of my kingdom between you. Let her marry her pride, which she calls "honesty."

og: I do invest you jointly with my power,  Preeminence, and all the large effects  That troop with majesty.
t: I now give the two of you all my power, privileges, and the riches that come with kingship.

og: Ourself, by monthly course,  With reservation of an hundred knights  By you to be sustained, shall our abode  Make with you by due turns.
t: For myself I will keep an entourage of a hundred knights, and I will live with one of you one month, and the other the next month.

og: Only shall we retain  The name, and all th' additions to a king.  The sway, revenue, execution of the rest,  Belovèd sons, be yours;
t: I'll keep the title of king and its accompanying honors, but everything else—the power, responsibility, and income—is now yours, my beloved sons-in-law.

og: which to confirm,  This coronet part between you.  [Gives CORNWALL and ALBANY the coronet]
t: To confirm this, take this crown and share it between you. [He gives CORNWALL and ALBANY the crown]

og: Royal Lear,  Whom I have ever honored as my king,
t: Royal Lear, I've always honored you as my king,

og: Loved as my father, as my master followed,  As my great patron thought on in my prayers—
t: loved you as my father, followed you as my master, and thanked you as my benefactor in my prayers—

og: The bow is bent and drawn. Make from the shaft.
t: I've already bent my bow and taken aim. Get out of the way of the arrow.

og: Let it fall rather, though the fork invade  The region of my heart. Be Kent unmannerly  When Lear is mad. What wouldst thou do, old man?
t: Let it strike me, no matter what, even if the arrow strikes my heart. Kent must be rude when Lear is acting madly. What are you doing, old man?

og: Think’st thou that duty shall have dread to speak  When power to flattery bows? To plainness honor’s bound  When majesty falls to folly.
t: Do you think that loyal men will be afraid to speak when a king gives in to flattery? If I consider myself honorable, then I'm obligated to speak bluntly when majesty turns to foolishness.

og: Reserve thy state,  And in thy best consideration check  This hideous rashness. Answer my life my judgment,  Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least,
t: Use your best judgment and rethink this rash, horrible decision. I swear on my life that your youngest daughter doesn't love you the least—

og: Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound  Reverbs no hollowness.
t: just because her words don't echo hollowly, it doesn't mean her heart is unloving.

og: Kent, on thy life, no more.
t: Kent, if you value your life, say nothing more.

og: My life I never held but as a pawn  To wage against thy enemies  ,
t: I've never valued my life except as a tool you could use against your enemies.

og: nor fear to lose it,  Thy safety being motive.
t: I don't fear to lose my life if it will help preserve your safety.

og: Out of my sight!
t: Get out of my sight!

og: See better, Lear, and let me still remainThe true blank of thine eye.
t: Lear, if it will help you see better, let me stay here and always be the target of your angry looks.

og: Now, by Apollo—
t: Now, I swear by Apollo—

og: Now, by Apollo, King,Thou swear’st thy gods in vain.
t: You swear by Apollo, King? Now you're taking the names of the gods in vain.

og: O vassal! Miscreant!
t: You peasant! Villain!

og: Dear sir, forbear!
t: Dear sir, please stop!

og: Do, kill thy physician, and the fee bestow  Upon thy foul disease.
t: Go ahead, kill your doctor and pay the medical bill to your foul disease.

og: Revoke thy gift,  Or whilst I can vent clamor from my throat,  I’ll tell thee thou dost evil.
t: Take back your gift to Albany and Cornwall, or as long as I can make a fuss, I'll keep telling you that you've done an evil thing.

og: Hear me, recreant! On thine allegiance hear me.  That thou hast sought to make us break our vows,  Which we durst never yet,
t: Listen to me, you traitor! If you still show me allegiance as my subject, hear me. You've tried to make me break my promise to Cornwall and Albany, and I've never broken a promise yet.

og: and with strained pride  To come betwixt our sentence and our power,  Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,  Our potency made good, take thy reward:
t: You tried to overturn my sentence of judgment on Cordelia, and neither my personality nor my role as king can accept such disrespect of power. To prove my authority, here is the reward for your actions:

og: Five days we do allot thee for provision  To shield thee from diseases of the world.  And on the sixth to turn thy hated back  Upon our kingdom.
t: you have five days to gather whatever you need to survive the misfortunes of the world. And on the sixth day you must turn your hated back on my kingdom.

og: If on the next day following  Thy banished trunk be found in our dominions,  The moment is thy death. Away! By Jupiter,  This shall not be revoked.
t: If your banished self is found here after that day, you will be immediately killed. Now go away! I swear by Jupiter I'll never take back what I've promised to do.

og: Why, fare thee well, King. Sith thus thou wilt appear,  Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here.
t: Well, farewell then, King. Since this is how you insist on acting, freedom has left this kingdom and been replaced by banishment.

og: [To CORDELIA]  The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid,  That justly think’st and hast most rightly said!
t: [To CORDELIA] Lady, may the gods shelter you, for you've thought with justice and spoken correctly.

og: [To REGAN and GONERIL]  And your large speeches may your deeds approve,  That good effects may spring from words of love.—
t: [To REGAN and GONERIL] And may your actions live up to your grand words, so that we can see good deeds spring from words of love.

og: Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu.  He’ll shape his old course in a country new.
t: And so Kent bids you all farewell, you princes. He'll go be his same old self in a new country.

og: Here’s France and Burgundy, my noble lord.
t: The rulers of France and Burgundy are here, my noble lord.

og: My lord of Burgundy.  We first address towards you, who with this king  Hath rivaled for our daughter.
t: My lord of Burgundy, I'll address you first. You've been a rival to this king in pursuing my daughter.

og: What in the least  Will you require in present dower with her  Or cease your quest of love?
t: What is the least amount you will accept as her dowry before you give up seeking her love?

og: Most royal majesty, I crave no more than hath your highness offered.Nor will you tender less.
t: Your most royal Majesty, I want nothing more than what your Highness has already offered, and I know you won't offer less than that.

og: Right noble Burgundy,  When she was dear to us we did hold her so,  But now her price is fallen.  Sir, there she stands.
t: Noble Burgundy, when my love for Cordelia was great, I considered her worth to be great too. But now her price has fallen. There she is, sir.

og: If aught within that little seeming substance,  Or all of it, with our displeasure pieced  And nothing more, may fitly like your grace,  She’s there, and she is yours.
t: If there's anything your Grace like about that small, worthless creature, who is now inseparable from my anger, then there she is—she's yours.

og: I know no answer.
t: I don't know what to say.

og: Sir, will you, with those infirmities she owes—  Unfriended, new adopted to our hate,
t: Sir, now that you know her flaws—that she is friendless and just now hated by her father,

og: Dowered with our curse and strangered with our oath—  Take her or leave her?
t: and that her only dowry is my curse—will you take her or leave her?

og: Pardon me, royal sir.Election makes not up in such conditions.
t: Forgive me, royal sir. It's impossible to choose in such a situation.

og: Then leave her, sir, for by the power that made me,  I tell you all her wealth.
t: Then leave her, sir, for I swear to God that I've described to you all the value she has.

og: [To FRANCE]  For you, great King,  I would not from your love make such a stray  To match you where I hate.
t: [To FRANCE] And you, great King: I would never want to alienate you by making you marry someone I hate.

og: Therefore beseech you  T' avert your liking a more worthier way  Than on a wretch whom Nature is ashamed  Almost t' acknowledge hers.
t: So please look elsewhere for a wife and forget this worthless girl, who can barely be called human.

og: This is most strange,  That she that even but now was your best object—  The argument of your praise, balm of your age,  Most best, most dearest—
t: This is very strange. How could Cordelia—who until just now was your favorite, the object of all your praise, your comfort in your old age, and your best and dearest—

og: should in this trice of time  Commit a thing so monstrous to dismantle  So many folds of favor.
t: have done something so monstrous that she suddenly stripped away the many layers of your love and favor?

og: Sure, her offense  Must be of such unnatural degree  That monsters it (or your fore-vouched affection  Fall into taint),
t: Surely she must have committed an atrocious crime to make your formerly strong affection for her turn rotten.

og: which to believe of her  Must be a faith that reason without miracle  Could never plant in me.
t: But it would take a miracle to make me believe that she could do something like that.

og: [To LEAR]  I yet beseech your majesty,  If for I want that glib and oily art  To speak and purpose not—  since what I well intend,  I’ll do ’t before I speak—
t: [To LEAR] Please, your Majesty, I lack the glib art of flattery and empty words. When I want to do something, I just do it instead of talking about it.

og: that you make known  It is no vicious blot, murder, or foulness,  No unchaste action or dishonored step  That hath deprived me of your grace and favor,
t: So let it be known that it wasn't because I committed an act of murder, lust, or dishonor that I lost your love and favor.

og: But even for want of that for which I am richer:  A still-soliciting eye and such a tongue  As I am glad I have not, though not to have it  Hath lost me in your liking.
t: It was because I lack a flattering tongue and a greedy eye. I'm a richer person even without these things. And I'm glad that I don't have them, although lacking them has lost me your love.

og: Go to, go to. Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleased me better.
t: Enough, go away. It would've been better for you to have never been born than to have displeased me like you did.

og: Is it no more but this—a tardiness in nature  Which often leaves the history unspoke  That it intends to do?—
t: Is that all? You're banishing her because she has a quiet nature that makes her act without telling the world about her actions?

og: My lord of Burgundy,  What say you to the lady? Love’s not love  When it is mingled with regards that stands  Aloof from th' entire point.
t: My lord of Burgundy, what do you have to say to the lady? Love is not love when it mingles with irrelevant matters.

og: Will you have her?  She is herself a dowry.
t: Will you marry her? She is a valuable dowry in and of herself.

og: [To LEAR]  Royal King,  Give but that portion which yourself proposed,
t: [To LEAR] Royal king, if you'll only give me the dowry that you offered me originally,

og: And here I take Cordelia by the hand,  Duchess of Burgundy.
t: then I'll marry Cordelia right away and make her the Duchess of Burgundy.

og: Nothing. I have sworn. I am firm.
t: I'll give nothing. I have sworn. I'll stand firm.

og: I am sorry then. You have so lost a fatherThat you must lose a husband.
t: I am sorry then. In losing the king as a father, you've also lost me as a husband.

og: Peace be with Burgundy.Since that respects and fortunes are his love, I shall not be his wife.
t: Peace be with you, Burgundy. Since your real love is money, I won't be your wife.

og: Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich being poor,  Most choice forsaken, and most loved despised!  Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon,  Be it lawful I take up what’s cast away.
t: Fairest Cordelia—in being poor you have become most rich; in being abandoned you are valuable; and in being hated you are loved! I accept you and your virtues right away, if it's legal to pick up and keep something that has been cast away by another man.

og: Gods, gods! 'Tis strange that from their cold’st neglect  My love should kindle to inflamed respect.—  Thy dowerless daughter, King, thrown to my chance,  Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France.
t: Gods, gods! It's strange that in treating you so coldly, they've fanned the flames of my love and made me respect you as well. King, your daughter without a dowry, whom you've rejected and thrown to me by chance, will now become the Queen of France and of my heart.

og: Not all the dukes of waterish Burgundy  Can buy this unprized precious maid of me.—  Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind.  Thou losest here, a better where to find.
t: No duke of watered-down Burgundy could buy this priceless, precious girl from me. Cordelia, bid them farewell, even though they've been unkind to you. You've lost your life here to find a better life elsewhere.

og: Thou hast her, France. Let her be thine, for we  Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see  That face of hers again.
t: You can take her, King of France. Let her be your wife, for she's no daughter of mine, and I'll never see that face of hers again.

og: [To CORDELIA]  Therefore be gone  Without our grace, our love, our benison.—  Come, noble Burgundy.
t: [To CORDELIA] So go away, and leave without any love or blessing from me. Come, noble Burgundy.

og: Bid farewell to your sisters.
t: Say goodbye to your sisters.

og: The jewels of our father, with washed eyes  Cordelia leaves you. I know you what you are,  And like a sister am most loath to call  Your faults as they are named.
t: Sisters, you jewels of our father's love, I leave you now with tears in my eyes. I know what you really are, but as a sister I am reluctant to criticize your faults and call them by their true names.

og: Love well our father.  To your professèd bosoms I commit him.  But yet, alas, stood I within his grace,  I would prefer him to a better place.  So farewell to you both.
t: Love our father and take care of him. I leave him to you who have claimed to love him so dearly. But, oh, I wish I were still in his favor, so I could recommend him to better caretakers. So farewell to you both.

og: Prescribe not us our duty.
t: Don't tell us what our duty is.

og: Let your study  Be to content your lord, who hath received you  At fortune’s alms.
t: You should focus on pleasing your lord and husband, who has accepted you out of charity.

og: You have obedience scanted,  And well are worth the want that you have wanted.
t: You have failed to be obedient to our father, and you deserve to lose the love that you yourself have lacked.

og: Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides,Who covers faults at last with shame derides.Well may you prosper.
t: Time will reveal what you're hiding under your cunning flattery. Those who cover their faults always end up being shamed by them. May you have prosperous lives.

og: Come, my fair Cordelia.
t: Come along, my fair Cordelia.

og: Sister, it is not a little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both. I think our father will hence tonight.
t: Sister, I have much to say about things that concern us both. I think our father will leave tonight.

og: That’s most certain, and with you. Next month with us.
t: Certainly, and he'll go to stay with you. Next month he'll stay with us.

og: You see how full of changes his age is. The observationwe have made of it hath not been little.
t: I know you see how moody and fickle he's gotten in his old age, as we've both been observing him so closely.

og: He always loved our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly.
t: He always loved our sister the most, and his poor judgment in banishing her now seems obvious.

og: 'Tis the infirmity of his age. Yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself.
t: It's the sickness of his old age. But even when he was younger, he never understood himself very well.

og: The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash.
t: Even in the prime of his life he was impulsive.

og: Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.
t: Now that he's old, we must deal not only with his deeply-rooted bad habits, but also with the unpredictable bad temper that comes with old age and senility.

og: Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent’s banishment.
t: We're likely to see more unpredictable outbursts from him, like his banishment of Kent.

og: There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him. Pray you, let’s sit together.
t: There is still going to be a farewell ceremony between the King of France and our father. Please, let's sit together and come up with a plan.

og: If our father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his will but offend us.
t: If our father continues to wield his authority in such a fickle way, then his recent surrender to his passions will only hurt us.

og: We shall further think on ’t.
t: We must think more about it.

og: We must do something, and i' th' heat.
t: We have to do something, and should strike while the iron is hot.

og: Thou, nature, art my goddess. To thy law  My services are bound.
t: You, Nature, are my goddess, and I only serve the laws of nature.

og: Wherefore should I  Stand in the plague of custom and permit  The curiosity of nations to deprive me  For that I am some twelve or fourteen moonshines  Lag of a brother?
t: So why should I put up with the sick injustice of man-made social rules, which deprive me of rights just because I was born some twelve or fourteen months after my brother?

og: Why “bastard?” Wherefore “base?”  When my dimensions are as well compact,  My mind as generous, and my shape as true  As honest madam’s issue?
t: Why call me a "bastard?" Why is a bastard inherently "worthless" when I'm as sound in my body and my mind as any legitimate child?

og: Why brand they us  With “base,” with “baseness,” “bastardy,” “base,” “base”—
t: Why do they call us "worthless," with "worthlessness," "bastard," "worthless," "worthless?"

og: Who in the lusty stealth of nature take  More composition and fierce quality  Than doth within a dull, stale, tirèd bed  Go to th' creating a whole tribe of fops  Got ’tween a sleep and wake?
t: We bastards were at least conceived in a moment of passionate, stealthy lust, and so we have a stronger and fiercer nature than those shallow fools who were conceived in a dull, stale, tired marriage bed, where half-asleep couples churn out whole tribes of children.

og: Well then,  Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land.  Our father’s love is to the bastard Edmund  As to the legitimate.—
t: Well then, legitimate brother Edgar, I must have your land. Our father loves me just as much as he loves his legitimate son.

og: Fine word, “legitimate!”—  Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed  And my invention thrive, Edmund the base  Shall top th' legitimate.
t: What a fine word, "legitimate!" Well, my legitimate brother, if this letter succeeds and my plan goes well, Edmund the worthless will triumph over Edgar the legitimate.

og: I grow, I prosper.  Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
t: I will grow, I will prosper. Now, gods, stand up for the bastards!

og: Kent banished thus? And France in choler parted?  And the king gone tonight, prescribed his power  Confined to exhibition?
t: Has Kent really been banished like this? And the King of France has gone away angry? And King Lear has left tonight, having given up all his power except for some money and his title?

og: All this done  Upon the gad?—Edmund, how now? What news?
t: All this done on the spur of the moment? Edmund, what's going on? What's the news?

og: So please your lordship, none.
t: There is no news, my lord.

og: Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter?
t: Why are you being so secretive about that letter?

og: I know no news, my lord.
t: I don't have any news, my lord.

og: What paper were you reading?
t: What's that letter you were reading?

og: Nothing, my lord.
t: Nothing, my lord

og: No? What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket? The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself.
t: No? Why did you look so terrified and stuff it in your pocket then? If it's nothing, then there's no need to hide it.

og: Let’s see. Come, if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.
t: Let's see it. Come on, if it's nothing, I won't need my glasses to read it.

og: I beseech you, sir, pardon me. It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read. And for so much as I have perused, I find it not fit for your o'erlooking.
t: Please sir, forgive me. It's a letter from my brother that I haven't finished reading yet. And, judging by what I have read, it's not fit for you to look over.

og: Give me the letter, sir.
t: Give me the letter, sir.

og: I shall offend, either to detain or give it. The contents, as in part I understand them, are to blame.
t: I see that I'll offend you whether I keep it or give it to you. The only offensive thing is the content of the letter, as far as I can understand it.

og: Let’s see, let’s see.
t: Let's see, let's see.

og: I hope, for my brother’s justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.
t: I hope, for my brother's sake, that he wrote this just to test my virtue.

og: [reads]  “This policy and reverence of age makes the world bitter to the best of our times, keeps our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish them. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage in the oppressionof aged tyranny, who sways not as it hath power but as it is suffered.
t: [Reading] "The craftiness of old men and society's custom of treating them with reverence makes life bitter for those of us in the prime of our lives, and keeps us from our inheritance until we're too old to enjoy it. I begin to see a kind of useless, foolish slavery in the oppressive power of the elderly—and they only have this power because we allow them to have it.

og: Come to me, that of this I may speak more. If our father would sleep till I waked him, you should enjoy half his revenue forever, and live the beloved of your brother,  Edgar.”
t: Come visit me, so I can speak more about this. If our father should happen to go to his eternal rest, then you would enjoy half of his wealth forever, and live as my beloved brother.Edgar"

og: Hum, conspiracy? “'Sleep till I wake him, you should enjoy half his revenue”—my son Edgar? Had he a hand to write this, a heart and brain to breed it in? When came this to you? Who brought it?
t: Hmm, is this a conspiracy? "If our father should happen to go to his eternal rest, then you would enjoy half of his wealth"—my son Edgar said this? How could he have a hand that would write such things, and a heart and brain to think them up? When did this letter come to you? Who brought it?

og: It was not brought me, my lord. There’s the cunning of it.I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.
t: It wasn't brought to me, my lord. That's what's cunning about it. I found it. It had been thrown through the window of my room.

og: You know the character to be your brother’s?
t: And you're sure this is your brother's handwriting?

og: If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.But in respect of that, I would fain think it were not.
t: My lord, if the letter's contents were good, I would swear that it was his handwriting. But because of what the letter does say, I would rather believe otherwise.

og: It is his.
t: It is his.

og: It is his hand, my lord, but I hope his heart is not inthe contents.
t: It is his handwriting, my lord. But I hope he didn't really mean what he said.

og: Hath he never heretofore sounded you in this business?
t: Has he ever spoken to you about anything like this before?

og: Never, my lord. But I have heard him oft maintain it tobe fit that, sons at perfect age and fathers declined, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.
t: Never, my lord. But I've often heard him argue that when sons reach full maturity and their fathers grow old and feeble, the son should take care of the father, and manage his money.

og: O villain, villain! His very opinion in the letter! Abhorred villain! Unnatural, detested, brutish villain—worse than brutish!
t: Oh, the villain, the villain! That's the same opinion he expresses in the letter! The hateful villain! The unnatural, hateful, beastly villain—worse than a beast!

og: Go, sirrah, seek him. I’ll apprehend him. Abominable villain! Where is he?
t: Go, sir, and find him. I'll arrest him. The abominable villain! Where is he?

og: I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please you tosuspend your indignation against my brother till you can derive from him better testimony of his intent, you shall run a certain course—
t: I don't know, my lord. If you can, you should restrain your anger against my brother until you can find out exactly what his intentions are. That would be a safer course.

og: where if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in your own honor and shake in pieces the heart of his obedience.
t: For if you immediately act violently against him and are mistaken about his purpose, then it would damage your own honor and badly hurt his loyalty to you.

og: I dare pawn down my life forhim that he hath wrote this to feel my affection to your honor and to no other pretense of danger.
t: I would dare to bet my life that he wrote this letter only to test my love for you, and he didn't actually mean anything dangerous.

og: Think you so?
t: Do you think so?

og: If your honor judge it meet, I will place you where youshall hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your satisfaction—and that without any further delay than this very evening.
t: If it would be acceptable to your sense of honor, I can hide you somewhere where you can hear us talking about the letter, and then you'll have the proof of your own hearing about his intentions. We can do it this very evening.
