og: He cannot be such a monster—
t: He can't be such a monster—

og: Nor is not, sure.
t: I'm sure he isn't.

og: To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him. Heaven and earth!
t: —to his own father, who so tenderly and completely loves him. By heaven and earth!

og: Edmund, seek him out, wind me into him, I pray you. Frame the business after your own wisdom. I would unstate myself to be in a due resolution.
t: Edmund, go find him, and gain his confidence for my sake, please. Do whatever needs to be done, and use your own common sense. I would give up anything to relieve my doubts.

og: I will seek him, sir, presently, convey the business asI shall find means, and acquaint you withal.
t: Sir, I'll find him immediately, and manage the business in the best way I can. Then I'll tell you everything.

og: These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no goodto us. Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects.
t: These recent eclipses of the sun and moon are evil omens for us. Though science can explain how they happen, they are still omens, and bad things always follow eclipses.

og: Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide, in cities mutinies, in countries discord, in palaces treason, and the bond cracked ’twixtson and father. This villain of mine comes under the prediction—there’s son against father.
t: Love loses its passion, friendships fall apart, brothers become enemies, riots break out in cities, civil wars begin, treason infiltrates palaces, and the bond between fathers and sons is broken. This villainous son of mine fits the prediction of the bad omens—that's son against father.

og: The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child. We have seen the best of our time. Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves.
t: The king goes against his former nature—that's father against child. The best part of our age has passed. Schemes, emptiness, treachery, and chaos will follow us loudly to our graves.

og: Find out this villain, Edmund. It shall lose thee nothing. Do it carefully.—Andthe noble and true-hearted Kent banished, his offense honesty! 'Tis strange, strange.
t: Find out the truth about this villain, Edmund. It won't damage your reputation. Just do it carefully. And the noble and true-hearted Kent has been banished, for the crime of being honest! It's strange, strange.

og: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when weare sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity,
t: This is the foolishness of the world, that when we are having bad luck—often because of our own excesses—we lay the blame for our disasters on the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if they forced us to be villains!

og: fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on.
t: As if we were fools because of the heavens' decree, or scoundrels, thieves, and traitors because of the influence of the planets, or drunkards, liars, and adulterers because the planets forced us to act that way. As if all our evil was the result of some divine compulsion!

og: An admirable evasion of whoremaster man, to lay his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father compounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail and my nativity was underUrsa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous.
t: This is a good technique for avoiding blame, a trick by which a lustful man can blame his lechery on a star! My father slept with my mother under the influence of Draco, and I was born under the Big Dipper, so it naturally follows that I have a rude and lustful nature.

og: Fut, I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing. Edgar—
t: Good God! I would have turned out the way I am even if the most virginal star in the sky had twinkled over my conception. Edgar—

og: and pat on ’s cue he comes like the catastrophe of the old comedy. My cue is villainous melancholy, with a sighlike Tom o' Bedlam.
t: And here he comes, right on cue, like the neat ending of a clichéd comedy. My role is to be falsely sad, and sigh like a crazy beggar.

og: Oh, these eclipses do portend thesedivisions! Fa, sol, la, mi.
t: Oh, these eclipses are bad omens of such disasters! Fa, sol, la, mi.

og: How now, brother Edmund? What serious contemplation areyou in?
t: How's it going, brother Edmund? What are you thinking about so seriously?

og: I am thinking, brother, of a prediction I read this other day, what should follow these eclipses.
t: Brother, I am thinking of a prediction I read about the other day. An astrologer wrote about what will follow these eclipses.

og: Do you busy yourself about that?
t: Are you really wasting your time with such things?

og: I promise you, the effects he writes of succeed unhappily — as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent, death, dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities, divisions in state,
t: I promise you, the predictions he made keep getting worse—things like divisions among children and parents, death, famine, the breaking of old friendships, political fighting,

og: menaces and maledictions against king and nobles, needless diffidences, banishment of friends, dissipation of cohorts, nuptial breaches, and I know not what.
t: treason and threats against kings and nobles, baseless suspicions, the banishment of friends, the desertion of troops, adultery, and I don't even know what else.

og: How long have you been a sectary astronomical?
t: How long have you been a follower of astrology?

og: Come, come. When saw you my father last?
t: Come now. When did you last see my father?

og: Why, the night gone by.
t: Why, just last night.

og: Spake you with him?
t: Did you speak with him?

og: Ay, two hours together.
t: Yes, we spent two hours together.

og: Parted you in good terms? Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?
t: Did you part on good terms? Did he seem displeased with you, in either his words or in his expression?

og: None at all.
t: Not at all.

og: Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended him. And at my entreaty forbear his presence till some littletime hath qualified the heat of his displeasure,
t: Try to remember how you might have offended him. And let me advise you to avoid his presence until he has some time to let off his rage.

og: which at this instant so rageth in him that with the mischief of your person it would scarcely allay.
t: At this moment his anger is so hot that even physically injuring you would hardly cool it down.

og: Some villain hath done me wrong.
t: Some villain has told a malicious lie about me.

og: That’s my fear. I pray you, have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower. And as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak.
t: That's what I'm afraid of. But please, keep control of yourself until his rage slows down a little. And now come with me to my rooms, and at the right moment I'll bring you to hear my father speak.

og: Pray ye, go.There’s my key. If you do stir abroad, go armed.
t: Please, go. There's my key. If you do go outside, arm yourself.

og: Armed, brother?
t: Arm myself, brother?

og: Brother, I advise you to the best. Go armed. I am no honest man if there be any good meaning towards you.
t: Brother, I'm giving you the best advice I can. Arm yourself. I would be lying if I said that our father had good intentions towards you.

og: I have told you what I have seen and heard—but faintly, nothing like the image and horror of it. Pray you, away.
t: I've told you what I've seen and heard—but only vaguely. I've toned down the horrible reality. Now please, go.

og: Shall I hear from you anon?
t: Will I hear from you soon?

og: I do serve you in this business.
t: Everything I'm doing in this business is to help you.

og: A credulous father, and a brother noble—  Whose nature is so far from doing harms  That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty  My practices ride easy.
t: A gullible father, and a noble brother, whose nature is so innocent of evil that he suspects no evil. My plots will easily work on his foolish honesty.

og: I see the business.  Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit.  All with me’s meet that I can fashion fit.
t: I see what I must do. If I can't have lands by birthright, then let me have them through cunning. Everything that I can shape to fit my own purposes is good for me.

og: Did my father strike my gentlemanFor chiding of his fool?
t: Did my father strike one of my servants for scolding his fool?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: By day and night he wrongs me. Every hour  He flashes into one gross crime or other  That sets us all at odds. I’ll not endure it.
t: He offends me constantly, day and night. Every hour he has an outburst, causing some new offense that makes everyone start fighting. I won't endure it anymore.

og: His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us  On every trifle. When he returns from hunting,  I will not speak with him. Say I am sick.
t: His knights are getting unruly, and he himself criticizes us about every little thing. When he returns from hunting, I won't speak to him. Say that I'm sick.

og: If you come slack of former services,  You shall do well. The fault of it I’ll answer.
t: And if you do less than you used to do to serve the king, you'll be doing the right thing. I'll take the blame for it.

og: He’s coming, madam. I hear him.
t: He's coming, madam. I hear him.

og: Put on what weary negligence you please,  You and your fellow servants. I’ll have it come to question.
t: Now be as tired and neglectful as you desire, you and your fellow servants. I want to confront him about it.

og: If he distaste it, let him to our sister,  Whose mind and mine I know in that are one,  Not to be overruled.
t: If he dislikes it, let him go to my sister. I know that she and I are of the same mind about this matter, and both of us will stand up to him.

og: Idle old man  That still would manage those authorities  That he hath given away!
t: That foolish old man, who thinks he can still wield the power he's given away!

og: Now by my life,  Old fools are babes again and must be used  With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.  Remember what I have said.
t: I swear by my life, old fools become like babies again, and you have to discipline them instead of flatter them—especially when they're clearly misguided. Remember what I've said.

og: Very well, madam.
t: Very well, madam.

og: And let his knights have colder looks among you.  What grows of it, no matter. Advise your fellows so.
t: And be unfriendly to his knights as well. Don't worry about what might happen. Tell your fellow servants about this.

og: I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall,  That I may speak. I’ll write straight to my sister  To hold my very course. Go, prepare for dinner.
t: I want confrontations to come from this, so I can scold my father. I'll write to my sister right away and tell her to do exactly as I do. Now go, prepare for dinner.

og: If but as well I other accents borrow,  That can my speech diffuse, my good intent  May carry through itself to that full issue  For which I razed my likeness.
t: If I can can disguise my voice as well as I've disguised my appearance, then I can carry out the plan for which I erased my true identity.

og: Now, banished Kent,  If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned,  So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest,  Shall find thee full of labors.
t: Now, banished Kent, you can serve the master who condemned you. Hopefully it will work out so that my master, whom I love, will find me to be an excellent worker.

og: Let me not stay a jot for dinner. Go get it ready.
t: Don't make me wait even a second for dinner. Go get it ready.

og: How now, what art thou?
t: Well now, who are you?

og: A man, sir.
t: A man, sir.

og: What dost thou profess? What wouldst thou with us?
t: What's your profession? What do you want with me?

og: I do profess to be no less than I seem—to serve him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest,
t: I swear that I am just what I seem to be. I'll faithfully serve a master who puts his trust in me, I'll love those who are honorable,

og: to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot choose,and to eat no fish.
t: and I'll associate with those who are wise and don't say much. I fear God, fight when I have to, and don't eat fish.

og: What art thou?
t: Who are you?

og: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.
t: I'm a very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.

og: If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king,thou'rt poor enough. What wouldst thou?
t: If you're as a poor a subject as he is a king, then you're certainly poor enough. What do you want?

og: Service.
t: To serve.

og: Who wouldst thou serve?
t: Whom do you want to serve?

og: You.
t: You.

og: Dost thou know me, fellow?
t: Do you know me, fellow?

og: No, sir. But you have that in your countenance which I would fain call master.
t: No, sir. But there's something in your face that makes me want to call you master.

og: What’s that?
t: What's that in my face?

og: Authority.
t: Authority.

og: What services canst thou do?
t: What services can you perform?

og: I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it, and deliver a plain message bluntly.
t: I can keep secrets, ride a horse, run, ruin an elaborate story by trying to tell it, and deliver a plain message bluntly.

og: That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in.And the best of me is diligence.
t: I'm qualified for anything that ordinary men can do. And the best part of me is that I'm hardworking.

og: How old art thou?
t: How old are you?

og: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything. I have years on my backforty- eight.
t: Sir, I'm not young enough to fall in love with a woman because she sings. But I'm not old enough to dote on a woman for any reason. I'm forty-eight years old.

og: Follow me. Thou shalt serve me. If I like thee no worseafter dinner, I will not part from thee yet.—Dinner, ho, dinner! Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
t: Follow me. You'll serve me. If I still like you after dinner, then I'll keep you around.  You, go and call my fool to come here.

og: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
t: You, you, sir, where's my daughter?

og: So please you—
t: Excuse me, I'm busy—

og: What says the fellow there? Call the clotpoll back.
t: What did that fellow say? Call the blockhead back in here.

og: Where’s my fool, ho? I think the world’s asleep.
t: Hey, where's my fool? It seems like the whole world's asleep.

og: How now? Where’s that mongrel?
t: What's going on? Where's that mangy dog of a steward?

og: He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.
t: My lord, he says that your daughter isn't feeling well.

og: Why came not the slave back to me when I called him?
t: Why didn't that rascal come back to me when I called him?

og: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he would not.
t: Sir, he answered me bluntly and said that he didn't want to.

og: He would not?
t: He didn't want to?

og: My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont.
t: My lord, I don't know what's the matter, but it seems to me that your Highness isn't being given the love and respect that you're used to.

og: There’s a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the duke himself also, and your daughter.
t: The duke himself, the servants, and your daughter all seem to share in this loss of respect towards you.

og: Ha! Sayest thou so?
t: What! Do you think so?

og: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—formy duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.
t: My lord, I beg your pardon if I'm mistaken—but I can't be silent when I think your Highness is being wronged.

og: Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception. I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of unkindness.
t: No, you're just reminding me of what I've noticed as well. I've observed a lazy neglectfulness in my subjects lately. But I had blamed it on my own sensitivity, and didn't suspect that they were being deliberately disrespectful.

og: I will look further into ’t. But where’s my fool? I have not seen him this two days.
t: I'll look into it further. But where's my fool? I haven't seen him these last two days.

og: Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.
t: Sir, ever since my lady Cordelia has gone away to France, the fool has been sad and solitary.

og: No more of that. I have noted it well. Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.
t: No more talking about that. I've noticed it too. Go and tell my daughter Goneril that I want to speak with her.

og: Go you, call hither my fool.
t: And you, go call my fool here.

og: O you sir, you, come you hither, sir. Who am I, sir?
t: Oh you, sir, you, come here, sir. Who am I, sir?

og: My lady’s father.
t: My lady's father.

og: “My lady’s father?” My lord’s knave, your whoreson dog!You slave, you cur!
t: "My lady's father?" You wretch, you bastard dog! You rogue, you dog!

og: I am none of these, my lord. I beseech your pardon.
t: I'm not any of those things, my lord. I beg your pardon.

og: Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal?
t: Do you dare make a face at me, you villain?

og: I’ll not be strucken, my lord.
t: I will not be struck, my lord.

og: Nor tripped neither, you base football player.
t: Or tripped, you filthy football player.

og: I thank thee, fellow. Thou servest me, and I’ll love thee.
t: I thank you, fellow. If you serve me like that, I'll love you.

og: Come, sir, arise, away! I’ll teach you differences. Away, away. If you will measure your lubber’s length again, tarry. But away, go to. Have you wisdom? So.
t: Come on, sir. Get up and go away! I'll teach you to respect your superiors. Away, away. If you want to be tripped again, then stay here. If not, go on. Do you have any common sense? Then go.

og: Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee.
t: Now, my friendly servant, I thank you.

og: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.
t: Let me hire him too. Here's my fool's cap.

og: How now, my pretty knave? How dost thou?
t: How are you, my clever fool? How are you doing?

og: Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb.
t: Sir, you had better take my cap.

og: Why, Fool?
t: Why, Fool?

og: Why? For taking one’s part that’s out of favor. Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly. There, take my coxcomb.
t: Why? For taking the side of this unpopular king. If you can't suck up to whoever has power, then you'll soon suffer for it. Here, take my fool's cap.

og: Why, this fellow has banished two on ’s daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will.  If thou follow him, thou mustneeds wear my coxcomb.—
t: Why, this fellow here has banished two of his daughters, and gave the third a blessing without meaning to. If you're going to follow him, you're a fool, and so you should wear my cap.

og: Why, my boy?
t: Why, my boy?

og: If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.There’s mine. Beg another of thy daughters.
t: If I gave them everything I owned, then I'd keep the caps for myself, to show what a fool I was. Here's my fool's cap. Beg your daughters for another one.

og: Take heed, sirrah—the whip.
t: Be careful, boy—remember you can be whipped.

og: Truth’s a dog that must to kennel. He must be whipped out, when Lady Brach may stand by th' fire and stink.
t: Truth's a dog that must go to his kennel. He must be whipped and driven out of the house, while Lady Bitch can stay by the fire, stinking with lies.

og: A pestilent gall to me!
t: Constantly irritating me!

og: Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.
t: Sir, I'll teach you a speech.

og: Do.
t: Do.

og: Mark it, nuncle.
t: Listen closely, uncle.

og: Have more than thou showest,  Speak less than thou knowest,  Lend less than thou owest,  Ride more than thou goest,
t: Have more than you show, speak less than you know, lend less than you own, ride more than you walk.

og: Learn more than thou trowest,  Set less than thou throwest,
t: Don't believe everything you hear. Don't bet everything on a throw of the dice.

og: Leave thy drink and thy whore  And keep in-a-door,  And thou shalt have more  Than two tens to a score.
t: Leave your drink and your whore, and stay indoors, and you'll surely prosper.

og: This is nothing, Fool.
t: That's nothing, Fool.

og: Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer. You gave me nothing for ’t.—Can you make no use of nothing, nuncle?
t: Then it's like the speech of an unpaid lawyer—you gave me nothing for it, and you get what you pay for. Can't you make some use out of nothing, uncle?

og: Why no, boy. Nothing can be made out of nothing.
t: Why no, boy. Nothing can be made out of nothing.

og: Prithee, tell him so much the rent of his land comes to. He will not believe a fool.
t: Please, remind him that no land means no income. He won't believe a fool.

og: A bitter fool.
t: What a bitter fool.

og: Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitterfool and a sweet fool?
t: My boy, do you know the difference between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?

og: No, lad. Teach me.
t: No, boy. Teach me.

og: That lord that counseled thee  To give away thy land,  Come place him here by me.  Do thou for him stand.
t: Bring me the lord who advised you to give away your land, and place him here by me. You stand in his place.

og: The sweet and bitter fool  Will presently appear—  The one in motley here,  The other found out there.
t: The sweet and bitter fool will instantly appear—the sweet fool in jester's clothes here, and the bitter fool over there.

og: Dost thou call me fool, boy?
t: Are you calling me a fool, boy?

og: All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast born with.
t: Well, you've given away all the other titles you were born with, so you might as well keep the title of "fool."

og: This is not altogether fool, my lord.
t: This fool's words aren't totally foolish, my lord.

og: No, faith, lords and great men will not let me. If I had a monopoly out, they would have part on ’t. And ladies too— they will not let me have all fool to myself;
t: No, truly, lords and important men won't let me be totally foolish. If I had a monopoly on foolishness, they would insist that I share it. And ladies too—they won't ever let me be the biggest fool.

og: they’ll be snatching. Give me an egg, nuncle, and I’ll give thee two crowns.
t: They're always snatching away my role. Uncle, give me an egg, and I'll give you two crowns.

og: What two crowns shall they be?
t: What two crowns do you mean?

og: Why—after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat—the two crowns of the egg. When thou clovest thy crown i' th' middle, and gavest away both parts, thou borest thy ass o' th' back o'er the dirt.
t: Why—after I've cut the egg in half and eaten the whites, the yolk will be like two golden crowns. When you cut your crown and your kingdom in two and gave away both parts, you were carrying your donkey on your back and foolishly reversing the order of nature.

og: Thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown when thou gavest thy golden one away. If I speak like myself in this, let himbe whipped that first finds it so.
t: You didn't have much wit in the bald crown of your head when you gave your golden crown away. If anyone thinks I'm speaking nonsense like a fool when I say this, let him be whipped.

og: [Sings]  Fools had ne'er less wit in a year,   For wise men are grown foppish.
t: [Singing]Fools have had a hard year,For wise men have grown foolish.

og: They know not how their wits to wear,  Their manners are so apish.
t: They don't know how to use their wits,They can only stupidly imitate others.

og: When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah?
t: When did you become so full of songs, boy?

og: I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy daughters thy mothers. For when thou gavest them the rod, and put’st down thine own breeches,
t: I've made a habit of singing, uncle, ever since you made your daughters into your mothers by giving them the switch and pulling down your own pants,

og: [Sings]  Then they for sudden joy did weep  And I for sorrow sung,  That such a king should play bo-peep   And go the fools among.
t: [Singing]Then they wept for sudden joy,And I sang for sorrow,That such a king should play a child's gameAnd go about with fools for company.

og: Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thyfool to lie. I would fain learn to lie.
t: Uncle, please hire a schoolteacher who can teach your fool to lie. I want to learn how to lie.

og: An you lie, sirrah, we’ll have you whipped.
t: If you lie, boy, then I'll have you whipped.

og: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are. They’ll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace.
t: I'm amazed at how alike you and your daughters are. They'll have me whipped for telling the truth, you'll have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I'm whipped for keeping quiet too.

og: I had rather be any kind o' thing thana fool. And yet I would not be thee, nuncle. Thou hast pared thy wit o' both sides and left nothing i' th' middle. Here comes one o' the parings.
t: I wish I were anything but a fool. And yet I wouldn't want to be you, uncle. You've sliced off your wits on both sides of your brain, and left nothing in the middle. Here comes one of the slices.

og: How now, daughter? What makes that frontlet on?Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.
t: How are you, daughter? Why are you wearing such a frown? It seems like you've been frowning too much lately.

og: [To LEAR]  Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for her frowning. Now thou art an O withouta figure. I am better than thou art now. I am a fool. Thou art nothing.
t: [To LEAR] You were a fine fellow back when you didn't need to care whether she was frowning or not. Now you're a zero without a digit in front of it to give it value. I'm better than you are now. I am a fool. You are nothing.

og: [To GONERIL]  Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue. So your face bids me, though you say nothing.
t: [To GONERIL] Yes, I will be quiet. That's what your face is commanding me to do, even though you don't say anything aloud.

og: Mum, mum,  He that keeps nor crust nor crumb,  Weary of all, shall want some.
t: Mum, mum, he who gives away his crust and crumbs when he's weary of possessions, will soon want some back.

og: [indicates LEAR]  That’s a shelled peascod.
t: [Pointing at LEAR] That's an empty pea pod right there.

og: [To LEAR]  Not only, sir, this your all-licensed fool,  But other of your insolent retinue  Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth  In rank and not-to-be-endurèd riots.
t: [To LEAR] Sir, not just your fool here—who is allowed to say whatever he wants—but others in your rude entourage keep complaining, fighting, and breaking out in foul and intolerable wildness.

og: Sir,  I had thought by making this well known unto you  To have found a safe redress,
t: Sir, I had thought that if I told you about this disrespectful behavior you would find a sure solution to it.

og: but now grow fearful  By what yourself too late have spoke and done  That you protect this course and put it on  By your allowance—
t: But now I'm worried because of what you yourself have said and done all too recently. I'm worried that you encourage this kind of behavior by allowing it to continue.

og: which if you should, the fault  Would not ’scape censure, nor the redresses sleep  Which in the tender of a wholesome weal  Might in their working do you that offense,
t: If that's the case, then your actions won't escape punishment, and there will be some kind of payment required of you for the good of the kingdom.

og: Which else were shame, that then necessity  Will call discreet proceeding.
t: I realize that having to punish your knights will seem shameful to you, but it's necessary in this instance.

og: For you know, nuncle,  The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long,
t: For you know, uncle, a sparrow raised a cuckoo in its nest for a long time,

og: That it’s had it head bit off by it young.  So out went the candle and we were left darkling.
t: until the cuckoo grew up and the sparrow had its head bitten off by its own child. And so the candle went out, and we were all left in the dark.

og: Are you our daughter?
t: Are you my daughter?

og: Come, sir,  I would you would make use of that good wisdom  Whereof I know you are fraught,
t: Come now, sir. I wish you would use your wisdom—which I know you are well-provided with—

og: and put away  These dispositions that of late transform you  From what you rightly are.
t: to snap out of these fickle moods that you've been in lately, so you can return to your true self.

og: May not an ass know when the cart draws the horse? Whoop, Jug! I love thee.
t: Even a fool can tell when everything's upside down and the cart is pulling the horse, can't he? Whoop, sweetheart! I love you!

og: Does any here know me? Why, this is not Lear.  Doth Lear walk thus? Speak thus? Where are his eyes?
t: Does anyone here know who I am? Why, I can't be Lear. Does Lear walk like this? Talk like this? Where are his eyes?

og: Either his notion weakens, or his discernings  Are lethargied. Ha, sleeping or waking?  Sure, ’tis not so.  Who is it that can tell me who I am?
t: Either his mind is getting weak or his senses are failing. Hey, am I awake? Surely not. Who can tell me who I am?

og: Lear’s shadow.
t: You are Lear's shadow.

og: I would learn that. For by the marksOf sovereignty, knowledge, and reason,I should be false persuaded I had daughters.
t: I want to learn who I am. The evidence given to me by my kingly nature, my knowledge, and my reason tries to falsely persuade me that I have daughters.

og: Which they will make an obedient father.
t: Daughters who will turn you into an obedient father.

og: Your name, fair gentlewoman?
t: What's your name, dear lady?

og: This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savor  Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you  To understand my purposes aright.
t: Sir, this pretended astonishment of yours seems very similar to your other recent pranks. Please try to understand my purpose.

og: As you are old and reverend, should be wise.  Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires,
t: You are old and respected, so try to be wise too. You're keeping a hundred knights and squires here—

og: Men so disordered, so debauched and bold  That this our court, infected with their manners,  Shows like a riotous inn.
t: men so disorderly, vulgar, and bold that our court has become infected with their manners and now seems like a cheap, rowdy inn.

og: Epicurism and lust  Make it more like a tavern or a brothel  Than a graced palace. The shame itself doth speak  For instant remedy.
t: Their gluttony and lust make this place feel more like a tavern or a brothel than an honored palace. It's so shameful that it requires immediate action.

og: Be then desired  By her that else will take the thing she begs,  A little to disquantity your train,
t: Therefore it's my desire—and if you won't do it when I ask politely, then I'll do it myself by force—that you reduce the number of knights in your entourage a little.

og: And the remainder that shall still depend  To be such men as may besort your age,  Which know themselves and you.
t: Keep the ones who are older, who suit your advanced age, and who know their proper place—as well as yours.

og: Darkness and devils!
t: Darkness and devils!

og: Saddle my horses. Call my train together.—
t: [To his attendants] Saddle my horses. Call my knights together.

og: Degenerate bastard, I’ll not trouble thee.  Yet have I left a daughter.
t: [To GONERIL] I won't trouble you any more, you worthless bastard. I still have one true daughter left.

og: You strike my people, and your disordered rabbleMake servants of their betters.
t: You strike my servants, and your disorderly rabble of knights treats their superiors like servants.

og: Woe that too late repents!—    O sir, are you come? Is it your will? Speak, sir.—Prepare my horses.
t: Prepare my horses.

og: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend,More hideous when thou show’st thee in a childThan the sea monster.
t: Ingratitude is a cold-hearted devil, and it's always at its ugliest when it appears in an ungrateful child. It's more hideous than a sea monster!

og: Pray, sir, be patient.
t: Sir, please be patient.

og: [To GONERIL]  Detested kite, thou liest!  My train are men of choice and rarest parts  That all particulars of duty know  And in the most exact regard support  The worships of their name.
t: [To GONERIL] You hateful vulture, you lie! My knights are men of excellent qualities and accomplishments, and they perfectly do their duty and live up to their honorable reputation.

og: O most small fault,  How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show,  That, like an engine, wrenched my frame of nature  From the fixed place, drew from heart all love,  And added to the gall! O Lear, Lear, Lear!
t: Oh, how ugly did Cordelia's small flaw seem to me! And now it has tortured me and broken my body, sucking the love from my heart and replacing it with bitterness! Oh Lear, Lear, Lear!

og: [strikes his head]  Beat at this gate that let thy folly in  And thy dear judgment out!—Go, go, my people.
t: [Striking himself on the head] Let me beat at this gate that let precious wisdom go out and foolishness come in! [To his attendants] Go, go, my people.

og: My lord, I am guiltless, as I am ignorant,Of what hath moved you.
t: My lord, I'm innocent and ignorant of whatever it is that's angered you.

og: It may be so, my lord.  Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!
t: That may be true, my lord. Now hear me, Nature, dear goddess, hear me!

og: Suspend thy purpose if thou didst intend  To make this creature fruitful.  Into her womb convey sterility.
t: If you had intended for this woman to bear children, then change your purpose for her. Make her womb sterile,

og: Dry up in her the organs of increase,  And from her derogate body never spring  A babe to honor her.
t: and dry it up so that no baby will ever emerge from her hateful body and honor her.

og: If she must teem,  Create her child of spleen, that it may live  And be a thwart disnatured torment to her.
t: But if she must give birth, then give her a spiteful child, so it might live to be a perverse, unnatural torment to her.

og: Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth,  With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks,
t: May it give her wrinkles in her youth, and carve lines in her cheeks from so many falling tears.

og: Turn all her mother’s pains and benefits  To laughter and contempt, that she may feel—  That she may feel  How sharper than a serpent’s tooth it is  To have a thankless child.—
t: Turn all her motherly care and nurturing into mockery and hatred, so she may feel . . so she may feel how an ungrateful child is sharper than a serpent's tooth.

og: Away, away!
t: [To his attendants] Now let's leave this place!

og: Now gods that we adore, whereof comes this?
t: By the gods, what caused all this?

og: Never afflict yourself to know more of it,But let his disposition have that scope That dotage gives it.
t: Don't trouble yourself about it. Just let him be the foolish old man that he is in his senility.

og: What, fifty of my followers at a clap?Within a fortnight?
t: What, fifty of my knights dismissed at a clap of your hands? After only two weeks?

og: What’s the matter, sir?
t: What's the matter, sir?

og: I’ll tell thee.
t: I'll tell you.

og: [To GONERIL]  Life and death! I am ashamed  That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus,  That these hot tears which break from me perforce  Should make thee worth them.
t: [To GONERIL] By life and death! I'm ashamed that you have the power to upset me like this, and that these hot tears that spring forth against my will reveal that I care enough about you to shed them.

og: Blasts and fogs upon thee!  Th' untented woundings of a father’s curse  Pierce every sense about thee!
t: May pain and sickness strike you! May you feel all the incurable pains a father's curse can inflict!

og: Old fond eyes,  Beweep this cause again, I’ll pluck ye out  And cast you, with the waters that you loose,  To temper clay. Yea, is ’t come to this?
t: If these old foolish eyes weep again because of you, I'll pluck them out and throw them to the ground so their wet tears can water the dirt. Has it really come to this?

og: Ha? Let it be so. I have another daughter,  Who I am sure is kind and comfortable.  When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails  She’ll flay thy wolvish visage.
t: Has it? Then so be it. I have another daughter, who I'm sure is kind and hospitable. When she hears what you've done, she'll rip up your wolfish face with her fingernails.

og: Thou shalt find  That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think  I have cast off for ever. Thou shalt, I warrant thee.
t: Then you'll find that I can again take up the power you thought I had cast off forever. I will, I promise you.

og: Do you mark that, my lord?
t: Did you hear all that, my lord?

og: I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you—
t: Goneril, I can't be anything but biased in your favor because of my great love for you—

og: Pray you, content.Come, sire, no more.—What, Oswald, ho!    You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master.
t: Please, be quiet and don't worry. No more protests, sir.  And you, sir, who are more a villain than a fool, run after your master.

og: Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tarry and take the fool with thee.  A fox when one has caught her  And such a daughter
t: Uncle Lear, uncle Lear, wait and take your fool with you. A fox, when you've caught her—and such a daughter—

og: Should sure to the slaughter,  If my cap would buy a halter.  So the fool follows after.
t: would certainly both be slaughtered. If my fool's cap is worth trading for a noose, so the fool follows you.

og: This man hath had good counsel—a hundred knights!  'Tis politic and safe to let him keep  At point a hundred knights, yes, that on every dream,  Each buzz, each fancy, each complaint, dislike,
t: This man has had good advice—a hundred knights! Yes, it's safe and prudent to let him keep a hundred knights around, so that every time he has an outburst, a dream, a change of mood, a complaint, or something that upsets him,

og: He may enguard his dotage with their powers  And hold our lives in mercy?—
t: he has a hundred swords to back up his senile whims and violently force us to accept them!

og: Oswald, I say!
t: [To her servant] Oswald, I say! Where is he?

og: Well, you may fear too far.
t: You might be overly nervous about this.

og: Safer than trust too far.  Let me still take away the harms I fear,  Not fear still to be taken. I know his heart.
t: It's better to be too nervous than too trusting. Let me always get rid of what frightens me, rather than risk being hurt by it.

og: What he hath uttered I have writ my sister.  If she sustain him and his hundred knights  When I have showed th' unfitness—
t: I've written to my sister and told her what he's said. If she welcomes him and his hundred knights after I've described his unwillingness to behave—

og: Here, madam.
t: Here I am, madam.

og: How now, Oswald?What, have you writ that letter to my sister?
t: How are you, Oswald? Have you written that letter to my sister yet?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: Take you some company, and away to horse.  Inform her full of my particular fear,  And thereto add such reasons of your own  As may compact it more.
t: Then take some men with you and ride off to deliver it. Tell her about my specific fears, and add details of your own to back them up.

og: Get you gone  And hasten your return.
t: Now get going, and hurry back.

og: No, no, my lord,  This milky gentleness and course of yours  Though I condemn not, yet,
t: No, no, my lord, I'm not condemning your mild gentleness in dealing with my father. But—if you'll excuse me for saying so—

og: under pardon  You are much more attasked for want of wisdom  Than praised for harmful mildness.
t: you should be criticized much more for lacking wisdom than be praised for being misguidedly gentle.

og: How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell. Striving to better, oft we mar what’s well.
t: I can't tell how far ahead you can see, or how deeply you can perceive. But often we break something in trying to fix it.

og: Nay, then—
t: No, but then—

og: Well, well, th' event.
t: All right, all right. We'll see what happens.

og: [to KENT, giving him letters]  Go you before to Gloucester with these letters. Acquaint my daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her demand out of the letter.
t: [To KENT, giving him a letter] Go ahead of me to Gloucester, and give this letter to Regan. Don't tell her anything or answer her questions about the letter.

og: If your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there afore you.
t: If you don't go fast enough, I'll get there before you.

og: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.
t: My lord, I won't sleep until I've delivered your letter.

og: If a man’s brains were in ’s heels, were ’t not in danger of kibes?
t: If a man's brains were in his feet, wouldn't they be in danger of chilblains?

og: Ay, boy.
t: Yes, boy.

og: Then, I prithee, be merry. Thy wit shall ne'er go slipshod.
t: Then please cheer up. Your brains won't ever have to wear slippers. Feet with brains would never make this useless journey.

og: Ha, ha, ha!
t: Ha, ha, ha!

og: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly. For though she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, yetI can tell what I can tell.
t: Your other daughter will treat you kindly, you'll see. Even though she and Goneril are as similar as two crabapples, I can still tell what I can tell.

og: Why, what canst thou tell, my boy?
t: Why, what can you tell, my boy?

og: She will taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou canst tell why one’s nose stands i' th' middle on ’s face?
t: That Regan will taste just like Goneril—both of them like sour crabapples. Can you tell me why a man's nose stands in the middle of his face?

og: No.
t: No.

og: Why, to keep one’s eyes of either side ’s nose, that what a man cannot smell out, he may spy into.
t: Why, to keep his eyes separated, so he can see whatever he can't sniff out.

og: I did her wrong—
t: I did her wrong—

og: Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?
t: Can you tell me how an oyster makes his shell?

og: No.
t: No.

og: Nor I neither. But I can tell why a snail has a house.
t: Me neither. But I can tell you why a snail carries its house.

og: Why?
t: Why?

og: Why, to put ’s head in—not to give it away to his daughters and leave his horns without a case.
t: Why, to keep himself dry. And then he can't give his house away to his daughters and leave himself without a place to go.

og: I will forget my nature. So kind a father!—Be my horsesready?
t: Are my horses ready?

og: Thy asses are gone about 'em. The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
t: Your attendant asses are getting them. There's a pretty reason why the constellation Pleiades has only seven stars.

og: Because they are not eight?
t: Because it doesn't have eight?

og: Yes indeed. Thou wouldst make a good fool.
t: Yes indeed. You would make a good fool.

og: To take ’t again perforce—Monster ingratitude!
t: I could have taken back my kingdom by force. What monstrous ingratitude!

og: If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being old before thy time.
t: Uncle, if you were my fool, I'd have you beaten for getting old before your time.

og: How’s that?
t: How's that?

og: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.
t: You shouldn't have gotten old until you'd also gotten wise.

og: O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!I would not be mad.Keep me in temper. I would not be mad.
t: Oh, don't let me go crazy, not crazy, sweet God! I don't want to go crazy. Keep me sane. I don't want to go crazy.

og: How now? Are the horses ready?
t: Well, are the horses ready?

og: Ready, my lord.
t: Ready, my lord.

og: Come, boy.
t: Come on, boy.

og: She that’s a maid now and laughs at my departure,Shall not be a maid long unless things be cut shorter.
t: Any girl who laughs at my departure won't be a virgin for long—not unless men are all castrated.

og: Save thee, Curan.
t: Hello, Curan. God bless you.

og: And you, sir. I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.
t: And you, sir. I've seen your father recently, and I told him that the Duke of Cornwall and the Duchess Regan will be staying here with him tonight.

og: How comes that?
t: Why is that?

og: Nay, I know not. You have heard of the news abroad?—I mean the whispered ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments.
t: I don't know. Have you heard the news from abroad? I mean the whispered rumors, since that's all they are right now.

og: Not I. Pray you, what are they?
t: No, but please tell me. What are they?

og: Have you heard of no likely wars toward ’twixt the twoDukes of Cornwall and Albany?
t: You haven't heard that there might be a war soon between the Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

og: Not a word.
t: Not at all.

og: You may do then in time. Fare you well, sir.
t: You may soon. Farewell, sir.

og: The duke be here tonight? The better—best!  This weaves itself perforce into my business.
t: The duke will be here tonight? This is even better—in fact, it's the very best! This can be woven into my plan.

og: My father hath set guard to take my brother.  And I have one thing, of a queasy question,  Which I must act.
t: My father is waiting to catch Edgar in the act of plotting against him, and I still have one risky action to take.

og: Briefness and fortune, work!—  Brother, a word. Descend, brother, I say.
t: May swift action and good fortune make me succeed! Brother, could I have a word with you? Come down, brother, I say.

og: My father watches. O sir, fly this place.  Intelligence is given where you are hid.  You have now the good advantage of the night.
t: My father is looking for you. Oh, sir, flee this place. Someone has spied out your hiding place. Leave now, while you have the cover of darkness.

og: Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall aught?  He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste,  And Regan with him.
t: Have you said anything criticizing the Duke of Cornwall? He's coming here—rushing here tonight, and Regan is with him.

og: Have you nothing said  Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany?  Advise yourself.
t: Have you said anything against the Duke of Albany, his enemy? Consider carefully.

og: I am sure on ’t, not a word.
t: I'm sure of it, not a word.

og: I hear my father coming. Pardon me.  In cunning I must draw my sword upon you.  Draw. Seem to defend yourself. Now quit you well.—
t: I hear my father coming. Pardon me. We must pretend to fight now. Draw your sword. Pretend to defend yourself. Now play your role convincingly.

og: [loudly]  Yield! Come before my father. Light, ho! Here!
t: [Loudly] Give up! I'll bring you before my father. Hey, bring in some light! Here!

og: [aside to EDGAR  ]  Fly, brother, fly.
t: [To EDGAR so that so only he can hear] Run, brother, run.

og: [loudly]  Torches, torches!
t: [Loudly] Torches, bring torches!

og: [aside to EDGAR  ]  So, farewell.
t: [To EDGAR, so that only he can hear] Farewell, then.

og: Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion  Of my more fierce endeavor.  [cuts his own arm]  I have seen drunkards  Do more than this in sport.—
t: [To himself] Some blood on me would give the impression that I fought more fiercely. [He cuts his own arm] I've seen drunkards do more than this as a joke.

og: Father, father!—  Stop, stop!—No help?
t: [To GLOUCESTER] Father, father! Stop, stop! Will no one help me?

og: Now Edmund, where’s the villain?
t: Now, Edmund, where's the villain?

og: Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out,Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the moonTo stand ’s auspicious mistress—
t: He was standing here in the dark with his sharp sword out, mumbling some wicked spells, asking the moon to give him good luck in his dark deeds—

og: But where is he?
t: But where is he?

og: Look, sir, I bleed.
t: Look, sir, I'm bleeding.

og: Where is the villain, Edmund?
t: Where is the villain, Edmund?

og: Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could—
t: He fled that way, sir, when he couldn't—

og: Pursue him, ho! Go after.
t: After him, now! Go.

og: “By no means” what?
t: "When he couldn't" what?

og: Persuade me to the murder of your lordship,  But that I told him the revenging gods  'Gainst parricides did all the thunder bend,  Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond  The child was bound to th' father.
t: When he couldn't persuade me to murder you, my lord. I told him that the angry gods unleash all their thunder on those who kill their fathers, and reminded him of the strong, sacred bond between a child and his father.

og: Sir, in fine,  Seeing how loathly opposite I stood  To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion,  With his preparèd sword he charges home  My unprovided body, latched mine arm.
t: Sir, in the end he saw how firmly opposed I was to his monstrous plan, and with a deadly thrust of his sword, he lunged at my unprotected body and pierced my arm.

og: And when he saw my best alarumed spirits,  Bold in the quarrel’s right, roused to the encounter,  Or whether ghasted by the noise I made,  Full suddenly he fled.
t: But when he saw my spirits rally and, as I prepared to fight, my boldness in defending my righteous cause, he suddenly ran away. Otherwise he was scared off by my shouting.

og: Let him fly far.  Not in this land shall he remain uncaught.  And found—dispatch. The noble duke my master,  My worthy arch and patron, comes tonight.
t: Let him run far. He won't escape for long in this country. And once he's found, he'll be executed. The Duke of Cornwall, my noble master and patron, is coming tonight.

og: By his authority I will proclaim it  That he which finds him shall deserve our thanks,  Bringing the murderous coward to the stake.  He that conceals him, death.
t: I'll proclaim this by his authority: that whoever finds Edgar and helps bring the murderous coward to justice will be rewarded. And if anyone conceals Edgar, they will die.

og: When I dissuaded him from his intent,  And found him pight to do it, with cursed speech  I threatened to discover him. He replied,  “Thou unpossessing bastard!
t: When I tried to persuade him not to kill you, and found him still determined to do it, I angrily threatened to expose him. He replied, "You penniless bastard!

og: Dost thou think  If I would stand against thee, would the reposal  Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee  Make thy words faithed? No.
t: Do you think that if I were to testify against you, anyone would put any trust, value, or worth in your words? You think they'd take your word over mine? No.

og: What I should deny—  As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce  My very character—I’d turn it all  To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.
t: I'd deny everything—yes, even if you produced evidence in my own handwriting—I'd turn it all against you, making it into evidence of your malice and treachery.

og: And thou must make a dullard of the world,  If they not thought the profits of my death  Were very pregnant and potential spirits  To make thee seek it.”
t: And you must think people are stupid if you think they wouldn't realize everything you would gain if I were to die, and thereby realize that you have motive to try to frame me."

og: O strange and fastened villain!  Would he deny his letter, said he? I never got him.—  Hark, the duke’s trumpets. I know not why he comes.  All ports I’ll bar. The villain shall not ’scape.
t: Oh, that monstrous, incurable villain! He would deny his letter, he said? Surely I never fathered him. Listen, there are the duke's trumpets. I don't know why he's come here. I'll shut the town gates and keep any ships from leaving our ports. The villain won't escape.

og: The duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture  I will send far and near, that all the kingdom  May have the due note of him.—
t: The duke must agree with me about that. I'll also send his picture near and far, so that all the kingdom will be able to look for him.

og: And of my land,  Loyal and natural boy, I’ll work the means  To make thee capable.
t: And about my lands, you loyal and loving boy, I'll find a way to make you my legitimate heir.

og: How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither,Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.
t: How are you, my noble friend? Ever since I came here—which was only just recently—I've been hearing strange news.

og: If it be true, all vengeance comes too short Which can pursue th' offender. How dost, my lord?
t: If it's true, no punishment could be harsh enough for the offender. How are you doing, my lord?

og: O madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.
t: Oh, madam, my old heart is broken, it's broken.

og: What, did my father’s godson seek your life?—He whom my father named, your Edgar?
t: What, did my father's godson really try to kill you? The one whom my father named—your son, Edgar?

og: O, lady, lady, shame would have it hid.
t: Oh, lady, lady, it's so shameful that I wish I could hide it

og: Was he not companion with the riotous knightsThat tend upon my father?
t: Wasn't he a companion of those unruly knights who tend to my father?

og: I know not, madam. 'Tis too bad, too bad.
t: I don't know, madam. It's too bad, too bad.

og: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.
t: Yes, madam, he was friendly with those knights.

og: No marvel then, though he were ill affected.  'Tis they have put him on the old man’s death,  To have th' expense and spoil of his revenues.
t: It's no surprise then that they had a bad influence on him. They must have put him up to killing his father, so they could loot the estate once Edgar inherited it.

og: I have this present evening from my sister  Been well informed of them—and with such cautions  That if they come to sojourn at my house  I’ll not be there.
t: Just tonight I got a letter from my sister, telling me all about them—and warning me that if they should come to stay at my house, I shouldn't be there.

og: Nor I, assure thee, Regan.—Edmund, I hear that you have shown your fatherA childlike office.
t: I won't be there either, Regan, I assure you. Edmund, I hear that you have been a true and loving son to your father.

og: It was my duty, sir.
t: It was my duty, sir.

og: He did bewray his practice, and receivedThis hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
t: He exposed Edgar's plans, and got this wound trying to stop him.

og: Is he pursued?
t: Is Edgar being pursued?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: If he be taken, he shall never more  Be feared of doing harm. Make your own purpose  How in my strength you please.—
t: If he's caught, we won't have to worry about him ever causing trouble again. Use my power and authority however you like in order to help your cause.

og: For you, Edmund,  Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant  So much commend itself, you shall be ours.
t: As for you, Edmund, your virtue and obedience have been clear throughout this whole affair, so you will serve me from now on.

og: Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.  You we first seize on.
t: I need people as trustworthy as you are. You are the first one I'll employ.

og: I shall serve you, sir,Truly, however else.
t: I will serve you truly and faithfully sir, if nothing else.

og: For him I thank your grace.
t: Your Grace, I thank you for honoring him like this.

og: You know not why we came to visit you—
t: You don't know why we came to visit you—

og: Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.  Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise,  Wherein we must have use of your advice:
t: And why we came in this way, unexpectedly and traveling through the dark-eyed night. Noble Gloucester, there are some weighty matters that we could use your advice about.

og: Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,  Of differences, which I least thought it fit  To answer from our home.
t: My father has written to me, and so has my sister, both of them describing an argument between them. I thought it would be best if I dealt with this away from my home, as the king might be on his way there.

og: The several messengers  From hence attend dispatch.
t: The messengers from Goneril and the king are here, waiting to be sent with a response.

og: Our good old friend,  Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow  Your needful counsel to our business,  Which craves the instant use.
t: So, our good old friend, give us some badly needed advice about this business. We need to act immediately.

og: I serve you, madam. Your graces are right welcome.
t: I'm at your service, madam. Your Graces are welcome here.

og: Good dawning to thee, friend. Art of this house?
t: Good morning to you, friend. Are a servant in this house?

og: Ay.
t: Yes.

og: Where may we set our horses?
t: Where can we stable our horses?

og: I' th' mire.
t: In the swamp.

og: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.
t: Please, my friend, tell me.

og: I love thee not.
t: I'm not your friend.

og: Why, then, I care not for thee.
t: Well then. If you're going to be like that, I don't care for you either.

og: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
t: If I had you between my teeth, I'd make you care.

og: Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.
t: Why are you treating me like this? I don't know you.

og: Fellow, I know thee.
t: But I know you, fellow.

og: What dost thou know me for?
t: What do you know about me then?

og: A knave, a rascal, an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave;
t: I know that you're a villain and a rascal; that you eat kitchen scraps; and that you're filthy, arrogant, shallow, and shameless. You're a cheapskate servant in dirty stockings;

og: a lily-livered, action-taking knave; a whoreson, glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue;  one-trunk-inheriting slave;
t: a cowardly villain who loves to sue people; a bastard; a narcissistic, effeminate rogue; and a villain with so few possessions, you could fit them all in one trunk.

og: one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service; and art nothing but the composition of a knave,beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; one whom I will beat into clamorous whining if thou deniest the least syllable of thy addition.
t: You'd play the pimp to please your masters. You're nothing but a combination of villain, beggar, coward, pimp, and the son and heir of a mangy bitch, and I'll beat you until you whine if you try to deny even a single one of my words.

og: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!
t: What a monstrous fellow you are, that you would slander someone you don't know, and who doesn't know you!

og: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king? Draw, you rogue, for though it be night yet the moon shines.
t: And what a bold-faced servant you are to deny that you know me! Wasn't it just two days ago that I tripped you and beat you up in front of the king? Draw your sword, you scoundrel. It might be nighttime, but there's enough moonlight to fight by.

og: I’ll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you.  [draws his sword]  Draw, youwhoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw!
t: I'll stab you so many times you can soak up the moonlight through your holes! [Drawing his sword] Draw, you villainous, preening son-of-a-bitch, draw!

og: Away! I have nothing to do with thee.
t: Away with you! I want nothing to do with you.

og: Draw, you rascal. You come with letters against the king and take Vanity the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father.
t: Draw your sword, you rascal. You're here with a letter plotting against the king, and you take the side of that vain puppet Goneril against her royal father.

og: Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks. Draw, you rascal! Come your ways.
t: Draw your sword, you scoundrel, or I'll slice you up like a hog. Draw, you rascal! Come on and fight!

og: Help, ho! Murder! Help!
t: Help, hey! Murder! Help!

og: Strike, you slave. Stand, rogue. Stand, you neat slave, strike!
t: Fight, you rogue. Stand still, scoundrel. Fight, you dainty villain, fight!

og: Help, ho! Murder, murder!
t: Help, hey! Murder, murder!

og: How now? What’s the matter? Part.
t: What's going on? What's the matter? Stop fighting!

og: With you, goodman boy, if you please. Come,I’ll flesh ye. Come on, young master.
t: I'll take you on then, boy, if you like! Come on, I'll strike first. Come on, young master.

og: Weapons, arms? What’s the matter here?
t: Swords out? What's the matter here?

og: Keep peace, upon your lives.He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?
t: Calm down, I command you. The next person to strike again will die. What is the matter?

og: The messengers from our sister and the king.
t: These two are the messengers from my sister and the king.

og: What is your difference? Speak.
t: What are you fighting about? Speak.

og: I am scarce in breath, my lord.
t: I'm out of breath, my lord.

og: No marvel, you have so bestirred your valor. You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee. A tailor madethee.
t: No wonder, with all your brave exertions. You cowardly rascal, Nature is ashamed to admit that she created you. A tailor made you.

og: Thou art a strange fellow. A tailor make a man?
t: You're a strange fellow. How could a tailor make a man?

og: Ay, a tailor, sir. A stone-cutter or painter could nothave made him so ill though they had been but two yearso' th' trade.
t: Yes, a tailor, sir. A sculptor or a painter could never have made something that awful, even if they had only been practicing their craft for two years.

og: Speak yet. How grew your quarrel?
t: But tell me: what are you fighting about?

og: This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared at suit of his gray beard—
t: This old ruffian, sir, whose life I spared because of my respect for the elderly—

og: Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter!—My lord, ifyou will give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar and daub the wall of a jakes with him.—Spare my gray beard, you wagtail?
t: So you spared my life because I'm old, did you, you puppy?

og: Peace, sirrah!You beastly knave, know you no reverence?
t: Quiet, sir! Don't you have any respect, you beast?

og: Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.
t: Yes, sir, but not when I'm angry.

og: Why art thou angry?
t: Why are you angry?

og: That such a slave as this should wear a sword,  Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,  Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain  Which are too intrinse t' unloose,
t: I'm angry that a dishonorable servant like this should wear a sword like a gentleman. Smiling scoundrels like him undo the holy bonds of love between people, gnawing like rats at knots that are too intricate to untie.

og: smooth every passion  That in the natures of their lords rebel,  Bring oil to fire, snow to the colder moods;
t: They encourage only the worst parts of their masters' personality, bringing oil to the fire of their anger and snow to the coldness of their cruelty.

og: Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks  With every gale and vary of their masters,  Knowing naught, like dogs, but following.—
t: They're like weathervanes, turning whichever way the wind is blowing, never taking a stand for anything true, and ignorantly following their masters like dogs.

og: A plague upon your epileptic visage!  Smile you my speeches as I were a fool?  Goose, an I had you upon Sarum plain,  I’d drive ye cackling home to Camelot.
t: [To OSWALD] Damn your ugly face! Are you smiling at my words like I'm a fool? You goose, if I found you on Salisbury Plain, I'd send you cackling all the way back to Camelot.

og: Why, art thou mad, old fellow?
t: What, are you crazy, old man?

og: How fell you out?Say that.
t: How did this fight begin? Tell us that.

og: No contraries hold more antipathy Than I and such a knave.
t: No two opposites could hate each other more than myself and that scoundrel.

og: Why dost thou call him “knave?” What’s his offense?
t: Why do you call him "scoundrel?" What crime has he committed?

og: His countenance likes me not.
t: I don't like his face.

og: No more perchance does mine, nor his, nor hers.
t: But perhaps you don't like mine either, or his, or hers.

og: Sir, ’tis my occupation to be plain.
t: Sir, it's my job to be honest,

og: I have seen better faces in my time  Than stands on any shoulder that I see  Before me at this instant.
t: and I've seen better faces in my day than those I see standing on the shoulders around me right now.

og: This is some fellow,  Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect  A saucy roughness and constrains the garb  Quite from his nature. He cannot flatter, he.
t: Look at this fellow, who gets praised for his honesty and then acts rude and insolent, using his "bluntness" as a cover for his cruelty. He cannot flatter, not he!

og: An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth.  An they will take it, so. If not, he’s plain.
t: He is honest and blunt, and so must speak the truth. And if people accept it, well and good. But if not, he's telling the truth and they just can't handle it!

og: These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness  Harbor more craft and more corrupter ends  Than twenty silly-ducking observants  That stretch their duties nicely.
t: I know this kind of villain, whose honesty hides more cunning and corruption than twenty brown-nosed servants who can only bow and flatter.

og: Sir, in good faith, or in sincere verity,  Under th' allowance of your great aspect,
t: Sir, truthfully, sincerely, if you'll give the approval of your magnificent face,

og: Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire  On flickering Phoebus' front—
t: which glows with the radiance of Phoebus' forehead—

og: What mean’st by this?
t: What do you mean by this?

og: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no flatterer.
t: I'm changing my manner of speech, since you disliked my plain words so much. Sir, I know that I'm no flatterer.

og: He that beguiled you in a plain accent was a plain knave, which for my part I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to ’t.
t: If a man tricked you with plain language, then he's just a plain scoundrel. But I'm not like that, though it's tempting to try to anger you.

og: What was th' offense you gave him?
t: How did you offend him?

og: I never gave him any.  It pleased the king his master very late  To strike at me upon his misconstruction  When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure,  Tripped me behind;
t: I never did. Recently his master the king felt like striking me because of a misunderstanding, and then this man here took the king's side, encouraging his anger, and tripped me from behind.

og: being down, insulted, railed,  And put upon him such a deal of man  That worthied him, got praises of the king  For him attempting who was self-subdued.
t: When I was down on the ground he insulted me, slandered me, and built himself up so he would seem like a worthy man to the king. The king then praised him for his courage in assaulting me, even though I never tried to fight back at all.

og: And in the fleshment of this dread exploit  Drew on me here again.
t: And just now, excited by remembering his last "mighty battle" with me, he drew his sword and attacked me again.

og: None of these rogues and cowardsBut Ajax is their fool.
t: These sorts of cowardly villains always boast like Ajax.

og: Fetch forth the stocks, ho!—You stubborn ancient knave, you reverend braggart,We’ll teach you.
t: Bring out the stocks!  We'll teach you, you stubborn old rascal, you arrogant geezer.

og: Sir, I am too old to learn.  Call not your stocks for me. I serve the king,  On whose employment I was sent to you.
t: Sir, I'm too old to learn. Don't put me in the stocks. I serve the king, who sent me here to you.

og: You shall do small respect, show too bold malice  Against the grace and person of my master,  Stocking his messenger.
t: You'll be insulting my master's royal and personal honor if you put his messenger in the stocks.

og: Fetch forth the stocks!As I have life and honor, there shall he sit till noon.
t: Bring the stocks! I swear on my life and honor, he'll be locked up until noon.

og: Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night too.
t: Until noon? Until night, my lord—and all night too.

og: Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog,You should not use me so.
t: Why, madam, you wouldn't treat me so badly even if I was your father's dog.

og: Sir, being his knave, I will.
t: But you're his villainous servant, sir. So I will.

og: This is a fellow of the selfsame colorOur sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!
t: This is exactly the kind of fellow your sister warned us about.—Come on, bring in the stocks!

og: Let me beseech your grace not to do so.  His fault is much, and the good king his master  Will check him for ’t.
t: Let me ask you not to do this, your Grace. The man has done wrong, and the good king his master will punish him for it.

og: Your purposed low correction  Is such as basest and contemned’st wretches  For pilferings and most common trespasses  Are punished with.
t: But the kind of punishment you intend for him is more appropriate for petty thieves than for royal servants.

og: The king his master needs must take it ill,  That he, so slightly valued in his messenger,  Should have him thus restrained.
t: His master, the king, will surely be insulted when he finds out that you value him so little, locking up and humiliating his messenger like this.

og: I’ll answer that.
t: I'll take responsibility for it.

og: My sister may receive it much more worseTo have her gentleman abused, assaultedFor following her affairs.—Put in his legs.
t: My sister may be more insulted to learn that her messenger was abused and assaulted just for following her orders.  Put his legs in the stocks.

og: Come, my good lord, away.
t: Come on, my good lord, let's go.

og: I am sorry for thee, friend. 'Tis the duke’s pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows,Will not be rubbed nor stopped. I’ll entreat for thee.
t: I'm sorry for you, friend. It's what the duke wants, and everyone knows that he won't allow even the slightest opposition once he's made up his mind. But I'll try to persuade him to release you.

og: Pray you do not, sir. I have watched and traveled hard.  Some time I shall sleep out. The rest I’ll whistle.
t: Please don't, sir. I've been awake and traveling for a long time. I can catch up on sleep while I'm locked up here, and I'll whistle for the rest of the time to entertain myself.

og: A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.  Give you good morrow.
t: Even good men can have their luck wear out. Have a good morning.

og: The duke’s to blame in this. 'Twill be ill taken.
t: The duke's to blame for this. The king won't be happy about it.

og: Good King, that must approve the common saw,  Thou out of heaven’s benediction comest  To the warm sun.  [takes out a letter]
t: Good King Lear, you're just proving the old saying that everything goes from good to bad. [He takes out a letter]

og: Approach, thou beacon to this underglobe,  That by thy comfortable beams I may  Peruse this letter. Nothing almost sees miracles  But misery.
t: Rise, sun, and shine on me so I can read this letter. Only those who are miserable are granted miracles.

og: I know ’tis from Cordelia,  Who hath most fortunately been informed  Of my obscurèd course and  [reads the letter]
t: I know that this letter is from Cordelia, who fortunately knows about my attempts to look after the king in this disguise. [Reading the letter]

og: “shall find time  From this enormous state, seeking to give  Losses their remedies.” All weary and o'erwatched,  Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold  This shameful lodging.
t: She says that she "will have time to fix things now that she's away from the monstrous state of affairs in this country." I'm exhausted, and I've been awake for far too long. I'll take advantage of my fatigue and shut my weary eyes, so I can't see my own humiliating situation.

og: Fortune, good night. Smile once more. Turn thy wheel.  [sleeps]
t: Good night, Fortune. Smile once more. Turn your wheel of fate. [He falls asleep]

og: I heard myself proclaimed,  And by the happy hollow of a tree  Escaped the hunt.
t: I heard myself declared an outlaw, and I was lucky to escape those hunting me by hiding in the trunk of a tree.

og: No port is free, no place  That guard and most unusual vigilance  Does not attend my taking.
t: No port or road is safe for me, and everywhere people are watching and waiting to arrest me.

og: Whiles I may ’scape,  I will preserve myself, and am bethought  To take the basest and most poorest shape  That ever penury in contempt of man  Brought near to beast.
t: But I'll survive as long as I can avoid being captured. I've decided to disguise myself as the filthiest, lowliest beggar that was ever hated by man.

og: My face I’ll grime with filth,  Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots,  And with presented nakedness outface  The winds and persecutions of the sky.
t: I'll smear my face with dirt, wear a loincloth, make my hair tangled and knotted, and face the wind and bad weather almost naked.

og: The country gives me proof and precedent  Of Bedlam beggars, who with roaring voices  Strike in their numbed and mortified bare arms  Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary,
t: I've seen in this country beggars who come from insane asylums, who shriek and stab pins, skewers, nails, and sprigs of rosemary into their numb and deadened arms.

og: And with this horrible object from low farms,  Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills,  Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers,  Enforce their charity.
t: With this horrible spectacle, along with their insane curses and occasional prayers, they force lowly farmers and poor villagers to give them alms.

og: “Poor Turlygod!” “Poor Tom!”—  That’s something yet. Edgar I nothing am.
t: "Poor Turylgood!" "Poor Tom!" they call themselves. That's at least something to be. I'm nothing when I'm known as Edgar.

og: 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home,And not send back my messenger.
t: It's strange that Regan and Cornwall left their home without sending back my messenger.

og: As I learned,The night before there was no purpose in themOf this remove.
t: I heard that, as of last night, they had no intention of leaving and going to stay with Gloucester.

og: Hail to thee, noble master!
t: Greetings to you, noble master!

og: Ha! Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
t: What! Are you in this humiliating position as a joke?

og: No, my lord.
t: No, my lord.

og: Ha, ha! Look, he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by theloins, and men by the legs.
t: Ha, ha! Look, he's wearing wooden stockings. Horses are tied up by their heads, dogs and bears by their necks, monkeys by their waists, and men by their legs.

og: When a man’s overlusty at legs, then he wears wooden nether-stocks.
t: When a man wants to run, then he must wear stockings like these.

og: What’s he that hath so much thy place mistookTo set thee here?
t: What man misunderstood your role as the king's messenger, and locked you up here?

og: It is both he and she:Your son and daughter.
t: It was a man and a woman: your son-in-law and daughter.

og: No.
t: No.

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: No, I say.
t: No, I say.

og: I say “Yea.”
t: And I say "yes."

og: No, no, they would not.
t: No, no, they wouldn't.

og: Yes, they have.
t: Yes, they have.

og: By Jupiter, I swear “No.”
t: By Jupiter, I swear "no."

og: By Juno, I swear “Ay.”
t: By Juno, I swear "yes."

og: They durst not do ’t.  They could not, would not do ’t. 'Tis worse than murder  To do upon respect such violent outrage.
t: They wouldn't dare. They couldn't. They wouldn't. It's worse than murder to so violently humiliate a king like this.

og: Resolve me with all modest haste which way  Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage,  Coming from us.
t: Tell me as quickly as you can what you did to deserve this punishment—or what made them abuse you like this—knowing that you were my messenger.

og: My lord, when at their home  I did commend your highness' letters to them.
t: My lord, I arrived at your son-in-law and daughter's home and delivered your Highness's letter.

og: Ere I was risen from the place that showed  My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,  Stewed in his haste, half breathless, panting forth  From Goneril his mistress salutations,
t: But before I had risen from my respectful kneeling position, a stinking messenger arrived, out of breath and panting out greetings from his mistress Goneril.

og: Delivered letters spite of intermission,  Which presently they read, on whose contents  They summoned up their meiny, straight took horse,
t: He didn't care at all about interrupting me, and he presented a letter from his lady, which they read immediately. Once they understood its contents, they summoned their servants and got on their horses to ride off straight away.

og: Commanded me to follow and attend  The leisure of their answer, gave me cold looks.
t: They commanded me to follow them if I wanted the pleasure of getting their answer, and they glared at me coldly.

og: And meeting here the other messenger,  Whose welcome I perceived had poisoned mine—  Being the very fellow which of late  Displayed so saucily against your highness—
t: Once we got here, I met that other messenger again, the rude one whom they welcomed while scorning me—and he was the very same fellow who was so insolent to you recently, your Highness.

og: Having more man than wit about me, drew.  He raised the house with loud and coward cries.  Your son and daughter found this trespass worth  The shame which here it suffers.
t: I had more anger than intelligence in me, so I drew my sword against him. He then woke up the whole house with his loud and cowardly cries. Your son-in-law and daughter decided that my error deserves this punishment of being locked so shamefully in the stocks here.

og: Winter’s not gone yet, if the wild geese fly that way.  Fathers that wear rags  Do make their children blind.
