t: If your daughter Regan and Cornwall are acting like that, then your troubles aren't over yet. Fathers who wear rags make their children blind to their needs.

og: But fathers that bear bags  Shall see their children kind.  Fortune, that arrant whore,  Ne'er turns the key to th' poor.
t: But fathers with bags of gold make their children kind. Fortune, that fickle whore, never opens the door to the poor.

og: But for all this thou shalt have as many dolors for thydaughters as thou canst tell in a year.
t: But despite all this, your daughters will give you as many dollars—or maybe sorrows—as you can count in a whole year.

og: O, how this mother swells up toward my heart!  Hysterica passio  , down, thou climbing sorrow.Thy element’s below.—Where is this daughter?
t: Where is this daughter of mine?

og: With the earl, sir, here within.
t: With the earl, sir, inside the castle.

og: Follow me not. Stay here.
t: Don't follow me. Stay here.

og: Made you no more offense but what you speak of?
t: Did you really not commit any worse crime than what you told the king?

og: None.How chance the king comes with so small a train?
t: I committed no crime at all. Why did the king come with such a small entourage of knights?

og: An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou’dst well deserved it.
t: If they had put you in the stocks for asking that question, you would've deserved it.

og: Why, Fool?
t: Why, Fool?

og: We’ll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there’s no laboring i' th' winter. All that follow theirnoses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there’s not a nose among twenty but can smell him that’s stinking.
t: You should learn from the ant that there's no use in working in the winter—no one will work for a master who can't pay them. Everyone but the blind can see that the king has fallen on bad luck, and even the blind can smell his decaying fortunes.

og: Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down ahill, lest it break thy neck with following it. But thegreat one that goes up the hill, let him draw thee after.
t: If a huge wheel goes rolling down a hill, don't try to cling to it, or else you'll break your neck. But if you see a wheel going up the hill, let it pull you up after it.

og: When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again. I would have none but knaves follow it since a fool gives it.
t: When a wise man gives you better advice than this, give me my advice back. I'm a fool dispensing advice, so I want only scoundrels taking it.

og: That sir which serves and seeks for gain,  And follows but for form,  Will pack when it begins to rain  And leave thee in the storm.
t: The man who works only for profit, and puts on a show of loyalty, will pack up when it starts to rain and leave you in the storm.

og: But I will tarry. The fool will stay.  And let the wise man fly.  The knave turns fool that runs away;  The fool, no knave, perdie.
t: But I will stay. The fool will stay. And let the wise man flee. The servant who runs away becomes a fool, but this fool is no scoundrel, so help me God.

og: Where learned you this, Fool?
t: Where did you learn all this, Fool?

og: Not i' th' stocks, fool.
t: Not in the stocks, fool.

og: Deny to speak with me? They are sick? They are weary?  They have traveled all the night?—mere fetches, ay!
t: They refuse to speak with me? They're sick? They're weary? They've traveled all night? These are just excuses!

og: The images of revolt and flying off.  Fetch me a better answer.
t: These are the signs of rebellion and desertion. Go back and bring me a better answer.

og: My dear lord,  You know the fiery quality of the duke,
t: My dear lord, you know the duke's fiery, stubborn nature,

og: How unremoveable and fixed he is  In his own course.
t: and how unshakeable he is once he's made a decision.

og: Vengeance, plague, death, confusion! “Fiery?” What “quality?” Why, Gloucester, Gloucester,I’d speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.
t: Vengeance, plague, death, and destruction! "Fiery?" What "stubborn nature?" Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, I want to speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

og: Well, my good lord, I have informed them so.
t: Well, my good lord, I've informed them of that.

og: “Informed them?” Dost thou understand me, man?
t: "Informed them?" Do you understand me, man?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: The king would speak with Cornwall. The dear father  Would with his daughter speak, commands, tends service.  Are they “informed” of this? My breath and blood!
t: The king wants to speak with Cornwall. The dear father wants to speak with his daughter. He commands that she attend to him. Are they "informed" of this? By my breath and blood!

og: “Fiery?” The “fiery” duke? Tell the hot duke that Lear—  No, but not yet. Maybe he is not well.
t: "Fiery?" The "fiery" duke? Well tell that hot-headed duke that Lear . . . But no, not yet. Maybe he's sick.

og: Infirmity doth still neglect all office  Whereto our health is bound. We are not ourselves  When nature, being oppressed, commands the mind  To suffer with the body.
t: Sickness can make us forget the duties that we owe when we're healthy. We're not ourselves when illness makes our minds suffer along with our bodies.

og: I’ll forbear,  And am fallen out with my more headier will  To take the indisposed and sickly fit  For the sound man.
t: I'll restrain my rage, and fight against my fickle temper, which makes me want to judge a sick man like a healthy one.

og: [notices KENT again]  Death on my state! Wherefore  Should he sit here? This act persuades me  That this remotion of the duke and her  Is practice only.
t: [He notices KENT again] A curse on my kingship! Why should Kent be locked up here? His punishment persuades me that the duke and Regan's refusal to see me is just trickery.

og: Give me my servant forth.  Go tell the duke and ’s wife I’d speak with them—  Now, presently.
t: Have my servant released. Go tell the duke and his wife that I will speak with them—now, immediately.

og: Bid them come forth and hear me,  Or at their chamber door I’ll beat the drum  Till it cry sleep to death.
t: Tell them to come out and listen to me, or else I'll beat a drum outside their bedroom door until they have to wake up.

og: I would have all well betwixt you.
t: I want there to be peace between you.

og: O me, my heart, my rising heart! But down.
t: Oh, my heart, my hysterical rising heart! But stay down, heart.

og: Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the eels when she put 'em i' th' paste alive. She knapped 'em o' th' coxcombs with a stick and cried, “Down, wantons, down!”
t: Good, uncle, yell at your heart like the housewife who yelled at the live eels she was putting in her pie. She hit them on their heads with a stick and cried, "Down, you naughty things, stay down!"

og: 'Twas her brother that, in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay.
t: And her brother wanted to be kind to his horse, so he buttered its hay.

og: Good morrow to you both.
t: Good morning to you both.

og: Hail to your grace.
t: Greetings to your Grace.

og: I am glad to see your highness.
t: I am glad to see your Highness.

og: Regan, I think you are. I know what reason  I have to think so:
t: I believe you are glad, Regan. And I know why I believe you:

og: if thou shouldst not be glad,  I would divorce me from thy mother’s tomb,  Sepulchring an adultress.
t: if you weren't glad to see me, then I'd divorce your dead mother, since you would be a bastard—no true daughter of mine—and I would know she had committed adultery.

og: [to KENT]  Oh, are you free?  Some other time for that.
t: [To KENT] Oh, are you free? We'll talk later.

og: Belovèd Regan,  Thy sister’s naught. O Regan, she hath tied  Sharp-toothed unkindness, like a vulture, here.  [indicates his heart]
t: Beloved Regan, your sister Goneril is worthless and wicked. Oh, Regan, she's torn me apart with her sharp unkindness, like a vulture, right here. [He points to his heart]

og: I can scarce speak to thee. Thou'lt not believe  With how depraved a quality— O Regan!
t: I can hardly speak about it. You won't believe how horribly—Oh, Regan!

og: I pray you, sir, take patience. I have hopeYou less know how to value her desertThan she to scant her duty.
t: Please, sir, calm down. I think it's more likely that you don't know how to value her good qualities than that she would neglect her duties to you.

og: Say, how is that?
t: What do you mean by that?

og: I cannot think my sister in the least  Would fail her obligation.
t: I can't believe that my sister would fail in her obligations at all.

og: If, sir, perchance  She have restrained the riots of your followers,  'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end  As clears her from all blame.
t: Sir, if she happened to restrain the rowdiness of your knights, then she must have had a good enough reason for it that she's free from all blame.

og: My curses on her!
t: My curses on her!

og: O sir, you are old.  Nature in you stands on the very verge  Of his confine.
t: Oh, sir, you are old. You're at the very edge of your allotted lifespan.

og: You should be ruled and led  By some discretion that discerns your state  Better than you yourself.
t: You should let yourself be ruled and led by someone who understands you better than you can understand yourself.

og: Therefore I pray you  That to our sister you do make return.  Say you have wronged her, sir.
t: So please go back to my sister's house. Admit that you've wronged her, sir.

og: Ask her forgiveness?  Do you but mark how this becomes the house?—
t: I should ask her forgiveness? Do you understand how that would shame our royal family's honor?

og: [kneels]  “Dear daughter, I confess that I am old.  Age is unnecessary. On my knees I beg  That you’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.”
t: [He kneels] "Dear daughter, I confess that I am old. Old people are unnecessary. On my knees I beg you to give me clothes, a bed, and food."

og: Good sir, no more. These are unsightly tricks.Return you to my sister.
t: Stop this, good sir. These are shameful antics. Go back to my sister.

og: [rising]  Never, Regan.  She hath abated me of half my train,  Looked black upon me, struck me with her tongue,  Most serpentlike, upon the very heart.
t: [Standing up] Never, Regan. She's dismissed half of my knights, glared at me evilly, and struck me in the heart with her venomous insults.

og: All the stored vengeances of heaven fall  On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones,  You taking airs, with lameness!
t: May all the anger of heaven strike her ungrateful head! May she get sick with infectious airs, and may her young limbs go lame!

og: Fie, sir, fie!
t: Stop, sir! Shame on you!

og: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames  Into her scornful eyes!
t: May lighting strike her in her scornful eyes!

og: Infect her beauty,  You fen-sucked fogs drawn by the powerful sun,  To fall and blister!
t: May swampy, poisonous fog blister her face and ruin her beauty!

og: O the blessed gods!So will you wish on me when the rash mood is on.
t: Oh, by the blessed gods! You'll aim the same curses at me if the mood strikes you.

og: No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse.  Thy tender-hafted nature shall not give  Thee o'er to harshness.
t: No, Regan, I'll never curse you. Your tender nature will never turn harsh and cruel.

og: Her eyes are fierce, but thine  Do comfort and not burn.
t: Her eyes are fierce and vicious, but yours are comforting.

og: 'Tis not in thee  To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train,  To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes,  And in conclusion to oppose the bolt  Against my coming in.
t: You would never deny me my pleasures, dismiss my knights, thoughtlessly insult me, reduce my privileges, or lock the door against me.

og: Thou better know’st  The offices of nature, bond of childhood,  Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude.
t: You know better than she does the natural duties of a child to a parent, the politeness and love that comes with gratitude.

og: Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot,  Wherein I thee endowed.
t: You haven't forgotten your half of the kingdom that I gave you.

og: Good sir, to the purpose.
t: Good sir, get to the point.

og: Who put my man i' th' stocks?
t: Who put my messenger in the stocks?

og: What trumpet’s that?
t: What's that trumpet?

og: I know ’t—my sister’s. This approves her letterThat she would soon be here.    Is your lady come?
t: I know it—it's my sister's. This is just what her letter said, that she would be here soon.  Has your lady arrived?

og: This is a slave whose easy borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.—Out, varlet, from my sight!
t: This is the villain whose cheap arrogance comes from his position as a steward to that fickle Goneril.  Out, you wretch, get out of my sight!

og: What means your grace?
t: What do you mean, your Grace?

og: Who stocked my servant? Regan, I have good hope  Thou didst not know on ’t.—Who comes here?
t: Who put my servant in the stocks? Regan, I hope you didn't know anything about it. Who's coming?

og: O heavens,  If you do love old men, if your sweet sway  Allow obedience, if yourselves are old,  Make it your cause. Send down, and take my part!
t: Oh, gods, if you love old men and approve of children being obedient to their parents—if you yourselves are old—then take my side. Hurl down a lightning bolt for my cause!

og: [to GONERIL  ]  Art not ashamed to look upon this beard?—
t: [To GONERIL] Aren't you ashamed to look at me, after you've abused me so badly in my old age?

og: O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?
t: [To REGAN] Oh, Regan, are you really taking her by the hand?

og: Why not by th' hand, sir? How have I offended?All’s not offense that indiscretion findsAnd dotage terms so.
t: Why shouldn't she take me by the hand, sir? What crime have I committed? Just because a senile old man calls something an insult doesn't mean it is one.

og: O sides, you are too tough.Will you yet hold?—How came my man i' th' stocks?
t: Oh, how can my ribs contain my grieving heart? Why don't they burst? How did my messenger come to be put in the stocks?

og: I set him there, sir, but his own disordersDeserved much less advancement.
t: I put him there, sir. But his disorderly behavior deserved a worse punishment.

og: You! Did you?
t: You! You did this?

og: I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.  If till the expiration of your month,  You will return and sojourn with my sister,  Dismissing half your train, come then to me.
t: Please, father, you are weak. Stop pretending to be strong. Dismiss half your knights and go back to stay with my sister for the rest of the month. Then you can stay with me the next month.

og: I am now from home, and out of that provision  Which shall be needful for your entertainment.
t: I'm away from home right now, so I can't provide you with the hospitality you deserve.

og: Return to her, and fifty men dismissed?  No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose  To be a comrade with the wolf and owl—
t: Return to her, and dismiss fifty knights? No, I would rather refuse to live under any roof at all, and choose to live as a comrade of the wolf and the owl—

og: To wage against the enmity o' th' air—  Necessity’s sharp pinch! Return with her?
t: fighting against the harshness of the open air, and living with the sharp pinch of poverty! Return with her?

og: Why, the hot-blooded France that dowerless took  Our youngest born—  I could as well be brought  To knee his throne, and, squirelike, pension beg  To keep base life afoot.  Return with her?
t: Why, it would be better for me to visit the hot-blooded King of France— who took my youngest daughter without a dowry—kneel before his throne, and beg like a servant that he should give me a pension to support my worthless life. Return with her?

og: Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter  To this detested groom.  [indicates OSWALD  ]
t: I'd rather be a scoundrel and a packhorse to this detestable stablehand here! [He points to OSWALD]

og: At your choice, sir.
t: Do any of that if you want to, sir.

og: Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.  I will not trouble thee, my child. Farewell.  We’ll no more meet, no more see one another.
t: No, please, daughter, don't make me go crazy. I won't bother you, my child. Farewell. We'll never meet or see each other again.

og: But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter—  Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh,  Which I must needs call mine.
t: But you're still my child, my daughter, my flesh and blood—or rather you're a disease that's in my flesh, which is still technically my "flesh and blood."

og: Thou art a boil,  A plague-sore or embossèd carbuncle  In my corrupted blood. But I’ll not chide thee.
t: You're a pimple, a sore, a raised tumor corrupting my blood. But I won't criticize you.

og: Let shame come when it will. I do not call it.  I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot,  Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.
t: Shame will come to you when it decides to. I won't encourage it now. I won't ask the gods to smite you with lightning, or complain about you to them.

og: Mend when thou canst. Be better at thy leisure.  I can be patient. I can stay with Regan,  I and my hundred knights.
t: Mend your ways if you can. Better yourself at your leisure. I can be patient. I can stay with Regan, along with my hundred knights.

og: Not altogether so, sir.  I looked not for you yet, nor am provided  For your fit welcome. Give ear, sir, to my sister.
t: Not quite, sir. I wasn't expecting your arrival, and I'm not ready to take care of you. Listen to what my sister is saying, sir.

og: For those that mingle reason with your passion  Must be content to think you old, and so—  But she knows what she does.
t: We're trying to mix some reason in with your passionate anger, even though we realize that you're old. But Goneril knows what she's doing.

og: Is this well spoken now?
t: Do you really mean what you've just said?

og: I dare avouch it, sir. What, fifty followers?  Is it not well? What should you need of more—  Yea, or so many—
t: I'll dare to say yes, sir. What, fifty knights? Isn't that enough for you? Why should you need more—or even that many—

og: sith that both charge and danger  Speak 'gainst so great a number? How, in one house,  Should many people under two commands  Hold amity? 'Tis hard; almost impossible.
t: since fifty knights are expensive and dangerous to keep? How can many people serve two masters and still be at peace under one roof? It's hard, almost impossible.

og: Why might not you, my lord, receive attendanceFrom those that she calls servants, or from mine?
t: Why can't you let yourself be attended by Regan's servants, or mine?

og: Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you,  We could control them. If you will come to me—  For now I spy a danger—
t: Why not, my lord? Then if they happened to neglect you, we could control them. But now that I think about how dangerous fifty knights are, I must say that if you come to stay with me,

og: I entreat you  To bring but five and twenty. To no more  Will I give place or notice.
t: please bring only twenty-five along with you. I won't house or acknowledge any more than that.

og: I gave you all—
t: I gave you everything—

og: And in good time you gave it.
t: And you took your time in giving it.

og: Made you my guardians, my depositaries,  But kept a reservation to be followed  With such a number.
t: I made you the protectors and trustees of my kingdom, on the condition that I could keep a hundred knights for myself.

og: What, must I come to you  With five and twenty, Regan? Said you so?
t: So why should I have to come to you with only twenty-five, Regan? Is that what you said?

og: And speak ’t again, my lord. No more with me.
t: Yes, and I'll say it again, my lord. I'll accept no more than twenty-five.

og: Those wicked creatures yet do look well favored  When others are more wicked. Not being the worst  Stands in some rank of praise.
t: Wicked people start to look better when others become even more wicked. Not being the worst daughter deserves a little praise, I suppose.

og: [to GONERIL]  I’ll go with thee.  Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty,  And thou art twice her love.
t: [To GONERIL] I'll go with you. Your fifty is still twice her twenty-five, so you must love me twice as much a she does.

og: Hear me, my lord.  What need you five and twenty, ten, or five
t: Hear me, my lord. Why do you need twenty-five, or ten, or even five

og: To follow in a house where twice so many  Have a command to tend you?
t: to follow you, when you'll be in a house with twice that many servants to take care of you?

og: What need one?
t: Why do you need even one?

og: O, reason not the need! Our basest beggars  Are in the poorest thing superfluous.  Allow not nature more than nature needs,  Man’s life’s as cheap as beast’s. Thou art a lady.
t: Oh, don't be so logical about needs! Even the poorest beggars have at least something they don't need. If you only allow people to have what they need to survive, then a man's life becomes as cheap as an animal's. You are a fashionable lady.

og: If only to go warm were gorgeous,  Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st,  Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But, for true need—
t: If you dressed only to stay warm, then you wouldn't need the gorgeous clothes you're wearing, as they hardly keep you warm at all. But as for my true needs—

og: You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need.  You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,  As full of grief as age, wretched in both.
t: may the heavens give me endurance, the endurance that I need. You see me here, you gods, a poor old man, as wretched in his grief as he is in his frailty.

og: If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts  Against their father, fool me not so much  To bear it tamely. Touch me with noble anger.
t: If it's you who inspire these daughters to turn against their father, then at least don't make me such a fool as to take their insolence without protesting. Give me noble anger,

og: And let not women’s weapons, water drops,  Stain my man’s cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,  I will have such revenges on you both  That all the world shall—  I will do such things—
t: and don't let any womanly tears stain my man's cheeks! No, you unnatural hags, I'll have such a revenge on you both that the whole world will . . . I'll do such things . . .

og: What they are yet I know not, but they shall be  The terrors of the earth. You think I’ll weep?  No, I’ll not weep.
t: I don't know what things I'll do yet, but they will be terrible. You think I'll weep? No, I won't weep.

og: I have full cause of weeping, but this heart  Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws,  Or ere I’ll weep.—
t: I have good reason to weep, but my heart will break into a hundred thousand pieces before I'll let myself weep.

og: O Fool, I shall go mad!
t: Oh, Fool, I'll go crazy!

og: Let us withdraw. 'Twill be a storm.
t: Let's go inside. There will be a storm.

og: This house is little. The old man and his peopleCannot be well bestowed.
t: This house is small. We can't properly shelter the old man and his followers here.

og: 'Tis his own blame. Hath put himself from rest,And must needs taste his folly.
t: That's his own fault. He has deprived himself of sleep, and must taste the results of his foolishness.

og: For his particular I’ll receive him gladly,But not one follower.
t: I'll be happy to keep him in my house, but I won't house a single one of his followers.

og: So am I purposed.Where is my lord of Gloucester?
t: And I'll do the same. Where is the lord of Gloucester?

og: Followed the old man forth. He is returned.
t: He followed the old man. But now he's coming back.

og: The king is in high rage.
t: The king is enraged.

og: Whither is he going?
t: Where is he going?

og: He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.
t: He called for his horse, but I don't know where he intends to ride.

og: 'Tis best to give him way. He leads himself.
t: It's best to just let him go. He'll only allow himself to be lead by himself.

og: My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.
t: My lord, don't try to convince him to stay.

og: Alack, the night comes on, and the high windsDo sorely ruffle. For many miles aboutThere’s scarce a bush.
t: Alas, night is falling, and the high winds are blowing angrily. There's hardly a bush for many miles around. He won't have any shelter at all.

og: O sir, to wilful men,  The injuries that they themselves procure  Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors.  He is attended with a desperate train.
t: Oh, sir, willful men only learn their lessons from the injuries they get in their foolishness. Shut your doors. His attendants are violent men,

og: And what they may incense him to, being apt  To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.
t: and I'm afraid of what they might encourage him to do, especially since he can be deceived so easily.

og: Shut up your doors, my lord. 'Tis a wild night.My Regan counsels well. Come out o' th' storm.
t: Shut your doors, my lord. It's a wild night. My sister Regan's advice is good. Come in out of the storm.

og: Who’s there, besides foul weather?
t: Who's there, besides bad weather?

og: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.
t: One whose mood is like the weather—very troubled.

og: I know you. Where’s the king?
t: I know you. Where's the king?

og: Contending with the fretful elements.  Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea  Or swell the curlèd water 'bove the main,  That things might change or cease.
t: Out struggling with the elements. He cries out for the winds to blow the earth into the sea, or make the sea's waves flood the land, that all life might end or change forever.

og: Tears his white hair,  Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage,  Catch in their fury and make nothing of.
t: He tears at his white hair, which the fierce winds blow about disdainfully, blind in their fury.

og: Strives in his little world of man to outscorn  The to-and-fro–conflicting wind and rain.
t: He is just a small mortal against the elements, but he's trying to be even angrier and wilder than the rain and winds blowing back and forth.

og: This night—wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,  The lion and the belly-pinchèd wolf  Keep their fur dry—unbonneted he runs,  And bids what will take all.
t: On a night like this, when even hungry bears, lions, and wolves would hide in their dens—he runs about bareheaded, calling for the world to end.

og: But who is with him?
t: But who is with him?

og: None but the fool, who labors to outjestHis heart-struck injuries.
t: Only the fool, who tries to soothe the wounds in the king's heart with his joking.

og: Sir, I do know you,  And dare upon the warrant of my note  Commend a dear thing to you.
t: Sir, I know you, and based on what I know about you, I will dare to trust you with an important job.

og: There is division,  Although as yet the face of it be covered  With mutual cunning, ’twixt Albany and Cornwall,  Who have—as who have not that their great stars  Throned and set high?—servants, who seem no less,
t: There is a feud growing between Albany and Cornwall, though they've cleverly hidden it so far. Like other rulers given power by destiny, Albany and Cornwall both have some servants who seem to be loyal to them,

og: Which are to France the spies and speculations  Intelligent of our state.
t: but who are actually French spies and scouts gathering intelligence against our country.

og: What hath been seen,  Either in snuffs and packings of the dukes,  Or the hard rein which both of them hath borne  Against the old kind king, or something deeper,  Whereof perchance these are but furnishings—
t: The spies have noticed something—the quarrels and intrigues of the dukes, or their harsh treatment of the kind old king, or something deeper, which is perhaps the root of both those problems.

og: But true it is. From France there comes a power  Into this scattered kingdom, who already,  Wise in our negligence, have secret feet  In some of our best ports and are at point  To show their open banner.
t: But it's true. There are already French troops entering this divided kingdom. They are aware of our negligence and have secretly occupied some of our best ports. And they're almost at the point of declaring open war.

og: Now to you.  If on my credit you dare build so far  To make your speed to Dover, you shall find  Some that will thank you, making just report  Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow  The king hath cause to plain.
t: But this is where you come in. If you trust me enough to hurry to Dover, you'll find some people there who will be very grateful if you'll deliver an accurate report of the monstrous and maddening sorrow of the king's suffering.

og: I am a gentleman of blood and breeding,  And from some knowledge and assurance offer  This office to you.
t: I am a gentleman of noble blood, and I know what I'm doing in offering this task to you.

og: I will talk further with you.
t: I'll need to discuss it further before I can give you an answer.

og: [giving GENTLEMAN a purse and a ring]  No, do not.  For confirmation that I am much more  Than my outwall, open this purse and take  What it contains.
t: [Giving the GENTLEMAN a purse and a ring] No, don't. To confirm that I'm much more than I seem from my outward appearance, open this purse and take the money inside.

og: If you shall see Cordelia—  As fear not but you shall—show her this ring.  And she will tell you who that fellow is  That yet you do not know.
t: If you see Cordelia—which you can be sure that you will—show her this ring. And she will tell you who I really am.

og: Fie on this storm!  I will go seek the king.
t: A curse on this storm! I will go and find the king.

og: Give me your hand. Have you no more to say?
t: Let me shake your hand. Do you have anything else to say?

og: Few words, but to effect more than all yet:  That when we have found the king—
t: Only a few words, but they're more important than all the rest. Once we've found the king—

og: in which your pain  That way; I’ll this—he that first lights on him  Holla the other.
t: you go that way, and I'll go this way—the first one to see him should shout to the other.

og: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage, blow!  You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout  Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!
t: Blow, winds, until your cheeks crack! Rage on, storm! You whirlwinds and tornadoes, pour out water until you've drenched the steeples of our churches and drowned their weathervanes!

og: You sulfurous and thought-executing fires,  Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts,  Singe my white head!
t: You sulfurous and deadly lightning—herald of the mighty thunderbolts that split oak trees—singe the white hair on my head!

og: And thou, all-shaking thunder,  Smite flat the thick rotundity o' th' world,  Crack nature’s molds, all germens spill at once  That make ingrateful man!
t: And you, thunder that shakes everything, crush the spherical world flat, and crack open the molds from which nature forms humans, and spill all the seeds that grow up to become ungrateful mankind!

og: O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better than this rainwater out o' door.
t: Oh, uncle, encountering false holy water (like flattering courtier's speeches) in a dry house is better than being outside getting soaked by rainwater.

og: Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters blessing. Here’s a night pities neither wise man nor fool.
t: Please, uncle, let’s go inside and ask your daughters to forgive you. This stormy night has no pity for either wise men or fools.

og: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! Spout, rain!  Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.  I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness.
t: Rumble your belly, thunder! Spit, fire! Pour down, rain! The rain, wind, thunder, and fire are not my daughters. I don't blame you, you elements of the storm, for being unkind.

og: I never gave you kingdom, called you children.  You owe me no subscription. Why then, let fall  Your horrible pleasure.
t: I never gave you a kingdom or called you my children. You don't owe me obedience. So be as horrible as you want to.

og: Here I stand, your slave—  A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man.
t: Here I stand, your slave—a poor, sick, weak, and hated old man.

og: But yet I call you servile ministers,  That will with two pernicious daughters joined  Your high engendered battles 'gainst a head  So old and white as this. Oh, ho! 'Tis foul.
t: But I can still accuse you of joining forces with my two wicked daughters, and using your heavenly powers to strike my old, white head. Oh! It's foul!

og: He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good headpiece.  The codpiece that will house  Before the head has any—
t: Whoever has a house to cover his head has a good hat.If a man finds housing for his genitals before he finds housing for his head—

og: The head and he shall louse.  So beggars marry many.
t: he'll end up poor and lice-infested. So whores have "married" many men by giving them housing.

og: The man that makes his toe  What he his heart should make  Shall of a corn cry woe,  And turn his sleep to wake.
t: The man who values his toe more than he values his heart will always have corns to complain of, and be kept awake at night.

og: For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths  in a glass.
t: For there's never been a pretty woman who didn't practice making pretty faces in the mirror.

og: No, I will be the pattern of all patience.I will say nothing.
t: No, I will act like a model of patience. I will say nothing.

og: Who’s there?
t: Who's there?

og: Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.
t: By God, here's majesty and genitalia—that is, a wise man and a fool.

og: [to LEAR]  Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night  Love not such nights as these. The wrathful skies  Gallow the very wanderers of the dark  And make them keep their caves.
t: [To LEAR] Alas, sir, are you here? Even creatures of the night avoid nights like this. These angry skies frighten even the bats and make them keep to their caves.

og: Since I was man,  Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,  Such groans of roaring wind and rain I never  Remember to have heard.
t: Never in my whole life have I seen or heard such fiery lightning, such bursts of horrible thunder, and such groans of roaring wind and rain.

og: Man’s nature cannot carry  Th' affliction nor the fear.
t: Human nature cannot bear all this danger and fear.

og: Let the great gods  That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads  Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch  That hast within thee undivulgèd crimes  Unwhipped of justice.
t: May the great gods who stirred up this commotion in the sky find and crush their enemies tonight. Tremble in fear, you wretched people who have committed secret crimes and gone unpunished by justice.

og: Hide thee, thou bloody hand,  Thou perjured, and thou simular man of virtue  That art incestuous.
t: Hide yourselves, you bloody-handed murderers, you perjurers, you men who seem to be virtuous but really practice incest.

og: Caitiff, to pieces shake,  That under covert and convenient seeming  Hast practiced on man’s life.
t: Tremble until you fall to pieces, you villains who have plotted against human lives in secret.

og: Close pent-up guilts,  Rive your concealing continents and cry  These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man  More sinned against than sinning.
t: Let all your secret, pent-up guilts burst from their hiding places, and beg for mercy from the dreadful gods who summoned such a storm. I am a man who has been sinned against more than he has sinned.

og: Alack, bareheaded?  Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel.  Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.
t: Alas, you're not even wearing a hat or hood? My gracious lord, there is a cow shed nearby. It will lend you some protection from this storm.

og: Repose you there, while I to this hard house—  More harder than the stones whereof ’tis raised,
t: Go there and rest, while I ask for help at the house where your heartless daughters are staying—those daughters who are more heartless than the stones the house is made of.

og: Which even but now, demanding after you,  Denied me to come in—return, and force  Their scanted courtesy.
t: Just now I went there and asked about you, but they wouldn't let me in. But now I'll return and force them to be courteous.

og: My wits begin to turn.—
t: I begin to see things differently.

og: [to FOOL] Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold?Iam cold myself.
t: [To the FOOL] Come on, my boy. How are you, my boy? Are you cold? I am cold myself.

og: [to KENT] Where is this straw, my fellow?  The art of our necessities is strange  That can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel.  Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart  That’s sorry yet for thee.
t: [To KENT] Where is this cow shed you spoke of, my fellow? It's strange how in a time of need even a worthless thing can become precious. Come, bring me to this shed. My poor fool, part of my heart still feels sorry for you.

og: [sings]  He that has and a little tiny wit—  With heigh-ho, the wind and the rain—
t: [Singing]The man with even a tiny bit of wit—With hey, ho, the wind and the rain—

og: Must make content with his fortunes fit,   For  the rain it raineth every day.
t: Must learn to take what he can get,For the rain it rains every day.

og: True, my good boy.—Come, bring us to this hovel.
t: True, my good boy. Come, bring us to this cow shed.

og: This is a brave night to cool a courtesan.  I’ll speak a prophecy ere I go.
t: Such a night would cool even a prostitute's hot lust. I'll deliver a prophecy before I go:

og: When priests are more in word than matter,  When brewers mar their malt with water,
t: when priests don't practice what they preach; when brewers dilute their beer with water;

og: When nobles are their tailors' tutors,  No heretics burned but wenches' suitors,  When every case in law is right,
t: when noblemen follow fashion more closely than their tailors do; when the only heretics being burned are faithless lovers, who burn with venereal disease; when every law case is just;

og: No squire in debt nor no poor knight,  When slanders do not live in tongues,  Nor cutpurses come not to throngs,  When usurers tell their gold i' th' field,
t: when no servants or knights are in debt; when tongues don't slander each other, and pickpockets don't steal from crowds; when moneylenders have nothing to hide;

og: And bawds and whores do churches build—  Then shall the realm of Albion  Come to great confusion.
t: and pimps and whores build churches—then the kingdom of England will come to ruin.

og: Then comes the time, who lives to see ’t,  That going shall be used with feet.  This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time.
t: Then those who live to see that day will stroll around on foot. This is a prophecy Merlin will make, because I live before his time.

og: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing. When I desire their leave that I might pity him,
t: Alas, alas, Edmund, I don't like this horrible business. When I asked the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall if I could help the king and give him shelter,

og: they took from me the use of mine own house, charged me on pain of their perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him,  entreat for him, nor any way sustain him.
t: they took away my command of my own house and ordered me to never speak of him, lobby on his behalf, or help him in any way, or else I should suffer their permanent anger.

og: Most savage and unnatural!
t: How savage and unnatural!

og: Go to, say you nothing. There’s a division betwixt the dukes. And a worse matter than that: I have received a letter this night. 'Tis dangerous to be spoken. I have locked the letter in my closet.
t: Oh well, say nothing about this. There is a quarrel between the two dukes. And there's worse news than that: I received a letter tonight. It's dangerous to discuss. I've locked the letter in my bedroom.

og: These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home. There’s part of a poweralready footed. We must incline to the king. I will look him and privily relieve him. Go you and maintain talk with the duke, that my charity be not of him perceived.
t: The injuries done to the king will be thoroughly avenged. Armed forces have already landed. We must side with the king. I will find him and secretly help him. You go and talk to the duke, so he won't notice that I'm helping the king.

og: If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed. Though I die for it—as no less is threatened me—the kingmy old master must be relieved. There is some strange thing toward, Edmund. Pray you, be careful.
t: If he asks for me, say that I'm ill and have gone to bed. Even if I must die for it—as they've threatened—I must help the king, my old master. There is something strange coming, Edmund. Please, be careful.

og: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke  Instantly know, and of that letter too.
t: I'll tell the duke right now about this forbidden kindness to the king, and about that letter too.

og: This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me  That which my father loses—no less than all.  The younger rises when the old doth fall.
t: Betraying my father is something that will get me a reward: it will win me everything my father will lose—which is everything he has. The young will rise when the old fall.

og: Here is the place, my lord. Good my lord, enter.The tyranny of the open night’s too roughFor nature to endure.
t: Here's the place, my lord. Please go in, my lord. Tonight's storm is too rough for human nature to endure.

og: Let me alone.
t: Leave me alone.

og: Good my lord, enter here.
t: My good lord, please enter the shed.

og: Wilt break my heart?
t: Do you want to break my heart?

og: I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.
t: I would rather break my own than yours. My good lord, please go in.

og: Thou think’st ’tis much that this contentious storm  Invades us to the skin. So ’tis to thee.  But where the greater malady is fixed  The lesser is scarce felt.
t: You think it's bad that this angry storm soaks us to the skin. So it seems to you. But a large pain makes a small pain feel insignificant.

og: Thou’dst shun a bear,  But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea  Thou’dst meet the bear i' th' mouth.
t: You would run from a bear, but if the only way to run was into the raging sea, then you'd turn and face the bear head-on.

og: When the mind’s free,  The body’s delicate. The tempest in my mind  Doth from my senses take all feeling else  Save what beats there—filial ingratitude.
t: When the mind is untroubled, the body is sensitive. The storm in my mind keeps me from noticing anything but the thing that tortures me—my ungrateful children.

og: Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand  For lifting food to ’t? But I will punish home.  No, I will weep no more. In such a night  To shut me out!
t: Isn't their ingratitude like the mouth biting the hand that feeds it? I will punish them thoroughly. No, I won't weep anymore. To shut me out on a night like this!

og: Pour on, I will endure.  In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril,  Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all—
t: But pour on, rain, I will endure. On a night like this! Oh Regan, Goneril, your kind old father, whose generous heart gave you everything . . .

og: Oh, that way madness lies. Let me shun that.  No more of that.
t: But no, that path leads to insanity. Let me avoid such thoughts. No more of that.

og: Good my lord, enter here.
t: My good lord, please go inside.

og: Prithee, go in thyself. Seek thine own ease.  This tempest will not give me leave to ponder  On things would hurt me more. But I’ll go in.
t: Please, go in yourself. Seek your own comfort. This storm keeps me from thinking thoughts that would hurt me even more. But I'll go in.

og: [to FOOL]  In, boy. Go first. You houseless poverty—  Nay, get thee in. I’ll pray, and then I’ll sleep.
t: [To the FOOL] Go in, boy. You go first. Oh, you poor homeless people . . . No, you go in. I'll pray, and then I'll sleep.

og: Poor naked wretches, whereso'er you are,  That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,  How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,  Your looped and windowed raggedness, defend you  From seasons such as these?
t: Poor homeless wretches, wherever you are, suffering through this pitiless storm—with no roof over your heads, no fat on your ribs, and only rags for clothing: how will you defend yourselves against such weather?

og: Oh, I have ta'en  Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp.
t: Oh, when I was king I should have done more for you! Cure yourself, men who live in luxury.

og: Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,  That thou mayst shake the superflux to them  And show the heavens more just.
t: Expose yourself to feel what the poor and homeless feel, so you can give them the surplus wealth you don't need, and make the world a more just place.

og: Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!
t: The water's nine feet deep, nine feet deep! Poor Tom!

og: Come not in here, nuncle. Here’s a spirit. Help me, help me!
t: Don't come in here, uncle—there's a ghost in here. Help me, help me!

og: Give me thy hand. Who’s there?
t: Give me your hand. Who's there?

og: A spirit, a spirit. He says his name’s Poor Tom.
t: A ghost, a ghost. He says his name's Poor Tom.

og: What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw? Come forth.
t: Who are you, grumbling in the straw in there? Come out.

og: Away! The foul fiend follows me! Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind. Hum! Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
t: Keep away! The devil follows me! The cold wind blows through the sharp hawthorn trees. Hum! Go to your cold beds and warm yourselves up.

og: Didst thou give all to thy two daughters, and art thoucome to this?
t: Did you give everything to your two daughters, and end up like this?

og: Who gives any thing to Poor Tom, whom the foul fiend hath led through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlipool, o'er bog and quagmire;
t: Who gives anything to Poor Tom? The devil has led him through fire and through flame, through rivers and whirlpools, over bogs and swamps.

og: that hath laid knives under his pillow and halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud of heart to ride on a bay trotting-horse over four-inched bridges tocourse his own shadow for a traitor? Bless thy five wits.
t: The devil's put knives under his pillow and nooses in his church pew, set rat poison near his soup and made him race his horse over narrow bridges to hunt his shadow like a traitor—all in an effort to get Poor Tom to kill himself. Bless your five senses.

og: Tom’s a-cold. Oh, do-de, do-de, do-de. Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do Poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now—and there—and there again—and there.
t: Tom's cold. Oh, do-de, do-de, do-de. May God protect you from whirlwinds, evil fates, and bewitchment! Be kind to Poor Tom, who is tormented by the devil. I could catch him there now—and there—and there again—and there!

og: What, has his daughters brought him to this pass?—Couldst thou save nothing? Wouldst thou give 'em all?
t: What, have his daughters reduced him to this miserable state?  Could you keep nothing for yourself? Did you give them everything?

og: Nay, he reserved a blanket, else we had been all shamed.
t: No, he kept a blanket for himself, or else he'd be naked and we'd be ashamed to look at him.

og: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o'er men’s faults light on thy daughters!
t: Then may your daughters be struck by all the plagues that hover in the air, controlling the fates of sinners!

og: He hath no daughters, sir.
t: He doesn't have any daughters, sir.

og: Death, traitor! Nothing could have subdued nature  To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
t: Death to you—you're a traitor for saying that! Nothing could have degraded him like this except for unkind daughters.

og: Is it the fashion that discarded fathers  Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
t: Is this the current style, that the bodies of neglected fathers should get so little pity ?

og: Judicious punishment! 'Twas this flesh begot  Those pelican daughters.
t: That's a fitting punishment! Because it was from my body that I fathered those bloodsucking daughters.

og: Pillicock sat on Pillicock hill. Alow, alow, loo, loo!
t: Pillicock sat on Pillicock hill. Alow, alow, loo, loo!

og: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.
t: This cold night will turn us all into fools and madmen.

og: Take heed o' th' foul fiend. Obey thy parents, keep thyword’s justice, swear not, commit not with man’s sworn spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array. Tom’s a-cold.
t: Beware the devil. Obey your parents; keep your word; don't use God's name in vain; don't commit adultery; and don't covet luxurious clothing. Tom's cold.

og: What hast thou been?
t: What were you before you became like this?

og: A servingman, proud in heart and mind, that curled my hair, wore gloves in my cap, served the lust of my mistress' heart and did the act of darkness with her, swore as many oaths as I spake words and broke them in the sweet face of heaven—one that slept in the contriving of lust and waked to do it.
t: I was a servant, proud in my heart and my mind. I curled my hair; carried tokens of my lovers; served my mistress's lust and slept with her; swore as many oaths as I spoke words; and broke them all without shame. I went to sleep planning lustful acts and woke up to do them.

og: Wine loved I deeply, dice dearly, and in woman outparamoured the Turk. False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand—hog in sloth, fox in stealth, wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey.
t: I loved wine deeply and gambling dearly, and I had more lovers than a sultan has in his harem. My heart was false, my ears were quick to hear gossip, and my hands were violent. I was as lazy as a hog, as stealthy as a fox, as greedy as a wolf, as crazy as a dog, and as violent as a lion.

og: Let not the creaking of shoes northe rustling of silks betray thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of brothels, thy hand out of plackets,thy pen from lenders' books, and defy the foul fiend.
t: Don't ever let your heart be seduced by a woman. Keep your feet out of brothels and your hands away from skirts, stay out of debt, and defy the devil.

og: Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind, says, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez. Let him trot by.
t: The cold wind still blows through the hawthorne trees, saying "Suum, mun, nonny." The devil my boy, my boy, stop that. Let him trot on by.

og: Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.—Is man no more than this? Consider him well.—
t: Why, you'd be better off dead than to face this violent storm with only your naked body. Is this all a man is? Look at him.

og: Thou owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! Here’s three on ’s are sophisticated. Thou art the thing itself.
t: [To EDGAR] You don't owe the silkworm for silk, the cow for leather, the sheep for wool, or the civet cat for perfume. Ha! The three of us are fake and shallow compared to you. You are the thing itself.

og: Unaccommodatedman is no more but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art.—Off, off, you lendings! Come. Unbutton here.  [tears at his clothes]
t: A man without the trappings of civilization is just a poor, naked, two-legged animal like you. Off, off with my clothing. Come, let me unbutton this. [He tears at his own clothes]

og: Prithee, nuncle, be contented. 'Tis a naughty night to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher’s heart—a small spark, all the rest on ’s body cold. Look, here comes a walking fire.
t: Please, uncle, calm down. It's a bad night for swimming. On a night like this a little fire in a barren field would be like the heart of a lustful old man—a small spark in a cold body.  Look, here comes a walking fire.

og: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet. He begins at curfew and walks till the first cock. He gives the web and the pin, squints the eye and makes the harelip, mildews the white wheat and hurts the poor creature of earth.
t: That is the devil Flibbertigibbet. He wakes up at nightfall and walks around until midnight. He makes eyes squint from cataracts, makes cleft lips, rots the ripe wheat, and hurts the poor creatures of the earth.

og: St. Withold footed thrice the 'old.  He met the nightmare and her ninefold,  Bid her alight,  And her troth plight.  And aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!
t: Saint Withold walked the field three times. He met a demon and her nine offspring, told her to fly away, and made her swear to never return. And begone, witch, begone!

og: How fares your grace?
t: How are you feeling, your Grace?

og: What’s he?
t: Who's he?

og: Who’s there? What is ’t you seek?
t: Who's there? What is it you want?

og: What are you there? Your names?
t: Who are you? What are your names?

og: Poor Tom, that eats the swimming frog, the toad, the tadpole, the wall newt, and the water; that in the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages, eats cow dung for salads, swallows the old rat and the ditch-dog, drinks the green mantle of the standing pool;
t: Poor Tom, who eats frogs, toads, tadpoles, lizards, and newts. When his heart is furious and the devil rages, Tom eats cow dung for salads, swallows old rats and dead dogs, and drinks the green pond scum.

og: who is whipped from tithing to tithing and stocked, punished and imprisoned; who hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his body,  Horse to ride and weapon to wear.
t: Tom is whipped in every town and put in the stocks, punished and imprisoned, but Tom once was a servant with three suits and six shirts. And a horse to ride and a sword to wear.

og: But mice and rats and such small deer  Have been Tom’s food for seven long year.  Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin. Peace, thou fiend!
t: But mice and rats and deer have been Tom's food for seven long years. Beware the devil who follows me. Quiet, Smulkin. Quiet, you devil!

og: What, hath your grace no better company?
t: What, don't you have any better companions than this, your Grace?

og: The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman. Modo he’s called, and Mahu.
t: The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman. He's called Modo and Mahu.

og: Our flesh and blood, my lord, is grown so vileThat it doth hate what gets it.
t: My lord, our children have grown so wicked that they hate the parents who made them.

og: Poor Tom’s a-cold.
t: Poor Tom is cold.

og: Go in with me. My duty cannot suffer  To obey in all your daughters' hard commands.
t: Come back to my house with me. My duty to you wouldn't allow me to obey all your daughters' harsh commands.

og: Though their injunction be to bar my doors  And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,  Yet have I ventured to come seek you out  And bring you where both fire and food is ready.
t: They ordered me to shut my doors and let this brutal night have its way with you. But instead I've come here to find you and bring you to a place where there's both food and fire.

og: First let me talk with this philosopher.—    What is the cause of thunder?
t: First let me talk with this philosopher.  What is the cause of thunder?

og: Good my lord, take his offer. Go into the house.
t: My good lord, take his offer and go back to the house with him.

og: I’ll talk a word with this same learnèd Theban.—What is your study?
t: First I'll talk with this Greek scholar here.  What is your field of study?

og: How to prevent the fiend and to kill vermin.
t: How to resist the devil and kill rats.

og: Let me ask you one word in private.
t: Let me ask you something in private.

og: Importune him once more to go, mylord.His wits begin t' unsettle.
t: Ask him again to go with you, my lord. He's beginning to go crazy.

og: Canst thou blame him?
t: Can you blame him?

og: His daughters seek his death. Ah, that good Kent—  He said it would be thus, poor banished man.  Thou say’st the king grows mad.
t: His daughters want him dead. Ah, that good Kent—he predicted that it would be like this, the poor banished man. You say the king is going crazy.

og: I’ll tell thee, friend,  I am almost mad myself. I had a son,  Now outlawed from my blood. He sought my life,  But lately, very late. I loved him, friend—
t: I'll tell you, friend, I have almost gone crazy myself. I had a son, but I've now disowned him. He tried to kill me just recently, very recently. I loved him, friend.

og: No father his son dearer. Truth to tell thee,  The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night’s this!
t: No father ever loved his son more than I did. To tell you the truth, the grief has almost made me crazy. What a night this is!

og: [to LEAR]  I do beseech your grace—
t: [To LEAR] Please, your Grace—

og: O, cry your mercy, sir.—    Noble philosopher, your company.
t:
Oh, I beg your pardon, sir. 

 Noble philosopher, speak with me.

og: Tom’s a-cold.
t: Tom's cold.

og: In, fellow. There, into th' hovel. Keep thee warm.
t: Then go in, man. There, into the cow shed. Keep yourself warm.

og: Come let’s in all.
t: Let's all go in.

og: This way, my lord.
t: No, come this way, my lord.

og: With him!I will keep still with my philosopher.
t: I'll go with him! I want to stay with my philosopher.

og: Good my lord, soothe him. Let him takethe fellow.
t: My good lord, let's humor him. Let him take that man with him.

og: Take him you on.
t: Bring him with you, then.

og: Sirrah, come on. Go along with us.
t: Sir, come on. Come along with us.

og: Come, good Athenian.
t: Come, good philosopher.

og: No words, no words. Hush.
t: Quiet, quiet. Hush.

og: Child Roland to the dark tower came,His word was still “Fie, foh, and fum,I smell the blood of a British man.”
t: The young knight Roland came to the dark tower. His motto was always "Fee, fie, fo, fum, I smell the blood of an Englishman."

og: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.
t: I'll have my revenge on Gloucester before I leave his house.

og: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus givesway to loyalty, something fears me to think of.
t: My lord, I'm somewhat afraid of how I might be criticized for letting my loyalty to you overcome my natural bond to my father.

og: I now perceive it was not altogether your brother’s evil disposition made him seek his death, but a provoking merit set awork by a reprovable badness in himself.
t: I now realize that it wasn't just your brother's evil nature that made him try to kill your father. Even though killing one's father is evil, Gloucester would be getting what he deserved.

og: How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just!  [giving CORNWALL a letter]
t: How evil is my fate, that I must apologize for doing the right thing! [Giving CORNWALL a letter]

og: This is the letter which he spoke of, which approves him an intelligent party to the advantages of France. O heavens, that this treason were not, or not I the detector!
t: This is the letter he was talking about, which confirms that he was a spy and informer for France. Oh God, I wish that this treason had never happened, or that I hadn't been the one to discover it!

og: Go with me to the duchess.
t: Come with me to see the duchess.

og: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mightybusiness in hand.
t: If the contents of this letter are true, then you have a lot to deal with.

og: True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester. Seek out where thy father is, that he may be ready for our apprehension.
t: True or false, this letter has made you the Earl of Gloucester. Find out where your father is, so we can be ready to arrest him.

og: I will persevere in my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore between that and my blood.
t: I'll remain loyal to you, even though it conflicts with my duty to my father.

og: I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love.
t: I'll put my trust in you, and you'll find me a better father than Gloucester was.

og: Here is better than the open air. Take it thankfully. Iwill piece out the comfort with what addition I can. I will not be long from you.
t: It's better in this shed than out in the open air. Be grateful for the shelter. I'll make you more comfortable in whatever way I can. I won't be gone long.

og: All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.The gods reward your kindness!
t: His passionate rage is driving him crazy. May the gods reward your kindness!

og: Frateretto calls me and tells me Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness. Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.
t: The devil Frateretto calls out to me. He says that the Roman emperor Nero is a fisherman in Hell's lake of darkness. Pray, innocent Fool, and beware the devil.

og: Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a gentleman or a yeoman?
t: Please, uncle, tell me whether this madman is a gentleman or an average man?

og: A king, a king!
t: He's a king, a king!

og: No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son, for he’s a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
t: No, he must be an average man with a gentleman for a son—since an average man would be crazy to let his son become a gentleman before he became a gentleman himself.

og: To have a thousand with red burning spitsCome hissing in upon 'em!
t: May a thousand hissing devils strike those daughters of mine with their red burning pitchforks!

og: The foul fiend bites my back.
t: The devil bites my back.

og: He’s mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a horse’s health, a boy’s love, or a whore’s oath.
t: A man would be crazy to trust a wolf's tameness, a horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's promise.

og: It shall be done. I will arraign them straight.    Thou, sapient sir, sit here.—Now, you she-foxes—
t: I will do it. I'll put my daughters on trial right away.  And you, wise sir, sit here. Now, you she-foxes—

og: Look, where he stands and glares!—Want’st thou eyes at trial, madam?      Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me—
t: Look, see the devil standing and glaring at me! Do you want spectators at your trial, madam?Come over the brook, Bessy, to me—

og: [sings]  Her boat hath a leak,
t: [Singing]Her boat has a leak,

og: And she must not speak  Why she dares not come over to thee.
t: And she must not speakAbout why she can't come over to see you.

og: The foul fiend haunts Poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale. Hoppedance cries in Tom’s belly for two white herring. Croak not, black angel. I have no food for thee.
t: The devil haunts Poor Tom by singing like a nightingale. That devil Hoppedance grumbles in Tom's belly, crying for two fish to eat. Stop rumbling, you black angel. I don't have any food for you.

og: How do you, sir? Stand you not so amazed.Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?
t: How are you, sir? Don't look so bewildered. Will you lie down and rest on the pillows?

og: I’ll see their trial first. Bring in the evidence.
t: I want to see their trial first. Bring in the witnesses against them.

og: [to EDGAR]  Thou robèd man of justice, take thy place.
t: [To EDGAR] Take your place, you judge in your robe.

og: [to FOOL]  And thou, his yoke-fellow of equity,  Bench by his side.
t: [To the FOOL] And you, his partner in justice, sit by his side.

og: [to KENT  ]  You are o' th' commission.  Sit you too.
t: [To KENT] You are allowed to be a judge as well. Sit down, too.

og: Let us deal justly.  [  sings]  Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?  Thy sheep be in the corn.
t: Let's deliver a fair trial.[Singing]Are you asleep or awake, happy shepherd?Your sheep are in the cornfield.

og: And for one blast of thy minikin mouth,  Thy sheep shall take no harm.  Purr! The cat is gray.
t: And if you blow your horn with your sweet little mouthYour sheep will come to no harm.Purr the Cat is a gray devil.

og: Arraign her first. 'Tis Goneril. I here take my oath before this honorable assembly, she kicked the poor kingher father.
t: Let's put Goneril on trial first. Here she is. I swear before this honorable assembly that she kicked her father, the poor king.

og: Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?
t: Come here, mistress. Is your name Goneril?

og: She cannot deny it.
t: She cannot deny it.

og: Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.
t: Forgive me, madam, I thought you were a stool.

og: And here’s another, whose warped looks proclaim  What store her heart is made on. Stop her there!
t: And here's Regan, whose twisted face shows what her heart is made of. Stop her there! Guards, catch her!

og: Arms, arms, sword, fire, corruption in the place!  False justicer, why hast thou let her ’scape?
t: Swords, fire, bribery in the courtroom! You false judge, why did you let her escape?

og: Bless thy five wits.
t: God bless your five senses.

og: O pity! Sir, where is the patience now,That thou so oft have boasted to retain?
t: How tragic! Sir, where is the self-control now, which you used to boast so much about?

og: My tears begin to take his part so much,They’ll mar my counterfeiting.
t: I feel so sorry for him that I'm afraid I'll cry and ruin my disguise.

og: The little dogs and all,Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they bark at me.
t: Even the little dogs, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they're barking at me.

og: Tom will throw his head at them.—Avaunt, you curs!  Be thy mouth or black or white,  Tooth that poisons if it bite,
t: Tom will threaten them. Begone, you mangy dogs!Whether your mouth is black or white, with teeth that poison when they bite;

og: Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,  Hound or spaniel, brach or him,  Bobtail tyke or trundle-tail—
t: whether mastiff, greyhound, or mean mutt, hound or spaniel, bitch or bloodhound, short-tail mutt or long-tail dog—

og: Tom will make them weep and wail.  For with throwing thus my head,  Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
t: Tom will make you weep and wail. When I threaten like this, dogs run out the door, and all are gone.

og: Do-de, de-de. Cessez! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.
t: Do-de, de-de. Stop! Come, run off to festivals and fairs and market towns. Poor Tom, your begging bowl is empty.

og: Then let them anatomize Regan. See what breeds about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that makes thesehard hearts?
t: Now let them dissect Regan. Study her heart well. Is there any natural reason for such a hard heart?

og: [to EDGAR]  You, sir, I entertain you for one of my hundred. Only I do not like the fashion of your garments. You will say they are Persian attire, butlet them be changed.
t: [To EDGAR] You, sir, I'll keep you as one of my hundred knights. Only I don't like the style of your clothes. You'll probably say that they're elegant and exotic, but change them anyway.

og: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.
t: Now, my good lord, lie down here and rest awhile.

og: Make no noise, make no noise. Draw the curtains—so, so,so. We’ll go to supper i' th' morning. So, so, so.
t: Make no noise, make no noise. Close the bed curtains—like that, like that, like that. We'll have dinner in the morning. So, so, so.

og: And I’ll go to bed at noon.
t: And I'll go to bed at noon.

og: Come hither, friend. Where is the king my master?
t: Come here, friend. Where is the king, my master?

og: Here, sir, but trouble him not. His wits are gone.
t: He's here, sir, but don't disturb him. He's lost his mind.

og: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms.  I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him.  There is a litter ready.
t: Good friend, please pick him up. I've overheard that there are people plotting to kill him. I have a carriage ready for him.

og: Lay him in ’t  And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet  Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master.
t: Put him in it and drive towards Dover, friend. There you'll find hospitality and protection. Pick up your master.

og: If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,  With thine and all that offer to defend him,  Stand in assurèd loss.
t: If you delay even half an hour he'll surely be killed, along with you and anyone else who offers to defend him.

og: Take up, take up,  And follow me, that will to some provision  Give thee quick conduct.
t: Get him, get him and follow me, and I'll quickly lead you to get some supplies.

og: Oppressèd nature sleeps.—
t: His suffering drives him to sleep.

og: This rest might yet have balmed thy broken sinews,  Which, if convenience will not allow,  Stand in hard cure.
t: [To the sleeping LEAR] This rest might have been able to soothe your shattered nerves. But, if there's no other convenient chance to sleep, your nerves aren't likely to be cured.

og: [to FOOL]  Come, help to bear thy master.  Thou must not stay behind.
t: [To the FOOL] Come, help to carry your master. You mustn't stay behind

og: Come, come, away.
t: Come on, come on, let's go.

og: When we our betters see bearing our woes,  We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
t: When we see our superiors suffering the same woes that we suffer, we can almost forget our own misery.

og: Who alone suffers, suffers most i' th' mind,  Leaving free things and happy shows behind.
t: Whoever suffers alone suffers the most, and loses his carefree nature and happy memories.

og: But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip  When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship.
t: But when grief is shared with friends and companions, the mind can rise above suffering.

og: How light and portable my pain seems now  When that which makes me bend makes the king bow.  He childed as I fathered. Tom, away!
t: My pain seems light and easy to endure now that I can see the king bearing my same sorrow. He found the same cruelty in his children that I found in my father. Tom, let's go!

og: Mark the high noises and thyself bewray  When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee,  In thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee.
t: We'll keep an eye on the situation, and you can reveal your true identity once you are proven innocent to the public. That will reconcile you with those who accuse you.

og: What will hap more tonight, safe ’scape the king!  Lurk, lurk.
t: Whatever else might happen tonight, may the king escape safely! Now, lurk out of sight, Tom, lurk.

og: Post speedily to my lord your husband. Show him this letter. The army of France is landed. —Seek out the traitor Gloucester.
t: Find the traitor Gloucester.

og: Hang him instantly.
t: Hang him at once.

og: Pluck out his eyes.
t: Pluck out his eyes.

og: Leave him to my displeasure.—
t: Leave him to my displeasure.

og: Edmund, keep you our sister company. The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding.
t: [To EDMUND] Edmund, you go with my sister-in-law Goneril. The punishment I am obligated to inflict on your father isn't fit for you to see.

og: Advise the duke where you are going, to a most festinate preparation. We are bound to the like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.—
t: Tell the Duke of Albany to prepare himself immediately for war. We are committed to doing the same. Our messengers will keep us both well-informed.

og: Farewell, dear sister.
t: [To GONERIL] Farewell, dear sister-in-law.

og: [to EDMUND]  Farewell, my lord of Gloucester.
t: [To EDMUND] Farewell, my lord of Gloucester.

og: How now? Where’s the king?
t: What's going on? Where's the king?

og: My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence.  Some five or six and thirty of his knights,  Hot questrists after him, met him at gate,
t: The lord of Gloucester has helped him escape. Thirty-five or thirty-six of his knights found him and met him at the gate.

og: Who with some other of the lord’s dependants  Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast  To have well-armèd friends.
t: Along with some of Gloucester's servants, they've all gone with him to Dover, where they claim to have well-armed friends.

og: Get horses for your mistress.
t: Prepare the horses for your mistress.

og: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.
t: Farewell, sweet lord, and you, sister.

og: Edmund, farewell.
t: Edmund, farewell.

og: Go seek the traitor Gloucester.Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.
t: Go find the traitor Gloucester. Tie his arms like a thief and bring him to me.

og: Though well we may not pass upon his life  Without the form of justice, yet our power  Shall do a courtesy to our wrath,
t: Though I cannot condemn him to death without a trial, I can still use my power to express my anger against him somehow.

og: which men  May blame, but not control.—Who’s there? The traitor?
t: Some men might blame me for this, but they won't dare oppose me. Who's there? The traitor?

og: Ingrateful fox, ’tis he.
t: The ungrateful fox! That's him.

og: Bind fast his corky arms.
t: Tie up his withered arms.

og: What mean your graces? Good my friends, considerYou are my guests. Do me no foul play, friends.
t: What do you mean by this, your Graces? My friends, remember that you are my guests in this house. Don't abuse your host, friends.

og: Bind him, I say.
t: Tie him up, I say.

og: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!
t: Bind him tighter, tighter. Oh, the filthy traitor!

og: Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.
t: I'm no traitor, you merciless lady.

og: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find—
t: Tie him to this chair. Villain, you'll see—

og: By the kind gods, ’tis most ignobly doneTo pluck me by the beard.
t: By the kind gods, it's disgraceful for you to pull my beard.

og: So white, and such a traitor?
t: So old and venerable, and still such a traitor?

og: Naughty lady,  These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin  Will quicken and accuse thee. I am your host.
t: Wicked lady, these white hairs you tear from my chin will come to life and accuse you. I am your host.

og: With robbers' hands my hospitable favors  You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?
t: You should not be grabbing at your host's face with your robbers' hands. What are you doing?

og: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?
t: Come, sir, what letters have you gotten from France lately?

og: Be simple-answered, for we know the truth.
t: Be honest, because we already know the truth.

og: And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom?
t: And what is your relationship with the traitors who have landed in our kingdom recently?

og: To whose handsYou have sent the lunatic king. Speak.
t: The ones to whom you've sent the insane king. Speak.

og: I have a letter guessingly set down,Which came from one that’s of a neutral heart,And not from one opposed.
t: I have a letter that only speculates about what's going on. It came from a neutral person, not someone opposed to you.

og: Cunning.
t: A cunning answer.

og: And false.
t: And a false one.

og: Where hast thou sent the king?
t: Where have you sent the king?

og: To Dover.
t: To Dover.

og: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril—
t: Why to Dover? Weren't you commanded, under penalty of death—

og: Wherefore to Dover?—Let him first answer that.
t: Why to Dover?—Let him answer first.

og: I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.
t: I'm backed into a corner now, but I must go on.

og: Wherefore to Dover, sir?
t: Why to Dover, sir?

og: Because I would not see thy cruèl nails  Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister  In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
t: Because I didn't want to watch your cruel fingernails pluck out his poor old eyes, or see your vicious sister sink her fangs into his kingly flesh.

og: The sea, with such a storm as his bare head  In hell-black night endured, would have buoyed up,  And quenched the stellèd fires.
t: You made him endure a storm so terrible that if it had occurred at sea, the waves would have risen up to extinguish the stars' fires.

og: Yet poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.  If wolves had at thy gate howled that stern time,  Thou shouldst have said, “Good porter, turn the key,”
t: But the poor old man just added to the rain with his tears. If wolves had been howling at your gate during that storm, you would have said, "Good doorman, let them in."

og: All cruèls else subscribed. But I shall see  The wingèd vengeance overtake such children.
t: Even the cruelest being would have given in to pity in such a situation, but you did not. I will see vengeance swoop down on you from heaven, you cruel children.

og: “See” ’t shalt thou never.—Fellows, hold the chair.—Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.
t: No, you won't "see" anything. Servants, hold his chair. I'm going to put my foot on his eyes.

og: He that will think to live till he be old,Give me some help!
t: If any man hopes to grow old someday, let him help me!

og: O cruel! O you gods!
t: Oh, cruel! Oh, you gods!

og: One side will mock another—th' other too.
t: Now his face is crooked—do the other eye too.

og: If you see vengeance—
t: If you ever "see" vengeance—

og: Hold your hand, my lord!  I have served you ever since I was a child.
t: Stop this, my lord! I've served you ever since I was a child.

og: But better service have I never done you  Than now to bid you hold.
t: But I've never done you a better service than by now telling you to stop.

og: How now, you dog?
t: What's this, you dog?

og: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,I’d shake it on this quarrel.
t: If you had a beard, lady, I'd pull it and spit in your face for this cause.

og: What do you mean?
t: What do you think you're doing?

og: My villain!
t: One of my own servants!

og: Nay then, come on, and take the chance of anger.
t: Come on then, let's fight—take your chances against me.

og: Oh, I am slain!—My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him. Oh!
t: Oh, I've been murdered!

og: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vile jelly!    Where is thy luster now?
t: Then we'll have to prevent it from seeing more. Come out, you worthless jelly!  Where is your sparkle now?

og: All dark and comfortless. Where’s my son Edmund?Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of natureTo quit this horrid act.
t: All is dark and comfortless. Where's my son Edmund? Edmund, let your love for your father inspire you to avenge this horrible act!

og: Out, treacherous villain!  Thou call’st on him that hates thee.
t: Enough, you treacherous villain! You call for a son who hates you.

og: It was he  That made the overture of thy treasons to us,  Who is too good to pity thee.
t: It was Edmund who revealed your treason to us. He is too good to have any pity for you.

og: O my follies! Then Edgar was abused. Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!
t: Oh, my stupidity! Then Edgar has been slandered. Kind gods, forgive me for that, and let him prosper!

og: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smellHis way to Dover.
t: Go throw him out at the gates, and let him smell his way to Dover.

og: How is ’t, my lord? How look you?
t: What is it, my lord? How do you feel?

og: I have received a hurt. Follow me, lady.—
t: I've been wounded. Follow me, lady.

og: Turn out that eyeless villain. Throw this slave  Upon the dunghill.—
