t: [To servants] Throw out that eyeless villain. And throw this treacherous servant onto the manure pit.

og: Regan, I bleed apace.  Untimely comes this hurt. Give me your arm.
t: [To REGAN] Regan, I'm bleeding badly. This is a bad time for such an injury. Give me your arm.

og: I’ll never care what wickedness I do,If this man come to good.
t: If our wicked master escapes justice, I'll stop caring about whether anything I do is wicked.

og: If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death,Women will all turn monsters.
t: And if Regan lives a long life and dies a natural death, then women might as well all become monsters.

og: Let’s follow the old earl, and get the BedlamTo lead him where he would. His roguish madnessAllows itself to any thing.
t: Let's follow the old earl, and get that crazy Tom to lead him where he wants to go. He's a homeless madman, so he can get away with anything.

og: Go thou. I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggsTo apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!
t: Go then. I'll get some cloth and egg whites to apply to his bleeding face. Now heaven help him!

og: Yet better thus, and known to be contemned,  Than still contemned and flattered.
t: I'm still better off like this—as a beggar who is openly hated—than when I was a nobleman who was flattered to my face and hated in secret.

og: To be worst,  The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune  Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear.
t: Even the worst, lowliest, and most dejected creatures still have a little hope for better things, and live without fear of getting worse.

og: The lamentable change is from the best;  The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,  Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
t: The worst kind of change is when good luck goes bad—but such a change can make us laugh at fortune's tricks. I welcome, then, these winds of change and freedom!

og: The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst  Owes nothing to thy blasts.
t: I've hit the bottom, so I have nothing more to fear from bad luck.

og: But who comes here?  My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!
t: But who's that coming? My father, accompanied only by one poor peasant? Oh world, world, world!

og: But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,  Life would not yield to age.
t: If the strange twists of fortune didn't make life hateful, we would never age and die.

og: O my good lord,I have been your tenant and your father’s tenant these fourscore years.
t: Oh, my good lord, I have been your tenant and your father's tenant for these last eighty years.

og: Away, get thee away. Good friend, be gone.Thy comforts can do me no good at all.Thee they may hurt.
t: Away, go away. Leave me, good friend. Your help can't do me any good, and it might put you in danger.

og: Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.
t: But you cannot see where you're going, sir.

og: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.  I stumbled when I saw.
t: I have nowhere to go, so I don't need eyes to see my path. And even when I could see, I followed the wrong path.

og: Full oft ’tis seen,  Our means secure us and our mere defects  Prove our commodities.
t: It's often the case that when we are prosperous we get overconfident. But being deprived of something teaches us humility and is actually beneficial.

og: O dear son Edgar,  The food of thy abusèd father’s wrath,  Might I but live to see thee in my touch,  I’d say I had eyes again!
t: Oh my dear son Edgar, the object of your deceived father's anger, if I might live to touch your face again, that would be as good as getting my eyes back!

og: How now? Who’s there?
t: What's that? Who's there?

og: O gods! Who is ’t can say “I am at the worst?”I am worse than e'er I was.
t: Oh gods! Who can ever say, "It can't get any worse?" I'm worse off now than I ever was before.

og: 'Tis poor mad Tom.
t: It's poor crazy Tom.

og: And worse I may be yet. The worst is notSo long as we can say “This is the worst.”
t: And things might get worse still. As long as we are able to say "this is the worst," then it's not the worst yet.

og: Fellow, where goest?
t: Where are you going, fellow?

og: Is it a beggarman?
t: Is it a beggar?

og: Madman and beggar too.
t: He's both a madman and a beggar.

og: He has some reason, else he could not beg.  I' th' last night’s storm I such a fellow saw,  Which made me think a man a worm.
t: He must still have some sanity, or else he couldn't beg. I saw a man like that in last night's storm, and he made me think of how insignificant humans are.

og: My son  Came then into my mind, and yet my mind  Was then scarce friends with him. I have heard more since.
t: He reminded me of my son, though at the time my son was my enemy. Now I know better.

og: As flies to wanton boys are we to th' gods.  They kill us for their sport.
t: To the gods, we are like flies killed for fun by undisciplined boys.

og: How should this be?Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow, Angering itself and others.—Bless thee, master!
t: Bless you, master!

og: Is that the naked fellow?
t: Is that the naked fellow?

og: Ay, my lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: Then prithee, get thee gone. If for my sake  Thou wilt o'ertake us hence a mile or twain  I' th' way toward Dover, do it for ancient love.
t: Then please go. If you're willing to do me a favor—for the sake of our long and loyal relationship—then catch up with us a mile or two down the road towards Dover.

og: And bring some covering for this naked soul,  Which I’ll entreat to lead me.
t: And bring some clothes for this naked beggar. I'll ask him to lead me.

og: Alack, sir, he is mad.
t: But alas, sir, he's crazy.

og: 'Tis the time’s plague when madmen lead the blind.Do as I bid thee. Or rather, do thy pleasure.Above the rest, be gone.
t: It's the sickness of our times that madmen must lead the blind. Do as I tell you. Or rather, do whatever you want. But above all, leave this place.

og: I’ll bring him the best 'parel that I have,Come on ’t what will.
t: I'll bring him the best clothes that I have, come what may.

og: Sirrah, naked fellow—
t: Sir, naked fellow—

og: Poor Tom’s a-cold.    I cannot daub it further.
t: Poor Tom's cold.  I can't continue this charade.

og: Come hither, fellow.
t: Come here, man.

og: And yet I must.—Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.
t: Bless your sweet eyes. They're bleeding.

og: Know’st thou the way to Dover?
t: Do you know the way to Dover?

og: Both stile and gate, horseway and footpath. Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits. Bless thee, goodman’s son, from the foul fiend! Five fiends have been in poor Tom at once: of lust, as Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness;
t: I know every step of the way—post and gate, horse path and footpath. Poor Tom has been scared out of his wits. Bless you, friend, and avoid the devil! Five devils have possessed poor Tom all at once: Obidicut, the devil of lust; Hobbididence, the devil of muteness;

og: Mahu, of stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of mopping and mowing,who since possesses chambermaids and waiting-women. So bless thee, master.
t: Mahu, the devil of stealing; Modo, the devil of murder; and Flibbertigibbet, the devil of making mocking faces, who possesses many chambermaids and serving ladies lately. So bless you, master.

og: [Giving EDGAR a purse]  Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues  Have humbled to all strokes. That I am wretched  Makes thee the happier. Heavens, deal so still.
t: [Giving EDGAR a purse] Here, take this purse, you who have been humbled by all the plagues of heaven. My misery makes yours seem less wretched. God, let it always be this way.

og: Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,  That slaves your ordinance, that will not see  Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly.
t: Let the spoiled and gluttonous man—who makes the laws serve his own desires, and won't see the misery around him because he doesn't feel it himself—let him feel your anger, you gods.

og: So distribution should undo excess,  And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?
t: The even distribution of wealth should rid us of excess luxuries, and then each man might have enough to live. Do you know Dover?

og: Ay, master.
t: Yes, master.

og: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head  Looks fearfully in the confinèd deep.
t: There is a cliff there, whose high and bending head leans precariously over the deep sea.

og: Bring me but to the very brim of it,  And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear  With something rich about me. From that place  I shall no leading need.
t: Bring me to the very edge of it, and I'll repay you for your troubles with something valuable on my person. Once I'm there I won't need to be led anymore.

og: Give me thy arm.Poor Tom shall lead thee.
t: Give me your arm. Poor Tom will lead you.

og: Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husbandNot met us on the way.
t: Welcome, my lord. I'm surprised that my bland husband hasn't met us on the way.

og: Now, where’s your master?
t: Now, where's your master?

og: Madam, within—but never man so changed.  I told him of the army that was landed.  He smiled at it. I told him you were coming.  His answer was “The worse.”
t: He's inside, madam. But you've never seen a man so changed. I told him that the French army had landed, and he smiled at the news. I told him that you were coming, and he answered with "too bad."

og: Of Gloucester’s treachery  And of the loyal service of his son,  When I informed him, then he called me “sot,”  And told me I had turned the wrong side out.
t: When I told him about Gloucester's treachery and his son Edmund's loyal service, he called me "fool," and told me I had it backwards.

og: What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;  What like, offensive.
t: The things he ought to dislike seem pleasant to him, and what should be good news offends him.

og: [to EDMUND  ]  Then shall you go no further.  It is the cowish terror of his spirit  That dares not undertake.
t: [To EDMUND] Then you shouldn't come any further. It's my husband's cowardly terror that keeps him from taking risks.

og: He’ll not feel wrongs  Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way  May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother.
t: He'll ignore insults that should require him to retaliate. But what you and I talked about on the way here—our desire for each other—may soon be realized. Edmund, go back to my brother-in-law Cornwall.

og: Hasten his musters and conduct his powers.  I must change names at home, and give the distaff  Into my husband’s hands.
t: Help gather his troops and lead his armies. When I get home I will change roles with Albany, and thus make my husband play the housewife.

og: This trusty servant  Shall pass between us. Ere long you are like to hear—  If you dare venture in your own behalf—  A mistress’s command.
t: This trusty servant Oswald can carry messages between us. If you trust yourself to ask, you will soon be likely to hear my command as both Duchess and as your lover.

og: Wear this. Spare speech.  Decline your head. This kiss, if it durst speak,  Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.  [kisses EDMUND]  Conceive, and fare thee well.
t: Wear this for me. [She gives him a favor] Don't speak. Bend down to me. If this kiss could speak, it would encourage you to do great things. [She kisses EDMUND] I hope you understand. Farewell.

og: Yours in the ranks of death.
t: I'm your servant until death.

og: My most dear Gloucester!
t: My dearest Gloucester!

og: Oh, the difference of man and man!To thee a woman’s services are due.My fool usurps my body.
t: Oh, how different two men can be! You deserve my services as a woman, Edmund. My foolish husband still thinks he possesses me.

og: Madam, here comes my lord.
t: Madam, here comes my lord.

og: I have been worth the whistle.
t: So I'm finally worth your time.

og: O Goneril,  You are not worth the dust which the rude wind  Blows in your face. I fear your disposition.  That nature, which contemns its origin  Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
t: Oh Goneril, you aren't worth the dust that the rude wind blows in your face. I fear your nature. I can't trust anyone who condemns her own father.

og: She that herself will sliver and disbranch  From her material sap perforce must wither  And come to deadly use.
t: A woman who cuts herself off from her family is like a branch that tries to break away from the tree that gave it life—she must wither and come to ruin.

og: No more. The text is foolish.
t: No more of that. Your sermon is stupid.

og: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile.  Filths savor but themselves. What have you done?  Tigers, not daughters, what have you performed?
t: Wisdom and goodness seem vile to vile people. To the filthy everything seems filthy. What have you done? You two tigers—not daughters—what wicked deeds have you done?

og: A father, and a gracious agèd man,  Whose reverence even the head-lugged bear would lick,  Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you madded.
t: You barbarous degenerates, you've driven your father crazy. He once was a gracious old man whom even an angry bear would respect.

og: Could my good brother suffer you to do it—  A man, a prince by him so benefited?
t: How could my good brother-in-law allow you to do it, when he himself was given his power by the king?

og: If that the heavens do not their visible spirits  Send quickly down to tame these vile offenses,  It will come:
t: If the heavens don't send down avenging angels to punish these terrible crimes, then the end will come:

og: Humanity must perforce prey on itself  Like monsters of the deep.
t: humanity must turn on itself, all of us destroying each other like monsters from the deep.

og: Milk-livered man  That bear’st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs—  Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning  Thine honor from thy suffering;
t: You cowardly man, you always turn the other cheek and let abuse rain down on your head. You can't tell the difference between restraining yourself and being taken advantage of.

og: that not know’st  Fools do those villains pity who are punished  Ere they have done their mischief. Where’s thy drum?
t: You don't realize that only fools pity villains like Gloucester, whom we punish before they can commit their crimes. Where's your war drum?

og: France spreads his banners in our noiseless land,  With plumèd helm thy state begins to threat,  Whiles thou, a moral fool, sits still and cries,  “Alack, why does he so?”
t: The King of France spreads his banners in our peaceful country and your kingdom is at risk of war. But all you do is sit here, you moralizing fool, and complain, "Alas, why is he doing that?"

og: See thyself, devil!Proper deformity shows not in the fiendSo horrid as in woman.
t: Look at yourself, devil! Moral deformity is expected in devils, so it doesn't seem as horrible in them as it does when it appears in a woman.

og: O vain fool!
t: Oh useless fool!

og: Thou changèd and self-covered thing, for shame!  Bemonster not thy feature.
t: Shame on you, you warped and false creature! Don't make faces at me and express your inner monstrous nature.

og: Were ’t my fitness  To let these hands obey my blood,  They are apt enough to dislocate and tear  Thy flesh and bones.
t: If I could allow my hands to do what my heart desires, I would rip you in two.

og: Howe'er thou art a fiend,  A woman’s shape doth shield thee.
t: But even if you are a devil, I won't hurt a woman.

og: Marry, your manhood, mew!
t: What a man you are, meowing like a kitten!

og: What news?
t: What's the news?

og: O my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall’s dead,Slain by his servant, going to put outThe other eye of Gloucester.
t: Oh, my lord, the Duke of Cornwall's dead. He was killed by his servant as he was about to gouge out Gloucester's other eye.

og: Gloucester’s eyes?
t: Gloucester's eyes?

og: A servant that he bred, thrilled with remorse,  Opposed against the act, bending his sword  To his great master;
t: A servant of his own house was moved by pity to oppose Cornwall's actions. He drew his sword against his great master,

og: who thereat enraged  Flew on him and amongst them felled him dead—  But not without that harmful stroke, which since  Hath plucked him after.
t: who became enraged and attacked and killed the servant—but not before he had received the wound that killed him afterward.

og: This shows you are above,  You justicers, that these our nether crimes  So speedily can venge!
t: This shows that there is justice in heaven. It's proved by the fact that these earthly crimes are punished so quickly!

og: But oh, poor Gloucester—  Lost he his other eye?
t: But oh, poor Gloucester. Did he lose his other eye?

og: Both, both, my lord.—This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer.'Tis from your sister.
t: Both, both, my lord.  This letter, madam, demands an immediate answer. It's from your sister.

og: [aside]  One way I like this well.  But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,  May all the building in my fancy pluck  Upon my hateful life.
t: [To herself] In a way I'm glad that Cornwall's dead. But now that Regan is a widow, and my Edmund is with her, then Edmund might choose her over me. Then all my fantasies will crumble and I'll have to continue this hateful life.

og: Another way  The news is not so tart.—
t: But in another way, the news is not so tragic.

og: I’ll read and answer.
t: [To FIRST MESSENGER and ALBANY] I'll go read the letter and answer it.

og: Where was his son when they did take his eyes?
t: Where was Gloucester's son Edmund when they took out his father's eyes?

og: Come with my lady hither.
t: He was riding here with my lady.

og: He is not here.
t: But he's not here.

og: No, my good lord. I met him back again.
t: No, my good lord. I met him on his way back.

og: Knows he the wickedness?
t: Does he know about all this wickedness?

og: Ay, my good lord. 'Twas he informed against him, And quit the house on purpose that their punishmentMight have the freer course.
t: Yes, my lord. He was the one who informed against his father, and left the house so that they could punish Gloucester fully without worrying about Edmund's feelings.

og: Gloucester, I live  To thank thee for the love thou showed’st the king,  And to revenge thine eyes.—
t: Gloucester, I will live to thank you for the love you showed the king, and I'll avenge your eyes.

og: Come hither, friend.  Tell me what more thou know’st.
t: [To FIRST MESSENGER] Come here, friend. Tell me what else you know.

og: Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the reason?
t: Do you know why the King of France went back home so suddenly?

og: Something he left imperfect in the state which, since his coming forth, is thought of;
t: He left something unfinished in his kingdom, which he remembered after arriving here.

og: which imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger that his personal returnwas most required and necessary.
t: It was important and dangerous enough that he had to return in person to deal with it.

og: Who hath he left behind him general?
t: Who has he left behind as his general?

og: The Marshal of France, Monsieur la Far.
t: The Marshal of France, Monsieur la Far.

og: Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration of grief?
t: Did the letters you delivered cause Queen Cordelia to show any grief?

og: Ay, sir. She took them, read them in my presence,  And now and then an ample tear trilled down  Her delicate cheek.
t: Yes, sir. She took them and read them in my presence, and now and then a large tear would trickle down her delicate cheek.

og: It seemed she was a queen  Over her passion, who, most rebel-like,  Sought to be king o'er her.
t: It seemed that she was able to control her deepest emotions, even though they tried to overcome her.

og: O, then it moved her?
t: Oh, then the news moved her?

og: Not to a rage. Patience and sorrow strove  Who should express her goodliest.
t: Not to any burst of passion. She seemed to struggle between patience and sorrow, deciding which would best express her feelings.

og: You have seen  Sunshine and rain at once—her smiles and tears  Were like a better way.
t: You've seen how it can rain while the sun is still shining—her smiles and tears were like that, but even more beautiful.

og: Those happy smilets  That played on her ripe lip seemed not to know  What guests were in her eyes, which parted thence  As pearls from diamonds dropped.
t: The little smiles on her lips seemed oblivious to her tears, which dropped like pearls from her diamond eyes.

og: In brief,  Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved  If all could so become it.
t: In short, sorrow would be a precious thing if everyone were as lovely in their sorrow as Cordelia was.

og: Made she no verbal question?
t: Did she ask anything out loud?

og: Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of “father”  Pantingly forth as if it pressed her heart,  Cried, “Sisters, sisters! Shame of ladies, sisters!
t: Well, once or twice she sighed the name "father," as if the word were pressing on her heart. And once she cried out, "Sister, sisters! You most shameful of all ladies, sisters!

og: Kent, father, sisters! What, i' th' storm, i' th' night?  Let pity not be believed.” There she shook  The holy water from her heavenly eyes,  And clamor moistened.
t: Kent, father, sisters! What, in a storm, in the middle of the night? No false shows of pity can be trusted!"

og: Then away she started  To deal with grief alone.
t: And then she shook the holy tears from her heavenly eyes, and went off to deal with her grief alone.

og: It is the stars,  The stars above us, govern our conditions.
t: It's the stars, the stars above us who decide our fates.

og: Else one self mate and mate could not beget  Such different issues.
t: Otherwise one couple couldn't have children so different from each other as Cordelia and her sisters are.

og: You spoke not with her since?
t: Have you spoken to her since then?

og: No.
t: No.

og: Was this before the king returned?
t: Was this before the King of France returned home?

og: No, since.
t: No, after that.

og: Well, sir, the poor distressèd Lear’s i' th' town,  Who sometime in his better tune remembers  What we are come about,
t: Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear is in Dover. When he's in his right mind, he remembers why we're here,

og: and by no means  Will yield to see his daughter.
t: and he refuses to see his daughter Cordelia.

og: Why, good sir?
t: Why, good sir?

og: A sovereign shame so elbows him. His own unkindness  That stripped her from his benediction turned her  To foreign casualties,
t: He is pained by a powerful sense of shame. He remembers how unkind he was to her; and how he stripped her of his blessing and turned her out to take her chances in a foreign land,

og: gave her dear rights  To his dog-hearted daughters.
t: and then gave her share of the kingdom to her two hard-hearted sisters.

og: These things sting  His mind so venomously that burning shame  Detains him from Cordelia.
t: These things sting his mind so venomously that a burning shame keeps him from going to see Cordelia.

og: Alack, poor gentleman!
t: Alas, the poor gentleman!

og: Of Albany’s and Cornwall’s powers you heard not?
t: Have you heard anything about Albany and Cornwall's troops?

og: 'Tis so. They are afoot.
t: Yes. They're on the march.

og: Well, sir, I’ll bring you to our master Lear  And leave you to attend him. Some dear cause  Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.
t: Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear, and leave you to attend to him. I have some important business that will force me to disguise myself again for a while.

og: When I am known aright you shall not grieve  Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you, go  Along with me.
t: When my true identity is revealed, you won't regret helping me like this. Please, come along with me.

og: Alack, ’tis he. Why, he was met even now  As mad as the vexed sea, singing aloud,  Crowned with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,
t: Alas, it's the king. Why, just recently he was seen acting as crazy as the stormy sea, singing out loud and wearing a crown of thick weeds—

og: With burdocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,  Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow  In our sustaining corn.—
t: burdock, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo, and all the weeds that struggle against our life-sustaining wheat.

og: A century send forth.  Search every acre in the high-grown field,  And bring him to our eye.
t: [To soldiers] Send out a hundred soldiers to find him. Search every acre of the overgrown fields, and bring him here for me to see.

og: What can man’s wisdom In the restoring his bereavèd sense?He that helps him take all my outward worth.
t: What can human medical knowledge do to restore his sanity? Whoever helps him can have all my material wealth.

og: There is means, madam.  Our foster nurse of nature is repose,  The which he lacks—
t: It is possible, madam. Rest is the best thing to comfort human nature, and rest is the thing Lear hasn't had.

og: that to provoke in him  Are many simples operative, whose power  Will close the eye of anguish.
t: But there are many medicinal herbs that will help him to forget his anguish and to sleep for a while.

og: All blessed secrets,  All you unpublished virtues of the earth,  Spring with my tears.
t: Then, you precious herbs—you secret healing plants of the earth—may you grow as fast as my tears fall,

og: Be aidant and remediate  In the good man’s distress.
t: and heal the good old man's distress.

og: Seek, seek for him,  Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life  That wants the means to lead it.
t: Now go, go find those herbs for him, before his overwhelming anger uses up all his life and energy.

og: News, madam.The British powers are marching hitherward.
t: I have news, madam. The British troops are marching this way.

og: 'Tis known before. Our preparation stands  In expectation of them. O dear father,  It is thy business that I go about.
t: We already knew this. Our troops are ready to receive them. Oh, dear father, I'm doing all this for you.

og: Therefore great France  My mourning and importuned tears hath pitied.
t: This is why the great King of France listened to and pitied my persistent and pleading tears.

og: No blown ambition doth our arms incite,  But love—dear love!—and our aged father’s right.  Soon may I hear and see him.
t: It wasn't inflated ambition that made us invade England, but love—dear love!—and my old father's abused rights. Hopefully I will hear him and see him soon.

og: But are my brother’s powers set forth?
t: But have my brother-in-law Albany's troops been sent forward?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: Himself in person there?
t: Is he there in person?

og: Madam, with much ado.Your sister is the better soldier.
t: Yes, madam, and making a big fuss. Your sister Goneril is the better soldier of the two.

og: Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?
t: Did Lord Edmund speak with your lord at home?

og: No, madam.
t: No, madam.

og: What might import my sister’s letter to him?
t: What did my sister's letter to him say?

og: I know not, lady.
t: I don't know, lady.

og: Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.  It was great ignorance, Gloucester’s eyes being out,  To let him live.
t: Well, he hurried away on some serious business. It was foolishness to let Gloucester live after plucking out his eyes.

og: Where he arrives he moves  All hearts against us. Edmund I think is gone  In pity of his misery to dispatch  His nighted life;
t: Wherever he goes, everyone pities him and turns against us. I think Edmund left to put his father out of his misery and end his sightless life—

og: moreover to descry  The strength o' th' enemy.
t: and also to spy out the strength of the enemy army.

og: I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.
t: I must go after him with my letter, madam.

og: Our troops set forth tomorrow. Stay with us.The ways are dangerous.
t: Our troops will set out tomorrow. Stay with us. The roads are dangerous.

og: I may not, madam.My lady charged my duty in this business.
t: I can't, madam. My lady ordered me to carry out her instructions.

og: Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you  Transport her purposes by word?
t: Why should she write to Edmund? Couldn't you just deliver her message verbally?

og: Belike  Some things—I know not what. I’ll love thee much.  Let me unseal the letter.
t: Perhaps it's . . . I don't know what. I'll make it worth your while if you let me unseal that letter.

og: Madam, I had rather—
t: Madam, I'd rather—

og: I know your lady does not love her husband.  I am sure of that.
t: I know your lady Goneril does not love her husband Albany. I'm sure of that.

og: And at her late being here  She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks  To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.
t: And when she was here recently she was giving strange, loving glances and significant looks to the noble Edmund. I know you're in her confidence.

og: I, madam?
t: I, madam?

og: I speak in understanding. Y' are. I know ’t.  Therefore I do advise you, take this note.  My lord is dead.
t: I'm sure about this. She trusts you, I know it. So I advise you to take note of what I'm about to tell you. My husband is dead.

og: Edmund and I have talked,  And more convenient is he for my hand  Than for your lady’s. You may gather more.
t: Edmund and I have talked, and it's more appropriate for him to marry me than to marry Goneril. You can draw your own conclusions from that.

og: If you do find him, pray you give him this.  And when your mistress hears thus much from you,  I pray desire her call her wisdom to her.
t: If you do find Edmund, please give him this. [She gives Oswald a favor] And when you talk to your mistress about all of this, please tell her to come to her senses.

og: So fare you well.  If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,  Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.
t: So farewell. If you happen to hear anything about that blind traitor Gloucester, there will be a reward for anyone who cuts his life short.

og: Would I could meet him, madam, I should showWhat party I do follow.
t: I wish I could meet him, madam. Then I would prove where my loyalties lie.

og: Fare thee well.
t: Farewell.

og: When shall we come to th' top of that same hill?
t: When will we come to the top of that cliff?

og: You do climb up it now. Look how we labor.
t: You're climbing up it now. See how we sweat and pant?

og: Methinks the ground is even.
t: The ground seems flat to me.

og: Horrible steep.Hark, do you hear the sea?
t: It's horribly steep. Listen, do you hear the sea?

og: No, truly.
t: No, to be honest.

og: Why then, your other senses grow imperfectBy your eyes' anguish.
t: Well then, your other senses must have been injured by the trauma of losing your eyes.

og: So may it be indeed.Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speak’stIn better phrase and matter than thou didst.
t: It might be so. It seems that your voice has changed, and you speak more eloquently than you did before.

og: You’re much deceived. In nothing am I changedBut in my garments.
t: You're mistaken. The only thing I've changed is my clothes.

og: Methinks you’re better spoken.
t: I think you're speak better now.

og: Come on, sir. Here’s the place. Stand still. How fearful  And dizzy ’tis to cast one’s eyes so low!
t: Come on, sir. Here's the place. Stand still. How terrifying and dizzying it is to look down so far!

og: The crows and choughs that wing the midway air  Show scarce so gross as beetles. Halfway down  Hangs one that gathers samphire—dreadful trade!
t: The crows and jackdaws flying below look smaller than beetles. Halfway down there's someone clinging to the cliff and gathering herbs—what a dreadful job!

og: Methinks he seems no bigger than his head.  The fishermen that walk upon the beach  Appear like mice.
t: He looks tiny to me from up here. The fishermen walking on the beach below look like mice.

og: And yon tall anchoring bark,  Diminished to her cock, her cock a buoy  Almost too small for sight.
t: And that tall ship anchored over there seems as small as its lifeboat, and its lifeboat seems as small as a tiny buoy that's almost too small to see.

og: The murmuring surge  That on th' unnumbered idle pebbles chafes  Cannot be heard so high.
t: You can't even hear the waves crashing against the rocks from up here.

og: I’ll look no more  Lest my brain turn and the deficient sight  Topple down headlong.
t: I can't look anymore, or else my head will spin and I'll fall headfirst from the edge.

og: Set me where you stand.
t: Lead me to where you stand.

og: Give me your hand. You are now within a footOf th' extreme verge. For all beneath the moonWould I not leap upright.
t: Give me your hand. You're now within a foot of the extreme edge. I wouldn't jump up and down here for anything under the sun.

og: Let go my hand.  [gives EDGAR another purse]  Here, friend, ’s another purse, in it a jewel  Well worth a poor man’s taking.
t: Let go of my hand. [He gives EDGAR another purse] Here, friend, here's another purse, and in it there's a jewel any poor man would be glad to have.

og: Fairies and gods  Prosper it with thee! Go thou farther off.  Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.
t: May the fairies and gods make your wealth increase! Go further away from here. Bid me farewell, and let me hear you leaving.

og: Now fare you well, good sir.
t: Now farewell, good sir.

og: With all my heart.
t: With all my heart.

og: Why I do trifle thus with his despairIs done to cure it.
t: I'm toying with his despair to try and cure him of it.

og: O you mighty gods,  [kneels]  This world I do renounce, and in your sights  Shake patiently my great affliction off.
t: Oh you mighty gods! [He kneels] I renounce this world, and in your sight, I shake off my great troubles and afflictions.

og: If I could bear it longer and not fall  To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,  My snuff and loathèd part of nature should  Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!—
t: If I could bear my troubles any longer—and not rebel against your inevitable will—then my useless life would end up burning itself out. If Edgar lives, then bless him!

og: Now, fellow, fare thee well.  (falls)
t: [To EDGAR] Now, fellow, farewell. [He falls]

og: Gone, sir. Farewell.
t: Gone, sir. Farewell.

og: [aside]  And yet I know not how conceit may rob  The treasury of life when life itself  Yields to the theft.
t: [To himself] I don't know whether a man's imagination can kill him, especially if he's so willing to die.

og: Had he been where he thought,  By this had thought been past. Alive or dead?—
t: If he had been where he thought he was, he'd be dead by now. But is he alive or dead?

og: Ho you, sir, friend! Hear you, sir? Speak.—
t: [To GLOUCESTER, disguising his voice] Hey you, sir, friend! Can you hear me, sir? Speak.

og: Thus might he pass indeed. Yet he revives.—
t: [To himself] Maybe he died after all. But he's waking up.

og: What are you, sir?
t: [To GLOUCESTER, disguising his voice] Who are you, sir?

og: Away, and let me die.
t: Go away, and let me die.

og: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,  So many fathom down precipitating,  Thou’dst shivered like an egg.
t: Even if you were made of only thread, feathers, and air, you should've shattered like an egg after falling as far as you did.

og: But thou dost breathe,  Hast heavy substance, bleed’st not, speak’st, art sound.
t: But you're breathing; your flesh is solid; you're not bleeding; you can speak. You are unbroken.

og: Ten masts at each make not the altitude  Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.  Thy life’s a miracle. Speak yet again.
t: Ten ship masts laying end to end couldn't measure the height you just fell from. Your life is a miracle. Speak again.

og: But have I fall'n, or no?
t: But have I fallen or not?

og: From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.Look up a-height. The shrill-gorged lark so farCannot be seen or heard. Do but look up.
t: You fell from the dreadful top of this chalky cliff. Look up at the height. The shrill-sounding lark up there can't be seen or heard. Just look up.

og: Alack, I have no eyes.  Is wretchedness deprived that benefit,  To end itself by death?
t: Alas, I have no eyes. Are wretched men now not even allowed to kill themselves?

og: 'Twas yet some comfort  When misery could beguile the tyrant’s rage  And frustrate his proud will.
t: It used to be some small comfort when someone in misery could cheat death's plan and frustrate its proud will.

og: Give me your arm. Up—so. How is ’t? Feel you your legs? You stand.
t: Give me your arm. Up—there you go. How do you feel? Can you feel your legs? You're standing.

og: Too well, too well.
t: Too well, too well.

og: This is above all strangeness.Upon the crown o' th' cliff, what thing was thatWhich parted from you?
t: This is stranger than strange. When you were up on the edge of the cliff, what was that thing I saw leaving you?

og: A poor unfortunate beggar.
t: A poor unfortunate beggar.

og: As I stood here below, methought his eyes  Were two full moons. He had a thousand noses,  Horns whelked and waved like the enragèd sea.
t: From down here it looked like his eyes were two full moons. He had a thousand noses, and horns twisted and wavy like a stormy sea.

og: It was some fiend. Therefore, thou happy father,  Think that the clearest gods, who make them honors  Of men’s impossibilities, have preserved thee.
t: It was some devil. You fortunate old man, you must realize that the purest gods have saved your life. They perform miracles like this to win the respect and worship of humans.

og: I do remember now. Henceforth I’ll bear  Affliction till it do cry out itself,  “Enough, enough,” and die.
t: I remember now. From now on, I'll bear my misery until the misery itself cries out, "Enough, enough!" and dies.

og: That thing you speak of,  I took it for a man. Often ’twould say,  “The fiend, the fiend!” He led me to that place.
t: That devil you speak of—I thought it was a man. He would often say, "The devil, the devil!" He led me to that place.

og: Bear free and patient thoughts.
t: Think carefree and peaceful thoughts.

og: But who comes here?The safer sense will ne'er accommodateHis master thus.
t: But who's that coming? A sane mind would never let its master dress like this.

og: No, they cannot touch me for coining. I am the king himself.
t: No, they can't punish me for counterfeiting coins. I am the king himself.

og: O thou side-piercing sight!
t: Oh, what a heartbreaking sight!

og: Nature’s above art in that respect. There’s your press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a crowkeeper. Draw me a clothier’s yard.
t: Nature is better than art in that respect. There's your enlistment money, recruit. That fellow handles his bow like a scarecrow. Draw the bowstring back farther, to the length of a tailor's yard.

og: Look, look, a mouse! Peace, peace, this piece of toasted cheese will do ’t. There’s my gauntlet. I’ll prove it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills.
t: Look, look, a mouse! Quiet, quiet, this piece of toasted cheese will catch him. There's my challenge. I'll prove my case by fighting a giant. Bring up the foot soldiers.

og: O, well flown, bird. I' th' clout, i' th' clout. Hewgh! Give the word.
t: Oh, well shot, arrow. Right in the bull's eye, in the bull's eye! Woosh! What's the password?

og: Sweet marjoram.
t: Sweet marjoram.

og: Pass.
t: That's it. You can pass.

og: I know that voice.
t: I know that voice.

og: Ha! Goneril with a white beard? Ha, Regan? They flattered me like a dog and told me I had white hairs inmy beard ere the black ones were there. To say “Ay” and“No” to everything that I said “Ay” and “No” to was no good divinity.
t: Ha! Goneril with a white beard? Ha, Regan? They flattered me like a dog would, and told me that I had wisdom before I had old age. To say "yes" and "no" to everything that I said "yes" and "no" to was insincere and sinful.

og: When the rain came to wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter, when the thunder would not peace at my bidding—there I found 'em, there I smelt 'emout.
t: When the rain came to soak me, and the wind to make me shiver, and the thunder wouldn't stop at my command—then I realized the truth about them. Then I sniffed them out.

og: Go to, they are not men o' their words. They told me I was everything. 'Tis a lie, I am not ague-proof.
t: They aren't honest. They told me I was everything—but I'm not immune to illness.

og: The trick of that voice I do well remember.Is ’t not the king?
t: Something about that voice is familiar to me. Is it the king?

og: Ay, every inch a king!  When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.  I pardon that man’s life. What was thy cause?  Adultery?
t: Yes, every inch a king! When I glare, see how my subjects tremble. I pardon that man's life. What was your crime? Adultery? You won't have to die. Die for adultery?

og: Thou shalt not die. Die for adultery? No.  The wren goes to ’t, and the small gilded fly  Does lecher in my sight.
t: No. The birds do it, and the flies copulate right in front of me.

og: Let copulation thrive, for Gloucester’s bastard son  Was kinder to his father than my daughters  Got ’tween the lawful sheets.
t: Let there be more copulation, in fact, for Gloucester's bastard son was kinder to him than my daughters—conceived on a marriage bed—have been to me.

og: To ’t, luxury, pell-mell!  For I lack soldiers. Behold yond simpering dame,  Whose face between her forks presages snow;
t: Go ahead, lust, rage on! For I need more soldiers. Look at that simpering woman over there—her stiff bonnet makes her look frigid and heartless.

og: That minces virtue and does shake the head  To hear of pleasure’s name.  The fitchew, nor the soiled horse, goes to ’t  With a more riotous appetite.
t: She coyly pretends to be virtuous and blushes at the word "sex," but really she's hornier than a stallion.

og: Down from the waist they are centaurs,  Though women all above.  But to the girdle do the gods inherit.
t: From the waist down women are lecherous centaurs, though they're chaste up above. God only gets the woman down to her belt—

og: Beneath is all the fiends'; there’s hell, there’s darkness,  There’s the sulphurous pit— burning, scalding,  Stench, consumption! Fie, fie, fie, pah, pah!
t: below that belongs to the devil. That part is hell, darkness, the lake of fire—burning, scalding, stench, sickness! Shame, shame, shame, ah, ah!

og: Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary,  To sweeten my imagination.  There’s money for thee.
t: Give me a strong perfume to sweeten my imagination, good pharmacist. There's some money for you.

og: O, let me kiss that hand!
t: Oh, let me kiss that hand!

og: Let me wipe it first. It smells of mortality.
t: Let me wipe it first. It smells of death.

og: O ruined piece of nature! This great worldShall so wear out to naught. Dost thou know me?
t: Oh, you ruined masterpiece of nature! This great world will end up the same way, worn down to nothing. Do you know me?

og: I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny at me? No, do thy worst, blind Cupid. I’ll not love. Read thou this challenge. Mark but the penning of it.
t: I remember your eyes well enough. Are you squinting at me? No, do your worst, blind Cupid. I'll never love again. Read this letter. Just notice the handwriting.

og: Were all thy letters suns, I could not see one.
t: Even if every word was a sun, I couldn't see a single one.

og: I would not take this from report. It is,And my heart breaks at it.
t: I wouldn't believe this scene if I weren't seeing it myself. And my heart breaks at the sight of it.

og: Read.
t: Read it.

og: What, with the case of eyes?
t: How, with my emptyeye sockets?

og: Oh ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head, norno money in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse in a light. Yet you see how this world goes.
t: Oh, ha, is that the way things are? You won't have eyes in your head until there's money in your purse? Your eyes are in a bad way and your purse is empty, but you see how this world works.

og: I see it feelingly.
t: I see by feeling.

og: What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes with no eyes. Look with thine ears. See how yon justice railsupon yon simple thief. Hark in thine ear:
t: What, are you crazy? A man can see how this world works without needing eyes. Look with your ears. See how that judge condemns an ordinary thief. But listen:

og: change placesand, handy-dandy, which is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen a farmer’s dog bark at a beggar?
t: if you have them switch places, do you think you could tell the difference between the judge and the thief? Have you seen a farmer's dog bark at a beggar?

og: Ay, sir.
t: Yes, sir.

og: And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightst behold the great image of authority: a dog’s obeyed in office.  Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand.  Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back.
t: And the man run from the mutt? There you can see the great image of authority: even a dog is obeyed when it's in power. You rascally officer, restrain your bloody hands! Why are you whipping that whore? Whip your own back instead.

og: Thou hotly lust’st to use her in that kind  For which thou whipp’st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.  Through tattered clothes great vices do appear;  Robes and furred gowns hide all.
t: You lust after her and long to use her for the same crime you're whipping her for. The loanshark hangs the cheater. It's easy to see sins through tattered clothes, but rich robes and gowns hide everything.

og: Plate sin with gold,  And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks.  Arm it in rags, a pigmy’s straw does pierce it.  None does offend—none, I say, none. I’ll able 'em.
t: Cover up a sin with gold, and the mighty sword of justice can't touch it. But dress a sin in rags, and even a piece of straw can pierce it. No one is a criminal—no one, I say, no one. I'll pardon them all.

og: Take that of me, my friend, who have the power  To seal th' accuser’s lips. Get thee glass eyes,  And like a scurvy politician seem  To see the things thou dost not.
t: Take that from me, my friend. I have the power to stop the prosecutors' lips. Get yourself some glass eyes, and pretend to see things you can't—like a corrupt politician.

og: Now, now, now, now,  Pull off my boots. Harder, harder. So.
t: Now, now, now, now, pull off my boots. Harder, harder. Like that.

og: O matter and impertinency mixed! Reason in madness!
t: Oh sense and nonsense mixed! Reason in madness!

og: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.  I know thee well enough. Thy name is Gloucester.  Thou must be patient. We came crying hither.
t: If you're going to cry over my bad luck, then take my eyes too. I know you well enough. Your name is Gloucester. You must be patient. I came here crying.

og: Thou know’st the first time that we smell the air  We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee. Mark me.
t: You know that when we first smell the air as newborns we wail and cry. I'll preach to you. Listen to me.

og: Alack, alack the day!
t: Alas, how awful!

og: When we are born, we cry that we are come  To this great stage of fools. This a good block.  It were a delicate stratagem to shoe  A troop of horse with felt.
t: When we're born, we cry because we've arrived at this great stage of fools. I like your hat. It's a clever strategy to make horseshoes out of felt.

og: I’ll put ’t in proof.  And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law,  Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
t: I'll put it to the test. And when I've sneaked up on those sons-in-law of mine, then I'll kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

og: Oh, here he is. Lay hand upon him.—Sir,Your most dear daughter—
t: Sir, your most dear daughter—

og: No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even  The natural fool of fortune. Use me well.
t: No rescue for me? What, I'm a prisoner? I was born to be the fool of fate. Treat me well.

og: You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons.  I am cut to th' brains.
t: You'll get your ransom. Let me have a doctor. I'm wounded in the brain.

og: You shall have anything.
t: You'll have anything you want.

og: No seconds? All myself?  Why, this would make a man a man of salt,
t: No one will support me? I'm by myself? Why, this loneliness could reduce a man to nothing but salty tears.

og: To use his eyes for garden water-pots,  Ay, and laying autumn’s dust.
t: He could use his eyes to water his garden, yes, and to tamp down the dust of autumn.

og: Good sir—
t: Good sir—

og: I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom.What, I will be jovial. Come, come.I am a king, my masters, know you that?
t: I'll die bravely, like a smug bridegroom. Well, I'll be jolly. Come, come. My gentlemen, I'm a king—did you know that?

og: You are a royal one, and we obey you.
t: You are a royal one, and we obey you.

og: Then there’s life in ’t. Come, an if you get it, you shall get it by running. Sa, sa, sa, sa.
t: Then there's still hope left. Come on—if you're going to get me, you'll have to catch me running! Sa, sa, sa, sa!

og: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,  Past speaking of in a king.
t: Such a sight would be pitiful even in the lowliest beggar, but it's unbearable in a king.

og: Thou hast a daughter  Who redeems nature from the general curse  Which twain have brought her to.
t: He still has one daughter good enough to redeem the evil of the other two.

og: Hail, gentle sir.
t: Hello, noble sir.

og: Sir, speed you. What’s your will?
t: God bless you, sir. What can I do for you?

og: Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?
t: Sir, do you know anything about an impending battle?

og: Most sure and vulgar. Everyone hears thatThat can distinguish sound.
t: Surely, it's common knowledge. Everyone who can hear has heard about it.

og: But, by your favor,How near’s the other army?
t: But, please, how near is the enemy army?

og: Near and on speedy foot. The main descryStands in the hourly thought.
t: Near, and approaching quickly. The main force is expected to arrive soon.

og: I thank you, sir. That’s all.
t: I thank you, sir. That's all.

og: Though that the queen on special cause is here,Her army is moved on.
t: The queen is here for a special reason, but her army has moved on.

og: I thank you, sir.
t: I thank you, sir.

og: You ever gentle gods, take my breath from me.Let not my worser spirit tempt me againTo die before you please.
t: Oh, you gentle gods: please take my life. Don't let me be tempted to suicide again. I will die when it's your will.

og: Well pray you, father.
t: You pray well, old man.

og: Now, good sir, what are you?
t: Now, good sir, who are you?

og: A most poor man made tame to fortune’s blows,  Who by the art of known and feeling sorrows  Am pregnant to good pity.
t: I'm a poor man who's been humbled by bad fortune. The profound sadness of my experience has made me more able to pity others.

og: Give me your hand,  I’ll lead you to some biding.
t: Give me your hand, and I'll lead you to a resting place.

og: Hearty thanks. The bounty and the benison of heavenTo boot and boot.
t: I thank you heartily. And in addition to my thanks, may heaven grant you blessings and prosperity.

og: A proclaimed prize! Most happy!  That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh  To raise my fortunes.
t: Look, a wanted man with a bounty on his life! What good luck for me! That eyeless head of yours was created just to make me rich.

og: Thou old unhappy traitor,  Briefly thyself remember. The sword is out  That must destroy thee.
t: You old unlucky traitor, say your prayers and prepare to die. The sword that will destroy you is ready to strike.

og: Now let thy friendly handPut strength enough to ’t.
t: Then may your hand strike surely—I welcome the blow.

og: Wherefore, bold peasant,  Darest thou support a published traitor?
t: How dare you support this well-known traitor, you bold peasant?

og: Hence,  Lest that th' infection of his fortune take  Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.
t: Get away, before his bad luck infects you too. Let go of his arm.

og: 'Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'casion.
t: I won't let go sir, not without a better reason than that.

og: Let go, slave, or thou diest!
t: Let go, villain, or you die!

og: Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor volk pass. An 'chud ha' bin zwaggered out of my life, ’twould not ha' bin zo long as ’tis by a vortnight.
t: [Speaking in a country accent] Good gentleman, walk away and let us poor folks pass by. If bullying like yours could kill me, I would have died at just two weeks old.

og: Nay, come not near th' old man. Keep out, che vor' ye, or I’se try whether your costard or my ballow be the harder. 'Chill be plain with you.
t: No, don't come near the old man. Keep away, I'm warning you, or I'll find out which is harder: your head or my club.

og: Out, dunghill!
t: Out of my way, you pile of dung!

og: 'Chill pick your teeth, zir. Come, no matter vor your foins.
t: I'll knock your teeth out, sir. Come on, I'm not afraid of your sword!

og: [falling]  Slave, thou hast slain me. Villain, take my purse.  If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body.
t: [Falling] You scoundrel, you've killed me! Villain, take my purse. If you have any decency, then bury my body.

og: And give the letters which thou find’st about me  To Edmund, Earl of Gloucester. Seek him out  Upon the British party. O untimely death! [  dies]
t: And deliver the letters I'm carrying to Edmund, Earl of Gloucester. Find him in the British camp. Oh, untimely death! [He dies]

og: I know thee well—a serviceable villain,As duteous to the vices of thy mistressAs badness would desire.
t: I know you well—a hardworking villain, and always obedient to your mistress' evil desires.

og: What, is he dead?
t: What, is he dead?

og: Sit you down, father. Rest you.  Let’s see these pockets. The letters that he speaks of  May be my friends.
t: Sit down, old man. Rest. Let's see what's in these pockets. The letters he spoke of might help me.

og: He’s dead. I am only sorry  He had no other death’s-man. Let us see.  [takes letters out of OSWALD’s pocket and opens them]
t: He's dead. I'm just sorry that I had to be the executioner. Let's see. [He takes letters out of OSWALD's pocket and opens them]

og: Leave, gentle wax, and, manners, blame us not.  To know our enemies' minds, we rip their hearts.  Their papers is more lawful.
t: Off you go, you wax seal. And, good manners—don't blame me for opening these letters. We kill our enemies to learn their secrets; reading their mail is a lesser evil.

og: [reads]  “Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have many opportunities to cut him off. If your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered.
t: [He reads] "Don't forget the vows we made to each other. You have many chances to cut off Albany's life. If your will is strong enough, you'll have lots of opportunities to do it.

og: There is nothing done if he return the conqueror. Then am I the prisoner and his bed my gaol, from the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the place for your labor.
t: Nothing will be accomplished if he returns as the victor. Then I'll be his prisoner again, and his bed will be my prison. Free me from his hateful presence, and as a reward for your work you can take his place.

og: Your—wife, so I would say—affectionate servant,  Goneril.”
t: Signed, your—I wish I could say 'wife'—affectionate servant,     Goneril."

og: O indistinguished space of woman’s will!  A plot upon her virtuous husband’s life,  And the exchange my brother!—
t: Oh, there is no limit to a woman's appetite! To plot against her virtuous husband's life, and replace him with my brother!

og: Here in the sands  Thee I’ll rake up, the post unsanctified  Of murderous lechers.
t: [To OSWALD's body] I'll bury you here in a shallow grave, you unholy messenger for lustful murderers.

og: And in the mature time  With this ungracious paper strike the sight  Of the death-practiced duke.
t: And when the time is ripe, I'll show this wicked letter to the duke whose life is being plotted against.

og: For him ’tis well  That of thy death and business I can tell.
t: It's a good thing for him that I can tell him about your death and the business of your letter.

og: The king is mad. How stiff is my vile sense,  That I stand up and have ingenious feeling  Of my huge sorrows. Better I were distract—
t: The king is insane, but my own unwanted sanity is too stubborn—I still have the senses to perceive my own great sorrow. It would be better if I went crazy.

og: So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs,  And woes by wrong imaginations lose  The knowledge of themselves.
t: Then my thoughts would be free from grief, and my hallucinations would make me forget my suffering.

og: Give me your hand. Far off methinks I hear the beaten drum.Come, father, I’ll bestow you with a friend.
t: Give me your hand. I think I hear drums in the distance. Come, old man, and I'll take you to stay with a friend.

og: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and workTo match thy goodness? My life will be too short,And every measure fail me.
t: Oh, good Kent, what can I do that will ever live up to your goodness? I won't live long enough to succeed, and all my attempts will fail.

og: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid. All my reports go with the modest truth,Nor more, nor clipped, but so.
t: Madam, to be thanked by you is too much payment. All that I've reported about the king is the truth—not exaggerated or understated, but just as it happened.

og: Be better suited.These weeds are memories of those worser hours.I prithee, put them off.
t: Change into better clothes. These rags are memories of bad times that are now in the past. Please, take them off.

og: Pardon, dear madam.  Yet to be known shortens my made intent.
t: I'm sorry, dear madam, but revealing myself now would ruin my plans.

og: My boon I make it that you know me not  Till time and I think meet.
t: The favor I beg of you is that you pretend not to know me until the time is right.

og: Then be ’t so, my good lord.—How does the king?
t: Then I'll do that, my good lord.  How is the king doing?

og: Madam, sleeps still.
t: Madam, he's still sleeping.

og: O you kind gods,  Cure this great breach in his abusèd nature,
t: Oh, you kind gods: heal the great wound in his suffering mind,

og: Th' untuned and jarring senses, O, wind up,  Of this child-changèd father!
t: and re-tune his discordant senses! Heal this father driven crazy by his children!

og: So please your majestyThat we may wake the king? He hath slept long.
t: Would it please your Majesty if we woke up the king? He's slept a long time.

og: Be governed by your knowledge, and proceed I' th' sway of your own will. Is he arrayed?
t: Do whatever your medical expertise tells you to, and go ahead as you see fit. Is he dressed?

og: Ay, madam. In the heaviness of his sleepWe put fresh garments on him.
t: Yes, madam. We put fresh clothes on him while he was sleeping deeply.

og: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him.I doubt not of his temperance.
t: Good madam, stay close by when we wake him up. I'm sure he'll stay calm.

og: Very well.
t: Very well.

og: Please you, draw near.—Louder the music there!
t: Please, come closer. Play the music louder!

og: [kisses LEAR]  O my dear father, restoration hang  Thy medicine on my lips,
t: [She kisses LEAR] Oh, my dear father, may my lips heal and restore you,

og: and let this kiss  Repair those violent harms that my two sisters  Have in thy reverence made!
t: and may this kiss repair those violent wounds that my two sisters have inflicted on your revered spirit!

og: Kind and dear princess!
t: Kind and dear princess!

og: Had you not been their father, these white flakes  Did challenge pity of them. Was this a face  To be opposed against the warring winds?
t: Even if you hadn't been their father, these white locks of hair should have made them pity you. Is this a face that ought to endure the violent winds,

og: To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder  In the most terrible and nimble stroke  Of quick cross lightning?
t: or stand against the dreadful thunder and the terrible, zigzagged lightning?

og: To watch—poor perdu!—  With this thin helm? Mine enemy’s meanest dog,  Though he had bit me, should have stood that night  Against my fire.
t: To stand guard all night—poor lonely sentry!—with only your thinning hair as a helmet? Even if my enemy's meanest dog had bit me, I still would have let it stay inside by my fireplace on that night.

og: And wast thou fain, poor father,  To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn  In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
t: And, poor father, were you glad to find shelter with pigs and beggars on a bed of musty straw? Alas, alas!

og: 'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once  Had not concluded all.—He wakes. Speak to him.
t: It's a wonder that your life and your sanity didn't end all at once. He's waking up. Speak to him.

og: Madam, do you. 'Tis fittest.
t: Madam, you speak first. That's most appropriate.

og: How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?
t: How are you, my royal lord? How is your Majesty doing?

og: You do me wrong to take me out o' th' grave.
t: You do me wrong to take me out of the grave.

og: Thou art a soul in bliss, but I am bound  Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears  Do scald like molten lead.
t: You are a soul in heaven, but I am chained to a wheel of fire, tormented endlessly, and even my tears burn me like molten lead.

og: Sir, do you know me?
t: Sir, do you know me?

og: You are a spirit, I know. Where did you die?
t: You are a spirit, I know. Where did you die?

og: Still, still far wide!
t: He's still far from sanity!

og: He’s scarce awake. Let him alone awhile.
t: He's barely awake. Let's leave him alone for a while.

og: Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?  I am mightily abused. I should ev'n die with pity  To see another thus.
t: Where have I been? Where am I? Is it daytime? I have been greatly deceived. I would even die of pity to see someone else in my situation.

og: I know not what to say.  I will not swear these are my hands. Let’s see.  I feel this pinprick. Would I were assured  Of my condition.
t: I don't know what to say. I can't even promise that these are my hands. Let's see. I feel this pinprick. I wish I could be sure of my condition.

og: O, look upon me, sir,And hold your hands in benediction o'er me.No, sir, you must not kneel.
t: Oh, look at me, sir. Hold your hands over me, and give me your blessing. No, sir, you must not kneel.

og: Pray, do not mock me.  I am a very foolish fond old man,  Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less.
t: Please do not mock me. I am a very foolish, silly old man, more than eighty years old, not an hour more or less.

og: And to deal plainly  I fear I am not in my perfect mind.   Methinks I should know you, and know this man.
t: And to put it plainly, I fear that I'm not in my right mind. I think I should recognize you, and this man too. [He points at KENT]

og: Yet I am doubtful, for I am mainly ignorant  What place this is, and all the skill I have  Remembers not these garments.
t: But I'm still doubtful, for I have no idea where I am, and I can't remember where I got these clothes.

og: Nor I know not  Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me,  For as I am a man, I think this lady  To be my child Cordelia.
t: I don't know where I slept last night either. Do not laugh at me, but I swear I think this lady is my child, Cordelia.

og: And so I am, I am.
t: And so I am, I am.

og: Be your tears wet? Yes, faith. I pray, weep not.  If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
t: Are your tears real? Yes, it's really happening. Please, don't cry. If you have poison for me, I'll drink it.

og: I know you do not love me, for your sisters  Have, as I do remember, done me wrong.  You have some cause; they have not.
t: I know you don't love me, for your sisters have done me wrong, if I remember correctly. And they don't even have a good reason to hate me, but you do.

og: No cause, no cause.
t: No reason, no reason.

og: Am I in France?
t: Am I in France?

og: In your own kingdom, sir.
t: You're in your own kingdom, sir.

og: Do not abuse me.
t: Don't trick me.

og: Be comforted, good madam. The great rage,  You see, is killed in him. And yet it is danger  To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
t: Be comforted, good madam. You see how his great frenzy is now over. But it's dangerous to make him try to fill in the blank spaces of his memory.

og: Desire him to go in. Trouble him no more  Till further settling.
t: Ask him to go inside. Don't trouble him further until his mind is more settled.

og: Will ’t please your highness walk?
t: Would it please your Highness to walk?

og: You must bear with me. Pray you now, forget and forgive.I am old and foolish.
t: You must bear with me. Please, forget and forgive. I am old and foolish.

og: Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was soslain?
t: Sir, is it true that the Duke of Cornwall was killed?

og: Most certain, sir.
t: Very true, sir.

og: Who is conductor of his people?
t: Who is leading his men now?

og: As ’tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.
t: They say it's Gloucester's bastard son.

og: They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.
t: I've heard that Edgar, Gloucester's banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.

og: Report is changeable. Tis time to look about. The powers of the kingdom approach apace.
t: Rumors are unreliable. It's time to be on our guard. The British army is approaching.

og: The arbitrement is like to be bloody. Fare you well, sir.
t: The battle will most likely be a bloody one. Farewell, sir.

og: My point and period will be throughly wrought,Or well or ill, as this day’s battle’s fought.
t: For better or for worse, my life and my plans completely depend on how today's battle ends.

og: [To a gentleman]  Know of the duke if his last purpose hold,  Or whether since he is advised by aught  To change the course.
t: [To a gentleman] Find out if the Duke of Albany plans to stick to his most recent plan, or if something has changed his mind.

og: He’s full of alteration  And self-reproving. Bring his constant pleasure.
t: He's very fickle and always second-guessing himself. Bring me a report of his final decision.

og: Our sister’s man is certainly miscarried.
t: My sister's messenger Oswald must have had an accident.

og: 'Tis to be doubted, madam.
t: That outcome is to be feared, madam.

og: Now, sweet lord,  You know the goodness I intend upon you.  Tell me but truly—
t: Now, sweet lord, you know that I intend to honor you with my hand in marriage. But tell me truly—

og: but then speak the truth—  Do you not love my sister?
t: be honest now—don't you love my sister Goneril?

og: In honored love.
t: With an honorable love.

og: But have you never found my brother’s wayTo the forfended place?
t: But have you never taken my brother-in-law's place in her bed?

og: That thought abuses you.
t: Such a question only insults yourself.

og: I am doubtful that you have been conjunctAnd bosomed with her as far as we call hers.
t: I'm suspicious that you have been both her ally and her lover, and are now hers.

og: No, by mine honor, madam.
t: No, madam. I swear by my honor.

og: I never shall endure her. Dear my lord,Be not familiar with her.
t: I won't be able to stand it if she takes you from me. My dear lord, don't be intimate with her.

og: Fear me not.She and the duke her husband!
t: Don't worry about me. Now she and the duke her husband are here!

og: I had rather lose the battle than that sisterShould loosen him and me.
t: I would rather lose this battle than let that sister of mine come between Edmund and me.

og: Our very loving sister, well be-met.
t: Good to see you, Regan, my loving sister-in-law.

og: Sir, this I hear: the king is come to his daughter,  With others whom the rigor of our state  Forced to cry out.
t: [To Edmund] Sir, I hear that the king has joined his daughter Cordelia, along with others who have rebelled against the harshness of our rule.

og: Where I could not be honest  I never yet was valiant. For this business,  It touches us as France invades our land,
t: I can't be brave if the cause I'm fighting for isn't honorable. This business concerns me only  because the French have invaded our land.

og: Not bolds the king, with others whom I fear  Most just and heavy causes make oppose.
t: I don't care whether the French support King Lear or others who I'm afraid have good reason to oppose us.

og: Sir, you speak nobly.
t: Sir, you speak nobly.

og: Why is this reasoned?
t: Why are we discussing this?

og: Combine together 'gainst the enemy, For these domestic and particular broilsAre not the question here.
t: We must unite against the enemy. These domestic and personal quarrels are not the issue here.

og: Let’s then determine with the ancient of warOn our proceedings.
t: Then let's meet with our experienced officers and determine how to proceed.

og: I shall attend you presently at your tent.
t: I'll meet you at your tent right away.

og: Sister, you’ll go with us?
t: Sister, will you come with us?

og: No.
t: No.

og: 'Tis most convenient. Pray you, go with us.
t: It would be best if you did. Please, come with us.

og: Oh ho, I know the riddle.—I will go.
t: All right, I'll go.

og: If e'er your grace had speech with man so poor,Hear me one word.
t: If your Grace would ever stoop to speak with a man as poor as I am, then hear what I have to say.

og: I’ll overtake you.—
t: I'll catch up with you.

og: Speak.
t: Tell me.

og: [Giving ALBANY a letter]  Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.  If you have victory, let the trumpet sound  For him that brought it.
t: [Giving ALBANY a letter] Before you fight the battle, open this letter. If you are victorious, then blow your trumpet to signal to me.

og: Wretched though I seem,  I can produce a champion that will prove  What is avouchèd there.
t: I seem wretched now, but I can produce a champion who will defend my claims.

og: If you miscarry,  Your business of the world hath so an end,  And machination ceases. Fortune love you.
t: If you die in battle, then your business in this world will be over, and the plot against your life will be over as well. Good luck to you.

og: Stay till I have read the letter.
t: Stay until I've read the letter.

og: I was forbid it.When time shall serve, let but the herald cry,And I’ll appear again.
t: I was ordered not to do that. When the time comes, all you have to do is blow a horn, and I'll appear again.

og: Why, fare thee well. I will o'erlook thy paper.
t: Well, farewell then. I'll read your letter.

og: The enemy’s in view. Draw up your powers.  [gives ALBANY a document]
t: The enemy's in sight. Prepare your troops. [He gives ALBANY a document]

og: Here is the guess of their true strength and forces  By diligent discovery, but your haste  Is now urged on you.
t: Here is an estimate of the enemy's true strength and weaponry, drawn up by our diligent scouts. But hurry now, please.

og: We will greet the time.
t: We will be ready for the occasion.

og: To both these sisters have I sworn my love,  Each jealous of the other as the stung  Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?  Both? One? Or neither?
t: I've pledged my love to both of these sisters now. And they're each suspicious of the other, as if they were both poisonous snakes. Which of them will I pick? Both? One? Or neither?

og: Neither can be enjoyed  If both remain alive. To take the widow  Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril,
t: I can't be happy with either one of them as long as the other remains alive. If I married the widowed Regan, it would drive Goneril crazy.

og: And hardly shall I carry out my side,  Her husband being alive.
t: But it would be difficult to carry out my plan with Goneril while her husband's still alive.

og: Now, then, we’ll use  His countenance for the battle, which being done,  Let her who would be rid of him devise  His speedy taking off.
t: Now then, I'll use Albany's authority and power to win this battle. And when it's over, let Goneril figure out how to get rid of him.

og: As for the mercy  Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,  The battle done and they within our power,  Shall never see his pardon, for my state  Stands on me to defend, not to debate.
t: Albany intends to be merciful to Lear and Cordelia, but if I win the battle and they become my prisoners, they won't live long enough to see his pardon. My position requires actions, not words.

og: Here, father, take the shadow of this tree  For your good host.
t: Here, old man, use the shadow of this tree for shelter.

og: Pray that the right may thrive.  If ever I return to you again,  I’ll bring you comfort.
t: Pray that the right side will win this battle. If I ever return to you again, I'll bring you good news.

og: Grace go with you, sir.
t: May God go with you, sir.

og: Away, old man. Give me thy hand. Away!King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en.Give me thy hand. Come on.
t: Let's go, old man. Give me your hand. Now! King Lear has been defeated, and he and his daughter are captured. Give me your hand. Come on.

og: No further, sir. A man may rot even here.
t: I can't go any further, sir. I might as well die here as anywhere else.

og: What, in ill thoughts again?
t: What, are you feeling depressed again?

og: Men must endure  Their going hence even as their coming hither.
t: We cannot choose our deaths any more than we can choose our births.

og: Ripeness is all. Come on.
t: We must ripen before we decay. Come on.

og: And that’s true too.
t: And that's true too.

og: Some officers take them away. Good guardUntil their greater pleasures first be knownThat are to censure them.
t: Have some officers take them away. Guard them carefully until we know what punishment has been decided for them.

og: [to LEAR  ]  We are not the first  Who with best meaning have incurred the worst.  For thee, oppressèd King, I am cast down.
t: [To LEAR] We're not the first ones to have made things worse with only the best of intentions. I'm unhappy for your sake, poor, oppressed King.

og: Myself could else outfrown false fortune’s frown.  Shall we not see these daughters and these sisters?
t: If it were me alone in this situation, I could be defiant in the face of bad luck. Should we see your daughters, my sisters?

og: No, no, no, no! Come, let’s away to prison.  We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage.  When thou dost ask me blessing, I’ll kneel down  And ask of thee forgiveness.
t: No, no, no, no! Come, let's go to prison. We two will sing like birds in a cage. When you ask me for my blessing, I'll kneel down and ask you for your forgiveness.

og: So we’ll live,  And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh  At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues  Talk of court news, and we’ll talk with them too—
t: So we'll live, and pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh at trivial matters, and listen to courtiers gossiping, and talk to them too—

og: Who loses and who wins, who’s in, who’s out—  And take upon ’s the mystery of things  As if we were God’s spies.
t: we'll find out who's winning and who's losing, who's in and who's out. And we'll ponder the mysteries of life as if we were God's spies sent to observe the world.

og: And we’ll wear out  In a walled prison packs and sects of great ones  That ebb and flow by the moon.
t: And in our walled prison we'll outlast all the politicians and rulers whose power comes and goes like the tide.

og: Take them away.
t: Take them away.

og: Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia,  The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught thee?  He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven  And fire us hence like foxes.
t: Even the gods should celebrate the sacrifices you've made for me, my Cordelia. Are we really together again? Now it would take divine lightning bolt to separate us, like a fire to drive foxes out of their den.

og: Wipe thine eyes.  The good years shall devour them, flesh and fell,  Ere they shall make us weep. We’ll see 'em starve first.  Come.
t: Wipe your eyes. Our enemies will waste away with age before they can make us cry again. We'll watch them starve before that. Come.

og: Come hither, captain. Hark.  [gives FIRST CAPTAIN a document]  Take thou this note.
t: Come here, captain. Listen. [He gives the FIRST CAPTAIN a document] Take this note.

og: Go follow them to prison.  One step I have advanced thee. If thou dost  As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way  To noble fortunes.
t: Follow them to prison. I've already gotten you promoted once. If you follow these instructions, you'll be well rewarded.

og: Know thou this: that men  Are as the time is. To be tender-minded  Does not become a sword.
t: Know this: we must adapt ourselves to these harsh times. A soldier can't afford to be tender-hearted.

og: Thy great employment  Will not bear question. Either say thou'lt do ’t,  Or thrive by other means.
t: There can be no discussion about this assignment. Say you'll do it, or else you can find a different job.

og: I’ll do ’t, my lord.
t: I'll do it, my lord.

og: About it, and write “happy” when thou’st done.Mark, I say, instantly, and carry it soAs I have set it down.
t: Then go to it, and feel fortunate that you've been given such a high-paying task. Go immediately, I say, and do exactly what I've written.

og: I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats. If it be man’s work, I’ll do ’t.
t: I can't do a horse's work, pulling a cart or eating dried oats. But if it's man's work, then I'll do it.

og: [to EDMUND]  Sir, you have shown today your valiant strain,  And fortune led you well. You have the captives  That were the opposites of this day’s strife.
t: [To EDMUND] Sir, today you've shown your courageous lineage, and luck has been on your side. You've captured the leaders of our opposition.

og: I do require them of you, so to use them  As we shall find their merits and our safety  May equally determine.
t: I need to take custody of them now, to treat them according to their honor and do what is best for our kingdom's safety.

og: Sir, I thought it fit  To send the old and miserable king  To some retention and appointed guard—  Whose age has charms in it, whose title more—
t: Sir, I thought it would be best if I sent the old, miserable king to a prison cell with a guard. Lear's old age and his title have the power

og: To pluck the common bosom on his side,  An turn our impressed lances in our eyes  Which do command them.
t: to make common folk take his side, and he could even make our drafted soldiers turn against us.

og: With him I sent the queen,  My reason all the same, and they are ready  Tomorrow or at further space t' appear  Where you shall hold your session.
t: I sent his daughter Queen Cordelia along with him, for the same reason. They're ready to appear whenever you want to hold your trial for them, tomorrow or at some future point.

og: At this time  We sweat and bleed. The friend hath lost his friend,  And the best quarrels, in the heat, are cursed  By those that feel their sharpness.
t: Right now we are all sweating and bleeding. Friends have lost friends, and soldiers will curse even the best of causes in the heat of battle.

og: The question of Cordelia and her father  Requires a fitter place.
t: We need to find a more appropriate place where we can make sure Cordelia and her father have a fair trial.

og: Sir, by your patience,I hold you but a subject of this war,Not as a brother.
