t: By your leave, sir: you are my subordinate in waging this war, not my equal.

og: That’s as we list to grace him.  Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded  Ere you had spoke so far.
t: That's for me to decide. I think you should have asked for my opinion before speaking to him like that.

og: He led our powers,  Bore the commission of my place and person—  The which immediacy may well stand up  And call itself your brother.
t: He led our armies, and acted as my proxy in battle. His close connection to me means that he might as well consider himself your equal.

og: Not so hot.In his own grace he doth exalt himselfMore than in your addition.
t: Not so fast. He has distinguished himself with his own merits more than any honors you've conferred upon him.

og: In my rights, By me invested, he compeers the best.
t: I'm the one who invested my authority in him, and with it he proved his merit.

og: That were the most if he should husband you.
t: If he married you, that investment would be complete.

og: Jesters do oft prove prophets.
t: You joke, but it might come true.

og: Holla, holla!That eye that told you so looked but asquint.
t: Hey, hey! You're squinting with jealousy and can't see straight.

og: Lady, I am not well, else I should answer  From a full-flowing stomach.
t: Lady, I'm not feeling well, or else I would answer you with my full temper.

og: [to EDMUND  ]  General,  Take thou my soldiers, prisoners, patrimony.  Dispose of them, of me. The walls is thine.
t: [To EDMUND] General, take my soldiers, my prisoners, and my inheritance. Do whatever you want with them, and with me. You have conquered the fortress of my heart.

og: Witness the world that I create thee here  My lord and master.
t: Let the world be my witness that I hereby make you my lord and master.

og: Mean you to enjoy him then?
t: Are you going to sleep with him right now?

og: The let-alone lies not in your good will.
t: It's not in your power to prevent it.

og: Nor in thine, lord.
t: Nor is it in yours, lord.

og: Half-blooded fellow, yes.
t: Yes it is, you illegitimate fellow.

og: Let the drum strike and prove my title thine.
t: Let the drums beat, and fight anyone who challenges your right to me.

og: Stay yet. Hear reason.—Edmund, I arrest thee  On capital treason, and in thine attaint  This gilded serpent.  [indicates GONERIL  ]
t: Wait, and listen to reason.—Edmund, I now arrest you for capital treason, and as an accessory to your treason I arrest this snake of a woman. [He points to GONERIL]

og: [to REGAN  ]  For your claim, fair sister,  I bar it in the interest of my wife.  'Tis she is subcontracted to this lord.
t: [To REGAN] But, my fair sister-in-law, as for your claim to him, I veto your engagement on my wife's behalf. She's the one who is already engaged to Edmund.

og: And I, her husband, contradict your banns.  If you will marry, make your loves to me,  My lady is bespoke.
t: If you want to get married, then start wooing me. My lady is already spoken for.

og: An interlude!
t: What a ridiculous story!

og: Thou art armed, Gloucester. Let the trumpet sound.  If none appear to prove upon thy person  Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons,  There is my pledge.  [throws down his glove]
t: You have a sword, Gloucester. Let the trumpets sound. If no one appears to challenge you and prove that you are a hideous traitor, then I'll do it myself. [He throws down his glove as a challenge]

og: I’ll make it on thy heart,  Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less  Than I have here proclaimed thee.
t: I make this promise on your life: I won't eat again until I prove that you're just as guilty as I say you are.

og: Sick, oh, sick!
t: Oh, I feel sick, sick!

og: If not, I’ll ne'er trust medicine.
t: If she's not sick, I'll never trust poison again.

og: [throwing down his glove]  There’s my exchange. What in the world he is  That names me traitor, villainlike he lies.  Call by thy trumpet.
t: [Throwing down his glove] I accept your challenge. Whoever calls me a traitor is a villainous liar. Blow your trumpet.

og: He that dares approach,  On him—on you, who not?—I will maintain  My truth and honor firmly.
t: I'll fight to firmly prove my truth and honor to anyone who dares approach—you, or anyone else.

og: A herald, ho!
t: Hey, a herald!

og: A herald, ho, a herald!
t: A herald, hey, a herald!

og: Trust to thy single virtue, for thy soldiers, All levied in my name, have in my nameTook their discharge.
t: Trust in your own unaided strength now, for your soldiers were all drafted in my name. And in my name they have been discharged.

og: My sickness grows upon me.
t: I can feel my sickness growing.

og: She is not well. Convey her to my tent.
t: She is not well. Take her to my tent.

og: Come hither, herald.—Let the trumpet sound,—And read out this.
t: Come here, herald.—Let the trumpet sound!—Read this.

og: Sound, trumpet!
t: Blow the trumpet!

og: [reads]  “If any man of quality or degree within the lists of the army will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl of Gloucester,
t: [Reading] "If any honorable man of the army will accuse Edmund, the supposed Earl of Gloucester,

og: that he is a manifold traitor, let him appear by the third sound of the trumpet. He is bold in his defense.”
t: of being a traitor, then let him appear by the  third sound of the trumpet. Edmund is willing to fight in his own defense."

og: Again!
t: Again!

og: Again!
t: Again!

og: Ask him his purposes, why he appearsUpon this call o' th' trumpet.
t: Ask him what he wants, and why he's stepping forward at this call of the trumpet.

og: What are you?Your name, your quality, and why you answerThis present summons?
t: Who are you? What is your name and your rank? And why do you step forward now?

og: O, know, my name is lost.  By treason’s tooth bare-gnawn and canker-bit.
t: Know this: my name has been lost to a traitorous worm.

og: Yet am I noble as the adversary  I come to cope withal.
t: But I am as noble as the opponent I've come to fight.

og: Which is that adversary?
t: And which opponent is that?

og: What’s he that speaks for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?
t: Who speaks for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?

og: Himself. What sayst thou to him?
t: I speak for myself. What do you have to say to me?

og: Draw thy sword,  That if my speech offend a noble heart  Thy arm may do thee justice.  [draws his sword]  Here is mine.
t: Draw your sword. If I offend your noble heart with my words, then you can take your revenge with your sword. Here is mine. [He draws his sword]

og: Behold: it is the privilege of mine honors,  My oath, and my profession. I protest—  Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence,
t: Look: it is the symbol of my honor, my vows, and my privilege as a knight. I now solemnly declare that—despite your strength, youth, rank, and power;

og: Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune,  Thy valor and thy heart—thou art a traitor,  False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father,  Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious prince,
t: and despite your recent victory, newly-minted fortune, courage, and bravery—you are a traitor. You have betrayed your gods, your brother, and your father, and you've conspired against this noble, glorious duke.

og: And from th' extremest upward of thy head  To the descent and dust below thy foot  A most toad-spotted traitor.
t: From the top of your head to the soles of your feet you are a filthy, tainted traitor.

og: Say thou “No,”  This sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent  To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak,  Thou liest.
t: If you disagree with me, then I'm ready to use my sword, my arm, and my courage to prove that you are a liar.

og: In wisdom I should ask thy name.  But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike,  And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes,  What safe and nicely I might well delay  By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn.
t: Prudence would suggest that I ask your name first. But since you look so noble and knightly—and since your speech implies that you are of a high rank—I will disdain the rules of knighthood that say I can refuse to fight a man I don't know.

og: Back do I toss these treasons to thy head,  With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart—
t: I toss your accusations of treason back at your own head, and your hateful lies back at your heart.

og: Which, for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise,  This sword of mine shall give them instant way,  Where they shall rest for ever.—Trumpets, speak!
t: They hardly hurt you now, but I'll follow them with my sword and embed the word "traitor" in your heart forever. Trumpets, blow!

og: Save him, save him!
t: Save him, save him!

og: This is practice, Gloucester.  By th' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer  An unknown opposite.
t: This was trickery, Gloucester. By the laws of dueling you didn't have to fight an unknown opponent.

og: Thou art not vanquished,  But cozened and beguiled.
t: You haven't been conquered—only cheated and deceived.

og: Shut your mouth, dame,  Or with this paper shall I stop it.—Hold, sir,  [gives the letter to EDMUND  ]  Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil.—
t: Shut your mouth, woman, or I'll plug it up with this paper. Look, sir. [He gives the letter to EDMUND] Read your own evil, you who are worse than any words could describe.

og: [to GONERIL]  Nay, no tearing, lady. I perceive you knowit.
t: [To GONERIL] No, don't tear it, lady. I think you know what it says.

og: Say, if I do? The laws are mine, not thine.Who can arraign me for ’t?
t: And what if I do? I make the laws, not you. Who can prosecute me for it?

og: Most monstrous, oh!    Know’st thou this paper?
t: Oh, how monstrous!  Do you know what this letter is?

og: Ask me not what I know.
t: Do not ask me what I know.

og: Go after her. She’s desperate. Govern her.
t: Go after her. She's desperate. Restrain her.

og: What you have charged me with, that have I done—  And more, much more. The time will bring it out.  'Tis past, and so am I.  [to EDGAR  ]
t: I have done all the things you've accused me of—and more, much more. You'll find out the rest in due time. But now it's over, and so am I.

og: But what art thou  That hast this fortune on me? If thou'rt noble,  I do forgive thee.
t: [To EDGAR] But who are you who defeated me? If you're a nobleman, I forgive you.

og: Let’s exchange charity.  I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund.  If more, the more thou’st wronged me.
t: Let's exchange forgiveness. I am no less noble than you are, Edmund. And if I'm more noble, then you've wronged me all the more.

og: My name is Edgar, and thy father’s son.  The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices  Make instruments to plague us.
t: My name is Edgar, and I'm your father's son. The gods are just, and use the sins we commit in giving ourselves pleasure as a means of making instruments to torment us.

og: The dark and vicious place where thee he got  Cost him his eyes.
t: The adultery he committed created you, and cost him his eyes.

og: Thou’st spoken right. 'Tis true.The wheel is come full circle. I am here.
t: You've spoken rightly. It's true. The wheel of fortune has come full circle. Here I am on the bottom again.

og: Methought thy very gait did prophesy  A royal nobleness. I must embrace thee.
t: I could tell that you were noble even by the way you walked. Let me hug you.

og: Let sorrow split my heart if ever I  Did hate thee or thy father.
t: I swear that I never hated you or your father.

og: Worthy prince, I know ’t.
t: Worthy prince, I know.

og: Where have you hid yourself?How have you known the miseries of your father?
t: Where have you been hiding yourself? How do you know about your father's suffering?

og: By nursing them, my lord. List a brief tale,  And when ’tis told, oh, that my heart would burst!  The bloody proclamation to escape,  That followed me so near—
t: By nursing him through it, my lord. Listen to my brief tale, and when it's over, oh, may my heart burst! To escape the proclamation condemning me to death, I disguised myself in the rags of a crazy beggar, making myself a creature scorned even by dogs.

og: O our lives' sweetness,  That we the pain of death would hourly die  Rather than die at once!—
t: Oh, how sweet life must be, that we prefer the pain of slowly dying to death itself!

og: taught me to shift  Into a madman’s rags, t' assume a semblance  That very dogs disdained.  And in this habit  Met I my father with his bleeding rings,  Their precious stones new lost,
t: In this disguise I met my father with his bloody eye sockets—his precious eyes recently lost—

og: became his guide,  Led him, begged for him, saved him from despair.
t: and I became his guide. I led him, begged for him, and saved him from despair.

og: Never—O fault!—revealed myself unto him  Until some half-hour past, when I was armed.
t: I never—oh, what a mistake!—revealed myself to him until just half an hour ago, when I was in my armor.

og: Not sure, though hoping of this good success,  I asked his blessing, and from first to last  Told him my pilgrimage.
t: I hoped for a successful outcome to the battle, but I still decided to ask for my father's blessing, and I told him the whole story of my journey.

og: But his flawed heart—  Alack, too weak the conflict to support—  'Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,  Burst smilingly.
t: But his cracked heart was too weak to support such extremes of joy and grief at once, and it gave out.

og: This speech of yours hath moved me,And shall perchance do good. But speak you on. You look as you had something more to say.
t: Your words have moved me, and may end up doing some good. But continue. You look like you have something more to say.

og: If there be more, more woeful, hold it in.For I am almost ready to dissolve,Hearing of this.
t: If there's anything more sorrowful to add, then keep it to yourself. I'm already about to lose myself to tears from hearing this much.

og: This would have seemed a period  To such as love not sorrow, but another  To amplify too much would make much more  And top extremity.
t: This might have seemed like a fitting end for a sad story. But if I go on I must add to what is already too much, and reach a new extremity of sorrow.

og: Whilst I was big in clamor came there in a man  Who, having seen me in my worst estate,  Shunned my abhorred society, but then, finding  Who ’twas that so endured, with his strong arms  He fastened on my neck, and bellowed out  As he’d burst heaven,
t: While I was crying loudly over my father, a man came in. He had seen me in my beggar's clothes and shunned me earlier, but when he found out who I was, he wrapped his strong arms around my neck and cried as if he was trying to burst heaven.

og: threw him on my father,  Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him  That ever ear received—
t: He then threw himself on my father and told the saddest story that was ever heard about Lear and him.

og: which in recounting  His grief grew puissant and the strings of life  Began to crack. Twice then the trumpets sounded,  And there I left him tranced.
t: And as he told the story his grief overcame him and his heart-strings began to break. Then I heard the trumpets blow twice, and I left him in a trance.

og: But who was this?
t: But who was this man?

og: Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who in disguiseFollowed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave.
t: Kent, sir. It was the banished Kent, who disguised himself and followed his hostile king—serving him with tasks too menial for even a slave.

og: Help, help, O, help!
t: Help, help, oh, help!

og: What kind of help?
t: What kind of help?

og: Speak, man.
t: Speak, man!

og: What means that bloody knife?
t: What does that bloody knife mean?

og: 'Tis hot, it smokes.It came even from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!
t: It's hot, it's still smoking with life blood. It was just removed from the heart of—oh, she's dead!

og: Who dead? Speak, man.
t: Who's dead? Speak, man.

og: Your lady, sir, your lady. And her sisterBy her is poisoned. She confesses it.
t: Your wife Goneril, sir, your wife. And she poisoned her sister Regan, who's now dead too. She confessed it.

og: I was contracted to them both. All threeNow marry in an instant.
t: I was engaged to them both. We three will now be united in death.

og: Here comes Kent.
t: Here comes Kent.

og: Produce their bodies, be they alive or dead. This judgment of the heavens that makes us trembleTouches us not with pity.
t: Bring the bodies here, whether they're alive or dead. The judgment of the gods makes us tremble, but it doesn't make us pity these deaths.

og: Oh, is this he?The time will not allow the complimentWhich very manners urges.
t: Oh, is this him? There's no time for the greetings that good manners require.

og: I am comeTo bid my king and master aye good night.Is he not here?
t: I am here to say goodnight forever to my king and master. Is he not here?

og: Great thing of us forgot!—Speak, Edmund, where’s the king? And where’s Cordelia?—
t: What a thing for us to forget! Speak, Edmund, where's the king? And where's Cordelia?

og: Seest thou this object, Kent?
t: Do you see this spectacle, Kent?

og: Alack, why thus?
t: Alas, why has this happened?

og: Yet Edmund was beloved.The one the other poisoned for my sake, And after slew herself.
t: Despite everything, Edmund was beloved. One sister poisoned the other for my sake, and then killed herself.

og: Even so.—Cover their faces.
t: It seems so. Cover their faces.

og: I pant for life. Some good I mean to do  Despite of mine own nature. Quickly send—  Be brief in it—to th' castle,
t: These are my last breaths. I want to do a little good despite my nature. Go quickly—be speedy about it—to the castle.

og: for my writ  Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia.  Nay, send in time!
t: For I've ordered the executions of Lear and Cordelia. Hurry, send someone now!

og: Run, run, O, run!
t: Run, run, oh, run!

og: To who, my lord?—Who hath the office? SendThy token of reprieve.
t: Where should we run, my lord? Who has the orders to kill them? Send something to prove that you've changed your commands.

og: Well thought on. Take my sword. The captain—Give it the captain.
t: Good idea. Take my sword. The captain—give it to the captain.

og: Haste thee for thy life.
t: Run as if your life depended on it.

og: He hath commission from thy wife and me  To hang Cordelia in the prison and  To lay the blame upon her own despair,
t: Your wife and I ordered the captain to hang Cordelia in the prison and lay the blame on her own despair,

og: That she fordid herself.
t: making it look like she killed herself.

og: The gods defend her!—bear him hence awhile.
t: May the gods protect her! Carry him away for now.

og: Howl, howl, howl, howl! Oh, you are men of stones.  Had I your tongues and eyes, I’d use them so  That heaven’s vault should crack. She’s gone forever.
t: Howl, howl, howl, howl! Oh, you are men of stone! If I had your eyes to weep and your tongues to cry out, I'd use them until the sky itself cracked. She's gone forever.

og: I know when one is dead and when one lives.  She’s dead as earth. Lend me a looking-glass.  If that her breath will mist or stain the stone,  Why then, she lives.
t: But I know how to tell when someone is dead and when they're alive. She's as dead as the senseless ground. Bring me a mirror. If her breath makes a mist on the glass, then she's still alive.

og: Is this the promised end?
t: Is this the end of the world?

og: Or image of that horror?
t: Or a reflection of that final horror?

og: Fall and cease.
t: Let the world collapse and end!

og: This feather stirs. She lives. If it be so, It is a chance which does redeem all sorrowsThat ever I have felt.
t: This feather moved with her breath. She lives. If it's true, then it will make up for all the sorrows I've ever felt.

og: O my good master!
t: Oh my good master!

og: Prithee, away.
t: Please, go away.

og: 'Tis noble Kent, your friend.
t: It's noble Kent, your friend.

og: A plague upon you, murderers, traitors all!  I might have saved her. Now she’s gone for ever.—
t: A plague on you, you're all murderers and traitors! I could have saved her. Now she's gone forever.

og: Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little. Ha?  What is ’t thou say’st?—
t: [To CORDELIA's body] Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little while. What? What are you saying?

og: Her voice was ever soft,  Gentle and low, an excellent thing in woman.—
t: [To the others] Her voice was always so soft, gentle, and low—an excellent thing in a woman.

og: I killed the slave that was a-hanging thee.
t: [To CORDELIA's body] I killed the scum who was hanging you.

og: 'Tis true, my lords, he did.
t: It's true, my lords, he did.

og: Did I not, fellow?  I have seen the day with my good biting falchion  I would have made them skip.
t: Didn't I, man? In the old days I would've made them all dance with my sword.

og: I am old now,  And these same crosses spoil me.
t: But I am old now, and my trials have worn me down.

og: [to KENT  ]  Who are you?  Mine eyes are not o' th' best, I’ll tell you straight.
t: [To KENT] Who are you? My eyesight's not the best. I'll recognize you soon.

og: If Fortune brag of two she loved and hated, One of them we behold.
t: This man was the luckiest and then the unluckiest that ever lived.

og: This a dull sight.Are you not Kent?
t: My vision is failing. Are you not Kent?

og: The same. Your servant Kent.Where is your servant Caius?
t: I am. Your servant Kent. Where is your servant Caius?

og: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.He’ll strike, and quickly too. He’s dead and rotten.
t: He's a good fellow, I can tell you that. He'll strike when in a fight, and quickly too. But now he's dead and rotting.

og: No, my good lord. I am the very man—
t: No, my good lord. I am Caius, the man—

og: I’ll see that straight.
t: I'll deal with this soon.

og: That from your first of difference and decayHave followed your sad steps.
t: —who followed you from the very beginning of your suffering and decline.

og: You’re welcome hither.
t: You're welcome here.

og: Nor no man else. All’s cheerless, dark, and deadly. Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves,And desperately are dead.
t: No, I'm not welcome. No one is welcome. Everything is cheerless, dark, and dreadful. Your eldest daughters have killed themselves and died in despair.

og: Ay, so I think.
t: Yes, I think that's true.

og: He knows not what he says, and vain it isThat we present us to him.
t: He doesn't know what he's saying. It's useless to try to explain it to him.

og: Very bootless.
t: It's pointless.

og: Edmund is dead, my lord.
t: Edmund is dead, my lord.

og: That’s but a trifle here.—  You lords and noble friends, know our intent.  What comfort to this great decay may come  Shall be applied.
t: That's just a drop in this ocean of sorrow. You lords and noble friends, hear what I intend to do. We must try to bring as much comfort as we can amid this great destruction.

og: For us, we will resign  During the life of this old majesty  To him our absolute power.
t: And as for me, I will surrender my power to the old king, that he should have absolute authority for the rest of his life.

og: [to EDGAR and KENT  ]  You, to your rights  With boot, and such addition as your honors  Have more than merited.—
t: [To EDGAR and KENT] And you will get back your rightful property and titles, along with rewards and distinctions that you have more than earned.

og: All friends shall taste  The wages of their virtue, and all foes  The cup of their deservings. O, see, see!
t: All my friends will taste the rewards of their virtue, and all my enemies will drink from the cup of punishment that they deserve. Oh, look, look!

og: And my poor fool is hanged.—No, no, no life?
t: And my poor child was hanged.

og: Why should a dog, a horse, a rat have life,  And thou no breath at all? Oh, thou'lt come no more,  Never, never, never, never, never.—
t: [To CORDELIA's body] No, no, no life left in you? Why should a dog, a horse, or a rat have life, but you have none at all? Oh, you'll never come to me again, never, never, never, never, never.

og: Pray you, undo this button. Thank you, sir.  Do you see this? Look on her. Look, her lips.  Look there, look there. O, O, O, O.  [dies]
t: To the others] Please, undo this button. Thank you, sir. Do you see this? Look at her. Look, her lips. Look there, look there. Oh, oh, oh, oh. [He dies]

og: He faints!—My lord, my lord!
t: He faints!  My lord, my lord!

og: Break, heart. I prithee, break!
t: Break, heart. Please, break!

og: Look up, my lord.
t: Look up, my lord.

og: Vex not his ghost. O, let him pass. He hates himThat would upon the rack of this tough worldStretch him out longer.
t: Don't disturb his departing spirit. Oh, let him pass on. He would hate anyone who made him linger in this torturous world any longer.

og: Oh, he is gone indeed.
t: Oh, he is dead indeed.

og: The wonder is he hath endured so long.He but usurped his life.
t: It's a wonder that he endured for so long. He was only living on borrowed time.

og: Bear them from hence. Our present business  Is to general woe.
t: Carry them away from here. Our business is now to grieve.

og: [to KENT and EDGAR]  Friends of my soul, you twain  Rule in this realm, and the gored state sustain.
t: [To KENT and EDGAR] My dear friends, you two should rule this kingdom and keep the wounded country alive.

og: I have a journey, sir, shortly to go.My master calls me. I must not say no.
t: I have a journey to make soon, sir. My master calls me on to following him to the next life, and I cannot say no.

og: The weight of this sad time we must obey.  Speak what we feel, not what we ought to say.
t: We must bear the weight of this sad day, and say what we feel, not what we ought to say.

og: The oldest hath borne most. We that are young  Shall never see so much, nor live so long.
t: The oldest has suffered the most. We who are young will never see as much as he has seen, or live so long.

og: In sooth, I know not why I am so sad.  It wearies me; you say it wearies you.
t: To tell the truth, I don't know why I am so sad. I'm tired of being sad, and you say you're tired of it, too.

og: But how I caught it, found it, or came by it,  What stuff ’tis made of, whereof it is born,  I am to learn.
t: But I don't know how I caught, found, or came by this sadness; what it's about; or where it came from.

og: And such a want-wit sadness makes of me,  That I have much ado to know myself.
t: And since I don't know anything about this sadness, I clearly have a ways to go in understanding myself.

og: Your mind is tossing on the ocean,  There, where your argosies with portly sail,  Like signors and rich burghers on the flood—  Or, as it were, the pageants of the sea—
t: Your mind is focused on the ocean where your merchant ships are sailing like rich, important men parading on the sea.

og: Do overpeer the petty traffickers  That curtsy to them, do them reverence  As they fly by them with their woven wings.
t: They tower over the little trade boats that they pass by, sailing along, and it's as if the little boats bow before the greatness of your ships.

og: Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth,  The better part of my affections would  Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still  Plucking the grass to know where sits the wind,  Peering in maps for ports and piers and roads.
t: Believe me, sir, if I were involved in a trade venture like yours, most of my mental energy would be with my ships, as well. I'd be pulling up shoots of grass to use them to check the wind, and looking at maps of ports and piers and roads.

og: And every object that might make me fear  Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt  Would make me sad.
t: And any little thing that might make me worry that something bad would happen to my ships would make me sad, without a doubt.

og: My wind cooling my broth  Would blow me to an ague when I thought  What harm a wind too great at sea might do.
t: I'd get upset blowing on my hot soup, because it would make me think of what a strong wind at sea could do to my ships.

og: I should not see the sandy hourglass run,  But I should think of shallows and of flats  And see my wealthy Andrew docked in sand,  Vailing her high top lower than her ribs  To kiss her burial.
t: If I saw the sands run in an hourglass, I would think of flat shallows where my ship, "The Andrew," run aground with all its riches and flipped over, completely done for.

og: Should I go to church  And see the holy edifice of stone  And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks,  Which, touching but my gentle vessel’s side,  Would scatter all her spices on the stream,  Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks,  And, in a word, but even now worth this,  And now worth nothing?
t: If I went to church and saw its stone construction, I couldn't help but think of dangerous rocks that could break the sides of my ships and scatter valuable spices all over the water, causing my silks to fall out and drape on the waves. They are worth so much, and would all of a sudden be lost and worth nothing to me.

og: Shall I have the thought  To think on this, and shall I lack the thought  That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?
t: How could I think of such things and not get sad?

og: But tell not me. I know Antonio  Is sad to think upon his merchandise.
t: But you don't need to tell me. I know that Antonio is sad because he's worrying about his merchandise.

og: Believe me, no. I thank my fortune for it—  My ventures are not in one bottom trusted,  Nor to one place, nor is my whole estate  Upon the fortune of this present year.
t: Believe me, you're wrong. Thank goodness, not all my merchandise is in one ship or any one place, and I haven't risked all my riches on this year's venture.

og: Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
t: Therefore, it's not my merchandise that is making me sad.

og: Why then, you are in love.
t: Well, then, you must be in love.

og: Fie, fie!
t: Oh please!

og: Not in love neither? Then let us say you are sad  Because you are not merry—  and ’twere as easy  For you to laugh and leap and say you are merry  Because you are not sad.
t: You're not in love either? Then let's just say you are sad because you are not happy. It would be just as easy for you to laugh and jump around and just say you are happy because you are not sad.

og: Now, by two-headed Janus,  Nature hath framed strange fellows in her time.
t: I swear, by two-headed Janus, nature has made all kinds of different people.

og: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes  And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper,
t: Some people are always happy and could even laugh at a funeral,

og: And other of such vinegar aspect  That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile  Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
t: while others are so sour they don't even crack a smile at anything, not even at a joke that Nestor called the funniest.

og: Here comes Bassanio, your most noble kinsman,Gratiano, and Lorenzo. Fare ye well.We leave you now with better company.
t: Here comes Bassanio, your most noble relative, along with Gratiano and Lorenzo. Goodbye. We'll leave you to these better friends.

og: I would have stayed till I had made you merryIf worthier friends had not prevented me.
t: If it weren't for these better friends coming along, I would have stayed until I made you smile.

og: Your worth is very dear in my regard.I take it your own business calls on youAnd you embrace th' occasion to depart.
t: I see you as very worthy. I gather you have business to take care of and are just taking this opportunity to leave.

og: Good morrow, my good lords.
t: Good day, my good lords.

og: Good signors both, when shall we laugh? Say, when?You grow exceeding strange. Must it be so?
t: Both of you are good men; when are we going to have fun times together? Tell me, when? You're practically strangers now. Does it have to be that way?

og: We’ll make our leisures to attend on yours.
t: The next time we get a chance, we'll spend some time together.

og: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you. But at dinnertimeI pray you have in mind where we must meet.
t: My Lord Bassanio, since you've found Antonio, the two of us will leave you two alone. But please remember where we're meeting for dinner.

og: I will not fail you.
t: Don't worry.

og: You look not well, Signor Antonio.
t: You don't look good, Sir Antonio.

og: You have too much respect upon the world.  They lose it that do buy it with much care.
t: You care too much about worldly things. Those who care too much about things end up losing them.

og: Believe me, you are marvelously changed.
t: Believe me, you really don't look yourself.

og: I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano—A stage where every man must play a part,And mine a sad one.
t: I value the world for what it is, Gratiano: a stage where every man must play a role. And my role is a sad one.

og: Let me play the fool.  With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come.
t: Well let me play the fool, then. I don't care if laughter causes wrinkles.

og: And let my liver rather heat with wine  Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
t: I'd rather destroy my liver with wine than waste away with sad groans.

og: Why should a man whose blood is warm within  Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster,  Sleep when he wakes, and creep into the jaundice  By being peevish?
t: Why should a warm-blooded man be as cold and stoic as a statue of his dead grandfather? Why should he be so inactive that he is practically asleep while awake, and start to get jaundice from being cranky so much?

og: I tell thee what, Antonio—  I love thee, and ’tis my love that speaks—  There are a sort of men whose visages  Do cream and mantle like a standing pond,
t: I tell you what, Antonio—I love you, and I'm speaking out of love—there are some people whose faces are so unmoving that they grow scum like a still pond,

og: And do a willful stillness entertain  With purpose to be dressed in an opinion  Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit,  As who should say, “I am Sir Oracle,  And when I ope my lips, let no dog bark!”
t: and they try hard to maintain a still expression so that they can seem to be wise, serious, and profound, like someone who could say, "I am Sir Oracle, and when I open my lips to speak, let no dog bark!"

og: O my Antonio, I do know of these  That therefore only are reputed wise  For saying nothing, when I am very sure  If they should speak, would almost damn those ears  Which, hearing them, would call their brothers fools.
t: Oh my Antonio, these kind of men only have the reputation of wisdom because they say nothing, and I'm sure that if they should speak, everyone listening would realize they are fools.

og: I’ll tell thee more of this another time.  But fish not with this melancholy bait  For this fool gudgeon, this opinion.—
t: I'll tell you more about this another time. But stop trying to get people to think you're serious and wise by acting all melancholy.

og: Come, good Lorenzo.—Fare ye well awhile.  I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.
t: Come with me now, good Lorenzo. Goodbye for now, Antonio. I'll finish the rest of my encouraging speech after dinner.

og: Well, we will leave you then till dinnertime.
t: Well, we'll leave you until dinnertime, then.

og: I must be one of these same dumb wise men,  For Gratiano never lets me speak.
t: I must be one of these dumb but wise-seeming men he talks about, because Gratiano never lets me speak.

og: Well, keep me company but two years more,Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.
t: Well, stick around with me for two more years and you'll forget what your voice even sounds like.

og: Farewell. I’ll grow a talker for this gear.
t: Goodbye. I'll start to talk more, now.

og: Thanks, i' faith, for silence is only commendableIn a neat’s tongue dried and a maid not vendible.
t: Thanks, because in fact the only tongues that should keep quiet are beef tongues on the dinner plate, and those of uncooperative maids.

og: Is that any thing now?
t: What do you think of all that?

og: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice.
t: Gratiano speaks an endless stream of nonsense, more than any man in all of Venice.

og: His reasons are as two grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff
t: Trying to find the point of what he's talking about is like looking for two grains of wheat hidden in bushels of hay.

og: —you shall seek all dayere you find them, and when you have them they are not worth the search.
t: You could look all day before you find them, and once you do it's not even worth the effort you put into it.

og: Well, tell me now what lady is the same To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage,That you today promised to tell me of?
t: Well, then tell me know who the lady is that you made an agreement with to go on a secret trip? You promised to tell me today.

og: 'Tis not unknown to you, Antonio,  How much I have disabled mine estate,  By something showing a more swelling port  Than my faint means would grant continuance.
t: Antonio, you know how I've been using up my wealth, living a more lavish life than I can afford.

og: Nor do I now make moan to be abridged  From such a noble rate.
t: Now, I'm not complaining about having to be more frugal,

og: But my chief care  Is to come fairly off from the great debts  Wherein my time something too prodigal  Hath left me gaged.
t: but I do care about fairly paying off the debts that I incurred while I was living beyond my means.

og: To you, Antonio,  I owe the most in money and in love,
t: I owe the most to you, Antonio, both in money and in love.

og: And from your love I have a warranty  To unburden all my plots and purposes  How to get clear of all the debts I owe.
t: And because we are good friends, I know I can tell you all my plans and plots for paying back all the debts I owe.

og: I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it.
t: Please do tell me, good Bassanio.

og: And if it stand, as you yourself still do,  Within the eye of honor, be assured  My purse, my person, my extremest means  Lie all unlocked to your occasions.
t: And if your plan is as honorable as you still are, rest assured that I will help you with my money, myself, and whatever other ways I can.

og: In my school days, when I had lost one shaft,
t: Back during my school days, I was shooting arrows once and lost one.

og: I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight  The selfsame way with more advisèd watch  To find the other forth—  and by adventuring both,  I oft found both.
t: So, I shot another arrow the same exact way and paid better attention to it so that I could follow its course, and it led me to the first arrow.

og: I urge this childhood proof  Because what follows is pure innocence.
t: With this example from my childhood in mind, listen to my plan, which is completely innocent.

og: I owe you much, and, like a willful youth,  That which I owe is lost.
t: I owe you a lot, and like a rash young man I have lost the money I owe you.

og: But if you please  To shoot another arrow that self way  Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt,  As I will watch the aim, or to find both  Or bring your latter hazard back again  And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
t: But if you shoot another arrow the same way you shot the first, by lending me money again, I have no doubt that I will bring both arrows back to you, because I'll watch the second one more carefully. Or at least I'll bring back the first, and remain in your debt for the second.

og: You know me well, and herein spend but time  To wind about my love with circumstance.
t: You know me well, and are wasting your time complicating my affection for you with explanation and reasoning.

og: And out of doubt you do me now more wrong  In making question of my uttermost  Than if you had made waste of all I have.
t: You do me more wrong in doubting that I love you enough to lend you more money than if you had wasted all of my money.

og: Then do but say to me what I should do  That in your knowledge may by me be done,  And I am pressed unto it. Therefore speak.
t: Simply tell me what you would like me to do, and I will do it. Tell me.

og: In Belmont is a lady richly left,  And she is fair and—fairer than that word—  Of wondrous virtues.
t: There's a lady in Belmont who has inherited some riches and is both beautiful—more beautiful than can be described—and virtuous.

og: Sometimes from her eyes  I did receive fair speechless messages.
t: We've occasionally exchanged some knowing glances.

og: Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued  To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.
t: Her name is Portia, and she lives up to her namesake, Cato's daughter and the wife of Brutus.

og: Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,  For the four winds blow in from every coast  Renownèd suitors, and her sunny locks  Hang on her temples like a golden fleece,  Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strand,  And many Jasons come in quest of her.
t: Her worthiness as a wife is well-known, and suitors come to her from all four corners of the world. Her blonde hair hangs over her temples like the Golden Fleece, and it makes many a Jason want to come on a quest for her.

og: O my Antonio, had I but the means  To hold a rival place with one of them,  I have a mind presages me such thrift  That I should questionless be fortunate!
t: Antonio, if I only had the means to stand as a rival with these suitors, I know without a doubt that I would be successful in wooing her!

og: Thou know’st that all my fortunes are at sea.  Neither have I money nor commodity  To raise a present sum.
t: You know that all my money has been put into my ships. I have neither money nor any goods to sell in order raise some funds for you.

og: Therefore go forth,  Try what my credit can in Venice do—  That shall be racked even to the uttermost  To furnish thee to Belmont, to fair Portia.
t: So go forth and see how far my credit will get you in Venice, all of which I will use to get you to Belmont and to beautiful Portia.

og: Go presently inquire, and so will I,  Where money is, and I no question make  To have it of my trust or for my sake.
t: Go ask around to find somewhere you can borrow some money, and so will I. I am certain that people will lend me the money, either for my own sake or for the sake of my business.

og: Three thousand ducats, well.
t: Three thousand ducats, eh?

og: Ay, sir, for three months.
t: Yes, sir, for three months.

og: For three months, well.
t: For three months, eh?

og: For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.
t: And, as I told you, Antonio will be the guarantor of the loan.

og: Antonio shall become bound, well.
t: Antonio will, eh?

og: May you stead me? Will you pleasure me? Shall I know your answer?
t: Can you help me out? Will you agree to the loan? Can I hear your answer?

og: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.
t: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio will be bound to guarantee the loan.

og: Your answer to that?
t: What's your answer to that offer?

og: Antonio is a good man.
t: Antonio is a good man.

og: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
t: Have you heard anyone say otherwise about him?

og: Ho, no, no, no, no. My meaning in saying he is a good man is to have you understand me that he is sufficient. Yet his means are in supposition.
t: Oh no, no, no, no I haven't. I just meant to suggest that is a sufficient guarantor for the loan. But, his wealth isn't certain at the moment.

og: He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies. I understand moreover, upon the Rialto, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he hath squandered abroad.
t: He has one ship bound for Tripoli and another for the Indies. Moreover, the word around the Rialto is that he has a third ship in Mexico, a fourth bound for England, and other ventures he has invested his money in abroad.

og: But ships are but boards, sailors butmen. There be land rats and water rats, water thieves and land thieves—I mean pirates—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks.
t: Ships are just wood, and sailors are just men. There are rats on land and sea, and thieves on land and sea, including pirates. And then there is also the matter of dangerous waters, winds, and rocks.

og: The man is notwithstanding sufficient.
t: But in spite of all these risks, he is still a sufficient guarantor.

og: Be assured you may.
t: You can be sure of that.

og: I will be assured I may, and that I may be assured,I will bethink me. May I speak with Antonio?
t: I will be sure, and I will figure out how I can be completely sure. May I speak with Antonio?

og: If it please you to dine with us.
t: Would you like to have dinner with Antonio and me?

og: Yes—to smell pork, to eat of the habitation which your prophet the Nazarite conjured the devil into.
t: Oh yes, I'd love to eat pork with you, the animal into which your Jesus exorcised the devil.

og: I will buywith you, sell with you, talk with you, walk with you, and so following, but I will not eat with you, drink with you, nor pray with you.
t: I will buy and sell with you, talk with you, walk with you, and so forth, but I will neither eat, nor drink, nor pray with you.

og: What news on the Rialto? Who is he comes here?
t: What's the news on the Rialto? Who is the man coming here?

og: This is Signor Antonio.
t: This is Mr. Antonio.

og: How like a fawning publican he looks!  I hate him for he is a Christian,
t: He looks like someone who wants to take my money but then ask me for a favor! I hate him because he is a Christian,

og: But more for that in low simplicity  He lends out money gratis and brings down  The rate of usance here with us in Venice.
t: but I hate him even more because he lends out money without charging interest, which forces me to lower the interest rates that I loan at.

og: If I can catch him once upon the hip,  I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him.
t: If I get the better of him just once, I will satisfy my old grudge against him.

og: He hates our sacred nation, and he rails,  Even there where merchants most do congregate,  On me, my bargains and my well-won thrift,  Which he calls “interest.”
t: He hates us Jews, and he speaks badly of me, my bargains, and my hard-won money in the company of other merchants, talking about "interest."

og: Cursèd be my tribe  If I forgive him!
t: May my Jewish tribe be cursed if I forgive him!

og: Shylock, do you hear?
t: Shylock, are you listening?

og: I am debating of my present store,  And by the near guess of my memory
t: I am thinking about how much money I have right now, and as best as I can remember,

og: I cannot instantly raise up the gross  Of full three thousand ducats. What of that?
t: I can't raise the gross sum of three thousand ducats right now. But that doesn't matter.

og: Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe,  Will furnish me. But soft! How many months  Do you desire?
t: Tubal, a wealthy Jew of my tribe, will supply the rest of the money. But wait! How many months do you want the money for?

og: Rest you fair, good signor.  Your worship was the last man in our mouths.
t: Hello, good sir. We were just talking about you.

og: Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor borrow  By taking nor by giving of excess,
t: Shylock, I normally don't lend or borrow money with interest,

og: Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend,  I’ll break a custom.
t: but in order to help my needy friend, I'll break my custom.

og: Is he yet possessed  How much ye would?
t: Does he know how much money you want yet?

og: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.
t: Yes, yes, three thousand ducats.

og: And for three months.
t: And for three months.

og: I had forgot—three months.    Well then, your bond, and let me see—But hear you, Methought you said you neither lend nor borrowUpon advantage.
t: I had forgotten—three months.  Well then, and you'll be the guarantor on behalf of Bassanio, let's see—but listen, I thought you said you don't lend or borrow money with interest.

og: I do never use it.
t: I never do.

og: When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban’s sheep—  This Jacob from our holy Abram was,
t: In the Bible, when Jacob looked after his uncle Laban's sheep—this is the Jacob who was descended from our holy ancestor Abram,

og: As his wise mother wrought in his behalf,  The third possessor, ay, he was the third—
t: and his wise mother made him his father's heir so that he was the third to possess God's promise—

og: And what of him? Did he take interest?
t: And what about him? Did he charge interest?

og: No, not take interest—not as you would say  Directly interest.
t: No, he didn't. He didn't exactly charge interest, as you would say.

og: Mark what Jacob did:  When Laban and himself were compromised  That all the eanlings which were streaked and pied  Should fall as Jacob’s hire, the ewes, being rank,  In the end of autumn turnèd to the rams.
t: But listen to what Jacob did do: when he and Laban agreed that all the streaked and spotted sheep would be his, it was the end of autumn and so the sheep were starting to mate.

og: And when the work of generation was  Between these woolly breeders in the act,  The skillful shepherd peeled me certain wands.  And in the doing of the deed of kind  He stuck them up before the fulsome ewes,
t: And when the wooly sheep were starting to couple off together to breed, the skillful shepherd Jacob put some dappled sticks in front of the ewes while they were conceiving.

og: Who then conceiving did in weaning time  Fall parti-colored lambs—and those were Jacob’s.
t: When they gave birth, they produced streaked and spotted lambs, and those became Jacob's.

og: This was a way to thrive, and he was blessed.  And thrift is blessing, if men steal it not.
t: Jacob became very prosperous in this way, and he was blessed. Profit is a blessing, if it is not obtained by stealing.

og: This was a venture, sir, that Jacob served for—  A thing not in his power to bring to pass  But swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven.
t: But that was something that wasn't in Jacob's power to bring about; it happened through the hand of God.

og: Was this inserted to make interest good?  Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
t: Did you tell this story to imply that it is good to charge interest? Is your gold and silver like a bunch of ewes and rams?

og: I cannot tell: I make it breed as fast.But note me, signor—
t: Maybe: I make the money multiply as fast as sheep. But listen, sir—

og: Mark you this, Bassanio,  The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose.
t: Take note, Bassanio: even the devil can quote the Bible for his own purpose.

og: An evil soul producing holy witness  Is like a villain with a smiling cheek,  A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
t: An evil soul quoting holy words is like a villain who pretends to be good, a good-looking apple with a rotten core.

og: Oh, what a goodly outside falsehood hath!
t: What a good appearance falsehood can have!

og: Three thousand ducats—’tis a good round sum. Three months from twelve, then. Let me see. The rate—
t: Three thousand ducats: that's a good, round number. Three months out of the twelve that make up the year, then. Let me see. The rate—

og: Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?
t: Well, Shylock, will we be in your debt?

og: Signor Antonio, many a time and oft  In the Rialto you have rated me  About my moneys and my usances.
t: Sir Antonio, many times you have criticized me about my money and habit of charging interest in the Rialto.

og: Still have I borne it with a patient shrug,  For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe.
t: I have endured it all with patience and a shrug, because we Jews are known for our ability to endure.

og: You call me misbeliever, cutthroat dog,  And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine—  And all for use of that which is mine own.
t: You say I believe in the wrong religion, call me a cut-throat dog, and spit on my Jewish clothing, all because I use my own money to make profit.

og: Well then, it now appears you need my help.  Go to, then! You come to me and you say,  “Shylock, we would have moneys.”
t: And now it appears that you need my help. Okay, then! You come to me and you say, "Shylock, I need money."

og: You say so!—  You, that did void your rheum upon my beard  And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur  Over your threshold! Moneys is your suit.
t: You tell me this! You who spat on my beard and kicked me as you'd kick a stray dog away from your threshold! You ask for money.

og: What should I say to you? Should I not say,  “Hath a dog money? Is it possible  A cur can lend three thousand ducats?”
t: What should I say to you? Shouldn't I say, "Does a dog have money? Is it possible for a dog to lend you three thousand ducats?"

og: Shall I bend low and in a bondman’s key  With bated breath and whispering humbleness  Say this:
t: Or should I get bend to my knees and with bated breath humbly whisper,

og: “Fair sir, you spet on me on Wednesday last;  You spurned me such a day; another time  You called me ’dog'—and for these courtesies  I’ll lend you thus much moneys?”
t: "Fair sir, you spat on me last Wednesday; you spurned me then; another time you called me a dog—and for all this courtesy you've shown me, I will gladly lend you this much money?"

og: I am as like to call thee so again,  To spet on thee again, to spurn thee too.
t: I am likely to call you such names again, spit on you again, and spurn you, too.

og: If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not  As to thy friends, for when did friendship take  A breed for barren metal of his friend?
t: If you decide to lend this money, don't do it as if we are your friends. After all, when have friends ever charged each other interest?

og: But lend it rather to thine enemy,  Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face  Exact the penalty.
t: Lend me the money as your enemy and if I break my part of the agreement you can more happily punish me.

og: Why, look you how you storm!  I would be friends with you and have your love,
t: Why, look at your temper! I would be friends with you and have your affection,

og: Forget the shames that you have stained me with,  Supply your present wants and take no doit  Of usance for my moneys—and you’ll not hear me!
t: forget about how you have shamed me, lend you what you need and take no interest—but you won't listen to me!

og: This is kind I offer.
t: I'm giving you a kind offer.

og: This were kindness.
t: That would be kind.

og: This kindness will I show.  Go with me to a notary, seal me there  Your single bond,
t: I'll show you this kindness. Go with me to a notary and sign an agreement:

og: and—in a merry sport—  If you repay me not on such a day,  In such a place, such sum or sums as are  Expressed in the condition,
t: if you do not repay me the agreed-upon amount of money on the agreed-upon day, in the agreed-upon place,

og: let the forfeit  Be nominated for an equal pound  Of your fair flesh,  to be cut off and taken  In what part of your body pleaseth me.
t: you will forfeit to me one pound of your fair flesh, to be cut off from whatever part of your body I choose.

og: Content, in faith. I’ll seal to such a bond,And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
t: Sure, why not? I'll agree to such a deal, and I'll admit there is much kindness in Jews.

og: You shall not seal to such a bond for me!I’ll rather dwell in my necessity.
t: I won't let you agree to such a deal on my behalf! I'd rather deal with my poverty.

og: Why, fear not, man. I will not forfeit it.
t: Don't worry, man. I won't have to give up the pound of flesh.

og: Within these two months—that’s a month before  This bond expires—I do expect return  Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
t: I expect to make nine times the amount of this contract within these next two months, and that's a month before I have to pay him back.

og: O Father Abram, what these Christians are,  Whose own hard dealings teaches them suspect  The thoughts of others!—  Pray you, tell me this:
t: Oh, Father Abram, what strange people these Christians are! They suspect the worst in others because of their own trickery. Please, tell me this:

og: If he should break his day, what should I gain  By the exaction of the forfeiture?
t: if he fails to pay me back in time, what would I gain by taking a pound of his flesh?

og: A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man  Is not so estimable, profitable neither,  As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats.
t: A pound of flesh taken from a man is not worth very much, and isn't as profitable as mutton, beef, or goat flesh.

og: I say,  To buy his favor I extend this friendship.  If he will take it, so. If not, adieu.  And for my love I pray you wrong me not.
t: I'm telling you, I'm giving him this kind offer to be friendly. If he will accept the offer, good. If not, goodbye. And for this kindness I show you, I ask you not to think poorly of me.

og: Yes, Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.
t: Yes, Shylock, I will enter into this contract

og: Then meet me forthwith at the notary’s.  Give him direction for this merry bond,
t: Then meet me right away at the notary's office. Explain to him this happy agreement,

og: And I will go and purse the ducats straight,  See to my house left in the fearful guard  Of an unthrifty knave, and presently  I will be with you.
t: and I will go immediately to gather up the ducats from my house, which I've left guarded by a careless clown. Then, soon, I'll meet you.

og: Hie thee, gentle Jew.
t: Take care, gentle Jew.

og: The Hebrew will turn Christian. He grows kind.
t: This Hebrew must be turning Christian, because he's getting kinder.

og: I like not fair terms and a villain’s mind.
t: I don't like fair terms when they're thought up by a villain's mind.

og: Come on. In this there can be no dismay.My ships come home a month before the day.
t: Come on. There's nothing bad about this. My ships will come home with the money a month before I have to pay him.

og: Mislike me not for my complexion,  The shadowed livery of the burnished sun,  To whom I am a neighbor and near bred.
t: Don't dislike me because of my skin color, the shadow-colored skin that results from the burning sun in Africa.

og: Bring me the fairest creature northward born,  Where Phoebus' fire scarce thaws the icicles,  And let us make incision for your love  To prove whose blood is reddest, his or mine.
t: Bring me the most beautiful person born in the north, where the light of the sun barely thaws the ice, and let's cut both him and me so you can see whose blood is reddest, his or mine.

og: I tell thee, lady, this aspect of mine  Hath feared the valiant. By my love I swear  The best-regarded virgins of our clime  Have loved it too.
t: I'm telling you, my lady, this aspect of my appearance has frightened brave men. By my love, I swear the best-regarded virgins of my land love me.

og: I would not change this hue  Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.
t: I wouldn't trade my dark skin color for anything, my gentle queen, except to have you think kindly of me.

og: In terms of choice I am not solely led  By nice direction of a maiden’s eyes.
t: In terms of my choosing a husband, I care about more than looks.

og: Besides, the lottery of my destiny  Bars me the right of voluntary choosing.
t: And besides, my destiny is to be decided by a lottery, so I can't even choose for myself.

og: But if my father had not scanted me  And hedged me by his wit to yield myself  His wife who wins me by that means I told you,
t: But if my father hadn't robbed me of that right as I described to you,

og: Yourself, renownèd Prince, then stood as fair  As any comer I have looked on yet  For my affection.
t: you would be as good a potential husband in me eyes, renowned Prince, as anyone else.

og: Even for that I thank you.  Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets  To try my fortune.
t: Thank you for that compliment. Therefore, I beg you to lead me to the caskets so I can try my luck.

og: By this scimitar  That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince  That won three fields of Sultan Solyman,
t: By this sword with which I killed the leader of Persia and a Persian prince, and with which I won three battles against Sultan Solyman,

og: I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look,  Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth,  Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear,  Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey,  To win the lady.
t: I swear that I would stare down the sternest eyes in the world, be braver than the most daring man on earth, steal the bear cubs from a suckling mother bear, and even mock a lion roaring at his prey—all to win you.

og: But, alas the while!  If Hercules and Lychas play at dice  Which is the better man, the greater throw  May turn by fortune from the weaker hand.
t: But alas! If Hercules and his servant Lychas had to play a game of dice to decide the better man, the weaker man might win by luck.

og: So is Alcides beaten by his page,  And so may I, blind fortune leading me,  Miss that which one unworthier may attain  And die with grieving.
t: So the great Hercules could be beaten by his own servant, and so I might lose you to a less worthy man because of blind luck. If that happened, I would die of grief.

og: You must take your chance,  And either not attempt to choose at all
t: You must try your luck. Either don't attempt it at all,

og: Or swear before you choose,  if you choose wrong  Never to speak to lady afterward  In way of marriage. Therefore be advised.
t: or promise before you choose a casket that if you choose the wrong one you will never speak to a lady about marriage again. Be warned.

og: Nor will not. Come, bring me unto my chance.
t: I promise. Come on, bring me to the caskets.

og: First, forward to the temple. After dinnerYour hazard shall be made.
t: First, let's go forward to the temple. After dinner, you can try your luck.

og: Good fortune then!—To make me blessed or cursed’st among men.
t: May I have good luck, then! I'll either be a blessed or a cursed man.

og: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew, my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me, saying to me, “Gobbo,” “Launcelot Gobbo,” “Good Launcelot,” or “Good Gobbo,” or “Good Launcelot Gobbo” —“use your legs, take the start, run away.”
t: Certainly part of me wants to run from my master, this Jew. The devil whispers in my ear, tempting me, saying to me, "Gobbo," "Launcelot Gobbo," "Good Launcelot," or "Good Gobbo," or "Good Launcelot Gobbo"—"use your legs, get going, run away."

og: My conscience says, “No. Take heed, honest Launcelot. Take heed, honest Gobbo,” or as aforesaid, “Honest Launcelot Gobbo, do not run. Scorn running with thy heels.”
t: But my conscience says, "No. Wait here, honest Launcelot. Wait here, honest Gobbo." Or it says, "Honest Launcelot Gobbo, do not run away. Don't you dare run away."

og: Well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack. “Fia!” says the fiend. “Away!” says the fiend. “For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.”
t: Well, the bold devil is encouraging me to get going. "Go!" says the devil. "Go away!" says the devil. "For heaven's sake, be brave and run," says the devil.

og: Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being anhonest man’s son”—or rather an honest woman’s son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to.He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend. “Budge not,” says my conscience.
t: But then my conscience pulls on my heart and says very wisely to me, "My honest friend Launcelot, since you are the son of an honest man"—or rather the son of an honest woman, for actually my father was somewhat dishonest and unfaithful. He had a kind of taste for it. Anyways, my conscience says, "Launcelot, don't budge!" "Budge!" says the devil. "Don't budge," says my conscience.

og: “Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To beruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil.
t: "Conscience," I say, "you give good advice." "Devil," I say, "you give good advice, too." If I listen to my conscience, I'd stay here with my master the Jew, who is a kind of devil himself.

og: Andto run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself.Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnation.
t: And if I run away from the Jew I'd be listening to the devil, who is the devil himself. But then again, the Jew is certainly the very devil incarnate.

og: And inmy conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew.The fiend gives the more friendly counsel. I will run, fiend. My heels are at your command. I will run.
t: And my conscience is being rather difficult in advising me to stay with the Jew. The devil is giving more friendly advice. I will run away, devil. My feet are at your command: I will run away.

og: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way toMaster Jew’s?
t: Excuse me, young man, where is the Jew's house?

og: O heavens, this is my true-begotten father, who, being more than sand-blind—high-gravel blind—knows me not. I will try confusions with him.
t: Oh God, this is my father. He is as blind as a bat and doesn't recognize me. I'll play some tricks on him.

og: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way toMaster Jew’s?
t: Young man, please, where is the Jew's house?

og: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left. Marry, at the verynext turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.
t: At the next intersection, take a right, and then at the next take a left. And then at the next intersection keep going straight and you'll be at the Jew's house.

og: By God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?
t: By God, it will be hard to find my way there. Do you know if someone named Launcelot, who lives with him, is there with him or not?

og: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?    Mark me now. Now will I raise the waters.—Talk you of young Master Launcelot?
t: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?  Are you talking about the young Master Launcelot?

og: No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son. His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.
t: Not a "master," sir, but a poor man's son. His father, though, is an honest, if very poor, man and—thank God—in good health.

og: Well, let his father be what he will, we talk of youngMaster Launcelot.
t: Well, whatever his father is like, we are talking about young Master Launcelot.

og: Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.
t: Yes, but just Launcelot, not "master," sir.

og: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?
t: But I ask you, ergo, old man, I beg you: are you talking about young Master Launcelot?

og: Of Launcelot, an ’t please your mastership.
t: Master, I am speaking of someone simply called  Launcelot.

og: Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master Launcelot, Father,
t: Ergo, Master Launcelot. Don't talk about Master Launcelot, father.

og: for the young gentleman, according to Fates and Destinies and such odd sayings, the Sisters Three and such branches of learning, is indeed deceased,
t: That young gentleman, according to his fate and destiny and so forth, the Three Sisters and so on, is deceased.

og: or as youwould say in plain terms, gone to heaven.
t: Or, to say it plainly, he has gone to heaven.

og: Marry, God forbid! The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.
t: God forbid! In my old age I relied on that boy, like a crutch!

og: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?Do you know me, Father?
t: Do I look like a crutch or a prop? Do you recognize me, father?

og: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman. But I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?
t: I swear, I don't know who you are, young gentleman. But please tell me: is my son—God rest his soul—alive or dead?

og: Do you not know me, Father?
t: Do you not know who I am, father?

og: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind. I know you not.
t: Alas, sir, I am completely blind. I don't know you.

og: Nay, indeed if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me. It is a wise father that knows his own child.
t: Even if you could see, you might not recognize me. It takes a wise father to recognize his own child.

og: Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son. Give me your blessing.
t: Well, old man, I will give you news regarding your son. Give me your blessing.

og: Truth will come to light. Murder cannot be hid long—a man’s son may, but in the end truthwill out.
t: The truth will come to light. Murder can't be hidden for long. A man's son can be hidden, but not the truth.

og: Pray you, sir, stand up. I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.
t: Please sir, stand up. I am sure you aren't my son Launcelot.

og: Pray you, let’s have no more fooling about it, but giveme your blessing. I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.
t: Please, enough fooling around. Give me your blessing. I am Launcelot, who was, is, and will continue to be your son.

og: I cannot think you are my son.
t: I can't believe that you are my son.

og: I know not what I shall think of that. But I am Launcelot, the Jew’s man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.
t: I don't know what to think of that. But I really am Launcelot, the Jew's servant, and I am sure your wife Margery is my mother.

og: Her name is Margery, indeed. I’ll be sworn, if thou beLauncelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.
t: My wife's name is Margery, indeed. If you're Launcelot, I'll swear you are my own flesh and blood.

og: Lord worshipped might he be, what a beard hast thou got!
t: Good lord, what a beard you have!

og: Thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.
t: You have more hair on your chin than my horse Dobbin has on his tail.

og: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward.I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.
t: It would seem that Dobbin's tail is shrinking, then. I am sure that he had more hair on his tail the last time I saw him than I have on my face.

og: Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy master agree? I have brought him a present. How 'gree you now?
t: Lord, you have changed! How are you and your master getting along? I have bought him a present. Are you getting along with him?

og: Well, well, but for mine own part, as I have set up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have run some ground. My master’s a very Jew.
t: Pretty well, but I've decided to run away from him, so I won't rest until I've run some distance. My master is very much a Jew.

og: Give him a present.Give him a halter. I am famished in his service. You may tell every finger I have with my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come.
t: Go ahead and give him a present; give him a noose. I work as his servant and he hardly feeds me. You can count my ribs, they protrude so much. I'm glad you've come, father.

og: Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.
t: Give me the present so I can give it to Master Bassanio, who gives his servants fancy new outfits.

og: If I servenot him, I will run as far as God has any ground.—O rare fortune! Here comes the man.—To him, Father, for I am a Jew if I serve the Jew any longer.
t: If I don't end up as his servant, I will run as far away as is possible. Oh, just my luck! Here he comes. Let's go talk to him, father, for if I serve the Jew any longer, I'll be a Jew myself.

og: You may do so, but let it be so hasted that supper be ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See these letters delivered, put the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.
t: You may do that, but do it quick so that supper is ready by five o'clock at the latest. Make sure these letters are delivered, get the outfits made, and tell Gratiano to come soon to my house.

og: To him, Father.
t: Go talk to him, father.

og: God bless your worship!
t: God bless you!

og: Gramercy! Wouldst thou aught with me?
t: Thanks! Do you want something?

og: Here’s my son, sir, a poor boy—
t: This here is my son, a poor boy—

og: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew’s man that would,sir, as my father shall specify—
t: Not a poor boy, sir, but a servant of the rich Jew. And I would like, sir, as my father will tell you—

og: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve—
t: He has a great desire, sir, as they say, to serve—

og: Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew and have a desire, as my father shall specify—
t: Yes, to make a long story short, I currently serve under the Jew and, as my father will tell you, I have a desire—

og: His master and he, saving your worship’s reverence, are scarce cater-cousins—
t: He and his master, your reverence, are not the closest of friends—

og: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being, I hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you—
t: To be brief, the truth is that the Jew, having wronged me, now makes it so that I, as my father, being an old man, will provide you with—

og: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon your worship, and my suit is—
t: I have a gift of a plate of doves here that I would give to you, and all I ask is—

og: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your worship shall know by this honest old man—and though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father—
t: In short, the request is about me, and you will learn from this honest old man—and even though I'm his son, I tell you, even though he's old and poor, my father—

og: One speak for both. What would you?
t: One of you speak for both of you. What do you want?

og: Serve you, sir.
t: To be your servant, sir.

og: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.
t: That is the heart of the matter, sir.

og: I know thee well. Thou hast obtained thy suit.  Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,  And hath preferred thee,
t: I know you well. You will get what you ask for. Your master Shylock spoke with me today and spoke well of you,

og: if it be preferment  To leave a rich Jew’s service, to become  The follower of so poor a gentleman.
t: if you really want to leave the service of a rich Jew to become a servant of such a poor gentleman.

og: The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir—you have “the grace of God,” sir, and he hath “enough.”
t: The old proverb says, "the grace of God is enough." It could be split up between you and my master Shylock, sir. You have the grace of God, and he has enough.

og: Thou speak’st it well.—Go, father, with thy son.—
t: Well said. Go along with your son, father.

og: Take leave of thy old master and inquire  My lodging out.—
t: Go leave your old master and come inquire at my house.

og: Give him a livery  More guarded than his fellows'. See it done.
t: Give him a outfit more frilled than his fellow servants. Make sure this is done.

og: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no. I have ne'er a tongue in my head.
t: Father, go. I can't get a job, no. I'm not very good at talking.

og: Well, if any man in Italy have afairer table which doth offer to swear upon a book, I shall have good fortune.
t: Well, I have as good a palm as any man in Italy to swear upon a Bible with. I will have good luck.

og: Go to, here’s a simple line of life. Here’s a small trifle of wives. Alas, fifteen wives is nothing! Eleven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man.
t: Look, here's the life line. It predicts several wives. Fifteen wives is nothing! Eleven widows and nine young women is good for one man.

og: And then to ’scape drowning thrice and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a feather-bed—here are simple ’scapes.
t: It looks like I will escape drowning three times and nearly lose my life in a feather-bed. Simple escapes.

og: Well, if Fortune be a woman, she’s a good wench for this gear.—Father, come. I’ll take my leave of the Jew in thetwinkling.
t: If Fortune is a lady, she's a good one for all this. Come with me, father. I'll leave the Jew in the blink of an eye.

og: I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this.  These things being bought and orderly bestowed,  Return in haste,
t: Please, Leonardo, pay attention to this. Buy and arrange these things and then come back to me quickly,

og: for I do feast tonight  My best esteemed acquaintance. Hie thee, go.
t: for I'm having my most respected acquaintance over for dinner tonight. Get going now.

og: My best endeavours shall be done herein.
t: I'll give it my best effort.

og: Where is your master?
t: Where is your master?

og: Yonder, sir, he walks.
t: Over there, sir, walking about.

og: Signor Bassanio!
t: Sir Bassanio!

og: Gratiano!
t: Gratiano!

og: I have a suit to you.
t: I have a favor to ask of you.

og: You have obtained it.
t: Your wish is my command.

og: You must not deny me. I must go with you to Belmont.
t: Please don't deny my favor. I must go with you to Belmont.

og: Why, then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano.  Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice—
t: Well then, you will. But listen, Gratiano. You are too wild and too rude, and you speak too boldly.

og: Parts that become thee happily enough  And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.
t: These qualities suit you well and I don't mind them.

og: But where thou art not known, why, there they show  Something too liberal.
t: But in a place where people don't know you, these qualities might seem excessive.

og: Pray thee, take pain  To allay with some cold drops of modesty  Thy skipping spirit,
t: Please, take care to moderate your hot-headed spirit with some cold drops of modesty,

og: lest through thy wild behavior  I be misconst’red in the place I go to,  And lose my hopes.
t: so that your wild behavior doesn't reflect poorly on me in Belmont, and ruin my own hopes there.

og: Signor Bassanio, hear me.  If I do not put on a sober habit,
t: Sir Bassanio, listen to me. I give you permission to never trust me again if I do not behave in a sober fashion,

og: Talk with respect and swear but now and then,  Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely—
t: talk respectfully and not swear too much, carry prayer books around with me, look modestly—

og: Nay more.  While grace is saying, hood mine eyes  Thus with my hat, and sigh and say, “Amen”—
t: even more, if during grace I do not pull my hat down over my eyes, sigh, and say "Amen"—

og: Use all the observance of civility  Like one well studied in a sad ostent  To please his grandam, never trust me more.
t: if I don't follow every guideline of good manners like someone who's studied hard to please his grandmother.

og: Well, we shall see your bearing.
t: Well, we will see how you behave.

og: Nay, but I bar tonight. You shall not gauge meBy what we do tonight.
t: But tonight is an exception. Don't gauge me based on what I do tonight.

og: No, that were pity.
t: No, it would be a pity to judge you based on tonight.

og: I would entreat you rather to put on  Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends  That purpose merriment.
