t: Rather, I encourage you to to put on your boldest display of merriment, for we are entertaining two friends whom I want to entertain.

og: But fare you well.  I have some business.
t: But I must say goodbye, because I have some business to take care of.

og: And I must to Lorenzo and the rest.But we will visit you at supper time.
t: And I must go to Lorenzo and the others. We will see you at dinner time.

og: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.  Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil,  Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.
t: I am sorry that you are leaving my father's service like this. Our house is hell, and you, a joking little devil, made life here a little less boring.

og: But fare thee well, there is a ducat for thee.  And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see  Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.  Give him this letter.
t: But I wish you well. Here is a ducat for you. And Launcelot, you will soon see a man named Lorenzo at dinner, a guest of your new master's. Give this letter to him.

og: Do it secretly.  And so farewell. I would not have my father  See me in talk with thee.
t: Do it secretly. Goodbye, now. I don't want my father to see me talking with you.

og: Adieu! Tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful pagan, most sweet Jew!
t: Goodbye! I am speaking through my tears. You most beautiful pagan, you sweet Jew!

og: If a Christian do not play the knave andget thee, I am much deceived. But adieu.
t: I'll bet some Christian will figure out a way to get you. But goodbye.

og: These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit. Adieu.
t: These silly tears aren't very manly. Goodbye.

og: Farewell, good Launcelot.
t: Farewell, good Launcelot.

og: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me  To be ashamed to be my father’s child!
t: Alas, what a heinous sin it is for me to be ashamed to be my father's child!

og: But though I am a daughter to his blood,  I am not to his manners.
t: I am his daughter by blood, but I have not inherited his manners.

og: O Lorenzo,  If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife,  Become a Christian and thy loving wife.
t: Oh, Lorenzo, if you keep your promise I will end this pain by becoming a Christian and your loving wife.

og: Nay, we will slink away in supper time,Disguise us at my lodging, and return,All in an hour.
t: No, we'll sneak off at dinner, disguise ourselves at my house, and then get back here all in an hour.

og: We have not made good preparation.
t: We haven't prepared well enough for this.

og: We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.
t: We haven't got ourselves torchbearers yet.

og: 'Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered,And better in my mind not undertook.
t: Unless we plan carefully, this will turn out badly, and it will be better not to try this.

og: 'Tis now but four o'clock. We have two hoursTo furnish us.
t: It's only four o'clock now. We have two hours to get ready.

og: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?
t: My friend Launcelot, what's the news?

og: An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seemto signify.
t: If you would open this up, it will tell you.

og: I know the hand. In faith, ’tis a fair hand,And whiter than the paper it writ onIs the fair hand that writ.
t: I know this handwriting. Truly written by a beautiful hand, one whiter than the paper it wrote on.

og: Love news, in faith?
t: Something about love, is it?

og: By your leave, sir.
t: May I leave, sir?

og: Whither goest thou?
t: Where are you going?

og: Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonightwith my new master the Christian.
t: Sir, I am going to tell my old master the Jew to dine tonight with my new master the Christian.

og: Hold here, take this. Tell gentle Jessica  I will not fail her.
t: Hold on. Take this. Tell gentle Jessica that I won't fail her.

og: Speak it privately.—  Go, gentlemen,  Will you prepare you for this masque tonight?
t: Tell her this privately. And you gentlemen, go and prepare for this masquerade party tonight.

og: I am provided of a torchbearer.
t: I have a torchbearer.

og: Ay, marry, I’ll be gone about it straight.
t: Yes, sure thing, I'll go see to it right away.

og: And so will I.
t: And so will I.

og: Meet me and GratianoAt Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.
t: Meet Gratiano and me at Gratiano's house a few hours from now.

og: 'Tis good we do so.
t: That's a good plan.

og: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?
t: Wasn't that letter from the beautiful Jessica?

og: I must needs tell thee all. She hath directed  How I shall take her from her father’s house,  What gold and jewels she is furnished with,  What page’s suit she hath in readiness.
t: I must tell you everything. She has instructed me in how to take her away from her father's house and told me what gold and jewels she has, and that she has a servant's outfit ready.

og: If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven,  It will be for his gentle daughter’s sake.
t: If her father the Jew ever gets into heaven, it will be thanks to his gentle, good daughter.

og: And never dare Misfortune cross her foot  Unless she do it under this excuse:  That she is issue to a faithless Jew.
t: And may misfortune never befall her unless under the excuse that she is the daughter of a faithless Jew.

og: Come, go with me.
t: Come now, go with me.

og: Peruse this as thou goest.  Fair Jessica shall be my torchbearer.
t: Read this as you go. Beautiful Jessica will be my torchbearer.

og: Well, thou shalt see, thy eyes shall be thy judge,  The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio.—
t: Well, you will see for yourself. You can be the judge of the difference between old Shylock and Bassanio.

og: What, Jessica!—
t: Jessica!

og: Thou shalt not gormandize  As thou hast done with me.—
t: You won't be able to gorge yourself on food like you've done with me.

og: What, Jessica!—
t: Jessica!

og: And sleep and snore, and rend apparel out—
t: And you won't be able to sleep and snore and wear out clothing.

og: Why, Jessica, I say!
t: Jessica! I'm calling for you!

og: Why, Jessica!
t: Jessica!

og: Who bids thee call? I do not bid thee call.
t: Who told you to call for her? I didn't order you to do that.

og: Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.
t: You did often tell me not to do anything unless you ordered me to.

og: Call you? What is your will?
t: You called? What do you want?

og: I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.  There are my keys.—
t: I have been invited to a dinner, Jessica. Here are my keys.

og: But wherefore should I go?  I am not bid for love.
t: But then again, why should I go? They haven't invited me out of friendly affection.

og: They flatter me.  But yet I’ll go in hate to feed upon  The prodigal Christian.—
t: They're just trying to flatter me. Nonetheless, I'll go out of spite to eat that extravagant Christian's food.

og: Jessica, my girl,  Look to my house. I am right loath to go.
t: Jessica, my girl, look after the house. I am reluctant to leave it.

og: There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest,  For I did dream of money bags tonight.
t: There are bad things being stirred up for me, for I had a dream about money bags last night.

og: I beseech you, sir, go. My young master doth expect your reproach.
t: I beg you, sir, go to the dinner. My young master expects your reproach.

og: So do I his.
t: And I expect his.

og: And they have conspired together. I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six o'clock i' th' morning falling out that yearon Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.
t: And they've been planning together. I'm not saying you will definitely see a masquerade party, but if you do then it really was a true omen when my nose started bleeding last Black Monday at six o'clock in the morning, just like Ash Wednesday four years ago in the afternoon.

og: What, are there masques? Hear you me, Jessica.
t: What, is there a masquerade party planned? Listen to me, Jessica.

og: Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum  And the vile squealing of the wry-necked fife,  Clamber not you up to the casements then,  Nor thrust your head into the public street  To gaze on Christian fools with varnished faces.
t: Lock up my doors, and when you hear the party drum and the vile squealing of the thin flute, don't look out of the balconies or put your head out into the street in order to look at the foolish Christians with masked faces.

og: But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements—  Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter  My sober house.
t: Shut up the windows and don't let the sound of their dumb celebration enter my sober house.

og: By Jacob’s staff, I swear,  I have no mind of feasting forth tonight.
t: By Jacob's staff I swear that I have no intention to feast and party tonight. But I will go to the dinner.

og: But I will go.—Go you before me, sirrah.  Say I will come.
t: Go ahead of me, Launcelot. Tell them I'm coming.

og: I will go before, sir.—
t: I will go ahead, sir.

og: Mistress, look out at window, for all this.
t: Mistress, despite your father's warnings, look out of a window.

og: There will come a Christian by  Will be worth a Jewess' eye.
t: You'll see a Christian come by who's worth your Jewish eye.

og: What says that fool of Hagar’s offspring, ha?
t: What did that foolish Christian tell you?

og: His words were, “Farewell, mistress.” Nothing else.
t: He said, "Farewell, mistress." Nothing else.

og: The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder,  Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day  More than the wildcat.
t: He's a nice enough fellow, but a voracious eater. He works as slowly as a snail and sleeps more than a cat during the day.

og: Drones hive not with me.  Therefore I part with him, and part with him  To one that would have him help to waste  His borrowed purse.
t: I'll have worker bees only for my hive. So I'll let him go, and send him to go use up all that man's money, which he borrowed from me.

og: Well, Jessica, go in.  Perhaps I will return immediately.  Do as I bid you.
t: Well, Jessica, go inside. Maybe I'll be back very soon. Do as I tell you.

og: Shut doors after you.  Fast bind, fast find.  A proverb never stale in thrifty mind.
t: Shut all the doors after you. Keep safe what you want to keep, as they say. That saying is always on my thrifty mind.

og: Farewell, and if my fortune be not crost, I have a father, you a daughter, lost.
t: Goodbye, and if I have any good luck, soon I will have lost a father and you will have lost a daughter.

og: This is the penthouse under which LorenzoDesired us to make stand.
t: This is the house Lorenzo wanted us to wait at.

og: His hour is almost past.
t: He's nearly late.

og: And it is marvel he outdwells his hour,For lovers ever run before the clock.
t: Yes, and that's surprising, because those in love are usually early.

og: Oh, ten times faster Venus' pigeons flyTo seal love’s bonds new made than they are wontTo keep obligèd faith unforfeited.
t: The doves of Venus fly ten times faster to consummate a new relationship than to keep couples together.

og: That ever holds. Who riseth from a feast  With that keen appetite that he sits down?
t: That's always true. Who leaves a meal as hungry as when he sat down?

og: Where is the horse that doth untread again  His tedious measures with the unbated fire  That he did pace them first?
t: What horse retraces its steps with as much eagerness as when it went forward?

og: All things that are,  Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.
t: The chase is always the most exciting part.

og: How like a younger or a prodigal  The scarfèd bark puts from her native bay,  Hugged and embraèd by the strumpet wind!
t: When a ship leaves its native bay its sails are hugged and embraced by the loving wind!

og: How like the prodigal doth she return,  With overweathered ribs and ragged sails  Lean, rent, and beggared by the strumpet wind!
t: But when the ship returns it has weathered sides and ragged sails, damaged and torn apart by the vicious wind!

og: Here comes Lorenzo. More of this hereafter.
t: Here comes Lorenzo. We can talk about this more later.

og: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.  Not I but my affairs have made you wait.
t: My sweet friends, forgive me for being late. I didn't keep you waiting on purpose, but had to because of my business.

og: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives,  I’ll watch as long for you then.
t: When you are the ones trying and steal your wives away, I'll wait just as patiently for you as you've waited for me.

og: Approach.  Here dwells my father Jew.—Ho! Who’s within?
t: Come here. This the house of the Jew that will be my father-in-law. Hello! Who's there?

og: Who are you? Tell me for more certainty,Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.
t: Who are you? Tell me so I can be sure, although I swear I recognize your voice.

og: Lorenzo, and thy love.
t: It is Lorenzo, your love.

og: Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed— For who love I so much? And now who knowsBut you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?
t: You are certainly Lorenzo, and definitely my love. Who do I love as much as you? And who other than yourself knows that I am yours?

og: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
t: Heaven and you yourself both know that you are mine.

og: Here, catch this casket. It is worth the pains.  I am glad ’tis night, you do not look on me,  For I am much ashamed of my exchange.
t: Here, catch this box. It's worth the effort. I am glad it's dark out so you can't see me. I'm very ashamed of how I look in my disguise.

og: But love is blind, and lovers cannot see  The pretty follies that themselves commit,
t: But love is blind and lovers cannot see the little faults in their relationships.

og: For if they could Cupid himself would blush  To see me thus transformèd to a boy.
t: If they could, Cupid himself would blush at how ridiculous I look disguised as a boy.

og: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.
t: Come down. You must be my torchbearer.

og: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?
t: What, I'm supposed to hold up a candle so you can see my shameful appearance?

og: They in themselves, good sooth, are too too light.
t: Speaking of light, my behavior is a little too light on morality.

og: Why, ’tis an office of discovery, love.  And I should be obscured.
t: The torchbearer brings things to light, my love, and I should be kept hidden in the shadows.

og: So are you, sweet,  Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.
t: You are hidden, sweetie, in the lovely disguise of a boy.

og: But come at once,  For the close night doth play the runaway,  And we are stayed for at Bassanio’s feast.
t: But come here at once. The night is going by quickly, and they're waiting for us at Bassanio's feast.

og: I will make fast the doors and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.
t: I'll make sure the doors are securely closed and get some more money, and then I'll be with you right away.

og: Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.
t: I swear, she's too gentle to be a Jew.

og: Beshrew me but I love her heartily.
t: Call me crazy, but I love her with all my heart.

og: For she is wise, if I can judge of her.  And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.  And true she is, as she hath proved herself.
t: If I'm any judge of character, she is wise. And if my eyes are trustworthy, she is beautiful.

og: And therefore, like herself—wise, fair and true—  Shall she be placèd in my constant soul.
t: Moreover, she has proven herself to be loyal. And since she is wise, beautiful, and loyal, she will always be in my heart.

og: What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
t: Are you here now? Gentlemen, let's go! Our fellow party-goers are waiting for us at the masquerade.

og: Who’s there?
t: Who's there?

og: Signor Antonio?
t: Sir Antonio?

og: Fie, fie, Gratiano! Where are all the rest?  'Tis nine o'clock.
t: Ah, Gratiano! Where is everyone else? It's nine o'clock.

og: Our friends all stay for you.  No masque tonight. The wind is come about.  Bassanio presently will go aboard.
t: Our friends are all waiting for you. There's not going to be a masquerade party tonight. The wind is blowing, so Bassanio is going to get on his sailboat right away.

og: I have sent twenty out to seek for you.
t: I have sent twenty men out looking for you.

og: I am glad on ’t. I desire no more delightThan to be under sail and gone tonight.
t: I'm glad. I don't want a party. All I want is to be on our way sailing tonight.

og: Now make your choice.
t: Now choose one of the caskets.

og: The first, of gold, who this inscription bears:  “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”
t: The first one, made of gold, has this inscription: "He who chooses me will get what many men desire."

og: The second, silver, which this promise carries:  “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”
t: The second one, made of silver, has this promise written on it: "He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves."

og: This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt:  “Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”  How shall I know if I do choose the right?
t: The third one, made of dull lead, has this blunt warning: "He who chooses me must give up and risk all that he has." How will I know if I choose the right casket?

og: The one of them contains my picture, Prince.If you choose that, then I am yours withal.
t: One of them has my picture inside, Prince. If you choose that one then I am yours.

og: Some god direct my judgment! Let me see.  I will survey th' inscriptions back again.  What says this leaden casket?
t: May some god help me make my choice! Let's see. I will look over the inscriptions again. What does the lead casket say?

og: “Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”  Must give—for what? For lead? Hazard for lead?  This casket threatens  .
t: "He who chooses me must give up and risk all that he has." Must give up for what? For some lead? Risk everything for lead? This casket's inscription doesn't bode well.

og: Men that hazard all  Do it in hope of fair advantages.  A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross.  I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.
t: If I am going to risk everything, it must be in hope of a big reward. A golden mind doesn't stoop to trash. I won't risk or give up anything for lead, then.

og: What says the silver with her virgin hue?  “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”  “As much as he deserves!”—pause there, Morocco,  And weigh thy value with an even hand.
t: What does the silver one, with its pure hue, say? "He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves." As much as he deserves! I need to think this over for a second, and consider how much I deserve.

og: If thou beest rated by thy estimation,  Thou dost deserve enough, and yet enough  May not extend so far as to the lady,  And yet to be afeard of my deserving  Were but a weak disabling of myself.
t: If I were to judge myself, I'd say that I deserve quite a bit, but quite a bit might not be enough to merit the lady. But I do myself a disservice in underestimating what I deserve.

og: As much as I deserve! Why, that’s the lady.  I do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes,  In graces, and in qualities of breeding.  But more than these, in love I do deserve.
t: I deserve her by my noble birth and my wealth, by my good graces and good breeding. But even more than this, I deserve her because of my love for her.

og: What if I strayed no further, but chose here?  Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold,  “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”  Why, that’s the lady. All the world desires her.
t: What if I didn't consider the other caskets and chose this one? Let's see the saying engraved on the gold one more time. "He who chooses me will get what many men desire." Well, that's the lady. The whole world desires her.

og: From the four corners of the earth they come  To kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.  The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds  Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now  For princes to come view fair Portia.
t: They come from the four corners of the earth to kiss her, this living saint. The deserts of the Middle East and the vast wilds of Arabia are practically highways now for princes to come see beautiful Portia.

og: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head  Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar  To stop the foreign spirits, but they come  As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.
t: The kingdom of the ocean, whose waves rise to touch heaven itself, cannot stop the foreign suitors from coming. They cross the sea as if it is a little stream to see beautiful Portia.

og: One of these three contains her heavenly picture.  Is ’t like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation  To think so base a thought. It were too gross  To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.
t: One of these three caskets contains her heavenly picture. Is it likely that ugly lead would contain her? I'd be damned if I thought such a horrible thought. It would be too terrible to enclose her beauty in such a casket.

og: Or shall I think in silver she’s immured,  Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?  O sinful thought! Never so rich a gem  Was set in worse than gold.
t: Or is she in the silver one, worth ten times less than gold? What a sinful thought! Such a rich gem as she is has never been set in anything worse than gold.

og: They have in England  A coin that bears the figure of an angel  Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.  But here an angel in a golden bed  Lies all within.—
t: In England there's a gold coin that's stamped with the figure of an angel, but that's just engraved on top of it. Here, an angel lies within a golden bed.

og: Deliver me the key.  Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!
t: Give me the key. I choose this one, and hope that my choice will bring me joy!

og: There, take it, Prince. And if my form lie thereThen I am yours.
t: There, take it, Prince. And if my picture is within, then I am yours.

og: O hell, what have we here?  A carrion death, within whose empty eye  There is a written scroll. I’ll read the writing.
t: Oh hell, what is this? A skull, and inside the eye socket is a scroll. I'll read what's written on it.

og: “All that glisters is not gold—  Often have you heard that told.  Many a man his life hath sold  But my outside to behold.
t: "All that glitters is not gold—you have often heard this saying. Many a man has given up his life just to see my outside.

og: Gilded tombs do worms enfold.  Had you been as wise as bold,  Young in limbs, in judgment old,  Your answer had not been inscrolled.
t: But golden tombs contain nothing but worms. If you had been as wise as you were bold, with the strength of youth in your body but the good judgment of old age in your mind, you wouldn't have chosen this casket.

og: Fare you well. Your suit is cold—  Cold, indeed, and labor lost.”
t: Fare well. Your attempt to get Portia is unsuccessful and all wasted effort."

og: Then, farewell, heat, and welcome, frost!  Portia, adieu. I have too grieved a heart  To take a tedious leave. Thus losers part.
t: Now, goodbye passion and hello cold solitude. Portia, goodbye. My heart is too sad to take long in leaving. This is how losers depart.

og: A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.—Let all of his complexion choose me so.
t: Good riddance. Close the curtains back up. I hope everyone of his complexion will choose that cask.

og: Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.With him is Gratiano gone along.And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.
t: Man, I saw Bassanio sail away and Gratiano went along with him. And I'm sure that Lorenzo is not with them in their ship.

og: The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
t: That villainous Jew cried out for the Duke's help, and got him to search Bassanio's ship.

og: He came too late. The ship was under sail.  But there the Duke was given to understand  That in a gondola were seen together  Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.
t: He came too late. The ship had already set sail. But it was explained to the Duke that Lorenzo and his loving Jessica were seen together in a gondola.

og: Besides, Antonio certified the Duke  They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
t: Besides, Antonio told the Duke that those two were not with Bassanio in his ship.

og: I never heard a passion so confused,  So strange, outrageous, and so variable,  As the dog Jew did utter in the streets
t: I have never heard a passionate outburst of rage as confused, strange, outrageous, and varied as that dog the Jew uttered in the streets.

og: “My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter,  Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!  Justice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter!
t: He was yelling, "My daughter! Oh, my ducats! O my daughter, she ran away with a Christian! Oh, my ducats that now belong to a Christian! Justice, and the law! My ducats and my daughter!

og: A sealèd bag, two sealèd bags of ducats,  Of double ducats, stol'n from me by my daughter!
t: A sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats, double the ducats, stolen from me by my own daughter!

og: And jewels—two stones, two rich and precious stones—  Stol'n by my daughter! Justice, find the girl!  She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.”
t: And jewels—two valuable, precious stones—stolen by my own daughter! Justice, I must find the girl! She has the jewels with her, and the ducats."

og: Why, all the boys in Venice follow him,Crying, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”
t: All the boys in Venice were following him, crying out, "His jewels, his daughter, and his ducats!"

og: Let good Antonio look he keep his day,Or he shall pay for this.
t: Antonio had better be careful not to miss the deadline for paying Shylock back, or else he will pay for this.

og: Marry, well remembered.  I reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday,  Who told me, in the narrow seas that part  The French and English, there miscarried  A vessel of our country richly fraught.
t: Yes, indeed. I talked yesterday with a French person who told me that there was a shipwreck in the narrow waters that separate England and France involving a ship from our country carrying lots of riches.

og: I thought upon Antonio when he told me,  And wished in silence that it were not his.
t: I thought of Antonio when he said this, and wished to myself that the ship was not his.

og: You were best to tell Antonio what you hear—Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.
t: You'd better tell Antonio what you've heard. But tell him gently; it may upset him.

og: A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.  I saw Bassanio and Antonio part.
t: No gentleman is as kind as Antonio is. I saw Bassanio and him leave each other.

og: Bassanio told him he would make some speed  Of his return. He answered, “Do not so.  Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio  But stay the very riping of the time.
t: Bassanio told him he would come back quickly and Antonio replied, "Don't rush. Don't muddle your business for my sake, Bassanio, but rather stay as long as you need to.

og: And for the Jew’s bond which he hath of me,  Let it not enter in your mind of love.
t: And don't worry about the agreement I have with the Jew.

og: Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts  To courtship and such fair ostents of love  As shall conveniently become you there.”
t: Be of good cheer and devote your thoughts to courtship and how you can best show your love there."

og: And even there, his eye being big with tears,  Turning his face, he put his hand behind him,  And with affection wondrous sensible  He wrung Bassanio’s hand. And so they parted.
t: And as his eyes filled with tears, he turned his face and put his hand out to shake Bassanio's hand with much affection. And that was how they parted.

og: I think he only loves the world for him.
t: I think Bassanio means the world to Antonio.

og: I pray thee, let us go and find him out  And quicken his embracèd heaviness  With some delight or other.
t: Please, let's go and find him and cheer him from his constant melancholy with some good times or something.

og: Do we so.
t: Yes, let's do that.

og: Quick, quick, I pray thee. Draw the curtain straight.The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oathAnd comes to his election presently.
t: Hurry, hurry, please. Close up the curtain right now. The Prince of Aragon has sworn his oath and now comes to make his selection.

og: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince.  If you choose that wherein I am contained,  Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.
t: Behold, there are the caskets, noble Prince. If you choose the one that contains a picture of me, we will get married right away.

og: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord,  You must be gone from hence immediately.
t: But if you make the wrong choice, you must leave here immediately, my lord, without saying another word.

og: I am enjoined by oath to observe three things:  First, never to unfold to any one  Which casket ’twas I chose;
t: I am bound by oath to do the following three things: first, I can never tell anyone which casket it was that I chose.

og: next, if I fail  Of the right casket, never in my life  To woo a maid in way of marriage;
t: Second, if I fail to choose the right casket, I will never again court a woman in marriage.

og: lastly,  If I do fail in fortune of my choice,  Immediately to leave you and be gone.
t: And third, if I fail to make the right choice, I must immediately be gone and leave you.

og: To these injunctions every one doth swearThat comes to hazard for my worthless self.
t: Everyone must agree to these conditions who wants to risk it for me, as worthless as I am.

og: And so have I addressed me. Fortune now  To my heart’s hope! Gold, silver, and base lead.  “Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”
t: I am prepared to take the risk. May fortune smile upon the hopes in my heart! Gold, silver, and lowly lead. "He who chooses me must give up and risk all that he has."

og: You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.  What says the golden chest? Ha, let me see.
t: You'd need to look better before I give up or risk everything for you. What does the golden chest say? Hm, let me see.

og: “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”  “What many men desire”—that “many” may be meant  By the fool multitude that choose by show,  Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach;
t: "He who chooses me will get what many men desire." What many men desire—"many" may refer to the majority of fools who choose things based on appearance, trusting their eyes alone.

og: Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet  Builds in the weather on the outward wall,  Even in the force and road of casualty.
t: But you can't see through to what's on the inside. Those people are like martlet birds, who build their nests on the outer walls, obsessed with the outside.

og: I will not choose what many men desire  Because I will not jump with common spirits  And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.
t: I will not choose that which many men desire, because I will not join in with the common, barbarous multitudes.

og: Why then, to thee, thou silver treasure house.  Tell me once more what title thou dost bear.  “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”
t: Well, then, on  to the silver casket. Let's see again what your inscription says. "He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves."

og: And well said too—for who shall go about  To cozen fortune and be honorable  Without the stamp of merit?
t: I agree with this saying, because who should attain good fortune and honor if they don't deserve it?

og: Let none presume  To wear an undeservèd dignity.  Oh, that estates, degrees and offices  Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honor  Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!
t: No one should pretend to have more dignity than they really deserve. I wish estates, degrees, and jobs were not gotten corruptly, and that honor was given out based on merit!

og: How many then should cover that stand bare!  How many be commanded that command!
t: If that were the case, many great men would be put in their place, and many men who are in command now would be commanded by others.

og: How much low peasantry would then be gleaned  From the true seed of honor!  And how much honor  Picked from the chaff and ruin of the times  To be new varnished!
t: How many nobleman would be transformed into common peasants! And how many commoners would now shine with honor!

og: Well, but to my choice.  “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”  I will assume desert.—Give me a key for this,  And instantly unlock my fortunes here.
t: But anyways, it's time for me to make my choice. "He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves." I know what I deserve. Give me the key for this one, and I will unlock my fortune here right away.

og: Too long a pause for that which you find there.
t: You've taken too much time for what you've found inside.

og: What’s here? The portrait of a blinking idiot  Presenting me a schedule! I will read it.—
t: What's here? The portrait of an idiot holding something for me to read! I will read it.

og: How much unlike art thou to Portia!  How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!  “Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves”!
t: How different this picture is from one of Portia! This is so unlike what I hoped for and what I deserved! "He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves!"

og: Did I deserve no more than a fool’s head?  Is that my prize? Are my deserts no better?
t: Did I deserve nothing but a fool's head? Is that my prize? Do I deserve no better?

og: To offend and judge are distinct officesAnd of opposèd natures.
t: If I were to answer you, it might offend you.

og: What is here?
t: What does it say here?

og: “The fire seven times tried this,  Seven times tried that judgment is,  That did never choose amiss.  Some there be that shadows kiss.  Such have but a shadow’s bliss.
t: This silver chest was put in the fire seven times. The kind of judgment that never chooses wrongly can withstand as many tests. Some people kiss shadows, and only have a shadow of bliss.

og: There be fools alive, iwis,  Silvered o'er—and so was this.  Take what wife you will to bed,  I will ever be your head.
t: There are some foolish people covered with silver hair, and this casket had a silver covering as well. Take whatever wife you want to bed, but this fool's head will always be yours.

og: So be gone. You are sped.  Still more fool I shall appear”  By the time I linger here.
t: So go away. You must leave." The more time I linger here, the more foolish I'll seem.

og: With one fool’s head I came to woo,  But I go away with two.—
t: I came to woo Portia with the head of a fool, and now I leave with two fool's heads.

og: Sweet, adieu. I’ll keep my oath  Patiently to bear my wroth.”
t: Goodbye, sweet lady. I'll keep my word and bear my misfortune patiently.

og: Thus hath the candle singed the moth.O these deliberate fools! When they do choose, They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
t: And he's gone, like a moth that's flown too close to the flame. These fools think it over so much! And when they finally choose, their wits aren't enough and they lose.

og: The ancient saying is no heresy.Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.
t: The ancient saying is true: death and marriage are matters of destiny.

og: Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.
t: Come on, close the curtain, Nerissa.

og: Where is my lady?
t: Where is my lady?

og: Here. What would my lord?
t: I am here. What do you want?

og: Madam, there is alighted at your gate  A young Venetian,
t: Madam, a young Venetian has come to your gate.

og: one that comes before  To signify th' approaching of his lord,
t: He has gone ahead of his lord to tell you that his master is approaching.

og: From whom he bringeth sensible regreets,  To wit—besides commends and courteous breath—  Gifts of rich value.
t: He brings kind greetings and, in addition to niceties and courteous manners, valuable gifts.

og: Yet I have not seen  So likely an ambassador of love.
t: I haven't yet seen any ambassador of love as likely to succeed as this one.

og: A day in April never came so sweet  To show how costly summer was at hand,  As this forespurrer comes before his lord.
t: This man coming ahead of his lord is sweeter than a warm April day showing summer is near.

og: No more, I pray thee. I am half afeard  Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee,  Thou spend’st such high-day wit in praising him.—
t: Enough, please. I'm worried next you'll tell me he's your cousin, since you praise him so much.

og: Come, come, Nerissa, for I long to see  Quick Cupid’s post that comes so mannerly.
t: Come on, Nerissa, I want to see this messenger of Cupid who comes with such good manners.

og: Bassanio, Lord Love, if thy will it be!
t: God of Love, please let it be Bassanio!

og: Now, what news on the Rialto?
t: What news is there from the Rialto now?

og: Why, yet it lives there unchecked that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wracked on the narrow seas.
t: Well, there's an unproven rumor around there that Antonio has lost a ship carrying many riches on the English Channel.

og: The Goodwins I think they call the place—a very dangerous flat, and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall shiplie buried, as they say,
t: It supposedly happened on a very dangerous, deadly sandbar I think they call The Goodwins, where the remains of many tall ships lie buried.

og: if my gossip report be an honest woman of her word.
t: That is, if this gossip turns out to be true.

og: I would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever knapped ginger or made her neighbors believe she wept for the death of a third husband.
t: I hope this rumor is as false as a woman who tells her neighbors she has wept over the death of her third husband.

og: But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk,
t: But it is true, at the risk of talking your ear off,

og: that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, that I had a title good enough to keep his name company!—
t: that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, I wish I had something to call him that was good enough to be next to his name!

og: Come, the full stop.
t: Come on, get to the point.

og: Ha, what sayest thou? Why, the end is he hath lost a ship.
t: Hm, what are you saying? Oh, the point is that he has lost a ship.

og: I would it might prove the end of his losses.
t: I hope this is the last of his losses.

og: Let me say “Amen” betimes, lest the devil cross my prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.
t: Let me say "amen" now,  so that the devil doesn't interfere with that prayer, because here comes the devil himself, in the shape of a Jew.

og: How now, Shylock? What news among the merchants?
t: How are you, Shylock? What's the news among the merchants?

og: You knew—none so well, none so well as you—of my daughter’s flight.
t: You knew about my daughter's plan to run away, and no one knew better than you.

og: That’s certain. I, for my part, knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal.
t: That's for sure. For my part, I knew the tailor who made the wings she flew away on.

og: And Shylock, for his own part, knew the bird was fledged, and then it is the complexion of them all to leave the dam.
t: And as for Shylock, he knew his little birdie had wings and he knew she was likely to leave the nest.

og: She is damned for it.
t: She is damned for running away.

og: That’s certain—if the devil may be her judge.
t: That's certain, if you, the devil, are her judge.

og: My own flesh and blood to rebel!
t: I can't believe my own flesh and blood rebelled against me!

og: Out upon it, old carrion! Rebels it at these years?
t: No way, you old thing! You can't control your flesh even at your age?

og: I say my daughter is my flesh and blood.
t: I mean my daughter is my own flesh and blood.

og: There is more difference between thy flesh and hers than between jet and ivory, more between your bloods than there is between red wine and rhenish.
t: There's a greater difference between your flesh and hers than between coal and ivory, and a greater difference between your blood and hers than between red and white wine.

og: But tell us,do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea orno?
t: But tell us, have you heard whether Antonio has suffered any losses at sea or not?

og: There I have another bad match!—
t: With him I have more bad luck!

og: a bankrupt, a prodigal who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto, a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart.
t: He is a bankrupt, reckless with money, and he doesn't dare show his head in the Rialto. He is a beggar who used to be smug in the market.

og: Let him look to his bond. He was wont to call me usurer; let himlook to his bond.
t: Let him pay attention to his obligations. He used to always insult me for charging interest; well, let him pay attention to his obligations.

og: He was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him look to his bond.
t: He used to lend money as a Christian favor; let him pay attention to his obligations.

og: Why, I am sure, if he forfeit thou wilt not take his flesh.What’s that good for?
t: Well, I'm sure that if he doesn't pay you back you won't actually take his flesh. What would that be good for?

og: To bait fish withal. If it will feed nothing else, it will feed my revenge.
t: I could use it as bait for fish. If it will feed nothing else, it will at least feed my revenge.

og: He hath disgraced me and hindered me half a million, laughed at my losses, mocked at my gains, scorned my nation, thwarted my bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine enemies—and what’s his reason?
t: Half a million times he has disgraced me and hindered me. He has laughed at my losses, mocked my profits, scorned my people, messed with my business deals, turned my friends against me, and encouraged my enemies. And what's his reason for all this?

og: Iam a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions?
t: I am a Jew. Does a Jew not have eyes? Does a Jew not have hands, organs, senses, affections, passions?

og: Fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed?
t: Are we not fed with the same food, hurt by the same weapons, affected by the same diseases, healed by the same medicines, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as Christians? If you stab us, do we not bleed?

og: If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And ifyou wrong us, shall we not revenge? If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that. If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility? Revenge.
t: If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, should we not take revenge? If we are like you in all the other ways, we will resemble you in terms of revenge, too. If a Jew wrongs a Christian, what does he do? He takes revenge.

og: If a Christian wrong a Jew, what should his sufferance be by Christian example? Why, revenge.
t: If a Christian wrongs a Jew, what should the Jew do, following the Christian example? Why, he should take revenge.

og: The villainy you teach me I will execute—and it shall go hard but I will betterthe instruction.
t: I will follow your own villainous example, and I'll probably outdo my teachers.

og: Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house and desires to speak with you both.
t: Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house and wishes to speak with both of you.

og: We have been up and down to seek him.
t: We've been all over the place looking for him.

og: Here comes another of the tribe. A third cannot be matched unless the devil himself turn Jew.
t: Here comes another Jew. There couldn't be a third to match these two unless the devil himself turned into a Jew.

og: How now, Tubal? What news from Genoa? Hast thou found my daughter?
t: How are things, Tubal? What's the news from Genoa? Have you found my daughter?

og: I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her.
t: I often found word of her, but I couldn't find her.

og: Why, there, there, there, there! A diamond gone cost metwo thousand ducats in Frankfurt—the curse never fell upon our nation till now! I never felt it till now—Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels.
t: Well there you go! One of the diamonds she took cost me two thousand ducats in Frankfurt. Our people are cursed but I've never felt the curse until now! Two thousand ducats lost in that diamond, plus the other precious, precious jewels.

og: I would my daughter were dead at my foot and thejewels in her ear! Would she were hearsed at my foot and the ducats in her coffin!
t: I wish my daughter were dead here at my feet, with the jewels in her ear. I wish she were dead in her coffin right here and the ducats were inside it with her!

og: No news of them? Why, so. And I know not what’s spent in the search.
t: There's no news of them? All right, then. And I don't even know how much I'm spending to search for them.

og: Why thou, loss upon loss! The thief gone with so much, and so muchto find the thief—and no satisfaction, no revenge.
t: Loss on top of loss! The thief took so much, and now it takes even more money to find the thief. And still I have no satisfaction, and can find no revenge.

og: Nor no ill luck stirring but what lights o' my shoulders, nosighs but o' my breathing, no tears but o' my shedding.
t: No one feels bad luck, remorse, or grief as much as I do now.

og: Yes, other men have ill luck too. Antonio, as I heard inGenoa—
t: Other men have bad luck, too. I heard in Genoa that Antonio—

og: What, what, what? Ill luck, ill luck?
t: What, what, what? He's had some bad luck? Bad luck?

og: Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis.
t: Antonio has lost a ship coming from Tripoli.

og: I thank God, I thank God! Is ’t true, is ’t true?
t: I thank God, I thank God! Is it true? Is it true?

og: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.
t: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the shipwreck.

og: I thank thee, good Tubal. Good news, good news! Ha, ha,heard in Genoa.
t: Thank you, good Tubal. Good news, good news! Ha ha, good news heard in Genoa.

og: Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one nightfourscore ducats.
t: As I heard, your daughter spent eighty ducats in one night in Genoa.

og: Thou stickest a dagger in me. I shall never see my goldagain. Fourscore ducats at a sitting! Fourscore ducats!
t: You stick a knife in my heart. I will never see my gold again. Eighty ducats in one sitting! Eighty ducats!

og: There came divers of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.
t: Some of Antonio's creditors came with me to Venice and swore that he has no choice but to forfeit on his loan.

og: I am very glad of it. I’ll plague him. I’ll torture him. I am glad of it.
t: I'm very glad to hear that. I'll keep after him. I'll torture him. I'm glad about this.

og: One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.
t: One of them showed me a ring that your daughter gave him in payment for a monkey.

og: Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my turquoise. I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor. I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.
t: Damn her! You are torturing me, Tubal, by telling me this. That must have been my turquoise ring. Leah gave it to me when I was a bachelor. I would not have given it away for a whole jungle full of monkeys.

og: But Antonio is certainly undone.
t: But Antonio is certainly ruined.

og: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true.  Go, Tubal, fee me an officer.
t: Yes, that's true, very true. Go and get a police officer for me, Tubal.

og: Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—
t: Pay for his services two weeks in advance. I will take Antonio's heart if he forfeits on the loan. If he's no longer around in Venice, I can do what I want with my trading business without his competition.

og: Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue. Go, good Tubal. At our synagogue, Tubal.
t: Go, go, Tubal, and then meet me at our synagogue. Go, good Tubal. Meet me at our synagogue, Tubal.

og: I pray you, tarry. Pause a day or two  Before you hazard, for in choosing wrong  I lose your company.
t: Please, take your time. Wait a day or two before you take the risk, because if you choose incorrectly then you will have to leave me.

og: Therefore forbear awhile.  There’s something tells me—but it is not love—  I would not lose you, and you know yourself  Hate counsels not in such a quality.
t: So wait a while. For some reason—but not because of love—I don't think I'd . It's not hate that would make me feel this way.

og: But lest you should not understand me well—  And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought—  I would detain you here some month or two  Before you venture for me.
t: But just so that I'm clear, even though it's not a young woman's place to speak her thoughts, I would like to keep you here for a month or two before you make your choice.

og: I could teach you  How to choose right, but I am then forsworn.  So will I never be.
t: I could tell you what the right casket is, but I've sworn not to. I will never tell you the right choice, so there's a chance you will make the wrong choice.

og: So may you miss me.  But if you do, you’ll make me wish a sin,  That I had been forsworn.
t: And if you do, you'll make me wish I had sinned and broken my oath not to reveal the correct casket.

og: Beshrew your eyes,  They have o'erlooked me and divided me.  One half of me is yours, the other half yours—  Mine own, I would say.
t: Darn your eyes—in looking upon me they have divided me in two. One half of me is yours, and the other half is yours—I mean mine.

og: But if mine, then yours,  And so all yours. Oh, these naughty times  Put bars between the owners and their rights!
t: Well, if that half of me is mine, then it is yours, too, so all of me is yours. Oh, it's wrong that you are kept from what is yours!

og: And so, though yours, not yours. Prove it so.  Let Fortune go to hell for it, not I.
t: Although I am yours, I am not yet officially yours. Make it so I am. Let Lady Luck go to hell for this game of chance, not me.

og: I speak too long, but ’tis to peize the time,  To eke it and to draw it out in length,  To stay you from election.
t: I'm talking too much, but I'm doing that just to waste time, to draw out the minutes and stretch out the seconds, keeping you from making your decision.

og: Let me choose, For as I am, I live upon the rack.
t: Let me choose a casket, for as it is right now I am in torture.

og: Upon the rack, Bassanio? Then confessWhat treason there is mingled with your love.
t: In torture, Bassanio? Then confess what treason you have committed out of your love.

og: None but that ugly treason of mistrust  Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love.
t: I am guilty of nothing but some mistrust, which makes me worry I may never be able to enjoy my love.

og: There may as well be amity and life  'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.
t: Snow and fire go better together than any treason and my love.

og: Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rackWhere men enforcèd do speak anything.
t: Yes, but I am worried that you are only saying this because you are being tortured. Men say anything when forced to by torture.

og: Promise me life, and I’ll confess the truth.
t: Promise me my life and I'll tell you the truth.

og: Well then, confess and live.
t: Well then, confess the truth and you will live.

og: “Confess and love”  Had been the very sum of my confession.
t: "Confess and love," yes, that's it.

og: O happy torment, when my torturer  Doth teach me answers for deliverance!
t: What nice torture, when my torturer tells me the right thing to say to be let go!

og: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
t: But now let me try my luck and go to the caskets.

og: Away, then. I am locked in one of them.  If you do love me you will find me out.—  Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.
t: Let's go, then. My picture is locked in one of the caskets. If you truly love me, you will find it. Nerissa and everyone else, stand back.

og: Let music sound while he doth make his choice.  Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end,  Fading in music.
t: Let some music play while he makes his choice. Then if he loses, he will at least have a swanlike end, dying with a song.

og: That the comparison  May stand more proper, my eye shall be the stream  And watery deathbed for him.
t: To make him really like a swan, I'll cry a river for him to swim and drown in.

og: He may win,  And what is music then? Then music is  Even as the flourish when true subjects bow  To a new-crownèd monarch.
t: And if he wins, what will be the point of the music? In that case, the music will be like the flourish that plays when subjects bow to a newly crowned king.

og: Such it is  As are those dulcet sounds in break of day  That creep into the dreaming bridegroom’s ear  And summon him to marriage.
t: The sweet sounds that wake up a dreaming groom at dawn on his wedding day, and announce that his wedding is here.

og: Now he goes  With no less presence but with much more love  Than young Alcides, when he did redeem  The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy  To the sea monster.
t: And now he goes to the caskets looking as noble as Hercules, but more loving, when Hercules rescued the Trojan princess from the sea monster.

og: I stand for sacrifice.  The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives,  With blearèd visages come forth to view  The issue of th' exploit.—Go, Hercules!
t: I am like that princess, awaiting death, and these people standing by are like the Trojan wives looking on with teary eyes. Go, my Hercules!

og: Live thou, I live. With much, much more dismay  I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.
t: If you live, then I live. I am much more troubled here watching you than you are, doing the deed.

og: Tell me where is fancy bred.    Or in the heart or in the head?    How begot, how nourishèd?
t: Tell me where our desires come from:The heart or the head?How do they start, how do they grow?

og: Reply, reply.
t: Answer, answer.

og: It is engendered in the eyes,  With gazing fed, and fancy dies  In the cradle where it lies.
t: Love starts in the eyes,And grows with gazing, and it diesIn the cradle where it lies.

og: Let us all ring fancy’s knell  I’ll begin it.—Ding, dong, bell.
t: Let us all sound love's death knell.I'll start—Ding, dong, bell.

og: Ding, dong, bell.
t: Ding, dong, bell.

og: So may the outward shows be least themselves.  The world is still deceived with ornament.
t: The appearances of these may be deceiving. The whole world is tricked by fancy appearances.

og: In law, what plea so tainted and corrupt  But, being seasoned with a gracious voice,  Obscures the show of evil?
t: In the court of law, a corrupt and false plea can hide its own evil with a pleasant voice.

og: In religion,  What damnèd error, but some sober brow  Will bless it and approve it with a text,  Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?
t: In religion, a damned mistake can be covered over with the nice show of a blessing and some scripture to justify it.

og: There is no vice so simple but assumes  Some mark of virtue on his outward parts.
t: Every vice has some outward appearance of virtue.

og: How many cowards whose hearts are all as false  As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins  The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars,  Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk,  And these assume but valor’s excrement  To render them redoubted.
t: Many cowards with disloyal hearts have beards like brave Hercules and Mars, the god of war, even though they have no guts and are easily frightened.

og: Look on beauty,  And you shall see ’tis purchased by the weight,  Which therein works a miracle in nature,  Making them lightest that wear most of it.
t: And think of beauty, which can be bought by the pound in the form of cosmetics, which work miracles on nature, making the women that wear the most of it the most beautiful.

og: So are those crispèd snaky golden locks  Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind,  Upon supposèd fairness, often known  To be the dowry of a second head,  The skull that bred them in the sepulcher.
t: The curly golden locks that are tousled in the wind so nicely and seem beautiful often turn out to be a wig, made from a dead person's hair.

og: Thus ornament is but the guilèd shore  To a most dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf  Veiling an Indian beauty—in a word,
t: Appearances are like an inviting shore that leads to a dangerous ocean, a beautiful scarf hiding an actually undesirable Indian "beauty."

og: The seeming truth which cunning times put on  To entrap the wisest.
t: In short, appearances can be tricky and often deceive even the wisest.

og: Therefore then, thou gaudy gold,  Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee.  Nor none of thee, thou pale and common drudge  'Tween man and man.
t: Therefore, you gold, the solid metal that Midas couldn't eat, I will have nothing to do with you. And I'll have nothing to do with silver either, that pale metal that men pass between themselves as currency.

og: But thou, thou meagre lead,  Which rather threaten’st than dost promise aught,  Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence,  And here choose I. Joy be the consequence!
t: But you, humble lead, you who threaten more than you promise, your paleness moves me more than I can say, and I choose you. I hope I will be happy with my decision!

og: How all the other passions fleet to air,  As doubtful thoughts, and rash-embraced despair,  And shuddering fear, and green-eyed jealousy!
t: All other emotions are flying away—doubt and rash despair, shuddering fear, and green-eyed jealousy!

og: O love, be moderate. Allay thy ecstasy.  In measure rein thy joy. Scant this excess.
t: I must moderate my love and restrain my ecstasy. I must rejoice within good measure and not too much.

og: I feel too much thy blessing. Make it less,  For fear I surfeit.
t: I feel too overjoyed. I must be less joyous, for I fear that I have an excess of happiness.

og: What find I here?  Fair Portia’s counterfeit! What demigod  Hath come so near creation?
t: What do I find here? The picture of beautiful Portia! What godly artist has rendered the image so close to real life?

og: Move these eyes?  Or whether, riding on the balls of mine,  Seem they in motion?
t: Do the eyes in this picture move? Or do they just seem to as I look around?

og: Here are severed lips,  Parted with sugar breath. So sweet a bar  Should sunder such sweet friends.
t: Here are her lips, parted by her sugary breath—that such sweetness should part such sweet friends.

og: Here in her hairs,  The painter plays the spider and hath woven  A golden mesh t' entrap the hearts of men  Faster than gnats in cobwebs.
t: Here in her hair, the painter has been like a spider weaving a golden web to trap men's hearts faster than gnats are caught in cobwebs.

og: But her eyes—  How could he see to do them? Having made one,  Methinks it should have power to steal both his  And leave itself unfurnished.
t: But her eyes—how could the artist have painted these? Once he made one of them, I think its beauty would have distracted him so that he could not have painted the other.

og: Yet look how far  The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow  In underprizing it, so far this shadow  Doth limp behind the substance.
t: But my praise wrongs this image because my words fall as short of its beauty as it falls short of the real person it depicts.

og: Here’s the scroll,  The continent and summary of my fortune.
t: Here's a scroll that summarizes my fortune.

og: “You that choose not by the view,  Chance as fair and choose as true.  Since this fortune falls to you,  Be content and seek no new.
t: "You who choose not based on appearances have good luck and chose correct! Since you have gained this fortune, be content and don't seek anything more.

og: If you be well pleased with this  And hold your fortune for your bliss,  Turn you where your lady is  And claim her with a loving kiss.”
t: If this pleases you well and you are happy with your good fortune, turn to your lady and claim her with a loving kiss."

og: A gentle scroll. Fair lady, by your leave,  I come by note to give and to receive.
t: What a nice scroll. Fair lady, if you will permit it, I come to give you a kiss and thus receive you, as this note instructs me.

og: Like one of two contending in a prize  That thinks he hath done well in people’s eyes,  Hearing applause and universal shout,  Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt  Whether these pearls of praise be his or no—
t: I'm like someone who has competed for a prize and thinks that everyone's applause and shouts are for his success, but isn't quite sure because he's so stunned and isn't certain whether all this praise is for him or not.

og: So, thrice fair lady, stand I even so,  As doubtful whether what I see be true  Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.
t: That's how I feel now, beautiful lady, but three times more intense! I can't be sure of whether what I see is true until it is confirmed, signed, and ratified by you.

og: You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand  Such as I am.
t: You see me as I am, standing here, Lord Bassanio.

og: Though for myself alone  I would not be ambitious in my wish  To wish myself much better, yet for you  I would be trebled twenty times myself—  A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich—
t: I wish I were twenty times better than myself. I wouldn't be so ambitious as to wish that just for myself, but for you I would, and I would wish I were a thousand times more beautiful, and ten thousand times richer.

og: That only to stand high in your account  I might in virtue, beauties, livings, friends  Exceed account.
t: I wish I could be infinitely good in virtue, beauty, wealth, and friends only so that you would think highly of me.

og: But the full sum of me  Is sum of something which, to term in gross,  Is an unlessoned girl, unschooled, unpracticèd;
t: But all you get in me is an inexperienced girl, unschooled, naive. But at least you are getting a girl who is not too old to learn, and one who is not so stupid that she cannot learn.

og: Happy in this—she is not yet so old  But she may learn. Happier than this—  She is not bred so dull but she can learn.  Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit  Commits itself to yours to be directed  As from her lord, her governor, her king.
t: Best of all for you, you are getting a girl whose gentle spirit is fully committed to yours and is willing to be directed by you as if by her lord, her governor, or her king.

og: Myself and what is mine to you and yours  Is now converted. But now I was the lord  Of this fair mansion, master of my servants,  Queen o'er myself.
t: Myself and all that is mine is now yours. Just a minute ago I was in charge of this beautiful mansion, all its servants, and myself, as well.

og: And even now, but now,  This house, these servants, and this same myself  Are yours, my lord’s.
t: And now this house, these servants, and myself are all yours, my lord's.

og: I give them with this ring,  Which when you part from, lose, or give away,  Let it presage the ruin of your love  And be my vantage to exclaim on you.
t: I give them to you along with this ring. Don't ever lose it or give it away, or else that will be the sign of the ruin of your love and will give me reason to scold you.

og: Madam, you have bereft me of all words.  Only my blood speaks to you in my veins.
t: Madam, I don't know what to say, but the very blood in my veins speaks to you.

og: And there is such confusion in my powers  As after some oration fairly spoke  By a belovèd prince there doth appear  Among the buzzing pleasèd multitude,  Where every something, being blent together,  Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy,  Expressed and not expressed.
t: And I am as dumbfounded as a buzzing crowd after listening to a brilliant speech by a beloved prince, when everything seems to blend together in unexpressed and expressed joy.

og: But when this ring  Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence.  O, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!
t: When this ring leaves this finger, then life will leave me. When you see this ring off my finger, feel free to say that Bassanio is dead!

og: My lord and lady, it is now our time,That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper,To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!”
t: My lord and lady, it is now time for those of us who have stood by here and seen our wishes come true, to cry out, "Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!"

og: My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady,  I wish you all the joy that you can wish,  For I am sure you can wish none from me.
t: My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that I can wish you, so that there's none left for you to wish for from me.

og: And when your honors mean to solemnize  The bargain of your faith, I do beseech you  Even at that time I may be married too.
t: And when you have your wedding ceremony to solidify your union, I beg that I may be married at the same time.

og: With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.
t: With all my heart, I say yes, if you can find a wife.

og: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.  My eyes, my lord, can look as swift as yours.  You saw the mistress, I beheld the maid.  You loved, I loved.
t: I thank you, my lord, because you have found me one. My eyes are as quick as yours, my lord. While you were looking at the mistress, I was watching her maid. You fell in love, and so did I.

og: For intermission  No more pertains to me, my lord, than you.  Your fortune stood upon the casket there,  And so did mine too, as the matter falls.
t: Just like you, I don't want to wait. Your fortune depended on the casket there, and so did mine, as it turns out.

og: For wooing here until I sweat again,  And swearing till my very roof was dry  With oaths of love, at last—if promise last—  I got a promise of this fair one here  To have her love, provided that your fortune  Achieved her mistress.
t: While we were standing here, I was wooing and swearing oaths of love until at last this beautiful woman here promised me her love, so long as your luck held out.

og: Is this true, Nerissa?
t: Is this true, Nerissa?

og: Madam, it is, so you stand pleased withal.
t: Madam, it is true, if you don't mind.

og: And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith?
t: And are you being sincere and honest, Gratiano?

og: Yes, faith, my lord.
t: Yes, truly, my lord.

og: Our feast shall be much honored in your marriage.
t: It will be our honor to celebrate your marriage, as well, at our wedding feast.

og: We’ll play with them the first boy for a thousand ducats.
t: We can bet them a thousand ducats that we'll have a son before they do.

og: What, and stake down?
t: You want to stake down that money now?

og: No, we shall ne'er win at that sport and stake down. But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?
t: No, we'll never win the bet if I stake down. But who is this coming here? Lorenzo and his un-Christian friend? What's this, and Salerio, too, my old friend from Venice?

og: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither,  If that the youth of my new interest here  Have power to bid you welcome.
t: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome, if I can welcome you here so soon after winning ownership of this place.

og: By your leave,  I bid my very friends and countrymen,  Sweet Portia, welcome.
t: With your permission, I bid my friends and countrymen welcome, Sweet Portia.

og: So do I, my lord.They are entirely welcome.
t: And so do I, my lord. They are entirely welcome.

og: I thank your honor. For my part, my lord,  My purpose was not to have seen you here.
t: Thank you, your honor. I didn't actually intend to come see you here, my lord,

og: But meeting with Salerio by the way,  He did entreat me, past all saying nay,  To come with him along.
t: but I ran into Salerio on the way, and he begged me to come with him and I couldn't refuse.

og: I did, my lord. And I have reason for it. Signor AntonioCommends him to you.
t: That's true, my lord, and I have good reason for making him come with me. Sir Antonio sends this to you.

og: Ere I ope his letter,I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.
t: Before I open this letter, please tell me how my good friend Antonio is doing.

og: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind,Nor well, unless in mind. His letter there Will show you his estate.
t: He's not sick, my lord, unless his mind is sick, but he's not doing well either, unless his mind is doing well. His letter there will show you how he is faring.

og: Nerissa, cheer yond stranger. Bid her welcome.—  Your hand, Salerio. What’s the news from Venice?  How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?
t: Nerissa, cheer up that stranger. Welcome her here. Salerio, let me shake your hand. What's the news from Venice? How is good Antonio, that royal merchant, doing?

og: I know he will be glad of our success.  We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.
t: I know he'll be glad to hear about our romantic successes here. We are like the hero Jason after retrieving the golden fleece.

og: I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.
t: I wish you had won enough to replace what Antonio has lost

og: There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper  That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.
t: There are some serious matters in that letter that are making Bassanio's face go pale.

og: Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world  Could turn so much the constitution  Of any constant man. What, worse and worse?—
t: Some close friend of his must have died. Nothing else in the world could affect such a stoic man this much. What could it be, something even worse?

og: With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself,  And I must freely have the half of anything  That this same paper brings you.
t: If you'll allow it, Bassanio, I am half of you now, and I must bear half of whatever this letter brings you.

og: O sweet Portia,  Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words  That ever blotted paper.
t: Sweet Portia, these are some of the most unpleasant words that were ever written on paper.

og: Gentle lady,  When I did first impart my love to you,  I freely told you, all the wealth I had  Ran in my veins.
t: Gentle lady, when I first told you of my love for you, I admitted that the only wealth I had was the blood running through my veins:

og: I was a gentleman,  And then I told you true. And yet, dear lady,  Rating myself at nothing, you shall see  How much I was a braggart.
t: I was a nobleman by birth. And I spoke truly then. And yet, even saying that I had no money was a bit of braggery, as you will see.

og: When I told you  My state was nothing, I should then have told you  That I was worse than nothing, for indeed  I have engaged myself to a dear friend,  Engaged my friend to his mere enemy  To feed my means.
t: When I told you that my estate was worth nothing, I should have told you that it was worth less than nothing, for I am in debt to a dear friend, and put him in debt to his complete enemy in order to support me in coming here.

og: Here is a letter, lady,  The paper as the body of my friend,  And every word in it a gaping wound,  Issuing life blood.—
t: This letter here is like the body of my friend, and every word on it is like a gaping wound, spilling out blood.

og: But is it true, Salerio?  Have all his ventures failed? What, not one hit?  From Tripolis, from Mexico and England,  From Lisbon, Barbary, and India?  And not one vessel ’scape the dreadful touch  Of merchant-marring rocks?
t: But is this true, Salerio? Have all of his business ventures failed? Not one was successful? Not the one from Tripoli, or the ones from Mexico and England, the ones from Lisbon, the African coast, or India? Not one of his ships escaped the dreadful rocks that ruin merchants' fortunes?

og: Not one, my lord.  Besides, it should appear that if he had  The present money to discharge the Jew,  He would not take it.
t: Not one ship, my lord. And even if Antonio had the money to pay the Jew back, it seems he wouldn't take it.

og: Never did I know  A creature that did bear the shape of man  So keen and greedy to confound a man.
t: I've never seen an animal in the shape of a man as greedy as him and as eager to spite another man.

og: He plies the duke at morning and at night,  And doth impeach the freedom of the state  If they deny him justice.
t: He pleads his case to the Duke every morning and every night, and says that if he is denied justice it would be a disgrace to the state.

og: Twenty merchants,  The duke himself, and the magnificoes  Of greatest port have all persuaded with him.  But none can drive him from the envious plea  Of forfeiture, of justice, and his bond.
t: Twenty merchants, the Duke himself, and the highest-ranking Venetian noblemen have all tried to persuade him, but no one can change his mind about the matter of his loan, of justice, and what Antonio must forfeit.

og: When I was with him I have heard him swear  To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen,  That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh  Than twenty times the value of the sum  That he did owe him.
t: When I was with Shylock I heard him swear to his fellow Jews Tubal and Chus that he would rather have Antonio's flesh than twenty times the amount of money Antonio owes him.

og: And I know, my lord,  If law, authority, and power deny not,  It will go hard with poor Antonio.
t: And I am sure, my lord, that he will take the flesh of poor Antonio if the power and authority of the law allow him to.

og: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?
t: Is this man who is in such trouble your dear friend?

og: The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,  The best conditioned and unwearied spirit  In doing courtesies,
t: He is my dearest friend, and the kindest man. He has the best, untiring spirit of courtesy

og: and one in whom  The ancient Roman honor more appears  Than any that draws breath in Italy.
t: and is a better example of ancient Roman honor than any man alive in Italy.

og: What sum owes he the Jew?
t: What amount of money does he owe the Jew?

og: For me, three thousand ducats.
t: Three thousand ducats, on my behalf.

og: What, no more?  Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!  Double six thousand, and then treble that,  Before a friend of this description  Shall lose a hair through Bassanio’s fault.
t: What, is that it? Pay him six thousand ducats and scrap the agreement! Double six thousand, and triple it before allowing such a close friend to lose even a hair on account of Bassanio.

og: First go with me to church and call me wife,  And then away to Venice to your friend.
t: First go with me to the church so we can finalize our marriage, and then go to Venice to help your friend.

og: For never shall you lie by Portia’s side  With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold  To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
t: You will never lie by my side with a troubled soul. You will have enough gold to pay twenty times this petty debt. Once it is paid off, bring your true friend back with you.

og: When it is paid, bring your true friend along.  My maid Nerissa and myself meantime  Will live as maids and widows.
t: My maid Nerissa and I will be as chaste as maids and widows while you are gone.

og: Come, away!  For you shall hence upon your wedding day.  Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer.
t: Come on, let's go! You are going to leave me on our very wedding day. Welcome your friends here, and show them a good time.

og: Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear.  But let me hear the letter of your friend.
t: Since it's going to cost me a lot to have you, I will love you a lot. But first let me hear the letter from your friend.

og: “Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried. My creditors grow cruel.
t: "Sweet Bassanio, all my ships have been wrecked. My creditors have become cruel.

og: My estate is very low. My bond to the Jew is forfeit.
t: I don't have much money. I cannot pay the Jew back.

og: And since in paying it, it is impossible I should live, all debts are cleared between you and I if I might but see you at my death.
t: And since once the Jew takes the flesh from me I will die, all your debts to me are cleared, if only I can see you before I die.

og: Notwithstanding, use your pleasure. If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.”
t: Regardless, enjoy yourself. If your love for me is not enough to make you come to me, then my letter should not be either."

og: O love, dispatch all business and be gone!
t: My love, forget about everything else and go!

og: Since I have your good leave to go away,  I will make haste.
t: Since I have your permission to go away, I will hurry.

og: But till I come again,  No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay,
t: But until I come back, I will not sleep a wink.

og: No rest be interposer ’twixt us twain.
t: I won't rest at all until we are reunited.

og: Jailer, look to him. Tell not me of mercy.This is the fool that lent out money gratis.Jailer, look to him.
t: Jailer, keep an eye on him. Don't say anything about mercy. That's the fool that lent out money with no interest. Keep an eye on him, jailer.

og: Hear me yet, good Shylock.
t: Just listen to me, good Shylock.

og: I’ll have my bond. Speak not against my bond.  I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.
t: I'll have what you owe me. Don't try to reason your way out of it. I have sworn an oath that I will have what you owe me.

og: Thou calledst me dog before thou hadst a cause.  But since I am a dog, beware my fangs.
t: You called me a dog without any reason. Well, if I'm a dog then look out for my bite.

og: The duke shall grant me justice.—I do wonder,  Thou naughty jailer, that thou art so fond  To come abroad with him at his request.
t: The Duke will grant me justice. I wonder, you naughty jailer, why you like him so much to have come outside the jail with him as he asked.

og: I pray thee, hear me speak.
t: I beg you, listen to what I have to say.

og: I’ll have my bond. I will not hear thee speak.  I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.
t: I'll have what you owe me. I won't listen to anything you say. I'll have what you owe me, so don't say another word to me.

og: I’ll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool  To shake the head, relent and sigh, and yield  To Christian intercessors.
t: I won't be a lenient, dull fool and just shake my head, sigh, and give in to the Christians who plead on your behalf.

og: Follow not.  I’ll have no speaking. I will have my bond.
t: Don't follow me. I won't listen to you. I will have what you owe me.

og: It is the most impenetrable curThat ever kept with men.
t: He is the most stubborn beast that ever kept company with men.

og: Let him alone.  I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
t: Leave him alone. I won't follow after him anymore with my useless pleas.

og: He seeks my life. His reason well I know.  I oft delivered from his forfeitures  Many that have at times made moan to me.
