t: He wants my life. And I know why. Often I helped men who owed things to him at the last minute, when they begged me.

og: Therefore he hates me.
t: That's why he hates me.

og: I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.
t: I am sure the Duke will never allow him to take the pound of flesh.

og: The duke cannot deny the course of law.  For the commodity that strangers have  With us in Venice, if it be denied,  Will much impeach the justice of his state,  Since that the trade and profit of the city  Consisteth of all nations.
t: The Duke cannot deny the law. If he goes against the law, foreign merchants will lose confidence in the justice of Venice, and the city's profit relies on foreigners.

og: Therefore go.  These griefs and losses have so bated me,  That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh  Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.—
t: So go. I've been so worried and upset that I've hardly been eating anything; I don't know if I even have a pound of flesh to spare to my bloody creditor tomorrow.

og: Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come  To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
t: Well, let's go, jailer. I pray that Bassanio will come and see me pay his debt. That's all I care about now.

og: Madam, although I speak it in your presence,  You have a noble and a true conceit  Of godlike amity, which appears most strongly  In bearing thus the absence of your lord.
t: Madam, if I may say so in front of you, I believe you have the noble and true goodwill of a god, which is most apparent in the way you are dealing with the absence of your husband.

og: But if you knew to whom you show this honor,  How true a gentleman you send relief,  How dear a lover of my lord your husband,
t: If you knew the man whom you are helping, how honest a gentleman you are sending relief to, how close a friend of your husband he is,

og: I know you would be prouder of the work  Than customary bounty can enforce you.
t: then I know you would be even prouder of what you are doing than you are now.

og: I never did repent for doing good,  Nor shall not now;
t: I have never regretted doing good, and I will not do so now.

og: for in companions  That do converse and waste the time together  Whose souls do bear an equal yoke of love,  There must be needs a like proportion  Of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit,  Which makes me think that this Antonio,  Being the bosom lover of my lord,  Must needs be like my lord.
t: Friends who converse and spend time together a lot, who love each other equally, share similar manners and spirit, so I think that this Antonio, being so close to my husband, must be like him.

og: If it be so,  How little is the cost I have bestowed  In purchasing the semblance of my soul  From out the state of hellish cruelty!
t: If he is as good as my husband, then it is a small sum of money that I have spent in purchasing his rescue from hellish cruelty, since he resembles my soul, my husband.

og: This comes too near the praising of myself.  Therefore no more of it.
t: But I'm coming too close to praising myself. Therefore I won't say anything more.

og: Hear other things.  Lorenzo, I commit into your hands  The husbandry and manage of my house  Until my lord’s return.
t: Let's talk about something else. Lorenzo, I put you in charge of managing my household until my husband returns.

og: For mine own part,  I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow  To live in prayer and contemplation,  Only attended by Nerissa here  Until her husband and my lord’s return.
t: As for myself, I have made a secret vow to heaven to live a life of prayer and contemplation, accompanied only by Nerissa here, until both our husbands return.

og: There is a monastery two miles off,  And there will we abide. I do desire you  Not to deny this imposition,  The which my love and some necessity  Now lays upon you.
t: There is a monastery two miles away where we will stay. I ask you not to refuse the duty I've asked of you, which necessity and my love for you compels me to lay on you.

og: Madam, with all my heart.I shall obey you in all fair commands.
t: Madam, I will obey you with all my heart in your fair commands.

og: My people do already know my mind  And will acknowledge you and Jessica  In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
t: My servants already know my intentions and will obey you and Jessica in place of Lord Bassanio and me.

og: So fare you well till we shall meet again.
t: Farewell until we meet again.

og: Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!
t: May you have pleasant thoughts and happy times!

og: I wish your ladyship all heart’s content.
t: I wish you contentment, my lady.

og: I thank you for your wish, and am well pleasedTo wish it back on you. Fare you well, Jessica.
t: Thank you for your wish, and I am pleased to wish you the same. Farewell, Jessica.

og: Now, Balthazar,  As I have ever found thee honest true,  So let me find thee still.
t: Now, Balthazar, be honest and true as I have always found you to be in the past.

og: Take this same letter,  And use thou all th' endeavour of a man  In speed to Padua.
t: Take this letter and go as fast as you can to Padua.

og: See thou render this  Into my cousin’s hands, Doctor Bellario.
t: Give the letter to my cousin, Doctor Bellario.

og: And look what notes and garments he doth give thee,  Bring them, I pray thee, with imagined speed  Unto the traject, to the common ferry  Which trades to Venice.
t: Bring whatever notes and clothes he gives you and take them with you as you catch the ferry to Venice as quickly as you possibly can.

og: Waste no time in words,  But get thee gone. I shall be there before thee.
t: Don't waste any time chitchatting; just go right away. I will be in Venice before you.

og: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
t: Madam, I will go as quickly as I can.

og: Come on, Nerissa, I have work in handThat you yet know not of. We’ll see our husbandsBefore they think of us.
t: Come on, Nerissa, I have a plan you don't know about yet. We'll see our husbands before they even think of us.

og: Shall they see us?
t: Will they see us?

og: They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit  That they shall think we are accomplishèd  With that we lack.
t: They will, Nerissa, but we will be dressed as the very thing we currently lack: men.

og: I’ll hold thee any wager,  When we are both accoutred like young men,  I’ll prove the prettier fellow of the two,
t: I'll bet you anything that when we are disguised as men I'll be the more handsome one,

og: And wear my dagger with the braver grace,  And speak between the change of man and boy  With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps  Into a manly stride,
t: and I'll carry my dagger with more manly bravery. My voice will sound high-pitched like a teenager not yet a man, and I'll turn my womanly steps into a manly walk.

og: and speak of frays  Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies,  How honorable ladies sought my love,  Which I denying, they fell sick and died—  I could not do withal!—
t: I'll talk about fights like a bragging young man and tell white lies about how honorable ladies sought my love and practically died when I denied them because I couldn't be bothered with them!

og: Then I’ll repent  And wish for all that, that I had not killed them.  And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell,  That men shall swear I have discontinued school  Above a twelvemonth.
t: And then I'll repent and say that I wish I hadn't caused their deaths. I'll tell twenty of these little lies, and men will swear that I am just a year out of school.

og: I have within my mind  A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks  Which I will practice.
t: I have a thousand of these little tricks and brags up my sleeve that I'll use.

og: Why, shall we turn to men?
t: Are we going to turn to men?

og: Fie, what a question’s that  If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!
t: What a question that is! Turn to men for sex? Is your mind in the gutter?

og: But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device  When I am in my coach, which stays for us  At the park gate.
t: But come with me, and I'll tell you my whole plan when we're in the carriage waiting for us at the gate.

og: And therefore haste away,  For we must measure twenty miles today.
t: Hurry up, because we have twenty miles to travel today.

og: Yes, truly, for look you, the sins of the father are tobe laid upon the children. Therefore I promise ye I fear you.
t: Yes, truly, for remember that the sins of the father fall upon his children. Therefore I worry for you.

og: I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter.
t: I have always been straightforward with you, so I will tell you what I am troubled about.

og: Therefore be o' good cheer, for truly I think you are damned.
t: Cheer up, for I think you really are doomed.

og: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is buta kind of bastard hope neither.
t: There's one hope that can result in any good for you, but that's only an illegitimate hope.

og: And what hope is that, I pray thee?
t: And what hope might that be?

og: Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.
t: Well, you can hope that your father is not really your father, and that you are not really the Jew's daughter.

og: That were a kind of bastard hope indeed. So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.
t: That I'm an illegitimate child? That really is an illegitimate hope. In that case it would be the sins of my mother falling to me.

og: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother. Thus when I shun Scylla your father, I fall intoCharybdis your mother. Well, you are gone both ways.
t: Then I fear you are doomed because of your mother and your father. You're caught between a rock and a hard place with the two of them, and you are doomed with both of them.

og: I shall be saved by my husband. He hath made me aChristian.
t: Then I will be saved by my husband. He has made me  a Christian.

og: Truly, the more to blame he.
t: Then he is even more blameworthy.

og: We were Christians eno' before, e'en as many as could well live one by another.
t: We had enough Christians already, as many as could live well together.

og: This making Christians will raise the price of hogs. If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly havea rasher on the coals for money.
t: Making you a Christian will raise the price of pigs. If everyone starts to eat pork, it won't be long before we won't be able to cook some bacon for all the money in the world.

og: I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say. Here he comes.
t: Launcelot, I'll tell my husband what you are saying. Here he comes.

og: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.
t: I'll be jealous of you soon, Launcelot, if you keep taking my wife alone into corners like this.

og: Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo. Launcelot and I areout.
t: No, you don't need to worry about us, Lorenzo. Launcelot and I aren't getting along.

og: He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter,
t: He tells me flat-out that there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew's daughter,

og: and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.
t: and he says you are not a good Christian because in converting Jews to Christianity you raise the price of pork.

og: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than youcan the getting up of the Negro’s belly. The Moor is with child by you, Launcelot.
t: I can give a reply to that better than you can reply to the charge of sleeping with an African. The Moor is pregnant with your child, Launcelot.

og: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason. But if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more than I took her for.
t: There's more of the Moor than there should be. But even if she's less than an honest woman, she's more than I thought she was.

og: How every fool can play upon the word! I think the bestgrace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots. Go in, sirrah. Bid them prepare for dinner.
t: Any fool can play with puns! I think keeping quiet is the best sign of true wit. Empty talk is only good for parrots. Go and tell everyone to prepare for dinner.

og: That is done, sir. They have all stomachs.
t: They're already prepared, sir. They all have their stomachs.

og: Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you! Then bid them prepare dinner.
t: What a sharp wit you have! Go tell them to get dinner ready.

og: That is done too, sir. Only “Cover!” is the word.
t: That's done, too, sir. The table just needs to be set.

og: Will you cover then, sir?
t: Will you cover it, then

og: Not so, sir, neither. I know my duty.
t: No, sir, I won't. I know my place.

og: Yet more quarreling with occasion! Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant?
t: Even more annoying nonsense! WIll you exhaust your store of wit anytime soon?

og: I pray thee, understand a plain man in his plain meaning. Go to thy fellows, bid them cover the table, serve in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.
t: Please, understand what I plainly mean. Go to your fellow servants, tell them to cover the table and serve the meat, and we will then come in to have dinner.

og: For the table, sir, it shall be served in. For the meat, sir, it shall be covered. For your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and conceits shall govern.
t: Sir, I will serve the table and cover the meat. Come in for dinner, sir, whenever you like.

og: O dear discretion, how his words are suited!
t: What a way he has with words!

og: The fool hath planted in his memory  An army of good words, and I do know  A many fools that stand in better place,  Garnished like him, that for a tricksy word  Defy the matter.
t: That fool has an army of clever words at his disposal, and I don't know of any fool better at avoiding things with wordplay.

og: How cheerest thou, Jessica?  And now, good sweet, say thy opinion.  How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?
t: How are you doing, Jessica? And tell me your opinion, sweetie: how do you like Lord Basanio's wife?

og: Past all expressing.
t: I like her more than I can say.

og: It is very meet  The Lord Bassanio live an upright life,  For having such a blessing in his lady,  He finds the joys of heaven here on earth.
t: Lord Bassanio must have lived a very virtuous life, for he has found such a blessing in his wife that he seems to have found the joys of heaven here on earth.

og: And if on earth he do not merit it,  In reason he should never come to heaven.
t: And if he doesn't deserve this happiness on earth then he doesn't deserve it in heaven.

og: Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match  And on the wager lay two earthly women,  And Portia one, there must be something else  Pawned with the other, for the poor rude world  Hath not her fellow.
t: If two gods were making some heavenly bet and used two women on their wager, and one chose Portia, the other one wouldn't be able to find her equal anywhere on earth.

og: Even such a husbandHast thou of me as she is for a wife.
t: I am as good a husband to you as she is a good wife to Bassanio.

og: Nay, but ask my opinion too of that!
t: But ask my opinion on that matter, too!

og: I will anon. First let us go to dinner.
t: I will soon. Let's go to dinner first.

og: Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.
t: No, let me praise you now before we eat.

og: No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.Then howsome'er thou speak’st ’mong other thingsI shall digest it.
t: No, please, let's talk about it at the dinner table. Then, I'll digest what you say along with everything else.

og: Well, I’ll set you forth.
t: I won't disappoint.

og: What, is Antonio here?
t: Well, is Antonio here?

og: Ready, so please your grace.
t: I'm here and ready, as you please.

og: I am sorry for thee.
t: I am sorry for you.

og: Thou art come to answer  A stony adversary,
t: You have come here to face an adversary as stubborn as a rock,

og: an inhuman wretch  Uncapable of pity, void and empty  From any dram of mercy.
t: an inhuman wretch incapable of pity, completely empty of a single drop of mercy.

og: I have heard  Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify  His rigorous course.
t: I have heard that you have tried your hardest to change his rigid mind.

og: But since he stands obdurate  And that no lawful means can carry me  Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose  My patience to his fury,
t: But since he remains stubborn and there's nothing I can do legally to escape him,

og: and am armed  To suffer with a quietness of spirit  The very tyranny and rage of his.
t: I will meet his anger with patience and suffer his tyranny and rage quietly.

og: Go, one, and call the Jew into the court.
t: One of you men go and tell the Jew to come to the court.

og: He is ready at the door. He comes, my lord.
t: He is waiting outside the door. Here he comes, my lord.

og: Make room, and let him stand before our face.—
t: Make room, so that he can stand right in front of me.

og: Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too,  That thou but lead’st this fashion of thy malice  To the last hour of act,
t: Shylock, everyone thinks—and I agree—that you're just putting on a show of such malice until the very last minute,

og: and then ’tis thought  Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse more strange  Than is thy strange apparent cruelty,
t: and then you will at last show some mercy and remorse, something maybe even more shocking to see from you than your cruelty.

og: And where thou now exacts the penalty—  Which is a pound of this poor merchant’s flesh—  Thou wilt not only loose the forfeiture  But—touched with human gentleness and love,—  Forgive a moiety of the principal,
t: It is widely thought that you will not only forget about the penalty, a pound of this poor merchant's flesh, but will even let some of the money go, touched by human gentleness and love,

og: Glancing an eye of pity on his losses  That have of late so huddled on his back  Eno' to press a royal merchant down  And pluck commiseration of his state  From brassy bosoms and rough hearts of flint,  From stubborn Turks and Tartars never trained  To offices of tender courtesy.
t: out of pity for the losses that recently have come to weigh upon Antonio, which were enough to ruin a royal merchant, enough to make even the stone-hearted feel bad for him, enough to make even the stubborn Turks and Tartars, who aren't used to showing any courtesy, take pity on him.

og: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
t: We all expect a gentle reply to this from you, Jew.

og: I have possessed your grace of what I purpose,  And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn  To have the due and forfeit of my bond.
t: Your grace, I have told you what my intention is, and I have sworn by the holy Sabbath to take what is owed to me by our legal contract.

og: If you deny it, let the danger light  Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.
t: If you deny me this rightful penalty, it will reflect poorly upon your city and its freedom.

og: You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have  A weight of carrion flesh than to receive  Three thousand ducats. I’ll not answer that  But say it is my humour. Is it answered?
t: I'm sure you're going to ask me why I would choose to have a pound of flesh rather than the three thousand ducats I've been offered. I won't give you any answer other than to say I just feel like it. Is that enough of an answer?

og: What if my house be troubled with a rat  And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats  To have it baned? What, are you answered yet?
t: What if I had a rat in my house and I felt like paying ten thousand ducats to have it killed? Is that enough of an answer for you?

og: Some men there are love not a gaping pig,  Some that are mad if they behold a cat,  And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose,  Cannot contain their urine.
t: Some men dislike pigs, others go crazy if they see a cat, and others can't help but urinate when they hear the bagpipes.

og: For affection,  Mistress of passion, sways it to the mood  Of what it likes or loathes.
t: People's likes and dislikes are fickle and depend on a person's mood.

og: Now, for your answer:  As there is no firm reason to be rendered  Why he cannot abide a gaping pig;  Why he, a harmless necessary cat;  Why he, a woollen bagpipe, but of force  Must yield to such inevitable shame  As to offend, himself being offended—
t: Now, as for your answer: just as a man who dislikes pigs, or who dislikes a harmless cat, or who can't help but embarrassingly urinate at the sound of bagpipes, has no real reason for this,

og: So can I give no reason, nor I will not  (More than a lodged hate and a certain loathing  I bear Antonio), that I follow thus  A losing suit against him.
t: so I can give no reason, and won't give one (aside from my long-standing hate and loathing for Antonio), for following through on our agreement.

og: Are you answered?
t: Is that enough of an answer for you?

og: This is no answer, thou unfeeling man,To excuse the current of thy cruelty.
t: This is not a sufficient answer, you unfeeling man, to excuse your cruelty.

og: I am not bound to please thee with my answers.
t: I don't have to please you with answers.

og: Do all men kill the things they do not love?
t: Do all men kill things they dislike?

og: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?
t: Wouldn't everyone like to kill the things they hate?

og: Every offense is not a hate at first.
t: Not every act of wrongdoing must lead to hate.

og: What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?
t: What, would you let a snake sting you twice?

og: I pray you, think you question with the Jew?  You may as well go stand upon the beach  And bid the main flood bate his usual height.
t: Please, are you trying to reason with the Jew? You might as well go stand on the beach and ask the tide not to come in as high as is its custom.

og: You may as well use question with the wolf  Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb.
t: You might as well ask the wolf why he makes the ewe cry by eating the lamb.

og: You may as well forbid the mountain pines  To wag their high tops and to make no noise  When they are fretten with the gusts of heaven.
t: You might as well forbid the mountain pines from swaying with their high tops and tell them to make no noise when gusts of wind blow through them.

og: You may as well do anything most hard,  As seek to soften that—than which what’s harder?—  His Jewish heart.
t: You might as well do anything impossible as try to soften his Jewish heart—is there anything harder than his heart?

og: Therefore I do beseech you  Make no more offers, use no farther means,  But with all brief and plain conveniency  Let me have judgment and the Jew his will.
t: Therefore I ask you to make no more offers and use no more strategies to persuade him. Rather, let judgment be passed on me and let the Jew have his way without any more delay.

og: For thy three thousand ducats here is six.
t: Here's six thousand ducats instead of the three thousand for you.

og: If every ducat in six thousand ducats Were in six parts, and every part a ducat,I would not draw them. I would have my bond.
t: I wouldn't take your offer if it were six times six thousand ducats. I would still take what is legally owed to me.

og: How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?
t: How can you hope for mercy if you don't show it yourself?

og: What judgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?
t: Why should I worry about mercy when I've done nothing wrong?

og: You have among you many a purchased slave,  Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules—  You use in abject and in slavish parts  Because you bought them.
t: You have among you many purchased slaves that you use horribly like donkeys, dogs, or mules because you bought them.

og: Shall I say to you,  “Let them be free! Marry them to your heirs!  Why sweat they under burdens?  Let their beds  Be made as soft as yours and let their palates  Be seasoned with such viands”?
t: Should I tell you to free them and marry them to your heirs? Why do you make them sweat doing work? Why not let their beds be as soft as yours and let them eat the same fine foods as you?

og: You will answer,  “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.
t: If I said that, you'd tell me that the slaves are yours. I give you the same answer.

og: The pound of flesh which I demand of him  Is dearly bought. 'Tis mine and I will have it.
t: I have bought the pound of flesh that I demand from him. It is mine and I will have it.

og: If you deny me, fie upon your law—  There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
t: If you deny me, your laws mean nothing and there's no power to legal agreements in Venice.

og: I stand for judgment. Answer, shall I have it?
t: What's your opinion of that? Tell me what your response is.

og: Upon my power I may dismiss this court,
t: I have the power to dismiss this court,

og: Unless Bellario, a learnèd doctor,  Whom I have sent for to determine this,  Come here today.
t: unless Bellario, a learned doctor of law, comes here today. I have sent for him to decide about this case.

og: My lord, here stays withoutA messenger with letters from the doctor,New come from Padua.
t: My lord, there's a messenger standing just outside with letters from Bellario. He's just arrived from Padua.

og: Bring us the letter. Call the messenger.
t: Bring me the letter and call the messenger in.

og: Good cheer, Antonio! What, man, courage yet!The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all,Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood.
t: Cheer up, Antonio! Keep your courage, man! The Jew will have all my flesh, blood, and bones before I let him take one drop of blood from you on my account.

og: I am a tainted wether of the flock,  Meetest for death.
t: I am like a diseased sheep in a flock, one who ought to die.

og: The weakest kind of fruit  Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me.
t: The weakest fruit drops earliest to the ground. Let me drop like that fruit.

og: You cannot better be employed, Bassanio,  Than to live still and write mine epitaph.
t: The best thing you can do, Bassanio, is stay alive and write my epitaph.

og: Came you from Padua, from Bellario?
t: Have you come from Padua, from Bellario?

og: From both, my lord. Bellario greets your grace.
t: Yes, from both, my lord. Bellario sends his greetings, your grace.

og: Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?
t: Why are you sharpening your knife so eagerly?

og: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.
t: To cut what is owed to me off of that bankrupt man over there.

og: Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew,  Thou makest thy knife keen.
t: You should be sharpening your knife not on the sole of your shoe, harsh Jew, but on your hardened soul.

og: But no metal can—  No, not the hangman’s axe—bear half the keenness  Of thy sharp envy.
t: But no blade, not even the executioner's axe, is half as sharp as your sharp envy.

og: Can no prayers pierce thee?
t: Can no prayers pierce your stubborn heart?

og: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.
t: No, at least no prayers that you are smart enough to make.

og: O, be thou damned, inexecrable dog,  And for thy life let justice be accused!
t: Oh, damn you, you relentless dog! I hope justice comes to you!

og: Thou almost makest me waver in my faith  To hold opinion with Pythagoras  That souls of animals infuse themselves  Into the trunks of men.
t: You almost make me change my mind and agree with Pythagoras that the souls of animals enter the bodies of men.

og: Thy currish spirit  Governed a wolf who, hanged for human slaughter,  Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet,  And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam  Infused itself in thee,
t: You have the spirit of a dog, of a wolf that was killed for killing a human, but even as it was being killed its soul left its body and entered you while you were in your mother's pregnant belly.

og: for thy desires  Are wolvish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.
t: Your desires are wolfish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.

og: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond,  Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.
t: Unless you can rip the official seal off my contract, all you're doing by speaking so loudly is hurting your own lungs.

og: Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall  To cureless ruin. I stand here for law.
t: Take care of your mind, young man, or it wall fall apart with time. I support the law.

og: This letter from Bellario doth commendA young and learnèd doctor to our court.Where is he?
t: This letter from Bellario recommends a young and well-educated doctor of law to our court. Where is this man?

og: He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.
t: He is waiting nearby to hear whether you'll let him into the court.

og: With all my heart.—Some three or four of you  Go give him courteous conduct to this place.—
t: With all my heart, I'll let him in. Three or four of you go and courteously bring him here.

og: Meantime the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.
t: In the meantime, the court will hear Bellario's letter.

og: “Your grace shall understand that at the receipt of your letter I am very sick, but in the instant that yourmessenger came, in loving visitation was with me a young doctor of Rome.
t: "Your grace should understand that at the time you are reading this I am very sick, but when your messenger came to me I happened to have a young lawyer from Rome visiting.

og: His name is Balthazar. I acquainted him with the cause in controversy between theJew and Antonio the merchant.
t: His name is Balthazar. I told him about the controversial case between the Jew and Antonio the merchant.

og: We turned o'er many bookstogether. He is furnished with my opinion, which—bettered with his own learning, the greatness whereof I cannot enough commend—comes with him at my importunity to fill up your grace’s request in my stead.
t: We consulted many law books together. He knows my opinion on the matter, which has been enriched by his own intelligence, which I can't speak of highly enough, and he brings my opinion to you in my place.

og: I beseech you, let his lack of years be no impediment tolet him lack a reverend estimation, for I never knew soyoung a body with so old a head.
t: I beg you, don't let his young age make you underestimate him. I have never seen a young man with so much wisdom.

og: I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.”
t: I hope you will welcome him graciously, and you will see how worthy of my recommendation he is."

og: You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.And here I take it is the doctor come.—Give me your hand. Come you from old Bellario?
t: You all have heard what the educated Bellario has written. And I assume this is the lawyer coming now.  Give me your hand. Have you come from old Bellario?

og: I did, my lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: You are welcome. Take your place.Are you acquainted with the differenceThat holds this present question in the court?
t: Welcome. Take your place here. Are you familiar with the different sides of the case facing the court right now?

og: I am informèd thoroughly of the cause.Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?
t: I have been thoroughly informed about the case. Which one of these men is the merchant, and which is the Jew?

og: Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.
t: Antonio and old Shylock, both of you come forward.

og: Is your name Shylock?
t: Is your name Shylock?

og: Shylock is my name.
t: Shylock is my name.

og: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow,  Yet in such rule that the Venetian law  Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—
t: You are pursuing a strange case, but there is nothing under Venetian law that can stop you from proceeding.

og: You stand within his danger, do you not?
t: You are at his mercy, aren't you?

og: Ay, so he says.
t: Yes, as Shylock says.

og: Do you confess the bond?
t: Do you confess that you have broken the agreement?

og: I do.
t: I do.

og: Then must the Jew be merciful.
t: Then the Jew must be merciful.

og: On what compulsion must I? Tell me that.
t: Why must I? Tell me why.

og: The quality of mercy is not strained.  It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven  Upon the place beneath.
t: Mercy is not something that one is forced to practice. It falls easily like gentle rain from the sky.

og: It is twice blessed:  It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
t: It is a doubly blessed thing: it blesses both the person showing mercy and the person receiving mercy.

og: 'Tis mightiest in the mightiest. It becomes  The thronèd monarch better than his crown.
t: Mercy is most admirable in the mightiest men. It looks better on a king than his crown.

og: His scepter shows the force of temporal power,  The attribute to awe and majesty  Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings,  But mercy is above this sceptered sway.
t: A king's scepter is a symbol of his earthly power, a source of awe and majesty, which makes people respect and fear him. But mercy is above the power of the scepter.

og: It is enthronèd in the hearts of kings.  It is an attribute to God himself.
t: It dwells in the hearts of kings. It is an attribute of God himself.

og: And earthly power doth then show likest God’s  When mercy seasons justice.
t: And earthly power resembles God's power when justice is mixed with mercy.

og: Therefore, Jew,  Though justice be thy plea, consider this—  That in the course of justice none of us  Should see salvation.
t: Therefore, Jew, although you are seeking justice, consider this: if God sought justice against all of us with no mercy, we would all go to hell.

og: We do pray for mercy,  And that same prayer doth teach us all to render  The deeds of mercy.
t: We pray to God for mercy, and that same prayer should teach us all to show mercy to others.

og: I have spoke thus much  To mitigate the justice of thy plea,  Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice  Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.
t: This is what I have to say against your desire to seek justice and make the strict court of Venice carry out the merchant's punishment.

og: My deeds upon my head. I crave the law,The penalty, and forfeit of my bond.
t: My deeds are my responsibility. I want the law to be upheld, the penalty, that which he must forfeit because of the loan.

og: Is he not able to discharge the money?
t: Can he not pay the money back?

og: Yes, here I tender it for him in the court—  Yea, twice the sum.
t: Yes, here, I have the money for him in the court, even twice the sum.

og: If that will not suffice,  I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er,  On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.
t: If that is not enough, I will pay ten times the sum of money, or else give up my hands, my head, my heart.

og: If this will not suffice, it must appear  That malice bears down truth.—
t: If none of this is enough, then Shylock's malice overwhelms his honesty.

og: And I beseech you,  Wrest once the law to your authority.
t: And I beg you, bend the law to your authority.

og: To do a great right, do a little wrong,  And curb this cruel devil of his will.
t: Violate the law a little to do the right thing, and stop this cruel devil from getting what he wants.

og: It must not be. There is no power in Venice  Can alter a decree establishèd.
t: He must not do that. No one in Venice is powerful enough to alter an agreed-upon decree.

og: 'Twill be recorded for a precedent,  And many an error by the same example  Will rush into the state. It cannot be.
t: It would set a bad precedent, and many errors would be made by following it as an example. That cannot happen.

og: A Daniel come to judgment, yea, a Daniel!—O wise young judge, how I do honor thee!
t: A Daniel is now judging, yes, a Daniel! I honor you, wise young judge.

og: I pray you, let me look upon the bond.
t: Please, let me look at the agreement.

og: Here ’tis, most reverend doctor, here it is.
t: Here it is, most honorable lawyer, here it is.

og: Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.
t: Shylock, you are being offered three times the money you are owed.

og: An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?No, not for Venice.
t: An oath, an oath, I have made an oath by heaven. Should I backtrack on my oath and make my soul guilty of perjury? No, not even for all of Venice.

og: Why, this bond is forfeit!
t: Well, the penalty must be paid!

og: And lawfully by this the Jew may claim  A pound of flesh to be by him cut off  Nearest the merchant’s heart.—
t: The Jew may lawfully claim a pound of flesh to be cut off from near the merchant's heart.

og: Be merciful.  Take thrice thy money. Bid me tear the bond.
t: Be merciful, Shylock. Take three times the money. Tell me to tear up the agreement.

og: When it is paid according to the tenor.  It doth appear you are a worthy judge.  You know the law.
t: You can tear it up after the debt has been paid. It seems that you are a worthy judge. You know the law.

og: Your exposition  Hath been most sound. I charge you by the law,  Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar,  Proceed to judgment.
t: Your interpretation has been correct. I order you by the law, which you must obey, to go on and make judgment.

og: By my soul I swear  There is no power in the tongue of man  To alter me. I stay here on my bond.
t: By my soul I swear that nothing anyone can say can change my mind. I am here to get what is owed to me in the contract.

og: Most heartily I do beseech the courtTo give the judgment.
t: With all my heart I ask the court to issue its judgment.

og: Why then, thus it is: You must prepare your bosom for his knife.
t: Well, then, this is it: you must prepare your chest for his knife.

og: O noble judge! O excellent young man!
t: What a noble judge! What an excellent young man!

og: For the intent and purpose of the lawHath full relation to the penalty,Which here appeareth due upon the bond.
t: The intent and purpose of the law relates to the penalty, which has been agreed upon in the contract.

og: 'Tis very true. O wise and upright judge!How much more elder art thou than thy looks!
t: That's very true. What a wise and just judge! You are wise beyond your years!

og: Therefore lay bare your bosom.
t: Therefore, lay bare your chest.

og: Ay, his breast.So says the bond. Doth it not, noble judge?“Nearest his heart”—those are the very words.
t: Yes, his breast. That's what the contract says. Doesn't it, noble judge? "Near his heart"—those are the very words.

og: It is so. Are there balance here to weighThe flesh?
t: That's right. Do we have a scale here to weigh the flesh?

og: I have them ready.
t: I have it ready.

og: Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge,To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.
t: Have some surgeon on call nearby, Shylock, to stop Antonio's wound so he doesn't bleed to death.

og: Is it so nominated in the bond?
t: Is this spelled out in the contract?

og: It is not so expressed, but what of that?'Twere good you do so much for charity.
t: It is not said explicitly, but so what? It would be good for you to do it out of charity.

og: I cannot find it. 'Tis not in the bond.
t: I can't find it in the contract. It's not in the contract.

og: You, merchant, have you any thing to say?
t: You, merchant, do you have anything to say?

og: But little. I am armed and well prepared.—  Give me your hand, Bassanio. Fare you well.
t: Just a little. I am ready and well prepared. Give me your hand, Bassanio. Farewell.

og: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you,  For herein Fortune shows herself more kind  Than is her custom.
t: Don't grieve because I have fallen into this misfortune on your behalf, for even in this situation Fortune has shown herself to be kinder than she usually is.

og: It is still her use  To let the wretched man outlive his wealth,  To view with hollow eye and wrinkled brow  An age of poverty—
t: She usually makes a wretched man outlive his wealth, so that when he is old and has a wrinkled brow he looks on his own poverty.

og: from which lingering penance  Of such misery doth she cut me off.
t: She at least cuts me off from this lingering misery.

og: Commend me to your honorable wife.  Tell her the process of Antonio’s end.
t: Speak well of me to your honorable wife. Tell her how I met my end.

og: Say how I loved you. Speak me fair in death.  And when the tale is told, bid her be judge  Whether Bassanio had not once a love.
t: Tell her how I loved you. Speak well of me after I die. And after you tell her, let her be the judge as to whether you have ever had a loving friend.

og: Repent but you that you shall lose your friend,  And he repents not that he pays your debt.
t: Only regret that you are losing a friend, and know that your friend does not regret paying your debt for you.

og: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough,  I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.
t: If the Jew cuts deeply enough, I'll gladly pay the debt with my own heart.

og: Antonio, I am married to a wife  Which is as dear to me as life itself.
t: Antonio, I am married to a wife who is as dear to me as life itself.

og: But life itself, my wife, and all the world  Are not with me esteemed above thy life.
t: But I don't think as highly of life itself, my wife, and all the world as of your life.

og: I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all  Here to this devil—to deliver you.
t: I would lose all of it—yes, I would sacrifice everything to this devil standing here—to rescue you.

og: Your wife would give you little thanks for thatIf she were by to hear you make the offer.
t: Your wife wouldn't be too happy to hear that, if she were around to hear you make that offer.

og: I have a wife, whom I protest I love.I would she were in heaven, so she couldEntreat some power to change this currish Jew.
t: I have a wife, whom I swear I love. I wish she were dead and in heaven so that she could beg some holy power to come change this beastly Jew's mind.

og: 'Tis well you offer it behind her back.The wish would make else an unquiet house.
t: It's a good thing you're making this wish behind her back. Such a wish would upset her.

og: These be the Christian husbands.
t: These men are such Christian husbands.

og: I have a daughter.  Would any of the stock of Barabbas  Had been her husband rather than a Christian!—
t: I have a daughter and I wish a descendant of Barabbas had married her rather than a Christian!

og: We trifle time. I pray thee, pursue sentence.
t: We're wasting time. Please, let's hear the court's sentence.

og: A pound of that same merchant’s flesh is thine. The court awards it, and the law doth give it.
t: A pound of that merchant's flesh is yours. The court awards it, and the law gives it to you.

og: Most rightful judge!
t: You are a most honest judge!

og: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast.The law allows it, and the court awards it.
t: And you must cut this flesh off of his breast. The law allows it, and the court awards this to you.

og: Most learnèd judge, a sentence! Come, prepare.
t: Such a wise judge! The right sentence! Come, get ready.

og: Tarry a little. There is something else.  This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood.
t: Hold on a second. There's something else. This agreement doesn't give you any drop of blood.

og: The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.”  Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,
t: The literal words are "a pound of flesh." So take what is yours, take your pound of flesh,

og: But in the cutting it if thou dost shed  One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods  Are by the laws of Venice confiscate  Unto the state of Venice.
t: but if in cutting it off you shed one drop of Christian blood, your lands and goods will be confiscated by the state of Venice by the city's laws.

og: O upright judge!—Mark, Jew.—O learnèd judge!
t: What a just judge! Listen to her, Jew. Oh you wise judge!

og: Is that the law?
t: Is that the law?

og: Thyself shalt see the act.For as thou urgest justice, be assuredThou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.
t: You'll see for yourself. Just as you are bent on absolute justice, rest assured that more justice than you want would be served for you.

og: O learnèd judge!—Mark, Jew, a learnèd judge!
t: What a wise judge! Look, Jew, a wise judge!

og: I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go.
t: I'll take this offer, then: I'll take three times the money and let this Christian man go.

og: Here is the money.
t: Here is the money.

og: Soft!The Jew shall have all justice. Soft, no haste.He shall have nothing but the penalty.
t: Wait! The Jew will have all his justice. Wait, don't rush this. He will have nothing but the penalty he asked for.

og: O Jew! An upright judge, a learnèd judge!
t: Oh, Jew! This is an upright judge, a wise judge!

og: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.  Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more  But just a pound of flesh.
t: So get ready to cut off the flesh. Don't shed any blood, and don't cut any more or less than exactly one pound of flesh.

og: If thou takest more  Or less than a just pound, be it but so much  As makes it light or heavy in the substance  Or the division of the twentieth part  Of one poor scruple—
t: If you take more or less than a pound, even if it's just a twentieth lighter or heavier than the tiniest measure—

og: nay, if the scale do turn  But in the estimation of a hair,  Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.
t: in fact, if the scale is off by so much as a hair—you will be sentenced to death and all your goods will be confiscated.

og: A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.
t: This is a second Daniel! A Daniel, Jew! Now I've got you, you unbeliever.

og: Why doth the Jew pause? Take thy forfeiture.
t: Why is the Jew waiting? Take what's owed to you.

og: Give me my principal, and let me go.
t: Give me the money and let me go.

og: I have it ready for thee. Here it is.
t: I have it ready for you. Here it is.

og: He hath refused it in the open court.He shall have merely justice and his bond.
t: He has refused the money in the open court. He will have only justice and the penalty owed to him.

og: A Daniel, still say I, a second Daniel!—I thank thee, Jew, for teaching me that word.
t: I'll say it again: he's a Daniel, a second Daniel! Thank you, Jew, for teaching me that phrase.

og: Shall I not have barely my principal?
t: Will I not be given back even the original amount I lent?

og: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeitureTo be so taken at thy peril, Jew.
t: You will have nothing but the penalty owed to you, which you can take at your own peril, Jew.

og: Why then, the devil give him good of it!I’ll stay no longer question.
t: Well then, I hope the devil gets him for this! I won't stay here any longer to argue.

og: Tarry, Jew.  The law hath yet another hold on you.
t: Wait, Jew. The law has another requirement of you.

og: It is enacted in the laws of Venice,  If it be proved against an alien  That by direct or indirect attempts  He seek the life of any citizen,  The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive  Shall seize one half his goods.
t: It is enacted in the laws of Venice that if a foreigner is proved to have directly or indirectly attempted to kill a citizen, the citizen against whom he plotted will take half of his goods.

og: The other half  Comes to the privy coffer of the state,  And the offender’s life lies in the mercy  Of the Duke only 'gainst all other voice.
t: The other half is confiscated by the state. And the guilty man's life is in the hands of the Duke alone and his mercy.

og: In which predicament I say thou stand’st,  For it appears by manifest proceeding  That indirectly—and directly too—  Thou hast contrived against the very life  Of the defendant,  and thou hast incurred  The danger formerly by me rehearsed.
t: And I say that this law applies to you because it seems clear that you have contrived indirectly and directly against Antonio's life and now must face the danger I just elaborated on.

og: Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.
t: On your knees, then, and beg for the Duke's mercy.

og: Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself,
t: Beg that you can have permission to hang yourself.

og: And yet, thy wealth being forfeit to the state,  Thou hast not left the value of a cord.
t: But since your property is forfeited to the state, you don't even have enough to buy a rope to hang yourself with.

og: Therefore thou must be hanged at the state’s charge.
t: Therefore you must be hanged at the state's expense.

og: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit,  I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.
t: I pardon your life even before you ask, Shylock, so that you can see how different my spirit is from yours.

og: For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.  The other half comes to the general state,  Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.
t: Half of your wealth belongs to Antonio. The other half goes to the state, and this may be reduced to a simple fine if you show humility.

og: Ay, for the state, not for Antonio.
t: Yes, the money due to the state can be reduced, not the money due to Antonio.

og: Nay, take my life and all. Pardon not that.  You take my house when you do take the prop  That doth sustain my house.
t: No, take my life and everything. Don't pardon me. If you take the prop that holds up my house, you take my house, too.

og: You take my life  When you do take the means whereby I live.
t: By taking the means by which I live, you'd be taking my life.

og: What mercy can you render him, Antonio?
t: What mercy can you show him, Antonio?

og: A halter gratis, nothing else, for God’s sake.
t: Give him rope for hanging, at no charge. Nothing else, for God's sake.

og: So please my lord the duke and all the court,  To quit the fine for one half of his goods  I am content,
t: If it pleases my lord the Duke and the rest of the court, I am content to give up the half of his goods owed to me,

og: so he will let me have  The other half in use to render it  Upon his death unto the gentleman  That lately stole his daughter.
t: as long as he gives me the other half of his wealth so that I can invest it and, upon his death, give it to the gentleman that recently eloped with his daughter.

og: Two things provided more: that for this favor  He presently become a Christian;
t: And I want two more things: that he converts to Christianity,

og: The other, that he do record a gift  Here in the court, of all he dies possessed,  Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.
t: and that he makes a will here in this court in which he leaves everything upon his death to his son-in-law Lorenzo and his daughter.

og: He shall do this, or else I do recantThe pardon that I late pronouncèd here.
t: He will do this, or else I will take back the pardon that I just pronounced here.

og: Art thou contented, Jew? What dost thou say?
t: Are you content, Jew? What do you say to this?

og: I am content.
t: I am content.

og: Clerk, draw a deed of gift.
t: Clerk, draw up a will.

og: I pray you, give me leave to go from hence.I am not well. Send the deed after me,And I will sign it.
t: Please, give me permission to leave here. I am not well. Send the will after me, and I will sign it.

og: Get thee gone, but do it.
t: Go, but do sign it.

og: In christening shalt thou have two godfathers. Had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more—To bring thee to the gallows, not to the font.
t: When you are Christened, you'll have two godfathers. If it were up to me, you'd have ten more, to make twelve judges to send you to the gallows instead of the baptismal fountain.

og: Sir, I entreat you home with me to dinner.
t: Sir, I invite you to come to my home for dinner with me.

og: I humbly do desire your grace of pardon.I must away this night toward Padua, And it is meet I presently set forth.
t: I must humbly beg your pardon, your grace. I must leave tonight for Padua, and I really must be getting on my way now.

og: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.—Antonio, gratify this gentleman,For in my mind you are much bound to him.
t: I am sorry you don't have more free time to spend here. Antonio, thank this gentleman, for I think you owe him a lot.

og: Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend  Have by your wisdom been this day acquitted  Of grievous penalties,
t: Most worthy gentleman, my friend and I have been acquitted of serious penalties because of your wisdom.

og: in lieu whereof  Three thousand ducats due unto the Jew  We freely cope your courteous pains withal.
t: In return for this, we gladly offer you the three thousand ducats we were going to pay to the Jew, for all your troubles.

og: And stand indebted, over and above, In love and service to you evermore.
t: And we stand in your debt, and are always in your loving service.

og: He is well paid that is well satisfied.  And I, delivering you, am satisfied,  And therein do account myself well paid.
t: Satisfaction is the best reward. And I am satisfied to have rescued you, so I feel rewarded enough.

og: My mind was never yet more mercenary.  I pray you, know me when we meet again.  I wish you well, and so I take my leave.
t: I didn't help you out of desire for payment. Please, recognize me when we meet again. I wish you well, and now I must leave.

og: Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further.  Take some remembrance of us as a tribute,  Not as a fee.
t: Dear sir, I must try to persuade you further. Take some remembrance of us as a gift, not payment.

og: Grant me two things, I pray you:  Not to deny me, and to pardon me.
t: Grant me two things, please: don't refuse me, and pardon me for insisting.

og: You press me far and therefore I will yield.
t: You keep urging me and so I will yield.

og: Give me your gloves. I’ll wear them for your sake.
t: Give me your gloves. I'll wear them for your sake.

og: And for your love, I’ll take this ring from you.  Do not draw back your hand.
t: And as a token of your gratitude I'll take your ring. Do not pull back your hand.

og: I’ll take no more,  And you in love shall not deny me this.
t: I won't take anything else, and in your gratitude you shouldn't deny me this ring.

og: This ring, good sir—alas, it is a trifle.I will not shame myself to give you this.
t: This ring, good sir—oh, it's a trifle. It would be shameful to give you such a worthless little thing.

og: I will have nothing else but only this.And now methinks I have a mind to it.
t: I want nothing else, only this. And now my mind is set on it.

og: There’s more depends on this than on the value.
t: This ring is worth more than its monetary value.

og: The dearest ring in Venice will I give you,  And find it out by proclamation.
t: I will find out what is the best ring in all of Venice and give it to you.

og: Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.
t: But please let me keep this one.

og: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers. You taught me first to beg, and now methinksYou teach me how a beggar should be answered.
t: I see you make generous offers. First you told me to beg for something from you, and now you show me how a beggar is answered.

og: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife.And when she put it on, she made me vowThat I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.
t: Good sir, this ring was given to me by my wife and when she put it on my hand she made me swear never to sell it or give it away or lose it.

og: That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts.
t: That's what many men say as an excuse not to give gifts away.

og: An if your wife be not a madwoman,  And know how well I have deserved the ring,  She would not hold out enemy forever  For giving it to me.
t: And unless your wife is a crazy person, if she knows what I have done to deserve the ring she won't be mad forever at you for giving it to me.

og: Well, peace be with you.
t: Anyway, peace be with you.

og: My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.Let his deservings and my love withalBe valued against your wife’s commandment.
t: My lord Bassanio, let him have the ring. Let my love and the fact that he deserves it outweigh your wife's command.

og: Go, Gratiano, run and overtake him.Give him the ring and bring him, if thou canst, Unto Antonio’s house. Away, make haste.
t: Go, Gratiano, run and catch up with him. Give him the ring, and, if you can, bring him to Antonio's house. Go, hurry.

og: Come, you and I will thither presently.And in the morning early will we bothFly toward Belmont. Come, Antonio.
t: Come on, you and I will go to the house now. And early in the morning we will both hurry to Belmont. Come on, Antonio.

og: Inquire the Jew’s house out. Give him this deed,  And let him sign it.
t: Go to the Jew's house. Give him this contract and have him sign it.

og: We’ll away tonight,  And be a day before our husbands home.
t: We'll leave tonight and be home a day before our husbands return.

og: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.
t: Lorenzo will be happy to see this contract.

og: Fair sir, you are well o'erta'en.
t: Fair sir, I'm glad I caught up with you.

og: My Lord Bassanio upon more advice  Hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat  Your company at dinner.
t: After thinking it over, my Lord Bassanio has sent this ring to you and also invites you to dinner.

og: That cannot be.  His ring I do accept most thankfully.
t: I cannot make it to dinner, but I accept the ring gratefully.

og: And so I pray you tell him.
t: Please relate my thanks to Bassanio.

og: Furthermore,  I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.
t: Also, can you show my young man here to old Shylock's house?

og: That will I do.
t: I will show him.

og: I’ll see if I can get my husband’s ring,Which I did make him swear to keep for ever.
t: I'm going to see if I can get my husband's ring, which I made him swear never to give to anyone.

og: Thou mayst, I warrant. We shall have old swearing  That they did give the rings away to men.  But we’ll outface them, and outswear them too.—
t: I'll bet you can get it. They'll swear they gave the rings to men, but we'll outsmart them.

og: Away, make haste. Thou know’st where I will tarry.
t: Go, hurry. You know where I'll be waiting for you.

og: Come, good sir. Will you show me to this house?
t: Come on, good sir. Will you show me the way to the house?

og: The moon shines bright. In such a night as this,  When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees  And they did make no noise,
t: The moon is shining bright. On a night just like this one, when the sweet wind was gently kissing the trees and the branches weren't making any noise,

og: in such a night  Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls  And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents  Where Cressid lay that night.
t: on this kind of a night I think Troilus climbed the Trojan walls and sighed, looking toward the Greek tents where Cressida was sleeping that night.

og: In such a nightDid Thisbe fearfully o'ertrip the dewAnd saw the lion’s shadow ere himselfAnd ran dismayed away.
t: On this kind of night, Thisbe fearfully looked and saw the shadow of a lion and ran away, frightened.

og: In such a night Stood Dido with a willow in her handUpon the wild sea banks, and waft her loveTo come again to Carthage.
t: On a night like this, Dido stood on the shore by the wild sea with a willow branch in her hand, trying to get her lover to come back to Carthage.

og: In such a nightMedea gathered the enchanted herbsThat did renew old Æson.
t: On a night like this, Medea gathered the magical herbs that made old Aeson young again.

og: In such a night Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew,And with an unthrift love did run from VeniceAs far as Belmont.
t: And on a night like this, Jessica ran away from the wealthy Jew and ran from Venice as far as Belmont with her lover, who squanders money.

og: In such a nightDid young Lorenzo swear he loved her well,Stealing her soul with many vows of faith,And ne'er a true one.
t: On a night like this, young Lorenzo swore he loved Jessica well, and stole her soul with many vows of his faithfulness, but not one vow was true.

og: In such a nightDid pretty Jessica, like a little shrew,Slander her love, and he forgave it her.
t: On a night like this, pretty Jessica slandered her lover like a little shrew, and he forgave her for it.

og: I would outnight you, did nobody come.But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
t: I would get the better of you with this back-and-forth, if no one were coming. But listen, I hear the footsteps of a man.

og: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
t: Who's there, coming so quickly on this silent night?

og: A friend.
t: A friend.

og: A friend? What friend? Your name, I pray you, friend?
t: A friend? What friend? Tell me your name, please, friend.

og: Stephano is my name, and I bring word  My mistress will before the break of day  Be here at Belmont.
t: My name is Stephano, and I bring word that my mistress will be here at Belmont before the break of day.

og: She doth stray about  By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays  For happy wedlock hours.
t: She is meandering her way here, stopping at holy crosses to kneel and pray for a happy marriage.

og: Who comes with her?
t: Who comes with her?

og: None but a holy hermit and her maid.I pray you, is my master yet returned?
t: Just her maid and a holy hermit. If I may, has my master returned yet?

og: He is not, nor we have not heard from him.—  But go we in, I pray thee, Jessica,
t: No, he hasn't, and we haven't heard from him. But let's go inside, please, Jessica,

og: And ceremoniously let us prepare  Some welcome for the mistress of the house.
t: and let's prepare a formal welcome for the mistress of the house.

og: Sola, sola! Wo, ha, ho! Sola, sola!
t: Hey, hey! Hey there! Hey, hey!

og: Who calls?
t: Who's calling?

og: Sola! Did you see Master Lorenzo? Master Lorenzo, sola,sola!
t: Hey! Have you seen Master Lorenzo? Master Lorenzo, hey, hey!

og: Leave holloaing, man. Here.
t: Stop shouting, man. He's right here.

og: Sola! Where, where?
t: Hey! Where, where is he?

og: Here.
t: Here.

og: Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news. My master will be here ere morning.
t: Tell him there's a letter from my master for him full of good news. My master will be here before morning.

og: Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.  And yet no matter.  Why should we go in?—
t: Sweetie, let's go inside and wait for their arrival. Then again, what does it matter? Why should we go inside?

og: My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you,  Within the house, your mistress is at hand.
t: My friend Stephano, please go into the house and announce that your mistress is on her way.

og: And bring your music forth into the air.
t: And bring the musicians here outside.

og: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!  Here will we sit and let the sounds of music  Creep in our ears.
t: How sweet the moonlight shines on this bank! We will sit here and let the sounds of music slip into our ears.

og: Soft stillness and the night  Become the touches of sweet harmony.
t: This soft stillness and night are perfect for some sweet harmony.

og: Sit, Jessica. Look how the floor of heaven  Is thick inlaid with patens of bright gold.
t: Sit down, Jessica. Look how the sky, which is like the floor of heaven, is inlaid with bright gold stars.

og: There’s not the smallest orb which thou behold’st  But in his motion like an angel sings,  Still choiring to the young-eyed cherubins.
t: All the little orbs that you see up in the sky are like angels singing to the young cherubs in a choir.

og: Such harmony is in immortal souls,  But whilst this muddy vesture of decay  Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it.
t: That same kind of harmony is in our immortal souls, but while our souls are enclosed in our mortal, deacaying bodies, we can't hear it.

og: Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn!With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear,And draw her home with music.
t: Come now, and wake up the moon with your song! Pierce your mistress's ear with sweet touches and draw her home with music.

og: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
t: I am never cheerful when I hear sweet music.

og: The reason is your spirits are attentive.
t: That's because your spirit is busy paying attention to the music.

og: For do but note a wild and wanton herd,  Or race of youthful and unhandled colts,  Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,  Which is the hot condition of their blood—
t: Take the example of a wild, wandering herd, or a bunch of untrained young horses, running around, bellowing and neighing loudly, as they naturally do.

og: If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound,  Or any air of music touch their ears,  You shall perceive them make a mutual stand,  Their savage eyes turned to a modest gaze  By the sweet power of music.
t: If they happen to hear a trumpet play or any music, you would see them all stand still and their savage eyes would be turned into a modest gaze by the sweet power of music.

og: Therefore the poet  Did feign that Orpheus drew trees, stones, and floods  Since naught so stockish, hard, and full of rage,  But music for the time doth change his nature.
t: That's why the Roman poet Ovid wrote that the musician Orpheus made trees, stones, and bodies of water follow him, because there's nothing hard or strong enough not to be changed by music.

og: The man that hath no music in himself,  Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds,  Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils.
t: Any man who is not himself musical and is not moved by harmonious, sweet sounds is prone to commit treason, make tricky plots, and steal things.

og: The motions of his spirit are dull as night,  And his affections dark as Erebus.  Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music.
t: His spirit is dull and he has an affinity for things dark as hell. Don't trust a man like that. Listen to the music.

og: That light we see is burning in my hall.How far that little candle throws his beams! So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
t: That light we can see is coming from my hall. How far that little candle can throw its beams of light! A good deed done in an evil world is like such a little candle, shining in the dark.

og: When the moon shone we did not see the candle.
t: While the moon was shining, we couldn't see the candle.

og: So doth the greater glory dim the less.
t: That's like how greater glory dims lesser glory.

og: A substitute shines brightly as a king  Until a king be by, and then his state  Empties itself, as doth an inland brook  Into the main of waters.
t: A substitute shines as brightly as a king until a king is nearby, and then he's outshined.

og: Music, hark.
t: Listen, there's music.

og: It is your music, madam, of the house.
t: It's music coming from your house, madam.

og: Nothing is good, I see, without respect.Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.
t: Nothing is good, I see now, outside of the proper context. I think this music sounds much sweeter now than when played during the day.

og: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.
t: The silence of the night makes it better, madam.

og: The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark  When neither is attended,
t: The crow sings as sweetly as the lark when no one's paying attention to them,

og: and I think  The nightingale, if she should sing by day  When every goose is cackling, would be thought  No better a musician than the wren.
t: and I think that if the nightingale sang during the day while all the geese were cackling, people would think it sounded no better than a wren.

og: How many things by season seasoned are  To their right praise and true perfection!
t: So many things are made perfect and as they should be by good timing!

og: Peace! How the moon sleeps with Endymion  And would not be awaked.
t: But quiet. Look how the moon won't be awakened. It must be sleeping with Endymion.

og: That is the voice, Or I am much deceived, of Portia.
t: Unless I'm wrong, that's the voice of Portia.

og: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo—By the bad voice.
t: He knows me the same way a blind man knows a cuckoo—from its bad voice.

og: Dear lady, welcome home.
t: Dear lady, welcome back home.

og: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare,Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.Are they returned?
t: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare and we hope our prayers have sped them up. Have our husbands returned yet?

og: Madam, they are not yet,But there is come a messenger beforeTo signify their coming.
t: They haven't yet, madam, but there was just a messenger here who told us that they are coming.

og: Go in, Nerissa.  Give order to my servants that they take  No note at all of our being absent hence.—
t: Go inside, Nerissa. Order my servants not to give any sign of the fact that we have been gone.

og: Nor you, Lorenzo.—Jessica, nor you.
t: And don't you say anything about it, Lorenzo. Or you, Jessica.

og: Your husband is at hand. I hear his trumpet.We are no tell-tales, madam. Fear you not.
t: Your husband is coming. I hear his trumpet. We aren't tattletales, madam. Don't worry.

og: This night methinks is but the daylight sick.It looks a little paler. 'Tis a day Such as the day is when the sun is hid.
t: This night, I think, is just the daytime only sick—it looks a little pale. It's like a day when the sun is behind some clouds.

og: We should hold day with the Antipodes,If you would walk in absence of the sun.
t: If you want to walk around when the sun's not out, it would be as if we were having daytime at the same time as the opposite side of the world.

og: Let me give light, but let me not be light.
t: Let me give light, but let me not be light with my morals.

og: For a light wife doth make a heavy husband,  And never be Bassanio so for me.
t: That kind of a light wife makes her husband heavy with worry. And I never want Bassanio to be like that for me.

og: But God sort all! You are welcome home, my lord.
t: But it's all up to God! Welcome home, my lord.

og: I thank you, madam. Give welcome to my friend.This is the man, this is Antonio,To whom I am so infinitely bound.
t: Thank you, madam. Welcome my friend here. This is the man, this is Antonio, to whom I owe so much.

og: You should in all sense be much bound to him.For as I hear he was much bound for you.
t: You owe him being all tied up and arrested, since I hear he was tied up for you.

og: No more than I am well acquitted of.
t: But I have been well compensated for that.

og: Sir, you are very welcome to our house.It must appear in other ways than words, Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.
t: Sir, you are very welcome to our house. I must welcome you in ways other than words, so I will stop speaking such courtesies.

og: By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong.  In faith, I gave it to the judge’s clerk.
t: By the moon there I swear you are doing me wrong. Honestly, I gave it to the judge's clerk.

og: Would he were gelt that had it, for my part,  Since you do take it, love, so much at heart.
t: Damn him for that, because this is really upsetting you, my love.

og: A quarrel, ho, already? What’s the matter?
t: A lovers' quarrel already? What's the matter?

og: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring  That she did give me,
t: It's over a hoop of gold, a little ring she gave me with some writing carved on it,

og: whose posy was  For all the world like cutler’s poetry  Upon a knife, “Love me and leave me not.”
t: the poetry of a knife-maker, saying, "Love me and don't leave me."

og: What talk you of the posy or the value?
t: Why are you talking about the inscription or the value of the ring?

og: You swore to me when I did give it you  That you would wear it till your hour of death,  And that it should lie with you in your grave.
t: You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it until you died, and that it would lie in your grave with you.

og: Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,  You should have been respective and have kept it.
t: You should have kept it and respected at least me, if not your strong oaths.

og: Gave it a judge’s clerk! No, God’s my judge.  The clerk will ne'er wear hair on ’s face that had it.
t: You gave it to a judge's clerk! No, with God as my witness, I bet whoever you gave it to had no beard.

og: He will, an if he live to be a man.
t: He will have one, if he lives long enough to grow into a man.

og: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.
t: Yes, if a woman can grow into a man.

og: Now, by this hand, I gave it to a youth,  A kind of boy,
t: I swear by my hand that I gave it to a young man, a boy,

og: a little scrubbèd boy  No higher than thyself, the judge’s clerk,  A prating boy that begged it as a fee.
t: a little boy no taller than you, the judge's clerk, a talkative boy who begged for it as payment.

og: I could not for my heart deny it him.
t: My heart couldn't bear denying him the ring.

og: You were to blame, I must be plain with you,  To part so slightly with your wife’s first gift,  A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger  And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
t: I have to say, you are to blame for giving up your wife's first gift to you so easily, something stuck on your finger with oaths and riveted onto your flesh with good faith.

og: I gave my love a ring and made him swear  Never to part with it.
t: I gave my husband a ring and made him swear never to lose it.

og: And here he stands.  I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it  Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth  That the world masters.
t: And here he stands. I daresay I'd swear on his behalf that he would not leave it or take it off his finger for all the money in the world.

og: Now in faith, Gratiano,  You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief.  An ’twere to me, I should be mad at it.
t: Now, really, Gratiano, you are giving your wife cause for grief. If I were in her place, I'd be mad about it, too.

og: Why, I were best to cut my left hand offAnd swear I lost the ring defending it.
t: I'd be better off cutting off my left hand and swearing that I lost the ring while trying to defend it.

og: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away  Unto the judge that begged it and indeed  Deserved it too.
t: My lord Bassanio gave his ring away to the judge that begged for it and, indeed, deserved it, too.

og: And then the boy, his clerk,  That took some pains in writing, he begged mine.
t: And then the boy, the judge's clerk, who went through a lot of trouble writing things, begged for my ring.

og: And neither man nor master would take aught  But the two rings.
t: Neither the judge nor his clerk would take anything but the two rings.

og: What ring gave you my lord?Not that, I hope, which you received of me.
t: What ring did you give him, my lord? I hope not the one you got from me.

og: If I could add a lie unto a faultI would deny it. but you see my fingerHath not the ring upon it. It is gone.
t: If I were able to top off my mistake with a lie, I'd deny it, but you can see that my finger doesn't have the ring on it. It is gone.

og: Even so void is your false heart of truth.By heaven, I will ne'er come in your bedUntil I see the ring.
t: Your false heart lacks truth just like your finger lacks the ring. By heaven, I will never go to bed with you until I see the ring.

og: Nor I in yoursTill I again see mine.
t: And I will never go to bed with you until I see my ring again.

og: Sweet Portia,  If you did know to whom I gave the ring,  If you did know for whom I gave the ring,
t: Sweet Portia, if you knew to whom and for whom and for what reason I gave the ring,

og: And would conceive for what I gave the ring,  And how unwillingly I left the ring  When naught would be accepted but the ring,
t: and if you knew how unwillingly I parted with it when the man accepted no gift other than the ring,

og: You would abate the strength of your displeasure.
t: you wouldn't be so upset.

og: If you had known the virtue of the ring,  Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,  Or your own honor to contain the ring,  You would not then have parted with the ring.
t: If you had known the virtue of the ring, or if you had realized half the worth of the woman who gave it to you, or if you had thought about your own honor in keeping the ring, then you would not have given the ring away.

og: What man is there so much unreasonable,  If you had pleased to have defended it  With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty  To urge the thing held as a ceremony?
t: What kind of unreasonable man would have been so immodest as to demand it as a gift if you had defended it with any zeal?

og: Nerissa teaches me what to believe.  I’ll die for ’t but some woman had the ring.
t: I will follow Nerissa's example. I'll bet my life that you gave it to some woman.

og: No, by my honor, madam, by my soul,  No woman had it but a civil doctor,
t: No, I swear by my honor, madam, by my soul, I didn't give it to a woman, but rather to a doctor of law.

og: Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me  And begged the ring, the which I did deny him  And suffered him to go displeased away—  Even he that did uphold the very life  Of my dear friend.
t: He refused an offer of three thousand ducats and begged for the ring, which I refused to give him. I even let him go away all displeased. And he is the one who saved my dear friend's life.

og: What should I say, sweet lady?
t: What should I say, sweet lady?

og: I was enforced to send it after him.  I was beset with shame and courtesy.
t: I was compelled to send the ring after him. I felt compelled by shame and courtesy.

og: My honor would not let ingratitude  So much besmear it.
t: My honor would not let me show such ingratitude to the man.

og: Pardon me, good lady,  For by these blessèd candles of the night,  Had you been there I think you would have begged  The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.
t: Pardon me, good lady. I swear by these blessed stars that if you were there you yourself would have begged me to give the ring to the worthy lawyer.

og: Let not that doctor e'er come near my house!  Since he hath got the jewel that I loved,  And that which you did swear to keep for me,  I will become as liberal as you.
t: I hope that lawyer never comes near my house! Since he got the jewel that I loved and that you swore to keep for me, I will become as generous as you.

og: I’ll not deny him anything I have,  No, not my body, nor my husband’s bed.
t: If he comes around, I won't deny him anything I have. No, not my body, not even my marriage bed.

og: Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.  Lie not a night from home.
t: I'll know who he is, I'm sure. You'd better not spend a single night away from home.

og: Watch me like Argus.  If you do not, if I be left alone,  Now, by mine honor—which is yet mine own—  I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.
t: Watch me like the god Argus, with his hundred eyes. If not, if you leave me alone, I swear by my honor (which is still mine) that I'll sleep with that lawyer.

og: And I his clerk. Therefore be well advisedHow you do leave me to mine own protection.
t: And I'll sleep with his clerk. So be wary of leaving me to my own ways.

og: Well, do you so, let not me take him then.For if I do I’ll mar the young clerk’s pen.
t: Well, go ahead, but don't let me catch him. If that happens, I'll break the clerk's pen.
