og: I am th' unhappy subject of these quarrels.
t: All this unhappy quarreling is because of me.

og: Sir, grieve not you. You are welcome notwithstanding.
t: Sir, don't worry. You are welcome here regardless.

og: Portia, forgive me this enforcèd wrong,
t: Portia, forgive me for this mistake that I was forced into.

og: And in the hearing of these many friends  I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes  Wherein I see myself—
t: In front of our friends I swear to you by your own beautiful eyes in which I can see my image—

og: Mark you but that!  In both my eyes he doubly sees himself—  In each eye, one.
t: Listen to that! In both my eyes he sees two images of himself, one in each eye.

og: Swear by your double self,  And there’s an oath of credit!
t: If you swear by your double self, then that will be a serious oath!

og: Nay, but hear me.Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swearI never more will break an oath with thee.
t: Listen to me. Pardon me for this and by my soul I swear I will never break another promise to you.

og: I once did lend my body for his wealth,  Which but for him that had your husband’s ring  Had quite miscarried.
t: Once I put my body in danger to get him money, and that arrangement would not have gone well if it wasn't for the man who now has your husband's ring.

og: I dare be bound again,  My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord  Will never more break faith advisedly.
t: I dare to risk something again: I'll wager my soul that your husband will never again break a promise to you.

og: Then you shall be his surety. Give him this,And bid him keep it better than the other.
t: Then you will vouch for him. Give him this ring, and tell him to hold onto it better than the last one.

og: Here, Lord Bassanio. Swear to keep this ring.
t: Here, Lord Bassanio. Swear that you will keep this ring.

og: By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!
t: By heaven, this is the same ring I gave to the lawyer!

og: I had it of him. Pardon me, Bassanio,For by this ring, the doctor lay with me.
t: He gave it to me. Forgive me, Bassanio, because I slept with the lawyer for the ring.

og: And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano, For that same scrubbèd boy, the doctor’s clerk,In lieu of this, last night did lie with me.
t: And forgive me, my gentle Gratiano, because I slept with that same young boy, the lawyer's clerk, in return for this ring last night.

og: Why, this is like the mending of highwaysIn summer where the ways are fair enough!What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it?
t: This is like fixing highways in the summer when there's nothing wrong with them! We've been cheated on before we've even deserved it!

og: Speak not so grossly.—You are all amazed.
t: Don't speak like that. You are all shocked.

og: Here is a letter. Read it at your leisure.  It comes from Padua, from Bellario.
t: Here is a letter. Read it when you can. It comes from Padua, from Bellario.

og: There you shall find that Portia was the doctor,  Nerissa there her clerk.
t: In the letter you will learn that Portia was the lawyer and Nerissa was her clerk. Lorenzo will testify that I left here when you did and just got back now.

og: Lorenzo here  Shall witness I set forth as soon as you,  And even but now returned.
t: I haven't even entered the house yet.

og: I have not yet  Entered my house.—Antonio, you are welcome.  And I have better news in store for you  Than you expect.  [gives ANTONIO another letter]
t: Antonio, you are welcome here. And I have even better news in store for you than you expect.

og: Unseal this letter soon.  There you shall find three of your argosies  Are richly come to harbor suddenly.
t: Open this letter soon and you will read that three of your ships have suddenly come into harbor full of riches.

og: You shall not know by what strange accident  I chancèd on this letter.
t: You can't guess by what strange coincidence I happened upon this letter.

og: I am dumb.
t: I am flabbergasted.

og: Were you the doctor and I knew you not?
t: Were you the lawyer and I didn't recognize you?

og: Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold?
t: Were you the clerk that supposedly slept with my wife?

og: Ay, but the clerk that never means to do itUnless he live until he be a man.
t: Yes, but the clerk will never sleep with your wife unless he becomes a man.

og: Sweet doctor, you shall be my bedfellow.When I am absent then lie with my wife.
t: Sweet lawyer, you will share my bed tonight. And when I am gone, you sleep alongside my wife.

og: Sweet lady, you have given me life and living.For here I read for certain that my shipsAre safely come to road.
t: Sweet lady, you have given me life and a living. I read here for certain that my ships have safely returned.

og: How now, Lorenzo?My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.
t: How are you now, Lorenzo? My clerk has something good for you, too.

og: Ay, and I’ll give them him without a fee.
t: Yes, and I'll give it to you for free.

og: There do I give to you and Jessica,  From the rich Jew, a special deed of gift,
t: I am giving you and Jessica a will from the rich Jew.

og: After his death of all he dies possessed of.
t: After he dies, all that he owns is yours.

og: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the wayOf starvèd people.
t: Fair ladies, it is as if you are giving blessed bread to starving people.

og: It is almost morning,  And yet I am sure you are not satisfied  Of these events at full.
t: It is almost morning, and yet I am sure you aren't completely satisfied with the story of these events.

og: Let us go in,  And charge us there upon interr'gatories,  And we will answer all things faithfully.
t: Let's go inside and there you can ask us more questions, and we will answer them all honestly.

og: Let it be so. The first interrogatory  That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is  Whether till the next night she had rather stay,  Or go to bed now, being two hours to day.
t: Let's do that. The first question that my Nerissa will have to answer is whether she would rather wait until the next night or just go to bed now, since it's daylight in two hours.

og: But were the day come, I should wish it dark,  That I were couching with the doctor’s clerk.
t: But if the day should come, I would wish it were dark out, so that I could be sleeping with the lawyer's clerk.

og: Well, while I live I’ll fear no other thing  So sore as keeping safe Nerissa’s ring.
t: Well, as long as I live I'll worry about nothing else as much as about keeping Nerissa's ring safe.

og: Good day, sir.
t: Hello.

og: I am glad you're well.
t: It's good to see you.

og: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?
t: It's been a while. How is everything in your world?

og: It wears, sir, as it grows.
t: Up and down, up and down.

og: Ay, that's well known:  But what particular rarity?
t: So they say. But how weird is this—have you ever seen anything like it?

og: what strange,  Which manifold record not matches? See,  Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power  Hath conjured to attend.
t: Look at how amazing wealth and generosity are, how they can summon all these people to attend to them.

og: I know the merchant.
t: I know this merchant.

og: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.
t: I know both of them. The other one is a jeweler.

og: O, 'tis a worthy lord.
t: Such a worthy man, this lord.

og: Nay, that's most fix'd.
t: Definitely.

og: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,To an untirable and continuate goodness:He passes.
t: There's no one like him, almost born to be forever generous. He exceeds everyone else.

og: I have a jewel here—
t: I have a jewel right here—

og: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?
t: Oh please, let's see it. Is it for the Lord Timon?

og: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that—
t: If he will pay the price. But for that—

og: 'When we for recompense have  praised the vile,
t: "When we write poetry praising bad things for money,

og: It stains the glory in that happy verse  Which aptly sings the good.'
t: it ruins the better verse that rightly supports good things."

og: 'Tis a good form.
t: It's beautiful.

og: And rich: here is a water, look ye.
t: And expensive from the looks of it. Look at how it shines!

og: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedicationTo the great lord.
t: You are captivated by some task, writing a poetic dedication to Lord Timon.

og: A thing slipp'd idly from me.  Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes  From whence 'tis nourish'd:
t: Something slipped my mind. Poetry is like sap that oozes from the tree it gets its nutrients from.

og: the fire i' the flint  Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame  Provokes itself and like the current flies  Each bound it chafes. What have you there?
t: The spark that illuminates in the flint does not reveal itself until the flint is hit with something, but our gentle flame lights itself up and runs like a current over every surface it touches. What is that right there?

og: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?
t: A portrait. When will your book be published?

og: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.Let's see your piece.
t: After I have presented my poem to Timon. Let me see your painting.

og: 'Tis a good piece.
t: It's nice.

og: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.
t: Yes, it looks well made.

og: Indifferent.
t: It's not bad.

og: Admirable: how this grace  Speaks his own standing!
t: It is incredible how its beauty reflects the dignity of its subject! Look at the intelligence that twinkles in the eye!

og: what a mental power  This eye shoots forth! how big imagination  Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture  One might interpret.
t: There is a certain imagination that moves in its lip! Even though the painting is silent I feel like I could understand what the man is saying.

og: It is a pretty mocking of the life.Here is a touch; is't good?
t: It is a pretty good imitation of life. Here is a nice touch, do you like it?

og: I will say of it,It tutors nature: artificial strifeLives in these touches, livelier than life.
t: I will admit it does represent nature well. The purpose of artlies in these touches. They're almost livelier than life itself.

og: How this lord is follow'd!
t: Look at all the people following the lord!

og: The senators of Athens: happy man!
t: They're Senators of Athens. How lucky is he!

og: Look, more!
t: And more too!

og: You see this confluence, this great flood  of visitors.  I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,  Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug  With amplest entertainment:
t: Look at this huge crowd of flooding visitors. I have in this draft of my poem drawn the outline of a man beloved and embraced by the earthly world.earthly world.

og: my free drift  Halts not particularly, but moves itself  In a wide sea of wax:
t: I do not mean to represent particular people, but work in generalities as if my tablet were an entire sea of wax.

og: no levell'd malice  Infects one comma in the course I hold;  But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,  Leaving no tract behind.
t: Personal grudges do not affect even the smallest details of my writing. My creative process flies forth, strong as an eagle in flight, and leaves no trace of its earthly inspirations.

og: How shall I understand you?
t: How could I possibly understand what you're talking about?

og: I will unbolt to you.  You see how all conditions, how all minds,  As well of glib and slippery creatures as  Of grave and austere quality, tender down  Their services to Lord Timon:
t: I will unlock the meaning for you. Notice how people of all types and temperaments, whether smooth-talking and self-interested or serious and truthful, offer their services to Lord Timon.

og: his large fortune  Upon his good and gracious nature hanging  Subdues and properties to his love and tendance  All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer  To Apemantus, that few things loves better  Than to abhor himself:
t: His immense wealth and his kind and gracious nature overwhelm people, and buy him the approval of all sorts of people eager to love and attend him, from the flatterer whose face mirrors the wishes of his counterpart, to Apemantus, who loves nothing more than hating himself.

og: even he drops down  The knee before him, and returns in peace  Most rich in Timon's nod.
t: Even he bows down on his knees to Timon, and leaves peacefully after receiving Timon's approval.

og: I saw them speak together.
t: I did see them speaking to one another.

og: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill  Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount  Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures,  That labour on the bosom of this sphere  To propagate their states:
t: I have written down here that the goddess Fortune is sitting high atop her throne on a beautiful hill. The base of the mountain is surrounded by men of all stations, all dispositions, all trying their hardest to get richer while on earth.

og: amongst them all,  Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd,  One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,  Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;  Whose present grace to present slaves and servants  Translates his rivals.
t: Among all of these men, who watch Fortune attentively, I have one meant to represent Lord Timon, whom Fortune beckons to her, instantly transforming all of the other men, his rivals, into servants and slaves.

og: 'Tis conceived to scope.  This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,  With one man beckon'd from the rest below,
t: How well you've depicted the scene! This throne, this depiction of Fortune, and this hill—with one man beckoned from the rest below,

og: Bowing his head against the sleepy mount  To climb his happiness, would be well express'd  In our condition.
t: bowing his head before the great mountain on which Fortune sits, the source of his happiness—perfectly captures the human condition.

og: Nay, sir, but hear me on.  All those which were his fellows but of late,  Some better than his value, on the moment  Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
t: Sir, listen to some more of the poem. All of those men who were his equals, some of an even better rank, immediately follow him, so that his rooms are suddenly filled with attendants

og: Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,  Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him  Drink the free air.
t: who shower his ears with whispers of their sacrificial devotion to him, and make sacred even his mounting of a horse, as if it were only because of him that they could breathe.

og: Ay, marry, what of these?
t: Indeed, and what do we make of these people?

og: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood  Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants
t: The moment Fortune changes her mind and spurns this newly chosen man, all of those who depended on him

og: Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top  Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,  Not one accompanying his declining foot.
t: and who helped him on their hands and knees to reach the mountain top, they let him slip without even trying to save him.

og: 'Tis common:  A thousand moral paintings I can show  That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's  More pregnantly than words.
t: That is true. I can show you a thousand paintings of moral lessons that demonstrate Fortune's sudden victims more effectively than words ever could.

og: Yet you do well  To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen  The foot above the head.
t: But you'd do well nevertheless to show the Lord Timon that even we commoners can see that he is falling.

og: Imprison'd is he, say you?
t: You say that he is imprisoned?

og: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,  His means most short, his creditors most strait:
t: Yes, my good lord: he owes five talents, and even though he has such a small income, his creditors are insistent that he give it back right away.

og: Your honourable letter he desires  To those have shut him up; which failing,  Periods his comfort.
t: He wants a letter from you to those who have imprisoned him, without which he claims he'll have no comfort.

og: Noble Ventidius! Well;  I am not of that feather to shake off  My friend when he must need me.
t: Great Ventidius! Well, I am not the type of man to neglect a friend in need.

og: I do know him  A gentleman that well deserves a help:  Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt,  and free him.
t: I know that he is a gentleman that deserves assistance, which he will get. I'll pay the debt for his freedom.

og: Your lordship ever binds him.
t: Your lordship always makes him grateful.

og: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;  And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.
t: Give him my regards. I will send his ransom and when he is free I will ask him to come to me.

og: 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,  But to support him after. Fare you well.
t: It is not enough simply to help the weak stand. One must also support them after helping them up. Farewell.

og: All happiness to your honour!
t: Goodbye. Be well!

og: Lord Timon, hear me speak.
t: Lord Timon, would you hear me speak?

og: Freely, good father.
t: Speak freely, good man.

og: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.
t: You have a servant named Lucilius.

og: I have so: what of him?
t: I do. What of him?

og: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.
t: Most noble Timon, would you call the man before you?

og: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!
t: Is he here right now? Lucilius!

og: Here, at your lordship's service.
t: Here, at your lordship's service.

og: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,  By night frequents my house.
t: This man, Lord Timon, this dependent of yours, comes by my house at night.

og: I am a man  That from my first have been inclined to thrift;  And my estate deserves an heir more raised  Than one which holds a trencher.
t: I am a man who has been thrifty from the start, and my estate deserves an heir of better rank than this lowly waiter here.

og: Well; what further?
t: Okay. What, then?

og: One only daughter have I, no kin else,  On whom I may confer what I have got:  The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,  And I have bred her at my dearest cost  In qualities of the best.
t: I have just one daughter, no other family, to whom I can give my estate. She is a good-looking girl, barely old enough to be a bride, and I have raised her well to possess the most desirable qualities.

og: The man is honest.
t: This man is honest.

og: Therefore he will be, Timon:His honesty rewards him in itself;It must not bear my daughter.
t: And because of that your man should be too, Timon. His honesty ought to reward him in and of itself. But it should not earn him my daughter too.

og: Does she love him?
t: Does she love him?

og: She is young and apt:Our own precedent passions do instruct usWhat levity's in youth.
t: She is young and impressionable. You and I know well from our past passions what lighthearted thoughtlessness there is in youth.

og: Love you the maid?
t: Do you love this young woman?

og: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.
t: Yes, my lord, and she loves me back.

og: If in her marriage my consent be missing,  I call the gods to witness,
t: If I do not consent to her marriage, with the gods as my witness,

og: I will choose  Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,  And dispossess her all.
t: I will choose my heir from all the beggars of the world and deprive her of everything.

og: How shall she be endow'd,if she be mated with an equal husband?
t: What dowry should she have if she married a husband from the same social class?

og: Three talents on the present; in future, all.
t: About $6,000 immediately, and everything I have in the future.

og: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:  To build his fortune I will strain a little,  For 'tis a bond in men.
t: This gentleman Lucilius has served me for a long time. I will make some efforts to build his fortune, such is the duty of friendship.

og: Give him thy daughter:  What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,  And make him weigh with her.
t: If you give him your daughter I will match whatever you give and make him her equal.

og: Most noble lord,Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.
t: Most noble lord, if you swear this on your honor, she is his.

og: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.
t: I swear on my own honor.

og: Humbly I thank your lordship: never mayThe state or fortune fall into my keeping,Which is not owed to you!
t: I humbly thank you, my Lord. There is nothing that should come to me that I do not owe to you!

og: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!
t: Accept this gift I made for you, and long live my lord!

og: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:Go not away. What have you there, my friend?
t: Thank you. I will let you know when I'd like to hear your work. But don't go away.  What do you have there, friend?

og: A piece of painting, which I do beseechYour lordship to accept.
t: A painting, which I'm begging you to accept as a gift from me.

og: Painting is welcome.  The painting is almost the natural man;  or since dishonour traffics with man's nature,  He is but outside:
t: I do like paintings, and this one is  looks almost exactly like me. Sometimes, because men can be duplicitous, a man becomes only what he lets other people see from the outside.

og: these pencill'd figures are  Even such as they give out. I like your work;  And you shall find I like it: wait attendance  Till you hear further from me.
t: But these pencil marks in your painting are no more than they appear to be. I like your work, and I'll let you know soon how much I like it. Wait here until you hear from me.

og: The gods preserve ye!
t: God bless you!

og: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand;We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewelHath suffer'd under praise.
t: Well goodbye, gentleman. Give me your hands. We must dine together sometime soon. Sir, your jewel has gotten too much praise!

og: What, my lord! dispraise?
t: What? You don't like it?

og: A more satiety of commendations.If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd,It would unclew me quite.
t: It's gotten too much praise. If I paid you based on how much it's been praised, I would go broke.

og: My lord, 'tis rated  As those which sell would give: but you well know,  Things of like value differing in the owners  Are prized by their masters:
t: My lord, it is valued as much as its sellers would pay for it. But you know well that the value of things differs in the hands of different owners, and increases when they belong to masters of higher status.

og: believe't, dear lord,  You mend the jewel by the wearing it.
t: Believe me, dear lord, you would make this jewel more expensive just by wearing it.

og: Well mock'd.
t: That's a compelling sales pitch.

og: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,Which all men speak with him.
t: No, my good lord. He says what everyone says. They all agree.

og: Look, who comes here: will you be chid?
t: Uh oh, look who's coming. Will we be mocked?

og: We'll bear, with your lordship.
t: We'll bear the brunt of his insults with you.

og: He'll spare none.
t: He won't spare anyone.

og: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!
t: Good day to you, gentle Apemantus!

og: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.
t: Save your "good morrow" until after I've been nice to you—

og: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.
t: Why do you call them villains? You don't even know them.

og: Are they not Athenians?
t: Are they from Athens?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: Then I repent not.
t: Then I don't feel bad for saying it.

og: You know me, Apemantus?
t: Do you know who I am, Apemantus?

og: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.
t: You know I do, because I called you by your name, "villain."

og: Thou art proud, Apemantus.
t: You are too arrogant, Apemantus.

og: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.
t: I couldn't be less like you in that way, Timon.

og: Whither art going?
t: Where are you going?

og: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.
t: To knock the brains out of an honest Athenian.

og: That's a deed thou'lt die for.
t: That is a deed that you will die for.

og: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.
t: Only if doing nothing would be punishable by death under the law.

og: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?
t: How do you like this portrait, Apemantus?

og: The best, for the innocence.
t: It's fine, but it's just a painting.

og: Wrought he not well that painted it?
t: Didn't the painter do a good job?

og: He wrought better that made the painter; and yethe's but a filthy piece of work.
t: Whoever made the painter did a better job, and he himself is a terribly flawed piece of work.

og: You're a dog.
t: You're a dog.

og: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a dog?
t: Your mother is of the same species: what is she if I am a dog?

og: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?
t: Will you dine with me, Apemantus?

og: No; I eat not lords.
t: No, I do not eat lords.

og: An thou shouldst, thou 'ldst anger ladies.
t: If you did, you would anger the ladies.

og: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.
t: Oh, they eat lords; that's how they get pregnant.

og: That's a lascivious apprehension.
t: That's a crude sentiment.

og: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.
t: That's how you've interpreted it: it's your fault then.

og: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?
t: Do you like this jewel, Apemantus?

og: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost aman a doit.
t: Not as much as I value telling the truth, which doesn't cost a penny.

og: What dost thou think 'tis worth?
t: What do you think it's worth?

og: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!
t: It's not worth my thinking about it. What about you, poet?

og: How now, philosopher!
t: And you, philosopher!

og: Thou liest.
t: You lie.

og: Art not one?
t: Are you not a philosopher?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: Then I lie not.
t: Then I do not lie.

og: Art not a poet?
t: Aren't you a poet?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thouhast feigned him a worthy fellow.
t: Then you lie: look at your last poem, in which you pretended that you think Timon is a worthy man.

og: That's not feigned; he is so.
t: I wasn't faking that. He is a worthy man.

og: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thylabour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!
t: Yes he is worthy of you, and to pay you for your labor. He who loves to be flattered is worthy of the flatterer. God, if only I were a lord!

og: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?
t: What would you do then, Apemantus?

og: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.
t: The same that I do right now: hate a lord with all my heart.

og: What, thyself?
t: What? Yourself?

og: Ay.
t: Yes.

og: Wherefore?
t: Why?

og: That I had no angry wit to be a lord.Art not thou a merchant?
t: Because I would have lost the angry wit I now have if I were a lord. Aren't you a merchant?

og: Ay, Apemantus.
t: Yes, Apemantus.

og: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!
t: I hope your business destroys you—that is, if the gods don't first!

og: If traffic do it, the gods do it.
t: If my business ruins me, the gods ruin me.

og: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!
t: Business is your god, and your god will ruin you.

og: What trumpet's that?
t: What's the trumpet for?

og: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,All of companionship.
t: It is Alcibiades and twenty horsemen, all together.

og: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us.
t: Welcome them and guide them to us.

og: You must needs dine with me: go not you henceTill I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.
t: You must dine with me. Don't go until I have thanked you for your painting, and when dinner is over show me your latest work. I will be happy to see you.

og: Most welcome, sir!
t: Welcome!

og: So, so, there!  Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
t: Yes, yes! Pains flare up and wither your tender joints!

og: That there should be small love 'mongst these  sweet knaves,  And all this courtesy!
t: That there can be so much disdain amongst these villains, who act with such politeness! All this politeness!

og: The strain of man's bred out  Into baboon and monkey.
t: The human species has bred itself into baboons and monkeys.

og: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feedMost hungerly on your sight.
t: Sir your presence has saved me from my longing, and I feed most hungrily at the sight of you.

og: Right welcome, sir!Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous timeIn different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.
t: You are welcome, sir! Before you depart, you'll have a wonderful time filled with many pleasures. Please, let's go inside!

og: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?
t: What time of day is it Apemantus?

og: Time to be honest.
t: Time to be honest.

og: That time serves still.
t: It is always that time.

og: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.
t: Shame on you then for having failed to do so.

og: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?
t: Are you going to Lord Timon's feast?

og: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.
t: Yes, to see idiots fill up on meat and fools get drunk on wine.

og: Fare thee well, fare thee well.
t: Farewell, farewell.

og: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.
t: You are a fool to bid me farewell twice.

og: Why, Apemantus?
t: Why, Apemantus?

og: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean togive thee none.
t: You should have kept one for yourself, because I have no intention of giving you one.

og: Hang thyself!
t: Go kill yourself!

og: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thyrequests to thy friend.
t: No, I won't do anything you ask me to do: go ask that of your friend.

og: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!
t: Go away you angry dog, or I'll kick you!

og: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' the ass.
t: I will run away like a dog so your heels catch nothing but my ass!

og: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in,And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoesThe very heart of kindness.
t: Apemantus is inhuman. Come, shall we go in and taste Lord Timon's bounty? He exceeds the meaning of the word kindness.

og: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,  Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays  Sevenfold above itself;
t: Kindness pours out of him. Even Plutus, the god of gold, seems like just a mere apprentice of Timon's. There is no service given him that he does not repay seven times in value.

og: no gift to him,  But breeds the giver a return exceeding  All use of quittance.
t: There is no gift he receives that doesn't return to the giver a sense of value exceeding the price paid for it.

og: The noblest mind he carriesThat ever govern'd man.
t: He has the noblest mind any man has ever had.

og: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?
t: May he live a long and wealthy life! Shall we go in?

og: I'll keep you company.
t: I'll accompany you.

og: Most honour'd Timon,  It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,  And call him to long peace.  He is gone happy, and has left me rich:
t: Honorable Timon, it has pleased the gods to remember the times of my father and to call him to a long peace in death. He is now happily gone and has left me rich.

og: Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound  To your free heart, I do return those talents,  Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help  I derived liberty.
t: Virtue has thus dictated, then, that I honor your generosity. I return all of that money you lent me, and double the amount in thanks and service to you, who helped free me.

og: O, by no means,  Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:  I gave it freely ever; and there's none  Can truly say he gives, if he receives:
t: By no means, good Ventidius. I helped you out of love and gave everything to you freely. No one can actually say that he gives if he receives something in return.

og: If our betters play at that game, we must not dare  To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.
t: The politicians play those kind of crafty games, and we must not do the same. If rich people ought to have faults, let them be good faults.

og: A noble spirit!
t: What a noble spirit!

og: Nay, my lords,
t: No, my lords.

og: Ceremony was but devised at first  To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,  Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;  But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
t: These kinds of formalities were first devised to give meaning to meaningless deeds, hollow greetings, and false kindness. It is sad that it is shown here, where true friendship and ceremony is not needed.

og: Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes  Than my fortunes to me.
t: Please sit down. You are more welcome to my fortunes than they are welcome to me.

og: My lord, we always have confess'd it.
t: My lord, we have always said the same.

og: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?
t: Haha, you've confessed it? And been hanged for the sin, have you not?

og: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.
t: Apemantus, you (and your humor) are welcome here.

og: No;You shall not make me welcome:I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.
t: No, I am not. You will not let me be welcome, because I have come to remove you.

og: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there  Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame.
t: Ah, you are a mean-spirited man. You have an unbecoming disposition and it's pretty sad.

og: They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;' but yond  man is ever angry.
t: My lords, they say, "anger is a brief madness," but this man here is angry all the time!

og: Go, let him have a table by  himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is  he fit for't, indeed.
t: Let him have a table for himself, for he neither wants company nor seems deserving of it.

og: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come toobserve; I give thee warning on't.
t: Let me stay at your own risk, Timon. I come only to observe and am giving you fair warning abo that.

og: I take no heed of thee; thou'rt an Athenian,therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;prithee, let my meat make thee silent.
t: I do not worry about your insults. You are an Athenian and therefore welcome. I myself would have no power to silence you, so please, just let my food keep you quiet.

og: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should  ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of  men eat Timon, and he sees 'em not!
t: I don't want your food. It would choke me because it is offered to flatterers, and I would never flatter you. Oh you gods, what number of men eat Timon's meat, and he doesn't even notice.

og: It grieves me  to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood;  and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.
t: It makes me sad to see so many dip their meat into the blood of one man, and the crazy thing about it all is that he encourages them to do it!

og: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:  Methinks they should invite them without knives;  Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.
t: I wonder how men dare to trust other men. They should be cautious of letting them bring their knives to such a feast. It would keep them from eating so much, and probably save their lives too!

og: There's much example for't; the fellow that sits  next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the  breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest  man to kill him: 't has been proved.
t: There are many examples of it: the man sitting next to him now, breaks bread with him, and shares his germs as he drinks from the same glass—that is the man most ready to kill him. It is certain.

og: If I were a  huge man, I should fear to drink at meals;  Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes:  Great men should drink with harness on their throats.
t: If I were a man of higher rank, I would fear drinking at my meals, because they might be able to see my neck's tenderest spots while I tilted my head back. Great men should drink with armor on their throats.

og: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.
t: Health to everyone!

og: Let it flow this way, my good lord.
t: I hope it flows this way, my lord!

og: Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides  well. Those healths will make thee and thy state  look ill, Timon.
t: Flow this way! What a fine man! He keeps time well. Those wishes of health will make you and your state sorry, Timon.

og: Here's that which is too weak to  be a sinner, honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire:  This and my food are equals; there's no odds:  Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.
t: Here before you stands a man not like the wine you toast with, but like honest water, which is too weak a drink to be a sinner and never abandoned a man in times of need. This food for thought is equal to the food you offer, no doubt. Men who attend feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.

og: Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;  I pray for no man but myself:
t: Immortal gods, I do not want money; I pray for no one other than myself.

og: Grant I may never prove so fond,  To trust man on his oath or bond;  Or a harlot, for her weeping;  Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping:  Or a keeper with my freedom;  Or my friends, if I should need 'em.
t: Please grant that I never become so dumb as to trust a man on his oath or promise; or a whore, when she weeps; or a dog, that seems to sleep; or a jailer with my freedom; or my friends if I ever need them.

og: Amen. So fall to't:  Rich men sin, and I eat root.
t: Amen. So let's get to eating: rich men will sin while I eat my root.

og: Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!
t: This food will do your heart much good, Apemantus!

og: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.
t: Captain Alcibiades, you seem to long for battle now.

og: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.
t: I always long to serve you, my lord.

og: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than adinner of friends.
t: It seems you would rather be at a breakfast with your enemies than a dinner with your friends.

og: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meatlike 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.
t: Only if my enemies are bleeding to death, my lord, there's no food like that. I would wish such a feast on my best friend.

og: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then,that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!
t: If only all these fat men here were your enemies, then you might kill them and bring them to me.

og: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that youwould once use our hearts, whereby we might expresssome part of our zeals, we should think ourselvesfor ever perfect.
t: Could we have the pleasure, my lord Timon, of serving you in some way? That way we could express our great enthusiasm for you, and be forever happy.

og: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods  themselves have provided that I shall have much help  from you: how had you been my friends else?
t: Without a doubt, my good friends, the gods themselves have made it so that I will need much help from you: how could you be my friends otherwise?

og: why  have you that charitable title from thousands, did  not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told  more of you to myself than you can with modesty  speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm  you.
t: Indeed, why else would you—out of thousands of men—have that charitable title of friend, if you did not belong in my heart? I have told you more about myself than you could tell yourself, and through that I have confirmed you to indeed be my friends.

og: O you gods, think I, what need we have any  friends, if we should ne'er have need of 'em? they  were the most needless creatures living, should we  ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble  sweet instruments hung up in cases that keep their  sounds to themselves.
t: I ask the gods sometimes, why would friends be so necessary if we never had any need for them? They would be the most useless creatures alive if we never had any use for them, and would be like beautiful instruments hung up in cases, but keeping their sounds to themselves.

og: Why, I have often wished  myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We  are born to do benefits: and what better or  properer can we can our own than the riches of our  friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis, to have  so many, like brothers, commanding one another's  fortunes!
t: Sometimes I wish that I were a poorer man, so that I could be closer to you all in rank. We are born to give and to do good—so what belongs to us more than the riches of our friends? Oh how comforting it is, to have so many friends, like brothers, enjoying one another's fortunes!

og: O joy, e'en made away ere 't can be born!  Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks: to  forget their faults, I drink to you.
t: What a joy, even if it expresses itself in tears before it can be expressed in words! I cannot help but cry, I think. And to forget the faults of my eyes, I drink to you.

og: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.
t: You cry so they can drink, Timon.

og: Joy had the like conception in our eyesAnd at that instant like a babe sprung up.
t: Joy has the same effect on our eyes, and suddenly tears spring up from them like a baby.

og: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.
t: Ha ha! I laugh when I imagine that baby as a bastard!

og: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.
t: I promise you, Timon, you have moved me greatly.

og: Much!
t: Much!

og: What means that trump?
t: What does that trumpet sound mean?

og: How now?
t: What is going on?

og: Please you, my lord, there are certainladies most desirous of admittance.
t: If you want, my lord, there are certain ladies who would like to come in.

og: Ladies! what are their wills?
t: Ladies! What do they want?

og: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, whichbears that office, to signify their pleasures.
t: They have brought with them someone to come in first, my lord, and whose job it is to tell you all what they want.

og: I pray, let them be admitted.
t: Please, let them be admitted.

og: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all  That of his bounties taste! The five best senses  Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely  To gratulate thy plenteous bosom:
t: Hail, worthy Timon, and all those who enjoy his bounty. All five of the senses acknowledge you as their patron, and that they come here freely to pay homage to you and your great wealth.

og: th' ear,  Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy tale rise;  They only now come but to feast thine eyes.
t: Yes, hearing, taste touch, and smell, all the senses have enjoyed what you offer. Now it is time to feast your eyes!

og: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:Music, make their welcome!
t: You are all welcome; please let the ladies kindly enter. Music, play them in!

og: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.
t: You see how well loved you are my lord?

og: Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!  They dance! they are mad women.  Like madness is the glory of this life.
t: Whoa, what a wave of vanity comes this way! The performers dance! They are mad women and celebrate their madness as if it were the glory of this life.

og: As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.  We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;  And spend our flatteries, to drink those men  Upon whose age we void it up again,  With poisonous spite and envy.
t: The way this feast exceeds the basic necessities of oil and root makes us all seem like fools to forget ourselves and waste our time flattering these men and drinking to the health of those who eventually stop giving in old age and we come to hate and envy.

og: Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?  Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves  Of their friends' gift?
t: Who alive is not either deprived or deprives others of wealth? Who dies that does not disrespect the graves of friends who once gave to them?

og: I should fear those that dance before me now  Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;  Men shut their doors against a setting sun.
t: I should be afraid of these people who dance in front of me right now, because one day they might stamp on me. It has happened before. Men shut their doors to those who decline in age like the setting sun.

og: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,  Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,  Which was not half so beautiful and kind;
t: You have pleasured us greatly, fair ladies, and set a wonderful mood for our feast, which before was not half so beautiful and kind.

og: You have added worth unto 't and lustre,  And entertain'd me with mine own device;  I am to thank you for 't.
t: You have added value and brilliance to the event and entertained me in my own home. Thank you.

og: My lord, you take us even at the best.
t: My lord, you are too kind.

og: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not holdtaking, I doubt me.
t: Yes, for the worst of you is filthy, and I fear too rotten to hold.

og: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:Please you to dispose yourselves.
t: Ladies, there is a small banquet here for you. Please enjoy yourselves.

og: Most thankfully, my lord.
t: Thank you, my lord.

og: Flavius.
t: Flavius.

og: My lord?
t: Yes my lord?

og: The little casket bring me hither.
t: Bring that little chest here.

og: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet!There is no crossing him in 's humour;
t: Yes, my lord.  Even more jewels! There is no opposing him when he is in this mood!

og: Else I should tell him,—well, i' faith I should,  When all's spent, he 'ld be cross'd then, an he could.
t: Otherwise I would tell him—and really I should, that when all these gifts are spent on others, which he has proven capable of doing, he'd have all his debts erased.

og: 'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,  That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.
t: It is sad that generosity is not more vigilant, that way man might never lack for having such a giving spirit.

og: Where be our men?
t: Where is everyone?

og: Here, my lord, in readiness.
t: Here, my lord, all ready.

og: Our horses!
t: Our horses!

og: O my friends,  I have one word to say to you:
t: Oh my friends, I wanted to say one thing to you.

og: look you, my good lord,  I must entreat you, honour me so much  As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,  Kind my lord.
t: You, my good lord, I must beg you—please—to honor me by taking this jewel. Accept it and wear it kindly, my lord.

og: I am so far already in your gifts,—
t: You have already given me so many gifts.

og: So are we all.
t: And us, too.

og: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senateNewly alighted, and come to visit you.
t: My lord, there are some senators who have just arrived and come to visit you.

og: They are fairly welcome.
t: They are welcome.

og: I beseech your honor,Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.
t: Could I speak with you a moment, your honor? It is urgent.

og: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:I prithee, let's be provided to show thementertainment.
t: Urgent! Let's do it another time. Please, let's get ready to entertain these new guests.

og: I scarce know how.
t: I don't know how we'll afford to.

og: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,Out of his free love, hath presented to youFour milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.
t: May it please your honor that Lord Lucius, out of pure kindness, has presented to you four milk-white horses wearing silver trappings.

og: I shall accept them fairly; let the presentsBe worthily entertain'd.
t: I shall accept them, and let the rest of those present be well entertained.

og: How now! what news?
t: What now?

og: Please you, my lord, that honourable  gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company  to-morrow to hunt with him,
t: If you like, my lord, the honorable Lord Lucullus begs that you accompany him hunting tomorrow,

og: and has sent your honour  two brace of greyhounds.
t: and has sent you two sets of greyhounds.

og: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received,Not without fair reward.
t: I'll hunt with him, and make sure he is not received into our home without fair compensation.

og: What will this come to?  He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,  And all out of an empty coffer:  Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,  To show him what a beggar his heart is,  Being of no power to make his wishes good:
t: What will this come to? He commands us to provide for others, and give great gifts, and all out of an empty pocket. He won't even let us tell him how much is left in his wallet, or let me show him what a beggar he truly is, having no power to actually make give the things he promises.

og: His promises fly so beyond his state  That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes  For every word: he is so kind that he now  Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books.
t: His promises exceed what he has by so much that what he offers is putting him even further in debt. He owes money for every word he gives. He is so kind that now he pays interest for it. His land has been incorporated into their accounts.

og: Well, would I were gently put out of office  Before I were forced out!  Happier is he that has no friend to feed  Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.  I bleed inwardly for my lord.
t: Well, I wish I were relieved of this job before he is forced to fire me! The man is happier that has no friends to feed than the one who has friends that do him more harm than enemies. I hurt so much for my lord!

og: You do yourselvesMuch wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.
t: You do yourselves much wrong and undervalue yourselves too much. Here, my lord, a small sign of my love.

og: With more than common thanks I will receive it.
t: I will receive it with great thanks.

og: O, he's the very soul of bounty!
t: Oh, he's the very meaning of generosity.

og: And now I remember, my lord, you gaveGood words the other day of a bay courserI rode on: it is yours, because you liked it.
t: And now I remember, my lord, you complimented me the other day when I rode on a great horse. Since you liked it so much, take it!

og: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.
t: Please, my lord, there is no need for that.

og: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man  Can justly praise but what he does affect:
t: You may take my word, my lord. I know no man who can fairly praise more than what he likes:

og: I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;  I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.
t: I count my friends' desires as my own. This is the truth. We'll see each other again.

og: O, none so welcome.
t: We would like nothing more.

og: I take all and your several visitations  So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;  Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,  And ne'er be weary.
t: I hold you all and your many visits so dear to my heart, there is not enough to give. I could deal kingdoms to my friends, and never tire of it.

og: Alcibiades,  Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich;  It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living  Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast  Lie in a pitch'd field.
t: Alcibiades, you are a soldier, and therefore will never be rich. To give to you would be genuine charity, because you live among the dead, and all the lands you have are in the battlefield.

og: Ay, defiled land, my lord.
t: Yes, ruined land, my lord.

og: We are so virtuously bound—
t: We are so indebted—

og: And soAm I to you.
t: And so am I to you.

og: So infinitely endear'd—
t: So infinitely owing—

og: All to you. Lights, more lights!
t: All to you. More lights please!

og: The best of happiness,Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!
t: May the best happiness, honor, and fortune be yours, Lord Timon!

og: Ready for his friends.
t: I am always there for friends.

og: What a coil's here!  Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!  I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums  That are given for 'em.
t: What a fuss of bows and butts sticking out, here! I wonder whether their bows are worth the money that you pay for them.

og: Friendship's full of dregs:  Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs,  Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.
t: Friendship is full of worthless people, and such false people should not have good legs, so that true fools do not give all their wealth for a few curtsies.

og: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would begood to thee.
t: Now Apemantus, if you weren't so sullen, I would be nice to you.

og: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too,  there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then  thou wouldst sin the faster.
t: No, I'll have nothing from you. Besides, if I were bribed like all the others, there wouldn't be anyone left to criticize you, and then you would fall even faster than you do now.

og: Thou givest so long,  Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in  paper shortly: what need these feasts, pomps and  vain-glories?
t: You give so much I worry that you will yourself away In IOUs shortly: why do you have these feasts, celebrations, and vanities?

og: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I amsworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and comewith better music.
t: No, if you attack all my friends again, I swear I will never listen to you. Goodbye, and come next time with better music to sing.

og: So:  Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then:  I'll lock thy heaven from thee.
t: Very well, then. You will not listen to me now, and I will not help you later. And I wont give you any more advice.

og: O, that men's ears should be  To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!
t: Oh, that human ears should be deaf to good advice, but not to flattery!

og: And late, five thousand: to Varro and to Isidore  He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum,  Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion  Of raging waste?
t: So Timon right now owes five thousand, plus the nine thousand he borrowed from Varro and Isidore, not including what he previously owed me, which totals up to twenty five thousand. And he is still wasting all of this money?

og: It cannot hold; it will not.  If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog,  And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.
t: This cannot last. Right now, if I want money, all I have to do is take a beggar's dog and give it to Timon. When he gives me gifts in return, it is as if the dog were made of gold.

og: If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more  Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,  Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me, straight,  And able horses.
t: If I wanted to sell my horse and then buy twenty better ones, all I need to do is give that horse to Timon, and without even asking for anything in return, he will give me horses right away—good ones, too.

og: No porter at his gate,  But rather one that smiles and still invites  All that pass by. It cannot hold: no reason  Can found his state in safety. Caphis, ho!  Caphis, I say!
t: It is as if he has no guard at the gate of his house, only a man that smiles and invites anyone walking by to enjoy his house. This cannot last, and no man of sound mind could think his estate is safe. Hey, Caphis! Caphis!

og: Here, sir; what is your pleasure?
t: Hello, sir, what do you want?

og: Get on your cloak, and haste you to Lord Timon;  Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased  With slight denial, nor then silenced when—  'Commend me to your master'—and the cap  Plays in the right hand, thus:
t: Get your cloak and go straight to Lord Timon. Ask him to give me my money, and do not take no for an answer. Don't even stop asking for my money when he asks you to bring him to me.

og: but tell him,  My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn  Out of mine own; his days and times are past  And my reliances on his fracted dates  Have smit my credit:
t: Tell him that I am busy with other things, and that the terms of his loans have expired and that my kindness to his delays in repaying them has damaged my credit.

og: I love and honour him,  But must not break my back to heal his finger;  Immediate are my needs, and my relief  Must not be toss'd and turn'd to me in words,  But find supply immediate.
t: I do like him, but I cannot suffer for his sake. I need money right away, and I will not accept excuses, only what I am owed. Go now, and make sure to seem urgent, like you are demanding and not asking him.

og: Get you gone:  Put on a most importunate aspect,  A visage of demand; for, I do fear,  When every feather sticks in his own wing,  Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,  Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.
t: I am afraid that by the time every creditor tries to take back what Timon borrowed from them, he will default with nothing, left like a naked seagull after everyone has plucked a feather from his wing, despite his current brilliant, phoenix-like appearance. Go right away.

og: I go, sir.
t: I will leave now, sir.

og: 'I go, sir!'—Take the bonds along with you,And have the dates in contempt.
t: Yes, leave, and take these notes of the debt with you, and make sure to show him that the time has already passed to pay me back.

og: I will, sir.
t: Ok, sir.

og: Go.
t: Go.

og: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense,  That he will neither know how to maintain it,  Nor cease his flow of riot:
t: He has no common sense, no restraint! He spends his money so thoughtlessly that there is no way he will ever learn to care for it responsibly or even stop lending it out extravagantly.

og: takes no account  How things go from him, nor resumes no care  Of what is to continue: never mind  Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.
t: He does not even take account of what he gives away, nor does he give a thought to what means he has to keep this up. I have never seen someone so dumb, but so kind.

og: What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel:  I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.  Fie, fie, fie, fie!
t: But what can we do? He will not listen until he suffers for his actions. I must be honest with him, and here he comes from hunting. Damn, damn, damn!

og: Good even, Varro: what,You come for money?
t: Good evening. You've come from Varro for money?

og: Is't not your business too?
t: Isn't that why you're here too?

og: It is: and yours too, Isidore?
t: Yes, and you come from Isidore for the same?

og: It is so.
t: Yes.

og: Would we were all discharged!
t: I just want to get paid!

og: I fear it.
t: I'm worried we won't be.

og: Here comes the lord.
t: Here he comes.

og: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?
t: So as soon as we're done with dinner you will be leaving, Alcibiades.  What? You're here to see me?

og: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.
t: Yes my lord, here is a note stating your debts.

og: Dues! Whence are you?
t: Debts! Where are you from?

og: Of Athens here, my lord.
t: Athens, my lord.

og: Go to my steward.
t: Go see my assistant.

og: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off  To the succession of new days this month:
t: Please, he has been putting me off every day for the past month.

og: My master is awaked by great occasion  To call upon his own, and humbly prays you  That with your other noble parts you'll suit  In giving him his right.
t: Please, my master is newly aware of reasons to want his money back, and only asks that your honor will prove consistent and give him what you owe.

og: Mine honest friend,I prithee, but repair to me next morning.
t: Fine,  just please wait until tomorrow morning.

og: Nay, good my lord,—
t: No.

og: Contain thyself, good friend.
t: Calm down.

og: One Varro's servant, my good lord,—
t: I come as Varro's servant, sir—

og: From Isidore;He humbly prays your speedy payment.
t: And I come as Isidore's. He wants you to pay him back as soon as possible.

og: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants—
t: If you knew why my master needed the money, sir—

og: 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks And past.
t: Your debt was owed six weeks ago.

og: Your steward puts me off, my lord;And I am sent expressly to your lordship.
t: Your assistant keeps ignoring me, and now I've been told to speak only to you.

og: Give me breath.I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;I'll wait upon you instantly.
t: Give me a second. Please wait a bit and I'll be with you as soon as I can.

og: Come hither: pray you,  How goes the world,
t: Come here, please. What the hell is going on?

og: that I am thus encounter'd  With clamourous demands of date-broke bonds,  And the detention of long-since-due debts,  Against my honour?
t: Why is everyone yelling at me about overdue payments, which I promised to pay a long time ago?

og: Please you, gentlemen,  The time is unagreeable to this business:
t: Please, sir. Now is not the time to talk about this.

og: Your importunacy cease till after dinner,  That I may make his lordship understand  Wherefore you are not paid.
t: Keep your questions until after dinner, then I will tell you why you have not repaid these debts.

og: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd.
t: Ok, and make sure to take care of them.

og: Pray, draw near.
t: Here it comes.

og: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus:let's ha' some sport with 'em.
t: Look! Here comes Apemantus with the fool. Let's make fun of them.

og: Hang him, he'll abuse us.
t: We should kill him before he harasses us.

og: A plague upon him, dog!
t: I do hope that dog dies.

og: How dost, fool?
t: What's up, fool?

og: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?
t: Are you talking to yourself?

og: I speak not to thee.
t: I'm not talking to you.

og: No,'tis to thyself.
t: Exactly, you could only be calling yourself a fool.

og: Come away.
t: Let's go.

og: There's the fool hangs on your back already.
t: Actually, it seems the "fool" goes with you.

og: No, thou stand'st single, thou'rt not on him yet.
t: You're not even good enough to come with me. You are the fool.

og: Where's the fool now?
t: Wait, now, who does the title, "fool," attend now?

og: He last asked the question. Poor rogues, andusurers' men! bawds between gold and want!
t: The man who needs to ask. You poor idiots, working for money-lenders. You're like whores who shuttle between money and greed?

og: What are we, Apemantus?
t: What did you call us?

og: Asses.
t: Asses.

og: Why?
t: Excuse me?

og: That you ask me what you are, and do not knowyourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.
t: Proof of it lies in the fact that you even need to ask, because you don't even know that you're asses. Go ahead, fool.

og: How do you, gentlemen?
t: Good day, gentlemen.

og: Gramercies, good fool: how does your mistress?
t: Why thank you! How is your whore girlfriend?

og: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickensas you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!
t: She's sitting over hot water to sweat out STDs like yourselves. If only we had known about you all at the Corinth whorehouse!

og: Good! gramercy.
t: Haha. Well done!

og: Look you, here comes my mistress' page.
t: Look, here comes my girlfriend's little man.

og: Why, how now, captain! what do youin this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?
t: What are you doing here with these people? And how are you Apemantus?

og: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answerthee profitably.
t: I wish my mouth were a bat to beat you with. That way, I could answer your question correctly.

og: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription ofthese letters: I know not which is which.
t: Please Apemantus, could you read the different lines in these letters? I can't make any sense of them.

og: Canst not read?
t: You can't read?

og: No.
t: No.

og: There will little learning die then, that day thou  art hanged.
t: You might as well die, because the day you can't learn is the day you are basically hanged.

og: This is to Lord Timon; this to  Alcibiades. Go; thou wast born a bastard, and thou't  die a bawd.
t: This one is to Lord Timon, and this one is to Alcibiades. You were born a bastard, and now you'll die a whore.

og: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish adog's death. Answer not; I am gone.
t: You talk like a dog and you're going to die like a dog. Don't even answer me, I'm leaving.

og: E'en so thou outrunnest grace. Fool, I will go withyou to Lord Timon's.
t: You're running away from the teaching that might have saved you.  Let's go together to Lord Timon's.

og: Will you leave me there?
t: I can't stay here?

og: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?
t: If Timon is there I'm going to leave a Fool with him.  The three of you are assistants to the money-lenders?

og: Ay; would they served us!
t: Yes, if only they were our assistants!

og: So would I,—as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.
t: Me too—that would be like an executioner serving a thief.

og: Are you three usurers' men?
t: Say again, you three are assistants to the money-lenders?

og: Ay, fool.
t: Yes, fool.

og: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant: my  mistress is one, and I am her fool.
t: Any assistant to a money-lender is a fool. My girlfriend is a fool, and I am her fool.

og: When men come  to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly, and  go away merry; but they enter my mistress' house  merrily, and go away sadly: the reason of this?
t: When people come to borrow from your bosses, they come with sad faces and leave with happy ones, but when they come to my girlfriend's whorehouse, they come with happy faces and leave with sad ones. What's the reason for this?

og: I could render one.
t: I can give you a reason.

og: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremasterand a knave; which not-withstanding, thou shalt beno less esteemed.
t: Give it then, so we can call you both a pimp and an idiot, which would not be any worse than what you are now.

og: What is a whoremaster, fool?
t: What is a pimp, fool?

og: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee.  'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord;  sometime like a lawyer;
t: A fool that wears nice clothes, not unlike you. He can change appearances. Sometimes he looks like a lord, and sometimes he looks like lawyer.

og: sometime like a philosopher,  with two stones moe than's artificial one: he is  very often like a knight; and, generally, in all  shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore  to thirteen, this spirit walks in.
t: Sometimes, he looks like a philosopher with two testicles to add to the stone he uses for alchemy. A lot of times he looks like a knight, but generally he sticks to the appearances men take between the ages of 13 and 80.

og: Thou art not altogether a fool.
t: You're not a complete fool.

og: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery asI have, so much wit thou lackest.
t: And you're definitely not the brightest bulb on the tree. As much as I am a fool, that's how much intelligence you lack.

og: That answer might have become Apemantus.
t: That response could have come from my own mouth.

og: Aside, aside; here comes Lord Timon.
t: Move away, here comes Lord Timon.

og: Come with me, fool, come.
t: Let's go, fool.

og: I do not always follow lover, elder brother andwoman; sometime the philosopher.
t: I do not always stick to lovers, women, and rich men. Sometimes I hang out with philosophers!

og: Pray you, walk near: I'll speak with you anon.
t: Let's walk and talk.

og: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time  Had you not fully laid my state before me,
t: I'm shocked. Why did you not tell me about all of the debts,

og: That I might so have rated my expense,  As I had leave of means?
t: so I could cut off my spending?

og: You would not hear me,At many leisures I proposed.
t: I brought it up many times. You didn't listen to me.

og: Go to:  Perchance some single vantages you took.
t: No way! Maybe you took some small opportunities to mention it to me,

og: When my indispos ition put you back:  And that unaptness made your minister,  Thus to excuse yourself.
t: and you took my deafness on a few occasions as an excuse not to ask me ever again.

og: O my good lord,  At many times I brought in my accounts,  Laid them before you; you would throw them off,  And say, you found them in mine honesty.
t: Oh no, I showed you the numbers several times and put them right in front of you. You would throw them away and say you had me look at them.

og: When, for some trifling present, you have bid me  Return so much, I have shook my head and wept;  Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, pray'd you  To hold your hand more close:
t: I have said no and cried when you offered huge amounts of money in return for small gifts, and I have told you to be tighter with your wallet, so bluntly that it was almost rude.

og: I did endure  Not seldom, nor no slight cheques, when I have  Prompted you in the ebb of your estate  And your great flow of debts.
t: I faced many hard outbursts of yours when I told you about your shrinking estate and your growing debts.

og: My loved lord,  Though you hear now, too late—yet now's a time—  The greatest of your having lacks a half  To pay your present debts.
t: Now that you are listening to me it's too late, and still I have to tell you that all your money will only pay half of all that you owe.

og: Let all my land be sold.
t: Sell all my land.

og: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone;  And what remains will hardly stop the mouth  Of present dues:
t: It's all mortgaged, and some of it already sold. What's left won't even come close to paying off everyone.

og: the future comes apace:  What shall defend the interim? and at length  How goes our reckoning?
t: And what are we going to do about the even greater number of creditors that will approach us soon? What can we do in the long run?

og: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.
t: My land extended all the way to Sparta.

og: O my good lord, the world is but a word:Were it all yours to give it in a breath,How quickly were it gone!
t: But sir, you would have given the entire world in one breath. Your holdings shrank so quickly!

og: You tell me true.
t: You are telling the truth.

og: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,  Call me before the exactest auditors  And set me on the proof.
t: If you think that my management has been poor or dishonest, have me inspected by the strictest auditors to prove my integrity.

og: So the gods bless me,  When all our offices have been oppress'd  With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept  With drunken spilth of wine, when every room  Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy,
t: This is how the gods reward me, when greedy freeloaders have eaten everything in the kitchen and drunk all the wine, and when hired musicians have been made to occupy and light up every room in the house.

og: I have retired me to a wasteful cock,  And set mine eyes at flow.
t: I have given myself up to wastefulness and now all I can do is cry about it.

og: Prithee, no more.
t: Please stop.

og: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!  How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants  This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?
t: And yet I have not touched on how loose you've been with your money! How many delicacies have poor men eaten tonight on your account? Who does not seem to belong to Timon?

og: What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is  Lord Timon's?  Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!  Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,  The breath is gone whereof this praise is made:
t: Is there anything in the world that you have not claimed as your own to give? They have called you great, noble, worthy, and royal, but when all you have to buy compliments is gone, there will be no praise left.

og: Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers,  These flies are couch'd.
t: What is quickly made is quickly lost, and these men will disappear like flies after seeing one winter cloud.

og: Come, sermon me no further:  No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;  Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.
t: Don't preach to me. I have not done a single bad thing in giving these gifts, for they were imprudently, not dishonorably, given.

og: Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack,  To think I shall lack friends?
t: Why are you so upset? Can't you see that I have all the friends in the world?

og: Secure thy heart;  If I would broach the vessels of my love,  And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,  Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use  As I can bid thee speak.
t: Don't worry, because if I could appeal to those who have received so much from me in love and work to inspire their sympathy, other men and their fortunes will prove themselves available to me. One word and someone will lend to me.

og: Assurance bless your thoughts!
t: I hope you're right.

og: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crown'd,  That I account them blessings; for by these  Shall I try friends:
t: In a way, these debts are a blessing in disguise, because this way I can see who my real friends are.

og: you shall perceive how you  Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.  Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!
t: You'll see how wrong you are about their loyalty to me—I have many friends! Come here Flaminius, Servilius!

og: My lord? my lord?
t: Hello?

og: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius;  to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour  to-day: you, to Sempronius:
t: I will split you all up and send you to Lord Lucius, you to Lord Lucullus, my hunting-partner today, and you to Sempronius.

og: commend me to their  loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions have  found time to use 'em toward a supply of money: let  the request be fifty talents.
t: Tell them you come from me, and due to extenuating circumstances I could use their help and some money. Ask for fifty talents from each.

og: As you have said, my lord.
t: Whatever you say.

og: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!
t: He's going to ask Lucius and Lucullus, of all people?

og: Go you, sir, to the senators—  Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have  Deserved this hearing
t: You go to the senators. I deserve an audience with them.

og: —bid 'em send o' the instant  A thousand talents to me.
t: Ask them to send me a thousand talents.

og: I have been bold—  For that I knew it the most general way—  To them to use your signet and your name;
t: I have used your badge as sign of my authority to act for you and approached them aggressively asking for money.

og: But they do shake their heads, and I am here  No richer in return.
t: They said no, and I came back with no more than I left with.

og: Is't true? can't be?
t: That can't be true!

og: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,  That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot  Do what they would; are sorry—you are honourable,—  But yet they could have wish'd—they know not—  Something hath been amiss
t: They answered in unison that they would like to help, but do not have enough to spare. They did say they were sorry and that they liked you, and that they had no idea anything was wrong with your estate.

og: —a noble nature  May catch a wrench—would all were well—'tis pity;—
t: They lamented that even the noblest men can come upon bad luck, wished life were better, and said it was all so sad.

og: And so, intending other serious matters,  After distasteful looks and these hard fractions,  With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods  They froze me into silence.
t: Then they moved on to what they said were more serious matters, and shared looks of disgust and hard, half-uttered sentences. Then they were so gruff with their grudging salutes and cold nods that I was shocked into silence.

og: You gods, reward them!  Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows  Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:
t: I hope the gods give them what they deserve! But calm down, those old cronies have ingratitude in their DNA.

og: Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;  'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
t: Their blood is thick and runs slow and cold. They do not have the warmth to be kind.

og: And nature, as it grows again toward earth,  Is fashion'd for the journey, dull and heavy.
t: And they must act as their nature dictates, dull and heavy.

og: Go to Ventidius.
t: Go to Ventidius.

og: Prithee, be not sad,Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak.No blame belongs to thee.
t: Please cheer up. You are a good man, and I don't blame you.

og: Ventidius lately  Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd  Into a great estate:
t: Ventidius just held his father's funeral, who died and left him heir to an enormous fortune.

og: when he was poor,  Imprison'd and in scarcity of friends,  I clear'd him with five talents:
t: When he was poor and had no one to turn to, I gave him five talents.

og: greet him from me;  Bid him suppose some good necessity  Touches his friend, which craves to be remember'd  With those five talents.
t: Go to him for me and ask that his friend needs him right now, and hopes that he remembers those five talents.

og: That had, give't these fellowsTo whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think,That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.
t: Now that that's done, give these men what they are due right now. Don't say or even imagine that my friends will fail me.

og: I would I could not think it: that thought isbounty's foe;Being free itself, it thinks all others so.
t: I wish I could unthink it. The idea that some will fail you is the enemy of generosity, because once it gets out that some are withholding their money, everyone will do the same.

og: I have told my lord of you; he is coming down to you.
t: I told Lucullus that you were here. He'll be in soon.

og: I thank you, sir.
t: Thanks.

og: Here's my lord.
t: There he is.

og: One of Lord Timon's men? a gift, I  warrant. Why, this hits right; I dreamt of a silver  basin and ewer to-night.
t: Is this one of Timon's servants? Great! I dreamt last night of expensive gifts.

og: Flaminius, honest  Flaminius; you are very respectively welcome, sir.
t: Welcome, Flaminius.

og: Fill me some wine.
t: Go get some wine for us.

og: And how does that honourable, complete, free-heartedgentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lordand master?
t: How is your master Timon? He's so honest and generous.

og: His health is well sir.
t: He is healthy.

og: I am right glad that his health is well, sir: andwhat hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?
t: It's important to be healthy. What do you have under your cloak, Flaminius?

og: 'Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir; which, in my  lord's behalf, I come to entreat your honour to  supply;
t: Nothing, just an empty box, which Timon asked that I beg you fill with some money.

og: who, having great and instant occasion to  use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to  furnish him, nothing doubting your present  assistance therein.
t: He could really use fifty talents, and thinks you would be kind enough to lend him that money. He thinks without a doubt you will assist him.

og: La, la, la, la! 'nothing doubting,' says he? Alas,  good lord! a noble gentleman 'tis, if he would not  keep so good a house.
t: Ha ha ha! He thinks so? He's a very nice guy, but he has spent too much money.
