og: Many a time and often I ha'  dined with him, and told him on't, and come again to  supper to him, of purpose to have him spend less,  and yet he would embrace no counsel, take no warning  by my coming.
t: I came over several times for dinner and told him to be more thrifty, but he would never listen or heed my warnings.

og: Every man has his fault, and honesty  is his: I ha' told him on't, but I could ne'er get  him from't.
t: No one is perfect, and his vice is generosity. I told him so, but never could change his ways.

og: Please your lordship, here is the wine.
t: Here's the wine.

og: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here's to thee.
t: I always thought you were smart, Flaminius. Take this.

og: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.
t: Timon says the same.

og: I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt  spirit—give thee thy due—and one that knows what  belongs to reason;
t: I always thought you were an able and efficient guy who—to give you your due credit—knows how to be reasonable.

og: and canst use the time well, if  the time use thee well: good parts in thee.
t: I always imagined that instead of being swept up in circumstance you'd be able to see an opportunity when it presented itself. These are good traits.

og: Get you gone, sirrah.
t: Leave and give us a moment.

og: Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a  bountiful gentleman: but thou art wise; and thou  knowest well enough, although thou comest to me,  that this is no time to lend money, especially upon  bare friendship, without security.
t: Come closer to me Flaminius. Your lord is a generous man, but you are smart and know as well as anybody, even though you've come to me, that now is not the time to lend money, especially to friends, without some kind of insurance.

og: Here's three  solidares for thee: good boy, wink at me, and say  thou sawest me not. Fare thee well.
t: Here are three coins. This way you can say that you never visited me and I did not reject your request for a loan. Goodbye.

og: Is't possible the world should so much differ,And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness,To him that worships thee!
t: Is it really possible that such bad men can exist when there are good ones too? You and your money sicken me.

og: Ha! now I see thou art a fool, and fit for thy master.
t: Ah, now I can tell that you're as dumb as Timon.

og: May these add to the number that may scald thee!  Let moulten coin be thy damnation,
t: I hope those coins melt into a burning hot liquid and scald you!

og: Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!
t: You make me sick.

og: Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,  It turns in less than two nights?
t: Is friendship really such a flimsy thing that it can break in less than two nights?

og: O you gods,  I feel master's passion! this slave,  Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him:  Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment,  When he is turn'd to poison?
t: God! I am offended for Timon. This idiot has eaten at his table, and what he ate should not have nourished him, but poisoned him!

og: O, may diseases only work upon't!  And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature  Which my lord paid for, be of any power  To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!
t: I hope he gets a fatal disease , and that whatever part of him existed thanks to eating Timon's food works to make his suffering even more painful.

og: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, andan honourable gentleman.
t: You're talking about Timon? He is my friend and a good guy.

og: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers  to him.
t: We've heard as much, even though we've never met the man.

og: But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and  which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's  happy hours are done and past, and his estate  shrinks from him.
t: Still, I can tell you something else which I've heard as a rumor: Timon's best days are behind him, and his estate is shrinking beyond his control.

og: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.
t: Psh, no, don't believe the rumors. He has plenty of money.

og: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago,  one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow  so many talents,
t: But, my lord, believe this: one of his men went to the Lord Lucullus to ask for that much.

og: nay, urged extremely for't and  showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.
t: Really, he begged desperately for it, showing just how much he really needed it, and still he was rejected.

og: How!
t: No way!

og: I tell you, denied, my lord.
t: Yes, totally rejected.

og: What a strange case was that! now, before the gods,  I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man!
t: That is so weird! God as my witness, I am ashamed to hear that such an honorable man was denied a loan.

og: there was very little honour showed in't. For my own  part, I must needs confess, I have received some  small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels  and such-like trifles, nothing comparing to his;
t: There is no honor at all in that, and when I think of myself, I must say I have received many gifts from him: money, silver, jewels, and other things—though nothing compared to what he gave Lucullus.

og: yet, had he mistook him and sent to me, I should  ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.
t: If Timon had foregone Lucullus and asked me for a loan, I never would have denied him so much.

og: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord;I have sweat to see his honour. My honoured lord,—
t: There you are, my lord, I've been look all over for you. My lord—

og: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well:commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my veryexquisite friend.
t: Servilius! It's good to see you. Please, bring me to Timon, my good friend.

og: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent—
t: If you are willing, Timon sent—

og: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared tothat lord; he's ever sending: how shall I thankhim, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?
t: Ha! What gift has he sent me? I owe that man so much, since he's always giving me gifts. How do you think I should thank him? What has he sent me?

og: Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord;requesting your lordship to supply his instant usewith so many talents.
t: Only me to state his current state of affairs, and to ask you to lend him some money.

og: I know his lordship is but merry with me;He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.
t: Timon must be joking. There's no way he needs fifty five hundred talents.

og: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.If his occasion were not virtuous,I should not urge it half so faithfully.
t: For now he wants less. I wouldn't speak with such urgency about this if it were a joke.

og: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?
t: You're serious?

og: Upon my soul,'tis true, sir.
t: Yes, I swear.

og: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself  against such a good time, when I might ha' shown  myself honourable!
t: I'm a horrible man for accepting all those gifts from Timon, when I could have been better!

og: how unluckily it happened, that I  should purchase the day before for a little part,  and undo a great deal of honoured!
t: I gave up the opportunity to be a good man for something that brings me no honor!

og: Servilius, now,  before the gods, I am not able to do,—the more  beast, I say:—I was sending to use Lord Timon  myself, these gentlemen can witness!
t: Servilius, I swear to god that I cannot help. I was actually going to send someone to borrow from Timon, and these men here will back me up.

og: but I would  not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done't now.
t: I swear on all the wealth of Athens!

og: Commend me bountifully to his good lordship;
t: Tell Timon what I've said.

og: and I  hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me,  because I have no power to be kind:
t: hope he will think of me well, even if I cannot help him.

og: and tell him  this from me, I count it one of my greatest  afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an  honourable gentleman.
t: Tell him that it pains me more than anything else that I cannot aid such a good man.

og: Good Servilius, will you  befriend me so far, as to use mine own words to him?
t: Servilius, would you be a good friend to me and tell him this?

og: Yes, sir, I shall.
t: Yes, I will.

og: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius.
t: I wish you the best, Servilius!

og: True as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed;And he that's once denied will hardly speed.
t: It's as you said, Timon is poor. And someone who is denied once does not have much hope of prospering.

og: Do you observe this, Hostilius?
t: Did you see that, Hostilius?

og: Ay, too well.
t: Yes.

og: Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the  same piece  Is every flatterer's spirit.
t: That's what the world is like, and every flatterer is the same.

og: Who can call him  His friend that dips in the same dish?
t: What is a friend who takes so much?

og: for, in  My knowing, Timon has been this lord's father,  And kept his credit with his purse,  Supported his estate;
t: Timon was so good to Lucilius, and kept him afloat with his own money.

og: nay, Timon's money  Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks,  But Timon's silver treads upon his lip;
t: It's Timon who paid for his servants, and he never enjoys anything that does not owe itself to him.

og: And yet—O, see the monstrousness of man  When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!—
t: But how monstrous he looks for being so ungrateful!

og: He does deny him, in respect of his,  What charitable men afford to beggars.
t: He denies him what rich men would give to beggars.

og: Religion groans at it.
t: It's unholy.

og: For mine own part,  I never tasted Timon in my life,  Nor came any of his bounties over me,  To mark me for his friend;
t: I myself have never received anything from Timon, and am not his friend.

og: yet, I protest,  For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue  And honourable carriage,  Had his necessity made use of me,  I would have put my wealth into donation,  And the best half should have return'd to him,
t: But I swear on all of his good qualities that if he approached me for money, I would have given him something.

og: So much I love his heart: but, I perceive,  Men must learn now with pity to dispense;  For policy sits above conscience.
t: I like him that much. Men don't know how to give and value shrewd money-making over their conscience.

og: Must he needs trouble me in 't,—hum!—'bove  all others?
t: Should Timon really have to struggle for this?

og: He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;  And now Ventidius is wealthy too,  Whom he redeem'd from prison:
t: He could go to Lord Lucius or Lucullus for a loan, and he could also call on the rich Ventidius, who is free from prison thanks to Timon.

og: all these  Owe their estates unto him.
t: All these men owe some of their wealth to Timon.

og: My lord,They have all been touch'd and found base metal, forThey have all denied him.
t: All those men must be under some wicked influence, because they all denied him.

og: How! have they denied him?  Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him?  And does he send to me? Three? hum!  It shows but little love or judgment in him:  Must I be his last refuge!
t: No way! Ventidius and Lucullus denied him? Has he approached me for a loan? It shows little Timon's friends loved him that all three of these men refused him, and now I must be his last hope!

og: His friends, like  physicians,  Thrive, give him over: must I take the cure upon me?
t: All his friends benefitted from the charity that leaves him without money, and now leave him for broke like doctor does a case he has deemed helpless. Must I now try to cure him of his debts?

og: Has much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him,  That might have known my place: I see no sense for't,  But his occasion might have woo'd me first;  For, in my conscience, I was the first man  That e'er received gift from him:
t: What a disgrace and an unenviable position for me! I cannot understand why he did not come to me first—I was the first to receive a gift from him, after all.

og: And does he think so backwardly of me now,  That I'll requite its last? No:  So it may prove an argument of laughter  To the rest, and 'mongst lords I be thought a fool.
t: Does he think so poorly of me as to believe I would be the last to repay him? No, and that way I'll have reason to laugh at him and all the others, who have called me an idiot.

og: I'd rather than the worth of thrice the sum,  Had sent to me first, but for my mind's sake;  I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return,  And with their faint reply this answer join;  Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin.
t: If Timon had approached me first, I would have three times the amount he asks for. But now, servant, go back to him and tell him this: whoever scorns me this way will never get my money.

og: Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The  devil knew not what he did when he made man  politic; he crossed himself by 't: and I cannot  think but, in the end, the villainies of man will  set him clear.
t: Wow, what a villain! Even the devil couldn't have known how evil men would be when he made them so crafty. He ruined himself in the process, and there's no way that all the badness in men will ever absolve him.

og: How fairly this lord strives to  appear foul! takes virtuous copies to be wicked,  like those that under hot ardent zeal would set  whole realms on fire: Of such a nature is his  politic love.
t: It is incredible how this lord actually works to seem horrible! He makes himself seem virtuous, but only so he can be as wicked as those who would burn entire empires to the ground. That's what political desire is made of.

og: This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled,  Save only the gods: now his friends are dead,  Doors, that were ne'er acquainted with their wards  Many a bounteous year must be employ'd  Now to guard sure their master.
t: He was Timon's best chance at getting money, and now all hopes are gone except for the will of the gods. Timon's friends are dead to him, and now all those doors he had left wide open all those years must be closed and used to protect him in his home.

og: And this is all a liberal course allows;  Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.
t: That's what being too generous gets you. He who cannot hang onto wealth must at least hang onto his house.

og: Well met; good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.
t: Right on time. Good day, Titus and Hortensius.

og: The like to you kind Varro.
t: And you as well.

og: Lucius!What, do we meet together?
t: Oh, a representative of Lucius! Are you here to see Timon as well?

og: Ay, and I thinkOne business does command us all; for mine Is money.
t: Yes. We do all have the same goal, and mine is money.

og: So is theirs and ours.
t: And your goal is our goal.

og: Lucius' Servant And Sir Philotus too!
t: Not only Lucius's Servant, but Philotus's too!

og: Good day at once.
t: Good day.

og: Welcome, good brother.What do you think the hour?
t: Hello. What time is it?

og: Labouring for nine.
t: Close to nine.

og: So much?
t: That late?

og: Is not my lord seen yet?
t: Has anyone seen Timon yet?

og: Not yet.
t: Not yet.

og: I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.
t: I wonder why. He usually wakes up at seven.

og: Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him:  You must consider that a prodigal course  Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.
t: Yeah, but the days have become shorter for him, because you should remember that the path of extravagance descends like the sun in winter, even if it does not regain its height the following year.

og: I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;  That is one may reach deep enough, and yet  Find little.
t: And I'm afraid that Lord Timon's estate is withering, no matter how hard he tries to recover money.

og: I am of your fear for that.
t: Me too.

og: I'll show you how to observe a strange event.Your lord sends now for money.
t: And I'll tell you something funny.  Your lord sent you to get money, right?

og: Most true, he does.
t: Yes.

og: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift,For which I wait for money.
t: And he now possesses jewels from Timon, which I lent him the money to buy.

og: It is against my heart.
t: Unfortunately, yes.

og: Mark, how strange it shows,  Timon in this should pay more than he owes:
t: It's so weird how Timon must pay out more than he owes,

og: And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels,  And send for money for 'em.
t: while your lord seems to get the privilege of wearing the jewels and getting to request the money paid for them.

og: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness:I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.
t: God I'm sick of this job. I know that my lord spent Timon's money and now in his ingratitude is as bad as a thief.

og: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours?
t: Yeah. My lord is asking for three thousand crowns. What about yours?

og: Five thousand mine.
t: Five thousand.

og: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun,Your master's confidence was above mine;Else, surely, his had equall'd.
t: Way too much. It seems your master is more brazen even than mine, otherwise mine would have asked for as much.

og: One of Lord Timon's men.
t: One of Timon's servants is coming

og: Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready tocome forth?
t: Flaminius! Can we talk for a second? Is Timon coming?

og: No, indeed, he is not.
t: No he's not.

og: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.
t: At least tell him we are waiting for him.

og: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent.
t: I don't have to do that. He knows how attentive you are.

og: Ha! is not that his steward muffled so?He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.
t: Ha! Is that his assistant wrapped up like that? Get him, he's trying to sneak away under cover.

og: Do you hear, sir?
t: Can we talk, please?

og: By your leave, sir,—
t: Please, sir—

og: What do ye ask of me, my friend?
t: What do you want?

og: We wait for certain money here, sir.
t: We want the money Timon owes.

og: Ay,  If money were as certain as your waiting,  'Twere sure enough.
t: Yes, if only money were as sure a thing as you all asking for it, then you would definitely have it.

og: Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills,  When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?  Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts  And take down the interest into their  gluttonous maws.
t: Why didn't your masters send you to pay the bills for the food they ate off Timon's plate? That way, they could smile and enjoy the debts he incurred and then shovel all the interest he owed into their greedy mouths.

og: You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;  Let me pass quietly:  Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end;  I have no more to reckon, he to spend.
t: You're not doing yourself any favors riling me up like this. Let me go. My lord and I have parted ways. I have no more counsel to give, and he has no more money to spend.

og: Ay, but this answer will not serve.
t: Yes, but that still isn't enough.

og: If 'twill not serve,'tis not so base as you;For you serve knaves.
t: If it's not enough, it's still worth more than all of you, because you serve bad men.

og: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?
t: What did the fired man just say?

og: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge  enough.
t: Whatever, he's poor and that's punishment enough for him.

og: Who can speak broader than he that has no  house to put his head in? such may rail against  great buildings.
t: After all, who can say whatever he wants more than the man with no home and nothing to lose?

og: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.
t: Here is Servilius. Now we'll know what is going on.

og: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some  other hour, I should derive much from't;
t: If I may ask, gentleman, please come back some other time, and it will help me a great deal.

og: for,  take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to  discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him;  he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber.
t: I swear, Timon is extremely upset. His cheerful disposition is gone, he is sick, and he keeps to his room.

og: Many do keep their chambers are not sick:  And, if it be so far beyond his health,
t: Lots of people who stay in their rooms aren't sick, and if he's as sick as you say he is,

og: Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,  And make a clear way to the gods.
t: all the more reason for him to pay off his debts before he dies.

og: Good gods!
t: Good lord!

og: We cannot take this for answer, sir.
t: We can't accept this.

og: Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!
t: Servilius, help! Timon! Timon!

og: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?  Have I been ever free, and must my house  Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?
t: What, are my own doors going to shut themselves to me? Am I not free to leave my own house?

og: The place which I have feasted, does it now,  Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?
t: Does the home to such great parties turn its back on me, like everyone else?

og: Put in now, Titus.
t: Calm down Titus.

og: My lord, here is my bill.
t: Here is the receipt for debts you owe me.

og: Here's mine.
t: Here's mine.

og: And mine, my lord.
t: And mine.

og: And ours, my lord.
t: And ours.

og: All our bills.
t: All our receipts.

og: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.
t: Go ahead, kill me with them.

og: Alas, my lord,-
t: But—

og: Cut my heart in sums.
t: Rip pieces of my heart out.

og: Mine, fifty talents.
t: My receipt is for fifty talents.

og: Tell out my blood.
t: Count my blood drop by drop and take it from me.

og: Five thousand drops pays that.What yours?—and yours?
t: Five thousand drops should cover. What about all your receipts?

og: My lord,—
t: My lord—

og: My lord,—
t: My lord—

og: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!
t: Tear me apart and take me away, and may the gods take their revenge upon you!

og: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their capsat their money: these debts may well be calleddesperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.
t: It seems our masters should probably give up on getting their money back. Now that Timon's mad, these debts are junk.

og: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves.Creditors? devils!
t: These men have even taken my breath away. They call themselves creditors? They are devils!

og: My dear lord,—
t: Timon—

og: What if it should be so?
t: But what if...

og: My lord,—
t: Timon—

og: I'll have it so. My steward!
t: Yes, that's it! Come here!

og: Here, my lord.
t: I'm here.

og: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again,
t: So soon? Go get all those men for me.

og: Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius:  All, sirrah, all:  I'll once more feast the rascals.
t: Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius, all of them! I'll throw them one last party!

og: O my lord,  You only speak from your distracted soul;
t: But my lord you only speak in a daze.

og: There is not so much left, to furnish out  A moderate table.
t: You do not have enough money yet to offer even a small meal.

og: Be't not in thy care; go,I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tideOf knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.
t: Don't worry about that. Go, and invite them all. Let in that wave of villains once more. My cook and I will figure it out.

og: My lord, you have my voice to it; the fault'sBloody; 'tis necessary he should die:Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.
t: You have my vote! He should die for this heinous act, because mercy would only lead to more behavior like it.

og: Most true; the law shall bruise him.
t: I agree. He must face the rule of law.

og: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!
t: Long live the senate!

og: Now, captain?
t: What, captain?

og: I am an humble suitor to your virtues;  For pity is the virtue of the law,  And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
t: I stand before you virtuous men to ask a favor. The law is a merciful thing, which only a tyrant could use for cruel purposes.

og: It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy  Upon a friend of mine, who, in hot blood,  Hath stepp'd into the law, which is past depth  To those that, without heed, do plunge into 't.
t: Time and hard luck have worked against a friend of mine who recently broke the law in a fit of rage, a state which unfortunately the law does not consider when men break it.

og: He is a man, setting his fate aside,  Of comely virtues:  Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice—  An honour in him which buys out his fault—  But with a noble fury and fair spirit,  Seeing his reputation touch'd to death,  He did oppose his foe:
t: My friend, this action aside, is a good man, who in the moment actually acted without cowardice—something which ought to be held against his crime—by bravely identifying and responding to one who had ruined his reputation.

og: And with such sober and unnoted passion  He did behave his anger, ere 'twas spent,  As if he had but proved an argument.
t: He opposed this enemy with a clearheaded and calculating passion, expressing his anger with a certain coldness, almost as if he were proving a point.

og: You undergo too strict a paradox,  Striving to make an ugly deed look fair:
t: Your argument is contradictory, a forced attempt to make gross actions seem justifiable.

og: Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd  To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling  Upon the head of valour;
t: Your rhetoric reaches almost to the point of labor as it tries to turn murder into a mere formality and feuding into an act of valor.

og: which indeed  Is valour misbegot and came into the world  When sects and factions were newly born:
t: Feuds actually prove to be valor in its most degenerate form, as they come from the formation of rivalries.

og: He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer  The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs  His outsides, to wear them like his raiment,  carelessly,
t: A man is truly valiant only when he can endure the worst insults men can speak, and even wear them like clothing without a care in the world.

og: And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart,  To bring it into danger.  If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,  What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!
t: True valor never takes injury to heart, or retaliates in violence. If acts of injustice are in fact evil and force us to kill others, how dumb it would be then to risk your life for such a cause!

og: My lord,—
t: But—

og: You cannot make gross sins look clear:To revenge is no valour, but to bear.
t: You cannot make terrible sins look innocent. Valor is patience, not revenge.

og: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me,  If I speak like a captain.  Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,  And not endure all threats?
t: Then forgive me for speaking like a military man, my lords. Why do good people fight and not patiently bear the insults of their enemies?

og: sleep upon't,  And let the foes quietly cut their throats,  Without repugnancy? If there be  Such valour in the bearing, what make we  Abroad? why then, women are more valiant  That stay at home,
t: Why do they not patiently let those same enemies murder them in their sleep? If there is such honor in patience, what do we make of our wars abroad, and why are women not considered more valiant for staying at home?

og: if bearing carry it,  And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon  Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,  If wisdom be in suffering.
t: Why do we not deem the donkey superior to the lion, or the prisoner to the judge, if there is such wisdom in suffering?

og: O my lords,  As you are great, be pitifully good:  Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?  To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust;  But, in defence, by mercy, 'tis most just.
t: You are great men, be compassionate. Who would not sentence a man for violent aggression? You are right, murder is the greatest sin, but when it is done for self-defense it is fair.

og: To be in anger is impiety;  But who is man that is not angry?  Weigh but the crime with this.
t: Anger is wicked, but who has not been angry before? Think about this as you judge the crime before you.

og: You breathe in vain.
t: Your speech is useless.

og: In vain! his service doneAt Lacedaemon and ByzantiumWere a sufficient briber for his life.
t: Useless! The man's heroism at the battles of Lacedaemon and Byzantium should be enough to win him his life.

og: What's that?
t: What?

og: I say, my lords, he has done fair service,  And slain in fight many of your enemies:
t: The man is a hero and has killed many of our enemies.

og: How full of valour did he bear himself  In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!
t: How bravely did he fight and wound many men in the last battle?

og: He has made too much plenty with 'em;  He's a sworn rioter: he has a sin that often  Drowns him, and takes his valour prisoner:
t: He wounded too many men. He's a crazy drunk, and that vice ruins his honor.

og: If there were no foes, that were enough  To overcome him: in that beastly fury  He has been known to commit outrages,  And cherish factions:
t: He would fight even if he had no enemies, and in his temper he has committed many crimes and encourages rebellion.

og: 'tis inferr'd to us,  His days are foul and his drink dangerous.
t: We have been told that he is a dangerous and wicked man.

og: He dies.
t: He will die.

og: Hard fate! he might have died in war.  My lords, if not for any parts in him—
t: How cruel! He would have died in battle if he did not have certain good qualities.

og: Though his right arm might purchase his own time  And be in debt to none
t: And even though his sword-arm has bought him a longer life, in which he owes nothing to anyone, take this as encouragement to change your ruling.

og: —yet, more to move you,  Take my deserts to his, and join 'em both:  And, for I know your reverend ages love  Security, I'll pawn my victories, all  My honours to you, upon his good returns.
t: Think of what's mine as his, and because I know you all love money, I'll give to you all that I have won at war in return for his safety.

og: If by this crime he owes the law his life,  Why, let the war receive 't in valiant gore  For law is strict, and war is nothing more.
t: If he owes his life for this crime, let it at least be had at war with the army. War can punish the way the law does.

og: We are for law: he dies; urge it no more,On height of our displeasure: friend or brother,He forfeits his own blood that spills another.
t: We represent the law. He will die, and stop pushing the point. Though it does not please us, he will die for murder, even if he is your friend or family.

og: Must it be so? it must not be. My lords,I do beseech you, know me.
t: Why does it have to be this way? It cannot be. Please, my lords, I beg you to trust me.

og: How!
t: How!

og: Call me to your remembrances.
t: Remember what I have done.

og: What!
t: What?

og: I cannot think but your age has forgot me;  It could not else be,
t: You cannot possibly have forgotten me, but there is no other reason you would deny me

og: I should prove so base,  To sue, and be denied such common grace:  My wounds ache at you.
t: after I have lowered myself to beg for something you would grant any other man. It hurts me to the very core.

og: Do you dare our anger?'Tis in few words, but spacious in effect;We banish thee for ever.
t: Are you seriously provoking us? In just a few words we can have an enormous impact. We banish you forever.

og: Banish me!Banish your dotage; banish usury,That makes the senate ugly.
t: Banish me! Banish your old ways! Banish your money-lending! Banish everything that has ruined the senate!

og: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee,  Attend our weightier judgment.
t: If we find you in Athens two days from now, you will face the most severe punishment.

og: And, not to swell  our spirit,  He shall be executed presently.
t: And even though it displeases us, your friend will be executed now.

og: Now the gods keep you old enough; that you may live  Only in bone, that none may look on you!  I'm worse than mad:
t: The gods have let you live so long that you are only skin and bones, and so ugly that no one will even look at you! I'm crazy with anger.

og: I have kept back their foes,  While they have told their money and let out  Their coin upon large interest, I myself  Rich only in large hurts. All those for this?
t: I have defended them from their enemies. They have lent their money to everyone and pocketed the earnings, while all I have are wounds from battle. All that fighting for this?

og: Is this the balsam that the usuring senate  Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment!  It comes not ill; I hate not to be banish'd;
t: Is this what the senate gives its captains for sacrificing themselves to battle? Banishment! Good! I would hate not to be banished.

og: It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury,  That I may strike at Athens. I'll cheer up  My discontented troops, and lay for hearts.
t: It makes me angry enough to attack Athens. I'll gather the troops and garner their support.

og: 'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds;  Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.
t: Countries are always at war, and soldiers should not have to face any more trials than the gods.

og: The good time of day to you, sir.
t: Good day, sir.

og: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lorddid but try us this other day.
t: You too. This feels familiar.

og: Upon that were my thoughts tiring, when weencountered: I hope it is not so low with him ashe made it seem in the trial of his several friends.
t: I was just thinking that when we met. I hope things are not so bad that Timon has had to borrow more from his friends.

og: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.
t: From what I see at this feast, I don't think so.

og: I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest  inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me  to put off;
t: I do. He sent me an invitation, and when I said I had other engagements,

og: but he hath conjured me beyond them, and  I must needs appear.
t: he pressed me further and told me I had to come.

og: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate  business, but he would not hear my excuse.
t: I also said I needed to deal with some business matters, but he didn't care.

og: I am  sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my  provision was out.
t: I am not happy to say it, but when he asked me for money, I had no more left to give him.

og: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how allthings go.
t: Same with me. I know how it is.

og: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed ofyou?
t: So does everyone here. How much money did he ask you for?

og: A thousand pieces.
t: A thousand pieces.

og: A thousand pieces!
t: A thousand pieces!

og: What of you?
t: What did he ask you for?

og: He sent to me, sir,—Here he comes.
t: He asked me for—here he is.

og: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?
t: Greetings, gentleman. How are you?

og: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.
t: Well, especially after seeing that you are well, too.

og: The swallow follows not summer more willing than weyour lordship.
t: We care as much about you as a bird that flies south cares for summer weather.

og: Nor more willingly leaves winter; such  summer-birds are men.
t: And you and other men have left me with the readiness that the bird flees from winter weather.

og: Gentlemen, our dinner will not  recompense this long stay: feast your ears with the  music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' the  trumpet's sound; we shall to 't presently.
t: Dinner is getting cold, gentlemen! Enjoy the music, if you like such humble playing. Let's go.

og: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordshipthat I returned you an empty messenger.
t: I hope you are not bitter that I could not lend you money.

og: O, sir, let it not trouble you.
t: Don't worry about it.

og: My noble lord,—
t: My noble lord—

og: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?
t: What a party!

og: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame,that, when your lordship this other day sent to me,I was so unfortunate a beggar.
t: Timon, I feel so bad that I had no money left to give you when you asked me.

og: Think not on 't, sir.
t: Don't worry about it.

og: If you had sent but two hours before,—
t: If you had come just two hours earlier—

og: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
t: Think about happier things.

og: Come, bring in all together.
t: Come here, the food is ready!

og: All covered dishes!
t: It must be good food if you cover it this way!

og: Royal cheer, I warrant you.
t: It looks like food for kings.

og: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yieldit.
t: As long as he has enough money and time, I would count on it from Timon.

og: How do you? What's the news?
t: Oh how are you? What is new with the world?

og: Alcibiades is banished: hear you of it?
t: Did you hear that Alcibiades is banished?

og: Alcibiades banished!
t: What? Alcibiades is banished?

og: 'Tis so, be sure of it.
t: I swear.

og: How! how!
t: What? How?

og: I pray you, upon what?
t: Why?

og: My worthy friends, will you draw near?
t: Come here, my friends.

og: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.
t: I'll tell you about it later. Let's eat now.

og: This is the old man still.
t: You speak of the famous Alcibiades?

og: Will 't hold? will 't hold?
t: Can it be? Will the punishment stick?

og: It does: but time will—and so—
t: Yes, but time will tell—

og: I do conceive.
t: I see.

og: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to  the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all  places alike.  Make not a city feast of it, to let  the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place:
t: Go to your chairs as hungrily as you might kiss the lips of your mistress. There are no assigned seats, when the food gets cold before people find out where they sit.

og: sit, sit. The gods require our thanks.  You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with  thankfulness. For your own gifts, make yourselves  praised: but reserve still to give, lest your  deities be despised.
t: Sit, sit, and thank the gods. I thank you for the gifts you have given, and hope you will keep enough for yourselves so that you can still be so charitable in the future.

og: Lend to each man enough, that  one need not lend to another; for, were your  godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the  gods.
t: You should have given enough that no man will have to give his own money to another, because even gods would not be successful in applying for a loan nowadays.

og: Make the meat be beloved more than the man  that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without  a score of villains: if there sit twelve women at  the table, let a dozen of them be—as they are.
t: Enjoy the meat more than you enjoy the man who provides you with it. Make sure also that twenty out of twenty men are villains, as you might let twelve women at a table be as they are.

og: The  rest of your fees, O gods—the senators of Athens,  together with the common lag of people—what is  amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for  destruction.
t: As for the rest, the senators and the commoners, destroy the worst parts of them.

og: For these my present friends, as they  are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to  nothing are they welcome.  Uncover, dogs, and lap.
t: My friends here, they mean nothing to me, so bless them with nothing. Here they are welcome to nothing. Uncover the dishes so the dogs may lick up the water.

og: What does his lordship mean?
t: What is this supposed to mean?

og: I know not.
t: I don't know.

og: May you a better feast never behold,  You knot of mouth-friends I smoke and lukewarm water  Is your perfection.
t: All you bottom-feeders, water and steam is the perfect meal for you, and I hope you never eat a better feast than this for the rest of your lives.

og: This is Timon's last;  Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,  Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces  Your reeking villany.
t: I, who endured all your flattery, wash myself of it and return to you your wickedness.

og: Live loathed and long,  Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,  Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,  You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies,  Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks!
t: I hope you live long and painful lives, you smooth-talking parasites, you wolves in sheeps' clothing, you weak fools of fortune, fake friends, worthless workers!

og: Of man and beast the infinite malady  Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go?
t: You'll die soon enough! May the worst disease cover you all over in scabs! What, are you leaving?

og: Soft! take thy physic first—thou too—and thou;—  Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none.
t: Come now, everyone, take your medicine first! Come on, I'll give you money and ask for nothing back!

og: What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast,  Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest.
t: What, everyone's leaving? From now on, let there never be a feast where such villains are not welcome.

og: Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be  Of Timon man and all humanity!
t: Burn down the house! Destroy all of Athens! Timon will from now on hate all of humanity!

og: How now, my lords!
t: What the hell was that?

og: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?
t: Have you ever seen someone as furious as Timon just now?

og: Push! did you see my cap?
t: Psh! Have you seen my hat?

og: I have lost my gown.
t: I can't find my coat.

og: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humour sways him.He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he hasbeat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?
t: He's a madman, and his insanity is what drives him. He gave me a jewel the other day, and now he has beaten it out of my hat. Have you seen the jewel?

og: Did you see my cap?
t: Have you seen my hat?

og: Here 'tis.
t: Here it is.

og: Here lies my gown.
t: And here's my coat.

og: Let's make no stay.
t: Let's get out of here.

og: Lord Timon's mad.
t: Timon is crazy.

og: I feel 't upon my bones.
t: Yes I am sure of it.

og: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.
t: One day he gives us diamonds, and the next day he throws stones at us!

og: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall,  That girdlest in those wolves, dive in the earth,  And fence not Athens!
t: Let me back on the city. Your walls that contain those ravenous wolves should sink into the earth instead of protecting you, Athens.

og: Matrons, turn incontinent!  Obedience fail in children! slaves and fools,  Pluck the grave wrinkled senate from the bench,
t: I hope your mothers become drunks and that your children grow bad-tempered! I hope that slaves and idiots replace the cranky old senators and rule from their seats,

og: And minister in their steads! to general filths  Convert o' the instant, green virginity,  Do 't in your parents' eyes! bankrupts, hold fast;  Rather than render back, out with your knives,  And cut your trusters' throats! bound servants, steal!
t: that little girls turn instantly into low whores and lose their virginities right in front of their parents' eyes, that bankrupt debtors pay back their debts by slitting their creditors' throats, and that servants bound to loyalty steal from their masters!

og: Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,  And pill by law. Maid, to thy master's bed;  Thy mistress is o' the brothel!
t: The great men of Athens are all greedy robbers and use the law to plunder for their own means. You, maid, go to your masters' bed, because your mistress is a whore!

og: Son of sixteen,  pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire,  With it beat out his brains!
t: You, sixteen-year-old son, steal the cane out of the hands of your old crippled father and use it to beat out his brains!

og: Piety, and fear,  Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,  Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighbourhood,  Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,  Degrees, observances, customs, and laws,  Decline to your confounding contraries,  And let confusion live!
t: All civic virtues—piety, fear, devotion, peace, justice, truth, respect, tranquility, neighborly love, education, manners, professions, ranks, observance, custom, law—let all your chaotic opposites reign in destruction!

og: Plagues, incident to men,  Your potent and infectious fevers heap  On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica,  Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt  As lamely as their manners.
t: You, plague, attack Athens with your powerful and infectious fevers! You, sciata, cripple all the senators and make their limbs as useless as their manners!

og: Lust and liberty  Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth,  That 'gainst the stream of virtue they may strive,  And drown themselves in riot!
t: You, free lust, crawl into the minds and bodies of teenagers so that they betray virtue and drown themselves in debauchery!

og: Itches, blains,  Sow all the Athenian bosoms; and their crop  Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath,  at their society, as their friendship, may  merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee,  But nakedness, thou detestable town!  Take thou that too, with multiplying bans!
t: I hope every Athenian is infected with horrible itches and boils, and be struck with leprosy. May each breath spread infection and make society poisonous! Evil city, I will spare you no evil but the sight of my naked body—but no, take that too!

og: Hear you, master steward, where's our master?Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?
t: Listen, where is our master? Are we done for? Fired? Is there nothing left?

og: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you?Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,I am as poor as you.
t: Guys, what do you want me to say? The gods hear me when I say that I am as broke as you are.

og: Such a house broke!  So noble a master fall'n! All gone!
t: How great a house gone bankrupt! How great a master fallen! Everything's gone!

og: and not  One friend to take his fortune by the arm,  And go along with him!
t: And there's not a single friend to help him in this unfortunate time and accompany him!

og: As we do turn our backs  From our companion thrown into his grave,
t: As we leave our friend, tossed into his grave,

og: So his familiars to his buried fortunes  Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,  Like empty purses pick'd;
t: so too do those friends whose fortunes were tied to his now run away, leaving with him only their lies, like purses emptied by a pick-pocket.

og: and his poor self,  A dedicated beggar to the air,  With his disease of all-shunn'd poverty,  Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows.
t: And the poor man will become a homeless beggar with his disease of poverty, walking alone in contempt. Look, here are more of our friends.

og: All broken implements of a ruin'd house.
t: All the shattered pieces of a ruined house.

og: Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery;  That see I by our faces; we are fellows still,  Serving alike in sorrow:
t: I can see in our sullen faces that all our hearts still wear the uniforms we served Timon in. We are still friends, serving him in sorrow.

og: leak'd is our bark,  And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,  Hearing the surges threat: we must all part  Into this sea of air.
t: It is as if our boat had a leak and we were standing on the sinking deck, hearing the water rising all around us. We must all leave each other to drown in this imaginary sea.

og: Good fellows all,  The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you.  Wherever we shall meet, for Timon's sake,
t: Friends, I'll share with you the last bit of money I have. Wherever we next meet, let's still be friends for Timon's sake.

og: Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say,  As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes,  'We have seen better days.'
t: Let's shake our heads and say, "We have seen better days," to honor our old master's fortune.

og: Let each take some;  Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:  Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.
t: Let's each take a bit of what's left. Put out your hands, and without saying one more word, let's all part poor in money, but rich in sadness.

og: O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!  Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,  Since riches point to misery and contempt?
t: Oh, the terrible sadness that glory can bring! Who wouldn't wish to never be rich, if all that riches lead to is misery and hate?

og: Who would be so mock'd with glory? or to live  But in a dream of friendship?  To have his pomp and all what state compounds  But only painted, like his varnish'd friends?
t: Who would ever accept fame or friendship, if all of the luxury and everything else that comes with it is fake, like those friends of Timon's?

og: Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,  Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,  When man's worst sin is, he does too much good!  Who, then, dares to be half so kind again?
t: Poor man, doing himself in by his own goodness! It's a strange curse when a man's worst sin is that he does too much good! Who will ever dare to be half as kind again?

og: For bounty, that makes gods, does still mar men.  My dearest lord, bless'd, to be most accursed,  Rich, only to be wretched, thy great fortunes  Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord!
t: The wealth that makes the gods ruins men. My good lord, blessed only to later be cursed, rich only to later be poor, your great fortune was built upon your greatest weaknesses. Oh what a kind man!

og: He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat  Of monstrous friends, nor has he with him to  Supply his life, or that which can command it.
t: He's cast out mad from this group of monsters, with nothing to live on at all and no way to make more money.

og: I'll follow and inquire him out:  I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;  Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still.
t: I'll follow and ask about him. I'll always serve him as well as I can. As long as I have any wealth, I'll be by his side.

og: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth  Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb  Infect the air!
t: Oh generous sun, suck all of this rotten dampness from the ground into the air below the moon!

og: Twinn'd brothers of one womb,  Whose procreation, residence, and birth,  Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes;  The greater scorns the lesser:
t: In the case of twin brothers, who were identically conceived, housed, and born out of the same womb into a world with different fortunes, it is the one with more who scorns the one with less.

og: not nature,  To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune,  But by contempt of nature.
t: Human nature is subject to many evils, and cannot bear great riches without reserving contempt for those without such luxuries.

og: Raise me this beggar, and deny 't that lord;  The senator shall bear contempt hereditary,  The beggar native honour.
t: I will become a beggar and restrain the lord within me, for the senator will be scorned, the beggar honored.

og: It is the pasture lards the rother's sides,  The want that makes him lean.
t: Whether or not one is wealthy is only a matter of luck: if an ox is born into abundant pastures, he will grow fat, whereas if he is born into scarcity, he will grow thin.

og: Who dares, who dares,  In purity of manhood stand upright,  And say 'This man's a flatterer?' if one be,  So are they all; for every grise of fortune  Is smooth'd by that below:
t: Who? Who will dare to stand up for what's right and call a man a flatterer? After all, if one man is a flatterer, so is everyone, because every level in a hierarchy is flattered by the one below it.

og: the learned pate  Ducks to the golden fool: all is oblique;  There's nothing level in our cursed natures,  But direct villany.
t: Smart men bow to rich fools. Everything is ridiculous, because we have nothing rational within our nature, just straight villainy.

og: Therefore, be abhorr'd  All feasts, societies, and throngs of men!  His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains:  Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots!
t: Thus I hate all feasts, society, and groups of people! Timon hates anything that resembles—or is—himself. All men go to hell! Earth, where are your roots?

og: Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate  With thy most operant poison! What is here?  Gold? yellow, glittering, precious gold? No, gods,  I am no idle votarist:
t: Whoever works to rise in the world ought to poison himself! What do we have here? Gold? Shiny yellow gold? No, I am not a false man—

og: roots, you clear heavens!
t: Where are you, roots?!

og: Thus much of this will make black white, foul fair,  Wrong right, base noble, old young, coward valiant.  Ha, you gods! why this?
t: Just this much gold will turn the world upside down, making black white, foul fair, wrong right, low high, old young, cowardice valor. Ha, gods! Why this little thing?

og: what this, you gods? Why, this  Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,  Pluck stout men's pillows from below their heads:
t: What is it, even? Why does this steal from you your loyal priests and servants, and steal the pillow from beneath a man's head?

og: This yellow slave  Will knit and break religions, bless the accursed,  Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves  And give them title, knee and approbation  With senators on the bench:
t: This yellow fiend will make and break religions, bless the lowly, and even make the leper liked, the thief as great as a senator!

og: this is it  That makes the wappen'd widow wed again;  She, whom the spital-house and ulcerous sores  Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices  To the April day again.
t: This little thing makes a widow get married a second time, and rejuvenates a woman so ugly that even the grossest men plagued with sores would have rejected her.

og: Come, damned earth,  Thou common whore of mankind, that put'st odds  Among the route of nations, I will make thee  Do thy right nature.
t: Come on, stupid earth, whoring around beneath the feet of different nations, I will lower myself to your level and take my revenge.

og: Ha! a drum ? Thou'rt quick,
t: What, a drum? So soon?

og: But yet I'll bury thee: thou'lt go, strong thief,  When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.  Nay, stay thou out for earnest.
t: I'll bury you: you will walk about again when your keeper cannot stand because of his gout. Actually, no, stay out here for leverage.

og: What art thou there? speak.
t: What are you doing there? Speak up.

og: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,For showing me again the eyes of man!
t: An animal, the same as you! Damn you for showing me again the eyes of a human!

og: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee,That art thyself a man?
t: What is your name? Has mankind been so awful to you? You are a man, after all.

og: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,That I might love thee something.
t: I am a man-hater, who hates mankind. I wish you were a dog, for your good as well as mine. Then I could love you at least a little.

og: I know thee well;But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.
t: I understand what you are saying, but do not know how you have arrived at these conclusions.

og: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee,  I not desire to know. Follow thy drum;  With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules:
t: I know you as well, more than I'd like to know. Go follow your drum and paint the ground with the red, red, red blood of men.

og: Religious canons, civil laws are cruel;  Then what should war be?
t: Religious and civil laws are cruel—why shouldn't war be cruel too?

og: Thy lips rot off!
t: Shut your filthy mouth!

og: I will not kiss thee; then the rot returnsTo thine own lips again.
t: Then I will not kiss you, so as not to dirty your mouth too.

og: How came the noble Timon to this change?
t: How has the noble Timon fallen to this place?

og: As the moon does, by wanting light to give:But then renew I could not, like the moon;There were no suns to borrow of.
t: Like the moon, which falls as it loses its light to give. But I cannot renew myself and start again like the moon. There are no suns out there to borrow light from.

og: Noble Timon,What friendship may I do thee?
t: Timon, what can I do for you?

og: None, but toMaintain my opinion.
t: Nothing, except follow my demands.

og: What is it, Timon?
t: What is it you want, Timon?

og: Promise me friendship, but perform none:
t: Promise me your friendship, but don't do anything that would make you seem like my friend.

og: if thou  wilt not promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art  a man! if thou dost perform, confound thee, for  thou art a man!
t: That way, whether you refuse or keep this promise, and whether you follow through or not, the gods may damn you, because you are like all these other men!

og: I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.
t: I have heard a bit about your bad luck.

og: Thou saw'st them, when I had prosperity.
t: You saw my bad luck even when I had my wealth.

og: I see them now; then was a blessed time.
t: No, I see your bad luck now. Those were great times when you had your wealth.

og: As thine is now, held with a brace of harlots.
t: Like your good times now with these whores.

og: Is this the Athenian minion, whom the worldVoiced so regardfully?
t: Is this the darling of Athens everyone spoke so well of?

og: Art thou Timandra?
t: You are Timandra?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: Be a whore still: they love thee not that use thee;  Give them diseases, leaving with thee their lust.
t: Keep whoring around. Those who use you don't love you, so you might as well give them diseases, because they give you their lust.

og: Make use of thy salt hours: season the slaves  For tubs and baths; bring down rose-cheeked youth  To the tub-fast and the diet.
t: Use these dirty hours well and prepare these villains for tubs and baths. Bring those bright youths down to their rightful place, trying to cure their venereal diseases with diets and salt-baths.

og: Hang thee, monster!
t: Go kill yourself you monster!

og: Pardon him, sweet Timandra; for his wits  Are drown'd and lost in his calamities.
t: Forgive him, Timandra. His mind has been muddled and lost in his troubles.

og: I have but little gold of late, brave Timon,  The want whereof doth daily make revolt  In my penurious band:
t: I have only a little money left, Timon, and the lack of it makes the possibility of revolt greater and greater each day in my poor band of soldiers.

og: I have heard, and grieved,  How cursed Athens, mindless of thy worth,  Forgetting thy great deeds, when neighbour states,  But for thy sword and fortune, trod upon them,—
t: I have heard and felt sorry for how Athens left you high and dry, completely forgetting you and your great deeds when neighboring states would have defeated the city had you not protected it with your sword and your wealth.

og: I prithee, beat thy drum, and get thee gone.
t: Please, play yourself out.

og: I am thy friend, and pity thee, dear Timon.
t: I'm your friend Timon. I feel for you.

og: How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?I had rather be alone.
t: Do you feel for the person whom you hurt? I'd rather be alone.

og: Why, fare thee well:Here is some gold for thee.
t: Well goodbye. Here is some gold.

og: Keep it, I cannot eat it.
t: Keep it. It won't feed me.

og: When I have laid proud Athens on a heap,—
t: When I destroy Athens in war—

og: Warr'st thou 'gainst Athens?
t: You're waging war on Athens?

og: Ay, Timon, and have cause.
t: Yes, Timon, and for a good reason.

og: The gods confound them all in thy conquest;And thee after, when thou hast conquer'd!
t: May the gods strike those you war against, and after you win, you as well!

og: Why me, Timon?
t: Why me too, Timon?

og: That, by killing of villains,  Thou wast born to conquer my country.
t: Because you were born to conquer my country by killing villains.

og: Put up thy gold: go on,—here's gold,—go on;  Be as a planetary plague, when Jove  Will o'er some high-viced city hang his poison  In the sick air:
t: Keep your gold and go, take it. Be like a plague that ravages the entire world, or like Zeus throwing poison over some wicked city.

og: let not thy sword skip one:  Pity not honour'd age for his white beard;  He is an usurer: strike me the counterfeit matron;  It is her habit only that is honest,  Herself's a bawd:
t: Do not spare any with your sword, and give no mercy to the elderly man, as he is a money-lender. Give no mercy to false women, because they only look honest and are all whores.

og: let not the virgin's cheek  Make soft thy trenchant sword; for those milk-paps,  That through the window-bars bore at men's eyes,  Are not within the leaf of pity writ,  But set them down horrible traitors:
t: Give no mercy to young virgins, because those breasts that break through the lines of her bodies and into men's eyes are horrible traitors and do not deserve pity.

og: spare not the babe,  Whose dimpled smiles from fools exhaust their mercy;  Think it a bastard, whom the oracle  Hath doubtfully pronounced thy throat shall cut,  And mince it sans remorse:
t: Do not spare any babies, whose smiling only earns the mercy of fools. Think of them as bastards, whom an oracle has foreseen will cut your throat, and crush it without any guilt.

og: swear against objects;  Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes;  Whose proof, nor yells of mothers, maids, nor babes,  Nor sight of priests in holy vestments bleeding,  Shall pierce a jot.
t: Swear not to listen to any objections, and arm your ears and your eyes so they shall not yield to the yells of mothers, maids, or babies, or the sight of priests bleeding in their holy clothes.

og: There's gold to pay soldiers:  Make large confusion; and, thy fury spent,  Confounded be thyself! Speak not, be gone.
t: Here's some gold to pay your soldiers. Make a riot, and after all your rage is gone, damn you! Don't speak to me. Just go.

og: Hast thou gold yet? I'll take the gold thougivest me,Not all thy counsel.
t: You still have gold? I'll take that, but not your advice.

og: Dost thou, or dost thou not, heaven's curseupon thee!
t: Do or don't, damn you.

og: Give us some gold, good Timon: hast thou more?
t: Give us some gold, too, Timon. Do you have any more?

og: Enough to make a whore forswear her trade,  And to make whores, a bawd. Hold up, you sluts,  Your aprons mountant:
t: Enough to get a whore to retire, as well as enough to turn women into whores too. Stop bothering me and holding your skirts up, you sluts.

og: you are not oathable,  Although, I know, you 'll swear, terribly swear  Into strong shudders and to heavenly agues  The immortal gods that hear you,
t: You are not trustworthy, though I do know you will swear shaking with supposed divinity onto the immortal gods.

og: —spare your oaths,  I'll trust to your conditions: be whores still;  And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you,  Be strong in whore, allure him, burn him up;
t: Spare your prayers, and I'll trust your characters. Keep whoring, and the man that tries to tell you to do otherwise, be sure to stay true to your profession, seduce him, and infect him with your venereal diseases.

og: Let your close fire predominate his smoke,  And be no turncoats: yet may your pains, six months,  Be quite contrary:
t: Let that hidden fire overpower his piety, and do not betray your craft so that you may keep laboring.

og: and thatch your poor thin roofs  With burthens of the dead;—some that were hang'd,  No matter:—wear them, betray with them: whore still;  Paint till a horse may mire upon your face,  A pox of wrinkles!
t: Cover your heads with wigs plucked from the hairs of the dead—even if they were hanged. Wear them and sin with them. Keep whoring around, with that thick makeup hiding all your wrinkles!

og: Well, more gold: what then?Believe't, that we'll do any thing for gold.
t: Tell us more with more gold. We'll do anything for gold!

og: Consumptions sow  In hollow bones of man; strike their sharp shins,  And mar men's spurring.
t: Plant syphilis into the hollow bones of men. Kick their shins and cripple them.

og: Crack the lawyer's voice,  That he may never more false title plead,  Nor sound his quillets shrilly: hoar the flamen,  That scolds against the quality of flesh,  And not believes himself:
t: Steal the voice of the lawyer, so he will never ever defend a false case or voice his small disagreements. Give diseases to the priest who scolds against carnal pleasures, but doesn't behave himself.

og: down with the nose,  Down with it flat; take the bridge quite away  Of him that, his particular to foresee,  Smells from the general weal: make curl'd-pate  ruffians bald;  And let the unscarr'd braggarts of the war  Derive some pain from you:
t: Make it so his nose rots off, so that for his private pleasures he loses the scent of public welfare. Make curly-haired scoundrels bald, and have the silly macho men in the army finally feel some pain from you.

og: plague all;  That your activity may defeat and quell  The source of all erection. There's more gold:  Do you damn others, and let this damn you,  And ditches grave you all!
t: Give diseases to everyone, so that in your profession you defeat all of men's power. Here's some more gold, so that you damn even more. But let it damn you, too, and send you to your graves!

og: More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.
t: We'll keep listening to you if you keep giving us money, Timon.

og: More whore, more mischief first; I have given you earnest.
t: With more whoring, and more mischief first. This payment is just a token.

og: Strike up the drum towards Athens! Farewell, Timon:If I thrive well, I'll visit thee again.
t: Drum up the march to Athens! Bye, Timon. If I am successful, I'll come back for you.

og: If I hope well, I'll never see thee more.
t: And I hope I never see you again.

og: I never did thee harm.
t: I never did you any harm.

og: Yes, thou spokest well of me.
t: Yes, you spoke well of me.

og: Call'st thou that harm?
t: And that's harm?

og: Men daily find it. Get thee away, and takeThy beagles with thee.
t: Some men think so. Go now and take your dogs with you.

og: We but offend him. Strike!
t: We're just making him more angry. Let's go!

og: That nature, being sick of man's unkindness,Should yet be hungry! Common mother, thou,
t: I cannot believe that those outraged at wicked men should still ask for money!

og: Whose womb unmeasurable, and infinite breast,  Teems, and feeds all;
t: You, earth, your fertile ground births and feeds everything.

og: whose self-same mettle,  Whereof thy proud child, arrogant man, is puff'd,  Engenders the black toad and adder blue,  The gilded newt and eyeless venom'd worm,
t: You are made of the same hard stuff that puffs out the chests of proud men, though is also the same stuff that produces disgusting critters like the black toad, the blue snake, the golden newt, and the blind, poisonous worm.

og: With all the abhorred births below crisp heaven  Whereon Hyperion's quickening fire doth shine;
t: The sun shines its life-giving fire equally on all of these horrid births.

og: Yield him, who all thy human sons doth hate,  From forth thy plenteous bosom, one poor root!  Ensear thy fertile and conceptious womb,  Let it no more bring out ingrateful man!
t: Earth, give me just one poor root, which all men hate! Dry up your fertile womb so that it never gives life to another man!

og: Go great with tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears;  Teem with new monsters, whom thy upward face  Hath to the marbled mansion all above  Never presented!
t: Bring forth tigers, dragons, wolves, and bears. Produce new monsters, never before presented to the world from your face which looks up into the heavens!

og: —O, a root,—dear thanks!—  Dry up thy marrows, vines, and plough-torn leas;  Whereof ungrateful man, with liquorish draughts  And morsels unctuous, greases his pure mind,  That from it all consideration slips!
t: Finally! A root! Dry up your marrow, vines, and grassy lands, which yield the sweet drinks and tasty food that grease the sides of ungrateful mens' minds, so that all that was considerate within them slips out!

og: More man? plague, plague!
t: Another man? The plague, the plague!

og: I was directed hither: men reportThou dost affect my manners, and dost use them.
t: I was directed here by men who tell me you have gone crazy and insult them.

og: 'Tis, then, because thou dost not keep a dog,Whom I would imitate: consumption catch thee!
t: It is true, and because you do not have a dog which I could imitate so as to flatter you, I hope you catch a disease!

og: This is in thee a nature but infected;  A poor unmanly melancholy sprung  From change of fortune.
t: This behavior is a symptom of your infected nature, which has caught an unmanly melancholy due to bad luck.

og: Why this spade? this place?  This slave-like habit? and these looks of care?  Thy flatterers yet wear silk, drink wine, lie soft;
t: Why this shovel? In this place? In these tattered clothes? With these sad looks? Those who flattered you still wear silk, drink wine, and lie down on soft beds.

og: Hug their diseased perfumes, and have forgot  That ever Timon was. Shame not these woods,  By putting on the cunning of a carper.
t: They hug their perfumed, diseased women, and have totally forgotten that Timon even existed. Do not curse these woods by becoming a cynic.

og: Be thou a flatterer now, and seek to thrive  By that which has undone thee: hinge thy knee,  And let his very breath, whom thou'lt observe,  Blow off thy cap; praise his most vicious strain,  And call it excellent:  thou wast told thus;
t: Be a flatterer and look to live off what once undid you. Bow your knee and heed every word of the men you would flatter as genius. Praise the worst parts of a man and call them excellent. That is what you used to be told.

og: Thou gavest thine ears like tapsters that bid welcome  To knaves and all approachers: 'tis most just  That thou turn rascal; hadst thou wealth again,  Rascals should have 't. Do not assume my likeness.
t: You once gave your ears to men like bartenders give their ears to the worst villains and rascals. It is only fair that you become a rascal. If you had your money again, rascals would have it. Do not act as I did to you, act like them!

og: Were I like thee, I'ld throw away myself.
t: If I were like you I'd throw myself away.

og: Thou hast cast away thyself, being like thyself;  A madman so long, now a fool. What, think'st  That the bleak air, thy boisterous chamberlain,  Will put thy shirt on warm?
t: You already have thrown yourself away, being the madman you were, and now an idiot. Do you really think that this cold air will act like a manservant and put on a warm shirt for you?

og: will these moss'd trees,  That have outlived the eagle, page thy heels,  And skip where thou point'st out? will the  cold brook,  Candied with ice, caudle thy morning taste,  To cure thy o'er-night's surfeit?
t: Do you really think that these mossy trees, which have outlived eagles, will follow your every step? That the cold brook crusted in ice will give you a warm drink to cure a hangover?

og: Call the creatures  Whose naked natures live in an the spite  Of wreakful heaven, whose bare unhoused trunks,  To the conflicting elements exposed,  Answer mere nature; bid them flatter thee;  O, thou shalt find—
t: Call out to the animals who live naked despite the fall of man, who expose their bodies to the harsh elements and contend with nature. Call them to flatter you and, oh, you will find—

og: A fool of thee: depart.
t: You're an idiot. Go away.

og: I love thee better now than e'er I did.
t: I love you more than I ever did.

og: I hate thee worse.
t: I hate you worse.

og: Why?
t: Why?

og: Thou flatter'st misery.
t: You flatter my misery.

og: I flatter not; but say thou art a caitiff.
t: I am not flattering you. I am calling you a wretch.

og: Why dost thou seek me out?
t: Why did you look for me?

og: To vex thee.
t: To anger you.

og: Always a villain's office or a fool's.Dost please thyself in't?
t: That was always the job of a villain or a fool. Do you like it?

og: Ay.
t: Sure.

og: What! a knave too?
t: Ah! So you're scoundrel too!

og: If thou didst put this sour-cold habit on  To castigate thy pride, 'twere well: but thou  Dost it enforcedly; thou'ldst courtier be again,  Wert thou not beggar.
t: If you assumed this disposition to punish yourself for our pride, that was a good idea. But you are forcing it! If you weren't a beggar, you could be a courtier again.

og: Willing misery  Outlives encertain pomp, is crown'd before:  The one is filling still, never complete;
t: Willful poverty is safer than uncertain luxury, and achieves what it wants sooner. One is always seeking more and never fulfilled.

og: The other, at high wish: best state, contentless,  Hath a distracted and most wretched being,  Worse than the worst, content.  Thou shouldst desire to die, being miserable.
t: The other will accept no better situation, but has a crazy and miserable existence and is happy with the worst of the worst. You should kill yourself, as miserable as you are.

og: Not by his breath that is more miserable.  Thou art a slave, whom Fortune's tender arm  With favour never clasp'd; but bred a dog.
t: Not under the advice of a man even more miserable. You are a slave, a dog, who was always unlucky.

og: Hadst thou, like us from our first swath, proceeded  The sweet degrees that this brief world affords  To such as may the passive drugs of it  Freely command, thou wouldst have plunged thyself  In general riot; melted down thy youth  In different beds of lust;
t: If you were born like I was into a sweet life this world gives to whoever it likes, you would have gone crazy and wasted your youth in lusty beds.

og: and never learn'd  The icy precepts of respect, but follow'd  The sugar'd game before thee.
t: You would never have learned hard reason, but instead followed all temptations before you.

og: But myself,  Who had the world as my confectionary,  The mouths, the tongues, the eyes and hearts of men  At duty, more than I could frame employment,  That numberless upon me stuck as leaves  Do on the oak, hive with one winter's brush  Fell from their boughs and left me open, bare  For every storm that blows:
t: But I, who was born right in the place where all sweet things are made, and where countless mouths, tongues, eyes, and hearts of men waited at my command, stuck to me like leaves stick to an oak, I was abandoned by all them, as if those leaves had all dropped at the first sight of winter and left me bare to feel every storm.

og: I, to bear this,  That never knew but better, is some burden:  Thy nature did commence in sufferance, time  Hath made thee hard in't. Why shouldst thou hate men?
t: Trust me, you who never knew any better, bearing this tragedy is a great burden. Your life began in suffering, and you have grown used to it. Why should you hate men?

og: They never flatter'd thee: what hast thou given?  If thou wilt curse, thy father, that poor rag,  Must be thy subject, who in spite put stuff  To some she beggar and compounded thee  Poor rogue hereditary.
t: They never flattered you? What did you give them? If you will curse anyone it should be your father, because he had sex with some poor woman out of spite and conceived you.

og: Hence, be gone!  If thou hadst not been born the worst of men,  Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.
t: So just go away! If you had not been born in the worst position, you would have been a false flatterer.

og: Art thou proud yet?
t: Ha! You are still proud?

og: Ay, that I am not thee.
t: Yes, proud of the fact that I'm not you.

og: I, that I wasNo prodigal.
t: And I'm proud of the fact that I was never a wasteful man like you.

og: I, that I am one now:  Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee,  I'ld give thee leave to hang it. Get thee gone.
t: Yes and I'm still proud that I am a wasteful man still. I would still give all the wealth I have—nothing—to you. Get away from me.

og: That the whole life of Athens were in this!  Thus would I eat it.
t: I wish all of Athens were in this! I would eat it!

og: Here; I will mend thy feast.
t: Here, improve your feast.

og: First mend my company, take away thyself.
t: First improve my company and get away from me.

og: So I shall mend mine own, by the lack of thine.
t: That way I would improve my own company for the lack of yours.

og: 'Tis not well mended so, it is but botch'd;if not, I would it were.
t: It would not be better that way, because you'd still be with yourself.

og: What wouldst thou have to Athens?
t: What report would you like me to bring Athens for you?

og: Thee thither in a whirlwind. If thou wilt,Tell them there I have gold; look, so I have.
t: A tornado, if you could, and tell them that I have more gold here. Look, right here.

og: Here is no use for gold.
t: Gold is useless here.

og: The best and truest;For here it sleeps, and does no hired harm.
t: And so it is here the best, where it sleeps and doesn't do any harm.

og: Where liest o' nights, Timon?
t: Where do you sleep here Timon?

og: Under that's above me.Where feed'st thou o' days, Apemantus?
t: Under what's above me. Where do you eat these days, Apemantus?

og: Where my stomach finds meat; or, rather, where I eatit.
t: Wherever I can find meat, or rather, where I eat meat.

og: Would poison were obedient and knew my mind!
t: I wish poison would go wherever my mind sent it!

og: Where wouldst thou send it?
t: Where would you send it?

og: To sauce thy dishes.
t: To your plates.

og: The middle of humanity thou never knewest, but the  extremity of both ends:
t: You never inhabited the middle ranks of humanity, only the very rich and the very poor.

og: when thou wast in thy gilt  and thy perfume, they mocked thee for too much  curiosity;
t: When you were basking in gold in perfume, they all mocked you for your meticulousness.

og: in thy rags thou knowest none, but art  despised for the contrary. There's a medlar for  thee, eat it.
t: In your tattered rags you don't have any of that left, but are despised for being messy and dirty. Here's a little fruit for you, eat it.

og: On what I hate I feed not.
t: I don't eat what I hate.

og: Dost hate a medlar?
t: You hate medlar?

og: Ay, though it look like thee.
t: Yes. It looks rotten like you.

og: An thou hadst hated meddlers sooner, thou shouldsthave loved thyself better now. What man didst thouever know unthrift that was beloved after his means?
t: If you had hated meddlers sooner, you would have loved your station better now. What wasteful man did you ever meet that was well-liked after his money was gone?

og: Who, without those means thou talkest of, didst thouever know beloved?
t: Who have you ever known that was well-liked without any means at all?

og: Myself.
t: Me.

og: I understand thee; thou hadst some means to keep adog.
t: True. The dogs love you because you only have enough means to keep a dog.

og: What things in the world canst thou nearest compareto thy flatterers?
t: What would you compare your flatterers to?
