og: Women nearest; but men, men are the thingsthemselves. What wouldst thou do with the world,Apemantus, if it lay in thy power?
t: Women, probably. But men too, because they are men themselves. What would you do with the world if you were all-powerful, Apemantus?

og: Give it the beasts, to be rid of the men.
t: Give it to the animals and get rid of all men.

og: Wouldst thou have thyself fall in the confusion ofmen, and remain a beast with the beasts?
t: Would you fall with the rest of the men and remain an animal?

og: Ay, Timon.
t: Yes, Timon.

og: A beastly ambition, which the gods grant thee t'  attain to! If thou wert the lion, the fox would  beguile thee; if thou wert the lamb, the fox would  eat three:
t: What a beastly thing for the gods to have you wish! If you were a lion, the fox would trick you; if you were a lamb, the fox would deceive three of you;

og: if thou wert the fox, the lion would  suspect thee, when peradventure thou wert accused by  the ass: if thou wert the ass, thy dulness would  torment thee, and still thou livedst but as a  breakfast to the wolf:
t: if you were a fox, the lion would be suspicious of you when you were accused by the donkey; if you were a donkey, your stupidity would torment you, and you would only be the breakfast of the wolf;

og: if thou wert the wolf, thy  greediness would afflict thee, and oft thou shouldst  hazard thy life for thy dinner: wert thou the  unicorn, pride and wrath would confound thee and  make thine own self the conquest of thy fury:
t: if you were a wolf, your greed would plague you, and you would have to risk your life just for dinner; if you were a unicorn, pride and anger would end you and when in your anger you rammed your horn and got stuck in a tree;

og: wert  thou a bear, thou wouldst be killed by the horse:  wert thou a horse, thou wouldst be seized by the  leopard: wert thou a leopard, thou wert german to  the lion and the spots of thy kindred were jurors on  thy life:
t: if you were a bear, you would be killed by the horse; if you were a horse; you would be attacked by the leopard; if you were a leopard, you would be related to the lion and the crimes of your relatives would condemn you to death.

og: all thy safety were remotion and thy  defence absence. What beast couldst thou be, that  were not subject to a beast? and what a beast art  thou already, that seest not thy loss in  transformation!
t: Your only safety would lie in leaving one place for another, so what beast could you be that you would not fall prey to some other beast? What kind of animal are you already that you cannot see what you would lose in changing into an animal!?

og: If thou couldst please me with speaking to me, thoumightst have hit upon it here: the commonwealth ofAthens is become a forest of beasts.
t: If your speech could ever please me, it would be these observations. The state of Athens has become a forest of beasts.

og: How has the ass broke the wall, that thou art out of the city?
t: How? Has a donkey broken down the wall, so you find yourself outside the city?

og: Yonder comes a poet and a painter: the plague of  company light upon thee!
t: Look, here comes a poet and a painter. I hope you catch the plague of their company!

og: I will fear to catch it  and give way: when I know not what else to do, I'll  see thee again.
t: For fear of catching it I'll leave now. I'll see you again when I have nothing better to do.

og: When there is nothing living but thee, thou shalt bewelcome. I had rather be a beggar's dog than Apemantus.
t: When you're the last man on earth, you'll be welcome here. I would rather be a beggar's dog than you.

og: Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.
t: You are the captain of all fools.

og: Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!
t: I wish you were clean enough to spit on.

og: A plague on thee! thou art too bad to curse.
t: Get bit! You aren't even good enough to curse.

og: All villains that do stand by thee are pure.
t: Villains look good in your company.

og: There is no leprosy but what thou speak'st.
t: Your speech is worse than leprosy.

og: If I name thee.I'll beat thee, but I should infect my hands.
t: When I say your name. I'll beat you up, if only touching you wouldn't infect my hands!

og: I would my tongue could rot them off!
t: I wish my tongue could rot them off!

og: Away, thou issue of a mangy dog!Choler does kill me that thou art alive;I swound to see thee.
t: Get away, you son of a bitch! Your life makes me angry enough to die. I swoon just looking at you!

og: Would thou wouldst burst!
t: Maybe you'll explode!

og: Away,Thou tedious rogue! I am sorry I shall loseA stone by thee.
t: Get away you dumb peasant! It's sad I have to waste a stone on you.

og: Beast!
t: Beast!

og: Slave!
t: Slave!

og: Toad!
t: Toad!

og: Rogue, rogue, rogue!  I am sick of this false world, and will love nought  But even the mere necessities upon 't.
t: You worthless, worthless man! I am sick of this lying world and will not love anything but the most basic necessities.

og: Then, Timon, presently prepare thy grave;  Lie where the light foam the sea may beat  Thy grave-stone daily:
t: So, Timon, prepare your own grave, lie down here where the light foam of the sea might lap against your grave stone every single day.

og: make thine epitaph,  That death in me at others' lives may laugh.
t: Make your own epitaph, so my death will laugh at the lives of others.

og: O thou sweet king-killer, and dear divorce  'Twixt natural son and sire! thou bright defiler  Of Hymen's purest bed! thou valiant Mars!
t: Oh you sweet little king-killer, which can set even a son and father at odds! You that can defile the bed of Hymen like Mars!

og: Thou ever young, fresh, loved and delicate wooer,  Whose blush doth thaw the consecrated snow  That lies on Dian's lap!
t: You forever young, fresh, beloved, and delicate wooer, that can ruin the chastity of Diana with just a blush!

og: thou visible god,  That solder'st close impossibilities,  And makest them kiss! that speak'st with  every tongue,  To every purpose!
t: You beautiful god, which can sew together impossible events and make them kiss! That can speak in every language and for any purpose!

og: O thou touch of hearts!  Think, thy slave man rebels, and by thy virtue  Set them into confounding odds, that beasts  May have the world in empire!
t: You tester of hearts, that think your slave man rebels against you and, with your power, set him at odds with himself so that beasts may rule the world!

og: Would 'twere so!But not till I am dead. I'll say thou'st gold:Thou wilt be throng'd to shortly.
t: If only it were so! But not until I am dead. I'll say to gold that it will be rushed to before long.

og: Throng'd to!
t: Rushed to!?

og: Ay.
t: Yes.

og: Thy back, I prithee.
t: Show me your back and leave.

og: Live, and love thy misery.
t: May you live in misery and love it too.

og: Long live so, and so die.
t: May you live long and miserable too, then die.

og: I am quit.Moe things like men! Eat, Timon, and abhor them.
t: I am rid of him, and yet more men! Hate them, Timon, and eat your food.

og: Where should he have this gold? It is some poor  fragment, some slender sort of his remainder:
t: Where could his gold be? It is the last scrap of his life of wealth.

og: the  mere want of gold, and the falling-from of his  friends, drove him into this melancholy.
t: It was the mere desire for gold and the betrayal of his friends which drove him to this depression.

og: It is noised he hath a mass of treasure.
t: I have heard he has a huge treasure.

og: Let us make the assay upon him: if he care notfor't, he will supply us easily; if he covetouslyreserve it, how shall's get it?
t: Let's test that. If he doesn't care about it, he'll give it to us without a care. If he covets it, how will we get it?

og: True; for he bears it not about him, 'tis hid.
t: That's a good question, because he doesn't have it with him. It's hidden.

og: Is not this he?
t: Is that not him?

og: Where?
t: Where?

og: 'Tis his description.
t: That's what he's supposed to look like.

og: He; I know him.
t: Him? I recognize him.

og: Save thee, Timon.
t: God bless you, Timon?

og: Now, thieves?
t: What do you want, thieves?

og: Soldiers, not thieves.
t: We're soldiers, not thieves.

og: Both too; and women's sons.
t: Both, and women's sons too.

og: We are not thieves, but men that much do want.
t: We are not thieves, just poor men.

og: Your greatest want is, you want much of meat.  Why should you want?
t: The greatest thing you lack is brought about by your great desire to eat a lot—why else would you feel poor?

og: Behold, the earth hath roots;  Within this mile break forth a hundred springs;  The oaks bear mast, the briers scarlet hips;
t: Look here, the earth has roots, and within a mile are a hundred springs. The oaks have nuts, the briers red berries.

og: The bounteous housewife, nature, on each bush  Lays her full mess before you. Want! why want?
t: Nature is a generous housewife, who gives a great meal on each bush. Poor! How could you feel poor?

og: We cannot live on grass, on berries, water,As beasts and birds and fishes.
t: We are not animals, birds, nor fish. We cannot live on just grass, berries, and water.

og: Nor on the beasts themselves, the birds, and fishes;  You must eat men.
t: No you cannot even live on animals like birds and fish yourselves. You must eat men.

og: Yet thanks I must you con  That you are thieves profess'd, that you work not  In holier shapes: for there is boundless theft  In limited professions.
t: Though I ought to thank you for at least being honest thieves who do not hide behind some more respectable disguise, for there is thievery in other professions as well.

og: Rascal thieves,  Here's gold. Go, suck the subtle blood o' the grape,  Till the high fever seethe your blood to froth,  And so 'scape hanging: trust not the physician;  His antidotes are poison, and he slays  Moe than you rob:
t: Here's some gold, you dirty thieves. Go now and drink all the wine you can until you catch a deadly fever that makes your blood foam. Do not trust the doctor, though, because his cures are poisonous and he kills men even more often than you rob them, taking both money and lives.

og: take wealth and lives together;  Do villany, do, since you protest to do't,  Like workmen. I'll example you with thievery.
t: Wreak havoc as your occupation dictates,  and like one being instructed in his occupation, I'll give you good examples of thieves.

og: The sun's a thief, and with his great attraction  Robs the vast sea: the moon's an arrant thief,  And her pale fire she snatches from the sun:  The sea's a thief, whose liquid surge resolves  The moon into salt tears: the earth's a thief,  That feeds and breeds by a composture stolen  From general excrement  :
t: The sun is a thief for robbing water from the vast sea; the moon is a thief for snatching light off the sun; the sea is a thief as its tides surge forth, dissolve the moon into salty tears; the earth is a thief as it steals and feeds off the manure of animals.

og: each thing's a thief:  The laws, your curb and whip, in their rough power  Have uncheque'd theft. Love not yourselves: away,  Rob one another. There's more gold.
t: Everything is a thief, from the laws to its enforcement, which use their unlimited power to steal. And do not make yourselves the exception, go away and rob one another. Here's some more gold.

og: Cut throats:  All that you meet are thieves: to Athens go,  Break open shops; nothing can you steal,  But thieves do lose it: steal no less for this  I give you; and gold confound you howsoe'er! Amen.
t: Go cut some throats, because everyone you meet is a thief. Go to Athens, pillage shops, because nothing you steal will not come from a thief's pocket. Do not steal any less because I'm giving you this, more gold, which I hope may curse you! Amen.

og: Has almost charmed me from my profession, bypersuading me to it.
t: He almost makes me want to give up my profession by talking me into it.

og: 'Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advisesus; not to have us thrive in our mystery.
t: His hatred of mankind is what gives us advice, not his concern for our craft.

og: I'll believe him as an enemy, and give over my trade.
t: I'd trust him about as much as my enemy and just give up thieving altogether.

og: Let us first see peace in Athens: there is no timeso miserable but a man may be true.
t: Let's at least wait until the war is over. There is no worse time to be honest than a war.

og: O you gods!  Is yond despised and ruinous man my lord?  Full of decay and failing? O monument  And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow'd!
t: Good god! Is that hateful man in tatters, looking so down and out, really my lord? Oh he is a memorial of what happens when good deeds are received ungratefully!

og: What an alteration of honour  Has desperate want made!  What viler thing upon the earth than friends  Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends!
t: Poverty has made such a remarkable change to his honorable appearance! How vile his friends were to bring down such a great man!

og: How rarely does it meet with this time's guise,  When man was wish'd to love his enemies!  Grant I may ever love, and rather woo  Those that would mischief me than those that do!
t: It really shows the accuracy of that saying, "Love your enemies!" I would indeed much rather love those who wish me harm to my face than those who pretend to be my friends and stab me in the back.

og: Has caught me in his eye: I will present  My honest grief unto him; and, as my lord,  Still serve him with my life. My dearest master!
t: He has seen me, and I will show him how much I grieve for him, and how I promise still to serve him. My fine master!

og: Away! what art thou?
t: Go away! Who are you?

og: Have you forgot me, sir?
t: Have you forgotten who I am?

og: Why dost ask that? I have forgot all men;Then, if thou grant'st thou'rt a man, I have forgot thee.
t: Why bother asking that? I have forgotten all men. If you agree that you are indeed a man, then I have forgotten you too.

og: An honest poor servant of yours.
t: I was your poor and loyal servant.

og: Then I know thee not:I never had honest man about me, I; allI kept were knaves, to serve in meat to villains.
t: Then I definitely do not know you, because I never had an honest man around me. All those I kept around me were liars, because I wanted to serve meat to villains.

og: The gods are witness,Ne'er did poor steward wear a truer griefFor his undone lord than mine eyes for you.
t: The gods know that there has never been an assistant racked with sadness for his lord the way I am looking at you.

og: What, dost thou weep? Come nearer. Then I  love thee,  Because thou art a woman,
t: What, are you crying? Come closer. I do love you, now, because these tears show you to be a woman.

og: and disclaim'st  Flinty mankind; whose eyes do never give  But thorough lust and laughter.
t: You give up your manhood, because no man's eyes ever did tear up, except for lust or laughter.

og: Pity's sleeping:  Strange times, that weep with laughing, not with weeping!
t: Pity may as well be asleep, for these are strange times, in which people weep for laughter and not in sadness.

og: I beg of you to know me, good my lord,To accept my grief and whilst this poor wealth lastsTo entertain me as your steward still.
t: I beg you, please recognize me, my good lord. That way you can accept my sadness and let me serve as your assistant while this bad luck continues.

og: Had I a steward  So true, so just, and now so comfortable?  It almost turns my dangerous nature mild.  Let me behold thy face. Surely, this man  Was born of woman.
t: Did I really have an assistant so honest, fair, and comforting? It almost cures me of my dangerous and violent thoughts. Let me see your face: you are definitely a man born of a woman.

og: Forgive my general and exceptless rashness,  You perpetual-sober gods! I do proclaim  One honest man—mistake me not—but one;  No more, I pray,—and he's a steward.  How fain would I have hated all mankind!
t: Forgive me gods, for assuming the worst of all men. I admit now that there is one honest man, only one. No more, I swear—and he's just an assistant. How I dared to hate all of mankind!

og: And thou redeem'st thyself: but all, save thee,  I fell with curses.  Methinks thou art more honest now than wise;  For, by oppressing and betraying me,  Thou mightst have sooner got another service:
t: You do redeem yourself, but the rest I did lay flat with insults. I think you are more honest than wise, because you might have been better off betraying me.

og: For many so arrive at second masters,  Upon their first lord's neck.
t: Many do have second masters at the expense of their first.

og: But tell me true—  For I must ever doubt, though ne'er so sure—  Is not thy kindness subtle, covetous,  If not a usuring kindness, and, as rich men deal gifts,  Expecting in return twenty for one?
t: But tell me, please, is your kindness not a subtle, greedy, and self-serving kind of kindness, which hopes to get what it gives twenty-to-one?

og: No, my most worthy master; in whose breast  Doubt and suspect, alas, are placed too late:  You should have fear'd false times when you did feast:  Suspect still comes where an estate is least.
t: No, master, in whom doubt and suspicion have taken hold too late. You should have feared lies when you threw feasts with your wealth, but your suspicion comes when you are most poor.

og: That which I show, heaven knows, is merely love,  Duty and zeal to your unmatched mind,  Care of your food and living;
t: What I show you is true love, duty, and enthusiasm for your outstanding mind, along with care for your wellbeing.

og: and, believe it,  My most honour'd lord,  For any benefit that points to me,  Either in hope or present, I'ld exchange  For this one wish, that you had power and wealth  To requite me, by making rich yourself.
t: Believe me, my lord, that any advantage I could gain now I would exchange for one wish: that you had the power and wealth to make yourself rich. That would be the return for my admiration.

og: Look thee, 'tis so! Thou singly honest man,  Here, take: the gods out of my misery  Have sent thee treasure.
t: Look here, it is true! You uniquely honest man, take this. The gods have given you a gift out of my misery.

og: Go, live rich and happy;  But thus condition'd: thou shalt build from men;  Hate all, curse all, show charity to none,
t: Go be rich and happy, but under one condition: you take advantage of other men, hate all of them, curse all of them, and show charity to none of them.

og: But let the famish'd flesh slide from the bone,  Ere thou relieve the beggar; give to dogs  What thou deny'st to men; let prisons swallow 'em,  Debts wither 'em to nothing;
t: Let the starving flesh slide off the bones of a beggar before you give him any money. Give to dogs what you do not give to men, whom you should let go to prison in debt.

og: be men like  blasted woods,  And may diseases lick up their false bloods!  And so farewell and thrive.
t: Let men be like dying woods, with diseases eating at their lying blood. Live this way, and goodbye.

og: O, let me stay,And comfort you, my master.
t: Let me stay and comfort you, master.

og: If thou hatest curses,Stay not; fly, whilst thou art blest and free:Ne'er see thou man, and let me ne'er see thee.
t: If you hate to be insulted, do not stay. Go away, and while you are blessed and free, never meet with another man, and never let me see you here again.

og: As I took note of the place, it cannot be far wherehe abides.
t: As I recall, he can't be far from here.

og: What's to be thought of him? does the rumour holdfor true, that he's so full of gold?
t: What do you think? Do you think it's true that he's got a hidden stash of gold?

og: Certain: Alcibiades reports it; Phrynia and  Timandra had gold of him:
t: Definitely. Alcibiades says so, and Phrynia and Timandra got gold from him.

og: he likewise enriched poor  straggling soldiers with great quantity: 'tis said  he gave unto his steward a mighty sum.
t: He also gave the poor soldiers a ton. I also heard he gave his assistant a lot too.

og: Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.
t: So his bankruptcy has just been a test for his friends.

og: Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens  again, and flourish with the highest.
t: It can't be anything else. You'll see him high and mighty in Athens again, to be sure.

og: Therefore  'tis not amiss we tender our loves to him, in this  supposed distress of his:
t: For that reason it's not crazy to appeal to him in his supposed distress.

og: it will show honestly in  us; and is very likely to load our purposes with  what they travail for, if it be a just true report  that goes of his having.
t: It'll look good for us, and it is likely to end in us receiving what the others got, if it is in fact true that he has money.

og: What have you now to present unto him?
t: What do you have to give to him?

og: Nothing at this time but my visitation: only I willpromise him an excellent piece.
t: Nothing but my presence for now. I will promise him an excellent work of art.

og: I must serve him so too, tell him of an intentthat's coming toward him.
t: Me too, and to promise him something in the future.

og: Good as the best. Promising is the very air o' the  time: it opens the eyes of expectation:  performance is ever the duller for his act;
t: Good idea. Promises are all the rage right now. They open the door for expectation, whereas actions themselves are merely done once they happen.

og: and,  but in the plainer and simpler kind of people, the  deed of saying is quite out of use. To promise is  most courtly and fashionable:
t: With the exception of the plainer and simpler sort, the fulfillment of promises has gone out of fashion. But still promising itself is current and stylish.

og: performance is a kind  of will or testament which argues a great sickness  in his judgment that makes it.
t: The actual doing of the thing is a kind of statement that shows a lack of judgment in the person who made the promise in the first place.

og: Excellent workman! thou canst not paint aman so bad as is thyself.
t: What an artist! You couldn't paint a man worse than yourself.

og: I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for  him: it must be a personating of himself;
t: I am thinking about what I will say I have brought him. It must be some kind of portrait of himself,

og: a satire  against the softness of prosperity, with a discovery  of the infinite flatteries that follow youth and opulency.
t: maybe a satire about the flightiness of wealth, with an exposition about the many flatteries that youth and opulence brings with it.

og: Must thou needs stand for a villain inthine own work? wilt thou whip thine own faults inother men? Do so, I have gold for thee.
t: Do you really need to model a villain in your work? Would you chastise your own vices in other men? Do it, and I've got gold for you.

og: Nay, let's seek him:Then do we sin against our own estate,When we may profit meet, and come too late.
t: Let's go look for him. We would do wrong to our own prosperity if we were to arrive to late to such an opportunity.

og: True;When the day serves, before black-corner'd night,Find what thou want'st by free and offer'd light. Come.
t: For sure. Before night falls, we ought to find what is offered freely in the light of day. Follow me.

og: I'll meet you at the turn. What a  god's gold,  That he is worshipp'd in a baser temple  Than where swine feed!
t: I'll play your own little game. What a magnificent god is gold, that it is worshipped in a place grosser than a pigpen.

og: 'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam,  Settlest admired reverence in a slave:
t: It is the thing that rigs the ship and sets it on its journey, the thing that makes a slave honor his master.

og: To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye  Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey!  Fit I meet them.
t: May people continue to worship it! May its disciples forever be chased with its own unique plagues. It's about time to talk to them.

og: Hail, worthy Timon!
t: Hey, Timon!

og: Our late noble master!
t: Our great master!

og: Have I once lived to see two honest men?
t: Have I ever seen two such honest men?

og: Sir,  Having often of your open bounty tasted,  Hearing you were retired, your friends fall'n off,  Whose thankless natures—O abhorred spirits!—  Not all the whips of heaven are large enough:
t: Sir, after having received so many of your gifts, and then hearing you were retired, abandoned by friends so ungrateful that all the whips of heaven are not large enough to punish them.

og: What! to you,  Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence  To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover  The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude  With any size of words.
t: Incredible! To you, whose stellar generosity gave life to them! It drives me mad, and I cannot conceive of any way to describe this level of ingratitude.

og: Let it go naked, men may see't the better:You that are honest, by being what you are,Make them best seen and known.
t: Let it go. Some men might be more optimistic. Your truthfulness, your being what you proclaim to be, make ungrateful men more noticeable.

og: He and myselfHave travail'd in the great shower of your gifts,And sweetly felt it.
t: He and I have triumphed in the great shower of your gifts and enjoyed it so much!

og: Ay, you are honest men.
t: Yes, you are honest men.

og: We are hither come to offer you our service.
t: We have come to offer you our service.

og: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you?Can you eat roots, and drink cold water? no.
t: Such honest men! How could I ever repay you? Can you eat roots or drink cold water? No.

og: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.
t: We'll do what we can for you.

og: Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold;I am sure you have: speak truth; ye're honest men.
t: You are both honest men and have heard that I have gold. I am sure that you have. Tell me the truth, honest men.

og: So it is said, my noble lord; but thereforeCame not my friend nor I.
t: We have heard that. But that is not why we've come.

og: Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeitBest in all Athens: thou'rt, indeed, the best;Thou counterfeit'st most lively.
t: Good honest men! You draw the best portrait in all of Athens. Yes, you are the best, your counterfeits are the most lifelike.

og: So, so, my lord.
t: So it is, my lord.

og: E'en so, sir, as I say.
t: Yes, it is as I said.

og: And, for thy fiction,  Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth  That thou art even natural in thine art.
t: And as for your fiction, the lines swell with material so fine and smooth that your art comes to equal nature.

og: But, for all this, my honest-natured friends,  I must needs say you have a little fault:  Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I  You take much pains to mend.
t: But in spite of all this, my truthful friends, I must say that you do have one vice. It's not such a bad thing, and you shouldn't try too hard to fix it.

og: Beseech your honourTo make it known to us.
t: Please, Timon, tell us what it is.

og: You'll take it ill.
t: You won't like it.

og: Most thankfully, my lord.
t: We'll appreciate it, my lord.

og: Will you, indeed?
t: Will you really?

og: Doubt it not, worthy lord.
t: Definitely.

og: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave,That mightily deceives you.
t: Both of you are too trustful of scoundrels who wish to deceive you.

og: Do we, my lord?
t: Are we really?

og: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble,  Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him,  Keep in your bosom:
t: Definitely. You hear him cheat, see him pretend, and watch him commit crimes, and all the while you love him, feed him, and keep him close,

og: yet remain assured  That he's a made-up villain.
t: knowing full well that he's a total villain.

og: I know none such, my lord.
t: I know no one like this.

og: Nor I.
t: Me neither.

og: Look you, I love you well; I'll give you gold,  Rid me these villains from your companies:
t: Hey, guys, I like you a lot. I'll give you some gold, and in return you may rid the world of some evil men.

og: Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught,  Confound them by some course, and come to me,  I'll give you gold enough.
t: Hang them, stab them, drown them in a toilet, I don't care. Get rid of them some way, and then come to me and I'll give you even more gold.

og: Name them, my lord, let's know them.
t: Name your enemies, Timon, we'd like to know.

og: You that way and you this, but two in company;  Each man apart, all single and alone,  Yet an arch-villain keeps him company.
t: You, that man, and you the other, each of you still in the company of the other. Each of you is single and alone when apart from the other, but now an enemy keeps you company.

og: If where thou art two villains shall not be,  Come not near him.
t: If you promise to rid the world of villains, do not go near the other guy.

og: If thou wouldst not reside  But where one villain is, then him abandon.
t: If you swear you will not stand where one villain is, abandon him.

og: Hence, pack! there's gold; you came for gold, ye slaves:
t: So go away! Here's the gold you came for, you slaves.

og: You have work'd for me; there's payment for you: hence!
t: Here's payment for the work you owe me. Now go!

og: You are an alchemist; make gold of that.Out, rascal dogs!
t: You make gold from metal. Here, make gold from this! Get out of here you dogs!

og: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon;
t: It's useless to speak with Timon.

og: For he is set so only to himself  That nothing but himself which looks like man  Is friendly with him.
t: He only trusts himself, and nobody that looks anything like a man appears friendly to him.

og: Bring us to his cave:It is our part and promise to the AtheniansTo speak with Timon.
t: Bring us to the cave. We promised the Athenians we would speak to Timon.

og: At all times alike  Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs  That framed him thus:
t: Men are not the same all the time. It was time and sadness that made him this way.

og: time, with his fairer hand,  Offering the fortunes of his former days,  The former man may make him. Bring us to him,  And chance it as it may.
t: Time presents to him the riches of his former days, the opportunity to become the man he was. Bring us to to him and we'll take our chances.

og: Here is his cave.  Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon!  Look out, and speak to friends:
t: Here is his cave. We come in peace and friendship! Timon! Timon! Come out and speak to two friends.

og: the Athenians,  By two of their most reverend senate, greet thee:  Speak to them, noble Timon.
t: The Athenians send their best to you in two honored senators. Speak to them, Timon.

og: Thou sun, that comfort'st, burn! Speak, and  be hang'd:
t: You, sun which comforts the world, burn them! Speak to me and then be hanged!

og: For each true word, a blister! and each false  Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue,  Consuming it with speaking!
t: Because each true word must to you be like a blister, and each lie burn you to the root of your tongue, eating it away with your own talk!

og: Worthy Timon,—
t: Great Timon—

og: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.
t: Great to no one but those like yourself, and you but to Timon.

og: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.
t: The Senators of Athens send their regards.

og: I thank them; and would send them back the plague,Could I but catch it for them.
t: I thank them, and would send them a disease if only I could catch it for them.

og: O, forget  What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.
t: Forget the things that have happened to you, which we are very sorry for.

og: The senators with one consent of love  Entreat thee back to Athens;
t: The senators unanimously agreed to ask you to come back to Athens.

og: who have thought  On special dignities, which vacant lie  For thy best use and wearing.
t: There are many honors there, totally ready for you to take up.

og: They confess  Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross:
t: They admit they had were too quick to forget your good deeds,

og: Which now the public body, which doth seldom  Play the recanter, feeling in itself  A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal  Of its own fail, restraining aid to Timon;
t: which they take back now that you have stopped aiding them, knowing full well that it is their fault for not extending their hands to you in your time of need.

og: And send forth us, to make their sorrow'd render,  Together with a recompense more fruitful  Than their offence can weigh down by the dram;
t: They sent us to tell you about our sadness, along with a repayment greater than their crime could possibly weigh on you.

og: Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth  As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs  And write in thee the figures of their love,  Ever to read them thine.
t: Indeed they promise such heaps of wealth and friendship that it should make you entirely forget how they wronged you, feeling within yourself instead such sentiments of love that you will always consider them your friends.

og: You witch me in it;  Surprise me to the very brink of tears:
t: You cast a spell on me. You've beaten me to the brink of tears,

og: Lend me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes,  And I'll beweep these comforts, worthy senators.
t: giving me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes, crying before these comforting words.

og: Therefore, so please thee to return with us  And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take  The captainship,
t: So come back with us to Athens, a city yours as well as ours, to become a captain.

og: thou shalt be met with thanks,  Allow'd with absolute power and thy good name  Live with authority:
t: You will be met with thanks and allowed absolute power and authority to your name.

og: so soon we shall drive back  Of Alcibiades the approaches wild,  Who, like a boar too savage, doth root up  His country's peace.
t: Soon enough we will drive back Alcibiades and his wild attacks. He is like a savage boar, rooting up the peace in his own country.

og: And shakes his threatening swordAgainst the walls of Athens.
t: He threatens the walls of Athens with his own sword.

og: Therefore, Timon,—
t: So Timon—

og: Well, sir, I will; therefore, I will, sir; thus:  If Alcibiades kill my countrymen,  Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,  That Timon cares not.
t: I will say this. If Alcibiades wants to kill my fellow citizens, let Alcibiades know that Timon does not care.

og: But if be sack fair Athens,  And take our goodly aged men by the beards,  Giving our holy virgins to the stain  Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain'd war,
t: But if he wants to pillage Athens, grabbing old men by the beards and sacrificing holy virgins to the horrors of war,

og: Then let him know, and tell him Timon speaks it,  In pity of our aged and our youth,  I cannot choose but tell him, that I care not,  And let him take't at worst;
t: then let him know that even as I pity the old and the young, I cannot help but say still that I do not care if he does his worst.

og: for their knives care not,  While you have throats to answer: for myself,  There's not a whittle in the unruly camp  But I do prize it at my love before  The reverend'st throat in Athens.
t: Their blades do not care that your throats suffer the consequences of their actions. And as for me, I put the smallest switchblade in their rebel barracks before the most honored throat in all of Athens.

og: So I leave you  To the protection of the prosperous gods,  As thieves to keepers.
t: I leave you to the protection of the gods, the way I might leave thieves to their jailers.

og: Stay not, all's in vain.
t: Let's go. It's hopeless.

og: Why, I was writing of my epitaph;  it will be seen to-morrow:
t: I was writing the epitaph for my tombstone, which will be seen tomorrow.

og: my long sickness  Of health and living now begins to mend,  And nothing brings me all things.
t: My blight of health and and living well is now being cured, and death will bring everything with it.

og: Go, live still;  Be Alcibiades your plague, you his,  And last so long enough!
t: Go and keep living. Let Alcibiades be your blight, and you his. Live that way as long as you can!

og: We speak in vain.
t: It's useless.

og: But yet I love my country, and am notOne that rejoices in the common wreck,As common bruit doth put it.
t: I do love my country, and contrary to what rumors may say, am not glad to see total destruction.

og: That's well spoke.
t: Well said.

og: Commend me to my loving countrymen,—
t: Give my best to my fellow Athenians—

og: These words become your lips as they passthorough them.
t: These words do the person who speaks them justice.

og: And enter in our ears like great triumphersIn their applauding gates.
t: And enter our ears like trumpeters celebrating at the gates.

og: Commend me to them,  And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs,  Their fears of hostile strokes,
t: Give them my best, and tell them that, to ease their sadness, their fear of war,

og: their aches, losses,  Their pangs of love, with other incident throes  That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain  In life's uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them:
t: their pains, their losses, their pangs of love, and all the other difficulties common to life, I send some kindness their way.

og: I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.
t: I'll teach them how to defend themselves against the wild Alcibiades's wrath.

og: I like this well; he will return again.
t: This sounds good. He will return soon enough.

og: I have a tree, which grows here in my close,  That mine own use invites me to cut down,  And shortly must I fell it:
t: I have a tree that grows around here that I need to cut down, and I need to do that soon.

og: tell my friends,  Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree  From high to low throughout,
t: Tell my friends in Athens of all stations that whoever wants to stop these pains

og: that whoso please  To stop affliction, let him take his haste,  Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe,  And hang himself.  I pray you, do my greeting.
t: should hurry here before my my axe touches the tree, so that they might hang themselves. Please, send those regards.

og: Trouble him no further; thus you still shall find him.
t: Stop bothering him. You will find him this way again.

og: Come not to me again: but say to Athens,  Timon hath made his everlasting mansion  Upon the beached verge of the salt flood;  Who once a day with his embossed froth  The turbulent surge shall cover:
t: Don't come back, and instead tell all of Athens that Timon has built his house on the shore, and everyday will cover himself with the surging foam of the sea.

og: thither come,  And let my grave-stone be your oracle.  Lips, let sour words go by and language end:  What is amiss plague and infection mend!
t: Tell them to come here and let my grave-stone be their guide. Oh lips, let these harsh words fall from you and be your last, let everything wrong with the world be healed by ravaging diseases!

og: Graves only be men's works and death their gain!  Sun, hide thy beams! Timon hath done his reign.
t: Graves are just another of men's works, and death another of their benefits! Go away, sun! Timon has finished his time on earth.

og: His discontents are unremoveablyCoupled to nature.
t: His sadness is now a part of himself.

og: Our hope in him is dead: let us return,And strain what other means is left unto usIn our dear peril.
t: He's hopeless. Let's go back and try whatever else we can do to save ourselves.

og: It requires swift foot.
t: We need to hurry.

og: Thou hast painfully discover'd: are his filesAs full as thy report?
t: You have retrieved information at great cost. Does he have as many troops as you say?

og: I have spoke the least:Besides, his expedition promisesPresent approach.
t: My estimate is conservative. Plus, he approaches at a great speed.

og: We stand much hazard, if they bring not Timon.
t: We are in great danger if the others do not bring Timon with them.

og: I met a courier, one mine ancient friend;  Whom, though in general part we were opposed,  Yet our old love made a particular force,  And made us speak like friends:
t: I met with a messenger friend of mine who, despite having argued with me in public, held a strong love for me and approached me like the old friend he is.

og: this man was riding  From Alcibiades to Timon's cave,  With letters of entreaty, which imported  His fellowship i' the cause against your city,  In part for his sake moved.
t: He was riding from Alcibiades to Timon with letters hoping he would join the cause against Athens, which was inspired partly by his poor treatment here.

og: Here come our brothers.
t: Here come our fellow Senators.

og: No talk of Timon, nothing of him expect.
t: Let's not talk about Timon. We can't expect any help from him.

og: The enemies' drum is heard, and fearful scouring  Doth choke the air with dust: in, and prepare:  Ours is the fall, I fear; our foes the snare.
t: The drum of the enemy armies can be heard in the city, and their marching lifts dust into the air. We fall right into the enemies' trap.

og: By all description this should be the place.  Who's here? speak, ho! No answer! What is this?
t: This looks like the place as it was described to me. Who's there? Speak up! No Answer! What is going on?

og: Timon is dead, who hath outstretch'd his span:  Some beast rear'd this; there does not live a man.  Dead, sure; and this his grave.
t: Timon has reached his final days. He is dead. Some horrible animal must have done this, for all men seem beasts to me now. He is definitely dead, and there is his grave.

og: What's on this tomb  I cannot read; the character I'll take with wax:
t: I cannot read what's written on his tomb. I'll use wax to mold out the lettering.

og: Our captain hath in every figure skill,  An aged interpreter, though young in days:  Before proud Athens he's set down by this,  Whose fall the mark of his ambition is.
t: My captain can read any kind of lettering, for despite being young he's an experienced interpreter. In front of Athens the man whose ambition was his downfall is set down by these words.

og: Sound to this coward and lascivious townOur terrible approach.
t: Make sure this cowardly and dirty town hears our troops approach.

og: Till now you have gone on and fill'd the time  With all licentious measure, making your wills  The scope of justice;
t: Previously, you filled your days by using your own power unchecked, making your own personal desires equivalent with justice.

og: till now myself and such  As slept within the shadow of your power  Have wander'd with our traversed arms and breathed  Our sufferance vainly:
t: Before now I and people like me slept in the shadow of your power, walking about with folded arms and voicing our opinions only in vain.

og: now the time is flush,  When crouching marrow in the bearer strong  Cries of itself 'No more:'
t: Now is the time for action, when the bones of those bowing down to you finally cry out, "No more!"

og: now breathless wrong  Shall sit and pant in your great chairs of ease,  And pursy insolence shall break his wind  With fear and horrid flight.
t: Now those supposed wrongdoers, voiceless then, will have the opportunity to sit in your positions of power. And those who were supposedly ill-mannered during your time shall be able to say and do whatever they like.

og: Noble and young,  When thy first griefs were but a mere conceit,  Ere thou hadst power or we had cause of fear,
t: Young, honorable, Alcibiades, when your grievances were just an idea, before you had any power and we had any fear of it,

og: We sent to thee, to give thy rages balm,  To wipe out our ingratitude with loves  Above their quantity.
t: we sent assistance to you to apologize for our ingratitude with endless admiration.

og: So did we woo  Transformed Timon to our city's love  By humble message and by promised means:
t: And we also tried to reach out to Timon and express our city's love for him with a message of humility and promised riches.

og: We were not all unkind, nor all deserve  The common stroke of war.
t: We were not unkind, and we do not deserve to fall to war.

og: These walls of ours  Were not erected by their hands from whom  You have received your griefs;
t: These walls of ours were not built by the people who insulted you,

og: nor are they such  That these great towers, trophies and schools  should fall  For private faults in them.
t: nor were they people that deserve their work to fall for the faults of others.

og: Nor are they living  Who were the motives that you first went out;  Shame that they wanted cunning, in excess  Hath broke their hearts.
t: The people who banished you are no longer living. Their shame at their actions broke their hearts.

og: March, noble lord,  Into our city with thy banners spread:  By decimation, and a tithed death—
t: March into our city with your banners, Alcibiades,

og: If thy revenges hunger for that food  Which nature loathes—take thou the destined tenth,  And by the hazard of the spotted die  Let die the spotted.
t: and if in an unnatural hunger for revenge you'd like to kill one tenth of the entire city, let those unfortunate enough to have gotten such a bad turn of the dice die for all the rest.

og: All have not offended;  For those that were, it is not square to take  On those that are, revenges: crimes, like lands,  Are not inherited.
t: It is not everyone's fault that you are offended. It is not fair to avenge yourself on those that are here now for those who offended you then. Crimes should not be inherited like the land.

og: Then, dear countryman,  Bring in thy ranks, but leave without thy rage:  Spare thy Athenian cradle and those kin  Which in the bluster of thy wrath must fall  With those that have offended:
t: Dear countrymen, bring in your army, but leave without your anger. Spare your hometown of Athens and those people who in your wrath you might otherwise kill.

og: like a shepherd,  Approach the fold and cull the infected forth,  But kill not all together.
t: Be like a shepherd and approach the herd and separate the infected parts of it. Do not kill everyone.

og: What thou wilt,Thou rather shalt enforce it with thy smileThan hew to't with thy sword.
t: Whatever you want, enforce it with mercy and not with violence.

og: Set but thy foot  Against our rampired gates, and they shall ope;
t: Set your foot against the ramped-up walls and they will open,

og: So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before,  To say thou'lt enter friendly.
t: but you should tell us before you come in peace.

og: Throw thy glove,  Or any token of thine honour else,  That thou wilt use the wars as thy redress  And not as our confusion,
t: Throw your gauntlet down, but do it so that you may use your army to redress the wrongs done to you, and not to destroy everyone here.

og: all thy powers  Shall make their harbour in our town, till we  Have seal'd thy full desire.
t: You can put your entire force here peacefully until you get what you want.

og: Then there's my glove;  Descend, and open your uncharged ports:
t: There's my glove, then. Descend now and open your gates.

og: Those enemies of Timon's and mine own  Whom you yourselves shall set out for reproof  Fall and no more:
t: Those who were enemies of Timon and me you will hand over. They, and no one else, will die.

og: and, to atone your fears  With my more noble meaning, not a man  Shall pass his quarter, or offend the stream  Of regular justice in your city's bounds,
t: And to calm your fear of me, no man of mine shall go beyond an assigned area, or disturb the peace within the city.

og: But shall be render'd to your public laws  At heaviest answer.
t: If they do they will have to answer to harsh punishment.

og: 'Tis most nobly spoken.
t: Well said.

og: Descend, and keep your words.
t: Descend and do what you have promised.

og: My noble general, Timon is dead;  Entomb'd upon the very hem o' the sea;
t: My noble general, Timon is dead. His grave lies on the shore,

og: And on his grave-stone this insculpture, which  With wax I brought away, whose soft impression  Interprets for my poor ignorance.
t: and on that tombstone there is this epitaph, which I brought here on wax which will show you what I cannot in ignorance.

og: 'Here lies a  wretched corse, of wretched soul bereft:  Seek not my name: a plague consume you wicked  caitiffs left!
t: "Here lies a poor corpse and a poor, disturbed soul. Do not look for my name, and may a disease strike all you remaining cowards!

og: Here lie I, Timon; who, alive, all living men did hate:  Pass by and curse thy fill, but pass and stay  not here thy gait.'
t: Here I lie, Timon, who when alive all living men hated. Pass here and insult me to your heart's content, but go and do not stay here too long."

og: These well express in thee thy latter spirits:
t: These words describe you in the depression of your later life.

og: Though thou abhorr'dst in us our human griefs,  Scorn'dst our brain's flow and those our  droplets which  From niggard nature fall, yet rich conceit  Taught thee to make vast Neptune weep for aye  On thy low grave, on faults forgiven.
t: Though you hated our human grievances, scorned our tears which from our sad dispositions fell, still your ingenious mind taught you to make the god of the sea cry for you on your low grave, on your forgiven faults.

og: Dead  Is noble Timon: of whose memory  Hereafter more.
t: The noble Timon is dead, who will be remembered from now on.

og: Bring me into your city,  And I will use the olive with my sword,  Make war breed peace, make peace stint war, make each  Prescribe to other as each other's leech.  Let our drums strike.
t: Bring me into your city, and I will combine peace with war. I will make war end in peace, then make peace stop war, as if each were the doctors curing the other. Strike the drums.

og: If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on  the like occasion whereon my services are now on  foot,
t: Camillo, if, in your duties as a servant to the king, you ever happen to visit Bohemia (as I'm visiting Sicily now),

og: you shall see, as I have said, great  difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.
t: you'll see how different our two countries are.

og: I think, this coming summer, the King of Siciliameans to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.
t: I think the King of Sicily is planning to visit the King of Bohemia this coming summer (as he should).

og: Wherein our entertainment shall shame us we will bejustified in our loves; for indeed—
t: The parties we throw might not be much to be proud of, but we make up for it with heart! Seriously—

og: Beseech you—
t: Oh, come on—

og: Verily, I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge:
t: No, really, I'm being honest—

og: we cannot with such magnificence—in so rare—I know not what to say.
t: we can't compete with such over-the-top, such amazing—I don't even know what to say.

og: We will give you sleepy drinks, that your senses, unintelligent of our insufficience, may, though they cannot praise us, as little accuse us.
t: We'll have to spike your drinks so that you get really groggy and won't be able to compliment or criticize our party.

og: You pay a great deal too dear for what's given freely.
t: You don't have to pay us back for anything; everything we give is a gift.

og: Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs meand as mine honesty puts it to utterance.
t: I'm only saying what I know to be true. I'm being completely honest with you.

og: Sicilia cannot show himself over-kind to Bohemia.
t: It would be impossible for the King of Sicily to be too kind to the King of Bohemia.

og: They were trained together in their childhoods; and  there rooted betwixt them then such an affection,  which cannot choose but branch now.
t: They went to school together when they were kids and became really close, though, naturally, they've grown apart since.

og: Since their  more mature dignities and royal necessities made  separation of their society,
t: Once they reached adulthood and were crowned as kings, they had to attend to business in their respective countries.

og: their encounters,  though not personal, have been royally attorneyed  with interchange of gifts, letters, loving  embassies;
t: Though they haven't been able to meet in person, they've exchanged gifts and letters and have sent servants on their behalf.

og: that they have seemed to be together,  though absent, shook hands, as over a vast, and  embraced, as it were, from the ends of opposed  winds.
t: They haven't really been together, of course, but it's as if they were shaking hands or hugging from opposite sides of the globe.

og: The heavens continue their loves!
t: God bless their friendship!

og: I think there is not in the world either malice or  matter to alter it.
t: I don't think anything in the world could change it.

og: You have an unspeakable  comfort of your young prince Mamillius:
t: You're so lucky to have your young prince, Mamillius.

og: it is a  gentleman of the greatest promise that ever came  into my note.
t: He's the most promising kid I've ever met.

og: I very well agree with you in the hopes of him:
t: I couldn't agree with you more; I have high expectations for him.

og: it  is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the  subject, makes old hearts fresh:
t: He's a great kid—like chicken soup for the soul, he keeps us old folks young.

og: they that went on  crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to  see him a man.
t: The Sicilians who were old and in wheelchairs before he was even born are hoping they live to see him grow up.

og: Would they else be content to die?
t: Otherwise, would they be happy to die?

og: Yes; if there were no other excuse why they shoulddesire to live.
t: Yes, if they had nothing else to live for.

og: If the king had no son, they would desire to liveon crutches till he had one.
t: If the king didn't have a son, they would want to hang onto life in their wheelchairs until he did!

og: Nine changes of the watery star hath been  The shepherd's note since we have left our throne  Without a burthen:
t: It's been nine months since I left my throne in Bohemia without a care in the world.

og: time as long again  Would be filled up, my brother, with our thanks;
t: I'd be happy to stay another nine months, brother, except that I would owe you forever.

og: And yet we should, for perpetuity,  Go hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher,
t: All I can repay you with are my thanks!

og: Yet standing in rich place, I multiply  With one 'We thank you' many thousands more  That go before it.
t: That being said, I'll have to multiply my single "thank you" into many thousands more.

og: Stay your thanks a while;And pay them when you part.
t: Oh, stop thanking me. You can "pay" me when you leave.

og: Sir, that's to-morrow.
t: I'm leaving tomorrow, sir.

og: I am question'd by my fears, of what may chance  Or breed upon our absence;
t: I'm worried about what might have happened in Bohemia while I've been gone—

og: that may blow  No sneaking winds at home, to make us say  'This is put forth too truly:'
t: unfavorable winds may be blowing, if you know what I mean.

og: besides, I have stay'd  To tire your royalty.
t: Besides, I've over-stayed my welcome here and I've worn you out.

og: We are tougher, brother,Than you can put us to't.
t: I'm tougher than you give me credit for!

og: No longer stay.
t: I can't stay any longer.

og: One seven-night longer.
t: Just one more week?

og: Very sooth, to-morrow.
t: Really, tomorrow.

og: We'll part the time between's then; and in thatI'll no gainsaying.
t: We'll say goodbye in a week, and after that I won't argue any more.

og: Press me not, beseech you, so.
t: Please, stop pushing me.

og: There is no tongue that moves, none, none i' the world,  So soon as yours could win me: so it should now,  Were there necessity in your request, although  'Twere needful I denied it.
t: There is no one in the whole world better at convincing me to do things than you. And now, if you really needed me, you would have almost won me over—except that I'd still have to say "no."

og: My affairs  Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder  Were in your love a whip to me;
t: Duty calls and I have to go home. If you keep me here, you'll only be hurting me in the long run;

og: my stay  To you a charge and trouble: to save both,  Farewell, our brother.
t: if I stay, I'll only be a burden to your hospitality. So if I leave, it's a win-win! Goodbye, brother.

og: Tongue-tied, our queen?speak you.
t: Hermione, are you tongue-tied? Say something!

og: I had thought, sir, to have held my peace until  You have drawn oaths from him not to stay.
t: Sir, I'd planned to stay quiet until you'd pushed him to the point of swearing not to stay.

og: You, sir,  Charge him too coldly. Tell him, you are sure  All in Bohemia's well; this satisfaction  The by-gone day proclaim'd:
t: You're too hard on him. Tell him everything in Bohemia's fine—we heard good news yesterday.

og: say this to him,  He's beat from his best ward.
t: If you tell him that, he's lost his best reason for leaving.

og: Well said, Hermione.
t: Well said, Hermione.

og: To tell, he longs to see his son, were strong:  But let him say so then, and let him go;
t: Of course, that he misses his son is a good excuse. If he says that, we'll let him go.

og: But let him swear so, and he shall not stay,  We'll thwack him hence with distaffs.
t: And if he swears that, we'll not only let him go, we'll chase him out the door with frying pans!

og: Yet of your royal presence I'll adventure  The borrow of a week. When at Bohemia  You take my lord, I'll give him my commission  To let him there a month behind the gest  Prefix'd for's parting:
t: Despite that, I'll still beg your royal self to stay another week. When my husband goes to Bohemia I'll give him permission to stay there a month past the agreed-upon departure date—

og: yet, good deed, Leontes,  I love thee not a jar o' the clock behind  What lady-she her lord.
t: and, Leontes, you know I love you not one bit less than any woman loves her husband.

og: You'll stay?
t: Will you stay?

og: No, madam.
t: No, ma'am.

og: Nay, but you will?
t: Oh, please, won't you?

og: I may not, verily.
t: Truly, I can't.

og: Verily!  You put me off with limber vows; but I,  Though you would seek t'unsphere the  stars with oaths,  Should yet say 'Sir, no going.'
t: "Truly!" You can keep putting me off with promises, but even if you swore by all the stars in the sky, I'd still say, "Sir, you're staying."

og: Verily,  You shall not go. A lady's 'Verily' is  As potent as a lord's. Will you go yet?
t: Truly, you can't leave—a woman's "truly" is as strong as a man's. Are you still intent on leaving?

og: Force me to keep you as a prisoner,  Not like a guest; so you shall pay your fees  When you depart, and save your thanks.
t: You'll force me to keep you as a prisoner rather than as a guest. Instead of thanking me, you'll have to pay your fees when you leave.

og: How say you?  My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,'  One of them you shall be.
t: What do you say to that? Will you be my prisoner, or my guest? Judging by your oh-so-serious "truly," you'll have to be one of them.

og: Your guest, then, madam:To be your prisoner should import offending;Which is for me less easy to commitThan you to punish.
t: I'll be your guest, then. For me to be your prisoner would imply that I'd committed some crime against you. It'd be harder for me to do that than it would be for you to punish me.

og: Not your gaoler, then,But your kind hostess. Come, I'll question youOf my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys:You were pretty lordings then?
t: Then I'm not your jailer; I'm your kind hostess. Come on, I'll ask you all about your and my husband's shenanigans back when you were kids. You were cute little kings-to-be back then, weren't you?

og: We were, fair queen,Two lads that thought there was no more behindBut such a day to-morrow as to-day,And to be boy eternal.
t: We were two kids who lived like there was no tomorrow, and thought we'd be boys forever.

og: Was not my lordThe verier wag o' the two?
t: And wasn't my husband the bigger troublemaker out of you two?

og: We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun,  And bleat the one at the other:
t: We were like two lambs that frolicked in the sunshine and bleated to each other;

og: what we changed  Was innocence for innocence; we knew not  The doctrine of ill-doing, nor dream'd  That any did.
t: we were completely innocent and knew nothing about evil. We couldn't even comprehend evil.

og: Had we pursued that life,  And our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd  With stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven  Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd  Hereditary ours.
t: If we'd stayed like that, and we'd never had to grow up, we could have gone to heaven and honestly told God that we'd never sinned.

og: By this we gatherYou have tripp'd since.
t: Should we take that to mean that you've slipped up since then?

og: O my most sacred lady!
t: Oh, you virtuous woman!

og: Temptations have since then been born to's; for  In those unfledged days was my wife a girl;
t: We have definitely come across temptation since then. But back in those days, my wife was still a young girl,

og: Your precious self had then not cross'd the eyes  Of my young play-fellow.
t: and you hadn't yet caught my young playmate's eye.

og: Grace to boot!
t: And wasn't that lucky!

og: Of this make no conclusion, lest you say  Your queen and I are devils:
t: Please, don't finish your story. Next you're going to say that your queen and I are devils.

og: yet go on;  The offences we have made you do we'll answer,  If you first sinn'd with us and that with us  You did continue fault and that you slipp'd not  With any but with us.
t: Actually, keep going—we'll admit to being the cause of your sin as long as you admit you sinned with us for the first time and swear you haven't sinned with anyone else since.

og: Is he won yet?
t: Have you convinced him yet?

og: He'll stay my lord.
t: He'll stay, sweetheart.

og: At my request he would not.Hermione, my dearest, thou never spokestTo better purpose.
t: He wouldn't when I asked! Hermione, you've never spoken better.

og: Never?
t: Never?

og: Never, but once.
t: Never, except once.

og: What! have I twice said well? when was't before?
t: What? Have I said the right thing twice? When was the first time?

og: I prithee tell me; cram's with praise, and make's  As fat as tame things:
t: Please tell me. Butter me up with praise 'til I'm as fat as a pig for the slaughter.

og: one good deed dying tongueless  Slaughters a thousand waiting upon that.
t: If you don't compliment a good deed, you'll stop that person from doing a thousand more good things that person might have done.

og: Our praises are our wages:
t: Your compliments are my reward.

og: you may ride's  With one soft kiss a thousand furlongs ere  With spur we beat an acre.  But to the goal:  My last good deed was to entreat his stay:  What was my first?
t: For a single kiss, you can ride me for a mile before you'd have to kick me with your spurs. Back to the point: if my most recent accomplishment was convincing him to stay, what was the first one?

og: it has an elder sister,  Or I mistake you: O, would her name were Grace!
t: This accomplishment must have a sister, unless I misunderstood you. If only her name were "Grace!"

og: But once before I spoke to the purpose: when?  Nay, let me have't; I long.
t: There was another time I said something good? What was it? Please tell me; I'm dying to know.

og: Why, that was when  Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death,  Ere I could make thee open thy white hand  And clap thyself my love:
t: Obviously that was when, after three long, bitter months, I convinced you to give me your hand in marriage.

og: then didst thou utter  'I am yours for ever.'
t: At that moment, you said, "I am yours forever."

og: 'Tis grace indeed.Why, lo you now, I have spoke to the purpose twice:The one for ever earn'd a royal husband;The other for some while a friend.
t: That was definitely "grace," wasn't it? Well, look at that, I've said the right thing two whole times. The first time, I earned a royal husband forever; the second time, I earned a friend for a while.

og: Too hot, too hot!  To mingle friendship far is mingling bloods.
t: Too far, too far! Friendships that get too close always end with the "friends" having sex.

og: I have  tremor cordis  on me: my heart dances;  But not for joy; not joy. This entertainment  May a free face put on, derive a liberty  From heartiness, from bounty, fertile bosom,  And well become the agent; 't may, I grant;
t: I'm having a heart attack. My heart is racing, but not with excitement—definitely not. They might as well be relaxed and open with each other here at the party, and blame it on the plentiful food and drink.

og: But to be paddling palms and pinching fingers,  As now they are, and making practised smiles,  As in a looking-glass, and then to sigh, as 'twere  The mort o' the deer;
t: But holding hands and linking fingers, and smiling stupidly at each other and sighing as if they were having an orgasm—

og: O, that is entertainment  My bosom likes not, nor my brows!
t: that kind of "party" hurts my heart and my head.

og: Mamillius,  Art thou my boy?
t: Mamillius, are you my son?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, sir.

og: I' fecks!  Why, that's my bawcock. What, hast  smutch'd thy nose?
t: Goodness gracious! There's my little chickadee. Is that some dirt on your nose?

og: They say it is a copy out of mine. Come, captain,  We must be neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain:
t: They say it looks just like mine. Come on, buddy, we should be part of the same herd.

og: And yet the steer, the heifer and the calf  Are all call'd neat.—
t: Did you know that a bull, a cow, and a calf are called a herd?

og: Still virginalling  Upon his palm!—
t: Still holding his hand!

og: How now, you wanton calf!  Art thou my calf?
t: Well, my silly little calf. Are you my calf?

og: Yes, if you will, my lord.
t: Yes, of course, sir.

og: Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have,  To be full like me: yet they say we are  Almost as like as eggs; women say so,
t: You'll need a beard and some horns if you want to be just like me! They say we're two peas in a pod—well, women say so,

og: That will say anything but were they false  As o'er-dyed blacks, as wind, as waters, false  As dice are to be wish'd by one that fixes  No bourn 'twixt his and mine, yet were it true  To say this boy were like me.
t: and they'd say anything. Women are as fake as dyed-blonde hair, as stable as wind, as solid as water, as fair as loaded dice—and yet, it's true that this boy looks like me.

og: Come, sir page,  Look on me with your welkin eye: sweet villain!  Most dear'st! my collop! Can thy dam?—may't be?—
t: Come here, buddy, look at me with your dreamy eyes! You precious thing! My dear! My son! Could your mother—can it be?

og: Affection! thy intention stabs the centre:  Thou dost make possible things not so held,  Communicatest with dreams;—how can this be?—
t: I'm going crazy! Madness is making me think this, making me believe impossible things, making nightmares a reality. How can this be?

og: With what's unreal thou coactive art,  And fellow'st nothing: then 'tis very credent  Thou mayst co-join with something; and thou dost,  And that beyond commission, and I find it,  And that to the infection of my brains  And hardening of my brows.
t: Madness and unreality together make nothing, so it makes sense that it would hook up with something, and it does, beyond compare, and I'm there already—so much so that my brain is sick and horns are sprouting out of my head!

og: What means Sicilia?
t: Is Leontes all right?

og: He something seems unsettled.
t: He seems a little upset.

og: How, my lord!What cheer? how is't with you, best brother?
t: Hey, are you all right? How are you, brother?

og: You look as if you held a brow of much distractionAre you moved, my lord?
t: Your forehead looks wrinkled with thought. Are you upset, my love?

og: No, in good earnest.
t: No, really, I'm fine.

og: How sometimes nature will betray its folly,  Its tenderness, and make itself a pastime  To harder bosoms!
t: See how our bodies give us away, giving other people a chance to laugh at us!

og: Looking on the lines  Of my boy's face, methoughts I did recoil  Twenty-three years, and saw myself unbreech'd,  In my green velvet coat, my dagger muzzled,  Lest it should bite its master, and so prove,  As ornaments oft do, too dangerous:
t: Just now, looking at my son's face, I went back in time twenty-three years and saw myself back before I wore pants, in my green velvet coat, with a blunt practice sword (it was blunt so that I didn't cut myself, since that kind of toy is dangerous when you're a kid).

og: How like, methought, I then was to this kernel,  This squash, this gentleman.
t: Back then I was so much like this kid.

og: Mine honest friend,  Will you take eggs for money?
t: Buddy, would you let yourself be robbed?

og: No, my lord, I'll fight.
t: No, sir, I'll fight.

og: You will! why, happy man be's dole! My brother,Are you so fond of your young prince as weDo seem to be of ours?
t: You will? Well, lucky me!  Brother, do you love your son as much as I seem to love mine?

og: If at home, sir,  He's all my exercise, my mirth, my matter,  Now my sworn friend and then mine enemy,  My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all:
t: When I'm at home I spend all my time playing, laughing, and working with him. He's my friend and my enemy, my shadow, my soldier, my little king-in-training.

og: He makes a July's day short as December,  And with his varying childness cures in me  Thoughts that would thick my blood.
t: He makes the days fly by and his crazy antics keep me from taking myself too seriously.

og: So stands this squire  Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord,  And leave you to your graver steps.
t: It's the same with me and my son. Well, Mamillius and I will walk along and leave you two to more serious business.

og: Hermione,  How thou lovest us, show in our brother's welcome;
t: Hermione, you can show your love for me by giving Polixenes a warm welcome.

og: Let what is dear in Sicily be cheap:  Next to thyself and my young rover, he's  Apparent to my heart.
t: Let him have what is expensive in Sicily for a small price. Next to you and our son, he's the person I care about the most.

og: If you would seek us,We are yours i' the garden: shall's attend you there?
t: If you need us, we'll be in the garden. Should we wait for you there?

og: To your own bents dispose you: you'll be found,  Be you beneath the sky.
t: Do whatever you want. I'll find you as long as you're underneath the sky.

og: I am angling now,  Though you perceive me not how I give line.  Go to, go to!
t: I'm reeling them in now, even if you can't see my fishing line. Oh, come on!

og: How she holds up the neb, the bill to him!  And arms her with the boldness of a wife  To her allowing husband!
t: Look how she holds up her mouth, her lips to him! As confidently as if he were her own husband! [

og: Gone already!  Inch-thick, knee-deep, o'er head and  ears a fork'd one!
t: There they go! I'm in thick and deep, over my head, and horns are sprouting above my ears!

og: Go, play, boy, play: thy mother plays, and I  Play too, but so disgraced a part, whose issue  Will hiss me to my grave: contempt and clamour  Will be my knell. Go, play, boy, play.
t: Go play, boy—play! Your mother's playing, and I play such a horrible part that its reviews will put me in my grave; booing and hissing will be the last thing I hear.

og: There have been,  Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now;  And many a man there is, even at this present,  Now while I speak this, holds his wife by the arm,  That little thinks she has been sluiced in's absence  And his pond fish'd by his next neighbour, by  Sir Smile, his neighbour:
t: Unless I'm mistaken, plenty of men have been cheated on by their wives before now. There may even be a man here, as I'm speaking, holding his wife by the arm not knowing she slept with someone else while he was gone. Little does he know that his neighbor (you know the one, Mr. Smiley) stuck his fishing rod in that pond while he was out of town.

og: nay, there's comfort in't  Whiles other men have gates and those gates open'd,  As mine, against their will. Should all despair  That have revolted wives, the tenth of mankind  Would hang themselves.
t: It's actually comforting to know that I'm not alone in having something taken from me against my will. If all men who've been cheated on gave up on themselves, ten percent of the male population would hang themselves.

og: Physic for't there is none;  It is a bawdy planet, that will strike  Where 'tis predominant; and 'tis powerful, think it,  From east, west, north and south: be it concluded,  No barricado for a belly; know't;
t: There's no solution to it. We live on a raunchy planet and the raunchiness can strike at any time (and powerfully, believe you me) from the east, west, north, or south.

og: It will let in and out the enemy  With bag and baggage: many thousand on's  Have the disease, and feel't not.
t: It'll let the enemy in and out with bag and baggage. Thousands of us suffer from this and have no idea.

og: How now, boy!
t: What's up, son?

og: I am like you, they say.
t: They say I'm like you.

og: Why that's some comfort. What, Camillo there?
t: Well, that's comforting.  Hey, Camillo, is that you?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, sir.

og: Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man.    Camillo, this great sir will yet stay longer.
t: Mamillius, go play. That's a good boy. Camillo, this all-important man has decided to stay longer.

og: You had much ado to make his anchor hold:When you cast out, it still came home.
t: You worked hard to make him stay. As hard as you tried, he insisted he had to get home.

og: Didst note it?
t: Did you notice that?

og: He would not stay at your petitions: madeHis business more material.
t: He wouldn't stay when you asked. It's like the more you pushed, the more he was convinced his business was more important.

og: Didst perceive it?    They're here with me already, whispering, rounding'Sicilia is a so-forth:' 'tis far gone,When I shall gust it last. How came't, Camillo,That he did stay?
t: Did you pick up on that? They're all gossiping about me already, whispering, "Leontes is such-and-such." It'll be too late by the time I hear about it. Camillo, why did he finally decide to stay?

og: At the good queen's entreaty.
t: Because the good queen asked.

og: At the queen's be't: 'good' should be pertinent  But, so it is, it is not.
t: The queen, huh? Whether or not she's "good" is up for debate.

og: Was this taken  By any understanding pate but thine?
t: Did anyone else notice this besides you?

og: For thy conceit is soaking, will draw in  More than the common blocks: not noted, is't,  But of the finer natures? by some severals  Of head-piece extraordinary?
t: I mean, you're pretty intelligent, but idiots wouldn't pick up on that, right?

og: lower messes  Perchance are to this business purblind? say.
t: It would have escaped the average person—they'd be totally blind to the matter. What do you say to that?

og: Business, my lord! I think most understandBohemia stays here longer.
t: The matter, sir! I think most people can understand the fact that Polixenes is staying here longer.

og: Ha!
t: Ha!

og: Stays here longer.
t: He's staying here longer.

og: Ay, but why?
t: Yes, but why?

og: To satisfy your highness and the entreatiesOf our most gracious mistress.
t: To satisfy you and because of your lovely wife's invitation.

og: Satisfy!  The entreaties of your mistress! satisfy!  Let that suffice.
t: "Satisfy!" "Satisfy" my wife's invitation! That says it all.

og: I have trusted thee, Camillo,  With all the nearest things to my heart, as well  My chamber-councils, wherein, priest-like, thou  Hast cleansed my bosom, I from thee departed  Thy penitent reform'd:
t: I've trusted you, Camillo, with my darkest secrets. I've confessed my soul to you as if you were a priest, and you've cleared my conscience and helped me to be a better man.

og: but we have been  Deceived in thy integrity, deceived  In that which seems so.
t: But now I see I was wrong about you. I thought you were a good man, but you're not!

og: Be it forbid, my lord!
t: That can't be, sir!

og: To bide upon't, thou art not honest, or,  If thou inclinest that way, thou art a coward,  Which hoxes honesty behind, restraining  From course required;
t: To be clear: you're a liar. You're a coward who shrinks away from honesty and who's afraid to do the right thing.

og: or else thou must be counted  A servant grafted in my serious trust  And therein negligent;
t: You're either a servant who won my trust only so you could betray me,

og: or else a fool  That seest a game play'd home, the rich stake drawn,  And takest it all for jest.
t: or an idiot who sees what's going on and, for his own gain, pretends it's all a joke.

og: My gracious lord,  I may be negligent, foolish and fearful;  In every one of these no man is free,  But that his negligence, his folly, fear,  Among the infinite doings of the world,  Sometime puts forth.
t: Sir, I may be careless, stupid, and afraid, but nobody's perfect. Carelessness, stupidity, and fear are just part of being in the world; you can't avoid them.

og: In your affairs, my lord,  If ever I were wilful-negligent,  It was my folly; if industriously  I play'd the fool, it was my negligence,  Not weighing well the end;
t: As long as I've worked for you, sir, any time I messed up, it was because I was stupid. If I acted stupidly, it's because I made a mistake and didn't think it through.

og: if ever fearful  To do a thing, where I the issue doubted,  Where of the execution did cry out  Against the non-performance, 'twas a fear  Which oft infects the wisest:  these, my lord,  Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty  Is never free of.
t: If I were ever so afraid to do something, so afraid I couldn't control the consequences that I wasn't able to carry it out, well, that's a fear even the smartest people have to deal with.

og: But, beseech your grace,  Be plainer with me; let me know my trespass  By its own visage: if I then deny it,  'Tis none of mine.
t: But, sir, I'm begging you to be straight with me. Tell me to my face how I messed up. If I deny it, then you'd better believe I didn't do it.

og: Ha' not you seen, Camillo—  But that's past doubt, you have, or your eye-glass  Is thicker than a cuckold's horn,
t: Camillo, haven't you seen (but you must have, unless your glasses are as thick as a cuckold's horn)

og: —or heard,—  For to a vision so apparent rumour  Cannot be mute,—or thought,—for cogitation  Resides not in that man that does not think,—  My wife is slippery?
