t: or heard (since something so obvious must have started rumors) or thought (for only someone incapable of thinking wouldn't have thought of this) that my wife is unfaithful?

og: If thou wilt confess,  Or else be impudently negative,  To have nor eyes nor ears nor thought, then say  My wife's a hobby-horse, deserves a name  As rank as any flax-wench that puts to  Before her troth-plight: say't and justify't.
t: Unless you're planning to say "no" or you're willing to claim that you're blind, deaf, and dumb, admit that my wife's a slut who deserves every name you'd call a corner prostitute. Just say it and swear by it.

og: I would not be a stander-by to hear  My sovereign mistress clouded so, without  My present vengeance taken:
t: I'd hate to even be a bystander overhearing someone talk about Hermione that way—I'd have to fight them.

og: 'shrew my heart,  You never spoke what did become you less  Than this; which to reiterate were sin  As deep as that, though true.
t: For goodness' sake, you've never said anything that made you look as badly as you do now. Just to repeat what you said would be a crime, even if it were true.

og: Is whispering nothing?  Is leaning cheek to cheek? is meeting noses?  Kissing with inside lip? stopping the career  Of laughing with a sigh?
t: Is whispering nothing? Leaning against each other, touching cheeks? Rubbing noses? French-kissing? Laughing until you can't breathe?

og: —a note infallible  Of breaking honesty—horsing foot on foot?  Skulking in corners?
t: Here's one you can't ignore—playing footsie? Hiding in corners?

og: wishing clocks more swift?  Hours, minutes? noon, midnight? and all eyes  Blind with the pin and web but theirs, theirs only,  That would unseen be wicked? is this nothing?
t: Counting down the minutes and hours until midnight, when, while all eyes but theirs are closed in sleep, they might be wicked in secret? Is all that nothing?

og: Why, then the world and all that's in't is nothing;  The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing;  My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings,  If this be nothing.
t: Well, then, the world and everything in it is nothing, the universe is nothing, Bohemia is nothing, my wife is nothing, and everything I'm saying is nothing, if this is "nothing."

og: Good my lord, be curedOf this diseased opinion, and betimes;For 'tis most dangerous.
t: Sir, please stop believing this sick lie, and soon; it's really dangerous.

og: Say it be, 'tis true.
t: Say that it's true.

og: No, no, my lord.
t: No, no, sir.

og: It is; you lie, you lie:  I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee,
t: It is! You lie! You lie! I say you lie, Camillo, and I hate you.

og: Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave,  Or else a hovering temporizer, that  Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil,  Inclining to them both:
t: You're a disgusting lowlife, a mindless slave, or maybe just a two-faced liar who can pay lip-service to good while really doing evil.

og: were my wife's liver  Infected as her life, she would not live  The running of one glass.
t: If my wife's liver were as diseased as her whole life is, she'd drop dead in an instant.

og: Who does infect her?
t: Who infected her?

og: Why, he that wears her like a medal, hanging  About his neck, Bohemia:
t: Um, the guy who's carrying her around like a trophy—Polixenes!

og: who, if I  Had servants true about me, that bare eyes  To see alike mine honour as their profits,  Their own particular thrifts, they would do that  Which should undo more doing:
t: And if I had loyal servants working for me, that kept an eye out for my reputation instead of just for their own profit and gain, they would do what needs to be done to end all this.

og: ay, and thou,  His cupbearer,—whom I from meaner form  Have benched and reared to worship, who mayst see  Plainly as heaven sees earth and earth sees heaven,  How I am galled,—
t: Yeah, you heard me. You, his cupbearer (don't forget, by the way, that I helped you get out of poverty and make a life for yourself, though you're clearly ungrateful), you who see clearly how wronged I am,

og: mightst bespice a cup,  To give mine enemy a lasting wink;  Which draught to me were cordial.
t: should poison him. Put him to sleep for good—that would be the best medicine for me.

og: Sir, my lord,  I could do this, and that with no rash potion,  But with a lingering dram that should not work  Maliciously like poison:
t: Sir, I'm capable of doing that, and I wouldn't use any fast-acting poison. I'd use something slow, that'd drift him off the sleep so that he wouldn't feel a thing.

og: but I cannot  Believe this crack to be in my dread mistress,  So sovereignly being honourable.  I have loved thee,—
t: But I can't believe Hermione would do this; she's always been so good. I've been loyal to you—

og: Make that thy question, and go rot!
t: Just stop there, and go to hell!

og: Dost think I am so muddy, so unsettled,  To appoint myself in this vexation, sully  The purity and whiteness of my sheets,  Which to preserve is sleep, which being spotted  Is goads, thorns, nettles, tails of wasps,
t: Do you think I'm so crazy and confused that I would make this up? Do you think I would destroy my own reputation and my marriage, just to welcome all the pain and difficulty that will come of that?

og: Give scandal to the blood o' the prince my son,  Who I do think is mine and love as mine,  Without ripe moving to't? Would I do this?  Could man so blench?
t: Do you really think I would just bastardize my son (who I think is mine and who I love as my own) without a good reason? Would I do that? Would any man have the guts to do that?

og: I must believe you, sir:  I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't;  Provided that, when he's removed, your highness  Will take again your queen as yours at first,  Even for your son's sake;
t: Sir, I have to believe you. I do. I'll take Bohemia out as long as, once he's gone, you'll take the queen back immediately for your son's sake

og: and thereby for sealing  The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms  Known and allied to yours.
t: and to stop any potential gossip from spreading to our allies' courts and countries at large.

og: Thou dost advise meEven so as I mine own course have set down:I'll give no blemish to her honour, none.
t: You're telling me to do exactly what I had already decided to do myself. I won't ruin Hermione's reputation, not at all.

og: My lord,  Go then; and with a countenance as clear  As friendship wears at feasts, keep with Bohemia  And with your queen.
t: Well, sir, then you should put on a happy face and go back to have dinner with Polixenes and Hermione.

og: I am his cupbearer:  If from me he have wholesome beverage,  Account me not your servant.
t: I'm his cupbearer. If he drinks an un-poisoned beverage, then I'm out of a job.

og: This is all:Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart;Do't not, thou split'st thine own.
t: That's it. Do it and I'll love you forever. If you don't do it, you're signing your own death warrant.

og: I'll do't, my lord.
t: I'll do it, sir.

og: I will seem friendly, as thou hast advised me.
t: And I'll put on a happy face, like you told me.

og: O miserable lady! But, for me,  What case stand I in?
t: Poor Hermione! But what am I supposed to do?

og: I must be the poisoner  Of good Polixenes; and my ground to do't  Is the obedience to a master, one  Who in rebellion with himself will have  All that are his so too.
t: If I do my job of serving Leontes, then I have to poison Polixenes (who's innocent). Leontes is messed up in the head and wants everyone else to be miserable, too.

og: To do this deed,  Promotion follows.
t: If I do this, he'll promote me.

og: If I could find example  Of thousands that had struck anointed kings  And flourish'd after, I'ld not do't;
t: But, wait—even if I could look through the history books and find thousands of men who'd killed kings and done well afterward, I still wouldn't do it.

og: but since  Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one,  Let villany itself forswear't.
t: And, in fact, since not a single record would tell you such a story, it's obvious how wrong this is in every way.

og: I must  Forsake the court: to do't, or no, is certain  To me a break-neck. Happy star, reign now!  Here comes Bohemia.
t: I have to get out of here. Whether I do it or not, I'll be hanged. Man, I could use some luck right about now! Here comes Polixenes.

og: This is strange: methinksMy favour here begins to warp. Not speak?Good day, Camillo.
t: This is weird, I think I'm starting to be less popular here. Why isn't he saying anything? Hello, Camillo.

og: Hail, most royal sir!
t: Greetings, sir!

og: What is the news i' the court?
t: What's new at court?

og: None rare, my lord.
t: Nothing special, sir.

og: The king hath on him such a countenance  As he had lost some province and a region  Loved as he loves himself:
t: The king has the face of someone who's just lost a much-loved territory in wartime.

og: even now I met him  With customary compliment;
t: Just now I saw him and greeted him as always.

og: when he,  Wafting his eyes to the contrary and falling  A lip of much contempt, speeds from me and  So leaves me to consider what is breeding  That changeth thus his manners.
t: He looked down at the floor, muttered to himself, and ran away, leaving me wondering what's going on that would so totally change his behavior.

og: I dare not know, my lord.
t: I'm afraid to know, sir.

og: How! dare not! do not. Do you know, and dare not?  Be intelligent to me: 'tis thereabouts;  For, to yourself, what you do know, you must.  And cannot say, you dare not.
t: Afraid? Do you know, but are afraid of what you know? Share your knowledge; it's in there somewhere, you must know. You can't just stand there and say, "I'm afraid to know."

og: Good Camillo,  Your changed complexions are to me a mirror  Which shows me mine changed too;
t: Camillo, your face is as white as I imagine mine is right now. I'm realizing this must have something to do with me.

og: for I must be  A party in this alteration, finding  Myself thus alter'd with 't.
t: Something has changed forever for me, hasn't it?

og: There is a sicknessWhich puts some of us in distemper, butI cannot name the disease; and it is caughtOf you that yet are well.
t: There's a sickness affecting some of us, but I don't know what to call the disease. And, even though you're well, you're the one who's contagious.

og: How! caught of me!  Make me not sighted like the basilisk:  I have look'd on thousands, who have sped the better  By my regard, but kill'd none so.
t: What? I'm contagious? Don't talk about me like I'm a basilisk; I've looked at thousands of people, and they've been fine. I've never killed anyone just by sight.

og: Camillo,—  As you are certainly a gentleman, thereto  Clerk-like experienced, which no less adorns  Our gentry than our parents' noble names,  In whose success we are gentle,—
t: Camillo, I know you're a good guy, and experienced in your job, which is as much a credit to you as a fancy last name is to royalty.

og: I beseech you,  If you know aught which does behove my knowledge  Thereof to be inform'd, imprison't not  In ignorant concealment.
t: I'm begging you, if you know anything that I should know, please don't keep it from me.

og: I may not answer.
t: I can't say.

og: A sickness caught of me, and yet I well!  I must be answer'd.
t: I'm contagious, even though I'm not sick? You have to explain.

og: Dost thou hear, Camillo,  I conjure thee, by all the parts of man  Which honour does acknowledge, whereof the least  Is not this suit of mine, that thou declare  What incidency thou dost guess of harm  Is creeping toward me;
t: Listen, Camillo, I demand, if you're honorable and you believe me to be, too, that you tell me what horrible things are coming my way.

og: how far off, how near;  Which way to be prevented, if to be;  If not, how best to bear it.
t: Tell me how far off they are (or how close at hand). Tell me how to avoid it or, if I can't, how to deal with it.

og: Sir, I will tell you;Since I am charged in honour and by himThat I think honourable: therefore mark my counsel,Which must be even as swiftly follow'd asI mean to utter it, or both yourself and meCry lost, and so good night!
t: Sir, I'll tell you, since you're bringing honor into this. Listen closely and do exactly what I say as soon as I say it, otherwise you and I are both done for!

og: On, good Camillo.
t: Go on, Camillo.

og: I am appointed him to murder you.
t: He ordered me to murder you.

og: By whom, Camillo?
t: Who ordered you, Camillo?

og: By the king.
t: The king.

og: For what?
t: Why?

og: He thinks, nay, with all confidence he swears,As he had seen't or been an instrumentTo vice you to't, that you have touch'd his queenForbiddenly.
t: He thinks—actually, he swears as confidently as if he saw you do it or told you to do it himself—that you're having a secret affair with Hermione.

og: O, then my best blood turn  To an infected jelly and my name  Be yoked with his that did betray the Best!
t: Well, then I might as well be dying of cancer and be named Judas Iscariot.

og: Turn then my freshest reputation to  A savour that may strike the dullest nostril  Where I arrive,
t: My reputation is ruined. From now on, I'll stink of this. I'll walk into a room and everyone will complain about the stench.

og: and my approach be shunn'd,  Nay, hated too, worse than the great'st infection  That e'er was heard or read!
t: I'll be shunned and hated more than the worst epidemic in the history of the world.

og: Swear his thought over  By each particular star in heaven and  By all their influences, you may as well  Forbid the sea for to obey the moon  As or by oath remove or counsel shake  The fabric of his folly,
t: You could swear by every star in the sky and you could force the tides to stop ebbing and flowing before you could convince him that what he now believes isn't true.

og: whose foundation  Is piled upon his faith and will continue  The standing of his body.
t: He's built it up in his mind so much now that he'll defend it with his life.

og: How should this grow?
t: How did this happen?

og: I know not: but I am sure 'tis safer to  Avoid what's grown than question how 'tis born.
t: I don't know, but it's probably safer to get out of the way than it is to stand around and debate about how it got started.

og: If therefore you dare trust my honesty,  That lies enclosed in this trunk which you  Shall bear along impawn'd, away to-night!  Your followers I will whisper to the business,  And will by twos and threes at several posterns  Clear them o' the city.
t: If you trust me, pack your things and leave tonight. I'll whisper the plan to your servants and we'll leave the city in groups of two or three, all by different gates.

og: For myself, I'll put  My fortunes to your service, which are here  By this discovery lost. Be not uncertain;  For, by the honour of my parents, I  Have utter'd truth:
t: From this point on, I offer my services to you, considering I'll be dead if I'm found here after you're gone. I swear on my parents' lives that everything I've told you is true.

og: which if you seek to prove,  I dare not stand by; nor shall you be safer  Than one condemn'd by the king's own mouth, thereon  His execution sworn.
t: If you want to test it on Leontes, you better believe I won't stick around—you'll be as condemned to die as a criminal sitting on death row.

og: I do believe thee:  I saw his heart in 's face. Give me thy hand:
t: I believe you; the look on his face said it all. Give me your hand:

og: Be pilot to me and thy places shall  Still neighbour mine. My ships are ready and  My people did expect my hence departure  Two days ago.
t: if you lead me out of here, you can continue to work for me as my servant. My ships are ready and my people are, too, because they had expected to leave two days ago.

og: This jealousy  Is for a precious creature: as she's rare,  Must it be great, and as his person's mighty,  Must it be violent, and as he does conceive  He is dishonour'd by a man which ever  Profess'd to him, why, his revenges must  In that be made more bitter.
t: Leontes is jealous of a very special woman and, because she's so special, his jealousy is intense; because he's a powerful king, his jealousy will be violent, too, and because he thinks he's been betrayed by his best friend, his revenge will be horrific.

og: Fear o'ershades me:  Good expedition be my friend, and comfort  The gracious queen, part of his theme, but nothing  Of his ill-ta'en suspicion!
t: I'm paralyzed with fear. Let's hope we have a safe journey out and that the queen doesn't become a victim, too, of his delusions.

og: Come, Camillo;  I will respect thee as a father if  Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.
t: Come on, Camillo. I'll love you as much as I love my own father if you can get me out of here alive. Let's go.

og: It is in mine authority to commandThe keys of all the posterns: please your highnessTo take the urgent hour. Come, sir, away.
t: I have the power to tell the gatekeepers to unlock the gates whenever I want, so just let me know when you think we should leave. Come on, sir, let's go.

og: Take the boy to you: he so troubles me,'Tis past enduring.
t: Take Mamillius with you. He's wearing me out; I can't deal with him anymore.

og: Come, my gracious lord,Shall I be your playfellow?
t: Come here, little man. Will you play with me?

og: No, I'll none of you.
t: No, I don't want you.

og: Why, my sweet lord?
t: Why not, little man?

og: You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as ifI were a baby still. I love you better.
t: You'll kiss me too hard and talk to me like I'm still a baby.  I love you better.

og: And why so, my lord?
t: And why's that, sir?

og: Not for becauseYour brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say,Become some women best, so that there be notToo much hair there, but in a semicircleOr a half-moon made with a pen.
t: Not because your eyebrows are dark, although they say dark eyebrows look good on some women. It's better if you pluck them in a semi-circle, or draw a half-moon shape with a pen.

og: Who taught you this?
t: Who taught you this?

og: I learnt it out of women's faces. Pray nowWhat colour are your eyebrows?
t: I learned it from women's faces. I have a question: what color are your eyebrows?

og: Blue, my lord.
t: Blue, sir.

og: Nay, that's a mock: I have seen a lady's noseThat has been blue, but not her eyebrows.
t: No, you're joking. I've seen a lady's nose that was blue, but never her eyebrows.

og: Hark ye;The queen your mother rounds apace: we shallPresent our services to a fine new princeOne of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us,If we would have you.
t: Listen, your mother is coming over. Pretty soon we'll have a new prince to take care of, and then you'll wish we'd play with you more.

og: She is spread of lateInto a goodly bulk: good time encounter her!
t: She's looking really pregnant all of a sudden. She'll go into labor soon!

og: What wisdom stirs amongst you? Come, sir, nowI am for you again: pray you, sit by us,And tell 's a tale.
t: What are you all talking about?  Come here, Mamillius, I'm ready to deal with you again. Come on, come sit by me and tell me a story.

og: Merry or sad shall't be?
t: A happy story, or a sad story?

og: As merry as you will.
t: As happy as you want it to be.

og: A sad tale's best for winter: I have oneOf sprites and goblins.
t: A sad story's best for winter. I know one about ghosts and goblins.

og: Let's have that, good sir.Come on, sit down: come on, and do your bestTo fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.
t: Let's hear it, then. Come on, sit down, come on. And do your best to scare me with your ghosts—you're very good at that.

og: There was a man—
t: "There was a man—

og: Nay, come, sit down; then on.
t: No, come and sit down. Now go on.

og: Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly;Yond crickets shall not hear it.
t: —who lived by a church." I'll whisper it so quietly that the crickets out there won't be able to hear it.

og: Come on, then,And give't me in mine ear.
t: Come on, then, and whisper it in my ear.

og: Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?
t: Did you find him? His servants? Was Camillo with him?

og: Behind the tuft of pines I met them; neverSaw I men scour so on their way: I eyed themEven to their ships.
t: I saw them while I was hiding behind a cluster of pine trees. I never saw men hurry away so quickly. I watched them go all the way to their ships.

og: How blest am I  In my just censure, in my true opinion!  Alack, for lesser knowledge! how accursed  In being so blest!
t: I am so blessed—I knew it; I was right. If only I knew less! This blessing is a curse!

og: There may be in the cup  A spider steep'd, and one may drink, depart,  And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge  Is not infected:
t: If someone has a cup with a poisonous spider hiding in it, he can drink and not be poisoned because his knowledge isn't infected.

og: but if one present  The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye, make known  How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides,  With violent hefts. I have drunk,  and seen the spider.
t: But if you pull the spider out of the cup, show it to him, and explain that he just drank poison, he'll start vomiting. I have drunk, and seen the spider.

og: Camillo was his help in this, his pander:  There is a plot against my life, my crown;  All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain  Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him:
t: Camillo was his accomplice; they're planning to kill me and take over my throne. Everything I suspected turned out to be true. That dirty liar—who worked for me— was a double agent working for Polixenes.

og: He has discover'd my design, and I  Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick  For them to play at will.
t: He figured out what I knew, but I'm still in their clutches and they're still playing me for a fool.

og: How came the posterns  So easily open?
t: How were they able to open the gates?

og: By his great authority;Which often hath no less prevail'd than soOn your command.
t: Camillo had the power to open them—he's done it many times at your command.

og: I know't too well.Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him:Though he does bear some signs of me, yet youHave too much blood in him.
t: Ah, I knew that. Give me the boy. I'm glad you didn't breastfeed him. Even though he looks kind of like me, you have too many of your genes in him already.

og: What is this? sport?
t: Is this a joke?

og: Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her;Away with him! and let her sport herselfWith that she's big with; for 'tis PolixenesHas made thee swell thus.
t: I know it was Polixenes that got you pregnant.

og: But I'ld say he had not,And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying,Howe'er you lean to the nayward.
t: But I say it wasn't him, and I am sure you will believe me, even if you were inclined to think otherwise .

og: You, my lords,  Look on her, mark her well; be but about  To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and  The justice of your hearts will thereto add  'Tis pity she's not honest, honourable:'
t: All right, men, take a good look at her. I know what you're thinking: "She's an attractive woman, but it's too bad that she's a liar and a cheater."

og: Praise her but for this her without-door form,  Which on my faith deserves high speech, and straight  The shrug, the hum or ha, these petty brands  That calumny doth use—O, I am out—  That mercy does, for calumny will sear  Virtue itself:
t: You can compliment her outer beauty, sure—I mean, she deserves that! But then you have to admit that liars use their good looks to manipulate others into thinking they're good people!

og: these shrugs, these hums and ha's,  When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between  Ere you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known,  From him that has most cause to grieve it should be,  She's an adulteress.
t: Your shrugs and your "hmms" show you're hesitant to say "she's honest," right? Everybody believe me; I'm the the real victim. She's having an affair.

og: Should a villain say so,The most replenish'd villain in the world,He were as much more villain: you, my lord,Do but mistake.
t: If the worst villain in the world said that, he'd be twice as evil just for saying so. But you—you've only made a mistake.

og: You have mistook, my lady,  Polixenes for Leontes: O thou thing!
t: You've made the mistake, sweetheart: mistaking Polixenes for Leontes. You monster!

og: Which I'll not call a creature of thy place,  Lest barbarism, making me the precedent,  Should a like language use to all degrees  And mannerly distinguishment leave out  Betwixt the prince and beggar:
t: I can't call you a queen anymore, because if I did, the word "queen" would cease to mean anything. You might as well call a beggar a queen.

og: I have said  She's an adulteress; I have said with whom:  More, she's a traitor and Camillo is  A federary with her,
t: I've said it: she's having an affair, and I said with whom. On top of that, she's a traitor and Camillo is in cahoots with her.

og: and one that knows  What she should shame to know herself  But with her most vile principal, that she's  A bed-swerver, even as bad as those  That vulgars give bold'st titles, ay, and privy  To this their late escape.
t: He knew all about the dirty deeds she and Polixenes got up to. He knew she was a whore and he knew all about their plan to escape.

og: No, by my life.  Privy to none of this.
t: No; I swear on my life. There was nothing to know.

og: How will this grieve you,  When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that  You thus have publish'd me!
t: You'll regret this when you come to your senses—you'll regret the things you've said about me!

og: Gentle my lord,  You scarce can right me throughly then to say  You did mistake.
t: Sweetheart, you can almost totally fix this now if you admit you made a mistake.

og: No; if I mistakeIn those foundations which I build upon,The centre is not big enough to bearA school-boy's top. Away with her! to prison!He who shall speak for her is afar off guiltyBut that he speaks.
t: No. If the foundation of everything I believe turns out to be fake, the whole thing will collapse.  Take her away to the prison! Anyone who tries to defend her is guilty, too.

og: There's some ill planet reigns:  I must be patient till the heavens look  With an aspect more favourable.
t: There's some kind of evil in the air. I'll have to be patient until this all clears up.

og: Good my lords,  I am not prone to weeping, as our sex  Commonly are; the want of which vain dew  Perchance shall dry your pities:
t: Listen, everyone: unlike most women, I'm not one to cry, and the fact that I'm not shedding a tear might lead you not to pity me.

og: but I have  That honourable grief lodged here which burns  Worse than tears drown:
t: But I promise you that my heart is hurting more right now than tears could show.

og: beseech you all, my lords,  With thoughts so qualified as your charities  Shall best instruct you, measure me; and so  The king's will be perform'd!
t: I'm begging you, all of you, to think clearly, see me clearly, and help the king to do the right thing!

og: Shall I be heard?
t: Is anyone listening to me?

og: Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness,  My women may be with me; for you see  My plight requires it.
t: Who's coming with me? Begging your pardon, Leontes, but I need some women to come with me on account of the pregnancy.

og: Do not weep, good fools;  There is no cause: when you shall know your mistress  Has deserved prison, then abound in tears  As I come out: this action I now go on  Is for my better grace.
t: Don't cry; there's no reason to cry. You can cry if and when you find out that I actually deserve to be in prison. What's happening here is only a chance for me to demonstrate grace.

og: Adieu, my lord:  I never wish'd to see you sorry; now  I trust I shall.
t: Goodbye, sir. I never hoped to see you regret something; now I'm sure I will.

og: My women, come; you have leave.
t: Ladies, come on, you have permission.

og: Go, do our bidding; hence!
t: Go, do what I say! Get out!

og: Beseech your highness, call the queen again.
t: Please, sir, tell the queen to come back.

og: Be certain what you do, sir, lest your justiceProve violence; in the which three great ones suffer,Yourself, your queen, your son.
t: You'd better be sure of what you're doing, sir, or what you think is "justice" will devolve into violence that only causes you, your queen, and your son to suffer.

og: For her, my lord,I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir,Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotlessI' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean,In this which you accuse her.
t: Sir, I swear on my life that the queen is innocent; I'd even die to defend it if you'd accept my sacrifice. I mean, she's innocent of what you've accused her.

og: If it prove  She's otherwise, I'll keep my stables where  I lodge my wife;
t: If it turns out otherwise, I'll make my wife sleep in the stable.

og: I'll go in couples with her;  Than when I feel and see her no farther trust her;
t: I'll rig her to my carriage and won't trust her any farther than I can throw her.

og: For every inch of woman in the world,  Ay, every dram of woman's flesh is false, If she be.
t: I mean, if Hermione's a cheater, then every atom of every woman in the world is, too.

og: Hold your peaces.
t: Everyone shut up.

og: Good my lord,—
t: Sir—

og: It is for you we speak, not for ourselves:  You are abused and by some putter-on  That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain,  I would land-damn him.
t: We're speaking for your sake, not ours. You've clearly been manipulated by some crook, and we'll punish him for it. I wish I knew the guy; I would ruin his life.

og: Be she honour-flaw'd,  I have three daughters; the eldest is eleven  The second and the third, nine, and some five;  If this prove true, they'll pay for't:
t: If Hermione's corrupt . . . I have three daughters. The oldest is eleven, the younger two are nine and five. If this turns out to be true, they'll pay for it.

og: by mine honour,  I'll geld 'em all; fourteen they shall not see,  To bring false generations: they are co-heirs;
t: I swear I'll neuter all of them. They'll never hit puberty and they'll never give birth to their own bastard children. Keep in mind, they're supposed to inherit my money and everything equally.

og: And I had rather glib myself than they  Should not produce fair issue.
t: I'd rather castrate myself than see them unable to have their own families.

og: Cease; no more.You smell this business with a sense as coldAs is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel'tAs you feel doing thus; and see withalThe instruments that feel.
t: Stop, no more. You're onto the scent about as much as a dead man's nose. But I do see how emotional you are, and I feel for you. I still have the capacity to feel.

og: If it be so,We need no grave to bury honesty:There's not a grain of it the face to sweetenOf the whole dungy earth.
t: If that's true, then we shouldn't have to do away with truth altogether. Right now it's like truth has disappeared from the face of the earth.

og: What! lack I credit?
t: What, you don't believe me?

og: I had rather you did lack than I, my lord,Upon this ground; and more it would content meTo have her honour true than your suspicion,Be blamed for't how you might.
t: I'd prefer not to believe you, sir, on this issue. I'd rather see Hermione defended, no matter how you might be blamed for starting things.

og: Why, what need we  Commune with you of this, but rather follow  Our forceful instigation?
t: Well, what do I need you guys for? I can carry out the investigation myself.

og: Our prerogative  Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness  Imparts this;
t: I don't ask your opinions because I want them; I ask because I'm a generous guy.

og: which if you, or stupefied  Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not  Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves  We need no more of your advice:
t: If you're too idiotic and inept to realize the truth like I have, then I guess I don't need your advice anymore.

og: the matter,  The loss, the gain, the ordering on't, is all  Properly ours.
t: The accusation, the execution, and the stakes are all mine.

og: And I wish, my liege,You had only in your silent judgment tried it,Without more overture.
t: And I wish, sir, that you'd thought this out in your head and never said it aloud.

og: How could that be?  Either thou art most ignorant by age,  Or thou wert born a fool.
t: Why would you say that? Either you're the most ignorant old man I've ever met or you were born an idiot.

og: Camillo's flight,  Added to their familiarity,  Which was as gross as ever touch'd conjecture,  That lack'd sight only, nought for approbation  But only seeing, all other circumstances  Made up to the deed, doth push on this proceeding:
t: The fact that Camillo ran away, on top of Hermione and Polixenes' disgusting hook-ups (even if we didn't see them, we have all the evidence except the visual proof), on top of everything else, makes putting Hermione on trial absolutely necessary.

og: Yet, for a greater confirmation,  For in an act of this importance 'twere  Most piteous to be wild, I have dispatch'd in post  To sacred Delphos, to Apollo's temple,  Cleomenes and Dion, whom you know  Of stuff'd sufficiency:
t: It would be wrong to go about something this serious haphazardly, so I've sent my servants Cleomenes and Dion (you know them; they're good guys) to Delphos, to Apollo's temple.

og: now from the oracle  They will bring all; whose spiritual counsel had,  Shall stop or spur me. Have I done well?
t: They'll bring back a prophecy from the oracle that will settle everything, for good or bad. How did I do?

og: Well done, my lord.
t: Well done, sir.

og: Though I am satisfied and need no more  Than what I know, yet shall the oracle  Give rest to the minds of others, such as he  Whose ignorant credulity will not  Come up to the truth.
t: Though I'm satisfied and don't need to know anything more than I already know, the oracle will put other people's minds at ease, especially those ignorant nonbelievers who can't stomach the truth.

og: So have we thought it good  From our free person she should be confined,  Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence  Be left her to perform.
t: I decided it was a good idea to keep Hermione in prison so that she didn't try to escape like Polixenes and Camillo.

og: Come, follow us;  We are to speak in public; for this business  Will raise us all.
t: Come on, follow me. I'm going to speak publicly, since news of this ordeal is bound to have spread.

og: To laughter, as I take it,If the good truth were known.
t: And everyone's laughing at him and at us, if truth be told.

og: The keeper of the prison, call to him;let him have knowledge who I am.    Now, good sir,You know me, do you not?
t: Tell the jailer to come in here. Tell him who I am. Now, sir, you know who I am, right?

og: For a worthy ladyAnd one whom much I honour.
t: I know your reputation, and I have a lot of respect for you.

og: Pray you then,Conduct me to the queen.
t: Well then, please take me to the queen.

og: I may not, madam:To the contrary I have express commandment.
t: I can't, ma'am. I have orders to do exactly the opposite.

og: Here's ado,To lock up honesty and honour fromThe access of gentle visitors!Is't lawful, pray you,To see her women? any of them? Emilia?
t: Well, isn't that something: locking up an innocent woman and keeping her from friendly visitors. Am I allowed to see any of her servants? Emilia?

og: So please you, madam,To put apart these your attendants, IShall bring Emilia forth.
t: If you'll get rid of your servants, ma'am, I can bring Emilia out.

og: I pray now, call her.Withdraw yourselves.
t: All right, then, call her.  You may all leave.

og: And, madam,I must be present at your conference.
t: And, ma'am, I'll have to stay in the room to monitor your conversation.

og: Well, be't so, prithee.     Dear gentlewoman,How fares our gracious lady?
t: Well, so be it, then.  How's Hermione doing?

og: As well as one so great and so forlornMay hold together: on her frights and griefs,Which never tender lady hath born greater,She is something before her time deliver'd.
t: As well as a queen with so many reasons to grieve can be expected to do. Poor thing—because of the stress, she went into labor early.

og: A boy?
t: A boy?

og: A daughter, and a goodly babe,Lusty and like to live: the queen receivesMuch comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner,I am innocent as you.'
t: A daughter. She's beautiful, healthy, and will probably live. The queen takes a lot of comfort from the baby. She keeps saying, "My poor prisoner, I am as innocent as you."

og: I dare be sworn  These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king,  beshrew them!
t: I swear—damn the king's crazy delusions!

og: He must be told on't, and he shall: the office  Becomes a woman best; I'll take't upon me:
t: We have to tell him about the baby. We will. It's a woman's job and I'll do it myself.

og: If I prove honey-mouth'd let my tongue blister  And never to my red-look'd anger be  The trumpet any more.
t: I won't have many nice things to say to him, I can guarantee you.

og: Pray you, Emilia,  Commend my best obedience to the queen:
t: Emilia, please tell the queen that I'm completely at her service.

og: If she dares trust me with her little babe,  I'll show't the king and undertake to be  Her advocate to the loud'st.
t: If she'll trust me with her tiny newborn, I'll show it to the king and will advocate for her to the best of my ability.

og: We do not know  How he may soften at the sight o' the child:  The silence often of pure innocence  Persuades when speaking fails.
t: It's hard to say how he'll react—he may be touched when he sees her. Sometimes the silent testimony of pure innocence can persuade when words fail.

og: Most worthy madam,  Your honour and your goodness is so evident  That your free undertaking cannot miss  A thriving issue:
t: Ma'am, you're so obviously good and virtuous that I can't imagine you not succeeding.

og: there is no lady living  So meet for this great errand.
t: There's no better woman for this job.

og: Please your ladyship  To visit the next room, I'll presently  Acquaint the queen of your most noble offer;
t: I'll go into the next room and tell the queen your plan.

og: Who but to-day hammer'd of this design,  But durst not tempt a minister of honour,  Lest she should be denied.
t: Though she only gave birth today, she's afraid to ask them to take the baby out of this prison. If they deny her request, who knows—they might kill the child.

og: Tell her, Emilia.I'll use that tongue I have: if wit flow from'tAs boldness from my bosom, let 't not be doubtedI shall do good.
t: Tell her, Emilia. I'll use my gift of speech. If I can be as articulate as I am bold, then I'll do well.

og: Now be you blest for it!I'll to the queen: please you,come something nearer.
t: And God bless you for that! I'll go to the queen. But please, come closer.

og: Madam, if't please the queen to send the babe,I know not what I shall incur to pass it,Having no warrant.
t: Ma'am, if the queen agrees to send the baby, I don't think I can allow it. I don't have a warrant.

og: You need not fear it, sir:This child was prisoner to the womb and isBy law and process of great nature thenceFreed and enfranchised, not a party toThe anger of the king nor guilty of,If any be, the trespass of the queen.
t: There's nothing to worry about, sir. The baby was imprisoned in the womb, but she's been freed by natural law. She's not under any accusations from the king, and she can't possibly be guilty of anything the queen did.

og: I do believe it.
t: I'll buy that.

og: Do not you fear: upon mine honour,I will stand betwixt you and danger.
t: Don't worry. I swear I'll keep you out of trouble.

og: Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness  To bear the matter thus; mere weakness.
t: Night and day I get no rest. I'm handling this the way I am because I'm weak, just weak.

og: If  The cause were not in being,—part o' the cause,  She the adulteress;
t: If only the problem weren't her as a person—I can't isolate the problem or cut it out, because it's her; she's unfaithful.

og: for the harlot king  Is quite beyond mine arm, out of the blank  And level of my brain, plot-proof;
t: Polixenes is beyond my reach, out of sight and out of mind, irrelevant.

og: but she  I can hook to me: say that she were gone,  Given to the fire, a moiety of my rest  Might come to me again. Who's there?
t: But Hermione is here and within my power. If she died, say, in a fire, I might be able to sleep at night. Who's there?

og: My lord?
t: Yes, sir?

og: How does the boy?
t: How's Mamillius doing?

og: He took good rest to-night;'Tis hoped his sickness is discharged.
t: He slept well tonight. We're hoping he's gotten through his illness.

og: To see his nobleness!  Conceiving the dishonour of his mother,
t: It's hard to see him like this! He got sick when he realized his mother is disgraced.

og: He straight declined, droop'd, took it deeply,  Fasten'd and fix'd the shame on't in himself,  Threw off his spirit, his appetite, his sleep,  And downright languish'd.
t: He took it hard, as if her shame were his own personal burden. He stopped smiling, eating, and sleeping and then became bedridden.

og: Leave me solely: go,  See how he fares.
t: Leave me alone; go see how he's doing. [The SERVANT leaves]

og: Fie, fie! no thought of him:  The thought of my revenges that way  Recoil upon me:
t: Shame on you! Don't think about Polixenes—you can't take revenge on him now without putting yourself in danger.

og: in himself too mighty,  And in his parties, his alliance; let him be  Until a time may serve:
t: He's too powerful; he has too many friends and allies. Leave him alone until the right moment.

og: for present vengeance,  Take it on her. Camillo and Polixenes  Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow:
t: Right now, just take your revenge on Hermione. Camillo and Polixenes are laughing at me; my suffering is a huge joke to them.

og: They should not laugh if I could reach them, nor  Shall she within my power.
t: They wouldn't be laughing if I could get to them—and she definitely won't, since she's within my power.

og: You must not enter.
t: You can't come in here.

og: Nay, rather, good my lords, be second to me:Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas,Than the queen's life? a gracious innocent soul,More free than he is jealous.
t: No, listen, men, follow my lead. Do you care more about what this crazy, tyrant king thinks of you than you do about the queen's life? She's incredibly gracious and innocent, and he's just jealous.

og: That's enough.
t: That's enough.

og: Madam, he hath not slept tonight; commandedNone should come at him.
t: Ma'am, he hasn't slept tonight, and he demanded that no one be allowed into his room.

og: Not so hot, good sir:  I come to bring him sleep.
t: Not so fast, sir; I came to help him get to sleep.

og: 'Tis such as you,  That creep like shadows by him and do sigh  At each his needless heavings, such as you  Nourish the cause of his awaking:
t: It's people like you, yes-men who encourage his delusional fantasies, that are keeping him awake.

og: I  Do come with words as medicinal as true,  Honest as either, to purge him of that humour  That presses him from sleep.
t: I came to tell him something so true that it'll work like medicine—my honesty will cure the disease that keeps him from sleeping.

og: What noise there, ho?
t: Hey, what's that noise?

og: No noise, my lord; but needful conferenceAbout some gossips for your highness.
t: It's not just noise, sir, it's an important discussion about godparents for you.

og: How!Away with that audacious lady! Antigonus,I charged thee that she should not come about me:I knew she would.
t: What? Get this ridiculous woman out of here.  Antigonus, I told you not to let her get to me. I knew she would.

og: I told her so, my lord,On your displeasure's peril and on mine,She should not visit you.
t: Sir, I told her not to come near you, and explained that you (and I) would both be angry with her if she did.

og: What, canst not rule her?
t: Oh, so you're not the boss of her?

og: From all dishonesty he can: in this,Unless he take the course that you have done,Commit me for committing honour, trust it,He shall not rule me.
t: He can tell me not to do something that's wrong, but right now I'm doing the right thing. Unless he follows your example and locks me up for doing good, he can't be the boss of me.

og: La you now, you hear:When she will take the rein I let her run;But she'll not stumble.
t: Ha, listen to that! She's like a galloping horse—once she gets it into her head, I have to let her go.

og: Good my liege, I come;  And, I beseech you, hear me, who profess  Myself your loyal servant, your physician,  Your most obedient counsellor,
t: Sir, I came to ask you to listen to me as your loyal servant, your doctor, your obedient advisor.

og: yet that dare  Less appear so in comforting your evils,  Than such as most seem yours:
t: I came because I'm bold enough (unlike your other servants, doctors, and advisors) to call you out on your evil actions.

og: I say, I come  From your good queen.
t: I come on behalf of your good queen.

og: Good queen!
t: "Good" queen?

og: Force her hence.
t: Get her out of here!

og: Let him that makes but trifles of his eyesFirst hand me: on mine own accord I'll off;But first I'll do my errand. The good queen,For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter;Here 'tis; commends it to your blessing.
t: If you want your eyes scratched out, then come at me. I'll leave on my own, but first I have to do what I came for. The good queen (because she is good) has given birth to your daughter. Here she is, now give her your blessing.

og: Out!A mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door:A most intelligencing bawd!
t: Get out! You manly witch! Take her away, out the door! That damn busybody!

og: Not so:I am as ignorant in that as youIn so entitling me, and no less honestThan you are mad; which is enough, I'll warrant,As this world goes, to pass for honest.
t: Nah, none of those names suits me at all. I'm as honest as you are crazy and, all things considered, that's honest enough for anyone.

og: Traitors!Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard.Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroostedBy thy dame Partlet here. Take up the bastard;Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.
t: You old fart! Your wife is the boss of you, you're completely whipped! Pick up the bastard. I said pick it up! Give it to your hag of a wife.

og: For everUnvenerable be thy hands, if thouTakest up the princess by that forced basenessWhich he has put upon't!
t: If you so much as touch the princess in response to his disgusting words, your hands will be cursed forever.

og: So I would you did; then 'twere past all doubtYou'ld call your children yours.
t: I wish you feared your wife, too. Then you'd know your children are yours beyond all reasonable doubt.

og: A nest of traitors!
t: This place is full of traitors!

og: I am none, by this good light.
t: I'm no traitor, sir, I swear.

og: Nor I, nor any  But one that's here, and that's himself,
t: Neither am I, and neither is anyone here except for you, Leontes.

og: for he  The sacred honour of himself, his queen's,  His hopeful son's, his babe's, betrays to slander,  Whose sting is sharper than the sword's;
t: You're a traitor to yourself, your honor, your queen, your son and heir, and your newborn baby. You've betrayed them all to gossip and rumor, causing a kind of pain that's worse than the physical.

og: and will not—  For, as the case now stands, it is a curse  He cannot be compell'd to't—once remove  The root of his opinion, which is rotten  As ever oak or stone was sound.
t: At this time, we can't convince him to stop unless we remove the root of the issue: the completely false idea that's rotted his brain.

og: A callat  Of boundless tongue,
t: Here's a slut who doesn't know when to shut up,

og: who late hath beat her husband  And now baits me! This brat is none of mine;  It is the issue of Polixenes:
t: who just beat her husband and is now trying to trick me! This brat is not mine, it's Polixenes's.

og: Hence with it, and together with the dam  Commit them to the fire!
t: Get it out of here, and throw it and the bitch into the fire!

og: It is yours;  And, might we lay the old proverb to your charge,  So like you, 'tis the worse.
t: She is yours and, as the saying goes, she's like you to a fault.

og: Behold, my lords,  Although the print be little, the whole matter  And copy of the father, eye, nose, lip,  The trick of's frown, his forehead, nay, the valley,  The pretty dimples of his chin and cheek,  His smiles,  The very mould and frame of hand, nail, finger:
t: Behold, gentlemen. Though she might be a smaller version, she's an exact copy of her father: eyes, nose, mouth, his usual frown, his forehead, the cheek and chin dimples, his smile, the exact shape of his hand, fingers, and nails.

og: And thou, good goddess Nature, which hast made it  So like to him that got it, if thou hast  The ordering of the mind too, 'mongst all colours  No yellow in't, lest she suspect, as he does,  Her children not her husband's!
t: Hermione's given birth to her husband's mini-me, and I guarantee you she has no doubt that her children are Leontes's!

og: Hang all the husbandsThat cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourselfHardly one subject.
t: If you hang all the husbands who can't keep their wives quiet, you won't have any subjects left.

og: Once more, take her hence.
t: For the last time, get her out of here!

og: A most unworthy and unnatural lordCan do no more.
t: A king as despicable and unfit to rule as you can't do much more.

og: I'll ha' thee burnt.
t: I'll have you burned to death.

og: I care not:  It is an heretic that makes the fire,  Not she which burns in't.
t: I don't care. In that case, the heretic would be the one making the fire, not the one burning in it!

og: I'll not call you tyrant;  But this most cruel usage of your queen,  Not able to produce more accusation  Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savours  Of tyranny
t: I'll stop short of calling you a tyrant, but this cruel treatment of your queen on the basis of nothing more than your unsupported fantasy definitely tastes like tyranny.

og: and will ignoble make you,  Yea, scandalous to the world.
t: The world will see you as horrible and scandalous from here on out.

og: On your allegiance,Out of the chamber with her! Were I a tyrant,Where were her life? she durst not call me so,If she did know me one. Away with her!
t: If you're loyal to me, you better get her out of this room! If I were a tyrant, she would be dead by now. She wouldn't dare to call me that if she actually thought I were one. Take her away!

og: I pray you, do not push me; I'll be gone.
t: Please, don't push me, I'll leave.

og: Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours:  Jove send her  A better guiding spirit!
t: Sir, take care of you child—since she is yours. May God send her a guardian angel!

og: What needs these hands?  You, that are thus so tender o'er his follies,  Will never do him good, not one of you.
t: Get your hands off me! All of you that are coddling his idiotic behavior: you won't do him any good, not one of you.

og: Thou, traitor, hast set on thy wife to this.  My child? away with't!
t: You traitor, you told your wife to do this. My child? Get it out of here!

og: Even thou, that hast  A heart so tender o'er it, take it hence  And see it instantly consumed with fire;
t: Since you seem to care so much about it: take it away and watch it burn.

og: Even thou and none but thou. Take it up straight:  Within this hour bring me word 'tis done,  And by good testimony, or I'll seize thy life,  With what thou else call'st thine.
t: I want it to be you and no one else. Do it immediately, and come back within an hour to confirm you've done it. If you're not honest with me about it, I'll execute you and your entire family.

og: If thou refuse  And wilt encounter with my wrath, say so;  The bastard brains with these my proper hands  Shall I dash out.
t: If you refuse, you'll have my anger to deal with, plus I'll dash its bastard brains out with my own two hands.

og: Go, take it to the fire;  For thou set'st on thy wife.
t: Go! Take it to the fire as punishment for what you've made your wife do.

og: I did not, sir:These lords, my noble fellows, if they please,Can clear me in't.
t: Sir, I didn't do anything. These gentlemen are my friends and can vouch for me.

og: We can: my royal liege,He is not guilty of her coming hither.
t: We can, your majesty. It's not his fault that she came here.

og: You're liars all.
t: You're all liars.

og: Beseech your highness, give us better credit:
t: Please, your highness, give us more credit than that.

og: We have always truly served you, and beseech you  So to esteem of us, and on our knees we beg,  As recompense of our dear services  Past and to come, that you do change this purpose,
t: We've always served you faithfully. We're begging you on our knees: in recognition of our past and future service to you, listen to us and stop what you're doing right now.

og: Which being so horrible, so bloody, must  Lead on to some foul issue: we all kneel.
t: It's too horrible, too bloody—and it's going to end badly. Watch us kneel. [All the gentlemen kneel to LEONTES]

og: I am a feather for each wind that blows:  Shall I live on to see this bastard kneel  And call me father?
t: You think my mind will be changed that easily, like a feather carried on the wind? Do you expect me to wait around until this bastard can kneel and call me "father?"

og: better burn it now  Than curse it then. But be it; let it live.  It shall not neither.
t: It's better to burn it now than to deal with it then. But fine, let it live. I'll neither burn it nor keep it.

og: You, sir, come you hither;  You that have been so tenderly officious  With Lady Margery, your midwife there,  To save this bastard's life,—for 'tis a bastard,  So sure as this beard's grey,
t: You! You've been in cahoots with the Wicked Witch, your wife, to save this bastard's life (and it is a bastard, as sure as my beard is gray).

og: —what will you adventure  To save this brat's life?
t: What are you willing to do to save this brat's life?

og: Any thing, my lord,That my ability may undergoAnd nobleness impose: at least thus much:I'll pawn the little blood which I have leftTo save the innocent: any thing possible.
t: Anything, sir, that I'm capable of doing. I'll lay down my life to save the innocent. I'll do anything that's possible.

og: It shall be possible. Swear by this swordThou wilt perform my bidding.
t: Oh, it will be possible. Swear by my sword that you'll do what I say.

og: I will, my lord.
t: I will, sir.

og: Mark and perform it, see'st thou! for the fail  Of any point in't shall not only be  Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife,  Whom for this time we pardon.
t: Listen closely and do exactly what I tell you. If you fail at any point, it means death for not only you, but for your horrible wife (who, at least for now, I forgive).

og: We enjoin thee,  As thou art liege-man to us, that thou carry  This female bastard hence and that thou bear it  To some remote and desert place quite out  Of our dominions, and that there thou leave it,  Without more mercy, to its own protection  And favour of the climate.
t: I command you as my subject to carry this bastard to some deserted place far away from this country. Leave it there, to the mercy of the elements.

og: As by strange fortune  It came to us, I do in justice charge thee,  On thy soul's peril and thy body's torture,  That thou commend it strangely to some place  Where chance may nurse or end it. Take it up.
t: It appeared in my life by a stroke of bad luck. Therefore, I command that you, on pain of damnation and death, leave it up to luck whether it lives or dies. Now pick it up.

og: I swear to do this, though a present death  Had been more merciful.
t: I'll swear to do this, though it would have been more merciful to just kill it.

og: Come on, poor babe:  Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens  To be thy nurses! Wolves and bears, they say  Casting their savageness aside have done  Like offices of pity.
t: Come on, poor baby. May a guardian angel protect you from vicious animals. They say that wolves and bears sometimes take pity on human babies on nurse them, too.

og: Sir, be prosperous  In more than this deed does require!
t: Sir, good luck to you.

og: And blessing  Against this cruelty fight on thy side,  Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!
t: I hope you're protected from everything horrible, you poor thing, even though you're condemned to be lost.

og: No, I'll not rearAnother's issue.
t: Nope, I won't raise someone else's kid.

og: Please your highness, postsFrom those you sent to the oracle are comeAn hour since: Cleomenes and Dion,Being well arrived from Delphos, are both landed,Hasting to the court.
t: Your highness? We just got news that the messengers you sent to Delphos are almost back. Cleomenes and Dion just got to the shore and are on their way to court.

og: So please you, sir, their speedHath been beyond account.
t: Sir, they've been much speedier than expected.

og: Twenty-three days  They have been absent: 'tis good speed; foretells  The great Apollo suddenly will have  The truth of this appear.
t: They've been gone for twenty-three days; they've made good time. That bodes well for the truth Apollo will give us soon.

og: Prepare you, lords;  Summon a session, that we may arraign  Our most disloyal lady,
t: Men, get ready for a special meeting so that we can have a trial for Hermione.

og: for, as she hath  Been publicly accused, so shall she have  A just and open trial.
t: Since I've accused her publicly, she should have a just and open trial.

og: While she lives  My heart will be a burthen to me. Leave me,  And think upon my bidding.
t: As long as she lives, it'll weigh on my heart. Now leave me alone, and go carry out my orders.

og: The climate's delicate, the air most sweet,Fertile the isle, the temple much surpassingThe common praise it bears.
t: The weather's fantastic, the air is fresh, the island is lush, and the temple is even more beautiful than everyone says it is.

og: I shall report,For most it caught me, the celestial habits,Methinks I so should term them, and the reverenceOf the grave wearers. O, the sacrifice!How ceremonious, solemn and unearthlyIt was i' the offering!
t: I'll talk about the thing that impressed me the most: the super-spiritual lifestyle (that's how I'd describe it, anyway) and discipline of the priests.

og: But of all, the burstAnd the ear-deafening voice o' the oracle,Kin to Jove's thunder, so surprised my senseThat I was nothing.
t: The best part was the blast of the oracle's ear-defeaning voice; it was like thunder! I was scared senseless. I felt tiny and insignificant.

og: If the event o' the journeyProve as successful to the queen,—O be't so!—As it hath been to us rare, pleasant, speedy,The time is worth the use on't.
t: Hopefully the reading of the prophecy is as successful as our journey (for the queen's sake). It was a great, enjoyable, quick trip, but we can only hope it was worth the time.

og: Great ApolloTurn all to the best! These proclamations,So forcing faults upon Hermione,I little like.
t: Dear Apollo, help it all go well! I don't like these accusations against Hermione one bit.

og: The violent carriage of it  Will clear or end the business:
t: Leontes's violent way of going about it all is about to come to an end.

og: when the oracle,  Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up,  Shall the contents discover, something rare  Even then will rush to knowledge.
t: When we read the oracle's prophecy, sealed and endorsed by Apollo, we'll find out the truth.

og: Go: fresh horses!  And gracious be the issue!
t: Let's get fresh horses! Let's hope the oracle has something good to say!

og: This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce,  Even pushes 'gainst our heart:
t: My extreme grief notwithstanding, I hereby pronounce this trial open. It pulls at my heart strings; really, it does:

og: the party tried  The daughter of a king, our wife, and one  Of us too much beloved.
t: the party tried here today is both the daughter of a king and my beloved wife.

og: Let us be clear'd  Of being tyrannous, since we so openly  Proceed in justice, which shall have due course,  Even to the guilt or the purgation.
t: In doing this, it should be clear that I'm not a tyrant; I'm proceeding openly in the due course of justice, whether it leads to a "guilty" sentence or an "innocent" one.

og: Produce the prisoner.
t: Bring in the prisoner.

og: It is his highness' pleasure that the queenAppear in person here in court. Silence!
t: The king has ordered that the queen appear at court in person. Silence!

og: Read the indictment.
t: Read the indictment.

og: Hermione, queen to the worthy  Leontes, king of Sicilia, thou art here accused and  arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery  with Polixenes, king of Bohemia, and conspiring  with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign  lord the king, thy royal husband:
t: Hermione, Queen of Sicily and wife of King Leontes: you are here accused and called to account for high treason, for committing adultery with Polixenes, King of Bohemia, and conspiring with Camillo to assassinate your husband the king.

og: the pretence  whereof being by circumstances partly laid open,  thou, Hermione, contrary to the faith and allegiance  of a true subject, didst counsel and aid them, for  their better safety, to fly away by night.
t: By nature of the circumstances, you are also charged with aiding and abetting the fugitives to their escape, which violates the trust and duty of a true subject.

og: Since what I am to say must be but that  Which contradicts my accusation and  The testimony on my part no other  But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me  To say 'not guilty:'
t: Since what I'm about to say can only be a rejection of my accusations, and the only testimony this court will hear on my behalf is my own, it's hardly worth it for me to say "not guilty."

og: mine integrity  Being counted falsehood, shall, as I express it,  Be so received.
t: Since you've already decided I'm a liar, you'll only interpret my words as lies.

og: But thus: if powers divine  Behold our human actions, as they do,  I doubt not then but innocence shall make  False accusation blush and tyranny  Tremble at patience.
t: But listen: if God watches over us, as he does, then I'm sure that innocence will triumph over false accusations, and that patience will defeat tyranny.

og: You, my lord, best know,  Who least will seem to do so, my past life  Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true,  As I am now unhappy;
t: You should know better than anyone (though, at the moment, you seem to know the least) how pure and faithful I've been my entire life.

og: which is more  Than history can pattern, though devised  And play'd to take spectators.
t: No falsified history can change that, no matter how well it's fabricated and performed for spectators.

og: For behold me  A fellow of the royal bed (which owe  A moiety of the throne), a great king's daughter,  The mother to a hopeful prince, here standing  To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore  Who please to come and hear.
t: Look at me: I'm the king's wife (making me half of the royal government), the daughter of a powerful king, the mother of a young prince, and I'm standing here babbling on to defend my life and reputation to any old person who'll come and listen.

og: For life, I prize it  As I weigh grief, which I would spare: for honour,  'Tis a derivative from me to mine,  And only that I stand for.
t: Honestly? My life is about as precious to me as my grief, which I'd rather not have to bear. I care about my reputation because it affects my children's future; that's the only reason I stand here now.

og: I appeal  To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes  Came to your court, how I was in your grace,  How merited to be so;
t: Sir, I appeal to your own conscience. Remember how much you loved me—and how much I deserved it—before Polixenes came to your court.

og: since he came,  With what encounter so uncurrent I  Have strain'd to appear thus:
t: Since he came, I've only tried to remain worthy of your love.

og: i  f one jot beyond  The bound of honour, or in act or will  That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts  Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin  Cry fie upon my grave!
t: If I've done a single thing outside the demands of duty, either in thought or deed, then everyone who hears me can hate me and my own family can curse my grave!

og: I ne'er heard yetThat any of these bolder vices wantedLess impudence to gainsay what they didThan to perform it first.
t: It's hardly uncommon for someone who committed such heinous offenses to deny them later.

og: That's true enough;Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.
t: That may be true of people who've actually done such things; it has nothing to do with me.

og: You will not own it.
t: So you won't admit it?

og: More than mistress of  Which comes to me in name of fault, I must not  At all acknowledge.
t: I can't admit to things that I haven't done.

og: For Polixenes,  With whom I am accused, I do confess  I loved him as in honour he required,  With such a kind of love as might become  A lady like me, with a love even such,  So and no other, as yourself commanded:
t: As far as Polixenes is concerned, I can only confess that I loved him as much as I should, with the kind of love that a woman in my position should give—the kind of love that you, yourself, commanded that I show.

og: Which not to have done I think had been in me  Both disobedience and ingratitude  To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke,  Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely  That it was yours.
t: If I hadn't cared for him, I would have been disobedient to you and inhospitable toward your friend. I mean, you've loved Polixenes since before you could speak, since you were a baby, and he's always loved you back.

og: Now, for conspiracy,  I know not how it tastes; though it be dish'd  For me to try how: all I know of it  Is that Camillo was an honest man;
t: As for conspiracy: I've never tasted it, despite the fact that you keep serving it to me on a plate. All I know is that Camillo was an honest man.

og: And why he left your court, the gods themselves,  Wotting no more than I, are ignorant.
t: God only knows why he left your court; I have no idea.

og: You knew of his departure, as you knowWhat you have underta'en to do in's absence.
t: You knew he was planning to leave, and you very well know what you've been working on in his absence.

og: Sir,You speak a language that I understand not:My life stands in the level of your dreams,Which I'll lay down.
t: You're speaking a language that I don't understand. It's as if my life were being made up by your dreams; I'll lay down what life I have now.

og: Your actions are my dreams;  You had a bastard by Polixenes,  And I but dream'd it.
t: Your actions are my dreams! Oh, so you had Polixenes's bastard, and I just dreamed it?

og: As you were past all shame,—  Those of your fact are so—so past all truth:
t: Like all of your kind, you're past shame, past truth.

og: Which to deny concerns more than avails; for as  Thy brat hath been cast out, like to itself,  No father owning it,—
t: Denying your crimes only proves you've committed them. The brat is gone, on its own now, since no father will claim it—

og: which is, indeed,  More criminal in thee than it,—so thou  Shalt feel our justice, in whose easiest passage  Look for no less than death.
t: though that's more your fault than the brat's. Now you'll feel my justice. Expect nothing less than a death sentence.

og: Sir, spare your threats:  The bug which you would fright me with I seek.  To me can life be no commodity:
t: You can save your threats. Death doesn't scare me; death is what I'm after. Life holds nothing for me now.

og: The crown and comfort of my life, your favour,  I do give lost; for I do feel it gone,  But know not how it went.
t: Your love, the light of my life? I've given up on that—it's gone, although I don't know where or why it went.

og: My second joy  And first-fruits of my body, from his presence  I am barr'd, like one infectious.
t: My second blessing, my firstborn son? I'm barred from seeing him as if I had a contagious disease.

og: My third comfort  Starr'd most unluckily, is from my breast,  The innocent milk in its most innocent mouth,  Haled out to murder:  myself on every post  Proclaimed a strumpet: with immodest hatred  The child-bed privilege denied, which 'longs  To women of all fashion;
t: My third blessing, my poor daughter, was ripped from my breast, the innocent milk still in her innocent mouth, and hauled out to be murdered. I've been publicized as a whore on every street-corner, was denied the normal hospital care for women who've just given birth,

og: l  astly, hurried  Here to this place, i' the open air, before  I have got strength of limit.
t: and, finally, was rushed to this place—in the open air—before I'd even gotten my strength back.

og: Now, my liege,  Tell me what blessings I have here alive,  That I should fear to die? Therefore proceed.
t: So, my king: tell me what blessings I have to live for, that would make me afraid to die? Therefore, carry on.

og: But yet hear this: mistake me not; no life,  I prize it not a straw, but for mine honour,  Which I would free, if I shall be condemn'd  Upon surmises, all proofs sleeping else  But what your jealousies awake, I tell you  'Tis rigor and not law.
t: But hear this, and don't misunderstand me: I don't value my own life at all, but my reputation—that I would clear. If I'm going to be condemned on your suspicions alone, with no proof except whatever your jealous mind has come up with, well—that is injustice, not law.

og: Your honours all,  I do refer me to the oracle:  Apollo be my judge!
t: Gentlemen, I defer to the oracle. May Apollo be my judge!

og: This your requestIs altogether just: therefore bring forth,And in Apollos name, his oracle.
t: Your request is perfectly reasonable. In Apollo's name, bring forth the oracle.

og: The Emperor of Russia was my father:O that he were alive, and here beholdingHis daughter's trial! that he did but seeThe flatness of my misery, yet with eyesOf pity, not revenge!
t: The Emperor of Russia was my father. I wish he were alive to see his daughter on trial now! Seeing my misery, he'd take pity, not revenge.

og: You here shall swear upon this sword of justice,  That you, Cleomenes and Dion, have  Been both at Delphos, and from thence have brought  The seal'd-up oracle, by the hand deliver'd  Of great Apollo's priest;
t: Swear on this sword of justice that you, Cleomenes and Dion, have been to Delphos and have brought back the sealed oracle delivered to you by Apollo's priest.

og: and that, since then,  You have not dared to break the holy seal  Nor read the secrets in't.
t: Swear that, since then, you have neither broken the holy seal nor read the secrets inside.

og: All this we swear.
t: We swear to all of this.

og: Break up the seals and read.
t: Break the seal and read it.

og: Hermione is chaste;Polixenes blameless; Camillo a true subject; Leontesa jealous tyrant; his innocent babe truly begotten;and the king shall live without an heir, if thatwhich is lost be not found.
t: Hermione is virtuous,Polixenes is blameless,Camillo is a loyal subject,Leontes is a jealous tyrant,The baby is his biological daughter,And the king will have no heirUntil he finds that which is lost.

og: Now blessed be the great Apollo!
t: Bless you, Apollo!

og: Praised!
t: Praise Apollo!

og: Hast thou read truth?
t: Have you read the truth?

og: Ay, my lord; even soAs it is here set down.
t: Yes, sir. Exactly as it's written down.

og: There is no truth at all i' the oracle:The sessions shall proceed: this is mere falsehood.
t: The oracle is complete garbage. The trial will proceed. This is a pack of lies.

og: My lord the king, the king!
t: Sir, the king, the king!

og: What is the business?
t: What's going on here?

og: O sir, I shall be hated to report it!The prince your son, with mere conceit and fearOf the queen's speed, is gone.
t: Oh sir, please don't shoot the messenger. The prince, your son, out of worrying so much about his mother, is gone.

og: How! gone!
t: What do you mean, "gone?"

og: Is dead.
t: He's dead.

og: Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselvesDo strike at my injustice.    How now there!
t: Apollo is angry. The heavens themselves are punishing me for my injustice.  Look out!

og: This news is mortal to the queen: look downAnd see what death is doing.
t: This news has killed the queen. Look down and see what death is doing!

og: Take her hence:  Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover:
t: Take her away. Her heart is just a little strained; she'll recover.

og: I have too much believed mine own suspicion:  Beseech you, tenderly apply to her  Some remedies for life.
t: I put too much stock in my own suspicions. Please, take care of her, get her some medicine.

og: Apollo, pardon  My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle!  I'll reconcile me to Polixenes,  New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo,  Whom I proclaim a man of truth, of mercy;
t: Apollo, please forgive my blasphemy against your oracle! I'll make up with Polixenes, win my wife over again, bring Camillo back since I know now that he's a good guy.

og: For, being transported by my jealousies  To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose  Camillo for the minister to poison  My friend Polixenes:
t: I was too carried away with my jealousy and got caught up with bloody thoughts of revenge. I told Camillo to poison my friend Polixenes,

og: which had been done,  But that the good mind of Camillo tardied  My swift command, though I with death and with  Reward did threaten and encourage him,
t: which would have happened if Camillo hadn't questioned my command (even though I threatened him with death if he didn't obey).

og: Not doing 't and being done: he, most humane  And fill'd with honour, to my kingly guest  Unclasp'd my practise, quit his fortunes here,  Which you knew great, and to the hazard  Of all encertainties himself commended,  No richer than his honour:
t: He admirably told Polixenes what I had planned, then gave up his comfortable position here to help Polixenes get away. He risked everything to do what was right.

og: how he glisters  Thorough my rust! and how his pity  Does my deeds make the blacker!
t: His goodness glitters through my dark intentions, making my actions look even more dark by contrast!

og: Woe the while!O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it,Break too.
t: Oh, woe is me! My heart is about to break!

og: What fit is this, good lady?
t: What's the matter with you, ma'am?

og: What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me?  What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling?  In leads or oils?
t: You tyrant, what tortures do you have in store for me? Stretch me on the rack? Burn me at the stake? Boil me in oil?

og: what old or newer torture  Must I receive, whose every word deserves  To taste of thy most worst?
t: What range of old and new punishments will I receive for cursing you the way you deserve?

og: Thy tyranny  Together working with thy jealousies,  Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle  For girls of nine, O, think what they have done  And then run mad indeed, stark mad!
t: Your tyranny and your jealous fantasies, which were more immature than young boys' passing thoughts and more useless then nine-year-old girls' daydreams—well, just consider what your fantasies have done! If you can get your head around it, you'll really go crazy now!

og: for all  Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.  That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing;  That did but show thee, of a fool, inconstant  And damnable ingrateful:
t: Everything you've done was just a byproduct of that. You betrayed Polixenes, but that was nothing; it just proved you were flaky and a damned ungrateful idiot.

og: nor was't much,  Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour,  To have him kill a king: poor trespasses,  More monstrous standing by:
t: It wasn't so bad, either, that you wrecked Camillo's life by trying to force him to kill a king. Those were small offenses compared to what came next.

og: whereof I reckon  The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter  To be or none or little; though a devil  Would have shed water out of fire ere done't:
t: You abandoned your daughter to the wilderness: that's not such a big deal (though even the devil himself wouldn't have done it).

og: Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death  Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts,  Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart  That could conceive a gross and foolish sire  Blemish'd his gracious dam:
t: And really, it's not your fault that the sensitive, young prince died of a broken heart, from disbelief that his disgusting, foolish father would destroy his beloved mother.

og: this is not, no,  Laid to thy answer: but the last,—O lords,  When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen,  The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead,  and vengeance for't  Not dropp'd down yet.
t: No, sir. You don't have to answer for any of this. But this most recent thing (and, gentleman, prepare to cry out as soon as you hear it): the queen, the queen, the sweetest, dearest creature is dead, and vengeance for it remains to be seen.

og: The higher powers forbid!
t: God forbid!

og: I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath  Prevail not, go and see:
t: I said she's dead; I'll swear it. If you don't believe me, go and see for yourself.

og: if you can bring  Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye,  Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you  As I would do the gods.
t: If you can bring the color back to her cheeks, open her eyes, or get her breathing again, it would be a miracle.

og: But, O thou tyrant!  Do not repent these things, for they are heavier  Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee  To nothing but despair.
t: You tyrant! Don't you dare repent what you've done. These crimes couldn't be offset even if you mustered every ounce of remorse in your body. From now on, your whole life should be nothing but misery.

og: A thousand knees  Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting,  Upon a barren mountain and still winter  In storm perpetual, could not move the gods  To look that way thou wert.
t: A thousand people praying naked and fasting on a mountain in a perpetual winter storm for ten thousand years could not convince the gods to have mercy on you.

og: Go on, go onThou canst not speak too much; I have deservedAll tongues to talk their bitterest.
t: Go on; go on. It's impossible for you to say too much. I deserve the most bitter words anyone can offer.

og: Say no more:Howe'er the business goes, you have made faultI' the boldness of your speech.
t: Say no more. Whatever's happened, you overstepped your boundaries in making that speech.
