og: I am sorry for't:  All faults I make, when I shall come to know them,  I do repent.
t: I'm sorry for that. Any faults that come to my attention, I'm sure I'll repent for.

og: Alas! I have show'd too much  The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd  To the noble heart.
t: Well, well. Just call me a classic, over-emotional woman; I've hurt the king's feelings.

og: What's gone and what's past help  Should be past grief: do not receive affliction  At my petition;
t: Don't cry over what's in the past and can't be helped. And don't be upset only because I told you to—I'd rather you punished me for reminding you of what you forgot.

og: I beseech you, rather  Let me be punish'd, that have minded you  Of what you should forget. Now, good my liege  Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman:  The love I bore your queen—lo, fool again!—
t: Now sir, forgive me for speaking so harshly. I loved your queen so much—oops, I did it again!

og: I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children;  I'll not remember you of my own lord,  Who is lost too: take your patience to you,  And I'll say nothing.
t: I won't talk about her anymore, or about your children, or about my husband, Antigonus, who is lost, too. Beg your pardon; I won't say a word.

og: Thou didst speak but well  When most the truth; which I receive much better  Than to be pitied of thee.
t: No, you said the right thing; you spoke the truth. I welcome it, actually, more than I would welcome your pity.

og: Prithee, bring me  To the dead bodies of my queen and son:  One grave shall be for both: upon them shall  The causes of their death appear, unto  Our shame perpetual.
t: Please, show me the dead bodies of my wife and son. I'll make them a double grave, and, as a mark of my shame, will write on their gravestones how and why they died.

og: Once a day I'll visit  The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there  Shall be my recreation: so long as nature  Will bear up with this exercise, so long  I daily vow to use it.
t: I'll visit the chapel where they're buried every day and will spend all my time crying over them. I'll do this for as long as I live.

og: Come and lead me  Unto these sorrows.
t: Lead me to my heartbreak.

og: Thou art perfect then, our ship hath touch'd uponThe deserts of Bohemia?
t: So you're sure we've arrived in Bohemia?

og: Ay, my lord: and fear  We have landed in ill time:
t: Yes, sir, and I'm afraid we've arrived at a bad time.

og: the skies look grimly  And threaten present blusters.
t: The skies look dark, which means it's about to storm.

og: In my conscience,  The heavens with that we have in hand are angry  And frown upon's.
t: In my opinion, the gods are angry at us and are punishing us.

og: Their sacred wills be done! Go, get aboard;Look to thy bark: I'll not be long beforeI call upon thee.
t: May the gods' will be done! Get back on board the boat; I'll be back in a minute.

og: Make your best haste, and go notToo far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather;Besides, this place is famous for the creaturesOf prey that keep upon't.
t: Hurry as fast as you can, and don't go too far inland—this storm looks bad. Besides, this place is famous for its man-eating animals.

og: Go thou away:I'll follow instantly.
t: Go on; I'll be right behind you.

og: I am glad at heartTo be so rid o' the business.
t: I'll be glad to get this over with.

og: Come, poor babe:  I have heard, but not believed,  the spirits o' the dead  May walk again:
t: Come here, poor baby. I've heard (but haven't believed) stories about spirits of the dead walking the earth.

og: i  f such thing be, thy mother  Appear'd to me last night, for ne'er was dream  So like a waking.
t: If these things do happen, then your mother appeared to me last night in a dream that was so real, it felt like I was awake.

og: To me comes a creature,  Sometimes her head on one side, some another;
t: Something walked toward me, moving its head from side to side.

og: I never saw a vessel of like sorrow,  So fill'd and so becoming:
t: I've never seen anything so sad and so completely beautiful.

og: in pure white robes,  Like very sanctity, she did approach  My cabin where I lay; thrice bow'd before me,  And gasping to begin some speech, her eyes  Became two spouts: the fury spent, anon  Did this break-from her:
t: In pure white robes, like a goddess, she walked toward the place where I was sleeping. She bowed three times, gasping as she tried to speak. Crying with rage, she finally burst out,

og: 'Good Antigonus,  Since fate, against thy better disposition,  Hath made thy person for the thrower-out  Of my poor babe, according to thine oath,  Places remote enough are in Bohemia,  There weep and leave it crying; and, for the babe  Is counted lost for ever, Perdita,  I prithee, call't.
t: "Antigonus, you have the bad luck to be disposing of my baby far away in Bohemia. Shed a tear as you leave her there. Since she's lost forever, you should call her 'Perdita.'

og: For this ungentle business  Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see  Thy wife Paulina more.' And so, with shrieks  She melted into air.
t: And for what my husband has made you do, you'll never see your wife, Paulina, again." Then, shrieking, she disappeared into thin air.

og: Affrighted much,  I did in time collect myself and thought  This was so and no slumber. Dreams are toys:  Yet for this once, yea, superstitiously,  I will be squared by this.
t: Terrified, it took me a while to collect myself, and I wasn't sure if it was a dream or not. Usually I don't put much stock in dreams, but this one I'd swear by superstitiously.

og: I do believe  Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that  Apollo would, this being indeed the issue  Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid,  Either for life or death, upon the earth  Of its right father.
t: I believe that Hermione died, and that Apollo wants this baby (who must be King Polixenes's daughter) to be laid here on its father's land, to either live or die.

og: Blossom, speed thee well!  There lie, and there thy character: there these;  Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty,  And still rest thine.
t: Good luck! There you are, and there's the story of your identity. If you make it, these things might help you.

og: The storm begins; poor wretch,  That for thy mother's fault art thus exposed  To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot,  But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I  To be by oath enjoin'd to this.
t: The storm is beginning! Poor brat, you're out in the elements thanks to your mother's mistake, and who knows what will happen! I can't cry, but my heart is bleeding and I'm damned for getting tangled up in this.

og: Farewell!  The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have  A lullaby too rough: I never saw  The heavens so dim by day. A savage clamour!  Well may I get aboard!
t: Goodbye! It's getting darker and darker. I'm afraid the lullaby you're about to get will be a little on the rough side; I've never seen the sky so black in the daytime. The thunder, the lightning! I need to get aboard the ship!

og: This is the chase:  I am gone for ever.
t: Well, this is it: I'm gone forever.

og: I would there were no age between sixteen and  three-and-twenty, or that youth would sleep out the  rest; for there is nothing in the between but  getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry,  stealing, fighting—
t: I wish we could go straight from sixteen to twenty-three, or that we could put our lives on pause in between those ages. Ya don't get up to much at that age except knocking girls up, embarrassing your old folks, stealing, fighting—

og: Hark you now! Would any but  these boiled brains of nineteen and two-and-twenty  hunt this weather? They have scared away two of my  best sheep, which I fear the wolf will sooner find  than the master:
t: Well, whadaya know! Only no-good youngsters would be out in this weather! They've scared away two of my best sheep, and I'll be darned if the wolves don't find them before I do.

og: if any where I have them, 'tis by  the seaside, browsing of ivy. Good luck, an't be thy  will what have we here! Mercy on 's, a barne a very  pretty barne! A boy or a child, I wonder?
t: If they're anywhere to be found, it's down by the sea, grazing on some weeds . . . [He looks into the basket] Lord have mercy, it's a baby, a very pretty little baby! Is it a boy or a girl, I wonder?

og: A  pretty one; a very pretty one: sure, some 'scape:  though I am not bookish, yet I can read  waiting-gentlewoman in the 'scape.
t: Ah, it's a pretty one, you're a very pretty one, aren't you, with a pretty face. I may not be all that smart, but I can tell from your face your mama's a high-class lady.

og: This has been  some stair-work, some trunk-work, some  behind-door-work: they were warmer that got this  than the poor thing is here. I'll take it up for  pity:
t: This has been some back-room, behind-closed-doors, under-the-covers business, huh, by two people who were hotter and heavier than you are now! You poor thing, come here.

og: yet I'll tarry till my son come; he hallooed  but even now. Whoa, ho, hoa!
t: I'll hold on 'til my son comes; I thought I heard him just now—Hey there!

og: Hilloa, loa!
t: Howdy-hey!

og: What, art so near? If thou'lt see a thing to talkon when thou art dead and rotten, come hither. Whatailest thou, man?
t: What're you doing up here? If you wanna see the darnedest thing you ever did see, get yourself over here! What's the matter with you, boy?

og: I have seen two such sights, by sea and by land!but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now thesky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrusta bodkin's point.
t: I've seen two unbelievable things, one in the sea and one on land! But now I don't know what's the sea and what's the sky; everything's all mixed up in this storm.

og: Why, boy, how is it?
t: What in the world do you mean, boy?

og: I would you did but see how it chafes, how it rages,  how it takes up the shore! but that's not the  point. O, the most piteous cry of the poor souls!
t: If only you could see how the water is roiling and raging all the way up the beach—but that's not the point! The pitiful cries of people who are doomed!

og: sometimes to see 'em, and not to see 'em; now the  ship boring the moon with her main-mast, and anon  swallowed with yest and froth, as you'ld thrust a  cork into a hogshead.
t: I could see 'em, and then I couldn't as the ship went up and down, to and fro, pushed around in the waves like you'd push a cork into a keg of beer.

og: And then for the  land-service, to see how the bear tore out his  shoulder-bone; how he cried to me for help and said  his name was Antigonus, a nobleman.
t: And then on land, if you'd seen how the bear tore his arm out of its socket, and heard how he cried to me for help and said his name was Antigonus, a gentleman.

og: But to make an  end of the ship, to see how the sea flap-dragoned  it: but, first, how the poor souls roared, and the  sea mocked them; and how the poor gentleman roared  and the bear mocked him, both roaring louder than  the sea or weather.
t: But back to the ship: if you'd seen how the sea gobbled them up, and the people screamed, and the sea laughed at them, and how the poor man screamed and the bear laughed at him, both screaming louder than the sea or the storm.

og: Name of mercy, when was this, boy?
t: Bless my soul. When was this, boy?

og: Now, now: I have not winked since I saw thesesights: the men are not yet cold under water, northe bear half dined on the gentleman: he's at itnow.
t: Now, now! I've barely blinked since I saw it all. The men have hardly sunk to the ocean floor yet and the bear hasn't finished eating the gentleman; he's at it now.

og: Would I had been by, to have helped the old man!
t: I wish I would have been there to have helped the old man!

og: I would you had been by the ship side, to havehelped her: there your charity would have lacked footing.
t: I wish you would have been alongside the ship, to have helped it, too, though that would have been pretty difficult.

og: Heavy matters! heavy matters! but look thee here,  boy. Now bless thyself: thou mettest with things  dying, I with things newborn.
t: That's heavy stuff! Heavy stuff! But lookee here, boy. Cross your heart—you came across the dying, and I came across something that's newborn.

og: Here's a sight for  thee; look thee, a bearing-cloth for a squire's  child!
t: Here's a sight for you: look, a blanket for a gentleman's baby!

og: look thee here; take up, take up, boy;  open't. So, let's see: it was told me I should be  rich by the fairies. This is some changeling:  open't. What's within, boy?
t: Lookee here, pick it up now, pick it up, boy, and open it! So, let's see: I've got an idea the fairies have made me rich. This is a changeling—open it. What's it say, boy?

og: You're a made old man: if the sins of your youthare forgiven you, you're well to live. Gold! all gold!
t: Your fortune is made, old man. Someone must have forgiven the sins of your youth; now you're set for life. Gold! All gold!

og: This is fairy gold, boy, and 'twill prove so: upwith't, keep it close: home, home, the next way.We are lucky, boy; and to be so still requiresnothing but secrecy. Let my sheep go: come, goodboy, the next way home.
t: This is fairy gold, boy, you'll see! Hold on to it tight. Let's get on home now. We are lucky, boy, and to hold on to our luck we need to keep this under wraps. Let the sheep go. Let's get on home now, boy!

og: Go you the next way with your findings. I'll go seeif the bear be gone from the gentleman and how muchhe hath eaten: they are never curst but when theyare hungry: if there be any of him left, I'll buryit.
t: Go on ahead with your findings. I'll go and see if the bear is gone and, if there's anything left of the gentleman, I'll bury it.

og: That's a good deed. If thou mayest discern by thatwhich is left of him what he is, fetch me to thesight of him.
t: That's a good thing to do. If you can tell from what's left who he is and where he's from, bring me there to see him.

og: Marry, will I; and you shall help to put him i' the ground.
t: Yes, sir, I will, and you can help me bury him.

og: 'Tis a lucky day, boy, and we'll do good deeds on't.
t: We're lucky today, boy. Let's give thanks by doing good.

og: I, that please some, try all, both joy and terror  Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error,  Now take upon me, in the name of Time,  To use my wings.
t: I reveal all—joy and terror, good and bad, mistakes made and mistakes paid for— to the benefit of some and to the detriment of others. I am Time, and I came here to flap my wings.

og: Impute it not a crime  To me or my swift passage, that I slide  O'er sixteen years and leave the growth untried  Of that wide gap, since it is in my power  To o'erthrow law and in one self-born hour  To plant and o'erwhelm custom.
t: Don't blame me for flying by, passing over sixteen years as if it were nothing. It's within my power to defy the rules and pack all of this into a single hour.

og: Let me pass  The same I am, ere ancient'st order was  Or what is now received: I witness to  The times that brought them in; so shall I do  To the freshest things now reigning and make stale  The glistering of this present, as my tale  Now seems to it.
t: I am the same now as I have been since ancient times, since the dawn of Time. I'm about to bring in something fresh and new to liven up our current tale, which is as old (and stale) as Time.

og: Your patience this allowing,  I turn my glass and give my scene such growing  As you had slept between: Leontes leaving,  The effects of his fond jealousies so grieving  That he shuts up himself,
t: If you don't mind, I'll turn my hourglass to while away the years before our next scene as quickly as if you'd slept through it. We'll leave Leontes there. He regretted the consequences of his jealousy so much that he shut himself away.

og: imagine me,  Gentle spectators, that I now may be  In fair Bohemia, and remember well,  I mentioned a son o' the king's, which Florizel  I now name to you; and with speed so pace  To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace  Equal with wondering:
t: Those of you in the audience: imagine I'm in Bohemia now. Remember when I mentioned the king's son? Now I can tell you that his name is Florizel, and I'll also tell you that Perdita has grow up into a beautiful woman.

og: what of her ensues  I list not prophecy; but let Time's news  Be known when 'tis brought forth.  A shepherd's daughter,  And what to her adheres, which follows after,  Is the argument of Time.
t: I won't tell you what becomes of her; you'll see everything in due Time. She was raised as a shepherd's daughter, and what happens to her next only Time will tell. Bear with us for the next part; you'll be glad you took the Time.

og: Of this allow,  If ever you have spent time worse ere now;  If never, yet that Time himself doth say  He wishes earnestly you never may.
t: Ever had a worse Time than you've had watching this play? Well, Time himself hopes that you never will.

og: I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate:'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death togrant this.
t: Please, Camillo, don't pester me. Though it's hard to deny you anything, it would be the death of you if I said "yes."

og: It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though  I have for the most part been aired abroad, I  desire to lay my bones there.
t: I haven't been home in fifteen years. I've been away for so long, but I do want to die and be buried there.

og: Besides, the penitent  king, my master, hath sent for me;
t: Besides, the remorseful king, my former boss, has asked me to come.

og: to whose feeling  sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to  think so, which is another spur to my departure.
t: I might be able to ease his suffering, which is just another reason I want to go.

og: As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of  thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of  thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to  have had thee than thus to want thee:
t: Camillo, if you're loyal to me, you wouldn't think of leaving me now; I need your services especially (and, since I've been spoiled with a servant as effective as you, I can hardly settle for someone else).

og: thou, having  made me businesses which none without thee can  sufficiently manage, must either stay to execute  them thyself or take away with thee the very  services thou hast done;
t: Plus, you've built industries for me here that no one but you can take care of, so you either need to stay here to do it yourself, or take your projects with you.

og: which if I have not enough  considered, as too much I cannot, to be more  thankful to thee shall be my study, and my profit  therein the heaping friendships.
t: I can never thank you enough for all the work you've done—and for your friendship.

og: Of that fatal  country, Sicilia, prithee speak no more; whose very  naming punishes me with the remembrance of that  penitent, as thou callest him, and reconciled king,  my brother; whose loss of his most precious queen  and children are even now to be afresh lamented.
t: Please, don't talk about Sicily anymore. The name alone dredges up bad memories of that "remorseful" king (as you call him), my friend, and the loss of his wife and children, which we should be mourning even now.

og: Say to me, when sawest thou the Prince Florizel, my  son? Kings are no less unhappy, their issue not  being gracious, than they are in losing them when  they have approved their virtues.
t: Anyway, when did you last see my son, Prince Florizel? It's just as bad for a king to misplace a good son as to have a bad one at hand.

og: Sir, it is three days since I saw the prince. Whathis happier affairs may be, are to me unknown: but Ihave missingly noted, he is of late much retiredfrom court and is less frequent to his princelyexercises than formerly he hath appeared.
t: Sir, I haven't seen the prince for three days. I'm not sure what he's up to, but I have noticed that he's been away from court a lot and that he's been neglecting his princely duties more than usual.

og: I have considered so much, Camillo, and with some  care; so far that I have eyes under my service which  look upon his removedness;
t: I've noticed, too, Camillo—so much so that I have people watching him for me wherever he goes.

og: from whom I have this  intelligence, that he is seldom from the house of a  most homely shepherd;
t: They've reported that he's spending most of his time at a poor shepherd's house.

og: a man, they say, that from  very nothing, and beyond the imagination of his  neighbours, is grown into an unspeakable estate.
t: They tell me that some time ago the shepherd suddenly went from rags to riches, to the complete shock of his neighbors.

og: I have heard, sir, of such a man, who hath adaughter of most rare note: the report of her isextended more than can be thought to begin from such a cottage.
t: I've heard of this guy, sir, and that he has a very beautiful daughter. By all reports, she's far beyond what you'd expect from such circumstances.

og: That's likewise part of my intelligence; but, I  fear, the angle that plucks our son thither.
t: I've heard that, too, and I'm afraid you've put your finger on the bait that's lured my son away.

og: Thou  shalt accompany us to the place; where we will, not  appearing what we are, have some question with the  shepherd;
t: You'll come with me to the place, where we'll disguise ourselves and question the shepherd.

og: from whose simplicity I think it not  uneasy to get the cause of my son's resort thither.
t: Since he's probably not all that bright, it won't be difficult to get the story of my son's shenanigans out of him.

og: Prithee, be my present partner in this business, and  lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.
t: Please forget about Sicily and come help me with this.

og: I willingly obey your command.
t: I'm happy to do as you say.

og: My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.
t: Atta boy, Camillo! Let's put on disguises.

og: When daffodils begin to peer,  With heigh! the doxy over the dale,  Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year;  For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.
t: When daffodils begin to bloom,(Say "hey!") roll around in the grass with your loverSince spring, the best time of the year, is here,After a winter of waiting and wanting.

og: The white sheet bleaching on the hedge,  With heigh! the sweet birds, O, how they sing!  Doth set my pugging tooth on edge;  For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.
t: The clean white sheets hanging out to dry(Say "hey!") and the birds' beautiful singingHave me hankering for a hook-up.I'm no snob—an ugly girl satisfies as much as any other.

og: The lark, that tirra-lyra chants,  With heigh! with heigh! the thrush and the jay,  Are summer songs for me and my aunts,  While we lie tumbling in the hay.
t: The lark that chirps, "tweet, tweet!"(Say "hey!" Say "hey!"), the thrush, and the blue jayAre the perfect soundtrack for me and my ladies,While we get down in the hay.

og: I have served Prince Florizel and in my time wore three-pile; but now I am out of service:
t: I served Prince Florizel back in the day and used to wear a fancy suit, but now I'm out of a job.

og: But shall I go mourn for that, my dear?  The pale moon shines by night:  And when I wander here and there,  I then do most go right.
t: But am I crying over that, sweetheart?The moon shines in the night:Its light guides me as I wander around after-hoursAt which time I (mostly) do good.

og: If tinkers may have leave to live,  And bear the sow-skin budget,  Then my account I well may, give,  And in the stocks avouch it.
t: If we tolerate handymenWho live on a piss-poor budgetThen I might as well "fix" my income.I'll pay for it with jail time if I have to.

og: My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to lesser linen.
t: I'm in the sheets business. If you see a hawk like me swooping in, you better get out your second-best linens.

og: My father named me Autolycus; who being, as I am, littered under Mercury, was likewise a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles.
t: My father named me "Autolycus." Like me, he was destined to be a thief, and, like me, he spent his time snapping up overlooked goodies.

og: With die and drab I purchased this caparison, and my revenue is the silly cheat. Gallows and knock are too powerful on the highway:
t: I paid for this outfit by pimping—not to mention the additional profit of cheap booty. The threats of jail and death are pretty real out here on the street.

og: beating and hanging are terrors to me: for the life to come, I sleep out the thought of it.
t: I live in constant fear of being beaten or hanged, and I can't even think about the afterlife! I drink to forget about it.

og: A prize! a prize!
t: Ah, here's a treat!

og: Let me see: every 'leven wether tods; every todyields pound and odd shilling; fifteen hundredshorn. what comes the wool to?
t: Let's see: every sheep yields eleven pounds of wool, every pound of wool is worth a dollar and a penny, and we've shaved fifteen hundred sheep. How much does that make us?

og: If the springe hold, the cock's mine.
t: If I do this right, I'll catch him.

og: I cannot do't without counters. Let me see; what am  I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast?
t: I can't do it without a calculator. Let's see: what do I need to buy for the sheep-shearing party?

og: Three pound  of sugar, five pound of currants, rice,—what will  this sister of mine do with rice? But my father  hath made her mistress of the feast, and she lays it  on.
t: Three pounds of sugar, five pounds of grapes, rice—no idea what my sister needs rice for, but my dad set her up as the debutante of the party, and she's in charge.

og: She hath made me four and twenty nose-gays for  the shearers, three-man-song-men all, and very good  ones; but they are most of them means and bases;
t: She made bouquets for all twenty-four of the men who'll shave the sheep tonight. They're all decent guys, but they're rascals.

og: but  one puritan amongst them, and he sings psalms to  horn-pipes. I must have saffron to colour the warden  pies; mace; dates?—none, that's out of my note;
t: There's only one religious guy out of all of them, and he's really strange. I need some spices for the pies, herbs . . . dates? No, not dates.

og: nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I  may beg; four pound of prunes, and as many of  raisins o' the sun.
t: Some nutmeg, a bit of ginger (but I could get that from a friend), four pounds of prunes, and tons of raisins.

og: O that ever I was born!
t: Oh, woe is me!

og: I' the name of me—
t: What in the world?

og: O, help me, help me! pluck but off these rags; andthen, death, death!
t: Oh, help me, help me! Get these rags off me, so I can die in peace!

og: Alack, poor soul! thou hast need of more rags to layon thee, rather than have these off.
t: You poor thing! In that case, you need clothes to be buried in, not for what's left of your clothes to be taken away.

og: O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me morethan the stripes I have received, which are mightyones and millions.
t: Man, these ugly rags hurt me more than the millions of punches and kicks I just received.

og: Alas, poor man! a million of beating may come to agreat matter.
t: Oh, poor man! A million punches and kicks can do a lot of damage.

og: I am robbed, sir, and beaten; my money and apparelta'en from me, and these detestable things put uponme.
t: I've been beaten and robbed. My money and clothes were stolen, and then they threw these rags on me.

og: What, by a horseman, or a footman?
t: Was it someone on horseback, or walking?

og: A footman, sweet sir, a footman.
t: Walking, my friend, walking.

og: Indeed, he should be a footman by the garments hehas left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat,it hath seen very hot service. Lend me thy hand,I'll help thee: come, lend me thy hand.
t: That makes sense—someone rich enough to ride a horse wouldn't have been wearing rags like this. Give me your hand, I'll help you up. Give me your hand.

og: O, good sir, tenderly, O!
t: Oh, thank you, sir—carefully, ow!

og: Alas, poor soul!
t: Ah, poor thing!

og: O, good sir, softly, good sir! I fear, sir, myshoulder-blade is out.
t: Oh, man, carefully! I think I've broken my shoulder blade.

og: How now! canst stand?
t: Really? Can you stand?

og: Softly, dear sir; good sir, softly. You ha' done mea charitable office.
t: You've really helped me out.

og: Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.
t: Do you need money? I can give you a little money.

og: No, good sweet sir; no, I beseech you, sir: I havea kinsman not past three quarters of a mile hence,unto whom I was going; I shall there have money, orany thing I want: offer me no money, I pray you;that kills my heart.
t: No! My dear friend, no, please. My uncle lives under a mile away, and I was just heading there. I can get some money and anything else I need there. Please, don't offer me any money, I can't bear that.

og: What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?
t: What kind of guy was it that robbed you?

og: A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about withtroll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of theprince: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of hisvirtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of thecourt.
t: A guy with a reputation for hanging out with prostitutes. I know he used to be the prince's servant. He was kicked out of court for one of his virtues; I can't remember which one.

og: His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whippedout of the court: they cherish it to make it staythere; and yet it will no more but abide.
t: You mean his vices, right? There's no virtue that would get you kicked out of court. They could use virtue there, considering they have none.

og: Vices, I would say, sir. I know this man well:
t: Vices, yes, that's what I meant. I know this guy well:

og: he  hath been since an ape-bearer; then a  process-server, a bailiff; then he compassed a  motion of the Prodigal Son, and married a tinker's  wife within a mile where my land and living lies;
t: he was an odd-jobs guy, then a police officer, then he wasted all his money for a while, and then he married a handyman's wife about a mile away from where I live now.

og: and, having flown over many knavish professions, he  settled only in rogue: some call him Autolycus.
t: He's tried his hand at several questionable professions and has now settled on being a criminal. Some call him Autolycus.

og: Out upon him! prig, for my life, prig: he hauntswakes, fairs and bear-baitings.
t: He's the worst! What a jerk! He hangs around funerals, fairs, and public events.

og: Very true, sir; he, sir, he; that's the rogue thatput me into this apparel.
t: That's true. He's the crook that put me in this outfit.

og: Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia: if you hadbut looked big and spit at him, he'ld have run.
t: He's the most cowardly criminal in the entire country. If you just shouted and looked intimidating, you'd scare him away.

og: I must confess to you, sir, I am no fighter: I amfalse of heart that way; and that he knew, I warranthim.
t: I have to admit, I'm not a fighter—my heart's too weak. I'll bet he knew that.

og: How do you now?
t: How are you feeling now?

og: Sweet sir, much better than I was; I can stand andwalk: I will even take my leave of you, and pacesoftly towards my kinsman's.
t: Much better than I was, my friend. I can stand and walk; I'll even say goodbye and make my way toward my uncle's house.

og: Shall I bring thee on the way?
t: Do you want me to come with you?

og: No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.
t: No, you sweet, caring man, you.

og: Then fare thee well: I must go buy spices for oursheep-shearing.
t: Goodbye, then. I have to go buy spices for our sheep-shearing.

og: Prosper you, sweet sir!    Jog on, jog on, the foot-path way,And merrily hent the stile-a:A merry heart goes all the day,Your sad tires in a mile-a.
t: God bless you, my friend!  Run along, run along the dirt pathAnd jump right over the cattle-guardA smile can go on all dayBut a frown only lasts for a mile.

og: These your unusual weeds to each part of you  Do give a life:
t: This costume looks good on you!

og: no shepherdess, but Flora  Peering in April's front.
t: You're not a shepherdess; you're Flora, the goddess of spring.

og: This your sheep-shearing  Is as a meeting of the petty gods,  And you the queen on't.
t: This sheep-shearing festival is a meeting of the gods, and you're the queen of all of them.

og: Sir, my gracious lord,  To chide at your extremes it not becomes me:
t: Sweetheart, I hate to correct your over-exaggerations—

og: O, pardon, that I name them! Your high self,  The gracious mark o' the land, you have obscured  With a swain's wearing, and me, poor lowly maid,  Most goddess-like prank'd up:
t: please forgive me for pointing them out. Though you've disguised yourself as a shepherd, you're still the prince of our country and I'm only a poor peasant girl playing dress-up.

og: but that our feasts  In every mess have folly and the feeders  Digest it with a custom, I should blush  To see you so attired, sworn, I think,  To show myself a glass.
t: If it weren't the kind of party where everyone will be looking a little silly, I'd be embarrassed for you to be dressed the way you are, and I could hardly look in a mirror.

og: I bless the timeWhen my good falcon made her flight acrossThy father's ground.
t: I'm thankful for the day my falcon landed on your father's farm.

og: Now Jove afford you cause!  To me the difference forges dread;
t: May God keep you safe here! I'm afraid of the consequences;

og: your greatness  Hath not been used to fear. Even now I tremble  To think your father, by some accident,  Should pass this way as you did:
t: you've been sheltered enough to not know what fear is. I'm terrified of what would happen if your dad showed up here by chance the way that you did.

og: O, the Fates!  How would he look, to see his work so noble  Vilely bound up? What would he say?
t: Oh, just imagine! What would he think of his royal son being engaged to someone like me? What would he say?

og: Or how  Should I, in these my borrow'd flaunts, behold  The sternness of his presence?
t: And how would I, in this ridiculous outfit, respond to his anger?

og: Apprehend  Nothing but jollity.
t: All I want you to think about is having a good time!

og: The gods themselves,  Humbling their deities to love, have taken  The shapes of beasts upon them:
t: You know, the gods turned themselves into animals for the sake of love:

og: Jupiter  Became a bull, and bellow'd; the green Neptune  A ram, and bleated; and the fire-robed god,  Golden Apollo, a poor humble swain,  As I seem now.
t: Jupiter became a bull, Neptune became a ram, and the sun god, Apollo, became a shepherd just like I am now.

og: Their transformations  Were never for a piece of beauty rarer,  Nor in a way so chaste, since my desires  Run not before mine honour, nor my lusts  Burn hotter than my faith.
t: And their transformations weren't for girls as beautiful as you. Or as pure—since, you know, I'm not trying to move too quickly here. My commitment to you goes beyond physical desire.

og: O, but, sir,  Your resolution cannot hold, when 'tis  Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king:
t: But it will be hard for you to maintain that when the king is against you.

og: One of these two must be necessities,  Which then will speak, that you must  change this purpose,  Or I my life.
t: One of two things will have to happen: you'll stop pursuing me, or I'll become a different person.

og: Thou dearest Perdita,  With these forced thoughts, I prithee, darken not  The mirth o' the feast.
t: Perdita, please don't ruin the party by worrying.

og: Or I'll be thine, my fair,  Or not my father's. For I cannot be  Mine own, nor any thing to any, if  I be not thine.
t: I belong to you, sweetheart, not my father. I'm nothing to myself and the world if I don't have you—

og: To this I am most constant,  Though destiny say no.
t: I swear I mean it, despite all the odds.

og: Be merry, gentle;  Strangle such thoughts as these with any thing  That you behold the while.
t: Be happy, relax, and get rid of all these negative thoughts.

og: Your guests are coming:  Lift up your countenance, as it were the day  Of celebration of that nuptial which  We two have sworn shall come.
t: Your guests are coming! Smile like today's the wedding day we've been planning.

og: O lady Fortune,Stand you auspicious!
t: I hope Lady Luck is on our side!

og: See, your guests approach:Address yourself to entertain them sprightly,And let's be red with mirth.
t: Look, your guests are coming. Try to have fun with them; let's all have a good time.

og: Fie, daughter! when my old wife lived, upon  This day she was both pantler, butler, cook,  Both dame and servant;
t: Shame on you, daughter! When your mother was alive, she was a jack-of-all-trades on the day of the festival.

og: welcomed all, served all;  Would sing her song and dance her turn; now here,  At upper end o' the table, now i' the middle;  On his shoulder, and his; her face o' fire  With labour and the thing she took to quench it,  She would to each one sip.
t: She welcomed everyone, served everyone, sang and danced—she was at one end of the table, then the other, serving this man and that man, sweating from working so hard and drinking all the while.

og: You are retired,  As if you were a feasted one and not  The hostess of the meeting:
t: Meanwhile, you're relaxing as if you were a guest and not the host!

og: pray you, bid  These unknown friends to's welcome; for it is  A way to make us better friends, more known.
t: Please welcome these strangers. I hope we can get to know them better.

og: Come, quench your blushes and present yourself  That which you are, mistress o' the feast:
t: All right, stop blushing and introduce yourself; you're the queen of the feast.

og: come on,  And bid us welcome to your sheep-shearing,  As your good flock shall prosper.
t: Come on, and welcome everyone to the sheep-shearing so that we can start enjoying ourselves.

og: You're welcome, sir.Give me those flowers there, Dorcas. Reverend sirs,For you there's rosemary and rue; these keepSeeming and savour all the winter long:Grace and remembrance be to you both,And welcome to our shearing!
t: Gentlemen, here are some herbs for you that will stay green all winter long; rosemary and rue are a gift to symbolize grace and remembrance. And welcome to our shearing!

og: Shepherdess,A fair one are you—well you fit our agesWith flowers of winter.
t: You are beautiful, shepherdess. And we see what you did there—you gave us winter flowers because we're old!

og: Sir, the year growing ancient,  Not yet on summer's death, nor on the birth  Of trembling winter,
t: Since it's spring, sir—summer's not over yet and winter hasn't come—

og: the fairest  flowers o' the season  Are our carnations and streak'd gillyvors,
t: the prettiest flowers blooming at the moment are carnations and multicolor gillyvors,

og: Which some call nature's bastards: of that kind  Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not  To get slips of them.
t: which some people call "nature's bastards." We don't grow those here, and I'm not a big fan.

og: Wherefore, gentle maiden,Do you neglect them?
t: Why don't you care for them?

og: For I have heard it saidThere is an art which in their piedness sharesWith great creating nature.
t: I've heard people say that engineering their multicoloredness is "playing God."

og: Say there be;  Yet nature is made better by no mean  But nature makes that mean:
t: Maybe you're right, but humans can't create anything in nature that doesn't already have the potential to exist;

og: so, over that art  Which you say adds to nature, is an art  That nature makes.
t: the "engineering" that you say is contrary to nature is actually enabled by nature itself.

og: You see, sweet maid, we marry  A gentler scion to the wildest stock,  And make conceive a bark of baser kind  By bud of nobler race:
t: You see, sweetheart, if we graft a purebred plant to a weed, we can make the weed produce a beautiful flower.

og: this is an art  Which does mend nature, change it rather, but  The art itself is nature.
t: This is "engineering" that improves nature, but the engineering itself is all natural.

og: So it is.
t: I suppose you're right.

og: Then make your garden rich in gillyvors,And do not call them bastards.
t: Then you should grow lots of gillyvors and stop calling them "bastards."

og: I'll not put  The dibble in earth to set one slip of them;
t: I won't plant a single one.

og: No more than were I painted I would wish  This youth should say 'twere well and only therefore  Desire to breed by me.
t: It'd be the same if my boyfriend only thought I was beautiful after I put on heavy make-up.

og: Here's flowers for you;  Hot lavender, mints, savoury, marjoram;  The marigold, that goes to bed wi' the sun  And with him rises weeping:
t: Here are flowers for you that close at night and open in the day to receive the sunshine.

og: these are flowers  Of middle summer, and I think they are given  To men of middle age. You're very welcome.
t: As midsummer flowers, they're the perfect gift for middle-aged men. You're very welcome here.

og: I should leave grazing, were I of your flock,And only live by gazing.
t: If I were one of your sheep, I wouldn't need to graze on grass—I could live just by gazing at your beautiful face.

og: Out, alas!  You'd be so lean, that blasts of January  Would blow you through and through.
t: Oh, stop it! You'd starve to death in that case.

og: Now, my fair'st friend,  I would I had some flowers o' the spring that might  Become your time of day; and yours, and yours,  That wear upon your virgin branches yet  Your maidenheads growing:
t: Now, my dear: if only I had some spring flowers for you and for my friends. Spring flowers are fitting for young virgins.

og: O Proserpina,  For the flowers now, that frighted thou let'st fall  From Dis's waggon!
t: I wish I had the flowers the spring goddess threw away when she was carted off to the underworld!

og: daffodils,  That come before the swallow dares, and take  The winds of March with beauty;
t: I wish I had daffodils (the earliest spring flowers),

og: violets dim,  But sweeter than the lids of Juno's eyes  Or Cytherea's breath;
t: violets (so dark and sweet),

og: pale primroses  That die unmarried, ere they can behold  Bright Phoebus in his strength—a malady  Most incident to maids;
t: primroses (that die when kissed by the sun),

og: bold oxlips and  The crown imperial; lilies of all kinds,  The flower-de-luce being one!
t: oxlips (the royal flowers), and every kind of lily, including the fleur-de-lis!

og: O, these I lack,  To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend,  To strew him o'er and o'er!
t: Unfortunately I don't have any of these to make a flower-crown for you, or to throw on top of you!

og: What, like a corse?
t: What, like a dead body?

og: No, like a bank for love to lie and play on;  Not like a corse;
t: No, like a grassy hill for lovers to roll around on, not like a dead body!

og: or if, not to be buried,  But quick and in mine arms.
t: Your body's not anywhere close to being buried, unless you mean buried in my arms.

og: Come, take your flowers:  Methinks I play as I have seen them do  In Whitsun pastorals:
t: Come on, take your flowers. I feel like I'm acting in a community play;

og: sure this robe of mine  Does change my disposition.
t: it's like this costume has totally changed my personality.

og: What you do  Still betters what is done. When you speak, sweet.  I'ld have you do it ever:
t: Everything you do is even more wonderful than what you did before. My darling, I can't get enough of your voice; I could listen to you talk forever.

og: when you sing,  I'ld have you buy and sell so, so give alms,  Pray so; and, for the ordering your affairs,  To sing them too:
t: Your singing is like charity for my poor soul, and makes me want to sing, too.

og: when you do dance, I wish you  A wave o' the sea, that you might ever do  Nothing but that; move still, still so,  And own no other function:
t: When you dance, I don't want you to stop, I want you to keep moving so gracefully forever.

og: each your doing,  So singular in each particular,  Crowns what you are doing in the present deed,  That all your acts are queens.
t: Everything you do—in exactly the way you do it—makes you even more perfect than you already are.

og: O Doricles,Your praises are too large: but that your youth,And the true blood which peepeth fairly through't,Do plainly give you out an unstain'd shepherd,With wisdom I might fear, my Doricles,You woo'd me the false way.
t: Oh, "Doricles," you exaggerate. If it weren't oh-so-obvious that you're nothing more than an innocent shepherd, I'm afraid I'd think you were just trying to get in my pants!

og: I think you haveAs little skill to fear as I have purposeTo put you to't. But come; our dance, I pray:Your hand, my Perdita: so turtles pair,That never mean to part.
t: You have nothing to be afraid of as far as that's concerned. Come on, let's dance. Give my your hand, Perdita, and never let go.

og: I'll swear for 'em.
t: I'll swear to that.

og: This is the prettiest low-born lass that everRan on the green-sward: nothing she does or seemsBut smacks of something greater than herself,Too noble for this place.
t: She's the prettiest peasant girl I've ever seen. Everything she does is graceful. She's too noble for this place.

og: He tells her somethingThat makes her blood look out: good sooth, she isThe queen of curds and cream.
t: He's telling her something that makes her blush. Just look how fair her skin is!

og: Come on, strike up!
t: Come on, start the music!

og: Mopsa must be your mistress: marry, garlic,To mend her kissing with!
t: Dance with Mopsa . . . though you might need some strong stuff to cover her bad breath!

og: Now, in good time!
t: Hey, cut that out!

og: Not a word, a word; we stand upon our manners.Come, strike up!
t: I won't say a word; I'll be perfectly polite. Come on, start the music!

og: Pray, good shepherd, what fair swain is thisWhich dances with your daughter?
t: Hey, shepherd: who's the young guy dancing with your daughter?

og: They call him Doricles; and boasts himself  To have a worthy feeding: but I have it  Upon his own report and I believe it;  He looks like sooth.
t: His name is Doricles. He says he owns a prosperous farm, and I believe it, considering how handsome and well-dressed he is.

og: He says he loves my daughter:  I think so too; for never gazed the moon  Upon the water as he'll stand and read  As 'twere my daughter's eyes:
t: He says he's in love with my daughter, and I think it's true. To be blunt, the way he stares at her completely gives it away!

og: and, to be plain.  I think there is not half a kiss to choose  Who loves another best.
t: You'd be hard pressed to say which one loves the other more.

og: She dances featly.
t: She's a great dancer.

og: So she does any thing; though I report it,That should be silent: if young DoriclesDo light upon her, she shall bring him thatWhich he not dreams of.
t: She's good at everything. And, just between you and me: if Doricles does marry her, she'll bring him more than he ever dreamed of.

og: O master, if you did but hear the pedlar at the  door, you would never dance again after a tabour and  pipe; no, the bagpipe could not move you:
t: Sir, there's a traveling salesman at the door who can play the drums and the flute better than anyone I've ever seen.

og: he sings  several tunes faster than you'll tell money; he  utters them as he had eaten ballads and all men's  ears grew to his tunes.
t: He knows all sorts of songs—he can sing any ballad you can think of.

og: He could never come better; he shall come in. Ilove a ballad but even too well, if it be dolefulmatter merrily set down, or a very pleasant thingindeed and sung lamentably.
t: Perfect timing, let him in! I love ballads more than I should: happy ones, sad ones, and even happy ones sung sadly.

og: He hath songs for man or woman, of all sizes; no  milliner can so fit his customers with gloves:
t: He has songs for men and women of all shapes and sizes. He can fit a song to a crowd better than a tailor can fit a suit to your body.

og: he  has the prettiest love-songs for maids; so without  bawdry, which is strange; with such delicate  burthens of dildos and fadings, 'jump her and thump  her;' and where some stretch-mouthed rascal would,  as it were, mean mischief and break a foul gap into  the matter, he makes the maid to answer 'Whoop, do me  no harm, good man;' puts him off, slights him, with  'Whoop, do me no harm, good man.'
t: He has love songs for the ladies (and they're not dirty, none of that funny business your average street musician puts into his songs).

og: This is a brave fellow.
t: This guy has some serious guts.

og: Believe me, thou talkest of an admirable conceitedfellow. Has he any unbraided wares?
t: Believe me, you've already sold us on this guy. Is he selling anything else?

og: He hath ribbons of an the colours i' the rainbow;  points more than all the lawyers in Bohemia can  learnedly handle,  though they come to him by the  gross: inkles, caddisses, cambrics, lawns:
t: He has ribbons of every color in the rainbow, more pens than anyone could ever use in a lifetime, ink, and all kinds of fabrics

og: why, he  sings 'em over as they were gods or goddesses; you  would think a smock were a she-angel, he so chants  to the sleeve-hand and the work about the square on't.
t: (and he absolutely raves about the workmanship of the weavers).

og: Prithee bring him in; and let him approach singing.
t: Please bring him in, and have him sing on the way.

og: Forewarn him that he use no scurrilous words in's tunes.
t: And please ask him not to use any inappropriate language in his songs.

og: You have of these pedlars, that have more in themthan you'ld think, sister.
t: These traveling salesmen sometimes have more to them than you might think, sis.

og: Ay, good brother, or go about to think.
t: Yes, brother, more than I want to think about.

og: Lawn as white as driven snow;  Cyprus black as e'er was crow;
t: Linen as white as snow,Cotton black as a crow,

og: Gloves as sweet as damask roses;  Masks for faces and for noses;
t: Sweet-smelling gloves,Masks for your face,

og: Bugle bracelet, necklace amber,  Perfume for a lady's chamber;
t: Beaded bracelets, gemstone necklaces,Perfume for ladies' bedrooms,

og: Golden quoifs and stomachers,  For my lads to give their dears:
t: Golden hairpieces and beltsFor young men to give their girlfriends,

og: Pins and poking-sticks of steel,  What maids lack from head to heel:
t: Steel pins and clipsFor ladies that need them:

og: Come buy of me, come; come buy, come buy;  Buy lads, or else your lasses cry: Come buy.
t: Come buy from me; come buy, come buy,Boys, buy up, or your girlfriends will be sad. Come buy!

og: If I were not in love with Mopsa, thou shouldst takeno money of me; but being enthralled as I am, itwill also be the bondage of certain ribbons and gloves.
t: If I weren't in love with Mopsa, I wouldn't spend any money, but since I am in love, I'll have to buy some ribbons and gloves.

og: I was promised them against the feast; but they comenot too late now.
t: You promised to get them for me before the feast, but they're just as good now.

og: He hath promised you more than that, or there be liars.
t: Unless people are lying, he's promised you more than that.

og: He hath paid you all he promised you; may be, he haspaid you more, which will shame you to give him again.
t: He's paid you all he owed you. He probably paid you too much, and you'll have to give something back.

og: Is there no manners left among maids? will they  wear their plackets where they should bear their  faces?
t: Do you ladies have no manners? Is this how you treat each other?

og: Is there not milking-time, when you are  going to bed, or kiln-hole, to whistle off these  secrets, but you must be tittle-tattling before all  our guests?
t: Isn't there some other place where you could call each other names, instead of doing it here in front of all our guests?

og: 'tis well they are whispering: clamour  your tongues, and not a word more.
t: Now everyone's whispering about you. Please shut up; don't say anything else.

og: I have done. Come, you promised me a tawdry-laceand a pair of sweet gloves.
t: I'm through. Come on, you promised me some lace and a pair of pretty gloves.

og: Have I not told thee how I was cozened by the wayand lost all my money?
t: Didn't I tell you how I was tricked and lost all my money?

og: And indeed, sir, there are cozeners abroad;therefore it behoves men to be wary.
t: Sir, it's true that there are tricksters out there, so it's always smart to be aware.

og: Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.
t: Don't worry; you're in no danger here.

og: I hope so, sir; for I have about me many parcels of charge.
t: I hope not, considering how much merchandise I have with me.

og: What hast here? ballads?
t: What do you have here? Ballads?

og: Pray now, buy some: I love a ballad in print o'life, for then we are sure they are true.
t: Aw, please buy some! I love a printed ballad, since if they're printed they must be true.

og: Here's one to a very doleful tune, how a usurer'swife was brought to bed of twenty money-bags at aburthen and how she longed to eat adders' heads andtoads carbonadoed.
t: Here's one (set to a very sad tune) about how a banker's wife gave birth to twenty money bags and how, during the pregnancy, she had cravings for snakes' heads and grilled frogs.

og: Is it true, think you?
t: Do you think it's true?

og: Very true, and but a month old.
t: Very true, and only a month old.

og: Bless me from marrying a usurer!
t: I'll never marry a banker!

og: Here's the midwife's name to't, one MistressTale-porter, and five or six honest wives that werepresent. Why should I carry lies abroad?
t: Look: the midwife, Mrs. Rumor, signed her name to prove it, along with five or six eyewitnesses. Why would I sell lies?

og: Pray you now, buy it.
t: Please buy it.

og: Come on, lay it by: and let's first see moeballads; we'll buy the other things anon.
t: All right, set it aside, but let's look through more ballads first. We'll buy the other things later.

og: Here's another ballad of a fish, that appeared upon  the coast on Wednesday the four-score of April,  forty thousand fathom above water,
t: Here's another ballad about a fish that washed up on the coast on Wednesday, April twenty-fourth, miles away from the water,

og: and sung this  ballad against the hard hearts of maids:
t: and sung this ballad to warn cold-hearted girls.

og: it was  thought she was a woman and was turned into a cold  fish for she would not exchange flesh with one that  loved her:
t: People thought she was a woman who'd been turned into a fish for not having sex with her boyfriend.

og: the ballad is very pitiful and as true.
t: The ballad is both sad and true.

og: Is it true too, think you?
t: Is it really true?

og: Five justices' hands at it, and witnesses more thanmy pack will hold.
t: Five judges verified it, and there were countless witnesses.

og: Lay it by too: another.
t: Put that one aside. Another.

og: This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.
t: This is a funny ballad, but it's pretty, too.

og: Let's have some merry ones.
t: Let's have some funny ones!

og: Why, this is a passing merry one and goes tothe tune of 'Two maids wooing a man:' there'sscarce a maid westward but she sings it; 'tis inrequest, I can tell you.
t: This is a really funny one that's set to the tune of "Two girls flirting with the same guy." Girls all over the country are singing it; it's in vogue, I'm happy to say.

og: We can both sing it: if thou'lt bear a part, thoushalt hear; 'tis in three parts.
t: If you'll take a part, we can do it, since it has three parts.

og: We had the tune on't a month ago.
t: We learned the tune of it a month ago.

og: I can bear my part; you must know 'tis myoccupation; have at it with you.
t: I can sing my part; it's my job, of course. Let's sing.

og: Get you hence, for I must goWhere it fits not you to know.
t: Get out of here; I have to goSomewhere you can't follow.

og: Whither?
t: Where?

og: O, whither?
t: Oh, where?

og: Whither?
t: Where?

og: It becomes thy oath full well,Thou to me thy secrets tell.
t: Since you promised to be my boyfriend,You shouldn't have any secrets from me.

og: Me too, let me go thither.
t: Me too; let's go there together.

og: Or thou goest to the orange or mill.
t: Are you going to the forest, or the town?

og: If to either, thou dost ill.
t: Whichever it is, it's a mistake.

og: Neither.
t: Neither.

og: What, neither?
t: What do you mean, "neither?"

og: Neither.
t: Neither.

og: Thou hast sworn my love to be.
t: You said you'd be my boyfriend.

og: Thou hast sworn it more to me:Then whither goest? say, whither?
t: No, you said you'd be my boyfriend!So where are you going? Tell me, where?

og: We'll have this song out anon by ourselves:
t: Well, we can finish this song by ourselves later on.

og: my  father and the gentlemen are in sad talk, and we'll  not trouble them.
t: My father and the gentlemen are having a serious discussion and we won't bother them.

og: Come, bring away thy pack after  me. Wenches, I'll buy for you both. Pedlar, let's  have the first choice. Follow me, girls.
t: Come on, bring your merchandise and follow me. Ladies, I'll buy something for both of you. Give them their first choice. Follow me, girls.

og: Will you buy any tape,  Or lace for your cape,
t: Do you want to buy any ribbonsOr lace to decorate your coat,

og: My dainty duck, my dear-a?  Any silk, any thread,
t: My beautiful girl, my dear?Any silk, any thread,

og: Any toys for your head,  Of the new'st and finest, finest wear-a?
t: Any hats or bows for your hairOf the newest and best there is?

og: Come to the pedlar;  Money's a medler.  That doth utter all men's ware-a.
t: Come to the traveling salesman.Money makes the world go 'roundAnd it's with money that men buy everything.

og: Master, there is three carters, three shepherds,  three neat-herds, three swine-herds, that have made  themselves all men of hair,
t: Sir, there are three wagon-makers, three shepherds, three cowboys, and three pig-herders outside dressed up as satyrs.

og: they call themselves  Saltiers, and they have a dance which the wenches  say is a gallimaufry of gambols, because they are  not in't;
t: They call themselves "The Wits" and say they have a dance to perform, but the girls are saying its a load of garbage.

og: but they themselves are o' the mind, if it  be not too rough for some that know little but  bowling, it will please plentifully.
t: But the men say that, if people aren't easily offended, they'll enjoy the performance.

og: Away! we'll none on 't: here has been too muchhomely foolery already. I know, sir, we weary you.
t: Tell them to go away! We won't have it. There's been enough shenanigans here already. Sir, I know you're getting tired of us.

og: You weary those that refresh us: pray, let's seethese four threes of herdsmen.
t: No, this is the kind of thing we like! Come on, let in this group of men.

og: One three of them, by their own report, sir, hathdanced before the king; and not the worst of thethree but jumps twelve foot and a half by the squier.
t: Three of them claim to have danced for the king, but they're all liars.

og: Leave your prating: since these good men arepleased, let them come in; but quickly now.
t: Oh, cut it out. If these men are all right with it, we'll let them in. Go quickly!

og: Why, they stay at door, sir.
t: They're waiting at the door, sir.

og: How now, fair shepherd!  Your heart is full of something that does take  Your mind from feasting.
t: Hello there, handsome shepherd! You're distracted by love and not too focused on this party, huh?

og: Sooth, when I was young  And handed love as you do, I was wont  To load my she with knacks:
t: I'll tell you, when I was your age, I was a sucker for buying gifts for my girlfriend.

og: I would have ransack'd  The pedlar's silken treasury and have pour'd it  To her acceptance; you have let him go  And nothing marted with him.
t: I would have bought every piece of silk from the traveling salesman if it would have won her over, but you've let him go without buying a single thing.

og: If your lass  Interpretation should abuse and call this  Your lack of love or bounty, you were straited  For a reply, at least if you make a care  Of happy holding her.
t: If your girlfriend interpreted this as a lack of love on your part, you'd be hard-pressed to convince her that you really care.

og: Old sir, I know  She prizes not such trifles as these are:
t: Sir, she doesn't care about stuff like that.

og: The gifts she looks from me are pack'd and lock'd  Up in my heart; which I have given already,  But not deliver'd.
t: The gifts she expects from me are the ones that come from the heart,  and I've given those to her already, though I haven't delivered them.

og: O, hear me breathe my life  Before this ancient sir, who, it should seem,  Hath sometime loved!
t: You must have had some experience with love, sir, at your age . . . let me explain how much I love her.

og: I take thy hand, this hand,  As soft as dove's down and as white as it,  Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd  snow that's bolted  By the northern blasts twice o'er.
t: Watch me take her hand—her soft, pure white hand.

og: What follows this?How prettily the young swain seems to washThe hand was fair before! I have put you out:But to your protestation; let me hearWhat you profess.
t: What comes next? This young shepherd speaks beautifully about a beautiful woman. I'd written you off but, since you ask, I'll listen.

og: Do, and be witness to 't.
t: Listen, and be a witness.

og: And this my neighbour too?
t: And my friend, too?

og: And he, and more  Than he, and men, the earth, the heavens, and all:
t: Sure—him, everyone, the earth, and the heavens.

og: That, were I crown'd the most imperial monarch,  Thereof most worthy, were I the fairest youth  That ever made eye swerve, had force and knowledge  More than was ever man's, I would not prize them  Without her love;
t: Even if I were king of the whole world, the most handsome man alive, and wiser than anyone in history, it wouldn't matter without her love.

og: for her employ them all;  Commend them and condemn them to her service  Or to their own perdition.
t: Everything I do, I do for her. I put my gifts and my faults into her hands, for better or worse.

og: Fairly offer'd.
t: Fair enough.

og: This shows a sound affection.
t: It sounds like you really love her.

og: But, my daughter,Say you the like to him?
t: Perdita, do you feel the same way about him?

og: I cannot speakSo well, nothing so well; no, nor mean better:By the pattern of mine own thoughts I cut outThe purity of his.
t: I can't speak as well as he does; not at all, and my words' meaning couldn't be better than his. But our thoughts are one and the same.

og: Take hands, a bargain!And, friends unknown, you shall bear witness to 't:I give my daughter to him, and will makeHer portion equal his.
t: Take each other's hands; let's make a wedding contract!  Our new friends will be our witnesses. I give my daughter to him in marriage, and will give them equal parts of my fortune.

og: O, that must be  I' the virtue of your daughter:
t: The only fortune I need is your beautiful daughter;

og: one being dead,  I shall have more than you can dream of yet;
t: when my father dies, I will have more money than you've ever dreamed of.

og: Enough then for your wonder. But, come on,  Contract us 'fore these witnesses.
t: But, come on, let's swear to our contract before these witnesses.

og: Come, your hand;And, daughter, yours.
t: Give me your hand. And, Perdita, give me yours.

og: Soft, swain, awhile, beseech you;Have you a father?
t: Just a minute, shepherd. Do you have a father?

og: I have: but what of him?
t: I do. What about him?

og: Knows he of this?
t: Does he know about this?

og: He neither does nor shall.
t: He doesn't and he never will.

og: Methinks a father  Is at the nuptial of his son a guest  That best becomes the table.
t: I think fathers are usually important guests at their sons' weddings.

og: Pray you once more,  Is not your father grown incapable  Of reasonable affairs? is he not stupid  With age and altering rheums?
t: Another question: has your father gone senile? Is he ancient and in poor health?

og: can he speak? hear?  Know man from man? dispute his own estate?
t: Can he speak? Hear? Recognize people? Take care of his property?

og: Lies he not bed-rid? and again does nothing  But what he did being childish?
t: Is he bedridden? Is he basically like a child again?

og: No, good sir;He has his health and ampler strength indeedThan most have of his age.
t: No, sir. He's healthy and stronger than most men at his age.

og: By my white beard,  You offer him, if this be so, a wrong  Something unfilial:
t: Well, then, you're a terrible son for not inviting him to your wedding.

og: reason my son  Should choose himself a wife, but as good reason  The father, all whose joy is nothing else  But fair posterity, should hold some counsel  In such a business.
t: If my son were choosing a wife, I'd have a say in it, considering the future of my family is at stake.

og: I yield all this;But for some other reasons, my grave sir,Which 'tis not fit you know, I not acquaintMy father of this business.
t: That's all true. But for some other reasons, sir, which you don't know, I can't tell my father about this.

og: Let him know't.
t: Tell him.

og: He shall not.
t: I can't.

og: Prithee, let him.
t: Please, let him know.

og: No, he must not.
t: No, he can't know.

og: Let him, my son: he shall not need to grieveAt knowing of thy choice.
t: Let him know, son. There's no reason he would disapprove your choice.

og: Come, come, he must not.Mark our contract.
t: I'm serious; he can't know. Let's sign the contract.

og: Mark your divorce, young sir,
t: Sign your divorce, sir—

og: Whom son I dare not call; thou art too base  To be acknowledged: thou a sceptre's heir,
t: I can hardly call you my son now; I wouldn't stoop down to your level.

og: That thus affect'st a sheep-hook!
t: Look at you, a prince, dressed up with a shepherd's staff!

og: Thou old traitor,  I am sorry that by hanging thee I can  But shorten thy life one week.
t: You old traitor, it's too bad that by hanging you I won't be shortening your life that much.

og: And thou, fresh piece  Of excellent witchcraft, who of force must know  The royal fool thou copest with,—
t: And you, you witch, as if you don't know that you're meddling with a prince.

og: O, my heart!
t: Oh, my heart!

og: I'll have thy beauty scratch'd with briers, and made  More homely than thy state.
t: I'll have your beautiful face scratched with thorns until you're uglier than your ugly poverty.

og: For thee, fond boy,  If I may ever know thou dost but sigh  That thou no more shalt see this knack, as never  I mean thou shalt, we'll bar thee from succession;  Not hold thee of our blood, no, not our kin,  Far than Deucalion off: mark thou my words:  Follow us to the court.
t: And you, lover boy, if you so much as sigh over not seeing this slut again, you'll never inherit the throne and, what's more, I'll disown you as my son. You'll be out of the family forever, mark my words. Follow me back to court.

og: Thou churl, for this time,  Though full of our displeasure, yet we free thee  From the dead blow of it.
t: This time you're off the hook, though I am not at all pleased.

og: And you, enchantment.—  Worthy enough a herdsman: yea, him too,  That makes himself, but for our honour therein,  Unworthy thee,—
t: And you, you witch! Your tricks might be good enough for a shepherd, but not for my son.

og: if ever henceforth thou  These rural latches to his entrance open,  Or hoop his body more with thy embraces,  I will devise a death as cruel for thee  As thou art tender to't.
t: If you ever let him through your gates again, or lay a hand on him, I'll think up the cruelest, most painful possible death for you.

og: Even here undone!  I was not much afeard; for once or twice  I was about to speak and tell him plainly,  The selfsame sun that shines upon his court  Hides not his visage from our cottage but  Looks on alike.
t: Ruined, at the last minute! I wasn't afraid, though. I was about to tell him that the same sun that shines in court shines here at our cottage, looking down on us equally.

og: Will't please you, sir, be gone?  I told you what would come of this: beseech you,  Of your own state take care: this dream of mine,—  Being now awake, I'll queen it no inch farther,  But milk my ewes and weep.
t: Will you go, then? I told you what would come of this. Please, remember that you are a prince. It was all a dream. Now I'm awake, and I won't imagine I'm a queen anymore. I'll just go back to my sheep and cry.

og: Why, how now, father!Speak ere thou diest.
t: What do you say for yourself, shepherd? Speak or you die.

og: I cannot speak, nor think  Nor dare to know that which I know.
t: I can't speak; I can't think or wrap my head around what I know now.

og: O sir!  You have undone a man of fourscore three,  That thought to fill his grave in quiet, yea,  To die upon the bed my father died,  To lie close by his honest bones:
t: Sir, you've ruined an eighty-three-year-old man who only wanted to die in peace on the same bed where his father passed away, and to be buried near him.

og: but now  Some hangman must put on my shroud and lay me  Where no priest shovels in dust.
t: Now some executioner will bury me, alone.

og: O cursed wretch,  That knew'st this was the prince,  and wouldst adventure  To mingle faith with him!
t: How dare you continue to play around with him, knowing he was the prince?

og: Undone! undone!  If I might die within this hour, I have lived  To die when I desire.
t: Ruined! Ruined! If I die within the hour, I'll be glad to be out of my misery.

og: Why look you so upon me?  I am but sorry, not afeard; delay'd,  But nothing alter'd:
t: Why are you looking at me like that? I'm sorry this happened, but I'm not afraid. This delays me, but doesn't change me.

og: what I was, I am;
t: I am who I was before.

og: More straining on for plucking back, not following  My leash unwillingly.
t: This setback makes me want to marry Perdita even more.

og: Gracious my lord,  You know your father's temper:
t: Sir, you know your father has a temper.

og: at this time  He will allow no speech, which I do guess  You do not purpose to him; and as hardly  Will he endure your sight as yet, I fear:
t: He doesn't want to hear from you right now, so I don't suggest you try it. He probably doesn't want to see you, either.

og: Then, till the fury of his highness settle,  Come not before him.
t: Stay away from him until his anger dies down.

og: I not purpose it.I think, Camillo?
t: I won't try it, then. You're Camillo, right?

og: Even he, my lord.
t: That's me, sir.

og: How often have I told you 'twould be thus!How often said, my dignity would lastBut till 'twere known!
t: I've told you so many times that this would happen! I've been saying that I'd be ruined as soon as we were found out!

og: It cannot fail but by  The violation of my faith; and then  Let nature crush the sides o' the earth together  And mar the seeds within!
t: You could only be ruined if I left you, but that will never happen!

og: Lift up thy looks:  From my succession wipe me, father; I  Am heir to my affection.
t: Chin up! My father can disown me; I have my love to sustain me.

og: Be advised.
t: You should think this through . . .

og: I am, and by my fancy: if my reasonWill thereto be obedient, I have reason;If not, my senses, better pleased with madness,Do bid it welcome.
t: I have, and I know what I'm doing—following my heart. Call me crazy; if I'm crazy, I embrace it.

og: This is desperate, sir.
t: This is irresponsible, sir.

og: So call it: but it does fulfil my vow;  I needs must think it honesty.
t: Maybe so, but it's keeping my promise and therefore it's the right thing to do.

og: Camillo,  Not for Bohemia, nor the pomp that may  Be thereat glean'd, for all the sun sees or  The close earth wombs or the profound sea hides  In unknown fathoms, will I break my oath  To this my fair beloved:
t: Camillo, I wouldn't break my vow to Perdita, not for the whole country, the sun, the earth, and the sea.

og: therefore, I pray you,  As you have ever been my father's honour'd friend,
t: So, as my father's friend,

og: cast your good counsels  Upon his passion;
t: please put in a good word for me

og: When he shall miss me,—as, in faith, I mean not  To see him any more,—
t: when he realizes he misses me (since, by the way, I won't be seeing him anymore).

og: let myself and fortune  Tug for the time to come.
t: Maybe I'll come back onto his good side in the future.

og: This you may know  And so deliver, I am put to sea  With her whom here I cannot hold on shore;  And most opportune to our need I have  A vessel rides fast by, but not prepared  For this design.
t: You can let him know that Perdita and I are sailing away on a ship I have nearby (which is lucky, though I had it ready for something else).

og: What course I mean to hold  Shall nothing benefit your knowledge, nor  Concern me the reporting.
t: I won't tell you where we're going, though.

og: O my lord!I would your spirit were easier for advice,Or stronger for your need.
t: Oh, sir, I wish you would listen to my advice; you might need it.

og: Hark, Perdita    I'll hear you by and by.
t: Perdita, come here.   I'll listen to you in a minute.

og: He's irremoveable,  Resolved for flight.
t: I can't change his mind; he's decided to leave.

og: Now were I happy, if  His going I could frame to serve my turn,  Save him from danger, do him love and honour,
t: I could make this work to my advantage and keep him safe, all the while being loyal to him and to Polixenes.

og: Purchase the sight again of dear Sicilia  And that unhappy king, my master, whom  I so much thirst to see.
t: This could be my chance to see Leontes again, who I've wanted to see so much.

og: Now, good Camillo;I am so fraught with curious business thatI leave out ceremony.
t: Now, Camillo: I've been so caught up with all this that I've been rude.

og: Sir, I thinkYou have heard of my poor services, i' the loveThat I have borne your father?
t: Sir, I think you're familiar with my reputation for service through the work I've done for your father.

og: Very noblyHave you deserved: it is my father's musicTo speak your deeds, not little of his careTo have them recompensed as thought on.
t: Of course; he speaks very highly of you, and is always rewarding you for a job well done.

og: Well, my lord,  If you may please to think I love the king  And through him what is nearest to him, which is  Your gracious self, embrace but my direction:
t: Well, sir, since you know I've served your father well, it follows that I would serve just as well the person he loves the most (that is, you). Hear me out:

og: If your more ponderous and settled project  May suffer alteration, on mine honour,  I'll point you where you shall have such receiving  As shall become your highness;
t: if you encounter any difficulties on your journey, I can tell you where to go,

og: where you may  Enjoy your mistress, from the whom, I see,  There's no disjunction to be made, but by—  As heavens forefend!—your ruin; marry her,
t: where to take Perdita (since it's clear you don't want to be separated from her, unless some sort of catastrophe got in your way), and where to marry her.

og: And, with my best endeavours in your absence,  Your discontenting father strive to qualify  And bring him up to liking.
t: And, while you're gone, I can try to win your father over for you.

og: How, Camillo,May this, almost a miracle, be done?That I may call thee something more than manAnd after that trust to thee.
t: Camillo, that would basically be a miracle, but how can we do it? You would be a superhero and I'd never doubt you again.

og: Have you thought onA place whereto you'll go?
t: Have you thought about where you'll go?

og: Not any yet:But as the unthought-on accident is guiltyTo what we wildly do, so we professOurselves to be the slaves of chance and fliesOf every wind that blows.
t: Nowhere yet, but since this was all unplanned, we're flying by the seat of our pants here.

og: Then list to me:  This follows, if you will not change your purpose  But undergo this flight, make for Sicilia,
t: Then, listen to me: If you're determined to leave the country, go to Sicily,

og: And there present yourself and your fair princess,  For so I see she must be, 'fore Leontes:  She shall be habited as it becomes  The partner of your bed.
t: introduce yourself, and call your bride a princess. If she's going to visit Leontes's court, it's only fitting that she be dressed as your royal wife should.

og: Methinks I see  Leontes opening his free arms and weeping  His welcomes forth; asks thee the son forgiveness,  As 'twere i' the father's person;
t: I can imagine Leontes greeting you with a hug, crying as he asks your forgiveness as if you were your own father.

og: kisses the hands  Of your fresh princess; o'er and o'er divides him  'Twixt his unkindness and his kindness; the one  He chides to hell and bids the other grow  Faster than thought or time.
t: He'll kiss your princess's hands. His kindness will be a complete departure from the cruelty you've heard about in the past. He's over that now; he's kicked his evil ways to hell and has been nurturing his better qualities all these years.

og: Worthy Camillo,What colour for my visitation shall IHold up before him?
t: But Camillo, what reason for visiting can I make up?

og: Sent by the king your father  To greet him and to give him comforts.
t: Say your father sent you to greet him and to bring him gifts.

og: Sir,  The manner of your bearing towards him, with  What you as from your father shall deliver,  Things known betwixt us three, I'll write you down:
t: I'll write down some instructions for how to behave toward him and will pack all the gifts you'll deliver on your father's behalf.

og: The which shall point you forth at every sitting  What you must say; that he shall not perceive  But that you have your father's bosom there  And speak his very heart.
t: All of it will support your story: that you've come to make peace between him and your father.

og: I am bound to you:There is some sap in this.
t: I'll do exactly as you say. This makes a lot of sense.

og: A cause more promising  Than a wild dedication of yourselves  To unpath'd waters, undream'd shores, most certain  To miseries enough; no hope to help you,  But as you shake off one to take another;  Nothing so certain as your anchors, who  Do their best office, if they can but stay you  Where you'll be loath to be:
t: It's a better reason, at least, than your completely haphazard journey overseas with no plan, no trajectory, and no help, with no company but each other. Take care of each other.

og: besides you know  Prosperity's the very bond of love,  Whose fresh complexion and whose heart together  Affliction alters.
