t: A heart full of love can make even the worst places bearable, and can bring a smile to your face even in the midst of suffering.

og: One of these is true:I think affliction may subdue the cheek,But not take in the mind.
t: Part of what you say is true: I think suffering may wipe the smile from your face, but it can never change the state of your mind.

og: Yea, say you so?There shall not at your father's house theseseven yearsBe born another such.
t: Oh, you think so? You're one-in-a-million, shepherd girl.

og: My good Camillo,She is as forward of her breeding asShe is i' the rear our birth.
t: Camillo, she's so far beyond her lower-class origins; she's basically as noble as you and I.

og: I cannot say 'tis pityShe lacks instructions, for she seems a mistressTo most that teach.
t: I would say "it's too bad she hasn't had an education," but she seems more capable than most teachers I know.

og: Your pardon, sir; for thisI'll blush you thanks.
t: I beg your pardon, sir. I'm embarrassed, but thank you.

og: My prettiest Perdita!  But O, the thorns we stand upon!
t: My beautiful Perdita! But we're in a sticky situation.

og: Camillo,  Preserver of my father, now of me,  The medicine of our house, how shall we do?
t: Camillo, you've rescued my father and now me; you're a life-saver. What should we do?

og: We are not furnish'd like Bohemia's son,  Nor shall appear in Sicilia.
t: I don't have the clothes and facilities I normally travel with as the prince of Bohemia, and I won't be able to get those things in Sicily.

og: My lord,  Fear none of this: I think you know my fortunes  Do all lie there:
t: Sir, don't worry. As you know, I have a lot of connections there.

og: it shall be so my care  To have you royally appointed as if  The scene you play were mine.
t: I can make sure you're provided for, as surely as if I were there myself.

og: For instance, sir,  That you may know you shall not want, one word.
t: For example, sir—if I can ease your mind, talk with me for a moment.

og: Ha, ha! what a fool Honesty is! and Trust, his  sworn brother, a very simple gentleman!
t: Ha, ha! Honest men are idiots, and people who trust me are just plain stupid.

og: I have sold  all my trumpery; not a counterfeit stone, not a  ribbon, glass, pomander, brooch, table-book, ballad,  knife, tape, glove, shoe-tie, bracelet, horn-ring,  to keep my pack from fasting:
t: I've sold all my junk. I don't have a single fake gem, ribbon, mirror, perfume, jewelry, book, ballad, knife, belt, glove, shoelace, bracelet, or ring left in my bag.

og: they throng who  should buy first, as if my trinkets had been  hallowed and brought a benediction to the buyer:  by which means I saw whose purse was best in  picture; and what I saw, to my good use I  remembered.
t: They all swarmed to be the first to buy, as if my stuff were some kind of holy charm. I took note of where they kept their wallets and remembered that for later.

og: My clown, who wants but something to  be a reasonable man, grew so in love with the  wenches' song, that he would not stir his pettitoes  till he had both tune and words;
t: The shepherd's son (he's not all that bright, by the way) was so impressed with the girls' song that he wouldn't budge until he learned the tune and the words.

og: which so drew the  rest of the herd to me that all their other senses  stuck in ears: you might have pinched a placket, it  was senseless;
t: That was the best advertisement, since it sent all the others running to me to get the song for themselves. There was nothing you could do; everyone was singing this god-awful song, non-stop.

og: 'twas nothing to geld a codpiece of a  purse; I could have filed keys off that hung in  chains: no hearing, no feeling, but my sir's song,  and admiring the nothing of it. So that in this  time of lethargy I picked and cut most of their  festival purses;
t: While they were all lying around, I took the opportunity to pick their pockets and rifled through most of their purses.

og: and had not the old man come in  with a whoo-bub against his daughter and the king's  son and scared my choughs from the chaff, I had not  left a purse alive in the whole army.
t: If that old man hadn't come in and raised a ruckus about the shepherd's daughter and the prince, scaring everyone away, I wouldn't have left a single penny in anyone's wallet.

og: Nay, but my letters, by this means being thereSo soon as you arrive, shall clear that doubt.
t: No, my letters will get there before you arrive and will clear up any doubt.

og: And those that you'll procure from King Leontes—
t: And the letters you'll get from King Leontes—

og: Shall satisfy your father.
t: —will satisfy your father.

og: Happy be you!All that you speak shows fair.
t: Thank you! You're so generous.

og: Who have we here?    We'll make an instrument of this, omitNothing may give us aid.
t: We'll make use of this; we can't overlook anything that might help us.

og: If they have overheard me now, why, hanging.
t: If they just overheard me, I'm dead.

og: How now, good fellow! why shakest thou so? Fearnot, man; here's no harm intended to thee.
t: Hello, sir! Why are you shaking? Don't be afraid; no one's going to hurt you.

og: I am a poor fellow, sir.
t: I'm a poor man, sir.

og: Why, be so still; here's nobody will steal that from  thee:
t: Calm down, no one here is going to steal from you.

og: yet for the outside of thy poverty we must  make an exchange; therefore discase thee instantly,  —thou must think there's a necessity in't,—and  change garments with this gentleman:
t: However, we would like to trade you for your poor man's clothes, so get undressed (it's necessary, you see) and change clothes with this gentleman.

og: though the  pennyworth on his side be the worst, yet hold thee,  there's some boot.
t: Though Florizel's getting the worst end of the deal already, we'll give you some money, too.

og: I am a poor fellow, sir.    I know ye well enough.
t: I'm a poor fellow, sir. I know exactly who you are.

og: Nay, prithee, dispatch: the gentleman is halfflayed already.
t: Come on, now, get your clothes off. Florizel's half-stripped already.

og: Are you in earnest, sir?    I smell the trick on't.
t: Are you serious, sir? This must be a trick.

og: Dispatch, I prithee.
t: Get on with it, please.

og: Indeed, I have had earnest: but I cannot withconscience take it.
t: Ah, I can see you're serious, but I can't take your clothes in good conscience.

og: Unbuckle, unbuckle.
t: Unbuckle, unbuckle.

og: Fortunate mistress,—let my prophecy  Come home to ye!—
t: Perdita, I hope my plan works out for your sake!

og: you must retire yourself  Into some covert: take your sweetheart's hat  And pluck it o'er your brows, muffle your face,  Dismantle you, and, as you can,
t: You need to hide yourself for the time being. Take Florizel's hat and cover your face, change your clothes,

og: disliken  The truth of your own seeming; that you may—  For I do fear eyes over—to shipboard  Get undescried.
t: and disguise yourself as much as possible. I'm afraid you're being watched, and you need to get onboard the ship undetected.

og: I see the play so liesThat I must bear a part.
t: I guess I'll play the part I've been given.

og: No remedy.Have you done there?
t: There's nothing we can do about it.  Are you all dressed?

og: Should I now meet my father,He would not call me son.
t: My own father wouldn't recognize me now.

og: Nay, you shall have no hat.    Come, lady, come. Farewell, my friend.
t: No, you don't need a hat.  Goodbye, friend.

og: Adieu, sir.
t: Goodbye, sir.

og: O Perdita, what have we twain forgot!Pray you, a word.
t: Perdita, are we forgetting anything? Let's talk.

og: What I do next, shall be to tell the king  Of this escape and whither they are bound;
t: Next I'll tell the king they escaped and where they're headed.

og: Wherein my hope is I shall so prevail  To force him after: in whose company  I shall review Sicilia, for whose sight  I have a woman's longing.
t: I'm hoping he'll go after them and that I'll get to come along to see my beloved country, Sicily.

og: Fortune speed us!Thus we set on, Camillo, to the sea-side.
t: I pray we have a quick journey! Camillo, we're off to the seaside.

og: The swifter speed the better.
t: The quicker the better.

og: I understand the business, I hear it: to have an  open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is  necessary for a cut-purse; a good nose is requisite  also, to smell out work for the other senses.
t: I see what's going on here. As a pickpocket, it's necessary to have an open ear, quick eye, fast hand—and a good nose, too, so you can smell out the good places to steal.

og: I see  this is the time that the unjust man doth thrive.  What an exchange had this been without boot! What  a boot is here with this exchange!
t: This is a great time to be a criminal. He just traded me fancy clothes for my rags; I gained everything, and he gained nothing!

og: Sure the gods do  this year connive at us, and we may do any thing  extempore. The prince himself is about a piece of  iniquity, stealing away from his father with his  clog at his heels:
t: The gods have clearly given me permission to do whatever I want now. The prince himself is up to no good, running away from his father with his whore in tow.

og: if I thought it were a piece of  honesty to acquaint the king withal, I would not  do't: I hold it the more knavery to conceal it;  and therein am I constant to my profession.
t: Even if it were a good deed to tell the king, I wouldn't do it. I think it's more crafty to keep it a secret, and since I'm a crook, I'll do just that.

og: Aside, aside; here is more matter for a hot brain:every lane's end, every shop, church, session,hanging, yields a careful man work.
t: But wait, there's more work to be done. Every street, store, church, meeting, and funeral can turn into an opportunity if you're savvy.

og: See, see; what a man you are now!There is no other way but to tell the kingshe's a changeling and none of your flesh and blood.
t: Well, look where you are now! The only thing to do is to tell the king she's a changeling and not your biological daughter.

og: Nay, but hear me.
t: No, listen to me.

og: Nay, but hear me.
t: No, listen to me.

og: Go to, then.
t: Go on, then.

og: She being none of your flesh and blood, your flesh  and blood has not offended the king; and so your  flesh and blood is not to be punished by him.
t: Since she's not actually part of your family, your family hasn't offended the king, and your family can't be punished by him.

og: Show  those things you found about her, those secret  things, all but what she has with her:
t: Show him the things you found with her—all the things that you kept secret all these years (except for whatever she took with her).

og: this being  done, let the law go whistle: I warrant you.
t: Then, the law can have nothing to do with us, I promise you.

og: I will tell the king all, every word, yea, and his  son's pranks too;
t: I'll tell the king everything, every word. And I'll tell him about Florizel's tricks, too.

og: who, I may say, is no honest man,  neither to his father nor to me, to go about to make  me the king's brother-in-law.
t: He hasn't been very truthful to his father or to me, considering he was about to make me a king's brother-in-law.

og: Indeed, brother-in-law was the farthest off youcould have been to him and then your blood had beenthe dearer by I know how much an ounce.
t: If they had actually gotten married and you were his brother-in-law by now, he'd hate you even more, and the price on your head would be even higher.

og: Very wisely, puppies!
t: Very smart, boys!

og: Well, let us to the king: there is that in thisfardel will make him scratch his beard.
t: Well, let's go to the king. The stuff in this bag will give him something to think about.

og: I know not what impediment this complaintmay be to the flight of my master.
t: I'm not sure how this will get in the way of Florizel's departure.

og: Pray heartily he be at palace.
t: Let's hope he's at the palace.

og: How now, rustics! whither are you bound?
t: Hello, peasants! Where are you going?

og: To the palace, an it like your worship.
t: To the palace, if it please you, sir.

og: Your affairs there, what, with whom, the conditionof that fardel, the place of your dwelling, yournames, your ages, of what having, breeding, and anything that is fitting to be known, discover.
t: Tell me what business you have there, and with whom. Tell me what's in that bag, where you live, your names, your ages, how much money you have, who your parents are, and anything else that I should know.

og: We are but plain fellows, sir.
t: We're simple people, sir.

og: A lie; you are rough and hairy. Let me have nolying: it becomes none but tradesmen, and theyoften give us soldiers the lie: but we pay them forit with stamped coin, not stabbing steel; thereforethey do not give us the lie.
t: That's a lie! You're rough and hairy. Don't lie to me. Only business people lie. But, since we soldiers pay them with money instead of pulling out our swords, they don't expose us for lying.

og: Your worship had like to have given us one, if youhad not taken yourself with the manner.
t: It seemed like you were going to try to expose us for lying, but you've just revealed that you're the liar.

og: Are you a courtier, an't like you, sir?
t: Are you a courtier or not, sir?

og: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier. Seest  thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings?
t: Whether I like it or not, I'm a courtier. Can't you see my courtly clothes?

og: hath not my gait in it the measure of the court?  receives not thy nose court-odor from me?
t: Don't I walk like a courtier? Smell like one?

og: reflect I  not on thy baseness court-contempt?
t: Look down my nose at you like one?

og: Thinkest thou,  for that I insinuate, or toaze from thee thy  business, I am therefore no courtier?
t: Just because I'm asking you questions, you think I'm not a courtier?

og: I am courtier  cap-a-pe; and one that will either push on or pluck  back thy business there: whereupon I command thee to  open thy affair.
t: I'm a courtier from head to toe and I have the power to help you to court or to stop you right there. For that reason I command you to tell me everything.

og: My business, sir, is to the king.
t: I have some business with the king, sir.

og: What advocate hast thou to him?
t: And who is pleading your case to him?

og: I know not, an't like you.
t: I don't know, sir.

og: Advocate's the court-word for a pheasant: say youhave none.
t: "Advocate" is court-speak for "pheasant;" say you don't have one.

og: None, sir; I have no pheasant, cock nor hen.
t: None, sir. I have no pheasant, male or female.

og: How blessed are we that are not simple men!Yet nature might have made me as these are,Therefore I will not disdain.
t: Thank God I'm not an idiot! But, since there but for the grace of God go I, I won't look down on them.

og: This cannot be but a great courtier.
t: He must be a really important courtier.

og: His garments are rich, but he wearsthem not handsomely.
t: His clothes are fancy, but he's not wearing them elegantly.

og: He seems to be the more noble in being fantastical:a great man, I'll warrant; I know by the pickingon's teeth.
t: The fact that he's a little crazy makes him seem even more noble. I could spot it a mile away.

og: The fardel there? what's i' the fardel?Wherefore that box?
t: What about the bag? What's in the bag? And why the box?

og: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box,which none must know but the king; and which heshall know within this hour, if I may come to thespeech of him.
t: Sir, there are secrets in this bag and this box which are for the king alone. If I get the chance to speak to him, he'll know within the hour.

og: Age, thou hast lost thy labour.
t: Old man, you're out of luck.

og: Why, sir?
t: Why, sir?

og: The king is not at the palace; he is gone aboard anew ship to purge melancholy and air himself: for,if thou beest capable of things serious, thou mustknow the king is full of grief.
t: The king is not at the palace. He went aboard a new ship to escape his sadness. Understand? The king is grieving.

og: So 'tis said, sir; about his son, that should havemarried a shepherd's daughter.
t: I've heard, sir, that he's grieving his son who almost married a shepherd's daughter.

og: If that shepherd be not in hand-fast, let him fly:the curses he shall have, the tortures he shallfeel, will break the back of man, the heart of monster.
t: If that shepherd isn't in jail already, he better run for it. The punishment he faces will be enough to break any man.

og: Think you so, sir?
t: Do you think so, sir?

og: Not he alone shall suffer what wit can make heavy  and vengeance bitter; but those that are germane to  him, though removed fifty times, shall all come  under the hangman:
t: He'll suffer horribly, but so will his family and everyone within fifty degrees of relation to him. They'll all be hanged;

og: which though it be great pity,  yet it is necessary. An old sheep-whistling rogue a  ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into  grace!
t: it's a pity, but it's necessary. Can you believe some old shepherd was grooming his daughter to catch a prince?

og: Some say he shall be stoned; but that death  is too soft for him, say I draw our throne into a  sheep-cote! all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.
t: Some say he'll be stoned to death, but I say that's too lenient for someone who almost ruined our prince! No punishment is too harsh for him.

og: Has the old man e'er a son, sir, do you hear. an'tlike you, sir?
t: Have you heard anything about the old man having a son, sir? If it please you, sir?

og: He has a son, who shall be flayed alive; then  'nointed over with honey, set on the head of a  wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters  and a dram dead;
t: Oh, he has a son. He'll be skinned alive, drizzled in honey, thrown into a wasp's nest, and forced to stay there until he's nearly dead.

og: then recovered again with  aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; then, raw as  he is, and in the hottest day prognostication  proclaims, shall be be set against a brick-wall, the  sun looking with a southward eye upon him, where he  is to behold him with flies blown to death.
t: Then they'll wake him up with a shot of whisky and stand him, raw flesh and all, on top of a brick wall to be baked in the sun and eaten by flies.

og: But what  talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries  are to be smiled at, their offences being so  capital? Tell me, for you seem to be honest plain  men, what you have to the king:
t: But why are we talking about these backstabbing traitors? We should be thankful they're going to be put to death for their crimes! Since you seem to be humble peasants, tell me what you're bringing to the king.

og: being something  gently considered, I'll bring you where he is  aboard, tender your persons to his presence,  whisper him in your behalfs; and if it be in man  besides the king to effect your suits, here is man  shall do it.
t: If it's worth his attention, I'll bring you aboard his ship and introduce you to him with a kind recommendation. If there's anyone besides the king who can help you, it's me.

og: He seems to be of great authority:
t: He seems to have a lot of power.

og: close with him,  give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn  bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold: show  the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand,  and no more ado.
t: Let's make friends with him and give him a little money. You can control even power with money; give him a few coins and see how easy everything becomes.

og: Remember 'stoned,' and 'flayed alive.'
t: Remember he said we're condemned to be "stoned to death" and "skinned alive!"

og: An't please you, sir, to undertake the business forus, here is that gold I have: I'll make it as muchmore and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.
t: If it please you to help us, sir, please take this money. I can give more afterward—as much as you like—and you can keep this young man as collateral until I do.

og: After I have done what I promised?
t: After I have done what I promised?

og: Ay, sir.
t: Yes, sir.

og: Well, give me the moiety. Are you a party in this business?
t: Well, give me that part of it. Are you a part of this business?

og: In some sort, sir: but though my case be a pitifulone, I hope I shall not be flayed out of it.
t: Sort of, sir. Even though my share is small, I hope I won't be skinned out of it.

og: O, that's the case of the shepherd's son: hang him,he'll be made an example.
t: Oh, that's the punishment for the shepherd's son. Forget about him! They'll make an example out of him.

og: Comfort, good comfort!
t: Isn't that comforting?

og: We must to the king and show  our strange sights: he must know 'tis none of your  daughter nor my sister; we are gone else.
t: We need to see the king and show him our secret stuff. He needs to know that she's neither your daughter nor my sister, otherwise we're dead.

og: Sir, I  will give you as much as this old man does when the  business is performed, and remain, as he says, your  pawn till it be brought you.
t: Sir, I'll give you as much money as this old man did after the business is done. And you can hold on to me as collateral in the meantime.

og: I will trust you. Walk before toward the sea-side;go on the right hand: I will but look upon thehedge and follow you.
t: I trust you. Walk down to the sea; I'll follow you from behind.

og: We are blest in this man, as I may say, even blest.
t: We are blessed to have met this man. Very blessed.

og: Let's before as he bids us: he was provided to do us good.
t: Let's get going and do what he says. God sent him to help us.

og: If I had a mind to be honest, I see Fortune would  not suffer me: she drops booties in my mouth. I am  courted now with a double occasion, gold and a means  to do the prince my master good;
t: If I were a good man, maybe I'd make even more money than I do as a criminal. Now I have a two-for-one deal: money and a chance to do Florizel, my former master, some good.

og: which who knows how  that may turn back to my advancement? I will bring  these two moles, these blind ones, aboard him:
t: Who knows how I can work this to my advantage? I'll bring these two idiots aboard to Polixenes.

og: if he  think it fit to shore them again and that the  complaint they have to the king concerns him  nothing, let him call me rogue for being so far  officious; for I am proof against that title and  what shame else belongs to't.
t: If he kicks them back to shore and their reason for seeing him turns out to be bogus, the worst that can happen is that he calls me "crook" (which doesn't offend me, since I've earned that title!).

og: To him will I present  them: there may be matter in it.
t: I'll present them to Polixenes; it may turn out to be something after all.

og: Sir, you have done enough, and have perform'd  A saint-like sorrow:
t: Sir, you've done enough; you've grieved enough. You've redeemed every one of your sins.

og: no fault could you make,  Which you have not redeem'd; indeed, paid down  More penitence than done trespass:
t: You've done more penitence than you did wrong.

og: at the last,  Do as the heavens have done, forget your evil;  With them forgive yourself.
t: For the last time: do what God does. Forget what your evil actions and forgive yourself.

og: Whilst I remember  Her and her virtues, I cannot forget  My blemishes in them,
t: As long as I remember her, I can't forget my mistakes.

og: and so still think of  The wrong I did myself; which was so much,  That heirless it hath made my kingdom and  Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man  Bred his hopes out of.
t: I still think about how badly I messed up, leaving my kingdom without a prince and myself without a wife.

og: True, too true, my lord:If, one by one, you wedded all the world,Or from the all that are took something good,To make a perfect woman, she you kill'dWould be unparallel'd.
t: Too true, too true, sir. No woman alive compares to the woman you killed.

og: I think so. Kill'd!  She I kill'd! I did so: but thou strikest me  Sorely, to say I did; it is as bitter  Upon thy tongue as in my thought:
t: I think you're right. Killed? The woman I killed? It's true, but it hurts to hear you say that. It hurts to think that.

og: now, good now,  Say so but seldom.
t: Please, don't say it often.

og: Not at all, good lady:You might have spoken a thousand things that wouldHave done the time more benefit and gracedYour kindness better.
t: Ma'am, please stop. Anything you could possibly say would be better than that.

og: You are one of thoseWould have him wed again.
t: You're one of those men who want him to marry again.

og: If you would not so,  You pity not the state, nor the remembrance  Of his most sovereign name; consider little  What dangers, by his highness' fail of issue,  May drop upon his kingdom and devour  Incertain lookers on.
t: If you're against him marrying, you're not thinking realistically about our country or the fact that Leontes needs an heir to his royal name. Consider what will happen if he dies without an heir—the kingdom will descend into warfare.

og: What were more holy  Than to rejoice the former queen is well?  What holier than, for royalty's repair,  For present comfort and for future good,  To bless the bed of majesty again  With a sweet fellow to't?
t: We should thank God Hermione is in heaven now. Only good could come of a new queen: companionship for Leontes and the possibility of future princes and princesses.

og: There is none worthy,  Respecting her that's gone. Besides, the gods  Will have fulfill'd their secret purposes;  For has not the divine Apollo said,  Is't not the tenor of his oracle,  That King Leontes shall not have an heir  Till his lost child be found?
t: No one but Hermione herself deserves that role. Besides, the gods intended this: didn't Apollo's oracle say that King Leontes would not have an heir until his lost child was found?

og: which that it shall,  Is all as monstrous to our human reason  As my Antigonus to break his grave  And come again to me; who, on my life,  Did perish with the infant.
t: It's about as likely that baby will return as it is that Antigonus, my husband (who died with it) will come back to life.

og: 'Tis your counsel  My lord should to the heavens be contrary,  Oppose against their wills.
t: You're advising the king to go against the gods' will.

og: Care not for issue;  The crown will find an heir:
t: Don't worry about having children; you'll find someone to inherit the throne.

og: great Alexander  Left his to the worthiest; so his successor  Was like to be the best.
t: Alexander the Great didn't have children, so he left his to whoever was most worthy. That worked out fine for him.

og: Good Paulina,  Who hast the memory of Hermione,  I know, in honour,
t: Paulina, you keep Hermione's memory alive.

og: O, that ever I  Had squared me to thy counsel! then, even now,  I might have look'd upon my queen's full eyes,  Have taken treasure from her lips—
t: I wish I would have listened to you before! If I had, I might be looking into my queen's eyes at this very moment. I might be kissing her precious lips—

og: And left themMore rich for what they yielded.
t: Her lips were precious, and you should consider yourself lucky they ever kissed you.

og: Thou speak'st truth.  No more such wives; therefore, no wife:
t: You speak the truth. I won't marry again, since there's no one else like Hermione.

og: one worse,  And better used, would make her sainted spirit  Again possess her corpse, and on this stage,  Where we're offenders now, appear soul-vex'd,  And begin, 'Why to me?'
t: If I married someone less wonderful than Hermione, yet treated that second wife better than I treated my first, I can only imagine Hermione's ghost would possess her body and come back to haunt me, asking "Why are you doing this to me?"

og: Had she such power,She had just cause.
t: If she had that power, she'd be justified in doing so.

og: She had; and would incense meTo murder her I married.
t: She would, and she'd force me to murder my new wife.

og: I should so.
t: I should think so.

og: Were I the ghost that walk'd, I'ld bid you mark  Her eye,  a  nd tell me for what dull part in't  You chose her;
t: If I were Hermione's ghost, I'd make you look your new wife in the eye. I'd ask you to tell me why you chose her.

og: then I'ld shriek, that even your ears  Should rift to hear me; and the words that follow'd  Should be 'Remember mine.'
t: Then I'd shriek loud enough to burst your eardrums, and say, "Remember me."

og: Stars, stars,And all eyes else dead coals! Fear thou no wife;I'll have no wife, Paulina.
t: No eyes are as beautiful as hers were. Don't be afraid of me marrying a wife, Paulina; I won't marry a new wife.

og: Will you swearNever to marry but by my free leave?
t: Will you swear never to marry unless I give you permission?

og: Never, Paulina; so be blest my spirit!
t: Never, Paulina, God bless my soul!

og: Then, good my lords, bear witness to his oath.
t: Then, gentlemen, bear witness to his promise.

og: You tempt him over-much.
t: You're playing to his weakness.

og: Unless another,As like Hermione as is her picture,Affront his eye.
t: He won't marry again unless another woman, the spitting image of Hermione, crosses his eye.

og: Good madam,—
t: Ma'am—

og: I have done.
t: I'm done.

og: Yet, if my lord will marry,—if you will, sir,  No remedy, but you will,—give me the office  To choose you a queen:
t: Yet, if you do intend to marry, sir, and won't be stopped, give me the right to choose your new queen.

og: she shall not be so young  As was your former; but she shall be such  As, walk'd your first queen's ghost,  it should take joy  To see her in your arms.
t: She won't be as young as your first one, but she'll be someone that Hermione's ghost would be happy to see you with.

og: My true Paulina,We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.
t: Paulina, I won't marry until you tell me.

og: ThatShall be when your first queen's again in breath;Never till then.
t: That will be when your first queen breathes again, and not a moment sooner.

og: One that gives out himself Prince Florizel,Son of Polixenes, with his princess, sheThe fairest I have yet beheld, desires accessTo your high presence.
t: A man calling himself Prince Florizel, son of Polixenes, is here with a beautiful princess. He's asked to see you.

og: What with him? he comes notLike to his father's greatness: his approach,So out of circumstance and sudden, tells us'Tis not a visitation framed, but forcedBy need and accident. What train?
t: What is he doing here? He's not arriving with his father's usual style. This can't be planned—he must have been forced to visit suddenly by some accident. Who did he bring with him?

og: But few,And those but mean.
t: Very few people, and most of them are peasants.

og: His princess, say you, with him?
t: Did you say he has his princess with him?

og: Ay, the most peerless piece of earth, I think,That e'er the sun shone bright on.
t: Yes, the most beautiful woman I think I've ever seen.

og: O Hermione,  As every present time doth boast itself  Above a better gone, so must thy grave  Give way to what's seen now!
t: Oh, Hermione, every new woman makes men forget the old ones.

og: Sir, you yourself  Have said and writ so, but your writing now  Is colder than that theme, 'She had not been,  Nor was not to be equall'd;'—thus your verse  Flow'd with her beauty once: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd,  To say you have seen a better.
t: Sir, you yourself have said and written that "Hermione was not, and will not be matched." Considering how you used to rave about her beauty, you're doing her a disservice now to say you've seen someone more beautiful.

og: Pardon, madam:  The one I have almost forgot,—your pardon,—
t: I'm sorry, ma'am. I'd almost forgotten Hermione.

og: The other, when she has obtain'd your eye,  Will have your tongue too.
t: When you see this princess, though, you'll want to praise her, too.

og: This is a creature,  Would she begin a sect, might quench the zeal  Of all professors else, make proselytes  Of who she but bid follow.
t: She's like a goddess who converts everyone who sees her to the religion of worshipping her.

og: How! not women?
t: Really? Women, too?

og: Women will love her, that she is a womanMore worth than any man; men, that she isThe rarest of all women.
t: Women will love her for being more worth their love than men. Men will love her because she's the most special woman that ever was.

og: Go, Cleomenes;Yourself, assisted with your honour'd friends,Bring them to our embracement. Still, 'tis strange He thus should steal upon us.
t: Go, Cleomenes. You and some of these gentleman should welcome them on my behalf. Still, it's strange for Florizel to surprise us like this.

og: Had our prince,Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair'dWell with this lord: there was not full a monthBetween their births.
t: If Mamillius had lived to see this day, he'd be Florizel's age. They were born about a month apart.

og: Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'st  He dies to me again when talk'd of: sure,  When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches  Will bring me to consider that which may  Unfurnish me of reason. They are come.
t: Please, no more—stop. You know that hearing that is like seeing him die all over again. But your words will keep me in check when I see this young man. Here they come.

og: Your mother was most true to wedlock, prince;  For she did print your royal father off,  Conceiving you:
t: Florizel, your mother should be proud: you look exactly like your father did when he was your age.

og: were I but twenty-one,  Your father's image is so hit in you,  His very air, that I should call you brother,  As I did him, and speak of something wildly  By us perform'd before.
t: So much so that I'm tempted to call you "brother," like I used to call him, and to start chatting with you about some wild escapades the two of us got up to!

og: Most dearly welcome!  And your fair princess,—goddess!—O, alas!  I lost a couple, that 'twixt heaven and earth  Might thus have stood begetting wonder as  You, gracious couple, do: and then I lost—
t: You are very welcome here. And your beautiful princess—she's like a goddess! Oh, I lost two children some time ago that would have been as wonderful to behold as you two are now. I lost—

og: All mine own folly—the society,  Amity too, of your brave father, whom,  Though bearing misery, I desire my life  Once more to look on him.
t: due to my own stupidity—your father's friendship, too. I'd do anything to see him again, no matter how painful it might be.

og: By his command  Have I here touch'd Sicilia and from him  Give you all greetings that a king, at friend,  Can send his brother:
t: I'm here in Sicily by his command. He's asked me to greet you not just as a king, but as a friend and brother.

og: and, but infirmity  Which waits upon worn times hath something seized  His wish'd ability, he had himself  The lands and waters 'twixt your throne and his  Measured to look upon you;
t: Though he wanted to come, he was held back by some unavoidable issues at home.

og: whom he loves—  He bade me say so—more than all the sceptres  And those that bear them living.
t: He asked me to tell you that he loves you more than all the thrones and all the kings in the world.

og: O my brother,  Good gentleman! the wrongs I have done thee stir  Afresh within me, and these thy offices,  So rarely kind, are as interpreters  Of my behind-hand slackness.
t: Oh, my brother! I'm thinking through the wrong I did you all over again; your friendly message only makes me feel more guilty.

og: Welcome hither,  As is the spring to the earth.
t: You two are as welcome as spring is on earth.

og: And hath he too  Exposed this paragon to the fearful usage,  At least ungentle, of the dreadful Neptune,  To greet a man not worth her pains, much less  The adventure of her person?
t: And has Polixenes put this beautiful girl through a long, uncomfortable boat journey just to see me, who's hardly worth the trouble?

og: Good my lord,She came from Libya.
t: Sir, she's from Libya.

og: Where the warlike Smalus,That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?
t: Where King Smalus rules, feared and loved by all?

og: Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughter  His tears proclaim'd his, parting with her: thence,  A prosperous south-wind friendly, we have cross'd,  To execute the charge my father gave me  For visiting your highness:
t: Exactly, sir. He was sad to part with her, his daughter, and we've just come from there to follow my father's instructions to visit you.

og: my best train  I have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd;  Who for Bohemia bend, to signify  Not only my success in Libya, sir,  But my arrival and my wife's in safety  Here where we are.
t: I didn't bring my gentlemen and servants here—I sent them back to Bohemia to tell everyone about our marriage, and that my wife and I have arrived safely here.

og: The blessed gods  Purge all infection from our air whilst you  Do climate here!
t: I hope you have a happy and healthy stay here!

og: You have a holy father,  A graceful gentleman; against whose person,  So sacred as it is, I have done sin:
t: Your father is a righteous man, and I've sinned against him.

og: For which the heavens, taking angry note,  Have left me issueless; and your father's blest,  As he from heaven merits it, with you  Worthy his goodness.
t: As a punishment, the gods have left me without any children of my own. Your father is blessed to have you!

og: What might I have been,  Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on,  Such goodly things as you!
t: I would be blessed, too, if I had a son and daughter like you two with me now!

og: Most noble sir,  That which I shall report will bear no credit,  Were not the proof so nigh.
t: Sir, you'll hardly believe this, but you have to because the one who sent me is about to arrive:

og: Please you, great sir,  Bohemia greets you from himself by me;  Desires you to attach his son,
t: Polixenes sends you his greetings. He asks that you hold his son here—

og: who has—  His dignity and duty both cast off—  Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with  A shepherd's daughter.
t: you see, his son ran away from his father and his responsibilities with a shepherd's daughter.

og: Where's Bohemia? speak.
t: Tell me, where's Polixenes?

og: Here in your city; I now came from him:  I speak amazedly; and it becomes  My marvel and my message.
t: Here in your city; I just came from him. And (it may seem crazy . . . I can hardly believe it myself)

og: To your court  Whiles he was hastening, in the chase, it seems,  Of this fair couple, meets he on the way  The father of this seeming lady and  Her brother, having both their country quitted  With this young prince.
t: while Polixenes was on his way to your court, chasing this young couple, he ran into this girl's father and brother, who have also fled the country.

og: Camillo has betray'd me;Whose honour and whose honesty till nowEndured all weathers.
t: Camillo has betrayed me, though he's always been loyal and honest before now.

og: Lay't so to his charge:He's with the king your father.
t: You can tell him yourself; he's with your father, the king.

og: Who? Camillo?
t: Who, Camillo?

og: Camillo, sir; I spake with him; who now  Has these poor men in question.
t: Camillo, sir. I spoke with him and with the shepherds.

og: Never saw I  Wretches so quake: they kneel, they kiss the earth;  Forswear themselves as often as they speak:  Bohemia stops his ears, and threatens them  With divers deaths in death.
t: I've never seen men so afraid: they kneel, kiss the ground, and swear every time they speak. Polixenes can hardly listen to them; he keeps threatening them with death.

og: O my poor father!The heaven sets spies upon us, will not haveOur contract celebrated.
t: Oh, my poor father! The spies have found us, and now we won't get to celebrate our wedding.

og: You are married?
t: Aren't you married?

og: We are not, sir, nor are we like to be;The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first:The odds for high and low's alike.
t: We're not, sir, and probably won't be. Pigs will fly before that happens. The odds don't seem to be in our favor.

og: My lord,Is this the daughter of a king?
t: Sir, is she a princess?

og: She is,When once she is my wife.
t: She will be, once she's my wife.

og: That 'once' I see by your good father's speedWill come on very slowly. I am sorry,Most sorry, you have broken from his likingWhere you were tied in duty, and as sorryYour choice is not so rich in worth as beauty,That you might well enjoy her.
t: That "once" isn't likely to come to pass now that your father's on his way. I'm very sorry to hear that you're at odds with your father; you should be obedient to him. And I'm sorry, too, that you won't be able to enjoy this girl, since her station in life does not match her beauty.

og: Dear, look up:  Though Fortune, visible an enemy,  Should chase us with my father, power no jot  Hath she to change our loves.
t: Chin up, sweetheart. Nothing that my father does can change the love we have for each other.

og: Beseech you, sir,  Remember since you owed no more to time  Than I do now: with thought of such affections,  Step forth mine advocate; at your request  My father will grant precious things as trifles.
t: Sir, I beg you—think of what you were like when you were my age and in love. Defend me to my father. If you ask, he'll give you an expensive gift as quickly as if it were a cheap one.

og: Would he do so, I'ld beg your precious mistress,Which he counts but a trifle.
t: If he'd really do anything, I'd ask him to give me your girlfriend, who he clearly doesn't care for.

og: Sir, my liege,Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazesThan what you look on now.
t: Sir? My lord! The way you're looking at her is hardly appropriate. Your queen, before she died, was much more beautiful than the girl you see now.

og: I thought of her,Even in these looks I made.    But your petitionIs yet unanswer'd. I will to your father:Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires,I am friend to them and you: upon which errandI now go toward him; therefore follow meAnd mark what way I make: come, good my lord.
t: I was thinking of her even while I looked at this young girl. I haven't answered your question. I will speak to your father. Your love hasn't compromised your duties as prince; I support you and your actions. I'll go to him now; come with me and watch what I do. Come, sir.

og: Beseech you, sir, were you present at this relation?
t: And, sir, were you there when all this was said?

og: I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the oldshepherd deliver the manner how he found it:whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were allcommanded out of the chamber; only this methought Iheard the shepherd say, he found the child.
t: I was there when they opened the bag, heard the old shepherd explain how he found it, and that's when, after a moment of shock, we were all told to leave. But I thought I heard the shepherd say that he found the child.

og: I would most gladly know the issue of it.
t: I'd love to know what happened next.

og: I make a broken delivery of the business; but the  changes I perceived in the king and Camillo were  very notes of admiration:
t: I'm not telling the story very well, but the king and Camillo seemed happy to see each other.

og: they seemed almost, with  staring on one another, to tear the cases of their  eyes; there was speech in their dumbness, language  in their very gesture; they looked as they had heard  of a world ransomed, or one destroyed: a notable  passion of wonder appeared in them;
t: They stared at each other so intensely it seemed like their eyes would pop out of their heads. They could hardly speak, but they said it all in their hugs and gestures. They looked like they'd seen the world rebuilt—or destroyed. They were filled with wonder.

og: but the wisest  beholder, that knew no more but seeing, could not  say if the importance were joy or sorrow; but in the  extremity of the one, it must needs be.
t: But no one who was watching could tell if they were joyful, or sad. It was the extreme version of one of those two.

og: Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more.  The news, Rogero?
t: Here comes another gentleman who probably knows more. What's the news, Rogero?

og: Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; theking's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder isbroken out within this hour that ballad-makerscannot be able to express it.    Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he candeliver you more. How goes it now, sir? this newswhich is called true is so like an old tale, thatthe verity of it is in strong suspicion: has the kingfound his heir?
t: Nothing but sensations! The oracle is fulfilled, the king's daughter is found. So many wonderful things have happened in the last hour that even ballad-writers won't be able to express it. How are you, sir? This news sounds so much like a fairytale that it can hardly be true. Has the king found his heir?

og: Most true, if ever truth were pregnant by  circumstance: that which you hear you'll swear you  see, there is such unity in the proofs.
t: It's really true, if we can believe the circumstances. You might have to see the evidence to believe it:

og: The mantle  of Queen Hermione's, her jewel about the neck of it,  the letters of Antigonus found with it which they  know to be his character, the majesty of the  creature in resemblance of the mother, the affection  of nobleness which nature shows above her breeding,
t: Hermione's scarf, her necklace, letters in Antigonus's handwriting, the girl's resemblance to her mother, her obvious nobility which proves she's not a shepherdess . . .

og: and many other evidences proclaim her with all  certainty to be the king's daughter. Did you see  the meeting of the two kings?
t: all this and more proves that she's the king's daughter. Did you see the meeting of the two kings?

og: No.
t: No.

og: Then have you lost a sight, which was to be seen,  cannot be spoken of. There might you have beheld one  joy crown another, so and in such manner that it  seemed sorrow wept to take leave of them, for their  joy waded in tears.
t: You missed a sight to be seen; I can't really explain it in words. They were so overjoyed that both of them were moved to tears.

og: There was casting up of eyes,  holding up of hands, with countenances of such  distraction that they were to be known by garment,  not by favour.
t: They looked up to heaven and held each other's hands. They looked so much alike that we could only tell them apart by their clothes!

og: Our king, being ready to leap out of  himself for joy of his found daughter, as if that  joy were now become a loss, cries 'O, thy mother,  thy mother!'
t: Leontes—who was about to leap out of his skin, he was so happy he found his daughter—cries out, "Oh, your mother, your mother!" as if the joy made his grief new, too.

og: then asks Bohemia forgiveness; then  embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his  daughter with clipping her; now he thanks the old  shepherd, which stands by like a weather-bitten  conduit of many kings' reigns.
t: He asked Polixenes for forgiveness, then hugged his new son-in-law, then hugged his daughter again, then thanked the old shepherd who stood by like an old watchman.

og: I never heard of such  another encounter, which lames report to follow it  and undoes description to do it.
t: I have never heard of anything like it. No report can fully sum it up. Description doesn't do it justice.

og: What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carriedhence the child?
t: What happened to Antigonus, who carried the baby to Bohemia?

og: Like an old tale still, which will have matter to  rehearse, though credit be asleep and not an ear  open.
t: That's like something out of a fairytale, too, which you won't believe no matter how many times I tell it.

og: He was torn to pieces with a bear: this  avouches the shepherd's son;
t: He was torn to pieces by a bear, according to the shepherd's son.

og: who has not only his  innocence, which seems much, to justify him, but a  handkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.
t: We should believe him because he's fairly stupid, but also because he had some handkerchiefs and rings of Antigonus' that Paulina recognized.

og: What became of his bark and his followers?
t: What happened to his ship and his servants?

og: Wrecked the same instant of their master's death and  in the view of the shepherd: so that all the  instruments which aided to expose the child were  even then lost when it was found.
t: The shepherd saw them wreck at the same instant that Antigonus died, so everything that brought the child to them disappeared at the moment she was found.

og: But O, the noble  combat that 'twixt joy and sorrow was fought in  Paulina! She had one eye declined for the loss of  her husband, another elevated that the oracle was  fulfilled:
t: But poor Paulina—she was torn between joy and grief! She was crying for her husband, but rejoicing that the oracle was fulfilled.

og: she lifted the princess from the earth,  and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pin  her to her heart that she might no more be in danger  of losing.
t: She kept hugging the princess, as if she would hold her to her heart forever so that she'd never be lost again.

og: The dignity of this act was worth the audience ofkings and princes; for by such was it acted.
t: Kings and princes could have watched a play like that, considering kings and princes were the actors.

og: One of the prettiest touches of all and that which  angled for mine eyes, caught the water though not  the fish,
t: One of the most beautiful parts of it (it brought tears to my eyes)

og: was when, at the relation of the queen's  death, with the manner how she came to't bravely  confessed and lamented by the king,  how  attentiveness wounded his daughter; till, from one  sign of dolour to another, she did, with an 'Alas,'  I would fain say, bleed tears,
t: was when the king explained how the queen died, and the poor princess listened to the whole thing, crying, saying "Oh, no!" and practically bleeding tears.

og: for I am sure my  heart wept blood. Who was most marble there changed  colour; some swooned, all sorrowed: if all the world  could have seen 't, the woe had been universal.
t: I think my heart wept blood. Even the most unemotional people there nearly fainted, and everyone cried. If the whole world had seen it, the sadness would have been universal.

og: Are they returned to the court?
t: Did they go back to the court?

og: No: the princess hearing of her mother's statue,  which is in the keeping of Paulina,—
t: No, because the princess just heard about the statue of her mother, which Paulina has.

og: a piece many  years in doing and now newly performed by that rare  Italian master, Julio Romano, who, had he himself  eternity and could put breath into his work, would  beguile Nature of her custom, so perfectly he is her  ape:
t: It's been in the works for years and was just finished by Julio Romano, the Italian master, whose sculptures are incredibly lifelike.

og: he so near to Hermione hath done Hermione that  they say one would speak to her and stand in hope of  answer: thither with all greediness of affection  are they gone, and there they intend to sup.
t: His "Hermione" statue looks so much like her that you'd be tempted to speak to it and wait for an answer. They've all hurried to see the statue, and they're planning to have dinner there.

og: I thought she had some great matter there in hand;for she hath privately twice or thrice a day, eversince the death of Hermione, visited that removedhouse. Shall we thither and with our company piecethe rejoicing?
t: I thought she must have some important business in that isolated house, since she's visited it alone two or three times a day every day since Hermione's death. Should we head that way and join the celebration?

og: Who would be thence that has the benefit of access?every wink of an eye some new grace will be born:our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge.Let's along.
t: Would anyone say "no" to that? Something incredible happens every time you blink! The longer we stay here, the less we'll see. Let's go.

og: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me,  would preferment drop on my head. I brought the old  man and his son aboard the prince:
t: If I weren't a thief, I'd be getting a promotion right about now. I brought the old man and his son onboard the prince's ship.

og: told him I heard  them talk of a fardel and I know not what: but he  at that time, overfond of the shepherd's daughter,  so he then took her to be, who began to be much  sea-sick, and himself little better, extremity of  weather continuing,
t: I told him what I'd heard about the bag and whatnot, but he was too busy worrying about the shepherd's daughter (as he thought she was then), who was sea-sick, and then he got sea-sick, too because of the storm.

og: this mystery remained  undiscovered. But 'tis all one to me; for had I  been the finder out of this secret, it would not  have relished among my other discredits.
t: So the mystery remained unsolved. But it's all the same to me; if I'd figured out this secret, it wouldn't have matched up very well with my other crimes.

og: Here come those I have done good to against my will,  and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.
t: Here come the guys I helped against my will, already decked out in their new, fancy clothes.

og: Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons anddaughters will be all gentlemen born.
t: My son, I won't be having any more children, but your sons and daughters will all be born gentlemen and women.

og: You are well met, sir. You denied to fight with me  this other day, because I was no gentleman born.
t: Good to see you, sir. You chose not to fight with me the other day because I wasn't a gentleman.

og: See you these clothes? say you see them not and  think me still no gentleman born:
t: See these clothes? Can you look at these and still think I wasn't born a gentleman?

og: you were best say  these robes are not gentlemen born: give me the  lie, do, and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.
t: You might as well say these clothes weren't born gentlemen! Call me a liar. Tell me I wasn't born a gentleman.

og: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.
t: I know you are now, sir, born a gentleman.

og: Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.
t: Yep, I was born a gentleman about four hours ago!

og: And so have I, boy.
t: Me, too, son.

og: So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my  father; for the king's son took me by the hand, and  called me brother;
t: That's true, but I was born a gentleman before my father. You see, the king's son took me by the hand, called me "Brother,"

og: and then the two kings called my  father brother; and then the prince my brother and  the princess my sister called my father father;  and  so we wept,
t: and then the two kings called my father "Brother." And then the prince my brother and the princess my sister called my father "Father," and we all cried.

og: and there was the first gentleman-like  tears that ever we shed.
t: Those were the first gentlemanly tears that we ever cried.

og: We may live, son, to shed many more.
t: We may live, son, to cry many more.

og: Ay; or else 'twere hard luck, being in sopreposterous estate as we are.
t: If we don't live to cry again, that'll be bad luck, considering how good we have it now.

og: I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon me all thefaults I have committed to your worship and to giveme your good report to the prince my master.
t: I am very sorry, sir, for all the wrong I've done you, sir. Please report good things about me to the prince my master.

og: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we aregentlemen.
t: You should do it, son. We should be "gentle" now that we're gentlemen.

og: Thou wilt amend thy life?
t: You'll change your ways?

og: Ay, an it like your good worship.
t: Of course, sir, if you like.

og: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thouart as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.
t: Let's shake hands.  I'll swear to the prince that you're as honest and loyal as any man in Bohemia.

og: You may say it, but not swear it.
t: You can say it, but don't swear it.

og: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? Let boors andfranklins say it, I'll swear it.
t: I can't swear it, now that I'm a gentleman? If the peasants and the middle class can swear, I can swear, too.

og: How if it be false, son?
t: But what if it's not true, son?

og: If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swear  it in the behalf of his friend:
t: If you believe it should be true, a true gentleman can swear it on behalf of his friend.

og: and I'll swear to  the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and  that thou wilt not be drunk;
t: I'lI swear to the prince that you're hardworking and not likely to get drunk,

og: but I know thou art no  tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt be  drunk:
t: but I know you're not hardworking and very likely to get drunk.

og: but I'll swear it, and I would thou wouldst  be a tall fellow of thy hands.
t: So I hope that, when I do swear it, you'll make a better effort to be hardworking and not a drunk.

og: I will prove so, sir, to my power.
t: I'll try to live up to that, sir, to the best of my ability.

og: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do not  wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, not  being a tall fellow, trust me not.
t: Yes, and please try to work hard (although it's fine by me if you get a little drunk once in a while).

og: Hark! the kings  and the princes, our kindred, are going to see the  queen's picture. Come, follow us: we'll be thy  good masters.
t: But wait! The kings and the prince (our new family) are going to see the queen's statue. Come on and follow us. We'll take care of you.

og: O grave and good Paulina, the great comfortThat I have had of thee!
t: Paulina, you've comforted me so much.

og: What, sovereign sir,  I did not well I meant well. All my services  You have paid home:
t: If there's anything I didn't do correctly, know that I meant to do it better. You've repaid me for everything,

og: but that you have vouchsafed,  With your crown'd brother and these your contracted  Heirs of your kingdoms, my poor house to visit,  It is a surplus of your grace, which never  My life may last to answer.
t: and now you, Polixenes, Perdita, and Florizel have come to visit my little house. It's extremely gracious for you to be here, and I can never thank you enough.

og: O Paulina,  We honour you with trouble:
t: Oh, Paulina, you know I'd do anything for you.

og: but we came  To see the statue of our queen: your gallery  Have we pass'd through, not without much content  In many singularities;
t: But I came to see the statue of my queen. But I've passed through your entire gallery—which was great, and all—

og: but we saw not  That which my daughter came to look upon,  The statue of her mother.
t: without my daughter seeing the statue of her mother that she came to see.

og: As she lived peerless,  So her dead likeness, I do well believe,  Excels whatever yet you look'd upon  Or hand of man hath done;
t: When Hermione was alive, no one was as beautiful as she was. It's the same with her statue; I'm sure you've never seen another man-made thing that's as perfect.

og: therefore I keep it  Lonely, apart. But here it is: prepare  To see the life as lively mock'd as ever  Still sleep mock'd death:
t: That's why I keep it hidden here. Here it is; get ready to see that which is to life as sleep is to death—the closest you can come without being the actual thing.

og: behold, and say 'tis well.
t: Take a look, and tell me what you think.

og: Her natural posture!
t: Exactly the way she used to stand!

og: Chide me, dear stone, that I may say indeed  Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art she  In thy not chiding, for she was as tender  As infancy and grace.
t: Statue, if you would reprimand me, I'd say you were the real Hermione. Actually, you're more like her because you're not reprimanding me, considering she was as sweet as a baby and as gentle as grace itself.

og: But yet, Paulina,  Hermione was not so much wrinkled, nothing  So aged as this seems.
t: But, Paulina, Hermione didn't have that many wrinkles. She wasn't as old as this statue seems.

og: O, not by much.
t: Not nearly as old.

og: So much the more our carver's excellence;Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes herAs she lived now.
t: That's the sculptor's skill: he made her look like she would if she lived now, sixteen years later.

og: As now she might have done,  So much to my good comfort, as it is  Now piercing to my soul.
t: And she might have done so; seeing it makes me happy but fills me with guilt, too.

og: O, thus she stood,  Even with such life of majesty, warm life,  As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!
t: She looked just like this when I first fell in love with her, though she was warm and living, not cold and made of stone.

og: I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me  For being more stone than it?
t: I'm ashamed. Is the statue reprimanding me for being more stony and cold-hearted than it?

og: O royal piece,  There's magic in thy majesty, which has  My evils conjured to remembrance and  From thy admiring daughter took the spirits,  Standing like stone with thee.
t: My queen, your magic has conjured up all the crimes I committed against you and your daughter, making me think neither of you could ever forgive me.

og: And give me leave,And do not say 'tis superstition, thatI kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady,Dear queen, that ended when I but began,Give me that hand of yours to kiss.
t: Call me superstitious, but I'm going to kneel and ask for her blessing.

og: O, patience!The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.
t: Oh, wait! The statue was just painted and it's not dry yet.

og: My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on,  Which sixteen winters cannot blow away,
t: Sir, you had a lot to grieve for, but sixteen years should have helped ease that pain.

og: So many summers dry; scarce any joy  Did ever so long live; no sorrow  But kill'd itself much sooner.
t: Few joys last that long, and any other sorrow would have fizzled out long before now.

og: Dear my brother,Let him that was the cause of this have powerTo take off so much grief from you as heWill piece up in himself.
t: My brother, I wish I could bear some of that grief for you.

og: Indeed, my lord,If I had thought the sight of my poor imageWould thus have wrought you,—for the stone is mine—I'ld not have show'd it.
t: Sir, if I knew my statue would make you so upset—since it belongs to me—I wouldn't have showed it to you.

og: Do not draw the curtain.
t: Don't close the curtain.

og: No longer shall you gaze on't, lest your fancyMay think anon it moves.
t: You shouldn't look at it anymore, or you'll start to hallucinate that it's moving.

og: Let be, let be.Would I were dead, but that, methinks, already—What was he that did make it? See, my lord,Would you not deem it breathed? and that those veinsDid verily bear blood?
t: Let it be, let it be. I wish I were dead. Except . . . I think . . . already . . . who made this?  Look, doesn't it look like it's breathing? Doesn't it look like those veins have blood running through them?

og: Masterly done:The very life seems warm upon her lip.
t: It's very well done. She looks almost alive.

og: The fixture of her eye has motion in't,As we are mock'd with art.
t: Her eyes almost look like they're moving; this art is too realistic.

og: I'll draw the curtain:My lord's almost so far transported thatHe'll think anon it lives.
t: I'll close the curtain. The king is so carried away, next he'll think that it lives.

og: O sweet Paulina,Make me to think so twenty years together!No settled senses of the world can matchThe pleasure of that madness. Let't alone.
t: Oh, Paulina, I want to believe that she lives. No perception of reality could be as blissful as that kind of insanity. Leave it alone.

og: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: butI could afflict you farther.
t: Sir, I'm sorry I've gotten you so worked up. But I could go one step further.

og: Do, Paulina;For this affliction has a taste as sweetAs any cordial comfort. Still, methinks,There is an air comes from her: what fine chiselCould ever yet cut breath? Let no man mock me,For I will kiss her.
t: Do it, Paulina. This suffering is sweet to me.  It looks like she's breathing. What artist could sculpt breath? No one make fun of me; I'm going to kiss her.

og: Good my lord, forbear:The ruddiness upon her lip is wet;You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your ownWith oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?
t: Sir, restrain yourself. The red paint on her lips is wet. You'll smudge it if you kiss it, and you'll get oil paint on your own face. Should I close the curtain?

og: No, not these twenty years.
t: No, never.

og: So long could IStand by, a looker on.
t: I could stand here forever, too, just looking.

og: Either forbear,  Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you  For more amazement.
t: Either restrain yourself, leave the chapel, or get ready for more amazement.

og: If you can behold it,  I'll make the statue move indeed, descend  And take you by the hand;
t: If you can handle it, I'll make the statue move, walk down, and take you by the hand.

og: but then you'll think—  Which I protest against—  I am assisted  By wicked powers.
t: But I'm afraid you'll think I'm a witch using black magic.

og: What you can make her do,I am content to look on: what to speak,I am content to hear; for 'tis as easyTo make her speak as move.
t: I'll watch anything you can make her do. I'll listen to anything you can make her say. Surely it's as easy to make her speak as it is to make her move?

og: It is requiredYou do awake your faith. Then all stand still;On: those that think it is unlawful businessI am about, let them depart.
t: You need to have faith. Everyone stand still. And anyone who thinks I'm doing something I shouldn't can leave.

og: Proceed:No foot shall stir.
t: Proceed. No one will leave.

og: 'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach;  Strike all that look upon with marvel.
t: It's time, come down. Don't be a statue anymore. Come to us and you'll amaze all of us who are watching.

og: Come,  I'll fill your grave up: stir, nay, come away,  Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him  Dear life redeems you.
t: Come, I'll close your grave. Move! Come on, now, forget death and come back to life.

og: You perceive she stirs:
t: Look, she's moving.

og: Start not; her actions shall be holy as  You hear my spell is lawful:
t: Don't be afraid! Everything she does is as safe as my spell, like I told you.

og: do not shun her  Until you see her die again; for then  You kill her double.
t: Don't reject her until you see her die again, or you'll be killing her a second time.

og: Nay, present your hand:  When she was young you woo'd her; now in age  Is she become the suitor?
t: No, give her your hand. You won her over when she was young. Now that you're old, is she the one who has to win you?

og: O, she's warm! If this be magic, let it be an artLawful as eating.
t: Wow, she's warm! If this is from your magic spell, your magic should be considered an art as natural as eating.

og: She embraces him.
t: She's hugging him.

og: She hangs about his neck:If she pertain to life let her speak too.
t: She's hanging on his neck. If she's so lifelike, she should speak, too.

og: Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived,Or how stolen from the dead.
t: Yes, and tell us where she's been living, or how she's come back from the dead.

og: That she is living,  Were it but told you, should be hooted at  Like an old tale:
t: If I just told you she was alive, you would write it off as an old fairytale.

og: but it appears she lives,  Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while.
t: But even though she hasn't spoken, it certainly looks like she's living. Wait a minute.

og: Please you to interpose, fair madam: kneel  And pray your mother's blessing.
t: Speak to her, ma'am. Kneel and ask for your mother's blessing.

og: Turn, good lady;  Our Perdita is found.
t: Turn around, my lady. Our Perdita is found.

og: You gods, look down  And from your sacred vials pour your graces  Upon my daughter's head!
t: God bless you, daughter.

og: Tell me, mine own.  Where hast thou been preserved? where lived? how found  Thy father's court?
t: Tell me, sweetheart: how did you escape? Where did you live? How did you get back to your father's court?

og: for thou shalt hear that I,  Knowing by Paulina that the oracle  Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved  Myself to see the issue.
t: You should know: Paulina told me that the oracle gave us hope that you were still alive. I kept myself going just to see you.

og: There's time enough for that;  Lest they desire upon this push to trouble  Your joys with like relation. Go together,  You precious winners all; your exultation  Partake to every one.
t: There's plenty of time for that and to tell all our stories. Go on, all of you lucky people! Go to the feast.

og: I, an old turtle,  Will wing me to some wither'd bough and there  My mate, that's never to be found again,  Lament till I am lost.
t: Meanwhile, I'll find some lonely place to mourn my husband until I die.

og: O, peace, Paulina!  Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent,  As I by thine a wife:
t: Oh hush, Paulina. I'll give you a husband, since you gave me a wife.

og: this is a match,  And made between's by vows.
t: She and I have just been married again by exchanging our promises.

og: Thou hast found mine;  But how, is to be question'd; for I saw her,  As I thought, dead, and have in vain said many  A prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far—  For him, I partly know his mind—  to find thee  An honourable husband.
t: You found her, and I have no idea how, since I was sure I saw her die and I prayed at her grave for years. I won't have to look far to find a husband for you.

og: Come, Camillo,  And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty  Is richly noted and here justified  By us, a pair of kings.
t: Come on, Camillo, and take her by the hand. Polixenes and I can vouch for him as a valuable, trustworthy man.

og: Let's from this place.  What! look upon my brother: both your pardons,  That e'er I put between your holy looks  My ill suspicion.
t: Let's leave this place. But first, take a look at my brother, Polixenes. Both of you, please forgive me for ever being suspicious of your friendship.

og: This is your son-in-law,  And son unto the king, who, heavens directing,  Is troth-plight to your daughter.
t: This is your son-in-law, Polixenes's son, who's engaged to your daughter.

og: Good Paulina,  Lead us from hence, where we may leisurely  Each one demand an answer to his part  Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first  We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.
t: Paulina, lead us out of here. We'll take all the time in the world asking each other what we've been up to in the many years since we were all separated. Quickly, lead the way!

og: Two households, both alike in dignity  In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,  From ancient grudge break to new mutiny,  Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean.
t: In beautiful Verona, where our play takes place, there are two families, both equally noble. From their old grudge there is an outbreak of new fighting, in which they stain their refined hands with fellow citizens' blood.

og: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes  A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life,  Whose misadventured piteous overthrows  Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.
t: A pair of ill-fated lovers from the deadly bloodlines of these two feuding households commit suicide. Their sad and tragic deaths put an end to their parents' fighting.

og: The fearful passage of their death-marked love  And the continuance of their parents' rage—  Which but their children's end, naught could remove—  Is now the two-hours' traffic of our stage;
t: Now, for the two hours in which we are onstage, we will present the story of their love and death, which was the only thing that could stop their families' rage.

og: The which if you with patient ears attend,  What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
t: If we've left anything out of this prologue, just listen with patient ears—we will work to make everything understood.

og: Gregory, on my word, we’ll not carry coals.
t: Gregory, I swear we won’t put up with their crap.

og: No, for then we should be colliers.
t: No, because then we’d be waste removers.

og: I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.
t: I mean, if they make us angry, we’ll draw our swords.

og: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out of collar.
t: Yes, you should spend your life trying to get yourself out of any trouble that might lead to the hangman’s collar.

og: I strike quickly, being moved.
t: I hit hard, when I’m motivated.

og: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
t: But you avoid getting “motivated,” so you don’t ever have to hit.

og: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.
t: One of those Montague scoundrels would motivate me.

og: To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand. Therefore if thou art moved thou runn’st away.
t: To be motivated is to act, while to be valiant is to face a fight. When you’re motivated, you just run away.

og: A dog of that house shall move me to stand. I will takethe wall of any man or maid of Montague’s.
t: If I saw a Montague rascl, I’d face him. I’d walk on the side of the street closer to the wall, and so force the Montague into the gutter.

og: That shows thee a weak slave, for the weakest goes to the wall.
t: Then you must be a weakling, because it’s the weak one who gets shoved up against a wall.

og: ‘Tis true, and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall. Therefore I will push Montague’s men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.
t: That’s true, which is why women, being the weaker sex, get thrust up against the wall. So I’ll push Montague’s men into the gutter, and thrust Montague women against the wall.

og: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
t: The feud is between our masters and us, their servants.

og: ‘Tis all one. I will show myself a tyrant. When I have fought with the men, I will be civil with the maids. I will cut off their heads.
t: It’s all the same. I’ll be the Montague’s master. After fighting with the men, I’ll be nice to the maids—I’ll cut off their heads.

og: The heads of the maids?
t: You’ll cut off the heads of the maids?

og: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.Take it in what sense thou wilt.
t: The heads of the maids or their maidenheads. Interpret my comment in whichever sense you prefer.

og: They must take it in sense that feel it.
t: It’s the maids you rape or kill or who will have to sense it.

og: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
t: The maids will feel me as long as I can stand upright. Everyone knows I’m a stud.

og: ‘Tis well thou art not fish. If thou hadst, thou hadst been poor-john.Draw thy tool! Here comes of the house of Montagues.
t: It’s a good thing you’re not a fish, or else you’d be dried and shriveled like salted hake. Draw your sword! Here come some Montague servants.

og: My naked weapon is out. Quarrel! I will back thee.
t: I’ve drawn my sword out of its sheath. Fight them! I’ll back you up.

og: How? Turn thy back and run?
t: How? By turning your back and running?

og: Fear me not.
t: Don’t worry about me.

og: No, marry. I fear thee.
t: No, indeed, I do worry about you.

og: Let us take the law of our sides. Let them begin.
t: Let’s make sure the law is on our side by getting them to start the fight.

og: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.
t: I’ll frown at them as I pass by them. How they respond is up to them.

og: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
t: No, I’ll bite my thumb at them. That’s an insult, and they’ll be disgraced if they don’t react.

og: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
t: Are you biting your thumb at us, sir?

og: I do bite my thumb, sir.
t: I am biting my thumb.

og: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
t: But are you biting your thumb at us, sir?

og: Is the law of our side if I say “ay”?
t: Will the law be on our side if I say yes?

og: No.
t: No.

og: No, sir. I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I bitemy thumb, sir.
t: I’m not biting my thumb at you, sir. But I am biting my thumb, sir.

og: Do you quarrel, sir?
t: Do you want to fight us, sir?

og: Quarrel, sir? No, sir.
t: Fight, sir? No, sir.

og: But if you do, sir, I am for you. I serve as good a manas you.
t: If you do want to fight, sir, then I’m up for it. My master is as good as yours.

og: No better.
t: But not better than mine.

og: Well, sir.
t: Very well then, sir.

og: Say “better.” Here comes one of my master’s kinsmen.
t: Say “better.” One of our master’s kinsmen has just arrived.

og: Yes, better, sir.
t: Yes, my master is better than yours, sir.

og: You lie.
t: You’re a liar.

og: Draw, if you be men.—Gregory, remember thy washing blow.
t: Draw your swords, if you’re men. Gregory, get ready to slash them.

og: Part, fools!Put up your swords. You know not what you do.
t: Break it up, fools! Sheathe your swords. You don’t know what you’re doing.

og: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?Turn thee, Benvolio. Look upon thy death.
t: What, have you drawn your sword to fight with servants? Turn around, Benvolio, and see the man who will kill you.

og: I do but keep the peace. Put up thy sword,Or manage it to part these men with me.
t: I’m just trying to keep the peace. Put away your sword, or else use it to help me stop this fighting.

og: What, drawn, and talk of peace? I hate the word,As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.Have at thee, coward!
t: You hold your sword drawn out, and say “peace?” I hate that word, just as I hate hell, all Montagues, and you. Now let's fight, you coward!

og: Clubs, bills, and partisans! Strike! Beat them down!Down with the Capulets! Down with the Montagues!
t: Beat them down with your clubs, spears, and axes. Hit them! Down with the Capulets! Down with the Montagues!

og: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!
t: What is this noise? Give me my long sword. Now!

og: A crutch, a crutch! Why call you for a sword?
t: You need a crutch! Why are you calling for a sword?

og: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
t: Give me my sword, I said! Old Montague has arrived, and he’s waving his sword just to spite me.

og: Thou villain Capulet! Hold me not. Let me go.
t: You are a villain, Capulet!  Let go of me. Don’t stop me.

og: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.
t: You’re not taking one step to try to fight an enemy.

og: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,  Profaners of this neighbor-stainèd steel!—
