t: You rebels and enemies of the peace, who curse your own weapons by turning them on your neighbors.

og: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach? Speak, nephew. Were you by when it began?
t: Who stirred this old feud up again? Tell me, nephew. Were you around when the fight began?

og: Here were the servants of your adversary,  And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.  I drew to part them.
t: Your servants were fighting Capulet's servants when I arrived. I drew my sword to try to stop them.

og: In the instant came  The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,  Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,  He swung about his head and cut the winds,  Who, nothing hurt withal, hissed him in scorn.
t: Just then, the reckless Tybalt showed up with his sword drawn. He taunted me while swinging his sword through the air, which made a hissing sound.

og: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,  Came more and more and fought on part and part,  Till the Prince came, who parted either part.
t: As we fought, more and more Capulets and Montagues showed up to join the battle. Finally, the Prince came and stopped the fighting.

og: Oh, where is Romeo? Saw you him today?Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
t: Oh, where’s Romeo? Have you seen him at all today? I’m happy he wasn’t around for this fight.

og: Madam, an hour before the worshipped sun  Peered forth the golden window of the east,  A troubled mind drove me to walk abroad,  Where, underneath the grove of sycamore  That westward rooteth from this city side,
t: Madam, my mind was troubled this morning, so an hour before dawn I went out for a walk. As I walked, I saw your son beneath the sycamore grove that grows near the western edge of the city.

og: So early walking did I see your son.  Towards him I made, but he was ‘ware of me  And stole into the covert of the wood.  I, measuring his affections by my own,  Which then most sought where most might not be found,
t: I walked toward him, but he noticed me and ran and hid in the woods. I assumed that he must be feeling the same way I was, and was looking for a place where he wouldn't be found.

og: Being one too many by my weary self,  Pursued my humor not pursuing his,  And gladly shunned who gladly fled from me.
t: So I continued on, following my own inclination to not pursue Romeo and ask him what was on his mind. I was happy to leave Romeo alone as he fled from me. Besides, I was feeling so weary of company that even being with myself was being with one too many people.

og: Many a morning hath he there been seen,  With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew,  Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
t: He’s been seen at that spot on many mornings, his tears adding to the morning dew and his deep sighs thickening the clouds in the sky.

og: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun  Should in the farthest east begin to draw  The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed,  Away from light steals home my heavy son,
t: Then, as soon as the happy sun begins to dawn, my unhappy son comes home in order to hide from the light.

og: And private in his chamber pens himself,  Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out,  And makes himself an artificial night.
t: He keeps to himself in his bedroom, shutting his windows to keep out the daylight so that he can sit in an artificial night.

og: Black and portentous must this humor prove  Unless good counsel may the cause remove.
t: His bad mood is likely to have a bad result, unless someone can give him good advice and remove the cause of his sadness.

og: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
t: My noble uncle, do you know what’s causing his mood?

og: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
t: I don’t know. And he refuses to tell me.

og: Have you importuned him by any means?
t: Have you done everything possible to get him to explain?

og: Both by myself and many other friends.  But he, his own affections’ counselor,  Is to himself—I will not say how true,
t: I and many of our friends have tried to speak with him. But he insists on sharing his thoughts only with himself, though I don’t know how good the advice is that he’s giving himself.

og: But to himself so secret and so close,  So far from sounding and discovery,  As is the bud bit with an envious worm,
t: He keeps his secrets so completely that he’s like a flower bud that can’t open to the air or sun, because it’s been poisoned from within by the bite of a worm.

og: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,  Or dedicate his beauty to the same.  Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.  We would as willingly give cure as know.
t: If we could just find out the cause of his sadness, we’d try to help him as eagerly as we have tried to figure out why he feels sad.

og: See, where he comes. So please you, step aside.I’ll know his grievance or be much denied.
t: Here he comes. If you don't mind, please leave us alone. I’ll make him either tell me what’s wrong, or else he'll just decline to tell me over and over again.

og: I would thou wert so happy by thy stayTo hear true shrift.—Come, madam, let’s away.
t: I hope you're lucky enough to hear the true story. Come on, madam, let’s go.

og: Good morrow, cousin.
t: Good morning, cousin.

og: Is the day so young?
t: Is it still that early?

og: But new struck nine.
t: The clock has just barely struck nine.

og: Ay me! Sad hours seem long.Was that my father that went hence so fast?
t: Oh, my! Time goes by slowly when you’re sad. Was that my father who just rushed away?

og: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo’s hours?
t: It was. What sadness is making Romeo's hours so long?

og: Not having that which, having, makes them short.
t: Lacking the thing which would make the hours short if I had it.

og: In love?
t: Are you in love?

og: Out.
t: Out.

og: Of love?
t: So you’re not in love?

og: Out of her favor, where I am in love.
t: I am in love. But the one I love does not love me back.

og: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!
t: Oh, it is sad how love, which in theory seems like such a gentle thing, should in actual experience be so rough!

og: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,  Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!  Where shall we dine?
t: How can love, which is supposed to be blind, force you to be able to do what it wants? Where should we eat?

og: —O me! What fray was here?  Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.  Here’s much to do with hate but more with love.
t: Oh my goodness, what fighting happened here? No, don’t tell me. I already know: it was something that had a lot to do with hate, but even more to do with love.

og: Why then, O brawling love, O loving hate,  O anything of nothing first created!  O heavy lightness, serious vanity,  Misshapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
t: Oh, fighting love! Oh, loving hate! Oh, love that originates from nothing! Oh heavy lightness! Serious frivolity! Beautiful shapes smashed together to create an ugly chaos!

og: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health,  Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!  This love feel I, that feel no love in this.  Dost thou not laugh?
t: Love is like heavy feathers, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health, waking sleep, the opposite of what it is! That’s the love I feel, since no one loves me in return. Are you laughing?

og: No, coz, I rather weep.
t: No, cousin—I'm crying instead..

og: Good heart, at what?
t: But why, my good man?

og: At thy good heart’s oppression.
t: Because of the way love has oppressed your heart.

og: Why, such is love’s transgression.  Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,  Which thou wilt propagate, to have it pressed  With more of thine.
t: That’s how it it goes with love. My own sadness is a heavy weight on my chest, and now you’re going to add your own sadness to mine.

og: This love that thou hast shown  Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.  Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;  Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers’ eyes;
t: The love you are showing me is only increasing my grief. Love is like a smoke made out of the sighs of lovers. When the smoke clears, love is a fire burning in the lovers' eyes.

og: Being vexed, a sea nourished with loving tears.  What is it else? A madness most discreet,  A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.  Farewell, my coz.
t: But if that love is thwarted, then it is a sea made out of lovers' tears. What else is love? A wise madness. A sweet candy that makes you choke. Goodbye, my cousin.

og: Soft! I will go along.And if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
t: Wait! I’ll come with you. If you leave me behind, you’ll be insulting me.

og: Tut, I have lost myself. I am not here.This is not Romeo. He’s some other where.
t: Oh, I’m not acting like myself. It’s as if I’m not even here. This is not Romeo, he’s somewhere else.

og: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.
t: Tell me, seriously, who is the one you love?

og: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
t: What? Should I cry out the name in a groan of sadness?

og: Groan! Why, no. But sadly, tell me who.
t: Groan?! Why, of course not. Just tell me who it is.

og: A sick man in sadness makes his will,A word ill urged to one that is so ill. In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
t: You wouldn’t ask a sick man to “seriously” write out his will—it would only make him feel worse. Seriously, cousin, I do love a woman.

og: I aimed so near when I supposed you loved.
t: I figured that out when I guessed you were in love.

og: A right good markman! And she’s fair I love.
t: Then you have good aim! And the woman I love is beautiful.

og: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
t: My dear cousin, a beautiful target is usually the one that is hit fastest.

og: Well, in that hit you miss. She’ll not be hit  With Cupid’s arrow. She hath Dian’s wit.  And, in strong proof of chastity well armed
t: Well, now you missed the target. She won’t be hit by Cupid’s arrow. She’s like Diana, protected by the armor of chastity.

og: From love’s weak childish bow, she lives uncharmed.  She will not stay the siege of loving terms,  Nor bide th’ encounter of assailing eyes,  Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold.
t: She is immune to the weak and childish arrows of love. She ignores words of love, refuses to even let you look at her with loving eyes, or open her lap to receive golden gifts that would even tempt a saint.

og: Oh, she is rich in beauty, only poor  That when she dies, with beauty dies her store.
t: Oh, she’s rich in beauty. But she’s also poor, because when she dies her beauty will die along with her.

og: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?
t: So she’s sworn to live her life a virgin?

og: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,  For beauty, starved with her severity,  Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
t: She has, and in doing so she wastes her beauty, because by living in chastity she ensures that she will never pass her beauty on to her children.

og: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,  To merit bliss by making me despair.
t: She’s too beautiful, and too smart, to be allowed to gain entrance to Heaven by making me despair.

og: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow  Do I live dead that live to tell it now.
t: She’s sworn never to love, and in that vow has sentenced me to a kind of living death.

og: Be ruled by me. Forget to think of her.
t: Listen to me. Stop thinking about her.

og: O, teach me how I should forget to think!
t: Oh, then teach me to forget how to think!

og: By giving liberty unto thine eyes.Examine other beauties.
t: By letting your eyes wander. Take a look at other beautiful girls.

og: ‘Tis the way  To call hers exquisite, in question more.  These happy masks that kiss fair ladies’ brows,  Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
t: Such comparisons will only make her own beauty more obvious. It will be like the masks that pretty girls wear to hide their faces. When they hide their beauty, they make us think of it more.

og: He that is strucken blind cannot forget  The precious treasure of his eyesight lost.
t: A blind man can’t forget the precious eyesight he lost.

og: Show me a mistress that is passing fair;  What doth her beauty serve but as a note  Where I may read who passed that passing fair?
t: Show me any beautiful girl. What good is her beauty, other than a reminder of  a girl who is even more beautiful?

og: Farewell. Thou canst not teach me to forget.
t: Goodbye. You can’t teach me to forget.

og: I'll pay that doctrine or else die in debt.
t: I'll teach you how to forget, or else I'll die owing you the lesson.

og: But Montague is bound as well as I,  In penalty alike.
t: Montague has sworn the same oath I have, and is bound by the same penalty.

og: And ’tis not hard, I think,  For men so old as we to keep the peace.
t: I don’t think it should be hard for men as old as us to remain peaceful.

og: Of honorable reckoning are you both.  And pity ’tis you lived at odds so long.
t: You both have honorable reputations. It’s a pity you’ve been enemies for so long.

og: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?
t: But, now, my lord: how do you respond to my request?

og: But saying o’er what I have said before.  My child is yet a stranger in the world.
t: By repeating what I’ve said before. My child is still extremely young.

og: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.  Let two more summers wither in their pride  Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.
t: She’s not even fourteen years old. Let’s allow two more summers to pass before we consider her ready for marriage.

og: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
t: Girls who are younger than your daughter have become happy mothers.

og: And too soon marred are those so early made.  Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she.  She’s the hopeful lady of my earth.
t: Girls who marry that young grow up too quickly. All of my other children are dead and buried in the earth, so all hopes on this earth rest in her.

og: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.  My will to her consent is but a part.  An she agreed within her scope of choice,  Lies my consent and fair according voice.
t: But you may woo her, kind Paris. Win her love. My permission for you to marry her is only part of the bargain; she must also agree to marry you. Then my blessing on the marriage will confirm her choice.

og: This night I hold an old accustomed feast,  Whereto I have invited many a guest  Such as I love. And you among the store,  One more, most welcome, makes my number more.
t: This very night I’m throwing a party that I’ve hosted for many years. I’ve invited many guests, many close friends. I’d like to invite you as a most welcome guest.

og: At my poor house look to behold this night  Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light.
t: At my humble home tonight, you’ll see see young women like stars that walk the earth and light the sky from below.

og: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel  When well-appareled April on the heel  Of limping winter treads.  Even such delight  Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night  Inherit at my house.
t: Like all lusty young men, you’ll be delighted by the young women who are as fresh as spring flowers.

og: Hear all, all see,  And like her most whose merit most shall be—  Which on more view of many, mine, being one,  May stand in number, though in reckoning none,  Come, go with me.
t: Look at them all, and choose whichever woman you like best. Amidst all these girls, you may no longer think that my daughter’s the most beautiful. Come with me.

og: Find them out whose names are written here? It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his penciland the painter with his nets.
t: Find the people whose names are on this list? It’s written that shoemakers and tailors should use each others’ tools, and that fisherman should play with paints while painters should play with with fishing nets.

og: But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ. I must to the learned in good time!
t: But now I’ve been sent to find the people on this list, and I can’t read. I’ll have to ask somebody educated to help me.

og: Tut man, one fire burns out another’s burning.  One pain is lessened by another’s anguish.
t: Come on, Romeo. Starting a new fire will put out the old one. An old pain is lessened by the arrival of a new one.

og: Turn giddy, and be helped by backward turning.  One desperate grief cures with another’s languish.
t: If you make yourself dizzy, you can cure yourself by spinning in the other direction. A new grief will cure an old one.

og: Take thou some new infection to thy eye,  And the rank poison of the old will die.
t: Stare obsessively at some new girl, and your former lovesickness will disappear.

og: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.
t: The plantain leaf is excellent for that.

og: For what, I pray thee?
t: For what?

og: For your broken shin.
t: For treating your injured shin.

og: Why Romeo, art thou mad?
t: Why, Romeo, have you gone crazy?

og: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is,Shut up in prison, kept without my food,Whipped and tormented and—Good e’en, good fellow.
t: No, though I’m bound more tightly than any mental patient is. I’m locked in a prison without food. I’m whipped, tortured.

og: God ‘i’ good e’en. I pray, sir, can you read?
t: A blessed good evening to you. Excuse me, sir, do you know how to read?

og: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.
t: Yes. I can read my fortune in my misery.

og: Perhaps you have learned it without book. But I pray, can you read anything you see?
t: Perhaps you’ve memorized it. But, I beg your answer, can you read anything you see?

og: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.
t: Yes, if I know the letters and the language.

og: Ye say honestly. Rest you merry.
t: You speak honestly. Have a nice day.

og: Stay, fellow. I can read.
t: Stay, man. I can read.

og: “Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters;  County Anselme and his beauteous sisters;
t: “Signor Martino and his wife and daughters; Count Anselme and his gorgeous sisters;

og: The lady widow of Vitruvio;  Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces;
t: Vitravio’s widow; Signor Placentio and his lovely nieces;

og: Mercutio and his brother Valentine;  Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters;
t: Mercutio and his brother Valentine; my uncle Capulet and his wife and daughters;

og: My fair niece Rosaline and Livia;  Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt;  Lucio and the lively Helena.”
t: my fair niece Rosaline and Livia; Signor Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.”

og: A fair assembly. Whither should they come?
t: That’s quite a lovely group of people. Where are they supposed to go?

og: Up.
t: Up.

og: Whither?
t: Where?

og: To supper; to our house.
t: To supper. To our house.

og: Whose house?
t: Whose house?

og: My master’s.
t: My master’s house.

og: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.
t: Indeed, I should have asked you that earlier.

og: Now I’ll tell you without asking. My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine. Rest youmerry!
t: I’ll tell you so that you don’t have to ask. My master is the great, rich Capulet. And as long as you are not a Montague, I invite you to come and drink a cup of wine at our house. Have a nice day!

og: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s  Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves  With all the admired beauties of Verona.
t: Rosaline whom you love so much is going to attend Capulet's traditional feast, along with all the beautiful woman of Verona.

og: Go thither, and with unattainted eye  Compare her face with some that I shall show,  And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
t: Go there and, without bias, compare her to some of the girls I’ll point out to you. I’ll show you that the woman you think is as beautiful as a swan is in fact as ugly as a crow.

og: When the devout religion of mine eye  Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires,
t: If my eyes ever show me such a lie about the woman they worship, then may my tears turn into flames.

og: And these, who, often drowned, could never die,  Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!
t: That way my eyes, which never drowned in all my tears, may be burned for being such clear liars!

og: One fairer than my love? The all-seeing sun  Ne’er saw her match since first the world begun.
t: A woman more beautiful than my love? The sun has never seen anyone as beautiful since the world began.

og: Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,  Herself poised with herself in either eye.
t: Oh come on. You decided she was beautiful when no one else was around and there was no one to compare her to except herself.

og: But in that crystal scales let there be weighed  Your lady’s love against some other maid  That I will show you shining at the feast,  And she shall scant show well that now shows best.
t: But if instead you compare her to some other beautiful woman who I’ll point out to you at this feast, you’ll see that she’s far from the best.

og: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
t: I'll go along with you—not to look at other women, but to rejoice in my love's beauty.

og: Nurse, where’s my daughter? Call her forth to me.
t: Nurse, where’s my daughter? Tell her to come here.

og: Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year oldI bade her come. What, lamb! What, ladybird!God forbid! Where’s this girl? What, Juliet!
t: I swear by my virginity at age twelve, I told her to come. What is this?! Heaven forbid! Where is that girl? Juliet!

og: How now, who calls?
t: What? Who’s calling me?

og: Your mother.
t: Your mother.

og: Madam, I am here. What is your will?
t: Madam, I’m here. What do you want?

og: This is the matter.—Nurse, give leave awhile,  We must talk in secret.
t: Here’s what I want—Nurse, leave us for a bit while we talk privately

og: —Nurse, come back again.  I have remembered me. Thou’s hear our counsel.  Thou know’st my daughter’s of a pretty age.
t: —wait, no, Nurse, come back. I just remembered, you can listen to our secrets. You know my daughter’s of a certain age.

og: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
t: Yes, I know her age to the hour.

og: She’s not fourteen.
t: She’s not yet fourteen.

og: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen be itspoken, I have but four—she is not fourteen. How long is it now to Lammastide?
t: I’d bet fourteen of my teeth—but, to be honest, I actually only have four teeth—that she’s not fourteen. How long is it until August 1st?

og: A fortnight and odd days.
t: Two weeks and a few odd days.

og: Even or odd, of all days in the year,  Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.  Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls!—  Were of an age.
t: Even or odd, of all the days in the year, she’ll be fourteen on the night of July 31st. She and my daughter Susan—God rest all Christian souls—were born that same day.

og: Well, Susan is with God.  She was too good for me. But, as I said,  On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.  That shall she.
t: Well, Susan died and is now with God. She was too good for me. But, as I said, on the night of July 31st, Juliet will be fourteen. Yes, she will indeed.

og: Marry, I remember it well.  ‘Tis since the earthquake now eleven years,  And she was weaned—I never shall forget it—
t: I remember it well. It’s been eleven years since the earthquake, and it was on that very day that she stopped nursing from my breast. I’ll never forget it.

og: Of all the days of the year, upon that day.  For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,  Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.  My lord and you were then at Mantua.—  Nay, I do bear a brain.
t: I had put some bitter wormwood on my breast as I was sitting in the sun, under the wall of the dovehouse. Your husband and you were in Mantua. Oh my, what a great memory I have!

og: —But, as I said,  When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple  Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,  To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
t: As I said, when Juliet tasted the bitter wormwood on my nipple, the pretty little thing got angry with my breast. That’s when the earthquake hit and the dovehouse started to shake.

og: “Shake!” quoth the dovehouse. ‘Twas no need, I trow,  To bid me trudge.  And since that time it is eleven years,  For then she could stand alone.
t: You didn’t have to tell me to get out of there. It’s been eleven years since then. She could stand up by herself then.

og: Nay, by the rood,  She could have run and waddled all about,  For even the day before, she broke her brow.
t: No, in fact, by then she could run and waddle all over the place. I remember because just the day before she had cut her forehead.

og: And then my husband—God be with his soul!  He was a merry man—took up the child.  “Yea,” quoth he, “Dost thou fall upon thy face?  Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit,  Wilt thou not, Jule?”
t: My husband—God rest his soul, he was a jolly man—picked Juliet up. “Oh,” he said, “Did you fall on your face? You’ll fall backward when you grow up, won’t you, Jule?”

og: and, by my holy dame,  The pretty wretch left crying and said “ay.”  To see now, how a jest shall come about!
t: And, by God, the pretty little thing stopped crying and said, “Yes.” To watch a joke come true!

og: I warrant, an I should live a thousand years,  I never should forget it. “Wilt thou not, Jule?” quoth he.  And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ay.”
t: Even if I live a thousand years I’ll never forget it. “Won’t you, Jule,” he said. And the pretty fool stopped crying and said, “Yes.”

og: Enough of this. I pray thee, hold thy peace.
t: Enough of this. Please, be quiet.

og: Yes, madam. Yet I cannot choose but laugh  To think it should leave crying and say “ay.”
t: Yes, madam. But I have to laugh when I think that the baby stopped crying and said, “Yes.”

og: And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow  A bump as big as a young cockerel’s stone,  A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.
t: What’s more, I swear she had a bump on her forehead as big as a rooster’s testicle. It was quite a knock she took, and she was crying bitterly.

og: “Yea,” quoth my husband, “Fall’st upon thy face?  Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age.  Wilt thou not, Jule?” It stinted and said “ay.”
t: “Yes,” said my husband, “Did you fall on your face? You’ll fall backward when you grow up, won’t you, Jule?” And she stopped crying and said, “Yes.’

og: And stint thou too, I pray thee, Nurse, say I.
t: Please, Nurse, I'm asking you to step, too.

og: Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace!
t: I'll be quiet. I’m done. May you receive God’s grace.

og: Thou wast the prettiest babe that e’er I nursed.  An I might live to see thee married once,  I have my wish.
t: You were the prettiest baby I ever nursed. If I live to see you get married someday, my wishes will be fulfilled.

og: Marry, that “marry” is the very themeI came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet,How stands your disposition to be married?
t: In fact, marriage is exactly what I came here to discuss. Tell me, Juliet, my daughter—what do you think about getting married?

og: It is an honor that I dream not of.
t: It's an honor that I don’t think about at all.

og: An honor! Were not I thine only nurse, I would say thou hadst sucked wisdom from thy teat.
t: “An honor!” If I weren’t the only nurse you’ve had, I’d say you’d sucked wisdom from the breast that fed you.

og: Well, think of marriage now. Younger than you  Here in Verona, ladies of esteem  Are made already mothers.
t: Well, you should start thinking about marriage. In Verona, girls from noble families who are younger than you have already become mothers.

og: By my count,  I was your mother much upon these years  That you are now a maid.
t: By my count, I was already your mother at around your age, while you remain a virgin.

og: Thus then in brief:  The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
t: So, to be brief: the valiant Paris wants to marry you.

og: A man, young lady! Lady, such a manAs all the world. Why, he’s a man of wax.
t: What a man, young lady! He’s a man as great as any other in the world. He’s so perfect it’s as if he were sculpted from wax.

og: Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.
t: Verona in the summertime has no flower as fine as him.

og: Nay, he’s a flower. In faith, a very flower.
t: He’s a fine flower, absolutely, a flower.

og: What say you? Can you love the gentleman?  This night you shall behold him at our feast.  Read o’er the volume of young Paris’ face  And find delight writ there with beauty’s pen.
t: What do you say, Juliet? Can you love this gentleman? Tonight he’ll be at our feast. Look at his face and delight in his beauty.

og: Examine every married lineament  And see how one another lends content,  And what obscured in this fair volume lies  Find written in the margin of his eyes.
t: Examine how all the lines of his features combine to make him handsome. And what you can’t see in his beauty, find by looking in his eyes.

og: This precious book of love, this unbound lover,  To beautify him only lacks a cover.  The fish lives in the sea, and ’tis much pride  For fair without the fair within to hide.
t: This wonderful, loving man lacks only a bride to make him perfect. As fish do not hide from the sea, neither should a beauty like you hide from a handsome man like him.

og: That book in many’s eyes doth share the glory  That in gold clasps locks in the golden story.  So shall you share all that he doth possess  By having him, making yourself no less.
t: Everyone thinks he’s handsome, and whoever becomes his bride would be equally loved. You would share all that he possesses, and lose nothing by having him.

og: No less? Nay, bigger. Women grow by men.
t: Lose nothing? No, you’d get bigger. Men make women bigger.

og: Speak briefly. Can you like of Paris, love?
t: Answer me now. Can you love Paris?

og: I’ll look to like if looking liking move. But no more deep will I endart mine eyeThan your consent gives strength to make it fly.
t: I’ll look at him with the intent to like him, if looking at him moves me to like him. But I won’t let myself fall for him any more than your permission allows.

og: Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the Nurse cursed in thepantry,
t: Madam, the guests are here and dinner is served. Your guests call for you and Juliet, while the servants in the pantry are cursing the Nurse.

og: and every thing in extremity. I must hence to wait. I beseech you, follow straight.
t: Things are getting out of control. I must rush off to serve the guests. Please, follow right after me.

og: We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.
t: We’ll follow you. Juliet, Paris is waiting for you.

og: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.
t: Go, girl, and look for the man who will give you happy nights at the end of happy days.

og: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?Or shall we on without apology?
t: What excuse will we make? Or should we enter without apology?

og: The date is out of such prolixity.  We’ll have no Cupid hoodwinked with a scarf,  Bearing a Tartar’s painted bow of lath,  Scaring the ladies like a crowkeeper,
t: It’s no longer fashionable to talk that much. We’re not going to announce our entrance with some guy blindfolded, dressed up as Cupid, and carrying a toy bow in order to frighten the ladies like some scarecrow.

og: Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke  After the prompter for our entrance.
t: Nor will we introduce ourselves with a memorized speech.

og: But let them measure us by what they will.  We’ll measure them a measure and be gone.
t: They can judge us however they want. We’ll dance for one dance, and then get out of there.

og: Give me a torch. I am not for this ambling.Being but heavy, I will bear the light.
t: Give me a torch. I don’t feel like dancing. Since I’m sad, I might as well carry the light.

og: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.
t: No, sweet Romeo, you have to dance.

og: Not I, believe me. You have dancing shoes With nimble soles. I have a soul of leadSo stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
t: Not me, believe me. You’ve got on dancing shoes with nimble soles. But my soul is made of lead so heavy that it anchors me to the ground and I can’t move.

og: You are a lover. Borrow Cupid’s wingsAnd soar with them above a common bound.
t: You’re a lover. Borrow Cupid’s wings and use them to soar higher than the average man.

og: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft
t: I’ve been too strongly pierced by his arrow to soar.

og: To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,  I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
t: My wounded heart won’t let me escape my dull sadness.

og: Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.
t: I am sinking under love’s heavy burden.

og: And to sink in it, should you burthen love—Too great oppression for a tender thing.
t: If you sink in love, then you’re burdening it. You’re putting too much weight on such a tender thing.

og: Is love a tender thing? It is too rough,Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.
t: Is love really so tender? To me it seems too rough, too rude, too unruly, and it pricks like a thorn.

og: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.  Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.—
t: If love is rough with you, be rough with love. Prick love when it pricks you, and you’ll beat love down.

og: Give me a case to put my visage in!  A visor for a visor.
t: Give me a mask to put over my face. A mask to cover that mask I call my face.

og: —What care I  What curious eye doth cote deformities?  Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.
t: What do I care if someone sees my flaws? Let the this mask, with its dark eyebrows, blush for me.

og: Come, knock and enter. And no sooner inBut every man betake him to his legs.
t: Come on, let’s knock and go inside. And once inside, let’s all start dancing.

og: A torch for me. Let wantons light of heart  Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.
t: Give me a torch to carry. Let those with light hearts dance.

og: For I am proverbed with a grandsire phrase,  I’ll be a candle holder, and look on.  The game was ne’er so fair, and I am done.
t: There’s an old proverb that fits me perfectly: I’ll hold a torch and watch. The game looks like fun, but I’m done with it.

og: Tut, dun’s the mouse, the constable’s own word.
t: Come on, “dun” is the color of a timid mouse. You’re being as timid as a patrolman on night duty.

og: If thou art dun, we’ll draw thee from the mire,  Or—save your reverence—love, wherein thou stick’st  Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!
t: If you’re a stick stuck in the mud, we’ll pull you out—pardon me for being rude— out of the love in which you’re stuck up to your ears. Come on, we’re wasting daylight.

og: Nay, that’s not so.
t: No, that’s wrong—it’s night.

og: I mean, sir, in delay.  We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.
t: I mean, sir, that by delaying we’re wasting our torches, which is like wasting the sunshine during the day.

og: Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits  Five times in that ere once in our five wits.
t: Show your good judgment by taking what I say the way I mean it, which is five times more important than literally trusting your five senses.

og: And we mean well in going to this mask,But ’tis no wit to go.
t: We mean well by going to this party, but it’s not smart of us to go.

og: Why, may one ask?
t: Why, may I ask?

og: I dreamt a dream tonight.
t: I dreamed a dream last night.

og: And so did I.
t: So did I.

og: Well, what was yours?
t: What was your dream?

og: That dreamers often lie.
t: I dreamed that dreamers often lie.

og: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.
t: They lie in bed while dreaming about true things.

og: Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
t: Oh, then I see Queen Mab has visited you.

og: Queen Mab, what’s she?
t: Queen Mab? Who’s she?

og: She is the fairies’ midwife, and she comes  In shape no bigger than an agate stone  On the forefinger of an alderman,  Drawn with a team of little atomi  Over men’s noses as they lie asleep.
t: She’s the fairies’ midwife, and is no bigger than the stone on the ring of a city councilman. She rides her carriage, which is pulled by tiny little creatures, over men’s noses as they lie sleeping.

og: Her wagon spokes made of long spinners’ legs,  The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,  Her traces of the smallest spider’s web,
t: The wheel spokes of her carriage are made of spiders’ legs; its cover is made of grasshopper wings; and its harnesses are made of the smallest spiderwebs.

og: Her collars of the moonshine’s watery beams,  Her whip of cricket’s bone, the lash of film,  Her wagoner a small gray-coated gnat,  Not half so big as a round little worm  Pricked from the lazy finger of a maid.
t: The horse collars are made from moonbeams, while her whip is a single cobweb attached to a cricket bone. Her wagon driver is a tiny gnat wearing a gray coat that is not even half as large as a little round worm that comes from the finger of a lazy young girl.

og: Her chariot is an empty hazelnut  Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,  Time out o’ mind the fairies’ coachmakers.  And in this state she gallops night by night  Through lovers’ brains, and then they dream of love;
t: Her carriage is an empty hazelnut, made by a squirrel and an old worm, which have been the fairies’ carriage-builders for countless years.  With this magnificent carriage she rides each night through the brains of lovers, who then dream about love.

og: On courtiers’ knees, that dream on curtsies straight;  O’er lawyers’ fingers, who straight dream on fees;  O’er ladies’ lips, who straight on kisses dream,
t: She rides across courtiers’ knees, who then dream about bowing and curtsying. She rides over lawyers’ fingers, who then dream about their fees. She rides over ladies’ lips, and they immediately dream of kisses.

og: Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,  Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are.  Sometime she gallops o’er a courtier’s nose,  And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.
t: But Queen Mab often puts blisters on their lips because their breath smells of candy, which angers her. Sometimes she rides over a courtier’s nose, and he dreams of sniffing out a way to make some money.

og: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail  Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep,  Then he dreams of another benefice.
t: Sometimes she tickles a priest’s nose with the tail of pig given as a tithe to the church, and he dreams of getting a high-paid church position.

og: Sometime she driveth o’er a soldier’s neck,  And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,  Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,  Of healths five fathom deep, and then anon  Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,  And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two  And sleeps again.
t: Sometimes she drives over a soldier’s neck, and he dreams of cutting the throats of foreigners, of breaking through fortifications, of ambushes, of the finest-quality Spanish swords, and of huge mugs of alcohol before suddenly waking, frightened, by the sound of drums in his ears. Then he says a prayer or two and goes back to sleep.

og: This is that very Mab  That plaits the manes of horses in the night  And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,  Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes.
t: Mab is the one who tangles the hair of horses’ manes at night and then hardens the tangles in the foul, dirty hairs; tangles which, if you undo them, bring bad luck.

og: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,  That presses them and learns them first to bear,  Making them women of good carriage.  This is she—
t: Mab is the hag who gives dreams of sex to virgins and teaches them how to bear the weight of a lover and to bear a child. She’s the one—

og: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!Thou talk’st of nothing.
t: Calm down, calm down! Mercutio, be calm. You’re talking about nothing.

og: True, I talk of dreams,  Which are the children of an idle brain,
t: True. I’m talking about dreams, which are produced by a brain that’s doing nothing.

og: Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,  Which is as thin of substance as the air
t: Dreams are born of no more than empty fantasy, which lack substance like air,

og: And more inconstant than the wind, who woos  Even now the frozen bosom of the north,  And, being angered, puffs away from thence,  Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.
t: and are more unpredictable than the wind, which can blow on the frozen north and then suddenly get angry and blow south.

og: This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves.Supper is done, and we shall come too late.
t: This wind you’re talking about is blowing us off course. Dinner is already over. We’re going to get there too late.

og: I fear too early, for my mind misgives  Some consequence yet hanging in the stars  Shall bitterly begin his fearful date  With this night’s revels, and expire the term  Of a despisèd life closed in my breast  By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
t: I fear we’re going to arrive too early. I have a feeling this party tonight is fated to set in motion some awful destiny that will result in my own untimely death.

og: But he that hath the steerage of my course,  Direct my sail. On, lusty gentlemen.
t: But whoever’s in charge of my fate can steer me where they want. Let’s go, my lusty friends!

og: Strike, drum.
t: Bang the drum!

og: Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He shift a trencher? He scrape a trencher!
t: Where’s Potpan, who’s not helping us clear the table? Has he even moved or scraped a plate?

og: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed too, ’tis a foul thing.
t: When all the good manners are owned by just one or two men, and even those two are dirty, it’s a bad thing.

og: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard,look to the plate. Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane,
t: Clear away the stools, sideboards, and plates. My friend, save me a piece of marzipan,

og: and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!
t: and if you love me, have the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell. Antony and Potpan!

og: Ay, boy, ready.
t: Yes, boy, I’m ready.

og: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
t: You’re being called for, asked after, and looked for in the great chamber.

og: We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys. Be briska while, and the longer liver take all.
t: We can’t be both here and there at once! Be cheerful, boys. Be quick for a while, and may the longest lived take everything.

og: Welcome, gentlemen! Ladies that have their toes  Unplagued with corns will walk a bout with you.  Ah, my mistresses! Which of you all  Will now deny to dance?
t: Welcome, gentlemen. All the ladies who aren’t suffering from corns on their feet will dance with you. Ha ha! My ladies, now which of you will refuse to dance now?

og: She that makes dainty,  She, I’ll swear, hath corns. Am I come near ye now?—
t: If any of you acts shyly, I’ll swear she has corns. Have I hit the mark?

og: Welcome, gentlemen! I have seen the day  That I have worn a visor and could tell  A whispering tale in a fair lady’s ear  Such as would please.
t: Welcome, gentlemen. Once there was a time when I could wear a mask and charm a girl by whispering a story in her ear.

og: ‘Tis gone, ’tis gone, ’tis gone.—  You are welcome, gentlemen.—Come, musicians, play.
t: No more, no more, no more. You are welcome gentlemen. Come, musicians, play.

og: A hall, a hall, give room!—And foot it, girls.—
t: Make room in the hall! Make room! Dance, girls.

og: By’r Lady, thirty years.
t: By the Virgin Mary, I’d swear thirty years.

og: What, man, ’tis not so much, ’tis not so much.  ‘Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,
t: What, man? It’s not been that long, not that long. It was at Lucentio’s wedding.

og: Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,  Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.
t: No matter how quickly the years fly by, it’s been just twenty-five years since we last wore masks.

og: ‘Tis more, ’tis more. His son is elder, sir.His son is thirty.
t: Longer, longer. Lucentio’s son is older than that, sir. He’s thirty.

og: Will you tell me that?His son was but a ward two years ago.
t: How can you say that? His son was still a minor two years ago.

og: What lady is that which doth enrich the handOf yonder knight?
t: Who is that girl on the arm of that man over there?

og: I know not, sir.
t: I don’t know, sir.

og: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!  It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night  Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope’s ear,  Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear.
t: Oh, she teaches the torches to burn bright! She glows in the darkness like a jewel in the ear of an African. Her beauty is too good to be used and worn, too precious for this world.

og: So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows  As yonder lady o’er her fellows shows.  The measure done, I’ll watch her place of stand,  And, touching hers, make blessèd my rude hand.
t: Like a white dove in a flock of crows, she surpasses all the other women. When this dance ends, I’ll note where she stands, and then I’ll touch her hand and thereby bless my ugly one.

og: Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight!  For I ne’er saw true beauty till this night.
t: Did I ever love anyone before this moment? Renounce that love, my eyes! I never saw true beauty until this night.

og: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—
t: By his voice I know that this man is a Montague.

og: Why, how now, kinsman? Wherefore storm you so?
t: What’s all this, nephew? Why are you so furious?

og: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,A villain that is hither come in spiteTo scorn at our solemnity this night.
t: Uncle, that is a Montague—our rival. He’s a rogue who’s come here out of spite to scorn our celebration.

og: Young Romeo is it?
t: It’s young Romeo, right?

og: ‘Tis he, that villain Romeo.
t: That’s him, that villain Romeo.

og: Content thee, gentle coz. Let him alone.  He bears him like a portly gentleman,  And, to say truth, Verona brags of him  To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
t: Calm yourself, gentle nephew. Leave him be. He holds himself like a gentleman of good manners, and, to be honest, everyone in Verona says that he is a virtuous and well-behaved youth.

og: I would not for the wealth of all the town  Here in my house do him disparagement.  Therefore be patient. Take no note of him.
t: Not for all the wealth in this town would I insult him in my own house. Be calm. Pretend you never saw him.

og: It is my will, the which if thou respect,  Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,  An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.
t: That is my command, and if you respect me, you’ll stop with all these frowns, which is no way to behave at a party.

og: It fits when such a villain is a guest. I’ll not endure him.
t: It’s the way to behave when a scoundrel like him shows up. I won’t stand him coming here.

og: He shall be endured.  What, goodman boy! I say, he shall. Go to.  Am I the master here, or you? Go to.
t: You will stand him. What, boy? I say you will. Get out of here. Am I the master here, or you? Get out.

og: You’ll not endure him! God shall mend my soul,  You’ll make a mutiny among my guests.  You will set cock-a-hoop. You’ll be the man!
t: You won’t stand him? God save my soul, you’ll start a riot among my guests! And you’ll crow like a rooster, like you’re the man!

og: Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.
t: But, uncle, we’re being dishonored.

og: Go to, go to.  You are a saucy boy. Is ’t so, indeed?  This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.  You must contrary me. Marry, ’tis time.—
t: Come on, come on. You’re an impertinent boy. Is that really how you think it is? This silliness is likely to come back to harm you. I know what I’m doing, but you feel the need to contradict me. Well, I’ll show you a thing or two.

og: Patience perforce with willful choler meeting  Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
t: The blend of enforced restraint with my burning rage is making me tremble.

og: I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall  Now seeming sweet, convert to bitterest gall.
t: I’ll leave. But I’ll make Romeo regret this prank, which at the moment seems to him like such great fun.

og: If I profane with my unworthiesthand  This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this:
t: If I offend you by touching your holy hand with my own unworthy one,

og: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand  To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.
t: then my lips stand ready, like two blushing pilgrims, to smooth my rough touch with a gentle kiss.

og: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,  Which mannerly devotion shows in this,
t: Good pilgrim, you are unfair to your hand. Your hand shows proper devotion by touching mine,

og: For saints have hands that pilgrims’ hands do touch,  And palm to palm is holy palmers’ kiss.
t: just as pilgrims reach out to touch the hands of saints. Holding palm to palm is like a pilgrim’s kiss.

og: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
t: Don’t saints have lips? And pilgrims, too?

og: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
t: Yes, pilgrim—lips they’re supposed to use to pray.

og: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
t: Oh, then, saint, let lips do what hands do: pray. Grant my prayer or my faith will turn to despair.

og: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers’ sake.
t: Saints don’t move, though they do grant prayers.

og: Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
t: Then remain still while I pray.

og: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
t: Now your lips have cleaned the sin from mine.

og: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
t: Then my lips now have the sin they took from yours.

og: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged! Give me my sin again.
t: Sin from my lips? Oh, how you urge me on to another crime. Give me back my sin.

og: You kiss by th’ book.
t: You kiss as if you’ve studied how.

og: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
t: Madam, your mother wants to speak with you.

og: What is her mother?
t: Who is her mother?

og: Marry, bachelor,  Her mother is the lady of the house,  And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.
t: Well, young man, her mother is the lady of the house. A good, wise, and virtuous lady.

og: I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.  I tell you, he that can lay hold of her  Shall have the chinks.
t: I nursed her daughter, who you were talking to just now. I tell you, the man who marries that girl will be rich.

og: Is she a Capulet?O dear account! My life is my foe’s debt.
t: Is she a Capulet? Oh, what a price I’ve paid! My life is now owned by my enemy.

og: Away, begone. The sport is at the best.
t: Let’s go, let’s go, now while everything is still perfect.

og: Ay, so I fear. The more is my unrest.
t: Yes, it is still perfect now. But I’m afraid it will never be perfect again.

og: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.  We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.—
t: No, gentlemen, don’t leave now. We have a bit of dessert arriving any moment.

og: Is it e’en so? Why, then, I thank you all.  I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night.—  More torches here!—Come on then, let’s to bed.
t: Is that so? Then, I thank you. I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night. Bring more torches over here! Come on, let’s all get to bed.

og: Come hither, Nurse. What is yond gentleman?
t: Come here, nurse. Who is that gentleman over there?

og: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
t: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

og: What’s he that now is going out of door?
t: Who’s the one going out the door?

og: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
t: That, I think, is young Petruchio.

og: What’s he that follows here, that would not dance?
t: What about the one over there, who wouldn’t dance?

og: I know not.
t: I don’t know him.

og: Go ask his name.
t: Go ask him for his name.

og: If he be married.My grave is like to be my wedding bed.
t: If he’s married, I’d rather die than marry someone else.

og: His name is Romeo, and a Montague,The only son of your great enemy.
t: His name is Romeo. He’s a Montague. He’s the only son of your greatest enemy.

og: My only love sprung from my only hate!  Too early seen unknown, and known too late!
t: The one man I love is the son of the one man I hate! I saw him before I knew who he was, and learned who he was too late!

og: Prodigious birth of love it is to me,  That I must love a loathèd enemy.
t: What a monster love is to make me love my worst enemy.

og: What’s this? What’s this?
t: What’s this? What’s this?

og: A rhyme I learned even nowOf one I danced withal.
t: A rhyme I learned just now from somebody I danced with.

og: Anon, anon. Come, let's away. The strangers are all gone.
t: On our way, on our way! Come along, let's go. The strangers have all left.

og: Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie,  And young affection gapes to be his heir.  That fair for which love groaned for and would die,  With tender Juliet matched, is now not fair.
t: Now Romeo's old desire for Rosaline lies in its deathbed, and a new love is ready to be its heir. Romeo used to groan and swear he would die for Rosaline's love, but now he finds Rosaline's beauty nothing in comparison to tender Juliet's.

og: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,  Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks;  But to his foe supposed he must complain,  And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks.
t: Now someone loves Romeo and Romeo loves someone, and they are both charmed by each other's looks. But Romeo must declare his love to someone who is supposed to be his enemy, and Juliet is love-struck, adoring someone she is supposed to fear.

og: Being held a foe, he may not have access  To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear,
t: Because he is considered an enemy, Romeo is not allowed to see Juliet, and make the sorts of oaths that lovers usually swear to each other.

og: And she as much in love, her means much less  To meet her new belovèd anywhere.
t: And Juliet—just as much in love with Romeo as he is with her—she has even fewer means of meeting her beloved Romeo.

og: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet,  Temp'ring extremities with extreme sweet.
t: But passion gives them the power, and time gives them the opportunity, to meet each other, tempering their extreme adversity with extreme sweetness.

og: Can I go forward when my heart is here?Turn back, dull earth, and find thy center out.
t: Can I continue on while my heart stays here? I’ll be nothing but an empty body unless I go back to find my heart.

og: Romeo, my cousin Romeo! Romeo!
t: Romeo! Cousin Romeo! Romeo!

og: He is wise,And, on my life, hath stol’n him home to bed.
t: He’s smart. I’d bet on my life that he’s snuck off towards home to go to bed.

og: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.Call, good Mercutio.
t: He ran this way and jumped over this orchard wall. Call him, Mercutio.

og: Nay, I’ll conjure too!  Romeo! Humours, madman, passion, lover!  Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh!  Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.
t: No, I’ll summon him as I would a spirit. Romeo! Humors! Madman! Passion! Lover! Appear to me in the form of a sigh. Speak just a single rhyme, and I’ll be satisfied.

og: Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.”  Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
t: Cry out, “Ah me!” Say “love” and “dove.” Say one pretty word to my good gossiping friend Venus.

og: One nickname for her purblind son and heir,  Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true  When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.—
t: Say the nickname of her blind son and heir, Cupid, who shot arrows so accurately and made King Cophetua fall in love with a beggar maid.

og: He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.  The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.—
t: —Romeo doesn’t hear me, stir, or move. The little monkey is dead, so I must conjure him to appear.—

og: I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes,  By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,  By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh,  And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,  That in thy likeness thou appear to us.
t: By Rosaline’s bright eyes, by her high forehead and her red lips, by her fine feet, straight legs, and trembling thighs, and by parts of her that lie next to her thighs, I summon you to appear before us in your actual form.

og: An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
t: You’ll make him angry if he hears you.

og: This cannot anger him. ‘Twould anger him  To raise a spirit in his mistress’ circle  Of some strange nature, letting it there stand  Till she had laid it and conjured it down.
t: This won’t make him angry. It would anger him if I conjured a strange spirit into Rosaline's room for her to have sex with.

og: That were some spite. My invocation  Is fair and honest. In his mistress’ name  I conjure only but to raise up him.
t: That would really anger him. But what I’m saying is fair and honest. I’m just saying the name of his love in order to call him out from the darkness.

og: To be consorted with the humorous night.Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
t: Come on. He’s hidden within these trees to be alone with the night. His love is blind, so it's fitting he share it with the dark.

og: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.  Now will he sit under a medlar tree  And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit  As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.—
t: If love is blind, it can’t hit the target. He’ll sit under a medlar tree and wish his love were one of its fruits, which women, when they’re alone, joke look like female genitals.

og: O Romeo, that she were! Oh, that she were  An open arse, and thou a poperin pear.
t: Oh, Romeo, I wish she were one such fruit! I wish she was an open-arse, and that you were a “pop her in” pear.

og: Romeo, good night. I’ll to my truckle bed.  This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep.—  Come, shall we go?
t: Good night, Romeo. I’m off to my little trundle bed. It’s too cold in this field for me to sleep here. Come on, Benvolio, shall we leave?

og: Go then, for 'tis in vainTo seek him here that means not to be found.
t: Yes, let's go, then. We'd be looking for Romeo in vain because he doesn't want to be found.

og: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
t: He jokes about scars from wounds he’s never felt.

og: But soft! What light through yonder window breaks?  It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.  Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,  Who is already sick and pale with grief,  That thou, her maid, art far more fair than she.
t: But wait! What light is that in the window over there? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun. Rise, beautiful sun, and kill the jealous moon, which is already sick and pale with grief because Juliet, her maid, is more beautiful than she is.

og: Be not her maid since she is envious.  Her vestal livery is but sick and green,  And none but fools do wear it. Cast it off!  It is my lady. Oh, it is my love.  Oh, that she knew she were!
t: Don’t be her maid, since she’s jealous. The moon’s virginity makes her look sick and green, and only fools hold on to their virginity. Throw it off. It is my lady. Oh, it is my love. Oh, I wish she knew I loved her.

og: She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that?  Her eye discourses. I will answer it.—  I am too bold. ‘Tis not to me she speaks.
t: She’s talking, but isn’t saying anything. Why is that? Her eyes are speaking. I’ll respond—no, I am too bold. It’s not to me she speaks.

og: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,  Having some business, do entreat her eyes  To twinkle in their spheres till they return.  What if her eyes were there, they in her head?  The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars  As daylight doth a lamp.
t: Two of the most beautiful stars in the sky had to go off on some business, and begged her eyes to twinkle in their place until they return. If her eyes were in the sky and the stars were in her head the brightness of her cheeks would overwhelm the stars, just as daylight outshines a lamp.

og: Her eye in heaven  Would through the airy region stream so bright  That birds would sing and think it were not night.
t: And her eyes in the night sky would shine so brightly that birds would start singing, thinking it was day.

og: See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.  Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand  That I might touch that cheek!
t: Look how she leans her cheek against her hand. I wish I were a glove on that hand, so I could touch her cheek.

og: Ay me!
t: Oh, my!

og: She speaks.  O, speak again, bright angel! For thou art  As glorious to this night, being o’er my head,  As is a wingèd messenger of heaven
t: She speaks. Speak again, bright angel. For tonight you are as glorious as an angel, shining above my head like a winged messenger from heaven;

og: Unto the white, upturnèd, wondering eyes  Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him  When he bestrides the lazy-puffing clouds  And sails upon the bosom of the air.
t: one who makes mortals fall onto their backs to gaze up in awe as the angel strides across the clouds and sails through the air.

og: O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?  Deny thy father and refuse thy name.
t: Oh, Romeo, Romeo, why must you be Romeo? Deny your father and give up your name.

og: Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,  And I’ll no longer be a Capulet.
t: Or, if you won’t change your name, just swear your love to me and I’ll give up being a Capulet.

og: Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?
t: Should I listen longer, or respond now to these words?

og: ‘Tis but thy name that is my enemy.  Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.  What’s Montague? It is nor hand, nor foot,  Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part  Belonging to a man.
t: Only your name is my enemy. You’d be yourself even if you ceased to be a Montague. What’s a Montague, after all? It’s not a hand, foot, arm, face, or any other body part.

og: O, be some other name!  What’s in a name? That which we call a rose  By any other word would smell as sweet.
t: Oh, change your name! What’s the significance of a name? The thing we call a rose would smell as sweet even if we called it by some other name.

og: So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called,  Retain that dear perfection which he owes  Without that title.
t: So even if Romeo had some other name, he would still be perfect.

og: Romeo, doff thy name,  And for that name, which is no part of thee  Take all myself.
t: Romeo, take off your name—which really has no connection to who you are—and take all of me instead.

og: I take thee at thy word. Call me but love, and I’ll be new baptized.Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
t: I take you at your word. If you call me your love, I’ll take a new name. From now on I’ll never again be Romeo.

og: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night,So stumblest on my counsel?
t: Who are you, hiding in the darkness and eavesdropping on my private thoughts?

og: By a name  I know not how to tell thee who I am.
t: I don’t know how to tell you who I am by using a name.

og: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself  Because it is an enemy to thee.  Had I it written, I would tear the word.
t: I hate my name, dear saint, because it is your enemy. If I had it written down, I would tear up the word.

og: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred wordsOf that tongue’s uttering, yet I know the sound. Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
t: I haven't even heard you say a hundred words yet, but I do recognize the sound of your voice. Aren’t you Romeo, the Montague?

og: Neither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.
t: Beautiful girl, I’ll be neither of those things, if you dislike them.

og: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?  The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
t: How and why did you come here? The orchard walls are high and difficult to climb.

og: And the place death, considering who thou art,  If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
t: And it will mean your death, because of who you are, if any of my family members find you here.

og: With love’s light wings did I o’erperch these walls,  For stony limits cannot hold love out,
t: I flew over these walls on the wings of love. No stone wall can keep love out.

og: And what love can do, that dares love attempt.  Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
t: Whatever a man in love can do, love will make him attempt to do it. Therefore your relatives can’t stop me.

og: If they do see thee they will murder thee.
t: If they see you they’ll murder you.

og: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eyeThan twenty of their swords. Look thou but sweet,And I am proof against their enmity.
t: Alas, there would be more danger for me in one angry look from you than there would be from twenty of your relatives with swords. If you just look at me with love, their hatred would not be able to touch me.

og: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
t: I’d give the world to make sure they do not see you here.

og: I have night’s cloak to hide me from their eyes,  And but thou love me, let them find me here.
t: The darkness of night will hide me from their eyes. And if you don’t love me, then let them find me.

og: My life were better ended by their hate  Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
t: I’d rather they killed me in hatred than experience the prolonged death of life without your love.

og: By whose direction found’st thou out this place?
t: Who told you how to find my my bedroom?

og: By love, that first did prompt me to inquire.  He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.
t: Love, which spurred me to come and find you. Love advised me, while I lent love my eyes.

og: I am no pilot. Yet, wert thou as far  As that vast shore washed with the farthest sea,  I would adventure for such merchandise.
t: I’m not a sailor. Still, even if you were on the shore across the farthest sea, I would set out to find you.

og: Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face,  Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek  For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
t: The darkness of night masks my face, or else you’d see me blushing about the things you heard me say tonight.

og: Fain would I dwell on form. Fain, fain deny  What I have spoke. But farewell compliment!
t: I would gladly stick to the proper manners of courtship and deny everything I said. But, instead: I'll say goodbye to good manners!

og: Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say “ay,”  And I will take thy word. Yet if thou swear’st  Thou mayst prove false.
t: Do you love me? I know you will answer “yes,” and I will trust you. But your swears may turn out to be false.

og: At lovers’ perjuries,  They say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,  If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.
t: They say that Jove laughs when lovers lie. Oh, noble Romeo, if you really love me, say it in truth.

og: Or if thou think’st I am too quickly won,  I’ll frown and be perverse and say thee nay,  So thou wilt woo. But else, not for the world.
t: Or if you think I’m letting myself be won too easily, then I’ll frown and act superior and unapproachable so that you’ll woo me. But if that’s not necessary, then I would never act that way.

og: In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,  And therefore thou mayst think my ‘havior light.
t: In truth, beautiful Montague, I like you too much, which might make it seem as if I am overly silly and flirtatious.

og: But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove more true  Than those that have more coying to be strange.  I should have been more strange, I must confess,  But that thou overheard’st, ere I was ‘ware,  My true love’s passion.
t: But trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove to be more faithful than girls who act coy and standoffish. I probably should have acted more standoffish, I confess, but you overheard me talking about my passion for you before I knew you were there.

og: Therefore pardon me,  And not impute this yielding to light love,  Which the dark night hath so discovered.
t: So please forgive me, and don’t condemn me for so quickly falling in love when it was only revealed to you because the dark night let you discover it.

og: Lady, by yonder blessèd moon I vow,That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops—
t: Lady, I swear by the sacred moon, which outlines in silver the tops of these fruit trees—

og: O, swear not by the moon, th’ inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circle orb,Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.
t: Please don’t swear by the moon, the unreliable moon, which changes its position in the sky each month. I do not want your love to end up being similarly variable.

og: What shall I swear by?
t: What should I swear by?

og: Do not swear at all.Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.
t: Don’t swear at all. Or, if you must swear, swear by your magnificent self, which is the god I worship like an idol, and I’ll believe you.

og: If my heart’s dear love—
t: If my heart’s dear love—

og: Well, do not swear. Although I joy in thee,  I have no joy of this contract tonight.  It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden,
t: Well, don’t swear. Although you bring me joy, I can’t take joy in this exchange of promises tonight. It’s too wild, thoughtless, sudden.

og: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be  Ere one can say “It lightens.”
t: It’s too much like lightning, which disappears before you can even say, “it’s lightning.”

og: Sweet, good night.  This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath,  May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
t: My love, good night. Our love, which now is like a flower bud, may blossom in the summer air into a beautiful flower by the next time we meet.

og: Good night, good night! As sweet repose and rest  Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
t: Good night! I hope you feel in your heart the same sweet calm and rest that I feel in mine.

og: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
t: Are you going to leave me so unsatisfied?

og: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?
t: What satisfaction could you have tonight?

og: Th’ exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.
t: If we exchanged vows of love.

og: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it,And yet I would it were to give again.
t: I pledged my love before you even requested it. But now I wish I could take that promise back to give it again.

og: Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?
t: You’d take back your vow? Why, my love?

og: But to be frank, and give it thee again.  And yet I wish but for the thing I have.
t: In order to generously give it to you again. But I’m wishing for something I have already.

og: My bounty is as boundless as the sea,  My love as deep. The more I give to thee,  The more I have, for both are infinite.
t: My generosity to you is as endless as the sea, my love as deep as the sea. The more love I give you, the more I have. Both are infinite.

og: I hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu.—Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.Stay but a little. I will come again.
t: I hear a noise from inside. Dear love, goodbye—Just a second, Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true. Stay for a moment. I’ll come right back.

og: O blessèd, blessèd night! I am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream,Too flattering sweet to be substantial.
t: Oh, blessed, blessed night! Because it’s night, I’m scared that all this is a dream. It is too wonderful to be real.

og: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.  If that thy bent of love be honorable,  Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow
t: Three words, dear Romeo, and then good night. If your love is honorable and you want to marry me, send me word tomorrow.

og: By one that I’ll procure to come to thee  Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite,
t: I’ll find a messenger who will come to you, and you can tell that messenger when and where we will be married.

og: And all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay  And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
t: All my fortunes I’ll lay at your feet and follow you, my lord, all over the world.

og: Madam!
t: Madam!

og: I come, anon.—But if thou mean’st not well,I do beseech thee—
t: I’ll be right there!

og: Madam!
t: Madam!

og: By and by, I come.—To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief. Tomorrow will I send.
t: In a second, I’m coming!

og: So thrive my soul—
t: My soul depends on it—

og: A thousand times good night!
t: A thousand times good night.

og: A thousand times the worse to want thy light.
t: It is a thousand times worse to leave you.

og: Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books,
t: A lover goes toward his beloved as joyfully as a schoolboy leaving his books.

og: But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
t: But when a lover leaves his beloved, he is as unhappy as a schoolboy on his way to school.

og: Hist! Romeo, hist!—Oh, for a falconer’s voice,  To lure this tassel-gentle back again!
t: Psst! Romeo! Psst! Oh, I wish I could cry out like a falconer, so I could call my little falcon to return to me.

og: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud,  Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,
t: Stuck as I am in my family’s house, I have to be quiet. Otherwise I would tear open the cave where Echo sleeps

og: And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,  With repetition of “My Romeo!”
t: and make her call out my love’s name until her voice grew more hoarse than mine by repeating, “My Romeo!”

og: It is my soul that calls upon my name.
t: It is my soul that calls out my name.

og: How silver-sweet sound lovers’ tongues by night,  Like softest music to attending ears!
t: Lovers' voices at night sound silver-sweet, the most lovely music to lovers’ ears.

og: Romeo!
t: Romeo!

og: My nyas?
t: My little hawk?

og: What o’clock tomorrowShall I send to thee?
t: At what time tomorrow should I send the messenger to you?

og: By the hour of nine.
t: Nine o’clock.

og: I will not fail. ‘Tis twenty year till then.I have forgot why I did call thee back.
t: I won’t fail. It will feel like twenty years until then. I’ve forgotten why I called you back.

og: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
t: I’ll stand here until you remember.

og: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,Remembering how I love thy company.
t: I’ll forget it, so you’ll have to stand there forever, because of how much I love your company.

og: And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget,Forgetting any other home but this.
t: And I’ll remain here, even if you keep forgetting. I’ll forget that I have any other home but here.

og: ‘Tis almost morning. I would have thee gone.  And yet no further than a wanton’s bird,  That lets it hop a little from his hand
t: It’s almost morning. I want to force you to go. Yet I would not let you move any further than a spoiled child would let his pet bird go.

og: Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,  And with a silken thread plucks it back again,  So loving-jealous of his liberty.
t: The child so loves the bird that he will not let the bird hop any more than a small distance from his hand before pulling it back by a silk thread.

og: I would I were thy bird.
t: I wish I were your bird.

og: Sweet, so would I.  Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
t: Sweetheart, so do I. But I would pet you so much it would kill you.

og: Good night, good night! Parting is such sweet sorrow  That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
t: Good night. Good night! Parting is such sweet sorrow that I will say good night until it becomes tomorrow.

og: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.
t:
May sleep shut your eyes,
 and may you feel peace in your heart.

og: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest, Hence will I to my ghostly sire's close cell,His help to crave, and my deap hap to tell.
t: I wish I were sleep and peace, so I could sweetly rest with you tonight. But now I'll go to my priest's cell, to ask for his help and tell him about my good luck.

og: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,  Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,  And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels  From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
t: The morning smiles as it replaces frowning night, and streaks light across the clouds in the east. Darkness staggers away from the sun’s path like a drunkard.

og: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,  The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry,  I must upfill this osier cage of ours  With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
t: Now, before the sun rises, bringing on the day and drying the dew, I must fill my basket with poisonous weeds and the precious nectar of flowers.

og: The earth, that’s natu re’s mother, is her tomb.  What is her burying, grave that is her womb.
t: The earth is both nature’s mother and its tomb. Plants arise from the earth as from a womb, and when they die, they are buried in the earth.

og: And from her womb children of divers kind  We sucking on her natural bosom find,  Many for many virtues excellent,  None but for some and yet all different.
t: Many different plants and animals come from the earth’s womb. All of these children find nourishment from the earth, and all have some special, unique virtue.

og: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies  In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.  For naught so vile that on the earth doth live  But to the earth some special good doth give.
t: There is a power that resides in herbs, plants, and stones. For there’s nothing on earth that’s so evil that it does not also provide the earth with some kind of good.

og: Nor aught so good but, strained from that fair use  Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.  Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied,  And vice sometime by action dignified.
t: Nor is there anything so good that it can’t be turned bad if it’s abused and used incorrectly. Virtue, when misused, turns to vice, while vice can sometimes become virtue through proper action.

og: Within the infant rind of this small flower  Poison hath residence and medicine power.  For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;  Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart.
t: Within the small rind of this little flower there is both poison and medicine. If you smell it, you feel good. If you taste it, it stops your heart.

og: Two such opposèd kings encamp them still,  In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.  And where the worser is predominant,  Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
t: Two opposing elements, good and evil, reside in both men and herbs. In the cases where evil predominates, death will soon kill the plant or body like a cancer.

og: Good morrow, Father.
t: Good morning, father.

og: Benedicite.  What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?  Young son, it argues a distempered head  So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
t: God bless you. Whose voice greets me so sweetly this early in the morning? My son, jumping so quickly out of bed this early indicates some trouble in your thoughts.
