og: Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye,  And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.  But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain  Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
t: All old men have concerns, and these worries never let them sleep. Young men, though, should be carefree and without worry, and their sleep should be restful and long.

og: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure  Thou art uproused by some distemperature.  Or if not so, then here I hit it right:  Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
t: Therefore, the fact that you’re awake so early makes it clear that some anxiety has you in its grip. Or, if that’s not true, then I’d guess that you actually never went to sleep at all tonight.

og: That last is true. The sweeter rest was mine.
t: That last is right. The rest I had was sweeter than sleep.

og: God pardon sin! Wast thou with Rosaline?
t: God forgive all sin!—Did you sleep with Rosaline?

og: With Rosaline, my ghostly Father? No.I have forgot that name and that name’s woe.
t: With Rosaline, my holy father? No, I have forgotten her and the sadness she gave me.

og: That’s my good son. But where hast thou been, then?
t: That’s good, my son. But where were you, then?

og: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.  I have been feasting with mine enemy,  Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,  That’s by me wounded.
t: I’ll tell you before you ask me again. I’ve been at a party with my enemy, where suddenly someone wounded me and was in turn wounded by me.

og: Both our remedies  Within thy help and holy physic lies.  I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo,  My intercession likewise steads my foe.
t: But both of us can be cured by your holy power. I hold no hatred, blessed father, because my request will also help my enemy.

og: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift.Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
t: Speak plainly, my son. Be clear. A confusing confession will result only in confused absolution.

og: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set  On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.  As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine,  And all combined, save what thou must combine  By holy marriage.
t: Here it is set plain: I love the beautiful daughter of rich Capulet. I love her, and she loves me. We’re bound together, and need only for you to combine us completely by marrying us.

og: When and where and how  We met, we wooed and made exchange of vow,  I’ll tell thee as we pass, but this I pray:  That thou consent to marry us today.
t: In good time I’ll tell you about when and where and how we met, how we wooed each other and vowed our love. But  now I pray that you will agree to marry us today.

og: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!  Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear,  So soon forsaken?
t: Holy Saint Francis, what an incredible change! Have you so quickly abandoned Rosaline, whom you loved so much?

og: Young men’s love then lies  Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.  Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine  Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!  How much salt water thrown away in waste  To season love that of it doth not taste!
t: If so, then young men love not with their hearts but with their eyes. Jesus and Mary, you cried so many tears for Rosaline! So many salty tear-drops wasted, seasoning a love you never even tasted!

og: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,  Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.  Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit  Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
t: The sun has not yet burned away the fog from all your sighs. My old ears are still ringing from your groans. And look, here on your cheek there’s a stain from an old tear that has not yet been washed off.

og: If e’er thou wast thyself and these woes thine,  Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
t: If you were ever yourself and this sorrow yours, you and your sorrow were all for Rosaline.

og: And art thou changed? Pronounce this sentence then:  Women may fall when there’s no strength in men.
t: And are you now changed? Then say the following: women will never be faithful when men are so unreliable.

og: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.
t: You often scolded me for loving Rosaline.

og: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
t: I scolded you for obsessing, not for loving, my student.

og: And badest me bury love.
t: And you urged me to bury my love.

og: Not in a grave,To lay one in, another out to have.
t: But not to bury it in a grave in order to start a new love.

og: I pray thee, chide not. Her I love nowDoth grace for grace and love for love allow.The other did not so.
t: I beg you, don’t scold me. The one I love now returns my love. The other did not.

og: Oh, she knew well  Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
t: Oh, Rosaline knew that you were play-acting at love but did not actually understand what love means.

og: But come, young waverer, come, go with me,  In one respect I’ll thy assistant be,  For this alliance may so happy prove  To turn your households’ rancor to pure love.
t: But come with me, my young unreliable friend. I’ll help you, because it’s possible that this marriage may transform your two families’ hatred into pure love.

og: Oh, let us hence. I stand on sudden haste.
t: Let’s go, then! Let’s do this quickly.

og: Wisely and slow. They stumble that run fast.
t: Go wisely, and go slowly. Those who rush into things stumble.

og: Where the devil should this Romeo be?Came he not home tonight?
t: Where the devil is Romeo? Did he come home last night?

og: Not to his father’s. I spoke with his man.
t: Not to his father’s house. I asked Romeo’s servant.

og: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
t: Rosaline—that pale-skinned, hard-hearted wench—torments him so much that he’s going to go insane.

og: Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet,Hath sent a letter to his father’s house.
t: Tybalt, old Capulet’s kinsman, has sent a letter to Romeo’s father’s house.

og: A challenge, on my life.
t: I bet it’s a challenge to fight.

og: Romeo will answer it.
t: Romeo will answer it.

og: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
t: Any man who can write is able to answer a letter.

og: Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.
t: No, Romeo will respond to the letter writer and accept the challenge.

og: Alas, poor Romeo! He is already dead, stabbed with a white wench’s black eye, shot through the ear with a love song,
t: Poor Romeo! He is already dead: stabbed by the black eye of a fair-skinned girl, cut through the ear by a love song.

og: the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy’s butt shaft. And is he a man to encounterTybalt?
t: The very core of his heart has been split by blind Cupid’s arrow. Is he really man enough to fight Tybalt?

og: Why, what is Tybalt?
t: Why, what’s up with Tybalt?

og: More than Prince of Cats. Oh, he’s the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion.
t: He’s more than just the Prince of Cats. Oh, he does everything according to convention. He fights like you sing printed music, carefully keeping the correct time, distance, and rhythm.

og: He rests his minim rests—one, two, and the third in your bosom.
t: He rests when it is proper to rest: one, two, and the third in your heart. He’s a master duelist who can hit any of his opponent’s buttons that he chooses.

og: The very butcher of a silk button, a duelist, a duelist, a gentleman of the very first house of the first and second cause.
t: He’s a gentleman who learned at the finest fencing school, and he’s skilled at identifying insults and slights to his honor so that he’s “forced” to fight.

og: Ah, the immortal passado, the punto reverso, the hai!
t: He knows the passado—the forward thrust—the punto reverso—the backhand thrust—and the hai—the thrust for the heart.

og: The what?
t: He knows what?

og: The pox on such antic, lisping, affecting fantasmines, these new tuners of accents! “By Jesu, a very good blade! A very tall man! A very good whore!”
t: A curse on these wild, pompous fellows who are always spouting exotic foreign phrases. These fellows, who say things like: “By Jesus, this is a very good blade! A very brave man! A very good whore.”

og: Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these “pardon me’s,”
t: Isn’t it a sad thing, good man, that we are forced to interact with these foreign flies, these fashionmongers, these fellows who say “pardon me”

og: who stand so much on the new form, that they cannot sit at ease on the oldbench? Oh, their bones, their bones!
t: and care so deeply about good manners that they can’t relax on a bench without groaning, “Oh, my aching bones!”

og: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.
t: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

og: Without his roe, like a dried herring. O flesh, flesh,how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.
t: He looks skinny as a dried herring without its eggs. O flesh, flesh, you’ve turned pale as a fish. Now he’s just like Petrarch’s hopeless love poetry.

og: Laura to his lady was but a kitchen-wench— marry, she had a better love to berhyme her—
t: In Romeo’s opinion, compared to his own lady love: Petrarch’s Laura was like a kitchen slave—though Laura clearly had a lover who was better at making rhymes;

og: Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose.
t: Dido was drab and dull; Cleopatra was a gypsy girl; Helen and Hero were good-for-nothing harlots; Thisbe might have had beautiful eyes, but that doesn’t matter.

og: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?
t: Good morning to you both. What do you mean I tricked you?

og: The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive?
t: You gave us the slip, sir, the slip. Do you understand me now?

og: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.
t: I’m sorry, good Mercutio. My business was so important that I must be forgiven for stretching good manners and courtesy.

og: That’s as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.
t: So what you’re saying is that your “business” forced you to flex your legs.

og: Meaning “to curtsy”?
t: Meaning make a curtsy?

og: Thou hast most kindly hit it.
t: Now you’ve “hit it.”

og: A most courteous exposition.
t: What a courteous explanation.

og: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
t: Indeed, I am the very “pink” of courtesy.

og: Pink for flower.
t: As in the pink flower.

og: Right.
t: Right.

og: Why, then is my pump well flowered.
t: Well, then my pump is covered in flowers.

og: Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing solely singular.
t: Ah, witty Romeo, now you’ve taken this joke so far that it’s worn out your pump. With the sole of your pump now worn away, the joke is all that remains.

og: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.
t: This jest has such a thin sole, and is unique only because of its lameness.

og: Come between us, good Benvolio. My wits faints.
t: Please break up this war of words, Benvolio. My wits can’t keep up.

og: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.
t: Continue, continue, or I’ll proclaim victory.

og: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five. Was I with youthere for the goose?
t: No, if our witticisms go on a wild-goose chase, I’m done for. You have more wild goose in one of your jokes than I have in five of mine. Was I  even close to you in our goose chase?

og: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast notthere for the goose.
t: You would not have been with me for anything if you weren’t there for the goose.

og: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
t: I’ll bite you on the ear for that joke.

og: Nay, good goose, bite not.
t: No, good goose, don’t bite me.

og: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting. It is a most sharp sauce.
t: Your wit is a bitter apple. It is a very spicy sauce.

og: And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
t: Isn’t that the perfect sauce for a sweet goose?

og: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
t: Oh, that joke is made of leather so thin it has been stretched from an inch wide to a full fat yard.

og: I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
t: I stretched it for that word “fat.” Add that to the goose, and it makes you a fat goose.

og: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love? Nowart thou sociable. Now art thou Romeo.
t: Now, isn’t this jesting better than groaning about love? Now you’re being sociable. Now you’re Romeo.

og: Now art thou what thou art—by art as well as by nature, for this driveling love is like a great natural that runs lollingup and down to hide his bauble in a hole.
t: Now you are what you truly are, both naturally and through education. In contrast, this love of yours made you like some fool who runs all over the place looking for a hole in which to hide his precious trinket.

og: Stop there, stop there.
t: Stop there, stop there.

og: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.
t: You’re asking me to stop my tale before it’s finished.

og: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
t: Continuing on would have made your tale too long.

og: Oh, thou art deceived. I would have made it short, forI was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
t: You’re wrong there. I would have made it short. I had come to the full depth of my tale, and intended to say nothing more about it.

og: Here’s goodly gear.
t: Now here’s something.

og: A sail, a sail!
t: A sail, a sail!

og: Two, two—a shirt and a smock.
t: No, two sails—a man in a shirt and a woman in a dress.

og: Peter!
t: Peter!

og: Anon!
t: In a moment.

og: My fan, Peter.
t: Give me my fan, Peter.

og: Good, Peter, to hide her face, for her fan’s the fairerface.
t: Good Peter, to hide her face, please give her the fan. Her fan is prettier than her face.

og: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
t: Good morning, gentlemen.

og: God ye good e’en, fair gentlewoman.
t: Good afternoon, beautiful lady.

og: Is it good e’en?
t: Is it afternoon?

og: ‘Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
t: It’s not any earlier, I tell you. The lusty hand of the clock is now upon the prick of noon.

og: Out upon you! What a man are you?
t: Get out of town! What kind of man are you?

og: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
t: A man, good lady, whom God has made for himself to ruin.

og: By my troth, it is well said. “For himself to mar,” quoth he? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
t: I swear, that seems the truth. “For himself to ruin,” he says. Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I can find young Romeo?

og: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him. I am theyoungest of that name, for fault of a worse.
t: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you began to look for him. I am the youngest man by that name, because there is none younger or worse.

og: You say well.
t: You speak well.

og: Yea, is the worst well? Very well took, i’ faith, wisely, wisely.
t: Is the worst well? Very well taken, in truth, very wise.

og: If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.
t: If you’re Romeo, sir, I would like to have a private conversation with you.

og: She will indite him to some supper.
t: She will invite him to dinner.

og: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! So ho!
t: A pimp! A pimp! A pimp! That’s it!

og: What hast thou found?
t: What have you discovered?

og: No hare, sir, unless a hare, sir, in a Lenten pie—that is, something stale and hoar ere it be spent.
t: Well, she can’t be a prostitute unless she’s so stale and old that she’s only tasted when nothing else is available.

og: An old hare hoar,  And an old hare hoar,  Is very good meat in Lent.
t: Old rabbit meat Old rabbit meatIs good meat if you can’t get anything else,

og: But a hare that is hoar  Is too much for a score  When it hoars ere it be spent.
t: But old moldy rabbit,Is a waste of your coinIf it goes moldy before you can eat it

og: Romeo, will you come to your father’s? We’ll to dinner, thither.
t: Romeo, are you going to your father’s? We’re having lunch there. Let’s go.

og: I will follow you.
t: I’ll follow after you.

og: Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.
t: Farewell, old lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.

og: I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?
t: Please tell me, sir, who was that foulmouthed fellow with all his dirty jokes?

og: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to ina month.
t: Nurse, he’s a gentleman who loves to hear himself talk. He says more in one minute than he will stand behind in a month.

og: An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.
t: If he says anything against me, I’ll teach him a lesson, even if he were tougher than he is—and twenty wise-asses like him.

og: And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall. Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills. I am none of his skains-mates.
t: And if I couldn’t take him down myself, I’ll find someone who can. That rotten scoundrel! I’m not one of his flirty girls. I’m not one of his low-life scheming friends.

og: I saw no man use you at his pleasure. If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.
t: I didn’t see anybody use you for pleasure. If I had, I’d have quickly pulled out my weapon, I assure you.

og: I dare draw as soon as another man if I see occasion in a good quarrel and the law on my side.
t: I draw my sword as quickly as any other man if I see a good fight brewing and the law is on my side.

og: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers. Scurvy knave!
t: Now, by God, I’m so upset that I’m shaking. That rotten scoundrel!

og: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I protest unto thee—
t: Nurse, speak well of me to your mistress. I pledge to you—

og: Good heart, and i’ faith, I will tell her as much. Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
t: Your heart is good, and I promise, I will tell her that. Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

og: What wilt thou tell her, Nurse? Thou dost not mark me.
t: What are you going to tell her, Nurse? You’re not understanding me.

og: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.
t: I will tell her, sir, that you protest to her, which I think is a gentlemanly offer.

og: Bid her devise  Some means to come to shrift this afternoon.  And there she shall at Friar Lawrence’ cell  Be shrived and married.
t: Tell her to devise a way to come to confession this afternoon. And there, at Friar Lawrence’s cell, she can make confession and we will be married.

og: Here is for thy pains.
t: Here is a reward for your efforts.

og: No, truly, sir. Not a penny.
t: No, truly, sir. I won’t take your money.

og: Go to. I say you shall.
t: Go on, I insist.

og: This afternoon, sir? Well, she shall be there.
t: This afternoon, sir? She will be there.

og: And stay, good Nurse. Behind the abbey wall  Within this hour my man shall be with thee  And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,
t: Just a moment, good Nurse. In an hour, behind the abbey wall, one of my servants will meet you and give you a rope ladder.

og: Which to the high top-gallant of my joy  Must be my convoy in the secret night.
t: I’ll then use the ladder to secretly climb up to Juliet’s room tonight.

og: Farewell. Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.  Farewell. Commend me to thy mistress.
t: Farewell. Be worthy of my trust, and I’ll repay you for your help. Farewell. Speak well of me to your mistress.

og: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.
t: May God in heaven bless you! Now listen, sir.

og: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
t: What, my dear Nurse?

og: Is your man secret? Did you ne’er hear say,“Two may keep counsel, putting one away?”
t: Can your servant be trusted? Have you ever heard the saying, “Two men may keep a secret, but only if one is far away?"

og: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.
t: I guarantee you that my man is as trustworthy as steel.

og: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord! when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard,
t: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady. Lord, Lord, when she was a little baby—Oh, there is one nobleman in the city, Paris, who would gladly lay claim to her.

og: but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.
t: But Juliet, good soul that she is, would rather be with a toad, a toad, than him. Sometimes I make her angry by telling her that Paris is better looking than you.

og: But, I’ll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin bothwith a letter?
t: I swear to you, when I say that she turns as white as any sheet in the entire world. Don’t “rosemary” and “Romeo” begin with the same letter?

og: Ay, Nurse, what of that? Both with an R.
t: Yes, Nurse, what about that? Both begin with an  “R.”

og: Ah, mocker, that’s the dog’s name. R is for the—No, I know it begins with some other letter, and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.
t: Ah, you jokester—that’s the dog’s name. “R” is for the—no, I know that word begins with another letter. She says such pretty things about you and rosemary that it would do you good to hear them.

og: Commend me to thy lady.
t: Speak well of me to your lady.

og: Ay, a thousand times —Peter!
t: Yes, a thousand times. Peter!

og: Anon!
t: I’m ready.

og: Before, and apace.
t: Go ahead of me, and go quickly.

og: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.  In half an hour she promised to return.  Perchance she cannot meet him. That’s not so.
t: It was nine o’clock when I sent the Nurse. She promised to be back in half an hour. Maybe she can’t find him. No, that makes no sense.

og: Oh, she is lame! Love’s heralds should be thoughts,  Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams,  Driving back shadows over louring hills.
t: Oh, she’s so slow! Love’s messengers should be thoughts, which fly ten times faster than sunbeams and drive the shadows back over the dark and scowling hills.

og: Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw love  And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.  Now is the sun upon the highmost hill  Of this day’s journey,
t: That’s how fast swift-winged doves carry the goddess of love in her chariot, and why Cupid has wings that propel him as quickly as the wind. Now the sun is at its highest point in the sky—it’s noon.

og: and from nine till twelve  Is three long hours, yet she is not come.  Had she affections and warm youthful blood,  She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
t: Three hours have passed since nine o’clock, and yet she hasn’t returned. If she were young and in love, she’d move as fast as a struck tennis ball.

og: My words would bandy her to my sweet love,  And his to me.  But old folks, many feign as they were dead,  Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
t: My words would bounce her to my sweet love, and his words would bounce her back to me. But old people act as though they’re already dead—awkward, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.

og: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?  Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away
t: Oh God, she’s here! Sweet Nurse, what’s your news? Did you meet with him? Send your servant away.

og: Peter, stay at the gate.
t: Peter, go back and wait at the gate.

og: Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?  Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
t: Now, good sweet Nurse—Oh Lord, why do you look so sad? If your news is sad, tell it to me as if it’s happy.

og: If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news  By playing it to me with so sour a face.
t: If it’s good, you’re messing it up by telling it to me with such a sour face like that.

og: I am aweary. Give me leave awhile.Fie, how my bones ache! What a jaunt have I!
t: I’m weary. Give me some time alone. Oh, my bones are aching! What a journey this has been today.

og: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.Nay, come, I pray thee, speak. Good, good Nurse, speak.
t: I wish you had my bones, and I had your news. I beg you, speak. Good, good Nurse, tell me!

og: Jesu, what haste! Can you not stay awhile? Do you not see that I am out of breath?
t: Jesus, what a rush you're in! Can’t you wait for awhile? Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

og: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath  To say to me that thou art out of breath?
t: How are you out of breath when you have the breath to tell me that you’re out of breath?

og: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay  Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
t: The excuse you’re making while delaying telling me the news is taking longer than it would to tell me your tale.

og: Is thy news good, or bad? Answer to that.  Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.  Let me be satisfied. Is ’t good or bad?
t: Is your news good or bad? Answer that. Tell me that, and I’ll wait for the details. Tell me at least that. Is it good or bad?

og: Well, you have made a simple choice. You know not how to choose a man. Romeo!
t: Well, you have made a foolish choice. You don’t know how to choose a man. Romeo?

og: No, not he, though his face be better than any man’s, yet his leg excels all men’s, andfor a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not tobe talked on, yet they are past compare.
t: No, not him, even though his face is more handsome than any other man’s, his legs are prettier. His hands and feet and body aren’t much to speak of, and yet they’re beyond compare.

og: He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb. Go thy ways, wench. Serve God. What, have you dined at home?
t: He isn’t the most courteous man, but, I’d swear that he’s as gentle as a lamb. So do what you want, girl. Be good. Hey, have you already eaten lunch?

og: No, no. But all this did I know before.What says he of our marriage? What of that?
t: No, no. I already knew everything you just said. What did he say about our marriage? What about that?

og: Lord, how my head aches! What a head have I!  It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.
t: Lord, I have such a headache! It’s pounding as if it’s about to break into twenty pieces.

og: My back a’ t’ other side. Ah, my back, my back!  Beshrew your heart for sending me about,  To catch my death with jaunting up and down!
t: And on my other side my back is aching—ah, my back! Curse your heart for sending me out and about. I could get sick and die from all this journeying around!

og: I’ faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?
t: Indeed, I’m sorry you’re in pain. Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what does my love say?

og: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, avirtuous— Where is your mother?
t: Your love says, like an honorable, courteous, kind, handsome, and, I believe, virtuous gentleman — where is your mother?

og: Where is my mother? Why, she is within.  Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!
t: Where’s my mother? Why, she’s inside. Where else would she be? What a strange answer!

og: “Your love says, like an honest gentleman,  ‘Where is your mother?’”
t: “Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, ‘Where is your mother?’”

og: O God’s lady dear,  Are you so hot?
t: Mary, mother of God! Are you in such a hurry?

og: Marry, come up, I trow.  Is this the poultice for my aching bones?  Henceforward do your messages yourself.
t: Indeed, you need to calm down. Is this the way to soothe my aching bones? From here on out, carry your own messages.

og: Here’s such a coil. Come, what says Romeo?
t: What a fuss you’re making. Come on, what did Romeo say?

og: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?
t: Do you have permission to go to confession today?

og: I have.
t: I do.

og: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’s cell.  There stays a husband to make you a wife.
t: Then hurry up and go to Friar Lawrence’s cell. There waits a husband to make you his wife.

og: Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks.  They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.  Hie you to church.
t: Now the lustful blood is rushing up to your cheeks. You blush scarlet whenever you get excited at some news. Get to church.

og: I must another way  To fetch a ladder, by the which your love  Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
t: I must go elsewhere to get a rope ladder that your love will use to climb up to your window when it’s dark.

og: I am the drudge and toil in your delight,  But you shall bear the burden soon at night.
t: I do the drudge work for your pleasure. But soon enough, you’ll be doing your “wifely work” tonight with Romeo.

og: Go. I’ll to dinner. Hie you to the cell.
t: Go. I’ll go to lunch. You go to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

og: Hie to high fortune! Honest Nurse, farewell.
t: I'll hurry off to my good fortune! Goodbye, trustworthy Nurse.

og: So smile the heavens upon this holy actThat after-hours with sorrow chide us not.
t: May the heavens smile upon this holy act of marriage, so that afterwards nothing happens to make us feel sorrowful about it.

og: Amen, amen. But come what sorrow can,  It cannot countervail the exchange of joy  That one short minute gives me in her sight.
t: Amen, amen. But whatever sorrow comes, it couldn’t overwhelm the joy I feel from a single look at her.

og: Do thou but close our hands with holy words,  Then love-devouring death do what he dare;  It is enough I may but call her mine.
t: If you join our hands with holy words, then love-devouring death can do whatever it wants. It’s enough for me if I can just call her mine.

og: These violent delights have violent ends  And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,  Which, as they kiss, consume.
t: Such passionate joys have violent endings. They die in their moment of triumph, just like a spark and gunpowder destroy themselves in an explosion once they touch.

og: The sweetest honey  Is loathsome in his own deliciousness  And in the taste confounds the appetite.
t: Even the most delicious honey is loathsome when you’ve had too much, and takes away your appetite.

og: Therefore love moderately. Long love doth so.  Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
t: Loving in moderation is therefore the key to long-lasting love. Going too fast is as bad as going too slow.

og: Here comes the lady. Oh, so light a foot  Will ne’er wear out the everlasting flint.
t: Here comes the lady. Oh, a footstep as light as hers will never endure the rocky road of life.

og: A lover may bestride the gossamers  That idles in the wanton summer air,  And yet not fall. So light is vanity.
t: Lovers are so light that they can walk upon a spiderweb floating on a summer breeze, and still not fall. That’s how flimsy and unreal pleasure is.

og: Good even to my ghostly confessor.
t: Good evening, my spiritual confessor.

og: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
t: Romeo will thank you, my girl, for both of us.

og: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
t: I’ll give him equal thanks, so we’re even.

og: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy  Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more  To blazon it,
t: Ah, Juliet, if you’re as happy as I am, and you’re better with words,

og: then sweeten with thy breath  This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue  Unfold the imagined happiness that both  Receive in either by this dear encounter.
t: tell me about the happiness you imagine we’ll have in our marriage.

og: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,  Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
t: I can imagine more than I can say—I have more on my mind than words.

og: They are but beggars that can count their worth.  But my true love is grown to such excess  I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.
t: Anyone who can count how much he has is poor. My true love has made me so rich that I can’t count even half of my wealth.

og: Come, come with me, and we will make short work, For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till Holy Church incorporate two in one.
t: Come on, come along with me, and we will do the ceremony quickly. Because, with your permission, I won't leave you two alone until you are united in holy matrimony.

og: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.  The day is hot; the Capulets, abroad;
t: I’m begging you, good Mercutio, let’s go home. It’s hot, and the Capulets are all over the place.

og: And if we meet we shall not ’scape a brawl,  For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.
t: If we should meet up with them, we’ll end up fighting them. Hot days like today get people all worked up and angry.

og: Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword uponthe table and says “God send me no need of thee!”
t: You’re the kind of guy who walks into a bar, slaps his sword down on the table and says, “I hope I don’t have to use you.”

og: and, by the operation of the second cup, draws it on the drawer when indeed there is no need.
t: By the time he’s having his second drink, he draws his sword on the bartender for no reason.

og: Am I like such a fellow?
t: You think I’m like that?

og: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
t: Come now. You can be as hot-blooded as any man in Italy. You get angry at the smallest thing, and when you’re in the mood to get angry you always find something to get angry about.

og: And what to?
t: So what?

og: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.
t: So, if there were two men such as you, it wouldn’t take long for there to be none, because each of you would kill the other. Why, you would fight with a man if he had one more or one less hair in his beard than you have in yours.

og: Thou wilt quarrel witha man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes. What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
t: You’ll fight a man who’s cracking nuts simply because your own eyes are the color of hazelnuts. Only someone like you would look for that kind of fight.

og: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.
t: Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of food, but your head has gotten scrambled like an egg from all your fighting.

og: Thouhast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep inthe sun. Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?
t: You once fought with a man who coughed in the street because he woke up your dog that was sleeping in the sun. And can you deny that you had a falling out with a tailor because he was wearing a new jacket before Easter?

og: With another, fortying his new shoes with old ribbon? And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!
t: And with another for tying his new shoes with old laces? And yet you’re trying to tell me how to avoid fighting?

og: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
t: If I were as quick to get into fights as you are, my life insurance rates would be immense.

og: The fee simple? O simple!
t: Your life insurance? You’re a fool!

og: By my head, here comes the Capulets.
t: By God, Here come the Capulets.

og: By my heel, I care not.
t: By my foot, I couldn’t care less.

og: Follow me close, for I will speak to them. Gentlemen, good e’en. A word with one of you.
t: Follow me closely. I’ll speak to them.

og: And but one word with one of us? Couple it with something. Make it a word and a blow.
t: You want a single word with one of us? Combine it with something else. Make it a word and a punch.

og: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
t: You’ll find me happy to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.

og: Could you not take some occasion without giving?
t: You can’t find a reason without my giving you one?

og: Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
t: Mercutio, you hang out with Romeo.

og: Consort? What, dost thou make us minstrels? An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords.Here’s my fiddlestick. Here’s that shall make you dance. Zounds, “consort”!
t: “Hang out?” What, are we musicians in a band? If we look like musicians to you, you can expect to hear nothing but noise.  This is my fiddlestick. It will make you dance. My God—“hang out!”

og: We talk here in the public haunt of men.  Either withdraw unto some private place,
t: We’re talking here in public. Either let’s go somewhere private and calmly discuss your complaints,

og: And reason coldly of your grievances,  Or else depart. Here all eyes gaze on us.
t: or else just go our separates ways. Here, everybody can see us.

og: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze. I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.
t: Men’s eyes were made to see. Let them watch. I won’t move for anyone.

og: Well, peace be with you, sir. Here comes my man.
t: Well, may peace be with you. Here comes the man I’m after.

og: But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.Marry, go before to field, he’ll be your follower.Your worship in that sense may call him “man.”
t: Sir, I’ll be hanged if he’s your man, in your servant's uniform. Walk out into a field and he’ll chase you. That’s the only sense in which you can call him your “man.”

og: Romeo, the love I bear thee can affordNo better term than this: thou art a villain.
t: Romeo, I have just one thing to say to you: you’re a villain.

og: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee  Doth much excuse the appertaining rage  To such a greeting.
t: Tybalt, I love you for a reason that allows me to ignore the rage I would normally feel in response to such a greeting.

og: Villain am I none.  Therefore, farewell. I see thou know’st me not.
t: I’m not a villain. Therefore, goodbye. I can see that you don’t know me at all.

og: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuriesThat thou hast done me. Therefore turn and draw.
t: Boy, these words don’t excuse the injuries you’ve done to me. Turn and draw your sword.

og: I do protest I never injured thee,  But love thee better than thou canst devise,  Till thou shalt know the reason of my love.
t: I’ve never done you harm. In fact, I love you more than you’ll be able to understand until you know the reason behind my love.

og: And so, good Capulet—which name I tender  As dearly as my own—be satisfied.
t: And so, good Capulet—which is a name I love as dearly as my own—be satisfied.

og: O calm dishonourable, vile submission!Alla stoccata carries it away.     Tybalt, you ratcatcher, will you walk?
t: Such a calm submission is both dishonorable and vile! The thrust of a sword will sweep it away.  Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you duel with me?

og: What wouldst thou have with me?
t: What do you want from me?

og: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine lives,that I mean to make bold withal, and, as you shall use me hereafter, dry-beat the rest of the eight.
t: Good King of Cats, I want nothing more than one of your nine lives. I’ll boldly take that one, and, depending on how you behave after that, I just may also beat the rest of the eight out of you too.

og: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears? Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.
t: Will you draw your sword from its sheath? Hurry, or mine will be at your ears before you have yours out.

og: I am for you.
t: I’ll duel with you.

og: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
t: Noble Mercutio, put your sword away.

og: Come, sir, your passado.
t: Get on with it, sir. Attack.

og: Draw, Benvolio. Beat down their weapons.  Gentlemen, for shame! Forbear this outrage.
t: Draw your sword, Benvolio, and help me beat down their weapons. Gentlemen, this is shameful.

og: Tybalt, Mercutio! The Prince expressly hath  Forbidden bandying in Verona streets.  Hold, Tybalt! Good Mercutio!
t: Tybalt! Mercutio! The Prince has explicitly forbidden fighting in the streets of Verona. Stop! Tybalt! Good Mercutio!

og: Away, Tybalt.
t: Let’s get out of here, Tybalt.

og: I am hurt.A plague o’ both your houses! I am sped.Is he gone and hath nothing?
t: I’m hurt. May a plague strike both your families. I’m done. Did he get away without injury?

og: What, art thou hurt?
t: What, are you hurt?

og: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch. Marry, ’tis enough. Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
t: Yes, yes. A scratch, just a scratch. Yet it’s enough. Where is my page? Go, villain. Get a doctor.

og: Courage, man. The hurt cannot be much.
t: Have courage, man. The injury can’t be so bad.

og: No, ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but ’tis enough, ’twill serve. Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.
t: It’s not as deep as a well or as wide as a church door, but it’s enough. Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me a grave man.

og: I am peppered, I warrant, for this world. A plague o’ both your houses! Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!
t: My time in this world is done, I believe. May a plague strike both your families. God! That dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat has scratched me to death!

og: A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!
t: That braggart, that scoundrel, that villain who fights as if he learned it all from some manual!

og: I thought all for the best.
t: I was trying to do what was right.

og: Help me into some house, Benvolio,  Or I shall faint. A plague o’ both your houses!
t: Carry me inside some house, Benvolio, or else I will faint. May a plague strike both your families!

og: They have made worms’ meat of me. I have it,  And soundly too. Your houses!
t: They’ve made me into food for worms. I’m finished. Curse your families!

og: This gentleman, the Prince’s near ally,  My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt  In my behalf. My reputation stained  With Tybalt’s slander.
t: This gentleman, a kinsman of the Prince and my friend, was killed while fighting on my behalf, to defend me against Tybalt’s insults.

og: —Tybalt, that an hour  Hath been my kinsman! O sweet Juliet,  Thy beauty hath made me effeminate  And in my temper softened valor’s steel!
t: Tybalt, who has been my own kinsman for an hour! Oh, sweet Juliet, your beauty has made me effeminate and softened the steel of my valor.

og: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.
t: Oh Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead! His noble spirit has gone to heaven, but it was too early for him to leave this life.

og: This day’s black fate on more days doth depend.This but begins the woe others must end.
t: Today’s dark fate will determine the future. These events only begin the sorrow that is to come.

og: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
t: The furious Tybalt has returned.

og: Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!  Away to heaven, respective lenity,  And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now.
t: Alive and triumphant, while Mercutio is dead? Begone, respect and compassion. Rage and fury will be my guide.

og: Now, Tybalt, take the “villain” back again  That late thou gavest me, for Mercutio’s soul  Is but a little way above our heads,  Staying for thine to keep him company.
t: Now, Tybalt, take back the “villain” that you called me earlier. Mercutio’s soul is waiting just a bit above our heads for you to join him.

og: Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.
t: Either you, I, or both of us must go with him.

og: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him hereShalt with him hence.
t: Wretched boy, you hung out with him here on earth, and now you’re going to go with him to heaven.

og: This shall determine that.
t: Our fight will decide who goes to heaven.

og: Romeo, away, be gone!  The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.
t: Romeo, get away from here. The citizens are coming, and Tybalt is dead.

og: Stand not amazed. The Prince will doom thee death  If thou art taken. Hence, be gone, away!
t: Don’t just stand there staring. If you’re caught, the Prince will execute you. Get out of here!

og: Oh, I am fortune’s fool!
t: Oh, fate has played me for a fool!

og: Why dost thou stay?
t: Why are you still here?

og: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio? Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?
t: Where did the man who killed Mercutio run? Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he go?

og: There lies that Tybalt.
t: Tybalt is lying right there.

og: Up, sir, go with me.I charge thee in the Prince’s name, obey.
t: Get up, sir, and come with me. By the name of the Prince, I command you to obey.

og: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
t: Where are the evil instigators of this fight?

og: O noble prince, I can discover all  The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.
t: Oh, noble prince, I can explain everything about the unfortunate events that led to this deadly fight.

og: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo,  That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
t: There lies Tybalt, the man who killed your relative, brave Mercutio. Tybalt was then killed by young Romeo.

og: Tybalt, my cousin! O my brother’s child!  O Prince! O cousin! Husband! Oh, the blood is spilled  Of my dear kinsman!
t: Tybalt, my nephew! My brother’s son! Oh Prince, oh nephew, oh husband! Oh, my dear kinsman is dead!

og: Prince, as thou art true,  For blood of ours shed blood of Montague.  O cousin, cousin!
t: Prince, you are a man of honor, and therefore must respond to this murder by killing a Montague. Oh nephew, nephew!

og: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?
t: Benvolio, who began this deadly fight?

og: Tybalt here slain, whom Romeo’s hand did slay.  Romeo, that spoke him fair, bade him bethink  How nice the quarrel was and urged withal  Your high displeasure.
t: Tybalt did, who then was killed by Romeo. Romeo spoke politely to Tybalt and begged him to see how ridiculous the disagreement was and to remember how displeased you would be if there was a fight.

og: All this uttered  With gentle breath, calm look, knees humbly bowed,  Could not take truce with the unruly spleen  Of Tybalt deaf to peace,
t: All this he said gently, calmly, kneeling down with humility. But he could not make peace. Tybalt’s anger was irrational, and he was deaf to any talk of peace.

og: but that he tilts  With piercing steel at bold Mercutio’s breast,  Who, all as hot, turns deadly point to point,  And, with a martial scorn, with one hand beats  Cold death aside and with the other sends  It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity,  Retorts it.
t: Soon Tybalt attacked Mercutio, who just as angry, fought back. They thrusted their swords and attacked each other.

og: Romeo, he cries aloud,  “Hold, friends! Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue,  His agile arm beats down their fatal points,  And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm  An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life  Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
t: Romeo cried out, “Stop, my friends. Step apart.” Then he jumped in between them, and forced down their swords. Tybalt, though, thrust his sword under Romeo’s arm, and hit brave Mercutio’s heart. Then Tybalt ran.

og: But by and by comes back to Romeo,  Who had but newly entertained revenge,  And to ’t they go like lightning, for ere I  Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain.
t: But, soon after, Tybalt returned to fight Romeo, who by now wanted revenge for Mercutio’s death. They began to fight as quick as lightning. Before I could separate them, Tybalt was killed.

og: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.  This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
t: As Tybalt fell, Romeo turned and ran. This is the truth, I swear on my life.

og: He is a kinsman to the Montague.  Affection makes him false. He speaks not true.
t: Benvolio is a Montague. His loyalty compels him to lie. He’s lying.

og: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife,  And all those twenty could but kill one life.
t: There must have been twenty Montagues fighting, and together all twenty of them could only kill one man.

og: I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give.  Romeo slew Tybalt. Romeo must not live.
t: I beg for justice that only you, Prince, can give. Romeo killed Tybalt. Romeo must die.

og: Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
t: Romeo killed Tybalt. Tybalt killed Mercutio. Who should pay the price for Mercutio’s life?

og: Not Romeo, Prince, he was Mercutio’s friend.His fault concludes but what the law should end,The life of Tybalt.
t: Not Romeo, Prince. He was Mercutio’s friend. His “crime” was justice, because it took the life of Tybalt.

og: And for that offense  Immediately we do exile him hence.  I have an interest in your hate's proceeding;  My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding.
t: And for that offense I immediately exile him from this place. I have a part in your rivalry; my blood relative, Mercutio, lies bleeding because of your rude fights.

og: But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine  That you shall all repent the loss of mine.  I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.
t: But I will punish you so harshly that you will regret causing me this loss. I will be deaf to your pleas and your excuses.

og: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses.  Therefore use none.
t: Neither tears nor prayers can buy you forgiveness for what you've done wrong. So don't use any.

og: Let Romeo hence in haste,  Else, when he is found, that hour is his last.
t: Let Romeo get out of here quickly. Otherwise, when he is found, he will be swiftly killed.

og: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
t: Take this body away, and obey my commands. Showing mercy and pardoning murderers only causes more killings.

og: Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds,  Toward Phoebus’ lodging. Such a wagoner  As Phaeton would whip you to the west  And bring in cloudy night immediately.
t: Move faster you fiery-footed horses, bearing the sun toward its nighttime resting place. Phaeton would whip you so hard that you would already have brought the sun west and night would come immediately.

og: Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night,  That runaways’ eyes may wink, and Romeo  Leap to these arms, untalked of and unseen.  Lovers can see to do their amorous rites  By their own beauties, or, if love be blind,  It best agrees with night.
t: Come, night, with your darkness, so that Romeo can come to me without anyone knowing and leap into my arms. In the dark, lovers can still see enough, by the light of their own beauty, to make love. Or, if love is blind, then it is best suited to the night.

og: Come, civil night,  Thou sober-suited matron, all in black,  And learn me how to lose a winning match  Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.
t: Come, night, you widow dressed in black, and teach me how to win my love so that we both can lose our virginities.

og: Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks,  With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold,  Think true love acted simple modesty.
t: Hide the blood rushing to my cheeks in your darkness, until my shy love grows bold enough to think of love-making as simple and true.

og: Come, night. Come, Romeo. Come, thou day in night,  For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night  Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.  Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-browed night,  Give me my Romeo.
t: Come, night. Come, Romeo. You’re like a day during the night, lying on the wings of night even whiter than snow on the wings of a raven. Come, gentle night. Come, loving, dark night. Give me my Romeo.

og: And when I shall die,  Take him and cut him out in little stars,  And he will make the face of heaven so fine  That all the world will be in love with night  And pay no worship to the garish sun.
t: And when I die, take him and cut him into stars that will make the night sky so beautiful that the entire world will fall in love with the night and forget about the tasteless sun.

og: Oh, I have bought the mansion of a love,  But not possessed it, and though I am sold,  Not yet enjoyed.
t: Oh, I have bought the mansion of love, but not yet possessed it. I belong to Romeo, but have not yet been enjoyed by him.

og: So tedious is this day  As is the night before some festival  To an impatient child that hath new robes  And may not wear them.
t: This day is so long and dull, just as the night before some festival is to an impatient child forced to wait to put on her fancy new clothes.

og: Oh, here comes my Nurse,  And she brings news, and every tongue that speaks  But Romeo’s name speaks heavenly eloquence.—
t: Oh, here comes my Nurse, bringing news. Every voice that speaks Romeo’s name speaks with heavenly beauty.

og: Now, Nurse, what news? What hast thou there? The cords  That Romeo bid thee fetch?
t: Now, Nurse, what’s your news? What is that you have there? The rope ladder Romeo told you to get?

og: Ay, ay, the cords.
t: Yes, yes, the ladder.

og: Ay me, what news? Why dost thou wring thy hands?
t: Oh no, what’s your news? Why are you wringing your hands?

og: Ah, weraday! He’s dead, he’s dead, he’s dead!We are undone, lady, we are undone!Alack the day! He’s gone, he’s killed, he’s dead!
t: Alas! He’s dead. He’s dead. He’s dead! We’re done for, lady, done for! Curse the day! He’s gone. He’s killed. He’s dead!

og: Can heaven be so envious?
t: Can God be so cruel?

og: Romeo can,Though heaven cannot. O Romeo, Romeo!Who ever would have thought it? Romeo!
t: Romeo can be, though God is not. Oh, Romeo, Romeo! Who ever would have guessed? Romeo!

og: What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?  This torture should be roared in dismal hell.
t: What kind of a devil are you to torment me in this way? This sort of torture is fit only for hell.

og: Hath Romeo slain himself? Say thou but “ay,”  And that bare vowel I shall poison more  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.
t: Has Romeo killed himself? Say “yes” and that single word will poison me more terribly than could even the deadly gaze of the cockatrice.

og: I am not I if there be such an I,  Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.”  If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.”  Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
t: I will cease to be myself if you say that Romeo killed himself. If he’s dead, say “yes.” If not, say “no.” Those little words will determine my joy or pain.

og: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes—  God save the mark!—here on his manly breast.
t: I saw the wound. I saw it with my own eyes. God bless that wound—here on his manly chest.

og: A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse.  Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaubed in blood,  All in gore blood. I swoonèd at the sight.
t: A pitiful corpse, a bloody, pitiful corpse. Pale, pale as ashes and covered in blood. Gory with blood. I fainted at the sight of it.

og: O, break, my heart, poor bankrupt, break at once!  To prison, eyes, ne’er look on liberty.
t: Oh, my poor, bankrupt heart is breaking. Go to prison, eyes, so you will never again be free to look at the world.

og: Vile earth, to earth resign. End motion here,  And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier.
t: I’ll bury my body in the earth, where it will lie motionless and share a single coffin with Romeo.

og: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!O courteous Tybalt! Honest gentleman!That ever I should live to see thee dead.
t: Oh Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I ever had! Oh, well-mannered, honorable Tybalt! If only I had not lived long enough to see him die.

og: What storm is this that blows so contrary?  Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?
t: What storm is this to cause so many different disasters? Has Romeo been killed, and Tybalt too?

og: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?
t: Tybalt, my dearest cousin, and Romeo who as my husband was even more dear to me?

og: Then, dreadful trumpet, sound the general doom!  For who is living if those two are gone?
t: May the last trumpet play to signal the onset of doomsday, because who could remain alive if those two are gone?

og: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.Romeo that killed him—he is banishèd.
t: Tybalt is dead. Romeo has been banished. It was Romeo who killed Tybalt, which is why he was banished.

og: O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
t: Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?

og: It did, it did. Alas the day, it did.
t: It did, it did. Unfortunately, it did.

og: O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!  Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?  Beautiful tyrant! Fiend angelical!
t: Oh, he has a traitor’s heart hidden behind a pretty face! Did any dragon ever nest in such a pretty cave? He’s a beautiful tyrant! A fiendish angel!

og: Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!  Despisèd substance of divinest show,  Just opposite to what thou justly seem’st.  A damnèd saint, an honorable villain!
t: A raven hiding under the feathers of a dove! A lamb that kills like a wolf! A hateful reality hidden by a beautiful appearance. The exact opposite of what he seemed. He seemed like a saint, but should be damned! He’s a villain who seemed honorable!

og: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell  When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend  In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?
t: Oh nature, what were you doing in hell when you placed the soul of a devil in the paradise of such a perfect man?

og: Was ever book containing such vile matter  So fairly bound? Oh, that deceit should dwell  In such a gorgeous palace!
t: Has any book with such awful contents ever had a more beautiful cover? Oh, how could such betrayal hide in such a gorgeous body?

og: There’s no trust,  No faith, no honesty in men. All perjured,  All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers.
t: There is no trust, faith, or honesty in men. They all break their oaths. They’re all wicked. They all lie.

og: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.—  These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.  Shame come to Romeo!
t: Where’s my servant?—Get me some brandy—These griefs, these miseries, these sorrows make me old. Shame on Romeo!

og: Blistered be thy tongue  For such a wish! He was not born to shame.  Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit,  For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.
t: May blisters cover your tongue for making a wish like that! Romeo was not born to have anything to do with shame. Shame could never be connected to him, because he is destined only to experience great and total honor.

og: Sole monarch of the universal earth,  Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!
t: Oh, I was such a beast to condemn him.

og: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
t: You’re going to speak well of the man who killed your cousin?

og: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?  Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name,  When I, thy three hours’ wife, have mangled it?
t: Should I speak badly of my own husband? Ah, my poor husband, who will speak well of you when I, your wife of three hours, have been calling you such dreadful names?

og: But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?  That villain cousin would have killed my husband.
t: But why, you villain, did you kill my cousin? Because my villain of a cousin would have killed you, my husband.

og: Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring.  Your tributary drops belong to woe,  Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.
t: I refuse to cry. These tears which seem like sadness for Tybalt’s death are actually tears of joy that Romeo is still alive.

og: My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain,  And Tybalt’s dead, that would have slain my husband.  All this is comfort. Wherefore weep I then?
t: My husband, whom Tybalt would have killed, is alive. And Tybalt, who wanted to kill my husband, is dead. This is good news. So why am I crying?

og: Some word there was, worser than Tybalt’s death,  That murdered me. I would forget it fain,  But oh, it presses to my memory,  Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners’ minds.
t: Because there was news that’s even worse than that of Tybalt’s death. Worse news that kills me inside. I wish I could forget it, but it forces its way into my memory the way sins obsess guilty minds.

og: “Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”  That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd”  Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt’s death  Was woe enough, if it had ended there.
t: “Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.” That word “banished,” that single word “banished,” is worse than the death of ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt’s death would have been misery enough even if nothing else had happened.

og: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship  And needly will be ranked with other griefs,  Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,”  “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both,  Which modern lamentations might have moved?
t: Or, if misery loves company, and one grief must necessarily follow another, then it would have been better had the Nurse, after telling me that Tybalt was dead, then told me that my mother or my father, or even both, were gone.

og: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death,  “Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word,  Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,  All slain, all dead. “Romeo is banishèd.”
t: That would have pushed me into normal feelings of grief. But to tell me that Tybalt’s is dead and then say, “Romeo has been banished.” To say that is the same as saying that my father, my mother, Tybalt, Romeo, and Juliet have all been killed, are all dead. “Romeo has been banished.”

og: There is no end, no limit, measure, bound,  In that word’s death. No words can that woe sound. Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?
t: The death contained in those four words is infinite, unmeasurable. No words can express that misery. Where are my father and mother, Nurse?

og: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse. Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
t: Crying over Tybalt’s corpse. Will you join them? I’ll bring you there.

og: Wash they his wounds with tears? Mine shall be spent  When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.  Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled,  Both you and I, for Romeo is exiled.
t: Do they wash Tybalt’s wounds with their tears? My tears will still be flowing because of Romeo’s banishment when their tears for Tybalt have gone dry. Take this rope ladder, this poor rope ladder made useless because Romeo has been exiled.

og: He made you for a highway to my bed,  But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.
t: He made this ladder to be his passageway to my bed, but I am a virgin and now will die a virgin and a widow.

og: Come, cords.—Come, Nurse. I’ll to my wedding bed.  And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
t: Come with me, rope ladder. Come with me, Nurse. I’m going to my wedding bed. Death, not Romeo, will take my virginity!

og: Hie to your chamber. I’ll find Romeo  To comfort you. I wot well where he is.
t: Go to your bedroom. I’ll go bring Romeo to comfort you. I know where he is.

og: Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.  I’ll to him. He is hid at Lawrence’ cell.
t: Pay attention: your Romeo will be here tonight. I’ll get him. He’s hiding in Friar Lawrence’s cell.

og: O, find him! Give this ring to my true knight, And bid him come to take his last farewell.
t: Oh, go and find him! Give this ring to my true knight. And tell him to come see me to say a final goodbye.

og: Romeo, come forth. Come forth, thou fearful man.Affliction is enamoured of thy parts,And thou art wedded to calamity.
t: Romeo, come here. Come here, you frightened man. Trouble follows you, and you’re married to catastrophe.

og: Father, what news? What is the Prince’s doom? What sorrow craves acquaintance at my handThat I yet know not?
t: Father, what’s the news? Did the Prince state how I am to be punished? What unknown suffering is coming for me?

og: Too familiarIs my dear son with such sour company.I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
t: My dear son, you’re too familiar with suffering. I do have news for you about the Prince’s punishment for you.

og: What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?
t: Is it anything less than my death?

og: A gentler judgment vanished from his lips:Not body’s death, but body’s banishment.
t: His judgment was gentler than that. You won’t be executed, but will be banished from Verona.

og: Ha, banishment! Be merciful, say “death,”For exile hath more terror in his look,Much more than death. Do not say “banishment.”
t: Banishment! Be merciful: say “death.” Exile is much worse to me than death. Don’t say “banishment.”

og: Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
t: You are banished from Verona. Be patient, the world is big and anything can happen.

og: There is no world without Verona walls  But purgatory, torture, hell itself.  Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world,  And world’s exile is death.
t: The world outside Verona’s walls is like purgatory, torture, hell itself. Being banished from Verona is the same as being banished from the world, and being banished from the world is the same as death.

og: Then “banishèd,”  Is death mistermed. Calling death “banishment,”  Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax  And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
t: Banishment is just a different name for death. So telling me that I’m banished is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while murdering me.

og: O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness!  Thy fault our law calls death,
t: Oh, deadly sin! Oh, you rude, unthankful child! Your crime is punishable by death,

og: but the kind Prince,  Taking thy part, hath rushed aside the law,  And turned that black word “death” to “banishment.”
t: but the Prince in his kindness defended you, and bypassed the law by replacing death with banishment.

og: This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.
t: This is mercy, but you can’t see it.

og: ‘Tis torture and not mercy. Heaven is here,  Where Juliet lives, and every cat and dog  And little mouse, every unworthy thing,  Live here in heaven and may look on her,  But Romeo may not.
t: It’s torture, not mercy. Heaven is in Verona because this is where Juliet lives. Every cat and dog and little mouse, every unworthy creature, that lives in Verona lives in heaven because it can see her. But I won’t be able to.

og: More validity,  More honorable state, more courtship lives  In carrion flies than Romeo.
t: Carrion-eating flies will have more vitality, a more blessed existence, and more romance than I will.

og: They may seize  On the white wonder of dear Juliet’s hand  And steal immortal blessing from her lips,  Who even in pure and vestal modesty,  Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin.
t: They can touch Juliet’s white hand and can steal kisses from her sweet lips, which—though she is a pure virgin—blush when they touch each other because they think it’s a sin.

og: But Romeo may not. He is banishèd.  Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.  They are free men, but I am banishèd.  And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?
t: But Romeo can’t touch her hand or kiss her. Flies can kiss her, but I must fly from the city. Flies are free, but I’ve been banished. Do you still argue that exile isn’t death?

og: Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife,  No sudden mean of death, though ne’er so mean,  But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!  O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.
t: You didn’t have some poison, a sharpened knife, or some other weapon that you could have used to kill me quickly, nothing so disgraceful, other than banishment? Oh Friar, damned souls use the word “banishment” to describe hell.

og: Howling attends it. How hast thou the heart,  Being a divine, a ghostly confessor,  A sin-absolver, and my friend professed,  To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?
t: They howl the word. How, as a priest, confessor, and my friend, can you have the heart to say to me the word “banished?”

og: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.
t: You silly madman, listen to me for a second.

og: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
t: Now you’re just going to talk again about banishment.

og: I’ll give thee armor to keep off that word— Adversity’s sweet milk, philosophy—To comfort thee though thou art banishèd.
t: I’ll protect you from that word by using the cure for adversity—philosophy—which will comfort you even though you’ve been banished.

og: Yet “banishèd”? Hang up philosophy!
t: In the face of banishment, let philosophy be hanged!

og: Unless philosophy can make a Juliet,  Displant a town, reverse a prince’s doom,  It helps not, it prevails not. Talk no more.
t: Unless philosophy can create a Juliet, move an entire town to a new place, or reverse a prince’s punishment, it can’t help me. Stop talking.

og: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
t: Ah, I’ve discovered that madmen are deaf.

og: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
t: Why should madmen hear, when wise men can’t see?

og: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
t: Let me discuss your situation with you.

og: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel.  Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love,  An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd,
t: You can’t talk about something you don’t feel. If you were as young as I am, in love with Juliet, married to her for just an hour, and had murdered Tybalt

og: Doting like me, and like me banishèd,  Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair  And fall upon the ground, as I do now,
t: ...If you loved her as I do and were banished as I am, then you could talk about it. Though instead you might tear out your hair and fall to the ground the way I do right now

og: Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
t: in order to measure out your grave.

og: Arise. One knocks. Good Romeo, hide thyself.
t: Get up. Someone’s knocking. Hide, good Romeo.

og: Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans,Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.
t: The only way I’ll hide is if my heartsick groans produce a mist that covers me from people’s searching eyes.

og: Hark, how they knock!—Who’s there?—Romeo, arise. Thou wilt be taken.—Stay awhile.—Stand up.
t: They knock again!—Who’s there?—Romeo, stand up. They’ll catch you.— Hold on a moment.—Romeo, stand up.

og: Run to my study.—By and by!—God’s will,What simpleness is this!—I come, I come.
t: Hide in my study.—Just a minute—For the love of God, don’t be so stupid! I’m coming. I’m coming.

og: Who knocks so hard? Whence come you? What’s your will?
t: Who is it that is knocking so hard? Where do you come from? What do you want?

og: Let me come in, and you shall know my errand. I come from Lady Juliet.
t: Let me in, and I’ll tell you why I’m here. I come from Lady Juliet.

og: Welcome then.
t: Welcome, then.

og: O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar,Where is my lady’s lord? Where’s Romeo?
t: Oh, holy Friar. Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s husband? Where’s Romeo?

og: There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.
t: There, on the ground, drunk on his own tears.

og: Oh, he is even in my mistress’ case,  Just in her case. O woeful sympathy,  Piteous predicament!
t: He’s acting like Juliet, exactly like her. Oh awful sympathy! What a dreadful predicament!

og: Even so lies she,  Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.  Stand up, stand up. Stand, an you be a man.
t: She’s lying on the ground just like him, blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering. Stand up. Stand up. Stand up if you’re a man.

og: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.  Why should you fall into so deep an O?
t: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand. Why do you moan so terribly?

og: Nurse!
t: Nurse!

og: Ah sir, ah sir. Death’s the end of all.
t: Well, sir, well. Death comes for everybody.

og: Spakest thou of Juliet? How is it with her?  Doth she not think me an old murderer,  Now I have stained the childhood of our joy  With blood removed but little from her own?
t: What of Juliet? How is she? Does she think that I’m a cold-blooded murderer because I corrupted our newfound love by killing her relative?

og: Where is she? And how doth she? And what says  My concealed lady to our canceled love?
t: Where is she? How is she? What does my wife say about our love?

og: Oh, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps,  And now falls on her bed, and then starts up,
t: Oh, she says nothing, sir. Instead she weeps and weeps. She falls on her bed, then starts to get up,

og: And “Tybalt” calls, and then on Romeo cries,  And then down falls again.
t: then calls out Tybalt’s name and then your name, and then she falls back down on the bed.

og: As if that name,  Shot from the deadly level of a gun,  Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand  Murdered her kinsman.
t: She calls out my name as if it were a bullet that had been shot from a gun and murdered her, just as I murdered her cousin.

og: O, tell me, Friar, tell me,  In what vile part of this anatomy  Doth my name lodge? Tell me, that I may sack  The hateful mansion.
t: Tell me, Friar, in what vile part of my body does my name rest? Tell me, so I can cut it out of myself.

og: Hold thy desperate hand.  Art thou a man? Thy form cries out thou art.  Thy tears are womanish. Thy wild acts denote  The unreasonable fury of a beast.  Unseemly woman in a seeming man,  And ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!
t: Stop! Don’t do anything out of desperation. Are you a man? You look like a man. But your tears are womanly. Your wildness is like the irrational fury of a beast. You’re like an inappropriate woman hiding within a man, or, even worse, a shameful beast hiding within a half-man, half-woman!

og: Thou hast amazed me. By my holy order,  I thought thy disposition better tempered.  Hast thou slain Tybalt? Wilt thou slay thyself,  And slay thy lady that in thy life lives  By doing damnèd hate upon thyself?
t: You amaze me. By my holy order, I swear I thought you were stronger and more stable than this. Have you killed Tybalt? Will you kill yourself, and in performing such a sin also kill your wife, who shares your life?

og: Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?  Since birth and heaven and earth, all three do meet  In thee at once, which thou at once wouldst lose?  Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit,
t: Why are you ranting about your birth, the heavens, and the earth? You are made of the joining of all three, and now want nothing to do with them? You bring shame to your body, your love, and your mind.

og: Which, like a usurer, abound’st in all  And usest none in that true use indeed  Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.  Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,  Digressing from the valor of a man;
t: You are blessed with all three, but like a moneylender you do not use your body, love, or mind for their true purpose. Without honor or nobility, your body is just a wax figure.

og: Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,  Killing that love which thou hast vowed to cherish;  Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,  Misshapen in the conduct of them both,  Like powder in a skill-less soldier’s flask,  Is set afire by thine own ignorance;  And thou dismembered with thine own defence.
t: The love that you swore is just a hollow lie, since you now threaten to kill the love that you vowed to cherish. Your mind, that key to both your body and your love, has failed to handle both of them. You’re like an unskilled soldier who accidentally explodes his own gunpowder because he does not know how to use it: you end up killing yourself with the very thing meant to protect you.

og: What, rouse thee, man! Thy Juliet is alive,  For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead—  There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,  But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.  The law that threatened death becomes thy friend  And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
t: Now get a hold of yourself, man! Your Juliet is alive (for whose sake you were just threatening to kill yourself). That is something to be happy about. Tybalt tried to kill you, but you killed Tybalt. That is something to be happy about. The law that promised death for you was mercifully changed into exile—another thing to be happy about.

og: A pack of blessings light upon thy back,  Happiness courts thee in her best array,  But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench,  Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.
t: You have been blessed multiple times, and are surrounded by brightest happiness. But like a misbehaved and sullen girl, you’re pouting about your bad luck and thwarted love.

og: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.  Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.  Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.
t: Now listen to me: those who act the way you are acting now die miserable. Go, be with your love, as we planned. Climb up to her bedroom and comfort her.

og: But look thou stay not till the watch be set,  For then thou canst not pass to Mantua,  Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time  To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,  Beg pardon of the Prince,
t: But make sure to leave before the watchmen take their positions, because they will stop you before you can escape to Mantua. You’ll live in Mantua until we can announce your marriage publicly, make peace between your families, and beg the Prince to pardon you.

og: and call thee back  With twenty hundred thousand times more joy  Than thou went’st forth in lamentation.—  Go before, Nurse.
t: Then we’ll welcome you back with twenty thousand times more joy than you’ll feel when leaving. Nurse, go to Juliet before Romeo follows.

og: Commend me to thy lady,  And bid her hasten all the house to bed,  Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.  Romeo is coming.
t: Give my regards to your lady, and tell her to hurry everybody in her house to bed. It's likely that their sorrow will make them want to go to sleep, anyway. Romeo is coming.

og: O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel. Oh, what learning is!My lord, I’ll tell my lady you will come.
t: Oh Lord, I could stay here all night listening to good advice like yours. Education is amazing!

og: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
t: Do that, and tell my beloved to be ready to scold me.

og: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.     Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
t: Here, sir, take this ring she asked me to give you.  Hurry, it’s getting late.

og: How well my comfort is revived by this!
t: This ring lifts my spirits!
