og: Oh, here  Will I set up my everlasting rest,  And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars  From this world-wearied flesh.
t: Oh, I’ll rest here forever and escape the control of the bad fortune that has plagued my body.

og: Eyes, look your last.  Arms, take your last embrace. And, lips, O you  The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss  A dateless bargain to engrossing death.
t: Eyes, see for the last time! Arms, make your last embrace! And lips, you doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss the infinite deal I have made with death.

og: Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide.  Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on  The dashing rocks thy seasick, weary bark.  Here’s to my love!
t: Come, bitter transport. Come, unpleasant guide! You desperate pilot, crash this seasick and weary ship into the rocks. Here’s to my love!

og: O true apothecary,  Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
t: Oh, honest pharmacist, your drugs work quickly. With this kiss, I die.

og: Saint Francis be my speed! How oft tonightHave my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?
t: Saint Francis, speed my steps! How often tonight have my old feet stumbled on gravestones! Who’s there?

og: Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
t: I am a friend who knows you well.

og: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,  What torch is yond that vainly lends his light  To grubs and eyeless skulls?
t: God bless you! Good friend, tell me why that torch is lying over there for no good reason? It's offering its light to no one but worms and eyeless skulls.

og: As I discern,  It burneth in the Capels’ monument.
t: As far as I can tell, it seems to be burning in the Capulet tomb.

og: It doth so, holy sir, and there’s my master,One that you love.
t: Holy father, it is there along with my master, whom you love.

og: Who is it?
t: Who is it?

og: Romeo.
t: Romeo.

og: How long hath he been there?
t: How long has he been there?

og: Full half an hour.
t: For a full half hour.

og: Go with me to the vault.
t: Go with me to the tomb.

og: I dare not, sir.  My master knows not but I am gone hence,
t: I don’t dare, sir. My master thinks I’ve gone from here.

og: And fearfully did menace me with death  If I did stay to look on his intents.
t: He threatened to kill me if I stayed to watch his actions.

og: Stay, then. I’ll go alone. Fear comes upon me.Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.
t: Stay, then. I’ll go alone. Now I’m frightened. Oh, I’m very worried something terrible and unfortunate has happened.

og: As I did sleep under this yew tree here,I dreamt my master and another fought,And that my master slew him.
t: As I slept under this yew-tree, I dreamed that my master fought someone else, and that my master killed him.

og: Romeo!—  Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains  The stony entrance of the sepulcher?
t: Romeo! Oh no! What’s this blood staining the stony entrance of this tomb?

og: What mean these masterless and gory swords  To lie discolored by this place of peace?
t: Why are these swords—discolored by gore and blood—lying abandoned here, in this place of peace?

og: Romeo! O, pale!—Who else? What, Paris too?  And steeped in blood?—Ah, what an unkind hour  Is guilty of this lamentable chance!  The lady stirs.
t: Romeo! Oh, he’s pale! Who else? What, Paris too? And covered in blood? Ah, during what cruel hour did this sad turn of events occur? The lady moves.

og: O comfortable Friar! Where is my lord?
t: Oh comforting friar! Where is my husband?

og: I do remember well where I should be,  And there I am.  Where is my Romeo?
t: I remember well where I should be, and here I am. Where is my Romeo?

og: I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest  Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.  A greater power than we can contradict  Hath thwarted our intents.
t: I hear a noise. Lady, come with me from this tomb of death, sickness, and unnatural sleep. A power greater than us has ruined our plans.

og: Come, come away.  Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead,  And Paris too. Come, I’ll dispose of thee  Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.
t: Come, come away. Your husband lies dead, resting against your chest. Paris is dead too. Come, I’ll bring you to join a sisterhood of holy nuns.

og: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming.  Come, go, good Juliet. I dare no longer stay.
t: Don’t wait here asking questions. The watch is coming. Come, come with me, good Juliet. I dare not stay any longer.

og: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.—  What’s here? A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?  Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.—
t: Go, go away. I’m not leaving.What’s this? A cup, held in my true love’s hand? I see poison has caused his death.

og: O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop  To help me after? I will kiss thy lips.  Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,  To make me die with a restorative.
t: How selfish, drinking it all, not leaving a drop to help me follow after you. I’ll kiss your lips. Maybe I’ll be lucky and there’s still some poison on your lips, a bit of medicine that will return me to my Romeo.

og: Thy lips are warm.
t: Your lips are warm.

og: Lead, boy. Which way?
t: Lead on, boy. Which way?

og: Yea, noise? Then I’ll be brief. O happy dagger,This is thy sheath. There rust and let me die.
t: What's that noise? I’ll act fast. Oh, what luck: here’s a dagger! I’ll be your sheath. Rust inside my body, and let me die.

og: This is the place. There, where the torch doth burn.
t: This is the place. There, where that torch is burning.

og: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.Go, some of you. Whoe’er you find, attach.
t: The ground is bloody. Search the graveyard. Go, a few of you, and arrest anyone you find.

og: Pitiful sight! Here lies the county slain,  And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead,  Who here hath lain these two days buried.—
t: What a pitiful sight! The count lies here, dead. And Juliet is bleeding. Her body is still warm even though she has been dead and buried for the last two days.

og: Go, tell the Prince. Run to the Capulets.  Raise up the Montagues.  Some others search.
t: Go, tell the Prince. Run to the Capulets. Wake up the Montagues. Have some others search.

og: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie,But the true ground of all these piteous woesWe cannot without circumstance descry.
t: We see the ground on which these bodies lie, but we won’t be able to figure out the true cause of all these awful events without an investigation.

og: Here’s Romeo’s man. We found him in the churchyard.
t: Here’s Romeo’s servant. We found him in the churchyard.

og: Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.
t: Hold him securely until the Prince arrives.

og: Here is a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.We took this mattock and this spade from him As he was coming from this churchyard’s side.
t: Here’s a friar who’s trembling, sighing, and weeping. We took this pickax and this shovel from him as he was leaving the graveyard.

og: A great suspicion. Stay the friar too.
t: Very suspicious. Hold the friar too.

og: What misadventure is so early upThat calls our person from our morning rest?
t: What disaster has occurred so early in the morning that it forces me from my bed?

og: What should it be, that they shriek so abroad?
t: What has happened to cause everyone to start shrieking?

og: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,”Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all runWith open outcry toward our monument.
t: Some people in the street are crying “Romeo.” Others cry “Juliet,” and still others “Paris.” They’re all running and screaming towards our tomb.

og: What fear is this which startles in our ears?
t: What terror has occurred to result in all this startling noise?

og: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain, And Romeo dead, and Juliet, dead before,Warm and new killed.
t: Prince, here lies Count Paris, killed. And Romeo dead. And Juliet, who was dead before, but is warm like someone newly killed.

og: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
t: Find out how this foul murder came to happen.

og: Here is a friar, and slaughtered Romeo’s man,With instruments upon them fit to open These dead men’s tombs.
t: Here is a friar, and dead Romeo’s servant. They’re carrying tools for opening a tomb.

og: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!  This dagger hath mista’en
t: Oh heavens! Oh, wife, look at how our daughter bleeds! That dagger is in the wrong place.

og: —for, lo, his house  Is empty on the back of Montague,  And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.
t: It should be in the empty sheath on the back of that Montague, but instead is misplaced, sheathed in my daughter’s chest.

og: O me! This sight of death is as a bell,That warns my old age to a sepulcher.
t: Woe is me! Seeing my daughter dead is like a warning bell of my own imminent death.

og: Come, Montague, for thou art early upTo see thy son and heir now early down.
t: Come, Montague. You’re up early to see your son and heir killed at too young an age.

og: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight. Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.What further woe conspires against mine age?
t: My liege, my wife died tonight. Her sadness about my son’s exile stopped her breath. What further misery must I endure in my old age?

og: Look, and thou shalt see.
t: Look, and you’ll see.

og: O thou untaught! What manners is in this,To press before thy father to a grave?
t: Oh, you rude boy! What terrible manners to die before your father.

og: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,  Till we can clear these ambiguities
t: Quiet your outrage for a time, until we can clear up the remaining uncertainties about the cause of all this.

og: And know their spring, their head, their true descent,  And then will I be general of your woes,  And lead you even to death.
t: Once we do know what happened, I will lead you in expressing our pain, all the way to our deaths.

og: Meantime forbear,  And let mischance be slave to patience.—  Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
t: In the meantime, hold on, and let your patience control your desire to act. Bring forth the men under suspicion.

og: I am the greatest, able to do least,  Yet most suspected, as the time and place  Doth make against me, of this direful murder.
t: I am the most suspected, and least able to defend myself, because I was here at the time of this terrible murder.

og: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge,  Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
t: Here I stand, to be questioned and punished. I have already condemned myself.

og: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
t: Then tell us immediately what you know about all this.

og: I will be brief, for my short date of breath  Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
t: I’ll be brief, because the time I have left to live is not long enough to tell a long story.

og: Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet,  And she, there dead, that Romeo’s faithful wife.
t: Romeo, who lies there dead, was Juliet’s husband. And she, who lies there dead, was Romeo’s faithful wife.

og: I married them, and their stol’n marriage day  Was Tybalt’s doomsday, whose untimely death  Banished the new-made bridegroom from the city—  For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.
t: I married them. Their secret wedding day was the same day Tybalt died. His untimely death led to the banishment of the bridegroom. Juliet was distraught not over Tybalt’s death, but rather over Romeo’s banishment.

og: You, to remove that siege of grief from her,  Betrothed and would have married her perforce  To County Paris. Then comes she to me,  And with wild looks bid me devise some mean  To rid her from this second marriage,  Or in my cell there would she kill herself.
t: To end her grief, you arranged for her to marry Count Paris. At that point she came to me, and, looking wild, threatened to kill herself unless I came up with a plan to help her escape this second marriage.

og: Then gave I her, so tutored by my art,  A sleeping potion, which so took effect  As I intended, for it wrought on her  The form of death.
t: Then I gave her a special sleeping potion that, as I had planned, made it seem as if she had died.

og: Meantime I writ to Romeo,  That he should hither come as this dire night,  To help to take her from her borrowed grave,  Being the time the potion’s force should cease.
t: Meanwhile, I wrote to Romeo to tell him to come here tonight, this awful night, to help get her out of her temporary grave when the sleeping potion wore off.

og: But he which bore my letter, Friar John,  Was stayed by accident, and yesternight  Returned my letter back. Then all alone  At the prefixèd hour of her waking  Came I to take her from her kindred’s vault,
t: But the man who carried my letter, Friar John, was stopped by an accident, and returned my letter to me last night. So at the time when Juliet was scheduled to wake up, I came here alone to take her out of her family’s tomb.

og: Meaning to keep her closely at my cell  Till I conveniently could send to Romeo,  But when I came, some minute ere the time  Of her awakening, here untimely lay  The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.
t: My plan was to hide her in my cell until I could get word to Romeo. But when I arrived, just a few minutes before Juliet awoke, Paris and Romeo were already here, lying dead.

og: She wakes, and I entreated her come forth,  And bear this work of heaven with patience.  But then a noise did scare me from the tomb,
t: She woke up, and I begged her to come out of the tomb with me and bear this work of God with patience. But then a noise frightened me, and I ran from the tomb.

og: And she, too desperate, would not go with me,  But, as it seems, did violence on herself.  All this I know, and to the marriage  Her Nurse is privy.
t: She was too desperate to leave with me, and, it seems, she killed herself. I know all of this. And her Nurse knows about the marriage.

og: And if aught in this  Miscarried by my fault, let my old life  Be sacrificed some hour before his time  Unto the rigor of severest law.
t: If any of this misfortune is my fault, let me be sacrificed and punished under the strictest law.

og: We still have known thee for a holy man.— Where’s Romeo’s man? What can he say in this?
t: We have always known you to be a holy man. Where is Romeo’s servant? What does he say about all this?

og: I brought my master news of Juliet’s death,  And then in post he came from Mantua  To this same place, to this same monument.
t: I brought my master news of Juliet’s death. And then with great haste he rode from Mantua to this tomb.

og: This letter he early bid me give his father,  And threatened me with death, going in the vault,  If I departed not and left him there.
t: Early this morning he told me to give this letter to his father. Then he threatened to kill me if I did not leave when he went into the tomb.

og: Give me the letter. I will look on it.    Where is the county’s page, that raised the watch?—Sirrah, what made your master in this place?
t: Give me the letter. I’ll read it.  Where is the count’s page, who called the watch? Boy, what was your master doing here?

og: He came with flowers to strew his lady’s grave,  And bid me stand aloof, and so I did.
t: He came with flowers to put on his lady’s grave. He asked me to stand apart from him, and so I did.

og: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb,  And by and by my master drew on him,  And then I ran away to call the watch.
t: Soon after someone with a torch came to open the tomb. One thing led to another, and my master drew his sword to fight him. That’s when I ran away to call the watch.

og: This letter doth make good the friar’s words,  Their course of love, the tidings of her death.  And here he writes that he did buy a poison  Of a poor ‘pothecary, and therewithal  Came to this vault to die and lie with Juliet.
t: This letter corroborates the friar’s story. It describes the course of their love and how he heard of her death. Then he writes that he bought poison from a poor pharmacist and came to this tomb to die and lie with Juliet.

og: Where be these enemies?—Capulet! Montague!  See what a scourge is laid upon your hate,  That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love!
t: Where are these enemies? Capulet! Montague! Do you see how your hate has cursed you? Heaven has in response conspired to kill your joys with love.

og: And I, for winking at your discords, too  Have lost a brace of kinsmen. All are punished.
t: And because I did not take a firm hand against your feud, I’ve lost two of my family members as well. Everyone is punished.

og: O brother Montague, give me thy hand.This is my daughter’s jointure, for no moreCan I demand.
t: Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand. This handshake is my daughter’s dowry. I can ask you for nothing more.

og: But I can give thee more,  For I will raise her statue in pure gold,
t: But I can give you more. I’ll raise a golden statue of her.

og: That whiles Verona by that name is known,  There shall no figure at such rate be set  As that of true and faithful Juliet.
t: So long as this city is called Verona, there will be no figure praised more than that of true and faithful Juliet.

og: As rich shall Romeo’s by his lady’s lie,Poor sacrifices of our enmity.
t: The statue of Romeo I’ll make to lie beside Juliet will be just as rich. Our hate was not worth their sacrifice.

og: A glooming peace this morning with it brings.  The sun for sorrow will not show his head.
t: This morning brings a gloomy peace with it. The sun won't shine because of his sadness.

og: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things;  Some shall be pardoned, and some punishèd;
t: Go forward, to talk more about these sad things. Some will be pardoned, and some will be punished.

og: For never was a story of more woe  Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.
t: For there was never a sadder story than this one of Juliet and her Romeo.

og: Now is the winter of our discontent  Made glorious summer by this son of York,
t: Now the winter of our troubles has been transformed into glorious summer by the ascension of my brother, King Edward IV, son of the house of York.

og: And all the clouds that loured upon our house  In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
t: All the clouds that had descended over our family have now been banished and returned to the sea.

og: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths,  Our bruisèd arms hung up for monuments,
t: Now we wear wreaths of victory on our foreheads, and we've hung up our armor as decoration.

og: Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,  Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
t: We've exchanged the sound of our battle trumpets for the sound of joyful greetings, and our death marches have become stately dances.

og: Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front;
t: The grim, warlike expressions on our faces have smoothed.

og: And now, instead of mounting barbèd steeds  To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,  He capers nimbly in a lady’s chamber  To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
t: And instead of charging on armored horses to frighten our opponents, we now dance in ladies' chambers to seductive songs on the lute.

og: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,  Nor made to court an amorous looking glass;
t: But as for me, I am not made for such games of love, or to admire myself in a mirror.

og: I, that am rudely stamped and want love’s majesty  To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
t: I was badly made, and I lack the good looks to strut in front of passing girls.

og: I, that am curtailed of this fair proportion,  Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
t: Nature has cheated me out of handsome features and proper proportions.

og: Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time  Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,  And that so lamely and unfashionable  That dogs bark at me as I halt by them—
t: I was born deformed, unfinished, and born prematurely. I was barely half-created when I came into the world, and left so lame and misshapen that dogs bark at me as I limp past them.

og: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,  Have no delight to pass away the time,
t: In such delicate times of peace, I have nothing to do

og: Unless to see my shadow in the sun  And descant on mine own deformity.
t: No joys help me pass the time, unless I want to see my own shadow in the sun and make speeches about my deformity.

og: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover  To entertain these fair well-spoken days,  I am determinèd to prove a villain
t: Therefore, since I cannot amuse myself by being a lover during these peaceful days, I am determined to become a villain.

og: And hate the idle pleasures of these days.  Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,  By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,
t: I have hatched plots and put dangerous plans into action, using prophecies made while drunk; slander; and stories about dreams

og: To set my brother Clarence and the king  In deadly hate, the one against the other;
t: in order to set my brother George, Duke of Clarence, against my other brother, the king, so that they hate each other.

og: And if King Edward be as true and just  As I am subtle, false, and treacherous,
t: If King Edward is as true as I am clever, false, and treacherous,

og: This day should Clarence closely be mewed up  About a prophecy which says that “G”  Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.
t: then this very day Clarence will be imprisoned because of a prophecy that "G" will murder Edward's children.

og: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul. Here Clarence comes.
t: But, you thoughts, hide yourselves deep down in my soul, for here comes Clarence.

og: Brother, good day. What means this armèd guardThat waits upon your Grace?
t: Good day, brother. Why do you have all these armed guards accompanying you, your Grace?

og: His majesty,Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
t: His Majesty was so concerned for my personal safety that he appointed this escort to conduct me to the Tower.

og: Upon what cause?
t: You're being arrested? For what reason?

og: Because my name is George.
t: Because my name is George.

og: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours.
t: Alas, my lord, that's no fault of yours.

og: He should, for that, commit your godfathers.
t: If that's the problem, then our brother, the king, should arrest those who named you instead.

og: O, belike his majesty hath some intent  That you shall be new christened in the Tower.
t: Or maybe his Majesty intends to baptize you and rename you in the Tower.

og: But what’s the matter, Clarence? May I know?
t: But what's the reason for this, Clarence? Will you tell me?

og: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest  As yet I do not.
t: Yes, Richard, I'll inform you when I know—but right now I have no idea.

og: But, as I can learn,  He hearkens after prophecies and dreams,
t: As far as I can tell, the king has been putting a lot of trust in prophecies and dreams lately.

og: And from the crossrow plucks the letter "G",  And says a wizard told him that by “G”  His issue disinherited should be.
t: And he picked the letter "G" from the alphabet, and says that a wizard told him that "G" will steal the throne from his children.

og: And for my name of George begins with "G",  It follows in his thought that I am he.
t: And my name, George, begins with "G," so he thinks that the prophecy refers to me.

og: These, as I learn, and such like toys as these  Have moved his Highness to commit me now.
t: Because of this, along with other trivial reasons, his Highness feels compelled to arrest me.

og: Why, this it is when men are ruled by women.  'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower.
t: Well, this is what happens when men are ruled by women. It isn't the king who's sending you to the Tower—

og: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she  That tempers him to this extremity.
t: it's his wife, Lady Elizabeth Grey. She's the one who persuaded him to take such an extreme action.

og: Was it not she and that good man of worship,  Anthony Woodeville, her brother there,  That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,
t: Didn't she and her brother, Anthony Woodeville, make the king send Lord Hastings to the Tower?

og: From whence this present day he is delivered?  We are not safe, Clarence. We are not safe.
t: He was released only today. We are not safe, Clarence. We are not safe.

og: By heaven, I think there is no man is secure  But the queen’s kindred and night-walking heralds  That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.
t: By heaven, I think the only people who are safe are the queen's relatives, and the secret messengers who travel between the king and his mistress, Jane Shore.

og: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant  Lord Hastings was to her for his delivery?
t: Didn't you hear how Lord Hastings had to beg Miss Shore in order to get released?

og: Humbly complaining to her deity  Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty.
t: Yes, Lord Hastings gained his liberty by humbly bowing down to that goddess.

og: I’ll tell you what: I think it is our way,  If we will keep in favor with the king,  To be her men and wear her livery.
t: I'll tell you what: if we want to stay in the king's favor, it would be best if we act like Miss Shore's servants too.

og: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,  Since that our brother dubbed them gentlewomen,  Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.
t: Ever since our brother declared that Miss Shore and the queen are nobility, they've become great gossips in the court.

og: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me.
t: I beg your pardon, your Graces.

og: His majesty hath straitly given in charge  That no man shall have private conference,  Of what degree soever, with his brother.
t: His Majesty the king has strictly ordered that no one can speak privately with your brother Clarence, no matter their social rank.

og: Even so. An please your Worship, Brakenbury,  You may partake of anything we say.
t: Is that so? If it please your Worship, Brakenbury, you can listen to anything we say.

og: We speak no treason, man. We say the king  Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen  Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous.
t: We're not plotting any treason, man. We say that the king is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen is well advanced in years, beautiful, and not jealous.

og: We say that Shore’s wife hath a pretty foot,  A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue,  And that the queen’s kindred are made gentlefolks.
t: We say that Mister Shore's wife has pretty feet, cherry lips, lovely eyes, and a pleasant voice. We say that the queen's relatives have all become nobles.

og: How say you, sir? Can you deny all this?
t: What do you say to that, sir? Can you deny any of this?

og: With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.
t: I have naught to do with this, my lord.

og: Naught to do with Mistress Shore? I tell thee, fellow,He that doth naught with her, excepting one, Were best he do it secretly, alone.
t: "Naught" to do with Miss Shore? I tell you, fellow, there's only one man who can do "naught" with her. And if anyone else is doing it, he'd best do it secretly.

og: What one, my lord?
t: Who is that, my lord?

og: Her husband, knave. Wouldst thou betray me?
t: Her husband, fool. Are you going to tell on me?

og: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
t: I beg your Grace to forgive me, and now please stop talking to the Duke of Clarence.

og: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
t: We know your orders, Brakenbury. And we'll obey.

og: We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.—  Brother, farewell.
t: We are the queen's lowly subjects, and we must obey. Farewell, brother.

og: I will unto the king,  And whatsoe'er you will employ me in,  Were it to call King Edward’s widow “sister,”  I will perform it to enfranchise you.
t: I will go to the king and do whatever you need me to do to get you released, even if it means calling King Edward's wife "sister."

og: Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood  Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
t: And just so you know, our brother's disgraceful conduct towards you upsets me more than you can imagine.

og: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
t: I know it doesn't make either of us very happy.

og: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long.I will deliver you or else lie for you.Meantime, have patience.
t: Well, your imprisonment won't be for long. I'll free you, or else go to prison in your place. In the meantime, have patience.

og: I must perforce. Farewell.
t: I have no choice in the matter. Farewell.

og: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
t: Go, walk down the path from which you'll never return.

og: Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so  That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,  If heaven will take the present at our hands.
t: Stupid, plain Clarence, I love you so much that I'll soon send your soul to heaven—if heaven will accept any presents from me.

og: But who comes here? The new-delivered Hastings?
t: But who's this coming? The newly released Hastings?

og: Good time of day unto my gracious lord.
t: Good day to you, my gracious lord.

og: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain. Well are you welcome to the open air.How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?
t: And the same to you, my good Lord Chamberlain. Welcome back to the open air. How have you tolerated imprisonment?

og: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanksThat were the cause of my imprisonment.
t: With patience,  as all prisoners must, noble lord. But I will live to thank those who imprisoned me, my lord, by taking revenge.

og: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too,For they that were your enemies are hisAnd have prevailed as much on him as you.
t: No doubt, no doubt. And so will Clarence, for the people who were your enemies are now his enemies, and they've overcome him just like they overcame you.

og: More pity that the eagle should be mewedWhile kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
t: It's a pity that the eagles should be caged while the buzzards are free to hunt.

og: What news abroad?
t: What's the news from outside the country?

og: No news so bad abroad as this at home:The king is sickly, weak and melancholy,And his physicians fear him mightily.
t: There's no foreign news as bad as the news at home: the king is sickly, weak, and depressed, and his physicians fear for his life.

og: Now, by Saint Paul, that news is bad indeed.
t: By Saint Paul, that is bad news indeed.

og: O, he hath kept an evil diet long,  And overmuch consumed his royal person.
t: Oh, the king has kept many bad habits all his life, and now they've consumed his health.

og: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.  Where is he, in his bed?
t: It's very sad to think about. Where is he, in his bed?

og: He is.
t: He is.

og: Go you before, and I will follow you.
t: Then you go ahead, and I will follow you.

og: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die  Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.
t: I hope the king won't survive. But he mustn't die until Clarence is sent off to heaven by the quickest route.

og: I’ll in to urge his hatred more to Clarence  With lies well steeled with weighty arguments,
t: I'll go in and incite the king to more hatred against Clarence, using lies backed up by sound reasoning.

og: And, if I fail not in my deep intent,  Clarence hath not another day to live;
t: And if I don't fail in my plan, then Clarence won't live even one more day.

og: Which done, God take King Edward to His mercy,  And leave the world for me to bustle in.
t: Once that's done, God can take King Edward to heaven as soon as he wants, and leave the world for me to run around in.

og: For then I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.  What though I killed her husband and her father?
t: For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter, Lady Anne Neville. What does it matter that I killed her husband and her father?

og: The readiest way to make the wench amends  Is to become her husband and her father;
t: The best way to make it up to the girl is to become her new husband and father.

og: The which will I, not all so much for love  As for another secret close intent  By marrying her which I must reach unto.
t: I'll do that then, not out of love for her, but because it's part of my secret plan.

og: But yet I run before my horse to market.  Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns.
t: But I'm getting ahead of myself. Clarence is still breathing. Edward still lives and reigns as king.

og: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
t: I can only count my gains when they're dead.

og: Set down, set down your honorable load,  If honor may be shrouded in a hearse,
t: Set down, set down your honorable load, men—if honor can be shrouded in a coffin—

og: Poor key-cold figure of a holy king,  Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster,  Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood,
t: Oh, you poor cold corpse of a holy king, you last remains of the house of Lancaster, you bloodless remnant of that royal blood!

og: Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost  To hear the lamentations of poor Anne,
t: If it's lawful to speak to your ghost, then listen to the sorrows of poor Anne.

og: Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered son,  Stabbed by the selfsame hand that made these wounds.
t: My husband was Edward—your slaughtered son—who was murdered by the same man who stabbed you.

og: Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life  I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.
t: Oh, let me pour my helpless tears into your wounds, those open windows that let your spirit escape.

og: O, cursèd be the hand that made these holes;  Cursèd the heart that had the heart to do it;  Cursèd the blood that let this blood from hence.
t: I curse the hand that made these holes in you. I curse the heart of the person who had the heart to do it. And I curse the blood of the man that shed your blood.

og: More direful hap betide that hated wretch  That makes us wretched by the death of thee  Than I can wish to wolves, to spiders, toads,  Or any creeping venomed thing that lives.
t: I hope evil fortunes fall upon that hateful man, the one who killed you and now makes me suffer. May his fate be worse than anything I would wish on wolves, spiders, toads, or any creeping venomous thing that lives.

og: If ever he have child, abortive be it,  Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,  Whose ugly and unnatural aspect  May fright the hopeful mother at the view,  And that be heir to his unhappiness.
t: If he ever has a child, may it be born premature and unnatural, and may its appearance be so ugly and monstrous that even its own hopeful mother will fear it.

og: If ever he have wife, let her be made  More miserable by the death of him  Than I am made by my poor lord and thee.—
t: That way, the child will inherit your murderer's own unhappiness. And if he ever has a wife, may she be more miserable at his death than I am now, mourning my husband and you, my father-in-law.

og: And still, as you are weary of this weight,Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry’s corse.
t: And whenever your burden grows too heavy, rest a while, and I will lament over King Henry's corpse.

og: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.
t: Stop, you who bear that corpse, and set down your load.

og: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds?
t: What evil magician has conjured up this devil to interrupt our sacred burial procession?

og: Villains, set down the corse or, by Saint Paul,I’ll make a corse of him that disobeys.
t: You base men, set down the corpse or, I swear by Saint Paul, I'll make corpses out of you.

og: My lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.
t: My lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.

og: Unmannered dog, stand thou when I command!—
t: Rude dog, halt when I command you to!

og: Advance thy halberd higher than my breast,  Or by Saint Paul I’ll strike thee to my foot  And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.
t: And raise your weapon so it isn't pointing at my chest, or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike you down and trample on you for your boldness, you beggar.

og: [to gentlemen and halberds]  What, do you tremble? Are you all afraid?  Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal,  And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.—
t: [To the gentlemen and guards] What, do you tremble at the sight of him? Are you all afraid? Alas, I don't blame you, for you're only mortal, and mortal eyes can't stand to look at the devil.

og: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.
t: Sweet saint, for goodness's sake, don't be so harsh.

og: Foul devil, for God’s sake, hence, and trouble us not,  For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,  Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
t: Foul devil, for God's sake, go away and leave us alone. You've made the pleasant earth into your hell, filling it with cursing cries and deep laments.

og: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,  Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
t: If you enjoy looking at your horrible deeds, then behold this example of your butchery.

og: O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds  Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh!—
t: Oh, gentlemen, see, see! Dead Henry's wounds have opened and are bleeding again!

og: Lady, you know no rules of charity,Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
t: Lady, you don't know the rules of charity, which transforms evil into good, and curses into blessings.

og: Villain, thou know’st not law of God nor man.No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
t: Villain, you don't know the laws of God or man. Even the fiercest beast has a touch of pity.

og: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
t: But I have no pity, so I must not be a beast.

og: O, wonderful, when devils tell the truth!
t: Oh, how amazing to hear a devil tell the truth!

og: More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
t: It's more amazing that an angel should be so angry.

og: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,  Of these supposèd crimes to give me leave  By circumstance but to acquit myself.
t: You divinely perfect woman, please allow me to clear myself of these crimes of which you've accused me.

og: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man,Of these known evils but to give me leave By circumstance to curse thy cursèd self.
t: You shapeless plague of a man, please allow me to curse your cursed self for the crimes I know you've committed.

og: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me haveSome patient leisure to excuse myself.
t: You who are more beautiful than words can say, give me some time and let me explain myself.

og: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst makeNo excuse current but to hang thyself.
t: You who are more awful than any heart could believe, the only explanation you can give is to go hang yourself.

og: By such despair I should accuse myself.
t: Such an act of despair would prove my guilt.

og: And by despairing shalt thou stand excusedFor doing worthy vengeance on thyselfThat didst unworthy slaughter upon others.
t: And such an act of despair would be a worthy act of revenge against yourself for slaughtering innocents.

og: Say that I slew them not.
t: Let's say that I didn't kill them.

og: Then say they were not slain. But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
t: Then we might as well say that they aren't dead. But, you devilish scoundrel, they are dead, and you killed them.

og: I did not kill your husband.
t: I did not kill your husband.

og: Why then, he is alive.
t: Well then, he must be alive.

og: Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edward’s hands.
t: No, he is dead, and Edward killed him.

og: In thy foul throat thou liest.
t: You're lying through your teeth.

og: Queen Margaret saw  Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood,  The which thou once didst bend against her breast,
t: Queen Margaret saw your murderous sword steaming with his blood—the same sword with which you once tried to kill her.

og: But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
t: She was only saved because your brothers restrained you.

og: I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue,That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
t: I was provoked by her lying tongue, which tried to lay guilt on my guiltless shoulders.

og: Thou wast provokèd by thy bloody mind, That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.Didst thou not kill this king?
t: No, you were provoked by your own bloody mind, which never thinks about anything but butchery. Did you kill this king?

og: I grant you.
t: Yes, I'll grant you that.

og: Dost grant me, hedgehog? Then, God grant me tooThou mayst be damnèd for that wicked deed.O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.
t: You'll grant me, you hedgehog? Then let God grant me my wish that you'll be damned for that wicked deed. Oh, Henry was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

og: The better for the King of heaven that hath him.
t: All the better for God, who has him now.

og: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
t: Yes, he's in heaven, where you will never go.

og: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither,For he was fitter for that place than earth.
t: Then let him thank me, who helped him get there. He's better suited for heaven than for earth.

og: And thou unfit for any place but hell.
t: And you're not suited for any place but hell.

og: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.
t: Yes, though I'm also suited for one other place, if you'll let me name it.

og: Some dungeon.
t: Some dungeon.

og: Your bedchamber.
t: Your bedroom.

og: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
t: There will be no rest in any bedroom where you lie!

og: So will it, madam till I lie with you.
t: That's true, madam, until I sleep with you.

og: I hope so.
t: I hope so—because then you'll never sleep.

og: I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne,  To leave this keen encounter of our wits  And fall something into a slower method—
t: I know so. But, dear Lady Anne, let's leave this battle of wits and move into a calmer, slower conversation.

og: Is not the causer of the timeless deaths  Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,  As blameful as the executioner?
t: Isn't the person who caused the untimely deaths of these Plantagenets—Henry and Edward—as much to blame as the person who physically committed the murders?

og: Thou wast the cause and most accursed effect.
t: You are both—the cause and the dreadful effect.

og: Your beauty was the cause of that effect—
t: No, your beauty was the cause of my deeds—

og: Your beauty, that did haunt me in my sleep  To undertake the death of all the world,  So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.
t: your beauty that haunted my sleep, and could have convinced me to kill the whole world to have just an hour of intimacy with you.

og: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide,These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.
t: If I believed you, murderer, then I tell you that I would scratch the beauty from my cheeks with my fingernails.

og: These eyes could never endure that beauty’s wrack.  You should not blemish it, if I stood by.
t: I couldn't stand to see you ruin your beauty. I would stop you if you tried to blemish it.

og: As all the world is cheerèd by the sun,  So I by that. It is my day, my life.
t: Your beauty encourages me like the sun encourages the whole world. Your beauty is my day, my life.

og: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life.
t: Then may black night overshadow your day, and death take your life.

og: Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.
t: Beautiful lady, don't curse yourself, since you are both my day and my life.

og: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.
t: I wish I were, so I could have some power to take revenge and kill you.

og: It is a quarrel most unnatural To be revenged on him that loveth thee.
t: It's unnatural to want to take revenge on the man who loves you.

og: It is a quarrel just and reasonableTo be revenged on him that killed my husband.
t: It's just and reasonable to want to take revenge on the man who killed my husband.

og: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husbandDid it to help thee to a better husband.
t: Lady, the man who robbed you of your husband did it to help you find a better husband.

og: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
t: There is no better man on earth than my husband.

og: He lives that loves thee better than he could.
t: But there is one man who loves you better than your husband could.

og: Name him.
t: Name him.

og: Plantagenet.
t: Plantagenet.

og: Why, that was he.
t: Yes, that's my husband's name.

og: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
t: I mean someone with the same name, but a better personality.

og: Where is he?
t: Where is he?

og: Here.
t: Right here.

og: Why dost thou spit at me?
t: Why do you spit at me?

og: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.
t: I wish my spit were deadly poison.

og: Never came poison from so sweet a place.
t: Poison never came from so sweet a place.

og: Never hung poison on a fouler toad.Out of my sight! Thou dost infect mine eyes.
t: Poison never fell onto a fouler toad. Get out of my sight! You're infecting my eyes.

og: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
t: Sweet lady, your eyes have infected mine with love.

og: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.
t: I wish they were basilisks, so they could strike you dead.

og: I would they were, that I might die at once,  For now they kill me with a living death.
t: I wish they were, so I could die at once. For right now your eyes are killing me with a living death.

og: Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,  Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops.
t: Your eyes have drawn salty tears from my eyes, making me weep shamefully like a child.

og: These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear—  No, when my father York and Edward wept  To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made  When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
t: My eyes have never cried like this before—not even when my father York and my brother Edward wept at the death of my brother Rutland, who was slaughtered by the gloomy Clifford.

og: Nor when thy warlike father, like a child,  Told the sad story of my father’s death  And twenty times made pause to sob and weep,
t: And when your warlike father told the sad story of my father's death, and had to pause twenty times to sob and weep like a child,

og: That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks  Like trees bedashed with rain—in that sad time,  My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;
t: so that all the bystanders' cheeks ended up as wet as trees in a rainstorm—even in that sad time I didn't shed a single tear.

og: And what these sorrows could not thence exhale  Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.
t: All these sorrows couldn't produce tears in me, but your beauty has blinded me with weeping.

og: I never sued to friend, nor enemy;  My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.
t: I never begged a friend or enemy or learned the art of flattery,

og: But now thy beauty is proposed my fee,  My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.
t: but if your beauty is the reward, then I'll flatter and beg as much as I have to.

og: Teach not thy lip such scorn, for it were made  For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.
t: Don't teach your lips to curl so scornfully—they were made for kissing, lady, not for such contempt.

og: If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,  Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword,  Which if thou please to hide in this true breast
t: If your vengeful heart cannot forgive me, then here, take my sharp-pointed sword and bury it in my chest.

og: And let the soul forth that adoreth thee,  I lay it naked to the deadly stroke  And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
t: That way my soul, which adores you, can be free. I lay myself open to being killed, and in fact, I humbly beg for death on my knees.

og: Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry—  But ’twas thy beauty that provokèd me.
t: No, don't pause. For I did kill King Henry—though your beauty provoked me to do it. Now go ahead.

og: Nay, now dispatch; ’twas I that stabbed young Edward—  But ’twas thy heavenly face that set me on.
t: I was the one who stabbed young Edward—though your heavenly face that drove me to it.

og: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
t: Take up the sword again, or else take me.

og: Arise, dissembler. Though I wish thy death,I will not be the executioner.
t: Stand up, liar. Though I wish you were dead, I won't be your executioner.

og: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.
t: Then tell me to kill myself, and I will do it.

og: I have already.
t: I have already.

og: That was in thy rage.  Speak it again and, even with the word,
t: You said it in a rage. Say it again, and as soon as you finish speaking,

og: This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love,  Shall for thy love kill a far truer love.
t: my hand—which killed your lover out of love for you—will kill your far truer lover.

og: To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.
t: You will be the cause of both these deaths.

og: I would I knew thy heart.
t: I wish I knew what was in your heart.

og: 'Tis figured in my tongue.
t: The same thing that was in my words.

og: I fear me both are false.
t: I fear that both your heart and your words are false.

og: Then never man was man true.
t: Then no man has ever been an honest man.

og: Well, well, put up your sword.
t: Very well, then. Put up your sword.

og: Say then my peace is made.
t: Then say that you'll accept me.

og: That shall you know hereafter.
t: You'll know about that later.

og: But shall I live in hope?
t: But should I live in hope?

og: All men I hope live so.
t: I hope that all men live in hope.

og: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
t: Consent to wear this ring.

og: To take is not to give.
t: To take is not to give. I'll accept it, but I won't promise anything in return.

og: Look, how this ring encompasseth finger;  Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart.
t: See how this ring encircles your finger. In the same way, my poor heart is enclosed inside your chest.

og: Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
t: Wear both of them, for both of them are yours.

og: And if thy poor devoted servant may  But beg one favor at thy gracious hand,  Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.
t: And if I, your poor devoted servant, can ask for one small favor from your gracious hand, then you'll guarantee my happiness forever.

og: What is it?
t: What is it?

og: That it would please you leave these sad designs  To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,  And presently repair to Crosby House,
t: Please leave these burial ceremonies for me to finish, as I have more reason to mourn than you do. Go immediately to my estate at Crosby House.

og: Where, after I have solemnly interred  At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king  And wet his grave with my repentant tears,  I will with all expedient duty see you.
t: After I have solemnly buried this noble king at Chertsey Abbey, and wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will hurry to meet you there.

og: For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you,  Grant me this boon.
t: Please do this for me, I beg you. My reasons must remain secret for now.

og: With all my heart, and much it joys me tooTo see you are become so penitent.—Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
t: I'll do it with all my heart, and it pleases me to see how remorseful you've become.

og: Bid me farewell.
t: Bid me farewell.

og: 'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you,Imagine I have said “farewell” already.
t: To "fare well" is more than you deserve. But since you're now teaching me how to flatter you, pretend that I've said "farewell" already.

og: Sirs, take up the corse.
t: Sirs, take up the corpse.

og: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
t: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

og: No, to Whitefriars. There attend my coming.
t: No, towards Whitefriars Monastery. Wait for me there.

og: Was ever woman in this humor wooed?  Was ever woman in this humor won?  I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.
t: Has a woman in such a mood ever been courted? Has a woman in such a mood ever been won? I'll get her, but I won't keep her long.

og: What, I that killed her husband and his father,  To take her in her heart’s extremest hate,  With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,  The bleeding witness of my hatred by,
t: How can it be that I—who killed her husband and his father—should win her over at the moment she hates me the most? When her mouth was full of curses, her eyes full of tears, and the bloody corpse of my victim right in front of her?

og: Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me,  And I no friends to back my suit at all  But the plain devil and dissembling looks?
t: She has God, her conscience, and the evidence of my deeds against me, and I have nothing to back me up but the devil and my own false looks!

og: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing! Ha!
t: And yet I won her over, with all odds against me! Ha!

og: Hath she forgot already that brave prince,  Edward, her lord, whom I some three months since  Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury?
t: Has she already forgotten her brave husband Prince Edward, whom I stabbed in an angry mood three months ago at the Battle of Tewkesbury?

og: A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman,  Framed in the prodigality of nature,  Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal,  The spacious world cannot again afford.
t: The world will never again be able to afford a man like him: such a sweet and lovely gentleman, blessed with all of nature's gifts. He was young, brave, wise, and no doubt meant to be king one day.

og: And will she yet abase her eyes on me,  That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince  And made her widow to a woeful bed?
t: And now she's going to cheapen herself by turning her eyes on me, who cut short her sweet prince's life and made her a widow in mourning?

og: On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?  On me, that halts and am misshapen thus?
t: On me, though I'm less than half of the man that Edward was? On me, who limps along, deformed like this?

og: My dukedom to a beggarly denier,  I do mistake my person all this while!
t: I'd bet my dukedom on a beggar's penny that I've been wrong about myself all this time!

og: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot,  Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.
t: Upon my life, she finds me to be a proper, handsome man—though I can't see it.

og: I’ll be at charges for a looking glass  And entertain a score or two of tailors  To study fashions to adorn my body.
t: I should buy a mirror and employ twenty or so tailors to study the current fashions and dress me up.

og: Since I am crept in favor with myself,  I will maintain it with some little cost.
t: Since I like myself now, it will be worth the cost.

og: But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave  And then return lamenting to my love.
t: But first I'll dump this fellow into his grave and then return, weeping, to my love.

og: Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,  That I may see my shadow as I pass.
t: Shine out, fair sun, so I can watch my shadow as I pass—until I've bought a mirror to admire my reflection.

og: Have patience, madam. There’s no doubt his majestyWill soon recover his accustomed health.
t: Have patience, madam. There's no doubt that his Majesty, King Edward, will soon recover his health.

og: In that you brook it ill, it makes him worse.Therefore, for God’s sake, entertain good comfort And cheer his grace with quick and merry eyes.
t: And if you're visibly worried, you'll make him worse. So for God's sake, let us comfort you, and then you can cheer up his Majesty with your lively, happy mood.

og: If he were dead, what would betide on me?
t: If he were dead, what would happen to me?

og: No other harm but loss of such a lord.
t: No harm would come to you but the loss of such a husband.

og: The loss of such a lord includes all harms.
t: The loss of such a husband includes all kinds of harm.

og: The heavens have blessed you with a goodly son To be your comforter when he is gone.
t: The heavens have blessed you with a good son, who will comfort you when the king is gone.

og: Ah, he is young, and his minorityIs put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester,A man that loves not me nor none of you.
t: Ah, but he is young, and while he's young he is still in the care of Richard, the Duke of Gloucester—a man who loves neither me nor any of you.

og: Is it concluded that he shall be Protector?
t: Has it been declared that Richard will be Protector?

og: It is determined, not concluded yet;But so it must be if the king miscarry.
t: It's been decided, but not officially declared yet. But that's the way it must be if the king dies.

og: Here comes the lord of Buckingham, and Derby.
t: Here comes the lords of Buckingham, and Derby.

og: Good time of day unto your royal Grace.
t: Good day to you, your royal Grace.

og: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been.
t: May God make your Majesty as happy as you once were.

og: The countess Richmond, good my lord of Derby,  To your good prayer will scarcely say amen.
t: My good Lord Stanley, the countess Richmond would hardly agree and say "amen" to you prayer.

og: Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she’s your wife  And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured  I hate not you for her proud arrogance.
t: But even though she's your wife and doesn't like me, you can be assured, good lord, that I don't hate you for her proud arrogance.

og: I do beseech you either not believe  The envious slanders of her false accusers,
t: Please don't believe the jealous lies of her slanderers.

og: Or if she be accused in true report,  Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds  From wayward sickness and no grounded malice.
t: And even if there's some truth to the rumors, then forgive her, for I think she only acts that way because she's sick—not because she hates you.

og: Saw you the king today, my lord of Derby?
t: Did you see the king today, Lord Stanley?

og: But now the duke of Buckingham and IAre come from visiting his majesty.
t: The Duke of Buckingham and I are just coming now from a visit to his Majesty.

og: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?
t: What are the chances of his recovery, lords?

og: Madam, good hope. His grace speaks cheerfully.
t: There is good hope, madam. The king seems cheerful.

og: God grant him health. Did you confer with him?
t: May God grant him health. Did you speak with him?

og: Ay, madam. He desires to make atonement  Betwixt the duke of Gloucester and your brothers,
t: Yes, madam. He wants to reconcile Richard with your brothers,

og: And betwixt them and my Lord Chamberlain,  And sent to warn them to his royal presence.
t: and your brothers with Lord Hastings. He has just summoned them all to his royal presence.

og: Would all were well—but that will never be.I fear our happiness is at the height.
t: I wish that all were well—but that will never be. I fear that our good fortune has reached its peak.

og: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!
t: They're abusing me, and I won't endure it!

og: Who is it that complains unto the king  That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not?
t: Who has been complaining to the king that I am harsh and don't like them?

og: By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly  That fill his ears with such dissentious rumors.
t: By Saint Paul, whoever is worrying the king with these treacherous rumors doesn't love him very much.

og: Because I cannot flatter and look fair,  Smile in men’s faces, smooth, deceive and cog,  Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,  I must be held a rancorous enemy.
t: Just because I cannot flatter and look handsome, smile in men's faces, ingratiate myself, lie and cheat, and bow like a pretentious Frenchman, people assume that I'm a foul enemy.

og: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,  But thus his simple truth must be abused  With silken, sly, insinuating jacks?
t: Can't a plain man live, wishing no harm on anyone, without his words being twisted like this by slick, sly, slithering lowlifes?

og: To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace?
t: Which of us are you referring to, your Grace?

og: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.  When have I injured thee? When done thee wrong?—
t: To you, who have neither honesty nor grace. When have I injured you? When have I done you any wrong?

og: Or thee?—Or thee? Or any of your faction?
t: Or you? Or you? Or any of you and your supporters?

og: A plague upon you all! His royal grace,  Whom God preserve better than you would wish,
t: Curse you all! The king—whom I hope God will preserve better than you'd like—

og: Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while  But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
t: can hardly catch his breath before you start troubling him with your wicked complaints.

og: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.
t: My brother-in-law of Gloucester, you're mistaken.

og: The king, on his own royal disposition,  And not provoked by any suitor else,  Aiming belike at your interior hatred  That in your outward actions shows itself  Against my children, brothers, and myself,
t: It was the king himself, unprovoked by anyone, who noticed your hatred for my children, my brothers, and myself—an inner hatred that expresses itself in your outward actions. He summoned people to ask them about your dislike of us,

og: Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground  Of your ill will, and thereby to remove it.
t: so that he might discover the reasons behind it and do something about it.

og: I cannot tell. The world is grown so bad  That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch.
t: I can't tell what's going on. The world has grown so bad that little wrens now live where eagles dare not perch.

og: Since every jack became a gentleman,  There’s many a gentle person made a jack.
t: Since every peasant has become a nobleman, there are now many noblemen who've been turned into peasants.

og: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester. You envy my advancement, and my friends'.God grant we never may have need of you.
t: Come, come, I know what you're referring to, brother-in-law Richard. You're jealous of my friends' rise in rank, and of my own. May God grant that I never need your help.

og: Meantime God grants that we have need of you.  Our brother is imprisoned by your means,
t: But in the meantime God grants that I need your help. My brother, the Duke of Clarence, is imprisoned because of your influence.

og: Myself disgraced, and the nobility  Held in contempt, while great promotions  Are daily given to ennoble those  That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
t: I am disgraced, and the nobility are scorned, while great promotions are handed out daily to those who weren't worth a noble two days ago.

og: By Him that raised me to this careful height  From that contented hap which I enjoyed,
t: I swear by the God who raised me up to this anxious height from the contented life I used to enjoy—

og: I never did incense his majesty  Against the duke of Clarence, but have been  An earnest advocate to plead for him.
t: I never provoked the king's anger against the Duke of Clarence. I have only ever advocated for him and pled on his behalf.

og: My lord, you do me shameful injury  Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.
t: My lord, you do me wrong to implicate me in these wicked suspicions.

og: You may deny that you were not the meanOf my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.
t: Then I'm sure you'll also deny that you were the cause of Lord Hastings' recent imprisonment

og: She may, my lord, for—
t: She may deny it, my lord, for—

og: She may, Lord Rivers. Why, who knows not so?  She may do more, sir, than denying that.
t: Yes, she may, Lord Rivers. Why, everyone knows that she may. And she may do more than just denying that, sir.

og: She may help you to many fair preferments  And then deny her aiding hand therein,  And lay those honors on your high desert.
t: She may help you to many nice promotions and then deny that she aided you, claiming that you won those honors through your own merit.

og: What may she not? She may, ay, marry, may she—
t: What may she not do? She may, yes, by God, she may—

og: What, marry, may she?
t: What, by God, may she do?

og: What, marry, may she? Marry with a king,A bachelor, a handsome stripling too.I wis, your grandam had a worser match.
t: What, by God, may she do? She may marry a king, a bachelor, a handsome young man. Certainly, your grandmother had a worse match.

og: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne  Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.
t: My Lord of Gloucester, for too long I've suffered your blunt insults and your bitter scorn.

og: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty  With those gross taunts that oft I have endured.
t: By heaven, I will tell the king about the vile taunts I've endured.

og: I had rather be a country servant-maid  Than a great queen with this condition,  To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.
t: I would rather be a country servant-maid than a great queen in such a situation—to be so taunted, scorned, and attacked.

og: Small joy have I in being England’s queen.
t: I've had very little joy in being England's queen.

og: And lessened be that small, God I beseech Him!Thy honor, state, and seat is due to me.
t: And may her joy be even less than that, God! Elizabeth's honor, rank, and throne all rightly belong to me.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]   What, threat you me with telling of the king?  Tell him, and spare not.
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] What, are you threatening me that you'll tell the king? Go ahead and tell him, and don't spare any details.

og: Look, what I have said,  I will avouch ’t in presence of the king;  I dare adventure to be sent to th' Tower.
t: Look, I will repeat what I have said here in the presence of the king. I'll even risk being sent to the Tower for it.

og: 'Tis time to speak. My pains are quite forgot.
t: It seems that all my efforts on Edward's behalf have been forgotten.

og: Out, devil! I do remember them too well:Thou killed’st my husband Henry in the Tower, And Edward, my poor son, at Tewkesbury.
t: You devil! I remember those efforts all too well: you killed my husband Henry in the Tower, and my poor son Edward at Tewkesbury.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]   Ere you were queen, ay, or your husband king,  I was a packhorse in his great affairs,
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Yes, before you were queen, or your husband was king, I was a beast of burden for his great affairs.

og: A weeder-out of his proud adversaries,  A liberal rewarder of his friends.
t: I weeded out his proud enemies and generously rewarded his friends.

og: To royalize his blood, I spent mine own.
t: I spent my own blood to make his blood royal.

og: Ay, and much better blood than his or thine.
t: Yes, and in killing my husband and son, you spent much better blood than yours or your brother's.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]   In all which time, you and your husband Grey  Were factious for the house of Lancaster.—
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] And during all that time, you and your first husband, Sir John Grey, were fighting for the house of Lancaster.

og: A murd'rous villain, and so still thou art.
t: You were a murderous villain, and you still are.

og: Poor Clarence did forsake his father Warwick,Ay, and forswore himself—which Jesu pardon!—
t: Poor Clarence abandoned his father-in-law Warwick, yes, and broke his own oath—may Jesus pardon him!—

og: Which God revenge!
t: And may God take revenge on him!

og: To fight on Edward’s party for the crown;  And for his meed, poor lord, he is mewed up.
t: —to fight for Edward's side and help him win the crown. And his reward for that, the poor lord, is to be imprisoned.

og: I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward’s,  Or Edward’s soft and pitiful, like mine.
t: I wish to God that my heart was made of stone, like Edward's—or that Edward's heart was soft and emotional, like mine.

og: I am too childish-foolish for this world.
t: I am too childlike and innocent for this world.

og: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world,Thou cacodemon! There thy kingdom is.
t: Hurry on to hell then, and leave this world, you evil spirit! Hell is where your true kingdom is.

og: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days  Which here you urge to prove us enemies,  We followed then our lord, our sovereign king.
t: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days, we were just following our lord, our rightful king—which you now bring up to prove that we're your enemies.

og: So should we you, if you should be our king.
t: And we would follow you in just the same way, if you were our king.

og: If I should be? I had rather be a peddler. Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof.
t: If I were king? I would rather be a peddler. Far be it for me to ever think of being king.

og: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose  You should enjoy were you this country’s king,
t: You would have just as little joy as you imagine if you were indeed this country's king.

og: As little joy may you suppose in me  That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.
t: As the queen, I have had no joy.

og: Ah, little joy enjoys the queen thereof,For I am she, and altogether joyless.I can no longer hold me patient.
t: Ah, no joy for that "queen" indeed. For I am the queen, and completely unhappy. I can no longer hold myself back.

og: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out  In sharing that which you have pilled from me!  Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
t: Hear me, you scheming pirates, who quarrel over what you've plundered from me! Which of you doesn't tremble to look at me?

og: If not, that I am queen, you bow like subjects,  Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels.—
t: If you're not trembling because I am the queen and you are my bowing subjects, then you're quivering because you're traitors who stole my throne!

og: Foul, wrinkled witch, what mak’st thou in my sight?
t: You foul, wrinkled witch, what are you doing here?

og: But repetition of what thou hast marred.That will I make before I let thee go.
t: Just trying to redo what you have undone. I will do that much before I let you go.

og: Wert thou not banishèd on pain of death?
t: Weren't you banished on pain of death?

og: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment  Than death can yield me here by my abode.  A husband and a son thou ow’st to me;
t: [To RICHARD] I was, but banishment is more painful to me than dying here at home. You owe me a husband and a son.

og: The curse my noble father laid on thee  When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper,  And with thy scorns drew’st rivers from his eyes,  And then, to dry them, gav’st the duke a clout  Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland—
t: The curse my noble father laid on you when you set a paper crown on his head, and drew rivers of tears from his eyes with your scorn, and then, to dry them, you gave him a handkerchief soaked in innocent Rutland's blood—

og: His curses then, from bitterness of soul  Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee,
t: the curses he laid on you then, when his bitter soul condemned you, have now come to pass.

og: And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.
t: God, not us, is punishing you for your bloody deeds.

og: So just is God to right the innocent.
t: God is just, and he rewards the innocent.

og: O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe,And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
t: Oh, killing that child, Rutland, was the foulest, most merciless deed that was ever heard of!

og: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
t: Even tyrants wept when they heard about it.

og: No man but prophesied revenge for it.
t: Everyone knew that there would be revenge for it.

og: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.
t: Even Northumberland, who was there, wept to see it.

og: What, were you snarling all before I came,  Ready to catch each other by the throat,  And turn you all your hatred now on me?
t: What, weren't you all snarling at each other before I came—about to jump at each others' throats like dogs? And now you're turning all your hatred on me?

og: Did York’s dread curse prevail so much with heaven  That Henry’s death, my Lovelly Edward’s death,  Their kingdom’s loss, my woeful banishment,  Could all but answer for that peevish brat?
t: Did the Duke of York's curse have so much power that Henry's death; my lovely Edward's death; the loss of their kingdom; and my sad banishment were all required to avenge the death of that peevish brat Rutland?

og: Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?  Why then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!
t: Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven? Well then, open up, you dark clouds—and hear my strong curses!

og: Though not by war, by surfeit die your king,  As ours by murder to make him a king.
t: Though your Yorkist king didn't die in battle, may he die from his gluttony, just as our Lancastrian king—my husband—was murdered to give your king his throne.

og: Have done thy charm, thou hateful, withered hag.
t: Enough of your witchcraft, you hateful, withered hag.

og: And leave out thee? Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
t: And leave you out, Richard? Stay, dog, for you must hear me out.

og: If heaven have any grievous plague in store  Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,
t: If heaven has any horrible plagues worse than anything I could imagine,

og: O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe  And then hurl down their indignation  On thee, the troubler of the poor world’s peace.
t: oh, let it keep them until you've committed the maximum amount of sin. And then let heaven hurl down its anger on you all at once, you disturber of the poor world's peace!

og: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul.  Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou liv’st,  And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends.
t: May the worm of guilt gnaw away at your soul constantly. May you suspect your friends of being traitors, and consider the worst traitors as your dearest friends.

og: No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine,  Unless it be while some tormenting dream  Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils.
t: May you never close your wicked eyes and be able to sleep—unless it's to dream some terrifying nightmare of a hell filled with ugly devils.

og: Thou elvish-marked, abortive, rooting hog,  Thou was sealed in they nativity  The slave of nature and the son of hell,
t: You cursed, prematurely born hog, wallowing in the mud; you who were born a deformed child of hell;

og: Thou slander of they heavy mother's womb,  Thou loathed issue of they father's loins,  Thou rag of honor, thou detested—
t: you insult to your sad mother's womb; you hated product of your father's loins; you filthy scrap of dishonor; you disgusting—

og: Margaret.
t: Margaret.

og: Richard!
t: Richard!

og: Ha?
t: Yes?

og: I call thee not.
t: I didn't call you.

og: I cry thee mercy, then, for I did thinkThat thou hadst called me all these bitter names.
t: I beg your pardon, then—for I thought you had called me all those bitter names.

og: Why, so I did, but looked for no reply.O, let me make the period to my curse!
t: Why, so I did. But I didn't want any reply from you. Oh, let me finish my curse!

og: 'Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”
t: I've already finished it. It ends in "Margaret."

og: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
t: See, you've only cursed yourself.

og: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune,  Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider,  Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
t: You poor imitation of a queen, you meaningless decoration on my throne: why do you give sugar to this swollen spider when he's already ensnared you in his deadly web?

og: Fool, fool, thou whet’st a knife to kill thyself.  The day will come that thou shalt wish for me  To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad.
t: Fool, fool, you're sharpening the knife that will kill you. The day will come when you'll wish that I could help you curse this poisonous, hunchbacked toad.

og: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.
t: You false prophet, stop your frantic curses before we lose our patience and cause you harm.

og: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.
t: Foul shame on you—I've already lost my patience with you all.

og: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
t: If you got what you deserved, you would be taught to show some respect.

og: To serve me well, you all should do me duty: Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects.O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
t: If I got what I deserved, you would all be showing me respect—I would be your queen, and you would be my subjects. Oh, give me what I deserve, then—and teach yourselves some respect!

og: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.
t: Don't try to argue with her. She's a lunatic.

og: Peace, Master Marquess, you are malapert.  Your fire-new stamp of honor is scarce current.
t: Quiet, Master Marquess, you're being impudent. Your noble title is so newly-minted that its not even legal yet.

og: O, that your young nobility could judge  What ’twere to lose it and be miserable!
t: Oh, that your recent nobility could understand what it means to be lost and miserable!

og: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them,  And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
t: Those who are very high up must be shaken by many blasts of wind. And when they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

og: Good counsel, marry. —Learn it, learn it, marquess.
t: Good advice, by God.

og: It touches you, my lord, as much as me.
t: It applies to you as much as to me, my lord.

og: Ay, and much more; but I was born so high.Our aerie buildeth in the cedar’s top,And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.
t: Yes, and even more so. But I was born at that high social rank. My family lives like eagles at the top of the tallest cedar tree, playing in the wind and looking fearlessly at the sun.

og: And turns the sun to shade. Alas, alas,  Witness my son, now in the shade of death,  Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath  Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
t: And turning the sun into shadow. Alas, alas, like my son, who is now in the shadow of death. Your cloudy anger has swallowed up his bright-shining beams, and now he dwells in eternal darkness.

og: Your aerie buildeth in our aerie’s nest.
t: You're building your nest in our nest.

og: O God, that seest it, do not suffer it!  As it was won with blood, lost be it so.
t: Oh God, witness this injustice and don't let it go unpunished! As the Yorks won the crown through bloodshed, let them also lose it in the same way.

og: Peace, peace, for shame, if not for charity.
t: Quiet, quiet—have some shame at least, if you can't be kind.

og: Urge neither charity nor shame to me.
t: Don't preach about kindness or shame to me.

og: Have done, have done.
t: Enough, enough.

og: O princely Buckingham, I’ll kiss thy hand  In sign of league and amity with thee.
t: Oh, princely Buckingham, I'll kiss your hand as a sign of my support and friendship.

og: Now fair befall thee and thy noble house!
t: May only good things come to you and your noble family!

og: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,  Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
t: Your clothes are not stained with my family's blood, and so you don't fall under my curse.
