og: Nor no one here, for curses never passThe lips of those that breathe them in the air.
t: No one here is under your curse either. For curses are just empty words, lost to the air as soon as they're spoken.

og: I will not think but they ascend the sky,  And there awake God’s gentle-sleeping peace.
t: No, I believe that they rise up to heaven and awaken God from his gentle, peaceful sleep.

og: What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?
t: What does she say, my lord of Buckingham?

og: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
t: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

og: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel,  And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
t: What, will you scorn me for my friendly advice, and comfort the devil that I'm warning you about?

og: O, but remember this another day,  When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,  And say poor Margaret was a prophetess.—
t: Oh, you will remember this, when one day he splits your heart in two with sorrow. Then you'll say that poor Margaret was a prophet.

og: Live each of you the subjects to his hate,  And he to yours, and all of you to God’s.
t: May Richard come to hate everyone here, and may you come to hate him, and may God hate you all!

og: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.
t: My hair stands on end when I hear her curses.

og: And so doth mine. I muse why she’s at liberty.
t: So does mine. I wonder why she's not in prison.

og: I cannot blame her. By God’s holy mother, She hath had too much wrong, and I repentMy part thereof that I have done to her.
t: I cannot blame her. By God's holy mother, she has suffered too much. And I'm sorry for the part I've played in her troubles.

og: I never did her any, to my knowledge.
t: I never did her any wrong, to my knowledge.

og: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.  I was too hot to do somebody good  That is too cold in thinking of it now.
t: But you've reaped all the benefits from her suffering. I was too eager in helping Edward to the throne, and now he seems to have forgotten my deeds.

og: Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid;  He is franked up to fatting for his pains.
t: Well, as for Clarence, he is being well repaid for his pains—shut in a pigsty to be fattened up and slaughtered.

og: God pardon them that are the cause thereof.
t: May God pardon those responsible.

og: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion To pray for them that have done scathe to us.
t: That's very virtuous and Christian of you to pray for those who have harmed us.

og: So do I ever    being well-advised,For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
t: I always do.

og: Madam, his majesty doth call for you,—And for your Grace, —and yours, my gracious lords.
t: Madam, his Majesty asks for you—and for you, Duke of Gloucester—and for you, my gracious lords.

og: Catesby, I come. —Lords, will you go with me?
t: I will go now, Catesby. Lords, will you go with me?

og: We wait upon your Grace.
t: We will attend you, your Grace.

og: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.  The secret mischiefs that I set abroach  I lay unto the grievous charge of others.
t: I commit the crimes, and I start the quarrels. I do wicked things in secret, and then lay the blame on others.

og: Clarence, whom I indeed have cast in darkness,  I do beweep to many simple gulls,  Namely, to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham,  And tell them ’tis the queen and her allies  That stir the king against the duke my brother.
t: I weep about Clarence, whom I've had thrown into prison, in front of these gullible fools—namely, Derby, Hastings, and Buckingham. And I tell them that it's the queen and her allies who have incited the King against Clarence.

og: Now they believe it and withal whet me  To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey;
t: Now they believe it, and they urge me to take revenge on Rivers, Dorset, and Grey...

og: But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture,  Tell them that God bids us do good for evil;
t: but then I sigh, and quote a piece of scripture to them, saying that God tells us to repay evil with good.

og: And thus I clothe my naked villainy  With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ,  And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
t: And so I clothe my naked villainy with odds and ends stolen from the Holy Bible, and I seem like a saint exactly when I act most like the devil.

og: But, soft! here come my executioners.—How now, my hardy, stout, resolvèd mates?Are you now going to dispatch this thing?
t: But quiet! Here come the executioners I've hired.

og: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrantThat we may be admitted where he is.
t: We are, my lord. We've come to get the warrant so we can be admitted into Clarence's cell.

og: Well thought upon. I have it here about me.
t: Good thinking. I have it on me here.

og: [He gives a paper]  When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.  But, sirs, be sudden in the execution,  Withal obdurate;
t: [He gives them a paper] When you're done, go to Crosby Place. But, sirs, be quick in your execution.

og: do not hear him plead,  For Clarence is well-spoken and perhaps  May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.
t: And don't let him plead for his life, for Clarence is well-spoken, and he may convince you to spare him if you listen too closely to his words.

og: Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate.Talkers are no good doers. Be assured We go to use our hands and not our tongues.
t: Tut, tut, my lord, we won't stand around and chat. Talkers are not good doers. Rest assured that we go to use our hands, not our tongues.

og: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears.I like you lads. About your business straight.Go, go, dispatch.
t: You remain stone-faced when fools' eyes drop tears. I like you lads. Go about your business right away. Go, go, get to it.

og: We will, my noble lord.
t: We will, my noble lord.

og: Why looks your grace so heavily today?
t: Why do you look so sad today, your Grace?

og: O, I have passed a miserable night,  So full of ugly dreams, of ugly sights,
t: Oh, I had a miserable night last night. It was so full of ugly dreams and terrifying visions

og: That, as I am a Christian faithful man,  I would not spend another such a night
t: that I swear I wouldn't choose to spend another night like it—

og: Though ’twere to buy a world of happy days,  So full of dismal terror was the time.
t: even if it bought me a lifetime of happy days.

og: What was your dream, my lord? I pray you tell me.
t: What was your dream, my lord? Please tell me.

og: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower  And was embarked to cross to Burgundy,  And in my company my brother Gloucester,
t: I dreamed that I had broken out of the Tower and was on a ship to France, and my brother Richard was with me.

og: Who from my cabin tempted me to walk  Upon the hatches.
t: He persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on the boat's deck with him.

og: Thence we looked toward England  And cited up a thousand fearful times,  During the wars of York and Lancaster  That had befall'n us.
t: From there we looked toward England and reminisced about our many frightening experiences during the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters.

og: O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown,  What dreadful noise of waters in my ears,  What sights of ugly death within my eyes.
t: As we paced along the boards of the deck, Richard seemed to stumble, and as I tried to grab him he knocked me overboard into the rolling waves. Oh Lord, how painful it was to drown—with the dreadful noise of water in my ears and the ugly visions of death in my eyes.

og: Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks,  Ten thousand men that fishes gnawed upon,  Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,  Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,  All scattered in the bottom of the sea.
t: I seemed to see a thousand shipwrecks; ten thousand men whose bodies had been gnawed by fish; bars of gold; huge anchors; heaps of pearls; and vast amounts of priceless jewels, all scattered on the bottom of the sea.

og: Some lay in dead men's skulls, and in the holes  Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept—  as 'twere in scorn of eyes—  reflecting gems,
t: Some of the jewels lay inside of dead men's skulls. And they had crept into their empty eye sockets—so that they looked like false eyes.

og: That wooed the slimy bottom of the deep  And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.
t: The gems reflected the slimy bottom of the ocean floor, and mocked the dead bones that lay scattered around.

og: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
t: Did you really have so much time to examine the secrets of the deep while you were dying?

og: Methought I had, and often did I strive  To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood  Stopped in my soul
t: It seemed like I did. And I often tried to die, but the jealous waves kept my soul bottled up inside of me,

og: and would not let it forth  To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air,
t: and wouldn't let it go free to find the empty, wandering air.

og: But smothered it within my panting bulk,  Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.
t: The water kept my soul smothered inside my panting body until I almost burst open.

og: Awaked you not in this sore agony?
t: Didn't you wake up during all this agony?

og: No, no, my dream was lengthened after life.  O, then began the tempest to my soul.
t: No, no, my dream continued after I died. Oh, then the real storm of my soul began!

og: I passed, methought, the melancholy flood,  With that sour ferryman which poets write of,  Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
t: I passed over the river of death with the help of Charon, the ferryman of the underworld, and I entered the kingdom of perpetual night.

og: The first that there did greet my stranger-soul  Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick,  Who cried aloud, “What scourge for perjury  Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?”
t: The first soul to greet me there was my great father-in-law, the Earl of Warwick, who cried aloud, "What terrible punishment for oath-breaking can this dark kingdom inflict on that false Clarence?"

og: And so he vanished. Then came wand'ring by  A shadow like an angel, with bright hair  Dabbled in blood,
t: And then he vanished. Next a shadow like an angel came wandering by, with its bright hair spattered with blood,

og: and he shrieked out aloud  "Clarence is come—false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,  That stabbed me in the field by Tewkesbury.  Seize on him, furies. Take him unto torment."
t: and it shrieked aloud, "Clarence is here—false, fickle, lying Clarence, who stabbed me in the field at Tewkesbury. Seize him, avenging devils. Take him and torture him."

og: With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends  Environed me and howled in mine ears  Such hideous cries that with the very noise  I trembling waked,
t: With that it seemed like a legion of foul demons surrounded me and howled in my ears, and their cries were so loud and horrible that I woke up trembling.

og: and for a season after  Could not believe but that I was in hell,  Such terrible impression made my dream.
t: And for a long time afterward I still believed that I was in hell—that was how terrible an impression this dream made on me.

og: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you. I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
t: It's no surprise that it frightened you, my lord. I'm afraid just hearing you tell it.

og: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things,  That now give evidence against my soul,  For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me.—
t: [To BRAKENBURY] Ah, jailer, jailer, I did all those things that the ghosts accused me of—and my crimes are now giving evidence against my soul. I did them all for King Edward's sake, and now see how he thanks me.

og: I will, my lord. God give your Grace good rest.
t: I will, my lord. May God give you good rest.

og: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,  Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.
t: Sorrow breaks natural rhythms and interrupts sleep, making night into morning and noon into night.

og: Princes have but their titles for their glories,  An outward honor for an inward toil,
t: The only glory princes really have are their titles, which are outward honors for their inner troubles.

og: And, for unfelt imaginations,  They often feel a world of restless cares,  So that betwixt their titles and low name  There's nothing differs but the outward fame.
t: They experience a world of worry about imaginary things, so that the only real difference between princes and peasants is the princes' outward fame.

og: Ho, who’s here?
t: Hey, who's there?

og: What wouldst thou, fellow? And how cam’st thou hither?
t: What do you want, man? And how did you get here?

og: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.
t: I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.

og: What, so brief?
t: What, do you dare to be so blunt with me?

og: 'Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.—Let him seeour commission, and talk no more.
t: It's better to be blunt than to be long-winded, sir.

og: I am in this commanded to deliver  The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.
t: This warrant commands me to deliver the noble Duke of Clarence into your hands.

og: I will not reason what is meant hereby  Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.
t: I won't ask what this means, for I'd rather not know about something that might make me guilty later.

og: There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.
t: There's the duke, sleeping, and here are the keys.

og: [He hands them the keys]  I’ll to the king and signify to him  That thus I have resigned my charge to you.
t: [He hands them the keys] I'll go to the king and tell him that I've handed over my prisoner to you.

og: You may, sir. 'Tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.
t: You may do that, sir. It's a wise idea. Farewell.

og: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?
t: Well, should I stab him as he sleeps?

og: No. He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
t: No. When he wakes up he'll say that we killed him like cowards.

og: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
t: Why, he won't be waking up until Judgment Day.

og: Why, then he’ll say we stabbed him sleeping.
t: Well, then on Judgment Day he'll say that we stabbed him in his sleep.

og: The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
t: That word "judgment" has made me feel a little bit guilty.

og: What, art thou afraid?
t: What, are you afraid?

og: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
t: Not afraid to kill him, since we have a warrant for it. But I'm afraid to be damned for killing him. No warrant can protect me from that.

og: I thought thou hadst been resolute.
t: I thought you were sure about this.

og: So I am—to let him live.
t: I am sure—that we should let him live.

og: I’ll back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
t: I'll go back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

og: Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humor of mine will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.
t: No, please, stay a minute. I'm hoping that my compassionate mood will pass. It usually only lasts about twenty seconds.

og: How dost thou feel thyself now?
t: How are you feeling now?

og: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
t: Honestly, my conscience is still troubling me a bit.

og: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.
t: Remember the reward we'll get when the deed is done.

og: Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.
t: By God, he must die! I had forgotten about the reward.

og: Where’s thy conscience now?
t: Where's your conscience now?

og: O, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.
t: Oh, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

og: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
t: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, your conscience will fly out.

og: 'Tis no matter. Let it go. There’s few or none will entertain it.
t: That won't matter. Let it fly off. No one will take it in.

og: What if it come to thee again?
t: What if it comes back to you?

og: I’ll not meddle with it. It makes a man a coward: a mancannot steal but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbor’s wife but it detects him.
t: I won't bother with it. A conscience makes a man a coward. A man can't steal without it accusing him; he can't swear without it restraining him; he can't sleep with his neighbor's wife without it exposing him.

og: 'Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles.
t: It's a blushing, shamefaced spirit that betrays a man's heart. It fills him with obstacles.

og: It made me once restore a purse of gold that by chance I found. It beggars any man that keeps it.
t: It once made me return a purse full of gold that I found. A conscience can turn any man into a beggar.

og: It is turned out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to live well endeavors to trust to himself and live without it.
t: It's been thrown out of towns and cities like a dangerous enemy. Any man who wants to live well should trust only himself, and live without his conscience.

og: Zounds, ’tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not tokill the duke.
t: My God, now it's even at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.

og: Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not. He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.
t: Ignore your conscience, and think about the devil instead. He might flatter you, but he won't make you sad.

og: I am strong-framed. He cannot prevail with me.
t: I'm strong-willed. My conscience won't overcome me.

og: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?
t: Spoken like a brave man who values his reputation. Come, shall we get to work?

og: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.
t: Hit him on the head with the hilt of your sword, and then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.

og: O excellent device— and make a sop of him.
t: Oh, what an excellent plan—we'll make him a sponge for the wine.

og: Soft, he wakes.
t: Quiet, he's waking up.

og: Strike!
t: Strike!

og: No, we’ll reason with him.
t: No, we'll talk to him first.

og: Where art thou, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.
t: Where are you, jailer? Give me a cup of wine.

og: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
t: You'll have plenty of wine soon enough, my lord.

og: In God’s name, what art thou?
t: In God's name, who are you?

og: A man, as you are.
t: A man, like you are.

og: But not, as I am, royal.
t: But not a royal man, as I am.

og: Nor you, as we are, loyal.
t: And you're not a loyal man, as we are.

og: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
t: You speak with authority, but you look like a common man.

og: My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
t: I'm speaking for the king—my looks are my own.

og: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! Your eyes do menace me. Why look you pale?Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?
t: Your words are so dark and threatening! Your eyes menace me. Why do you look so pale? Who sent you here? Why have you come?

og: To, to, to—
t: To, to, to—

og: To murder me?
t: To murder me?

og: Ay, ay.
t: Yes, yes.

og: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it. Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?
t: You hardly have the heart to tell me, so you must not have the heart to do it. Besides, my friends, have I offended you?

og: Offended us you have not, but the king.
t: You haven't offended us—you offended the king.

og: I shall be reconciled to him again.
t: He and I will be reconciled again.

og: Never, my lord. Therefore prepare to die.
t: Never, my lord. So prepare to die.

og: Are you drawn forth among a world of men  To slay the innocent? What is my offense?
t: Have you been chosen specially, just to kill the innocent? What is my offense?

og: Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?  What lawful quest have given their verdict up  Unto the frowning judge?
t: Where is the evidence against me? What jury has sentenced me in front of a frowning judge?

og: Or who pronounced  The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death  Before I be convict by course of law?
t: Or who has pronounced this death sentence on me before I could be convicted by a court of law?

og: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
t: To threaten me with death is wrong.

og: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption,  By Christ’s dear blood shed for our grievous sins,  That you depart, and lay no hands on me.
t: If you hope to be saved by Christ's dear blood—which was shed for our sins—then I tell you to leave now without touching me.

og: What we will do, we do upon command.
t: What we do, we do because we were commanded to.

og: And he that hath commanded is our king.
t: And the one who has commanded us is our king.

og: Erroneous vassals, the great King of kings  Hath in the tables of His law commanded  That thou shalt do no murder.
t: You misguided subjects, the great King of Kings—God—has said in his Ten Commandments that "you shall not murder."

og: Will thou then  Spurn at His edict and fulfill a man’s?
t: Will you then disobey God's commandment just to obey a man's?

og: Take heed, for He holds vengeance in His hand  To hurl upon their heads that break His law.
t: Beware, for God holds vengeance in his hand, waiting to smite those who break his laws.

og: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee  For false forswearing and for murder too.
t: And he will smite you with that same vengeance for breaking your oaths, and for murder too.

og: Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight  In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
t: You swore a holy oath to fight for the house of Lancaster.

og: And, like a traitor to the name of God,Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade Unrippedst the bowels of thy sovereign’s son.
t: And—like a traitor to the name of God—you broke that vow, and with your treacherous sword you ripped open the chest of your king, Henry's, son Edward.

og: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
t: Whom you were sworn to cherish and defend.

og: How canst thou urge God’s dreadful law to usWhen thou hast broke it in such dear degree?
t: How can you preach about God's laws to us when you have broken them to such an extreme degree?

og: Alas! For whose sake did I that ill deed?  For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
t: Alas! But for whose sake did I do that terrible deed? For my brother Edward, for his sake.

og: He sends you not to murder me for this,  For in that sin he is as deep as I.
t: He can't be sending you to murder me for the prince's death—because in that, he is just as guilty as I am.

og: If God will be avengèd for this deed,  O, know you yet He doth it publicly!
t: If God intends to punish me for this deed, oh, you know that he will do it publicly!

og: Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm;  He needs no indirect or lawless course  To cut off those that have offended Him.
t: God has no need for indirect or illegal methods of killing those who have offended him.

og: Who made thee then a bloody ministerWhen gallant-springing, brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?
t: Who provoked you to kill that brave and lively youth, Prince Edward?

og: My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.
t: My brother's love; the devil; and my rage.

og: Thy brother’s love, our duty, and thy faultsProvoke us hither now to slaughter thee.
t: Well, your brother's love; our duty; and your own crimes now provoke us to kill you.

og: If you do love my brother, hate not me.  I am his brother, and I love him well.
t: If you really love my brother Richard, then don't hate me. I am his brother, and I love him very much.

og: If you are hired for meed, go back again,  And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,  Who shall reward you better for my life  Than Edward will for tidings of my death.
t: If you're hired to do this for money, then go back again and talk to my brother the Duke of Gloucester. He will reward you better for sparing my life than King Edward will for news of my death.

og: You are deceived. Your brother Gloucester hates you.
t: You are deceived. Your brother Richard hates you.

og: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.Go you to him from me.
t: Oh, no, he loves me and cherishes me. Go to him from me.

og: Ay, so we will.
t: Yes, so we will.

og: Tell him, when that our princely father York  Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,  And charged us from his soul to love each other,  He little thought of this divided friendship.
t: Tell him that when our princely father, the Duke of York, blessed his three sons and commanded us to love each other, he never imagined that our friendship would end up divided like this.

og: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
t: Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.

og: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.
t: Yes, he'll weep stones, as he taught us to do.

og: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.
t: Oh, do not slander him, for he is a kind man.

og: As snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself.'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.
t: As kind as snow during harvest time. Come, you're deceiving yourself. It's Richard who sent us here to kill you.

og: It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune,And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobsThat he would labor my delivery.
t: It cannot be. He wept over my imprisonment. And he hugged me in his arms, and swore while sobbing that he would work to have me released.

og: Why, so he doth, when he delivers youFrom this earth’s thralldom to the joys of heaven.
t: Why, that's what he did—and now you'll be released from the prison of earth, to be free among the joys of heaven.

og: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
t: Make your peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

og: Have you that holy feeling in your souls  To counsel me to make my peace with God,  And art you yet to your own souls so blind  That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?
t: You have enough holy feeling in your souls to advise me to make my peace with God. But you're still willing to disobey God by murdering me?

og: O sirs, consider: they that set you on  To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
t: Oh, sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.

og: What shall we do?
t: What should we do?

og: Relent, and save your souls.
t: Give up this attempt, and save your souls.

og: Which of you—if you were a prince's son  Being pent from liberty, as I am now—  If two such murderers as yourselves came to you,  Would you not entreat for life?
t: Which of you, if you were in my position—a prince's son in prison, and two murderers like yourselves came to you—wouldn't beg for your life?

og: Ay, you would beg,  Were you in my distress.
t: Yes, you would beg, if you were in my situation.

og: Relent? No. 'Tis cowardly and womanish.
t: Give up? No. That's cowardly and womanish.

og: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.
t: But to not give up, and murder me, is beastly, savage, and devilish.

og: Look behind you, my lord.
t: Look behind you, my lord.

og: Take that, and that.    If all this will not do,I’ll drown you in the malmsey butt within.
t: Take that, and that.  If all this won't do the job, then I'll drown you in that wine barrel.

og: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched. How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my handsOf this most grievous murder.
t: A bloody deed, and desperately done. I wish I could wash my hands of this sad murder, as Pontius Pilate did.

og: How now? What mean’st thou, that thou help’st me not?By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.
t: What's going on? What's wrong with you, that you didn't help me? By God, the duke will hear about how you've neglected your duty.

og: I would he knew that I had saved his brother. Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say,For I repent me that the duke is slain.
t: I wish he could hear that I had saved his brother. You take the reward, and tell him what I've said. I'm sorry that the Duke of Clarence has been killed.

og: So do not I. Go, coward as thou art.  Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole  Till that the duke give order for his burial.
t: I'm not sorry. Go, coward that you are. Well, I'll go hide the body in some hole until the Duke of Gloucester gives orders for its burial.

og: And when I have my meed, I will away,  For this will out, and then I must not stay.
t: And when I have my reward, I'll flee. For this murder will be found out, and I must not be around then.

og: Why, so. Now have I done a good day’s work.  You peers, continue this united league.
t: Well, now I've done a good day's work. You must all maintain this unity and friendship.

og: I every day expect an embassage  From my Redeemer to redeem me hence,  And more in peace my soul shall part to heaven  Since I have made my friends at peace on earth  Rivers and Hastings, take each other’s hand.
t: Every day I expect a messenger of God to bear me away from here, and I can leave for heaven in peace now that my friends have made their peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand.

og: Dissemble not your hatred. Swear your love.
t: Don't just hide your hatred under a facade of friendship. Swear your love for each other.

og: By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand I seal my true heart’s love.
t: By heaven, my soul is now cleansed of all grudges and hatred. With this handshake I swear that this love is true.

og: So thrive I as I truly swear the like.
t: So may I prosper, as I swear the same thing.

og: Take heed you dally not before your king,
t: Make sure that you don't mock your king by lying in front of him.

og: Lest He that is the supreme King of kings  Confound your hidden falsehood, and award  Either of you to be the other’s end.
t: Otherwise God, the supreme King of Kings, will uncover your hidden lies and cause you to be the death of each other.

og: So prosper I as I swear perfect love.
t: I swear perfect love for Rivers, or may I never prosper.

og: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.
t: And I love Hastings with all my heart.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  Madam, yourself is not exempt in this,—
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Madam, you're not exempt from this.

og: There, Hastings, I will never more rememberOur former hatred, so thrive I and mine.
t: Here's my hand, Hastings. I will forget all our past hatred for each other, and may we both prosper in the future.

og: Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.
t: Now Dorset, hug Hastings. Hastings, befriend Lord Marquess of Dorset.

og: This interchange of love, I here protest,Upon my part shall be inviolable.
t: I swear that I will never go back on this exchange of love and friendship.

og: And so swear I.
t: And I swear it too.

og: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife’s alliesAnd make me happy in your unity.
t: Now, princely Buckingham, seal this friendship by embracing my wife's allies, and through your unity make me happy.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate  Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love  Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me  With hate in those where I expect most love.
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] If I should ever come to hate your Grace, and fail to love and cherish you and your relatives, may God punish me by making me find hatred where I expect love.

og: When I have most need to employ a friend,  And most assurèd that he is a friend,  Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile  Be he unto me:
t: When I most need a friend and am sure that my friends are trustworthy, may they turn false, treacherous, and full of deceit.

og: this do I beg of God  When I am cold in love to you or yours.
t: I beg that God will do this if I ever lose my love for you and your allies.

og: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,  Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.
t: Noble Buckingham, your vow of friendship is like medicine for my sickly heart.

og: There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here  To make the blessèd period of this peace.
t: Now all we need is my brother Richard to bring the blessed conclusion to this time of peace.

og: And in good time,Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
t: And just in time, here comes Richard with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.

og: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen,And, princely peers, a happy time of day.
t: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen. And I'm happy to see you too, my princely peers.

og: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.
t: Happy indeed—that's the way we've spent the day.

og: Brother, we have done deeds of charity,  Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,  Between these swelling, wrong-incensèd peers.
t: Brother, we have done deeds of love, turning enmity to peace and hatred to love between these misguidedly angry nobles.

og: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.
t: A blessed labor, my sovereign lord.

og: Amongst this princely heap, if any here  By false intelligence, or wrong surmise  Hold me a foe,  If I unwittingly, or in my rage,  Have aught committed that is hardly borne  By any in this presence,
t: If any among this princely group considers me an enemy—whether from lies they've heard about me, or because by accident or in anger I've done something to give offense—

og: I desire  To reconcile me to his friendly peace.
t: I want us to be reconciled and become peaceful friends.

og: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity;  I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.
t: To be enemies with anyone is like death to me; I hate it, and only desire the love of all good men.

og: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.  I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
t: This will be remembered as a holy day. I wish to God that all troubles could end this well.

og: My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness  To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
t: But I must also ask your Highness to pardon your brother Clarence.

og: Why, madam, have I offered love for this,To be so flouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?
t: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be mocked in front of the king? Who doesn't know that the gentle duke is dead?

og: You do him injury to scorn his corse.
t: You do him wrong to joke about his death.

og: Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?
t: Who doesn't know that he's dead? Who knew that he was!

og: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
t: Oh all-seeing God, what a terrible world!

og: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?
t: Do I look as pale as everyone else, Lord Dorset?

og: Ay, my good lord, and no one in the presenceBut his red color hath forsook his cheeks.
t: Yes, my good lord. Everyone here in the king's presence has gone totally pale.

og: Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.
t: Is Clarence dead? The death sentence had been reversed.

og: But he, poor man, by your first order died,  And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.
t: But Clarence died by your first order, the poor man. The death sentence must have been carried by Mercury, the winged messenger god,

og: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand,  That came too lag to see him burièd.
t: while the counter-order was carried by some slow cripple. It arrived too late even for his burial.

og: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,  Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood,
t: It seems that someone less noble and less loyal—nearer in bloody thoughts but not a blood relation—

og: Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,  And yet go current from suspicion.
t: deserves the punishment that poor Clarence got, but instead goes free without suspicion.

og: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done.
t: I must ask you a favor in return for the service I've done for you, my king.

og: I prithee, peace. My soul is full of sorrow.
t: Quiet, please. My soul is full of sorrow.

og: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.
t: I will not rise until your Highness hears my request.

og: Then say at once what is it thou requests.
t: Then quickly say what it is you want.

og: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant’s life,Who slew today a riotous gentlemanLately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.
t: I ask you to spare the life of my servant, who just today killed a rowdy gentleman that used to serve the Duke of Norfolk.

og: Have I a tongue to doom my brother’s death,  And shall the tongue give pardon to a slave?
t: I was willing to condemn my own brother to death, and now you want me to pardon a servant?

og: My brother killed no man; his fault was thought,  And yet his punishment was bitter death.
t: My brother Clarence didn't kill anyone. His only fault was his ideas, and yet he was punished with bitter death.

og: Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath,  Kneeled at my feet, and bade me be advised?
t: Who pled on his behalf?  When I was so angry, who kneeled at my feet and asked me to think about what I was doing?

og: Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love?  Who told me how the poor soul did forsake  The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?
t: Who spoke to me about brotherhood? Who spoke about love? Who told me how the poor soul abandoned his father-in-law—the mighty Earl of Warwick—to come fight for me?

og: Who told me, in the field by Tewkesbury,  When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,  And said “Dear brother, live, and be a king?”
t: Who told me of the battlefield at Tewkesbury, where Clarence rescued me when Oxford had me down, saying, "Dear brother, live, and be a king?"

og: Who told me, when we both lay in the field  Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me  Even in his garments and did give himself,  All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night?
t: Who told me how, when we both lay in the field almost freezing to death, he wrapped me in his own clothes and left himself naked, exposed to the mercy of the numbingly cold night?

og: All this from my remembrance brutish wrath  Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you  Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
t: All this seemed erased from my memory in my brutish rage, and not a man of you had the grace to remind me.

og: But when your carters or your waiting vassals  Have done a drunken slaughter and defaced  The precious image of our dear Redeemer,
t: But when your servants drunkenly kill someone and scorn the law of our dear Christ,

og: You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon,  And I, unjustly too, must grant it you.
t: you immediately get on your knees and beg, "pardon, pardon." And I, unfair as I am, must give it to you.

og: [STANLEY rises]  But for my brother, not a man would speak,  Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself  For him, poor soul.
t: [Stanley rises] But no one spoke on behalf my brother, and I didn't speak to myself on his behalf either, the poor soul.

og: The proudest of you all  Have been beholding to him in his life,  Yet none of you would once beg for his life.
t: Even the proudest among you owed him something, and yet none of you would beg for his life.

og: O God, I fear Thy justice will take hold  On me and you, and mine and yours for this!—
t: Oh God, I fear that your justice will punish me and all these gathered here, and our families as well, because of this!

og: This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not  How that the guilty kindred of the queen  Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
t: This sorrow is the result of recklessness. Didn't you notice how the queen's guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence's death?

og: O, they did urge it still unto the king.  God will revenge it.
t: Oh, they were always urging the king to do it. God will revenge it.

og: Come, lords, will you go  To comfort Edward with our company?
t: Come, lords, will you come with me to comfort Edward with our companionship?

og: We wait upon your Grace.
t: We will attend you, your Grace.

og: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?
t: Good grandmother, tell us, is our father dead?

og: No, boy.
t: No, boy.

og: Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast,And cry, “O Clarence, my unhappy son?”
t: Then why do you weep so often, and beat your chest, and cry, "Oh, Clarence, my unlucky son?"

og: Why do you look on us and shake your head,And call us orphans, wretches, castaways,If that our noble father were alive?
t: If our noble father is still alive, why do you look at us and shake your head, and call us orphans, wretches, and castaways?

og: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.  I do lament the sickness of the king,
t: My pretty grandchildren, you both misunderstand me. I'm lamenting the sickness of the king,

og: As loath to lose him, not your father’s death.  It were lost sorrow to wail one that’s lost.
t: because I don't want to lose him. I'm not lamenting your father's death. It would be wasted sorrow to cry over someone who's already dead.

og: Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.  The king mine uncle is to blame for it.
t: Then, my grandmother, you're admitting that our father is dead. My uncle, the king, is to blame for it.

og: God will revenge it, whom I will importune  With earnest prayers, all to that effect.
t: God will revenge it, and I'll pray earnestly every day that he does so.

og: And so will I.
t: And so will I.

og: Peace, children, peace. The king doth love you well.Incapable and shallow innocents,You cannot guess who caused your father’s death.
t: Quiet, children, quiet. The king loves you both very much. You innocent, naive children, you cannot guess who caused your father's death.

og: Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester  Told me the king, provoked to it by the queen,  Devised impeachments to imprison him;
t: But we can, grandmother, for my good uncle Richard told me. He said that the king was provoked by the queen to make up accusations against my father that would get him arrested.

og: And when my uncle told me so, he wept,  And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek,
t: When my uncle told me about this he wept, and pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek.

og: Bade me rely on him as on my father,  And he would love me dearly as a child.
t: He told me that I could rely on him as if he were my father, and that he would love me as dearly as if I were his child.

og: Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape,  And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice.
t: Ah, it's terrible that liars can steal the appearance of gentle people, and hide their wickedness under a virtuous mask.

og: He is my son, ay, and therein my shame,  Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.
t: Yes, he is my son. And in being my son, he is the source of my shame as a mother. But he didn't get his deceitfulness from my breast.

og: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
t: Do you think that my uncle was lying, grandmother?

og: Ay, boy.
t: Yes, boy.

og: I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?
t: I can't believe it. Wait, what's that noise?

og: Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,  To chide my fortune and torment myself?
t: Ah, who can stop me from wailing and weeping, cursing my bad luck, and tormenting myself?

og: I’ll join with black despair against my soul  And to myself become an enemy.
t: I'll ally myself with the black despair that threatens my soul, and become my own enemy.

og: What means this scene of rude impatience?
t: What do you mean by this melodramatic scene?

og: To make an act of tragic violence.  Edward, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead.
t: I'm performing the violent tragedy of my life. Edward—my husband, your son, our king—is dead.

og: Why grow the branches when the root is gone?  Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
t: Why should we keep living when our leader and lifeblood is gone? How can the branches keep growing when the root is gone? Why aren't the leaves withering now that the sap is dried up?

og: If you will live, lament. If die, be brief,  That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the king’s,
t: If you will live, then lament. If you will die, then be quick about it, so our swift-winged souls might catch up with the king's—

og: Or, like obedient subjects, follow him  To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.
t: or at least follow him, like obedient subjects, into his new kingdom of never-ending night.

og: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow  As I had title in thy noble husband.  I have bewept a worthy husband’s death  And lived with looking on his images;
t: Ah, I was your noble husband's mother, so I have just as large a share in your grief. I've already wept over my own worthy husband's death and kept myself alive only by looking at his sons, his mirror images.

og: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance  Are cracked in pieces by malignant death,  And I, for comfort, have but one false glass  That grieves me when I see my shame in him.
t: But now two of those mirrors have been cracked into pieces by death, and the only one left to comfort me is Richard—an untrustworthy mirror who only causes me shame and grief.

og: Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother,  And hast the comfort of thy children left,
t: You are a widow, but you're also a mother, and you still have the comfort of your children left.

og: But death hath snatched my husband from mine arms  And plucked two crutches from my feeble hands,  Clarence and Edward.
t: But death has snatched my husband from my arms and then plucked my two crutches, Clarence and Edward, from my feeble hands.

og: O, what cause have I,  Thine being but a moiety of my moan,  To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!
t: Oh, I have every reason to surpass you in sorrow and drown out your weeping with my own, as your loss is only half of mine!

og: Ah, aunt, you wept not for our father’s death.How can we aid you with our kindred tears?
t: Oh, Aunt, you didn't weep for our father's death. So why would we help you with our tears?

og: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned. Your widow-dolor likewise be unwept!
t: You didn't mourn with us when we were left fatherless. Your sadness as a widow will likewise go unmourned by us!

og: G  ive me no help in lamentation.  I am not barren to bring forth complaints.
t: I don't need any help in mourning. I am full of sorrows to complain about.

og: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,  That I, being governed by the watery moon,  May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.
t: May all the earth's springs keep my eyes replenished with tears, so that when the tide is high in the ocean of my weeping, I can drown the world.

og: Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!
t: Ah, for my husband, my dear lord Edward!

og: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
t: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

og: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!
t: Alas for both Edward and Clarence, both mine!

og: What stay had I but Edward? And he’s gone.
t: What support did I have besides Edward? And he's dead.

og: What stay had we but Clarence? And he’s gone.
t: What support did we have besides Clarence? And he's dead.

og: What stays had I but they? And they are gone.
t: What supports did I have besides both of them? And they are dead.

og: Was never widow had so dear a loss.
t: A widow never suffered so great a loss.

og: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.
t: Orphans never suffered so great a loss.

og: Was never mother had so dear a loss.  Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.
t: A mother never suffered so great a loss. Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.

og: Their woes are parceled; mine are general.  She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;
t: Each of you has only a single loss, while I suffer all of them. Elizabeth weeps for Edward, and so do I,

og: I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.  These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;
t: but she does not weep for Clarence like I do. These children weep for Clarence, and so do I,

og: I for an Edward weep; so do not they.
t: but they don't weep for Edward like I do.

og: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distressed,  Pour all your tears. I am your sorrow’s nurse,  And I will pamper it with lamentations.
t: You three should pour all your tears onto me. I will be your sorrow's nurse, and feed your tears with more mourning.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]   Comfort, dear mother. God is  much displeased  That you take with unthankfulness, his doing.
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Dear Mother, let yourself be comforted. God is displeased that you respond to his doings so unthankfully.

og: In common worldly things, ’tis called ungrateful  With dull unwillingness to repay a debt  Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;
t: In everyday business, it's considered ungrateful if someone is unwilling to repay a debt which was generously loaned in the first place.

og: Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,  For it requires the royal debt it lent you.
t: It's much worse to be so opposed to heaven, now that it requires the royal debt it lent to you.

og: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,  Of the young prince your son.
t: Madam, think of your son, the young prince, and be a careful mother.

og: Send straight for him.  Let him be crowned. In him your comfort lives.
t: Send for him right away. Let him be crowned king. He is your hope for future peace of mind.

og: Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward’s grave  And plant your joys in living Edward’s throne.
t: Drown your desperate sorrows in dead Edward's grave, and plant your future joys in Prince Edward's new throne.

og: Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause  To wail the dimming of our shining star,  But none can help our harms by wailing them.—
t: Sister, let yourself be comforted. All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of the king, our shining star, but none of us can help anything by wailing.

og: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
t: God bless you, and fill you with humility, love, charity, obedience, and true duty.

og: And make me die a good old man! That is the butt end of a mother’s blessing;I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.
t: Amen.

og: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers  That bear this heavy mutual load of moan,  Now cheer each other in each other’s love.
t: You weeping princes and sorrowful nobles who bear this mutual weight of grief, let us now cheer each other up with our love.

og: Though we have spent our harvest of this king,  We are to reap the harvest of his son.
t: Though we have lost our old, fruitful king, we will now reap the harvest of his son.

og: The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates,  But lately splintered, knit, and joined together,  Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.
t: Our former hatreds were only recently broken and then rejoined as friendship, and now we must gently preserve, cherish, and keep this new goodwill.

og: Meseemeth good that with some little train  Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet  Hither to London, to be crowned our king.
t: It seems like a good idea that a small group of us should now set out for Ludlow Castle in Wales, to fetch the young prince and bring him here to London, where he will be crowned our king.

og: Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?
t: Why only a "small group," my Lord of Buckingham?

og: Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude  The new-healed wound of malice should break out,  Which would be so much the more dangerous  By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned.
t: Well, my lord, if a large group goes, the newly-healed hostilities between us might break out again. This could be very dangerous, as the Yorkist rule is still new and untested.

og: Where every horse bears his commanding rein  And may direct his course as please himself,  As well the fear of harm as harm apparent,  In my opinion, ought to be prevented.
t: We should prevent a situation where it seems like every man is out for himself, with everyone paranoid about imagined enemies.

og: I hope the king made peace with all of us;And the compact is firm and true in me.
t: The king tried to make peace among all of us, and I hope he succeeded. For me, at least, those vows of friendship were firm and true.

og: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.
t: And for me also. And so, I think, for all of us.

og: Yet since it is but green, it should be put  To no apparent likelihood of breach,  Which haply by much company might be urged.
t: But since our agreement is so fresh, we shouldn't risk putting it under too much stress—which might happen if all of us go at once to fetch the prince.

og: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham  That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.
t: So I agree with noble Buckingham that it's best for only a few to go.

og: And so say I.
t: And I agree.

og: Then be it so, and go we to determine  Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.—
t: Then we'll do that. Now let's go and figure out which of us will ride off to Ludlow.

og: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince,  For God’s sake let not us two at home.
t: My lord, whoever ends up journeying to meet the prince, for God's sake let us be part of the group.

og: For by the way I’ll sort occasion,  As index to the story we late talked of,  To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.
t: Along the way I'll create an opportunity to separate him from the queen's proud relatives—as the first step in the plan we discussed recently.

og: My other self, my council’s consistory,  My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin,
t: My dear cousin, you are my other self, my council of advisors, my oracle, my prophet!

og: I, as a child, will go by thy direction  Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
t: I will let you lead me like a child. Let's go to Wales then, for we won't stay behind.

og: Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?
t: Good morning, neighbor. Where are you hurrying off to?

og: I promise you I scarcely know myself.Hear you the news abroad?
t: I swear, I hardly know where I'm going myself. Have you heard the news going around?

og: Yes, that the king is dead.
t: Yes, that the king is dead.

og: Ill news, by 'r Lady. Seldom comes the better. I fear, I fear, ’twill prove a giddy world.
t: Bad news, by the Virgin Mary. The news is always bad, and likely to get worse. I fear that the world will go crazy.

og: Neighbors, God speed.
t: Hello, neighbors.

og: Give you good morrow, sir.
t: Good morning to you, sir.

og: Doth this news hold of good King Edward’s death?
t: Is the news true that good King Edward has died?

og: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.
t: Yes, sir, it's too true, God help us.

og: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.
t: Then be ready for troubled times, sirs.

og: No, no, by God’s good grace, his son shall reign.
t: No, no, by God's good grace, his son will become king.

og: Woe to the land that’s governed by a child.
t: It's bad for a country to be ruled by a child.

og: In him there is a hope of government,
t: There is hope for the country under his rule, though.

og: Which, in his nonage, council under him,  And, in his full and ripened years, himself,  No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.
t: A young king who governs wisely under his advisors will govern wisely on his own when he reaches adulthood.

og: So stood the state when Henry the SixthWas crowned in Paris but at nine months old.
t: That's how it went when Henry the Sixth was crowned in Paris at just nine months old.

og: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot,
t: Is that how it was? No, no, good friends,

og: For then this land was famously enriched  With politic grave counsel; then the king  Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.
t: back then the country was rich with intelligent advisors, and the king had virtuous uncles to protect him.

og: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.
t: Why, this king—Edward's son—has uncles too, on both his father's and his mother's side.

og: Better it were they all came by his father,  Or by the father there were none at all,  For emulation who shall now be nearest  Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.
t: It would be better if they were all on his father's side, or if none at all were on his father's side. For as it is, the contest over which uncles will be closest to the king is likely to affect all of us, if God doesn't prevent it.

og: O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester,  And the queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud,
t: The Duke of Gloucester—Richard—is a dangerous man. And Queen Elizabeth's sons and brothers are haughty and proud.

og: And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,  This sickly land might solace as before.
t: This sickly country will only have a chance of being healed if they end up as subjects, not rulers.

og: Come, come, we fear the worst. All will be well.
t: Come, come, we're worrying about the worst possible outcome. I'm sure that everything will be all right.

og: When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks;
t: You know what they say: when clouds appear, wise men put on their coats.

og: When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand;  When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?
t: When leaves fall from the trees, winter is coming. When the sun sets, who doesn't expect night?

og: Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.  All may be well; but if God sort it so,  'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.
t: When storms arrive early, men expect a bad harvest. Everything may be all right, as you say. But if God wills it to turn out all right, that will be more than we deserve, and not what I expect.

og: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear.Ye cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of dread.
t: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear. There's hardly anyone who isn't unreasonably worried right now.

og: Before the days of change, still is it so.  By a divine instinct, men’s minds mistrust  Ensuing dangers,
t: It's always like this before times of great change. By some divine instinct, we get nervous when danger is coming—

og: as by proof we see  The water swell before a boist'rous storm.
t: just like when we see the waves swelling before a storm arrives.

og: But leave it all to God. Whither away?
t: But leave it all to God. Where are you off to?

og: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.
t: Indeed, the judges have sent for us.

og: And so was I. I’ll bear you company.
t: And for me to. I'll keep you company.

og: Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony Stratford,And at Northampton they do rest tonight.Tomorrow or next day they will be here.
t: I hear that last night they slept at Stony Stratford, and tonight they'll rest in Northampton. Tomorrow or the next day they'll be here.

og: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
t: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he's grown a lot since the last time I saw him.

og: But I hear no; they say my son of YorkHas almost overta'en him in his growth.
t: I heard he hasn't though. They say that my son of York has almost passed him in height.

og: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.
t: Yes, Mother, but I wish it weren't so.

og: Why, my young cousin? It is good to grow.
t: Why, my child? It is good to grow.

og: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,  My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow  More than my brother:
t: Grandmother, one night while we were eating dinner, my uncle Rivers mentioned that I had grown more than my brother.

og: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester,  “Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.”
t: "Yes," said my uncle Richard, "Small herbs grow with grace, while big weeds grow quickly."

og: And since, methinks I would not grow so fast  Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
t: And since then, I've wished that I wouldn't grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow, and weeds are hasty.

og: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold  In him that did object the same to thee!
t: Honestly, honestly, that saying certainly didn't hold true for Richard!

og: He was the wretched’st thing when he was young,  So long a-growing and so leisurely,  That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
t: He was a terrible child, and took such a long time to grow up that if that rule were true, he should be a very gracious adult.

og: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
t: And no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

og: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
t: I hope he is, but mothers can have their doubts.

og: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered,I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
t: Now, if I'd considered something I once heard about him, I could have scoffed at my uncle—and mocked his growth more than he mocked mine.

og: How, my pretty York? I prithee let me hear it.
t: How, my clever York? Let me hear your comeback.

og: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast  That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.
t: Well, they say that my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw a crust of bread at two hours old.

og: 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.  Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.
t: For me, it took two full years before I could get a single tooth. Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

og: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?
t: Please tell me, clever York, who told you this about him?

og: Grandam, his nurse.
t: His nurse, grandmother.

og: His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.
t: His nurse? Why, she was dead before you were born.

og: If ’twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
t: If it wasn't her, then I can't say who told me.

og: A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.
t: A cunning boy! Get out of here, you're too clever for your own good.

og: Good madam, be not angry with the child.
t: Good madam, don't be angry with the child.

og: Pitchers have ears.
t: Little pitchers have wide ears.

og: Here comes a messenger. —What news?
t: Here comes a messenger.

og: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.
t: It's news that grieves me to report, my lord.

og: How doth the prince?
t: How is the prince?

og: Well, madam, and in health.
t: Madam, he's well and in good health.

og: What is thy news then?
t: What's your news then?

og: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.
t: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey have been sent to Pomfret, and Sir Thomas Vaughan with them. They're all prisoners.

og: Who hath committed them?
t: Who had them arrested?

og: The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.
t: The mighty dukes of Gloucester and Buckingham.

og: For what offence?
t: For what crime?

og: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.Why, or for what, the nobles were committedIs all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
t: I've told you all that I know. Why the nobles were arrested, and on what charges, is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.

og: Ay me! I see the ruin of my house.  The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind.
t: God help us! I see the ruin of my family. The tiger has now seized the gentle deer.

og: Insulting tyranny begins to jut  Upon the innocent and aweless throne.
t: Brute tyranny begins to attack the innocent, weak throne.

og: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.  I see, as in a map, the end of all.
t: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre! I can see how this will end as clearly as if I was reading it on a map.

og: Accursèd and unquiet wrangling days,  How many of you have mine eyes beheld?
t: Oh, how many cursed and violent days of unrest have my old eyes seen?

og: My husband lost his life to get the crown,  And often up and down my sons were tossed  For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.
t: My husband lost his life to get the crown. And my sons' lives have been tossed up and down for me to rejoice over their gains and weep over their losses.

og: And being seated, and domestic broils  Clean overblown, themselves the conquerors  Make war upon themselves, brother to brother,  Blood to blood, self against self.
t: And when one of them gained the throne and got rid of the domestic quarrels, now the conquerors turn on each other, making war among themselves—brother against brother, blood against blood, self against self.

og: O, preposterous  And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen,  Or let me die, to look on death no more.
t: Oh, it's a perversion of the natural order, a frenzied outrage! Let it end—or let me die—so I won't have to see any more death.

og: Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary.Madam, farewell.
t: Come, come, my boy. We'll go take sanctuary. Madam, farewell.

og: Stay, I will go with you.
t: Wait, I will go with you.

og: You have no cause.
t: You have no reason to.

og: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  My gracious lady, go,  And thither bear your treasure and your goods.
t: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] My gracious lady, go. And take your money and belongings with you.

og: For my part, I’ll resign unto your Grace  The seal I keep; and so betide to me  As well I tender you and all of yours.
t: For my part, I'll reassign the seal I keep to you, and I'll try to take care of you and all your relatives.

og: Go. I’ll conduct you to the sanctuary.
t: Go, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

og: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.
t: Welcome to your room here in London, sweet prince.

og: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign.The weary way hath made you melancholy.
t: Welcome, dear nephew, ruler of my thoughts. It seems that the tiring journey has made you sad.

og: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.I want more uncles here to welcome me.
t: No, uncle, but the annoyances on the way made the journey tedious, tiring, and dull. I wish more uncles were here to welcome me.

og: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years  Hath not yet dived into the world’s deceit;
t: Sweet prince, you are young and innocent, and haven't experienced the deceitfulness of the world yet.

og: Nor more can you distinguish of a man  Than of his outward show, which, God He knows,  Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.
t: You can't perceive the truth about a man except for what he shows on the outside—which, God knows, hardly ever corresponds with his heart.

og: Those uncles which you want were dangerous.  Your Grace attended to their sugared words  But looked not on the poison of their hearts.
t: Those uncles you wish for were dangerous. You heard their sugary words, but you couldn't see the poison in their hearts, your Grace.

og: God keep you from them, and from such false friends.
t: May God protect you from them, and from all such false friends!

og: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.
t: May God protect me from false friends—but my uncles weren't false.

og: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.
t: My lord, the mayor of London is here to greet you.

og: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.
t: May God bless your Grace with health and happy days.

og: I thank you, good my lord, and thank you all.—  I thought my mother and my brother York  Would long ere this have met us on the way.
t: I thank you, my good lord, and thank you all. But I thought my mother and my brother York would have met us on our way long before now.

og: Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not  To tell us whether they will come or no!
t: And it's shameful what a slug Hastings is, that he hasn't even come to tell us whether or not they're coming!

og: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.
t: And just in time, here comes the sweating lord.

og: Welcome, my lord. What, will our mother come?
t: Welcome, my lord. Well, is my mother coming?

og: On what occasion God He knows, not I,  The Queen your mother and your brother York  Have taken sanctuary.
t: Only God knows why, but the queen your mother and your brother York have taken sanctuary in Westminster Abbey.

og: The tender prince  Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace,  But by his mother was perforce withheld.
t: The tender prince wanted to come with me to meet your Grace, but his mother forced him to stay.

og: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course  Is this of hers!
t: For shame, what a devious and perverse course the queen is taking!

og: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory  Can from his mother win the duke of York,  Anon expect him here;
t: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak words can persuade his mother to give up the Duke of York, then you can expect him here soon.

og: but if she be obdurate  To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid  We should infringe the holy privilege  Of blessèd sanctuary!
t: But if she resists my mild requests, then God forbid that we should break the holy laws of sanctuary!

og: Not for all this land  Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
t: I would not commit such a terrible sin even in exchange for a kingdom.

og: You are too senseless obstinate, my lord,  Too ceremonious and traditional.
t: My lord, you are foolishly stubborn, and too tied to formalities and traditions.

og: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,  You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
t: Consider the moral roughness of these times, and you'll see that you're not really breaking sanctuary in seizing him.

og: The benefit thereof is always granted  To those whose dealings have deserved the place  And those who have the wit to claim the place.
t: The benefit of sanctuary is always given to those who really deserve protection, or those who are smart enough to claim it.

og: This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it  And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
t: This prince has neither claimed it nor does he deserve it.

og: Then taking him from thence that is not there,  You break no privilege nor charter there.
t: Therefore, in my opinion, he cannot have it. If you seize him from sanctuary when he was never really taking sanctuary in the first place, then you aren't breaking any laws or traditions.

og: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,  But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.
t: I've often heard of "sanctuary men," but until now I've never heard of "sanctuary children."

og: My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once.—Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?
t: My lord, I'll let you convince me this once.

og: I go, my lord.
t: I will, my lord.

og: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
t: Good lords, go as quickly as you can.

og: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
t: Tell me, Uncle Richard: if my brother comes, where will we stay until my coronation ceremony?

og: Where it seems best unto your royal self.
t: Wherever seems best for your royal self.

og: If I may counsel you, some day or two  Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower;
t: If I can advise you, though, you should stay a day or two in the Tower.

og: Then where you please and shall be thought most fit  For your best health and recreation.
t: After that you can stay wherever you like, and wherever seems best for your health and pleasure.

og: I do not like the Tower, of any place.—Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
t: Of all places, I don't like the Tower at all. Didn't Julius Caesar build it, my lord?

og: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place,Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
t: He began it, my gracious lord. And since then succeeding generations have added on to it.

og: Is it upon record, or else reportedSuccessively from age to age, he built it?
t: Is it on record that he built the Tower, or is it just reported by word of mouth from generation to generation?

og: Upon record, my gracious lord.
t: On record, my gracious lord.

og: But say, my lord, it were not registered,  Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
t: But even if it weren't recorded, I think that the truth would live on from generation to generation—

og: As ’twere retailed to all posterity,  Even to the general all-ending day.
t: being told as part of legend and history—all the way until Judgment Day.

og: So wise so young, they say, do never live long.
t: They say that those who are so wise when so young never live long.

og: What say you, uncle?
t: What did you say, uncle?

og: I say, without characters fame lives long.    Thus, like the formal Vice, Iniquity,I moralize two meanings in one word.
t: I said that without written records, fame lives long.

og: That Julius Caesar was a famous man.  With what his valor did enrich his wit,  His wit set down to make his valor live.
t: That Julius Caesar was a famous man. His courage aided his intelligence, and his intelligence helped him make sure that his reputation for courage outlived him.

og: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror,
t: Death didn't conquer that conqueror.

og: For now he lives in fame, though not in life.  I’ll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham—
t: Now he lives on in fame, though not in life. I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham—

og: What, my gracious lord?
t: What, my gracious lord?

og: An if I live until I be a man,I’ll win our ancient right in France againOr die a soldier, as I lived a king.
t: If I live to be a man, I'll conquer France and win back our claim to the throne there. Otherwise I'll die as a soldier, though I lived as a king.

og: Short summers lightly have a forward spring.
t: Short summers often have an early spring, as they say. Those who die young are usually precocious.

og: Now in good time here comes the duke of York.
t: Now here comes the Duke of York, right on time.

og: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?
t: Richard of York, how are you, my loving brother?

og: Well, my dread lord—so must I call you now.
t: I'm well, my sovereign lord—for that's what I must call you now.

og: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours.Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.
t: Yes, Brother, and it's a sad occasion for both of us. Our father—the man who should have kept that title—died too recently. And the sadness of his death makes the title seem much less majestic.

og: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?
t: How are you, my nephew, noble Lord of York?

og: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
t: I thank you for asking, noble uncle. Oh, my lord, you once said that lazy weeds grow quickly. The prince my brother has far outgrown me.

og: He hath, my lord.
t: He has, my lord.

og: And therefore is he idle?
t: So is he lazy then?

og: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.
t: Oh, my fair nephew, I can't say that.

og: Then is he more beholding to you than I.
t: Then he has more power over you than I do.

og: He may command me as my sovereign,But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
t: He may command me as my king, but you still have power over me as my relative.

og: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.
t: Please give me your dagger, uncle.

og: My dagger, little cousin? With all my heart.
t: My dagger, little Nephew? With all my heart.

og: A beggar, brother?
t: Are you begging, Brother?

og: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give,And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
t: Only from my kind uncle. I know he'll give it to me, and it's not valuable, so it shouldn't make him sad to lose it.

og: A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.
t: I'll give my nephew a greater gift than that.

og: A greater gift? O, that’s the sword to it.
t: A greater gift? Oh, that must mean a sword.

og: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.
t: Yes, noble nephew. That is, if it's light enough for you to hold.

og: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.
t: Oh, then I see that you'll only part with light, trivial gifts. You'll refuse a beggar's request in heavier, more valuable things.

og: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
t: A sword is too heavy for your Grace to wear.

og: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
t: I'd consider it light and trivial even if it were heavier.

og: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?
t: What, do you want my weapon, little lord?

og: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.
t: I do, so I can thank you for what you called me.

og: How?
t: What do you mean?

og: Little.
t: You called me "little."

og: My lord of York will still be cross in talk.Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.
t: The Lord of York is always argumentative. Uncle, you know how to bear with him.

og: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.—
t: You mean to bear me, not to bear with me.

og: [aside]  With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!
t: [To himself] What a sharp and thoughtful mind he has!

og: To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,  He prettily and aptly taunts himself.
t: To smooth over his mockery of his uncle, he cleverly and politely mocks himself.

og: So cunning and so young is wonderful.
t: It's amazing that he's so cunning while so young.

og: [to PRINCE]  My lord, will ’t please you pass along?
t: [To the PRINCE] My lord, would you like to continue on?

og: Myself and my good cousin Buckingham  Will to your mother, to entreat of her  To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.
t: My good cousin Buckingham and I will go to your mother and ask her to meet you at the Tower.

og: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?
t: What, are you going to the Tower, my lord?

og: My lord protector needs will have it so.
t: My Lord Protector Richard insists on it.

og: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
t: I won't sleep peacefully at the Tower.

og: Why, what should you fear?
t: Why, what do you have to be afraid of?

og: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost. My grandam told me he was murdered there.
t: Well, my uncle Clarence's angry ghost. My grandmother told me he was murdered there.

og: I fear no uncles dead.
t: I'm not afraid of any dead uncle.

og: Nor none that live, I hope.
t: Nor living ones, I hope.

og: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.    But come, my lord. With a heavy heart,Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.
t: If they're still alive, I should hope that I don't need to fear them.

og: Think you, my lord, this little prating YorkWas not incensèd by his subtle motherTo taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?
t: My lord, don't you think that this talkative little York was encouraged by his deceitful mother to taunt and scorn you in that outrageous manner?

og: No doubt, no doubt. O, ’tis a parlous boy,Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable. He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
t: No doubt, no doubt. Oh, he's a dangerous and cunning boy—bold, lively, ingenious, outspoken, and capable. He takes after his mother, from head to toe.

og: Well, let them rest.—
t: Well, let's leave them for the moment.

og: He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.
t: Hastings loves the Prince because of his great love for his father, the late King Edward. We won't be able to convince him.

og: What think’st thou then of Stanley? Will not he?
t: What do you think about Stanley then? Won't he join us?

og: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
t: He'll do whatever Hastings does.
