og: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,  And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings  How he doth stand affected to our purpose  And summon him tomorrow to the Tower  To sit about the coronation.
t: Well then, just do this, noble Catesby: go and sound out Lord Hastings regarding our cause. But make it seem like a vague plan for the distant future. Find out how he feels, and summon him to the Tower tomorrow for the coronation.

og: If thou dost find him tractable to us,  Encourage him and show him all our reasons.
t: If he seems like he could be convinced to join us, then encourage him and explain all our reasons to him.

og: If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling,  Be thou so too, and so break off the talk,
t: If he's surly, cold, or unwilling, then you should act like that too, and break off the conversation.

og: And give us notice of his inclination;  For we tomorrow hold divided councils,  Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.
t: Let us know how he responds, for tomorrow we will hold two separate council meetings—one public, and one in secret, only for our supporters—and you'll have lots of work to do at them.

og: Commend me to Lord William. Tell him, Catesby,  His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries  Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret castle,
t: Give my regards to Lord Hastings. Tell him, Catesby, that the dangerous enemies who have plagued him for years will be executed tomorrow at Pomfret Castle.

og: And bid my lord, for joy of this good news,  Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.
t: And to celebrate this good news, tell him to give Miss Shore an extra kiss.

og: Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.
t: Good Catesby, go do your work well.

og: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
t: My good lords, I'll do the best I can.

og: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?
t: Will we hear from you before we go to sleep, Catesby?

og: You shall, my lord.
t: You will, my lord.

og: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.
t: You'll find us both at Crosby Place.

og: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceiveLord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
t: Now, my lord, what will we do if Lord Hastings won't go along with our conspiracy?

og: Chop off his head. Something we will determine.  And look when I am king,  claim thou of me  The earldom of Hereford,
t: Chop off his head. We'll come up with something. And when I am king, you will have the earldom of Hereford—

og: and all the moveables  Whereof the king my brother was possessed.
t: and all the wealth and possessions that go with it—which my brother, King Edward, used to own.

og: I’ll claim that promise at your Grace’s hands.
t: I'll take you up on that promise, your Grace.

og: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwardsWe may digest our complots in some form.
t: And you'll see that I'll give it gladly. Come, let's eat early, so that afterwards we can think about our plot further.

og: My lord, my lord.
t: My lord, my lord.

og: Who knocks?
t: Who's knocking?

og: One from the Lord Stanley.
t: A messenger from Lord Stanley.

og: What is ‘t o’clock?
t: What time is it?

og: Upon the stroke of four.
t: Four in the morning.

og: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?
t: Can't Lord Stanley sleep on this long night?

og: So it appears by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble self.
t: It appears not, based on his message. First, he sends his regards to your noble self.

og: What then?
t: And what else?

og: Then certifies your Lordship that this night  He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm.
t: He then tells your Lordship that tonight he dreamed that the boar cut off his head.

og: Besides, he says there are two councils kept,  And that may be determined at the one  Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.
t: He also says that there will be two council meetings tomorrow, and that the results of one meeting may make you and Stanley—who will be at the other—very sorry indeed.

og: Therefore he sends to know your Lordship’s pleasure,  If you will presently take horse with him  And with all speed post with him toward the north  To shun the danger that his soul divines.
t: Because of this, he wants to know if you'll ride with him to the north as soon as possible, to escape the danger that his soul senses.

og: Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord.  Bid him not fear the separated council.
t: Go, fellow, go. Return to your lord. Tell him not to worry about the two separate meetings.

og: His Honor and myself are at the one,  And at the other is my good friend Catesby,  Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us  Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
t: He and I will be at one meeting, and my good friend Catesby will be at the other. Nothing important can happen at the secret meeting without us hearing about it.

og: Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.  And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple  To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.
t: Tell your lord that his fears are shadows without evidence. And as for his dreams, I'm surprised that he's so foolish as to trust the imaginings of restless sleep.

og: To fly the boar before the boar pursues  Were to incense the boar to follow us  And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
t: To flee the boar before he even pursues us would make the boar angry, and incite him to chase us even if he never intended to in the first place.

og: Go, bid thy master rise and come to me,  And we will both together to the Tower,  Where he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.
t: Go tell your master to get up and meet me, and we'll go together to the Tower. There he'll see that the boar will treat us kindly.

og: I’ll go, my lord, and tell him what you say.
t: I'll go and tell him what you say, my lord.

og: Many good morrows to my noble lord.
t: Good morning to you, my noble lord.

og: Good morrow, Catesby. You are early stirring.What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
t: Good morning, Catesby. You're up early. What's the news in our unsteady kingdom?

og: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord,And I believe will never stand uprightTill Richard wear the garland of the realm.
t: It is a crazy world indeed, my lord. And I believe it will never stand upright again until Richard wears the garland of the realm.

og: How “wear the garland?” Dost thou mean the crown?
t: What do you mean, "wears the garland?" Do you mean the crown?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shouldersBefore I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
t: I'll have my head cut from my shoulders before I'll see the crown so terribly misplaced. But do you think that's his intention?

og: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward  Upon his party for the gain thereof;
t: Yes, I swear on my life. And he hopes that you'll join his side and help him.

og: And thereupon he sends you this good news,  That this same very day your enemies,  The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
t: For that reason he sends you this good news: that this very day your enemies—the queen's relatives—will die at Pomfret Castle.

og: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,  Because they have been still my adversaries.
t: Indeed, I'm not sorry to hear that news, for they have always been my enemies.

og: But that I’ll give my voice on Richard’s side  To bar my master’s heirs in true descent,  God knows I will not do it, to the death.
t: But as for the idea that I'd support Richard's side in keeping my master's true heirs from the throne—God knows I'll never do it. I'd rather die.

og: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.
t: May God preserve your Lordship in that noble state of mind.

og: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,  That they which brought me in my master’s hate,  I live to look upon their tragedy.
t: But I'll laugh at all this in a year, and rejoice that I could see tragedy come to those who once convinced King Edward to hate me.

og: Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older  I’ll send some packing that yet think not on ’t.
t: Well, Catesby, before two weeks have passed I'll send some people packing who won't be expecting it at all.

og: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
t: It's a terrible thing to die when you're unprepared and not expecting it, my gracious lord.

og: O monstrous, monstrous! And so falls it out  With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey;
t: Yes, it's monstrous, monstrous! That's how it is for Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey.

og: and so ’twill do  With some men else that think themselves as safe  As thou and I, who, as thou know’st, are dear  To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
t: And that's how it will be soon for some other men who think they're as safe as you and I are—we who are dear to princely Richard and Buckingham.

og: The princes both make high account of you—    For they account his head upon the Bridge.
t: Those two lords both think highly of you.

og: I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
t: I know they do, and I deserve it.

og: Come on, come on. Where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
t: Come on, come on. Where is your boar-hunting spear, man? You're afraid of the boar, but you'll go around unarmed?

og: My lord, good morrow. —Good morrow, Catesby.—You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood,I do not like these several councils, I.
t: My lord, good morning.

og: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours,  And never in my days, I do protest,  Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.
t: My lord, I care about my life as much as you care about yours, and I swear I care about it as much now as I ever have.

og: Think you but that I know our state secure,  I would be so triumphant as I am?
t: Do you think I would be as confident as I am if I wasn't certain of our safety?

og: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,  Were jocund and supposed their states were sure,  And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;
t: When the queen's relatives rode from London, they too were joyful and felt sure that they were safe. And indeed they had no reason to worry.

og: But yet you see how soon the day o'ercast.
t: But see how quickly the day grew cloudy for them—now they're imprisoned at Pomfret Castle.

og: This sudden stab of rancor I misdoubt.  Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
t: Richard's sudden attack on them makes me worried. I pray to God that it turns out I'm being cowardly for no reason. Well, should we go to the Tower?

og: What, shall we toward the Tower? The day is spent.
t: The day has already begun.

og: Come, come. Have with you. Wot you what, my lord?Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.
t: Come, come. Let's go. Do you know what, my lord? Those lords you just mentioned—Rivers and Grey—will be beheaded today.

og: They, for their truth, might better wear their headsThan some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, let’s away.
t: To be honest, they deserve to keep their heads more than the people who've accused them deserve to keep their duke's caps. But come, my lord, let's go.

og: Go on before. I’ll talk with this good fellow.
t: Go on ahead. I'll talk with this good fellow.

og: How now, sirrah! How goes the world with thee?
t: Hello, sir! How's the world treating you?

og: The better that your Lordship please to ask.
t: Better, now that your Lordship was kind enough to ask.

og: I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now  Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.
t: I tell you, man, it's better with me now than it was the last time you met me here.

og: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower  By the suggestion of the queen’s allies.
t: At that time I was on my way to be imprisoned in the Tower, accused by the queen's allies.

og: But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself—  This day those enemies are put to death,  And I in better state than e'er I was.
t: But now, I tell you—and keep this to yourself—those enemies are being put to death today, and I'm better than ever.

og: God hold it, to your Honor’s good content!
t: May God preserve your good luck, your Honor!

og: Gramercy, fellow. There, drink that for me.
t: Thank you very much, fellow. Here, have a drink on me.

og: I thank your Honor.
t: I thank your Honor.

og: Well met, my lord. I am glad to see your Honor.
t: Hello, my lord. I'm glad to see you.

og: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.I am in your debt for your last exercise.Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.
t: I thank you with all my heart, Sir John. I'm in your debt for your last sermon. Next Sunday I'll give the church a nice donation.

og: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
t: I'll come to see you, your Lordship.

og: What, talking with a priest, Lord Chamberlain?Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
t: What, talking with a priest, Lord Hastings? Your friends at Pomfret Castle, they're the ones who need a priest. You, your Honor, have no deathbed confessions to make.

og: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,The men you talk of came into my mind.What, go you toward the Tower?
t: Honestly, when I ran into this holy man, I did think of those men you mention. So, are you going to the Tower?

og: I do, my lord, but long I shall not stay there. I shall return before your Lordship thence.
t: I am, my lord. But I won't stay there long. I'll return from there before your Lordship does.

og: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
t: That's likely, since I'm staying for lunch there.

og: And supper too, although thou know’st it not.—Come, will you go?
t: And for dinner too, though you don't know it yet.

og: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
t: I'll follow your Lordship.

og: Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell thee this:Today shalt thou behold a subject dieFor truth, for duty, and for loyalty.
t: Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell you this: today you will watch a man die for truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

og: God bless the prince from all the pack of you! A knot you are of damnèd bloodsuckers.
t: May God protect the prince from the pack of you! All of you are damned bloodsuckers.

og: You live that shall cry woe for this hereafter.
t: You'll live to regret this later.

og: Dispatch. The limit of your lives is out.
t: Enough. You've reached the limit of your lives.

og: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,Fatal and ominous to noble peers! Within the guilty closure of thy walls,Richard the Second here was hacked to death,And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.
t: Oh, Pomfret, Pomfret! Oh, you bloody prison, fatal to noblemen! King Richard II was hacked to death within your guilty walls. And now—to bring greater shame to your ominous name—we must offer up our innocent lives here.

og: Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads,When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.
t: Now old Queen Margaret's curse has fallen on our heads, when she condemned me, Hastings, and you for standing by while Richard stabbed her son.

og: Then cursed she Richard, then cursed she Buckingham.Then cursed she Hastings. O, remember, God,To hear her prayer for them, as now for us!And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.
t: Then she cursed Richard, then she cursed Buckingham, and then she cursed Hastings. Oh, God, remember to hear her prayer and punish them as you now punish us! But, dear God, please be satisfied with our blood—which is being unjustly spilled—and don't punish my sister and her princely sons.

og: Make haste. The hour of death is expiate.
t: Hurry up. The hour of death has come.

og: Come, Grey. Come, Vaughan. Let us all embrace.    Farewell until we meet in heaven.
t: Come, Grey. Come, Vaughan. Let us all embrace.  Farewell, until we meet again in heaven.

og: Now, noble peers. the cause why we are metIs to determine of the coronation.In God’s name, speak. When is the royal day?
t: Now, noble peers, we are meeting today to come to a decision about the coronation. In God's name, speak. When will the royal day be?

og: Is all things ready for the royal time?
t: Is everything ready for the royal event?

og: It is, and wants but nomination.
t: Yes, and all we need to do is name the day.

og: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.
t: Then I think tomorrow should be a favorable day.

og: Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?Who is most inward with the noble duke?
t: Who knows what the Lord Protector Richard thinks about this? Who is closest to the noble duke?

og: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
t: We think you would best know his mind, your Grace.

og: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts,  He knows no more of mine than I of yours,  Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.—
t: We know each other's faces. But as for our hearts, he doesn't know mine any more than I know yours or his, or you know mine.

og: I thank his Grace. I know he loves me well.
t: I thank you for saying that. I know he loves me well.

og: But for his purpose in the coronation,  I have not sounded him, nor he delivered  His gracious pleasure any way therein.
t: But I haven't asked him out about the coronation, and he hasn't told me his preferences about it.

og: But you, my honorable lords, may name the time,  And in the duke’s behalf I’ll give my voice,  Which I presume he’ll take in gentle part.
t: But you can name a time, my honorable lords. And I'll give my vote on the duke's behalf. I'm sure he won't mind.

og: In happy time here comes the duke himself.
t: Here comes the duke himself, right on time.

og: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
t: Good morning, my noble lords and kinsmen.

og: I have been long a sleeper; but I trust  My absence doth neglect no great design  Which by my presence might have been concluded.
t: I slept late, but I trust that my absence hasn't delayed any important decisions that required me to be here.

og: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord,William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part—I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
t: My lord, if you hadn't shown up when you did, Lord Hastings would have taken your part. He was going to cast a vote on your behalf in deciding about the coronation of the king.

og: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.  His Lordship knows me well, and loves me well.—
t: There's no man bolder than Lord Hastings. He knows me well, and loves me well.

og: Marry and will, my lord, with all my heart.
t: Indeed, I will do so with pleasure, my lord.

og: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
t: Cousin Buckingham, a word with you.

og: [they move aside]  Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business  And finds the testy gentleman so hot
t: [They move aside and speak so the others can't hear] Catesby has sounded Hastings about our business, and he found the quick-tempered gentleman to be so passionately opposed to our plan

og: As he will lose his head ere give consent  His master’s child, as worshipfully he terms it,  Shall lose the royalty of England’s throne.
t: that—as Hastings devotedly put it—he would lose his head before he'd allow his master's child to lose the throne of England.

og: Withdraw yourself awhile. I’ll go with you.
t: Go to the next room for a while. I'll go with you.

og: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
t: We haven't yet set the date for the triumphant coronation day.

og: Tomorrow, in my judgement, is too sudden,  For I myself am not so well provided  As else I would be, were the day prolonged.
t: In my opinion, tomorrow is too sudden, for I myself am not as well prepared as I would be if a later date were set.

og: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?I have sent for these strawberries.
t: Where is my lord the Duke of Gloucester? I've sent for those strawberries.

og: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.  There’s some conceit or other likes him well  When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.
t: His Grace Richard looks so cheerful and calm this morning. He has some idea or plan that he's pleased about whenever he says "good morning" with such spirit.

og: I think there’s never a man in Christendom  Can lesser hide his love or hate than he,  For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
t: I don't think there's a man in all the Christian kingdoms who's worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard is. You can know his heart from looking at his face.

og: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any livelihood he showed today?
t: And what do you see in his heart today, based on the cheer in his face?

og: Marry, that with no man here he is offended,For were he, he had shown it in his looks.
t: That he's not offended with any man here. If he were, he would have shown it in his face.

og: I pray God he be not, I say.
t: I pray to God that you're right.

og: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve  That do conspire my death with devilish plots  Of damnèd witchcraft,
t: Please tell me, what is the proper punishment for someone who conspires to kill me with wicked plots and witchcraft—

og: and that have prevailed  Upon my body with their hellish charms?
t: and who has already plagued my body with hellish magic?

og: The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord,  Makes me most forward in this princely presence  To doom th' offenders, whosoe'er they be.
t: My love for your Grace makes me say forcefully among all these lords that the offenders should be executed.

og: I say, my lord, they have deservèd death.
t: My lord, they deserve death.

og: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.
t: Then let your eyes be the witness of their evil.

og: [shows his arm]  Look how I am bewitched! Behold mine arm  Is like a blasted sapling withered up;
t: [He shows his arm] See how I am bewitched! Look at how my arm has shriveled up like a withered tree branch.

og: And this is Edward’s wife, that monstrous witch,  Consorted with that harlot, strumpet Shore,  That by their witchcraft thus have markèd me.
t: This is the work of King Edward's wife Elizabeth—that monstrous witch—and her associate, that whorish Jane Shore. They've done this to me with their witchcraft.

og: If they have done this deed, my noble lord—
t: If they have done this, my noble lord—

og: If? Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet,  Talk’st thou to me of “ifs?” Thou art a traitor—
t: "If?" You protector of that damned whore, are you talking to me about "ifs?" You are a traitor.

og: Off with his head. Now by Saint Paul I swear  I will not dine until I see the same.—
t: Off with his head. By Saint Paul, I swear I won't eat until I see him dead.

og: Woe, woe for England! Not a whit for me,  For I, too fond, might have prevented this.
t: Woe, woe for England! I pity her fate, but save no pity for myself. I might have prevented this, but I was too foolish.

og: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm,  And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.
t: Stanley dreamed that the boar cut off his head, and I laughed at him and refused to flee.

og: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble,  And started when he looked upon the Tower,  As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.  O, now I need the priest that spake to me!
t: Three times today my horse stumbled, and he bucked when he looked upon the Tower—as if reluctant to carry me to the slaughterhouse. Oh, now I need that priest I spoke to earlier!

og: I now repent I told the pursuivant,  As too triumphing, how mine enemies  Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered,  And I myself secure in grace and favor.
t: And now I regret boasting to the pursuivant that my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I was safe and secure.

og: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse  Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
t: Oh, Margaret, Margaret, now your heavy curse has fallen on poor Hastings' wretched head!

og: Come, come, dispatch. The duke would be at dinner. Make a short shrift. He longs to see your head.
t: Come, come, that's enough. The duke wants to eat his dinner. Make a quick confession. He's eager to see your head.

og: O momentary grace of mortal men,  Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
t: Oh, why do we spend so much time hunting for the temporary approval of mortal men, instead of seeking God's favor?

og: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks  Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,  Ready with every nod to tumble down  Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
t: Anyone who builds his hopes on the airy foundation of mankind's approval must live like a drunken sailor on the ship's mast—ready with every nod of his head to tumble down into the fatal ocean.

og: Come, come, dispatch. 'Tis bootless to exclaim.
t: Come on, that's enough. It's useless to make speeches.

og: O bloody Richard! Miserable England,  I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee  That ever wretched age hath looked upon.—
t: Oh, bloody Richard! Miserable England, I predict that the most frightening time you've ever seen is coming.

og: Come, cousin, canst thou quake and change thy color,  Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,
t: Come, cousin, can you shake and turn pale, and stop speaking suddenly,

og: And then begin again, and stop again,  As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?
t: and then begin again, and then stop again—as if you were driven crazy from terror?

og: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian,  Speak, and look back, and pry on every side,  Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,  Intending deep suspicion.
t: Of course, I can imitate the best of tragic actors. I can speak, and then look back, and search all around me, trembling, and jump at the least movement as if I were paranoid.

og: Ghastly looks  Are at my service, like enforcèd smiles,  And both are ready in their offices,  At any time to grace my stratagems.
t: Frightened looks and forced smiles are both at my service, ready to perform their functions whenever I need them.

og: But what, is Catesby gone?
t: But what, has Catesby gone?

og: He is; and see, he brings the mayor along.
t: He has. But see, here he comes with the mayor.

og: Lord Mayor—
t: Lord Mayor—

og: Look to the drawbridge there!
t: Look out, the drawbridge!

og: Hark, a drum!
t: Listen, a drum!

og: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.
t: Catesby, look out over the walls for us.

og: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent—
t: Lord Mayor, the reason we sent—

og: Look back! Defend thee! Here are enemies.
t: Look behind you! Defend yourself! There are enemies here.

og: God and our innocence defend and guard us!
t: May God and our own innocence defend us!

og: Be patient. They are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.
t: Calm yourself. These are friends—Ratcliffe and Lovell.

og: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.
t: Here is the head of that wicked traitor, the dangerous and unsuspected Hastings

og: So dear I loved the man that I must weep.
t: I loved the man so dearly that I must weep.

og: I took him for the plainest harmless creature  That breathed upon this earth a Christian;
t: I took him to be the most honest, harmless Christian that ever walked the earth.

og: Made him my book, wherein my soul recorded  The history of all her secret thoughts.
t: I made him like my diary, and trusted him with all my soul's most secret thoughts.

og: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue  That, his apparent open guilt omitted—
t: He covered his wickedness with a virtuous facade so well that, if his guilt hadn't become apparent—

og: I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife—  He lived from all attainder of suspects.
t: I mean his affair with Shore's wife—I never would have suspected him.

og: Well, well, he was the covert’st sheltered traitor Thatever lived.
t: Well, well, he was the most secretive, hidden traitor that ever lived.

og: [to the MAYOR]  Would you imagine, or almost believe,  Were ’t not that by great preservation  We live to tell it,
t: Can you imagine, Lord Mayor—if we hadn't been lucky enough to stop him—

og: that subtle traitor  This day had plotted, in the council house  To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?
t: that sneaky traitor was plotting to murder me and the Lord of Gloucester in the council room today?

og: Had he done so?
t: Is that true?

og: What, think you we are Turks or infidels?
t: What, do you think we're heathens or savages?

og: Or that we would, against the form of law,  Proceed thus rashly in the villain’s death,  But that the extreme peril of the case,
t: You think that we would have broken the law and executed this villain unless it was a case of extreme danger,

og: The peace of England and our persons' safety  Enforced us to this execution?
t: with England's peace and our own lives at stake?

og: Now fair befall you! He deserved his death,  And your good Graces both have well proceeded  To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
t: May only good things happen to you from now on! He deserved to die, and your Graces did well in making an example of him and discouraging other false traitors from attempting similar plots.

og: Yet had we not determined he should die  Until your Lordship came to see his end
t: Yes, but we had decided that he shouldn't die until you, Lord Mayor, were able to come and witness his execution.

og: (Which now the loving haste of these our friends,  Something against our meaning, have prevented),
t: But this was prevented by the loving haste of our friends, Lovell and Ratcliffe, who went slightly against our intentions by executing him so soon.

og: Because, my lord, I would have had you heard  The traitor speak, and timorously confess  The manner and the purpose of his treasons,
t: My lord, if you could have heard the traitor speak—and fearfully confess his plots of treason—

og: That you might well have signified the same  Unto the citizens, who haply may  Misconstrue us in him, and wail his death.
t: then you could have told the citizens what you heard. However, as it is now, they're likely to misunderstand our methods of dealing with Hastings, and mourn his death.

og: But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve  As well as I had seen and heard him speak;
t: But, my good lord, your Graces' words are just as trustworthy as if I had seen him and heard him myself.

og: And do not doubt, right noble princes both,  But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens  With all your just proceedings in this case.
t: And don't worry, you noble princes. I'll tell our citizens about how fairly you dealt with this case.

og: And to that end we wished your Lordship hereT' avoid the censures of the carping world.
t: That is why we wanted you here, your Lordship—to avoid the condemnation of the critical public.

og: Which since you come too late of our intent,Yet witness what you hear we did intend.And so, my good Lord Mayor, we bid farewell.
t: But since you came too late to see the execution as we intended, at least bear witness t our good intentions. And so, my good Lord Mayor, we bid you farewell.

og: Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.  The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post.
t: Go after him, cousin Buckingham. He's riding quickly to the town hall.

og: There, at your meetest vantage of the time,  Infer the bastardy of Edward’s children.
t: There, at the most advantageous moment, bring up the possibility that King Edward's children are illegitimate.

og: Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen  Only for saying he would make his son  Heir to the Crown—meaning indeed his house,  Which, by the sign thereof, was termèd so.
t: Tell the public how Edward executed a citizen just for saying that he would make his son "heir to the crown"—when he was only talking about the tavern he owned, "The Crown."

og: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury  And bestial appetite in change of lust,  Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,  Even where his raging eye or savage heart,  Without control, lusted to make his prey.
t: And then bring up Edward's hateful lust and his insatiable appetite for women, which stretched even to the citizens' servants, daughters, and wives—anyone that his lustful eye and savage heart wanted to prey on.

og: Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:  Tell them when that my mother went with child  Of that insatiate Edward,
t: If you need to, you can even bring me up: tell them that when my mother became pregnant with that insatiable Edward,

og: noble York  My princely father then had wars in France,
t: my noble father York was away fighting wars in France.

og: And, by true computation of the time,  Found that the issue was not his begot,  Which well appearèd in his lineaments,  Being nothing like the noble duke my father.
t: If you calculate the time of Edward's birth, and consider the fact that he looks nothing like my father, then it's clear that he's not my father's true son.

og: Yet touch this sparingly, as ’twere far off,  Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.
t: But only vaguely touch on that subject. For, as you know, my lord, my mother is still alive.

og: Doubt not, my lord. I’ll play the oratorAs if the golden fee for which I plead Were for myself. And so, my lord, adieu.
t: Don't worry, my lord. I'll speak as persuasively as if I were trying to win the throne for myself. And so farewell, my lord.

og: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard’s Castle,Where you shall find me well accompaniedWith reverend fathers and well-learnèd bishops.
t: If things go well, bring the citizens to my estate at Baynard's Castle. There you'll find me accompanied by priests and bishops.

og: I go; and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
t: I'll go now. At around three or four o'clock you should expect the news from the town hall.

og: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaw.    Go thou to Friar Penker. Bid them bothMeet me within this hour at Baynard’s Castle.
t: Lovell, go as quickly as you can to the Mayor's brother, Doctor Shaw.

og: Now will I go to take some privy order  To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight,
t: Now I'll go and make some secret arrangement to keep Clarence's brats out of sight.

og: And to give order that no manner of person  Have any time recourse unto the princes.
t: And I'll give orders that no one is to see King Edward's sons.

og: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings,  Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed,  That it may be today read o'er in Paul’s.
t: This here is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings. It's been written neatly in a formal, legal hand, so that it can be read aloud today in Saint Paul's Cathedral.

og: And mark how well the sequel hangs together:  Eleven hours I have spent to write it over,
t: But see how well the sequence of events holds together: last night, Catesby brought me the indictment, and it took me eleven hours to copy it all out.

og: For yesternight by Catesby was it sent me;  The precedent was full as long a-doing,  And yet within these five hours Hastings lived,  Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty.
t: The original indictment must have taken just as long to write. And yet, five hours, earlier Lord Hastings was alive, innocent, free, and at liberty.

og: Here’s a good world the while. Who is so gross  That cannot see this palpable device?
t: What a world we live in now! Who is so stupid that he can't see this obvious trickery?

og: Yet who so bold but says he sees it not?
t: And yet who is bold enough to speak out against it?

og: How now, how now? What say the citizens?
t: Tell me, tell me, what did the citizens say?

og: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,The citizens are mum, say not a word.
t: I swear by the holy mother of our Lord—the citizens didn't say a word.

og: Touched you the bastardy of Edward’s children?
t: Did you mention that Edward's children are bastards?

og: I did, with his contract with Lady Lucy  And his contract by deputy in France;
t: I did. I brought up his earlier engagements—to Lady Lucy, who bore him a child, and Lady Bona in France.

og: Th' unsatiate greediness of his desire  And his enforcement of the city wives;
t: And I described the insatiable greediness of his lust, and his rape of citizens' wives.

og: His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,  As being got, your father then in France,  His resemblance being not like the duke.
t: I reminded them of his harsh punishments for trivial offenses, and said that he was nothing like the duke your father, as the duke was away in France when Edward was conceived.

og: Withal, I did infer your lineaments,  Being the right idea of your father,  Both in your form and nobleness of mind;
t: Then I brought up your own appearance and suggested that you were the spitting image of your father, both in your looks and in your noble mind.

og: Laid open all your victories in Scotland,  Your discipline in war, wisdom in peace,  Your bounty, virtue, fair humility;
t: I described all your victories in Scotland, your discipline in battle, your wisdom in peacetime, your generosity, your virtue, and your noble humility.

og: Indeed, left nothing fitting for your purpose  Untouched or slightly handled in discourse.
t: Indeed, I didn't leave out anything that might have helped your case at all.

og: And when mine oratory grew toward end,  I bid them that did love their country’s good  Cry “God save Richard, England’s royal king!”
t: And then when my speech came to an end, I asked those who loved their country to cry, "God save Richard, England's royal king!"

og: And did they so?
t: And did they do it?

og: No. So God help me, they spake not a word  But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
t: No. So help me God, they didn't say a word, but just sat there like silent statues or breathing stones.

og: Stared each on other and looked deadly pale;  Which when I saw, I reprehended them  And asked the mayor what meant this willful silence.
t: They looked at each other and turned deadly pale, and when I saw this, I scolded them and asked the mayor what they meant by this stubborn silence.

og: His answer was, the people were not used  To be spoke to but by the recorder.
t: The mayor said that the citizens weren't used to being spoken to except by the town's official recorder.

og: Then he was urged to tell my tale again:  “Thus saith the duke. Thus hath the duke inferred”—  But nothing spoke in warrant from himself.
t: So I made the recorder repeat my tale. Everything was "the duke said this" and "the duke means that," and he added nothing of his own opinion.

og: When he had done, some followers of mine own,  At the lower end of the hall, hurled up their caps,  And some ten voices cried “God save King Richard!”
t: When he was done, some of my own followers at the end of the hall threw their caps in the air, and ten or so voices cried, "God save King Richard!"

og: And thus I took the vantage of those few.  “Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,” quoth I.
t: So I pounced on that feeble opportunity and said, "Thank you, noble citizens and friends.

og: "This general applause and cheerful shout  Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard"—  And even here brake off, and came away.
t: This public applause and joyful shouting clearly shows your wisdom and your love for Richard." And then I broke off my speech, and came straight here.

og: What tongueless blocks were they! Would not they speak?Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?
t: What tongueless blockheads! Why wouldn't they speak? Will the mayor and his fellow citizens not come here?

og: The Mayor is here at hand. Intend some fear;  Be not you spoke with but by mighty suit.
t: The mayor is on his way and nearly here. Pretend to be afraid, and don't let yourself be spoken to until we plead with you.

og: And look you get a prayer book in your hand  And stand between two churchmen, good my lord,  For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant
t: And get a prayer book in your hand and stand between two priests, my good lord. I'll use that to improvise an argument for your holiness.

og: And be not easily won to our requests.  Play the maid’s part: still answer “nay,” and take it.
t: But don't be easily won over by our requests to be king. Be like a coy virgin: refuse for a long time, and then finally accept.

og: I go. An if you plead as well for themAs I can say “nay” to thee for myself,No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.
t: I'm going now. If you're as good at pleading on their behalf as I am at saying "no" to you, then there's no doubt this will end well.

og: Go, go, up to the leads. The Lord Mayor knocks.
t: Go, go, up to the roof. The Lord Mayor knocks.

og: Welcome, my lord. I dance attendance here.I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
t: Welcome, my lord. I'm just entertaining myself and waiting for an audience with the duke. I don't think he wants to be spoken to.

og: Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
t: Now, Catesby, what does your lord say to my request?

og: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord,  To visit him tomorrow or next day.
t: My noble lord, he asks your Grace to please visit him tomorrow or the next day. He is inside with two priests, deep in prayer.

og: He is within, with two right reverend fathers,  Divinely bent to meditation,  And in no worldly suits would he be moved  To draw him from his holy exercise.
t: He doesn't want to be disturbed from his holy labors by any worldly business.

og: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.
t: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.

og: Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen,  No less importing than our general good,  In deep designs, and matters of great moment  Are come to have some conference with his grace.
t: Tell him that I, the mayor, and some citizens have come to confer with his Grace about matters of great importance, which concern the good of all.

og: I’ll signify so much unto him straight.
t: I'll tell him that right away.

og: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!
t: Aha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!

og: He is not lolling on a lewd love bed,  But on his knees at meditation;
t: He's not lolling about in a lustful bed, but on his knees in prayer;

og: Not dallying with a brace of courtesans,  But meditating with two deep divines;
t: not enjoying himself with a few prostitutes, but praying with two learned priests;

og: Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,  But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.
t: not sleeping to fatten up his lazy body, but praying to enrich his attentive soul.

og: Happy were England would this virtuous prince  Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof.
t: England would be blessed to have this virtuous prince wearing its crown.

og: But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.
t: But I'm afraid he won't agree to it.

og: Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!
t: Indeed, God forbid that he should say no to us!

og: I fear he will. Here Catesby comes again.
t: I fear that he will. Here comes Catesby again.

og: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
t: Now, Catesby, what does his Grace say?

og: He wonders to what end you have assembled  Such troops of citizens to come to him,  His grace not being warned thereof before.
t: He wonders why you have assembled such a large group of citizens to come to him without warning him beforehand.

og: He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
t: He fears that you mean him harm, my lord.

og: Sorry I am my noble cousin should  Suspect me that I mean no good to him.
t: I'm sorry that my noble cousin should suspect that I wish him harm.

og: By heaven, we come to him in perfect love,  And so once more return and tell his grace.
t: By heaven, we are here because we love him. Go back and tell him.

og: When holy and devout religious menAre at their beads, ’tis much to draw them thence,So sweet is zealous contemplation.
t: When holy and devout religious men are praying, it takes a great deal to draw them away, because they are so wrapped up in their eager contemplation of God.

og: See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.
t: See where his Grace is standing—between two clergymen.

og: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,  To stay him from the fall of vanity;
t: They are like two virtuous supports for a Christian prince, to prevent him from the downfall of vanity.

og: And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,  True ornaments to know a holy man.—
t: And see, he has a prayer book in his hand. These are the accessories of a holy man.

og: My lord, there needs no such apology.  I do beseech your Grace pardon me,
t: My lord, there's no need for such an apology. I ask your Grace to pardon me instead.

og: Who, earnest in the service of my God,  Deferred the visitation of my friends.  But, leaving this, what is your Grace’s pleasure?
t: I've been so focused on serving God that I kept my friends waiting. But aside from this, what is it you want?

og: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above And all good men of this ungoverned isle.
t: Only that which will, I hope, please God above, and all good men of this ungoverned island.

og: I do suspect I have done some offenseThat seems disgracious in the city’s eye,And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
t: I suspect that I've committed some offense that the citizens disapprove of, and you've come to reprimand me for my ignorance.

og: You have, my lord. Would it might please your Grace, On our entreaties, to amend your fault.
t: You have, my lord. If it would please your Grace, you should listen to our request and make up for your offense.

og: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?
t: Why else would I live in a Christian country, if I can't be forgiven for my faults?

og: Know, then, it is your fault that you resign  The supreme seat, the throne majestical,  The sceptered office of your ancestors,
t: Know, then, that it is your fault that you've given up the supreme seat, the majestic throne, the powerful office of your ancestors,

og: Your state of fortune, and your due of birth,  The lineal glory of your royal house,  To the corruption of a blemished stock,
t: your position of greatness, and the glory of your royal family—all of which are yours by birth. And instead you've handed it over to a corrupted, impure usurper.

og: Whiles in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,  Which here we waken to our country’s good,
t: You have been lost in prayer and dreamy contemplation, but now we've come to alert you of your country's needs.

og: The noble isle doth want her proper limbs—  Her face defaced with scars of infamy,  Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,
t: Our noble island wants her true self back—her face has been scarred by Edward's infamous deeds, and her royal family has been corrupted by ignoble outsiders.

og: And almost shouldered in the swallowing gulf  Of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion;
t: Its majesty is almost lost in an abyss of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion.

og: Which to recure, we heartily solicit  Your gracious self to take on you the charge  And kingly government of this your land,
t: To fix this situation, we beg your Grace to take charge and become king of this land—

og: Not as Protector, steward, substitute,  Or lowly factor for another’s gain,  But as successively, from blood to blood,  Your right of birth, your empery, your own.
t: not Lord Protector, steward, substitute, or lowly agent to another ruler, but king, the successor of a noble bloodline. This is your right by birth, your empire, your own.

og: For this, consorted with the citizens,  Your very worshipful and loving friends,  And by their vehement instigation,  In this just suit come I to move your Grace.
t: It's for this purpose that I have come with these citizens—who are your devoted and loving friends, and vehemently begged me to do this—to try and convince your Grace to accept our plea.

og: I cannot tell if to depart in silence  Or bitterly to speak in your reproof  Best fitteth my degree or your condition.
t: I can't decide if I should leave in silence or bitterly scold you. I don't know which response is more appropriate to my rank and your social position.

og: If not to answer, you might haply think  Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded  To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,  Which fondly you would here impose on me.
t: If I say nothing, you might think that my silence means consent, and you'll assume that I agree to bear the golden burden of responsibility that you're foolishly trying to impose on me.

og: If to reprove you for this suit of yours,  So seasoned with your faithful love to me,  Then on the other side I checked my friends.
t: But if I scold you for this request just after you've proven your faithful love for me, then I would be guilty of rebuking my friends.

og: Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,  And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,  Definitively thus I answer you:
t: Therefore I will speak, and so avoid the first possibility, but with my words I will avoid the second. So this is my answer, once and for all:

og: Your love deserves my thanks, but my desert  Unmeritable shuns your high request.
t: I thank you for your love, but I don't deserve to be king. So I must turn down your noble request.

og: First, if all obstacles were cut away  And that my path were even to the crown  As the ripe revenue and due of birth,
t: Even if all obstacles were removed and my path led straight to the crown—my proper birthright—

og: Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,  So mighty and so many my defects,  That I would rather hide me from my greatness,
t: my poverty of spirit and my many other flaws would still make me prefer to hide from my greatness, rather than be swallowed up by it and be smothered in glory.

og: Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,  Than in my greatness covet to be hid  And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
t: I am only a small boat, unprepared for the stormy sea of kingship.

og: But, God be thanked, there is no need of me,  And much I need to help you, were there need.
t: But, thank God, there is no need for me to rule.

og: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,  Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time,  Will well become the seat of majesty,  And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
t: The royal tree has left us royal fruit, which, with time, will fit the throne well, and make us all happy as our king.

og: On him I lay what you would lay on me,  The right and fortune of his happy stars,  Which God defend that I should wring from him.
t: I lay on him the responsibility you want to lay on me, as it is his birthright and his happy destiny. God forbid that I should steal the crown from him.

og: My lord, this argues conscience in your Grace,  But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,  All circumstances well considerèd.
t: My lord, your response shows that you have a strong conscience, but your objections are trivial, especially considering the circumstances.

og: You say that Edward is your brother’s son;  So say we too, but not by Edward’s wife.
t: You say that Prince Edward is your brother's son. We agree, but not by your brother's wife.

og: For first was he contract to Lady Lucy—  Your mother lives a witness to that vow—  And afterward by substitute betrothed  To Bona, sister to the king of France.
t: King Edward was first engaged to Lady Lucy—and your mother lives as a witness to this—and after that he was betrothed to Lady Bona, the King of France's sister-in-law.

og: These both put off, a poor petitioner,  A care-crazed mother to a many sons,  A beauty-waning and distressèd widow,  Even in the afternoon of her best days,  Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye,  Seduced the pitch and height of his degree  To base declension and loathed bigamy.
t: But when both these engagements failed, Elizabeth Grey—a harried mother of many sons, a poor widow losing her former beauty, a woman past her prime—took advantage of his lust and seduced him away from his role of majesty.

og: By her in his unlawful bed he got  This Edward, whom our manners term “the Prince.”  More bitterly could I expostulate,
t: She led him to drop his standards and commit adultery with her. With him she conceived this illegitimate Edward, whom we now politely call "the Prince."

og: Save that, for reverence to some alive,  I give a sparing limit to my tongue.
t: I could describe even worse things, too, but I'll restrain myself out of respect for some who are still alive.

og: Then, good my lord, take to your royal self  This proffered benefit of dignity,  If not to bless us and the land withal,  Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry  From the corruption of abusing times  Unto a lineal, true-derivèd course.
t: Therefore, my good lord, even if you don't want to bless us and the land with your rule, then at least accept this offered crown to rescue your noble family from its current corruption. Return the line of hereditary kingship to a true, straight course.

og: Do, good my lord. Your citizens entreat you.
t: Do accept, my lord. Your citizens beg you.

og: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.
t: Don't refuse this love we offer you, mighty lord.

og: O, make them joyful. Grant their lawful suit.
t: Oh, make them joyful. Grant their request!

og: Alas, why would you heap this care on me?  I am unfit for state and majesty.
t: Alas, why would you heap this responsibility on me? I am unfit for power and majesty.

og: I do beseech you, take it not amiss;  I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.
t: Don't take this the wrong way, but I cannot and will not give in to you.

og: If you refuse it, as in love and zeal  Loath to depose the child, your brother’s son—  As well we know your tenderness of heart
t: If you're refusing this out of love and family honor, because you're reluctant to depose the child, your brother's son—we all know how tender your heart is.

og: And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,  Which we have noted in you to your kindred  And equally indeed to all estates—
t: We know what gentle, kind, and tearful feelings you have for your relatives, and indeed for people of any rank and status.

og: Yet know whe'er you accept our suit or no,  Your brother’s son shall never reign our king,  But we will plant some other in the throne,  To the disgrace and downfall of your house.
t: But know this: whether or not you accept our request, your brother's son will never be our king. We'll find someone else to take the throne, to the disgrace and downfall of your family.

og: And in this resolution here we leave you.—
t: And with this we leave you.

og: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!
t: Oh, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!

og: Call them again, sweet prince. Accept their suit.If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
t: Call them back, sweet prince. Accept their request. If you deny them, the whole country will regret it.

og: Will you enforce me to a world of cares?  Call them again.
t: Would you force me into a world of worries? Call them back then.

og: I am not made of stones,  But penetrable to your kind entreaties,  Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
t: I am not made of stone. I can be persuaded by these kind pleas, even though it goes against my conscience and my soul.

og: Cousin of Buckingham and sage, grave men,  Since you will buckle fortune on my back,  To bear her burden, whe'er I will or no,  I must have patience to endure the load;
t: Cousin Buckingham and you wise, solemn men, since you intend to force the crown onto my head—to bear its burden whether I want to or not—then I must have the patience to endure the load.

og: But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach  Attend the sequel of your imposition,  Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me  From all the impure blots and stains thereof,
t: But if any foul scandal or ugly criticism comes of this, the mere fact that you forced me to accept must clear me from any future blame.

og: For God doth know, and you may partly see,  How far I am from the desire of this.
t: For God knows, and you can see, how reluctant I am to accept this responsibility.

og: God bless your Grace! We see it and will say it.
t: God bless your Grace! We will bear witness to the fact that you didn't want the crown.

og: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.
t: And in saying so, you'll only be telling the truth.

og: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!
t: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, England's worthy king!

og: Amen.
t: Amen.

og: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?
t: Will you let yourself be crowned tomorrow?

og: Even when you please, since you will have it so.
t: Whenever you want, since you will insist on it.

og: Tomorrow, then, we will attend your Grace, And so most joyfully we take our leave.
t: Tomorrow, then. We will wait on your Grace. And now we joyfully bid you farewell.

og: Come, let us to our holy task again.—Farewell, my cousin. Farewell, gentle friends.
t: Come, let us return to our holy labors.

og: Who meets us here? My niece Plantagenet  Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
t: Who is this? My granddaughter Plantagenet, led by the hand of her kind aunt, the Duchess of Gloucester?

og: Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower,  On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.—
t: Now, I swear, she's heading to the Tower to greet the young prince, whom she loves so purely.

og: God give your Graces bothA happy and a joyful time of day.
t: May God grant both of you a nice day.

og: As much to you, good sister. Whither away?
t: And you too, good sister-in-law. Where are you off to?

og: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess,Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.
t: Just to the Tower. And I can guess that I'm going for the same reason you are: to greet the gentle princes who are staying there.

og: Kind sister, thanks. We’ll enter all together.
t: Kind sister-in-law, thanks. We'll all go together.

og: And in good time here the lieutenant comes.—Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,How doth the prince and my young son of York?
t: And here comes the lieutenant, right on time.

og: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,I may not suffer you to visit them.The king hath strictly charged the contrary.
t: They are well, dear madam. But if you'll pardon me, I'm not allowed to let you visit them. The king has strictly forbidden it.

og: The king? Who’s that?
t: The king? Who's that?

og: I mean, the Lord Protector.
t: I mean the Lord Protector.

og: The Lord protect him from that kingly title! Hath he set bounds between their love and me?I am their mother. Who shall bar me from them?
t: And may the Lord protect the crown from him! Is he trying to set up barriers between my children and me? I am their mother. Who will forbid me from seeing them?

og: I am their father’s mother. I will see them.
t: I am their father's mother. I will see them.

og: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother.Then bring me to their sights. I’ll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
t: I am their aunt by marriage, but I love them like a mother. Bring me to see them. I'll take your office upon myself, Lieutenant—and take all the blame as well.

og: No, madam, no. I may not leave it so.I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.
t: No, madam, no. I cannot do that. I am bound by oath, so you must forgive me.

og: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence,  And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother  And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.
t: If I were greeting you ladies again in just an hour, I would be saluting you, Duchess of York, as the mother of two fair queens.

og: Ah, cut my lace asunder that my pent heart May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon With this dead-killing news!
t: Oh, cut my dress open so that my constrained heart can have some room to beat, or else I'll faint from this deadly news!

og: Despiteful tidings! O, unpleasing news!
t: Cruel tidings! Oh, unhappy news!

og: Be of good cheer, mother. How fares your Grace?
t: Cheer up, mother. How are you feeling?

og: O Dorset, speak not to me. Get thee gone.  Death and destruction dogs thee at thy heels.
t: Oh Dorset, don't speak to me. Leave immediately. Death and destruction are snapping at your heels.

og: Thy mother’s name is ominous to children.  If thou wilt outstrip death, go, cross the seas,  And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell.
t: Your mother's name has become a bad omen. If you want to outrun death, then go. Cross the seas to France, and live with Richmond, out of the reach of hell.

og: Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughterhouse,  Lest thou increase the number of the dead
t: Go, run away. Run away from this slaughterhouse, before you end up a body increasing the number of the dead,

og: And make me die the thrall of Margaret’s curse,  Nor mother, wife, nor England’s counted queen.
t: and make me die the slave of Margaret's curse—neither wife, nor mother, nor England's queen.

og: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.    Take all the swift advantage of the hours.You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way.Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
t: Madam, your advice is full of wisdom and caring.

og: Come, madam, come. I in all haste was sent.
t: Come, madam, come. I was sent in a great hurry.

og: And I in all unwillingness will go.  O, would to God that the inclusive verge  Of golden metal that must round my brow  Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!
t: And with great unwillingness I'll go. Oh, I wish to God that the golden crown I must wear would turn to red-hot steel, and burn my skull to the brains!

og: Anointed let me be with deadly venom,  And die ere men can say, “God save the Queen.”
t: Let me be anointed with deadly venom instead of holy oil, so I can die before anyone manages to say, "God save the Queen!"

og: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory.To feed my humor, wish thyself no harm.
t: Go, go, poor soul. I don't envy your new throne. But make me happy by not wishing harm on yourself.

og: No? Why? When he that is my husband now  Came to me, as I followed Henry’s corse,  When scarce the blood was well washed from his hands  Which issued from my other angel husband
t: No? Why not? Richard—who is now my husband—first came to me when he'd hardly washed all the blood off his hands from killing both my first, angelic husband and my husband's father—

og: And that dear saint which then I weeping followed—  O, when, I say, I looked on Richard’s face,  This was my wish: be thou, quoth I, accursed  For making me, so young, so old a widow;
t: that dear saint Henry—whose corpse I was tearfully following. Oh, I tell you, when I looked at Richard's face then, my only wish was this: "May you be cursed for making me a widow so young.

og: And, when thou wedd’st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;  And be thy wife, if any be so mad,  More miserable by the life of thee  Than thou hast made me by my dear lord’s death.
t: When you get married, let sorrow haunt your bed, and may your wife—if any woman is crazy enough to marry you—be made more miserable by your life than you've made me by my dear husband's death."

og: Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,  Within so small a time my woman’s heart  Grossly grew captive to his honey words  And proved the subject of mine own soul’s curse,
t: But alas! Before I could even repeat my curse again, my woman's heart stupidly fell prey to his honeyed words. I then proved the victim of my own soul's curse.

og: Which hitherto hath held my eyes from rest,  For never yet one hour in his bed  Did I enjoyed the golden dew of sleep,  But with his timorous dreams was still awaked.
t: From then on, I haven't had one hour of precious sleep in his bed without being awakened by the sounds of his nightmares.

og: Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick,  And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.
t: It doesn't matter, though—Richard hates me because of my father, Warwick, who was his enemy. He'll soon get rid of me, no doubt.

og: Poor heart, adieu. I pity thy complaining.
t: Poor heart, farewell. I pity your troubles.

og: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
t: No more than I mourn for yours, from the depths of my soul.

og: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.
t: Farewell, you sad new queen.

og: Adieu, poor soul that tak’st thy leave of it.
t: And farewell to you, sad old queen.

og: [to DORSET]  Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee.
t: [To DORSET] You go to Richmond, and may good fortune go with you.

og: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.—
t: Wait, and look back at the Tower with me.

og: Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes  Whom envy hath immured within your walls—
t: You ancient stones of the Tower, have pity on those tender children who are locked inside your walls because of envy.

og: Rough cradle for such little pretty ones.
t: You are a rough cradle for such little pretty ones.

og: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow  For tender princes, use my babies well.
t: You rude, ragged nurse; you old, sullen playmate for tender princes—treat my babies well.

og: So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.
t: And so I bid your stones farewell, you Tower, with all my foolish sorrow.

og: Stand all apart. —Cousin of Buckingham.
t: Everyone stand aside.

og: My gracious sovereign.
t: My gracious sovereign.

og: Give me thy hand.
t: Give me your hand.

og: Thus high, by thy advice  And thy assistance is King Richard seated.
t: I now have this high seat as King Richard because of your advice and assistance.

og: But shall we wear these glories for a day,  Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?
t: But will I have these glories for a day only, or will they last long enough for me to enjoy them?

og: Still live they, and forever let them last.
t: May they live on forever.

og: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed.Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
t: Ah, Buckingham, now I must test you to see if you're true gold indeed. Young Prince Edward is alive. Think about what I might say next.

og: Say on, my loving lord.
t: Go on, my loving lord.

og: Why, Buckingham, I say I would be king,
t: Why, Buckingham, I said I wanted to be king.

og: Why so you are, my thrice-renownèd lord.
t: Why, you are king, my glorious lord.

og: Ha! Am I king? 'Tis so—but Edward lives.
t: Ha! Am I king? Perhaps it's so—but Edward still lives.

og: True, noble prince.
t: True, noble prince.

og: O bitter consequence  That Edward still should live “true noble prince!”  Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.
t: Oh, what a bitter conclusion that Edward should still live as the "true, noble prince!" Cousin, you didn't use to be so stupid.

og: Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead,  And I would have it suddenly performed.
t: Shall I speak plainly? I want the bastards dead, and I want it done immediately.

og: What sayest thou now? Speak suddenly. Be brief.
t: What do you say now? Speak quickly, and be brief.

og: Your Grace may do your pleasure.
t: Your Grace can do as he pleases.

og: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?
t: Tut, tut, you've grown icy. Your kindness freezes over. Tell me, do you agree that they must die?

og: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord,Before I positively speak in this.I will resolve you herein presently.
t: Give me a moment to breathe, dear lord, a pause before I make a statement. I'll give you my answer shortly.

og: The king is angry. See, he gnaws his lip.
t: The king is angry. See how he bites his lip.

og: [aside]  I will converse with iron-witted fools  And unrespective boys.
t: [To himself] I only want to deal with unfeeling fools and careless boys.

og: None are for me  That look into me with considerate eyes.
t: I want nothing to do with anyone who can read me well.

og: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.—
t: Ambitious Buckingham is growing too thoughtful.

og: My lord?
t: My lord?

og: Know’st thou not any whom corrupting goldWill tempt unto a close exploit of death?
t: Do you know anyone who can be tempted with gold into secretly killing someone?

og: I know a discontented gentleman  Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit.
t: I know one unhappy gentleman whose empty wallet doesn't match his proud spirit.

og: Gold were as good as twenty orators,  And will, no doubt, tempt him to anything.
t: Gold is better than twenty speeches, and will, no doubt, tempt him to do anything.

og: What is his name?
t: What is his name?

og: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
t: His name is Tyrrel, my lord.

og: I partly know the man. Go, call him hither, boy
t: I know the man a little. Go, call him here, boy.

og: [aside]  The deep-revolving witty Buckingham  No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels
t: [To himself] The deep-thinking, clever Buckingham will no longer be privy to my plots.

og: Hath he so long held out with me, untired,  And stops he now for breath? Well, be it so.
t: Has he run with me for so long, only to stop for a "moment to breathe" now? Well, so be it.

og: How now, Lord Stanley, what’s the news?
t: Hello, Lord Stanley, what's the news?

og: Know, my loving lord,The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.
t: You should know, my loving lord: I've heard that the Marquess of Dorset has fled to Richmond in France.

og: Come hither, Catesby. Rumor it abroad  That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.
t: Come here, Catesby. Spread around a rumor that my wife Anne is very sick.

og: I will take order for her keeping close.  Enquire me out some mean poor gentleman,  Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.
t: I will make arrangements for keeping her locked up. And find me some poor gentleman whom I can marry straight away to Clarence's daughter.

og: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.  Look how thou dream’st! I say again, give out  That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.
t: Clarence's son is an idiot, so I'm not afraid of him. But look at you daydreaming! I say again: spread the rumor that Anne, my queen, is sick and likely to die.

og: About it, for it stands me much upon  To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
t: Hurry up—it's very important that I destroy anything that might come to damage me.

og: [aside]  I must be married to my brother’s daughter,  Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
t: [To himself] I must marry my brother Edward's daughter, or else my kingdom is only standing on fragile glass.

og: Murder her brothers, and then marry her—  Uncertain way of gain.
t: Murder her brothers, and then marry her—it's a strange way to go about things.

og: But I am in  So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin.  Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
t: But I'm so steeped in blood at this point that one sin must follow another. These eyes of mine have no tears of pity.

og: Is thy name Tyrrel?
t: Is your name Tyrrel?

og: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
t: James Tyrrel, your most obedient subject.

og: Art thou indeed?
t: Are you indeed?

og: Prove me, my gracious lord.
t: Let me prove it, my gracious lord.

og: Dar’st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
t: Would you dare to kill a friend of mine?

og: Please you. But I had rather kill two enemies.
t: If it would please you. But I would rather kill two enemies.

og: Why then, thou hast it. Two deep enemies,  Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleep’s disturbers,  Are they that I would have thee deal upon.
t: Well, you can do that then. I want you to kill two great enemies of mine, enemies of my sleep and my peace of mind.

og: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.
t: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

og: Let me have open means to come to them,And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.
t: Let me have free access to reach them, and soon you won't have to fear them anymore.

og: Thou sing’st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
t: Your words are sweet music. Come here, Tyrrel.

og: Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear.
t: Go, with this password. Rise and listen.

og: There is no more but so. Say it is done,And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.
t: There's nothing more than that. When you tell me the deed is done, I will love you and promote you for it.

og: I will dispatch it straight.
t: I'll do it straight away.

og: My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.
t: My lord, I've been considering the request you just asked me about.

og: Well, let that rest. Dorset is fled to Richmond.
t: Well, forget about that. Dorset has fled to join Richmond.

og: I hear the news, my lord.
t: I heard that news, my lord.

og: Stanley, he is your wife’s son. Well, look unto it.
t: Stanley, Richmond is your wife's son. Well, find out what she knows.

og: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise,  For which your honor and your faith is pawned—
t: My lord, I want to claim the gift you promised me on your honor and faith—

og: Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables  Which you promisèd I shall possess.
t: the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it, which you swore that I would have.

og: Stanley, look to your wife. If she conveyLetters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
t: Stanley, watch your wife. If she sends any letters to Richmond, you will answer for it.

og: What says your Highness to my just request?
t: What does your Highness say to my just request?

og: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth  Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
t: I remember that Henry the Sixth prophesied that Richmond would be king one day,

og: When Richmond was a little peevish boy.  A king, perhaps—
t: when Richmond was only a foolish boy. A king, perhaps—

og: My lord—
t: My lord—

og: How chance the prophet could not at that timeHave told me, I being by, that I should kill him?
t: But why wasn't the prophet able to foresee that I, who was there at the time, would kill him?

og: My lord, your promise for the earldom—
t: My lord, your promise of the earldom—

og: Richmond? When last I was at Exeter,  The mayor in courtesy showed me the castle  And called it Rougemont,
t: Richmond? The last time I was in Exeter, the mayor politely showed me a castle and called it "Rougemont."

og: at which name I started,  Because a bard of Ireland told me once  I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
t: The name startled me, for an Irish poet once told me that I wouldn't live long after seeing Richmond.

og: My Lord—
t: My lord—

og: Ay, what’s o'clock?
t: Hey, what time is it?

og: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mindOf what you promised me.
t: I am reminding your Grace of what you promised me.

og: Well, but what’s o'clock?
t: Well, but what time is it?

og: Upon the stroke of ten.
t: Almost ten o'clock.

og: Well, let it strike.
t: Well, let it strike ten then.

og: Why let it strike?
t: Why "let it strike?"

og: Because that, like a jack, thou keep’st the strokeBetwixt thy begging and my meditation.I am not in the giving vein today.
t: Because you're like the peasant who strikes the bell, interrupting my thoughts with your begging. I'm not in the giving mood today.

og: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.
t: Well then, give me a final answer of whether I'll have the earldom or not.

og: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.
t: You're annoying me. I'm not in the mood.

og: And is it thus? Repays he my deep service  With such deep contempt? Made I him king for this?
t: Is this how it is? He rewards my great service with such great contempt? Did I make him king for this?

og: O, let me think on Hastings and be gone  To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
t: Oh, let me learn from Hastings and hurry away to Brecknock, while my frightened head is still on my shoulders!

og: The tyrannous and bloody act is done,  The most arch deed of piteous massacre  That ever yet this land was guilty of.
t: The tyrannous and bloody act is done. It was the worst, most horrible massacre of which this land has ever been guilty.

og: Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn  To do this piece of ruthless butchery,
t: Dighton and Forrest—whom I hired to do this piece of ruthless butchery—are experienced villains.

og: Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs,  Melted with tenderness and mild compassion,  Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story.
t: They are like bloody hunting dogs. But even they melted with tenderness and compassion, and wept like children when they told the sad story of what they'd done.

og: “O thus” quoth Dighton, “lay those gentle babes.”  “Thus, thus,” quoth Forrest, “girdling one another  Within their alabaster innocent arms.
t: "The gentle children lay like this," Dighton said. "Like this," said Forrest, "embracing each other with their white innocent arms.

og: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,  And in their summer beauty kissed each other.
t: Their lips were touching, like four red roses on a stalk.

og: A book of prayers on their pillow lay,  Which once,” quoth Forrest, “almost changed my mind,  But O, the devil—”There the villain stopped;
t: And a prayer book lay on their pillow," said Forrest, "which almost made me change my mind. But oh, the devil—" And there the villain stopped talking,

og: When Dighton thus told on: “We smotherèd  The most replenishèd sweet work of nature  That from the prime creation e'er she framed.”
t: and Dighton continued the tale: "We smothered the most perfect, sweet work that nature ever created."

og: Hence both are gone with conscience and remorse;  They could not speak; and so I left them both  To bear this tidings to the bloody king.
t: Both men were crushed with remorse, so that they couldn't speak any more. I left them both to bring this news to the bloody king.

og: And here he comes.—All health, my sovereign lord.
t: And here he comes.

og: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?
t: Kind Tyrrel, will your news make me happy?

og: If to have done the thing you gave in chargeBeget your happiness, be happy then,For it is done.
t: If the completion of your task will make you happy, be happy then. For it is done.

og: But did’st thou see them dead?
t: But did you see them dead?

og: I did, my lord.
t: I did, my lord.

og: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?
t: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

og: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them, But where, to say the truth, I do not know.
t: The chaplain of the Tower has buried them. But to tell you the truth, I don't know where.

og: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after-supper,  When thou shalt tell the process of their death.
t: Tyrrel, come back to me soon after dessert, and tell me the details of their deaths.

og: Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,  And be inheritor of thy desire.  Farewell till then.
t: In the meantime, think about how I can reward you with whatever you desire. Farewell until then.

og: I humbly take my leave.
t: I humbly leave you.

og: The son of Clarence have I pent up close,  His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage,  The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham’s bosom,  And Anne my wife hath bid this world goodnight.
t: I have Clarence's son locked up, and Clarence's daughter married off to a poor fellow. Edward's sons are sleeping in heaven, and my wife Anne has bid this world goodnight.

og: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims  At young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter,  And by that knot looks proudly on the crown,  To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.
