t: But I know that Richmond aims to marry young Elizabeth—my brother Edward's daughter—and win the crown through that match. So now I go to her: a jolly, lively wooer.

og: My lord!
t: My lord!

og: Good or bad news, that thou com’st in so bluntly?
t: Is it good news or bad news, that you come bursting in here?

og: Bad news, my lord. Morton is fled to Richmond,And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen,Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.
t: Bad news, my lord. The Bishop of Ely has fled to Richmond. And Buckingham, backed by his army of hardy Welshmen, is on the march, his power still growing.

og: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near  Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength.
t: Ely joining Richmond troubles me more than Buckingham and his hastily raised army.

og: Come, I have learned that fearful commenting  Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
t: Come, I have learned that frightened talk only leads to delay, and delay leads to slow ruin. Fiery speed will be my course of action.

og: Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary;  Then fiery expedition be my wing,  Jove’s Mercury, and herald for a king.
t: I will be Jupiter, with wing-footed Mercury as my messenger.

og: Go, muster men. My counsel is my shield.  We must be brief when traitors brave the field.
t: Go, rally men to fight. My sword will be my advisor. We must act quickly when traitors march to war.

og: So now prosperity begins to mellow  And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
t: So now the Yorks' prosperity has ripened and rotted, falling into the mouth of death.

og: Here in these confines slyly have I lurked  To watch the waning of mine enemies.
t: I've been lurking in the shadows here to watch my enemies come to ruin,

og: A dire induction am I witness to,  And will to France, hoping the consequence  Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
t: and it's a terrible scene I've witnessed—an ominous prologue to what I hope will be a bitter, dark, and tragic conclusion.

og: Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret. Who comes here?
t: I'll head to France. But hide now, wretched Margaret. Who's coming?

og: Ah, my poor princes! Ah, my tender babes,  My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets,
t: Ah, my poor princes! Ah, my tender babes—my flowers who didn't have a chance to bloom!

og: If yet your gentle souls fly in the air  And be not fixed in doom perpetual,
t: If your gentle souls are still flying about in the air and haven't yet landed in their final resting place,

og: Hover about me with your airy wings  And hear your mother’s lamentation.
t: then hover about me now with your airy wings, and hear your mother's cries of mourning.

og: Hover about her; say that right for rightHath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.
t: Hover about her, spirits, and say that she got what she deserved, since you were also killed before your time.

og: So many miseries have crazed my voiceThat my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute.Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
t: So many miseries have cracked my voice that my tongue is weary of wailing and has gone silent. Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?

og: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet;Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.
t: One Plantagenet makes up for another. Edward dies to pay the debt for another Edward's death.

og: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambsAnd throw them in the entrails of the wolf?When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
t: Oh God, will you abandon such gentle lambs, and throw them to the wolf? How could you sleep when such a deed was done?

og: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.
t: God slept when my holy husband Henry died, and my sweet son Edward.

og: [sitting down]  Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost,
t: [Sitting down] My life has died. My sight has gone blind. I'm like a ghost that's still alive.

og: Woe’s scene, world’s shame, grave’s due by life usurped,
t: I am the bearer of misfortune; the shame of the world; a soul that rightfully belongs to the grave.

og: Brief abstract and record of tedious days,  Rest thy unrest on England’s lawful earth,  Unlawfully made drunk with innocent blood.
t: As a summary and brief record of my unbearable life, I will rest my restless bones on England's lawful earth, which is now covered with innocent blood, against the laws of man and nature.

og: [sitting down beside her]  Ah, that thou wouldst as soon afford a grave  As thou canst yield a melancholy seat,
t: [Sitting down beside her] Ah, if only the earth could provide me with a grave instead of just a sad seat,

og: Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.  O, who hath any cause to mourn but we?
t: then I would bury my bones, instead of simply resting them here. Oh, who has any right to mourn except for us?

og: [joining them]  If ancient sorrow be most reverend,  Give mine the benefit of seigniory,  And let my griefs frown on the upper hand.
t: [Joining them and sitting] If the oldest sorrow is the most revered, then give mine the privilege of seniority, and let my grief have the upper hand.

og: If sorrow can admit society,  Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine.
t: If you can accept company in your sadness, then consider your losses again by looking at mine.

og: I had an Edward till a Richard killed him;  I had a husband till a Richard killed him.
t: I had an Edward until a Richard killed him. And I had a husband, Henry, until a Richard killed him.

og: Thou hadst an Edward till a Richard killed him;  Thou hadst a Richard till a Richard killed him.
t: You had an Edward until a Richard killed him, and you had a Richard, young York, until a Richard killed him.

og: I had a Richard too, and thou did’st kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holp’st to kill him.
t: I had a Richard too, my husband, and you killed him. I had a Rutland too, and you helped to kill him.

og: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard killed him  Then forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept  A hellhound that doth hunt us all to death—
t: You had a Clarence too, and Richard killed him. The kennel of your womb has let loose a hellhound that hunts us all to death—

og: That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,  To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood;
t: a dog that had teeth before it had eyes. His teeth attack lambs and lap up their gentle blood.

og: That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,  That reigns in gallèd eyes of weeping souls;
t: He is the greatest tyrant of the earth, and thrives among the tears of those he has injured.

og: That foul defacer of God’s handiwork  Thy womb let loose to chase us to our graves.
t: That foul creature who defaces God's handiwork came forth from your womb to chase us to our graves.

og: O upright, just, and true-disposing God,  How do I thank thee that this carnal cur  Preys on the issue of his mother’s body  And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!
t: Oh, upright, just, and generous God, how can I thank you enough that this deadly mutt preys on his mother's offspring and makes her a companion to others' sorrow?

og: O Harry’s wife, triumph not in my woes! God witness with me, I have wept for thine.
t: Oh, Henry's wife, do not triumph in my woes! As God is my witness, I have wept for yours.

og: Bear with me, I am hungry for revenge,  And now I cloy me with beholding it.
t: Bear with me. I am hungry for revenge, and now I'm almost sick from gorging myself upon it.

og: Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward,  Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
t: Your son Edward—who killed my son Edward—is dead. Your grandson Edward is also dead,

og: Young York, he is but boot, because both they  Matched not the high perfection of my loss.
t: with young York thrown in as an extra, because both your grandsons didn't equal my lost son.

og: Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward,  And the beholders of this frantic play,  Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,  Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.
t: Your Clarence—who stabbed my son Edward—is dead. And the audience to this frantic play—the adulterer Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey—have all been smothered in early graves.

og: Richard yet lives, hell’s black intelligencer,  Only reserved their factor to buy souls  And send them thither.
t: Richard still lives as hell's dark spy, only allowed to remain long enough to buy souls and send them down below.

og: But at hand, at hand  Ensues his piteous and unpitied end.
t: But soon, soon his pitiful and well-deserved end will come.

og: Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray,  To have him suddenly conveyed from hence.
t: The earth gapes open, hell burns, devils roar, and saints pray that he might be quickly sent from this earth.

og: Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray,  That I may live to say, “The dog is dead.”
t: Dear God, end his life soon, so that I may live to say, "The dog is dead!"

og: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curseThat bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!
t: Oh, you once did prophesy that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that swollen spider, that foul hunchbacked toad!

og: I called thee then “vain flourish of my fortune.”  I called thee then poor shadow, “painted queen,”  The presentation of but what I was,
t: And then I called you a "poor imitation of a queen" and a "meaningless decoration on my throne"—the image of what I was in reality—

og: The flattering index of a direful pageant,  One heaved a-high, to be hurled down below,  A mother only mocked with two fair babes,  A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag  To be the aim of every dangerous shot,  A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble,  A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
t: the pretty prologue to an ominous tragedy; a woman lifted high only to be hurled down below; a mother mocked with the gifts of two dear babies, only to lose them. You were a shadow of a queen; a gaudy banner that enemies could target; an empty symbol of dignity; a breath; a bubble; a mockery of a queen; a stand-in only there to fill the role.

og: Where is thy husband now? Where be thy brothers?  Where are thy two sons? Wherein dost thou joy?
t: And where is your husband now? Where are your brothers? Where are your two sons?

og: Who sues and kneels and says “God save the queen?”  Where be the bending peers that flattered thee?  Where be the thronging troops that followed thee?
t: Where do you find your joy? Who kneels before you and makes requests and says, "God save the queen?" Where are the bowing noblemen who flattered you? Where are the crowds that followed you?

og: Decline all this, and see what now thou art:  For happy wife, a most distressèd widow;  For joyful mother, one that wails the name;  For queen, a very caitiff crowned with care;
t: Without all this, see what you are: instead of a happy wife, a grieving widow; instead of a joyful mother, a woman who wails over her children; instead of a queen, a poor wretch crowned only with worries;

og: For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;  For she that scorned at me, now scorned of me;  For she being feared of all, now fearing one;  For she commanding all, obeyed of none.
t: instead of one granting favors, one humbly begging for favors. She who mocked me is now mocked by me, and she who commanded everyone is now obeyed by no one. See how the wheel of justice has turned, leaving you the victim of time.

og: Thus hath the course of justice whirled about  And left thee but a very prey to time,  Having no more but thought of what thou wast  To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
t: All you have left are the memories of your former glory, which torture you even more when you consider what you've become.

og: Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not  Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
t: You usurped my position, and now see how you usurp my sorrow.

og: Now thy proud neck bears half my burdened yoke,  From which even here I slip my weary head  And leave the burthen of it all on thee.
t: Your proud neck bears half of my heavy burden, but now let me give it all to you.

og: Farewell, York’s wife, and queen of sad mischance.  These English woes will make me smile in France.
t: Farewell, York's wife, queen of sad misfortune. These English woes will make me smile in France.

og: O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile,And teach me how to curse mine enemies.
t: Oh, you who are so skilled in curses, stay a while and teach me how to curse my enemies.

og: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;  Compare dead happiness with living woe;
t: Don't sleep at night, and don't eat during the day. Compare lost happiness with current suffering.

og: Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were,  And he that slew them fouler than he is.
t: Remember your children as being sweeter than they were, and think of the one that killed them as fouler than he is.

og: My words are dull. O, quicken them with thine!
t: My words are dull. Oh, give them life with yours!

og: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.
t: Your suffering will make them sharp, so they can pierce like mine.

og: Why should calamity be full of words?
t: Why should this catastrophe be accompanied by so many words?

og: Windy attorneys to their clients' woes,  Airy succeeders of intestate joys,  Poor breathing orators of miseries,
t: Words are useless breath, like lawyers pleading on their sad clients' behalf; like the children of joys who inherit nothing; like poor speech-makers going on about misery.

og: Let them have scope, though what they will impart  Help nothing else, yet do they ease the heart.
t: Even so, let them have a chance. Though they won't help in any other way, they still help ease the heart.

og: If so, then be not tongue-tied. Go with me,And in the breath of bitter words let’s smotherMy damnèd son that thy two sweet sons smothered.
t: If that's so, then don't be tongue-tied. Come with me, and with our bitter words let's smother my damned son Richard who smothered your two sons.

og: The trumpet sounds. Be copious in exclaims.
t: The trumpet sounds—he's coming. Don't restrain yourself.

og: Who intercepts my expedition?
t: Who's blocking my path?

og: O, she that might have intercepted thee,By strangling thee in her accursèd womb,From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
t: Oh, you wretch! It is she who could have blocked you from all the murders you've committed—by strangling you in her cursed womb.

og: Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown  Where should be branded, if that right were right,
t: Are you hiding that forehead with a golden crown, when, if the world was just, it would be branded with the mark of your crimes—

og: The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown  And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?
t: the slaughter of the prince who rightfully possessed that crown, and the monstrous deaths of my poor sons and brothers?

og: Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?
t: Tell me, you low-born criminal, where are my children?

og: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?And little Ned Plantagenet his son?
t: You toad, you toad, where is your brother Clarence? And little Ned Plantagenet, his son.

og: Where is gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?
t: Where is noble Rivers, and Vaughan, and Grey?

og: Where is kind Hastings?
t: Where is kind Hastings?

og: A flourish, trumpets! Strike alarum, drums! Let not the heavens hear these telltale womenRail on the Lord’s anointed. Strike, I say!
t: Trumpets, play! Drums, a call to arms! Don't let the heavens hear these tattle-tale women abuse the Lord's anointed king. Play, I say!

og: Either be patient and entreat me fair,Or with the clamorous report of warThus will I drown your exclamations.
t: Either be patient and treat me with courtesy or I'll drown you out with the noisy music of war.

og: Art thou my son?
t: Are you my son?

og: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.
t: Yes, and for that I thank God, my father, and yourself.

og: Then patiently hear my impatience.
t: Then patiently listen to my impatience.

og: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
t: Madam, I have some of your temperament, in that I can't tolerate the language of disapproval.

og: O, let me speak!
t: Oh, let me speak!

og: Do then, but I’ll not hear.
t: Speak then, but I won't listen.

og: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
t: I will be mild and gentle in my words.

og: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.
t: And be brief too, good mother, for I'm in a hurry.

og: Art thou so hasty? I have stayed for thee,God knows, in torment and in agony.
t: Are you so impatient? God knows I waited for you, in torment and in agony, when I was giving birth to you.

og: And came I not at last to comfort you?
t: And didn't I come at last to comfort you?

og: No, by the Holy Rood, thou know’st it well.  Thou cam’st on earth to make the earth my hell.
t: No, by the Holy Cross, and you know it well. You came to earth to make the earth my hell.

og: A grievous burden was thy birth to me;  Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;  Thy school days frightful, desp'rate, wild, and furious;  Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous;
t: Your birth was a painful burden to me. You were fussy and willful as a baby. Your school days were frightening, wild, and angry. As a young man, you were daring, bold, and adventurous.

og: Thy age confirmed, proud, subtle, sly, and bloody,  More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred.
t: And in your maturity you've grown proud, cunning, sly, and bloody—less wild but more dangerous, flattering in your hatred.

og: What comfortable hour canst thou name,  That ever graced me in thy company?
t: Can you name a comfortable hour I've ever had in your company?

og: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace  To breakfast once, forth of my company.
t: Well, none but Humphrey Hour, who once invited you to have breakfast without my company.

og: If I be so disgracious in your eye,  Let me march on and not offend you, madam.—
t: If I'm so displeasing to look at, then let me march on and not offend you, madam.

og: I prithee, hear me speak.
t: Please, listen to me speak.

og: You speak too bitterly.
t: You speak too bitterly.

og: Hear me a word,For I shall never speak to thee again.
t: Just listen a moment, and then I'll never speak to you again.

og: So.
t: Then do it.

og: Either thou wilt die by God’s just ordinance  Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,  Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish  And nevermore behold thy face again.
t: Either you'll die—as God's just punishment—before you can return victorious from this war, or else I will die from grief and old age. At any rate, I'll never see your face again.

og: Therefore take with thee my most grievous curse,  Which in the day of battle tire thee more  Than all the complete armor that thou wear’st.
t: So take with you my most terrible curse, and may it weigh you down in battle more than your suit of armor. My prayers will fight on your enemies' side.

og: My prayers on the adverse party fight,  And there the little souls of Edward’s children  Whisper the spirits of thine enemies  And promise them success and victory.
t: And the little souls of Edward's children will encourage your enemies, promising them success and victory.

og: Bloody thou art; bloody will be thy end.  Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.
t: You have lived in violence, and now you will die with violence. Your life has been shameful, so let your death be as well.

og: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curseAbides in me. I say amen to her.
t: Though I have far more reason to curse you, I don't have her energy. I'll just say "amen" to everything she said.

og: Stay, madam. I must talk a word with you.
t: Wait, madam. I must speak with you.

og: I have no more sons of the royal blood  For thee to slaughter.
t: have no more sons of royal blood for you to murder.

og: For my daughters, Richard,  They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens,  And therefore level not to hit their lives.
t: And as for my daughters, Richard, they'll become praying nuns, not weeping queens. So don't aim to destroy their lives.

og: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.
t: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, who is virtuous and beautiful, royal and gracious.

og: And must she die for this? O, let her live,  And I’ll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty,  Slander myself as false to Edward’s bed,  Throw over her the veil of infamy.
t: And must she die for this? Oh, let her live, and I'll ruin her manner, mar her beauty, lie and say she is illegitimate, and destroy her reputation.

og: So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter,  I will confess she was not Edward’s daughter.
t: So that she might escape being murdered, I'll say that she was not Edward's daughter.

og: Wrong not her birth. She is a royal princess.
t: Don't lie about her birth. She is a royal princess.

og: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.
t: To save her life, I'll say she isn't.

og: Her life is safest only in her birth.
t: Her royal birth is what makes her safest.

og: And only in that safety died her brothers.
t: Her brothers died because of that same "safety."

og: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.
t: Alas, at birth they were badly fated.

og: No, to their lives ill friends were contrary.
t: No, in their lives they were opposed by bad friends.

og: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.
t: No one can avoid the doom of destiny.

og: True, when avoided grace makes destiny. My babes were destined to a fairer deathIf grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.
t: That's true, when someone who has avoided God's grace is controlling that destiny. My children would have been destined to better deaths if you had been blessed with a more virtuous life.

og: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.
t: You speak as if I had killed my nephews.

og: Cousins, indeed, and by their uncle cozened  Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
t: Indeed, your nephews were cheated by their uncle of their comfort, kingdom, relatives, freedom, and life.

og: Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts,  Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction.
t: Some other hand might have pierced their tender hearts, but you're the one who gave the order.

og: No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt  Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,  To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
t: No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt until it was sharpened against your hard heart of stone, and after that it could rejoice among my little lambs' bloody innards.

og: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,  My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys  Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes,
t: But constant talk of grief makes wild grief tame, so I won't say my boys' names again until I've anchored my fingernails in your eyes and gouged them out.

og: And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death,  Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft,  Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
t: I am like a poor boat without sails in a stormy bay of death, and I'll break myself to pieces against your rocky heart.

og: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise  And dangerous success of bloody wars
t: Madam, if I am successful in these dangerous, bloody wars to which I am marching off,

og: As I intend more good to you and yours  Than ever you or yours were by me harmed!
t: I then intend to do more good to you and your relatives than I've ever done them harm!

og: What good is covered with the face of heaven,To be discovered, that can do me good?
t: What good is there still undiscovered in this world that can do me good now?

og: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.
t: The advancement of your children, noble lady.

og: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.
t: Advancing them up to some scaffold, to lose their heads.

og: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth’s glory.
t: Advancement to the dignity and height of fortune, the most kingly symbol of this world's glory.

og: Flatter my sorrow with report of it.Tell me what state, what dignity, what honor,Canst thou demise to any child of mine?
t: Flatter me in my sorrow then. Tell me what rank, what dignity, or what honor you could possibly offer to any child of mine?

og: Even all I have— ay, and myself and all—  Will I withal endow a child of thine;
t: Only everything I have—yes, including myself. That's what I'll give to a child of yours.

og: So in the Lethe of thy angry soul  Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs  Which thou supposest I have done to thee.
t: May Lethe drown your sad memories of the wrongs you imagine I've done to you.

og: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
t: Explain yourself quickly, before this speech about your kindness outlasts whatever kindness you have.

og: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.
t: Then know that from my soul I love your daughter Elizabeth.

og: My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.
t: And I believe it with my soul.

og: What do you think?
t: What do you believe?

og: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul. So from thy soul’s love didst thou love her brothers,And from my heart’s love I do thank thee for it.
t: That you love my daughter from your soul—far from your soul. Just like you loved her brothers. And from my heart's same love I thank you for it.

og: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.I mean that with my soul I love thy daughterAnd do intend to make her Queen of England.
t: Don't be so quick to confuse my meaning. I mean that I love your daughter with my soul, and I intend to make her Queen of England.

og: Well then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?
t: Well then, who will be her king?

og: Even he that makes her queen. Who else should be?
t: The same man who makes her queen. Who else should it be?

og: What, thou?
t: What, you?

og: Even so. How think you of it?
t: Of course. What did you think?

og: How canst thou woo her?
t: How would you go about wooing her?

og: That would I learn of you,As one being best acquainted with her humor.
t: That's what I want to learn from you, since you know her temperament best.

og: And wilt thou learn of me?
t: And will you learn from me?

og: Madam, with all my heart.
t: Madam, with all my heart.

og: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,  A pair of bleeding hearts; thereon engrave  “Edward” and “York.” Then haply she will weep.
t: Then send to her—from the man who killed her brothers—a pair of bleeding hearts. Write "Edward" and "York" on them. Then she might weep.

og: Therefore present to her—as sometime Margaret  Did to thy father, steeped in Rutland’s blood—
t: So to wipe up her tears, present her with a handkerchief—like the one Margaret gave to your father, steeped in his son Rutland's blood—

og: A handkerchief, which say to her did drain  The purple sap from her sweet brother’s body,  And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withal.
t: and tell her that this handkerchief wiped up the blood that drained from her sweet brother's body.

og: If this inducement move her not to love,  Send her a letter of thy noble deeds;
t: Tell her to wipe her weeping eyes with it. If all this doesn't convince her to love you, then send her a letter describing your other noble deeds.

og: Tell her thou mad’st away her uncle Clarence,  Her uncle Rivers, ay, and for her sake  Mad’st quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.
t: Tell her that you secretly killed her uncle Clarence, her uncle Rivers, yes, and speedily killed her good aunt Anne for her sake.

og: You mock me, madam. This is not the wayTo win your daughter.
t: You mock me, madam. This is not the way to win your daughter.

og: There is no other way,Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.
t: There is no other way, unless you could change your shape and be someone other than the Richard who has committed all these deeds.

og: Say that I did all this for love of her.
t: Say that I did all those things out of love for her.

og: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
t: No, for then she has no choice but to hate you, as you tried to buy her love with murder.

og: Look what is done cannot be now amended.  Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,  Which after-hours give leisure to repent.
t: Whatever is done cannot be undone. Men make mistakes sometimes, and then they repent when they have the time.

og: If I did take the kingdom from your sons,  To make amends I’ll give it to your daughter.
t: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, then to make up for it I'll give it to your daughter.

og: If I have killed the issue of your womb,  To quicken your increase I will beget  Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter.
t: If I've killed your children, then I'll give them new life by having children with your daughter.

og: A grandam’s name is little less in love  Than is the doting title of a mother.
t: A grandmother is hardly loved less than a mother. Grandchildren are just one step removed from children,

og: They are as children but one step below,  Even of your metal, of your very blood,  Of all one pain, save for a night of groans  Endured of her for whom you bid like sorrow.
t: made of your same substance and your very blood. They take the same amount of effort, minus that one night of labor which you suffered for your daughter's sake.

og: Your children were vexation to your youth,  But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
t: Your children troubled you in your youth, but my children will comfort you in your old age.

og: The loss you have is but a son being king,  And by that loss your daughter is made queen.
t: Your only real loss is that your son wasn't king, but through that loss your daughter will become queen.

og: I cannot make you what amends I would;  Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
t: I can't repay you as much as I'd like to, so accept what kindness I can offer.

og: Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul  Leads discontented steps in foreign soil,  This fair alliance quickly shall call home  To high promotions and great dignity.
t: Your son Dorset—who fled in fear and joined the French army against me—would come quickly home to high promotions and great dignity if this marriage takes place.

og: The king that calls your beauteous daughter wife  Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother.
t: The king who calls your beautiful daughter "wife" will call Dorset "brother."

og: Again shall you be mother to a king,  And all the ruins of distressful times  Repaired with double riches of content.  What, we have many goodly days to see!
t: Once again you'll be the mother to a king, and all the ruins of unhappy times will be repaired with double their value in contentment. Why, we can look forward to many good days ahead!

og: The liquid drops of tears that you have shed  Shall come again, transformed to orient pearl,  Advantaging their love with interest  Of ten times double gain of happiness.
t: The liquid tears you've shed will return, transformed into pearls. Your happiness will increase to ten times its original size, plus interest.

og: Go then, my mother; to thy daughter go.  Make bold her bashful years with your experience;  Prepare her ears to hear a wooer’s tale;
t: Go then, my future mother-in-law; go to your daughter. Use your experience to make her bold in her youthful innocence. Prepare her ears to hear my courting words.

og: Put in her tender heart th' aspiring flame  Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the Princess  With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys;
t: Put in her tender heart the ambition to be queen. Acquaint the Princess with the sweet, silent hours of joy in marriage,

og: And when this arm of mine hath chastisèd  The petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham,
t: and when I've punished that petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham,

og: Bound with triumphant garlands will I come  And lead thy daughter to a conqueror’s bed,
t: I will return crowned with victory wreaths and lead your daughter to a conquerer's bed.

og: To whom I will retail my conquest won,  And she shall be sole victoress, Caesar’s Caesar.
t: I will transmit all my victory to her, and she will be the  real conqueror—the emperor of the emperor.

og: What were I best to say? Her father’s brother  Would be her lord? Or shall I say her uncle?
t: What should I say to her? Her father's brother wants to be her husband? Or should I say it's her uncle?

og: Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
t: Or should I say it's the man who killed her brothers and uncles?

og: Under what title shall I woo for thee,  That God, the law, my honor and her love  Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
t: Under what name should I go wooing on your behalf? What name can please God, the law, and my honor, and also seem appealing to such a young woman?

og: Infer fair England’s peace by this alliance.
t: Imply that fair England's peace depends on this marriage.

og: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.
t: So she will purchase that peace with everlasting war.

og: Tell her the king, that may command, entreats—
t: Tell her that the King, who has the power to command, instead begs her—

og: That, at her hands, which the king’s King forbids.
t: Begs her to do what God, the King of Kings, forbids—marriage between an uncle and a niece.

og: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.
t: Say that she will be a high and mighty queen.

og: To vail the title, as her mother doth.
t: Only so that she can give up that title, as her mother has.

og: Say I will love her everlastingly.
t: Say I will love her forever.

og: But how long shall that title “ever” last?
t: But how long will that "ever" last?

og: Sweetly in force unto her fair life’s end.
t: For as long as her fair life lasts.

og: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?
t: But how long will her sweet life last?

og: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
t: As long as heaven and nature lengthen it.

og: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.
t: As long as hell and Richard decide.

og: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.
t: Say that I, her king, am her lowly subject.

og: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.
t: But she, your actual subject, hates such a king.

og: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
t: Speak well of me to her.

og: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
t: An honest tale works best when it's told plainly.

og: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.
t: Then plainly tell her my loving tale.

og: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
t: Plain and not honest is too harsh to hear. Lies need some decoration.

og: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
t: Your answers are too shallow and too lively.

og: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead—Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.
t: Oh no, my reasons are too deep and too dead—too deep and too dead, just like my poor infants in their graves.

og: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.
t: Don't harp on that string, madam—that's in the past.

og: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
t: I'll harp on it until my heartstrings break.

og: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown—
t: Now, by my Saint George, my garter, and my crown—

og: Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.
t: The first one profaned, the second dishonored, and the third stolen.

og: I swear—
t: I swear—

og: By nothing, for this is no oath.  Thy George, profaned, hath lost his lordly honor;
t: By nothing—because this is no proper oath. Your Saint George, profaned by you, has lost his lordly honor.

og: Thy garter, blemished, pawned his knightly virtue;  Thy crown, usurped, disgraced his kingly glory.
t: Your garter, stained by you, has lost its knightly virtue. Your crown, stolen by you, has disgraced its kingly glory.

og: If something thou wouldst swear to be believed,  Swear then by something that thou hast not wronged.
t: If you want to swear by something that I might believe in, then swear by something that you haven't wronged.

og: Then, by myself—
t: Then I swear by myself—

og: Thyself is self-misused.
t: You've misused yourself.

og: Now, by the world—
t: By the world then—

og: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
t: It's full of your foul crimes.

og: My father’s death—
t: By my father's death—

og: Thy life hath it dishonored.
t: Your life has dishonored his death.

og: Why then, by God.
t: Why then, by God.

og: God’s wrong is most of all.  If thou didst fear to break an oath by Him,  The unity the king my husband made  Thou hadst not broken, nor my brothers died.
t: You've abused God most of all. If you really feared to break an oath sworn by God, you never would have broken the oath of friendship and unity we made to the king my husband before he died—

og: If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him,  Th' imperial metal circling now thy head  Had graced the tender temples of my child,
t: and my brothers wouldn't have been killed. If you really feared to break an oath sworn by God, then the crown you now wear would instead be gracing the tender head of my child—

og: And both the princes had been breathing here,  Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust,  Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
t: and both the princes would still be alive. Your broken oaths have resulted in many corpses, and much food for the worms.

og: What canst thou swear by now?
t: What can you swear by now?

og: The time to come.
t: By the future.

og: That thou hast wrongèd in the time o'erpast;  For I myself have many tears to wash  Hereafter time, for time past wronged by thee.
t: You've already wronged that with your past actions. I myself have many tears left to cry in the future because of your past crimes.

og: The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered,  Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age;
t: The children whose fathers you slaughtered are still alive, and they will grow up without guidance, unfortunate in their adulthood.

og: The parents live whose children thou hast butchered,  Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.
t: The parents whose children you butchered are still alive too, old barren plants who will be miserable in their old age.

og: Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast  Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.
t: Don't swear by the future, for with your past you've already ruined it.

og: As I intend to prosper and repent,  So thrive I in my dangerous affairs  Of hostile arms!
t: May I succeed in my dangerous battles to the same degree that I truly intend to repent and prosper!

og: Myself myself confound,  Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours,  Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest,
t: May I ruin myself; be deprived of happiness by heaven and destiny; my days be dark; my nights sleepless;

og: Be opposite all planets of good luck  To my proceedings if, with dear heart’s love,  Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,  I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.  In her consists my happiness and thine.
t: and my luck be bad if I don't love your beautiful, royal daughter with dear affection, pure devotion, and holy thoughts. Both my happiness and yours depends on her.

og: Without her follows to myself and thee,  Herself, the land, and many a Christian soul,  Death, desolation, ruin and decay.
t: Without her as my queen, death, desolation, ruin, and decay will fall on me, you, your daughter, the land, and many a Christian soul. It cannot be avoided except by this marriage.

og: It cannot be avoided but by this;  It will not be avoided but by this.
t: It will not be avoided except by this marriage.

og: Therefore, dear mother—I must call you so—  Be the attorney of my love to her:  Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
t: Therefore, dear mother-in-law—for I must call you that now—be my advocate, pleading on my behalf to her. Describe what I will be, not what I have been.

og: Not my deserts, but what I will deserve.  Urge the necessity and state of times,  And be not peevish found in great designs.
t: Don't mention what I deserve now, but what I will deserve. Remind her of how necessary this marriage is for the good of the country right now, and tell her not to be foolishly willful about such an important decision.

og: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
t: Will I let myself be tempted by the devil like this?

og: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.
t: Yes, if the devil tempts you to do good.

og: Shall I forget myself to be myself?
t: Will I forget to be who I am?

og: Ay, if your self’s remembrance wrong yourself.
t: Yes, if your memories of yourself only hurt you.

og: Yet thou didst kill my children.
t: But you killed my children.

og: But in your daughter’s womb I bury them,Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breedSelves of themselves, to your recomforture.
t: But I will bury them in your daughter's womb, and in that nest of fragrant spices they will be reborn again, to grow and comfort you.

og: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
t: Will I really go win my daughter over for you?

og: And be a happy mother by the deed.
t: And make yoursel a happy mother by doing so.

og: I go. Write to me very shortly,And you shall understand from me her mind.
t: I'll go. Write to me very soon, and I'll tell you how she feels.

og: Bear her my true love’s kiss; and so, farewell.
t: Give her my true love's kiss. And so, farewell.

og: Relenting fool and shallow, changing woman!
t: Weak fool! Shallow, fickle woman!

og: How now, what news?
t: Hello, what's the news?

og: Most mighty sovereign, on the western coast  Rideth a puissant navy. To our shores  Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,  Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.
t: Most mighty king, a powerful navy is sailing to our western coast. Many weak, unreliable allies of ours have gathered at the shore to meet the ships—but they are unarmed and undecided about whether or not to fight them.

og: 'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;  And there they hull, expecting but the aid  Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
t: It's thought that Richmond is the invading navy's admiral. Right now the ships are just drifting around offshore, waiting for Buckingham to welcome them to land.

og: Some light-foot friend post to the duke of Norfolk—Ratcliffe, thyself, or Catesby. Where is he?
t: Send some speedy ally to the duke of Norfolk. You go yourself, Ratcliffe—or Catesby. Where is Catesby?

og: Here, my good lord.
t: Here, my good lord.

og: Catesby, fly to the duke.
t: Catesby, hurry to the Duke of Buckingham.

og: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.
t: I will go as quickly as I can, my lord.

og: Ratcliffe, come hither. Post to Salisbury.  When thou com’st thither
t: Ratcliffe, come here. Ride quickly to Salisbury. When you get there—

og: First, mighty liege, tell me your Highness' pleasure,What from your Grace I shall deliver to him.
t: First, mighty King, tell me what your Highness wants, so I can deliver your message to him.

og: O true, good Catesby. Bid him levy straightThe greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.
t: Oh, true, good Catesby. Tell him to gather the largest army he can in a hurry, and meet me at Salisbury right away.

og: I go.
t: I'm off.

og: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?
t: And what would you like me to do at Salisbury?

og: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?
t: Why, what would you do there before I arrive?

og: Your Highness told me I should post before.
t: Your Highness just told me that I should hurry there.

og: My mind is changed.
t: I've changed my mind.

og: Stanley, what news with you?
t: Stanley, what's the news?

og: None good, my liege, to please you with the hearing,Nor none so bad but well may be reported.
t: My lord, it's nothing so good that it will please you to hear it, but nothing so bad that I can't report it.

og: Hoyday, a riddle! Neither good nor bad.
t: Aha, a riddle! Neither good nor bad.

og: What need’st thou run so many mile about  When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way?  Once more, what news?
t: Why do you need to run in such wide circles when you can get straight to the point with your story? I'll ask you again: what's the news?

og: Richmond is on the seas.
t: Richmond is on the seas.

og: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!White-livered runagate, what doth he there?
t: Let him sink there, so the seas will be on him! The cowardly rebel, what is he doing there?

og: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.
t: I don't know, mighty king. I can only guess.

og: Well, as you guess?
t: Well, what do you guess?

og: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton,He makes for England, here to claim the crown.
t: That he's been stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, and now he's coming to England to claim the crown.

og: Is the chair empty? Is the sword unswayed?  Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?
t: Is the throne empty? Does the royal sword have no owner? Is the king dead, the kingdom dispossessed?

og: What heir of York is there alive but we?
t: What living heir of the York family is there but me?

og: And who is England’s king but great York’s heir?  Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?
t: And who can be England's king but great York's heir? So tell me, what is he doing at sea?

og: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.
t: Unless it's for that then I cannot guess, my lord.

og: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.Thou wilt revolt and fly to him, I fear.
t: Unless he's coming to be your new king, you can't guess why that Welshman Richmond is coming? You will rebel and join him, I fear.

og: No, my good lord. Therefore mistrust me not.
t: No, my good lord. Don't distrust me.

og: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?  Where be thy tenants and thy followers?
t: Where is your army, then, to beat him back? Where are your tenants and your followers?

og: Are they not now upon the western shore,  Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships?
t: Aren't they on the western shore right now, helping his rebels disembark safely from their ships?

og: No, my good lord. My friends are in the north.
t: No, my good lord. My friends are in the north.

og: Cold friends to me. What do they in the northWhen they should serve their sovereign in the west?
t: Then they're cold friends to me. What are they doing in the north when they should be serving their king in the west?

og: They have not been commanded, mighty king.
t: They haven't been commanded to do so, mighty king.

og: Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave,  I’ll muster up my friends and meet your Grace  Where and what time your Majesty shall please.
t: If it would please your Majesty, I'll gather up my friends and meet your Grace wherever and whenever your Majesty wants.

og: Ay, thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond,But I’ll not trust thee.
t: Yes, you want to leave so you can join Richmond. But I won't trust you.

og: Most mighty sovereign,You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.I never was nor never will be false.
t: Most mighty king, you have no reason to doubt my friendship. I never have been false, and never will be.

og: Go then and muster men, but leave behindYour son George Stanley. Look your heart be firm. Or else his head’s assurance is but frail.
t: Go then and get your men, but leave behind your son, George Stanley. Make sure your loyalty stays firm, or else he has a good chance of losing his head.

og: So deal with him as I prove true to you.
t: So treat him as well as my faithfulnes deserves.

og: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,  As I by friends am well advertisèd,
t: My gracious king, my friends have informed me

og: Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate,  Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother,  With many more confederates are in arms.
t: that Sir Edward Courtney and his elder brother—the arrogant Bishop of Exeter—are now in Devonshire with an army.

og: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms,And every hour more competitorsFlock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.
t: My lord, Buckingham's supporters—the Guilfords—are armed and gathering in Kent. Every hour more men flock to join the rebels, and their army grows strong.

og: My lord, the army of great Buckingham—
t: My lord, great Buckingham's army—

og: Out on you, owls! Nothing but songs of death.    There, take thou that till thou bring better news.
t: Enough, you owls! All I hear are songs of death.  There, take that until you bring me better news.

og: The news I have to tell your Majesty  Is that by sudden floods and fall of waters  Buckingham’s army is dispersed and scattered,
t: The news I have to tell your Majesty is that sudden floods and heavy rains have dispersed and scattered Buckingham's army.

og: And he himself wandered away alone,  No man knows whither.
t: Buckingham himself has wandered away alone, though no one knows where.

og: I cry thee mercy.  There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.
t: I beg your pardon. Here's some money to cure that blow I gave you.

og: [he gives money]  Hath any well-advisèd friend proclaimed  Reward to him that brings the traitor in?
t: [He gives money] Has any quick-thinking friend of mine offered a reward to whoever brings that traitor in?

og: Such proclamation hath been made, my lord.
t: Yes, that proclamation has been made, my lord.

og: Sir Thomas Lovell and Lord Marquess Dorset,  'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms.  But this good comfort bring I to your Highness:
t: It's reported that Sir Thomas Lovell and the Lord Marquess of Dorset are gathering an army in Yorkshire. But I bring your Highness this comfort:

og: The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest.  Richmond, in Dorsetshire, sent out a boat  Unto the shore to ask those on the banks  If they were his assistants, yea or no—
t: Richmond's navy has been dispersed by a storm. At Dorsetshire, Richmond sent a boat to shore to ask the men on the banks if they were his allies.

og: Who answered him they came from Buckingham  Upon his party. He, mistrusting them,  Hoisted sail and made his course for Brittany.
t: They answered that they were with Buckingham. Richmond didn't trust them, and he hoisted sail and returned to Brittany.

og: March on, march on, since we are up in arms,If not to fight with foreign enemies,Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
t: March on, march on, since we're already prepared for battle. Even if we don't have to fight foreign enemies, we'll still beat down these rebels here at home.

og: My liege, the duke of Buckingham is taken.  That is the best news.
t: My lord, the Duke of Buckingham has been captured. That's the best news.

og: That the earl of Richmond  Is with a mighty power landed at Milford,  Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.
t: There's worse, but it must be told: The Earl of Richmond has landed at Milford with a mighty army.

og: Away towards Salisbury! While we reason here,  A royal battle might be won and lost.
t: We must go away towards Salisbury! While we talk here, a royal battle might be won and lost.

og: Someone take order Buckingham be brought  To Salisbury. The rest march on with me.
t: Someone deliver the order that Buckingham should be brought to Salisbury. The rest of you, march on with me.

og: Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me:  That in the sty of the most deadly boar  My son George Stanley is franked up in hold;
t: Sir Christopher, bring this message to Richmond for me: my son George Stanley is locked up in the deadly boar's pen.

og: If I revolt, off goes young George’s head;  The fear of that holds off my present aid.
t: If I revolt, off goes young George's head. My fear of that happening prevents me from helping right now.

og: So get thee gone. Commend me to thy lord.  Withal, say that the queen hath heartily consented  He should espouse Elizabeth her daughter.
t: So go quickly, and give my regards to your lord. Also say that Queen Elizabeth has readily agreed that Richmond should marry her daughter Elizabeth.

og: But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
t: But tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

og: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.
t: At Pembroke, or at Haverford West in Wales.

og: What men of name resort to him?
t: What noblemen have joined him?

og: Sir Walter Herbert, a renownèd soldier;  Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley,  Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt,  And Rhys-ap-Thomas, with a valiant crew,  And many other of great name and worth;
t: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot; your brother, Sir William Stanley; Oxford; the powerful Pembroke; Sir James Blunt; Rhys-ap-Thomas, with a brave crew; and many other famous and powerful men.

og: And towards London they do bend their power,  If by the way they be not fought withal.
t: They're now sending their armies straight to London, if they don't have to fight along the way.

og: Well, hie thee to thy lord. I kiss his hand. My letter will resolve him of my mind.Farewell.
t: Well, hurry to your lord. Kiss his hand for me. This letter will explain my thoughts to him. Farewell.

og: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?
t: Won't King Richard let me speak with him?

og: No, my good lord. Therefore be patient.
t: No, my good lord. So calm down.

og: Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers,  Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward,  Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd  By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice,
t: Oh, Hastings; Edward's children; Grey and Rivers; holy King Henry and your fair son Edward; Vaughan; and all who have died because of underhanded, corrupt, foul injustice—

og: If that your moody, discontented souls  Do through the clouds behold this present hour,  Even for revenge mock my destruction.—
t: if your angry souls still cannot rest and are witnessing this scene through the clouds, then enjoy your revenge and mock my destruction.

og: It is.
t: It is.

og: Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.  This is the day which, in King Edward’s time,  I wished might fall on me when I was found  False to his children and his wife’s allies.
t: Why, then All Souls' Day is also my body's Judgment Day. This is the punishment that I once wished might fall on me if I was ever false to King Edward's children or his wife's allies.

og: This is the day wherein I wished to fall  By the false faith of him who most I trusted.
t: This is the punishment I wished might fall on me—that I would be betrayed by the man I trusted most.

og: This, this All Souls' Day to my fearful soul  Is the determined respite of my wrongs.
t: This, this All Souls' Day, is the predestined punishment for my frightened soul.

og: That high All-seer which I dallied with  Hath turned my feignèd prayer on my head  And given in earnest what I begged in jest.
t: I tried to play games with God—the all-knowing seer—but he has turned my false prayer on my head and earnestly given me what I asked for as a joke.

og: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men  To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms.
t: This is how he forces wicked men to turn their swords against their masters.

og: Thus Margaret’s curse falls heavy upon my neck:  “When he,” quoth she, “shall split thy heart with sorrow,  Remember Margaret was a prophetess.”—
t: Now Margaret's curse falls heavy on my neck. "When Richard splits your heart in two with sorrow," she said, "remember that Margaret was a prophetess."

og: Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends,  Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny,
t: Fellow soldiers and loving friends, all who have suffered under the burden of Richard's tyranny—

og: Have we marched on without impediment,  Thus far into the bowels of the land
t: we have marched this far without obstacles, all the way to the center of England.

og: And here receive we from our father Stanley  Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.
t: And here we receive news of encouragement and comfort from my stepfather Stanley.

og: The wretched, bloody, and usurping boar,  That spoiled your summer fields and fruitful vines,  Swills your warm blood like wash, and makes his trough  In your embowelled bosoms—
t: He says this: the wretched, violent, and usurping boar, that ruined your fields and vineyards; drinks your warm blood like water; and uses your disemboweled stomachs as his feeding trough—

og: this foul swine  Is now even in the center of this isle,  Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn.  From Tamworth thither is but one day’s march.
t: this foul swine is right now in the center of the country, near the town of Leicester. It's only a day's march from Tamworth, where we are now.

og: In God’s name, cheerly on, courageous friends,  To reap the harvest of perpetual peace  By this one bloody trial of sharp war.
t: In God's name, let's continue with cheerful spirits, my courageous friends, to reap the harvest of eternal peace from this one bloody trial of war.

og: Every man’s conscience is a thousand men,To fight against this guilty homicide.
t: Every man's clean conscience is like a thousand swords to fight against this guilty murderer.

og: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
t: I don't doubt that his friends will turn on him and join us.

og: He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.Which in his dearest need will fly from him.
t: He has no friends except for those who are too afraid to leave him. But they'll abandon him in his time of greatest need.

og: All for our vantage. Then, in God’s name, march.True hope is swift, and flies with swallow’s wings.Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.
t: All to our advantage. Then, in God's name, let's march. True hope is swift, and flies as fast as a swallow. Hope makes kings into gods, and lesser men into kings.

og: Here pitch our tent, even here in Bosworth field.—My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?
t: Pitch our tents right here, in Bosworth field.

og: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
t: My heart is ten times lighter than my appearance.

og: My Lord of Norfolk—
t: My Lord of Norfolk—

og: Here, most gracious liege.
t: Here, most gracious lord.

og: Norfolk, we must have knocks, ha, must we not?
t: Norfolk, we must have a few swings of the sword, ha, must we not?

og: We must both give and take, my loving lord.
t: We must both give them and take them, my loving lord.

og: Up with my tent!—Here will I lie tonight.But where tomorrow? Well, all’s one for that.Who hath descried the number of the traitors?
t: Put up my tent! I'll sleep here tonight. But where will I sleep tomorrow? Well, it makes no difference. Who has spied out the size of the traitor's army?

og: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
t: Six or seven thousand, at the most.

og: Why, our battalia trebles that account.  Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength  Which they upon the adverse party want.
t: Why, our army is three times that many. Besides, the King's name is a tower of strength, which the opposition lacks.

og: Up with the tent!—Come, noble gentlemen,  Let us survey the vantage of the ground.  Call for some men of sound direction.
t: Put up the tent! Come, noble gentlemen, let's survey the military advantages of this battlefield. Call for some experienced officers.

og: Let’s lack no discipline, make no delay,  For, lords, tomorrow is a busy day.
t: Let's lack no discipline and make no delay, for tomorrow will be a busy day, my lords.

og: The weary sun hath made a golden set,  And by the bright track of his fiery car,  Gives token of a goodly day tomorrow.—
t: The weary sun has had a golden sunset, and left a bright trail in the sky. This is an omen that tomorrow will be a good day.

og: Unless I have mista'en his colors much,  Which well I am assured I have not done,
t: Unless I've mistaken his banners—which I'm sure I haven't—

og: His regiment lies half a mile, at least,  South from the mighty power of the king.
t: his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the King's mighty army.

og: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him,And give him from me this most needful note.
t: Sweet Captain Blunt, if it can be done without too much danger, find a way to speak with him, and give him this important note from me.

og: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll undertake it.And so God give you quiet rest tonight!
t: I swear by my life that I'll do this for you, my lord. And may God give you a quiet, restful night!

og: Good night, good Captain Blunt.
t: Goodnight, good Captain Blunt.

og: Come, gentlemen,Let us consult upon tomorrow’s businessInto my tent. The dew is raw and cold.
t: Come, gentlemen, let's go to my tent and discuss tomorrow's business. The night is too raw and cold to stay outside.

og: What is “t o”clock?
t: What time is it?

og: It’s suppertime, my lord. It’s nine o'clock.
t: It's dinnertime, my lord. It's nine o'clock.

og: I will not sup tonight. Give me some ink and paper.What, is my beaver easier than it was?And all my armor laid into my tent?
t: I will not eat tonight. Give me some ink and paper. Is my helmet's visor working better now? And is my armor laid out in my tent?

og: It is, my liege, and all things are in readiness.
t: It is, my lord. Everything's ready.

og: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge. Use careful watch. Choose trusty sentinels.
t: Good Norfolk, hurry to your post. Make sure everyone is on constant alert. Choose trusty watchmen.

og: I go, my lord.
t: I'm off to do it, my lord.

og: Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.
t: Rise with the lark at dawn tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.

og: I warrant you, my lord.
t: I promise I will, my lord.

og: Catesby.
t: Catesby.

og: My lord.
t: My lord.

og: Send out a pursuivant-at-arms  To Stanley’s regiment.
t: Send out a junior officer to Stanley's regiment.

og: Bid him bring his power  Before sunrising, lest his son George fall  Into the blind cave of eternal night.
t: Tell Stanley to bring his army here before sunrise, or else his son George will go to his eternal rest.

og: [to soldiers]  Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.  Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.
t: [To soldiers] Give me a goblet of wine. Give me a personal guard. Saddle my white horse Surrey for the battle tomorrow.

og: Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy.—
t: Make sure that my lances are strong, but not too heavy.

og: My lord.
t: My lord.

og: Sawst thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
t: Did you see the gloomy Lord Northumberland?

og: Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself,Much about cockshut time, from troop to troopWent through the army cheering up the soldiers.
t: He and Thomas, the Earl of Surrey, were moving from troop to troop around twilight, and cheering up the soldiers.

og: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine.  I have not that alacrity of spirit  Nor cheer of mind that I was wont to have.
t: Good, I am satisfied. Give me some wine. I don't have the same energetic spirit or optimistic mind that I used to.

og: Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?
t: Set down the goblet. Is the ink and paper ready?

og: It is, my lord.
t: It is, my lord.

og: Bid my guard watch. Leave me. Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tentAnd help to arm me. Leave me, I say.
t: Tell my guard to be on alert. Now leave me. Ratcliffe, come to my tent around midnight and help me put on my armor. Now leave me, I say.

og: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
t: May fortune and victory be yours!

og: All comfort that the dark night can affordBe to thy person, noble father-in-law. Tell me, how fares our loving mother?
t: Take all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer, noble father-in-law. Tell me, how is my loving mother?

og: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother,  Who prays continually for Richmond’s good.  So much for that. The silent hours steal on,  And flaky darkness breaks within the east.
t: I bless you on your mother's behalf. She prays continually for you. But enough of that. The silent hours keep passing, and dawn is breaking in the east.

og: In brief, for so the season bids us be,  Prepare thy battle early in the morning,  And put thy fortune to the arbitrament  Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
t: To be brief—as the situation requires—you should prepare your army early in the morning. Let bloody fighting and deadly war be the judges of your destiny.

og: I, as I may—that which I would I cannot,—  With best advantage will deceive the time,  And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms.
t: I can't help you in this battle as much as I'd like to, but I'll do the best I can without Richard finding out.

og: But on thy side I may not be too forward,  Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George,  Be executed in his father’s sight.
t: If I act too boldly on your behalf and Richard notices, then your stepbrother, young George, will be executed in front of me.

og: Farewell. The leisure and the fearful time  Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love  And ample interchange of sweet discourse,  Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.
t: Farewell. The danger and urgency of the current situation must keep us from the long greetings and happy catching-up that friends like us, who have been separated for so long, should have.

og: God give us leisure for these rites of love!  Once more, adieu. Be valiant, and speed well.
t: But may God grant us time for all that soon! Once more, farewell. Be brave, and do well.

og: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment:  I’ll strive with troubled thoughts to take a nap,
t: Good lords, escort him to his regiment. I'll wrestle with my troubled thoughts and try to take a nap,

og: Lest leaden slumber peise me down tomorrow,  When I should mount with wings of victory.
t: so that sleepiness won't weigh me down tomorrow and keep me from flying on the wings of victory.

og: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.
t: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.

og: O Thou, whose captain I account myself,  Look on my forces with a gracious eye.
t: Oh God—of whose side I call myself captain—please look upon my forces with a gracious eye.

og: Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath,  That they may crush down with a heavy fall  The usurping helmets of our adversaries!
t: Put the bruising swords of anger in their hands, so they can crush the helmets of our enemies!

og: Make us thy ministers of chastisement,  That we may praise thee in the victory!
t: Make us agents of your divine punishment, so we can praise you when we're victorious!

og: To thee I do commend my watchful soul,  Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes.
t: I entrust my soul to you now, before I close my eyes and fall asleep.

og: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!  [Sleeps]
t: Oh God, defend me always, whether sleeping or waking! [He falls asleep]

og: [to RICHARD]  Let me sit heavy on thy soul tomorrow!
t: [To RICHARD] May I weigh down your soul tomorrow!

og: Think how thou stabbed’st me in my prime of youth  At Tewkesbury. Despair therefore, and die!
t: Remember how you stabbed me at Tewkesbury in the prime of my life. So despair, and die!

og: [to RICHARD]  When I was mortal, my anointed body  By thee was punchèd full of deadly holes.
t: [To RICHARD] When I was alive, you stabbed my kingly body full of deadly holes.

og: Think on the Tower and me. Despair, and die!  Harry the Sixth bids thee despair and die.
t: Remember the Tower, and remember me. Despair, and die! Henry the Sixth tells you to despair and die!

og: [to RICHARD]  Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow,  I, that was washed to death with fulsome wine,  Poor Clarence, by thy guile betrayed to death.
t: [To RICHARD] May I weigh down your soul tomorrow! It's me, poor Clarence, who was drowned to death in a barrel of sickening wine, betrayed by your plotting.

og: Tomorrow in the battle think on me,  And fall thy edgeless sword. Despair, and die!
t: Remember me tomorrow in the battle, and let your blunted sword fall from your hand. Despair, and die!

og: Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow,Rivers, that died at Pomfret. Despair, and die!
t: May I weigh down your soul tomorrow! It's me, Rivers, who died at Pomfret. Despair, and die!

og: Think upon Grey, and let thy soul despair!
t: Remember Grey, and let your soul despair!

og: Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fearLet fall thy lance. Despair, and die!
t: Remember Vaughan, and drop your lance with guilt and fear. Despair, and die!

og: Awake, and think our wrongs in Richard’s bosomWill conquer him! Awake, and win the day.
t: Wake up, and believe that Richard's guilty conscience will be his downfall! Wake up, and win the day!

og: [to RICHARD]  Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower.
t: [To RICHARD] Dream about your nephews, smothered in the Tower.

og: Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard,  And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death.  Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die.
t: Richard, may we weigh down your soul like lead, and drag you down to ruin, shame, and death. Your nephews' souls tell you to despair and die!

og: [to RICHARD]  Bloody and guilty, guiltily awake,  And in a bloody battle end thy days.
t: [To RICHARD] You bloody, guilty man, wake up full of guilt and then die in a bloody battle!

og: Think on Lord Hastings. Despair and die!
t: Remember Lord Hastings. Despair, and die!

og: [to RICHARD]  Richard, thy wife, that wretched Anne thy wife,  That never slept a quiet hour with thee,  Now fills thy sleep with perturbations.
t: [To RICHARD] Richard, it's your wife, wretched Anne your wife, who never had a quiet hour of sleep with you. Now I've come to fill your sleep with disturbing thoughts.

og: Tomorrow, in the battle, think on me,  And fall thy edgeless sword: Despair and die!
t: Tomorrow in the battle, remember me and drop your blunted sword. Despair, and die!

og: [to RICHARD]  The last was I that helped thee to the crown;  The last was I that felt thy tyranny.
t: [To RICHARD] I was the last to help you to the crown, and the last to feel the sting of your tyranny.

og: O, in the battle think on Buckingham,  And die in terror of thy guiltiness.
t: Oh, in battle remember Buckingham, and die in terror of your own guilt. Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.

og: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.  Fainting, despair; despairing, yield thy breath.
t: And tomorrow, fall and despair, and despairing die!

og: Give me another horse! Bind up my wounds!  Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.  O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!
t: Give me another horse! Bind up my wounds! Have mercy, Jesus! But wait, I was only dreaming. Oh, you coward conscience, how you torture me!

og: The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.  Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh.
t: The candles burn blue. It is now dead midnight. I'm in a cold sweat and trembling with fear.

og: What do I fear? Myself? There’s none else by.  Richard loves Richard; that is, I and I.
t: What am I so afraid of? Myself? There's no one else here. Richard loves Richard; that is, I am only myself.

og: Is there a murderer here? No. Yes, I am.  Then fly! What, from myself? Great reason why:  Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself?
t: Is there a murderer here? No. But yes, it's me. Then run away! What, from myself? Yes, so I won't take revenge. What, revenge myself upon myself?

og: Alack, I love myself. Wherefore? For any good  That I myself have done unto myself?
t: Alas, I love myself. But why? Have I ever done myself any good?

og: O, no! Alas, I rather hate myself  For hateful deeds committed by myself.
t: No, no! Alas, I hate myself instead, for all the hateful deeds I've committed. I am a villain.

og: I am a villain. Yet I lie. I am not.  Fool, of thyself speak well.
t: But I'm lying—I am not a villain. Fool, speak well of yourself.

og: Fool, do not flatter.  My conscience hath a thousand several tongues,  And every tongue brings in a several tale,  And every tale condemns me for a villain.
t: Fool, do not flatter yourself. My conscience has a thousand separate voices, and each voice tells a separate story, and each story condemns me as a villain.

og: Perjury, perjury, in the highest degree;  Murder, stern murder, in the direst degree;  All several sins, all used in each degree,  Throng to the bar, crying all, “Guilty! guilty!”
t: Perjury, perjury, in the highest degree; murder, ominous murder, in the highest degree; all kinds of sins, all done in each degree—bad, worse, and worst—all of these crimes cry out "Guilty! guilty!"

og: I shall despair. There is no creature loves me,  And if I die no soul will pity me.  And wherefore should they, since that I myself  Find in myself no pity to myself?
t: I will despair. There is no one who loves me, and if I die no one will pity me. And why should they, since I can't even find any pity for myself in myself?

og: Methought the souls of all that I had murdered  Came to my tent, and every one did threat  Tomorrow’s vengeance on the head of Richard.
t: Just now it seemed like the souls of all those I murdered came to my tent, and every one of them threatened that vengeance would fall on my head tomorrow.

og: My lord.
t: My lord.

og: Zounds, who is there?
t: By God! Who's there?

og: Ratcliffe, my lord, ’tis I. The early village cockHath twice done salutation to the morn.Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.
t: My lord, it's Ratcliffe, it's me. The village rooster has already crowed twice to welcome the dawn. Your friends are up and putting on their armor.

og: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream! What think’st thou, will our friends prove all true?
t: Oh, Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream! What do you think, will all our friends prove loyal?

og: No doubt, my lord.
t: No doubt, my lord.

og: O Ratcliffe, I fear, I fear.
t: Oh, Ratcliffe, I'm afraid, I'm afraid.

og: Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.
t: No, my good lord, don't be afraid of shadows.

og: By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight  Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard  Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers  Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond.
t: By Saint Paul, tonight shadows have struck more terror in my soul than ten thousand soldiers could, even if they were dressed in impenetrable armor and led by that fool Richmond.

og: 'Tis not yet near day. Come, go with me;  Under our tents I’ll play the eavesdropper  To see if any mean to shrink from me.
t: It's not yet daytime. Come with me; I'll eavesdrop under our tents to see if anyone plans to desert me

og: Good morrow, Richmond.
t: Good morning, Richmond.

og: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen,That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.
t: I beg your pardon, lords and gentlemen who stayed awake and alert—you've caught me sleeping late.

og: How have you slept, my lord?
t: How did you sleep, my lord?

og: The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams  That ever entered in a drowsy head  Have I since your departure had, my lords.
t: My lords, since you last left me, I've had the sweetest sleep and the most hopeful dreams that ever entered someone's drowsy head.

og: Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered  Came to my tent and cried on victory.
t: It seemed like the souls of those Richard had murdered came to my tent and encouraged me to victory.

og: I promise you, my soul is very jocund  In the remembrance of so fair a dream.  How far into the morning is it, lords?
t: I promise you, my soul is very joyful now, remembering that beautiful dream. How late in the morning is it, lords?

og: Upon the stroke of four.
t: Almost four o'clock.

og: Why, then ’tis time to arm and give direction.
t: Why, then it's time to arm myself and direct my troops.

og: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?
t: What did Northumberland say regarding Richmond?

og: That he was never trainèd up in arms.
t: That he was never trained to be a soldier.

og: He said the truth. And what said Surrey then?
t: He said the truth. And what did Surrey say to that?

og: He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.”
t: He smiled and said, "All the better for us."

og: He was in the right, and so indeed it is.
t: He was right, and so indeed it is.

og: Tell the clock there. Give me a calendar.    Who saw the sun today?
t: Read the clock there. Give me an almanac.  Has anyone seen the sun yet today?

og: Not I, my lord.
t: Not I, my lord.

og: Then he disdains to shine, for by the bookHe should have braved the east an hour ago A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliffe!
t: Then it's refusing to shine. For according to this almanac, it should have risen in the east an hour ago. It will be a dark day for somebody today. Hey, Ratcliffe!

og: My lord.
t: My lord.

og: The sun will not be seen today.  The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.  I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
t: The sun won't come out today. The sky frowns and scowls at our army. I wish there wasn't all this dew on the ground.

og: Not shine today? Why, what is that to me  More than to Richmond, for the selfsame heaven  That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.
t: So the sun won't shine today? Why, that shouldn't matter any more to me than it does to Richmond. The same heaven that frowns on me also looks sadly on him.

og: Arm, arm, my lord. The foe vaunts in the field.
t: Arm yourself, my lord. The enemy is on the battlefield.

og: Come, bustle, bustle. Caparison my horse.—  Call up Lord Stanley; bid him bring his power.—
t: Come, hurry, hurry. Prepare my horse. Call up Lord Stanley. Tell him to bring his army.

og: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain,  And thus my battle shall be orderèd:
t: I will lead my soldiers in the field, with my army arranged like this:

og: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length,  Consisting equally of horse and foot;  Our archers shall be placèd in the midst.
t: the front lines will be equal parts horsemen and foot soldiers and our archers will be placed in the middle.

og: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey,  Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.
t: John—the Duke of Norfolk—and Thomas—the Earl of Surrey—will lead the horsemen and foot soldiers.

og: They thus directed, we will follow  In the main battle, whose puissance on either side  Shall be well wingèd with our chiefest horse.
t: With them placed like this, I will follow with the main army, which will be defended on both sides by our best horsemen.

og: This, and Saint George to boot—What think’st thou, Norfolk?
t: We will have all this, and Saint George on our side as well. What do you think, Norfolk?

og: A good direction, warlike sovereign.
t: A good plan, my warrior king.

og: This found I on my tent this morning.
t: I found this on my tent this morning.

og: [reads]  Jockey of Norfolk, be not so bold.  For Dickon thy master is bought and sold.  A thing devisèd by the enemy.—
t: [Reading] "Jack of Norfolk, don't be too bold, for Dick your master's been bought and sold." Some plot of the enemy's.

og: Go, gentlemen, every man unto his charge.  Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls.
t: Go, gentlemen, every man to his position. Don't let our babbling dreams frighten our souls.

og: Conscience is but a word that cowards use,  Devised at first to keep the strong in awe.
t: "Conscience" is just a word that cowards use to keep down the strong.

og: Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law.  March on.
