t: Our strength will make us right; our swords will be the law. March on.

og: Join bravely. Let us to it pell mell  If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.
t: Meet the enemy bravely. Let's go down fighting—if not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.

og: Hark! I hear their drum.  Fight, gentlemen of England.—Fight, bold yeomen.—
t: Listen! I hear their drums. Fight, gentlemen of England! Fight, bold citizens!

og: Draw, archers, draw your arrows to the head.—
t: Draw, archers—draw your bows all the way back!

og: Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blood.  Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—
t: Horsemen, spur your proud horses hard, and ride with violence, to violence! Break your lances against the enemy and amaze even the heavens!

og: What says Lord Stanley? Will he bring his power?
t: What does Lord Stanley say? Will he bring his army?

og: My lord, he doth deny to come.
t: My lord, he refuses to come.

og: Off with his son George’s head!
t: Off with his son George's head!

og: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh.After the battle let George Stanley die.
t: My lord, the enemy has passed the marsh. Let George Stanley die after the battle is over.

og: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom.  Advance our standards. Set upon our foes.
t: A thousand hearts seem to beat within my chest. Advance our banners. Attack our enemies.

og: Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George,  Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons.  Upon them! Victory sits on our helms.
t: May our ancient battle cry of courage, fair Saint George, inspire us with the fury of fiery dragons! Attack! Victory rides with us.

og: Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!  The king enacts more wonders than a man,  Daring an opposite to every danger.
t: Help, my lord of Norfolk, help, help! The king has performed more wonders than seems humanly possible, facing down every dangerous enemy himself.

og: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights,  Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.  Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
t: His horse is killed, and now he's fighting on foot, searching for Richmond even in the face of death. Help, honorable lord, or else the battle is lost!

og: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
t: A horse, a horse! I'd give my kingdom for a horse!

og: Withdraw, my lord. I’ll help you to a horse.
t: Retreat from the fighting, my lord. I'll help you get to a horse.

og: Slave, I have set my life upon a cast,  And I will stand the hazard of the die.  I think there be six Richmonds in the field;
t: You villain, I have gambled my life on this throw of the dice, and I will take the risks that come with it. I think there are six Richmonds on the battlefield;

og: Five have I slain today instead of him.  A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
t: I've killed five already who looked like him. A horse, a horse! I'd give my kingdom for a horse!

og: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends!The day is ours; the bloody dog is dead.
t: May God and your swords be praised, victorious friends! The day is ours. The bloody dog is dead.

og: [offering him the crown]  Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee.
t: [Offering him the crown] Courageous Richmond, you fought well.

og: Lo, here this long-usurpèd royalty  From the dead temples of this bloody wretch  Have I plucked off, to grace thy brows withal.
t: See, I took this long-stolen crown from the dead forehead of that bloody wretch. Now let it grace your brows.

og: Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.
t: Wear it, enjoy it, and do much with it.

og: Great God of heaven, say amen to all!But tell me, is young George Stanley living?
t: Great God of heaven, say amen to all of this! But tell me, is young George Stanley still alive?

og: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town,Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
t: My lord, he is alive, and safe in Leicester, where we can now go, if you'd like.

og: What men of name are slain on either side?
t: What noblemen have been killed on either side?

og: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers,Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.
t: John—the Duke of Norfolk; Lord Walter Ferrers; Sir Robert Brakenbury; and Sir William Brandon.

og: Inter their bodies as becomes their births.  Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled  That in submission will return to us.
t: Bury them in a manner appropriate to their social rank. Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers who fled, if they'll return and submit to me.

og: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament,  We will unite the white rose and the red.
t: And then—as I swore I would—I will marry Elizabeth, uniting the York and Lancaster families.

og: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction,  That long have frowned upon their enmity.
t: God, smile upon this fair union now, after frowning so long upon the hatred between the two families.

og: What traitor hears me and says not “Amen?”  England hath long been mad and scarred herself.  The brother blindly shed the brother’s blood.
t: What traitor hears me and doesn't agree? England has been crazy for a long time, and injured herself. Brothers have blindly shed their brothers' blood.

og: The father rashly slaughtered his own son.  The son, compelled, been butcher to the sire.
t: Fathers have impulsively slaughtered their own sons. Sons have been compelled to butcher their fathers.

og: All this divided York and Lancaster,  Divided, in their dire division.
t: All this divided York and Lancaster even more, when they were already ominously divided.

og: O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth,  The true succeeders of each royal house,  By God’s fair ordinance conjoin together,
t: Oh, but now let Richmond and Elizabeth—the true heirs of each royal house—be joined together in holy marriage!

og: And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so,  Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace,  With smiling plenty and fair prosperous days!
t: And if God wills it, let their heirs enrich the future with peace, plenty, and beautiful, prosperous days!

og: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord,  That would reduce these bloody days again,  And make poor England weep in streams of blood!
t: Gracious God, may you blunt the sharpness of traitors' swords and anyone who would bring back these violent days to make poor England weep tears of blood!

og: Let them not live to taste this land’s increase,  That would with treason wound this fair land’s peace.
t: If any would try to wound this land's fair peace with treason, then don't let them live to enjoy its prosperity.

og: Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.  That she may long live here, God say amen.
t: Now civil wounds are bandaged and can heal, and peace lives again. Long may she live here. Let God say amen!

og: I come no more to make you laugh: things now,  That bear a weighty and a serious brow,  Sad, high, and working, full of state and woe,  Such noble scenes as draw the eye to flow,  We now present.
t: I haven't come to make you laugh anymore. Now we're showing you things that are serious, sad, noble, and full of dignity and sadness: scenes that make you cry.

og: Those that can pity, here  May, if they think it well, let fall a tear;  The subject will deserve it.
t: Those who are able to feel pity can cry at this if they want. The subject deserves it.

og: Such as give  Their money out of hope they may believe,  May here find truth too.
t: Those who pay money hoping to see something true will find truth here too.

og: Those that come to see  Only a show or two, and so agree  The play may pass, if they be still and willing,  I'll undertake may see away their shilling  Richly in two short hours.
t: Those who have only come to see a play or two to make themselves happy can sit through this play if they want to and if they can sit still. I'll make sure they get a good show lasting two short hours in return for their money.

og: Only they  That come to hear a merry bawdy play,  A noise of targets, or to see a fellow  In a long motley coat guarded with yellow,  Will be deceived;
t: Only those who come to see a funny, dirty play, to hear the noise of shields clashing together, or to see a man in a long fool's coat with a yellow border will not be satisfied.

og: for, gentle hearers, know,  To rank our chosen truth with such a show  As fool and fight is, beside forfeiting  Our own brains, and the opinion that we bring,  To make that only true we now intend,  Will leave us never an understanding friend.
t: Because, dear listeners, spoiling the true story we have chosen to tell with a show full of fools and fighting would mean losing all our intelligent friends as well as giving up our own brains and our intention only to show the truth.

og: Therefore, for goodness' sake, and as you are known  The first and happiest hearers of the town,  Be sad, as we would make ye: think ye see  The very persons of our noble story  As they were living;
t: So, for goodness' sake, you who are known to be the best and happiest theater audience in town, be as sad as we want to make you. Imagine you see the real characters in our noble story as if they were alive.

og: think you see them great,  And follow'd with the general throng and sweat  Of thousand friends; then in a moment, see  How soon this mightiness meets misery:
t: Imagine you see them powerful and followed by a sweaty crowd of a thousand friends. Then see how, all at once, this power runs into disaster.

og: And, if you can be merry then, I'll say  A man may weep upon his wedding-day.
t: And if you can be happy then, I'll believe a man can weep on the day he gets married.

og: Good morrow, and well met. How have ye doneSince last we saw in France?
t: Good morning, and good to see you. How have you been since we last met in France?

og: I thank your grace,Healthful; and ever since a fresh admirerOf what I saw there.
t: Thank you, sir, I've been well. And ever since I've been thinking admiringly about what I saw there.

og: An untimely ague  Stay'd me a prisoner in my chamber
t: An unfortunate sickness kept me prisoner in my room

og: when  Those suns of glory, those two lights of men,  Met in the vale of Andren.
t: when those two men as glorious and bright as suns met in the valley of Andren.

og: 'Twixt Guynes and Arde:  I was then present, saw them salute on horseback;
t: Between Guynes and Arde. I was there and saw them greet each other on horseback. I saw them when they got off the horses.

og: Beheld them, when they lighted, how they clung  In their embracement, as they grew together;
t: They held on to each other so hard when they hugged that it looked like they were two plants growing together.

og: Which had they, what four throned ones could have weigh'd  Such a compounded one?
t: If they had, those two together would have been worth more than four kings.

og: All the whole timeI was my chamber's prisoner.
t: The whole time I was stuck in my room like a prisoner.

og: Then you lost  The view of earthly glory: men might say,  Till this time pomp was single, but now married  To one above itself.
t: Then you lost your chance to see glory on earth. It's as if all glory has been single in the past, but now it's married to glory greater than itself.

og: Each following day  Became the next day's master, till the last  Made former wonders its. To-day the French,  All clinquant, all in gold, like heathen gods,  Shone down the English;
t: Every day was better than the one before until the last one was full of all the wonders seen before. One day the French, all clanking, all dressed in gold like heathen gods, shone brighter than the English.

og: and, to-morrow, they  Made Britain India: every man that stood  Show'd like a mine. Their dwarfish pages were  As cherubins, all guilt:
t: The next day, the British were dressed so richly that they made Britain seem like India. Every man standing up looked like a mine because they were covered in gold. Their short pages looked like gold-covered cherubs.

og: the madams too,  Not used to toil, did almost sweat to bear  The pride upon them, that their very labour  Was to them as a painting:
t: The ladies, too, not used to work, almost sweated to carry the beautiful things they wore, and their effort was like makeup: it made them look better.

og: now this masque  Was cried incomparable; and the ensuing night  Made it a fool and beggar.
t: One day this display was said to be incomparable, but the next night it was made to look like the display of a fool and a beggar.

og: The two kings,  Equal in lustre, were now best, now worst,  As presence did present them; him in eye,  Still him in praise: and, being present both  'Twas said they saw but one; and no discerner  Durst wag his tongue in censure.
t: Of the two kings, equal in brightness, one seemed better, then worse, at any moment. One looked better at one time, but the other one was praised more. When they were both present, people said they only saw one. No onlooker dared criticize anything.

og: When these suns—  For so they phrase 'em—by their heralds challenged  The noble spirits to arms, they did perform  Beyond thought's compass;
t: When these suns, as they were called, had their announcers challenge the noblemen to fight, those nobles did better than you can imagine.

og: that former fabulous story,  Being now seen possible enough, got credit,  That Bevis was believed.
t: The old legend of Bevis now seemed possible and was believed.

og: O, you go far.
t: Oh, you're praising them highly.

og: As I belong to worship and affect  In honour honesty, the tract of every thing  Would by a good discourser lose some life,  Which action's self was tongue to.
t: I swear by my reputation and love for honesty, the description of everything that was done there couldn't do justice to it even if it were described by a good talker.

og: All was royal;  To the disposing of it nought rebell'd.  Order gave each thing view; the office did  Distinctly his full function.
t: Things went perfectly. Everything was done in good order, and the people in charge did their job well.

og: Who did guide,I mean, who set the body and the limbsOf this great sport together, as you guess?
t: Who was in charge? I mean, who was the one to organize this sport, like a mind in charge of the parts of a body?

og: One, certes, that promises no elementIn such a business.
t: Someone you wouldn't expect to have any part in such business.

og: I pray you, who, my lord?
t: Tell me, who, my lord?

og: All this was order'd by the good discretionOf the right reverend Cardinal of York.
t: This was organized wisely by the honorable Cardinal of York.

og: The devil speed him! no man's pie is freed  From his ambitious finger. What had he  To do in these fierce vanities?
t: May the devil take good care of him! He's got his ambitious finger in everyone's pie. What did he have to do with this foolish fighting?

og: I wonder  That such a keech can with his very bulk  Take up the rays o' the beneficial sun  And keep it from the earth.
t: I'm surprised that such a lump of fat can block the rays of the kind sun with his bulk and keep them from the earth.

og: Surely, sir,  There's in him stuff that puts him to these ends;  For, being not propp'd by ancestry, whose grace  Chalks successors their way, nor call'd upon  For high feats done to the crown;
t: Surely, sir, there's something in him that makes him want these things. He doesn't have the help of being from a good family, which guarantees succession to power, and he isn't being rewarded for brave deeds done for the king.

og: neither allied  For eminent assistants; but, spider-like,  Out of his self-drawing web, he gives us note,
t: Nor does he have powerful allies. But, like a spider, spinning his own web for himself, he makes us notice him.

og: The force of his own merit makes his way  A gift that heaven gives for him, which buys  A place next to the king.
t: He clears a path for himself with his own worth. It's a gift to him from God, which buys him a place next to the king.

og: I cannot tell  What heaven hath given him,—let some graver eye  Pierce into that; but I can see his pride  Peep through each part of him: whence has he that,  If not from hell?
t: I can't tell what God has given him. Let some wiser man look into that. But I can see his pride showing in every part of him. Where did he get that, if not from hell?

og: the devil is a niggard,  Or has given all before, and he begins  A new hell in himself.
t: The devil doesn't like to give anything away, or he's already given away everything, so the Cardinal begins a new hell inside himself.

og: Why the devil,  Upon this French going out, took he upon him,  Without the privity o' the king, to appoint  Who should attend on him?
t: Why the devil, when this French expedition took place, did he take it upon himself to decide who would go with the king without asking him?

og: He makes up the file  Of all the gentry; for the most part such  To whom as great a charge as little honour  He meant to lay upon:
t: He made up the list of all the nobles. Mostly it was those he meant to get a lot of money out of without giving them credit for it.

og: and his own letter,  The honourable board of council out,  Must fetch him in the papers.
t: He sends for the money by writing a letter, without consulting the king's honorable councilors.

og: I do know  Kinsmen of mine, three at the least,
t: I know relatives of mine, at least three,

og: that have  By this so sickened their estates,  that never  They shall abound as formerly.
t: who because of this are in so much financial trouble that they'll never get their finances back to where they were before.

og: O, many  Have broke their backs with laying manors on 'em  For this great journey.
t: Oh, many people have broken their backs paying for mansions for the court to stay in on this great journey.

og: What did this vanity  But minister communication of  A most poor issue?
t: What did this foolish man do, except help this bad thing happen?

og: Grievingly I think,The peace between the French and us not valuesThe cost that did conclude it.
t: Sadly, I think the peace between the French and us isn't worth the money that was paid to make it.

og: Every man,  After the hideous storm that follow'd, was  A thing inspired; and, not consulting, broke  Into a general prophecy;
t: Every man, after the horrible storm that followed the peace-making, was a prophet. Without thinking, they broke into a prophecy about general things:

og: That this tempest,  Dashing the garment of this peace, aboded  The sudden breach on't.
t: that this storm, dashing against the clothes of the people making this peace, meant that it would be broken soon.

og: Which is budded out;For France hath flaw'd the league, and hath attach'dOur merchants' goods at Bourdeaux.
t: And the peace has been broken. Because France has broken the treaty and has seized our merchants' goods at Bordeaux.

og: Is it thereforeThe ambassador is silenced?
t: Is that why the ambassador has been silenced?

og: Marry, is't.
t: Yes, it is.

og: A proper title of a peace; and purchasedAt a superfluous rate!
t: So we have just a title deed for a peace, and bought at too high a price!

og: Why, all this businessOur reverend cardinal carried.
t: The respected cardinal carried out all this business.

og: Like it your grace,  The state takes notice of the private difference  Betwixt you and the cardinal.
t: Your grace, the government notices the private quarrel between you and the cardinal.

og: I advise you—  And take it from a heart that wishes towards you  Honour and plenteous safety—that you read  The cardinal's malice and his potency  Together;
t: I advise you—this comes from a heart that wishes you honor and safety—to consider both the cardinal's ill-will and his power.

og: to consider further that  What his high hatred would effect wants not  A minister in his power.
t: Consider furthermore that he has all the minions he needs to do what he wants out of his powerful hatred.

og: You know his nature,  That he's revengeful, and I know his sword  Hath a sharp edge: it's long and, 't may be said,  It reaches far, and where 'twill not extend,  Thither he darts it.
t: You know his vengeful nature and I know his sword has a sharp edge. It's long and they say it reaches far and, where it doesn't reach, he throws it.

og: Bosom up my counsel,  You'll find it wholesome. Lo, where comes that rock  That I advise your shunning.
t: Remember my advice. You'll find that it's good. See, the rock I advise you to avoid is coming now.

og: The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor, ha?Where's his examination?
t: The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor! Where's his paperwork?

og: Here, so please you.
t: Here, sir.

og: Is he in person ready?
t: Is he ready to appear in person?

og: Ay, please your grace.
t: Yes, your grace.

og: Well, we shall then know more; and BuckinghamShall lessen this big look.
t: Well, I'll find out more. Buckingham won't look this confident soon.

og: This butcher's cur is venom-mouth'd, and I  Have not the power to muzzle him;
t: This dog of a butcher's son has a poisonous bite, and I can't muzzle him.

og: therefore best  Not wake him in his slumber. A beggar's book  Outworths a noble's blood.
t: So it's better not to wake him when he's sleeping. A beggar's pocket book is worth more than the blood of a nobleman.

og: What, are you chafed?Ask God for temperance; that's the appliance onlyWhich your disease requires.
t: Are you angry? Ask God to make you patient. That's what you need to be cured of this disease of anger.

og: I read in's looks  Matter against me; and his eye reviled  Me, as his abject object:
t: I saw from how he looked at me that he has a grudge against me. His eye seemed to be disgusted by me, thinking I was a worthless thing to look at.

og: at this instant  He bores me with some trick: he's gone to the king;  I'll follow and outstare him.
t: Right now he's plotting against me. He's gone to the king. I'll follow and glare at him.

og: Stay, my lord,  And let your reason with your choler question  What 'tis you go about: to climb steep hills  Requires slow pace at first:
t: Wait, my lord, and think about what you're doing. You have to go slowly at first when climbing steep hills.

og: anger is like  A full-hot horse, who being allow'd his way,  Self-mettle tires him.
t: Anger is like a horse eager to run. Allowed to do what he wants, he tires himself out.

og: Not a man in England  Can advise me like you: be to yourself  As you would to your friend.
t: Not a single man in England can give me as good advice as you can. Act the same way toward yourself as you would to a friend, and give yourself good advice.

og: I'll to the king;  And from a mouth of honour quite cry down  This Ipswich fellow's insolence;
t: I'll go to the king. I'll use my honorable position to insult this arrogant man from Ipswich.

og: or proclaim  There's difference in no persons.
t: If I don't succeed, it shows that people of different classes are equal.

og: Be advised;  Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot  That it do singe yourself: we may outrun,  By violent swiftness, that which we run at,  And lose by over-running.
t: Think about this. Don't hurt yourself by plotting against your enemy. By running too quickly towards what you run toward, you can miss it and lose.

og: Know you not,  The fire that mounts the liquor til run o'er,  In seeming to augment it wastes it? Be advised:
t: Don't you know that a fire that makes a pot boil over seems to increase its volume but actually wastes it? Think about this.

og: I say again, there is no English soul  More stronger to direct you than yourself,  If with the sap of reason you would quench,  Or but allay, the fire of passion.
t: Again, there is no English man who could give you better advice than you could give yourself, if you would just be reasonable and stop being angry, or at least be less angry.

og: Sir,  I am thankful to you; and I'll go along  By your prescription: but this top-proud fellow,  Whom from the flow of gall I name not but  From sincere motions,
t: Sir, I'm thankful to you, and I'll do what you say. But I know this arrogant man, whom I despise not because of hot-headed anger but for good reason,

og: I do know  To be corrupt and treasonous.
t: to be corrupt and a traitor.

og: by intelligence,  And proofs as clear as founts in July when  We see each grain of gravel,
t: I know this from secret sources, with proof as clear as streams in July, when you can see every stone at the bottom.

og: Say not 'treasonous.'
t: Don't say "a traitor."

og: To the king I'll say't; and make my vouch as strong  As shore of rock. Attend. This holy fox,  Or wolf, or both,—
t: I'll say it to the king. And I'll swear it with a promise as strong as a rock. Listen.

og: for he is equal ravenous  As he is subtle, and as prone to mischief  As able to perform't; his mind and place  Infecting one another, yea, reciprocally—
t: This holy man is like a fox, or a wolf, or both: he is as greedy as he is sly and he's as willing to do evil as he is able to do it. His mind and his social position infect each other.

og: Only to show his pomp as well in France  As here at home, suggests the king our master  To this last costly treaty, the interview,  That swallow'd so much treasure, and like a glass  Did break i' the rinsing.
t: He suggested this expensive alliance to the king only so he could show off as much in France as he does here at home. The meeting swallowed so much money, and like a glass it broke as it was being made.

og: Faith, and so it did.
t: That's true, it did.

og: Pray, give me favour, sir. This cunning cardinal  The articles o' the combination drew  As himself pleased; and they were ratified  As he cried 'Thus let be':
t: Listen, sir. This sly cardinal drew up the treaty as he pleased. It was signed when he said "Let it be this way."

og: to as much end  As give a crutch to the dead: but our count-cardinal  Has done this, and 'tis well; for worthy Wolsey,  Who cannot err, he did it.
t: It's as useful as giving a crutch to a dead person. But our ruler the cardinal did it anyway, and that's good. Because honest Wolsey, who never makes mistakes, did it.

og: Now this follows,—  Which, as I take it, is a kind of puppy  To the old dam, treason,—Charles the emperor,  Under pretence to see the queen his aunt—
t: Then this happened (which looks a lot like treason, as much as a dog looks like its mother). Charles the emperor, claiming he wanted to see the queen his aunt

og: For 'twas indeed his colour, but he came  To whisper Wolsey,—here makes visitation:  His fears were, that the interview betwixt  England and France might, through their amity,  Breed him some prejudice;
t: (that was his story, but he came to whisper to Wolsey) visited. He was afraid that the meeting between England and France might do him harm if they became allies.

og: for from this league  Peep'd harms that menaced him: he privily  Deals with our cardinal; and, as I trow,—  Which I do well; for I am sure the emperor  Paid ere he promised; whereby his suit was granted  Ere it was ask'd;
t: He talked privately to our cardinal. I think (and it's something I do well) that the emperor paid before he agreed to anything. And then his request was granted before he asked.

og: but when the way was made,  And paved with gold, the emperor thus desired,  That he would please to alter the king's course,  And break the foresaid peace.
t: But anyway, when the path had been cleared with bribes, the emperor asked the cardinal to change the king's actions and break this alliance.

og: Let the king know,  As soon he shall by me, that thus the cardinal  Does buy and sell his honour as he pleases,  And for his own advantage.
t: The king should know, and I'll tell him, that the cardinal buys and sells his honor whenever he wants, for his own advantage.

og: I am sorryTo hear this of him; and could wish he wereSomething mistaken in't.
t: I am sorry to hear this about him, and I hope there's a mistake in what you say about him.

og: No, not a syllable:I do pronounce him in that very shapeHe shall appear in proof.
t: No, not at all. I describe him exactly as he is, and I'll prove it.

og: Your office, sergeant; execute it.
t: Do your job, sergeant.

og: Sir,  My lord the Duke of Buckingham, and Earl  Of Hereford, Stafford, and Northampton,
t: My lord the Duke of Buckingham, Earl of Hereford, Stafford, and Northampton, sir,

og: I  Arrest thee of high treason, in the name  Of our most sovereign king.
t: I arrest you for high treason in the name of our king.

og: Lo, you, my lord,The net has fall'n upon me! I shall perishUnder device and practise.
t: See, my lord, I've been caught in his trap! I'll die from his plots.

og: I am sorry  To see you ta'en from liberty, to look on  The business present:
t: I'm sorry to see you captured and to see this happen.

og: 'tis his highness' pleasure  You shall to the Tower.
t: The king wants you to go to the Tower.

og: It will help me nothing  To plead mine innocence; for that dye is on me  Which makes my whitest part black.
t: It won't help me to say I'm innocent. Even the most innocent part of me will be made to seem guilty.

og: The will of heaven  Be done in this and all things! I obey.  O my Lord Abergavenny, fare you well!
t: May God's will be done in this and all things! I obey. Oh, lord Abergavenny, goodbye!

og: Nay, he must bear you company.     The king is pleased you shall to the Tower, till you knowHow he determines further.
t: No, he must go with you.  The king wants you to go the Tower until he decides what will happen to you.

og: As the duke said,The will of heaven be done, and the king's pleasureBy me obey'd!
t: As the duke said, may God's will be done and may I do what the king wants!

og: Here is a warrant from  The king to attach Lord Montacute;
t: Here is a warrant from the king to arrest Lord Montacute,

og: and the bodies  Of the duke's confessor, John de la Car,  One Gilbert Perk, his chancellor—
t: the duke's confessor, John de la Car, and a certain Gilbert Perk, his chancellor—

og: So, so;These are the limbs o' the plot: no more, I hope.
t: All right. That's the end of his plot. I hope no more people will be arrested.

og: A monk o' the Chartreux.
t: A Chartreux monk.

og: O, Nicholas Hopkins?
t: Oh no, Nicholas Hopkins?

og: He.
t: That's him.

og: My surveyor is false; the o'er-great cardinal  Hath show'd him gold; my life is spann'd already:
t: My surveyor is a liar. The overly-powerful cardinal gave him gold. My life is already over.

og: I am the shadow of poor Buckingham,  Whose figure even this instant cloud puts on,  By darkening my clear sun. My lord, farewell.
t: I am the shadow of poor Buckingham, and even now clouds cover me and darken the bright sun of my life. Goodbye, my lord.

og: My life itself, and the best heart of it,  Thanks you for this great care: I stood i' the level  Of a full-charged confederacy, and give thanks  To you that choked it.
t: I thank you with all my heart and my life itself for this great thing you've done. I was the target of a plot that was about to be carried out and I thank you for stopping it.

og: Let be call'd before us  That gentleman of Buckingham's; in person  I'll hear him his confessions justify;
t: Have Buckingham's servant called before me. I'll hear him speak for himself

og: And point by point the treasons of his master  He shall again relate.
t: and he'll tell every detail of his master's treason again.

og: Nay, we must longer kneel: I am a suitor.
t: No, I have to kneel longer. I have a request.

og: Arise, and take place by us: half your suit  Never name to us; you have half our power:
t: Get up and sit next to me. Don't tell me half your request, since you have half my power.

og: The other moiety, ere you ask, is given;  Repeat your will and take it.
t: I grant you the other half before you ask. Tell me your request and grant it yourself.

og: Thank your majesty.  That you would love yourself, and in that love  Not unconsider'd leave your honour,
t: Thank you, your majesty. My request is that you love yourself and, by doing that,

og: nor  The dignity of your office, is the point  Of my petition.
t: that you not neglect your honor or the dignity of your position.

og: Lady mine, proceed.
t: Go on, my lady.

og: I am solicited, not by a few,  And those of true condition, that your subjects  Are in great grievance: there have been commissions  Sent down among 'em, which hath flaw'd the heart  Of all their loyalties:
t: I am told by many people, important ones, that your subjects are unhappy. Taxes have been imposed on them that make them disloyal.

og: wherein, although,  My good lord cardinal, they vent reproaches  Most bitterly on you, as putter on  Of these exactions, yet the king our master—
t: So, although, my good lord cardinal, they reproach you bitterly for convincing the king to order these taxes, not even the king our master—

og: Whose honour heaven shield from soil!—even he  escapes not  Language unmannerly, yea, such which breaks  The sides of loyalty, and almost appears  In loud rebellion.
t: may God protect his honor!—escapes their rude criticism. The language they use is too strong for loyal subjects and almost turns into a loud rebellion.

og: Not almost appears,  It doth appear; for, upon these taxations,  The clothiers all, not able to maintain  The many to them longing, have put off  The spinsters, carders, fullers, weavers,
t: It doesn't almost turn into that, it does. Because of these taxes, the makers of clothing can't afford to pay all those working for them and have dismissed the spinners, wool-combers, wool-cleaners, and weavers

og: who,  Unfit for other life, compell'd by hunger  And lack of other means, in desperate manner  Daring the event to the teeth, are all in uproar,  And danger serves among then!
t: who don't have any other skills and who have become desperate from hunger and poverty. They're in an uproar, daring anyone to resist them, and they're putting us in danger!

og: Taxation!  Wherein? and what taxation?
t: Taxes! On what? What taxes?

og: My lord cardinal,  You that are blamed for it alike with us,  Know you of this taxation?
t: My lord cardinal, you're being blamed too. Do you know about these taxes?

og: Please you, sir,  I know but of a single part, in aught  Pertains to the state;
t: Sir, I know only a part of state business,

og: and front but in that file  Where others tell steps with me.
t: and I am only the most important of the many people in charge of this business.

og: No, my lord,  You know no more than others; but you frame  Things that are known alike; which are not wholesome  To those which would not know them, and yet must  Perforce be their acquaintance.
t: No, my lord, you don't know any more than anyone else. But you cause things to happen that can be known about. These things are bad for those who don't want to know about them but have to.

og: These exactions,  Whereof my sovereign would have note, they are  Most pestilent to the bearing; and, to bear 'em,  The back is sacrifice to the load.
t: These taxes my king wants to know about are very hard to bear. For the people trying to bear them it's like they're laborers breaking their backs to carry their loads.

og: They say  They are devised by you; or else you suffer  Too hard an exclamation.
t: They say the taxes were your idea. Or perhaps you're being unfairly talked about.

og: Still exaction!The nature of it? in what kind, let's know,Is this exaction?
t: Taxes again! What is this? Tell me, what are these taxes?

og: I am much too venturous  In tempting of your patience; but am bolden'd  Under your promised pardon.
t: I'm worried about boring you, but I take courage from your promise to forgive me.

og: The subjects' grief  Comes through commissions, which compel from each  The sixth part of his substance, to be levied  Without delay;
t: The subjects are suffering from taxes that take a sixth of each person's wealth, to be collected immediately.

og: and the pretence for this  Is named, your wars in France: this makes bold mouths:  Tongues spit their duties out, and cold hearts freeze  Allegiance in them;
t: The excuse for this is said to be your wars in France. That makes people say bold things. People refuse to do their duties and no longer feel loyalty.

og: their curses now  Live where their prayers did: and it's come to pass,  This tractable obedience is a slave  To each incensed will.
t: Instead of praying for you, they curse you. And now their obedience has been overpowered by their anger.

og: I would your highness  Would give it quick consideration, for  There is no primer business.
t: I would like you to think about this, your highness, because there's nothing more important.

og: By my life,This is against our pleasure.
t: I swear by my life, this is not what I wanted.

og: And for me,  I have no further gone in this than by  A single voice; and that not pass'd me but  By learned approbation of the judges.
t: As for me, I haven't been any more responsible for it than a single man giving his opinion can be. And I only approved it because wise judges agreed it was a good idea.

og: If I am  Traduced by ignorant tongues, which neither know  My faculties nor person, yet will be  The chronicles of my doing, let me say  'Tis but the fate of place, and the rough brake  That virtue must go through.
t: If I have been betrayed by ignorant people who don't know me or my good qualities but insist on reporting what I do, let me say that that's the fate of important people and the rough obstacle that virtue has to face.

og: We must not stint  Our necessary actions, in the fear  To cope malicious censurers; which ever,  As ravenous fishes, do a vessel follow  That is new-trimm'd, but benefit no further  Than vainly longing.
t: We must do what is necessary to stop evil-minded critics. These people are like hungry sharks following a newly-loaded ship, who can do nothing but wish the boat would sink and provide them with food.

og: What we oft do best,  By sick interpreters, once weak ones, is  Not ours, or not allow'd; what worst, as oft,  Hitting a grosser quality, is cried up  For our best act.
t: Weak interpreters say that the good things we do are either not our doing or just not true. What's worse, just as often, they choose something unpleasant about us and say it's our greatest act.

og: If we shall stand still,  In fear our motion will be mock'd or carp'd at,  We should take root here where we sit, or sit  State-statues only.
t: If we stand still, fearing that we'll be mocked or complained about for moving, we'll grow roots where we sit and become silent trees, or just sit like powerful statues.

og: Things done well,  And with a care, exempt themselves from fear;  Things done without example, in their issue  Are to be fear'd. Have you a precedent  Of this commission?
t: Things done well and carefully give you nothing to fear. You should fear the consequences of things that have never been done before. Do you have a precedent for this tax?

og: I believe, not any.  We must not rend our subjects from our laws,  And stick them in our will. Sixth part of each?  A trembling contribution!
t: I don't think you have one. We must not break our own laws to make our subjects do what we want. A sixth of each one's property? That's a terrible contribution!

og: Why, we take  From every tree lop, bark, and part o' the timber;  And, though we leave it with a root, thus hack'd,  The air will drink the sap.
t: It's like we're taking the top, the bark, and part of the stump from every tree! And, although we leave each one with a root once it's been hacked, the air will dry its sap.

og: To every county  Where this is question'd send our letters, with  Free pardon to each man that has denied  The force of this commission:
t: Send a letter to every county where this tax was taken with a free pardon for every man who refused to pay this tax.

og: pray, look to't;  I put it to your care.
t: Do it, I trust you to take care of it.

og: [To the Secretary]  Let there be letters writ to every shire,  Of the king's grace and pardon. The grieved commons  Hardly conceive of me;
t: [To the SECRETARY] Let there be letters written to every part of the country announcing the king's kindness and pardon. The unhappy commoners think badly of me.

og: let it be noised  That through our intercession this revokement  And pardon comes: I shall anon advise you  Further in the proceeding.
t: Let it be said that I asked for this retraction and pardon. Then I will tell you what to do next.

og: I am sorry that the Duke of BuckinghamIs run in your displeasure.
t: I'm sorry you're unhappy with the Duke of Buckingham.

og: It grieves many:  The gentleman is learn'd, and a most rare speaker;  To nature none more bound; his training such,  That he may furnish and instruct great teachers,  And never seek for aid out of himself.
t: Many people are. The gentleman is well-read and a very good speaker. No one has better natural qualities. He's educated enough to teach great teachers all by himself without asking for help.

og: Yet see,  When these so noble benefits shall prove  Not well disposed, the mind growing once corrupt,  They turn to vicious forms, ten times more ugly  Than ever they were fair.
t: But see, when these noble qualities are not well put together in a man and the mind is corrupted, they turn into bad qualities, ten times uglier than they were beautiful.

og: This man so complete,  Who was enroll'd 'mongst wonders, and when we,  Almost with ravish'd listening, could not find  His hour of speech a minute;
t: This perfect man was thought to be a wonder of nature. He could make an hour of speaking seem like a minute because we were listening in such fascination.

og: he, my lady,  Hath into monstrous habits put the graces  That once were his, and is become as black  As if besmear'd in hell.
t: He, my lady, has put all the energy that once made him good into monstrous habits and has become as evil as if he had been smeared with hell's ashes.

og: Sit by us; you shall hear—  This was his gentleman in trust—of him  Things to strike honour sad. Bid him recount  The fore-recited practises; whereof  We cannot feel too little, hear too much.
t: Sit next to me and you will hear things that will make an honorable person sad. This was his trusted servant. Tell him to repeat the things he told us before about Buckingham's actions. I can't feel too little or hear too much about them.

og: Stand forth, and with bold spirit relate what you,Most like a careful subject, have collectedOut of the Duke of Buckingham.
t: Stand up and bravely tell what you observed about the Duke of Buckingham, like a good subject should.

og: Speak freely.
t: Speak freely.

og: First, it was usual with him, every day  It would infect his speech, that if the king  Should without issue die, he'll carry it so  To make the sceptre his:
t: First, it was a habit with him, every day he would infect his speech by saying it, that if the king died without an heir, he would take power himself.

og: these very words  I've heard him utter to his son-in-law,  Lord Abergavenny; to whom by oath he menaced  Revenge upon the cardinal.
t: I've heard him say these very words to his son-in-law, Lord Abergavenny, and he promised him he would take revenge on the cardinal.

og: Please your highness, note  This dangerous conception in this point.
t: Please, your highness, pay attention to this dangerous idea.

og: Not friended by his wish, to your high person  His will is most malignant; and it stretches  Beyond you, to your friends.
t: He means you harm. He wants to do evil to you, and his anger stretches beyond you, to your friends.

og: My learn'd lord cardinal,Deliver all with charity.
t: Wise lord cardinal, speak charitably.

og: Speak on:  How grounded he his title to the crown,  Upon our fail?
t: Go on. How did he justify his claim to the crown when I die?

og: to this point hast thou heard him  At any time speak aught?
t: Have you heard him say anything about that point at any time?

og: He was brought to thisBy a vain prophecy of Nicholas Hopkins.
t: He thought of this because of Nicholas Hopkins's meaningless prophecy.

og: What was that Hopkins?
t: Who was Hopkins?

og: Sir, a Chartreux friar,His confessor, who fed him every minuteWith words of sovereignty.
t: A Chartreux friar, sir, his confessor, who told him every minute he'd be king.

og: How know'st thou this?
t: How do you know this?

og: Not long before your highness sped to France,  The duke being at the Rose, within the parish  Saint Lawrence Poultney, did of me demand  What was the speech among the Londoners  Concerning the French journey:
t: Not long before you went to France, your Highness, the duke was at the Rose in the town of Saint Lawrence Poultney. He asked me what the Londoners were saying about the French journey.

og: I replied,  Men fear'd the French would prove perfidious,  To the king's danger. Presently the duke  Said, 'twas the fear, indeed;
t: I replied that men were afraid the French would be treacherous and harm the king. Then the duke said that this was indeed what people were afraid of,

og: and that he doubted  'Twould prove the verity of certain words  Spoke by a holy monk; 'that oft,' says he,  'Hath sent to me, wishing me to permit  John de la Car, my chaplain,  a choice hour  To hear from him a matter of some moment:
t: and that he thought it would prove the truth of some words spoken by a holy monk. "This monk often," he said, "has written to me asking me to allow him to meet with John de la Car, my priest, for an hour to hear about an important matter.

og: Whom after under the confession's seal  He solemnly had sworn, that what he spoke  My chaplain to no creature living,  but  To me, should utter, with demure confidence  This pausingly ensued:
t: Under the safety of confession he said that my priest should repeat what he said to no one except me. He hesitantly said this:

og: neither the king nor's heirs,  Tell you the duke, shall prosper: bid him strive  To gain the love o' the commonalty: the duke  Shall govern England.'
t: tell the duke that neither the king nor his heirs will prosper. Tell him to try to gain the people's affection. The duke will govern England."

og: If I know you well,  You were the duke's surveyor, and lost your office  On the complaint o' the tenants:
t: If I recognize you, you were the duke's surveyor and lost your job because of his tenants' complaints.

og: take good heed  You charge not in your spleen a noble person  And spoil your nobler soul: I say, take heed;  Yes, heartily beseech you.
t: Take care you don't accuse a noble person out of anger and damn your soul, which is even nobler. Watch out, I beg you.

og: Let him on.Go forward.
t: Let him go on. Come forward.

og: On my soul, I'll speak but truth.  I told my lord the duke, by the devil's illusions  The monk might be deceived; and that 'twas dangerous for him  To ruminate on this so far, until  It forged him some design,
t: I swear on my soul, I'll tell the truth. I told my lord the duke that the monk might have been deceived by the devil's tricks and that it was dangerous for him to think about this so much because it would make him start thinking about a plot.

og: which, being believed,  It was much like to do: he answer'd, 'Tush,  It can do me no damage;'
t: This was likely to happen if he believed it. He answered, "Shh, it can't do me any harm."

og: adding further,  That, had the king in his last sickness fail'd,  The cardinal's and Sir Thomas Lovell's heads  Should have gone off.
t: He added that if the king had died of his last sickness the cardinal's and Sir Thomas Lovell's heads would have come off.

og: Ha! what, so rank? Ah ha!There's mischief in this man: canst thou say further?
t: What! He said this so openly? Aha! That man is trouble. Can you say anything more?

og: I can, my liege.
t: I can, my king.

og: Proceed.
t: Go on.

og: Being at Greenwich,After your highness had reproved the dukeAbout Sir William Blomer,—
t: At Greenwich, when you had scolded the duke about Sir William Blomer—

og: I rememberOf such a time: being my sworn servant,The duke retain'd him his. But on; what hence?
t: I remember that. He was my servant and the duke hired him. But go on, what happened then?

og: 'If,' quoth he, 'I for this had been committed,  As, to the Tower, I thought, I would have play'd  The part my father meant to act upon  The usurper Richard;
t: He said, "If I had been imprisoned for this in the Tower, as I thought I might be, I would have done what my father meant to do to the usurper Richard.

og: who, being at Salisbury,  Made suit to come in's presence; which if granted,  As he made semblance of his duty, would  Have put his knife to him.'
t: When the king was at Salisbury my father asked to be brought into his presence. If this had been allowed, he would have stabbed him as he pretended to kiss his hand.

og: A giant traitor!
t: What a giant traitor!

og: Now, madam, may his highness live in freedom,and this man out of prison?
t: Now, ma'am, can the king live safely if this man is not in jail?

og: God mend all!
t: May God make all this better!

og: There's something more would out of thee; what say'st?
t: There's something more you want to say. What is it?

og: After 'the duke his father,' with 'the knife,'  He stretch'd him, and, with one hand on his dagger,  Another spread on's breast, mounting his eyes  He did discharge a horrible oath;
t: After he said these things about "the duke his father" and "the knife," he stretched himself out and, with one hand on his dagger and another on his chest, he rolled his eyes and let out a horrible curse.

og: whose tenor  Was,—were he evil used, he would outgo  His father by as much as a performance  Does an irresolute purpose.
t: The gist of it was that, if he were badly treated, he would do so much better than his father: as if he were going to do what his father only sort of wished he could do.

og: There's his period,  To sheathe his knife in us. He is attach'd;  Call him to present trial: if he may  Find mercy in the law, 'tis his:
t: That's what he wants, to stab me. He has been arrested. Call him to trial at once. If he can find any mercy for himself in the law, it's his.

og: if none,  Let him not seek 't of us: by day and night,  He's traitor to the height.
t: If not, he won't get any from me. I swear by day and night, he's the worst of traitors.

og: Is't possible the spells of France should juggleMen into such strange mysteries?
t: Is it possible that France could enchant men to do such strange things?

og: New customs,Though they be never so ridiculous,Nay, let 'em be unmanly, yet are follow'd.
t: New fashions are being followed, however ridiculous or even unmanly they are.

og: As far as I see, all the good our English  Have got by the late voyage is but merely  A fit or two o' the face; but they are shrewd ones;
t: As far as I can see, the only good thing our Englishmen got from the recent voyage was a few new facial expressions. But they're good ones.

og: For when they hold 'em, you would swear directly  Their very noses had been counsellors  To Pepin or Clotharius, they keep state so.
t: When they put on those expressions, you would swear their noses had been counsellors to kings Pepin or Clotharius because they look so dignified.

og: They have all new legs, and lame ones: one would take it,That never saw 'em pace before, the spavinOr springhalt reign'd among 'em.
t: They have new ways of walking, and they seem lame. You would think if you had never seen them walk like that before that they had leg diseases.

og: Death! my lord,Their clothes are after such a pagan cut too,That, sure, they've worn out Christendom.
t: For the love of God! My lord, their clothes look like pagan clothes. They don't look like Christians anymore.

og: How now!What news, Sir Thomas Lovell?
t: Hello! What's the news, Sir Thomas Lovell?

og: Faith, my lord,I hear of none, but the new proclamationThat's clapp'd upon the court-gate.
t: Truly, my lord, I haven't heard about anything except the new proclamation that's been put up on the gate to the court.

og: What is't for?
t: What is it for?

og: The reformation of our travell'd gallants,That fill the court with quarrels, talk, and tailors.
t: To reform the returned travelers who fill the court with quarrels, talk, and tailors.

og: I'm glad 'tis there: now I would pray our monsieursTo think an English courtier may be wise,And never see the Louvre.
t: I'm glad it's there. I want these courtiers who act French to think that an English courtier can be wise even if he's never seen the Louvre.

og: They must either,  For so run the conditions, leave those remnants  Of fool and feather that they got in France,  With all their honourable point of ignorance  Pertaining thereunto,
t: The proclamation asks that they give up those scraps of foolish cloth and feathers they got in France along with all their pointless knowledge, or rather ignorance, about them.

og: as fights and fireworks,  Abusing better men than they can be,  Out of a foreign wisdom, renouncing clean  The faith they have in tennis, and tall stockings,
t: They must also give up fights and fireworks and insulting better men than they can ever be for not knowing about foreign things. They must completely renounce their faithfulness to tennis and tall stockings,

og: Short blister'd breeches, and those types of travel,  And understand again like honest men;  Or pack to their old playfellows:
t: short pants that look like they have blisters on them, and that sort of thing they picked up from traveling, and act like honest men again. Or head back to their old playmates in France.

og: there, I take it,  They may, 'cum privilegio,' wear away  The lag end of their lewdness and be laugh'd at.
t: There, as I understand, the proclamation allows them "freely" to indulge in the rest of their foolishness and be laughed at.

og: 'Tis time to give 'em physic, their diseasesAre grown so catching.
t: It's time to give them medicine, as their diseases have become so contagious.

og: What a loss our ladiesWill have of these trim vanities!
t: The ladies will miss these neat pointless things!

og: Ay, marry,  There will be woe indeed, lords:
t: Yes, it's true. There will be sadness about that, lords.

og: the sly whoresons  Have got a speeding trick to lay down ladies;  A French song and a fiddle has no fellow.
t: The clever bastards have figured out a quick trick to make ladies go to bed with them. You can't compete with a French song and a fiddle.

og: The devil fiddle 'em! I am glad they are going,  For, sure, there's no converting of 'em: now  An honest country lord, as I am, beaten  A long time out of play,
t: May the devil fiddle them! I am glad they are going because it's impossible to change them. Now an honest country noblemen like me, who couldn't compete,

og: may bring his plainsong  And have an hour of hearing; and, by'r lady,  Held current music too.
t: can bring my church songs and be listened to for an hour. And, by the virgin Mary, it will be considered fashionable music too.

og: Well said, Lord Sands;Your colt's tooth is not cast yet.
t: Well said, Lord Sands. You're still a wild young colt with all its teeth.

og: No, my lord;Nor shall not, while I have a stump.
t: Yes, my lord, and I'll keep at it while I still have a tooth in my head.

og: Sir Thomas,Whither were you a-going?
t: Sir Thomas, where were you headed?

og: To the cardinal's:Your lordship is a guest too.
t: To the cardinal's. You're a guest there too.

og: O, 'tis true:  This night he makes a supper, and a great one,  To many lords and ladies;
t: Oh, it's true. Tonight he's having a dinner, a huge one, for many lords and ladies.

og: there will be  The beauty of this kingdom, I'll assure you.
t: All the beauties in the kingdom will be there, I assure you.

og: That churchman bears a bounteous mind indeed,A hand as fruitful as the land that feeds us;His dews fall every where.
t: That churchman has a generous mind and gives as freely as the land that grows food for us. His gifts go everywhere.

og: No doubt he's noble;He had a black mouth that said other of him.
t: No doubt he's noble. Anyone who says otherwise has an evil mouth.

og: He may, my lord; has wherewithal: in him  Sparing would show a worse sin than ill doctrine:
t: They may, my lord, and probably do. Hoarding would be a worse sin for him than a wrong belief.

og: Men of his way should be most liberal;  They are set here for examples.
t: Men like him should be generous. They are put on this earth as examples to the rest.

og: True, they are so:  But few now give so great ones. My barge stays;  Your lordship shall along. Come, good Sir Thomas,  We shall be late else;
t: It's true, they are. But few men now are such great examples. My barge is waiting. You'll come with me. Come, Sir Thomas, or we'll be late.

og: which I would not be,  For I was spoke to, with Sir Henry Guildford  This night to be comptrollers.
t: I wouldn't want to be, because I was asked (along with Sir Henry Guildford) to be a master of ceremonies.

og: I am your lordship's.
t: I'm at your service.

og: Ladies, a general welcome from his grace  Salutes ye all; this night he dedicates  To fair content and you:
t: Ladies, the cardinal welcomes all of you. He dedicates tonight to happiness and you.

og: none here, he hopes,  In all this noble bevy, has brought with her  One care abroad;
t: No one here, he hopes, in this troop of nobles, has brought a single sorrow with her.

og: he would have all as merry  As, first, good company, good wine, good welcome,  Can make good people. O, my lord, you're tardy:
t: He wants everyone to be as happy as good company, good wine, and a good welcome can make good people. Oh, my lord, you're late.

og: The very thought of this fair companyClapp'd wings to me.
t: The thought of this beautiful company made me hurry.

og: You are young, Sir Harry Guildford.
t: You are young, Sir Harry Guildford.

og: Sir Thomas Lovell, had the cardinal  But half my lay thoughts in him, some of these  Should find a running banquet ere they rested,
t: Sir Thomas Lovell, if the cardinal had even half my unreligious thoughts in him, some of these women would have a quick refreshment before they rested

og: I think would better please 'em: by my life,  They are a sweet society of fair ones.
t: that I think would please them more than this one. I swear by my life, they're a sweet band of beauties.

og: O, that your lordship were but now confessorTo one or two of these!
t: Oh, if only you were the confessor of one or two of them!

og: I would I were;They should find easy penance.
t: I wish I were. I would give them an easy penance.

og: Faith, how easy?
t: Really? How easy?

og: As easy as a down-bed would afford it.
t: As easy as a feather-bed would make it.

og: Sweet ladies, will it please you sit? Sir Harry,  Place you that side; I'll take the charge of this:  His grace is entering. Nay, you must not freeze;
t: Sweet ladies, would you sit? Sir Harry, you seat this half of them. I'll be in charge of the other half. The cardinal is entering. No, don't freeze us:

og: Two women placed together makes cold weather:  My Lord Sands, you are one will keep 'em waking;  Pray, sit between these ladies.
t: two women placed together makes cold weather. My Lord Sands, you'll keep them awake. Please, sit between these ladies.

og: By my faith,  And thank your lordship. By your leave, sweet ladies:
t: Certainly, and thank you, your lordship. Please, sweet ladies,

og: If I chance to talk a little wild, forgive me;  I had it from my father.
t: if I talk a little wildly, forgive me. I inherited it from my father.

og: Was he mad, sir?
t: Was he crazy, sir?

og: O, very mad, exceeding mad, in love too:But he would bite none; just as I do now,He would kiss you twenty with a breath.
t: Oh, very crazy, extremely crazy, including in love. But he wouldn't bite anyone. Like I do now, he would give you twenty kisses in one breath.

og: Well said, my lord.  So, now you're fairly seated.
t: Well said my lord. So, now you're beautifully seated between two beauties.

og: Gentlemen,  The penance lies on you, if these fair ladies  Pass away frowning.
t: Gentleman, you'll be punished if these beautiful ladies leave looking unhappy.

og: For my little cure,Let me alone.
t: As for me, don't worry.

og: You're welcome, my fair guests: that noble lady,  Or gentleman, that is not freely merry,  Is not my friend:
t: You're welcome, my beautiful guests. Whatever noble lady or gentleman is not happy is not my friend.

og: this, to confirm my welcome;  And to you all, good health.
t: I drink to confirm my welcome. Good health to you all.

og: Your grace is noble:Let me have such a bowl may hold my thanks,And save me so much talking.
t: You're noble, your grace. Let me have a cup like that to hold my thanks and I'll drink it to save so much talking.

og: My Lord Sands,  I am beholding to you: cheer your neighbours.
t: My Lord Sands, thank you. Entertain your neighbors.

og: Ladies, you are not merry: gentlemen,  Whose fault is this?
t: Ladies, you are not happy. Gentlemen, whose fault is this?

og: The red wine first must riseIn their fair cheeks, my lord; then we shall have 'emTalk us to silence.
t: The red wine must first flush their beautiful faces, my lord. Then they'll talk so much we'll have to be silent.

og: You are a merry gamester,My Lord Sands.
t: You're a cheerful player, my lord Sands.

og: Yes, if I make my play.Here's to your ladyship: and pledge it, madam,For 'tis to such a thing,—
t: Yes, if I have something to play. Here's to you, your ladyship. Drink to it, ma'am, because it's a toast to a thing—

og: You cannot show me.
t: You can't show me.

og: I told your grace they would talk anon.
t: I told you they would talk soon, your grace.

og: What's that?
t: What's that?

og: Look out there, some of ye.
t: Some of you go look outside.

og: What warlike voice,And to what end is this? Nay, ladies, fear not;By all the laws of war you're privileged.
t: What warlike noise was that, and what was it for? No, don't be afraid, ladies. The laws of war will protect you.

og: How now! what is't?
t: Well? What is it?

og: A noble troop of strangers;  For so they seem: they've left their barge and landed;
t: It seems like a noble band of strangers. They've left their barge and come to land.

og: And hither make, as great ambassadors  From foreign princes.
t: They're heading here as great ambassadors from foreign princes.

og: Good lord chamberlain,  Go, give 'em welcome; you can speak the French tongue;
t: Good lord chamberlain, go welcome them. You can speak French.

og: And, pray, receive 'em nobly, and conduct 'em  Into our presence, where this heaven of beauty  Shall shine at full upon them. Some attend him.
t: And please treat them well and bring them to us, where beauty as plentiful as in heaven will shine on them. Go with him, some of you.

og: You have now a broken banquet; but we'll mend it.A good digestion to you all: and once moreI shower a welcome on ye; welcome all.
t: Your feast has been broken up, but we'll fix that. I wish all of you good digestion. I welcome you once more: welcome, all.

og: A noble company! what are their pleasures?
t: This is a noble band! What do they want?

og: Because they speak no English, thus they pray'd  To tell your grace, that, having heard by fame  Of this so noble and so fair assembly  This night to meet here,
t: Because they don't speak English, they asked me to tell you that, having heard rumors of this noble and beautiful crowd meeting here tonight,

og: they could do no less  Out of the great respect they bear to beauty,
t: they had to leave their flocks because of the great respect they have for beauty.

og: But leave their flocks; and, under your fair conduct,  Crave leave to view these ladies and entreat  An hour of revels with 'em.
t: They beg you to allow them to see these ladies and they ask for an hour of dancing with them.

og: Say, lord chamberlain,They have done my poor house grace; for which I pay 'emA thousand thanks, and pray 'em take their pleasures.
t: Tell them, lord chamberlain, they have done an honor to my house. I give them a thousand thanks in return and ask them to do as they like.

og: The fairest hand I ever touch'd! O beauty,Till now I never knew thee!
t: The most beautiful hand I ever touched! Oh, I never knew what beauty was until now!

og: My lord!
t: My lord!

og: Your grace?
t: Yes, your grace?

og: Pray, tell 'em thus much from me:  There should be one amongst 'em, by his person,  More worthy this place than myself;
t: Please, tell them this from me: one of them should be more worthy of sitting here than me.

og: to whom,  If I but knew him, with my love and duty  I would surrender it.
t: If I could only recognize him, I would give up this seat to him out of my love and duty.

og: I will, my lord.
t: I will, my lord.

og: What say they?
t: What do they say?

og: Such a one, they all confess,There is indeed; which they would have your graceFind out, and he will take it.
t: They all confess that there is one like that. If you can find him he will take the seat.

og: Let me see, then.By all your good leaves, gentlemen; here I'll makeMy royal choice.
t: Let me see, then. Allow me, gentlemen. I choose the king here.

og: Ye have found him, cardinal:
t: You found him, cardinal.

og: You hold a fair assembly; you do well, lord:You are a churchman, or, I'll tell you, cardinal,I should judge now unhappily.
t: You throw a beautiful party. That's a good thing, lord. If you weren't a churchman, cardinal, I can tell you I would judge you badly.

og: I am gladYour grace is grown so pleasant.
t: I am glad you're making so many jokes, your grace.

og: My lord chamberlain,Prithee, come hither: what fair lady's that?
t: Please, come here, my lord chamberlain. Who's that beautiful lady?

og: An't please your grace, Sir Thomas Bullen's daughter—The Viscount Rochford,—one of her highness' women.
t: Your grace, that's Sir Thomas Bullen's daughter. He's the Viscount Rochford. She's one of the queen's ladies in waiting.

og: By heaven, she is a dainty one. Sweetheart,  I were unmannerly, to take you out,  And not to kiss you.
t: By God, she's a pretty one. Sweetheart, I would be rude to dance with you and not kiss you.

og: A health, gentlemen!  Let it go round.
t: Drink to her health, gentlemen! Everyone drink.

og: Sir Thomas Lovell, is the banquet readyI' the privy chamber?
t: Sir Thomas Lovell, is the banquet in the private room ready?

og: Yes, my lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: Your grace,I fear, with dancing is a little heated.
t: I'm worried you feel a little hot from dancing, your grace.

og: I fear, too much.
t: Yes, I'm afraid I feel very hot.

og: There's fresher air, my lord,In the next chamber.
t: There's fresher air in the next room, my lord.

og: Lead in your ladies, every one: sweet partner,  I must not yet forsake you: let's be merry:  Good my lord cardinal, I have half a dozen healths  To drink to these fair ladies,
t: Everyone, lead in your ladies. Dear partner, I won't abandon you yet. Let's be cheerful. My good lord cardinal, I have half a dozen toasts to drink to these beautiful ladies,

og: and a measure  To lead 'em once again; and then let's dream  Who's best in favour. Let the music knock it.
t: and I have to dance with them again. And then let's think about whom I like best. Let the music play.

og: Whither away so fast?
t: Where are you going so fast?

og: O, God save ye!Even to the hall, to hear what shall becomeOf the great Duke of Buckingham.
t: Oh, hello! To the hall to hear what will happen to the great Duke of Buckingham.

og: I'll save youThat labour, sir. All's now done, but the ceremonyOf bringing back the prisoner.
t: I'll spare you that effort, sir. It's all over, except for bringing the prisoner back to jail.

og: Were you there?
t: Were you there?

og: Yes, indeed, was I.
t: Yes, I was.

og: Pray, speak what has happen'd.
t: Please tell me what happened.

og: You may guess quickly what.
t: You can easily guess.

og: Is he found guilty?
t: Was he found guilty?

og: Yes, truly is he, and condemn'd upon't.
t: Yes, and condemned for it.

og: I am sorry for't.
t: I'm sorry about that.

og: So are a number more.
t: So are many other people.

og: But, pray, how pass'd it?
t: But tell me, how did it happen?

og: I'll tell you in a little. The great duke  Came to the bar; where to his accusations  He pleaded still not guilty and alleged  Many sharp reasons to defeat the law.
t: I'll tell you in a few words. The great duke came to court, where he still pled not guilty to the accusations against him and made many good arguments to escape the law.

og: The king's attorney on the contrary  Urged on the examinations, proofs, confessions  Of divers witnesses; which the duke desired  To have brought viva voce to his face:
t: But the king's lawyer brought against him the questioning, proofs, and confessions of many different witnesses. The duke asked to have them testify in front of him.

og: At which appear'd against him his surveyor;  Sir Gilbert Peck his chancellor; and John Car,  Confessor to him; with that devil-monk,  Hopkins, that made this mischief.
t: So his surveyor appeared against him along with Sir Gilbert Peck (his chancellor), John Car (his confessor) and that devilish monk Hopkins, who caused this trouble.

og: That was heThat fed him with his prophecies?
t: He was the one who fed the duke his prophecies?

og: The same.  All these accused him strongly; which he fain  Would have flung from him, but, indeed, he could not:
t: Yes. They all accused him strongly. He tried to deny everything but couldn't.

og: And so his peers, upon this evidence,  Have found him guilty of high treason.
t: So his peers, seeing this evidence, found him guilty of high treason. He said a lot that was very learned to argue for his life.

og: Much  He spoke, and learnedly, for life; but all  Was either pitied in him or forgotten.
t: But everything he said was either pitied (but not listened to) or forgotten.

og: After all this, how did he bear himself?
t: After all this, how did he act?

og: When he was brought again to the bar, to hear  His knell rung out, his judgment, he was stirr'd  With such an agony, he sweat extremely,  And something spoke in choler, ill, and hasty:
t: When he was brought back to the stand to hear the judgement, he was filled with such agony that he sweated a lot and spoke words angrily, badly, and hastily.

og: But he fell to himself again, and sweetly  In all the rest show'd a most noble patience.
t: But he came back to himself and showed a noble patience for the rest of it.

og: I do not think he fears death.
t: I do not think he fears death.

og: Sure, he does not:He never was so womanish; the causeHe may a little grieve at.
t: Surely he doesn't. He was never that womanish. He may be a little sad about the cause of his death.

og: CertainlyThe cardinal is the end of this.
t: Certainly the cardinal is responsible for this.

og: 'Tis likely,  By all conjectures: first, Kildare's attainder,  Then deputy of Ireland;
t: It's likely, and everyone thinks so. First, there's the fact that Kildare was arrested, who was then the deputy of Ireland.

og: who removed,  Earl Surrey was sent thither, and in haste too,  Lest he should help his father.
t: Once he was removed, the Earl of Surry was sent there, and quickly too, so he couldn't help his father.

og: That trick of stateWas a deep envious one.
t: That was a sneaky, jealous trick.

og: At his return  No doubt he will requite it.
t: No doubt he'll take his revenge for it when he returns.

og: This is noted,  And generally, whoever the king favours,  The cardinal instantly will find employment,  And far enough from court too.
t: It has been noticed that, in general, the cardinal instantly finds a job far from court for whomever the king favors.

og: All the commons  Hate him perniciously, and, o' my conscience,  Wish him ten fathom deep:
t: All the common people hate him and I swear they want him dead and buried.

og: this duke as much  They love and dote on; call him bounteous Buckingham,  The mirror of all courtesy;—
t: They love this duke as much as they hate the cardinal. They call him generous Buckingham, the best example of all good qualities—

og: Stay there, sir,And see the noble ruin'd man you speak of.
t: Stop there, sir, and look at the noble, ruined man you're talking about.

og: Let's stand close, and behold him.
t: Let's get closer and look at him.

og: All good people,  You that thus far have come to pity me,  Hear what I say, and then go home and lose me.
t: Good people, you who have come here to pity me, listen to what I say and then go home and forget me.

og: I have this day received a traitor's judgment,  And by that name must die: yet, heaven bear witness,  And if I have a conscience, let it sink me,  Even as the axe falls, if I be not faithful!
t: Today I was sentenced as a traitor, and I must die as one. But, may heaven bear witness, and may my conscience sink me into the ground just as the axe is falling if I lie, I am a faithful subject!

og: The law I bear no malice for my death;  'T has done, upon the premises, but justice:  But those that sought it I could wish more Christians:  Be what they will, I heartily forgive 'em:
t: I don't blame the law for my death. It did what was right based on the evidence. But I wish those who prosecuted me were better Christians. Whatever they are, I gladly forgive them.

og: Yet let 'em look they glory not in mischief,  Nor build their evils on the graves of great men;  For then my guiltless blood must cry against 'em.
t: But let them be sure not to be proud of the mischief they do or kill great men to pursue their evil goals. Because then my innocent blood will accuse them.

og: For further life in this world I ne'er hope,  Nor will I sue, although the king have mercies  More than I dare make faults.
t: I don't hope for more life in this world and I won't ask for it, although the king is able to forgive more evil deeds than I would dare do.

og: You few that loved me,  And dare be bold to weep for Buckingham,  His noble friends and fellows, whom to leave  Is only bitter to him, only dying,  Go with me, like good angels, to my end;
t: You few who loved me and dare to weep for Buckingham, his noble friends, the only pain and death he feels is having to leave you. Go with me to my death like good angels.

og: And, as the long divorce of steel falls on me,  Make of your prayers one sweet sacrifice,  And lift my soul to heaven. Lead on, o' God's name.
t: And, as the blade cuts me in two, offer your prayers as a sweet offering to God and lift my soul to heaven. Let's go, in God's name.

og: I do beseech your grace, for charity,If ever any malice in your heartWere hid against me, now to forgive me frankly.
t: Please, your grace, as a kindness, forgive me if there was ever any resentment against me in your heart.

og: Sir Thomas Lovell, I as free forgive you  As I would be forgiven: I forgive all;  There cannot be those numberless offences  'Gainst me, that I cannot take peace with:
t: Sir Thomas Lovell, I forgive you as freely as I wish to be forgiven. I forgive everything. There can't be so many crimes against me that I can't forgive them all.

og: no black envy  Shall mark my grave. Commend me to his grace;  And if he speak of Buckingham, pray, tell him  You met him half in heaven: my vows and prayers  Yet are the king's;
t: No evil resentment will be left in me when I die. Give my best to the king. If he talks about Buckingham, please, tell him you saw him already half in heaven. My prayers are still with the king

og: and, till my soul forsake,  Shall cry for blessings on him: may he live  Longer than I have time to tell his years!
t: and until I die I will bless him: may he live longer than I have time to count his age!

og: Ever beloved and loving may his rule be!  And when old time shall lead him to his end,  Goodness and he fill up one monument!
t: May he be always beloved and loving! And when it's time for him to die, may he lie in the same grave as goodness!

og: To the water side I must conduct your grace;Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux,Who undertakes you to your end.
t: I must lead you to the riverbank, your grace, then hand you over to Sir Nicholas Vaux, who will lead you to your death.

og: Prepare there,  The duke is coming:
t: Prepare yourselves, the duke is coming.

og: see the barge be ready;  And fit it with such furniture as suits  The greatness of his person.
t: Make sure the barge is ready and fill it with furniture good enough for someone that important.

og: Nay, Sir Nicholas,  Let it alone; my state now will but mock me.  When I came hither, I was lord high constable  And Duke of Buckingham; now, poor Edward Bohun:
t: No, Sir Nicholas, leave it alone. Standing on ceremony will only mock me now. When I came here I was lord high constable and the Duke of Buckingam. Now, I'm just Edward Bohun.

og: Yet I am richer than my base accusers,  That never knew what truth meant: I now seal it;  And with that blood will make 'em one day groan for't.
t: But I am better than my low accusers who never knew what truth was. I am now showing them. And my blood will punish them for this someday.

og: My noble father, Henry of Buckingham,  Who first raised head against usurping Richard,  Flying for succor to his servant Banister,  Being distress'd, was by that wretch betray'd,  And without trial fell; God's peace be with him!
t: My noble father, Henry of Buckingham, who first revolted against the usurper Richard, ran for help to his servant Bannister when he was in trouble and was betrayed by that wretch and died without a trial. May he rest in peace!

og: Henry the Seventh succeeding, truly pitying  My father's loss, like a most royal prince,  Restored me to my honours, and, out of ruins,  Made my name once more noble.
t: Henry VII succeeded to the throne and pitied the death of my father. Like a good king should, he gave me back the titles I had lost and made my name noble again.

og: Now his son,  Henry the Eighth, life, honour, name and all  That made me happy at one stroke has taken  For ever from the world. I had my trial,  And, must needs say, a noble one; which makes me,  A little happier than my wretched father:
t: Now his son, Henry VIII, takes my life, honor, name, and everything that made me happy from this world with one stroke. I had my trial and I have to say it was a noble one. That makes me a little luckier than my poor father.

og: Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both  Fell by our servants, by those men we loved most;  A most unnatural and faithless service!
t: But we are the same in our fortune in this way: we were both brought down by our servants, by the men we loved most. Those were unnatural and unfaithful servants!

og: Heaven has an end in all: yet, you that hear me,  This from a dying man receive as certain:  Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels  Be sure you be not loose;
t: God is responsible for everything. But you who listen to me, know this for sure since you hear it from a dying man. Be sure that you are not too generous with your love and your secrets.

og: for those you make friends  And give your hearts to, when they once perceive  The least rub in your fortunes, fall away  Like water from ye, never found again  But where they mean to sink ye.
