t: Because those you make your friends and give your hearts to will fall away from you like drops of water when they see the smallest misfortune ahead of you. And they will disappear forever, except when they come back to drown you.

og: All good people,  Pray for me! I must now forsake ye: the last hour  Of my long weary life is come upon me.
t: All good people should pray for me! I must leave you now. The last hour of my long, tired life has arrived.

og: Farewell:  And when you would say something that is sad,  Speak how I fell. I have done; and God forgive me!
t: Goodbye. And when you want to hear something sad, talk about how I died. I am done. May God forgive me!

og: O, this is full of pity! Sir, it calls,I fear, too many curses on their headsThat were the authors.
t: Oh, this is sad! I'm afraid this will damn the people who did it.

og: If the duke be guiltless,  'Tis full of woe:
t: If the duke is innocent, this is really sad.

og: yet I can give you inkling  Of an ensuing evil, if it fall,  Greater than this.
t: But I can give you a hint of a future evil that will be worse than this if it happens.

og: Good angels keep it from us!What may it be? You do not doubt my faith, sir?
t: May good angels protect us from it! What can it be? You trust me to keep it secret, don't you sir?

og: This secret is so weighty, 'twill requireA strong faith to conceal it.
t: This secret is so important that it will require great strength of character to keep it secret.

og: Let me have it;I do not talk much.
t: Let me hear it. I don't talk much.

og: I am confident,  You shall, sir:
t: I trust you. You will hear it, sir.

og: did you not of late days hear  A buzzing of a separation  Between the king and Katharine?
t: Did you not recently hear talk about a separation between the king and Katharine?

og: Yes, but it held not:  For when the king once heard it, out of anger  He sent command to the lord mayor straight  To stop the rumor,
t: Yes, but it wasn't true. Because when the king heard about it, he was angry and sent an order immediately to the mayor to stop the rumor

og: and allay those tongues  That durst disperse it.
t: and arrest the people who dared to spread it.

og: But that slander, sir,  Is found a truth now: for it grows again  Fresher than e'er it was; and held for certain  The king will venture at it.
t: But it turns out that this lie is true now. Because the rumor has reappeared stronger than it ever was, and it's believed that the king will definitely try to get a separation.

og: Either the cardinal,  Or some about him near, have, out of malice  To the good queen, possess'd him with a scruple  That will undo her:
t: Either the cardinal or some of his people have, out of malice against the good queen, ruined her by sowing some doubt in the king.

og: to confirm this too,  Cardinal Campeius is arrived, and lately;  As all think, for this business.
t: What confirms the truth of this is that Cardinal Campeius has recently arrived, and everyone thinks it's about this business.

og: 'Tis the cardinal;  And merely to revenge him on the emperor  For not bestowing on him,
t: It's the cardinal. And he's doing this just to get revenge against the emperor for not making him

og: at his asking,  The archbishopric of Toledo, this is purposed.
t: archbishop of Toledo as he asked.

og: I think you have hit the mark: but is't not cruelThat she should feel the smart of this? The cardinalWill have his will, and she must fall.
t: I think you're right. But isn't it cruel to make her suffer for that? The cardinal will get what he wants and she will lose power.

og: 'Tis woful.We are too open here to argue this;Let's think in private more.
t: It is sad. We shouldn't talk about this so openly. Let's consider this more in private.

og: 'My lord, the horses your lordship sent for, with  all the care I had, I saw well chosen, ridden, and  furnished.
t: "My lord, I made sure the horses you sent for were well chosen, trained, and cared for.

og: They were young and handsome, and of the  best breed in the north. When they were ready to  set out for London, a man of my lord cardinal's, by  commission and main power, took 'em from me; with  this reason:
t: They were young and good-looking, and of the best breed of the north. When they were ready to send to London, a servant of the cardinal's took them from me by force and with a warrant he had. He said this was the reason:

og: His master would be served before a  subject, if not before the king; which stopped our  mouths, sir.'
t: his master had to be served before a subject, if not before the king. We couldn't say anything to that, sir."

og: I fear he will indeed: well, let him have them:  He will have all, I think.
t: I am afraid he will be served before the king. Well, let him have them. I think he will have everything.

og: Well met, my lord chamberlain.
t: Hello, my lord chamberlain.

og: Good day to both your graces.
t: Good day to both of you.

og: How is the king employ'd?
t: What is the king doing?

og: I left him private,Full of sad thoughts and troubles.
t: I left him alone, thinking sad thoughts and feeling troubled.

og: What's the cause?
t: Why?

og: It seems the marriage with his brother's wifeHas crept too near his conscience.
t: It seems that he's feeling guilty about his marriage to his brother's wife.

og: No, his conscienceHas crept too near another lady.
t: No, I think he's thinking about another lady.

og: 'Tis so:  This is the cardinal's doing, the king-cardinal:
t: It's true. This is the cardinal's doing, the king-cardinal more like.

og: That blind priest, like the eldest son of fortune,  Turns what he list. The king will know him one day.
t: That blind priest does what he wants as if he's fortune's oldest son and heir. The king will find out what he's really like someday.

og: Pray God he do! he'll never know himself else.
t: I pray to God he does! Or he'll never understand himself.

og: How holily he works in all his business!  And with what zeal! for, now he has crack'd the league  Between us and the emperor, the queen's great nephew,
t: He acts so religiously in everything he does! And so eagerly! Because now he has broken the alliance between us and the emperor, the queen's powerful nephew,

og: He dives into the king's soul, and there scatters  Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience,  Fears, and despairs; and all these for his marriage:
t: he messes with the king's mind and scatters dangerous thoughts, doubts, fears, and despair, and troubles his conscience. All this is about his marriage.

og: And out of all these to restore the king,  He counsels a divorce; a loss of her  That, like a jewel, has hung twenty years  About his neck, yet never lost her lustre;
t: And to cure the king of all this he suggests a divorce. That would mean the loss of the woman who hung around his neck like a jewel for twenty years and never lost her brightness.

og: Of her that loves him with that excellence  That angels love good men with; even of her  That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls,  Will bless the king: and is not this course pious?
t: The loss of the woman who loves him as much as angels love good men. The woman who would still bless the king even if the worst disaster happened. Isn't this a religious thing to do?

og: Heaven keep me from such counsel! 'Tis most true  These news are every where; every tongue speaks 'em,  And every true heart weeps for't:
t: May heaven protect me from advice like that! It's true that this news is everywhere. Everyone is saying this and every good heart weeps for it.

og: all that dare  Look into these affairs see this main end,  The French king's sister.
t: Everyone who dares look into this affair see that he wants the king to marry the French king's sister.

og: Heaven will one day open  The king's eyes, that so long have slept upon  This bold bad man.
t: One day God will open the king's eyes. He hasn't seen this bold, bad man as he really is for so long.

og: And free us from his slavery.
t: And God will free us from slavery to him.

og: We had need pray,  And heartily, for our deliverance;  Or this imperious man will work us all  From princes into pages:
t: We need to pray (and to pray strongly) for help, or this proud man will turn us from princes into servants.

og: all men's honours  Lie like one lump before him, to be fashion'd  Into what pitch he please.
t: He does whatever he wants with men's honors.

og: For me, my lords,  I love him not, nor fear him; there's my creed:  As I am made without him, so I'll stand,  If the king please;
t: As for me, my lord, I neither love him nor fear him. That's what I say. I'll do the best I can without his help, if the king wishes it.

og: his curses and his blessings  Touch me alike, they're breath I not believe in.  I knew him, and I know him;
t: His curse and his blessings affect me equally: they're just breath and I don't believe in them. I always knew what he was like and I still do.

og: so I leave him  To him that made him proud, the pope.
t: So I leave him to the man who made him proud, the Pope.

og: Let's in;  And with some other business put the king  From these sad thoughts,
t: Let's go in and distract the king from these sad thoughts

og: that work too much upon him:  My lord, you'll bear us company?
t: that affect him too much with some other business. Will you accompany us, my lord?

og: Excuse me;  The king has sent me otherwhere:
t: I can't, I'm sorry. The king has sent me elsewhere.

og: besides,  You'll find a most unfit time to disturb him:  Health to your lordships.
t: Besides, this isn't a good time to disturb him. Goodbye.

og: Thanks, my good lord chamberlain.
t: Thank you, lord chamberlain.

og: How sad he looks! sure, he is much afflicted.
t: He looks so sad! He's definitely feeling very disturbed.

og: Who's there, ha?
t: Who's there?

og: Pray God he be not angry.
t: I pray to God he isn't angry.

og: Who's there, I say? How dare you thrust yourselvesInto my private meditations?Who am I? ha?
t: I said, who's there? How dare you interrupt me when I'm thinking? Who do you think I am, huh?

og: A gracious king that pardons all offences  Malice ne'er meant:
t: A kind king who forgives offenses that weren't intentional.

og: our breach of duty this way  Is business of estate; in which we come  To know your royal pleasure.
t: We failed in our duty because of state business and we've come to know what you want to do about it.

og: Ye are too bold:Go to; I'll make ye know your times of business:Is this an hour for temporal affairs, ha?
t: You're too bold. Go away. I'll let you know what time you can come talk about business. Does this seem like a time for unholy business?

og: Who's there? my good lord cardinal? O my Wolsey,The quiet of my wounded conscience;Thou art a cure fit for a king.    My good lord, have great careI be not found a talker.
t: Who's there? The cardinal? Oh my dear Wolsey, you heal my wounded conscience. You're a cure good enough for a king. My good lord, make sure I don't talk too much.

og: Sir, you cannot.I would your grace would give us but an hourOf private conference.
t: You couldn't possibly, sir. I wish you would just give us an hour of private conversation, your grace.

og: We are busy; go.
t: I'm busy; go away.

og: This priest has no pride in him?
t: Surely this priest doesn't have any pride in him?

og: Not to speak of:I would not be so sick though for his place:But this cannot continue.
t: None to speak of. I wouldn't be like him in return for all his power. This can't go on.

og: If it do,I'll venture one have-at-him.
t: If it does, I'll attack him.

og: I another.
t: So will I.

og: Your grace has given a precedent of wisdom  Above all princes, in committing freely  Your scruple to the voice of Christendom:
t: You have shown greater wisdom than all other princes in telling your doubts to the spokesperson of all Christianity.

og: Who can be angry now? what envy reach you?  The Spaniard, tied blood and favour to her,  Must now confess, if they have any goodness,  The trial just and noble.
t: Who can be angry now, or envious? The Spanish, who are her relatives and loyal to her, must confess if they are good people that the trial is fair and noble.

og: All the clerks,  I mean the learned ones, in Christian kingdoms  Have their free voices: Rome, the nurse of judgment,  Invited by your noble self,
t: All the clerks, I mean the learned ones, in Christian kingdoms can speak wisely about this. Rome, with its good judgement, invited by you,

og: hath sent  One general tongue unto us, this good man,  This just and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius;  Whom once more I present unto your highness.
t: has sent one man to speak for it to us, this good man, this fair and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius. I introduce him to you once more, your highness.

og: And once more in mine arms I bid him welcome,And thank the holy conclave for their loves:They have sent me such a man I would have wish'd for.
t: And once more I welcome him with a hug and thank the cardinals for their affection to me. They have sent me just the kind of man I hoped for.

og: Your grace must needs deserve all strangers' loves,  You are so noble. To your highness' hand  I tender my commission; by whose virtue,  The court of Rome commanding,
t: You deserve the love of all strangers, your grace, because you are so noble. I give my warrant to you, your highness. In it the court of Rome

og: you, my lord  Cardinal of York, are join'd with me their servant  In the unpartial judging of this business.
t: makes me, their servant, and you, my lord Cardinal of York, impartial judges in this matter.

og: Two equal men. The queen shall be acquaintedForthwith for what you come. Where's Gardiner?
t: Two equally virtuous men. The queen will be told what you've come for immediately. Where's Gardiner?

og: I know your majesty has always loved her  So dear in heart, not to deny her that  A woman of less place might ask by law:
t: I know you've always loved her so much that you won't deny her what even a less important woman has the right to ask for:

og: Scholars allow'd freely to argue for her.
t: scholars allowed to argue freely on her side.

og: Ay,
t: Yes,

og: God forbid else.
t: God forbid,

og: and the best she shall have; and my favour  To him that does best:
t: and she'll have the best ones. I'll reward the one who does best.

og: Cardinal,  Prithee, call Gardiner to me, my new secretary:  I find him a fit fellow.
t: Cardinal, please call Gardiner, my new secretary. I like him.

og: Give me your hand much joy andfavour to you;You are the king's now.
t: Shake my hand. I wish you well. You work for the king now.

og: But to be commandedFor ever by your grace, whose hand has raised me.
t: But I'll always do as you command, your grace. You helped me rise in power.

og: Come hither, Gardiner.
t: Come here, Gardiner.

og: My Lord of York, was not one Doctor PaceIn this man's place before him?
t: My Lord of York, didn't a certain Doctor Pace do this man's job before him?

og: Yes, he was.
t: Yes, he did.

og: Was he not held a learned man?
t: Wasn't he thought to be a learned man?

og: Yes, surely.
t: Yes, absolutely.

og: Believe me, there's an ill opinion spread thenEven of yourself, lord cardinal.
t: Believe me, then, there's a bad rumor being spread about you, lord cardinal.

og: How! of me?
t: What! About me?

og: They will not stick to say you envied him,  And fearing he would rise, he was so virtuous,
t: They're not afraid to say you envied him and you were afraid he would rise in power because he was virtuous,

og: Kept him a foreign man still; which so grieved him,  That he ran mad and died.
t: so you kept him away from the king. This made him so sad that he went crazy and died.

og: Heaven's peace be with him!  That's Christian care enough: for living murmurers  There's places of rebuke. He was a fool;
t: May he rest in peace! That's all my Christian duty to him: saying that. As for living slanderers, there are places they can be punished. He was a fool,

og: For he would needs be virtuous: that good fellow,  If I command him, follows my appointment:
t: because he insisted on being virtuous. That good man does what I say when I give him commands.

og: I will have none so near else. Learn this, brother,  We live not to be grip'd by meaner persons.
t: I have no one else as faithful. Learn this, brother: we don't need less important people meddling with us.

og: Deliver this with modesty to the queen.
t: Tell the queen kindly about this.

og: The most convenient place that I can think of  For such receipt of learning is Black-Friars;  There ye shall meet about this weighty business.
t: The best place I can think of to hear the case is Black-Friars. You will meet about this important business there.

og: My Wolsey, see it furnish'd. O, my lord,  Would it not grieve an able man to leave  So sweet a bedfellow? But, conscience, conscience!  O, 'tis a tender place; and I must leave her.
t: Have it prepared, my dear Wolsey. Oh, my lord, wouldn't a man who had a choice about it be sad to leave such a sweet wife? But my conscience, my conscience! My conscience is disturbed about this and I must leave her.

og: Not for that neither: here's the pang that pinches:  His highness having lived so long with her, and she  So good a lady that no tongue could ever  Pronounce dishonour of her;
t: No, that's not it. This is what bothers me: the king has lived with her for so long and she's such a good wife that no one could ever speak badly of her.

og: by my life,  She never knew harm-doing: O, now, after  So many courses of the sun enthroned,  Still growing in a majesty and pomp,
t: I swear she's never hurt anyone. Oh, now she's shared the king's throne for so long and grown so powerful and majestic

og: the which  To leave a thousand-fold more bitter than  'Tis sweet at first to acquire,—after this process,  To give her the avaunt! it is a pity  Would move a monster.
t: that it will be a thousand times more sad for him to leave her than it was delightful for him to get her at first. Kicking her out after all this time! Even a monster would pity her.

og: Hearts of most hard temperMelt and lament for her.
t: Even the hardest hearts melt and are sad for her.

og: O, God's will! much better  She ne'er had known pomp: though't be temporal,
t: Oh, I wish she had never been in power. Power is just a temporary worldly good,

og: Yet, if that quarrel, fortune, do divorce  It from the bearer, 'tis a sufferance panging  As soul and body's severing.
t: but being separated from it by bad fortune hurts as badly as death.

og: Alas, poor lady!She's a stranger now again.
t: Poor woman! Now she's a stranger in this country again.

og: So much the more  Must pity drop upon her. Verily,  I swear, 'tis better to be lowly born,
t: So much the more reason to pity her. I swear it's better to be low-born

og: And range with humble livers in content,  Than to be perk'd up in a glistering grief,  And wear a golden sorrow.
t: and wander around happily with other humble  people than to be dressed up in glittering costumes but be sad, as if you were wearing sadness made of gold.

og: Our contentIs our best having.
t: Happiness is our most important possession.

og: By my troth and maidenhead,I would not be a queen.
t: I swear by my faithfulness and virginity I wouldn't want to be a queen.

og: Beshrew me, I would,  And venture maidenhead for't; and so would you,  For all this spice of your hypocrisy:
t: Damn me, I would, and I would give my virginity to become one. And so would you, even though you're being a hypocrite about it.

og: You, that have so fair parts of woman on you,  Have too a woman's heart; which ever yet  Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty;
t: You have all the attractive parts a woman should have including a woman's heart, which always wants high status, wealth, and power.

og: Which, to say sooth, are blessings; and which gifts,  Saving your mincing, the capacity  Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive,  If you might please to stretch it.
t: And those things really are blessings. You would be able to fit all those gifts in your soft conscience if you were willing to stretch it out like a kid-skin glove.

og: Nay, good troth.
t: Goodness, no.

og: Yes, troth, and troth; you would not be a queen?
t: Goodness yes, and say yes. You don't want to be a queen?

og: No, not for all the riches under heaven.
t: No, not for all the wealth in the world.

og: 'Tis strange: a three-pence bow'd would hire me,  Old as I am, to queen it:
t: It's strange. I could be hired to be a queen with a three-penny coin, old as I am.

og: but, I pray you,  What think you of a duchess? have you limbs  To bear that load of title?
t: But what do you think of being a duchess? Would you be strong enough to bear that title?

og: No, in truth.
t: Really, no.

og: Then you are weakly made: pluck off a little;  I would not be a young count in your way,  For more than blushing comes to:
t: Then you're weak. Come on. I wouldn't want to be a young count going after you: he wouldn't get any more than blushing from you.

og: if your back  Cannot vouchsafe this burthen,'tis too weak  Ever to get a boy.
t: If your back can't bear this burden of a title it's too weak for you to lie on it to conceive a boy.

og: How you do talk!I swear again, I would not be a queenFor all the world.
t: You say such terrible things! I promise again, I wouldn't agree to be queen for everything in the world.

og: In faith, for little England  You'ld venture an emballing:
t: For little England, you'd dare to bear an emballing.

og: I myself  Would for Carnarvonshire, although there long'd  No more to the crown but that. Lo, who comes here?
t: I would just for Carnarvonshire, even if the king didn't own anything more than that.

og: Good morrow, ladies. What were't worth to knowThe secret of your conference?
t: Good morning, ladies. What would I have to give you to hear what you were talking about?

og: My good lord,Not your demand; it values not your asking:Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.
t: My good lord, don't even give us your question. It's not worth asking about. We were feeling sorry for our mistress.

og: It was a gentle business, and becomingThe action of good women: there is hopeAll will be well.
t: That was kind, and the right thing for good women to do. There's hope that everything will be fine.

og: Now, I pray God, amen!
t: I hope so!

og: You bear a gentle mind, and heavenly blessings  Follow such creatures. That you may, fair lady,  Perceive I speak sincerely, and high note's  Ta'en of your many virtues,
t: You have a good mind. God blesses people like you. So that you know I'm speaking sincerely, beautiful lady, when I say that important people notice your virtue,

og: the king's majesty  Commends his good opinion of you, and  Does purpose honour to you no less flowing  Than Marchioness of Pembroke:
t: the king says he thinks highly of you and wants to do you the honor of making you Marchioness of Pembroke.

og: to which title  A thousand pound a year, annual support,  Out of his grace he adds.
t: In addition to this title he kindly adds a thousand pounds a year as annual support.

og: I do not know  What kind of my obedience I should tender;  More than my all is nothing: nor my prayers  Are not words duly hallow'd,
t: I don't know how to show my gratefulness. Even giving him more than all I have would count for nothing. It's not that my prayers aren't holy words

og: nor my wishes  More worth than empty vanities; yet prayers and wishes  Are all I can return.
t: and my wishes are pointless, but prayers and wishes are all I can give him in return.

og: Beseech your lordship,  Vouchsafe to speak my thanks and my obedience,  As from a blushing handmaid, to his highness;  Whose health and royalty I pray for.
t: Please, your lordship, tell the king that my thankfulness and obedience are as great as if I were just a blushing servant. I pray for his health and royalty.

og: Lady,  I shall not fail to approve the fair conceit  The king hath of you.
t: Lady, I will confirm the king's good opinion of you.

og: I have perused her well;  Beauty and honour in her are so mingled  That they have caught the king:
t: [To himself] I have examined her carefully. She has so much beauty and honor that she has captured the king's heart.

og: and who knows yet  But from this lady may proceed a gem  To lighten all this isle?
t: Who knows, maybe this lady will have a child like a gem that will brighten this whole island.

og: I'll to the king,  And say I spoke with you.
t: [To Anne] I'll go to the king and say I spoke to you.

og: My honour'd lord.
t: Goodbye, my lord.

og: Why, this it is; see, see!  I have been begging sixteen years in court,  Am yet a courtier beggarly, nor could  Come pat betwixt too early and too late  For any suit of pounds;
t: See? See? This is it! I have been begging in court for sixteen years and I'm still a poor courtier and have never been in the right place at the right time to be given money.

og: and you, O fate!  A very fresh-fish here—fie, fie, fie upon  This compell'd fortune!—have your mouth fill'd up  Before you open it.
t: But you, oh this is fate! You're new here—damn, damn this fortune forced on you!—your mouth is filled with fortune before you even open it.

og: This is strange to me.
t: This is strange to me.

og: How tastes it? is it bitter? forty pence, no.
t: How does it taste? Does it taste bad? I bet forty cents it doesn't.

og: There was a lady once, 'tis an old story,  That would not be a queen, that would she not,  For all the mud in Egypt: have you heard it?
t: There was once a lady, it's an old story, who didn't want to be a queen, she didn't, for all the mud in Egypt. Have you heard it?

og: Come, you are pleasant.
t: Come on, you're joking.

og: With your theme, I could  O'ermount the lark. The Marchioness of Pembroke!  A thousand pounds a year for pure respect!  No other obligation!
t: With your gifts, I could rise higher in court than a lark rises in the sky. The Marchioness of Pembroke! A thousand pounds a year just because he respects you! No other obligations!

og: By my life,  That promises moe thousands: honour's train  Is longer than his foreskirt.
t: By my life, that promises more thousands. Honor is like a dress with a longer back than front: more follows than came before this.

og: By this time  I know your back will bear a duchess: say,  Are you not stronger than you were?
t: By this time I know you will be able to bear the title of duchess. Tell me, aren't you already stronger than you were?

og: Good lady,  Make yourself mirth with your particular fancy,  And leave me out on't.
t: My good lady, make yourself laugh with the things you imagine and leave me out of it.

og: Would I had no being,  If this salute my blood a jot: it faints me,  To think what follows.
t: I'd rather die than feel excited about this. I'm scared to think about what will happen next.

og: The queen is comfortless, and we forgetful  In our long absence: pray, do not deliver  What here you've heard to her.
t: The queen is in despair and we are neglecting her by being gone so long. Please don't tell her what you heard here.

og: What do you think me?
t: What kind of person do you think I am?

og: Whilst our commission from Rome is read,Let silence be commanded.
t: Silence while our warrant from Rome is being read.

og: What's the need?  It hath already publicly been read,  And on all sides the authority allow'd;
t: Why? It has already been read publicly and its authority has been accepted by everyone.

og: You may, then, spare that time.
t: So don't waste that time.

og: Be't so. Proceed.
t: Very well. Go on.

og: Say, Henry King of England, come into the court.
t: Say, Henry King of England, come into the court.

og: Henry King of England, & c.
t: Henry King of England, come into the court.

og: Here.
t: Here.

og: Say, Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.
t: Say, Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.

og: Katharine Queen of England, & c.
t: Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.

og: Sir, I desire you do me right and justice;  And to bestow your pity on me: for  I am a most poor woman, and a stranger,  Born out of your dominions;
t: Sir, I ask you to do what is right and just by me and to pity me. I am a very miserable woman and a stranger born outside your land.

og: having here  No judge indifferent, nor no more assurance  Of equal friendship and proceeding. Alas, sir,  In what have I offended you?
t: I have no unbiased judge here and no guarantee of fair treatment. Sir, how have I offended you?

og: what cause  Hath my behavior given to your displeasure,  That thus you should proceed to put me off,  And take your good grace from me?
t: What cause has my behavior given you to be angry and to divorce me and take away your kindness from me?

og: Heaven witness,  I have been to you a true and humble wife,  At all times to your will conformable;  Ever in fear to kindle your dislike,  Yea, subject to your countenance, glad or sorry  As I saw it inclined:
t: May heaven be my witness, I have been a faithful and humble wife to you and have always done what you wanted. I have always been afraid of making you dislike me and have been guided by your appearance: I have been happy or sad according to how happy or sad you seemed.

og: when was the hour  I ever contradicted your desire,  Or made it not mine too? Or which of your friends  Have I not strove to love, although I knew  He were mine enemy?
t: When have I ever refused anything you desired or not also desired it for you? Or which of your friends have I not tried to love even if I knew he was my enemy?

og: what friend of mine  That had to him derived your anger, did I  Continue in my liking? nay, gave notice  He was from thence discharged.
t: What friend of mine who had made you angry did I continue to like? No, I always had him sent away.

og: Sir, call to mind  That I have been your wife, in this obedience,  Upward of twenty years, and have been blest  With many children by you:
t: Sir, remember I have been your wife, obedient to you in this way, for more than twenty years and have been blessed in becoming pregnant with many of your children.

og: if, in the course  And process of this time, you can report,  And prove it too, against mine honour aught,  My bond to wedlock, or my love and duty,  Against your sacred person, in God's name,  Turn me away;
t: If, in the course of all this time, you can report and prove anything against my honor, my faithfulness in marriage, or my love and duty to you, in God's name, send me away.

og: and let the foul'st contempt  Shut door upon me, and so give me up  To the sharp'st kind of justice.
t: Hate me, shut your door to me, and give me up to the law's punishment.

og: Please you sir,  The king, your father, was reputed for  A prince most prudent, of an excellent  And unmatch'd wit and judgment:
t: Please sir, the king your father was known as a very wise king, of excellent and unequalled intelligence and judgement.

og: Ferdinand,  My father, king of Spain, was reckon'd one  The wisest prince that there had reign'd by many  A year before:
t: Ferdinand, my father, king of Spain, was thought to be one of the wisest princes to have ruled Spain for many years.

og: it is not to be question'd  That they had gather'd a wise council to them  Of every realm, that did debate this business,  Who deem'd our marriage lawful:
t: Undoubtedly they gathered wise advisers from every country to debate this business and they thought it would be legal for us to marry.

og: wherefore I humbly  Beseech you, sir, to spare me, till I may  Be by my friends in Spain advised; whose counsel  I will implore: if not, i' the name of God,  Your pleasure be fulfill'd!
t: So I humbly ask you, sir, to wait until I can be advised by my friends in Spain. I will beg for their advice. If not, in the name of God, I hope you will do what gives you pleasure!

og: You have here, lady,  And of your choice, these reverend fathers; men  Of singular integrity and learning,  Yea, the elect o' the land, who are assembled  To plead your cause:
t: Lady, you have your choice of these wise scholars here. They're men of unmatched honesty and learning. They're the best in the country, assembled to argue the case for you.

og: it shall be therefore bootless  That longer you desire the court; as well  For your own quiet, as to rectify  What is unsettled in the king.
t: So it won't help you to keep asking the court for this; it won't help you either by making you feel better or solving the problem worrying the king.

og: His grace  Hath spoken well and justly: therefore, madam,  It's fit this royal session do proceed;
t: The cardinal has spoken the truth well. So, ma'am, this royal trial should go on.

og: And that, without delay, their arguments  Be now produced and heard.
t: With no more delay, let the arguments be made and heard.

og: Lord cardinal,To you I speak.
t: Lord cardinal, I speak to you.

og: Your pleasure, madam?
t: What would you like, ma'am?

og: Sir,  I am about to weep; but, thinking that  We are a queen, or long have dream'd so,
t: Sir, I'm about to cry. But, considering that I am a queen, or at least have thought I was for a long time

og: certain  The daughter of a king, my drops of tears  I'll turn to sparks of fire.
t: (certainly I am the daughter of a king), I'll turn my teardrops into fiery sparks.

og: Be patient yet.
t: Be patient.

og: I will, when you are humble; nay, before,  Or God will punish me. I do believe,  Induced by potent circumstances, that  You are mine enemy, and make my challenge  You shall not be my judge:
t: I will, when you are humble. No, before that, or God will punish me because that will never happen. I have strong reasons to believe you're my enemy, and I say you will not be my judge.

og: for it is you  Have blown this coal betwixt my lord and me;  Which God's dew quench! Therefore I say again,  I utterly abhor, yea, from my soul  Refuse you for my judge;
t: You are the one who started this trouble between my husband and me, which I hope God will put an end to! So I say again, I hate, yes, I absolutely refuse you as my judge.

og: whom, yet once more,  I hold my most malicious foe, and think not  At all a friend to truth.
t: Again, I think you are my worst enemy and not at all truthful.

og: I do profess  You speak not like yourself; who ever yet  Have stood to charity, and display'd the effects  Of disposition gentle, and of wisdom  O'ertopping woman's power.
t: I think you don't sound like yourself. You've always been kind and good-natured and seemed wiser than other women.

og: Madam, you do me wrong:  I have no spleen against you; nor injustice  For you or any:
t: Ma'am, you're treating me badly. I don't have any anger towards you and I don't want to treat you or anyone unjustly.

og: how far I have proceeded,  Or how far further shall, is warranted  By a commission from the consistory,  Yea, the whole consistory of Rome.
t: What I've done and will do is allowed by a warrant from the holy council, the whole holy council, of Rome.

og: You charge me  That I have blown this coal: I do deny it:  The king is present: if it be known to him  That I gainsay my deed, how may he wound,  And worthily, my falsehood!
t: You accuse me of starting this trouble. I deny it. The king is here. If he knows that I'm lying about what I did, he can rightly punish me for my lie!

og: yea, as much  As you have done my truth. If he know  That I am free of your report, he knows  I am not of your wrong.
t: Yes, he can punish me as much for lying as you have punished me for being true to him. If he knows that I am innocent of what you say, he knows you have been unfair to me.

og: Therefore in him  It lies to cure me: and the cure is, to  Remove these thoughts from you:
t: So it's up to him to help me. That help is, to stop you from believing this about me.

og: the which before  His highness shall speak in, I do beseech  You, gracious madam, to unthink your speaking  And to say so no more.
t: Before he says anything about this, I beg you, ma'am, to change your mind and not say what you said again.

og: My lord, my lord,  I am a simple woman, much too weak  To oppose your cunning.
t: My lord, my lord, I am a simple woman, much too weak to fight your cleverness.

og: You're meek and  humble-mouth'd;  You sign your place and calling, in full seeming,  With meekness and humility; but your heart  Is cramm'd with arrogancy, spleen, and pride.
t: You're quiet and speak humbly, you talk about your position and your job in public quietly and humbly. But your heart is stuffed with arrogance, anger, and pride.

og: You have, by fortune and his highness' favours,  Gone slightly o'er low steps and now are mounted  Where powers are your retainers, and your words,  Domestics to you, serve your will as't please  Yourself pronounce their office.
t: You have by fortune and with the help of powerful people risen quickly from the lower class and now you are in a high enough position that kings are your servants and your words, which are also your servants, do whatever you wish them to do.

og: I must tell you,  You tender more your person's honour than  Your high profession spiritual: that again  I do refuse you for my judge;
t: I must tell you, you care more about your own honor than your important religious position. Again, I say I refuse you as my judge.

og: and here,  Before you all, appeal unto the pope,  To bring my whole cause 'fore his holiness,  And to be judged by him.
t: And here, before all of you, I appeal to the Pope. I'll bring my whole case to him and be judged by him.

og: The queen is obstinate,  Stubborn to justice, apt to accuse it, and  Disdainful to be tried by't:
t: The queen is stubborn and refuses justice. She's quick to accuse it and unwilling to be judged by it.

og: 'tis not well.  She's going away.
t: This is bad. She's going away.

og: Call her again.
t: Call her again.

og: Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.
t: Katharine Queen of England, come into the court.

og: Madam, you are call'd back.
t: Ma'am, you are being called back.

og: What need you note it? pray you, keep your way:  When you are call'd, return. Now, the Lord help,  They vex me past my patience!
t: Why do you have to point it out? Please, go away. Come back when you're called. Now, God help me, they're making me lose my patience!

og: Pray you, pass on:  I will not tarry; no, nor ever more  Upon this business my appearance make  In any of their courts.
t: Please, go away. I won't stay. No, nor will I appear in any of their courts anymore about this business.

og: Go thy ways, Kate:  That man i' the world who shall report he has  A better wife, let him in nought be trusted,  For speaking false in that:
t: Go away, Kate. Don't trust anyone in the whole world who says he has a better wife, because he's lying about that.

og: thou art, alone,  If thy rare qualities, sweet gentleness,  Thy meekness saint-like, wife-like government,  Obeying in commanding,
t: You alone would be declared the queen of earthly queens if your rare good qualities, sweet gentleness, saint-like patience, wife-like actions, obedience,

og: and thy parts  Sovereign and pious else, could speak thee out,  The queen of earthly queens:
t: and your other royal and holy qualities, could speak for you.

og: she's noble born;  And, like her true nobility, she has  Carried herself towards me.
t: She comes from a noble family and she has always acted towards me with true nobility.

og: Most gracious sir,  In humblest manner I require your highness,  That it shall please you to declare, in hearing  Of all these ears,—
t: Dear sir, I humbly ask you to declare in front of everyone whether I first spoke of this business to you or put any doubt in your way that would make you think about it.

og: for where I am robb'd and bound,  There must I be unloosed, although not there  At once and fully satisfied,—
t: It is as though I have been robbed and tied up by being accused of this and I have to be untied, even if not here at once, and repaid for it.

og: whether ever I  Did broach this business to your highness; or  Laid any scruple in your way, which might  Induce you to the question on't?
t: Or have I ever spoken the smallest word to you that led you to question your marriage?

og: or ever  Have to you, but with thanks to God for such  A royal lady, spake one the least word that might  Be to the prejudice of her present state,  Or touch of her good person?
t: Or have I ever said something that could hurt her or her character, without always also thanking God for giving you such a royal wife?

og: My lord cardinal,  I do excuse you; yea, upon mine honour,  I free you from't.
t: My lord cardinal, I say you're innocent. Yes, I swear by my honor you're innocent of this.

og: You are not to be taught  That you have many enemies, that know not  Why they are so, but, like to village-curs,  Bark when their fellows do: by some of these  The queen is put in anger. You're excused:
t: You don't need to be told you have many enemies who don't know why they're your enemies but, like village dogs, bark when the others do. The queen has been made angry by some of these. You're innocent.

og: But will you be more justified? You ever  Have wish'd the sleeping of this business; never desired  It to be stirr'd; but oft have hinder'd, oft,  The passages made toward it:
t: But do you want me to go on making excuses for you? You always wanted this business put to rest, never wanted it started, but have often slowed it down.

og: on my honour,  I speak my good lord cardinal to this point,  And thus far clear him. Now, what moved me to't,  I will be bold with time and your attention:
t: On my honor, I'll say that for the good cardinal and clear him of the accusations. Now, I'll be so bold as to ask for your time and attention to tell you what made me want to do this.

og: Then mark the inducement. Thus it came; give heed to't:  My conscience first received a tenderness,  Scruple, and prick, on certain speeches utter'd  By the Bishop of Bayonne, then French ambassador;
t: So listen to how this started. It came about like this. Listen. I had my first doubt because of some things the Bishop of Bayonne, then the French ambassador, said,

og: Who had been hither sent on the debating  A marriage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and  Our daughter Mary: i' the progress of this business,  Ere a determinate resolution, he,  I mean the bishop, did require a respite;
t: who had been sent here to talk about a marriage between the Duke of Orleans and our daughter Mary. During this business, before a decision was made, he, I  mean the bishop, asked for a pause.

og: Wherein he might the king his lord advertise  Whether our daughter were legitimate,  Respecting this our marriage with the dowager,  Sometimes our brother's wife.
t: He wanted to let the king his master find out whether my daughter was legitimate, given my marriage to the woman who was once my brother's wife.

og: This respite shook  The bosom of my conscience, enter'd me,  Yea, with a splitting power, and made to tremble  The region of my breast; which forced such way,  That many mazed considerings did throng  And press'd in with this caution.
t: This pause shook me, entered into my conscience, yes, it almost split me in two and made my heart tremble. This thought forced its way into my conscience in such a way that many amazed considerations pushed and forced their way in along with it.

og: First, methought  I stood not in the smile of heaven; who had  Commanded nature, that my lady's womb,  If it conceived a male child by me, should  Do no more offices of life to't than  The grave does to the dead;
t: First, I thought God wasn't happy with me. He had commanded nature that, if a male child was conceived in my wife's womb by me, the womb would not give life to him but instead would be his grave.

og: for her male issue  Or died where they were made, or shortly after  This world had air'd them: hence I took a thought,  This was a judgment on me;
t: Her male children either died where they were conceived or shortly after they were born. So I thought this was a punishment against me

og: that my kingdom,  Well worthy the best heir o' the world, should not  Be gladded in't by me: then follows, that  I weigh'd the danger which my realms stood in  By this my issue's fail; and that gave to me  Many a groaning throe.
t: and that my kingdom, which deserves the best heir in the world, would not get one from me to make it happy. Then I considered the danger my kingdom was in because I didn't have a child. And that made me groan and suffer.

og: Thus hulling in  The wild sea of my conscience, I did steer  Toward this remedy, whereupon we are  Now present here together:
t: So, thrown around in my conscience like a ship in a storm, I came up with this way to fix things that we are all engaged in today.

og: that's to say,  I meant to rectify my conscience,—which  I then did feel full sick, and yet not well,—  By all the reverend fathers of the land  And doctors learn'd:
t: That is, I wanted all the holy churchmen and learned academics in the country to cure my conscience, which felt sick then and isn't better yet.

og: first I began in private  With you, my Lord of Lincoln; you remember  How under my oppression I did reek,  When I first moved you.
t: I began by speaking privately with you, my Lord of Lincoln. You remember how upset I was when I first spoke to you.

og: Very well, my liege.
t: Very clearly, my king.

og: I have spoke long: be pleased yourself to sayHow far you satisfied me.
t: I have spoken for a long time. Please tell me what you have done to satisfy my conscience.

og: So please your highness,  The question did at first so stagger me,  Bearing a state of mighty moment in't  And consequence of dread,
t: Your highness, the matter was so important and had such terrible consequences that it amazed me at first.

og: that I committed  The daring'st counsel which I had to doubt;  And did entreat your highness to this course  Which you are running here.
t: I worried I was advising you too boldly. I begged you to go about settling the matter in the way you are now.

og: I then moved you,  My Lord of Canterbury; and got your leave  To make this present summons: unsolicited  I left no reverend person in this court;
t: I then convinced you, my Lord of Canterbury, and got your approval for summoning these people here. I talked to every wise person in this courthouse.

og: But by particular consent proceeded  Under your hands and seals: therefore, go on:  For no dislike i' the world against the person  Of the good queen, but the sharp thorny points  Of my alleged reasons, drive this forward:
t: But particularly I put myself in your hands and did what you advised. So, continue. It was not because I disliked my good queen but because of the terrible reasons I just told you that this is happening.

og: Prove but our marriage lawful, by my life  And kingly dignity, we are contented  To wear our mortal state to come with her,  Katharine our queen, before the primest creature  That's paragon'd o' the world.
t: Just prove our marriage to be legal and I swear by my life and my dignity as king that I will be happy to stay with her, Katharine my queen,  for the rest of my life, sooner than marry even the best woman in the world.

og: So please your highness,  The queen being absent, 'tis a needful fitness  That we adjourn this court till further day:
t: Your highness, since the queen is absent it's necessary and right to adjourn this trial.

og: Meanwhile must be an earnest motion  Made to the queen, to call back her appeal  She intends unto his holiness.
t: Meanwhile someone should be sent to talk honestly to the queen to convince her not to appeal to the Pope.

og: [Aside]  I may perceive  These cardinals trifle with me: I abhor  This dilatory sloth and tricks of Rome.
t: [To himself] I can see that these cardinals are playing with me. I hate the delaying laziness and tricks of Rome.

og: My learn'd and well-beloved servant, Cranmer,  Prithee, return: with thy approach, I know,  My comfort comes along.
t: Please come back, my learned and beloved servant Cranmer. When you come back, I know that my happiness will too.

og: Break up the court:  I say, set on.
t: [To the court] The court is dismissed. I said, go.

og: Take thy lute, wench: my soul grows sad with troubles;Sing, and disperse 'em, if thou canst: leave working.
t: Play your lute, girl. My soul is sad. Sing and send them away if you can. Stop sewing.

og: [singing]  Orpheus with his lute made trees,  And the mountain tops that freeze,  Bow themselves when he did sing:
t: [singing]Orpheus made trees And the freezing mountain topsBow when he sang.

og: To his music plants and flowers  Ever sprung; as sun and showers  There had made a lasting spring.
t: His music made plants and flowersGrow as if sun and rainHad created an eternal Spring there.

og: Every thing that heard him play,  Even the billows of the sea,  Hung their heads, and then lay by.
t: Everything that heard him play,Even the waves of the sea,Hung their heads then lay down next to him.

og: In sweet music is such art,  Killing care and grief of heart  Fall asleep, or hearing, die.
t: Beautiful music makesMurderous sadness and heartacheFall asleep when they hear it or die.

og: How now!
t: Hello!

og: An't please your grace, the two great cardinalsWait in the presence.
t: Your grace, the two important cardinals are waiting in your reception room.

og: Would they speak with me?
t: Do they want to speak to me?

og: They will'd me say so, madam.
t: They asked me to say they do, madam.

og: Pray their gracesTo come near.
t: Ask them to come near.

og: What can be their business  With me, a poor weak woman, fall'n from favour?  I do not like their coming.
t: What can their business be with me, a poor weak woman out of favor with the king? I don't like them coming here.

og: Now I think on't,  They should be good men; their affairs as righteous:  But all hoods make not monks.
t: Now I think about it, they should be good men and their business should be good, too, but appearances are deceiving and just wearing a monk's habit doesn't make you holy.

og: Peace to your highness!
t: Hello, your highness!

og: Your graces find me here part of a housewife,I would be all, against the worst may happen.What are your pleasures with me, reverend lords?
t: You can see that I'm a part of a housewife. I want to be a whole one, whatever happens. What do you want from me, wise lords?

og: May it please you noble madam, to withdrawInto your private chamber, we shall give youThe full cause of our coming.
t: Please, ma'am, if we can go into your private room, we will tell you the whole reason we came.

og: Speak it here:  There's nothing I have done yet, o' my conscience,  Deserves a corner: would all other women  Could speak this with as free a soul as I do!
t: Say it here. I haven't done anything yet that has to be whispered about in a corner. I wish all other women could say that as truly as I can!

og: My lords, I care not, so much I am happy  Above a number, if my actions  Were tried by every tongue, every eye saw 'em,  Envy and base opinion set against 'em,  I know my life so even.
t: My lords, I don't care if everyone talks about and sees my actions or if those actions are attacked by envious and disapproving people, because I'm so much luckier than most people in knowing my life is virtuous.

og: If your business  Seek me out, and that way I am wife in,  Out with it boldly: truth loves open dealing.
t: If you have business to do with me and my marriage, say it boldly. Truth should be spoken openly.

og: Tanta est erga te mentis integritas, reginaserenissima,—
t: Your conduct is so honorable, most serene queen—

og: O, good my lord, no Latin;  I am not such a truant since my coming,  As not to know the language I have lived in:
t: My good lord, don't speak Latin. I haven't been so lazy since coming here that I don't know the language of the country I have been living in.

og: A strange tongue makes my cause more strange,  suspicious;  Pray, speak in English: here are some will thank you,  If you speak truth, for their poor mistress' sake;
t: Speaking in a foreign language makes my cause seem more strange and suspicious. Please, speak English. There are some people here who will thank you for their mistress's sake if you tell the truth.

og: Believe me, she has had much wrong: lord cardinal,  The willing'st sin I ever yet committed  May be absolved in English.
t: Believe me, she has been treated very badly. Lord cardinal, even the worst sin I have ever committed can be forgiven in English.

og: Noble lady,  I am sorry my integrity should breed,  And service to his majesty and you,  So deep suspicion, where all faith was meant.
t: Noble lady, I am sorry you are so suspicious about my honesty and my service of your majesty and you, when I meant to serve you faithfully.

og: We come not by the way of accusation,  To taint that honour every good tongue blesses,  Nor to betray you any way to sorrow,  You have too much, good lady;
t: We don't come to accuse you or taint your honor, which every good person blesses, or to make you sad in any way since you are already too sad, good lady.

og: but to know  How you stand minded in the weighty difference  Between the king and you; and to deliver,  Like free and honest men, our just opinions  And comforts to your cause.
t: We just want to know your thoughts in the great quarrel between you and the king and to tell you like open and honest men should our true opinions, and comfort you.

og: Most honour'd madam,  My Lord of York, out of his noble nature,  Zeal and obedience he still bore your grace,  Forgetting, like a good man your late censure  Both of his truth and him, which was too far,
t: Honored lady, because of his noble character and the obedience he still wants to show you, my Lord of York has forgotten your recent criticism of his honesty and him, which went too far.

og: Offers, as I do, in a sign of peace,  His service and his counsel.
t: He and I offer you his service and advice as a peace offering.

og: [Aside]  To betray me.—
t: [To herself] To betray me.—

og: My lords, I thank you both for your good wills;  Ye speak like honest men; pray God, ye prove so!  But how to make ye suddenly an answer,  In such a point of weight, so near mine honour,—
t: [To the CARDINALS] My lords, I thank both of you for your kindness. You speak like honest men. I pray to God you turn out to be honest men! But I don't know how to answer you immediately about such an important matter that threatens my honor—

og: More near my life, I fear,—with my weak wit,  And to such men of gravity and learning,  In truth, I know not.
t: and my life even more, I'm afraid—since my mind is weak and you are such serious and learned men.

og: I was set at work  Among my maids: full little, God knows, looking  Either for such men or such business.  For her sake that I have been,—for I feel  The last fit of my greatness,—
t: I was sewing with my maids and didn't expect such men or such business, God knows.

og: good your graces,  Let me have time and counsel for my cause:  Alas, I am a woman, friendless, hopeless!
t: Your graces, for the sake of the woman I have been—because I feel my power dying—let me have time and a lawyer on my side. I am a friendless and hopeless woman!

og: Madam, you wrong the king's love with these fears:Your hopes and friends are infinite.
t: Ma'am, you're being unfair to the king's love with this fear. You have infinite hopes and friends.

og: In England  But little for my profit: can you think, lords,  That any Englishman dare give me counsel?
t: The ones in England won't help me. Can you imagine any Englishman daring to give me advice, my lords?

og: Or be a known friend, 'gainst his highness' pleasure,  Though he be grown so desperate to be honest,  And live a subject?
t: Or be known to be my friend and side with me against the king, even if he is desperate to do the right thing, and continue living here as a subject?

og: Nay, forsooth, my friends,  They that must weigh out my afflictions,  They that my trust must grow to, live not here:
t: No, the friends who will understand my suffering and whom I have to trust don't live here.

og: They are, as all my other comforts, far hence  In mine own country, lords.
t: They are, like all my other comforts, far away from here, in my own country, lords.

og: I would your graceWould leave your griefs, and take my counsel.
t: I wish you would stop being sad and take my advice.

og: How, sir?
t: How, sir?

og: Put your main cause into the king's protection;  He's loving and most gracious: 'twill be much  Both for your honour better and your cause;
t: Let the king take care of this business for you. He's loving and very generous. It will be much better both for your honor and your case.

og: For if the trial of the law o'ertake ye,  You'll part away disgraced.
t: Because if you go to trial over this, you'll go away disgraced.

og: He tells you rightly.
t: He's telling you the truth.

og: Ye tell me what ye wish for both,—my ruin:  Is this your Christian counsel? out upon ye!
t: You tell me to do what will get you what you both want—for me to be destroyed. Is this your Christian advice? Get out!

og: Heaven is above all yet; there sits a judge  That no king can corrupt.
t: God is still in charge. He is a judge no king can corrupt.

og: Your rage mistakes us.
t: Your anger makes you misjudge us.

og: The more shame for ye: holy men I thought ye,  Upon my soul, two reverend cardinal virtues;  But cardinal sins and hollow hearts I fear ye:  Mend 'em, for shame, my lords. Is this your comfort?
t: You should be all the more ashamed. I thought you were holy men, I swear, as if you were two wise virtues instead of men. But I fear that you two cardinals are actually deadly sins and have cruel hearts. Fix your hearts, my lords. You should be ashamed. Is this how you're trying to comfort me?

og: The cordial that ye bring a wretched lady,  A woman lost among ye, laugh'd at, scorn'd?  I will not wish ye half my miseries;
t: Is this the help you bring to a poor lady lost in this country, laughed at, and hated? I won't wish that you suffer half of what I suffer.

og: I have more charity: but say, I warn'd ye;  Take heed, for heaven's sake, take heed, lest at once  The burthen of my sorrows fall upon ye.
t: I am too kind for that. But I have warned you. Be careful, for heaven's sake be careful, or all of my suffering will fall on you at once.

og: Madam, this is a mere distraction;You turn the good we offer into envy.
t: Ma'am, you're talking nonsense. You're turning our good intentions towards you into bad ones.

og: Ye turn me into nothing: woe upon ye  And all such false professors! would you have me—  If you have any justice, any pity;  If ye be any thing but churchmen's habits—  Put my sick cause into his hands that hates me?
t: You're turning me, a queen, into nothing. Damn you and all lying tricksters! If you have any justice or pity or are anything more than the clothes of churchmen, do you want me to put my cause into the hands of someone who hates me?

og: Alas, has banish'd me his bed already,  His love, too long ago! I am old, my lords,  And all the fellowship I hold now with him  Is only my obedience.
t: He already banished me from his bed and his love all too long ago! I am old, my lords, and the only bond I have to him is my obedience.

og: What can happen  To me above this wretchedness? all your studies  Make me a curse like this.
t: What more can happen to me that is worse than this suffering? You're scheming to make me suffer like this.

og: Your fears are worse.
t: Your fears are worse than the reality.

og: Have I lived thus long—let me speak myself,  Since virtue finds no friends—a wife, a true one?  A woman, I dare say without vain-glory,  Never yet branded with suspicion?
t: Haven't I lived this long—let me speak for myself, since a virtuous person can't find any friends to speak for her—as a wife, and an honest one? As a woman, I can say without bragging, who has never been suspected of anything?

og: Have I with all my full affections  Still met the king? loved him next heaven?  obey'd him?
t: Haven't I always loved the king completely, second only to God? And obeyed him?

og: Been, out of fondness, superstitious to him?  Almost forgot my prayers to content him?  And am I thus rewarded? 'tis not well, lords.
t: Haven't I been so fond of him he almost became my god and I almost forgot to pray because I was focusing on making him happy? And am I rewarded with this? This is not good, lords.

og: Bring me a constant woman to her husband,  One that ne'er dream'd a joy beyond his pleasure;  And to that woman, when she has done most,  Yet will I add an honour, a great patience.
t: Bring me a woman true to her husband, one whose only joy was to make him happy, and compared to that woman who has done everything she could, I have one more quality, which is that I have had enormous patience.

og: Madam, you wander from the good we aim at.
t: Ma'am, you're getting distracted from the good things we're offering you.

og: My lord, I dare not make myself so guilty,  To give up willingly that noble title  Your master wed me to:
t: My lord, I wouldn't dare to commit the sin of willingly giving up the noble title I gained when your master married me.

og: nothing but death  Shall e'er divorce my dignities.
t: Nothing but death will ever divorce me from my dignity and power.

og: Pray, hear me.
t: Please listen to me.

og: Would I had never trod this English earth,  Or felt the flatteries that grow upon it!
t: I wish I had never set foot on this English land or been flattered by the people in it!

og: Ye have angels' faces, but heaven knows your hearts.  What will become of me now, wretched lady!  I am the most unhappy woman living.
t: You have angels' faces, but heaven knows what you're really like. What will become of poor me? I am the unhappiest woman alive.

og: Alas, poor wenches, where are now your fortunes!  Shipwreck'd upon a kingdom, where no pity,  No friend, no hope; no kindred weep for me;
t: [To her attendants] Poor girls, where are your fortunes now? You're shipwrecked in this country where there's no pity, no friend to us, and no hope. No family members cry for me.

og: Almost no grave allow'd me: like the lily,  That once was mistress of the field and flourish'd,  I'll hang my head and perish.
t: There's barely a grave allowed for me. Like a lily that once flourished as the queen of a field, I'll hang my head and die.

og: If your grace  Could but be brought to know our ends are honest,  You'ld feel more comfort: why should we, good lady,  Upon what cause, wrong you? alas, our places,  The way of our profession is against it:
t: If you could just be convinced that we mean well you wouldn't feel as bad. Why would we treat you badly, good lady? Our positions and our profession prevent that.

og: We are to cure such sorrows, not to sow 'em.  For goodness' sake, consider what you do;  How you may hurt yourself, ay, utterly  Grow from the king's acquaintance, by this carriage.
t: We're supposed to cure suffering like this, not cause it. For goodness' sake, think about what you're doing. You could hurt yourself, in fact you could cause the king to cut himself off from you completely, if you keep acting this way.

og: The hearts of princes kiss obedience,  So much they love it; but to stubborn spirits  They swell, and grow as terrible as storms.
t: Kings love obedience so much they kiss obedient people, but they grow as violent as storms towards stubborn ones.

og: I know you have a gentle, noble temper,  A soul as even as a calm: pray, think us  Those we profess, peace-makers, friends, and servants.
t: I know you have a gentle, noble personality and a calm, reasonable mind. Please, consider us to be what we claim to be: peace-makers, your friends, and your servants.

og: Madam, you'll find it so. You wrong your virtues  With these weak women's fears: a noble spirit,  As yours was put into you, ever casts  Such doubts, as false coin, from it.
t: Ma'am, you'll find that we are those things. You're betraying your virtues by being afraid like a weak woman. A noble mind like the one you have throws out suspicions like this as if they were fake coins.

og: The king loves you;  Beware you lose it not: for us, if you please  To trust us in your business, we are ready  To use our utmost studies in your service.
t: The king loves you. Be careful not to lose his love. As for us, if you will trust us with your business, we are ready to work as hard as we can to help you.

og: Do what ye will, my lords: and, pray, forgive me,  If I have used myself unmannerly;  You know I am a woman, lacking wit  To make a seemly answer to such persons.
t: Do what you want, my lords. Please forgive me if I have been rude. You know I am a woman and don't have the brains to answer such people as you politely.

og: Pray, do my service to his majesty:  He has my heart yet; and shall have my prayers  While I shall have my life. Come, reverend fathers,  Bestow your counsels on me:
t: Please, send my best to the king. I still love him and will pray for him for the rest of my life. Come, wise priests, give me your advice.

og: she now begs,  That little thought, when she set footing here,  She should have bought her dignities so dear.
t: Now I'm begging. When I set foot in this country, I didn't know I would pay such a price for the honors done to me.

og: If you will now unite in your complaints,  And force them with a constancy, the cardinal  Cannot stand under them:
t: If you all make your complaints together and stick to them, the cardinal can't resist them.

og: if you omit  The offer of this time, I cannot promise  But that you shall sustain moe new disgraces,  With these you bear already.
t: If you fail to take this opportunity, I can't promise you'll be safe from suffering more disgrace than you already have.

og: I am joyful  To meet the least occasion that may give me  Remembrance
t: I am happy to have the smallest opportunity to be reminded

og: of my father-in-law, the duke,  To be revenged on him.
t: to take revenge for the death of my father-in-law, the duke.

og: Which of the peers  Have uncontemn'd gone by him, or at least  Strangely neglected?
t: What noble hasn't been criticized by him, or at least ignored?

og: when did he regard  The stamp of nobleness in any person  Out of himself?
t: When did he have any consideration for a noble other than himself?

og: My lords, you speak your pleasures:  What he deserves of you and me I know;  What we can do to him, though now the time  Gives way to us, I much fear.
t: My lords, you say what you want. I know what he deserves from you and me. I am afraid we can't do anything to him, even with this opportunity.

og: If you cannot  Bar his access to the king, never attempt  Any thing on him; for he hath a witchcraft  Over the king in's tongue.
t: If you can't stop him getting to the king, don't try anything against him, because he can charm the king when he speaks.

og: O, fear him not;  His spell in that is out: the king hath found  Matter against him that for ever mars  The honey of his language.
t: Oh, don't be afraid of that. He doesn't have that power anymore. The king has found out something against him that will stop his words from ever being convincing.

og: No, he's settled,  Not to come off, in his displeasure.
t: No, the king's firm in his anger and will not let it go.

og: Sir,I should be glad to hear such news as thisOnce every hour.
t: Sir, I wish I could hear news this good every hour.

og: Believe it, this is true:  In the divorce his contrary proceedings  Are all unfolded
t: Believe me, this is true. His plots against the divorce procedures were revealed

og: wherein he appears  As I would wish mine enemy.
t: and he comes off as badly as I could wish my enemy to.

og: How cameHis practises to light?
t: How were his plots revealed?

og: Most strangely.
t: Very strangely.

og: O, how, how?
t: How? How?

og: The cardinal's letters to the pope miscarried,  And came to the eye o' the king: wherein was read,  How that the cardinal did entreat his holiness  To stay the judgment o' the divorce;
t: The cardinal's letters to the pope went astray and were seen by the king. In them the cardinal begged the Pope to put off his judgement on the divorce.

og: for if  It did take place, 'I do,' quoth he, 'perceive  My king is tangled in affection to  A creature of the queen's, Lady Anne Bullen.'
t: If it took place, he said "I see that my king's affections have been caught by the queen's servant, Lady Anne Bullen."

og: Has the king this?
t: Does the king have this letter?

og: Believe it.
t: Yes.

og: Will this work?
t: Will this work?

og: The king in this perceives him, how he coasts  And hedges his own way.
t: The king sees his true nature in this, how he changes his allegiances and works for himself.

og: But in this point  All his tricks founder, and he brings his physic  After his patient's death: the king already  Hath married the fair lady.
t: But in this case his plots have failed and he is too late to make a difference, like a doctor who brings medicine after a patient's death: the king has already married the beautiful lady.

og: Would he had!
t: I wish he had!

og: May you be happy in your wish, my lordFor, I profess, you have it.
t: I hope you're happy with your wish, my lord, because it's been granted.

og: Now, all my joyTrace the conjunction!
t: I wish them the best in their marriage!

og: My amen to't!
t: Amen!

og: All men's!
t: All men say amen!

og: There's order given for her coronation:  Marry, this is yet but young, and may be left  To some ears unrecounted.
t: Her coronation has been arranged. This is still recent and shouldn't be spoken to everyone.

og: But, my lords,  She is a gallant creature, and complete  In mind and feature: I persuade me, from her  Will fall some blessing to this land, which shall  In it be memorised.
t: But my lords, she's a good person with all the best qualities of mind and body. I'm sure she'll bless this land with something good which will go down in history.

og: But, will the kingDigest this letter of the cardinal's?The Lord forbid!
t: But will the king let the cardinal get away with his letter? God forbid!

og: Marry, amen!
t: Amen!

og: No, no;  There be moe wasps that buzz about his nose  Will make this sting the sooner. Cardinal Campeius  Is stol'n away to Rome; hath ta'en no leave;
t: No, no. There are more irritating things going on that will make him even angrier. Cardinal Campeius has run away to Rome without saying goodbye

og: Has left the cause o' the king unhandled; and  Is posted, as the agent of our cardinal,  To second all his plot. I do assure you  The king cried Ha! at this.
t: and has left the king's business unmanaged. He's been sent as the cardinal's agent to carry out his plot. I assure you the king was annoyed and cried out "Ha!" when that happened.

og: Now, God incense him,And let him cry Ha! louder!
t: May God make him angry and have him cry "Ha!" louder.

og: But, my lord,When returns Cranmer?
t: But my lord, when does Cranmer come back?

og: He is return'd in his opinions; which  Have satisfied the king for his divorce,  Together with all famous colleges  Almost in Christendom:
t: It's as if he has returned because he has sent back his arguments which convinced the king and almost all the famous academics in Christian countries that this divorce should happen.

og: shortly, I believe,  His second marriage shall be publish'd, and  Her coronation. Katharine no more  Shall be call'd queen, but princess dowager  And widow to Prince Arthur.
t: I think his second marriage will be announced soon as well as her coronation. Katharine will be called princess dowager and Prince Arthur's widow, not queen.

og: This same Cranmer'sA worthy fellow, and hath ta'en much painIn the king's business.
t: That Cranmer's a good man and has worked hard to do the king's business.

og: He has; and we shall see himFor it an archbishop.
t: He has, and he'll be made an archbishop for it.

og: So I hear.
t: So I hear.

og: 'Tis so.The cardinal!
t: It's true. The cardinal!

og: Observe, observe, he's moody.
t: Watch, watch, he's upset.

og: The packet, Cromwell.Gave't you the king?
t: The letters, Cromwell. Did you give them to the king?

og: To his own hand, in's bedchamber.
t: I handed them to him myself, in his bedroom.

og: Look'd he o' the inside of the paper?
t: Did he look inside?

og: Presently  He did unseal them: and the first he view'd,  He did it with a serious mind; a heed  Was in his countenance.
t: He opened them immediately. He looked at the first seriously and you could tell he was paying attention.

og: You he bade  Attend him here this morning.
t: He asked you to come see him here this morning.

og: Is he readyTo come abroad?
t: Is he ready to come here?

og: I think, by this he is.
t: I think by this time he is.

og: Leave me awhile.
t: Leave me here for a while.

og: He's discontented.
t: He's unhappy.

og: May be, he hears the kingDoes whet his anger to him.
t: Maybe he's heard that the king is angry at him.

og: Sharp enough,Lord, for thy justice!
t: I hope he's angry enough to punish him properly!

og: [Aside]  The late queen's gentlewoman,  a knight's daughter,  To be her mistress' mistress! the queen's queen!  This candle burns not clear:
t: [To himself] The last queen's lady in waiting, a knight's daughter, becoming her mistress's mistress! The queen's queen! This is like a candle that's not burning properly.

og: 'tis I must snuff it;  Then out it goes. What though I know her virtuous  And well deserving?
t: I'll have to be the one to put it out. So out it goes. So what if I know she's virtuous and deserving?

og: yet I know her for  A spleeny Lutheran; and not wholesome to  Our cause, that she should lie i' the bosom of  Our hard-ruled king.
t: I still know she's an irritable Lutheran and it would not be good for me if she were at the side of the king, who's already difficult to order around.

og: Again, there is sprung up  An heretic, an arch one, Cranmer; one  Hath crawl'd into the favour of the king,  And is his oracle.
t: Again, a heretic has sprung up, a terrible one, Cranmer. He's crawled into the king's favor and is telling his fortune for him.

og: He is vex'd at something.
t: He's annoyed at something.

og: I would 'twere something that would fret the string,The master-cord on's heart!
t: I wish it were something bad enough to break his heart!

og: The king, the king!
t: The king, the king!

og: What piles of wealth hath he accumulated  To his own portion! and what expense by the hour  Seems to flow from him!
t: He's piled up so much wealth for himself! And he seems to spend so much money every hour!

og: How, i' the name of thrift,  Does he rake this together! Now, my lords,  Saw you the cardinal?
t: How on earth does he collect all this wealth, in the name of economy? My lords, have you seen the cardinal?

og: My lord, we have  Stood here observing him: some strange commotion  Is in his brain: he bites his lip, and starts;  Stops on a sudden, looks upon the ground,
t: My lord, we have been standing here watching him. There's something upsetting him. He bites his lips and jumps, stops suddenly, looks at the ground,

og: Then lays his finger on his temple, straight  Springs out into fast gait; then stops again,  Strikes his breast hard, and anon he casts  His eye against the moon: in most strange postures  We have seen him set himself.
t: then puts his finger to his forehead and starts walking quickly. Then he stops again, hits his chest hard, and looks up at the moon. We have seen him put himself into very strange positions.

og: It may well be;  There is a mutiny in's mind. This morning  Papers of state he sent me to peruse,  As I required: and wot you what I found  There,—on my conscience, put unwittingly?
t: It may well be. His mind is rebelling. This morning he sent me state documents to look at, as I asked. And do you know what I found there—left there accidentally, I bet?

og: Forsooth, an inventory, thus importing;  The several parcels of his plate, his treasure,  Rich stuffs, and ornaments of household; which  I find at such proud rate, that it out-speaks  Possession of a subject.
t: An inventory that went like this: a list of his silver plates, his treasure, rich fabrics, and household ornaments. They're so expensive that no subject can possess such wealth.

og: It's heaven's will:Some spirit put this paper in the packet,To bless your eye withal.
t: It's God's will. Some angel put this paper among the others so you would see it.

og: If we did think  His contemplation were above the earth,  And fix'd on spiritual object, he should still  Dwell in his musings:
t: If I thought he were thinking about something above the earth, contemplating something holy, I would let him think.

og: but I am afraid  His thinkings are below the moon, not worth  His serious considering.
t: But I am afraid he's thinking about earthly things that aren't worth serious consideration.

og: Heaven forgive me!Ever God bless your highness!
t: Heaven forgive me! May God bless you forever, your highness!

og: Good my lord,  You are full of heavenly stuff, and bear the inventory  Of your best graces in your mind; the which  You were now running o'er:
t: My lord, you're full of heavenly treasure and carry the inventory of your best qualities in your mind. You were reading that over just now.

og: you have scarce time  To steal from spiritual leisure a brief span  To keep your earthly audit:
t: You barely have time to steal a short break from your spiritual thoughts to take care of earthly business.

og: sure, in that  I deem you an ill husband, and am glad  To have you therein my companion.
t: I think you're bad at managing your affairs but I'm glad you're my companion.

og: Sir,  For holy offices I have a time; a time  To think upon the part of business which  I bear i' the state;
t: Sir, I have a time for holy ceremonies, a time to think about the state business I do,

og: and nature does require  Her times of preservation, which perforce  I, her frail son, amongst my brethren mortal,  Must give my tendence to.
t: and nature requires me, her weak son, to take some time to take care of my body in the same way she requires that of all my fellow men.

og: You have said well.
t: You have spoken well.

og: And ever may your highness yoke together,As I will lend you cause, my doing wellWith my well saying!
t: I will give you good reason, your highness, for always associating my speaking well with my acting well!

og: 'Tis well said again;  And 'tis a kind of good deed to say well:  And yet words are no deeds. My father loved you:
t: That's well said again. And it's a kind of good action to speak well, but words aren't actions. My father loved you.

og: He said he did; and with his deed did crown  His word upon you. Since I had my office,  I have kept you next my heart;
t: He said he did. And by his action of giving you a cardinal's crown, he showed that he spoke the truth. Since I inherited the throne I have confided in you.

og: have not alone  Employ'd you where high profits might come home,  But pared my present havings, to bestow  My bounties upon you.
