t: I have not just employed you in important business that would be profitable, but parted with some of my own money to give you gifts.

og: What should this mean?
t: What does this mean?

og: The Lord increase this business!
t: May God bless this!

og: Have I not made you,  The prime man of the state? I pray you, tell me,  If what I now pronounce you have found true:
t: Haven't I made you the most important man in the country? Please, tell me if you think what I say now isn't true.

og: And, if you may confess it, say withal,  If you are bound to us or no. What say you?
t: And if you can confess it, tell me whether you owe me or not. What do you say?

og: My sovereign, I confess your royal graces,  Shower'd on me daily, have been more than could  My studied purposes requite; which went  Beyond all man's endeavours:
t: My king, I confess the royal gifts you gave me every day have been more than I could ever pay back, although I tried harder than anyone.

og: my endeavours  Have ever come too short of my desires,  Yet filed with my abilities: mine own ends  Have been mine so that evermore they pointed  To the good of your most sacred person and  The profit of the state.
t: I have done everything I could to pay you back, but less than I wish I could. I have wanted everything I wanted only for your good and the good of the country.

og: For your great graces  Heap'd upon me, poor undeserver, I  Can nothing render but allegiant thanks,  My prayers to heaven for you, my loyalty,
t: I can only give you loyal thanks, my prayers for you, and my loyalty

og: Which ever has and ever shall be growing,  Till death, that winter, kill it.
t: which is always growing and always will until death kills it like winter kills plants, in return for the great gifts you've heaped on me, which I don't deserve.

og: Fairly answer'd;  A loyal and obedient subject is  Therein illustrated: the honour of it  Does pay the act of it;
t: Well answered. You've showed how a loyal and obedient subject would answer. The honor of the response repays the effort that went into it

og: as, i' the contrary,  The foulness is the punishment. I presume  That, as my hand has open'd bounty to you,  My heart dropp'd love, my power rain'd honour, more  On you than any;
t: just as evil is its own punishment. I presume that because I have given you more gifts, loved you more, and given you more power and honor than anyone else,

og: so your hand and heart,  Your brain, and every function of your power,  Should, notwithstanding that your bond of duty,  As 'twere in love's particular, be more  To me, your friend, than any.
t: your hand, heart, brain, and all your actions should be more loyal to me than anyone else's. Not because it is your duty, but because you love me.

og: I do profess  That for your highness' good I ever labour'd  More than mine own; that am, have, and will be—
t: I swear that I have always worked for your good, your highness, more than my own.

og: Though all the world should crack their duty to you,  And throw it from their soul; though perils did  Abound, as thick as thought could make 'em, and  Appear in forms more horrid,—
t: That will be true even if the whole world abandons their duty to you completely or if as many dangers surround us as it's possible to imagine, and more horrible than one could imagine.

og: yet my duty,  As doth a rock against the chiding flood,  Should the approach of this wild river break,  And stand unshaken yours.
t: Still my obedience, like a rock standing against a pushing river, would stand in the way of this wild river of dangers and remain firmly obedient to you.

og: 'Tis nobly spoken:Take notice, lords, he has a loyal breast,For you have seen him open't. Read o'er this;
t: That's nobly spoken. Notice, lords, he has a loyal heart. You've heard him show it. Read this.

og: And after, this: and then to breakfast withWhat appetite you have.
t: And read this afterwards. Then go to breakfast with whatever appetite you have left.

og: What should this mean?  What sudden anger's this? how have I reap'd it?  He parted frowning from me, as if ruin  Leap'd from his eyes:
t: What does this mean? Why is he suddenly angry? How have I deserved it? He left me frowning as if he wanted to destroy me with his eyes.

og: so looks the chafed lion  Upon the daring huntsman that has gall'd him;  Then makes him nothing. I must read this paper;  I fear, the story of his anger. 'Tis so;
t: An angry lion looks like that at a bold hunter that stabbed him. Then he kills him. I must read this paper. I'm afraid it will tell me why he's angry. It does.

og: This paper has undone me: 'tis the account  Of all that world of wealth I have drawn together  For mine own ends; indeed, to gain the popedom,  And fee my friends in Rome. O negligence!
t: This paper has ruined me. It's the list of all the huge wealth I have piled up for my plots, to become Pope and pay my friends in Rome. What carelessness!

og: Fit for a fool to fall by: what cross devil  Made me put this main secret in the packet  I sent the king? Is there no way to cure this?  No new device to beat this from his brains?
t: I'm a fool who deserves to be destroyed by this. What damned devil made me put the most important secret I have in the package I sent to the king? Is there no cure to this? No new plot to  make him forget it?

og: I know 'twill stir him strongly; yet I know  A way, if it take right, in spite of fortune  Will bring me off again. What's this? 'To the Pope!'  The letter, as I live, with all the business  I writ to's holiness. Nay then, farewell!
t: I know he'll be angry, but I know a way—if it works—to get out of this. What's this? It says "To the Pope!" I swear, it's the letter I wrote to the Pope about all this business. No, then it's over!

og: I have touch'd the highest point of all my greatness;  And, from that full meridian of my glory,  I haste now to my setting: I shall fall  Like a bright exhalation in the evening,  And no man see me more.
t: I have reached the highest point of my power and will now quickly descend from that glorious point. I will fall like a bright star in the evening and will not be seen again.

og: Hear the king's pleasure, cardinal: who commands you  To render up the great seal presently  Into our hands;
t: Listen to what the king says, cardinal. He commands you to give us the great seal at once

og: and to confine yourself  To Asher House, my Lord of Winchester's,  Till you hear further from his highness.
t: and to shut yourself in Asher House, the Lord of Winchester's house, until you hear more from him.

og: Stay:Where's your commission, lords? words cannot carryAuthority so weighty.
t: Wait: where's your warrant, lords? You don't have the authority to tell me to do something like this.

og: Who dare cross 'em,Bearing the king's will from his mouth expressly?
t: Who would dare to disobey us, since we're telling you what the king wants straight from his mouth?

og: Till I find more than will or words to do it,  I mean your malice, know, officious lords,  I dare and must deny it. Now I feel  Of what coarse metal ye are moulded, envy:
t: Until I find more reason than words or wants, by which I mean your ill will to me, busybody lords, I dare and must refuse to obey. Now I see what rough stuff you're made of: envy.

og: How eagerly ye follow my disgraces,  As if it fed ye! and how sleek and wanton  Ye appear in every thing may bring my ruin!  Follow your envious courses, men of malice;
t: You're as eager about my disgrace as if it were food for you! You are so delighted and quick to do anything that can ruin me! Go on and do your envious deeds, evil men.

og: You have Christian warrant for 'em, and, no doubt,  In time will find their fit rewards. That seal,  You ask with such a violence, the king,  Mine and your master, with his own hand gave me;
t: You have a right to do them and no doubt you'll be punished for them someday. That seal you ask me for so violently was handed to me personally by the king, who is your master and mine.

og: Bade me enjoy it, with the place and honours,  During my life; and, to confirm his goodness,  Tied it by letters-patents: now, who'll take it?
t: He told me to enjoy it as long as I live, along with the position and honors that went with it. To confirm this good deed, he wrote up official documents. Now, who still wants to take it away?

og: The king, that gave it.
t: The king, who gave it to you.

og: It must be himself, then.
t: He'll have to do it himself, then.

og: Thou art a proud traitor, priest.
t: You're an arrogant traitor, priest.

og: Proud lord, thou liest:Within these forty hours Surrey durst betterHave burnt that tongue than said so.
t: Arrogant lord, you're lying. Within forty hours you'll wish you'd burned your tongue rather than say that.

og: Thy ambition,  Thou scarlet sin, robb'd this bewailing land  Of noble Buckingham, my father-in-law:
t: Your ambition, your horrible sin, robbed this sad land of noble Buckingham, my father-in-law.

og: The heads of all thy brother cardinals,  With thee and all thy best parts bound together,  Weigh'd not a hair of his. Plague of your policy!
t: The heads of all your cardinal friends along with you and all your best possessions all bound together aren't worth a hair on his head. Damn your plots!

og: You sent me deputy for Ireland;  Far from his succor, from the king, from all  That might have mercy on the fault thou gavest him;
t: You sent me as a representative to Ireland. I was too far away to help him, far from the king and from everyone who might have mercy on him for what you accused him of.

og: Whilst your great goodness, out of holy pity,  Absolved him with an axe.
t: In your great goodness, out of holy pity, you forgave him—with an axe.

og: This, and all else  This talking lord can lay upon my credit,  I answer is most false. The duke by law  Found his deserts:
t: I answer that this and everything else this babbling lord says I did is false. The duke was punished by the law.

og: how innocent I was  From any private malice in his end,  His noble jury and foul cause can witness.
t: How innocent I was of having a secret grudge against him is obvious if you look at the noble jury that judged him and his terrible crime.

og: If I loved many words, lord, I should tell you  You have as little honesty as honour,  That in the way of loyalty and truth  Toward the king, my ever royal master,
t: If I loved to talk, lord, I would tell you that you have as little honesty as honor and that in my loyalty and honest to the king, my always-royal master,

og: Dare mate a sounder man than Surrey can be,  And all that love his follies.
t: I'm a better man than Surrey and everyone who loves his foolishness can be.

og: By my soul,  Your long coat, priest, protects you; thou  shouldst feel  My sword i' the life-blood of thee else.
t: I swear by my soul that your cardinal's robe protects you, priest. Otherwise you would feel my sword kill you now.

og: My lords,  Can ye endure to hear this arrogance?  And from this fellow? if we live thus tamely,  To be thus jaded by a piece of scarlet,  Farewell nobility;
t: My lords, can you bear to hear this arrogance? From this fellow? If we can stand here meekly being insulted like this by a churchman, our nobility is gone.

og: let his grace go forward,  And dare us with his cap like larks.
t: Let him go on and wave his hat at us as if we were birds he was trying to catch.

og: All goodnessIs poison to thy stomach.
t: All goodness is poison to you.

og: Yes, that goodness  Of gleaning all the land's wealth into one,  Into your own hands, cardinal, by extortion;
t: Yes, the goodness of taking all the country's wealth for yourself, cardinal, by force.

og: The goodness of your intercepted packets  You writ to the pope against the king: your goodness,  Since you provoke me, shall be most notorious.
t: The goodness of those letters you wrote to the Pope against the king. Since you're provoking me, everyone will find out about your "goodness."

og: My Lord of Norfolk, as you are truly noble,  As you respect the common good, the state  Of our despised nobility, our issues,  Who, if he live, will scarce be gentlemen,
t: My Lord of Norfolk, if you're really noble and love the common good and our insulted nobility and our children who will barely be gentleman, let alone noblemen, if he stays alive,

og: Produce the grand sum of his sins, the articles  Collected from his life. I'll startle you  Worse than the scaring bell, when the brown wench  Lay kissing in your arms, lord cardinal.
t: bring out the list of his sins, the observations about his life. I'll startle you worse than a bell ringing when you're holding and kissing the brown girl, lord cardinal.

og: How much, methinks, I could despise this man,But that I am bound in charity against it!
t: I could hate this man so much, I think, if it weren't wrong to hate anyone!

og: Those articles, my lord, are in the king's hand:But, thus much, they are foul ones.
t: The king has that list, my lord. But I'll say this much, his sins are terrible.

og: So much fairerAnd spotless shall mine innocence arise,When the king knows my truth.
t: My innocence then will seem so much more beautiful and guiltless when the king finds out how honest I am.

og: This cannot save you:  I thank my memory, I yet remember  Some of these articles; and out they shall.
t: This can't save you. I remember some of the things on the list and I'll say what they are.

og: Now, if you can blush and cry 'guilty,' cardinal,  You'll show a little honesty.
t: Now, if you can blush and say you're guilty, cardinal, you'll seem a little honest.

og: Speak on, sir;I dare your worst objections: if I blush,It is to see a nobleman want manners.
t: Go on and speak, sir. I can face your worst accusations. If I blush it's because I see a nobleman with no manners.

og: I had rather want those than my head. Have at you!  First, that, without the king's assent or knowledge,
t: I'd rather be without manners than without a head. Take this! First, without the king's agreement or knowledge,

og: You wrought to be a legate; by which power  You maim'd the jurisdiction of all bishops.
t: you made yourself an ambassador to the Pope. By doing this you stole power from all bishops.

og: Then, that in all you writ to Rome, or else  To foreign princes, 'Ego et Rex meus'  Was still inscribed;
t: Then, that in all the letters you wrote to Rome or to foreign prince, "I and my king" was always written.

og: in which you brought the king  To be your servant.
t: So you represented the king as your servant.

og: Then that, without the knowledge  Either of king or council,
t: Then, without the king's or council's knowledge,

og: when you went  Ambassador to the emperor, you made bold  To carry into Flanders the great seal.
t: when you went to the emperor as an ambassador you dared to carry the great seal into Flanders.

og: Item, you sent a large commission  To Gregory de Cassado, to conclude,
t: Then, you sent a large amount of money to Gregory to Cassado

og: Without the king's will or the state's allowance,  A league between his highness and Ferrara.
t: to make an alliance between the king and Ferrara without the king's or country's agreement.

og: That, out of mere ambition, you have causedYour holy hat to be stamp'd on the king's coin.
t: Then, out of simple ambition, you had your cardinal's hat stamped on coins.

og: Then that you have sent innumerable substance—  By what means got, I leave to your own conscience—  To furnish Rome, and to prepare the ways  You have for dignities;
t: Then, that you sent countless wealth—how you got it is between you and your conscience—to Rome for their use and to pay for honors for yourself,

og: to the mere undoing  Of all the kingdom. Many more there are;  Which, since they are of you, and odious,  I will not taint my mouth with.
t: which was bad for the kingdom. There are many more items on the list which, since they are about you and disgusting, I will not contaminate my mouth with.

og: O my lord,  Press not a falling man too far! 'tis virtue:  His faults lie open to the laws;
t: My lord, don't kick a man when he's down! It's not virtuous. His faults will be judged by the laws.

og: let them,  Not you, correct him. My heart weeps to see him  So little of his great self.
t: Let them punish him instead of doing it yourself. My heart weeps to see him diminished like this.

og: I forgive him.
t: I forgive him.

og: Lord cardinal, the king's further pleasure is,  Because all those things you have done of late,  By your power legatine, within this kingdom,  Fall into the compass of a praemunire,
t: Lord cardinal, because the things you've done lately with your power as a papal deputy in this kingdom fall under the crime of praemunire,

og: That therefore such a writ be sued against you;  To forfeit all your goods, lands, tenements,  Chattels, and whatsoever, and to be  Out of the king's protection. This is my charge.
t: the king also wants to sue you for all your goods, lands, holdings, moveable property, and anything else, and to throw you out of his protection. I was told to tell you this.

og: And so we'll leave you to your meditations  How to live better. For your stubborn answer  About the giving back the great seal to us,
t: So we'll leave you to your thoughts about how to live better. As for your stubborn answer about giving the great seal back to us,

og: The king shall know it, and, no doubt, shall thank you.  So fare you well, my little good lord cardinal.
t: the king will know it and no doubt will thank you. So goodbye, not good lord cardinal.

og: So farewell to the little good you bear me.  Farewell! a long farewell, to all my greatness!  This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth  The tender leaves of hopes;
t: So goodbye to your feelings about me, which are not good. Goodbye! Goodbye to all my power! This is what it is to be human. One day a man is full of hope, like a plant producing its first tender leaves.

og: to-morrow blossoms,  And bears his blushing honours thick upon him;  The third day comes a frost, a killing frost,
t: The next day he blossoms and is covered with honor. On the third day a frost, a murderous frost, comes

og: And, when he thinks, good easy man, full surely  His greatness is a-ripening, nips his root,  And then he falls, as I do.
t: and when the confident man thinks that his greatness is certainly ripening, the frost kills his root and he falls, like I do.

og: I have ventured,  Like little wanton boys that swim on bladders,  This many summers in a sea of glory,  But far beyond my depth: my high-blown pride  At length broke under me and now has left me,
t: Like little boys swimming on inflatable toys, I have dared to swim for many summers in a sea of glory, far beyond my depth. My blown-up pride finally broke under me and now has left me,

og: Weary and old with service, to the mercy  Of a rude stream, that must for ever hide me.  Vain pomp and glory of this world, I hate ye:
t: tired by public service and old, to the mercy of a rough stream that will drown me. I hate you, pointless ceremony and worldly glory.

og: I feel my heart new open'd. O, how wretched  Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favours!
t: My heart feels newly opened. How miserable a poor man is who depends on the favors of kings!

og: There is, betwixt that smile we would aspire to,  That sweet aspect of princes, and their ruin,  More pangs and fears than wars or women have:  And when he falls, he falls like Lucifer,  Never to hope again.
t: More suffering and fear than you get from wars or women lies between the smile we wish for, I mean a kind expression on a king's face, and destruction. And when a man like that falls, he falls like Lucifer, with no hope left.

og: Why, how now, Cromwell!
t: Well hello, Cromwell!

og: I have no power to speak, sir.
t: I don't know what to say, sir.

og: What, amazed  At my misfortunes?
t: What, are you amazed at my bad luck?

og: can thy spirit wonder  A great man should decline? Nay, an you weep,  I am fall'n indeed.
t: Are you surprised a great man can fall? Well, if you're crying I must really have fallen.

og: How does your grace?
t: How are you?

og: Why, well;  Never so truly happy, my good Cromwell.  I know myself now; and I feel within me  A peace above all earthly dignities,  A still and quiet conscience.
t: Well, actually. I've never been so truly happy, my dear Cromwell. Now I know myself and I feel inside me a peace greater than all earthly honors, a calm and satisfied conscience.

og: The king has cured me,  I humbly thank his grace; and from these shoulders,  These ruin'd pillars, out of pity, taken  A load would sink a navy, too much honour:
t: The king has cured me and I thank him. Out of pity, he's taken a weight off these shoulders, these broken pillars, that would sink a navy: too much honor.

og: O, 'tis a burthen, Cromwell, 'tis a burthen  Too heavy for a man that hopes for heaven!
t: Oh, it's a burden, Cromwell, it's a burden too heavy for a man who hopes to go to heaven.

og: I am glad your grace has made that right use of it.
t: I am glad you've made good use of it, your grace.

og: I hope I have: I am able now, methinks,  Out of a fortitude of soul I feel,
t: I hope I have. I think I am able now, because of how strong my soul feels,

og: To endure more miseries and greater far  Than my weak-hearted enemies dare offer.  What news abroad?
t: to bear more and greater suffering by far than my cowardly enemies dare cause me. What news is there?

og: The heaviest and the worstIs your displeasure with the king.
t: The saddest and worst is the king's anger at you.

og: God bless him!
t: God bless him!

og: The next is, that Sir Thomas More is chosenLord chancellor in your place.
t: The next is that Sir Thomas More has been chosen as lord chancellor to replace you.

og: That's somewhat sudden:  But he's a learned man. May he continue  Long in his highness' favour, and do justice  For truth's sake and his conscience;
t: That's very sudden, but he's a learned man. I hope he stays in the king's favor for a long time and does his job well for the sake of truth and his conscience.

og: that his bones,  When he has run his course and sleeps in blessings,  May have a tomb of orphans' tears wept on em! What more?
t: And I hope that when he has died and gone to heaven, orphans will cry over his body because he has been so kind to them! What else?

og: That Cranmer is return'd with welcome,Install'd lord archbishop of Canterbury.
t: Cranmer has returned and his welcome is that he has been made archbishop of Canterbury.

og: That's news indeed.
t: Well, that's news.

og: Last, that the Lady Anne,  Whom the king hath in secrecy long married,  This day was view'd in open as his queen,
t: Finally, the Lady Anne, whom the king married secretly long ago, was today openly presented as his queen

og: Going to chapel; and the voice is now  Only about her coronation.
t: when they went to church together. Now the only thing anyone talks about is her coronation.

og: There was the weight that pull'd me down. O Cromwell,  The king has gone beyond me: all my glories  In that one woman I have lost for ever:
t: That was what destroyed me. Oh, Cromwell, the king has moved on from me. I lost all my glories because of that one woman.

og: No sun shall ever usher forth mine honours,  Or gild again the noble troops that waited  Upon my smiles. Go, get thee from me, Cromwell;
t: No sun will rise on a day that brings me honor or shine on the noble crowds that depended on me. Go, get away from me, Cromwell.

og: I am a poor fall'n man, unworthy now  To be thy lord and master: seek the king;  That sun, I pray, may never set! I have told him  What and how true thou art:
t: I'm a poor, ruined man, unworthy to be your lord and master. Go to the king, may he be powerful forever! I have told him about your qualities and how honest you are.

og: he will advance thee;  Some little memory of me will stir him—  I know his noble nature—not to let  Thy hopeful service perish too:
t: He will promote you. Some small memory of me will keep him from letting you suffer for doing your duty—I know his noble character.

og: good Cromwell,  Neglect him not; make use now, and provide  For thine own future safety.
t: Good Cromwell, be good to him. Go on, take care of yourself and consider your own safety.

og: O my lord,  Must I, then, leave you? must I needs forego  So good, so noble and so true a master?
t: My lord, do I have to leave you? Do I have to abandon such a good, noble, and honest master?

og: Bear witness, all that have not hearts of iron,  With what a sorrow Cromwell leaves his lord.  The king shall have my service: but my prayers  For ever and for ever shall be yours.
t: Those of you who aren't hard-hearted, bear witness to how sadly Cromwell leaves his master. I'll serve the king but I'll pray for you for ever and ever.

og: Cromwell, I did not think to shed a tear  In all my miseries; but thou hast forced me,  Out of thy honest truth, to play the woman.  Let's dry our eyes: and thus far hear me, Cromwell;
t: Cromwell, I didn't think I would cry despite all my suffering. But you've forced me to act like a woman and cry because of your honest faithfulness. Let's dry our eyes. And listen to me, Cromwell.

og: And, when I am forgotten, as I shall be,  And sleep in dull cold marble, where no mention  Of me more must be heard of, say, I taught thee,
t: When I have been forgotten, as I will be, and lie in my cold marble tomb, where no one will mention me again, say I taught you.

og: Say, Wolsey, that once trod the ways of glory,  And sounded all the depths and shoals of honour,  Found thee a way, out of his wreck, to rise in;  A sure and safe one, though thy master miss'd it.
t: Say, Wolsey, who was once powerful and explored all the depths and shallow places in the sea of honor, found you a way to rise when he was shipwrecked. A secure and safe way, even though your master couldn't take it too.

og: Mark but my fall, and that that ruin'd me.  Cromwell, I charge thee, fling away ambition:  By that sin fell the angels; how can man, then,  The image of his Maker, hope to win by it?
t: Just consider my fall and what ruined me. Cromwell, I tell you, don't be ambitious. That's the sin that made the angels fall. So, how can a man, made in the image of God, hope to get anything by it?

og: Love thyself last: cherish those hearts that hate thee;  Corruption wins not more than honesty.  Still in thy right hand carry gentle peace,  To silence envious tongues. Be just, and fear not:
t: Love yourself less than everyone else, love those who hate you. Corruption doesn't get you any more than honesty. Always be ready to impose peace, to silence critical voices. Be just and don't be afraid.

og: Let all the ends thou aim'st at be thy country's,  Thy God's, and truth's; then if thou fall'st,  O Cromwell,  Thou fall'st a blessed martyr! Serve the king;  And,—prithee, lead me in:
t: Let the only goal you work toward be the good of your country, your God, and truth. Then if you fall, Cromwell, you'll fall as a blessed saint! Serve the king and—please, take me inside.

og: There take an inventory of all I have,  To the last penny; 'tis the king's: my robe,  And my integrity to heaven, is all  I dare now call mine own. O Cromwell, Cromwell!
t: There make a list of everything I have, down to the last penny. It belongs to the king. My robe and my trust in heaven are all I can call mine now. Oh, Cromwell, Cromwell!

og: Had I but served my God with half the zeal  I served my king, he would not in mine age  Have left me naked to mine enemies.
t: If I had only served my God with half the eagerness I served my king, he would not have left me defenseless against my enemies in my old age.

og: Good sir, have patience.
t: Be calm, sir.

og: So I have. FarewellThe hopes of court! my hopes in heaven do dwell.
t: I am. Goodbye, the hopes I had in court. My hopes now live in heaven.

og: You're well met once again.
t: Hello, again.

og: So are you.
t: Hello.

og: You come to take your stand here, and beholdThe Lady Anne pass from her coronation?
t: You've come to stand here and watch Lady Anne pass through on her way back from her coronation?

og: 'Tis all my business. At our last encounter,The Duke of Buckingham came from his trial.
t: That's exactly it. When we last met, the Duke of Buckingham was coming from his trial.

og: 'Tis very true: but that time offer'd sorrow;This, general joy.
t: That's true. That was a sad occasion, and this is one filled with joy.

og: 'Tis well: the citizens,  I am sure, have shown at full their royal minds—  As, let 'em have their rights, they are ever forward—
t: It's a good occasion. The citizens have shown their royal feelings about it—to be fair, they're always quick to show their emotions—

og: In celebration of this day with shows,  Pageants and sights of honour.
t: by celebrating this day with plays, parades, and other festivities.

og: Never greater,Nor, I'll assure you, better taken, sir.
t: There was never a greater celebration, nor, I'm sure, a better reason for one.

og: May I be bold to ask at what that contains,That paper in your hand?
t: Could I be so bold as to ask what that paper you're holding says?

og: Yes; 'tis the list  Of those that claim their offices this day  By custom of the coronation.
t: Yes. It's the list of those who are getting titles today, as is usual on a coronation.

og: The Duke of Suffolk is the first, and claims  To be high-steward; next, the Duke of Norfolk,  He to be earl marshal: you may read the rest.
t: The Duke of Suffolk is the first. He wants to be high-steward. Then is the Duke of Norfolk, who wants to be earl marshal. You can read the rest.

og: I thank you, sir: had I not known those customs,  I should have been beholding to your paper.
t: Thank you, sir. If I hadn't known about these customs I would have been very grateful to see the paper.

og: But, I beseech you, what's become of Katharine,  The princess dowager? how goes her business?
t: But tell me, what's become of Katharine, the princess dowager? How is she?

og: That I can tell you too. The Archbishop  Of Canterbury, accompanied with other  Learned and reverend fathers of his order,  Held a late court at Dunstable, six miles off  From Ampthill where the princess lay;
t: I can tell you that too. The Archbishop of Canterbury and other learned, wise fathers of that religion held a court at Dunstable, six miles away from Ampthill where the princess was staying.

og: to which  She was often cited by them, but appear'd not:  And, to be short, for not appearance and  The king's late scruple,
t: She was often called up by them but didn't appear. In short, because she didn't appear and because of the king's recent doubts,

og: by the main assent  Of all these learned men she was divorced,  And the late marriage made of none effect  Since which she was removed to Kimbolton,  Where she remains now sick.
t: these learned men agreed that she should be divorced and the marriage was ended. Since then she moved to Kimbolton, where she still is, and is sick.

og: Alas, good lady!
t: Poor, good lady!

og: The trumpets sound: stand close, the queen is coming.
t: The trumpets are sounding. Get closer, the queen is coming.

og: A royal train, believe me. These I know:Who's that that bears the sceptre?
t: This is a royal-looking procession, believe me. I know these people, but who's that carrying the scepter?

og: Marquess Dorset:And that the Earl of Surrey, with the rod.
t: Marquess Dorset. And that's the Earl of Surrey with the staff.

og: A bold brave gentleman. That should beThe Duke of Suffolk?
t: He's a brave, daring man. So that'll be the Duke of Suffolk next?

og: 'Tis the same: high-steward.
t: Exactly. He's high-steward.

og: And that my Lord of Norfolk?
t: And that's the Lord of Norfolk?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: [Looking on QUEEN ANNE]   Heaven bless thee!  Thou hast the sweetest face I ever look'd on.  Sir, as I have a soul, she is an angel;
t: [Looking at QUEEN ANNE] God bless you! You have the sweetest face I've ever seen. Sir, I swear on my soul that she's an angel.

og: Our king has all the Indies in his arms,  And more and richer, when he strains that lady:  I cannot blame his conscience.
t: When our king hugs that lady he's holding something more precious than all of India. I can't blame him for his doubts about his former marriage.

og: They that bearThe cloth of honour over her, are four baronsOf the Cinque-ports.
t: Those who carry the canopy over her are four barons, officers of the Cinque-ports.

og: Those men are happy; and so are all are near her.I take it, she that carries up the trainIs that old noble lady, Duchess of Norfolk.
t: Those men are lucky, and so is everyone near her. I assume the woman carrying her train is the old, noble Duchess of Norfolk.

og: It is; and all the rest are countesses.
t: She is, and the others are countesses.

og: Their coronets say so. These are stars indeed;And sometimes falling ones.
t: I can tell from their crowns. They look like stars—sometimes falling stars.

og: No more of that.
t: Shh, that's enough.

og: God save you, sir! where have you been broiling?
t: Hello, sir! What crowd have you been in?

og: Among the crowd i' the Abbey; where a fingerCould not be wedged in more: I am stifledWith the mere rankness of their joy.
t: The crowd in the Abbey. You couldn't have wedged in even one more finger. I feel suffocated by their disgusting happiness.

og: You sawThe ceremony?
t: You saw the coronation?

og: That I did.
t: I did.

og: How was it?
t: How was it?

og: Well worth the seeing.
t: Well worth seeing.

og: Good sir, speak it to us.
t: Tell us about it, good sir.

og: As well as I am able. The rich stream  Of lords and ladies, having brought the queen  To a prepared place in the choir, fell off  A distance from her;
t: I will tell you as well as I can. The expensively dressed procession of lords and ladies brought the queen to a place prepared in the choir of the cathedral and separated from her.

og: while her grace sat down  To rest awhile, some half an hour or so,  In a rich chair of state, opposing freely  The beauty of her person to the people.
t: She sat down to rest a while, a half an hour or so, in a beautiful throne, openly showing her beauty to the people.

og: Believe me, sir, she is the goodliest woman  That ever lay by man: which when the people  Had the full view of, such a noise arose  As the shrouds make at sea in a stiff tempest,  As loud,
t: Believe me, sir, she's the most beautiful woman a man ever slept with. When the people saw her clearly, they made a noise as loud as the sails on a ship in a bad storm,

og: and to as many tunes: hats, cloaks—  Doublets, I think,—flew up; and had their faces  Been loose, this day they had been lost. Such joy  I never saw before.
t: and made up of as many different tunes. They threw up their hats, cloaks, and even shirts I think. If their faces had been loose, they would have thrown and lost them today. I never saw such happiness before.

og: Great-bellied women,  That had not half a week to go, like rams  In the old time of war, would shake the press,  And make 'em reel before 'em.
t: Hugely pregnant women who had less than a week before labor shook the crowd and knocked them over like those battering rams that used to be used in war.

og: No man living  Could say 'This is my wife' there; all were woven  So strangely in one piece.
t: No man alive could have identified his wife there because all the people were so woven together.

og: But, what follow'd?
t: But what happened next?

og: At length her grace rose, and with modest paces  Came to the altar; where she kneel'd, and saint-like  Cast her fair eyes to heaven and pray'd devoutly.
t: Finally the queen rose and walked modestly to the altar. She kneeled there and, like a saint, turned her eyes to heaven and prayed piously.

og: Then rose again and bow'd her to the people:  When by the Archbishop of Canterbury  She had all the royal makings of a queen;  As holy oil,
t: Then she got up again and bowed to the people. Then the Archbishop of Canterbury put on her all the things that make you a queen, like holy oil,

og: Edward Confessor's crown,  The rod, and bird of peace, and all such emblems  Laid nobly on her: which perform'd, the choir,  With all the choicest music of the kingdom,  Together sung 'Te Deum.'
t: Edward the Confessor's crown, the staff and bird that symbolize peace, and all the other symbols. When this was done, the choir, which was made up of the best singers in the kingdom, sang "Te Deum."

og: So she parted,  And with the same full state paced back again  To York-place, where the feast is held.
t: She left and walked back to York-place where the feast is with the same dignified walk.

og: Sir,  You must no more call it York-place, that's past;
t: Sir, you shouldn't call it York-place anymore. That's its old name.

og: For, since the cardinal fell, that title's lost:  'Tis now the king's, and call'd Whitehall.
t: Since the cardinal fell from power, it hasn't been called that. Now it belongs to the king and is called Whitehall.

og: I know it;But 'tis so lately alter'd, that the old nameIs fresh about me.
t: I know. But the name was changed so recently that I still think of it by its old name.

og: What two reverend bishopsWere those that went on each side of the queen?
t: Who were the two respectable bishops walking on either side of the queen?

og: Stokesly and Gardiner; the one of Winchester,Newly preferr'd from the king's secretary,The other, London.
t: Stokesly and Gardiner. The first is bishop of Winchester, recently promoted from his job as the king's secretary. The other is bishop of London.

og: He of WinchesterIs held no great good lover of the archbishop's,The virtuous Cranmer.
t: The bishop of Winchester is believed to dislike the archbishop, virtuous Cranmer.

og: All the land knows that:However, yet there is no great breach; when it comes,Cranmer will find a friend will not shrink from him.
t: Everyone knows that. But there hasn't been a big fight yet. When it comes, Cranmer will find a friend who won't abandon him.

og: Who may that be, I pray you?
t: Really? Who's that?

og: Thomas Cromwell;  A man in much esteem with the king, and truly  A worthy friend.
t: Thomas Cromwell, a man the king thinks very highly of and a very good friend.

og: The king has made him master  O' the jewel house,  And one, already, of the privy council.
t: The king has put him in charge of the treasury and he's already one of his private advisers.

og: He will deserve more.
t: He will deserve further promotions.

og: Yes, without all doubt.  Come, gentlemen, ye shall go my way, which  Is to the court, and there ye shall be my guests:
t: Yes, definitely. Come on, gentleman, you'll go with me to the court and be my guests there.

og: Something I can command. As I walk thither,  I'll tell ye more.
t: I have some authority there. As we walk there I'll tell you more.

og: You may command us, sir.
t: We'll do as you say, sir.

og: How does your grace?
t: How are you, your grace?

og: O Griffith, sick to death!  My legs, like loaden branches, bow to the earth,  Willing to leave their burthen. Reach a chair:
t: Oh, Griffith, I'm terminally ill! My legs are like branches weighed down by something and bow to the earth, trying to put down the weight they carry. Get me a chair.

og: So; now, methinks, I feel a little ease.  Didst thou not tell me, Griffith, as thou led'st me,  That the great child of honour, Cardinal Wolsey,  Was dead?
t: Ahh, now, I think, I feel a little better. Didn't you tell me, Griffith, as you led me, that that honorable man, Cardinal Wolsey, was dead?

og: Yes, madam; but I think your grace,Out of the pain you suffer'd, gave no ear to't.
t: Yes, ma'am. But I think you were in too much pain to listen.

og: Prithee, good Griffith, tell me how he died:If well, he stepp'd before me, happilyFor my example.
t: Please, good Griffith, tell me how he died. If he died well, I'm lucky in that he's given me an example to follow.

og: Well, the voice goes, madam:  For after the stout Earl Northumberland  Arrested him at York,
t: They say he did die well, ma'am. After the brave Earl of Northumberland arrested him at York

og: and brought him forward,  As a man sorely tainted, to his answer,  He fell sick suddenly, and grew so ill  He could not sit his mule.
t: and brought him to court to answer for the terrible crimes he was accused of, he suddenly got sick and became so unwell he couldn't even sit up on his donkey.

og: Alas, poor man!
t: Poor man!

og: At last, with easy roads, he came to Leicester,  Lodged in the abbey; where the reverend abbot,  With all his covent, honourably received him;  To whom he gave these words,
t: At last, he took easy roads to Leicester and stayed in the abbey. The respected abbot and all the monks received him honorably there. He said to the abbot,

og: 'O, father abbot,  An old man, broken with the storms of state,  Is come to lay his weary bones among ye;  Give him a little earth for charity!'
t: "Oh, father abbot, an old man injured by the uproars of politics has come to die among you. Be kind enough to give him a grave!"

og: So went to bed; where eagerly his sickness  Pursued him still: and, three nights after this,  About the hour of eight, which he himself  Foretold should be his last,
t: So he went to bed, where his sickness eagerly attacked him. Three nights later, around eight, which was the time he had foretold he would die,

og: full of repentance,  Continual meditations, tears, and sorrows,  He gave his honours to the world again,  His blessed part to heaven, and slept in peace.
t: full of repentance, continual meditation, tears, and sadness, he gave back his honors to the world and his soul to heaven and slept peacefully.

og: So may he rest; his faults lie gently on him!  Yet thus far, Griffith, give me leave to speak him,  And yet with charity.
t: May he rest in peace and not be punished harshly for his faults! Let me say just this about him, Griffith, but I'll speak it kindly.

og: He was a man  Of an unbounded stomach, ever ranking  Himself with princes; one that, by suggestion,  Tied all the kingdom: simony was fair-play;
t: He was a man with boundless appetites, always thinking he was equal to kings. He ruled the kingdom with his words. He was fine with buying and selling public offices.

og: His own opinion was his law: i' the presence  He would say untruths; and be ever double  Both in his words and meaning: he was never,  But where he meant to ruin, pitiful:
t: His own opinion was the law for him. He would lie to the king and was always ambiguous in what he said. He never pitied anyone except when he meant to destroy them.

og: His promises were, as he then was, mighty;  But his performance, as he is now, nothing:  Of his own body he was ill, and gave  The clergy in example.
t: He promised great things and he was great, but he did nothing and he is nothing now. He treated his own body badly and was a bad example to churchmen.

og: Noble madam,  Men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues  We write in water.
t: Noble lady, men's bad qualities are remembered as if they were engraved in metal, but their virtues are forgotten as quickly as if they were written on water.

og: May it please your highness  To hear me speak his good now?
t: May I say good things about him now?

og: Yes, good Griffith;I were malicious else.
t: Yes, good Griffith, it would be cruel of me to refuse.

og: This cardinal,  Though from an humble stock, undoubtedly  Was fashion'd to much honour from his cradle.  He was a scholar, and a ripe and good one;
t: This cardinal, although he came from a humble family, was undoubtedly meant to win great honor from the day he was born. He was a scholar, and an excellent one.

og: Exceeding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading:  Lofty and sour to them that loved him not;  But to those men that sought him sweet as summer.
t: He was very wise, well-spoken, and persuasive. He was proud and bitter towards those who hated him, but to those who wanted to be his friends he was as sweet as summer.

og: And though he were unsatisfied in getting,  Which was a sin, yet in bestowing, madam,  He was most princely: ever witness for him  Those twins of learning that he raised in you,  Ipswich and Oxford!
t: And although he was never content with what he had, which was a sin, he was as generous in giving gifts as a king. Consider those two colleges he started in Ipswich and Oxford!

og: one of which fell with him,  Unwilling to outlive the good that did it;  The other, though unfinish'd, yet so famous,  So excellent in art, and still so rising,  That Christendom shall ever speak his virtue.
t: One of them fell along with him, unwilling to outlive its benefactor. The other one, although not yet finished, is still so famous, so learned, and still getting better, that he will always be praised in Christian countries.

og: His overthrow heap'd happiness upon him;  For then, and not till then, he felt himself,  And found the blessedness of being little:
t: His loss of power was a good thing for him, because it was not until then that he understood himself and found the joy in being unimportant.

og: And, to add greater honours to his age  Than man could give him, he died fearing God.
t: And it gave him greater honor in his old age than any man could give him that he died thinking of God.

og: After my death I wish no other herald,  No other speaker of my living actions,  To keep mine honour from corruption,  But such an honest chronicler as Griffith.
t: After my death I don't want anyone to talk about my actions when I was alive to praise me except an honest historian like Griffith.

og: Whom I most hated living, thou hast made me,  With thy religious truth and modesty,  Now in his ashes honour: peace be with him!
t: With your religious truth and modesty, you have made me honor the man I hated most when he was alive now that he is dead. May he rest in peace!

og: Patience, be near me still; and set me lower:  I have not long to trouble thee.
t: Patience, stay near me and lower my chair. I won't bother you long.

og: Good Griffith,  Cause the musicians play me that sad note  I named my knell, whilst I sit meditating  On that celestial harmony I go to.
t: Good Griffith, have the musicians play me that sad song I called my funeral music, while I sit thinking about heaven, where I am going.

og: She is asleep: good wench, let's sit down quiet,For fear we wake her: softly, gentle Patience.
t: She's asleep. Dear girl, let's sit down quietly, or we'll wake her. Quietly, dear Patience.

og: Spirits of peace, where are ye? are ye all gone,And leave me here in wretchedness behind ye?
t: Peaceful spirits, where are you? Have you all gone and left me miserable behind you?

og: Madam, we are here.
t: Ma'am, we're here.

og: It is not you I call for:Saw ye none enter since I slept?
t: I wasn't calling for you. Didn't you see anyone come in here while I was asleep?

og: None, madam.
t: No one, ma'am.

og: No? Saw you not, even now, a blessed troop  Invite me to a banquet; whose bright faces  Cast thousand beams upon me, like the sun?
t: No? Didn't you see a holy band of angels—whose bright faces cast a thousand beams on me as if they were the sun—invite me to a feast just now?

og: They promised me eternal happiness;  And brought me garlands, Griffith, which I feel  I am not worthy yet to wear: I shall, assuredly.
t: They promised me eternal happiness and brought me crowns, Griffith, that I think I'm not yet worthy enough to wear. I will, though.

og: I am most joyful, madam, such good dreamsPossess your fancy.
t: I am very happy, ma'am, that you've had such good dreams.

og: Bid the music leave,They are harsh and heavy to me.
t: Have the music stop. It sounds harsh and slow to me.

og: Do you note  How much her grace is alter'd on the sudden?
t: Do you see how different she suddenly looks?

og: How long her face is drawn? how pale she looks,  And of an earthy cold? Mark her eyes!
t: How drawn her face seems? How pale she looks, and cold as earth? Look at her eyes!

og: She is going, wench: pray, pray.
t: She's dying, girl. Pray, pray.

og: Heaven comfort her!
t: God help her!

og: An't like your grace,—
t: Your grace—

og: You are a saucy fellow:Deserve we no more reverence?
t: You're a rude fellow. Don't I deserve more politeness?

og: You are to blame,Knowing she will not lose her wonted greatness,To use so rude behavior; go to, kneel.
t: You should know she won't let you treat her so rudely, since she's used to being powerful. Go on, kneel.

og: I humbly do entreat your highness' pardon;My haste made me unmannerly. There is stayingA gentleman, sent from the king, to see you.
t: I beg your pardon, your highness. I was in a hurry and that made me rude. A gentleman sent from the king is waiting to see you.

og: Admit him entrance, Griffith: but this fellowLet me ne'er see again.
t: Let him in, Griffith, but let me never see this fellow again.

og: If my sight fail not,You should be lord ambassador from the emperor,My royal nephew, and your name Capucius.
t: If I'm not going blind, you're the ambassador to the emperor, my royal nephew, and your name is Capucius.

og: Madam, the same; your servant.
t: That's right, ma'am. At your service.

og: O, my lord,  The times and titles now are alter'd strangely  With me since first you knew me.
t: Oh, my lord, things have gone strangely since we first met, and I have a different title.

og: But, I pray you,  What is your pleasure with me?
t: But please tell me what you want from me.

og: Noble lady,  First mine own service to your grace; the next,  The king's request that I would visit you;
t: Noble lady, first, I wanted to see you on my own behalf. Second, the king asked me to visit you.

og: Who grieves much for your weakness, and by me  Sends you his princely commendations,  And heartily entreats you take good comfort.
t: He's very sad about your illness and sends you his best wishes through me and asks you to get better.

og: O my good lord, that comfort comes too late;  'Tis like a pardon after execution:
t: Oh, my good lord, it's too late to get better. That's like being pardoned after your execution.

og: That gentle physic, given in time, had cured me;  But now I am past an comforts here, but prayers.  How does his highness?
t: The sweet medicine of hearing from the king would have cured me if I'd gotten it in time. But now I am past all cures on earth except prayers. How is the king?

og: Madam, in good health.
t: He's in good health, ma'am.

og: So may he ever do! and ever flourish,  When I shal l dwell with worms, and my poor name  Banish'd the kingdom!
t: I hope he always is! And that he's always well when I am dead and living with the worms and no one speaks my name anymore in this country!

og: Patience, is that letter,  I caused you write, yet sent away?
t: Patience, did you send that letter I had you write yet?

og: No, madam.
t: No, ma'am.

og: Sir, I most humbly pray you to deliverThis to my lord the king.
t: Sir, I ask you humbly to give this to the king.

og: Most willing, madam.
t: Willingly, ma'am.

og: In which I have commended to his goodness  The model of our chaste loves, his young daughter;  The dews of heaven fall thick in blessings on her!
t: In it I asked him to treat his young daughter well, who was created by our virtuous love. May heaven rain blessings on her!

og: Beseeching him to give her virtuous breeding—  She is young, and of a noble modest nature,  I hope she will deserve well,—and a little  To love her for her mother's sake, that loved him,  Heaven knows how dearly.
t: I ask him to raise her well—she is young and of a noble modest character, so I hope she will turn out well—and to love her a little for her mother's sake, who loved him so much.

og: My next poor petition  Is, that his noble grace would have some pity  Upon my wretched women, that so long  Have follow'd both my fortunes faithfully:
t: My next small request is that he'll take a little pity on my poor maids who have stuck by me for so long.

og: Of which there is not one, I dare avow,  And now I should not lie, but will deserve  For virtue and true beauty of the soul,  For honesty and decent carriage,  A right good husband, let him be a noble
t: There is not a single one, I swear, and I can't lie now that I'm dying, who doesn't deserve an excellent husband, a noble, for her virtue and true inner beauty and for honesty and decency.

og: And, sure, those men are happy that shall have 'em.  The last is, for my men; they are the poorest,  But poverty could never draw 'em from me;
t: Certainly, the men who get them will be lucky. The last request is for my men. They are the poorest, but they never abandoned me despite their poverty.

og: That they may have their wages duly paid 'em,  And something over to remember me by:  If heaven had pleased to have given me longer life  And able means, we had not parted thus.
t: I ask that their wages be paid, and a little more be given to them to remember me by. If God had wished to give me a longer life and more money, I would not have parted with them like this.

og: These are the whole contents: and, good my lord,  By that you love the dearest in this world,  As you wish Christian peace to souls departed,  Stand these poor people's friend, and urge the king  To do me this last right.
t: That's all that's in the letter. And, my good lord, if you love the best people in this world and wish Christian souls to rest in peace, be a friend to these poor people and encourage the king to do this last duty for me.

og: By heaven, I will,Or let me lose the fashion of a man!
t: I will, by God, or let me not be called a man anymore!

og: I thank you, honest lord. Remember me  In all humility unto his highness:  Say his long trouble now is passing  Out of this world;
t: Thank you, honest lord. Remind the king of me humbly. Tell him the trouble he's had for so long is passing away.

og: tell him, in death I bless'd him,  For so I will. Mine eyes grow dim. Farewell,  My lord. Griffith, farewell.
t: Tell him I blessed him when I died, and I will do that. Death is clouding my eyes and making me blind. Goodbye, my lord. Griffith, goodbye.

og: Nay, Patience,  You must not leave me yet: I must to bed;  Call in more women. When I am dead, good wench,  Let me be used with honour:
t: No, Patience, don't leave me yet. I have to go to bed. Call the other maids. When I am dead, dear girl, have me be treated honorably.

og: strew me over  With maiden flowers, that all the world may know  I was a chaste wife to my grave: embalm me,
t: Sprinkle flowers that symbolize virtue over me so the whole world knows I was a good wife up to the day I died. Embalm me,

og: Then lay me forth: although unqueen'd, yet like  A queen, and daughter to a king, inter me.  I can no more.
t: then put me in my coffin. Although I'm not a queen anymore, bury me like a queen and the daughter to a king. I can't say anything else.

og: It's one o'clock, boy, is't not?
t: It's one o'clock, isn't it, boy?

og: It hath struck.
t: Yes, the clock struck one.

og: These should be hours for necessities,  Not for delights;
t: This is not a time for fun but for necessities.

og: times to repair our nature  With comforting repose,  and not for us  To waste these times.
t: It's a time when we should be sleeping to repair our bodies, not wasting time.

og: Good hour of night, Sir Thomas!  Whither so late?
t: Good evening, Sir Thomas! Where are you going so late?

og: Came you from the king, my lord?
t: Did you come from the king, my lord?

og: I did, Sir Thomas: and left him at primeroWith the Duke of Suffolk.
t: I did, Sir Thomas. I left him playing cards with the Duke of Suffolk.

og: I must to him too,Before he go to bed. I'll take my leave.
t: I must go to him, too, before he goes to bed. Goodbye.

og: Not yet, Sir Thomas Lovell. What's the matter?  It seems you are in haste: an if there be  No great offence belongs to't, give your friend  Some touch of your late business:
t: Wait, Sir Thomas Lovell. What's the matter? You seem to be in a hurry. If there's no harm in it, give me an idea of what you're doing so late.

og: affairs, that walk,  As they say spirits do, at midnight, have  In them a wilder nature than the business  That seeks dispatch by day.
t: Business that arises at midnight like ghosts is more urgent than the business done by day.

og: My lord, I love you;  And durst commend a secret to your ear  Much weightier than this work.
t: My lord, I love you and I will dare to tell you an important secret.

og: The queen's in labour,  They say, in great extremity; and fear'd  She'll with the labour end.
t: The queen's in labor and they say she's in great danger. It's feared that she'll die in childbirth.

og: The fruit she goes with  I pray for heartily, that it may find  Good time, and live:
t: I pray that the child she's pregnant with survives.

og: but for the stock, Sir Thomas,  I wish it grubb'd up now.
t: As for her, Sir Thomas, I hope she dies now.

og: Methinks I could  Cry the amen;
t: I think I could say amen to that.

og: and yet my conscience says  She's a good creature, and, sweet lady, does  Deserve our better wishes.
t: But my conscience tells me she's a good person and deserves our best wishes for her, the sweet lady.

og: But, sir, sir,  Hear me, Sir Thomas: you're a gentleman  Of mine own way; I know you wise, religious;
t: But sir, sir, listen to me, Sir Thomas. You're a gentleman like me. I know you're wise and religious.

og: And, let me tell you, it will ne'er be well,  'Twill not, Sir Thomas Lovell, take't of me,  Till Cranmer, Cromwell, her two hands, and she,  Sleep in their graves.
t: Let me tell you, things will never be all right, they won't, Sir Thomas Lovell, believe me, until Cranmer and Cromwell, her two servants, and she are dead and buried.

og: Now, sir, you speak of two  The most remark'd i' the kingdom. As for Cromwell,  Beside that of the jewel house, is made master  O' the rolls, and the king's secretary;
t: Sir, you're talking about two of the most respected men in the country. As for Cromwell, he's now in charge of court records in addition to the treasury, and the king's secretary.

og: further, sir,  Stands in the gap and trade of moe preferments,  With which the time will load him.
t: And, sir, there are more promotions coming to him soon.

og: The archbishop  Is the king's hand and tongue; and who dare speak  One syllable against him?
t: The archbishop is the king's right hand man and speaks for him, so who dares say a single word against him?

og: Yes, yes, Sir Thomas,  There are that dare; and I myself have ventured  To speak my mind of him:
t: Yes, yes, Sir Thomas, some people dare. I myself have dared to speak my mind about him.

og: and indeed this day,  Sir, I may tell it you, I think I have  Incensed the lords o' the council, that he is,  For so I know he is, they know he is,  A most arch heretic, a pestilence  That does infect the land:
t: In fact today, sir, I can tell you, I think I convinced the king's counselors that he is, as I know he is and they know he is, a terrible heretic and a disease that has infected the country.

og: with which they moved  Have broken with the king; who hath so far  Given ear to our complaint, of his great grace  And princely care foreseeing those fell mischiefs  Our reasons laid before him,
t: They, convinced about this, have spoken with the king. He has listened to our complaint enough to understand what we have said about the disasters in store.  Out of fairness and care for the country,

og: hath commanded  To-morrow morning to the council-board  He be convented. He's a rank weed, Sir Thomas,  And we must root him out.
t: he has commanded that man to appear at the counsel meeting tomorrow morning. That man's a disgusting weed, Sir Thomas, and we have to dig him out.

og: From your affairs  I hinder you too long: good night, Sir Thomas.
t: I'm keeping you too long from your business. Good night, Sir Thomas.

og: Many good nights, my lord: I rest your servant.
t: Good night, my lord. I am still at your service.

og: Charles, I will play no more tonight;My mind's not on't; you are too hard for me.
t: Charles, I won't play any more tonight. My mind isn't on it. You're too good at it.

og: Sir, I did never win of you before.
t: Sir, I've never won against you before.

og: But little, Charles;Nor shall not, when my fancy's on my play.Now, Lovell, from the queen what is the news?
t: You only won a little money, Charles, and won't when my mind is on playing cards. Now, Lovell, what's the news from the queen?

og: I could not personally deliver to her  What you commanded me, but by her woman  I sent your message;
t: I couldn't personally deliver the message you gave to her, but I sent it to her through her maid.

og: who return'd her thanks  In the great'st humbleness, and desired your highness  Most heartily to pray for her.
t: She thanked you as humbly as possible and asked you to pray for her.

og: What say'st thou, ha?To pray for her? what, is she crying out?
t: What? What did you say? To pray for her? Is she screaming?

og: So said her woman; and that her sufferance madeAlmost each pang a death.
t: That's what her maid said. And that she suffered so much at every contraction that she almost died.

og: Alas, good lady!
t: Poor lady!

og: God safely quit her of her burthen, andWith gentle travail, to the gladding ofYour highness with an heir!
t: May God deliver the child safely, with an easy labor, and make you happy by giving you an heir!

og: 'Tis midnight, Charles;  Prithee, to bed; and in thy prayers remember  The estate of my poor queen. Leave me alone;
t: It's midnight, Charles. Please go to bed, and pray for my poor queen's health. Leave me alone.

og: For I must think of that which company  Would not be friendly to.
t: I have to think about things and need to be alone.

og: I wish your highnessA quiet night; and my good mistress willRemember in my prayers.
t: I hope you have a peaceful night and I will pray for my good queen.

og: Charles, good night.
t: Charles, goodnight.

og: Well, sir, what follows?
t: Well, sir, what is it?

og: Sir, I have brought my lord the archbishop,As you commanded me.
t: Sir, I have brought the archbishop as you asked.

og: Ha! Canterbury?
t: What, the archbishop of Canterbury?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my lord.

og: 'Tis true: where is he, Denny?
t: It's true, I asked to see him. Where is he, Denny?

og: He attends your highness' pleasure.
t: He's waiting for you, your highness.

og: This is about that which the bishop spake:I am happily come hither.
t: This is about the business the bishop told me about. I came here at a good time.

og: Avoid the gallery.
t: Empty the room.

og: Ha! I have said. Be gone. What!
t: I told you what to do. Get out!

og: I am fearful: wherefore frowns he thus?'Tis his aspect of terror. All's not well.
t: I am afraid. Why does he frown like that? That's how he looks when he's angry. Something is wrong.

og: How now, my lord! you desire to knowWherefore I sent for you.
t: Hello, my lord! You want to know why I sent for you.

og: It is my dutyTo attend your highness' pleasure.
t: It's my duty to do as you wish.

og: Pray you, arise,  My good and gracious Lord of Canterbury.  Come, you and I must walk a turn together;  I have news to tell you: come, come, give me your hand.
t: Please, get up, my good lord of Canterbury. Come on, we have to walk a little. I have news to tell you. Come on, come on, give me your hand.

og: Ah, my good lord, I grieve at what I speak,  And am right sorry to repeat what follows  I have, and most unwillingly, of late  Heard many grievous, I do say, my lord,  Grievous complaints of you;
t: My good lord, I'm sad to have to say this and I'm sorry to tell you the following: I have, very unwillingly, lately heard many terrible, I must say, terrible complaints about you.

og: which, being consider'd,  Have moved us and our council, that you shall  This morning come before us; where, I know,  You cannot with such freedom purge yourself,
t: Hearing these complaints made me and my council call you before us this morning. Unfortunately, because it'll take time to clear your name,

og: But that, till further trial in those charges  Which will require your answer, you must take  Your patience to you, and be well contented  To make your house our Tower:
t: you'll have to wait for your trial patiently in the Tower.

og: you a brother of us,  It fits we thus proceed, or else no witness  Would come against you.
t: Since you're like my brother, it's right to proceed like this. Otherwise no witness would dare to appear against you.

og: [Kneeling]  I humbly thank your highness;  And am right glad to catch this good occasion  Most throughly to be winnow'd, where my chaff  And corn shall fly asunder:
t: [Kneeling] I thank you humbly, your highness. I'm very happy to have this opportunity to be investigated thoroughly and judged.

og: for, I know,  There's none stands under more calumnious tongues  Than I myself, poor man.
t: I know that no one is more lied about than I am, poor me.

og: Stand up, good Canterbury:  Thy truth and thy integrity is rooted  In us, thy friend: give me thy hand, stand up:  Prithee, let's walk. Now, by my holidame.
t: Stand up, good Canterbury. I am convinced of your faithfulness and honesty. Give me your hand, stand up. Please, let's walk. Now, by the virgin Mary,

og: What manner of man are you? My lord, I look'd  You would have given me your petition, that  I should have ta'en some pains to bring together  Yourself and your accusers;
t: what kind of man are you? My lord, I thought you would ask me to bring your accusers to you,

og: and to have heard you,  Without indurance, further.
t: and that I'd hear you defend yourself.

og: Most dread liege,  The good I stand on is my truth and honesty:  If they shall fail, I, with mine enemies,  Will triumph o'er my person;
t: Most powerful king, I stand by my truth and honesty. If they fail me, I will dislike myself as much as my enemies do.

og: which I weigh not,  Being of those virtues vacant. I fear nothing  What can be said against me.
t: I don't care about my body except because of the virtue in it. I'm not afraid of anything that can be said against me.

og: Know you not  How your state stands i' the world, with the whole world?  Your enemies are many, and not small; their practises  Must bear the same proportion;
t: Don't you know what people think about you, what everyone thinks? You have a lot of enemies, and important ones. You should worry about their plotting.

og: and not ever  The justice and the truth o' the question carries  The due o' the verdict with it: at what ease  Might corrupt minds procure knaves as corrupt  To swear against you? such things have been done.
t: It's not always justice and truth that wins in a lawsuit. Think how easily bad people could find criminals as bad as they are to tell lies against you in court. Such things have happened.

og: You are potently opposed; and with a malice  Of as great size. Ween you of better luck,  I mean, in perjured witness, than your master,  Whose minister you are, whiles here he lived  Upon this naughty earth?
t: You have powerful and evil enemies. Do you think you'll have better luck, I mean luck in avoiding lying witnesses, than me, the master you serve while I'm alive on this evil earth?

og: Go to, go to;  You take a precipice for no leap of danger,  And woo your own destruction.
t: Really, it's like you think jumping off a cliff isn't dangerous. You're risking destruction.

og: God and your majestyProtect mine innocence, or I fall intoThe trap is laid for me!
t: May God and you protect me in my innocence, or I'll fall into the trap that's been set for me!

og: Be of good cheer;  They shall no more prevail than we give way to.  Keep comfort to you; and this morning see  You do appear before them:
t: Don't worry. They won't do anything I don't let them do. Take heart and appear before them this morning.

og: if they shall chance,  In charging you with matters, to commit you,  The best persuasions to the contrary  Fail not to use, and with what vehemency  The occasion shall instruct you:
t: If in the course of accusing you they sentence you, make sure to argue as hard as you can against it, with whatever force the occasion demands.

og: if entreaties  Will render you no remedy, this ring  Deliver them, and your appeal to us  There make before them. Look, the good man weeps!
t: If arguing doesn't help, give them this ring and appeal to me in front of them. Look, the good man is crying!

og: He's honest, on mine honour. God's blest mother!  I swear he is true-hearted; and a soul  None better in my kingdom. Get you gone,  And do as I have bid you.
t: I swear he must be honest. By God's blessed mother! I swear he's good-hearted, and there's no better man in my kingdom. Go on and do as I told you.

og: He has strangledHis language in his tears.
t: He can't talk through his tears.

og: Come back: what mean you?
t: Come back: what are you doing?

og: I'll not come back; the tidings that I bring  Will make my boldness manners.
t: I won't come back. The news I bring will make my rudeness seem like good manners.

og: Now, good angels  Fly o'er thy royal head, and shade thy person  Under their blessed wings!
t: May good angels fly over your royal head and shade you with their holy wings!

og: Now, by thy looksI guess thy message. Is the queen deliver'd?Say, ay; and of a boy.
t: I can guess what you'll say from looking at you. Has the queen given birth? Say yes, and to a boy.

og: Ay, ay, my liege;  And of a lovely boy: the God of heaven  Both now and ever bless her! 'tis a girl,  Promises boys hereafter.
t: Yes, yes, my king. And to a beautiful boy: may God bless her now and forever! It's a girl, who guarantees boys will be born later.

og: Sir, your queen  Desires your visitation, and to be  Acquainted with this stranger 'tis as like you  As cherry is to cherry.
t: Sir, your queen wants you to visit her so you can meet this stranger who looks as much like you as a cherry looks like a cherry.

og: Lovell!
t: Lovell!

og: Sir?
t: Sir?

og: Give her an hundred marks. I'll to the queen.
t: Pay her a hundred marks. I'll go see the queen.

og: An hundred marks! By this light, I'll ha' more.  An ordinary groom is for such payment.  I will have more, or scold it out of him.
t: A hundred marks! I swear I'll get more. That's what you pay an ordinary groom for taking care of your horse. I'll get more or keep scolding him till I get it.

og: Said I for this, the girl was like to him?  I will have more, or else unsay't; and now,  While it is hot, I'll put it to the issue.
t: Did I say the girl looked like him for this? I'll have more or I'll take that back. Now, I'll ask for more while there's still a chance.

og: I hope I am not too late; and yet the gentleman,  That was sent to me from the council, pray'd me  To make great haste.
t: I hope I'm not too late. But the gentleman sent to me by the council asked me to hurry.

og: All fast? what means this? Ho!  Who waits there? Sure, you know me?
t: Locked? What does this mean? Hello? Who's waiting there? Don't you recognize me?

og: Yes, my lord;But yet I cannot help you.
t: Yes, my lord, but I can't help you.

og: Why?
t: Why?

og: Your grace must wait till you be call'd for.
t: You have to wait until you're called.

og: So.
t: All right.

og: This is a piece of malice. I am gladI came this way so happily: the kingShall understand it presently.
t: This is some evil scheme. I'm glad I happened to come this way. The king will hear about this at once.

og: [Aside]  'Tis Butts,  The king's physician: as he pass'd along,  How earnestly he cast his eyes upon me!  Pray heaven, he sound not my disgrace!
t: [To himself] That was Butts, the king's physician. He looked at me so earnestly as he passed! I pray he doesn't spread the word about my disgrace!

og: For certain,  This is of purpose laid by some that hate me—  God turn their hearts! I never sought their malice—  To quench mine honour:
t: This must have been done on purpose by some people who hate me—may God change their minds! I never wanted to make enemies of them.

og: they would shame to make me  Wait else at door, a fellow-counsellor,  'Mong boys, grooms, and lackeys. But their pleasures  Must be fulfill'd, and I attend with patience.
t: They must want to dishonor me, or they would be ashamed to make me wait at the door, a council-member like them, among all sorts of servants. But I have to do what they want, and I'm waiting patiently.

og: I'll show your grace the strangest sight—
t: I'll show you the strangest sight—

og: What's that, Butts?
t: What's that, Butts?

og: I think your highness saw this many a day.
t: I think you've seen in many days.

og: Body o' me, where is it?
t: Goodness, where?

og: There, my lord:  The high promotion of his grace of Canterbury;
t: There, my lord. The good treatment of the archbishop of Canterbury,

og: Who holds his state at door, 'mongst pursuivants,  Pages, and footboys.
t: who's waiting at the door among petitioners and servants.

og: Ha! 'tis he, indeed:  Is this the honour they do one another?  'Tis well there's one above 'em yet.
t: What? Yes, it's him. Is this the way they treat each other? It's good there's still someone more important than them.

og: I had thought  They had parted so much honesty among 'em  At least, good manners, as not thus to suffer  A man of his place, and so near our favour,  To dance attendance on their lordships' pleasures,
t: I thought they had enough honesty between them, or at least good manners, not to make a man of his importance and good standing with me wait for their attention,

og: And at the door too, like a post with packets.  By holy Mary, Butts, there's knavery:  Let 'em alone, and draw the curtain close:  We shall hear more anon.
t: and at the door, too, as if he were a postman delivering packages. But, by holy Mary, Butts, this is vicious. Leave them alone and let's close the curtain. We'll hear more soon.

og: Speak to the business, master-secretary:Why are we met in council?
t: Tell us about this business, secretary. Why has the council met?

og: Please your honours,The chief cause concerns his grace of Canterbury.
t: Your honors, the main reason is the archbishop of Canterbury.

og: Has he had knowledge of it?
t: Does he know about it?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: Who waits there?
t: Who's waiting there?

og: Without, my noble lords?
t: Outside, my noble lords?

og: Yes.
t: Yes.

og: My lord archbishop;And has done half an hour, to know your pleasures.
t: The archbishop. He's waited half an hour to hear what you want.

og: Let him come in.
t: Let him in.

og: Your grace may enter now.
t: You can enter now, your grace.

og: My good lord archbishop, I'm very sorry  To sit here at this present, and behold  That chair stand empty:
t: My lord archbishop, I'm very sorry to sit here now and see that chair remain empty.

og: but we all are men,  In our own natures frail, and capable  Of our flesh; few are angels: out of which frailty  And want of wisdom, you, that best should teach us,  Have misdemean'd yourself, and not a little,
t: But we are all men with weak natures and our bodies can have power over us. There aren't many angels. It's this weakness, as well as a lack of wisdom, that made you act badly, very badly,

og: Toward the king first, then his laws, in filling  The whole realm, by your teaching and your chaplains,  For so we are inform'd, with new opinions,  Divers and dangerous;
t: towards the king and his laws—you, who should provide a good example for us all. We've been told you've filled the whole country, by teaching and appointing priests who agree with you, with new opinions that are different and dangerous.

og: which are heresies,  And, not reform'd, may prove pernicious.
t: They're heresies and if they're not stopped they might be bad for the country.

og: Which reformation must be sudden too,  My noble lords; for those that tame wild horses  Pace 'em not in their hands to make 'em gentle,  But stop their mouths with stubborn bits, and spur 'em,  Till they obey the manage.
t: They have to be stopped at once, my noble lords. People who tame wild horses don't lead them in their hands to tame them but they put hard bits in their mouths and spur them until they obey commands.

og: If we suffer,  Out of our easiness and childish pity  To one man's honour, this contagious sickness,  Farewell all physic: and what follows then?
t: If we allow this contagious sickness to go on without stopping it because we're too forgiving and childishly pity one man, medicine won't be able to help us. What then?

og: Commotions, uproars, with a general taint  Of the whole state: as, of late days, our neighbours,  The upper Germany, can dearly witness,  Yet freshly pitied in our memories.
t: Riots, uproar, complete destruction of the whole country. Lately our neighbor, northern Germany, has shown us what happens when heresy takes over, and we're still pitying their recent disaster.

og: My good lords, hitherto, in all the progress  Both of my life and office, I have labour'd,  And with no little study, that my teaching  And the strong course of my authority  Might go one way, and safely;
t: My good lords, so far, in both my daily life and my job, I have worked and studied hard to make my teaching and my power lead safely to one thing.

og: and the end  Was ever, to do well: nor is there living,  I speak it with a single heart, my lords,  A man that more detests, more stirs against,  Both in his private conscience and his place,  Defacers of a public peace, than I do.
t: This goal was always to do the right thing. There is no one alive, and I say this honestly my lords, who hates or works harder to stop people who cause public disruptions, either in his private thoughts or his public office, than I do.

og: Pray heaven, the king may never find a heart  With less allegiance in it! Men that make  Envy and crooked malice nourishment  Dare bite the best.
t: I pray to God the king will always be surrounded by people as loyal as I am to him! Men whose lives are full of envy and evil resentment dare to attack even the best people.

og: I do beseech your lordships,  That, in this case of justice, my accusers,  Be what they will, may stand forth face to face,  And freely urge against me.
t: I beg you, my lords, to bring my accusers (whoever they are) face to face with me to accuse me in this trial.

og: Nay, my lord,That cannot be: you are a counsellor,And, by that virtue, no man dare accuse you.
t: No, my lord, that can't happen. You're a councilor and because of that no one dares to accuse you.

og: My lord, because we have business of more moment,  We will be short with you. 'Tis his highness' pleasure,  And our consent, for better trial of you,  From hence you be committed to the Tower;
t: My lord, we'll hurry this along because we have more important business. The king wishes and we agree that you should be imprisoned in the Tower.

og: Where, being but a private man again,  You shall know many dare accuse you boldly,  More than, I fear, you are provided for.
t: Then you'll be just a private citizen again and you'll find out who dares to accuse you. It'll be more people, I'm afraid, than you're ready to face.
