og: Ah, my good Lord of Winchester, I thank you;  You are always my good friend; if your will pass,  I shall both find your lordship judge and juror,  You are so merciful:
t: Ah, thank you, my good lord of Winchester. You have always been my good friend. If you do what you want, you're so merciful that you will act as both judge and jury to me.

og: I see your end;  'Tis my undoing: love and meekness, lord,  Become a churchman better than ambition:  Win straying souls with modesty again,  Cast none away.
t: I see your goal: it's to destroy me. Love and humility are more fitting for a churchman than ambition, lord. Win back sinners by being modest: don't banish them.

og: That I shall clear myself,  Lay all the weight ye can upon my patience,  I make as little doubt, as you do conscience  In doing daily wrongs.
t: I have less doubt that I will clear my name, whatever you make me suffer in the meantime, than you have any doubts about whether you should be doing evil things every day.

og: I could say more,  But reverence to your calling makes me modest.
t: I could say more, but respect for your job makes me modest.

og: My lord, my lord, you are a sectary,That's the plain truth: your painted gloss discovers,To men that understand you, words and weakness.
t: My lord, my lord, you're a heretic. That's the simple truth. Men who understand you can see there's nothing under your false appearance but words and weakness.

og: My Lord of Winchester, you are a little,  By your good favour, too sharp;
t: My Lord of Winchester, excuse me but you're a little too rude.

og: men so noble,  However faulty, yet should find respect  For what they have been: 'tis a cruelty  To load a falling man.
t: Noble men, whatever their faults, should be respected for what they once were. It's cruel to kick a man when he's down.

og: Good master secretary,I cry your honour mercy; you may, worstOf all this table, say so.
t: Secretary, I'm sorry. You have the least right of anyone here to say that.

og: Why, my lord?
t: Why, my lord?

og: Do not I know you for a favourerOf this new sect? ye are not sound.
t: Don't I know you're a follower of this new religion? You are not trustworthy.

og: Not sound?
t: Not trustworthy?

og: Not sound, I say.
t: Not trustworthy, that's what I said.

og: Would you were half so honest!Men's prayers then would seek you, not their fears.
t: I wish you were half as honest as I am trustworthy! Then men would pray for you, not fear you.

og: I shall remember this bold language.
t: I'll remember this arrogant language.

og: Do.Remember your bold life too.
t: Do. Remember your arrogant life too.

og: This is too much;Forbear, for shame, my lords.
t: This is too much. Stop this—you should be ashamed of yourselves, my lords.

og: I have done.
t: I'm done.

og: And I.
t: So am I.

og: Then thus for you, my lord: it stands agreed,  I take it, by all voices, that forthwith  You be convey'd to the Tower a prisoner;
t: So as for you, my lord, I take it we've all agreed that you'll be taken immediately to the Tower as a prisoner.

og: There to remain till the king's further pleasure  Be known unto us: are you all agreed, lords?
t: You'll stay there as a prisoner until we know what the king wants. Have you all agreed, lords?

og: We are.
t: We have.

og: Is there no other way of mercy,But I must needs to the Tower, my lords?
t: Is there no other way? Do I have to go to the Tower, my lords?

og: What otherWould you expect? you are strangely troublesome.Let some o' the guard be ready there.
t: What other way do you expect? You're unusually annoying. Let's have some guards in here.

og: For me?Must I go like a traitor thither?
t: For me? Must I be led there like a traitor?

og: Receive him,And see him safe i' the Tower.
t: Take him and put him safely in the Tower.

og: Stay, good my lords,  I have a little yet to say. Look there, my lords;
t: Wait, my good lords, I still have a few things to say. Look here, my lords.

og: By virtue of that ring, I take my cause  Out of the gripes of cruel men, and give it  To a most noble judge, the king my master.
t: By the power of this ring, I take my cause out of the hands of cruel men and give it to a noble judge, the king my master.

og: This is the king's ring.
t: This is the king's ring.

og: 'Tis no counterfeit.
t: It's not a fake.

og: 'Tis the right ring, by heaven: I told ye all,When ye first put this dangerous stone a-rolling,'Twould fall upon ourselves.
t: That's the ring, by heaven. I told you when you started this dangerous business that it would backfire on us.

og: Do you think, my lords,The king will suffer but the little fingerOf this man to be vex'd?
t: My lords, do you think the king will allow even this man's little finger to get hurt?

og: 'Tis now too certain:How much more is his life in value with him?Would I were fairly out on't!
t: Now it's all too clear. His life is worth so much more to the king than his little finger! I wish I had nothing to do with this!

og: My mind gave me,  In seeking tales and informations  Against this man, whose honesty the devil  And his disciples only envy at,
t: I was already worried, looking for stories and information against this man who's so honest that the devil and his minions can only envy him, not hurt him.

og: Ye blew the fire that burns ye: now have at ye!
t: You're the reason I'm in trouble now, damn you!

og: Dread sovereign, how much are we bound to heaven  In daily thanks, that gave us such a prince;  Not only good and wise, but most religious:
t: Powerful king, we're so grateful every day to God for giving us a king like you! You're not just good and wise, but very religious.

og: One that, in all obedience, makes the church  The chief aim of his honour; and, to strengthen  That holy duty, out of dear respect,
t: You're someone who obediently works for the good of the church. And, to strengthen that holy tie between the king and the church,

og: His royal self in judgment comes to hear  The cause betwixt her and this great offender.
t: you come yourself as a judge to hear the case between it and this terrible criminal.

og: You were ever good at sudden commendations,  Bishop of Winchester. But know, I come not  To hear such flattery now, and in my presence;  They are too thin and bare to hide offences.
t: You were always good at sudden flattery, Bishop of Winchester. But I haven't come to be flattered to my face like that now. That flattery is too thin and bare to hide crimes behind.

og: To me you cannot reach, you play the spaniel,  And think with wagging of your tongue to win me;  But, whatsoe'er thou takest me for, I'm sure  Thou hast a cruel nature and a bloody.
t: You can't reach me like that. You act like a dog and think wagging your tongue will win me over. But, whatever you take me for, I'm sure you have a cruel and bloody nature.

og: [To CRANMER]  Good man, sit down. Now let me see the proudest  He, that dares most, but wag his finger at thee:
t: [To CRANMER] Sit down, you good man. Now let me just see a man arrogant enough even just to wag his finger at you.

og: By all that's holy, he had better starve  Than but once think this place becomes thee not.
t: By everything that's holy, he would be better off starving to death than even thinking once that you don't deserve to sit here.

og: May it please your grace,—
t: Please, your grace—

og: No, sir, it does not please me.  I had thought I had had men of some understanding  And wisdom of my council; but I find none.  Was it discretion, lords, to let this man,  This good man,—few of you deserve that title,—
t: No, sir, it does not please me. I thought I had men of some intelligence and wisdom on my council, but I can't see any. Was it wise, lords, to let this man, this good man—few of you deserve that title—

og: This honest man, wait like a lousy footboy  At chamber—door? and one as great as you are?  Why, what a shame was this! Did my commission  Bid ye so far forget yourselves?
t: this honest man, wait like a lice-covered servant at the door? A man as important as you are? What a shameful thing to do! Did I give you permission to do something so unworthy of you?

og: I gave ye  Power as he was a counsellor to try him,  Not as a groom:
t: I gave you power to try his case as a councilor, not a servant.

og: there's some of ye, I see,  More out of malice than integrity,  Would try him to the utmost, had ye mean;  Which ye shall never have while I live.
t: There are some of you, I see, who would give him the death penalty if you could, more out of resentment than honesty. You will never be able to do that while I am alive.

og: Thus far,  My most dread sovereign, may it like your grace  To let my tongue excuse all.
t: My extremely powerful king, please let me tell you our excuses.

og: What was purposed  Concerning his imprisonment, was rather,  If there be faith in men, meant for his trial,  And fair purgation to the world, than malice,  I'm sure, in me.
t: We meant to imprison him more, I swear, because we needed to try him and show that we had done so fairly, than out of resentment—at least on my part, I'm sure.

og: Well, well, my lords, respect him;  Take him, and use him well, he's worthy of it.  I will say thus much for him, if a prince  May be beholding to a subject, I  Am, for his love and service, so to him.
t: All right, my lords, respect him. Take him and treat him well—he deserves it. I will say this much for him: if a prince can owe anything to a subject, I owe him for his love and service to me.

og: Make me no more ado, but all embrace him:  Be friends, for shame, my lords! My Lord of  Canterbury,  I have a suit which you must not deny me;
t: Don't make any more fuss, but hug him, all of you. Be friends, my lords, honestly! My Lord of Canterbury, I have a request you can't deny.

og: That is, a fair young maid that yet wants baptism,  You must be godfather, and answer for her.
t: That is, there's a beautiful young girl who still needs to be baptized. You must be her godfather in the ceremony.

og: The greatest monarch now alive may gloryIn such an honour: how may I deserve itThat am a poor and humble subject to you?
t: The greatest king alive would be proud of this honor. How can I deserve it, when I am just a poor, humble, subject of yours?

og: Come, come, my lord, you'ld spare your spoons: you  shall have two noble partners with you; the old  Duchess of Norfolk, and Lady Marquess Dorset:
t: Come, come, my lord, you just don't want to pay for a gift. There will be two other nobles as godparents too: the old Duchess of Norfolk and Lady Marquess Dorset.

og: will  these please you?  Once more, my Lord of Winchester, I charge you,  Embrace and love this man.
t: Do they sound good to you? Once more, my Lord of Winchester, I command you to hug and love this man.

og: With a true heartAnd brother-love I do it.
t: I do it with an honest heart and brotherly love.

og: And let heavenWitness, how dear I hold this confirmation.
t: Let God be my witness that I am very happy about this confirmation of friendship.

og: Good man, those joyful tears show thy true heart:  The common voice, I see, is verified  Of thee, which says thus, 'Do my Lord of Canterbury  A shrewd turn, and he is your friend for ever.'
t: Good man, your happy tears show your honesty. I see that everyone is right in saying about you, "Do a favor for my Lord of Canterbury and he will be your friend forever."

og: Come, lords, we trifle time away; I long  To have this young one made a Christian.  As I have made ye one, lords, one remain;  So I grow stronger, you more honour gain.
t: Come on, lords, we're wasting time. I can't wait for this young one to be made a Christian. Now that I've united all of you, lords, stay that way. That'll make me stronger and you more honorable.

og: You'll leave your noise anon, ye rascals: do youtake the court for Paris-garden? ye rude slaves,leave your gaping.
t: Stop this noise now, you jerks. Do you think the court is a public amusement park? You rude slaves, shut your mouths.

og: Good master porter, I belong to the larder.
t: Mister porter, I work in the kitchen.

og: Belong to the gallows, and be hanged, ye rogue! is  this a place to roar in? Fetch me a dozen crab-tree  staves, and strong ones:
t: Work in a noose and be hanged, you rogue! Is this somewhere to roar? Get me a dozen wooden poles, and strong ones.

og: these are but switches to  'em. I'll scratch your heads: you must be seeing  christenings? do you look for ale and cakes here,  you rude rascals?
t: These ones are just twigs compared to those. I'll scratch your heads. You insist on seeing baptisms? Do you expect beer and cake here, you rude jerks?

og: Pray, sir, be patient: 'tis as much impossible—  Unless we sweep 'em from the door with cannons—
t: Please sir, calm down. It's impossible—unless we blast them away from the door with cannons—

og: To scatter 'em, as 'tis to make 'em sleep  On May-day morning; which will never be:  We may as well push against Powle's, as stir em.
t: to make them go away, as impossible as making them sleep on May-day morning. That will never happen. We might as well be pushing against St. Paul's cathedral, they'll be just as hard to move.

og: How got they in, and be hang'd?
t: How did they get in, damn you?

og: Alas, I know not; how gets the tide in?
t: I don't know. How does the tide get in?

og: You did nothing, sir.
t: You did nothing, sir.

og: I am not Samson, nor Sir Guy, nor Colbrand,  To mow 'em down before me:
t: I'm not a hero like Samson or Sir Guy or Colbrand. I couldn't mow them down in front of me.

og: but if I spared any  That had a head to hit, either young or old,  He or she, cuckold or cuckold-maker,
t: I didn't refrain from hitting anyone's head, young or old, man or woman, anyone with an unfaithful wife or anyone cheating with someone else's wife.

og: Let me ne'er hope to see a chine again  And that I would not for a cow, God save her!
t: If I did, let me never see meat again, and I wouldn't make that bargain in exchange for a cow, God bless it!

og: I shall be with you presently, good master puppy.Keep the door close, sirrah.
t: I'll be with you soon, mister dog. Keep the door closed, you.

og: What would you have me do?
t: What do you want me to do?

og: What should you do, but knock 'em down by the  dozens? Is this Moorfields to muster in? or have  we some strange Indian with the great tool come to  court, the women so besiege us?
t: What would you do except knock them down by the dozens? Is this a public field to meet in? Or do we have some strange Indian with a huge tool visiting court to make the women attack us like this?

og: Bless me, what a  fry of fornication is at door! On my Christian  conscience, this one christening will beget a  thousand; here will be father, godfather, and all together.
t: Bless me, what a fornicating mob is at the door! On my Christian conscience, this one baptism will cause a thousand more. Here are the future fathers and godfathers all gathered together.

og: The spoons will be the bigger, sir. There is a  fellow somewhat near the door, he should be a  brazier by his face, for, o' my conscience, twenty  of the dog-days now reign in's nose; all that stand  about him are under the line,
t: The presents will be all the bigger, sir. There's a fellow kind of near the door. I think he's a smith from his face, because his face looks as hot as the dog days of summer. Everyone standing around him is in the southern hemisphere.

og: they need no other  penance: that fire-drake did I hit three times on  the head, and three times was his nose discharged  against me; he stands there, like a mortar-piece, to  blow us.
t: They don't need to burn in hell because they're already in it. I hit that dragon three times on the head and three times his nose was discharged at me. He stands there like a bomb ready to blow us up.

og: There was a haberdasher's wife of small  wit near him, that railed upon me till her pinked  porringer fell off her head, for kindling such a  combustion in the state.
t: There was a dumb clothes-seller's wife near him who shouted at me until her hat, which looked like a decorated bowl, fell off her head, for starting such a fire in the country.

og: I missed the meteor once,  and hit that woman; who cried out 'Clubs!' when I  might see from far some forty truncheoners draw to  her succor, which were the hope o' the Strand, where  she was quartered.
t: I missed the meteor-like man once and hit that woman. She cried out "clubs!" and I could see about forty people with clubs run to help her. They were the best hope in the Strand, where she was.

og: They fell on; I made good my  place: at length they came to the broom-staff to  me; I defied 'em still: when suddenly a file of  boys behind 'em, loose shot, delivered such a shower  of pebbles,
t: They attacked. I defended myself. Finally they were hitting me and I kept defying them. Suddenly, a group of boys behind them threw such a number of pebbles

og: that I was fain to draw mine honour in,  and let 'em win the work: the devil was amongst  'em, I think, surely.
t: that I had to let them win the battle. The devil was fighting with them, for sure.

og: These are the youths that thunder at a playhouse,  and fight for bitten apples; that no audience, but  the tribulation of Tower-hill, or the limbs of  Limehouse, their dear brothers, are able to endure.
t: Those are the boys who make such noise at a play and fight for bitten apples. No audience except the worst ones at Tower-hill or the similar ones at Limehouse can stand them.

og: I have some of 'em in Limbo Patrum, and there they  are like to dance these three days; besides the  running banquet of two beadles that is to come.
t: I have some of them locked up and they'll stay there for three days. And the noise will be worse when the officials meant to keep the peace arrive.

og: Mercy o' me, what a multitude are here!  They grow still too; from all parts they are coming,  As if we kept a fair here! Where are these porters,  These lazy knaves? Ye have made a fine hand, fellows:
t: Lord, what a crowd is here! It's still growing, too. They're coming from everywhere as if this were a fair! Where are those porters, those lazy good-for-nothings? You've done well, fellows.

og: There's a trim rabble let in: are all these  Your faithful friends o' the suburbs? We shall have  Great store of room, no doubt, left for the ladies,  When they pass back from the christening.
t: You've let in a nice crowd. Are these all your good friends from town? No doubt we'll have plenty of room left for the ladies when they come back from the baptism.

og: An't please  your honour,  We are but men;
t: Your honor, we're only human.

og: and what so many may do,  Not being torn a-pieces, we have done:  An army cannot rule 'em.
t: And we've done what two men can do without being torn to pieces. An army couldn't stop them.

og: As I live,  If the king blame me for't, I'll lay ye all  By the heels, and suddenly; and on your heads  Clap round fines for neglect: ye are lazy knaves;
t: I swear if the king blames me for it, I'll knock you over immediately. And I'll fine you for neglecting your jobs. You're lazy good-for-nothings.

og: And here ye lie baiting of bombards, when  Ye should do service. Hark! the trumpets sound;  They're come already from the christening:
t: You lie here drinking when you should be working. Listen! The trumpets are sounding. They've already come from the baptism.

og: Go, break among the press, and find a way out  To let the troop pass fairly; or I'll find  A Marshalsea shall hold ye play these two months.
t: Go on, make a break in the crowd to let them pass. Or I'll find a jail to hold you for two months.

og: Make way there for the princess.
t: Make room for the princess.

og: You great fellow,Stand close up, or I'll make your head ache.
t: You big fellow, make room or I'll make your head ache.

og: You i' the camlet, get up o' the rail;I'll peck you o'er the pales else.
t: You in the camel-hair cloth, get on the fence or I'll throw you over it.

og: Heaven, from thy endless goodness, send prosperouslife, long, and ever happy, to the high and mightyprincess of England, Elizabeth!
t: From your endless supply of goodness, God, send a lucky, long, and happy life to the powerful princess of England, Elizabeth!

og: [Kneeling]  And to your royal grace, and the good queen,  My noble partners, and myself, thus pray:
t: [Kneeling] Your grace, you, the good queen, my noble fellow-godparents, and I pray in this way:

og: All comfort, joy, in this most gracious lady,  Heaven ever laid up to make parents happy,  May hourly fall upon ye!
t: may heaven give you all the comfort and joy in this princess that ever made parents happy every hour!

og: Thank you, good lord archbishop:What is her name?
t: Thank you, lord archbishop. What is her name?

og: Elizabeth.
t: Elizabeth.

og: Stand up, lord.
t: Stand up, lord.

og: With this kiss take my blessing: God protect thee!Into whose hand I give thy life.
t: Take my blessing with this kiss. May God protect you! I trust him to keep you safe.

og: Amen.
t: Amen.

og: My noble gossips, ye have been too prodigal:I thank ye heartily; so shall this lady,When she has so much English.
t: My noble friends, you have been too generous. Thank you very much. This girl will thank you too when she learns enough English.

og: Let me speak, sir,  For heaven now bids me; and the words I utter  Let none think flattery, for they'll find 'em truth.  This royal infant—heaven still move about her!—
t: Let me speak, sir, because now God tells me to. I hope no one thinks that the words I say are flattery, because they'll find them to be true. This royal child—may God be with her always!—

og: Though in her cradle, yet now promises  Upon this land a thousand thousand blessings,  Which time shall bring to ripeness: she shall be—  But few now living can behold that goodness—
t: although still a baby, promises to bring a thousand, thousand blessings to this country in time. She will be—few alive now will live to see this goodness—

og: A pattern to all princes living with her,  And all that shall succeed: Saba was never  More covetous of wisdom and fair virtue  Than this pure soul shall be:
t: an example for all the kings alive then, and all to come. This pure soul will have as much wisdom and virtue as the queen of Sheba wished for.

og: all princely graces,  That mould up such a mighty piece as this is,  With all the virtues that attend the good,  Shall still be doubled on her:
t: She'll have double all the royal qualities that go into making someone as powerful as this along with all the virtues that good people have.

og: truth shall nurse her,  Holy and heavenly thoughts still counsel her:  She shall be loved and fear'd: her own shall bless her;  Her foes shake like a field of beaten corn,  And hang their heads with sorrow: good grows with her:
t: Truth will raise her, holy and religious thoughts will advise her always, she will be loved and feared, her family and friends will bless her, her enemies will shake in fear like a field of beaten corn and hang their heads in sorrow. Goodness will grow as she grows.

og: In her days every man shall eat in safety,  Under his own vine, what he plants; and sing  The merry songs of peace to all his neighbours:  God shall be truly known;
t: In her life everyone will eat what he plants safely in his own field and sing the happy songs of peace to all his neighbors. God will be truly understood

og: and those about her  From her shall read the perfect ways of honour,  And by those claim their greatness, not by blood.  Nor shall this peace sleep with her:
t: and those around her will learn how to be honorable from her and will be great because of that, not because they come from good families. Nor will this peace die with her.

og: but as when  The bird of wonder dies, the maiden phoenix,  Her ashes new create another heir,  As great in admiration as herself;
t: But like when that amazing bird, the virgin phoenix, dies, a new heir as amazing as she was will be born from her ashes.

og: So shall she leave her blessedness to one,  When heaven shall call her from this cloud of darkness,  Who from the sacred ashes of her honour  Shall star-like rise, as great in fame as she was,  And so stand fix'd:
t: So someone will inherit her blessings who will rise like a star from the holy ashes of her honor and stay firmly in the sky when heaven calls her from this dark cloud, the earth.

og: peace, plenty, love, truth, terror,  That were the servants to this chosen infant,  Shall then be his, and like a vine grow to him:
t: Peace, plenty, love, truth, terror, which served this chosen baby, will belong to him and grow on him like a vine.

og: Wherever the bright sun of heaven shall shine,  His honour and the greatness of his name  Shall be, and make new nations:
t: Wherever the bright sun shines, his honor and the greatness of his name will be found and will create new countries.

og: he shall flourish,  And, like a mountain cedar, reach his branches  To all the plains about him: our children's children  Shall see this, and bless heaven.
t: He will grow and, like  a tree on a mountain, reach his branches over all the plains around him. Our children's children will see this and bless God.

og: Thou speakest wonders.
t: You say amazing things.

og: She shall be, to the happiness of England,  An aged princess; many days shall see her,  And yet no day without a deed to crown it.
t: She will live to be an old queen and make England happy. She will live many days and do a great deed on every one.

og: Would I had known no more! but she must die,  She must, the saints must have her; yet a virgin,  A most unspotted lily shall she pass  To the ground, and all the world shall mourn her.
t: I wish I knew nothing more! But she must die, she must, the saints must have her. Still a virgin, a pure flower, she will fall to the ground and the whole world will miss her.

og: O lord archbishop,  Thou hast made me now a man! never, before  This happy child, did I get any thing:
t: Oh, lord archbishop, now you've made me a man! It's like I never made anything before I conceived this happy child.

og: This oracle of comfort has so pleased me,  That when I am in heaven I shall desire  To see what this child does, and praise my Maker.  I thank ye all.
t: This comforting prophecy has pleased me so much that when I am in heaven I will want to see what this child does, and praise God. I thank you all.

og: To you, my good lord mayor,  And your good brethren, I am much beholding;  I have received much honour by your presence,  And ye shall find me thankful. Lead the way, lords:
t: I am very thankful to you, my good lord mayor, and your good companions. You have done me a lot of honor in being here and I will repay you. Lead the way, lords.

og: Ye must all see the queen, and she must thank ye,  She will be sick else. This day, no man think  Has business at his house; for all shall stay:  This little one shall make it holiday.
t: You must all see the queen and she must thank you or she will be sick. Today, no one should think he has to go home. Everyone will stay. It's a holiday because of this little one.

og: 'Tis ten to one this play can never please  All that are here: some come to take their ease,  And sleep an act or two; but those, we fear,  We have frighted with our trumpets;
t: It's almost certain that this play can't please everyone here. Some have come to relax and sleep for an act or two. But I'm afraid we've frightened those people with our trumpets.

og: so, 'tis clear,  They'll say 'tis naught: others, to hear the city  Abused extremely, and to cry 'That's witty!'  Which we have not done neither:
t: So of course they'll say the play's worthless. Others came to hear the city insulted and to cry out, "That's witty!" and we haven't done that either.

og: that, I fear,  All the expected good we're like to hear  For this play at this time, is only in  The merciful construction of good women;
t: So I fear the only good we'll hear about this play for now is from good women who like it because we've showed them a good woman.

og: For such a one we show'd 'em: if they smile,  And say 'twill do, I know, within a while  All the best men are ours; for 'tis ill hap,  If they hold when their ladies bid 'em clap.
t: If they smile and say it'll do, I know that all the best men will be on our side. Because it won't do them any good not to clap when their wives tell them to.

og: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
t: Stop trying to convince me, enamored Proteus!

og: Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
t: Young people who always stay at home are very dull.

og: Were't not affection chains thy tender days  To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,
t: If love didn't keep you here—chaining you to your beloved's sweet looks—

og: I rather would entreat thy company  To see the wonders of the world abroad,
t: I would ask you to join me, so you can see the wonders of the world abroad.

og: Than, living dully sluggardized at home,
t: That's better than to live in a dull way, being lazy at home

og: Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
t: and wasting your youth by doing nothing.

og: But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,  Even as I would when I to love begin.
t: But since you're in love, continue to love and let your love grow. I'll do the same when I fall in love.

og: Wilt thou be gone?  Sweet Valentine, adieu!
t: Are you going, then? Sweet Valentine, goodbye!

og: Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest  Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
t: Don't forget your Proteus, when you happen upon some special, remarkable object on your travels.

og: Wish me partaker in thy happiness  When thou dost meet good hap;
t: Let me be a part of your happiness, when you stumble upon good luck.

og: and in thy danger,  If ever danger do environ thee,  Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,  For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.
t: And when you are in danger—if you ever are surrounded by trouble—direct your unhappiness to me, and I will pray for you, Valentine.

og: And on a love-book pray for my success?
t: And will you swear on the Book of Love that you'll pray for my success?

og: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.
t: I swear I'll pray for you, on some book I love.

og: That's on some shallow story of deep love:How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.
t: That book would contain a silly story of deep love; about young Leander swimming across the Hellespont.

og: That's a deep story of a deeper love:For he was more than over shoes in love.
t: That's a deep story of even a deeper love, since he was head over heels in love.

og: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,And yet you never swum the Hellespont.
t: That's true. You, though, are head over boots in love, and yet you have never swum to Hellespont.

og: Over the boots? Nay, give me not the boots.
t: I am head over boots in love? No, don't make fun of me.

og: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.
t: No, I won't, because it doesn't help me in any way.

og: What?
t: What do you mean?

og: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans;  Coy looks with heart-sore sighs;  one fading moment's mirth  With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:
t: To be in love means to court rejection with moans; provoke disdainful looks with sorrowful sighs; and exchange one disappearing moment of happiness for twenty wakeful, tired, and exhausted nights.

og: If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain;  If lost, why then a grievous labour won;
t: If love is won by luck, perhaps it's an unlucky gain. If love is lost, then it was good for nothing except sadness and toil.

og: However, but a folly bought with wit,  Or else a wit by folly vanquished.
t: No matter the situation, love is merely foolishness bought with wisdom—or otherwise wisdom crushed by foolishness.

og: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.
t: So, judging from this elaborate speech, you're calling me a fool.

og: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.
t: So, judging from your situation, I'm afraid you are a fool.

og: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.
t: You're complain about love. But I am not Love himself.

og: Love is your master, for he masters you:
t: Love is your master and he has power over you.

og: And he that is so yoked by a fool,  Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.
t: And I think we should not consider anyone wise who is totally controlled by a fool.

og: Yet writers say,
t: Yet writers say that

og: as in the sweetest bud  The eating canker dwells,
t: the worm survives by feeding off the sweetest bud, destroying the whole plant.

og: so eating love  Inhabits in the finest wits of all.
t: So consuming love makes one live in the best sense of them all.

og: And writers say, as the most forward bud  Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,
t: And writers also say that—as the worm eats the most tender bud before it blooms—

og: Even so by love the young and tender wit  Is turn'd to folly,
t: so too does love turn young and vulnerable wit into foolishness.

og: blasting in the bud,  Losing his verdure even in the prime  And all the fair effects of future hopes.
t: With love wearing down the bud, wit loses its green freshness, even in its prime—and along with it all the promise of future hopes.

og: But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,  That art a votary to fond desire?
t: But why am I wasting my time here, advising you—a devoted worshiper to foolish desire?

og: Once more adieu!  My father at the road  Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd  .
t: Once more, goodbye! My father expects my arrival at the harbor, where I will board a ship.

og: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.
t: I'll take you there, Valentine.

og: Sweet Proteus, no;  now let us take our leave.  To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
t: No, kind Proteus. Let's say goodbye now. Write me letters when I'm in Milan.

og: Of thy success in love, and what news else  Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
t: Write to me about your success in love, and other news while your friend is gone.

og: And likewise will visit thee with mine.
t: And my letters will be similarly full of news.

og: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!
t: I hope only that you'll find only happiness in Milan!

og: As much to you at home! And so, farewell.
t: And I hope you will only have happiness here at home! And so, goodbye.

og: He after honour hunts, I after love:
t: He pursues honor, and I pursue love.

og: He leaves his friends to dignify them more,  I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.
t: He leaves his friends to honor them more. And I abandon myself, my friends, and everything—all for the sake of love.

og: Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,
t: Julia, you have changed me completely.

og: Made me neglect my studies,  lose my time,  War with good counsel,  set the world at nought;  Made wit with musing weak,  heart sick with thought.
t: You've made me neglect my studies; waste my time; combat good advice; think nothing of the world; exhaust my wits with wondering; and sicken my heart with thinking!

og: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?
t: God save you, Sir Proteus! Have you seen my master Valentine?

og: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.
t: He just left here, to set off for Milan.

og: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.
t: I bet twenty to one that he is on board the ship already, and I have played the sheep by losing him.

og: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,An if the shepherd be a while away.
t: Indeed, a sheep wanders very often, if the shepherd is away for a while.

og: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,and I a sheep?
t: You agree that my master is a shepherd, then? And I am a sheep?

og: I do.
t: I do.

og: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.
t: Well then, since he owns me, my horns belong to him—whether I am awake or asleep.

og: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.
t: That's a silly answer, suitable for a sheep.

og: This proves me still a sheep.
t: This proves that I am still a sheep.

og: True; and thy master a shepherd.
t: True, and your master is a shepherd.

og: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.
t: No, I can deny that with a logical argument.

og: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.
t: Well, it may be a challenge, but I can prove it by another argument.

og: The shepherd seeks the sheep,  and not the sheep the  shepherd;
t: The shepherd looks for the sheep; the sheep doesn't look for its shepherd.

og: but I seek my master,  and my master seeks  not me:  therefore I am no sheep.
t: But I look for my master, and my master does not look for me. That's why I'm not a sheep.

og: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd;
t: The sheep will follow the shepherd because the shepherd is the one who feeds the sheep.

og: the  shepherd for food follows not the sheep:
t: The shepherd doesn't follow the sheep to be fed.

og: thou for  wages followest thy master;  thy master for wages  follows not thee:
t: You follow your master because he pays you. Your master does not follow you, because you don't pay him.

og: therefore thou art a sheep.
t: That's why you are a sheep.

og: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'
t: Such an explanation makes me want to say "baa."

og: But, dost thou hear? Gavest thou my letter to Julia?
t: But tell me: did you give my letter to Julia?

og: Ay sir:  I, a lost mutton,  gave your letter to her,  a laced mutton,
t: Yes sir. I, a lost sheep, gave your letter to her, a prostitute wearing a tightly laced bodice.

og: and she, a laced mutton,  gave me, a  lost mutton, nothing for my labour.
t: And she, this prostitute, gave me, a lost sheep, nothing for my work.

og: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.
t: This field is not big enough for such a great quantity of sheep.

og: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.
t: If the ground is overcrowded, you'd better slaughter her.

og: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.
t: No, you are wandering into error there. It would be best if we confined you in a dog pound.

og: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me forcarrying your letter.
t: No, sir. I shall get less than a pound for delivering your letter.

og: You mistake; I mean the pound,—a pinfold.
t: You are mistaken. I mean the pound—an animal pen.

og: From a pound to a pin?  Fold it over and over,
t: From a pound to a pin? Multiply and fold it over and over,

og: 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to  your lover.
t: and it's three times too little for carrying a letter to your lover.

og: But what said she?
t: But what did she say?

og: Ay.
t: Yes.

og: Nod—Ay—why, that's noddy.
t: Nodding—yes—well, he's a fool.

og: You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you askme if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'
t: You misunderstood me, sir. I am saying that she nodded. And you asked me if she nodded, and I said: "Yes."

og: And that set together is noddy.
t: Everything you just said makes you an ever bigger fool.

og: Now you have taken the pains to set it together,take it for your pains.
t: Now that you have taken trouble to put it together, have it as a reward for the trouble you have taken.

og: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.
t: No, no. You will take it for bringing the letter to her.

og: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.
t: Well, it looks like I must be obliged to put up with you.

og: Why sir, how do you bear with me?
t: How do you put up with me, sir?

og: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothingbut the word 'noddy' for my pains.
t: Indeed, sir, I'll take the letter very dutifully, since I've gotten nothing in exchange for my efforts besides being called a "fool."

og: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.
t: The devil take me, you are quick-witted!

og: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.
t: And yet my wit cannot be quicker than your hesitation to pay me.

og: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?
t: Come, come: reveal the information. What did she say?

og: Open your purse, that the money and the matter maybe both at once delivered.
t: Open your purse, so that the money and the information can be delivered both at once.

og: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?
t: Well, sir, here is for your trouble.  What did she say?

og: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.
t: Really, sir, I think you won't be able to win her that easily.

og: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?
t: How could you understand so much from her?

og: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her;  no,  not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:
t: Sir, I received nothing from her at all. No, I did not even get a gold coin from her for delivering your letter.

og: and being so hard to me that brought your mind,  I  fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your  mind.
t: And since she was so hard on me—the person who only conveyed your feelings to her—I am afraid she will be as hard on you when you tell her about your feelings yourself.

og: Give her no token but stones;  for she's as  hard as steel.
t: Don't give her any gifts but jewels, since she is as hard as steel.

og: What said she? Nothing?
t: What did she say? Nothing?

og: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.'
t: No, not as much as "Take this for your troubles."

og: To  testify your bounty, I thank you,  you have testerned  me  ;
t: I tip my hat to you for your generosity, since you've given me a tip.

og: in requital whereof,  henceforth carry your  letters yourself  : and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.
t: And in return for my good word, you should carry your letters yourself. And so sir, I'll speak well of you to my master.

og: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,
t: Go, go! Go away to save your ship from a shipwreck—

og: Which cannot perish having thee aboard,  Being destined to a drier death on shore.
t: it can't sink as long as you're on board, because you're destined to hang. You'll have a drier death on shore.

og: I must go send some better messenger:
t: I must go and send a better messenger.

og: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,  Receiving them from such a worthless post.
t: I am afraid my Julia won't accept my letter if she receives it from such a worthless idiot.

og: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?
t: Now that we're alone, tell me, Lucetta: would you advise me to fall in love?

og: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.
t: Yes, madam. Provided that you won't have sex carelessly.

og: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen  That every day with parle encounter me,
t: Out of the group of  beautiful gentlemen that talk to me every day,

og: In thy opinion  which  is worthiest love?
t: which man do you think deserves my love the most?

og: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mindAccording to my shallow simple skill.
t: Could you please repeat their names? I'll reveal what I think as my shallow, simple skill allows.

og: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?
t: What do you think of the handsome Sir Eglamour?

og: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;But, were I you, he never should be mine.
t: For a knight, he's well-spoken, elegant, and refined. But if I were you, I'd never have him.

og: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?
t: What do you think of the rich Mercatio?

og: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.
t: I think well of his money. But him? I think he's just so-so.

og: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?
t: What do you think of the noble Proteus?

og: Lord, Lord! To see what folly reigns in us!
t: Oh God, oh God! We are ruled by such foolishness.

og: How now! What means this passion at his name?
t: What? Why such an outburst of passion at the sound of his name?

og: Pardon, dear madam:
t: Excuse me, dear madam.

og: 'tis a passing shame
t: It's very shameful

og: That I,  unworthy body as I am,
t: for an unworthy person like myself

og: Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.
t: to pass judgment in this way on lovely gentlemen like him.

og: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?
t: Why not judge Proteus like we have judged all the others?

og: Then thus: of many good I think him best.
t: Well, it's like this: I think he is the best one of them all.

og: Your reason?
t: Why do you think that?

og: I have no other, but a woman's reason;I think him so because I think him so.
t: My reasoning is simply a woman's reasoning. I think he is the best simply because I think he is.

og: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?
t: And would you have me give my love to him?

og: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.
t: Yes, if you thought your love wouldn't be wasted on him.

og: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.
t: It's interesting that, out of all of them, he has never wooed me.

og: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.
t: Yet I think that, out of all of them, he loves you the most.

og: His little speaking shows his love but small.
t: He gives very few words on the subject; this shows his love is small.

og: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.
t: Fire that's the closest to us burns the hottest.

og: They do not love that do not show their love.
t: You can't love if you don't show your love.

og: O, they love least that let men know their love.
t: Oh, those who let men know about their love are the ones who love the least.

og: I would I knew his mind.
t: If only I knew what he's thinking.

og: Peruse this paper, madam.
t: Read this paper here, madam.

og: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?
t: It says "To Julia." Tell me, who is this from?

og: That the contents will show.
t: The contents of the letter will reveal that.

og: Say, say, who gave it thee?
t: Tell me, tell me, who gave it to you?

og: Valentine's page;  and sent, I think, from Proteus.  He would have given it you;
t: Valentine's servant. And I think it was sent from Proteus. He would have given it to you himself.

og: but I, being in the way,  Did in your name receive it:  pardon the  fault I pray.
t: But since I happened to meet him, I took the letter on your behalf. I am sorry if I did the wrong thing.

og: Now, by my modesty,   a goodly broker!  Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?  To whisper and conspire against my youth?
t: I swear by my modesty that you're a good intermediary! Do you dare to presume to hang onto this passionate letter? To whisper and conspire against my young age?

og: Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth  And you an officer fit for the place.  There, take the paper; see it be returned,  Or else return no more into my sight.
t: Now, trust me, it's a powerful position, and you should be up for the challenge. There, take the letter, and make sure it gets a response, or don't ever let me set eyes on you again.

og: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.
t: To ask for love deserves a greater reward than to ask for hate.

og: Will ye be gone?
t: Will you leave?

og: That you may ruminate.
t: Yes, to give you some time to think about it.

og: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:  It were a shame to call her back again  And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
t: And yet, I wish I had read that letter! It would be a shame to call her back again, and beg her to carry out the mistake that I just scolded her for doing.

og: What a fool is she,  that knows I am a maid,  And would not force the letter to my view!
t: She is such a fool! She knows that I am a young girl, and still she would not force me to read the letter!

og: Since maids,  in modesty, say 'no' to that  Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
t: Young modest women say "no" when they want the hearer to understand they mean "yes."

og: Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love  That,  like a testy babe,  will scratch the nurse  And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
t: Ugh! This foolish love is so unreasonable that—like an irritable child—it will scratch its nurse and then immediately be obedient!

og: How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,  When willingly I would have had her here!
t: How roughly have I treated Lucetta there, when I would have wanted to have her here!

og: How angerly I taught my brow to frown,  When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!
t: How angrily I made myself frown, when an inside joy has made my heart smile!

og: My penance is to call Lucetta back  And ask remission for my folly past.  What ho! Lucetta!
t: I can only call Lucetta back to make up for it and to ask for her forgiveness for my recent foolishness. [To LUCETTA] Hello, Lucetta!

og: What would your ladyship?
t: What would you like, your Ladyship?

og: Is't near dinner-time?
t: Is it almost time for dinner?

og: I would it were,That you might kill your stomach on your meatAnd not upon your maid.
t: I wish it would be! That way, you could satisfy your appetite tearing into your meat, instead of tearing into your servant.

og: What is't that you took up so gingerly?
t: What did you just pick up so carefully?

og: Nothing.
t: Nothing.

og: Why didst thou stoop, then?
t: Why did you stoop down, then?

og: To take a paper up that I let fall.
t: To pick up a paper that I dropped.

og: And is that paper nothing?
t: And that paper is nothing?

og: Nothing concerning me.
t: Nothing that concerns me.

og: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.
t: Let it lie there for the people it's meant for.

og: Madam, it will not lie where it concernsUnless it have a false interpeter.
t: Madam, I won't let it lie here, in case someone who it's not meant for intercepts the letter.

og: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.
t: Some lover of yours has written you a love poem.

og: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.Give me a note: your ladyship can set.
t: So I may sing it to a melody, madam. Give me a starting note, your Ladyship, so this letter can be set to music.

og: As little by such toys as may be possible.Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'
t: I will indulge you in your joking as little as possible. You'd better sing it to the melody of "Light o' love."

og: It is too heavy for so light a tune.
t: Its content is too serious for such a light melody.

og: Heavy! Belike it hath some burden then?
t: Serious! Maybe it carries a heavy burden, then?

og: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.
t: Yes. And if it were melodious, you'd sing it.

og: And why not you?
t: And why wouldn't you?

og: I cannot reach so high.
t: I cannot sing at such a high pitch.

og: Let's see your song. How now, minion!
t: Let me see your song! Come on, you minx!

og: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:And yet methinks I do not like this tune.
t: Keep the melody going so you can finish the song. Although I don't like this melody.

og: You do not?
t: You don't?

og: No, madam; it is too sharp.
t: No, madam. It's too sharp.

og: You, minion, are too saucy.
t: You are too bold, minx.

og: Nay, now you are too flat  And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:
t: No, you are too blunt and spoil the harmony with a variation that's too harsh.

og: There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.
t: Your song should be filled with a sweet-sounding tenor.

og: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.
t: The middle point is drowned out by your uncontrolled bass voice.

og: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.
t: Yes, I am pretending to sing the male part as Proteus would.

og: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.Here is a coil with protestation!
t: I won't let this nonsense trouble me anymore. I'll make a fuss with this declaration of love!

og: Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:You would be fingering them, to anger me.
t: Leave me, and let the papers lie there. You would fiddle with picking up all the pieces, just to make me angry.

og: She makes it strange; but she would be best pleasedTo be so anger'd with another letter.
t: She pretends she doesn't care. But she would feel so happy to get angry over another letter.

og: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!  O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!
t: Ah, I wish I actually felt angry about the letter! Oh, hateful hands, you tore up such loving words!

og: Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey  And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
t: Harmful wasps, to feed on such sweet honey and use your sting to kill the bees that give it up!

og: I'll kiss each several paper for amends.  Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.'  Unkind Julia!
t: I'll kiss each scrap of the torn-up paper to make up for it. Look, here "kind Julia" is written. Cruel Julia!

og: As in revenge of thy ingratitude,  I throw thy name against the bruising stones,  Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
t: As if in revenge for your ungratefulness, I throw your name down on these harmful stones. And I trample scornfully all over your disdain.

og: And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'  Poor wounded name!  My bosom as a bed  Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd;  And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
t: And here "love-wounded Proteus" is written. Poor, wounded name! I shall keep the scrap of paper with your name on it near my heart, and so place a healing kiss on it.

og: But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.  Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away  Till I have found each letter in the letter,
t: Two or three times "Proteus" is written down. Be calm, good wind, don't blow away a word of this,

og: Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear  Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock  And throw it thence into the raging sea!
t: until I have found each letter in this letter. Except for my own name: you can carry that off in a whirlwind to a rugged scary cliff, and throw it from there into the raging sea!

og: Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,  'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,  To the sweet Julia:'  that I'll tear away.
t: Look, here in one line his name is written twice. "Poor, helpless Proteus, passionate Proteus, to the sweet Julia." I will tear that away.

og: And yet I will not, sith so prettily  He couples it to his complaining names.  Thus will I fold them one on another:  Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.
t: No wait, I won't, since he links my name so nicely to his lamenting name. So, I will fold them on one another. Now kiss, embrace, grapple, and do what you want.

og: Madam,Dinner is ready, and your father stays.
t: Madam: dinner is ready and your father is waiting.

og: Well, let us go.
t: Well, let's go.

og: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?
t: What? Will these papers just lie here then? Like sources of gossip?

og: If you respect them, best to take them up.
t: If you value them, you should pick them up.

og: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.
t: No, I was told off for dropping them. Yet they shouldn't lie here, or they'll catch a cold.

og: I see you have a month's mind to them.
t: I see you like them.

og: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see;I see things too, although you judge I wink.
t: Yes, madam, you can call it like you see it. I also see things, although I pretend that my eyes are closed.

og: Come, come; will't please you go?
t: Come, come. Will you please go?

og: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was thatWherewith my brother held you in the cloister?
t: Tell me, Panthino: what were you talking about so seriously with my brother in the cloister?

og: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.
t: It was about his nephew Proteus—your son.

og: Why, what of him?
t: What about him?

og: He wonder'd that your lordship  Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,  While other men, of slender reputation,  Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:
t: He was wondering why you had him spend his young days at home while other men—of less significant status—send their sons into the world.

og: Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;  Some to discover islands far away;  Some to the studious universities.
t: Some go to the wars, to try their luck there; some go to discover islands far away; some go to study at universities.

og: For any or for all these exercises,  He said that Proteus your son was meet,  And did request me to importune you  To let him spend his time no more at home,
t: He said that Proteus is fit for any and all of these tasks, and he asked me to urge you to not have him spend any more time at home.

og: Which would be great impeachment to his age,  In having known no travel in his youth.
t: That would be a great discredit to him when he's older, since he wouldn't have traveled in his younger days.

og: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that  Whereon this month I have been hammering.
t: And you don't need to urge me to do what I've already been thinking about doing all month.

og: I have consider'd well his loss of time  And how he cannot be a perfect man,  Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:
t: I have considered how he's losing time, and how he can't be a fully-experienced man if he isn't tested and tutored abroad.

og: Experience is by industry achieved  And perfected by the swift course of time.
t: Experience is achieved by activity, and perfected by the quick passing of time.

og: Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?
t: So, where do you think I should send him?

og: I think your lordship is not ignorantHow his companion, youthful Valentine,Attends the emperor in his royal court.
t: I think your Lordship is aware that Proteus' friend—the young Valentine—is waiting on the Duke of Milan in his royal court.

og: I know it well.
t: I know about that.

og: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:  There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,  Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen.
t: I think it would be good to send him there, your Lordship. There, he can take part in jousts and tournaments; hear elegant conversation; and speak with noblemen.

og: And be in eye of every exercise  Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.
t: And he can see for himself every task worthy of his youth and noble social status.

og: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:  And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,  The execution of it shall make known.
t: I like your advice; you have given a good recommendation. And you can see just how much I liked your counsel; I will make it happen.

og: Even with the speediest expedition  I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.
t: I will send him to the emperor's court with the fastest haste.

og: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,  With other gentlemen of good esteem,
t: Don Alphonso, let him go tomorrow, if you like. He can go with other respected gentlemen

og: Are journeying to salute the emperor  And to commend their service to his will.
t: who are already planning to travel there in order to pay their respects to the emperor, and to commit their services to him.

og: Good company; with them shall Proteus go:And, in good time! Now will we break with him.
t: Good company! Proteus will go with them. And just at the right moment! I will tell him now.

og: Sweet love! Sweet lines! Sweet life!
t: Sweet love! Sweet lines! Sweet life!

og: Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
t: Here is her handwriting—her heart's representative.

og: Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn.
t: Here is her promise of love—her honor's pledge.

og: O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,  To seal our happiness with their consents!  O heavenly Julia!
t: Oh, I hope that our fathers will be happy with our love, and accept our happiness by approving our relationship.  Oh, heavenly Julia!

og: How now! What letter are you reading there?
t: What's all this? What letter are you reading?

og: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two  Of commendations sent from Valentine,
t: If it's all right with your Lordship, it's a word or two of greeting sent from Valentine,

og: Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.
t: delivered by one of his friends who came from him.

og: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.
t: Give me the letter. Let me see what news it brings.

og: There is no news, my lord,
t: There is no news, my lord!

og: but that he writes  How happily he lives, how well beloved  And daily graced by the emperor;
t: He only writes how happily he lives in Milan; how he is well-loved; and how the emperor shows Valentine his favor every day.

og: Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.
t: He wishes I were there with him, to share in his good fortune.

og: And how stand you affected to his wish?
t: And what do you think of his wish?

og: As one relying on your lordship's willAnd not depending on his friendly wish.
t: I rely on what you tell me to do, your Lordship. I don't depend upon his friendly wish.

og: My will is something sorted with his wish.  Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;  For what I will, I will, and there an end.
t: My wish is somewhat in agreement with his wish. Don't wonder why I decided so suddenly. Because I will have what I want—and that's that.

og: I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time  With Valentinus in the emperor's court:
t: I have decided that you will spend some time with Valentine in the emperor's court.

og: What maintenance he from his friends receives,  Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
t: I'll give you the same amount of money that he gets for allowance from his relatives.

og: To-morrow be in readiness to go:  Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.
t: Be ready to go tomorrow. Make no excuses, because it's already decided.

og: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:Please you, deliberate a day or two.
t: My lord, I can't be ready that soon. Please, let me have a day or two more.

og: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:
t: Look, anything you're missing will be sent to you after you go.

og: No more of stay!  To-morrow thou must go.
t: No further talk of lingering around here! You must go tomorrow.

og: Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd  To hasten on his expedition.
t: [To PANTHINO] Come on, Panthino. You will make sure that this expedition is hastened.

og: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,  And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.
t: And so I have avoided the fire, because I was afraid I'd burn. And I avoided being drenched in the sea, where I would drown.

og: I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,  Lest he should take exceptions to my love;  And with the vantage of mine own excuse  Hath he excepted most against my love.
t: I was scared to show Julia's letter to my father because he would have made objections to my love. And with the benefit of my own excuse about Valentine sending me this letter, my father has caused the greatest obstacle to my love.

og: O, how this spring of love resembleth  The uncertain glory of an April day,  Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,  And by and by a cloud takes all away!
t: Oh, how similar is this spring of love to the uncertain weather of a beautiful April day! Days in April can be gloriously sunny—until a cloud comes along to take all of that beauty away.

og: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you:He is in haste; therefore, I pray you to go.
t: Sir Proteus, your father is calling for you. He is in a hurry, so please go now.

og: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'
t: This is it! My heart agrees to the journey, and yet it answers "no" a thousand times over.

og: Sir, your glove.
t: Sir, your glove.

og: Not mine; my gloves are on.
t: That's not mine. My gloves are on.

og: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.
t: Well, then, this one may be yours—because this is only one.

og: Ha! Let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine:
t: Ha! Let me see! Yes, give it to me. It's mine.

og: Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!  Ah, Silvia, Silvia!
t: Sweet item of clothing that adorns a heavenly thing! Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

og: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!
t: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

og: How now, sirrah?
t: What's that, sir?

og: She is not within hearing, sir.
t: She's not within earshot, sir.

og: Why, sir, who bade you call her?
t: Who asked you to call her, sir?

og: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.
t: Your Worship, sir. Or else I misunderstood you.

og: Well, you'll still be too forward.
t: Well, you'll always be too hasty.

og: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.
t: And yet, last time I was told off for being too slow.

og: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?
t: Oh, that's enough, sir! Tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

og: She that your worship loves?
t: Is that the lady whom your Worship loves?

og: Why, how know you that I am in love?
t: Oh, but how do you know that I'm in love?

og: to walk alone, like one that had  the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had  lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had  buried her grandam;
t: to walk alone, like someone that has the plague; to sigh, like a school boy that has forgotten the alphabet; to cry, like a young girl that buried her grandmother;

og: to fast, like one that takes  diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to  speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas.
t: to fast, like someone on a diet; to remain awake, as if worried about being robbed; to whine like a beggar on All Saints' Day.

og: You were  wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you  walked, to walk like one of the lions;
t: Before you fell in love, when you laughed, you crowed like a rooster; when you walked, you walked like a lion;

og: when you  fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you  looked sadly, it was for want of money:
t: and when you didn't eat, it was because you'd just finished your dinner; when you looked sad, it was because you didn't have money.

og: and now you  are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look  on you, I can hardly think you my master  .
t: And now you've changed so much because of your mistress, that, when I look at you, I can hardly think that you are my master.

og: Are all these things perceived in me?
t: Can you spot all these changes in me?

og: They are all perceived without ye.
t: They are easy to see all around you.

og: Without me? They cannot.
t: They're visible all around me? They can't be.

og: Without you? Nay, that's certain, for, without you  were so simple, none else would:
t: All around you? Yes, for sure, because if you could simply hide the signs of love, nobody would perceive them.

og: but you are so  without these follies, that these follies are within  you and shine through you like the water in an  urinal,
t: But you are so madly in love, inside and out, that all of the symptoms of love shine through you like urine in a doctor's test cup,

og: that not an eye that sees you but is a  physician to comment on your malady.
t: and anyone who just looks at you can diagnose your illness as if they were a physician.

og: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?
t: Tell me, though: do you know my lady Silvia?

og: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?
t: Is she the one that you stare at when she is having dinner?

og: Hast thou observed that? Even she, I mean.
t: Have you noticed that? I mean, yes, that's her.

og: Why, sir, I know her not.
t: Well, sir, I don't know her.

og: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yetknowest her not?
t: So, you know her by my staring at her—and yet you don't know her?

og: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?
t: Isn't she ugly, sir?

og: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.
t: Not so beautiful, boy, as she is attractive.

og: Sir, I know that well enough.
t: Sir, I know that.

og: What dost thou know?
t: What do you know?

og: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.
t: That she isn't so much beautiful as preferred by you.

og: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.
t: I mean that her beauty is rare, but her charm is never-ending.

og: That's because the one is painted and the other outof all count.
t: That's because the one is artificial, and the other is beyond calculation.

og: How painted? And how out of count?
t: What do you mean, "artificial?" And how  is it "beyond calculation?"

og: Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that noman counts of her beauty.
t: Well, sir, she's so artificial, to make herself beautiful, that no man values her beauty.

og: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.
t: Do you think nothing of my judgment, then? I value her beauty.

og: You never saw her since she was deformed.
t: You haven't seen her since she was disfigured.

og: How long hath she been deformed?
t: How long has she been disfigured?

og: Ever since you loved her.
t: Ever since you fell in love with her.

og: I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still Isee her beautiful.
t: I have loved her ever since I saw her. And she is still beautiful in my eyes.

og: If you love her, you cannot see her.
t: You can't see her if you love her.

og: Why?
t: Why?

og: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes;
t: Because Love is blind. Oh, if only you had my eyes!

og: or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to  have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going  ungartered!
t: Or if your own eyes had the clear-sighted ability they used to have when you told Sir Proteus off for being disheveled!

og: What should I see then?
t: What would I see then?

og: Your own present folly and her passing deformity:  for he, being in love, could not see to garter his  hose,
t: Your own foolishness and her extreme deformity. Because Proteus—who is in love—at least made himself presentable by putting on his pants properly. A

og: and you, being in love, cannot see to put on yourhose.
t: nd you—also blindly in love—can't even do that.

og: Belike, boy, then, you are in love; for lastmorning you could not see to wipe my shoes.
t: In that case, boy, you are in love. Because yesterday morning, you couldn't see well enough to clean my shoes.

og: T  rue, sir; I was in love with my bed:
t: That's true, sir. I was in love with my bed.

og: I thank you,  you swinged me for my love, which makes me the  bolder to chide you for yours.
t: Thank you for beating me for my love. It makes me braver to tell you off for yours.

og: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.
t: To sum it up, I am in love with her.

og: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.
t: I wish you were calm, so that your affection would stop.

og: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines toone she loves.
t: Last night she told me to write some lines to someone she loves.

og: And have you?
t: And have you?

og: I have.
t: I have.

og: Are they not lamely writ?
t: Are they not written badly?

og: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace!Here she comes.
t: No, boy, I wrote them as well as I could. Be quiet! Here she is.

og: O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet!Now will he interpret to her.
t: Oh, that's a great puppet-show! Oh, that's a great puppet! Now he will provide the words for the puppet.

og: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.
t: Madam, beloved, I wish you a thousand good mornings.

og: O, give ye good even! Here's a million of manners.
t: Oh, good grief! This is a very excessive display of manners.

og: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.
t: Sir Valentine, lover, I wish you two thousand.

og: He should give her interest and she gives it him.
t: He should show his interest in her, but she pays him interest instead by offering him twice as many good mornings.

og: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter  Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;
t: As you have instructed, I have written your letter to your secret, unnamed lover.

og: Which I was much unwilling to proceed in  But for my duty to your ladyship.
t: I didn't want to do it, but I did it because of my duty to you.

og: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.
t: Thank you, kind servant. You've done it very scholarly.

og: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off;
t: Trust me, madam, it was difficult to do.

og: For being ignorant to whom it goes  I writ at random, very doubtfully.
t: Since I didn't know who it was meant for, I wrote randomly and with much hesitation.

og: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?
t: Perhaps you think it's not worth making so much effort?

og: No, madam; so it stead you, I will writePlease you command, a thousand times as much; And yet—
t: No, madam. As long as it is helpful to you, I will write. Order me to write a thousand times as much. And yet—

og: A pretty period!  Well, I guess the sequel;  And yet I will not name it; and yet I care not;
t: A clever pause! Well, I guess what follows. And yet I won't say it. And yet I don't care.

og: And yet take this again; and yet I thank you,  Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.
t: And yet take this again. And yet I thank you. I don't mean to trouble you any longer.

og: And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'
t: And yet you will. And yet another "yet."

og: What means your ladyship? Do you not like it?
t: What do you mean, your Ladyship? Don't you like the letter?

og: Yes, yes; the lines are very quaintly writ;
t: Yes, yes, the lines are written very skillfully.

og: But since unwillingly, take them again.  Nay, take them.
t: But since they are written unwillingly, take them back. No, take them.

og: Madam, they are for you.
t: They are for you, madam.

og: Ay, ay: you writ them, sir, at my request;
t: Yes, yes, you wrote them, sir, because I asked you to.

og: But I will none of them; they are for you;  I would have had them writ more movingly.
t: But I don't want them. They are for you. I would have had them written with more emotion.

og: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.
t: If you'd like, I can write your Ladyship another one.

og: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.
t: And when it's written, read it over for my sake. And if you're happy with it, so be it; if not, well, so be it.

og: If it please me, madam, what then?
t: Madam, if I'm happy with it, then what?

og: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:And so, good morrow, servant.
t: Well, if you're happy with it, take it as a payment for your efforts. And so, good day, servant.

og: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,  As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!
t: Oh, an unseen, mysterious, invisible joke! It's like the nose on your face; or a weathervane on top of a spire!

og: My master sues to her, and she hath  taught her suitor,  He being her pupil, to become her tutor.
t: My master courts her, and she taught her suitor. He is her student in order to become her teacher.

og: O excellent device! Was there ever heard a better,  That my master, being scribe, to himself should write  the letter?
t: Oh, that's a genius scheme! Has anyone heard of a better one, than that my master—who is the writer— should write the letter to himself?

og: How now, sir? What are you reasoning with yourself?
t: What's that, sir? What is it you're talking to yourself about?

og: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.
t: No, I was rhyming. You are the one who has a reason.

og: To do what?
t: To do what?

og: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.
t: To speak for Madam Silvia.

og: To whom?
t: To whom?

og: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.
t: To yourself! She courts you by an ingenious device.

og: What figure?
t: What device?

og: By a letter, I should say.
t: The letter!

og: Why, she hath not writ to me?
t: But she didn't write it to me.

og: What need she, when she hath made you write toyourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?
t: Why would she need to, when she has already made you write it to yourself? Don't you get the joke?

og: No, believe me.
t: No, believe me.

og: No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceiveher earnest?
t: I don't believe it, that's for sure, sir. But did you really think she was serious?

og: She gave me none, except an angry word.
t: She gave me nothing except for an angry word.

og: Why, she hath given you a letter.
t: She gave you a letter.

og: That's the letter I writ to her friend.
t: That's the letter I wrote for her lover.

og: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.
t: And she has delivered the letter. And there's the end to the matter.

og: I would it were no worse.
t: I wish it weren't so bad.

og: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:
t: I assure you, it's all good.

og: For often have you writ to her,
t: You have written to her a lot,

og: and she, in modesty,  Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;
t: and she couldn't reply because of her modesty, or because she doesn't have enough down-time.

og: Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,  Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.
t: Or she was afraid that some messenger might find out what she thinks. So she has taught her love to write a letter to her lover.

og: All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
t: I am speaking very precisely about all of this—exactly as I see it.

og: Why muse you, sir? 'Tis dinner-time.
t: Why are you lost in thought, sir? It's time for dinner.

og: I have dined.
t: I've already dined on beauty.

og: Ay, but hearken, sir;  though the chameleon Love can  feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my  victuals, and would fain have meat.
t: Yes, but listen, sir. Although Love is changeable like the chameleon, and can feed on air, I can only feed on food and would like to have meat.

og: O, be not like  your mistress; be moved, be moved.
t: Oh, don't be like your mistress. Be persuaded, be persuaded.

og: Have patience, gentle Julia.
t: Be patient, dear Julia.

og: I must, where is no remedy.
t: I have to be patient. There's no way to fix this.

og: When possibly I can, I will return.
t: I will return as soon as I can.

og: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.
t: If you stay faithful, you will return sooner. Keep this love token, for the sake of your Julia.

og: Why then, we'll make exchange; here, take you this.
t: Well then, we'll make an exchange. Here, you take this.

og: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.
t: And seal the contract with a holy kiss.

og: Here is my hand for my true constancy;
t: Here is my hand swearing true fidelity.

og: And when that hour o'erslips me in the day  Wherein I sigh not  , Julia, for thy sake,
t: And if it should ever happen that I won't swoon with love for you, Julia,

og: The next ensuing hour some foul mischance  Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!
t: then the next hour some horrible misfortune will torture me—because I have forgotten my love!

og: My father stays my coming; answer not;  The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears;  That tide will stay me longer than I should.  Julia, farewell!
t: My father is waiting for me to go. Don't say anything. The best tide for sailing is ready now; no, not your tide of tears. That tide will make me stay longer than I should. Julia, goodbye!

og: What, gone without a word?
t: Is she gone without saying anything?

og: Ay, so true love should do:
t: Yes, true love should do just that.

og: it cannot speak;  For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.
t: True love can't speak; besides, actions speak the truth louder than words.

og: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.
t: Sir Proteus, they are waiting for you.

og: Go; I come, I come.Alas! This parting strikes poor lovers dumb.
