t: Go. I'm coming, I'm coming. Ah! Goodbyes like this can make poor lovers speechless.

og: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping;  all the kind of the Lances have this very fault. I  have received my proportion, like the prodigious  son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's  court.
t: A lot of time will pass before I stop crying. Everyone from my family—the Lances—suffers from this. I have received my inheritance, like the prodigious son, and am now going to the emperor's court with Sir Proteus.

og: I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured  dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father  wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat  wringing her hands, and all our house in a great  perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed  one tear:
t: I think that my dog Crab has the sourest nature of all dogs. My mother is sobbing, my father is lamenting, my sister is crying, our servant is crying loudly, our cat wringing her hands to get the water out from all the crying, and all our house is in such a state—yet this cruel-hearted dog didn't cry one tear!

og: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and  has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have  wept to have seen our parting; why, my grandam,  having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my  parting.
t: He is made of stone, a very rough stone, and has no more pity than a dog. A Jew would have cried to have seen my family say goodbye. Look, even my grandma, who has no eyes, cried herself blind when I was leaving.

og: Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This  shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father:  no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that  cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it  hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in  it, is my mother, and this my father; a vengeance  on't! There 'tis: now, sit,
t: I'll show you how it happened. This shoe is my father. No, this left shoe is my father. No, no. This left shoe is my mother. No, that can't be correct either. Yet that's how it is, yes. It has a worse sole. This shoe, with the hole in it, is my mother, and this is my father. Damn it! There it is. Now, stay there.

og: this staff is my  sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and  as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I  am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the  dog—Oh! The dog is me, and I am myself; ay, so,  so.
t: This walking stick is my sister because, as you can see, she is as white as a lily and as slim as a stick. This hat is Nan, our servant. I am the dog. No, the dog is himself, and I am the dog...Oh! The dog is me and I am myself. Yes, that's it.

og: Now come I to my father; Father, your blessing:  now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:  now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on.
t: Now I come to my father. Father, give me your blessing. Now the shoe couldn't speak a word because it was crying. Now I kiss my father and well, he continues to cry.

og: Now  come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now  like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there  'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now  come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes.
t: Now I come to my mother. Oh, if only she could speak now like a mad woman! Well, I kiss her, there it is. This smells like my mother's breath exactly. Now I come to my sister. Note the moan that she makes.

og: Now  the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a  word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.
t: Now, the dog doesn't cry a single tear all this time, nor does he speak a word! But look how I make the dust on the ground wet with my own tears.

og: Launce, away, away, aboard! Thy master is shipped  and thou art to post after with oars.
t: Lance, go, go! Get on board! Your master is already on the ship, and you are supposed to hurry along and bring some oars.

og: What's the  matter? Why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll  lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.
t: What's the matter? Why are you crying, man? Get out of here, you jackass! You'll lose the tide if you stay here any longer.

og: It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is theunkindest tied that ever any man tied.
t: It doesn't matter if the tied was lost because it is the unkindest tied that any man ever had.

og: What's the unkindest tide?
t: What's the unkindest tide?

og: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.
t: Well, he that's tied here. My dog Crab.

og: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in  losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing  thy voyage, lose thy master,
t: Oh please, man: I meant that you'll lose the sea's tide. And in losing the tide, you'll miss your voyage. And in missing your voyage, you'll lose your master. A

og: and, in losing thy  master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy  service,—Why dost thou stop my mouth?
t: nd in losing your master you'll lose your employment. And in losing your employment—why are you shutting me up?

og: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.
t: Because I'm afraid that you'll lose your tongue.

og: Where should I lose my tongue?
t: Where should I lose my tongue?

og: In thy tale.
t: In your story.

og: In thy tail!
t: In your tail!

og: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and  the service, and the tied!
t: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the employment, and the dog!

og: Why, man, if the river  were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears;
t: Indeed, man, if the river were dry, I'd be able to fill it with my tears.

og: if the  wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.
t: If the wind wasn't blowing, I could push the boat with my sighs.

og: Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.
t: Come, come away, man. I was sent to call you away.

og: Sir, call me what thou darest.
t: Sir, call me what you like.

og: Wilt thou go?
t: Will you go?

og: Well, I will go.
t: Well, I will go.

og: Servant!
t: Servant!

og: Mistress?
t: Mistress?

og: Master, Sir Turio frowns on you.
t: Master, Sir Turio is frowning at you.

og: Ay, boy, it's for love.
t: Ah, yes, boy. He's frowning because of his love.

og: Not of you.
t: Not his love for you.

og: Of my mistress, then.
t: Love for my mistress, then.

og: 'Twere good you knocked him.
t: It would be a good idea for you to hit him.

og: Servant, you are sad.
t: You are sad, servant.

og: Indeed, madam, I seem so.
t: Indeed, madam, I seem sad.

og: Seem you that you are not?
t: Do you seem what you are not?

og: Haply I do.
t: Maybe I do.

og: So do counterfeits.
t: So do impostors.

og: So do you.
t: So do you.

og: What seem I that I am not?
t: What do I seem that I'm not?

og: Wise.
t: Wise.

og: What instance of the contrary?
t: What's the evidence that I'm not wise?

og: Your folly.
t: Your foolishness.

og: And how quote you my folly?
t: And how can you tell that I'm foolish?

og: I quote it in your jerkin.
t: I can tell by your sleeveless jacket.

og: My jerkin is a doublet.
t: My sleeveless jacket is a doublet.

og: Well, then, I'll double your folly.
t: Well, then, I'll double your foolishness.

og: How?
t: How?

og: What, angry, Sir Turio! Do you change colour?
t: Oh, are you angry, Sir Turio? Is your face changing color?

og: Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.
t: Let him be, madam. He is like a chameleon.

og: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than livein your air.
t: A chameleon that would rather feed on your blood than live off of the same air you breathe.

og: You have said, sir.
t: Well, you have said it, sir.

og: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.
t: Yes, sir, and I am finished too. For now.

og: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.
t: I know that well enough, sir. You always stop before you've started.

og: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.
t: That's a fine exchange of words, gentlemen. And quickly fired.

og: 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.
t: It is indeed, madam. We thank the one who gave it to us.

og: Who is that, servant?
t: Who is that, servant?

og: Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire.
t: You, sweet lady. Because you gave us the spark to set it off.

og: Sir  Turio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks,  and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.
t: Sir Turio borrows his wit from your Ladyship's appearance, and spends what he borrows in your company.

og: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shallmake your wit bankrupt.
t: Sir, if you waste a word with me, I shall bankrupt your wit.

og: I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words,
t: I know that well enough, sir. You have a treasury of words.

og: and, I think, no other treasure to give your  followers,
t: And I think that no other treasure helps you get servants.

og: for it appears by their bare liveries,  that they live by your bare words.
t: It seems that they live on your words alone, based on their shabby uniforms.

og: No more, gentlemen, no more:—here comes my father.
t: No more, gentlemen. No more. My father is coming.

og: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.  Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:
t: Now you are besieged by suitors, my daughter Silvia. [To VALENTINE] Sir Valentine, your father is well.

og: What say you to a letter from your friends  Of much good news?
t: What would you say to a letter from your friends, passing on a lot of good news?

og: My lord, I will be thankful.To any happy messenger from thence.
t: My lord, I would be thankful for any happy message from home.

og: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?
t: Do you know Don Antonio? He is from your country.

og: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentlemanTo be of worth and worthy estimationAnd not without desert so well reputed.
t: Yes, my good lord. I know that he is a gentleman of high rank; one who deserves respect and esteem.

og: Hath he not a son?
t: Doesn't he have a son?

og: Ay, my good lord; a son that well deservesThe honour and regard of such a father.
t: Yes, my good lord. He has a son that deserves the honor and regard of such a great father.

og: You know him well?
t: Do you know him well?

og: I know him as myself; for from our infancy  We have conversed and spent our hours together:  And though myself have been an idle truant,
t: I know him like I know myself. Ever since we were children, we have talked and spent all our time together. And although I have been a lazy delinquent—

og: Omitting the sweet benefit of time  To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,  Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,  Made use and fair advantage of his days;
t: disregarding the benefit of time to perfect myself in my old age—Sir Proteus (that's the son's name) used his time well.

og: His years but young, but his experience old;  His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe;
t: He is young, but he is old if we consider his experience. There are no grey hairs on his head, and yet his judgement is mature.

og: And, in a word, for far behind his worth  Comes all the praises that I now bestow,  He is complete in feature and in mind  With all good grace to grace a gentleman.
t: And, to sum it up (because my praises are not enough to praise his worth), he is perfect in his appearance and in his mind. And he has all the good grace that a gentleman has.

og: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,  He is as worthy for an empress' love  As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
t: Curse me, sir, if he is as good as you say he is. He deserves an empress' love as well as a position to advise an emperor.

og: Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,  With commendation from great potentates;  And here he means to spend his time awhile:
t: Well, sir, this gentleman is coming to me, with recommendation from powerful rulers. And he is thinking of spending some time here.

og: I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.
t: I think you like this news too.

og: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.
t: If I could have wished for something, it would have been for him to come here!

og: Welcome him then according to his worth.
t: Welcome him, then, according to his worth.

og: Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Turio;  For Valentine, I need not cite him to it:  I will send him hither to you presently.
t: Silvia and Sir Turio, I speak to you, because I don't need to urge Valentine. I will send Proteus here to you immediately.

og: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship  Had come along with me,
t: This is the gentleman I told your Ladyship about. He would have come along with me,

og: but that his mistress  Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.
t: but his mistress kept his eyes locked on her.

og: Belike that now she hath enfranchised themUpon some other pawn for fealty.
t: Perhaps she has now freed his eyes, and instead chosen another man's vow of loyalty.

og: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.
t: No, I think she still holds his eyes as prisoners.

og: Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blindHow could he see his way to seek out you?
t: No, then he should be blind. And if he's blind, how could he see his way to find you?

og: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.
t: Indeed, Lady: Love has twenty pair of eyes.

og: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.
t: They say that Love is blind.

og: To see such lovers, Turio, as yourself:Upon a homely object Love can wink.
t: Love is blind to such lovers as yourself, Turio. Love can shut its eyes when it meets an unattractive object.

og: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.
t: Enough, enough! Here he comes.

og: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,Confirm his welcome with some special favour.
t: Welcome, dear Proteus!  Mistress, I beg you to welcome him with a special favor.

og: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.
t: His worth is a guarantee for his welcome here, if this is the same man that you have often wanted to hear from.

og: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain himTo be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.
t: Mistress, it is him. Sweet lady, receive him as my fellow servant to your Ladyship.

og: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.
t: I am a mistress too humble to have such a superior servant.

og: Not so, sweet lady: but too mean a servantTo have a look of such a worthy mistress.
t: Not at all, sweet lady. I am an unworthy servant to have ever seen such a worthy mistress.

og: Leave off discourse of disability:Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.
t: Stop this talk of inadequacy.  Sweet lady, receive him as your servant.

og: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.
t: I will only boast of my sense of duty, nothing else.

og: And duty never yet did want his meed:Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.
t: And duty never lacked its reward. You are welcome, servant, to a worthless mistress.

og: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.
t: I'll die fighting with anyone who says that—except for you, of course.

og: That you are welcome?
t: Anyone who says that you are welcome?

og: That you are worthless.
t: Anyone who says that you are worthless.

og: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.
t: Madam, my lord—your father—would like to speak to you.

og: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Turio,  Go with me.
t: I will come to please him. Come, Sir Turio, go with me.

og: Once more, new servant, welcome:  I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;
t: [To PROTEUS] Once more, welcome, new servant. I'll leave you to catch up about what's happening at home.

og: When you have done, we look to hear from you.
t: When you're done, we look forward to hearing from you.

og: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.
t: We both serve your Ladyship.

og: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?
t: Now, tell me: how are things from where you've come?

og: Your friends are well and have them much commended.
t: Your friends are well, and they send their hearty greetings.

og: And how do yours?
t: And how are your friends?

og: I left them all in health.
t: They were all well when I left them.

og: How does your lady? And how thrives your love?
t: How is your lady doing? And how is your love?

og: My tales of love were wont to weary you;I know you joy not in a love discourse.
t: My tales of love used to make you tired. I know that you don't enjoy talking about love.

og: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:  I have done penance for condemning Love,
t: Yes, Proteus, but that's all changed now. I am repenting for condemning love.

og: Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me  With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,  With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;
t: Love's high, domineering thoughts have punished me with bitter fasting; with groans of penance; with nightly tears and daily sighs from heartache.

og: For in revenge of my contempt of love,  Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes  And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
t: In revenge for my sneering at love, love has taken sleep from my enslaved eyes, and keep them open, as watchers of my heart's sorrow.

og: O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord,  And hath so humbled me
t: Oh, dear Proteus, Love is a powerful lord, and has made me so humble.

og: , as, I confess,  There is no woe to his correction,
t: And, I confess, no misery is as bad as that which results from love's punishment.

og: Nor to his service no such joy on earth.
t: And yet, there is no joy on earth that can compare with serving love.

og: Now no discourse, except it be of love;  Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,  Upon the very naked name of love.
t: Now there is no discussion, except about love. Now I can have breakfast, lunch, dinner and sleep—only feeding on the mere name of love.

og: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.Was this the idol that you worship so?
t: That's enough. I can read it all from your eyes. Was Silvia the idol that you worship?

og: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?
t: That's her. And isn't she like a saint from heaven?

og: No; but she is an earthly paragon.
t: No. But she is person from earth who's beyond compare.

og: Call her divine.
t: Call her divine.

og: I will not flatter her.
t: I won't flatter her.

og: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.
t: Oh, then flatter me. Because love enjoys praises.

og: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,And I must minister the like to you.
t: When I was in love, you didn't mince words. So I must give you the same treatment.

og: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
t: Then speak the truth about her.

og: Yet let her be a principality,  Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.
t: If she is not divine, let her be one of the nine orders of angels, ruling all the creatures of the earth.

og: Except my mistress.
t: Except for my mistress.

og: Sweet, except not any;Except thou wilt except against my love.
t: Ah, no! Except for no one. Unless you will object to my love.

og: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?
t: Do I not have a reason to promote my own?

og: And I will help thee to prefer her too:  She shall be dignified with this high honour—  To bear my lady's train,
t: And I will help you to promote her too. She will be dignified with this high honor: to carry my lady's train.

og: lest the base earth  Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
t: Then, the lowly earth won't brush against her dress.

og: And, of so great a favour growing proud,  Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower  And make rough winter everlastingly.
t: And if she did let the earth touch it,  the earth might glow so much with pride that it could refuse to allow summer flowers to take root. It would make the harsh winter last forever.

og: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?
t: Valentine, what's with your bragging?

og: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothingTo her whose worth makes other worthies nothing;She is alone.
t: I'm sorry, Proteus. All that I can say is nothing compared to her. Her worth makes other valuable nothing. She is unique.

og: Then let her alone.
t: Then let her be alone and remain unique.

og: Not for the world:  why, man, she is mine own,
t: Not for the whole world! Indeed, man: she is my own.

og: And I as rich in having such a jewel  As twenty seas,
t: And, having a jewel like her, I am as twenty seas—

og: if all their sand were pearl,  The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.
t: if all their sand were pearls; their water, nectar; and their rocks, pure gold.

og: Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,  Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.
t: Forgive me that I'm not paying much attention to you, because you see me only focusing lovingly on my love.

og: My foolish rival, that her father likes  Only for his possessions are so huge,  Is gone with her along,
t: My foolish rival in love—the one that her father likes only because he is rich—has gone with her.

og: and I must after,  For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.
t: And so I must follow them. Because love, as you know, is full of jealousy.

og: But she loves you?
t: But she loves you, doesn't she?

og: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our,  marriage-hour,
t: Yes, and we are engaged. No, more than that.

og: With all the cunning manner of our flight,  Determined of;
t: We have decided on the time of our marriage, as well as an ingenious escape plan.

og: how I must climb her window,  The ladder made of cords, and all the means  Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
t: I must climb up to her window on a rope ladder, and we have planned and agreed on all the other details for my happiness.

og: Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,  In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.
t: Good Proteus, go with me to my room, and you can help me with your advice on these matters.

og: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:
t: Go before me. I will seek you out.

og: I must unto the road, to disembark  Some necessaries that I needs must use,
t: I have to go back to the road to unpack some things from my luggage that I need to use.

og: And then I'll presently attend you.
t: And then I'll help you afterwards.

og: Will you make haste?
t: Will you hurry?

og: I will.
t: I will.

og: Even as one heat another heat expels,  Or as one nail by strength drives out another,  So the remembrance of my former love  Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
t: It's like one source of heat replaces another one; or as if one nail drives out another by being stronger. So my memory of my past love is quite forgotten because of this newer sight.

og: Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,  Her true perfection, or my false transgression,  That makes me reasonless to reason thus?
t: Is it my or Valentine's praise of her true perfection? Or is it my faithless sin that makes me justify myself without cause?

og: She is fair; and so is Julia that I love—  That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd;  Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire,  Bears no impression of the thing it was.
t: She is beautiful and so is Julia whom I love—whom I loved. My love for Julia has now melted, like an image out of wax put next to a fire, which no longer looks like the thing it was.

og: Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,  And that I love him not as I was wont.  O, but I love his lady too too much,  And that's the reason I love him so little.
t: I think that my devotion to Valentine has gone cold, and that I don't love him like I used to. Oh, but I love this lady Silvia far too much, and that's why I love him less.

og: How shall I dote on her with more advice,  That thus without advice begin to love her!  'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,  And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
t: How shall I adore her upon more reflection, since I started to fall in love with her without giving it a thought at all? It's only her appearance that I've seen so far, and that has dazzled me more than the light of my reason.

og: But when I look on her perfections,  There is no reason but I shall be blind.  If I can cheque my erring love, I will;  If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.
t: But when I come to look at her exquisite inner qualities, no doubt I will be completely blinded by love. If I can restrain my wandering love, I will. If not, I will use my skill to win her.

og: Lance! By mine honesty, welcome to Milan!
t: Lance! I swear by my honesty: welcome to Milan!

og: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not  welcome.
t: Don't swear falsely by that, sweet boy, because I am not welcome.

og: I reckon this always, that a man is never  undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a  place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess  say 'Welcome!'
t: I think it's always the case that a man is never ruined until he is hanged. In the same way, a man is never welcomed in a place until some bill is paid and the landlady of an inn says: "Welcome!"

og: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you  presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou  shalt have five thousand welcomes.
t: Come on, you madman. I'll go to the bar with you immediately. You shall have five thousand welcomes for one payment of five pence.

og: But, sirrah, how  did thy master part with Madam Julia?
t: But, sir, how did your master say goodbye to Lady Julia?

og: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted veryfairly in jest.
t: Indeed, after they genuinely hugged each other, they said goodbye cordially, as a bit of a joke.

og: But shall she marry him?
t: But will she marry him?

og: No.
t: No.

og: How then? Shall he marry her?
t: Then what? Will he marry her?

og: No, neither.
t: No, not that either.

og: What, are they broken?
t: What, have they broken up?

og: No, they are both as whole as a fish.
t: No, they are together; as whole as a fish.

og: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?
t: Well then, what's the problem that caused their falling out?

og: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, itstands well with her.
t: Indeed, this is the problem: when things are going well for him, then she is well.

og: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.
t: You are such an idiot! I don't understand you.

og: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! Mystaff understands me.
t: You are such a blockhead that you can't understand me! My staff understands me.

og: What thou sayest?
t: What do you say?

og: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean,and my staff understands me.
t: Yes, and I do too. Look! I'll lean and my staff understands me.

og: It stands under thee, indeed.
t: It stands under you, yes.

og: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.
t: Well, stand-under and under-stand is the same thing.

og: But tell me true, will't be a match?
t: But tell me truth: will there be a wedding?

og: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! If he say no,it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.
t: Ask my dog; if he says yes, it will. If he says no, it will. If he shakes his tail and says nothing, it will.

og: The conclusion is then that it will.
t: So then it will!

og: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.
t: You will never get such a secret from me apart from using cryptic and confusing speech.

og: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Lance, how sayestthou, that my master is become a notable lover?
t: It's good that I get it now. Lance, what do you say to this? My master has become a notorious lover!

og: I never knew him otherwise.
t: I never knew him as anything else.

og: Than how?
t: Anything else than what?

og: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.
t: A notorious lubber—a clumsy fool, as you have just said he is.

og: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.
t: Ah, you bastard ass, you aren't understanding me!

og: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.
t: You fool, I didn't mean you. I meant your master!

og: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.
t: I am telling you that my master has become a passionate lover.

og: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself  in love.  If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse;
t: I am telling you that I don't care if he burns himself in love. If you want to, come with me to the pub.

og: if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the  name of a Christian.
t: If not, you are a Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.

og: Why?
t: Why?

og: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as togo to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?
t: Because you don't have enough charity in you to go to the pub with a Christian. Will you go?

og: At thy service.
t: I'm at your service.

og: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;  To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;  To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
t: If I were to leave Julia, I would break my promise. If I love the beautiful Silvia, I would break my promise. And I will break an even bigger promise if I hurt my friend Valentine.

og: And even that power which gave me first my oath  Provokes me to this threefold perjury;  Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
t: And yet even love—which made me swear to be faithful to Julia—provokes me to break my promise three times over. Love made me swear, but love wants me to break that promise.

og: O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,  Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!  At first I did adore a twinkling star,  But now I worship a celestial sun.
t: Oh, sweetly tempting Love: if you have ever sinned, teach me—your tempted subject—how to justify it! At first, I adored a star, who shone for just a moment. But now I worship the heavenly sun.

og: Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,  And he wants wit that wants resolved will  To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.  Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! To call her bad,  Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd  With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
t: Thoughtless promises can be carefully broken. And a man lacks intelligence if he can't take resolute action, teaching his wit to exchange a bad thing for a better thing. Ah, ah, impudent tongue! How could you call Julia bad, when you felt her power over you, and urged it on with twenty thousand soul-strengthening oaths?

og: I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;  But there I leave to love where I should love.  Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:  If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;  If I lose them, thus find I by their loss  For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.
t: I cannot stop loving, and yet I do stop loving. But I stop loving the woman I should love, Julia. If I lose Julia, then I also lose Valentine. If I keep them, I must lose myself. Yet if I lose them, then I'll change places with Valentine, and Silvia will change places with Julia.

og: I to myself am dearer than a friend,  For love is still most precious in itself;  And Silvia—witness Heaven, that made her fair!—  Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
t: I mean more to myself than a friend means to me, since love is still most precious in and of itself. And Silvia—Heaven look, you made her so beautiful!—shows Julia to be only a dark-complexioned Ethiopian.

og: I will forget that Julia is alive,  Remembering that my love to her is dead;  And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,  Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
t: I will forget that Julia is alive, and remember that my love for her is therefore dead. I'll consider Valentine my enemy, and direct myself to Silvia as my sweeter friend.

og: I cannot now prove constant to myself,  Without some treachery used to Valentine.  This night he meaneth with a corded ladder  To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,  Myself in counsel, his competitor.
t: I cannot be faithful to myself now, without committing some act of treason on Valentine. Tonight, he is planning on climbing a rope ladder to the window of heavenly Silvia's room. He told me this in confidence, and trusts me—but I am also his rival.

og: Now presently I'll give her father notice  Of their disguising and pretended flight;  Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;  For Turio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
t: Now I will immediately let her father know of their deceptive plan to escape. He will be angry, and will cast Valentine out, since he wants Turio to marry his daughter.

og: But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross  By some sly trick blunt Turio's dull proceeding.  Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,  As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!
t: But as soon as Valentine is gone, I'll quickly use some clever trick to prevent the stupid Turio's progress. Love, give me wings so my purpose can be quick, just like you have lent me wit to plan this scheme!

og: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;
t: Give me advice, Lucetta. Dear girl, help me.

og: And even in kind love I do conjure thee,
t: I beg you with kind love.

og: Who art the table wherein all my thoughts  Are visibly character'd and engraved,
t: You are like the notebook where all my thoughts are clearly written and engraved.

og: To lesson me and tell me some good mean  How, with my honour, I may undertake  A journey to my loving Proteus.
t: So teach me, and tell me about some good method by which I could travel to my loving Proteus, and still maintain my honor.

og: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!
t: Ah, the journey is tiring and long!

og: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary  To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
t: A truly devoted traveler doesn't get tired from traveling across kingdoms with his weak steps.

og: Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,  And when the flight is made to one so dear,  Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.
t: And she who flies on Love's wings will be even less tired. Especially when she flies to someone so dear—someone of such heavenly perfection—as Sir Proteus.

og: Better forbear till Proteus make return.
t: You'd better have patience until Proteus returns.

og: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?  Pity the dearth that I have pined in,  By longing for that food so long a time.
t: Oh, don't you know that his looks are the food that my soul feeds on? It's a pity that I have to waste away in a famine, because I have been longing for that food for so long.

og: Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,  Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow  As seek to quench the fire of love with words.
t: If you only knew the inward touch of love, you would as soon light a fire with snow as try to extinguish the fire of love with words.

og: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,But qualify the fire's extreme rage,Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.
t: I don't want to suffocate your love's hot fire, but instead moderate the fire's extreme power—so it doesn't burn beyond what's reasonable.

og: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.  The current that with gentle murmur glides,  Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;
t: The more you try to moderate it, the more it burns. The current that flows gently and slowly impatiently rages when it's stopped.

og: But when his fair course is not hindered,  He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones,  Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge  He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,
t: But when its flowing isn't prevented, it creates a pleasing sound as it babbles over the smooth stones, giving a gentle kiss to every plant it passes by on its journey.

og: And so by many winding nooks he strays  With willing sport to the wild ocean.  Then let me go and hinder not my course  I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
t: And so it stops at many twisting corners; it goes off with entertaining activity toward the wild ocean. Then let me go, and don't prevent my going. I'll be as patient as the gentle stream,

og: And make a pastime of each weary step,  Till the last step have brought me to my love;  And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil  A blessed soul doth in Elysium.
t: and make an entertainment out of every tiring step, until the last step brings me to my love. And there I will remain, as a blessed soul would in heaven, after going to a lot of trouble.

og: But in what habit will you go along?
t: But what clothes will you wear?

og: Not like a woman; for I would prevent  The loose encounters of lascivious men:
t: Not a woman's clothes, since I hope to avoid greedy men's improper advances.

og: Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds  As may beseem some well-reputed page.
t: Dear Lucetta, give me clothes that are appropriate for some well-regarded servant.

og: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.
t: Well, then your Ladyship must cut your hair.

og: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings  With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.
t: No, girl. I'll tie it up with silken strings in twenty elaborately devised knots.

og: To be fantastic may become a youth  Of greater time than I shall show to be.
t: Being imaginative is quite appropriate for a boy who's older than I will appear.

og: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?
t: In what style shall I make your pants?

og: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,  What compass will you wear your farthingale?'
t: That's as if you were asking: "Tell me, my good lord, in what perimeter will you wear your petticoat?"

og: Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.
t: In any style that you like, Lucetta.

og: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.
t: You should have the pants with a codpiece, madam.

og: Out, out, Lucetta! That would be ill-favour'd.
t: Get out, Lucetta! That's unheard of!

og: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.
t: Pants aren't worth anything unless you have a codpiece to pin on them.

og: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have  What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.
t: Lucetta, since you love me, let me have anything that you think is appropriate.

og: But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me  For undertaking so unstaid a journey?  I fear me, it will make me scandalized.
t: But tell me, girl, what will the world think of me for going on such an immodest journey? I am afraid that it will be a scandal.

og: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.
t: If you think so, then stay at home and don't go.

og: Nay, that I will not.
t: No, I won't do that.

og: Then never dream on infamy, but go.
t: Then don't worry about getting a bad reputation and just go.

og: If Proteus like your journey when you come,  No matter who's displeased when you are gone:
t: If Proteus is happy that you came when you arrive, it doesn't matter who is unhappy when you are gone.

og: I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.
t: I am afraid that he won't be that happy about it.

og: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:  A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears
t: That is the least of my worries, Lucetta. A thousand promises, an ocean of his tears,

og: And instances of infinite of love  Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.
t: and evidence of his never-ending love guarantee that Proteus will welcome my arrival.

og: All these are servants to deceitful men.
t: All these things simply help deceitful men in their treachery.

og: Base men, that use them to so base effect!  But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth  His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
t: They are lowly men that use them to such a lowly effect! But truer stars shone when Proteus was born. His words are binding promises;

og: His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,  His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,  His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.
t: his love is sincere; his thoughts are pure; his tears are poor messengers sent from his heart; his heart is as far from lies as heaven is from earth.

og: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!
t: I hope to God that he'll prove to be true when you go to him!

og: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong  To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
t: Now since you love me, don't speak like that about him. Don't have such a tough opinion of his sincerity.

og: Only deserve my love by loving him;  And presently go with me to my chamber,  To take a note of what I stand in need of,  To furnish me upon my longing journey.
t: Earn my love by loving him. And go to my room immediately, to find out what I need to take with me on my journey, which will be full of yearning.

og: All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,  My goods, my lands, my reputation;  Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
t: I leave everything I have under your control: my things, my lands, my reputation. All I ask for in exchange is that you send me on my way.

og: Come, answer not, but to it presently!  I am impatient of my tarriance.
t: Come, don't answer, just do it now! I am impatient from your delay.

og: Sir Turio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;We have some secrets to confer about.
t: Sir Turio, leave us alone for a while, please. We have to discuss some secrets.

og: Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?
t: Now, what did you want to tell me, Proteus?

og: My gracious lord, that which I would discover  The law of friendship bids me to conceal;  But when I call to mind your gracious favours  Done to me, undeserving as I am,  My duty pricks me on to utter that  Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
t: My gracious lord, the rules of friendship tell me to keep certain things a secret. But when I remind myself of your kindness to me, my duty forces me to tell you a secret that nobody else could ever get out of me.

og: Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,  This night intends to steal away your daughter:  Myself am one made privy to the plot.  I know you have determined to bestow her  On Turio, whom your gentle daughter hates;  And should she thus be stol'n away from you,  It would be much vexation to your age.
t: My friend Sir Valentine is planning on stealing away with your daughter tonight. I have been entrusted with this secret information. I know you are determined to give her in marriage to Turio, whom your dear daughter hates. And if she were taken away from you like this, it would distress you—especially at your age.

og: Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose  To cross my friend in his intended drift  Than, by concealing it, heap on your head  A pack of sorrows which would press you down,  Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.
t: So, for the sake of my duty, I would rather choose to go against my friend's intended plan than hide it. That way, you won't be weighed down with sorrow, which could easily kill you.

og: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;  Which to requite, command me while I live.
t: Proteus, I thank you for your honesty and care. To repay you, ask any favor of me while I'm still alive.

og: This love of theirs myself have often seen,  Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,  And oftentimes have purposed to forbid  Sir Valentine her company and my court:
t: I have often seen signs that Valentine and Silvia are in love, usually while they think I'm sleeping. And I have often thought of forbidding Sir Valentine to see her, and of banishing him from my court.

og: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err  And so unworthily disgrace the man,
t: But I was worried that my suspicions may be wrong, which would unfairly shame him.

og: A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,  I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find  That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
t: I put that rash decision out of my mind, and I looked upon him kindly in order to try and discover the information which you have just told me.

og: And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,  Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
t: You can guess that this causes me to worry about her. And knowing how young people are easily tempted,

og: I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,  The key whereof myself have ever kept;  And thence she cannot be convey'd away.
t: I keep her in a high tower every night, and I hold onto the key so she can't be taken away.

og: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean  How he her chamber-window will ascend  And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
t: But, noble lord, they have come up with a plan to use a rope ladder—he'll climb up it to get to the window of her room, and will bring her down.

og: For which the youthful lover now is gone  And this way comes he with it presently;  Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.
t: The young man has just left to get that ladder, and he will soon come this way with it. If you wish, you may catch him bringing it here.

og: But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly  That my discovery be not aimed at;  For love of you, not hate unto my friend,  Hath made me publisher of this pretence.
t: But, my good lord, do it cleverly, so that I am not suspected of disclosing his secret plan. My love for you—not hatred of my friend—made me reveal his intention.

og: Upon mine honour, he shall never knowThat I had any light from thee of this.
t: I swear on my honor that he will never know that I heard any of this from you.

og: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.
t: Goodbye, my Lord. Sir Valentine is coming!

og: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?
t: Sir Valentine, where are you going so fast?

og: Please it your grace, there is a messengerThat stays to bear my letters to my friends,And I am going to deliver them.
t: I am sorry, your Grace. There is a messenger that is waiting to take my letters to my friends, and I'm going to give them to him.

og: Be they of much import?
t: Are these letters important?

og: The tenor of them doth but signifyMy health and happy being at your court.
t: They just talk of my health, and how happy I am at your court.

og: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;  I am to break with thee of some affairs  That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
t: Then they are not so important. Stay with me for a while. I want to tell you about some things that are close to my heart, and you must keep them secret.

og: 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought  To match my friend Sir Turio to my daughter.
t: You know yourself that I have been trying to make a match between my friend Sir Turio and my daughter.

og: I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match  Were rich and honourable;
t: I know that well, my Lord. And that match is rich and honorable, of course.

og: besides, the gentleman  Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities  Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:
t: Also, the gentleman is virtuous, generous,  and worthy. And he has all the right qualities that are suitable for such a wife as your beautiful daughter will be.

og: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?
t: Can't you win her over so she likes him, your Grace?

og: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,  Proud, disobedient, stubborn,
t: No, trust me. She is headstrong, sour, obstinate, proud, disobedient, and stubborn.

og: lacking duty,  Neither regarding that she is my child  Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
t: She doesn't respect the duty that she owes me as my child, and doesn't fear my parental authority.

og: And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,  Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;
t: And, I can tell you this, after thinking it over, this pride of hers has turned my love away from her.

og: And, where I thought the remnant of mine age  Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,
t: I thought that, in my old age, she might cherish me and be dutiful to me.

og: I now am full resolved to take a wife  And turn her out to who will take her in:
t: But now I have decided to get a wife, and shun my daughter, so anyone can take her in.

og: Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;  For me and my possessions she esteems not.
t: Then, let her beauty be her dowry. She is not worth me and my possessions.

og: What would your Grace have me to do in this?
t: Your Grace, what do you want me to do about this?

og: There is a lady in Verona here  Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy  And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
t: There is a lady here in Verona whom I love. But she is reluctant and shy, and does not care to speak of love with me, an old man.

og: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor—  For long agone I have forgot to court;  Besides, the fashion of the time is changed—
t: I'd like you to be my tutor, since it's been a while and I have forgotten how to woo. And the fashion of the time has changed too.

og: How and which way I may bestow myself  To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.
t: Tell me how and in what way I should behave to be well-regarded in her eyes.

og: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:Dumb jewels often in their silent kindMore than quick words do move a woman's mind.
t: Win her with gifts, if she doesn't care for words. Jewels often influence a woman's mind; they're silent, but jewels move a woman quicker than words ever could.

og: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.
t: But she refused a gift that I sent her.

og: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.  Send her another; never give her o'er;  For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
t: A woman sometimes refuses what she likes the best. Send her another gift; don't give up on her. Refusal at first makes later love greater.

og: If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,  But rather to beget more love in you:  If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;  For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.
t: If she frowns, it's not because she hates you. Instead, she wants to get more love out of you. If she tells you off, it's not because she wants you to stop or go away. These foolish women go crazy when they are left alone.

og: Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;  For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'  Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;  Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.
t: Don't take her refusals seriously, no matter what she says. When she says "leave," she doesn't necessarily mean "go away." Flatter her, praise her, elaborate on all her virtues. However dark-complexioned women may be, say that they have angels' faces.

og: That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,  If with his tongue he cannot win a woman  .
t: I think that a man that has a tongue is no man at all if he can't use his tongue to win a woman.

og: But she I mean is promised by her friends  Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
t: But her family has promised to marry her to some young, worthy gentleman.

og: And kept severely from resort of men,  That no man hath access by day to her.
t: She is kept away from any other men, so that no man has access to her during the day.

og: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.
t: Well then, I would go to her at night.

og: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,That no man hath recourse to her by night.
t: Yes, but her door is locked. And the keys are kept safely tucked away, so that no man can get to her at night.

og: What lets but one may enter at her window?
t: What prevents you from entering her room through her window?

og: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,And built so shelving that one cannot climb itWithout apparent hazard of his life.
t: Her room is up high, quite far from the ground. And it's built in a way that you can't climb up without endangering your life.

og: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,So bold Leander would adventure it.
t: Well, then a ladder made out of ropes could be thrown up to her, and set with a pair of heavy hooks. These would work to get to another Hero's tower, so bold Leander would try to reach her.

og: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,Advise me where I may have such a ladder.
t: Now, since you are a gentleman from a good family, tell me where I may find such a ladder.

og: When would you use it? Pray, sir, tell me that.
t: When would you need it? Please tell me when, sir.

og: This very night; for Love is like a child,That longs for every thing that he can come by.
t: Tonight! Because Love is like a child. It wants everything that  it can get.

og: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.
t: I'll get you this ladder by seven o'clock.

og: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:How shall I best convey the ladder thither?
t: But, wait. I will be going to her alone, so how can I carry the ladder there?

og: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear itUnder a cloak that is of any length.
t: It's not heavy, my lord. And you can hide it under any coat, long or short.

og: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?
t: Would a coat as long as yours work?

og: Ay, my good lord.
t: Yes, my good lord.

og: Then let me see thy cloak:I'll get me one of such another length.
t: Then let me see your coat. I'll get one of this length for myself.

og: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.
t: Any coat will be work, my lord.

og: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?  I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.
t: How can I get used to wearing a coat? Please, let me try yours. [He tries on the coat and finds a letter]

og: What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!
t: What's this letter? What does it say? [Reading]"To Silvia!"

og: And here an engine fit for my proceeding.  I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.
t: This is a device suitable for the very scheme I have been planning. I'll be so bold as to break the seal for once.

og: 'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,  And slaves they are to me that send them flying:
t: [Reading]"My thoughts take refuge with my Silvia every night, and whoever sends those thoughts flying are like scoundrels to me.

og: O, could their master come and go as lightly,  Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!
t: Oh, if only I could come and go as easily my thoughts. Then I would choose to stay where all my thoughts of Silvia reside imperceptibly within my mind.

og: My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:  While I, their king, that hither them importune,  Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,  Because myself do want my servants' fortune:
t: My thoughts are like messages delivered to your pure heart. I—their sender—urge them to go there. But I also curse the good fortune that my thoughts have been blessed with, because I long to be as lucky as they are.

og: I curse myself, for they are sent by me,  That they should harbour where their lord would be.'
t: I curse myself because even though I'm the one who sent them, I can't be where they get to be—with you."

og: What's here?  'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'  'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.  Why, Phaeton,—for thou art Merops' son,—  Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car  And with thy daring folly burn the world?
t: What's this here? [Reading]"Silvia, I will free you tonight." Is that so? And here is the ladder for that purpose. Are you like Phateon, Merops' son, and will you hope to drive the heavenly chariot and burn the world with your daring foolishness?

og: Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?  Go, base intruder! Overweening slave!
t: Will you reach the stars because they shine on you? Go, you lowly invader! You arrogant scoundrel!

og: Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,  And think my patience, more than thy desert,  Is privilege for thy departure hence:
t: Give your smiles to women of your own worth. I hope you know that it is because of my patience—and not because you deserve it in any way—that I'm allowing you to leave.

og: Thank me for this more than for all the favours  Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
t: Thank me for this more than for all the kind things I've done for you—of which there have been far too many.

og: But if thou linger in my territories  Longer than swiftest expedition  Will give thee time to leave our royal court,  By heaven! My wrath shall far exceed the love  I ever bore my daughter or thyself.
t: But, if you stay behind in my lands longer than the short time that I'll give you to leave my royal court, I swear to God that my anger will be stronger than the love I've ever had for my daughter or for you.

og: Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;  But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.
t: Get out of here! I don't want to hear any of your excuses. If you love your life, you'd better get out of here as fast as possible.

og: And why not death rather than living torment?  To die is to be banish'd from myself;  And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her  Is self from self: a deadly banishment!
t: And why don't I die rather than live in torment? To die is to be banished from myself, and Silvia is myself. Being banished from her is like being banished from myself. That's a deadly banishment!

og: What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?  What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?  Unless it be to think that she is by  And feed upon the shadow of perfection
t: What light is light, if Silvia can't be seen? What joy is joy, if Silvia isn't nearby? Unless joy is to simply think that she is nearby and feed on that image of perfection.

og: Except I be by Silvia in the night,  There is no music in the nightingale;  Unless I look on Silvia in the day,  There is no day for me to look upon;
t: If I'm not by Silvia during the night, then the nightingale doesn't sing. Unless I look at Silvia during the day, there is no day for me to see.

og: She is my essence, and I leave to be,  If I be not by her fair influence  Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.
t: She is my everything, and I will cease to exist if I am not nurtured, illuminated, comforted, and kept alive by her power.

og: I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:  Tarry I here, I but attend on death:  But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.
t: It'll be as bad as dying under his death sentence if I run away. But, I will flee—even though I'll be fleeing from life itself.

og: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.
t: Run, boy, run, run; and look for him.

og: Soho, soho!
t: Oh, oh!

og: What seest thou?
t: What do you see?

og: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's headbut 'tis a Valentine.
t: I found the man we wanted to find. Look, I swear that every hair on that man's head belongs to Valentine.

og: Valentine?
t: Valentine?

og: No.
t: No.

og: Who then? His spirit?
t: Who then? His ghost?

og: Neither.
t: Not his ghost neither.

og: What then?
t: What then?

og: Nothing.
t: Nothing.

og: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?
t: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I hit it?

og: Who wouldst thou strike?
t: Who would you hit?

og: Nothing.
t: Nothing.

og: Villain, forbear.
t: Rogue, stand by.

og: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,—
t: But sir, I won't hit anything, I swear—

og: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.
t: I said, stand by, sir.  Valentine, my friend, speak to me.

og: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,So much of bad already hath possess'd them.
t: My ears are blocked up and can't hear good news, since they have been packed with so much bad news already.

og: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.
t: Then I will bury my news in silence, because my news is harsh and bad.

og: Is Silvia dead?
t: Is Silvia dead?

og: No, Valentine.
t: No, Valentine.

og: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.Hath she forsworn me?
t: Then, indeed, there will be no Valentine for sacred Silvia. Has she rejected me?

og: No, Valentine.
t: No, Valentine.

og: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.What is your news?
t: There will be no Valentine, if Silvia has rejected me. What is your news?

og: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.
t: Sir, it has been announced that you are vanished.

og: That thou art banished—O, that's the news!—From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.
t: That you are banished! Oh, that's the news! Banished from here, from Silvia and from me, your friend.

og: O, I have fed upon this woe already,And now excess of it will make me surfeit.Doth Silvia know that I am banished?
t: Oh, I have already heard this bad news—and now more of it will make me ill. Does Silvia know that I am banished?

og: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom—  Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force—  A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:
t: Yes, yes, and her reaction to the sentence—which, as long as it's not reversed, will be as powerful as ever—was a sea of tears.

og: Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;  With them, upon her knees, her humble self;  Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them  As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
t: She offered them and her whole self at her father's feet, begging on her knees. She was wringing her hands, which were so white it was like they had just gone pale with sadness.

og: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,  Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,  Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;  But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.
t: But neither her knees, nor her hands held up. Her sad sighs, deep groans, and tears couldn't reach out to her unfeeling father. But, if you are taken, you will die.

og: Besides, her intercession chafed him so,  When she for thy repeal was suppliant,  That to close prison he commanded her,  With many bitter threats of biding there.
t: Also, her prayer—in which she asked for the reversal of your sentence—made her father so angry that he locked her up in a secluded prison. He made many awful threats if she didn't stay there.

og: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st  Have some malignant power upon my life:
t: Say no more, unless your next word has some evil power over my life.

og: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,  As ending anthem of my endless dolour.
t: If so, then I ask you, whisper it in my ear, like a tune playing at my funeral, to remember my endless suffering.

og: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,  And study help for that which thou lament'st.  Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.  Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;  Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.
t: Stop moaning; that won't help you. Instead, let's figure out how to help the situation you are moaning about. Time heals all wounds, and makes everything good. If you stay here, you won't be able to see your love. Besides, your staying here will shorten your life.

og: Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that  And manage it against despairing thoughts.  Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;  Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd  Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.  The time now serves not to expostulate:
t: Hope is like a lover's staff, and therefore you can walk with that and handle it against your despairing thoughts. Your letters can be here, even if you are away. Address them to me, and they'll be delivered your love's milk-white bosom. We have no time to discuss it further.

og: Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;  And, ere I part with thee, confer at large  Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.  As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,  Regard thy danger, and along with me!
t: Come, I'll walk you out through the city gate. And, before I say goodbye, we'll discuss anything that may concern your love affair in detail. For your love of Silvia—even if not for your own sake—do what you can to avoid danger, and come along with me!

og: I pray thee, Lance, an if thou seest my boy,Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.
t: Lance, if you see my boy, tell him to hurry up and meet me at the North Gate, please.

og: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.
t: Come, Valentine.

og: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!
t: Oh, my dear Silvia! Unfortunate Valentine!

og: I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to  think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's  all one, if he be but one knave.
t: I am only a fool, you know. And yet I am clever enough to think that my master is some kind of villain. But that's all right if he's one specific kind of a villain.

og: He lives not now  that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a  team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who  'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman;
t: Not a man alive knows that I am in love. Yet I am in love. But a group of horses can't get that secret out of me, nor whom I love. And yet, it's a woman,

og: but what woman, I  will not tell myself;  and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet  'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis  a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for  wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;  which is much in a bare Christian.
t: but I won't say what woman. And yet, it's a milkmaid. Yet, it's not a servant, because she knows the gossip and provides domestic services for money. She has more accomplishments than a submissive dog, which is saying a lot for a mere Christian.

og: Here is the cate-log of her condition.  'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse  can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only  carry; therefore is she better than a jade.
t: Here is the list of her attributes. [Reading] "In the first place: She can bring and carry things." A horse can do that. No, a horse can't bring things, but only carry them. Therefore, she is better than a worthless old horse. [Reading]

og: 'Item:  She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid  with clean hands.
t: "Next: She can milk a cow." Yes, that is a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.

og: How now, Signior Lance! What news with yourmastership?
t: How are you, Mr. Lance? What is the news with your Mastership?

og: With my master's ship? Why, it is at sea.
t: With my master's ship? It's at sea.

og: Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. Whatnews, then, in your paper?
t: Ah, your old bad habit! You didn't understand the word. What news is in your paper, then?

og: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.
t: The blackest news that you've ever heard.

og: Why, man, how black?
t: How black, man?

og: Why, as black as ink.
t: As black as ink.

og: Let me read them.
t: Let me read the news.

og: Fie on thee, jolt-head! Thou canst not read.
t: Damn you, idiot! You can't read.

og: Thou liest; I can.
t: You lie. I can.

og: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?
t: I will test you. Tell me, who conceived you?

og: Marry, the son of my grandfather.
t: Indeed, my grandfather's son.

og: O illiterate loiterer! It was the son of thy grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.
t: Oh, you illiterate slowpoke! It was your grandmother's son. This proves that you can't read.

og: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.
t: Come on, you fool, come on! Test me with your paper.

og: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!
t: Start reading here, and may St. Nicholas help you!

og: 'Imprimis: She can milk.'
t: "In the first place: She can milk."

og: Ay, that she can.
t: Yes, that she can do.

og: 'Item: She brews good ale.'
t: "Next: She makes good beer."

og: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of yourheart, you brew good ale.'
t: And that's where the proverb comes from: "Bless your heart, you make a good beer."

og: 'Item: She can sew.'
t: "Next: She can stitch."

og: That's as much as to say, 'Can she so?'
t: That's as if we were to say: "Can she really?"

og: 'Item: She can knit.'
t: "Next: She can knit."

og: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, whenshe can knit him a stock?
t: Why does a man need a dowry from a woman when she can knit him a stocking?

og: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'
t: "Next: She can wash and scrub."

og: A special virtue: for then she need not be washedand scoured.
t: That's a special virtue, because then she doesn't need to be cleaned and rubbed clean.

og: 'Item: She can spin.'
t: "Next: She can spin thread."

og: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she canspin for her living.
t: Then I may have an easy life, when she can spin for a living.

og: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'
t: "Next: She has many inexpressible qualities."

og: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that,indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.
t: That's as if we were to say that she has illegitimate children that don't know their fathers, and, therefore, have no names.

og: 'Here follow her vices.'
t: "Here are her bad qualities."

og: Close at the heels of her virtues.
t: Right after the list of her virtues.

og: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respectof her breath.'
t: "Next: She shouldn't be kissed before she has eaten, because of her breath."

og: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.
t: Well, that fault can be fixed by breakfast. Carry on reading.

og: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'
t: "Next: She has a sweet tooth."

og: That makes amends for her sour breath.
t: That makes up for her sour breath.

og: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'
t: "Next: She talks in her sleep."

og: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.
t: That doesn't matter, as long as she doesn't sleep when she talks.

og: 'Item: She is slow in words.'
t: "Next: She is slow with words."

og: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To  be slow in words is a woman's only virtue:
t: Oh, you rogue! You put that as one of her bad qualities! To be slow with words is a woman's only virtue.

og: I pray  thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.
t: Take it out of there, I beg you, and put it as her main virtue.

og: 'Item: She is proud.'
t: "Next: She is greedy."

og: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannotbe ta'en from her.
t: Take that one out too. Women got that quality from Eve in the Garden of Eden, and greed can't be taken from her.

og: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'
t: "Next: She doesn't have any teeth."

og: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.
t: I don't care about that one either, because I love to eat crusts.

og: 'Item: She is curst.'
t: "Next: She is bad-tempered."

og: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.
t: Well, at least she has no teeth to bite me with.

og: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'
t: "Next: She drinks liquor often."

og: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, Iwill; for good things should be praised.
t: If her liquor is good, she will drink it. If she won't drink it, I will—because good things should be drunk.

og: 'Item: She is too liberal.'
t: "Next: She is too unrestrained."

og: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she  is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that  I'll keep shut:
t: She can't be unrestrained in speaking, because the list says she is slow in that. She can't unrestrained with her money, because I will be in charge of the money.

og: now, of another thing she may, and  that cannot I help. Well, proceed.
t: Now, she may be unrestrained in another thing, and I can't help that. Well, carry on.

og: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faultsthan hairs, and more wealth than faults.'
t: "Next: She has more hair than wisdom; and more faults than hair; and more money than faults."

og: Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not  mine, twice or thrice in that last article.
t: Stop there. I will have her. She was mine, and then not mine—two or three times in that last item you read.

og: Rehearse that once more.
t: Say that one again.

og: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'—
t: "Next: She has more hair than wisdom,—"

og: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The  cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it  is more than the salt;
t: More hair than wisdom? It very well may be; let me prove it logically. The lid of a large salt container hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt.

og: the hair that covers the wit  is more than the wit, for the greater hides the  less. What's next?
t: The hair that covers the wisdom is more than the wisdom, because the greater hides the smaller. What's next?

og: 'And more faults than hairs,'—
t: "And more faults than hair,—"

og: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!
t: That's outrageous! Oh, that should not be on the list.

og: 'And more wealth than faults.'
t: "And more money than faults."

og: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing isimpossible,—
t: That fact makes the faults acceptable. Well, I'll have her; and if it's a match, since nothing is impossible—

og: What then?
t: Then what?

og: Why, then will I tell thee—that thy master staysfor thee at the North-gate.
t: Then I'll tell you that my master is waiting for you at the North Gate.

og: For me?
t: For me?

og: For thee! Ay, who art thou? He hath stayed for abetter man than thee.
t: For you! Yes, who are you? He has waited for a better man than you.

og: And must I go to him?
t: And should I go to him?

og: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so longthat going will scarce serve the turn.
t: You must run to him, because you've stayed here for so long that just going won't be enough.

og: Why didst not tell me sooner? Pox of your love letters!
t: Why didn't you tell me earlier? Curse your love letters!

og: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; anunmannerly slave, that will thrust himself intosecrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.
t: Now he will be beaten for reading my letter. He is an ill-mannered rascal who will reveal all secrets! I'll follow him so that I can enjoy watching his punishment.

og: Sir Turio, fear not but that she will love you,Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.
t: Sir Turio, don't be worried! She will love you now that Valentine is banished and out of her sight.

og: Since his exile she hath despised me most,Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,That I am desperate of obtaining her.
t: Since his departure, she has hated me the most. She's rejected my company, and ranted so abusively at me that I have no chance in gaining her favor.

og: This weak impress of love is as a figure  Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat  Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
t: This weak impression of love is a shape cut out ice, which will dissolve into water and lose its form if you heat it for an hour.

og: A little time will melt her frozen thoughts  And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.
t: A little time will melt her frozen thoughts, and she'll forget all about worthless Valentine.

og: How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countrymanAccording to our proclamation gone?
t: How are you, Sir Proteus? Is your friend gone, just like our announcement says?

og: Gone, my good lord.
t: He's gone, my good lord.

og: My daughter takes his going grievously.
t: My daughter grieves over his departure.

og: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.
t: It will take just a little time for her grief to be over, my lord.

og: So I believe; but Turio thinks not so.
t: I believe so too, but Turio doesn't think so.

og: Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee—  For thou hast shown some sign of good desert—  Makes me the better to confer with thee.
t: Since you've shown some signs that you deserve the good opinion I have of you, I feel more inclined to talk to you.

og: Longer than I prove loyal to your graceLet me not live to look upon your grace.
t: I will prove my loyalty to your Grace. If not, don't let me live any longer to look upon your face.

og: Thou know'st how willingly I would effectThe match between Sir Turio and my daughter.
t: You know how willingly I would bring about the marriage between Sir Turio and my daughter.

og: I do, my lord.
t: I do, my lord.

og: And also, I think, thou art not ignorantHow she opposes her against my will.
t: And I also think that you are quite aware of how vehemently she disagrees with my plan for her future.

og: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.
t: She did disagree when Valentine was here, my lord.

og: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
t: Yes, and she continues to do so.

og: What might we do to make the girl forget  The love of Valentine and love Sir Turio?
t: What could we do to make her forget her love for Valentine, and to love Sir Turio instead?

og: The best way is to slander Valentine  With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,
t: The best way is to speak badly of Valentine—speak of his falsehood, cowardice, and low social status.

og: Three things that women highly hold in hate.
t: Women hate these three things very much.

og: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.
t: Yes, but she'll think that this criticism is motivated by hatred.

og: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:Therefore it must with circumstance be spokenBy one whom she esteemeth as his friend.
t: Yes, but only if Valentine's enemy says these things to her. That's why someone she considers as his friend should speak about this with detailed evidence.

og: Then you must undertake to slander him.
t: Then you have to speak badly of him.

og: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,Especially against his very friend.
t: I am very reluctant to do that, my lord. It doesn't suit a gentleman, especially if he does it against his best friend.

og: Where your good word cannot advantage him,  Your slander never can endamage him;
t: Since your good words can't help him, your bad words can't hurt him.

og: Therefore the office is indifferent,  Being entreated to it by your friend.
t: Therefore, your position is indifferent, since I am asking you to do it as a friend.

og: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it  By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,  She shall not long continue love to him.
t: You have won me over, my lord. If I can do it by saying things in order to damage his reputation, she won't continue to love him.

og: But say this weed her love from Valentine,  It follows not that she will love Sir Turio.
t: But, even if we root out her love for Valentine, it doesn't necessarily mean that she will then love Sir Turio.

og: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,  Lest it should ravel and be good to none,  You must provide to bottom it on me;
t: Therefore, as you untangle her from her love for Valentine—unless it should get tangled up and be of no use to any of us—you must prepare to wind her around me.

og: Which must be done by praising me as much  As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.
t: This must be done by praising me just as much as you speak badly of Sir Valentine.

og: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,  Because we know, on Valentine's report,  You are already Love's firm votary  And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
t: And Proteus, we trust you with all of this because we know—from Valentine—that you are already a great preacher of love, and wouldn't go against it and change your mind all of a sudden.

og: Upon this warrant shall you have access  Where you with Silvia may confer at large;  For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,  And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
t: I authorize you to have access to Silvia; you may speak together as much as you want, since she is dull, gloomy, and melancholy. She'll be happy to see you, her friend.

og: Where you may temper her by your persuasion  To hate young Valentine and love my friend.
t: There you may mold her by your persuasion to hate young Valentine, and to love my friend Turio.

og: As much as I can do, I will effect:  But you, Sir Turio, are not sharp enough;
t: I will do as much as I can. [To TURIO] But you, Sir Turio, are not eager enough.

og: You must lay lime to tangle her desires  By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes  Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.
