t: You must lay a trap to catch her desires with longing love poems, whose carefully-constructed rhymes should be entirely filled with vows of service.

og: Ay,Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.
t: Yes, that's the poetry inspired by heaven.

og: Say that upon the altar of her beauty  You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:  Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears
t: Say to her that you sacrifice your tears, your sighs, and your heart on the altar of her beauty. Write until your pen is dry, and make it wet again with your tears.

og: Moist it again, and frame some feeling line  That may discover such integrity:  For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,  Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,  Make tigers tame and huge leviathans  Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
t: Compose some emotional poetry that may reveal your absolute devotion. Indeed, Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' tendons. When he played, his golden touch could melt steel and stones, make tigers tame, and huge sea monsters abandon the unfathomed parts of the sea.

og: After your dire-lamenting elegies,  Visit by night your lady's chamber-window  With some sweet concert; to their instruments  Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence  Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.  This, or else nothing, will inherit her.
t: After sending your deeply sorrowful, yearning love poems, come to the window of your lady's room at night with a group of musicians. Sing a melancholic melody to the music of their instruments. The night's dead silence will be perfect for such a sweet lament. If this doesn't win her over, nothing will.

og: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.
t: This teaching shows that you have been in love.

og: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.  Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,  Let us into the city presently  To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
t: And I'll put your advice to practice tonight. Therefore, sweet Proteus, my giver of directions: let's go to the city at once, to choose some gentlemen who are skilled musicians.

og: I have a sonnet that will serve the turn  To give the onset to thy good advice.
t: I have a sonnet that will work; it will do the trick, according to your good advice.

og: About it, gentlemen!
t: Get on with it, gentlemen!

og: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,And afterward determine our proceedings.
t: We'll wait for your Grace until after dinner, and then we'll determine what to do afterwards.

og: Even now about it! I will pardon you.
t: So get on with it now! I excuse you.

og: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.
t: Be ready, guys. I see a traveler.

og: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.
t: If there are ten of them, don't hesitate. Take them down.

og: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.
t: Stop, sir, and give us what you've got there. If not, we'll make you sit, and we'll rob you.

og: Sir, we are undone; these are the villainsThat all the travellers do fear so much.
t: Sir, this is the end of us. These are the villains that all travelers are afraid of.

og: My friends,—
t: My friends—

og: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.
t: No, sir. We are your enemies.

og: Peace! We'll hear him.
t: Quiet! Let's hear him out.

og: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.
t: Yes, I swear by my beard that we will. He is a fine-looking man.

og: Then know that I have little wealth to lose:  A man I am cross'd with adversity;
t: Then you should know that I don't have much wealth to lose. I am a man destroyed by misfortune.

og: My riches are these poor habiliments,  Of which if you should here disfurnish me,  You take the sum and substance that I have.
t: I only own these poor clothes, and if you would deprive me of those, you'd take everything that I have.

og: Whither travel you?
t: Where are you heading?

og: To Verona.
t: To Verona.

og: Whence came you?
t: Where did you come from?

og: From Milan.
t: From Milan.

og: Have you long sojourned there?
t: Did you stay there for a long time?

og: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.
t: Around sixteen months; we might have stayed longer if such bad luck hadn't come my way.

og: What, were you banish'd thence?
t: What, were you banished from there?

og: I was.
t: I was.

og: For what offence?
t: For what crime?

og: For that which now torments me to rehearse:  I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;
t: For something that's painful to repeat now. I killed a man, and I regret his death very much.

og: But yet I slew him manfully in fight,  Without false vantage or base treachery.
t: But I killed him in a fight like a man should, without unfair advantage or lowly treachery.

og: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.But were you banish'd for so small a fault?
t: Well, since it was done in that way, you don't have to regret it. But were you banished for just this small crime?

og: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.
t: I was, and I was glad to get such a reasonable sentence.

og: Have you the tongues?
t: Can you speak any foreign languages?

og: My youthful travel therein made me happy,Or else I often had been miserable.
t: Thanks to the traveling I did in my younger years, I am accomplished in speaking other languages. Otherwise, I would have been miserable quite often.

og: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,This fellow were a king for our wild faction!
t: By the bare head of Robin Hood's fat priest, this guy would be a king for our wild group!

og: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.
t: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

og: Master, be one of them; it's an honourable kind of thievery.
t: Master, you should be one of them! It's an honorable kind of thievery.

og: Peace, villain!
t: Quiet, rogue!

og: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?
t: Tell us: do you have any resources?

og: Nothing but my fortune.
t: Nothing apart from my fortune.

og: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,  Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth  Thrust from the company of awful men:
t: You should know that some of us are gentlemen, thrust from the company of respectful men like reckless youngsters.

og: Myself was from Verona banished  For practising to steal away a lady,  An heir, and near allied unto the duke.
t: I was banished from Verona for plotting to steal a lady, an heir, who was closely allied with the Duke.

og: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.
t: And I was banished from Mantua because I stabbed a gentlemen in the heart in a rage.

og: And I for such like petty crimes as these,  But to the purpose—for we cite our faults,  That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives;
t: And I was banished for small crimes like these. But let's focus on our purpose. We acknowledge our faults so that they may justify our lawless lives.

og: And partly, seeing you are beautified  With goodly shape and by your own report  A linguist and a man of such perfection  As we do in our quality much want—
t: And also because we see that you are of a beautiful physical appearance; and by what you said to us, you're a linguist and a man of such perfection that we would want you in our profession.

og: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,  Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
t: Indeed, because you are a banished man, we negotiate with you. We're suggesting this because of this reason above all.

og: Are you content to be our general?  To make a virtue of necessity  And live, as we do, in this wilderness?
t: Would you be happy to be our general? To make a virtue of necessity and live like we do, in this wilderness?

og: What say'st thou? Wilt thou be of our consort?
t: What do you say? Will you be a part of our company?

og: Say ay, and be the captain of us all:  We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,  Love thee as our commander and our king.
t: Say yes, and be our captain. We'll perform acts of allegiance, be ruled by you, and love you as our commander and our king.

og: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.
t: But if you reject what we offer you, you'll die.

og: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.
t: You won't live to boast about what we've just offered you.

og: I take your offer and will live with you,
t: I accept your offer and will live with you—

og: Provided that you do no outrages  On silly women or poor passengers.
t: but only if you won't commit any acts of violence on defenseless women or poor travelers.

og: No, we detest such vile base practises.  Come, go with us,
t: No, we hate such vicious practices. Come along with us!

og: we'll bring thee to our crews,  And show thee all the treasure we have got,  Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.
t: We'll take you to our gang, and show you all our treasures. Like us, they are at your disposal.

og: Already have I been false to Valentine  And now I must be as unjust to Turio.  Under the colour of commending him,  I have access my own love to prefer:
t: I have already lied to Valentine, and now I have to be unfair to Turio. Under the pretense of praising him, I have access to my own love, and can praise her.

og: But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,  To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.  When I protest true loyalty to her,  She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
t: But Silvia is too beautiful, too true, too saintly, to be corrupted by my worthless gifts. When I swear true loyalty to her, she'll taunt me for how falsely I've treated my friend.

og: When to her beauty I commend my vows,  She bids me think how I have been forsworn  In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
t: When I declare my vows to her beauty, she'll ask me to think about how I have broken a promise to Julia, whom I loved.

og: And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,  The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,  Yet, spaniel-like,
t: Despite all her sudden sharp retorts—the smallest of which would crush a lover's hope—I'll be devoted to her like a dog.

og: the more she spurns my love,  The more it grows and fawneth on her still.
t: The more she rejects my love, the more it grows and flatters her still.

og: But here comes Turio: now must we to her window,  And give some evening music to her ear.
t: But here comes Turio. Now we must go to her window, and play some evening music for her.

og: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?
t: How are you, Sir Proteus? Have you snuck here quietly before us?

og: Ay, gentle Turio: for you know that loveWill creep in service where it cannot go.
t: Yes, noble Turio. Because you know that love will crawl in service where it is forbidden to go.

og: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.
t: Yes. But I hope, sir, that you don't come here as a lover.

og: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.
t: But I do, sir. Otherwise I wouldn't be here.

og: Who? Silvia?
t: Whom do you love? Silvia?

og: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.
t: Yes, Silvia—in your name.

og: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.
t: Thank you, for your own sake, that you made your meaning clear. Now, gentlemen, let's play and do so heartily!

og: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: Ipray you, why is it?
t: My young guest, I think you're melancholic. Tell me, what's wrong?

og: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.
t: Indeed, I can't be happy, my host.

og: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you whereyou shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.
t: Come, we'll make you happy! I'll bring you where you will hear music, and see the gentleman that you asked for.

og: But shall I hear him speak?
t: But will I hear him speak?

og: Ay, that you shall.
t: Yes, you will.

og: That will be music.
t: Now that will be music.

og: Hark, hark!
t: Listen, listen!

og: Is he among these?
t: Is he among these gentlemen?

og: Ay: but, peace! Let's hear 'em.
t: Yes, but quiet! Let's hear them!

og: Who is Silvia? What is she?  That all our swains commend her?  Holy, fair and wise is she;
t: Who is Silvia? What is she? That all our lovers praise her? She is saintly, beautiful and wise.

og: The heaven such grace did lend her,  That she might admired be.  Is she kind as she is fair?  For beauty lives with kindness.
t: The heavens lent her such virtue, So that she might be admired. Is she as kind as she is beautiful? Because beauty lives with kindness.

og: Love doth to her eyes repair,  To help him of his blindness,  And, being help'd, inhabits there.  Then to Silvia let us sing,  That Silvia is excelling;
t: Love hastens to her eyes, To help him with his blindness, And being helped, stays there. Then let us sing to Silvia, That Silvia is perfection.

og: She excels each mortal thing  Upon the dull earth dwelling:  To her let us garlands bring.
t: She is better than every mortal thingDwelling on this dull earth: Let us bring wreaths to her.

og: How now! Are you sadder than you were before? Howdo you, man? The music likes you not.
t: What's this? Are you sadder than you were before? What's wrong, man? The music doesn't please you.

og: You mistake; the musician likes me not.
t: You're wrong. The musician doesn't please me.

og: Why, my pretty youth?
t: Why, my pretty young boy?

og: He plays false, father.
t: He plays out of tune, old man.

og: How? Out of tune on the strings?
t: Out of tune on the strings?

og: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my veryheart-strings.
t: No. But yet he's so out of tune that he makes my heart-strings sad.

og: You have a quick ear.
t: You have a sharp ear.

og: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.
t: Yes. I wish that I were deaf. This is making my heart heavy.

og: I perceive you delight not in music.
t: I see that you don't enjoy music.

og: Not a whit, when it jars so.
t: Not at all, when it sounds discordant like this.

og: Hark, what fine change is in the music!
t: Listen, what a nice variation in the music!

og: Ay, that change is the spite.
t: Yes, that change is what vexes me.

og: You would have them always play but one thing?
t: You would have them always play only one melody?

og: I would always have one play but one thing.But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk onOften resort unto this gentlewoman?
t: I would always have one play only one melody. But, host, does this Sir Proteus that we are talking about come to see this gentlewoman often?

og: I tell you what Lance, his man, told me: he lovedher out of all nick.
t: I'll tell you what his servant Lance told me. He loved her beyond reckoning.

og: Where is Lance?
t: Where is Lance?

og: Gone to seek his dog; which tomorrow, by hismaster's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.
t: He's gone to look for his dog, which he must carry to his lady as a present tomorrow—as his master ordered.

og: Peace! Stand aside: the company parts.
t: Quiet! Let's back up. The men are leaving.

og: Sir Turio, fear not you: I will so pleadThat you shall say my cunning drift excels.
t: Sir Turio, don't be afraid. I will carry on so that you shall say my clever plan is successful.

og: Where meet we?
t: Where should we meet?

og: At Saint Gregory's well.
t: At Saint Gregory's Well.

og: Farewell.
t: Goodbye.

og: Madam, good even to your ladyship.
t: Madam, good evening to your Ladyship.

og: I thank you for your music, gentlemen.Who is that that spake?
t: Thank you for your music, gentlemen. Who was the man that spoke to me?

og: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.
t: One whose voice you would quickly learn to recognize, if you knew the truth of his pure heart.

og: Sir Proteus, as I take it.
t: I take it that it's Sir Proteus.

og: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.
t: Sir Proteus, noble lady. I am your servant.

og: What's your will?
t: What's your intent?

og: That I may compass yours.
t: That I may fulfill your wishes.

og: You have your wish; my will is even this:  That presently you hie you home to bed.  Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man!
t: You have your wish. My wish is this: that you hurry home to bed immediately. You treacherous, lying, false, disloyal man!

og: Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,  To be seduced by thy flattery,  That hast deceived so many with thy vows?
t: Do you think that I am so shallow, so witless that I can be seduced by your flattery; you that have deceived so many with your promises?

og: Return, return, and make thy love amends.  For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,  I am so far from granting thy request  That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,
t: Return, return, and make things right with your beloved. I swear by this moon that I am so far from agreeing to your request that I hate you and your insulting courtship.

og: And by and by intend to chide myself  Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.
t: And for that, I plan to scold myself for spending even this time talking to you.

og: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady;But she is dead.
t: I agree, sweet love, that I did love a lady. But she is dead.

og: 'Twere false, if I should speak it;For I am sure she is not buried.
t: That's not true, if I should say it. I'm sure she's not buried yet.

og: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend  Survives; to whom,
t: Even if she is dead, your friend Valentine is alive.

og: thyself art witness,  I am betroth'd  : and art thou not ashamed  To wrong him with thy importunacy?
t: You know that we are engaged, and yet you're not ashamed to wrong him with your persistent courtship?

og: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.
t: I also heard that Valentine is dead.

og: And so suppose am I; for in his graveAssure thyself my love is buried.
t: So then, imagine that I am dead too. You can be sure that my love is buried with Valentine in his grave.

og: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.
t: Sweet lady, let me gather your buried love from the earth.

og: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence,Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.
t: Go to your lady's grave, and call her there. Or at least bury your love with hers there.

og: He heard not that.
t: He didn't hear that.

og: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,  Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,  The picture that is hanging in your chamber;
t: Madam, if your heart is so unyielding, allow me to get your picture for my love. The picture that is hanging in your room.

og: To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep:  For since the substance of your perfect self  Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;  And to your shadow will I make true love.
t: I'll speak to that; I'll sigh and cry to that. Since the substance of your perfect self is devoted elsewhere, I am only a shadow. I will woo your image.

og: If 'twere a substance, you would, sure,deceive it,And make it but a shadow, as I am.
t: If this picture of Silvia were a real live woman, you would be unfaithful to it. You'd act as if it were a mere shadow to be discarded—the same way you've treated me.

og: I am very loath to be your idol, sir;
t: I hate to be your idol, sir.

og: But since your falsehood shall become you well  To worship shadows and adore false shapes,
t: It would be just like you to worship shadows and adore false shapes, because you are so false to women.

og: Send to me in the morning and I'll send it:  And so, good rest.
t: Send for the picture in the morning and I'll give it to you. And so, goodnight

og: As wretches have o'ernightThat wait for execution in the morn.
t: I feel like the wretches who have to wait overnight for an execution in the morning.

og: Host, will you go?
t: Host, will you go?

og: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.
t: By all I consider holy, I fell asleep.

og: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?
t: Tell me, where is Sir Proteus staying?

og: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almostday.
t: Indeed, at my inn. Trust me, I think it's almost day.

og: Not so; but it hath been the longest nightThat e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.
t: No, it's not. But it has been the longest night that I've ever stayed up, and the most sorrowful.

og: This is the hour that Madam Silvia  Entreated me to call and know her mind:
t: This is the time that Madam Silvia told me to come and talk to her.

og: There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.  Madam, madam!
t: There's something she wants me to do. [To SILVIA] Madam, madam!

og: Who calls?
t: Who's calling me?

og: Your servant and your friend;One that attends your ladyship's command.
t: Your servant and your friend. One that is waiting to hear your Ladyship's order.

og: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.
t: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morning.

og: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:  According to your ladyship's impose,
t: As many good mornings to yourself, worthy lady. According to your ladyship's command,

og: I am thus early come to know what service  It is your pleasure to command me in.
t: I was supposed to come this early to find out what service you'd like me to carry out.

og: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman—  Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not—  Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd:
t: Oh, Eglamour, you are a gentleman. Don't think that I'm flattering you; I swear I'm not. You are brave, wise, compassionate, well-accomplished.

og: Thou art not ignorant what dear good will  I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,  Nor how my father would enforce me marry  Vain Turio, whom my very soul abhors.
t: You know how much I care about the banished Valentine, and how my father wants to force me to marry the foolish Turio, whom I hate with all my heart.

og: Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say  No grief did ever come so near thy heart  As when thy lady and thy true love died,  Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.
t: You have been in love. And I have heard you say that you have never felt more grief in your heart than you did when your lady—your true love—died. And you have vowed pure chastity on her grave.

og: Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,  To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode;  And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,  I do desire thy worthy company,  Upon whose faith and honour I repose.
t: Sir Eglamour, I want to go to Valentine in Mantua, where I heard he is. And since the journey is dangerous, I would like your worthy company, because I rely on your faith and honor.

og: Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,  But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,  And on the justice of my flying hence,  To keep me from a most unholy match,  Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.
t: Don't encourage my father's anger, Eglamour. Just think about my grief—a lady's grief—and about the justice of my running away from here; and from a most unholy marriage—which heaven and fortune would always make horrible.

og: I do desire thee, even from a heart  As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,  To bear me company and go with me:  If not, to hide what I have said to thee,  That I may venture to depart alone.
t: This is coming from a heart as full of sorrows as the sea is full of sand. I want you to keep me company and go with me. If you won't then keep secret what I have said to you so that I may go alone.

og: Madam, I pity much your grievances;  Which since I know they virtuously are placed,  I give consent to go along with you,
t: Madam, I am sorry for your distress. Since I know your cause is right and virtuous, I agree to go with you.

og: Recking as little what betideth me  As much I wish all good befortune you.  When will you go?
t: I don't care much about what will happen to me. My wish is that only good things happen to you. When are you planning on going?

og: This evening coming.
t: This evening.

og: Where shall I meet you?
t: Where shall I meet you?

og: At Friar Patrick's cell,Where I intend holy confession.
t: At Friar Patrick's cell, where I intend to make a holy confession.

og: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.
t: You can rely on me, your Ladyship. Have a good morning, gentle lady.

og: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.
t: Good morning to you, too, kind Sir Eglamour.

og: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him,  look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a  puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when three or  four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it.
t: When a master's servant behaves like a dog to him, it is tough. I brought this one up from a puppy; I saved this one from drowning, when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters drowned.

og: I have taught him, even as one would say precisely,  'thus I would teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver  him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master;  and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he  steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg:
t: I have taught him, even as one would say precisely, "I would teach a dog like this." I was sent to deliver him as a present from my master to Mistress Silvia, and as soon as I came into the dining room, he comes to her plate and steals her chicken leg.

og: O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself  in all companies! I would have, as one should say,  one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be,  as it were, a dog at all things.
t: Oh, it's a horrible thing when a dog can't behave himself in different kinds of company! But, as they really should say, I happen to have a dog that is a dog indeed—a dog in everything he does.

og: If I had not had  more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did,  I think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as I  live, he had suffered for't; you shall judge.
t: If I didn't have more wisdom than he does—to plead guilty for his wrongdoing—I really think he would have been hanged for it. For as sure as I live, he's suffered for it, as you'll see.

og: He  thrusts me himself into the company of three or four  gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had  not been there—bless the mark!—a pissing while, but  all the chamber smelt him.
t: He thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentlemanly dogs under the Duke's table. He had not been there (pardon my language) as long as the time it takes to piss—and everybody in the room smelled him.

og: 'Out with the dog!' says  one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him  out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke.
t: "Out with the dog!" someone says. "What dog is that?" someone else says. "Whip him!" a third says. "Hang him up" says the Duke.

og: I, having been acquainted with the smell before,  knew it was Crab,
t: Since I have known the smell before, I knew it was Crab.

og: and goes me to the fellow that  whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip  the dog?'
t: So I go to the man that whips the dogs: "Friend," I say, "are you going to whip the dog?"

og: 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he.
t: "Yes, I am" he says.

og: 'You do him  the more wrong,' quoth I; ''twas I did the thing you  wot of.'
t: "You'll make things even worse for him if you do," I say. "I was the one who did the thing you know about."

og: He makes me no more ado, but whips me out  of the chamber.
t: He makes no more fuss about it, but whips me out of the room.

og: How many masters would do this for  his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the  stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had  been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese  he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't.  Thou thinkest not of this now.
t: How many masters would do this for their servants? No, I swear, I have sat in the stocks for sausages he has stolen. Otherwise, he would have been executed. I have also been punished for geese he has killed. Otherwise, he would have suffered for it. Don't think about this now.

og: Nay, I remember the  trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam  Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I  do? When didst thou see me heave up my leg and make  water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? Didst  thou ever see me do such a trick?
t: No, I remember the trick you played on me when I left Madam Silvia. Didn't I ask you to always pay attention to me, just like I pay attention to you? When did you see me raise up my leg and urinate onto a gentlewoman's skirt? Have you ever seen me do such a trick?

og: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee wellAnd will employ thee in some service presently.
t: Is your name Sebastian? I like you, and so I'll give you a job to do soon.

og: In what you please: I'll do what I can.
t: I'll do whatever you'd like, if I can.

og: I hope thou wilt.
t: I hope you will.

og: How now, you whoreson peasant!Where have you been these two days loitering?
t: What's this? You bastard peasant! Where have you been these past two days?

og: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.
t: I carried the dog to Mistress Silvia like you asked me to, sir.

og: And what says she to my little jewel?
t: And what does she say to my pretty little dog?

og: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells youcurrish thanks is good enough for such a present.
t: She says that your dog is badly-behaved. And she tells you that a snide "thanks" is good enough for a present like that.

og: But she received my dog?
t: But did she receive my dog?

og: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought himback again.
t: No, she didn't. I have brought him back here again.

og: What, didst thou offer her this from me?
t: Wait a second! Did you offer her this dog from me?

og: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by  the hangman boys in the market-place:
t: Yes, sir. Some mischievous boys in the market square stole the other small dog from me.

og: and then I  offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of  yours,
t: So then I offered her my own dog, who is as big as ten of yours.

og: and therefore the gift the greater.
t: And therefore the gift was all the greater.

og: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,  Or ne'er return again into my sight.
t: Get out of here and go find my dog! And if you don't, I don't ever want to see you again.

og: Away, I say! Stay'st thou to vex me here?
t: Go away, I say! Are you staying here to make me angry?

og: A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!  Sebastian, I have entertained thee,  Partly that I have need of such a youth  That can with some discretion do my business,
t: He is a rascal that continuously makes me ashamed! Sebastian, I have taken you into service, partly because I need such a young boy who can carry out my business with discretion.

og: For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,  But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,  Which, if my augury deceive me not,  Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:
t: There's no point in trusting that foolish man over there. But I have mostly employed you because of your face and your manners, which—if my prediction is correct—are evidence of a good upbringing, fortune, and truth.

og: Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.  Go presently and take this ring with thee,  Deliver it to Madam Silvia:  She loved me well deliver'd it to me.
t: Therefore, you should know that I have taken you for these reasons. Go at once and take this ring with you. Deliver it to Madam Silvia. The girl who gave it to me loved me well.

og: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.She is dead, belike?
t: It seems that you didn't love her, since you parted with her token. Is she dead?

og: Not so; I think she lives.
t: No, I think she is alive.

og: Alas!
t: Ah!

og: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?
t: Why do you cry, "Ah?"

og: I cannot chooseBut pity her.
t: I can't help myself: I feel sorry for her.

og: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?
t: Why should you feel sorry for her?

og: Because methinks that she loved you as well  As you do love your lady Silvia:
t: Because I think that she loved you as well as you love your lady Silvia.

og: She dreams of him that has forgot her love;  You dote on her that cares not for your love.
t: She dreams of the man who has forgotten her love. You are obsessed with someone who doesn't care to have your love.

og: 'Tis pity love should be so contrary;  And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'
t: It's a pity that love should be so contrary. And thinking of it makes me cry, "Ah!"

og: Well, give her that ring and therewithal  This letter. That's her chamber.
t: Well, give her that ring, and with it, this letter. That's her room there.

og: Tell my lady  I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.
t: Tell my lady that she should keep her promise and give me her heavenly picture.

og: Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,  Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.
t: Once you deliver the message, go home to my room, where you will find me sad and alone.

og: How many women would do such a message?  Alas, poor Proteus! Thou hast entertain'd  A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.
t: How many women would carry such a message? Ah, poor Proteus! You have employed a fox to be the shepherd of your lambs.

og: Alas, poor fool! Why do I pity him  That with his very heart despiseth me?  Because he loves her, he despiseth me;  Because I love him I must pity him.
t: Oh, I am a poor fool! Why do I pity the man who hates me with his heart? Because he loves her, he hates me.  And because I love him, I have to feel sorry for him.

og: This ring I gave him when he parted from me,  To bind him to remember my good will;  And now am I, unhappy messenger,  To plead for that which I would not obtain,  To carry that which I would have refused,  To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.
t: I gave him this ring when we said goodbye—to make him promise to remember me. And now I am an unhappy messenger, who has to ask for the picture that I don't want to get; to carry the ring which I should have refused; to praise his faith—which I should have said bad things about.

og: I am my master's true-confirmed love;  But cannot be true servant to my master,  Unless I prove false traitor to myself.
t: I am my master's truly-confirmed love. But I cannot be a true servant to my master, unless I betray myself.

og: Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly  As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.
t: Yes, I will woo Silvia for him. But I'll do it coldly since I don't want him to succeed, as heaven knows.

og: Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my meanTo bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.
t: Good day, gentlewoman! I beg you to take me where I can speak with Madam Silvia.

og: What would you with her, if that I be she?
t: What do you want with her? Pretend that I'm her.

og: If you be she, I do entreat your patienceTo hear me speak the message I am sent on.
t: If you are her, then I ask you to patiently hear the message I am sent here to deliver.

og: From whom?
t: A message from whom?

og: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.
t: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

og: O, he sends you for a picture.
t: Oh, he sends you here for a picture.

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: Ursula, bring my picture here.  Go give your master this:
t: [To a servant] Ursula, bring my picture here. [To JULIA] Go and give your master this.

og: tell him from me,  One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,  Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.
t: Tell him, from me, that one Julia—whom he has forgotten in his changing thoughts—would better suit his room than this shadow of a picture.

og: Madam, please you peruse this letter.—
t: [She hands SILVIA a letter] Madam, please read this letter—

og: Pardon me, madam;
t: Wait! Pardon me, madam.

og: I have unadvised  Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:
t: I have accidentally given you a paper that I shouldn't have.

og: This is the letter to your ladyship.
t: [She hands SILVIA another letter] This is the letter addressed to your Ladyship.

og: I pray thee, let me look on that again.
t: Please, let me look at that one again.

og: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.
t: No, I don't think that's a good idea, good madam. Forgive me.

og: There, hold!  I will not look upon your master's lines:
t: Wait a moment! I will not read your master's lines.

og: I know they are stuff'd with protestations  And full of new-found oaths; which he will break  As easily as I do tear his paper.
t: I know they are full of declarations of love and recently-invented oaths—which he will break as easily as I tear his letter apart.

og: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.
t: Madam, he sends your Ladyship this ring.

og: The more shame for him that he sends it me;  For I have heard him say a thousand times  His Julia gave it him at his departure.
t: He should be ashamed for sending it to me, because I have heard him say a thousand times that his Julia gave him this ring when they said goodbye.

og: Though his false finger have profaned the ring,  Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.
t: Though his false finger has abused the ring, my finger will not do his Julia so much wrong by wearing the ring.

og: She thanks you.
t: She thanks you.

og: What say'st thou?
t: What did you say?

og: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.Poor gentlewoman! My master wrongs her much.
t: I thank you, madam, that you care for her. Poor gentlewoman! My master has really wronged her.

og: Dost thou know her?
t: Do you know her?

og: Almost as well as I do know myself:To think upon her woes I do protestThat I have wept a hundred several times.
t: Almost as well as I know myself. I have thought about her suffering a hundred times, and it has made me cry.

og: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.
t: She probably thinks that Proteus has abandoned her.

og: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.
t: I think she does, and that's why she is mourning.

og: Is she not passing fair?
t: Isn't she beautiful?

og: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:  When she did think my master loved her well,  She, in my judgment, was as fair as you:
t: She has been more beautiful than she is now, madam. When she thought that my master loved her, I think she was as beautiful as you.

og: But since she did neglect her looking-glass  And threw her sun-expelling mask away,  The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks  And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,  That now she is become as black as I.
t: But since she stopped looking in the mirror and threw her mask away, the air has starved the rosy blush on her cheeks, and eroded the lily-white color of her face, so now she has become as black as I.

og: How tall was she?
t: How tall was she?

og: About my stature; for at Pentecost,  When all our pageants of delight were play'd,  Our youth got me to play the woman's part,  And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,  Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,  As if the garment had been made for me:
t: About my height, because at Pentecost, when all our enjoyable plays are performed, I played the woman's part. And I dressed up in Madam Julia's dress, which fitted me as well as my men's clothes, as if the dress was made for me.

og: Therefore I know she is about my height.  And at that time I made her weep agood,  For I did play a lamentable part:
t: Therefore, I know she is about my height. And, at that time, I made her cry in earnest because I played a tragic role.

og: Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning  For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;  Which I so lively acted with my tears  That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,  Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead  If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!
t: It was Ariadne's passionate sorrowing for Theseus not keeping his promise and unjustly running away, madam. I was so convincing with my acting, and even shed tears. Because of this, my poor mistress—moved by it all—cried bitterly. If I didn't feel her sorrow in that moment, I should have been dead!

og: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.  Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!  I weep myself to think upon thy words.
t: She is indebted to you, gentle boy. Ah, poor lady, abandoned and left behind! I cry just thinking about your words.

og: Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this  For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.  Farewell.
t: Here, boy, take my purse. I give you this for the sake of your sweet mistress, because you love her. Goodbye.

og: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.  A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful  I hope my master's suit will be but cold,  Since she respects my mistress' love so much.
t: And she will thank you for it, if you ever meet her. She is a virtuous, kind and beautiful gentlewoman. I hope my master's wooing will be received coldly, since Silvia respects my mistress Julia's love so much.

og: Alas, how love can trifle with itself!  Here is her picture: let me see; I think,  If I had such a tire, this face of mine  Were full as lovely as is this of hers:  And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,  Unless I flatter with myself too much.
t: Ah, how love can play with itself! Here is her picture. Let me see, I think if I had accessories like these, my face would be as lovely as hers. And yet the painter painted her more beautiful than she is, unless I think of myself as more beautiful.

og: Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:  If that be all the difference in his love,  I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.  Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:  Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.
t: Her hair is auburn, mine is perfectly blond. If that's the only difference in his love, I can get myself a wig of that color. Her eyes are as gray as glass—and so are mine. Yes, but her forehead is low, whereas mine is high.

og: What should it be that he respects in her  But I can make respective in myself,  If this fond Love were not a blinded god?  Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up,  For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,  Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored!
t: What does he admire in her that I can make worthy of respect in myself—if this Love were not a blinded god? Come, shadow. Come and pick up this picture of a shadow, since it's your rival. Oh, you unconscious image: you will be worshiped, kissed, loved and adored!

og: And, were there sense in his idolatry,  My substance should be statue in thy stead.  I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,  That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow,  I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes  To make my master out of love with thee!
t: And if Proteus' idolatry were to make sense, I would be the idol instead of you. I'll treat you kindly for the sake of your mistress Silvia, who likewise treated me kindly. Or else I'll swear by Jove that I should have scratched out your unseeing eyes to make my master fall out of love with you!

og: The sun begins to gild the western sky;  And now it is about the very hour  That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.
t: The sun begins to tinge the western sky with gold. And now it's time for Silva to meet me at Friar Patrick's place.

og: She will not fail, for lovers break not hours,  Unless it be to come before their time;  So much they spur their expedition.
t: She won't be late. Lovers never miss the time they're supposed to meet up—unless they arrive early if they really can't wait to see each other.

og: See where she comes.
t: Here she comes.

og: Lady, a happy evening!
t: Good evening to you, lady!

og: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:I fear I am attended by some spies.
t: Amen to that! Let's go, good Eglamour. Let's go out at the back gate by the abbey wall. I am afraid that some spies are following me.

og: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;If we recover that, we are sure enough.
t: Don't be afraid. The forest is less than nine miles away. If we reach it, we'll be safe enough.

og: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?
t: Sir Proteus, what does Silvia say about my wooing?

og: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;And yet she takes exceptions at your person.
t: Oh, sir, I think she is more gracious than she was before. And yet, she is not so sure about your physical appearance.

og: What, that my leg is too long?
t: What? Is it because my legs are too long?

og: No; that it is too little.
t: No, it's because your legs are too thin.

og: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.
t: I'll wear boots to make my legs look a bit thicker.

og: But love will not be spurr'd to whatit loathes.
t: But love won't be inspired by something it hates.

og: What says she to my face?
t: What does she say about my face?

og: She says it is a fair one.
t: She says it's pale.

og: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.
t: No, I think that willful woman lies. My face is tan.

og: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.
t: But pearls are white. And the old saying goes that tan men are pearls in the eyes of beautiful ladies.

og: 'Tis true; such pearls as put outladies' eyes;For I had rather wink than look on them.
t: That's true. Such pearls make ladies' eyes useless. I would rather shut my eyes than look at them.

og: How likes she my discourse?
t: How does she like my conversation?

og: Ill, when you talk of war.
t: She doesn't like it when you talk about violence.

og: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?
t: Then, what does she think when I speak about love and peace?

og: But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.
t: It's better when you just keep silent.

og: What says she to my valour?
t: What does she say about my bravery?

og: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.
t: Oh, sir, she has no doubt of that.

og: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.
t: She doesn't need to doubt your bravery, because she knows that you're a coward.

og: What says she to my birth?
t: What does she say about my noble ancestry?

og: That you are well derived.
t: That you are well descended.

og: True; from a gentleman to a fool.
t: True. You've gone from a gentleman to a fool.

og: Considers she my possessions?
t: Does she consider my possessions?

og: O, ay; and pities them.
t: Oh, yes, and she feels sorry for them.

og: Wherefore?
t: Why?

og: That such an ass should owe them.
t: Because such an ass owns them.

og: That they are out by lease.
t: That they are borrowed or rented and not entirely in your possession.

og: Here comes the duke.
t: Here comes the Duke.

og: How now, Sir Proteus! How now, Turio!Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?
t: Sir Proteus! How's it going? And Turio, how are you? Which of you saw Sir Eglamour recently?

og: Not I.
t: I didn't.

og: Nor I.
t: Neither did I.

og: Saw you my daughter?
t: Have you seen my daughter?

og: Neither.
t: Not her either.

og: Why then,  She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;  And Eglamour is in her company.
t: Well, then, she has run away to find that peasant Valentine, and Eglamour has accompanied her.

og: 'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,  As he in penance wander'd through the forest;  Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,  But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;
t: It's true. Friar Lawrence has met them both as he wandered through the forest, repenting. He recognized Eglamour, and guessed that it was Silvia—but since she was masked, he wasn't sure of it.

og: Besides, she did intend confession  At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;  These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
t: Besides, she was planning on going to confession tonight at Patrick's place, but she wasn't there. All of these instances confirm that she has run away.

og: Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,  But mount you presently and meet with me  Upon the rising of the mountain-foot  That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:
t: Therefore, please, don't delay by talking. Get on horseback at once, and meet me by the base of the mountain that leads toward Mantua, where they are going.

og: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.
t: Hurry up, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

og: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,  That flies her fortune when it follows her.
t: Well, she's a foolish girl for fleeing from a good courtship when it follows her.

og: I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour  Than for the love of reckless Silvia.
t: I'll go after her—not so much because I love the uncaring Silvia, but more because I want to take revenge on Eglamour.

og: And I will follow, more for Silvia's loveThan hate of Eglamour that goes with her.
t: And I'll follow—because I love Silvia more than I hate Eglamour, who accompanies her.

og: And I will follow, more to cross that loveThan hate for Silvia that is gone for love.
t: And I'll follow, so I can frustrate Proteus' love—not because I hate Silvia, who has left for love's sake.

og: Come, come,Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.
t: Come, come and be patient. We have to bring you to our captain.

og: A thousand more mischances than this oneHave learn'd me how to brook this patiently.
t: A thousand misfortunes greater than this one have taught me how to endure this patiently.

og: Come, bring her away.
t: Come, bring her here.

og: Where is the gentleman that was with her?
t: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

og: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,  But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
t: He moved quickly and lightly, so he outran us. But Moyses and Valerius are following him.

og: Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;  There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;  The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.
t: Go with her to the west end of the forest—that's where our captain is. We'll follow the one who ran away. The bushes surround him; he can't escape.

og: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,And will not use a woman lawlessly.
t: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave. Don't be afraid. He has an honorable mind, and won't mistreat a woman.

og: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!
t: Oh, Valentine, I bear all of this for you!

og: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
t: Increasing familiarity can make people feel more at home, no matter where they are!

og: This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,  I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:
t: This shadowy deserted place—a forest that no one ever visits—now feels better to me than towns bustling with people.

og: Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,  And to the nightingale's complaining notes  Tune my distresses and record my woes.
t: Here, I can sit alone, and no one sees me. I can tune the sad songs I sing to the nightingale's sorrowful notes.

og: O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,  Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,  Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall  And leave no memory of what it was!
t: Oh, you that live in my breast: don't leave my love's dwelling place so long without a tenant. Otherwise, it will become a ruin, and the building will fall and leave no memory of what it was!

og: Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;  Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain!  What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
t: Revive me with your presence, Silvia. You gentle, beautiful creature: treasure me, your abandoned lover! What's this shouting and what hustle do we have here today?

og: These are my mates, that make their wills their law,  Have some unhappy passenger in chase.
t: These are my friends that make their desires into their laws. They are following some unfortunate traveler.

og: They love me well; yet I have much to do  To keep them from uncivil outrages.
t: They love me, but I have a lot to do to keep them from committing uncivil and shocking acts.

og: Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?
t: Valentine, keep away for now. Who's coming here?

og: Madam, this service I have done for you,  Though you respect not aught your servant doth,
t: Madam, I have done you this service. But you don't value what I—your servant—have done.

og: To hazard life and rescue you from him  That would have forced your honour and your love;
t: I risked my life and rescued you from the outlaw that would have raped you.

og: Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;
t: Give me just one beautiful look as my reward.

og: A smaller boon than this I cannot beg  And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.
t: I cannot ask for a smaller favor. And I am sure this is the least you can do for me.

og: How like a dream is this I see and hear!Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.
t: What I see and hear is like a dream! Love, give me patience to wait for a while.

og: O miserable, unhappy that I am!
t: Oh, I am miserable and unhappy!

og: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;But by my coming I have made you happy.
t: You were unhappy before I came, madam. But my coming here has made you happy.

og: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.
t: But your loving advances make me very unhappy.

og: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.
t: And when he makes those advances to you, Silvia, it makes me unhappy.

og: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,  I would have been a breakfast to the beast,  Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
t: If I were taken by a hungry lion, I would rather have been the beast's breakfast than have the false Proteus rescue me.

og: O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,  Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!
t: Oh, Heaven may be the judge of how much I love Valentine, whose life's as precious to me as my soul!

og: And full as much, for more there cannot be,  I do detest false perjured Proteus.  Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.
t: And I hate the false, lying Proteus the most—more than words can express. Therefore, leave. Don't pursue me anymore.

og: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,  Would I not undergo for one calm look!
t: I would take on any fight—even a deadly one—just for one loving glance!

og: O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,  When women cannot love where they're beloved!
t: Oh, it's still proved true that love's curse is a woman who cannot reciprocate love.

og: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.  Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,
t: No, when Proteus can't reciprocate love. Study Julia's heart, your first and truest love.

og: For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith  Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths  Descended into perjury, to love me.
t: You tore up your fidelity to Julia into a thousand false promises (which are now just lies) in order to love me.

og: Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;  And that's far worse than none;
t: You have no fidelity left now—unless you maintain two separate senses of loyalty, one to her and one to me. And that's worse than if you had none.

og: better have none  Than plural faith which is too much by one:
t: It's better to be faithful to no one than to be faithful to two women. That's too much for either woman to bear.

og: Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!
t: You are a false imitation of a true friend like Valentine!

og: In loveWho respects friend?
t: Who takes a friend into consideration when it comes to love?

og: All men but Proteus.
t: All men do, except Proteus.

og: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words  Can no way change you to a milder form,
t: No, if the gentle nature of my wooing words cannot in any way make you behave more mildly,

og: I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,  And love you 'gainst the nature of love,—force ye.
t: then I'll woo you like a soldier. I'll rape you at knife point, and love you in a way that goes against the nature of love.

og: O heaven!
t: Oh God!

og: I'll force thee yield to my desire.
t: I'll force you to give in to my desire.

og: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,Thou friend of an ill fashion!
t: Rascal, stop that rude, brutish behavior, you wicked friend!

og: Valentine!
t: Valentine!

og: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,  For such is a friend now; treacherous man!
t: You are an ordinary friend that's without faith or love. And such a friend is now a treacherous man!

og: Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye  Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say  I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
t: You have deceived my hopes: nothing could have persuaded me about that except for witnessing your behavior firsthand. Now I won't dare to say that I have only one friend that's alive—because you would prove me wrong.

og: Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand  Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,  I am sorry I must never trust thee more,  But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
t: Who should be trusted, when one's closest friend is a liar? Proteus, I am sorry I must never trust you again, but consider you a stranger.

og: The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,  'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!
t: The personal wound is the deepest one. Oh, what an awful moment! Its terrible when a friend should be the worst among your enemies.

og: My shame and guilt confounds me.  Forgive me, Valentine:
t: My shame and guilt overcome me. Forgive me, Valentine.

og: if hearty sorrow  Be a sufficient ransom for offence,  I tender 't here;
t: If hearty sorrow can be enough to make up for my offense, I offer it here.

og: I do as truly suffer  As e'er I did commit.
t: I do suffer for the wrongs I've committed.

og: Then I am paid;  And once again I do receive thee honest.  Who by repentance is not satisfied  Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.
t: Then I am satisfied. And once again, I'll regard you as an honest man. He who is not satisfied with someone else's repentance is not of heaven or of earth. For repentance pleases both people on earth, and also God.

og: By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:  And, that my love may appear plain and free,  All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.
t: Repentance calms God's anger. And to prove that my friendship can be honest and generous, I give you my claim to Silvia.

og: O me unhappy!
t: Oh, I am unhappy!

og: Look to the boy.
t: Take care of that boy.

og: Why, boy! Why, wag! How now! What's the matter?Look up; speak.
t: Boy! Come on, boy! What's the matter? Look up and speak.

og: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ringto Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.
t: Oh, good sir. My master instructed me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which I forgot to do.

og: Where is that ring, boy?
t: Where is that ring, boy?

og: Here 'tis; this is it.
t: Here it is.

og: How! Let me see:Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.
t: Let me see. But this is the ring I gave to Julia!

og: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:This is the ring you sent to Silvia.
t: Oh, forgive me sir. I have made a mistake. This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

og: But how camest thou by this ring? At my departI gave this unto Julia.
t: But how is it that you have this ring? I gave it to Julia when we said goodbye.

og: And Julia herself did give it me;And Julia herself hath brought it hither.
t: And Julia herself gave it to me. And Julia herself has brought it here.

og: How! Julia!
t: Julia?! Is that you?

og: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,  And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.  How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
t: Look at me, the women who was once the object of all your promises. I received them deeply in my heart. How often have you split the bottom of my heart when you broke a promise!

og: O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!  Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me  Such an immodest raiment, if shame live  In a disguise of love:
t: Oh, Proteus, let my outfit make you blush! Be ashamed that I have been wearing such immodest clothing—if it can be shameful to wear a disguise for the sake of love.

og: It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,  Women to change their shapes than men their minds.
t: It's much more appropriate and a lesser fault for women to be deceptive in their appearance than for men to be deceptive in their love.

og: Than men their minds! 'Tis true.  O heaven! Were man  But constant, he were perfect.
t: Than for men to be unfaithful! That's true. Oh heaven! If only man could be faithful, then he would be perfect.

og: That one error  Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
t: Because one mistake fills him with faults, he commits so many sins.

og: Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
t: Being unfaithful gets old very fast.

og: What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy  More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?
t: What is in Silvia's face, that I can't see more clearly in Julia's with faithful eyes?

og: Come, come, a hand from either:  Let me be blest to make this happy close;
t: Come, come, give me your hands. Let me be blessed to make a happy end to this.

og: 'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.
t: It would be a pity if two friends like you should be enemies.

og: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.
t: Heaven, be my witness. I will keep my wish forever.

og: And I mine.
t: And I will keep mine.

og: A prize, a prize, a prize!
t: A prize, a prize, a prize!

og: Forbear, forbear, I say! It is my lord the duke.Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,Banished Valentine.
t: Stop, stop, I say! It is my lord, the Duke. It is I, a dishonored man—the banished Valentine—who welcomes Your Grace.

og: Sir Valentine!
t: Sir Valentine!

og: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.
t: There's Silvia, and Silvia is mine.

og: Turio, give back, or else embrace thy death;  Come not within the measure of my wrath;  Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,  Verona shall not hold thee.
t: Turio, move back, or else accept your death. Don't come close to the range of my anger. Do not call Silvia yours. If you do that once more, Verona won't protect you.

og: Here she stands;  Take but possession of her with a touch:  I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.
t: Here she is. Go ahead, try to only touch her and take her as your own; I dare you to do so much as breathe on my love.

og: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;  I hold him but a fool that will endanger  His body for a girl that loves him not:
t: Sir Valentine, I don't care about her. I think a man would be foolish to put his body in danger for a girl that doesn't love him.

og: I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.
t: I don't call her mine, and therefore she is yours.

og: The more degenerate and base art thou,  To make such means for her as thou hast done  And leave her on such slight conditions.
t: [To TURIO] You are all the more degenerate and lowly, because you went to such lengths to win her, and then just left her based on such insubstantial grounds.

og: Now, by the honour of my ancestry,  I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,  And think thee worthy of an empress' love:
t: [To VALENTINE] Now, by the honor of my ancestry, I congratulate your spirit, Valentine. And I think you are worthy of an empress' love.

og: Know then, I here forget all former griefs,  Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,  Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,  To which I thus subscribe:
t: Know that I will now forget all previous trouble, cancel all hatred, and allow you to return to your home again. Ask for a new set of circumstances based on your unquestionable merit, and I'll agree to them.

og: Sir Valentine,  Thou art a gentleman and well derived;  Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.
t: Sir Valentine, you are a gentleman. Take Silvia, because you have earned her.

og: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
t: Thank you, your Grace. The gift has made me happy.

og: I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,  To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.
t: I now ask you—for your daughter's sake—to do me one more favor.

og: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.
t: I'll grant your request, whatever it may be.

og: These banish'd men that I have kept withal  Are men endued with worthy qualities:
t: These banished men that I have lived with have some valuable qualities.

og: Forgive them what they have committed here  And let them be recall'd from their exile:
t: Forgive them for what they have done here, and let them return home from their exile.

og: They are reformed, civil, full of good  And fit for great employment, worthy lord.
t: They are reformed, civil, full of goodness, and ready to do you great service, noble Lord.

og: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:  Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
t: You have convinced me. I pardon them, and I pardon you. Make arrangements for them in accordance with what they deserve.

og: Come, let us go: we will include all jars  With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.
t: Come, let's go. We will bring this all to an end with festivities, joy, and a marvelous celebration.

og: And, as we walk along, I dare be boldWith our discourse to make your grace to smile.What think you of this page, my lord?
t: And as we walk along, I will dare to be bold with our conversation—so I can make your Grace smile.  What do you think of this boy, my lord?

og: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.
t: I think the boy is charming. He blushes.

og: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.
t: I guarantee, my lord, that this person is more beautiful and charming than this person is a boy.

og: What mean you by that saying?
t: What do you mean by that?

og: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,  That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
t: If you wish, I'll tell you while we walk—and you will marvel at what has happened.

og: Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear  The story of your loves discovered:
t: [To PROTEUS] Come, Proteus. Your punishment will be to listen to the story of your discovered love.

og: That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;  One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
t: When that's done, our wedding day will also be yours. One feast, one house, and one mutual happiness.

og: If music be the food of love, play on.  Give me excess of it that, surfeiting,  The appetite may sicken, and so die.
t: If music feeds love and makes it stronger, then keep playing music. Give me too much of it, so much that it kills my longing for love and makes it go away.

og: That strain again, it had a dying fall.  O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,  That breathes upon a bank of violets,  Stealing and giving odor.
t: Play that part again—it sounded melancholy. Oh, it sounded to me like a sweet breeze blowing over a bank of violets, stealing their scent and distributing it to everyone.

og: Enough, no more.  'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
t: That's enough now, no more music. It doesn't sound as sweet as it did before.

og: O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thou,  That, notwithstanding thy capacity  Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,  Of what validity and pitch soe'er,
t: Oh spirit of love, how restless you are! You make me want to accept everything, like the sea does,

og: But falls into abatement and low price  Even in a minute.
t: but then the next minute everything seems worthless, no matter how valuable it is.

og: So full of shapes is fancy  That it alone is high fantastical.
t: Love is like a hallucination—nothing else is so imaginative and extravagant.

og: Will you go hunt, my lord?
t: Do you want to go hunting, my lord?

og: What, Curio?
t: Hunting what, Curio?

og: The hart.
t: The hart.

og: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.
t: I am already hunting a hart, but it's also my heart being hunted.

og: Oh, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,  Methought she purged the air of pestilence.
t: Oh, when I first saw Olivia, it seemed to me that she purified the air with her very presence.

og: That instant was I turned into a hart,  And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,  E'er since pursue me.
t: In that instant I was transformed into a hart, and ever since then my desire for her has pursued me like a pack of cruel hunting hounds.

og: How now! What news from her?
t: What's going on? What's the news from her?

og: So please my lord, I might not be admitted,  But from her handmaid do return this answer:
t: I'm sorry, my lord, they wouldn't let me enter, but Olivia's handmaid gave me this answer:

og: The element itself, till seven years' heat,  Shall not behold her face at ample view,
t: the outside world won't see Olivia's face for the next seven years.

og: But like a cloistress, she will veiled walk  And water once a day her chamber round  With eye-offending brine
t: She'll wear a veil like a nun, and once a day she'll water her room with her tears.

og: —all this to season  A brother’s dead love, which she would keep fresh  And lasting in her sad remembrance.
t: All of this is to preserve her love for her dead brother, whose memory she wants to keep fresh forever.

og: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame  To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
t: Oh, if the heart inside Olivia's beautiful body loves her brother this much,

og: How will she love, when the rich golden shaft  Hath killed the flock of all affections else  That live in her, when liver, brain, and heart,  These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and filled  Her sweet perfections with one self king!
t: then imagine how she will love me once Cupid's arrow has killed all her other emotions except love! Her mind, heart, and body—each of them a precious kingdom—will all be ruled by one man—me!

og: Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.  Love thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.
t: Now take me to a garden of flowers. My thoughts of love will be strengthened by a beautiful setting.

og: What country, friends, is this?
t: What country is this, friends?

og: This is Illyria, lady.
t: This is Illyria, my lady.

og: And what should I do in Illyria?  My brother he is in Elysium.
t: And what should I do in Illyria? My brother is in Heaven.

og: Perchance he is not drown’d.—What think you, sailors?
t: Or perhaps there's a chance he didn't drown. What do you think, sailors?

og: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
t: It was only by chance that you yourself were saved.

og: O, my poor brother! And so perchance may he be.
t: Oh, my poor brother! But maybe he has been saved by chance too.

og: True, madam. And, to comfort you with chance,  Assure yourself, after our ship did split,  When you and those poor number saved with you  Hung on our driving boat,
t: True, madam. And let me comfort you: when our ship was wrecked, and you and the few other survivors hung onto our drifting lifeboat,

og: I saw your brother,  Most provident in peril, bind himself,  Courage and hope both teaching him the practice,  To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,
t: I saw your brother tie himself to the mast that was floating on the waves—acting with courage and hope in the middle of great danger.

og: Where, like Arion on the dolphin’s back,  I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves  So long as I could see.
t: For as long as I could see him, he safely rode upon the waves like Arion on the dolphin's back.

og: For saying so, there’s gold.
t: Here's some gold to thank you for telling me this.

og: Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,  Whereto thy speech serves for authority,  The like of him.
t: My own escape gives me hope for my brother, and what you've told me now gives me even more reason to hope.

og: Know’st thou this country?
t: Do you know this country?

og: Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and bornNot three hours' travel from this very place.
t: Yes, madam, I was born and raised less than three hours' travel from here.

og: Who governs here?
t: Who rules here?

og: A noble duke, in natureAs in name.
t: A duke who is as noble in his character as he is in his rank.

og: What is his name?
t: What is his name?

og: Orsino.
t: Orsino.

og: Orsino. I have heard my father name him. He was a bachelor then.
t: Orsino—I have heard my father mention him. He was a bachelor back then.

og: And so is now, or was so very late.
t: And he still is, or was very recently at least.

og: For but a month ago I went from hence,  And then ’twas fresh in murmur
t: I only left here a month ago, and at that time there was a popular rumor

og: —as, you know,  What great ones do the less will prattle of—
t: —as, you know, people gossip about the nobility—

og: That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
t: that he was courting the fair Olivia.

og: What’s she?
t: Who's she?

og: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count  That died some twelvemonth since,
t: A virtuous young woman, the daughter of a count who died a year ago.

og: then leaving her  In the protection of his son, her brother,  Who shortly also died,
t: He left her in the care of his son, Olivia's brother, but the brother died soon after.

og: for whose dear love,  They say, she hath abjured the company  And sight of men.
t: They say that out of love for her brother, Olivia has stopped interacting with men altogether.

og: Oh, that I served that lady
t: Oh, I wish that I could serve that lady—

og: And might not be delivered to the world,  Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,  What my estate is.
t: then I wouldn't have to reveal myself to the world until I was ready to identify my place in society.

og: That were hard to compass,Because she will admit no kind of suit,No, not the duke’s.
t: That would be hard to bring about, because she won't allow anyone in to see her, not even the duke's men.

og: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,  And though that nature with a beauteous wall  Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee  I will believe thou hast a mind that suits  With this thy fair and outward character.
t: You seem to be a good man in both behavior and appearance, captain, and even though nature often makes beautiful people corrupt on the inside, I believe that you have a noble mind to fit your good looks and manners.

og: I prithee—and I’ll pay thee bounteously—  Conceal me what I am, and be my aid  For such disguise as haply shall become  The form of my intent
t: Please—and I'll pay you well for this—help me conceal my identity, and find me the disguise that will suit my intentions.

og: . I’ll serve this duke.  Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.
t: I want to serve this duke. You will present me to him as a eunuch.

og: It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing  And speak to him in many sorts of music  That will allow me very worth his service.
t: It will be worth your trouble, for I can sing and speak well, and he will surely consider me for his service.

og: What else may hap to time I will commit.
t: What might happen after that, only time will tell.

og: Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.
t: You must only match my wit with your silence and discretion.

og: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.
t: You will be his eunuch, and I will be your mute attendant. If I tell your secret, may I lose my sight.

og: I thank thee. Lead me on.
t: I thank you. Lead me on.

og: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care’s an enemy to life.
t: What is ailing my niece, that she reacts so strongly to her brother's death? I'm now sure that caring too much is bad for one's health.

og: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
t: By God, Sir Toby, you must come home earlier at night. Your niece, my lady, strongly disapproves of the late hours you keep.

og: Why, let her except, before excepted.
t: Well, let her disapprove of me—I disapprove of her.

og: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.
t: Yes, but you must at least confine yourself within the limits of order and decency.

og: Confine? I’ll confine myself no finer than I am.
t: Confine myself? I'll only confine myself to these clothes I'm wearing.

og: These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.
t: They're good enough to drink in, and these boots are too.

og: An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
t: And if they aren't, then let them hang themselves by their own straps.

og: That quaffing and drinking will undo you:
t: All this drinking will be your ruin:

og: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.
t: I heard my lady Olivia talking about it yesterday. She also spoke of some foolish knight you brought here one night to woo her.

og: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
t: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

og: Ay, he.
t: Yes, him.

og: He’s as tall a man as any’s in Illyria.
t: He's as tall and brave as any man in Illyria.

og: What’s that to the purpose?
t: What does that have to do with anything?

og: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
t: Well, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.

og: Ay, but he’ll have but a year in all these ducats. He’sa very fool and a prodigal.
t: Yes, but he'll only make all those ducats last for one year. He's foolish, wasteful, and reckless.

og: Fie, that you’ll say so! He plays o' the viol-de-gamboys,
t: How dare you say so! He plays the violin,

og: and speaks three or four languages wordfor word without book,
t: and speaks three or four languages word for word from memory.

og: and hath all the good gifts of nature.
t: He has all of nature's good gifts.

og: He hath indeed, almost natural,
t: He does indeed seem like a natural-born fool

og: for besides that he’s afool, he’s a great quarreler,
t: —and besides being a fool, he's argumentative.

og: and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling,
t: If he didn't have the coward's gift of stepping away from a fight,

og: ’tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.
t: they say he would've been long dead by now.

og: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors thatsay so of him. Who are they?
t: By God, anyone who says that about him is a villain and a naysayer. Who said that?

og: They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in your company.
t: They also say that he gets drunk with you every night.

og: With drinking healths to my niece. I’ll drink to her aslong as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.
t: We are only toasting my niece when we drink. I'll drink to her as long as there's a hole in my throat and alcohol in Illyria.

og: He’s a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like aparish top.
t: Only cowards and scum wouldn't drink to my niece until their brains spin round like a top.

og: What, wench!
t: What do you have to say to that!

og: Castiliano vulgo  , for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.
t: But hush, we must be polite. Here comes Sir Andrew Agueface himself.

og: Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!
t: Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?

og: Sweet Sir Andrew!
t: Sweet Sir Andrew.

og: Bless you, fair shrew.
t: And hello to you, pretty wench.

og: And you too, sir.
t: Hello to you, sir.

og: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.
t: Accost her, Sir Andrew, accost her.

og: What’s that?
t: What's that?

og: My niece’s chambermaid.
t: This is my niece's chambermaid.

og: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
t: Good Miss Accost-her, I look forward to knowing you better.

og: My name is Mary, sir.
t: My name is Mary, sir.

og: Good Mistress Mary Accost—
t: Good Miss Mary Accost-her—

og: You mistake, knight. “Accost” is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.
