t: You're mistaken, knight. "Accost her" isn't her name—I meant that you should face her, greet her, woo her, and conquer her.

og: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.Is that the meaning of “accost”?
t: I say, I wouldn't do that in this company. Is that really what you meant by "accost her?"

og: Fare you well, gentlemen.
t: Goodbye, gentlemen.

og: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
t: If you let her leave like that, Sir Andrew, you don't deserve to ever draw your sword again.

og: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
t: If you leave like this, miss, I swear I won't ever draw my sword again. Why are you leaving, fair lady—do you think you have fools on your hands here?

og: Sir, I have not you by the hand.
t: Sir, I'm not holding your hand.

og: Marry, but you shall have, and here’s my hand.
t: Indeed, but you will be, and here's my hand.

og: Now, sir, thought is free.
t: Now, sir, everyone has a right to their opinions.

og: I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.
t: Please, take your hand to the dairy and let it drink.

og: Wherefore, sweetheart? What’s your metaphor?
t: What do you mean, sweetheart? Is this a metaphor?

og: It’s dry, sir.
t: A dry one, sir.

og: Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But what’s your jest?
t: Well, I should hope so. I'm not such a fool that I can't keep my hand dry. But what's the joke?

og: A dry jest, sir.
t: Just some dry humor, sir.

og: Are you full of them?
t: Are you full of such jokes?

og: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends. Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
t: Yes, sir, I have a handful of them. Although now that I've let go of your hand, I've lost the biggest joke I had.

og: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?
t: Oh knight, you need some wine. Have you ever been put down like that before?

og: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary putme down.
t: Never, I think, except when I've been put down by too much wine.

og: Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.
t: Sometimes I think I'm no smarter than a humble, ordinary man.

og: But I am a great eaterof beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.
t: But I eat a lot of beef, and maybe that hurts my intelligence.

og: No question.
t: There's no question about that.

og: An I thought that, I’d forswear it. I’ll ride home tomorrow,Sir Toby.
t: If I really thought that, I'd give up beef altogether. I think I'll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

og: Pourquoi,  my dear knight?
t: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

og: What is “pourquoi”? Do, or not do?
t: What does "pourquoi" mean? Does it mean to do or not do?

og: I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!
t: I wish I had spent more time learning languages instead of fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. Oh, if I'd only studied more!

og: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
t: Then you would have an excellent head of hair.

og: Why, would that have mended my hair?
t: Why, would that have improved my hair?

og: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
t: Certainly, for you can see that it won't curl naturally.

og: But it becomes me well enough, does ’t not?
t: But my hair still suits me well enough, doesn't it?

og: Excellent. It hangs like flax on a distaff.
t: It looks excellent. It hangs like flax waiting to be spun.

og: And I hopeto see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.
t: And I hope to see some hussy take it between her legs and spin it off with a venereal disease.

og: Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen.
t: Truly, I'm going home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece refuses to see anyone.

og: Or if she be, it’s four to one she’ll none of me.
t: Even if she did see me, chances are she'd reject me.

og: The count himself here hard by woos her.
t: The duke himself is courting her nearby.

og: She’ll none o' the count.
t: She'll reject the duke.

og: She’ll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have heard her swear ’t
t: She won't marry anyone who's above her social rank, her wealth, her age, or her intelligence—I've heard her swear this.

og: . Tut, there’s life in ’t, man.
t: So cheer up, you're still in the running, man.

og: I’ll stay a month longer.
t: I'll stay a month longer then.

og: I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world. I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
t: I must be the strangest fellow on earth. Sometimes my greatest pleasures are masquerades, plays, and dancing.

og: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?
t: Are you good at such trifles, knight?

og: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters.
t: As good as any man in Illyria, as long as he isn't better than I am.

og: And yet I will not compare with anold man.
t: And yet I'm not as good as an experienced dancer.

og: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?
t: How good are you at the fast dances, knight?

og: Faith, I can cut a caper.
t: Well, I can cut a caper.

og: And I can cut the mutton to ’t.
t: And I can cut the meat to go with your capers.

og: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
t: And I think I can do that tricky backward step as well as any man in Illyria.

og: Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture?
t: Why do you keep these things hidden? Why do you keep your gifts behind a curtain? Are you afraid they'll get dusty, like some woman's portrait?

og: Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto?
t: Why don't you show off your skill by going to church dancing a galliard and coming home dancing a coranto?

og: My verywalk should be a jig. I would not so much as make waterbut in a sink-a-pace.
t: If I were you, even my walk would be a dance. I wouldn't even pee unless I was dancing at the same time.

og: What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?
t: What do you mean by this? Is this a world where we should hide our virtues?

og: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star ofa galliard.
t: I could always tell from your excellent legs that you were born under a dancing star.

og: Ay, ’tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some revels?
t: Yes, my legs are strong, and they don't look bad in brown stockings. Should we have a little dance?

og: What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?
t: What else are we going to do? Weren't we born under the sign of Taurus?

og: Taurus! That’s sides and heart.
t: Taurus! But that governs the torso and the heart.

og: No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper.    Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!
t: No, sir, it governs the legs and the thighs. Let me see you dance. Ha, higher! Ha ha, excellent!

og: If the duke continue these favors towards you, Cesario,you are like to be much advanced.
t: If the duke keeps favoring you like this, Cesario, you're likely to get promoted very high.

og: He hath known you butthree days, and already you are no stranger.
t: He's only known you for three days, and already he's treating you like a friend.

og: You either fear his humor or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love.
t: You must be afraid of his moodiness or my faults, if you think there's any chance that he'll stop liking me.

og: Is he inconstant, sir, in his favors?
t: Is he usually fickle in his moods and favors?

og: No, believe me.
t: No, believe me.

og: I thank you. Here comes the count.
t: I thank you for telling me. Here comes the duke.

og: Who saw Cesario, ho?
t: Hey, has anyone seen Cesario?

og: On your attendance, my lord, here.
t: I'm here, my lord, at your service.

og: Stand you a while aloof.
t: Give us some privacy for a while.

og: Cesario,  Thou know’st no less but all. I have unclasped  To thee the book even of my secret soul.
t: Cesario, you know everything about me. I have opened the book of my most secret soul to you.

og: Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;  Be not denied access, stand at her doors,
t: Therefore, good youth, direct your steps to Olivia's house. Don't let them deny you access—stand outside her door

og: And tell them there thy fixed foot shall grow  Till thou have audience.
t: and tell them that you'll plant roots there until they let you see her.

og: Sure, my noble lord,  If she be so abandoned to her sorrow  As it is spoke
t: But my noble lord, if she is really as brokenhearted as they say,

og: , she never will admit me.
t: she is sure to deny me an audience.

og: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds,
t: Be loud and obnoxious, and go beyond the limits of decency and civility if you have to—

og: Rather than make unprofited return.
t: just don't come back without having spoken to her.

og: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?
t: And if I do get to speak to her, my lord, what do I do then?

og: O, then unfold the passion of my love,  Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:
t: Oh, then describe the passion of my love for her. Ambush her with descriptions of my faithfulness.

og: It shall become thee well to act my woes;
t: It will be best if you act out my feelings—

og: She will attend it better in thy youth  Than in a nuncio’s of more grave aspect.
t: she'll pay closer attention to you, as a young man, than to an older, more serious messenger.

og: I think not so, my lord.
t: I don't think so, my lord.

og: Dear lad, believe it.  For they shall yet belie thy happy years  That say thou art a man.
t: Dear boy, believe me. Anyone who says that you're a man is denying you the happy years of your youth.

og: Diana’s lip  Is not more smooth and rubious. Thy small pipe  Is as the maiden’s organ, shrill and sound,  And all is semblative a woman’s part.
t: Your lips are as smooth and ruby-red as the goddess Diana's. Your small voice is like a girl's, high and clear, and the rest of you is feminine as well.

og: I know thy constellation is right apt  For this affair.
t: I know you have been predestined to do this job.

og: Some four or five attend him.  All, if you will, for I myself am best  When least in company.
t: Four or five of you go with him. All of you can go if you want to, for I feel my best when I'm away from people.

og: Prosper well in this,  And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,  To call his fortunes thine.
t: If you succeed in this you will live as well as I do, and share in all my fortune.

og: I’ll do my best  To woo your lady—
t: I'll do my best to woo this lady for you.

og: Yet, a barful strife—  Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
t: And yet, what a conflict—I must go courting on behalf of the man I want to marry myself!

og: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will notopen my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in way of thy excuse.
t: No, either tell me where you've been, or I won't say a word in your defense.

og: My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
t: My lady Olivia will have you hanged for being absent.

og: Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colors.
t: Let her hang me then. A well-hanged (and well-hung) man doesn't need to be afraid of anything he sees.

og: Make that good.
t: Explain—and clean up your language.

og: He shall see none to fear.
t: He'll be dead, and so he won't see anything to be afraid of.

og: A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that sayingwas born, of “I fear no colors.”
t: That's a meager answer. And I can tell you where you got that saying about not being afraid of anything.

og: Where, good Mistress Mary?
t: Where, good Mistress Mary?

og: In the wars. And that may you be bold to say in your foolery.
t: From soldiers at war. And it's bold of you to talk like a soldier, when you're only a fool.

og: Well, God give them wisdom that have it. And those thatare fools, let them use their talents.
t: Well, let God give wisdom to those who have it. Everyone has their talents, and for those of us who are fools, let us use our gifts.

og: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.
t: But you'll still be hanged for being gone so long.

og: Or tobe turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?
t: Or at least fired and kicked out, and wouldn't that be just as bad for you?

og: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage,
t: Sometimes getting hanged saves a man from getting into a bad marriage,

og: and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.
t: and as for getting kicked out, it's summer, so being homeless won't be so bad.

og: You are resolute, then?
t: You are firm in your resolve, then?

og: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.
t: No, but I am resolved on two points.

og: That if one break, the other will hold.
t: Yes—the two points where your suspenders are buttoned on. If one breaks, the other will hold.

og: Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.
t: But if both break, your pants will fall.

og: Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way.
t: Very clever, really, very clever. Well, go along now.

og: If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece ofEve’s flesh as any in Illyria.
t: If only Sir Toby would stop drinking, you'd be a woman who was as funny as any person in Illyria.

og: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady.Make your excuse wisely, you were best.
t: Quiet, you villain, no more of that. Here comes my lady. It would be best for you if you came up with a good excuse for being gone so long.

og: Wit, an ’t be thy will, put me into good fooling!
t: Come on, wit, give me something good to say now!

og: Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools.
t: Those people who think they're witty often prove to be fools.

og: And I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus?
t: And I'm sure that I'm not witty, so I might pass for a wise man. For what did the philosopher Quinapalus say?

og: “Better awitty fool, than a foolish wit.”
t: "Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit."

og: God bless thee, lady!
t: God's greetings to you, my lady!

og: Take the fool away.
t: Take the fool away.

og: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.
t: Didn't you hear her, fellows? Take the lady away.

og: Go to, you’re a dry fool. I’ll no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.
t: That's enough—you're a dull, dry fool. I'm tired of you. Besides, you're getting unreliable.

og: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend. For give the dry fool drink, then is the fool notdry.
t: My holy lady, these are two flaws that some alcohol and good advice will fix. If you give the dry fool a drink, then the fool won't be dry anymore.

og: Bid the dishonest man mend himself. If he mend, heis no longer dishonest.
t: And if you give the unreliable man some good advice, then he can mend his ways and won't be unreliable anymore.

og: If he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything that’s mended is but patched.
t: And if he can't mend his ways, then let the tailor mend him. Anything that's mended is only patched up.

og: Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue.
t: A virtuous man who does something wrong is only patched with sin, and a sinner who mends his ways is only patched with virtue.

og: If that this simple syllogism will serve, so. If it will not, what remedy?
t: If this logical argument will convince you, then good. But if not, what can be done?

og: As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty’s a flower.
t: The only truly betrayed husband is one deserted by luck, and beauty is a lucky flower—so you won't remain alone for long, my lady.

og: The lady bade take away the fool. Therefore, I say again, take her away.
t: But you gave orders to take away the fool. So I tell you all again, take the lady away.

og: Sir, I bade them take away you.
t: Sir, I told them to take you away.

og: Misprision in the highest degree!
t: An error of the worst kind!

og: Lady, Cucullus non facit monachum—
t: Lady, don't judge a book by its cover—

og: that’s as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain.
t: that's to say that I wear jester's clothes on the outside,

og: Good madonna, give me leave to proveyou a fool.
t: but my brain is still sharp. My holy lady, let me prove that you're a fool.

og: Can you do it?
t: Can you do it?

og: Dexterously, good madonna.
t: Easily, my good lady.

og: Make your proof.
t: Then prove it.

og: I must catechise you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
t: I must ask you some questions then, my holy lady. Please answer them, my virtuous little mouse.

og: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.
t: Well, sir, I have nothing better to do, so I'll go along with this.

og: Good madonna, why mournest thou?
t: Dear lady, why are you in mourning?

og: Good fool, for my brother’s death.
t: Dear fool, because of my brother's death.

og: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
t: I think his soul is in hell, lady.

og: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
t: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

og: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.
t: Then you're a fool, holy lady, to mourn your brother's soul being in heaven. Now take away the fool, gentlemen.

og: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? Doth he not mend?
t: What do you think of this fool, Malvolio? Hasn't he gotten better?

og: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him.
t: Yes, and he will until the day he dies.

og: Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
t: Old age and senility hurt wise people, but improve fools.

og: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!
t: Then may God send you old age and senility, that you might become a better fool!

og: Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence thatyou are no fool.
t: Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I'm not a clever man, but he wouldn't bet two cents that you're not a fool.

og: How say you to that, Malvolio?
t: What do you say to that, Malvolio?

og: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.
t: I'm surprised that your ladyship enjoys the company of such an empty-headed villain.

og: I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that has no more brain than a stone.
t: The other day I saw him lose a battle of wits to an ordinary idiot who had no more brains than a stone.

og: Look you now, he’s out of his guard already. Unless you laughand minister occasion to him, he is gagged.
t: Look at him now, he's without a witty retort already. Unless you laugh and give him an opportunity, he can't think of a thing to say.

og: I protest Itake these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
t: I declare that the so-called wise men who laugh so hard at these jesters' well-rehearsed routines are no better than jesters' assistants themselves.

og: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste witha distempered appetite.
t: Oh, you're sick with vanity, Malvolio, and it affects your good taste.

og: To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets.
t: If you were generous, innocent, and friendly, then you wouldn't make such mountains out of mole-hills.

og: There is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail.
t: There's no real harm in a professional fool, even if he does nothing but mock people.

og: Nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.
t: In the same way there's no real mockery in a wise man, even if he does nothing but criticize people.

og: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
t: May Mercury—that god of deception—make you a skilled liar, to reward you for speaking so highly of fools!

og: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
t: Madam, there's a young gentleman at the gate who greatly desires to speak with you.

og: From the Count Orsino, is it?
t: Is he sent from Duke Orsino?

og: I know not, madam. 'Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
t: I don't know, madam. He's a good-looking young man, and has some attendants with him.

og: Who of my people hold him in delay?
t: Which of my people is delaying him right now?

og: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
t: Sir Toby, madam, your uncle.

og: Fetch him off, I pray you. He speaks nothing but madman.Fie on him!
t: Send Sir Toby away, please. He talks like a madman. Shame on him!

og: Go you, Malvolio. If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home.
t: You go, Malvolio. If this visitor is a messenger from the duke, then tell him that I'm sick, or not at home.

og: What you will, to dismiss it.
t: Do whatever you have to to make him go away.

og: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.
t: Now you see, sir, how your jokes grow stale, and people dislike them.

og: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool,
t: Holy lady, you've spoken so highly of us fools—it's almost as if your eldest son was going to be a fool.

og: whose skull Jove cram with brains, for—here he comes—one of thy kin has a most weak  pia mater.
t: And may God cram his skull with brains, for here comes one of your relatives whose head is quite empty.

og: By mine honor, half-drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?
t: I swear, he's half-drunk. Who is that at the gate, uncle?

og: A gentleman.
t: A gentleman.

og: A gentleman? What gentleman?
t: A gentleman? What gentleman?

og: 'Tis a gentleman here—
t: There's a gentleman here—

og: a plague o' these pickle herring!  How now, sot!
t: Damn those pickled herring! They upset my stomach. How's it going, you drunken fool?

og: Good Sir Toby!
t: Good Sir Toby!

og: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?
t: Uncle, uncle, it's so early in the day—how are you already so sick?

og: Lechery! I defy lechery. There’s one at the gate.
t: Tricks? I hate tricks. There's a man at the gate.

og: Ay, marry, what is he?
t: Yes, I heard, but who is he?

og: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not. Give me faith, say I. Well, it’s all one.
t: Let him be the devil if he wants to be, I don't care. God will give me the faith to resist him. It doesn't matter to me.

og: What’s a drunken man like, fool?
t: Tell me what a drunk man is like, fool.

og: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman. One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
t: He's like a drowned man, a fool, and a madman. The first drink makes him a fool, the second makes him a madman, and the third drowns him.

og: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz.
t: Go and find the coroner then, and let him investigate my uncle—

og: For he’s in the third degree of drink, he’s drowned. Go look after him.
t: for he's in the third degree of drunkenness, and has drowned. Go look after him.

og: He is but mad yet, madonna, and the fool shall look to the madman.
t: He's still only in the second degree, my lady, so the fool will take care of the madman.

og: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you.I told him you were sick.
t: Madam, that young fellow out there swears that he must speak with you no matter what. I told him you were sick.

og: He takes on him to understandso much, and therefore comes to speak with you.
t: He claims to know that already, and says that that's why he came to speak with you.

og: I told him you were asleep. He seems to have a foreknowledge ofthat too, and therefore comes to speak with you.
t: I told him you were asleep. He claims to know that already too, and said that that's why he came to speak with you.

og: What is to be said to him, lady? He’s fortified against any denial.
t: What should I say to him, lady? He's too strong for all my excuses.

og: Tell him he shall not speak with me.
t: Just tell him that he won't speak with me.

og: He's been told so, and he says he’ll stand at your door like a sheriff’s post, and be the supporter to a bench, but he’ll speak with you.
t: I told him that already, but he says he'll stand at your door like a signpost or the leg of a bench until he is allowed to speak with you.

og: What kind o' man is he?
t: What kind of man is he?

og: Why, of mankind.
t: Why, part of mankind.

og: What manner of man?
t: But what is his manner?

og: Of very ill manner. He’ll speak with you, will you or no.
t: He has very bad manners. He says he'll speak to you whether you like it or not.

og: Of what personage and years is he?
t: But what does he look like, and how old is he?

og: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy,
t: He's not yet old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy either.

og: as a squash is before ’tis a peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple.
t: He's like a pea pod or an apple just before it's ripe.

og: 'Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.
t: He's like a slack tide, caught between coming in and going out—between boyhood and manhood.

og: He is very well-favored, andhe speaks very shrewishly.
t: He's very good-looking, but he's nagging.

og: One would think his mother’smilk were scarce out of him.
t: It seems like he's just barely stopped breastfeeding.

og: Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.
t: Let him enter. Call in my lady-in-waiting.

og: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
t: Gentlewoman, my lady calls for you.

og: Give me my veil. Come, throw it o'er my face.    We’ll once more hear Orsino’s embassy.
t: Give me my veil. Come, throw it over my face.  Let's hear Orsino's offer once more.

og: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
t: Which of you is the honorable lady of the house?

og: Speak to me. I shall answer for her. Your will?
t: Speak to me—I'll answer for her. What do you want?

og: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her.
t: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty—but please, tell me if you're really the lady of the house, for I've never actually seen her.

og: I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it.
t: I would hate to throw away my speech on the wrong person, for it is excellently written and was very hard for me to memorize.

og: Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn.
t: Good beauties, please don't scorn me.

og: I am very comptible, even to the leastsinister usage.
t: I'm very sensitive, even to the slightest bit of rudeness.

og: Whence came you, sir?
t: Where do you come from, sir?

og: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part.
t: I can only repeat what I've memorized, and that question isn't part of my lines.

og: Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that Imay proceed in my speech.
t: Please, gentle lady, just assure me that you are the lady of the house, so I can go on with my speech.

og: Are you a comedian?
t: Are you an actor?

og: No, my profound heart. And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?
t: No, my dear lady. But I also swear that I'm not the same person as the part I'm playing. Are you the lady of the house?

og: If I do not usurp myself, I am.
t: If I haven't stolen this role from myself, then I am.

og: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.
t: If you are the lady of the house, then you certainly have stolen from yourself, because what's yours to give away is not yours to keep for yourself.

og: Butthis is from my commission. I will on with my speech inyour praise and then show you the heart of my message.
t: But this isn't what I was sent to say. I'll go on with my speech praising you, and then I'll get to the heart of my message.

og: Come to what is important in ’t. I forgive you the praise.
t: Just tell me the important part. I'll excuse you for skipping the praise.

og: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis poetical.
t: Oh, but I worked so hard memorizing it, and it's poetic.

og: It is the more like to be feigned. I pray you, keep it in.
t: Then it's more likely to be fake. Please, keep it to yourself.

og: I heard you were saucy at my gates and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you.
t: I heard you were rude at my gates, and I let you in because I was curious about you, not to hear your message.

og: If you be not mad, be gone. If you have reason, be brief.
t: If you're not crazy, then go. If you're sane, be quick.

og: 'Tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.
t: I am not in the mood for lively conversation.

og: Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.
t: Will you set sail and leave now, sir? Here's the door.

og: No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady.
t: No, good sailor, I'll dock here a little longer. My lady, would you call off your giant here?

og: Tell me your mind.
t: Tell me what you want.

og: I am a messenger.
t: I am a messenger.

og: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when thecourtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.
t: Then you must have a horrible message to deliver, since you're so afraid to get to the point. Speak your business.

og: It alone concerns your ear.
t: It only concerns you.

og: I bring no overture of war,no taxation of homage. I hold the olive in my hand
t: I'm not bringing a declaration of war or a demand for praise. I'm only bringing you an olive branch.

og: . My words are as full of peace as matter.
t: My words are full of peace.

og: Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?
t: Yet you began rudely. Who are you? What do you want?

og: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment.
t: I only learned my rudeness from the way I was received here.

og: What I am and what I would are assecret as maidenhead.
t: Who I am and what I want are as secret as a girl's virginity.

og: To your ears, divinity. To any other’s, profanation.
t: I have a holy message for your ears only. It would be blasphemy for anyone else to hear it.

og: Give us the place alone. We will hear this divinity.
t: Everyone, leave us alone. I will hear this "holy message."

og: Now, sir, what is your text?
t: Now, sir, what is your sacred text?

og: Most sweet lady—
t: Most sweet lady—

og: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?
t: This sounds like a comforting doctrine of faith, one that deserves to be spoken of. Where is the sacred text your "holy message" comes from?

og: In Orsino’s bosom.
t: In Orsino's heart.

og: In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?
t: In his heart? In what chapter and verse of his heart?

og: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.
t: To continue this metaphor—in the first chapter of his heart.

og: Oh, I have read it. It is heresy. Have you no more to say?
t: Oh, I have read that. It's not a holy message, it's heresy. Do you have anything more to say?

og: Good madam, let me see your face.
t: Good madam, let me see your face.

og: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text.
t: Did your lord order you to negotiate with my face? You've gone off your script now.

og: But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.
t: But I'll draw the curtain and show you the picture.

og: Look you, sir, such a one I was this present. Is ’t not well done?
t: Look, sir, this is a portrait of me in this present moment. Isn't it well done?

og: Excellently done, if God did all.
t: It's excellently done, if that's the way God made it.

og: 'Tis in grain, sir. 'Twill endure wind and weather.
t: It's natural, sir. Wind and rain won't wash it off.

og: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white  Nature’s own sweet and cunning hand laid on.
t: It's truly beautiful—your red lips and white skin painted by Nature's sweet and skillful hand.

og: Lady, you are the cruel’st she alive  If you will lead these graces to the grave  And leave the world no copy.
t: My lady, you are the cruelest woman alive if you'll let your beauty go with you to the grave, instead of having children and passing it on.

og: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted. I will give out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labeled to my will:
t: Oh, sir, I won't be so cruel. I'll give out lists of my beauty. I'll make a detailed inventory, with every part labeled and added to my will.

og: as, item, two lips indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?
t: For example—item: two lips, moderately red. Item: two grey eyes, with lids attached. Item: one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you only sent here to praise my beauty?

og: I see you what you are, you are too proud.  But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
t: I see what you are—you're too proud. But even if you were the devil, you'd still be beautiful.

og: My lord and master loves you. Oh, such love  Could be but recompensed though you were crowned  The nonpareil of beauty.
t: My lord and master loves you. Such love as his couldn't be repaid even if you were crowned the most beautiful woman in the world.

og: How does he love me?
t: How does he love me?

og: With adorations, fertile tears, With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.
t: With adoration, with abundant tears, with thunderous groans, with passionate sighs.

og: Your lord does know my mind. I cannot love him.
t: Your lord knows my mind. I cannot love him.

og: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,  Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth.
t: I'm sure he is a virtuous man, and I know he's noble, rich, and young.

og: In voices well divulged, free, learned, and valiant;  And in dimension and the shape of nature  A gracious person.
t: Public opinion reports that he is generous, smart, and brave, both gracious in his manner and good-looking.

og: But yet I cannot love him;  He might have took his answer long ago.
t: But despite all that, I cannot love him. He should have accepted my answer long ago.

og: If I did love you in my master’s flame,  With such a suffering, such a deadly life,
t: If I loved you with my master's passion—with such suffering and a life that is like death—

og: In your denial I would find no sense;  I would not understand it.
t: your rejection would make no sense to me. I would not understand it.

og: Why, what would you?
t: Well, what would you do if you were your master?

og: Make me a willow cabin at your gate  And call upon my soul within the house.
t: I would build a little cabin outside your gates, and from there I'd call out to you, my soul, in your house.

og: Write loyal cantons of contemned love  And sing them loud even in the dead of night.
t: I would write loyal songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly even in the dead of night.

og: Halloo your name to the reverberate hills  And make the babbling gossip of the air  Cry out “Olivia!”
t: I would shout your name to the hills and make their echoes cry out "Olivia!"

og: Oh, you should not rest  Between the elements of air and earth,  But you should pity me.
t: Oh, you wouldn't be able to go anywhere under the sun without pitying me.

og: You might do much.What is your parentage?
t: There's a lot you would do. What rank are your parents?

og: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.I am a gentleman.
t: I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman.

og: Get you to your lord.  I cannot love him. Let him send no more—
t: Go back to your lord. I cannot love him. Tell him not to send any more messengers—

og: Unless perchance you come to me again  To tell me how he takes it.
t: unless, perhaps, you were to return and tell me how he takes my rejection.

og: Fare you well.  I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.
t: Farewell. Thank you for your trouble. Here is something for you to spend.

og: I am no fee’d post, lady. Keep your purse.  My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
t: I'm no paid messenger, my lady. Keep your money. It's my master, not myself, who's going without his due reward.

og: Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,  And let your fervor, like my master’s, be  Placed in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.
t: May the man you fall in love with have a heart of stone, and may your passion, like my master's, be scornfully rejected. Farewell, you beautiful cruelty.

og: “What is your parentage?”  “Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.  I am a gentleman.”
t: "What rank are your parents?" "I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman."

og: I’ll be sworn thou art;  Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit,  Do give thee fivefold blazon.
t: Yes, I'll swear that you are; your words, your face, your body, your actions, and your spirit all seem like a coat of arms for a lord.

og: Not too fast! Soft, soft!  Unless the master were the man. How now?  Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
t: But not so fast! Calm down, calm down! If only Orsino were Cesario. But what's going on? Can someone catch the plague of love this quickly?

og: Methinks I feel this youth’s perfections  With an invisible and subtle stealth  To creep in at mine eyes.
t: I think I can feel this youth's perfection creeping stealthily and invisibly in through my eyes.

og: Well, let it be.—  What ho, Malvolio!
t: Well, let it happen. [Calling out to MALVOLIO] Come, Malvolio!

og: Here, madam, at your service.
t: Here, madam, at your service.

og: Run after that same peevish messenger,  The county’s man. He left this ring behind him,  Would I or not. Tell him I’ll none of it.
t: Run after that irritating messenger who just left, the duke's man. He left this ring behind, whether I wanted it or not. Tell him I want nothing to do with it.

og: Desire him not to flatter with his lord,  Nor hold him up with hopes.  I am not for him.
t: Tell him not to encourage Orsino, or get his hopes up. I am not for him.

og: If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,  I’ll give him reasons for ’t. Hie thee, Malvolio.
t: And tell that youth that if he'll come by tomorrow, I'll give him reasons why. Now hurry up, Malvolio.

og: Madam, I will.
t: Madam, I will.

og: I do I know not what and fear to find  Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
t: I don't know what I'm doing, and I'm afraid that I'm falling in love based entirely on good looks—using my eyes instead of using my head.

og: Fate, show thy force. Ourselves we do not owe.  What is decreed must be, and be this so.
t: Fate, do what you will. We can't control our destinies. What must be will be, so let it happen.

og: Will you stay no longer, nor will you not that I go with you?
t: Won't you stay longer? And don't you want me to go with you?

og: By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over me. The malignancy of my fate might perhaps distemper yours.
t: If you'll allow it, no. My luck is bad, and my doomed fate might disturb your own destiny.

og: Therefore I shall crave of you your leave that I may bear my evils alone. It
t: Therefore I will say farewell, and face the evils of my fate alone.

og: were a bad recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.
t: It would be a bad way of thanking you if I burdened you with any of my troubles.

og: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.
t: At least let me know where you're headed to.

og: No, sooth, sir. My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a touchof modesty that you will not extort from me what I am willing to keep in.
t: Truly, I can't, sir. The voyage I am determined to make is merely wandering without a destination. But I can tell that you're polite enough to not force me to tell you something I want to keep to myself—

og: Therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express myself.
t: so it's only good manners for me to tell you what I can, Antonio.

og: You must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian, which I called Roderigo. My father was that Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard of.
t: My name is Sebastian, though I called myself Roderigo. My father was Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you've heard of.

og: He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour. If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended!
t: He is dead now, but he left behind myself and my twin sister, who was born the same hour as me. If only God had allowed us to die in the same hour as well!

og: But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.
t: But you, sir, kept that from happening, for my sister drowned an hour before you pulled me from the breaking waves.

og: Alas the day!
t: What a tragic day!

og: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful.
t: She was a lady who many people said looked just like me, but she was also considered beautiful.

og: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.
t: Forgive me, sir, for not being a better host.

og: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.
t: Oh good Antonio, forgive me for causing you trouble.

og: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.
t: Let me be your servant and go with you—if you won't return my devotion, you'll be killing me.

og: If you will not undo what you have done—that is, kill him whom you have recovered—desire it not.
t: And if you won't undo what you have done—that is, if you don't want to kill the man whose life you saved—then you won't come with me.

og: Fare you wellat once. My bosom is full of kindness, and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell tales of me.
t: Say goodbye at once. My heart is full of affection for you, and I'm feeling so effeminate that I'm about to cry.

og: I am bound to the Count Orsino’s court. Farewell.
t: My destination is Duke Orsino's court. Farewell.

og: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
t: May the blessings of the gods go with you!

og: I have many enemies in Orsino’s court,  Else would I very shortly see thee there.
t: I have many enemies in Orsino's court, or else I would join you there soon.

og: But, come what may, I do adore thee so  That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.
t: But I don't care—my adoration for you is too strong, and the danger seems trivial to me. I'll go.

og: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?
t: Weren't you with the Countess Olivia just now?

og: Even now, sir. On a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.
t: Yes, just now, sir. I've only made it this far, walking at a moderate pace.

og: She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have savedme my pains to have taken it away yourself.
t: She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have saved me the trouble and taken it with you.

og: She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperateassurance she will none of him.
t: She also adds that you should make it clear to your lord that there is no hope—she wants nothing to do with him.

og: And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs,unless it be to report your lord’s taking of this.
t: And one thing more: you should never return here as Orsino's messenger again, unless it is to report how he takes the bad news.

og: Receive it so.
t: Take the ring now.

og: She took the ring of me. I’ll none of it.
t: She took that ring from me. I don't want it.

og: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her will is it should be so returned.
t: Come, sir, you rudely threw it to her, and she wants it to be returned just as rudely.

og: If it be worth stooping for, there it lies in your eye. If not, be it his that finds it.
t: If it's worth stooping to pick up, there it is where you can see it. If not, let whoever finds it first have it.

og: I left no ring with her. What means this lady?
t: I didn't leave any ring with her. What does this lady mean by this?

og: Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!  She made good view of me, indeed so much  That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,  For she did speak in starts distractedly.
t: God forbid that she's smitten by my appearance! She did look intently at me, indeed so much that I thought her eyes had caused her to lose her tongue, for she spoke wildly and distractedly.

og: She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion  Invites me in this churlish messenger.
t: I think she loves me! She is crafty in her passion, and has used this rude messenger to subtly invite me back.

og: None of my lord’s ring? Why, he sent her none.  I am the man.
t: So she doesn't want my lord's ring? Well, he never sent her one. I am the man she wants.

og: If it be so, as ’tis,  Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
t: If this is true, which it is, then the poor lady would be better off loving a dream.

og: Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness,  Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.
t: I now see that disguises are a tool to aid the resourceful devil.

og: How easy is it for the proper false  In women’s waxen hearts to set their forms!
t: How easy it is for attractive, deceitful men to mold women's hearts to their will!

og: Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we,  For such as we are made of, such we be.
t: Alas, it's our female frailty that's to blame—we can't help it. We turn out the way we're made.

og: How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly,  And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,  And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.
t: But how will all this play out? My master loves her dearly, and I, poor androgynous fool, love him just as much. And now she, mistaking me for a man, seems to have fallen in love with me.

og: What will become of this? As I am man,  My state is desperate for my master’s love.  As I am woman, now, alas the day,  What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!
t: What will become of all this? In my disguise as a man, I have no hope of winning Orsino's love, but as I am really a woman, Olivia's love for me is hopeless too!

og: O time, thou must untangle this, not I.  It is too hard a knot for me to untie!
t: Oh time, you must untangle this mess—I can't do it myself. It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

og: Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and  diluculo surgere,  thou know’st,—
t: Come, Sir Andrew. To be still awake after midnight is to be up early in the morning, and you surely know that waking up at dawn is supposed to be healthy—

og: Nay, my troth, I know not. But I know to be up late is to be up late.
t: No, truly, I don't know. But I do know that to be up late is to be up late.

og: A false conclusion. I hate it as an unfilled can.
t: A false conclusion. I hate your logic like I hate an empty wine goblet.

og: To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early, sothat to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes.
t: To stay up past midnight means going to bed in the early morning, so therefore to stay up past midnight is to go to bed early.

og: Does not our life consist of the four elements?
t: Doesn't life consist of the four elements—fire, water, earth, and air?

og: Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.
t: Well, that's what they say, but I think life consists of eating and drinking.

og: Thou'rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and drink. Marian,I say! A stoup of wine!
t: You're a smart man. Let us eat and drink then. Maria, I say! Bring us a big mug of wine!

og: Here comes the fool, i' faith.
t: Here comes the fool, actually.

og: How now, my hearts! Did you never see the picture of “WeThree”?
t: How's it going, my sweethearts! We are like that picture "We Three"—three fools together.

og: Welcome, ass. Now let’s have a catch.
t: Welcome, you jackass. Now sing us a song.

og: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has.—
t: I swear, the fool has an excellent voice. I would give forty shillings to have legs like his and his beautiful singing voice.

og: In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. 'Twas very good, i' faith.
t: Truly, that was some elegant fooling last night when you spoke that astrological nonsense about Pigrogromitus, and the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. It was very funny, really.

og: I sent thee sixpence for thy leman. Hadst it?
t: I sent you some money to spend on your sweetheart. Did you get it?

og: I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio’s nose is no whipstock.
t: I put your little gift in my pocket, for Malvolio can't keep his nose out of anything.

og: My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
t: My lady has lovely white hands, and ancient warriors aren't low class taverns, you know.

og: Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when all is done.Now, a song.
t: Excellent! Why, this nonsense talk is the best kind of fooling when all's said and done. Now sing us a song.

og: Come on. There is sixpence for you. Let’s have a song.
t: Come on. Here's sixpence for you. Let's have a song.

og: There’s a testril of me too. If one knight give a—
t: There's money from me too. If one knight gives a—

og: Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
t: Do you want a love song or a drinking song?

og: A love song, a love song.
t: A love song, a love song.

og: Ay, ay. I care not for good life.
t: Yes, yes. I don't care about virtuous living.

og: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?    O, stay and hear! Your true love’s coming,    That can sing both high and low:    Trip no further, pretty sweeting.    Journeys end in lovers meeting,    Every wise man’s son doth know.
t: Oh my mistress, where are you roaming?Oh, stay and listen! Your true love's coming:He can sing both high and low.Travel no more, my pretty sweetheart.Journeys end when lovers meet,As every wise man's son should know.

og: Excellent good, i' faith.
t: That was excellent, truly.

og: Good, good.
t: Good, good.

og: What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.    Present mirth hath present laughter.    What’s to come is still unsure.    In delay there lies no plenty.    Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.    Youth’s a stuff will not endure.
t: What is love? It's not the future.Joy in the present means present laughter.What's to come is still unsure.There's no reward for wasting time.So come kiss me while you're sweet and twenty.Youthful beauty will not endure.

og: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
t: A sweet voice if I ever heard one.

og: A contagious breath.
t: A catchy song.

og: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
t: Yes, both sweet and catchy, truly.

og: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed?
t: If we could hear with our noses, his plague-breath would be sweet indeed. But will we make the sky dance with our antics?

og: Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?
t: Will we wake up the night owl and sing loud enough to make people pray? Will we?

og: An you love me, let’s do ’t. I am dog at a catch.
t: If we're friends, let's do it. I am dog at singing catches.

og: By 'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.
t: We'll do it then—some dogs are good at playing catch.

og: Most certain. Let our catch be “Thou Knave.”
t: Certainly. Let our catch be "You Villain."

og: “Hold thy peace, thou knave,” knight? I shall be constrained in ’t to call thee knave, knight.
t: You mean "Shut your mouth, you villain," right? If we sing that then I'll have to call you a villain, knight.

og: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to call me“knave.” Begin, Fool. It begins “Hold thy peace.”
t: It won't be the first time someone has had to call me "villain." You begin, Fool. It begins, "Shut your mouth."

og: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.
t: I won't ever begin if I shut my mouth.

og: Good, i' faith. Come, begin.
t: That's a good one. But come on, begin.

og: What a caterwauling do you keep here!
t: What a racket you're making out here!

og: If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.
t: My lady Olivia called up her steward Malvolio and told him to kick you out of the house—it's true.

og: My lady’s a Cataian. We are politicians, Malvolio’s a Peg- a-Ramsey, and  (sings) Three merry men be we.
t: My lady Olivia's a trickster, we are clever plotters, Malvolio's a loose woman, and [singing] We are three merry men.

og: —Am notI consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tillyvally! “Lady”!
t: Aren't we related? I'm Olivia's uncle, right? Well la-dee-da! "Lady!"

og: (  sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
t: [singing]There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!

og: Beshrew me, the knight’s in admirable fooling.
t: My my, the knight's very good at playing the fool.

og: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do I too.He does it with a better grace, but I do it more natural.
t: Yes, he's good enough when he feels like it, and I am too. He has more experience, but it comes to me naturally.

og: (sings) O' the twelfth day of December—
t: On the twelfth day of December—

og: For the love o' God, peace!
t: For the love of God, be quiet!

og: My masters, are you mad? Or what are you?
t: Masters, are you crazy? What's wrong with you?

og: Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?
t: Have you no wit, manners, or honesty, that you're making such a racket at this time of night?

og: Do you make an alehouse of my lady’shouse, that you squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice?
t: Are you trying to turn my lady's house into a noisy tavern by singing these rowdy songs without bothering to lower your voices at all?

og: Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
t: Do you have no respect for people, this place, or this time of night?

og: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!
t: We did respect the time, sir, in the beat of our songs. So go hang yourself!

og: Sir Toby, I must be round with you.
t: Sir Toby, I must be plain with you.

og: My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders.
t: My lady told me to tell you that she lets you stay here because you're her relative, but she doesn't approve of your disorderly behavior.

og: If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcometo the house. If not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
t: If you can start cleaning yourself up, you are welcome to stay in the house, but if not, and you would prefer to leave, then my lady would be glad to bid you farewell.

og: (sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.
t: Farewell, sweetheart, since I have to go now.

og: Nay, good Sir Toby.
t: No, good Sir Toby.

og: (  sings  )  His eyes do show his days are almost done.
t: His eyes do show that his life is almost over.

og: Is ’t even so?
t: Is this really happening?

og: (  sings  )  But I will never die.
t: But I will never die.

og: (  sings  )  Sir Toby, there you lie.
t: Sir Toby, that's a lie.

og: This is much credit to you.
t: This isn't helping your case.

og: (sings) Shall I bid him go?
t: Should I tell him to go?

og: (sings) What an if you do?
t: And what if you do?

og: (sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
t: Should I tell him to go, and not spare his feelings?

og: (sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.
t: Oh no, no, no, no, don't you dare.

og: Out o' tune, sir. You lie.
t: You're out of tune, sir. You lie.

og: Art any more than a steward?
t: You're nothing more than a steward.

og: Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shallbe no more cakes and ale?
t: Do you think that just because you are boring and virtuous, food and wine will disappear?

og: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.
t: By Saint Anne, we'll have spiced ale too.

og: Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!
t: You've got the right idea.  Go rub your steward's chain in some crumbs, sir. Maria, bring us more wine!

og: Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady’s favor at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule.
t: Miss Maria, if you care at all about Lady Olivia's approval, then you won't bring more wine and contribute to this boorish behavior.

og: She shall know of it, by this hand.
t: She'll hear about this—I'll tell her.

og: Go shake your ears!
t: Go wiggle your donkey's ears.

og: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man’s a-hungry,
t: Making a fool out of that man would be as virtuous a deed as giving wine to the thirsty.

og: to challenge him the field and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.
t: I could challenge him to a duel and then not show up—that might work.

og: Do ’t, knight. I’ll write thee a challenge. Or I’ll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
t: Do it, knight. I'll write a letter challenging him on your behalf. Or I'll tell him your insults myself.

og: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youthof the count’s was today with thy lady, she is much outof quiet.
t: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Ever since the Duke's young messenger visited Lady Olivia, she's been in a strange mood.

og: For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him.If I do not gull him into a nayword and make him a common recreation, do not think I have wit enough to liestraight in my bed.
t: And as for Mister Malvolio, let me take care of him. If I can't trick him into making a fool of himself and turn him into a big joke, then I'm not even smart enough to lie straight in my bed.

og: I know I can do it.
t: I know I can do it.

og: Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.
t: Give us the facts, give us the facts—tell us something about him.

og: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.
t: Well, sir, sometimes he acts like a Puritan—opposed to anything fun.

og: O, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!
t: Oh, I'd beat him like a dog for that!

og: What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?
t: What, for being a Puritan? And what's your far-fetched reason for that, dear knight?

og: I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.
t: I don't have a far-fetched reason for it, but my reason is good enough.

og: The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly,but a time-pleaser;
t: He's not always a Puritan, though. He doesn't remain anything for long, except for a flatterer and a yes-man,

og: an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swarths;
t: an affected jackass who tries to talk like the nobility.

og: the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him.
t: He has such a high opinion of himself and thinks he's so crammed full of excellent qualities that he's sure everyone loves him.

og: And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.
t: And that's the weakness that I'll use to get my revenge on him.

og: What wilt thou do?
t: What will you do?

og: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love,
t: I'll drop some mysterious love letters in his path.

og: wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg,the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated.
t: They'll describe the color of his beard, the shape of his legs, the way he walks, and the expression of his eyes, forehead, and complexion—so he'll be sure that they're addressed to him.

og: I can write very like my lady yourniece: on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.
t: I can make my handwriting look just like your niece Lady Olivia's. Sometimes we can't tell our writing apart.

og: Excellent! I smell a device.
t: Excellent! I can smell the trick.

og: I have ’t in my nose too.
t: I smell it too.

og: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she’s in love with him.
t: He'll think, based on the letters you drop, that they come from my niece, and assume that she's in love with him.

og: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
t: My purpose is indeed a horse of that color, so to speak.

og: And your horse now would make him an ass.
t: And your horse would now make him into a jackass.

og: Ass, I doubt not.
t: Yes, you jackass.

og: Oh, ’twill be admirable!
t: Oh, it's going to be great!

og: Sport royal, I warrant you.
t: It will be royal fun, I promise you.

og: I know my physic will work with him.
t: I know my medicine will work on him.

og: I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter. Observe his construction of it.
t: You two will hide, along with the Fool, in the place where I'll leave the letter. Then you can observe how he interprets it.

og: For this night, to bed, and dream onthe event. Farewell.
t: But for tonight, it's time to go to bed and dream about this plan. Farewell.

og: Good night, Penthesilea.
t: Good night, queen of the Amazons.

og: Before me, she’s a good wench.
t: She's a good wench—I swear.

og: She’s a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me. Whato' that?
t: She's a little purebred hunting hound, and she adores me. What of it?

og: I was adored once too.
t: Someone once adored me, too.

og: Let’s to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.
t: Let's go to bed, knight. You need to send for some more money.

og: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.
t: If I don't marry your niece, then I'm going to be in horrible financial trouble.

og: Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i' the end, call me “Cut.”
t: Send for more money, knight. If you don't end up with her in the end, then I'm a fool.

og: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
t: If I don't, never trust me again—interpret that how you want to.

og: Come, come, I’ll go burn some sack. 'Tis too late to goto bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.
t: Come, come, I'll go warm up some sherry for us. It's too late to go to bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.

og: Give me some music.
t: Give me some music.

og: Now, good morrow, friends.—
t: Now, good morning, friends.

og: Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,  That old and antique song we heard last night.
t: Now, good Cesario, have them play that old-fashioned song we heard last night.

og: Methought it did relieve my passion much,  More than light airs and recollected terms  Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:  Come, but one verse.
t: It helped ease my passion and made me feel better, more than the silly songs and memorized words of these fast-paced modern times. Come, have them sing just one verse at least.

og: He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.
t: Forgive me, my lord, but the man who should sing it isn't here.

og: Who was it?
t: Who is that?

og: Feste, the jester, my lord, a fool that the lady Olivia’s father took much delight in. He is about the house.
t: Feste the jester, my lord, a fool that Olivia's father used to like. He's somewhere in the house.

og: Seek him out, and play the tune the while.
t: Go find him, and in the meantime you all play the tune.

og: Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love,  In the sweet pangs of it remember me;
t: Come here, boy. If you ever fall in love, remember me when you feel its bittersweet pangs.

og: For such as I am, all true lovers are,  Unstaid and skittish in all motions else  Save in the constant image of the creature  That is beloved.
t: Because the way I am now is the way all true lovers are—moody and fickle in every emotion, constant only in imagining the face of the person they love.

og: How dost thou like this tune?
t: How do you like this song?

og: It gives a very echo to the seatWhere Love is throned.
t: It echoes poignantly in the heart.

og: Thou dost speak masterly.
t: You speak well.

og: My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye  Hath stay’d upon some favor that it loves.
t: I'd bet my life that, young as you are, you've fallen in love with a woman before.

og: Hath it not, boy?
t: Am I right, boy?

og: A little, by your favor.
t: A little bit, sir.

og: What kind of woman is’t?
t: What kind of woman is she?

og: Of your complexion.
t: She looks something like you.

og: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?
t: She's not worthy of you, then. How old is she?

og: About your years, my lord.
t: About your age, my lord.

og: Too old by heaven. Let still the woman take  An elder than herself.
t: Then she's too old, by heaven. A woman should be with a man older than she is,

og: So wears she to him,  So sways she level in her husband’s heart.
t: so she can adapt herself to her husband and keep his love constant.

og: For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,  Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,  More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,  Than women’s are.
t: We men praise ourselves, boy, but in reality we are more fickle and inconstant in love than women are—our desires waver and disappear sooner and more frequently.

og: I think it well, my lord.
t: I think you're right, my lord.

og: Then let thy love be younger than thyself,  Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.
t: Then your beloved should be younger than you are, or you won't be able to maintain your feelings for her.

og: And so they are. Alas, that they are so, To die even when they to perfection grow!
t: So they are. It's too bad that this is how it is—beauty starts to die just as it reaches its perfection!

og: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.—
t: Oh, you fellow, come sing the song we heard last night.

og: Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;  The spinsters and the knitters in the sun  And the free maids that weave their thread with bones  Do use to chant it
t: Listen closely to it, Cesario, it's a simple old song. The wool spinners and knitters used to sing it while they sewed, and innocent maidens recited it over their weaving.

og: . It is silly sooth,  And dallies with the innocence of love,  Like the old age.
t: It tells the simple truth about the innocence of love, as it was in the good old days.

og: Are you ready, sir?
t: Are you ready, sir?

og: Ay; prithee, sing.
t: Yes; please, sing.

og: Come away, come away, death,    And in sad cypress let me be laid.    Fly away, fly away breath,    I am slain by a fair cruel maid.    My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,    O, prepare it!    My part of death, no one so true    Did share it.    Not a flower, not a flower sweet    On my black coffin let there be strown.    Not a friend, not a friend greet    My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown.    A thousand thousand sighs to save,    Lay me, O, where    Sad true lover never find my grave,    To weep there!
t: Come now, come now death,And let me be laid in a cypress coffin.Fly away, fly away breath,I've been killed by a fair, cruel girl.My shroud of white, adorned with yew sprigs,Oh, prepare it for me!No one as faithful as IHas ever died like me.Throw no flowers, no sweet flowersUpon my black coffin.Let no friends, no friends seeMy poor corpse, or my scattered bones.Save your thousand sighs of mourning,And bury me, Oh, whereNo sad true lovers can find my grave,To weep there!

og: There’s for thy pains.
t: That's for your trouble.

og: No pains, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.
t: It was no trouble, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.

og: I’ll pay thy pleasure then.
t: I'll pay you for your pleasure, then.

og: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.
t: All right then, sir. We all pay for our pleasures eventually.

og: Give me now leave to leave thee.
t: Allow me to let you leave now.

og: Now, the melancholy god protect thee, and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal.
t: May the god of melancholy watch over you, and may a tailor make you a jacket of opal, for your mind changes like the colors of an opal.

og: I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be everything and their intent everywhere, for that’s it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.
t: Men as changeable as you should be put out to sea, where they can make everything their business and scatter their ideas everywhere, drifting about on the changeable waves—that's how you make a good voyage out of nothing. Farewell.

og: Let all the rest give place.
t: The rest of you can leave too.

og: Once more, Cesario,  Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.
t: Once more, Cesario, go visit that supremely cruel woman.

og: Tell her my love, more noble than the world,  Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;  The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her,  Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;
t: Tell her that my love is more noble than anything else in the world, and has nothing to do with her property or the riches she has inherited.

og: But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems  That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
t: Tell her that the fortune I value the most is her gem-like beauty, which is priceless and attracts my helpless soul.

og: But if she cannot love you, sir?
t: But if she cannot love you, sir?

og: I cannot be so answer’d.
t: I cannot accept that answer.

og: Sooth, but you must.
t: Truly, but you must.

og: Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,  Hath for your love a great a pang of heart  As you have for Olivia.
t: Imagine a lady—who probably exists somewhere—who loves you just as passionately as you love Olivia.

og: You cannot love her.  You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?
t: But you cannot love her, and you tell her so. Doesn't she have to accept your answer then?

og: There is no woman’s sides  Can bide the beating of so strong a passion  As love doth give my heart.
t: There is no woman strong enough to withstand the passion of love that's in my heart.

og: No woman’s heart  So big, to hold so much. They lack retention.
t: No woman's heart is big enough to hold so much emotion. Women can't carry too much.

og: Alas, their love may be called appetite,  No motion of the liver, but the palate,  That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt;
t: Alas, love for them is just a shallow appetite—a matter of taste, not a matter of the heart. If they try to eat too much, they get sick,

og: But mine is all as hungry as the sea,  And can digest as much.
t: but my love is as insatiable as the sea, and can swallow just as much as the ocean.

og: Make no compare  Between that love a woman can bear me  And that I owe Olivia.
t: Don't compare my love for Olivia to any love a woman could have for me.

og: Ay, but I know—
t: Yes, but I know—

og: What dost thou know?
t: What do you know?

og: Too well what love women to men may owe.  In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
t: I know too well how strongly a woman can love a man. Really, their hearts are as true as ours are.

og: My father had a daughter loved a man  As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,  I should your lordship.
t: My father had a daughter who loved a man just as strongly as I might love you, if I were a woman.

og: And what’s her history?
t: And what's her story?

og: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,  But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,  Feed on her damask cheek.
t: Her story is blank, my lord. She never spoke of her love, but kept her passion concealed. It tormented her from the inside, like a worm trapped inside a closed flower bud, and fed on her outer beauty until it faded.

og: She pined in thought,  And with a green and yellow melancholy  She sat like patience on a monument,  Smiling at grief.
t: She pined away quietly and sadly, and sat like a sculpture of patience itself, smiling despite her grief.

og: Was not this love indeed?  We men may say more, swear more, but indeed  Our shows are more than will,
t: Now wasn't this true love? We men might say more and promise more, but indeed our words are stronger than our passions.

og: for still we prove  Much in our vows, but little in our love.
t: We are good at making vows of love, but worse at keeping them.

og: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
t: But did your sister die of her love, my boy?

og: I am all the daughters of my father’s house,  And all the brothers too—and yet I know not.
t: I am all of my father's daughters, and all of his sons too—and yet I'm not certain of that.

og: Sir, shall I to this lady?
t: Sir, should I go see this lady then?

og: Ay, that’s the theme.To her in haste. Give her this jewel. SayMy love can give no place, bide no denay.
t: Yes, that's right. Go to her quickly. Give her this jewel. Say that my love cannot yield, and cannot be denied.

og: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.
t: Come along, Mister Fabian.

og: Nay, I’ll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
t: I'm coming, don't worry. If I miss the tiniest bit of this joke, may I get boiled to death.

og: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascallysheep-biter come by some notable shame?
t: Won't you be glad to see that pretentious, rascally dog get humiliated?

og: I would exult, man. You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.
t: I'll rejoice, man. You know, he got me in trouble with my lady Olivia once, when I held a bear-baiting here.

og: To anger him, we’ll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue. Shall we not, Sir Andrew?
t: We'll bring the bear back just to make him angry then, and we'll make a fool of him until he's ruined. Won't we, Sir Andrew?

og: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.
t: If we don't, it will be the worst mistake of our lives.

og: Here comes the little villain.
t: Here comes the little villain.

og: How now, my metal of India?
t: How's it going, my golden one?

og: Get you all three into the boxtree.
t: All three of you hide in the hedge.

og: Malvolio’s coming down this walk. He has been yonder i' the sun practisingbehavior to his own shadow this half hour.
t: Malvolio's coming this way down the path. He's been over there practicing his elegant manner for the past half hour.

og: Observe him,for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.
t: Watch him closely, if you love mockery, because I know that this letter will turn him into a starry-eyed fool.

og: Close, in the name ofjesting!
t: Now hide, if you love jokes!

og: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comesthe trout that must be caught with tickling.
t: You lie there now , for here comes the fish that must be caught by tickling it.

og: 'Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion.
t: All is luck, only luck. Maria once told me that Lady Olivia liked me, and I've almost heard Olivia herself say that if she should love a man, he would be someone with my personality.

og: Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her. What should Ithink on ’t?
t: Besides, she treats me with more respect and admiration than anyone else in her service. So what should I think of all this?

og: (  aside  ) Here’s an overweening rogue!
t: What an arrogant villain!

og: O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock of him.
t: Oh, gimme a break! When he's alone and musing to himself he acts even more like a proud peacock.

og: How he jets under his advanced plumes!
t: See how he struts and shows his feathers!

og: (  aside  ) 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!
t: By God, I'd like to beat him up!

og: (  aside  ) Peace, I say.
t: Quiet, I say.

og: To be Count Malvolio!
t: I could be "Count Malvolio!"

og: (  aside  ) Ah, rogue!
t: Ah, that villain!

og: (  aside  ) Peace, peace!
t: Quiet, quiet!

og: There is example for ’t. The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.
t: There are other instances of such things happening. The Lady Strachy married her wardrobe assistant.

og: (  aside  ) Fie on him, Jezebel!
t: Curse him, wicked Jezebel!

og: O, peace! Now he’s deeply in. Look how imagination blows him.
t: Oh, quiet! Now he's really lost in his imagination. Look how his fantasies puff him up.

og: Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state—
t: Imagine me after three months being married to her, sitting in my majestic chair—

og: (  aside  ) Oh, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!
t: Oh, if only I had a slingshot, to shoot him in the eye!

og: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed, where I have left Olivia sleeping—
t: Calling my servants around me, dressed in my embroidered velvet gown, having just come from the sofa where I've left Olivia sleeping—

og: (  aside  ) Fire and brimstone!
t: Bloody hell!

og: (  aside  ) O, peace, peace!
t: hispering] Oh quiet, quiet!

og: And then to have the humor of state, and after a demuretravel of regard,
t: And then to have an expression of great authority, and to gravely survey the room

og: telling them I know my place as I would they should do theirs, to ask for my kinsman Toby—
t: and then tell them that I know my place, and I'd like them to know theirs. I'd ask for my cousin Toby—

og: (  aside  ) Bolts and shackles!
t: My God!

og: (  aside  ) O peace, peace, peace! Now, now.
t: Oh quiet, quiet, quiet! Now, now.

og: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him.
t: Seven of my servants obediently would go to find him.

og: I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch,or play with my—some rich jewel.
t: I frown while I wait, and perhaps wind my watch, or play with my—with some rich jewel I'm wearing.

og: Toby approaches, curtsies there to me—
t: Toby approaches me and bows—

og: (  aside  ) Shall this fellow live?
t: Will we let this fellow live?

og: Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.
t: We must keep our silence—even though it is hard to, when he's being this offensive. Quiet.

og: I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control—
t: I reach out my hand to him like so, extinguishing my usual smile and replacing it with a severe look of authority—

og: (  aside  ) And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?
t: And doesn't Toby give you a punch in the mouth then?

og: Saying, “Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on your niece give me this prerogative of speech—”
t: And I say, "Cousin Toby, since fortune has allowed me to marry your niece, I have the right to say this—"

og: (  aside  ) What, what?
t: What, what?

og: “You must amend your drunkenness.”
t: "You must give up your drinking."

og: (  aside  ) Out, scab!
