t: Out of here, you scab!

og: (  aside  ) Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.
t: No, be patient, or we'll ruin our plan.

og: “Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight—”
t: "And another thing—you're wasting your valuable time with that foolish knight—"

og: (  aside  ) That’s me, I warrant you.
t: That's me, I'm sure.

og: “One Sir Andrew—”
t: "That Sir Andrew—"

og: (  aside  ) I knew ’twas I, for many do call me fool.
t: I knew it was me, for I've often been called foolish.

og: (  seeing the letter  ) What employment have we here?
t: And what do we have here?

og: (  aside  ) Now is the woodcock near the gin.
t: Now the bird approaches the snare.

og: O, peace! And the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him!
t: Oh, quiet! I hope the mood strikes him to read it out loud!

og: It is, in contempt of question, her hand.
t: It's her handwriting, without question.

og: (  aside  ) Her C’s, her U’s and her T’s. Why that?
t: Her C's, her U's, and her T's. Why only mention those?

og: “To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes”—Her very phrases! By your leave, wax.  Soft! And the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal.'Tis my lady. To whom should this be?
t: "To my beloved, who doesn't know of my love, I send this letter and my good wishes"—And it's phrased just how she would speak! Excuse me for breaking your seal, wax. But wait! This wax is stamped with an image of Lucrece, which Olivia uses for her seal. This letter is from my lady. But who is it written to?

og: (  aside  ) This wins him, liver and all.
t: This is winning him over, heart and all.

og: (  aside  ) Marry, hang thee, brock!
t: Damn, go hang yourself, you badger!

og: “I may command where I adore, But silence, like a Lucrece knife,With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore;M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.”
t: "I may command the one I love,But silence, like a knife,Cuts my heart with a bloodless wound.M.O.A.I. rules my life."

og: (  aside  ) A fustian riddle!
t: An elaborate riddle!

og: (  aside  ) Excellent wench, say I.
t: Such a clever girl, I say.

og: “M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.” Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.
t: "M.O.A.I. rules my life." No, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.

og: (  aside  ) What dish o' poison has she dressed him!
t: What a dish of poison she's prepared for him!

og: (  aside  ) And with what wing the staniel checks at it!
t: And see how eagerly he goes to eat it!

og: (  aside  ) O, ay, make up that.—He is now at a cold scent.
t: Oh, yes, notice that. The trail's gone cold for him.

og: Sowter will cry upon ’t for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.
t: He'll pick up the scent eventually, no matter how much it smells of a prank.

og: “M”—Malvolio. “M”—why, that begins my name.
t: "M"—Malvolio. "M"—why, that's the first letter of my name.

og: Did not I say he would work it out? The cur is excellent at faults.
t: Didn't I say he would figure it out? This dog is excellent at tracking.

og: “M.” But then there is no consonancy in the sequel.
t: "M." But then the next letter doesn't agree with my name.

og: That suffers under probation. “A” should follow but “O” does.
t: This theory doesn't stand up to the test. "A" should be next, but instead it's "O."

og: (  aside  ) And “O” shall end, I hope.
t: And this will all end in an "O" as well, I hope—the "O" of a hangman's noose.

og: (  aside  ) Ay, or I’ll cudgel him and make him cry “O!”
t: Yes, or else I'll beat him with a club and make him yell "O!"

og: And then “I” comes behind.
t: And then an "I" comes last.

og: Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.
t: Yes, and if you had an "I" in the back of your head, you might see more trouble behind you than good luck before you.

og: “M.O.A.I.” This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft, here follows prose.
t: "M.O.A.I." The hidden meaning of this part isn't like the other one, but if I force it a little, it too could refer to me—for every one of these letters is in my name. Wait, there's some more prose now.

og: “If this fall into thy hand, revolve.
t: "If this should fall into your hands, consider it well.

og: In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
t: By birth I am ranked above you, but don't be afraid of my greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.

og: Thy Fates open their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them. And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh.
t: Your fate welcomes you. Accept it with your body and spirit. And, to prepare yourself for the upper-class life you will have soon, cast aside your lowly outer self and become a new, fresh person.

og: Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity.
t: Be rude to your companions, and be mean to servants. Talk loudly and often about politics, and make a habit of being unique and eccentric.

og: She thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered. I say, remember.
t: The woman who sighs with love for you advises you to do this. Remember who it was who complimented your yellow stockings, and asked to see you always wearing crossed laces going up your legs. Remember her, I say.

og: Go to, thou art made, if thou desir’st to be so; if not, let me see theea steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthyto touch Fortune’s fingers.
t: Now go. You are assured of becoming a gentleman, if you want to be. If not, just keep acting like a steward, a companion of servants, and not worthy to grasp the greatness before you.

og: Farewell. She that would alter services with thee,  The Fortunate Unhappy”
t: Farewell. Signed, one who would switch places with you and be your servant,The Fortunate Unfortunate"

og: Daylight and champaign discovers not more. This is open.
t: Daylight in an open field couldn't be clearer than this.

og: I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point- devise the very man.
t: This is obvious. I will act proud, I will study politics, I will insult Sir Toby, I will rid myself of lower-class acquaintances, and I will act exactly as she asked me to.

og: I donot now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
t: I'm not fooling myself now, or letting my imagination trick me—reason points to the inevitable conclusion that my lady Olivia loves me.

og: Shedid commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praisemy leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.
t: She did compliment my yellow stockings lately, and she did praise my crossed laces, and in this she has proven that she loves me.

og: I thank my stars I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yeta postscript.
t: I thank my lucky stars. I'm so happy. I will act just as she wanted—I'll be proud and aloof, and put on my yellow stockings and crossed laces as quickly as I can. May God and my lucky stars be praised! And here's more, a postscript.

og: “Thou canst not choose but know who I am.
t: "You have probably figured out who I am.

og: If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling. Thy smiles become thee well.
t: If you accept my love, then let me know by smiling. Your smiles look good on you.

og: Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”
t: So please smile whenever you're in my presence, my dear sweetheart."

og: Jove, I thank thee! I will smile. I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
t: Thank you God! I will smile for her. I'll do everything she wants me to.

og: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.
t: I wouldn't have missed this entertainment for a pension of thousands, to be paid by the Shah of Persia.

og: I could marry this wench for this device.
t: I could marry that Maria for coming up with this scheme.

og: So could I too.
t: So could I.

og: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
t: And I wouldn't ask for any bridal dowry except for her to come up with another joke like this.

og: Nor I neither.
t: Neither would I.

og: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
t: Here comes my noble fool-catcher.

og: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?
t: Should I kiss your feet?

og: Or o' mine either?
t: Or should I?

og: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?
t: Should I gamble away my freedom at dice, and become your slave?

og: I' faith, or I either?
t: Or should I?

og: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.
t: Why, you've sent Malvolio into such a fantasy that he'll go mad when he learns the truth.

og: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
t: No, tell me the truth, did he fall for my letter?

og: Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
t: He swallowed it hook, line, and sinker.

og: If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady.
t: If you want to see the real results of this joke, then watch him when he first approaches my lady.

og: He will come to her in yellow stockings, and ’tis a color she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests.
t: He'll come to her in yellow stockings—a color she hates—and with crossed laces on his legs—a fashion she despises.

og: And he will smileupon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she i
t: And he'll smile constantly at her, which will go completely against her current mood, as she seems addicted to melancholy lately.

og: s, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.
t: All of it together will surely make her notice him and scorn him. If you want to see this, follow me.

og: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!
t: I'll follow you to the deepest gates of Hell, you witty devil!

og: I’ll make one too.
t: I'll join the group too.

og: Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live by thytabour?
t: God bless you, friend, and your music. Do you make your living by playing your drum?

og: No, sir, I live by the church.
t: No, sir, I live by the church.

og: Art thou a churchman?
t: Are you a clergyman?

og: No such matter, sir. I do live by the church; for I dolive at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.
t: Not at all, sir. I live by the church because I live in my house, and my house is by the church.

og: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggardwell near him,
t: You may as well say then that the king sleeps with a beggar if a beggar lives near him,

og: or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
t: or that the church stands next to your drum if your drum stands next to the church.

og: You have said, sir. To see this age!
t: You're right, sir. What a wonder this modern age is!

og: A sentence is buta cheveril glove to a good wit. How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
t: A sentence is like a supple glove for good wit—it can be turned inside out so quickly!

og: Nay, that’s certain. They that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.
t: Yes, that's certainly true. Those who play around with words too much can quickly make them changeable and promiscuous.

og: I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
t: If that's so, then I wish my sister didn't have a name, sir.

og: Why, man?
t: Why, man?

og: Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton.
t: Well, sir, her name's a word, and to play around with that word might make my sister promiscuous.

og: But, indeed, words arevery rascals since bonds disgraced them.
t: But indeed, words have been rascals ever since people started needing written contracts to guarantee them.

og: Thy reason, man?
t: What's your reason for that, man?

og: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
t: Truly, sir, I can't give you a reason without using words, and since words have become so false and unreliable, I'm hesitant to use them for my proof.

og: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
t: I'll bet you're a happy fellow, without a care in the world.

og: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you.
t: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But honestly, sir, I don't care for you.

og: If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
t: If that means that I care for nothing, sir, then you should become invisible right now—as you're nothing.

og: Art not thou the Lady Olivia’s fool?
t: Aren't you the Lady Olivia's fool?

og: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly. She willkeep no fool, sir, till she be married,
t: No indeed, sir, the Lady Olivia has no foolishness. She won't keep a fool until she gets married.

og: and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings; the husband’s the bigger:
t: Fools are to husbands as anchovies are to sardines—husbands are the larger version.

og: I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.
t: I'm not her fool, just her corrupter of words.

og: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino’s.
t: I saw you at Duke Orsino's recently.

og: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun. It shines everywhere.
t: Foolishness, sir, wanders about the earth like the sun. It's everywhere.

og: I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: Ithink I saw your wisdom there.
t: I'd be sorry if your master was less acquainted with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.

og: Nay, an thou pass upon me, I’ll no more with thee. Hold, there’s expenses for thee.
t: If you're just going to make fun of me, I want nothing to do with it. But wait, here's a coin for you.

og: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
t: May God, in his next shipment of hair, send you a beard!

og: By my troth, I’ll tell thee, I am almost sick for one,  (aside]  though I would not have it grow on my chin.    Is thy lady within?
t: Honestly, I'm telling you, I'm dying for one,  though I don't want it on my own chin—I'm dying for a certain man with a beard.

og: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?
t: If I had a pair of these coins, sir, do you think they'd have children?

og: Yes, being kept together and put to use.
t: Yes, if they were kept together and invested.

og: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring aCressida to this Troilus.
t: I'd like to play the pimp, sir, and bring these two lovers together.

og: I understand you, sir. 'Tis well begged.
t: I understand you sir. You're pretty good at begging.

og: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar. Cressida was a beggar.
t: It's no problem for me, sir, as I'm only begging on a beggar's behalf. The famous lover Cressida became a beggar in her old age, they say.

og: My lady is within, sir. Iwill construe to them whence you come.
t: My lady is inside, sir. I'll explain where you come from,

og: Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.
t: but who you are and what you want are beyond my knowledge. I'd say I'm "not in my element," but those words are overused.

og: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,  And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
t: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, and to do that well you have to be clever.

og: He must observe their mood on whom he jests,  The quality of persons, and the time,  And, like the haggard, check at every feather  That comes before his eye.
t: He has to pay attention to the mood and status of the person he's mocking, the time, and must also pursue every target he sees.

og: This is a practise  As full of labor as a wise man’s art,  For folly that he wisely shows is fit.  But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
t: This is a skill that requires just as much work as any wise man's job, for he plays the fool very wisely. Wise men, on the other hand, ruin their reputation for intelligence when they try to play the fool.

og: Save you, gentleman.
t: God bless you, sir.

og: And you, sir.
t: And you, sir.

og: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.
t: May God protect you, sir.

og: Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!
t: And you also. At your service!

og: I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.
t: I hope so, sir, and I am at your service too.

og: Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.
t: Will you come in the house? My niece wants you to, if your business is with her.

og: I am bound to your niece, sir. I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
t: I'm bound for your niece, sir. I mean, she's the destination of my voyage.

og: Taste your legs, sir. Put them to motion.
t: Try your legs then sir, and put them in motion.

og: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understandwhat you mean by bidding me taste my legs.
t: My legs stand under me better than I understand you, and what you mean by "try your legs."

og: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
t: I mean to enter the house, sir.

og: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented.
t: I'll answer you by walking in. But we've been anticipated.

og: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
t: Most excellent accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!

og: (  aside  ) That youth’s a rare courtier. “Rain odors.” Well.
t: That youth's a classy fellow. "Rain odors." Nice.

og: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
t: My message can't be told to anyone, my lady. It's only for your own willing and receptive ears.

og: “Odors,” “pregnant,” and “vouchsafed.” I’ll get'em all three all ready.
t: [To himself) "Odors," "willing," and "receptive." I'll have to remember those.

og: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
t: Close the garden door and let me be alone to hear this message.

og: Give me your hand, sir.
t: Give me your hand, sir.

og: My duty, madam, and most humble service.
t: I offer you my obedience, madam, and my most humble service.

og: What is your name?
t: What is your name?

og: Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.
t: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

og: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world  Since lowly feigning was call’d compliment.
t: My servant, sir! The world has gone downhill since false humility started passing for a compliment.

og: You’re servant to the Count Orsino, youth.
t: You're Duke Orsino's servant, youth, not mine.

og: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:Your servant’s servant is your servant, madam.
t: But he is your servant, so all that he has is yours too. Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

og: For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.
t: As for him, I don't think about him. And as for his thoughts, I wish that they were blank pages instead of filled with pictures of me.

og: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughtsOn his behalf.
t: Madam, I've come on his behalf to improve your feelings towards him.

og: O, by your leave, I pray you,  I bade you never speak again of him.
t: Oh, please, I beg you, I asked you never speak of him again.

og: But, would you undertake another suit,  I had rather hear you to solicit that  Than music from the spheres.
t: But if you would tell me that another man loves me instead, I would rather hear that than angels singing.

og: Dear lady—
t: Dear lady—

og: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,  After the last enchantment you did here,  A ring in chase of you.
t: Please, let me speak. After the magic spell you cast on me last time you were here, I sent that ring to you.

og: So did I abuse  Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you:
t: With that trick I degraded myself, my servant, and you, I'm afraid.

og: Under your hard construction must I sit,  To force that on you, in a shameful cunning  Which you knew none of yours.
t: I must then accept your judgment of this act, which you probably condemn—for I forced that ring on you through shameful trickery, and without your consent.

og: What might you think?  Have you not set mine honor at the stake,  And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts  That tyrannous heart can think?
t: What must you think of me? Haven't you tied my honor to a stake like a bear, and let the hounds of your anger attack it?

og: To one of your receiving  Enough is shown.
t: But I've shown my situation clearly enough for someone of your intelligence to understand.

og: A cypress, not a bosom,  Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.
t: My heart's on my sleeve—I can't hide my passion. So let me hear you speak.

og: I pity you.
t: I pity you.

og: That’s a degree to love.
t: That's a step towards love.

og: No, not a grize. For ’tis a vulgar proofThat very oft we pity enemies.
t: No, not a step. It's a common experience that we often pity our enemies.

og: Why then methinks ’tis time to smile again.  O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
t: Then I think it's time for me to smile again. Oh, how easy it is for the poor to be proud of something they don't have!

og: If one should be a prey, how much the better  To fall before the lion than the wolf!
t: But if I must be defeated, then better to be defeated by a noble enemy than a lowly one.

og: The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.  Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.
t: See, the clock scolds me for wasting time. Don't worry, youth, I won't keep pursuing you.

og: And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,  Your wife is like to reap a proper man.
t: And when you're older and wiser, your future wife will have a fine handsome husband.

og: There lies your way, due west.
t: There's your way back home, due west.

og: Then westward ho!Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!You’ll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?
t: Then I'm off to the west! I wish you the best of fortune. You don't have a message for the duke?

og: Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
t: Stay, please, and tell me what you really think of me.

og: That you do think you are not what you are.
t: I think that you're not who you think you are.

og: If I think so, I think the same of you.
t: If that's true, then I think the same thing of you.

og: Then think you right: I am not what I am.
t: Then you're correct. I am not what I seem to be.

og: I would you were as I would have you be!
t: I wish you were what I want you to be!

og: Would it be better, madam, than I am? I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
t: Would that be better, madam, than me being what I am? I wish that it would, for right now I'm a fool.

og: Oh, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful  In the contempt and anger of his lip!
t: Oh, look how beautiful he is even in his anger and contempt!

og: A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon  Than love that would seem hid. Love’s night is noon.
t: A murderer's guilt is easier to hide than feelings of love. Midday is like nighttime for love—that's how brightly passion shines.

og: Cesario, by the roses of the spring,  By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,  I love thee so,
t: Cesario, I swear by the roses of spring, by virginity, by honor, by truth, and by everything, that I love you. I love you so much

og: that, maugre all thy pride,  Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
t: that neither my wit nor my reason can hide my passion, despite your pride.

og: Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,  For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,
t: Don't draw the wrong conclusions from this, though—just because I'm wooing you doesn't mean you shouldn't woo me.

og: But rather reason thus with reason fetter.  Love sought is good, but given unsought better.
t: Use your better logic and see that love asked for is good, but love freely given is better.

og: By innocence I swear, and by my youth  I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,
t: And I swear by innocence and by my own youth that I have only one heart and one love to give,

og: And that no woman has, nor never none  Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
t: and no woman has ever ruled them, and never will—except for myself.

og: And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore  Will I my master’s tears to you deplore.
t: And so I'll say farewell, good madam. I'll never again try to make you pity my master's passion.

og: Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.
t: But come again, for you might still convince my heart, which hates him now, to somehow accept his love.

og: No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.
t: No, really, I won't stay a moment longer.

og: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
t: What's your reason for leaving, my bitter friend?

og: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
t: Yes, you must tell us your reason, Sir Andrew.

og: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me. I saw’t i'theorchard.
t: Well, I saw your niece Olivia treating the Duke's messenger better than she has ever treated me. I saw it in the garden.

og: Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.
t: Did she see you at the time though, old boy? Tell me that.

og: As plain as I see you now.
t: Yes, she saw me as plainly as I see you now.

og: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.
t: Then that was proof that she loves you.

og: 'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
t: What, are trying to make a fool of me?

og: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
t: I'll prove it to be true, sir, with judgment and logic.

og: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
t: And judgment and logic have been wise jury members since the time of Noah's ark.

og: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
t: She treated the youth so well while you were watching to exasperate and anger you, to wake up your meekly sleeping boldness, to fire up your passions.

og: You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
t: You should have approached her that minute, whipped out some excellent jokes you invented right there on the spot, and humiliated the youth into silence.

og: This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked.
t: That was the opening she gave you, but you missed it.

og: The double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my lady’s opinion, where you will hang like an icicle on a Dutchman’s beard,
t: This was a golden opportunity for you, but you let it slip away, and now you've sailed out of the warmth of my lady's good opinion. You'll stay there like an icicle in a sailor's beard

og: unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt either of valor or policy.
t: unless you can redeem yourself to her through some noble act of bravery or politics.

og: An ’t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
t: If I have to do something, it must be something brave, for I hate politics. I'd rather be a heretic than a politician.

og: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor. Challenge me the count’s youth to fight with him.
t: Well then, improve your fortunes through your bravery. Challenge the duke's young servant to a fight.

og: Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall take note of it,
t: Hurt him in eleven places. My niece will notice this,

og: and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s commendation with woman than report of valor.
t: and let me assure you, no matchmaker in the world can win you a woman's love like a reputation for bravery can.

og: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
t: This is the only way, Sir Andrew.

og: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
t: Will either of you deliver the message of my challenge to him?

og: Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and brief. Itis no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.
t: Go and write it down, in fierce handwriting. Be rude and brief. It doesn't need to be witty, as long as it's eloquent and original.

og: Taunt him with the license of ink.
t: Taunt him with all the possibilities of writing.

og: If thou “thou”-est him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, althoughthe sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down.
t: Refer to him familiarly three times at least, which will insult his pride as a nobleman. As many lies as you can fit on a piece of paper—even if the paper's as big as a royal bed—write 'em all down.

og: Go, about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.
t: Go, get started now. Even if you're using an ordinary pen, you can still fill it with bitter, venomous ink. Now go ahead.

og: Where shall I find you?
t: Where will I find you when I'm done?

og: We’ll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.
t: We'll meet you in the little room. Now go.

og: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
t: This knight is a beloved puppet to you, Sir Toby.

og: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong,or so.
t: And I've been a beloved expense to him, as he's spent two thousand or so of his ducats on me.

og: We shall have a rare letter from him: but you’ll not deliver ’t?
t: His letter's sure to be a work of art. But you won't deliver it, will you?

og: Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.
t: Never trust me again if I don't. And by all means encourage the youth to answer the knight's challenge. An oxcart couldn't haul them close enough together to fight.

og: For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I’ll eat the rest of the anatomy.
t: As for Andrew, if you dissected him and found enough red blood in his liver for even a flea to notice, I'd eat the rest of his body. He's a coward through and through.

og: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.
t: And his opponent, the youth, doesn't seem to have much aggression in his face either.

og: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
t: Look, here comes the smallest bird of all.

og: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.
t: If you want to have a laughing fit, and really laugh until you split your sides, then follow me.

og: Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado. For there is no Christian thatmeans to be saved by believing rightly can ever believesuch impossible passages of grossness.
t: That gullible Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, for no Christian who intends to go to heaven by his faith could ever believe the absurd, exaggerated things like we put in that letter.

og: He’s in yellow stockings.
t: He's wearing yellow stockings.

og: And cross-gartered?
t: With crossed laces?

og: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.
t: Yes, and they look awful—like an unfashionable village schoolteacher.

og: I have dogged him, like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him.
t: I've been stalking him like a murderer, and he's followed every instruction I gave in that letter I dropped.

og: He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.
t: He smiles so much that his face has more lines in it than a map of the Indies.

og: You have not seen such a thing as ’tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.
t: You've never seen anything like this. I can hardly keep from throwing things at him.

og: I know my lady will strike him. If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
t: I know my lady will get so annoyed she'll hit him eventually, and when she does, he'll just smile and imagine that she's flattering him.

og: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
t: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

og: I would not by my will have troubled you,But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,I will no further chide you.
t: I didn't want to trouble you, but you seem to take pleasure in enduring suffering, so I won't scold you about it anymore.

og: I could not stay behind you. My desire,  More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth.
t: I couldn't stay behind. My desire to go was sharper than a knife, and it spurred me onward.

og: And not all love to see you, though so much  As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
t: It wasn't just love for you, though that much might have inspired a man to go on an even longer voyage.

og: But jealousy what might befall your travel,  Being skilless in these parts, which to a stranger,  Unguided and unfriended, often prove  Rough and unhospitable.
t: I was also worried about what might happen to you in your travels, since you don't know this area, and it can be rough and inhospitable to a stranger without a guide or friend.

og: My willing love,  The rather by these arguments of fear,  Set forth in your pursuit.
t: My willing love for you, combined with these fears for your safety, drove me to follow you.

og: My kind Antonio,  I can no other answer make but thanks,  And thanks, and ever thanks.
t: My kind Antonio, the only answer I can give you is thanks, and thanks, and infinite thanks.

og: And oft good turns  Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.  But were my worth as is my conscience, firm,  You should find better dealing.
t: Often such good deeds are only rewarded with cheap words, but if I had any wealth I would strengthen my gratitude with money.

og: What’s to do?  Shall we go see the relics of this town?
t: Now what should we do? Should we go see the monuments of this town?

og: Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.
t: We'll do that tomorrow, sir. First we should find a place for you to stay.

og: I am not weary, and ’tis long to night:
t: I'm not weary, and night is a long way away.

og: I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes  With the memorials and the things of fame  That do renown this city.
t: Please, let's go satisfy our eyes with the sight of the memorials and statues that make this city famous.

og: Would you’d pardon me;  I do not without danger walk these streets:
t: I hope you'll pardon me: I can't walk these streets without being in danger.

og: Once in a sea-fight 'gainst the Count his galleys  I did some service, of such note indeed,
t: Once in a battle at sea I served on the side fighting against Duke Orsino's ships, and I distinguished myself enough that I might be recognized.

og: That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answered.
t: If I were arrested here, they'd make me answer for my deeds.

og: Belike you slew great number of his people?
t: Then you must have killed many of his men?

og: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;  Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel  Might well have given us bloody argument.
t: My deeds weren't so bloody as that, though we had just cause to shed some blood over that quarrel.

og: It might have since been answered in repaying  What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake,  Most of our city did.
t: We could have since resolved the matter by paying reparations for the damage we did to them in battle, for the sake of maintaining our trade relations. Most of our city did.

og: Only myself stood out;  For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,  I shall pay dear.
t: I was the only one who refused to pay anything. That's why I'll pay dearly if I should be cap here.

og: Do not then walk too open.
t: Then don't walk around too conspicuously.

og: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here’s my purse.
t: It's not a good idea for me, certainly. Wait, sir, here's my purse.

og: In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,  Is best to lodge.
t: The best place to stay is an inn called the Elephant. It's in the suburbs to the south.

og: I will bespeak our diet,  Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge  With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.
t: I'll order our meals while you spend your time pleasantly and educate yourself by exploring the town. You can find me back at the Elephant.

og: Why I your purse?
t: Why should I take your purse, though?

og: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy  You have desire to purchase,
t: Just if some trinket should catch your eye and you want to buy it—

og: and your store,  I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
t: I have the feeling that your store of money isn't large enough for useless purchases.

og: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave youFor an hour.
t: I'll carry your purse then, and leave you for an hour.

og: To the Elephant.
t: And meet me at the Elephant.

og: I do remember.
t: I remember.

og: I have sent after him. He says he’ll come.  How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?  For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrow’d.  I speak too loud.
t: [To herself] I've sent for him. He says he'll come. What food should I give him? What gifts? For it's better to buy something than beg for it or borrow it—and it's the same with youth and love. But I'm speaking too loud.

og: (to MARIA)  Where’s Malvolio? He is sad and civil  And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.  Where is Malvolio?
t: [To MARIA] Where's Malvolio? He is very serious and solemn, which is appropriate for someone in mourning like I am. Where is Malvolio?

og: He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He is sure possessed, madam.
t: He's coming, madam, but in a very strange manner. He seems crazy, madam.

og: Why, what’s the matter? Does he rave?
t: Why, what's the matter? Is he talking nonsense?

og: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.
t: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. It would be best if you had a guard nearby if he comes here, for the man is surely sick in his head.

og: Go call him hither.
t: Go call him here.

og: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.
t: I am as mad as he is, if sad madness and merry madness are equals.

og: How now, Malvolio?
t: What's going on, Malvolio?

og: Sweet lady, ho, ho.
t: Sweet lady, hello.

og: Smilest thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.
t: Are you smiling? I sent for you on a sad occasion.

og: Sad, lady! I could be sad. This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but whatof that?
t: Sad, my lady! I could be sad. These crossed laces do cut off the circulation in my legs a bit, but what of that?

og: If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.”
t: If a certain person likes them, then it's like that poem says: "Please one, and please all."

og: Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?
t: Why, what's going on, man? What is the matter with you?

og: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs.
t: My legs are yellow, but I don't feel blue.

og: It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
t: The letter came to me, and its commands must be obeyed. I think I recognized the fancy Italian handwriting.

og: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?
t: Don't you think you ought to go to bed, Malvolio?

og: To bed? “Ay, sweetheart, and I’ll come to thee.”
t: To bed? "Yes, sweetheart, I'll come to you."

og: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thyhand so oft?
t: For God's sake! Why are you smiling like that, and kissing your hand so often?

og: How do you, Malvolio?
t: Are you okay, Malvolio?

og: At your request! Yes, nightingales answer daws!
t: You think I'll answer you? Noblemen don't answer servants!

og: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?
t: Why are you acting with such ridiculous arrogance in front of my lady?

og: “Be not afraid of greatness.” 'Twas well writ.
t: "Don't be afraid of my greatness." It was well written.

og: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
t: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

og: “Some are born great—”
t: "Some are born great—"

og: Ha?
t: What?

og: “Some achieve greatness—”
t: "Some achieve greatness—"

og: What sayest thou?
t: What did you say?

og: “And some have greatness thrust upon them.”
t: "And some have greatness thrust upon them."

og: Heaven restore thee!
t: May heaven restore your sanity!

og: “Remember who commended thy yellow stockings—”
t: "Remember who it was who complimented your yellow stockings—"

og: Thy yellow stockings?
t: Your yellow stockings?

og: “And wished to see thee cross-gartered.”
t: "And asked to see you always wearing crossed laces going up your legs."

og: Cross-gartered?
t: Crossed laces?

og: “Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so—”
t: "Now go. You are assured of becoming a gentleman, if you want to be—"

og: Am I made?
t: Am I a gentleman?

og: “If not, let me see thee a servant still.”
t: "If not, just keep acting like a servant."

og: Why, this is very midsummer madness.
t: This is surely insanity.

og: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is returned. I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship’s pleasure.
t: Madam, Duke Orsino's young gentleman has returned. I had to beg him to come back, but he is here now and ready to see you when you're ready.

og: I’ll come to him.
t: I'll go to him.

og: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where’s my cousin Toby?
t: Good Maria, take care of this fellow here. Where's my cousin Toby?

og: Let some of my people have a special care of him. I would not have him miscarry for the half of mydowry.
t: Let some of my servants take special care of Malvolio. I'd give half my wealth to keep him from harm.

og: Oh, ho! Do you come near me now? No worse man than SirToby to look to me. This concurs directly with the letter.
t: Oh ho! Do you see me now? Sir Toby himself has been told to take care of me. This fits exactly with the letter.

og: She sends him on purpose that I may appear stubborn to him, for she incites me to that in the letter.
t: She sends Sir Toby to me on purpose so that I can be rude to him, just as she told me to in the letter.

og: “Cast thy humble slough,” says she. “Be oppositewith a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang with arguments of state. Put thyself into the trickof singularity,” and consequently sets down the manner how:
t: "Cast aside your lowly outer self," she said. "Be rude to your companions, and be mean to servants. Talk loudly and often about politics, and make a habit of being unique and eccentric." And then she wrote down the ways I should go about this:

og: as, a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue,in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth.
t: I should have a solemn face and a dignified demeanor, speak slowly, dress like a distinguished gentleman, and so forth.

og: I have limed her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful!
t: I've caught her now, but it is really God's doing—and may God make me thankful!

og: And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be looked to.” “Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.”
t: And when she went away just now, she said "take care of this fellow here." "Fellow!" Not "Malvolio," nor anything appropriate for a servant, but "fellow."

og: Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—what canbe said?
t: Almost "companion" or "partner." Why, everything is coming together perfectly, and not the tiniest amount of doubt, no obstacle, no incredible or unfortunate event could ruin it—what else can be said?

og: Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is thedoer of this, and he is to be thanked.
t: Nothing that exists can now come between me and the fulfillment of my hopes. Well, God is responsible for this, not me, and he is to be thanked.

og: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity?
t: Where is he, in the name of all that's holy?

og: If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
t: Even if all the devils of hell are crammed together inside of him, even if a troop of demons possesses him, I still want to speak to him.

og: Here he is, here he is. How is’t with you, sir? How is’t with you, man?
t: Here he is, here he is. How are you, sir? How are you feeling, man?

og: Go off, I discard you. Let me enjoy my private. Go off.
t: Go away, I cast you off. Let me enjoy my privacy. Go away.

og: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! Did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care of him.
t: Oh my, the demon speaks so loudly from within him. Didn't I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady asks you to take care of him.

og: Aha! Does she so?
t: Aha! Does she?

og: Go to, go to! Peace, peace. We must deal gently with him. Let me alone.
t: Come on, come on! Quiet, quiet. We must be gentle with him. Let me deal with this.

og: —How do you, Malvolio? How is ’t with you? What, man, defy the devil!Consider, he’s an enemy to mankind.
t: How are you, Malvolio? How are you feeling? Come on, man, renounce the devil! Remember, he's the enemy of mankind.

og: Do you know what you say?
t: Do you know what you're saying?

og: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!
t: Look, he resents it when you insult the devil! Pray to God that he's not bewitched!

og: Carry his water to the wisewoman.
t: Get a urine sample from him and take it to the healing woman.

og: Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.
t: Sure, I'll do it tomorrow morning, I swear. My lady would give a lot to keep from losing him.

og: How now, mistress?
t: What's that, mistress?

og: O Lord!
t: Oh Lord!

og: Prithee, hold thy peace. This is not the way. Do you not see you move him? Let me alone with him.
t: Please, keep quiet. This isn't the way to go about it. Don't you see that you're making him upset? Leave me alone with him.

og: No way but gentleness, gently, gently. The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.
t: The only way to deal with him is gently, gently. The demon in him is rough, but we can't treat it roughly.

og: Why, how now, my bawcock! How dost thou, chuck?
t: Why, hello, my fine fellow! How are you, little chicken?

og: Sir!
t: Sir!

og: Ay, Biddy, come with me.
t: Yes, little chicken, come with me.

og: —What, man! 'Tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan. Hang him, foulcollier!
t: What, man! You're too serious to play games with Satan. Damn him, that dirty coal miner devil!

og: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.
t: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

og: My prayers, minx?
t: My prayers, you hussy?

og: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.
t: No, I'm telling you, he doesn't want to hear about God.

og: Go, hang yourselves all! You are idle, shallow things. I am not of your element. You shall know more hereafter.
t: Go hang yourselves, all of you! You are lazy, shallow creatures. I'm made of better stuff than you. You'll learn more about that, later.

og: Is ’t possible?
t: Is it possible?

og: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
t: If this were being acted out on a stage, I would complain that it was unrealistic.

og: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device,man.
t: He's really taken our trick to heart—it seems to have infected his very soul.

og: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.
t: No, pursue him now, before he exposes the prank and it gets ruined.

og: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
t: Why, we're really going to make him crazy.

og: The house will be the quieter.
t: The house will be a calmer place for it.

og: Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound. My nieceis already in the belief that he’s mad.
t: Come, we'll get him into a madhouse soon enough. My niece already thinks that he's crazy.

og: We may carry itthus, for our pleasure and his penance, till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt us to have mercy onhim,
t: We can take it as far as we want, punishing him and having fun, until we're tired and out of breath from laughing so hard, and then we can have mercy on him

og: at which time we will bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see!
t: and reveal the joke, and crown you, Maria, the prank's mastermind. Come on, come on!

og: More matter for a May morning.
t: Here's more material for our comedy.

og: Here’s the challenge, read it. Warrant there’s vinegar and pepper in ’t.
t: Here's my challenge; read it. I promise that it's feisty enough.

og: Is ’t so saucy?
t: Is it that insulting?

og: Ay, is ’t, I warrant him. Do but read.
t: Yes, it is, I promise. Just read it.

og: Give me.    “Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.”
t: Give it to me.  "Youth, whatever you are, you're nothing but a filthy fellow."

og: Good, and valiant.
t: Good, and brave.

og: “Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for ’t.”
t: "And don't be amazed or ask why I call you that, for I won't give you any reason for it."

og: A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.
t: Good job, that vagueness will keep you from being accused of slander.

og: (reads)   “Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly.
t: [Reading] "You came to the lady Olivia, and she was kind to you in front of me.

og: But thou liest in thy throat. That is not the matter I challenge thee for.”
t: But you lie like a dog. That's not what I'm challenging you about."

og: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.
t: Very brief, and full of good sense... or nonsense.

og: “I will waylay thee going home, where if it be thy chance to kill me—”
t: "I will ambush you on your way home, and if you happen to kill me there—"

og: Good.
t: Good.

og: “Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain.”
t: "You'll be killing me like a criminal and a villain."

og: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law. Good.
t: You're still keeping on the safe side of the law. Good.

og: “Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope is better, and so look to thyself.
t: "Farewell then, and may God have mercy upon one of our souls. He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope of surviving is better than yours, so watch yourself.

og: Thy friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,  Andrew Aguecheek”
t: Signed, your friend, if you were friendly in return, and your sworn enemy,Andrew Aguecheek"

og: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot. I’ll give’t him.
t: [To ANDREW] If this letter won't make him get up and fight, then his legs must not work. I'll give it to him.

og: You may have very fit occasion for ’t. He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.
t: You have a very convenient opportunity for it. He's doing some business with my lady right now, and he'll be leaving sooner or later.

og: Go, Sir Andrew. Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily.
t: Go, Sir Andrew. Look for him in the corner of the garden as if you were a bounty hunter.

og: So soon as ever thou seest him, draw, and as thou drawest, swear horrible,
t: As soon as you see him, draw your sword, and swear horribly as you draw it.

og: for it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof itself would have earned him. Away!
t: It's often the case that a terrible swear word uttered with an arrogant tone can increase your reputation for courage better than actually fighting would. Now go!

og: Nay, let me alone for swearing.
t: No, I can't bear to swear.

og: Now will not I deliver his letter, for the behavior of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacityand breeding. His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth.
t: Now I won't deliver this letter, for the young gentleman's behavior shows that he is noble and sensible, and his role as a messenger between his lord and my niece confirms this. Therefore this letter, which is so incredibly ignorant, won't frighten him at all

og: He will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I willdeliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity.
t: . He'll know it came from a fool. But, sir, I will deliver Sir Andrew's challenge by word of mouth. I'll describe him as having a great reputation for bravery, and convince the youth that Sir Andrew is angry, courageous, and skilled with a sword—and he'll believe me because he's so young.

og: This will so fright them both that theywill kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.
t: Then they'll both be so afraid, that when they see each other they'll kill each other with just a look, like basilisks.

og: Here he comes with your niece. Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.
t: Here comes the youth with your niece. Stay away until he leaves her, and then confront him.

og: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.
t: While I wait I'll come up with some horrible message to be the challenge.

og: I have said too much unto a heart of stone  And laid mine honor too unchary on ’t.
t: I've said too much to your heart of stone, and carelessly laid my honor and reputation on that stone.

og: There’s something in me that reproves my fault,  But such a headstrong potent fault it is  That it but mocks reproof.
t: There's something in me that condemns my love, but that love is so willful and powerful that it ignores all condemnation.

og: With the same 'havior that your passion bearsGoes on my master’s grief.
t: My master's behavior in his passion for you is the same as yours in your passion for me.

og: Here, wear this jewel for me. 'Tis my picture.  Refuse it not. It hath no tongue to vex you.
t: Here, wear this locket for me. My picture is inside. Don't refuse it, please. Unlike me, it has no voice to upset you with.

og: And I beseech you come again tomorrow.  What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny,  That honor, saved, may upon asking give?
t: And I beg you to come again tomorrow. What could you ask of me that I would deny, as long as I can retain my honor in giving it?

og: Nothing but this: your true love for my master.
t: Nothing but this: give your true love to my master.

og: How with mine honor may I give him thatWhich I have given to you?
t: How could I keep my honor and  give him what I have already given to you?

og: I will acquit you.
t: I will release you from any obligation to me.

og: Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
t: Well, come again tomorrow. Farewell. A devil who wore your face could lead my soul to hell.

og: Gentleman, God save thee.
t: Hello, gentleman.

og: And you, sir.
t: And hello to you, sir.

og: That defense thou hast, betake thee to ’t
t: Prepare yourself with whatever fighting defenses you have.

og: . Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end.
t: I don't know what you've done to insult him, but someone is full of defiance and bloodthirstiness towards you, and he waits for you at the end of the garden.

og: Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.
t: Draw your sword and prepare yourself swiftly, for your assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

og: You mistake, sir. I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any imageof offense done to any man.
t: You must be mistaken, sir. I'm sure no man has any reason to quarrel with me. I can't remember ever offending anyone.

og: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you.
t: You'll find the truth to be otherwise, I assure you.

og: Therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard,
t: So if you value your life at all, be on your guard,

og: for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath can furnish man withal.
t: for your opponent has all the youth, strength, skill, and anger that God can give to a man.

og: I pray you, sir, what is he?
t: Please, sir, who is he?

og: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl.
t: He is a knight. His sword has never been used in battle, and he was knighted through his court connections rather than his battle skill, but he's a devil when he's fighting a private duel.

og: Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre.
t: He's killed three people, and his anger is so great right now that the only thing he'll be satisfied with is seeing you dead and buried.

og: Hob, nob, is his word. “Give ’t or take ’t.”
t: "Kill or be killed, it doesn't matter" is his motto.

og: I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady.
t: I'll go back into the house and ask for a protective escort from the lady.

og: I am no fighter.
t: I'm no fighter.

og: I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.
t: I've heard of some men who pick fights with people on purpose, just to test their bravery. This man must have that kind of personality.

og: Sir, no. His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury. Therefore get you on and give him his desire.
t: No, sir. His fury comes from a very real insult you gave him. So go ahead and give him what he wants.

og: Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him.
t: You won't be allowed to go back into the house unless you want to fight me, and if you're going to do that you might as well fight him instead.

og: Therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked, for meddle you must, that’s certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.
t: So go on to the garden, or else draw your sword right now. There's no way you're going to avoid a fight today, unless you want to give up your title as a gentleman and swear that you'll never carry a sword again.

og: This is as uncivil as strange.
t: This is as rude as it is strange.

og: I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is.
t: I beg you, please do me the favor of asking the knight how I've offended him. I

og: It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
t: t must be something I've done without knowing it, not on purpose.

og: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
t: I will do so. Sir Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I return.

og: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
t: Please, sir, do you know anything about this matter?

og: I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a mortal arbitrament, but nothing of the circumstance more.
t: I know the knight is furious with you, even to the degree of wanting a fight to the death, but I don't know any more details.

og: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
t: Please, what kind of man is he?

og: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by his form, as you are like to find him in the proof of his valor.
t: He doesn't look so great from the outside, but in fighting he always proves his bravery.

og: He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found inany part of Illyria.
t: Indeed, sir, he's the most skillful, bloodthirsty, and deadly opponent that you could find in all of Illyria.

og: Will you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him if I can.
t: Will you go see him? I'll try to appease him for you if I can.

og: I shall be much bound to you for ’t. I am one that hadrather go with sir priest than sir knight. I care not who knows so much of my mettle.
t: I'll be in your debt if you can do it. I'm a man who would rather deal with priests than with knights. I don't care if everyone knows that I'm not brave.

og: Why, man, he’s a very devil. I have not seen such a firago.
t: Why, man, he's a real devil. I've never seen such a virago.

og: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable.
t: I fought a round with him, with real swords and all, and his thrusts and lunges are so deadly that defeat is inevitable.

og: And on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they stepon.
t: And when he strikes at you, he'll hit you as surely as your feet hit the ground they're standing on.

og: They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
t: They say that he used to fence for the Shah of Persia.

og: Pox on ’t! I’ll not meddle with him.
t: Damn my luck! I won't mess with him.

og: Ay, but he will not now be pacified. Fabian can scarcehold him yonder.
t: Yes, but now he can't be calmed down. Fabian can barely keep him from coming over here now.

og: Plague on ’t, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damned ere I’d have challenged him.
t: Damn it, if I'd known that he was so brave and skilled at fighting, I wouldn't have challenged him in a million years.

og: Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, gray Capilet.
t: If he'll forget the whole matter, I'll give him my gray horse Capilet.

og: I’ll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on ’t.  This shall end without the perdition of souls.
t: I'll make him the offer. Stand here and put on a brave face. We'll end this without anyone dying.

og: Marry,  I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
t: And I'll ride your horse just like I ride you.

og: I have his horse to take up the quarrel. Ihave persuaded him the youth’s a devil.
t: He's offered his horse to settle the quarrel. I've persuaded him that the youth's a fighting devil.

og: He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and lookspale, as if a bear were at his heels.
t: The youth is just as afraid of Sir Andrew. He's pale and gasping, as if a bear were chasing him.

og: (t  o  VIOLA  )  There’s no remedy, sir; he will fight with you for ’s oath sake.
t: [To VIOLA] There's nothing to be done, sir; he still wants to fight you just because he swore that he would.

og: Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of.
t: But he's reconsidered his reasons for challenging you, and now realizes that they're so insignificant that they're not worth discussing.

og: Therefore, draw for the supportance ofhis vow. He protests he will not hurt you.
t: So draw your sword so that he can fulfill his promise. He promises he won't hurt you.

og: Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.
t: May God defend me! Whatever insignificant insult I committed will now reveal just how unmanly I am.

og: Give ground, if you see him furious.
t: Back off, if you see him get angry.

og: Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy. The gentleman will, for his honor’s sake, have one bout with you.
t: Come, Sir Andrew, there's nothing to be done. The gentleman insists on fighting one round with you for his honor's sake.

og: He cannot by the duello avoid it.
t: The rules of dueling say he can't avoid it.

og: But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on, to ’t.
t: But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, that he won't hurt you. Come on, get to it.

og: Pray God, he keep his oath!
t: I pray to God that he keeps his promise!

og: I do assure you, ’tis against my will.
t: I assure you, I wish none of this was happening.

og: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman  Have done offence, I take the fault on me.
t: Put away your sword. If this young gentleman has offended you, then let the blame pass to me.

og: If you offend him, I for him defy you.
t: And if you've offended him, then I'll fight you on his behalf.

og: You, sir? Why, what are you?
t: You, sir? Why, who are you?

og: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do moreThan you have heard him brag to you he will.
t: I'm his friend, sir, and I would do more to you for his sake than whatever he might have said he would .

og: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
t: Well, if you're someone who accepts challenges, then I'll challenge you.

og: O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.
t: Oh good Sir Toby, stop! Here come the officers.

og: I’ll be with you anon.
t: We'll continue this later.

og: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.
t: Please, sir, put away your sword, please.

og: Marry, will I, sir. And for that I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word. He will bear you easily and reinswell.
t: I will then, sir. And as for what I promised you, I'll be as good as my word. He is easy to ride, and responds well to the reins.

og: This is the man. Do thy office.
t: This is the man. Do your duty.

og: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.
t: Antonio, I arrest you on the orders of Duke Orsino.

og: You do mistake me, sir.
t: You've mistaken me for someone else, sir.

og: No, sir, no jot. I know your favor well,Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.—Take him away. He knows I know him well.
t: No, sir, not a bit. I know your face well, even without a sailor's cap on your head. Take him away. He knows that I've recognized him.

og: I must obey.  (t  o  VIOLA  )  This comes with seeking you:  But there’s no remedy. I shall answer it
t: I must obey. [To VIOLA] This happened because I was looking for you, but there's nothing to be done now. I'll answer for what I've done.

og: What will you do, now my necessity  Makes me to ask you for my purse?
t: But what will you do, now that I am forced to ask for my purse back?

og: It grieves me  Much more for what I cannot do for you  Than what befalls myself.
t: I feel worse about not being able to help you than I do about what's going to happen to me.

og: You stand amazed,  But be of comfort.
t: You look confused, but don't worry about me.

og: Come, sir, away.
t: Come, sir, let's go.

og: I must entreat of you some of that money.
t: I must ask you for some of that money.

og: What money, sir?  For the fair kindness you have showed me here,  And part being prompted by your present trouble,  Out of my lean and low ability  I’ll lend you something.
t: What money, sir? I'll lend you what I can to thank you for the kindness you've shown me here, and because I pity your current troubles,

og: My having is not much.  I’ll make division of my present with you.  Hold, there’s half my coffer.  (offering him money)
t: but I don't have much. I'll divide my money with you. Here is half of all that I have. [Offering him money]

og: Will you deny me now?  Is ’t possible that my deserts to you  Can lack persuasion?
t: Will you really deny that you know me now? Is it possible that all I've done for you can't persuade you to help me?

og: Do not tempt my misery,  Lest that it make me so unsound a man  As to upbraid you with those kindnesses  That I have done for you.
t: Don't make my misery even worse, or make me so angry that I list out all the kind things I've done for you.

og: I know of none,  Nor know I you by voice or any feature.
t: I don't know of any kind thing you've done, and I don't know your voice or your face.

og: I hate ingratitude more in a man  Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,  Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption  Inhabits our frail blood—
t: I hate an ungrateful man more than I hate lying, vanity, babbling, drunkenness, or any other sin that corrupts our frail human blood—

og: O heavens themselves!
t: Oh God!

og: Come, sir, I pray you, go.
t: Come on, sir, please, let's go.

og: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here  I snatched one half out of the jaws of death,  Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
t: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here—I snatched him from the jaws of death and nursed him back to health with tenderness and love,

og: And to his image, which methought did promise  Most venerable worth, did I devotion.
t: and I thought that he seemed so noble and worthy that I totally devoted myself to him.

og: What’s that to us? The time goes by. Away!
t: What do we care about that? You're wasting time. Let's go!

og: But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!  Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
t: But oh, this god turned out to be a false idol! Sebastian, you have shamed your good looks.

og: In nature there’s no blemish but the mind.  None can be called deformed but the unkind.
t: On the outside you seem perfect, but you are really a deformed monster because of your unkind soul.

og: Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil  Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
t: Virtue is beauty, but someone beautiful and evil is like an empty chest decorated by the devil.

og: The man grows mad. Away with him. Come, come, sir.
t: The man is going mad. Take him away. Come on, come on, sir.

og: Lead me on.
t: Lead me on.

og: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,  That he believes himself. So do not I.
t: His words are so passionate that he must believe what he's saying. But I can hardly believe it.

og: Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true,  That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!
t: Please be true, imagination, oh please be true—let it be true that I've been mistaken for you, my dear brother!

og: Come hither, knight. Come hither, Fabian. We’ll whispero'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.
t: Come here, Sir Andrew. Come here, Fabian. We'll whisper together about some wise sayings.

og: He named Sebastian. I my brother know  Yet living in my glass.
t: He called me Sebastian. I have seen my brother when I look in my mirror.

og: Even such and so  In favor was my brother, and he went  Still in this fashion, color, ornament,  For him I imitate.
t: My brother looked like me, and now I'm dressed as he used to dress, in the same fashion, colors, and with the same accessories—because I imitated him in my disguise.

og: Oh, if it prove,  Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love!
t: Oh, if it's true, then storms are kind and the ocean is full of love!

og: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare.
t: What a dishonorable, puny boy, and more cowardly than a rabbit.

og: His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him.
t: He shows his dishonesty in abandoning his friend in his time of need, and denying that he even knew him.

og: And for his cowardship, ask Fabian.
t: And as for his cowardice, ask Fabian.

og: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.
t: He's a coward, a true coward, religiously devoted to his cowardice.

og: 'Slid, I’ll after him again and beat him.
t: By God's eyelid, I'll go after him again and fight him.

og: Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.
t: Please do, beat him up well, but don't draw your sword.

og: An I do not—
t: And if I don't—

og: Come, let’s see the event.
t: Come, let's go see what will happen.

og: I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.
t: I'll bet any money that nothing will happen—still.

og: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?
t: Are you trying to convince me that I wasn't sent to fetch you?

og: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow. Let me be clear of thee.
t: Go away, go on, you're a foolish fellow. Leave me alone.

og: Well held out, i' faith.
t: Good job keeping up this trick of yours—seriously.

og: No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither.
t: No, I don't know you, and my lady didn't send me to fetch you, and she doesn't want you to speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this isn't my nose, either.

og: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else. Thou know’st not me.
t: Please, go spout your nonsense somewhere else. You don't know me.

og: Vent my folly? He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly!
t: Spout my nonsense? He must have heard that word used by some great man and now he applies it to a jester. Spout my nonsense!

og: I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney.
t: This foolish world, it turns out, is an effeminate dandy.

og: I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?
t: Now please abandon your strange behavior and tell me what I should "spout" to my lady. Should I spout to her that you're coming?

og: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me. There’s money for thee.    If you tarry longer, I shall give worse payment.
t: Please, foolish jester, leave me alone. Here's some money for you.  If you stay longer, I'll give you something worse.

og: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—afterfourteen years' purchase.
t: I swear, you are a generous man. These wise men who give fools money will earn themselves a good reputation—after fourteen years of payments.

og: Now, sir, have I met you again? There’s for you.
t: Can this be, sir, that we meet again? Take that.

og: Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o'er the house.
t: Stop, sir, or I'll throw your dagger over the roof.

og: This will I tell my lady straight. I would not be in some of your coats for two pence.
t: I'll tell my lady about this straight away. She won't like anyone attacking Cesario—I wouldn't take money to be in some of your shoes.

og: (  seizi    ng  SEBASTIAN)  Come on, sir, hold!
t: Come on, sir, stop!

og: Nay, let him alone. I’ll go another way to work with him.
t: No, leave him be. I'll get him in a different way. I

og: I’ll have an action of battery against him if therebe any law in Illyria.
t: 'll sue him for assault and battery, if there's any justice and law in Illyria.

og: Though I struck him first, yet it’s no matter for that.
t: I struck him first, but that shouldn't matter.

og: Let go thy hand.
t: Let me go.

og: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron. You are well fleshed. Come on.
t: Come, sir, I won't let you go yet. Come on, my young soldier, put your weapon away. You've gotten excited by a taste of battle. Come on.

og: I will be free from thee.
t: I will get free from you!

og: What wouldst thou now? If thou darest tempt me further,draw thy sword.
t: What will you do now? If you dare to try my patience further, then draw your sword.

og: What, what? Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
t: What, what? No, for then I'd have to spill an ounce or two of your impudent blood.

og: Hold, Toby! On thy life I charge thee, hold!
t: Stop, Toby! I command you to stop!

og: Madam!
t: Madam!

og: Will it be ever thus?
t: Will it always be like this with you?

og: Ungracious wretch,  Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,  Where manners ne'er were preach’d!
t: You ungrateful wretch, you are only fit to live in the mountains and caves far from civilization, where good manners are unnecessary!

og: Out of my sight!—
t: Get out of my sight!

og: Be not offended, dear Cesario.—
t: [To SEBASTIAN] Don't be offended, dear Cesario.

og: Rudesby, be gone!
t: [To TOBY]Go away, you brute!

og: I prithee, gentle friend,  Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway  In this uncivil and unjust extent  Against thy peace.
t: Please, gentle friend, may your wisdom, not your passion, guide you through these uncivilized actions against you.

og: Go with me to my house,  And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks  This ruffian hath botched up, that thou thereby  Mayst smile at this.
t: Come with me to my house, and let me tell you about the many pointless practical jokes my beastly uncle has clumsily attempted, so you might come to laugh at this one.

og: Thou shalt not choose but go.  Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me!
t: You mustn't leave. Don't deny me. Damn that Toby's soul!

og: He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
t: He startled my heart—my heart which lives in you.

og: What relish is in this? How runs the stream?  Or I am mad, or else this is a dream.
t: Something strange is going on. Where is all this leading? I must be mad, or else this is a dream.

og: Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep.  If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
t: But if this is my imagination, then let me forget my sense of reality. And if dreaming is like this, then let me sleep!

og: Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou’dst be ruled by me!
t: Now come, please. I wish you would take my advice!

og: Madam, I will.
t: Madam, I will.

og: Oh, say so, and so be!
t: Oh, say it, and do it too!

og: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard. Make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate.
t: No, I'm telling you, put on this robe and beard. Make him believe that you're Sir Topas the priest.

og: Do it quickly. I’ll call Sir Toby the whilst.
t: Do it quickly. I'll call Sir Toby while you're getting dressed.

og: Well, I’ll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in ’t, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled insuch a gown.
t: Well, I'll put it on, and I'll disguise myself in it. If only I was the first person to play the hypocrite while wearing a priest's robe.

og: I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student,
t: I'm not tall enough to look like a real priest, nor skinny enough to look like a good student,

og: but to be saidan honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.
t: but if you're known as an honest man and a good neighbor, then that's just as good as being dutiful and intelligent. Now here come my associates.

og: Jove bless thee, master Parson.
t: God bless you, Mr Priest.

og: Bonos dies, Sir Toby. For, as the old hermit of Prague,that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, “That that is is.”
t: Bonos dies, Sir Toby. As the old hermit of Prague, who never learned to read or write, said very wittily to a niece of King Gorboduc, "That which is, is."

og: So I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson. For, what is “that” but“that,” and “is” but “is”?
