t: So if I'm Mr. Priest, then I'm Mr. Priest. For doesn't "that" just mean "that," and isn't "is" just "is?"

og: To him, Sir Topas.
t: Go to him, Sir Topas.

og: (  disguising his voice   )  What ho, I say! Peace in this prison!
t: What's going on, I say! Quiet in this prison!

og: The knave counterfeits well. A good knave.
t: The fool is good at acting. A good fool.

og: (  from within   )  Who calls there?
t: Who's that calling?

og: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.
t: Sir Topas the priest, who is here to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

og: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady—
t: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, please go to my lady—

og: Out, hyperbolical fiend! How vexest thou this man! Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
t: Out, you enormous devil!  See how you're hurting this man! Can't you talk about anything but ladies?

og: (  aside  ) Well said, Master Parson.
t: Well said, Mr. Priest.

og: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged. Good Sir Topas,do not think I am mad. They have laid me here in hideous darkness.
t: Sir Topas, no man has ever been as badly treated as I have been. Good Sir Topas, don't believe that I'm mad. They've left me here in this horrible darkness.

og: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most modest terms,
t: Shame on you, dishonorable Satan! I address you with moderate language,

og: for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy.
t: for I'm one of those courteous people who will be polite even to the devil himself.

og: Sayest thou that house is dark?
t: Did you say that this house is dark?

og: As hell, Sir Topas.
t: Dark as hell, Sir Topas.

og: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony.
t: Why, it has bay windows as transparent as walls, and the upper windows facing toward the south-north are as clear as ebony.

og: And yet complainest thou of obstruction?
t: And you're complaining about darkness and a bad view?

og: I am not mad, Sir Topas. I say to you this house is dark.
t: I'm not crazy, Sir Topas. I tell you that this house is dark.

og: Madman, thou errest.
t: You madman, you're wrong.

og: I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.
t: I say that there's no darkness but ignorance, and you're more ignorant than the Egyptians during Moses' plague of fog.

og: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell.
t: And I say that this house is as dark as ignorance, and ignorance is as dark as hell.

og: And I say, there was never man thus abused.
t: And I say that no man has ever been abused like I've been.

og: I am no more mad than you are. Make the trial of it in any constant question.
t: I'm no more crazy than you are. Ask me any question and I'll prove my sanity.

og: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?
t: What did the philosopher Pythagoras believe about wild birds?

og: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
t: That our grandmother's soul could end up inhabiting a bird.

og: What thinkest thou of his opinion?
t: What do you think of his belief?

og: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
t: I think that the soul is very noble, and I disagree with his belief.

og: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness.
t: Farewell then. Remain in the darkness.

og: Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow ofthy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.
t: I won't declare you sane until you agree with Pythagoras, and fear to kill a pigeon because it might have the soul of your grandmother. Farewell.

og: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
t: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

og: My most exquisite Sir Topas!
t: Perfect, Sir Topas!

og: Nay, I am for all waters.
t: Yes, I can play many parts.

og: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.He sees thee not.
t: You might have done this without the robe and beard. He never saw you.

og: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him. I would we were well rid of this knavery.
t: Go talk to him with your own voice, and tell me how he's feeling. I want this foolishness to be over soon.

og: If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot.
t: If we can conveniently let him go, I want to do it, for I'm now in so much trouble with my niece that I can't safely pursue this prank to its conclusion.

og: Come by and by to my chamber.
t: Come to my room in a while.

og: Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,    Tell me how thy lady does.
t: Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,Tell me how your lady is.

og: Fool!
t: Fool!

og: (sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.
t: My lady is unkind indeed.

og: Fool!
t: Fool!

og: (sings) Alas, why is she so?
t: Alas, why is she like this?

og: Fool, I say!
t: Fool, I say!

og: (sings) She loves another—Who calls, ha?
t: She loves another man—Who's that shouting?

og: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper.
t: Good fool, I'll certainly reward you if you'll help me get a candle, a pen, ink, and paper.

og: As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for ’t.
t: I swear on my word as a gentleman that I'll always be grateful to you for it.

og: Master Malvolio?
t: Master Malvolio?

og: Ay, good fool.
t: Yes, good fool.

og: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?
t: Alas, sir, how did you lose your sanity?

og: Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I am as well in my wits, Fool, as thou art.
t: Fool, no one has ever been abused like I've been. I'm just as sane as you are, Fool.

og: But as well? Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
t: Just as sane as me? You must be crazy then, if you're no saner than a fool.

og: They have here propertied me, keep me in darkness, sendministers to me
t: They've treated me like their property here, kept me in the darkness, sent their minions after me

og: —asses!—and do all they can to face me out of my wits.
t: —those asses!—and done all they could to drive me insane by pretending I was insane.

og: Advise you what you say. The minister is here.
t: Be careful what you say. The priest is here.

og: Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore! Endeavor thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble-babble.
t: Malvolio, Malvolio, may God restore your sanity! Try to sleep, and stop your silly babbling.

og: Sir Topas!
t: Sir Topas!

og: I will, sir, I will.
t: Yes, sir, yes.

og: Fool, fool, fool, I say!
t: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

og: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am shent forspeaking to you.
t: Alas, sir, be patient. What do you have to say, sir? I've just been scolded for speaking to you.

og: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper. I tellthee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.
t: Good fool, please help me find a candle and some paper. I tell you, I'm as sane as any man in Illyria.

og: Well-a-day that you were, sir.
t: If only you were, sir.

og: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady.
t: I swear by my own hand, I am. Good fool, bring me some ink, paper, and light, and then deliver the letter I'll write to my lady.

og: It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.
t: You'll be better rewarded for delivering this letter than you've ever been rewarded before.

og: I will help you to ’t. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed? Or do you but counterfeit?
t: I'll help you. But tell me the truth, are you really not crazy? Or are you just acting?

og: Believe me, I am not. I tell thee true.
t: Believe me, I'm not crazy. I'm telling you the truth.

og: Nay, I’ll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains.I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.
t: No, I'll never believe a madman until he's dead and I can see his brains. But I'll bring you a candle, and paper, and ink.

og: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree. I prithee,be gone.
t: Fool, I'll repay you for this many times over. Now please, go.

og: I am gone, sir,    And anon, sir,    I’ll be with you again,    In a trice,    Like to the old Vice,    Your need to sustain,    Who, with dagger of lath    In his rage and his wrath,    Cries “Aha,” to the devil,    Like a mad lad,    “Pare thy nails, dad,    Adieu, goodman devil.”
t: I am going, sir,But soon, sir,I'll be with you again,In just a moment,Like the old Vice,Who helps you in your time of need,With a wooden dagger,And his rage and wrath,Who shouts "Aha" to the devil,Like a mad boy,Yelling "Trim your nails, dad,And farewell, you peasant devil."

og: This is the air, that is the glorious sun.  This pearl she gave me, I do feel ’t and see ’t,
t: This is really the air, and that's really the glorious sun. Here's the pearl she gave me—I can feel it and see it.

og: And though ’tis wonder that enwraps me thus,  Yet ’tis not madness.
t: And though I'm full of amazement and confusion, I'm not crazy.

og: Where’s Antonio, then?  I could not find him at the Elephant.  Yet there he was, and there I found this credit,  That he did range the town to seek me out.
t: But where's Antonio, then? I couldn't find him at the Elephant. But he had been there before me, and they told me that he was walking about the town and looking for me.

og: His counsel now might do me golden service.
t: His advice would be like gold to me right now.

og: For though my soul disputes well with my sense  That this may be some error, but no madness,
t: My soul makes the same strong argument as my senses, which is that all this is some mistake, but that I'm not crazy.

og: Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune  So far exceed all instance, all discourse,  That I am ready to distrust mine eyes  And wrangle with my reason that persuades me  To any other trust but that I am mad—
t: Yet this mistake is such a sudden flood of good fortune, which exceeds all my expectations or possibility, that it makes me distrust my own eyes and wrestle with my reason, and suggests that maybe I am insane

og: Or else the lady’s mad. Yet if ’twere so,  She could not sway her house, command her followers,  Take and give back affairs and their dispatch  With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing  As I perceive she does.
t: —or that the lady's insane. But if that were so, she wouldn't be able to run her house, command her servants, and take care of all her business affairs in the smooth, discreet, and stable way that she does.

og: There’s something in ’t  That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.
t: There's something deceptive going on here. But here comes the lady.

og: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,  Now go with me and with this holy man  Into the chantry by.
t: Don't blame me for being so hasty. If you mean well, then come with me and this holy priest into the little chapel over there.

og: There, before him  And underneath that consecrated roof,  Plight me the full assurance of your faith,  That my most jealous and too doubtful soul  May live at peace.
t: There, before the priest and under that sacred roof, you can swear your everlasting love for me, make your marriage vows, and soothe my jealous and doubtful soul.

og: He shall conceal it  Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,  What time we will our celebration keep  According to my birth. What do you say?
t: The priest will keep it a secret until you're willing for it to be made public, and then we can have a full wedding ceremony and celebration that fits my social rank. What do you say?

og: I’ll follow this good man, and go with you;And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
t: I'll follow this good priest, and go with you; and once I've sworn to be faithful, I'll be faithful forever.

og: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine That they may fairly note this act of mine.
t: Then lead the way, good father; and may the sun shine brightly to recognize and bless this marriage.

og: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.
t: Now, if you're really my friend, let me see his letter.

og: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.
t: Good Master Fabian, do me a favor first.

og: Anything.
t: Anything.

og: Do not desire to see this letter.
t: Don't ask to see this letter.

og: This is, to give a dog and in recompense desire my dogagain.
t: That request is like giving me a dog, and as payment asking for the dog back.

og: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
t: Are you in the service of the Lady Olivia, friends?

og: Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.
t: Yes, sir, we are part of her entourage.

og: I know thee well. How dost thou, my good fellow?
t: I know you well. How are you, my good fellow?

og: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.
t: Truly, sir, I'm better because of my enemies, and worse because of my friends.

og: Just the contrary. The better for thy friends.
t: Don't you mean the opposite? You're better because of your friends.

og: No, sir, the worse.
t: No, sir, I'm worse.

og: How can that be?
t: How can that be?

og: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass.
t: Well, sir, my friends praise me and in so doing make a fool of me, while my enemies tell me plainly that I am a fool.

og: So that by my foes,sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused.
t: Therefore my enemies help me gain knowledge of myself, while my friends deceive me.

og: So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.
t: The same rule applies to both conclusions and kisses—since four negatives make two affirmatives, I'm worse because of my friends and better because of my enemies.

og: Why, this is excellent.
t: Why, this is excellent wordplay.

og: By my troth, sir, no—though it please you to be one of my friends.
t: Truly sir, don't say so—unless you want to be one of my friends.

og: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there’s gold.
t: You won't be worse off because of me: here's some gold.

og: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.
t: I wish you'd deal me another coin, sir, but then it would be double-dealing, and therefore dishonorable.

og: O, you give me ill counsel.
t: Oh, you're giving me bad advice.

og: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.
t: Put your virtue away just this once, sir, and let your human weakness take my advice.

og: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a double-dealer.There’s another. (  giving a coin  )
t: Well I'll be a sinner then, and a double-dealer. Here's another.

og: Primo, secundo, tertio is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all.
t: Three rolls of the dice is lucky, sir, and the old saying goes "the third time's the charm."

og: The triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind—one, two, three.
t: Triple-time is a good beat for dancing, and the bells of Saint Bennet's church chime—one, two, three.

og: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw.
t: You won't win any more money from me with this third roll of the dice.

og: If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her,and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.
t: But if you'll tell your lady that I'm here to speak with her, and bring her along with you when you return, then you might wake up my generosity.

og: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again.
t: Well then, sir, I'll sing a lullaby to your generosity while I'm gone, so it can nap until I return.

og: I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness.
t: I'll go now, sir, but don't think that I'm doing this just because I'm greedy—I'm more interested in the art of begging than the actual money.

og: But, as yousay, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.
t: But as you say, sir, let your generosity sleep, and I'll wake it up soon.

og: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.
t: Here comes the man who rescued me, sir.

og: That face of his I do remember well.  Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared  As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.
t: I remember that face well, though the last time I saw it it was blackened by the smoke of war.

og: A baubling vessel was he captain of,  For shallow draught and bulk unprizable,   With which such scathful grapple did he make  With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
t: He was the captain of a small, flimsy ship, worthless because of its size—but with that pitiful boat he fought such a damaging battle against my fleet's most noble warship

og: That very envy and the tongue of loss
t: that we had to admire him even in our bitter defeat.

og: Cried fame and honor on him.  —What’s the matter?
t: [To the officer] What's going on here?

og: Orsino, this is that Antonio  That took the  Phoenix  and her fraught from Candy,  And this is he that did the  Tiger  board  When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.
t: Orsino, this is the same Antonio who took our ship the Phoenix and its cargo from Crete, and who boarded the Tiger in the battle where your young nephew Titus lost his leg.

og: Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,  In private brabble did we apprehend him.
t: We arrested him here in the streets, where he was recklessly brawling as if he didn't care that we were looking for him.

og: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side,
t: He was kind to me, sir, and drew his sword to defend me,

og: But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.  I know not what ’twas but distraction.
t: but then he said some strange things to me. I don't know what he meant, except that he might be insane.

og: Notable pirate! Thou saltwater thief,
t: You famous pirate! You thief of the seas,

og: What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,  Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,  Hast made thine enemies?
t: what foolish boldness inspired you to visit the enemies you once robbed and murdered?

og: Orsino, noble sir,  Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me.  Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,  Though, I confess, on base and ground enough,  Orsino’s enemy.
t: Orsino, noble sir, I must deny those names you give me. I have never been a thief or a pirate, though I admit to being your enemy for good and solid reasons.

og: A witchcraft drew me hither.
t: I am here because I've been bewitched.

og: That most ingrateful boy there by your side  From the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth  Did I redeem.
t: I rescued that ungrateful boy—the one there by your side—from the rude sea's angry waves.

og: A wreck past hope he was.  His life I gave him and did thereto add  My love, without retention or restraint,  All his in dedication.
t: He was a wreck, and seemed past hope. I saved his life and gave him my love, without reservation or restraint, and dedicated myself to him totally

og: For his sake  Did I expose myself, pure for his love,  Into the danger of this adverse town,  Drew to defend him when he was beset,
t: . For his sake I endangered myself in this town, and purely out of love for him I drew my sword to defend him when he was being attacked.

og: Where being apprehended, his false cunning,  (Not meaning to partake with me in danger)  Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
t: But when I was arrested, he decided not to endanger himself, and he used his treacherous cunning to pretend that he'd never met me before.

og: And grew a twenty-years-removed thing  While one would wink, denied me mine own purse,  Which I had recommended to his use  Not half an hour before.
t: In the blink of an eye he became a totally different person, and he refused to give me back my own purse, which I had lent to him just half an hour before.

og: How can this be?
t: How is this possible?

og: When came he to this town?
t: When did he come to this town?

og: Today, my lord, and for three months before, No interim, not a minute’s vacancy,Both day and night did we keep company.
t: Today, my lord. For three months before that we spent every day and night together without a break.

og: Here comes the Countess. Now heaven walks on earth.
t: Look, an angel is walking on earth—here comes the Countess.

og: But for thee, fellow. Fellow, thy words are madness:  Three months this youth hath tended upon me;  But more of that anon.
t: But as for you, fellow, your words are madness: this youth has worked for me for three months. But more of that later.

og: Take him aside.
t: Take him away.

og: What would my lord, but that he may not have,  Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
t: What do you want, my lord—except for the one thing you cannot have—that I can help you with?

og: Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.
t: Cesario, you broke your promise to me.

og: Madam?
t: Madam?

og: Gracious Olivia—
t: Gracious Olivia—

og: What do you say, Cesario?—Good my lord—
t: What do you have to say for yourself, Cesario?—My lord, a moment—

og: My lord would speak. My duty hushes me.
t: My lord wants to speak. It's my duty to be silent.

og: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear As howling after music.
t: If you're just going to repeat the same old things, my lord, then it will be as pleasant to my ears as hearing howling after listening to beautiful music.

og: Still so cruel?
t: Are you still so cruel?

og: Still so constant, lord.
t: I am still consistent, my lord.

og: What, to perverseness?
t: Consistent in what, being horrible?

og: You, uncivil lady,  To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars  My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out  That e'er devotion tendered
t: I have breathed from my soul the most faithful, devoted offerings possible, but they've only fallen upon your ungrateful and unwelcoming altar, you rude lady.

og: —what shall I do?
t: What else can I do?

og: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.
t: Do whatever pleases you, within reason.

og: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,  Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,  Kill what I love?
t: Why shouldn't I—if I had the heart to do it—kill what I love, like that Egyptian thief Thyamis who murdered the woman he loved just before he died?

og: —A savage jealousy  That sometimes savors nobly.
t: That kind of savage jealousy sometimes seems noble.

og: But hear me this:  Since you to nonregardance cast my faith,  And that I partly know the instrument  That screws me from my true place in your favor,  Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still.
t: But listen to me now: since you keep denying my faithful love, and since I can guess who has forced me from my rightful place in your heart, you can go on being a cold-hearted tyrant as long as you like—

og: But this your minion, whom I know you love,  And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,  Him will I tear out of that cruel eye  Where he sits crowned in his master’s spite.
t: but I'm going to take your darling Cesario from you. I know that you love him, and I swear that I care deeply for him as well, but I must tear him away from you because his place in your heart humiliates me.

og: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly,To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
t: And I would cheerfully, readily, and willingly die a thousand deaths if it would bring you peace.

og: Where goes Cesario?
t: Where is Cesario going?

og: After him I love  More than I love these eyes, more than my life,  More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.
t: I'm following the man I love more than I love my eyes or my life, more, far more, than I'll ever love a wife.

og: If I do feign, you witnesses above,  Punish my life for tainting of my love!
t: If I'm lying about this, you angels above, put me to death for dishonoring my love.

og: Ay me, detested! How am I beguiled!
t: Oh no, you scorn me! I've been tricked!

og: Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?
t: Who tricked you? Who has done you wrong?

og: Hast thou forgot thyself? Is it so long?—Call forth the holy father.
t: Have you forgotten your own actions? Has it been so long?—Call the priest who was with us earlier.

og: Come, away!
t: Come, let's go!

og: Whither, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.
t: Where are you taking him, my lord?—Cesario, my husband, stay.

og: Husband?
t: Husband?

og: Ay, husband. Can he that deny?
t: Yes, husband. Can he deny it?

og: Her husband, sirrah?
t: Are you her husband, you wretch?

og: No, my lord, not I.
t: No, my lord, I'm not.

og: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear  That makes thee strangle thy propriety.  Fear not, Cesario.
t: Alas, your fear is so great that it makes you disguise your true identity. But don't be afraid, Cesario.

og: Take thy fortunes up.  Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art  As great as that thou fear’st.
t: Reach out and accept your good fortune. Be the person you know you are, and then you will be as powerful as the person you fear.

og: O, welcome, father!  Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,  Here to unfold
t: Oh, welcome, father! Father, can I respectfully ask you to explain

og: (though lately we intended  To keep in darkness what occasion now  Reveals before ’tis ripe)
t: (though we recently wanted to hide it, the time is now ripe to reveal it)

og: what thou dost know  Hath newly passed between this youth and me.
t: what you know has happened between this youth and me?

og: A contract of eternal bond of love,  Confirmed by mutual joinder of your hands,  Attested by the holy close of lips,  Strengthened by interchangement of your rings,
t: You made an oath of eternal love, which was confirmed by joining hands, proved by a holy kiss, and strengthened by an exchange of rings.

og: And all the ceremony of this compact  Sealed in my function, by my testimony,
t: I witnessed and approved all this in my official capacity as a priest.

og: Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave  I have traveled but two hours.
t: All this took place only two hours ago.

og: O thou dissembling cub! What wilt thou be  When time hath sowed a grizzle on thy case?
t: Oh, you lying little puppy! How much worse will you be when you're old and gray?

og: Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow  That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
t: Or will you get so good at being crafty that your own tricks will trick you?

og: Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet  Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.
t: Farewell, and take her; but go somewhere where you and I will never meet again.

og: My lord, I do protest—
t: My lord, I promise—

og: O, do not swear!Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
t: Oh, don't promise! Keep a little faith—your faith in me—even though you're so afraid.

og: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to SirToby.
t: For the love of God, someone get a doctor! Send one to Sir Toby right away.

og: What’s the matter?
t: What's the matter?

og: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too. For the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.
t: He's cut my head open and given Sir Toby a bloody head too. For the love of God, help! I'd pay forty pounds to be at home right now.

og: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?
t: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

og: The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario. We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.
t: That Cesario, the Duke's gentleman. We thought he was a coward, but he actually fights like the devil himself.

og: My gentleman, Cesario?
t: My servant Cesario?

og: 'Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.
t: By God, here he is!—You broke my head for no reason. I didn't do anything, and whatever I did, Sir Toby made me do.

og: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you.
t: Why are you saying this to me? I never hurt you.

og: You drew your sword upon me without cause,  But I bespoke you fair and hurt you not.
t: You drew your sword against me without a good reason, but I spoke politely to you and didn't hurt you.

og: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me. I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
t: If a bloody head is an injury, then you've hurt me. I don't think you care at all about a bloody head.

og: Here comes Sir Toby halting. You shall hear more.
t: Here comes Sir Toby, limping. He'll tell you more about what happened.

og: But if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.
t: If he hadn't been drunk, he would have hurt you more than he did.

og: How now, gentleman? How is ’t with you?
t: Hello, gentleman! How are you?

og: That’s all one: has hurt me, and there’s the end on ’t.    Sot, didst see Dick Surgeon, sot?
t: It doesn't matter: he has hurt me, and that's all there is to it.  You drunken fool, have you seen Dick the surgeon?

og: Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone. His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.
t: Oh, he's drunk, Sir Toby, since an hour ago. He was cross eyed at eight in the morning.

og: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin. I hate adrunken rogue.
t: Then he's a rogue, and I hate a drunken rogue. He spins and sways like he's doing a slow dance.

og: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them?
t: Take him away! Who has caused all this trouble?

og: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
t: I'll help you, Sir Toby. They'll bandage us up together.

og: Will you help?—An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave,a thin-faced knave, a gull!
t: Will you help me—an ass, and a fool, and a bastard, a gullible skinny bastard?

og: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to.
t: Get him to bed, and make sure his wounds are tended to.

og: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman,  But, had it been the brother of my blood,  I must have done no less with wit and safety.
t: I am sorry, madam. I've hurt your relative, but I would've had to do the same thing even to my own brother, for I was acting in self-defense.

og: You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that  I do perceive it hath offended you.
t: You're looking at me like I'm a stranger, so I can tell that I've offended you.

og: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows  We made each other but so late ago.
t: Forgive me, sweet one, for the sake of the vows we made to each other so recently.

og: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons!A natural perspective, that is and is not!
t: One face, one voice, one manner of dressing, but two people! An optical illusion—it both is and is not!

og: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!How have the hours racked and tortured meSince I have lost thee!
t: Antonio, oh my dear Antonio! How time has tortured me ever since I lost you!

og: Sebastian are you?
t: Are you Sebastian, then?

og: Fear’st thou that, Antonio?
t: Do you doubt that, Antonio?

og: How have you made division of yourself?
t: How have you divided yourself in two?

og: An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin  Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?
t: These two people are as identical as two halves of an apple. Which is Sebastian?

og: Most wonderful!
t: It's unbelievable!

og: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;  Nor can there be that deity in my nature,  Of here and everywhere.
t: Is that me standing there? I never had a brother, and I'm not a god who can be everywhere at once.

og: I had a sister,  Whom the blind waves and surges have devoured.
t: I had a sister, but she was drowned by the cruel ocean.

og: Of charity, what kin are you to me?  What countryman? What name? What parentage?
t: Please tell me, are you related to me? What country are you from? What is your name? Who are your parents?

og: Of Messaline. Sebastian was my father;  Such a Sebastian was my brother too,
t: I am from Messaline. Sebastian was my father, and my brother was also named Sebastian.

og: So went he suited to his watery tomb
t: He was dressed just like you when he drowned.

og: If spirits can assume both form and suit  You come to fright us.
t: If ghosts can take on human forms and clothes, then you must be here to frighten us.

og: A spirit I am indeed,  But am in that dimension grossly clad  Which from the womb I did participate.
t: I am a spirit indeed, as I have a soul. But my spirit wears the same earthly form that I've had since I was born. I

og: Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
t: f you were only a woman—since everything else about you fits—

og: My father had a mole upon his brow.
t: My father had a mole on his forehead.

og: And so had mine.
t: Mine did too.

og: And died that day when Viola from her birthHad numbered thirteen years.
t: And he died on the day that Viola turned thirteen.

og: Oh, that record is lively in my soul! He finished indeed his mortal actThat day that made my sister thirteen years.
t: Oh, that memory is still so vivid to me! He did indeed die on the day my sister turned thirteen.

og: If nothing lets to make us happy both  But this my masculine usurped attire,  Do not embrace me till each circumstance  Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump  That I am Viola.
t: If the only thing keeping us from being happy is my deceptive masculine clothes, then don't hug me until every circumstance of place, time, and luck fit together and prove that I am Viola.

og: Which to confirm,  I’ll bring you to a captain in this town,  Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help  I was preserved to serve this noble count.
t: To confirm this, I'll take you to a captain in this town who has been keeping my woman's clothing, and who saved my life so that I might serve this noble Duke.

og: All the occurrence of my fortune since  Hath been between this lady and this lord.
t: Everything that's happened to me since then has involved this lady and this lord.

og: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook.  But nature to her bias drew in that.
t: So you've been mistaken, my lady. But nature has fixed everything and drawn you to your natural orientation. Your love for Cesario was really an inclination for someone like me.

og: You would have been contracted to a maid;
t: You wanted to be married to a maiden,

og: Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived.  You are betrothed both to a maid and man.
t: but you weren't actually deceived about that, given that you believed you were married to my sister.

og: Be not amazed. Right noble is his blood.
t: Don't be shocked. His blood is pure and noble.

og: If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,  I shall have share in this most happy wreck.
t: If all this is true, as the two really seem to be brother and sister, then I too will share in the spoils of this lucky shipwreck.

og: Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times  Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.
t: Boy, you've said to me a thousand times that you'd never love a woman like you love me.

og: And all those sayings will I overswear;
t: Everything I said before I'll promise once again,

og: And those swearings keep as true in soul  As doth that orbèd continent the fire  That severs day from night.
t: and I'll keep my promises in my soul like fire is kept in the sun.

og: Give me thy hand,And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.
t: Give me your hand, and let me see you in your woman's clothes.

og: The captain that did bring me first on shore  Hath my maid’s garments.
t: The captain who first brought me to shore has my woman's clothing.

og: He, upon some action,  Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit,  A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
t: He has some legal charge against him, and is in prison because he's been sued by Malvolio—a gentleman and a servant of my lady's.

og: He shall enlarge him.
t: He'll release him.

og: Fetch Malvolio hither:  And yet, alas, now I remember me,  They say, poor gentleman, he’s much distract.
t: Bring Malvolio here—but no, now I remember, they say that the poor gentleman is mentally confused.

og: A most extracting frenzy of mine own  From my remembrance clearly banished his.
t: My own distracting madness made me forget all about him.

og: (to FOOL)  How does he, sirrah?
t: [To the FOOL] How is he, fool?

og: Truly, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the staves' end as well as a man in his case may do.
t: Truly, madam, he keeps the devil away as well as a man in his situation can.

og: Has here writ a letterto you. I should have given ’t you today morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.
t: He's written a letter to you here. I should have given it to you this morning, but a madman's letters aren't gospel truth, so it doesn't matter too much when they're delivered.

og: Open ’t, and read it.
t: Open it, and read it.

og: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers themadman.    “By the Lord, madam,”—
t: Be prepared to learn a lot now, for a fool is reciting the words of a madman.  "By God, madam,"—

og: How now? Art thou mad?
t: What's this? Are you crazy?

og: No, madam, I do but read madness. An your ladyship willhave it as it ought to be, you must allow  vox.
t: No, madam, but I'm reading the words of craziness. And if you want things done the right way, then let me do a dramatic reading.

og: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.
t: Please, read it like a sane person.

og: So I do, madonna. But to read his right wits is to readthus.Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.
t: I will, holy lady, but even if I read this letter sanely, I'll still sound crazy. So pay attention, my princess, and listen.

og: Read it you, sirrah.
t: You read it, sir.

og: “By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it.
t: "By God, madam, you've wronged me, and the world will know about it.

og: Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefitof my senses as well as your Ladyship.
t: You've put me in a dark room and let your drunken uncle torment me, but I've still kept my sanity and am no more crazy than you are.

og: I have your own letter that induced me to the semblance I put on, with the which I doubt not but to do myself much right or youmuch shame.
t: I have your own letter, which encouraged me to act the way I did, and with this letter I will prove that I am innocent and you are guilty.

og: Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury. The madly used Malvolio.”
t: Think of me however you want. I will leave my role as your steward and speak out about the injuries you've caused me. Signed, the madly-abused Malvolio."

og: Did he write this?
t: Did he write this?

og: Ay, madam.
t: Yes, madam.

og: This savors not much of distraction.
t: This doesn't sound much like madness.

og: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.
t: Release him, Fabian, and bring him here.

og: My lord so please you, these things further thought on,  To think me as well a sister as a wife,
t: My lord, if you'll take into consideration what you've just seen and heard, I hope that you'll accept me as a sister-in-law instead of a wife.

og: One day shall crown the alliance on ’t, so please you,  Here at my house and at my proper cost.
t: We can have the two weddings on the same day, if you want, here at my house, and I'll pay for everything.

og: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
t: Madam, I'll happily accept your offer.

og: (to VIOLA)  Your master quits you, and for your service done him,  So much against the mettle of your sex,  So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
t: [To VIOLA] Your master releases you from his service. Because you served me so well, doing things that no woman, especially one of your noble birth,

og: And since you called me “master” for so long,  Here is my hand.
t: should be expected to do, and because you called me "master" for so long, I will offer you my hand in marriage.

og: You shall from this time be  Your master’s mistress.
t: From now on you'll be your master's mistress.

og: A sister! You are she.
t: And you will be my sister!

og: Is this the madman?
t: Is this the madman?

og: Ay, my lord, this same.How now, Malvolio!
t: Yes, my lord, that's him. How are you, Malvolio?

og: Madam, you have done me wrong,Notorious wrong.
t: Madam, you have mistreated me. Scandalously mistreated me.

og: Have I, Malvolio? No.
t: Have I, Malvolio? No.

og: (handing a paper)   Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter.  You must not now deny it is your hand.
t: [Handing OLIVIA a paper] Lady, you have. Please look at that letter. You can't deny that it's in your handwriting.

og: Write from it if you can, in hand or phrase;  Or say ’tis not your seal, not your invention:  You can say none of this.
t: Try to write differently if you can, or try to say that that isn't your seal, with your design on it—you can't deny any of this.

og: Well, grant it then  And tell me, in the modesty of honor,  Why you have given me such clear lights of favor,  Bade me come smiling and cross-gartered to you,  To put on yellow stockings, and to frown  Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people?
t: Well, admit it then and tell me, with the sincerity of an honorable person, why you gave me such clear signs of affection, telling me to come to you smiling, with crossed laces, to wear yellow stockings, and to be rude to Sir Toby and the servants?

og: And, acting this in an obedient hope,  Why have you suffered me to be imprisoned,  Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
t: And when I obeyed all your commands, why did you then let me be imprisoned in a dark house, be visited by a priest—

og: And made the most notorious geck and gull  That e'er invention played on? Tell me why.
t: and make me into the biggest fool and sucker that ever had a joke played on him? Tell me why.

og: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,  Though, I confess, much like the character.
t: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my handwriting. Though, I admit, the letters look very similar.

og: But out of question, ’tis Maria’s hand.  And now I do bethink me, it was she  First told me thou wast mad, then camest in smiling,  And in such forms which here were presupposed  Upon thee in the letter.
t: But it's definitely Maria's handwriting. And now that I think about it, she was the one who first told me you were crazy, and then you came in smiling and acting in the way the letter instructed you to act.

og: Prithee, be content.  This practice hath most shrewdly passed upon thee;  But when we know the grounds and authors of it,  Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge  Of thine own cause.
t: Please, don't be so upset. You've been fooled by a cruel practical joke, but when we find out who's responsible for this, you will be the judge and jury who sentences the culprits to a punishment for their crime.

og: Good madam, hear me speak,  And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come  Taint the condition of this present hour,  Which I have wonder’d at.
t: Good madam, let me speak, and don't let any quarreling cast a shadow over the surprised joy of these happy couples, which I have been amazed by.

og: In hope it shall not,  Most freely I confess, myself and Toby  Set this device against Malvolio here,  Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts  We had conceived against him.
t: To avoid any fighting, I'll confess that Toby and I were the ones who tricked Malvolio here, because of the arrogant and rude behavior we had observed in him.

og: Maria writ  The letter at Sir Toby’s great importance,  In recompense whereof he hath married her.
t: Maria only wrote the letter at Sir Toby's urgent request, and he has rewarded her for it by marrying her.

og: How with a sportful malice it was followed,  May rather pluck on laughter than revenge,  If that the injuries be justly weighed  That have on both sides passed.
t: The whole practical joke should inspire laughter instead of revenge, especially if we consider that both sides injured each other equally.

og: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!
t: Alas, you poor fool, how they've humiliated you!

og: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was one, sir, in this interlude, one Sir Topas, sir, but that’s all one.
t: Well, "some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them." I was a member of this farce as well, pretending to be a priest named Sir Topas, but what does that matter?

og: “By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.”
t: "By God, fool, I am not mad."—

og: —But do you remember? “Madam, why laugh you at sucha barren rascal; an you smile not, he’s gagged?”
t: But do you remember what else he said? "Madam, why do you laugh at such an empty-headed villain? If you don't laugh at him, he can't think of anything to say."

og: and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.
t: And so—what goes around comes around.

og: I’ll be revenged on the whole pack of you.
t: I'll get my revenge on the whole pack of you.

og: He hath been most notoriously abused.
t: He really has been badly treated.

og: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace.
t: Follow him and try to calm him down some.

og: He hath not told us of the captain yet.
t: He hasn't told us about that captain yet.

og: When that is known and golden time convents,  A solemn combination shall be made  Of our dear souls.—
t: When that's taken care of and the time is convenient, we will be married.

og: Meantime, sweet sister,  We will not part from hence.
t: Until then, sweet sister-in-law, we won't leave this place.

og: Cesario, come,  For so you shall be, while you are a man.  But when in other habits you are seen,  Orsino’s mistress and his fancy’s queen.
t: Cesario, come here. You'll be Cesario to me while you're still a man, but when I see you in women's clothes, then you'll be Orsino's mistress, and his love's queen.

og: When that I was and a little tiny boy,    With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,    A foolish thing was but a toy,    For the rain it raineth every day.    But when I came to man’s estate,    With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,    'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,    For the rain it raineth every day.    But when I came, alas! to wive,    With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,    By swaggering could I never thrive,    For the rain it raineth every day.    But when I came unto my beds,    With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,    With toss-pots still had drunken heads,    For the rain it raineth every day.    A great while ago the world begun,    With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,    But that’s all one, our play is done,    And we’ll strive to please you every day.
t: When I was just a tiny little boy,With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,Mischief didn't matter much,For the rain it rains every day.But when I became a man,With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,We shut our gates to villains and thieves,For the rain it rains every day.But when—alas!—I got married,With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,Bragging and bullying did me no good,For the rain it rains every day.But when I had to go to bed,With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,With the drunkards and the fools,For the rain it rains every day.The world began a long time ago,With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,But that doesn't matter, our play is done,And we'll try to please you every day.
